title: METS UNDONE BY SUICIDE SQUEEZE IN 8th
description: The Mets four-game winning streak came tumbling down tonight when they lost to the San Diego Padres, 4-3, on a suicide squeeze bunt by Carmelo Martinez with two down in the eighth inning.

title: New Chairman Named At Hirshhorn Museum
description: Sydney Lewis, a Richmond arts patron, has been elected chairman of the board of trustees of the Hirshhorn Museum, the contemporary art museum of the Smithsonian Institution.

title: Shopping List
description: If the United States Football League were to fold tomorrow, how many of its home-grown players -that is, those who haven't previously performed in the National Football League - would be sure-fire standouts in the N.F.L.? About 15, according to The Sporting News, which interviewed a number of anonymous N.F.L. general managers, scouts and personnel specialists to come up with this list of the blue-chippers:

title: Phillips Holders Back Stock Split
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company said today that its shareholders had approved a plan for a 3-for-1 split of its common stock and the issuance of a special dividend of $300 million in preferred stock. Voting was completed at the Phillips annual meeting on Wednesday, but computer problems and reports of duplicate ballots hampered vote counting.

title: NEW VERNACULAR
description: Sports is no longer the cloistered world of sweat that it was, or was thought to be, just a few years ago.

title: NBC, AT NO. 1, SNAPS 10-YEAR RATINGS DECLINE
description: For the first time in almost 11 years, NBC has finished in first place for a ratings sweeps period. The last time NBC won the sweeps - the monthlong ratings surveys by which network advertising rates are determined - was in November 1974. The last time it won both the A. C. Nielsen Company and the Arbitron ratings -as it did this May - was in 1969. So at the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center and in the NBC offices in Burbank, Calif., there was a mood of euphoria yesterday.

title: FIRST NATIONAL SUPERMARETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Includes gains from the termination of a pension plan of $93,000 for the quarter and $2,836,000 for the year, a charge from the reversal of a tax credit of $93,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $1,664,000 for the year. c-Includes a gain of $12,000,000 from the termination of a pension plan.

title: SUFFOLK OFFICIAL, IN SHIFT, ORDERS SHOREHAM DRILL
description: The Suffolk County Executive, reversing a long-held position, ordered county employees yesterday to run a test of an emergency evacuation plan required for the Shoreham nuclear power plant to go into operation.

title: Applications to New York's High Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Silent Night
description: Neil Hope, a linebacker for the Denver Gold, used to play for Southern Cal, and he knows what it is like to feel the thunder of 60,000 cheering fans packed into the cavernous, 92,000-seat Los Angeles Coliseum. Thursday night, when the Gold played the Los Angeles Express, he found out what it is like to sense the faint rattle of a crowd of 3,059 lonely fans dwarfed by empty seats. ''I never thought I'd play a game in the Coliseum in front of a crowd this small,'' said Hope, who did not seem to appreciate the fact that the announced attendance (about double media estimates of the actual number present) represented the smallest crowd ever to see a a United States Football League game.

title: Young Law Buffs Honored for Success
description: As befits a legal whiz, Edward Tantleff spends a good deal of time in court these days, including appearances before the State Court of Appeals in Albany and the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit here.

title: ADMIRAL SAYS HE WAS WRONGED IN REMOVAL OVER $659 ASHTRAYS
description: A rear admiral who was removed from his command over the purchase of $659 ashtrays for warplanes said today that he had been wrongfully accused and that his punishment was ''patently absurd.''

title: Your Money;   Planning For Tax Shifts
description: THE tax proposals of President Reagan -issued this week and designed to take effect in 1986 - will affect most Americans if they are enacted. And while these proposals have a long way to go before they have the force of law, their very existence should entail some additional personal financial planning by taxpayers.

title: Wheeling Seeks End to Labor Pact
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, seeking labor cost cuts of 29 percent, today asked the Federal bankruptcy judge overseeing its Chapter 11 reorganization to dissolve its contract with the United Steelworkers of America.

title: PLAYERS
description: She had moved halfway around the world to America to take her place among the running greats, and two years ago, in Central Park, that is what Anne Audain did. In her second L'eggs Mini Marathon, she found herself well ahead of Grete Waitz, then the four-time champion, then and now the world's fastest woman over 10 kilometers. Mrs. Audain was so far ahead that there was no one else to cheer when the crowds near the finish line first spotted the approaching leader. There were no male competitors to obscure her achievement. Anne Audain's moment of triumph had arrived. ''I just kind of thought, 'Gosh. My chance to be recognized,' '' she remembered.

title: PHONE COMPANIES TOLD TO SHARE DISTANCE CALLS
description: Telephone customers who do not select a long-distance company when asked to do so will have one selected for them under an order issued today by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: QUANEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $1 million for the quarter and 6 months.

title: NORSTAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CONCHEMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,000 for the quarter and income from the disposal of discontinued operations of $369,000, or 64 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: ESPIONAGE SUSPECT IS LINKED TO KLAN
description: A former Ku Klux Klan leader said today that he and John A. Walker Jr., accused last week of spying for the Soviet Union, became close friends while serving together aboard a nuclear submarine.

title:
PATENTS;

Selectively Eliminating Parts of Broadcasts
description: A system for selective elimination of portions of television and radio programs was patented this week by Henry Von Kohorn of Greenwich, Conn., a retired engineering executive.

title: Italy Will Try Six Lebanese Linked to U.S. Embassy Plot
description: An Italian investigating magistrate ordered today that a trial be held for six Lebanese accused of conspiring to blow up the United States Embassy in Rome last November. The six are Shiite Moslem supporters of the Iranian leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: EVEN IN THE SOUTH, THEY TAN INDOORS
description: It's lunchtime and there are four cars parked in front of Cherry Miller's Tanning Salon on State Road 69, just across from Gile's Muffler Shop. Inside, all three tanning booths are busy.

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page article Thursday about medical malpractice insurance in New York State incorrectly reported the position of the Medical Liability Mutual Insurance Company on an increase in premiums. The company is awaiting the outcome of legislative proposals for changes in malpractice insurance policies before deciding whether to file for any rate increases.

title: LEGAL DRINKING TO BEGIN AT 21 IN CONNECTICUT
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill has signed legislation raising Connecticut's legal drinking age to 21, from 20, on Sept. 1, his office announced today.

title: COURT FINDS UNCONSTITUTIONAL 2 JUDGES' ROLE IN CRIME PANEL
description: A divided Federal appeals court panel in Atlanta said this week that the membership of two Federal judges on President Reagan's Commission on Organized Crime violated the constitutional separation of powers.

title: HOUSING THE HOMELESS
description: The crisis of homelessness in New York City has generated a myth that no matter what New Yorkers do, the number of homeless will continue to increase rapidly. But they need not.

title: BRANIFF INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $700,000, or 6 cents a share, from a tax benefit. c-Net loss.

title: RENAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: PRETORIA COOLS TO U.S.-BACKED TALKS
description: South Africa said today that it was ''no longer sure'' that United States-sponsored negotiations could be held to secure a withdrawal of Cuban soldiers from Angola in return for a settlement to bring independence to neighboring South-West Africa.

title: OFFICIALS DISPUTE TIMES ARTICLE ON NUCLEAR ARMS
description: Fred C. Ikle, the Under Secretary of Defense for policy, has disputed an article in The New York Times, for which he was one of the sources, that reported that the United States was planning to integrate offensive nuclear forces with a projected antimissile shield.

title: Mount St. Helens Lava Flow
description: Mount St. Helens today continued a slow oozing eruption that added new lava to a huge dome that has formed in the steaming, cloud-shrouded crater of the 8,365-foot-high volcano in southwest Washington.

title: Westway or No, Jersey Emits Toxic Gases
description: To the Editor:

title: NEUTROGENA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Jan. 17, 1985.

title: Reagan Says Plan Will Aid Economy
description: President Reagan, visiting a thriving high-technology community today, said that more such economic vitality would spring up if Congress adopted his plan to revise the Federal income tax.

title: FORECAST FOR QUAKE DOESN'T UPSET A COAST TOWN, WHICH IS USED TO THEM
description: Donalee Thomason remembers riding her horse around the family farm as a young girl in the 1930's and watching earthquakes pass through the bucolic Parkfield-Cholame valley from north to south, bending the trees and making the ground undulate.

title: Hotel Murder Is Investigated
description: Detectives questioned scores of employees and guests of the Dorset Hotel yesterday as they began investigating the murder of a woman who was bludgeoned to death Thursday in her room at the hotel, at 30 West 54th Street.

title: White House Report On Arms Pact Delayed
description: The White House notified Congress today that it was delaying a report on adherence to the second strategic arms limitation agreement until June 10 to give it time to consult with North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies and to assess further its military and diplomatic options.

title: Henry (Billy) Roland Is Dead; Big Band Pianist Was 71
description: Henry (Billy) Roland, the pianist with Les Brown's big band before and during World War II, died of cancer Thursday in Glen Cove (L.I.) Community Hospital. He was 71 years old.

title: PICTURE EMERGES OF FAMILY LIFE OF MEN ARRESTED IN SPY CASE
description: In the working-class neighborhood of West Scranton, James Walker, 45 years old, arrived home from his factory job, put his lunchbox down and looked sadly at the front page of the local paper, reflecting on the dismantling of his family.

title: Books of The Times;   Hemingway at Sunset
description: THE DANGEROUS SUMMER. By Ernest Hemingway. Introduction by James A. Michener. 228 pages. Charles Scribner's Sons. $17.95.

title: 'TILTED ARC' TO BE MOVED FROM PLAZA AT FOLEY SQ.
description: The controversial sculpture ''Tilted Arc,'' a 120-foot steel wall disparaged by many of the workers who pass it every day on Federal Plaza in lower Manhattan, will be moved, officials of the General Services Administration announced yesterday.

title: MAIL CARRIER SURRENDERS IN SHOOTING AT POST OFFICE
description: A mail carrier facing dismissal from his job shot and seriously wounded a postal clerk and held his supervisor hostage for almost two hours yesterday at Postal Service offices in lower Manhattan before surrendering to authorities, the police said.

title: F.B.I. WIDENS NET IN SOVIET SPY CASE
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun surveillance of at least three California men who once worked in the Navy with John A. Walker Jr., who is accused of spying for the Soviet Union, Government officials said today.

title: AN OPTIMISTIC PARIS AIR SHOW
description: With a noise like shredding silk, General Dynamics' F-16C fighter went spiraling up to turn somersaults in a cloudless blue sky. Then Lockheed's P-3 radar plane came lumbering majestically over the stands, a big black mushroom growing out of its back. In McDonnell Douglas's lavish pavilion, company guests watched the display from comfortable chairs amid the compulsory array of lobsters and champagne.

title: FOR BANGLADESH VICTIMS, 'NO PLACE ELSE FOR US TO GO'
description: Thousands of peasant families in search of a livelihood migrate each year to the low-lying fringes of this impoverished country. Once there, they say they will remain despite the hazard of being washed violently away.

title: Tokyo Festival Opens With a Kurosawa Film
description: The first Tokyo International Film Festival opened today with the premiere of ''Ran,'' a Shakespearean story in a Japanese feudal setting by Japan's most acclaimed director, Akira Kurosawa.

title: JUMP OF 272 WINS IN N.C.A.A. MEET
description: Mike Conley was tired from all his competition the two previous days, and he was worried about tightness and a fatigue cramp in his legs. But he put his troubles aside and ran and jumped near his best today in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 64th annual outdoor track and field championships.

title: Henry Kearns Is Dead; Headed Export Bank
description: Henry Kearns, who served in the Nixon Administration as president of the Export-Import Bank and in the Eisenhower Administration as Assistant Secretary of Commerce for International Affairs, died of cancer Wednesday. He was 74 years old.

title: GULFSTREAM OPTION SOLD TO CHRYSLER
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it had purchased an option to buy 20 percent of the stock of Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation at $19 a share and was talking with the company about a full merger.

title: Generals Are Perfect Hosts
description: The Generals will try for their 12th straight victory at Giants Stadium tonight when they play the Memphis Showboats in a contest having some bearing on the United States Football League's playoffs.

title: JUDGE FORBIDS ARMY TO BUILD GERM WAR FACILITY
description: In a setback for the Pentagon's plans for new chemical and biological warfare programs, a Federal district judge today forbade the Army to build new research laboratories at Dugway Proving Ground in Utah.

title: SPRINKLERS NOT SOUGHT, ATTRACTION BUILDER SAYS
description: The contractor who built the Haunted Castle at the Great Adventure amusement park testified today that the Six Flags Corporation required him to add a sprinkler system in a similar attraction that he built in Missouri but not in its Great Adventure attraction here.

title: Devils Drop Ron Low
description: The Devils, blessed with what they see as a wealth of talented young goaltenders, said hello to two promising minor leaguers yesterday and farewell to an ailing veteran - Ron Low, the 34-year-old backup goalie who missed 33 games because of back problems and ligament damage last season. Low, an 11-year veteran who came to the Devils from the Edmonton Oilers in 1982 and compiled a 6-11-4 record with a 3.85-goals-against average in 26 games last season, was told that he would not be offered a new contract and would be free to sign with another club without compensation to the Devils.

title: Iraq Announces Attack On Iranians in the South
description: Iraq said today that it had launched a sweeping attack on Iranian troops in Iraq's southern marshes.

title: USER-FRIENDLY AND UNFRIENDLY Confused Arrivals
description: Public transportation in New York City attracts any number of adjectives - but user-friendly isn't one of them. It's hard to get through to the Subway Bus and Information Service.

title: DUCKWALL-ALCO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REVISIONS FEARED IN SUBURBS
description: Municipal officials in suburban New York areas believe they will be faced with a taxpayer revolt if President Reagan's plan to eliminate deductions for local taxes becomes law.

title: Herman Entering Brooklyn Shrine
description: More than half a century ago, amid the magic of a place called Brooklyn, there was an outfielder and first baseman named Floyd Caves Herman, whose prodigious hitting and erratic - even eccentric - fielding and base running made him one of the most beloved of the borough's beloved Dodgers. Herman, who once fell victim to a fly ball that hit him squarely on the head and another time wound up at third base with not one but two other Brooklyn runners, was, notwithstanding all that, so gifted that in 1930 he batted .393, belted 35 homers, drove in 130 runs and scored 143 himself.

title: Protesters Lose Bid To Form Human Chain
description: It would have been a troubled bridge over water.

title: India Tightens Security As Sikhs Plan Protests
description: The Indian authorities said today that they had tightened security here and elsewhere in northern India in expectation of a week of anti-Government protests by Sikhs.

title: Puerto Rico Disaster Areas
description: President Reagan today issued a major disaster declaration for Puerto Rico because of severe storms, landslides, mud slides and flooding that began May 16. The action will permit the use of Federal funds in relief and recovery efforts in designated areas. Announcement of the move was made as Mr. Reagan visited this area to make a speech.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, JUNE 1, 1985

title: MOBILITY FOR THE POOR SOUGHT IN HOUSING PLAN
description: In January 1981, a Presidential commission touched off a heated debate by proposing that the Federal Government stop spending money to restore old industrial cities and instead help the inner-city poor to move and find jobs elsewhere.

title: CONCERT: YAMAKOSHI ON KOTO
description: Brian Yamakoshi performed on a recent invention, the 20-stringed koto, Thursday at Carnegie Recital Hall. The larger version of the traditional 13-stringed Japanese koto was created in 1969 by Keiko Nosaka, one of Mr. Yamakoshi's teachers, and the composer Minoru Miki, two of whose works were on the program.

title: A LIMITED PARTNERSHIP ESTABLISHED BY UNOCAL
description: In a follow-up to the anti-takeover strategy that led to a settlement with T. Boone Pickens, the Unocal Corporation yesterday registered a master limited partnership, a portion of which it will sell to the public and a portion of which it will distribute as an extra dividend to its shareholders.

title: SHULTZ, MEETING YOGOSLAV PREMIER, PROMISES ECONOMIC ASSISTANCE
description: Prime Minister of Yugoslavia met today with President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz for sessions that both sides described as friendly and useful.

title: GOOD HOUSEKEEPING: TESTS BEHIND THE SEAL
description: In the Beauty Clinic of the Good Housekeeping Institute, amid mauve upholstery, glass walls and computerized lighting, the subject for the day was hair mousse. One manufacturer, it seems, claims its product leaves hair shinier than its competitors'. But institute scientists slathered the brand on hair samples, massaged it onto live models and decided it did not.

title: Booklets at an Exhibition
description: For the first time, the Phillips Collection has produced a guide booklet to try to interest children in its masterpieces.

title: CONSOLIDATED PROFESSOR MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DAD'S ARCADIA (ALSO KNOWN AS THE BACKYARD)
description: Once upon a time, when ''upward mobility'' meant ''out of the city,'' my father decided he'd had enough of the brutalizing effects of Manhattan. Life in the giant grid, where one is propelled from job to home and back again, was, he said, far too rigorous. So we struggled into the Connecticut suburbs. My parents were proud to join the ranks of the other urban pilgrims, especially my father, who delighted in the prospect of having his ''own backyard.''

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 34. 1. As winner of the Jersey Derby, the Cherry Hill Mile, the Garden State Stakes and the Kentucky Derby, Spend a Buck won a series that earned him a $2 million bonus, for a total purse of $2.6 million, the largest in racing history. As well as being the fourth leg of that series, the Jersey Derby is the first leg of the New Jersey Challenge, a newly created three-race series that will offer a $1 million bonus. 2. The outburst was by Mehmet Ali Agca, a Turkish national convicted of wounding Pope John Paul II in an assassination attempt in 1981, as he gave testimony at the trial of eight defendants accused of plotting the assassination. 3. Unit 1 is the undamaged reactor at Three Mile Island that was shut down since its twin, Unit 2, was severely damaged in a nuclear accident in 1979. 4. Since the drug promotes hair growth as a side effect, doctors have been prescribing it to patients to combat baldness. 5. Mr. Navrotsky was a Red Army deserter who was discovered after hiding in a pigsty for 41 years. 6. The physicians say they are forced to restrict their practices because of rising malpractice insurance rates, increasing lawsuits and higher court awards. 7. Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the Emir of Kuwait, escaped assassination by car bomb for which a terrorist group, Islamic Holy War, claimed responsibility. President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon escaped injury when artillery shells and rockets struck the Presidential palace in Beirut. 8.

title: NEW YORK STUDYING THE HIRING PRACTICES OF CATHOLIC AGENCIES
description: Officials of the Koch administration are investigating whether city-financed social-service agencies run by the Archdiocese of New York require acceptance of Catholic religious beliefs as a qualification for employment.

title: PULLOUT IS NEARLY COMPLETE, BUT SOME ISRAELIS EXPECT TO STAY
description: A new steel gate set into concrete blocks on a back road here, 15 miles north of the Israeli border, marks the northernmost point of the security zone that Israel hopes to establish when it completes its formal withdrawal from Lebanon shortly.

title: CHILD-CARE CENTER REOPENS, BURYING THE TALES OF ABUSE
description: A Bronx day-care center that was closed last summer after three of its employees were indicted on charges of rape and child abuse, was reopened yesterday with new sponsorship, a bigger budget and room for more children.

title: Hormel to Terminate Contract With Union
description: Geo. A. Hormel & Company said today that it was terminating its contract with the meatpackers' union at its company headquarters plant, where workers have been protesting a wage cut.

title: MICROCOMPUTER MEMORIES reports earnings for Year to March 2
description: b-Revenues were not reported for the year-ago period.

title: PALESTINIAN STRONGHOLD IN BEIRUT FALLS TO SHIITES
description: Shiite Moslem militiamen, backed by soldiers from the Lebanese Army's mainly Shiite Sixth Brigade, won control of the last stronghold in the Palestinian refugee settlement of Sabra today.

title: Added Attraction
description: The discouragement of rival base runners is another way in which Gary Carter's acquisition has marked a strengthening of the Mets.

title: BRITON WILL LAUNCH U.S. PUBLISHING HOUSE
description: Three months after gaining a foothold in American book publishing with his $2 million purchase of Grove Press, George Weidenfeld, the chairman of one of Britain's leading publishing houses, is about to launch Weidenfeld & Nicolson in New York. Lord Weidenfeld's partner is Ann Getty, the wife of an heir to the Getty oil fortune.

title: SHOREHAM PLANT: 3 OBSTACLES REMAIN
description: The Long Island Lighting Company made a friend yesterday out of one of its worst enemies, the Suffolk County Executive. It was a major step toward licensing the Shoreham nuclear power plant, but the company still has at least three other obstacles to overcome. The utility's new ally, Peter F. Cohalan, has for the last two years been perhaps the most important opponent of the plant, arguing that Long Island's geography would make evacuation impossible in an emergency, and therefore that the county would not participate in developing the emergency plans required before a license can be issued.

title: HURCO COS reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,977,000.

title: ASSAULT BY CRANE
description: Another assault by construction crane took place on Thursday in broad daylight at 63rd Street and Third Avenue. A woman pedestrian was severely hurt; both her legs were partially severed below the knee. The results of emergency surgery will not be known for a while.

title: KOCH TO SEEK CRIMINAL CHARGES IN CRANE TOPPLING
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the city would seek criminal charges against everyone responsible in the toppling of the crane Thursday on the Upper East Side that seriously injured a pedestrian.

title: SHULTZ SEES GAINS FOR MIDEAST PEACE FROM HUSSEIN VISIT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that talks with King Hussein of Jordan during his visit here this week had advanced the prospects for Middle East peace ''in a very significant way.''

title: Wallace Attacker's Hearing
description: Arthur H. Bremer, who tried to assassinate Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama when he was campaigning for the Presidency in 1972, will get his first parole hearing Thursday, state officials said today. Mr. Bremer, 34 years old, is serving a 53-year sentence at the Maryland Correctional Institution near here for the attack, which took place at a shopping center in Laurel. Mr. Wallace was paralyzed below the waist when he was shot five times. Mr. Bremer is automatically entitled to the parole hearing because he has served about one-fourth of his sentence, a prison official said.

title: Turner's Detente Plan
description: Ted Turner, who recently announced an agreement for his Turner Broadcasting System to exchange news and entertainment programs with Soviet television, has reportedly asked Soviet approval for a binational ''Goodwill Games,'' which would be held in non-Olympic years at sites alternating between the United States and the Soviet Union. Turner would not comment on the report in The Atlanta Journal, but the reported proposal may have a certain appeal.

title: Produce Prices Dip
description: Prices farmers receive for raw products dropped 1.5 percent in May, to their lowest average level in more than two years, the Agriculture Department said today. The preliminary reading was 11 percent below a year ago.

title: Case of the Duplicate Pseudo-Barabbas, Cont.
description: To the Editor:

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Seattle Mariners, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. (Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Padres, at San Diego (Television - SportsChannel, 10 P.M. (Radio - WHN, 1050; 10 P.M.) Tigers vs. California Angels, at Detroit. (Television -Channel 4, 1:15 P.M.) Astros vs. Chicago Cubs, at Houston. Second game of the radio-game-of-the-week revival. (Radio - WCBS, 880; 8:20 P.M.) Atlanta Braves vs. Pirates, at Pittsburgh. (Television - WTBS, 7:05 P.M.) College World Series: Opening round, Stanford vs. Miami. (Television - ESPN, 5 P.M.); Texas vs. Arizona (Television - ESPN, 10:30 P.M., tape). Boxing Carlos Santos vs. Louis Acaries, 15 rounds for the I.B.F. junior middleweight championship, at Paris. This is the third title defense for Santos (27-1), who won his title from Mark Medal last November and has 19 career knockouts. Acaries, former junior middleweight and middleweight champion of France, is 39-5 with 19 knockouts. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M.) Football Generals vs. Memphis Showboats at Giants Stadium, 7 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; 7 P.M.) New York's Finest vs. New York's Bravest, Fun City Bowl XIII, to benefit Widows and Children's Fund, at Baker Field, 218th Street and Broadway, 8 P.M. This is the annual clash between police and fire department teams. Running L'eggs Mini Marathon, 10,000 meters (6.2 miles), at Tavern on the Green, 67th Street and West Drive, Central Park, 10:30 A.M. Grete Waitz, the defending champion, will be challenged by Joan Benoit, winner of the first Olympic women's marathon last year as Miss Waitz won the silver.

title: PERFECT-GAME BID IS ENDED AFTER 7-2/3
description: The St. Louis right-hander Danny Cox pitched perfect ball for 7Z innings, finishing with a brilliant two-hitter, and Jack Clark's two-run homer highlighted a three-run third inning, leading the Cardinals to a 5-0 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

title: ENGLISH QUIT EUROPEAN SOCCER FOR A YEAR
description: The organization that governs soccer competition in England, acting two days after English fans helped instigate a fatal stadium riot in Brussels, announced today that no clubs under its jurisdiction would enter European competition next season.

title: Sharon Steel Continues Talks
description: The Sharon Steel Corporation said yesterday that it plans to continue negotiations with Jeffrey Schultz, senior vice president of the Seidman Capital Corporation and Sharon's largest debenture holder, a day after Mr. Schultz threatened to force the company into filing for bankruptcy protection.

title: FACTORY ORDERS FALL 0.5% MORE
description: Factory orders fell five-tenths of 1 percent in April, with both durable and nondurable goods showing declines, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: OILERS LOOK AHEAD
description: After the Edmonton Oilers won their second straight Stanley Cup Thursday night, Glen Sather, their coach, general manager and president, said he wanted more of them.

title: IN PARAGUAY, FROM LOYALTY FLOWS GOOD FORTUNE
description: Occasionally hidden behind high walls but more often standing proudly among lawns and trees, the tourist sights of this city are monuments to a 31-year-old dictatorship.

title: NEW BOARD FOR COAST THRIFT UNIT
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board yesterday announced the appointment of a new board of directors for the ailing Central Savings and Loan Association of San Diego, after efforts to find a buyer apparently failed.

title: PITTSBURGH BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FILM: 'SILENT MADNESS,' SORORITY HOUSE HORROR
description: ''Silent Madness'' is an inept, talky horror film that looks as if it may have been designed for 3-D, though it has not been released that way. The credits say it was filmed in ''Arrivision 3-D,'' and the color is characteristically wan. Every now and then, somebody aims something - an ax, a meat hook, a rifle - at the camera. This small peculiarity is the film's only noteworthy feature.

title: Impressing the Russians
description: President Reagan has moved to give more prestige to the delegation he sent to Geneva to negotiate arms reduction with the Soviet Union. To impress the Russians with the caliber of the delegation, the President has given what is called ''personal rank of Ambassador'' to four deputies and one coordinator at the talks.

title: No Retirement in Fight Against a Disease
description: Forty years ago, Sylvia Lawry placed a three-line classified advertisement in this newspaper: ''Multiple sclerosis. Will anyone recovered from it please communicate with patient.

title: VON BULOW DEFENSE REBUTS INSULIN COMA THEORY
description: Claus von Bulow's trial defense team today pressed its attack on the theory that deliberate insulin injections caused Martha von Bulow to suffer comas in 1979 and 1980.

title: 5 Additional Members Of Neo-Nazi Group Held
description: The second-in-command of the white supremacist group the Covenant, the Sword and the Arm of the Lord was arrested today on weapons charges, and four reputed members were arrested in Missouri, the authorities said.

title: How to Live Up to the Spirit of the Refugee Act
description: To the Editor:

title: Hughes Aides Set Meeting
description: The Howard Hughes Medical Institute, owner of the Hughes Aircraft Company, said yesterday that its nine trustees would meet in Manhattan Tuesday amid signs that it will announce the winner of a multibillion-dollar sealed bidding contest for the giant defense supplier.

title: YANKEES NUDGE 3 HONORS
description: Is there such a thing as a bloop home run? If there isn't, the Yankees invented one last night when they popped three balls just inside the Yankee Stadium foul poles, and just over the fences.

title: Out-of-State Wine Products Allowed in New York Stores
description: New York's 23,000 grocery stores can start stocking their shelves with out-of-state wine coolers today.

title:
Patents;

Advances In Laser Recording
description: THE RCA Corporation registered advances this week in its development of solid-state lasers for optical recording. Such equipment can be used to store vast quantities of information from weather satellites and other sources on disks by using light beams.

title: 3 Killed in Basque Violence
description: Three people, including a 14-year-old boy, have been killed in what appears to be an upsurge of Basque separatist violence in the last 24 hours. The boy and a policeman were killed by a bomb that wounded three other policemen and a woman Thursday night. The bomb exploded shortly after two men shot and killed a munitions factory manager near the Basque port of Bilbao.

title: SEVEN INDICTED FOR DRUGS ARE SAID TO SELL TO PLAYERS
description: Seven men were indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on drug charges. No baseball players were mentioned in the indictments, but sources familiar with the investigation said all seven men were involved in selling drugs to players and that one traveled to at least five other National League cities to supply cocaine to players.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Italy Without Opera?
description: The Italian Ambassador, Rinaldo Petrignani, is opening his Washington residence, Villa Firenze, for a party next Friday night to help the Washington Opera raise money.

title: OSHMAN'S SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: b-Net income.

title: CONCERT: BENSON AND FLACK
description: George Benson and Roberta Flack, who headlined a three-night engagement at Radio City Music Hall, Thursday through Saturday, have more in common than simply being paragons of adult pop-soul music. Both are singer-instrumentalists whose vocal personalities are very much related to their respective instruments - the piano and the guitar.

title: TRADE DEFICIT UP $11.9 BILLION
description: The foreign trade deficit, symbol of a sputtering economy, surged by a near-record $11.9 billion in April as domestic manufacturers found it increasingly difficult to market their high-priced goods abroad, the Government said today.

title: MARCOS FAULTS AQUINO TRIAL
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, in remarks made public today, has dismissed as perjury the testimony against the military men who are on trial for the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. Opposition figures immediately accused Mr. Marcos of trying to sway the three-judge court that is now hearing the case against 26 defendants, who include the former Armed Forces Chief of Staff, Gen. Fabian C. Ver, a relative and close friend of the President.

title: WILSON FOODS CORP reports earnings for 13wks to April 27
description: b-Net income after extraordinary gains of $5,817,000 for the quarter and $30,726,000 for the 9 months. c-After an extraordinary gain of $564,000. The 1984 figures have been reclassified for accounting changes.

title: WHEN NEW YORK CARES
description: Sometimes the worst of events extracts the best from humanity. Brigitte Gerney's ordeal is proof of that.

title: THE RESTRUCTURING OF APPLE COMPUTER
description: Apple Computer Inc. took a giant step today in the painful transition from its entrepreneurial origins to the ranks of more conventionally managed multibillion-dollar companies.

title: MGF PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After provisions amounting to $20,601,000 for additional depreciation depletion and amortization. c-After provisions amounting to $26,029,000 for additional depreciation depletion and amortization.

title:
PATENTS;

Detecting Cancer
description: A common garden slug, limax flavus, is the source of a new and potentially powerful cancer-detecting chemical patented this week by Ronald L. Miller, a biochemist at the Medical University of South Carolina in Charleston. The chemical, called a lectin, reacts strongly with sialic acid, which is believed to exist in large quantities in the blood serum of cancer patients. Patent No. 4,520,111 is assigned to the Research Corporation, a nonprofit foundation with offices in New York and Tucson, Ariz., which is offering licenses.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Placed Len Barker, pitcher, on 15-day disabled list.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SATURDAY, JUNE 1, 1985

title: A SHARP RISE IN BOND PRICES
description: Bond prices rose sharply yesterday, as a spate of weak economic data led many traders and investors to conclude that the Federal Reserve will promote lower interest rates in the future.

title: Steel Lobby Cuts Back
description: As the steel industry goes, so goes the American Iron and Steel Institute.

title: 9th Loss for Streaky Twins
description: Cecil Cooper smacked a three-run triple in the fifth inning tonight to help the Milwaukee Brewers hand the Minnesota Twins its ninth straight loss, 6-4.

title: RESTORING CIVIL RIGHTS
description: Should a school or hospital be free to discriminate in hiring for, say, its cafeteria, while it accepts Federal funds to build a new department? Overwhelming majorities in Congress believe not and were dismayed last year when the Supreme Court narrowed the scope of anti-discrimination laws to permit such devious bookkeeping.

title: A THREAT TO THE AIRWAVES
description: The recent sale of American Broadcasting Companies and current attempts to take over CBS Inc. signal a threat to public control of the airwaves. The merger activity reflects a larger tendency - spurred by key decisions of the Federal Communications Commission - toward the greatest concentration of communications power in American history.

title: 106 Reported Injured In a British Train Crash
description: An express train carrying tourists from the Gatwick Airport to Victoria Station in London today struck the rear of a commuter train, railroad and hospital officials said.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46. 1. This was a $2 million finish and, perhaps, a $1 million start. Explain. 2. ''I am Jesus Christ! I am omnipotent, and I announce the end of the world!'' Whose exclamations were these and what were the circumstances? 3. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted to lift the order that has kept Unit 1 idle for over five years. What is Unit 1? 4. Minoxidil tablets, manufactured by the Upjohn Company and meant to be taken internally for the treatment of hypertension, are instead being crushed, mixed with liquids and rubbed. What is the reason? 5. ''Will I be punished?'' asked a bearded, ragged and unwashed 74-year-old man, Pavel Navrotsky, as he emerged from a pigsty in the tiny Soviet village of Sarazhentsy. What were the circumstances? 6. The six neurosurgeons in private practice in Syracuse will no longer perform operations there, and other neurosurgeons, obstetricians and orthopedic surgeons across upstate New York are also sharply restricting their practices. What is the reason? 7. Two leaders of nations in the Middle East escaped bombings, one that was an assassination attempt, the other that was not. Who are they and what were the circumstances? 8. According to recent research, the most important determinant of job satisfaction is (a high income/a harmonious relationship with colleagues/an ability to influence what happens on the job). 9. According to the White House, about (10/15/20/25) percent of taxpayers would see their income tax bills go up under President Reagan's new tax proposals, and the remainder would pay either a smaller tax bill or about the same as they pay now. 10.

title: Farrell Gains Ground In His Home Territory
description: Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr.'s sputtering mayoral candidacy has received a much-needed boost from an endorsement by the Manhattan Democratic organization.

title:
PATENTS;

Method to Detect Virus That Is Linked to AIDS
description: A method of detecting antibodies in blood samples that indicate the presence of the virus believed to cause Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome, or AIDS, and other diseases was patented this week for the Department of Health and Human Services.

title:
PATENTS;

New Heart Device
description: An instrument for non-invasive measurement of cardiovascular conditions, invented by Dr. William J.M. Hrushesky of the medical faculty at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis, was patented this week. Patent No. 4,519,395 describes the machine's microcomputer, heart rate and respiration detectors and means for displaying the many calculations. Dr. Hrushesky has said his invention will provide a method of screening cardiovascular function.

title: I.R.S. STARTS PAYING INTEREST ON REFUNDS
description: The Internal Revenue Service began paying interest today on a huge backlog of taxpayer refunds that has built up because of computer problems and a deluge of last-minute returns during the filing season.

title: SUPERTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary credit of $105,000 for the quarter and a tax benefit of $855,000 for the year.

title: TAX PLAN PROMISES LEAN YEARS FOR BUSINESS LUNCH
description: ''Frank,'' a pin-striped man asked Frank Melman, ''how do you see all of this impacting lunch?''

title: Young Liberals Get the Juices Flowing Again at Fund Event
description: These days it is the conservatives who rent the big halls, attract the crowds and, it seems, have all the fun. It can get a bit dispiriting for all the young liberals who came here from places like Ann Arbor, Oshkosh and Des Moines. They want to be movers and shakers, at the center of things, but instead find themselves exiled to a political underground, scrambling to find a sympathetic ear for their programs and ideas.

title: Bridge: Veteran Players Reach Final Of Reisinger Championship
description: Two great veteran players, Sam Stayman of Palm Beach, Fla., and Cliff Russell of Miami, led teams that survived hard semifinal battles in the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship Thursday night and faced each other in the final last night.

title: MAKING MAKEUP AT HOME
description: ''THIS mask, you put it in the freezer then put it on your eyes to reduce puffiness,'' said the woman, demonstrating. ''It costs $20.''

title: STANDARD BRANDS PAINT CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
U.S. Out of World Cup
description: Evaristo Coronado scored late in the first half tonight to lift Costa Rica to a 1-0 victory over the United States national team in a World Cup qualifying soccer match. The loss ended the United States' bid to reach the 1986 World Cup tournament in Mexico.

title: By 6 Die in Carolina Crash Of Truck and School Bus
description: A tractor-trailer truck carrying farm produce collided with a school bus today, killing five pupils and the truck driver and injuring 20 others, the authorities said.

title: User-Friendly and Unfriendly Reserved Parking
description: New York City contains too many vehicles and too few places to park them legally. That's why drivers are continually cajoled to take public transportation, and penalized with high tolls.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: NEW OPERA They are smaller than previews and bigger than promotional glimpses, and they should give their audiences a taste of a new work that will make its official appearance in November at the New York City Opera. They are the performances of excerpts from the opera ''Casanova'' tomorrow at 7 P.M. and Monday at 8 P.M. at the Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue and 88th Street.

title: ASBESTOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results include a foreign exchange gain of $212,000 in the latest quarter and a foreign exchange loss of $1,116,000 in the year-ago period, and shutdown costs of $2,049,000 in the latest quarter and $2,739,000 in the year- ago quarter. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: WORSE THAN ZUCCHINI
description: We are in a rustic town, a town whose houses have lawns whose main crop is grass, which is not the most pointless crop you can grow, but a close second after zucchini, or so it has always seemed to me until 90 minutes ago. Since then I have been reflecting that even zucchini may be preferable to grass.

title: COLLEGE COST HAS MATCHED INFLATION SINCE '74
description: Spot checks of colleges and universities around the country indicate that most private institutions will raise their charges for the 1985-86 academic year by 7 to 9 percent.

title: Reagan the Joke Thief
description: The chairman of the New Jersey Governor's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, Edward W. Bradley, thought the joke was familiar. It was about a man who kept missing a golf ball next to an anthill, with one of the ants saying that for continued survival it was necessary to get on the ball.

title: GRAND AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings include an estimated LIFO adjustment based on current prices and inventory levels. The year-end determination, made at Jan. 26, 1986, could vary from this estimate.

title: As the Church Sees It
description: To the Editor:

title: GANDHI AND SRI LANKA LEADER PLAN A JOINT BANGLADESH VISIT
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India and President J. R. Jayewardene of Sri Lanka will travel together to Bangladesh to express sympathy for the victims of the recent cyclone disaster there, an Indian spokesman said today.

title: Trade Panel Gives Relief to Tandon
description: The International Trade Commission today granted the Tandon Corporation's request for temporary relief against the Sony Corporation, the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation and the Teac Corporation involving the importing of double-sided floppy disk drive products into the United States. Tandon lawyers said that the company expects the commission to order the Japanese companies to post bond for all domestic floppy disk-drive sales while a patent infringement case is pending.

title: RASPBERRY JAM WITH LESS SUGAR
description: ''The trouble with most raspberry jam,'' says Rose Levy Beranbaum, ''is that it has too much sugar in it, and if you try to cut back on the sugar the pectin won't jell the jam.''

title: Strong Buy Advice Spurs UAL Stock
description: The stock of UAL Inc., parent of United Airlines, jumped $4.25 today, to $53.625, in active trading after the First Boston Corporation issued a ''strong buy'' recommendation. The increase was credited with helping push the Dow Jones index of transporation issues up 15.51, to 645.16.

title: A SPIRITED CAMPAIGN ENDS IN GREECE
description: The Greek election campaign came to a close tonight with the last of three huge and exuberant rallies in the capital, this one featuring Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Palestinians need hope, the Israelis need trust. It is important for all of us to provide the hope and the trust they need.''

title: TSENG LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: TAX PLAN WARMLY RECEIVED IN HIGH-TECH CENTER
description: Entrepreneurs, workers, executives and other residents of greater Philadelphia's emerging high-technology area greeted President Reagan and his tax program today with open arms, decorous enthusiasm and in some cases, mild skepticism.

title: CITY PLANS ADDED WATER CURBS FOR RESIDENTS AND BUSINESSES
description: New York City, faced with a dwindling water supply at a time when use normally increases, plans to increase water-use restrictions next week, officials said yesterday.

title: Blast Near Rhein-Main Base
description: A bomb exploded today in a safety shaft leading to an underground fuel pipeline near Rhein-Main Air Base, the police said. A spokesman said no one was hurt in the explosion, which occurred in the village of Morfelden-Walldorf, and there was little damage. A leftist group called the Revolutionary Cells took responsibility for the bombing in a telephone call to the village priest.

title: MACDERMID INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring after-tax gain of $648,000 on the sale of a subsidiary. Share earnings have been restated to reflect the effects of a 2-for-1 stock split effective Sept. 4, 1984.

title: U.S. WILL BAN 'ECSTASY,' A HALLUCINOGENIC DRUG
description: Federal officials announced today that they were taking emergency action to ban a drug widely known as Ecstasy, saying that abuse of the drug had become a nationwide problem.

title: 'Are the Armenians There Wiped Out?'
description: To the Editor:

title: Techniques for Finding Missing Children
description: To the Editor:

title: THE PAPAL PLOT IN COURT
description: Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turkish gunman, claims he is the reincarnation of Jesus. . . . A distinguished Italian magistrate believes Mr. Agca was hired by Bulgaria to kill Pope John Paul II to serve ''the higher interests of the Soviet bloc.'' . . . The Soviet Government charges the trial was inspired by the C.I.A. Not all these assertions can be adjudicated, but the great trial now begun in Italy may finally test the probabilities - about Mr. Agca's sanity, his contacts with Bulgaria and the reasons for bringing this case to court.

title: DOCTORS PRAISE HER COURAGE
description: When Brigitte Gerney opened her eyes yesterday after surgery at Bellevue Hospital Center, she gave thanks to those who had helped her during what she called ''this terrible ordeal.''

title: LED MINERS' UNION
description: W. A. Boyle, the powerful leader of the nation's coal miners until he was convicted of embezzlement and of ordering the murder of a union rival and his family, died yesterday morning at Wilkes-Barre General Hospital in Wilkes-Barre, Pa. He was 83 years old.

title: MCDERMOTT INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
45 HOTELS STRUCK BY 12,000 WORKERS
description: Bellhops, maids, clerks, chefs and other workers struck 45 of New York City's biggest and best-known hotels early today in a labor dispute that was expected to affect tens of thousands of hotel residents and guests.

title: DOW GAINS 9.63, to a Record 1,315.41
description: Stock prices rose sharply yesterday on Wall Street, and the Dow Jones industrial average shattered its 10-day-old record, as investors reacted favorably to lower interest rates and speculation that borrowing costs would come down even more.

title: LOPEZ WIDENS LEAD TO 4
description: One day after being assessed a two-stroke penalty but nevertheless taking the tournament lead by three strokes, Nancy Lopez said that the incident interfered with her concentration today. But that did not prevent her from increasing her lead to four shots after the second round of the 31st annual Ladies Professional Golf Association Championship.

title: Stars Dim for Brooks
description: Lou Nanne, the general manager of the Minnesota North Stars, said he had broken off negotiations with Herb Brooks because of the former Ranger coach's ambivalence about taking the vacant coaching job. He said he was interviewing other candidates.

title: DANCE: 'LUNAR PARABLES' BY PEARSON COMPANY
description: Sara and Jerry Pearson have put to good use the lessons they learned as onetime members of the Alwin Nikolais and Murray Louis dance companies. A basic dance technique, tied to an accompanying view about man's place in the universe, serves as their creative springboard.

title: GROCERY BAGS AID SEARCH FOR CHILDREN
description: GROCERY bags have joined toll tickets, milk cartons, posters, videotapes and television spots in the nationwide effort to find some 1.8 million children who disappear each year.

title: EMBATTLED GEMAYEL TURNS TO SYRIA
description: SHIITE Moslem forces last week advanced in their drive to win control of West Beirut and southern Lebanon, where they are the largest ethnic group. The Shiite successes dealt new blows to the virtually powerless Government of President Amin Gemayel, a Maronite Christian.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN SPECIAL INTEREST MAGAZINES;

RACING TO REACH THE OVER-50 MARKET
description: TIME was when old folks were thought of as fogeys living on Social Security, ''old ladies in shawls sitting in rocking chairs,'' as Robert Thompson put it.

title: A SUB-MINIMUM WAGE IS WORTH TRYING
description: JOBLESSNESS among teen-agers has expanded steadily over the last 30 years despite numerous efforts to combat it. In 1954, the overall youth unemployment rate was 12.6 percent. Last year, in the midst of a national economic resurgence, it was 18.9 percent. And for young black people, the unemployment rate was a demoralizing 43 percent.

title:
ANTIQUES;

OLD SKILLS TO BE DEMONSTRATED
description: NO matter what other profession or trade might also have been followed in colonial Connecticut, there were few families who did not own farmland. Many could boast, as one wrote, that, with the help of their families, everything needed was produced on the family farm.

title: NATIVE ORCHIDS: ENJOY THEM, BUT DO NOT DISTURB
description: Every wildflower gardener at some time usually has the temptation to cultivate one or more native orchids.

title: Jolt of Electricity From Phone Is Cited in Teen-Ager's Death
description: A healthy 17-year-old who died while talking on the telephone might have been killed by a charge of electricity caused by lightning striking phone wires, an investigator with the New Jersey Medical Examiner's office said.

title: A MT. VERNON REPLICA SOUGHT FOR COUNTY
description: IT may be a tad large for a family of four. But County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke believes that the Somers estate once belonging to William and Mildred Lasdon - which includes a 25-room, 8,000-square-foot mansion set on 207 acres - is just the right size for a county of 866,599 residents.

title: AFTER A BURGLARY
description: I HEARD GLASS BREAK, but it didn't wake me enough to crawl out from under the comforter on the coldest night of the winter. I heard voices, but they were too remote for me to realize they came from our living room. It wasn't until the telephone receiver hit the floor in the kitchen that I accepted the idea that someone I didn't know had found his way in.

title: Bronx Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: IN QUOTES
description: The tax system is 'a system whose most serious sin may be its most subtle. . . . For it seems so rigged, so unfair, that it corrupts otherwise honest people by encouraging them to cheat.'

title: RESTRICTIONS ON WATER USE FORWEWARNED
description: WITHOUT long, soaking rains in coming weeks, much of Connecticut may face late-summer restrictions on washing cars, watering lawns and filling swimming pools.

title:
ART;

THE POWER OF THE PLUM BLOSSOM
description: THE featured exhibition at the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven carries a poetically imposing title: ''Bones of Jade, Soul of Ice.'' What is being described is the simple plum blossom, and that seemingly modest theme, explored in its many ramifications, makes for a sweeping and absorbing show.

title: TRAVEL
description: There are two kinds of travel books - those that tell how to get there and those that tell how the writer went there himself. The first is useful; the second is fun. The first you thumb through frantically while you're on the road; the second you read comfortably at home, imagining a trip of your own someday.

title: COMMUNICATION FAMILY-STYLE
description: IN this age of information explosion, with radio, television, computers and satellites, there is one mundane source of communication available in every home and critical to the passage of information among family members - the refrigerator door.

title: ROBERTA WEXLER WED TO MORTON MANEKER
description: The marriage of Roberta Wexler, director of public relations for the Direct Marketing Association in New York, and Morton M. Maneker, a partner in the New York law firm of Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn, took place yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria. Justice Leonard H. Sandler of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: Boxer Listed Critical After Brain Surgery
description: Shawn Thomas of Detroit remained hospitalized in critical condition today after being knocked out in a boxing match and then undergoing brain surgery Wednesday night.

title: TARA FIELDS, THERAPIST, IS ENGAGED TO A WRITER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Fields of New York and Woodstock, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tara Temple Fields, and Randall Sullivan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Sullivan of Portland, Ore.

title: SECOND-BEST 'EVITA!' IS AT THE PAPER MILL
description: ONE DOES not have to be an inveterate theatergoer to know that this past Broadway season was the most depressing and uneventful in an eon or two.

title: USING THE OUTDOORS AS A CLASSROOM
description: FLOATING across Blue Heron Lake in an inflatable boat, students from the Fox Lane Middle School collected samples of algae that will help them understand the aging process of ponds and lakes. An earth sciences class from Fox Lane High School plotted the contours of the landscape shaped long ago by glaciers. Tory Mercer stared into a dragonfly's eyes. In pursuit of historical research, Lisa Franzen drove a team of oxen. A book is being written. Lady-slippers are spotted.

title: His Later Conservatism
description: To the Editor:

title: GASOLINE PRICES HIT SUMMER PEAK
description: THE price of gasoline, which has been rising on Long Island for the last few months, is at its seasonal peak and should remain at that level or cheaper for the rest of the summer, according to both private and government sources.

title: Amber Light for Three Mile Island
description: Memories of the 1979 accident at Three Mile Island, when a nuclear generating plant's cooling system failed and radiation spewed over a patch of Pennsylvania countryside southeast of Harrisburg, have had a long half-life. The incident continues to be cited as proof that power-plant designers, builders and operators cannot yet safely transform a nuclear reaction into electrical power.

title: WHEN TV LOOKS AT AN ISSUE, THE PICTURE OFTEN CHANGES
description: Television raises disposable issues. Topics come and go. New causes, fresh diversions, change with the seasons. Television shapes the popular culture, and the popular culture thrives on what is new. Merchandising is seldom far behind. This season television turned its attention to missing children, for example, and in the wake came marketable products - abduction insurance, abduction kits, dental microchips that may be placed in children's teeth for positive identification. Television is not responsible for the products, of course, any more than it is responsible for the missing children. At the same time, television promotes an issue when it examines it, no matter how responsibly it conducts the examination. It does the same with people and movements, too.

title: No Headline
description: Beach Erosion's Effects on Economy The grim, unsettling article on Westhampton's barrier beach [''Ocean Winning Battle of Barrier Beach,'' May 12] pertinently describes how the seemingly inevitable ocean breakthrough will dramatically alter the ecology - but what of the equally important economy?

title: Picking Sides
description: As a player-manager he may have a slice in both slots, but when it comes to labor negotiations, Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds knows which side his hyphen is buttered on. ''My vote is like every other player's vote should be: to honor the players' association,'' he said before the Reds conducted a strike authorization vote yesterday. Rose, who indicated that he would support a strike even though it would interrupt his run at Ty Cobb's record for career hits, said he was supporting the union ''because of the things they've done for the players over the course of the last 20 years.'' As for the owners, who say they lost as much as $42 million last year and $66 million the year before, Rose doesn't buy it. ''Don't you ever ask yourself,'' he asked, ''why one team can give a guy $2 million a year, then turn around and say they're losing money? I happen to think I know a little bit about what's going on. I went through free agency. Have you ever heard of a player going to an owner and talking with a gun to his head, holding him up? Yet don't they give out 40-year contracts and things like that? Does that sound like they're losing money?'' . . . Not to Ron Davis, the player representative, and 24 other Minnesota Twins. They joined the Yankees, the Chicago Cubs, the Milwaukee Brewers and the Seattle Mariners in lopsided strike authorizattion votes that Davis hopes will send the owners an unmistakable message: Give up the idea of taking back the one-third share of television revenue that now goes to the players' pension fund.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: SAFELY AFLOAT When it comes to timeliness, Safe Boating Week this week is right up there because the Island's waterways will soon be clogged with boaters. But before they cast off, the folks who oversee these waterways want to be sure the boaters know what they're doing. Hence, the week begins with two festivals today: from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. at the Bay Shore Marina (South Clinton Avenue); and from noon to 5 P.M. at the Wantagh Park Marina, off Merrick Road. Both festivals feature safe-boating demonstrations and exhibitions. In Bay Shore, at 2 P.M., what the boaters learn will be put to use as they sail by for a traditional blessing of the fleet. In Wantagh, the blessing takes place at noon Saturday.

title: Denver Pollution
description: FOR 305 days of the year, the carbon monoxide in Denver's air is ''well below'' the Federal limit of 9 parts per million for any eight-hour average, according to the Colorado Department of Health. But in the remaining 60 days, the city has one of the highest levels of carbon monoxide in the country - 24 parts per million on the average.

title: MINORITY GROUPS ASSAIL END OF SAN DIEGO HIRING GOALS
description: Local black and Hispanic leaders have criticized the agreement between the Justice Department and the City of San Diego to drop court-sanctioned numerical goals for the city's hiring of women and members of minorities. The department and the city contend that the goals had substantially been reached.

title: CHILDREN'S DENTISTRY STUDIED
description: DR. MONICA H. CIPES knows a visit to the dentist does not have to be a terrifying experience for a preschooler, because for her own children, ages 3 and 5, ''dentistry is just a part of life.''

title: NINA LEROY HAS NUPTIALS
description: Nina LeRoy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Palmer LeRoy of Bedford, N.Y., and Nantucket, Mass., and Ogden McClurg Hunnewell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Hunnewell of Westwood, Mass., and Prouts Neck, Me., were married yesterday. The Rev. William Foley performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford.

title: PARENTAL ROLE CITED IN CURBING DRUG USE
description: ALTHOUGH many of New Jersey's 55 private boarding and day schools have taken steps to curb student abuse of drugs and alcohol, those steps, say doctors and school officials, will be futile without the cooperation of parents.

title: WASTE DISPOSAL BY INCINERATION
description: EACH year, the advanced industrial society that has given the American people the highest living standard in the world generates more than a quarter-billion tons of hazardous waste.

title: ADELPHI NAMES EX-CALIFORNIA EDUCATOR AS ITS NEW PRESIDENT
description: A former president of California State University at Sonoma has been appointed the new president of Adelphi University in Garden City, L.I.

title: ITALIAN WITH A PERSONAL TOUCH
description: DARIO Piccola Trieste, a small, bright, five-month-old restaurant in West Hempstead, is decorated with the red walls and scenic oil paintings that can be typical in Italian restaurants. But the atmosphere is distinctive in a manner unrelated to the setting. It is place where the convivial enthusiasm and attentiveness of the owner, Dario Viscovi, helps to make a meal enjoyable.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: AT A TIME when much of the news about nongame wildlife has to do with declining and endangered species, the Eastern meadowlark, a brightly colored songbird, appears to be prospering in New Jersey.

title: New Food Rules In Massachusetts
description: The Massachusetts Department of Public Health has revised its 20-year-old regulations for restaurants and food stores. The new rules, which are to be effective Oct. 1, were announced after the disclosure two weeks ago of a 1982 survey by the Federal Food and Drug Administration that found restaurants in 10 Massachusetts communities to be dirtier than most.

title: STUDENTS PUT THEIR BEST NOTES FORWARD
description: More than 1,200 county children from elementary school through high school participated in the New York State Music Association's yearly two-day Solo and Ensemble Evaluation Festival, held this year at the Dow's Lane Elementary School in Irvington.

title: FLIGHTS OF FLORAL FANCY
description: VISITS THIS SPRING TO FLOWER shows in Philadelphia, Boston and New York reveal how the art of landscape design has now transformed these events into garden fantasies.

title: Top Golfers
description: Clark Burroughs, the collegiate golf champion from Ohio State, and Scott Verplank, the United States Amateur champion from Oklahoma State, head a list of eight players named to the 1985 All-America team by the Golf Coaches Association of America. Others are Duffy Waldorf of U.C.L.A., Steve Elkington of Houston, Dave Peege of Mississippi, Trevor Dodds of Lamar, Sam Randolph of Southern California and Davis Love 3d of North Carolina. . . . Ben Crenshaw, winner of the 1984 Masters Tournament, will receive the annual Gold Tee Award for contribtuions to the game of golf from the Metropolitan Golf Writers and Golf Casters Association Tuesday night at the organization's annual banquet.

title: FAREWELL TO THE JEEP
description: In the confusion over the President's military budget and tax reform plans, it has scarcely been noticed that the Pentagon decided the other day to get rid of the Jeep, and replace it with something called a ''High Mobility Multipurpose Wheeled Vehicle'' (H.M.M.W.V.) at $25,000 a copy.

title: OFFICIAL CRITICIZED FOR REMARKS ON NOISE
description: Madam, choke on your words!

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: THE First Jersey National Corporation, a $2.7 billion bank holding company based in Jersey City, opened its 100th office yesterday at the site of a former Montclair railroad station.

title: New England Boat Deaths
description: Massachusetts had more recreational boating deaths last year and Rhode Island had fewer than any other New England state, according to the Coast Guard. It said that 19 people died in 16 Massachusetts boating accidents in 1984, while Rhode Island had only two. Nationwide, the fatalities totaled 1,063, the lowest since 1962, when there were 1,114 deaths, the Coast Guard said.

title: For Women, Change Is Not Evolution
description: I found Thelma Sokoloff's article ''She's Nobody's Stereotype Now'' [Opinion Page, April 21] rather interesting. I believe the writer is trying to say that, although her personal life style has always been the antithesis of the stereotypical suburban housewife, what a woman chooses to do professionally - be it full-time homemaking, outside the home employment, or volunteer work - is irrelevant as concerns her degree of intellectual development.

title: THE REAL NORMAN MAINE
description: To the Editor:

title: JUDGE GRANDE: SHE KEEPS VON BULOW CASE ON TRACK
description: One day in 1935, when Corinne Grande was 6 years old, her father, William, a lawyer, took her to Courtroom 8 of Providence County Superior Court. As they waited in the front row of spectator seats, the girl told her father, quietly at first but with increasing vehemence, that she wanted to sit in the judge's chair. The judge was amused, Mr. Grande recalled in a recent interview, and granted the child's request.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

DOES ANYBONE REMEMBER KOREA?
description: DURING the recent commemoration of the end of the war in Vietnam, commentators frequently pointed out that troops in that war were treated differently. They went into action younger, their average age was seven years less than the troops in World War II. They were isolated. They dribbed into the country as replacements and left as individuals whose tour was up. And when they came home, there were no brass bands. They were forgotten.

title: Supreme Soviet to Meet
description: The Supreme Soviet, the Soviet parliament, is to meet on July 2, it was announced today. The session may be used to make Mikhail S. Gorbachev the Soviet Union's President in addition to party leader, following a precedent set by Leonid I. Brezhnev. This is largely a protocol device, allowing the party chief, who wields the real power in the Soviet Union, to meet foreign heads of state on equal terms.

title: REAL REFORM IS UP TO THE DEMOCRATS
description: President Reagan's tax-revision plan presents the Democrats with a perfect opportunity to regain the political high ground. The Administration has worked hard to present the proposal as a populist revolt against special interests. And, over all, the President's plan is an improvement on the present system. But the substance of the proposal falls far short of its populist packaging.

title: PACT REDUCES PAY DISPARITY IN CORTLANDT
description: A UNION contract giving female clerical employees special raises to reduce pay disparities between their jobs and those held mainly by men was recently adopted by the town of Cortlandt.

title: FRESH AIR FUND VISIT AWAITED
description: WHEN the Templeton family moved from Rocky Point, L.I., to its split-level suburban home in the rolling hills of Chappaqua last year, the family's children feared that their Fresh Air Fund ''sister,'' Bernice Vasquez, would be left behind.

title: A SQUEEZE ON DOCTORS' PROFITS
description: THE waiting room is filled with the normal mixture of maladies. Diabetes.

title: METS' LATE RALLY TOPS PADRES, 5-3
description: The Mets defeated the Padres tonight when they rallied in the late innings for a 5-3 victory that kept them in first place in the National League's East.

title: New Snags On Namibia
description: The killing of two South African commandos in Angola last week and the capture of a third have further snarled efforts to reach a settlement over South West Africa, the territory controlled by South Africa against the wishes of most of the world.

title: ITALY SEEKING TO CUT FALLOUT FROM THE TRIAL
description: An Italian diplomat, in a recent conversation, was upbraided by a Bulgarian colleague. The Bulgarian said the trial here that is examining a possible conspiracy, involving Bulgarian citizens, to assassinate Pope John Paul II slandered Bulgarian Communism and undermined East-West ties.

title: The Anxiety of Being A Japanese-American
description: Gene Oishi writes with impressive restraint and clarity about the enduring emotional wound inflicted upon Americans of Japanese ancestry who were interned during World War II (''The Anxiety of Being a Japanese-American,'' April 28). His conclusion that his discomfort with racial stereotypes stems from an ever-present fear that it could happen again seems an especially important statement.

title: ELIZABETH MIZE IS WED TO PAUL ELICKER, EXECUTIIVE
description: Elizabeth Mize of Washington and St. Michaels, Md., was married yesterday to Paul H. Elicker, chairman and president of the SCM Corporation in New York. The Rev. Donald Etherton of Christ Episcopal Church in St. Michaels performed the ceremony at Mount Pleasant Farm, the bride's home there.

title: WHY DO THEY BAR THE PIPE ORGAN?
description: New York justly prides itself on being the nation's cultural capital, but in at least one regard this city's musical life is woefully remiss. That is the absence of pipe organs in all but one of our major concert halls, the single exception being Alice Tully Hall.

title: KATHLEEN DOBBIN WED IN BRONXVILLE
description: Kathleen Mary Dobbin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Dobbin of Bronxville, N.Y., and Stowe, Vt., was married in Bronxville yesterday to Scott Sears Parmelee, the son of Marilyn S. Lord of Rye, N.Y., and Edward T. Parmelee of Miami. The Rev. Eugene O'Brien performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: W. E. HILSON, BARBARA LETO ARE MARRIED
description: The marriage of Barbara Jean Leto, a daughter of Mrs. Philip Joseph Leto of Yonkers and the late Mr. Leto, to William Edwin Hilson took place in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday. The Rev. Rayner Hesse, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John Stern Hilson, father and stepmother of the bridegroom, who is a son also of Mrs. John Thurston Beaty of Greenwich.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: BRUSH HOLLOW Road in Westbury isn't exactly the Great White Way. But for four young Long Island actors opening this Tuesday in the Westbury Music Fair's production of ''Evita,'' it's still show business on a major scale.

title: Swift Maxis to Open Season
description: The most powerful of yachting's oceangoing racers, the multimillion-dollar maxi boats, are expected to gather in Newport, R.I., late this week for a regatta that will mark the beginning of the 1985 world championship racing circuit.

title: ELEGANT CARD PLAY
description: One of the most exciting matches ever played on a major American occasion took place in Memphis two weeks ago. After wild oscillations in the score and a nail-biting finish, it determined the composition of the United States team in the 1985 world championship, scheduled to start in Sao Paulo, Brazil, at the end of October.

title: Antiship Missile Tested
description: A Navy Tomahawk cruise missile designed to hit ships was launched from a ship Friday off southern California to test a vertical launching system and the missile's abililty, the Navy announced today.

title: SCENTS AND SUCCESS
description: HISTORICALLY, PERFUMES and scents have been associated with images of power and success. They still are. In a 1984 survey compiled for the Fragrance Foundation, for example, 486 women executives were asked their views on using fragrances at work and for leisure activities. More than half responded that they wore perfume every workday, and 88 percent said that they wore it at least once a week. And 36 percent said they believed that wearing a fragrance to work helped a woman's career.

title: Talking;   Private Roads Cachet Can Be Costly
description: MANY suburban communities developed so haphazardly that some of the streets are private, neither serviced nor maintained by the municipality.

title: Concise Guides Useful in the Field
description: MANY who are truly interested in the natural world have an insatiable hunger for books that can range from huge volumes devoted exclusively to trees, plants, fish, mammals or birds to general-purpose guides.

title: REGIONAL THEATER SHOWS ITS BEST
description: America's resident theaters have played an increasingly significant role in the development of new plays and playwrights over the last three decades. Theaters such as the Tyrone Guthrie in Minneapolis, the Arena Stage in Washington and Trinity Square Repertory in Providence, R.I., have nurtured writers, actors and designers for their own communities. Indeed an argument can be - and often is - made that our true national theater consists of the 200-odd resident companies around the country.

title: ELIZABETH MONTGOMERY BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., yesterday Elizabeth Catton Montgomery, a daughter of Mrs. Henry Sanford and Wright Montgomery, both of Fairfield, Conn., was married to Stephen Kellogg Galpin Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Galpin of Southport. The Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund performed the ceremony.

title: 5 Killed in Train Collision
description: Five men who were believed to be undocumented aliens were killed when the car they were pushing across a railroad crossing was hit by an Amtrak passenger train, officials said today. ''The train was traveling between 75 and 80 miles per hour,'' an official of the San Diego Sheriff's Department said today.

title: Mize Surges to 4-Stroke Lead
description: Unheralded Larry Mize shot a four-under-par 68 today to surge to a four-stroke lead after three rounds of the $500,000 Kemper Open.

title: JERSEY CITY: ''MYSTERY SHOW''
description: THE Jersey City Museum's ''Mystery Show'' will be no mystery to regular observers of the scene and will not make matters any worse for those already baffled by contemporary art.

title: TRANSSEXUAL SEEKS TO LEAD LEGION POST
description: THE term of the commander of the American Legion post in New London is just about over, and the legionnaires might be ready for a new leader. They might not be ready, though, for a new leader who is a transsexual.

title: DAVID MURRAY BRINGS FRESHNESS TO JAZZ
description: In the nearly seven years since the tenor saxophonist David Murray premiered his big band at the Public Theater, he has emerged as a consistently inventive, startling soloist and as a band leader whose compositions and arrangements encompass the breadth of jazz. Mr. Murray, whose work has been dubbed avant-gutbucket, is one of the leaders of the neotraditionalist movement in jazz. This doesn't mean, however, that he and his cohorts are given to mere mimicry or the use of nostalgic ready-mades. Mr. Murray strives to personalize song forms, to expand the possibilities of individual expression by recasting the vernacular of generations of jazz. He makes fresh use of melodic invention, stacked harmonies, swirling contrapuntal lines and call-and-response passages that are as crucial for their juxtaposition of melodic lines as for rhtyhmic tension.

title: S.R.O. Woes
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;

SOLUTIONS FOR SMALL SPACES
description: MOST suburban gardeners share at least two restrictions on their gardening efforts: limited space and too little time to devote to the task. Both limitations necessitate good planning, if worthwhile results are to be obtained.

title: Social Climbing
description: Michael S. Berman, a former aide to Walter F. Mondale, and his wife, Carol, lately have the following message on their phone recorder: ''Hello, this is Carol.
