Michael and I are not able to answer your call right now because we are out social climbing. Please leave your name, phone number, time of call and credentials so we can decide whether to respond.''

title: FAREWELL TO A JAUNTY GENTLEMAN OF THE STAGE
description: I must report this for posterity, which will want to know. The late Abe Burrows, the great big bear-hug of an Abe Burrows, was - as a writer for the theater -absolutely incorrigible. He simply would not play by the rules.

title: NEW AWARD FOR CONDUCTORS
description: Two young conductors found themselves $75,000 richer late last month, thanks to the organization called Affiliate Artists.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN SPECIAL INTEREST MAGAZINES
description: OVER the last few decades, dire rumblings have been heard in publishing circles about the fatal wounds television would inflict on magazines. But the truth is, the magazine industry is glowing with health. Last year advertising revenues for the 140 publications tracked by the Publishers Information Bureau reached $4.6 billion, a 16.5 percent increase over 1983 and the largest jump since 1978.

title: MARINA ZHIRNOVA WED TO DAVID D. BROWN 4TH
description: Marina N. Zhirnova, the daughter of Valentina Pavlovskaya of Leningrad, was married yesterday to David D. Brown 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Brown 3d of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Claude L. Peters performed the ceremony at the Talmadge Hill Community Church in Darien.

title: West German Takes Epee in Grand Master
description: Juergen Hehn of West Germany, a double silver medalist at the 1976 Olympics in Montreal, won the Grand Masters fencing tournament men's epee championship yesterday aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2d.

title: 5 Navy Officers Are Removed In Aircraft Carrier Collision
description: The captain and four other officers of the aircraft carrier Coral Sea, which two months ago collided with an Ecuadoran tanker, have been relieved of duty.

title: MILLIONAIRE DROPOUT
description: THE PRICE OF POWER A Biography of Charles Eugene Bedaux. By Jim Christy. Illustrated. 342 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $21.95. BEING a pimp's assistant would not seem, on first consideration, to be good training for a future captain of industry, yet Charles Eugene Bedaux learned valuable lessons on the streets of Montmartre in early 20th-century Paris.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Fiction 1 THE WHEEL OF FORTUNE, by Susan Howatch. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A wealthy Welsh family haunted by an ominous heritage. 2 THE WALKING DRUM, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $3.95.) A young man from Brittany sets out to free his father, enslaved in 12th-century Asia. 3 ''. . . AND LADIES OF THE CLUB,'' by Helen Hooven Santmyer. (Berkley, $5.95.) Life in an Ohio hamlet, 1868-1932. 4 TENDER IS THE STORM, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $3.95.) A New York heiress's passionate encounter with an Arizona rancher. 5 MISSISSIPPI! by Dana Fuller Ross. (Bantam, $3.95.) The ''Wagons West'' series reaches the post-Civil War South and New Orleans. 6 POSSESSIONS, by Judith Michael. (Pocket, $4.50.) A woman discovers the truth about her husband after he disappears. 7 ROLE OF HONOR, by John Gardner. (Berkley, $3.95.) James Bond leaves Government service to become a private spy. 8 THE MODIGLIANI SCANDAL, by Ken Follett. (NAL/Signet, $3.50.) A ''lost masterpiece'' and dirty dealings in the international art world. 9 THE AQUITAINE PROGRESSION, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $4.50.) A lawyer finds himself caught in a conspiracy to take over the world. 10 HOOLIGANS, by William Diehl. (Ballantine, $3.95.) A Federal racket squad ace finds his old hometown in the clutches of the Mafia. 11 RAMBO: First Blood Part II, by David Morrell. (Jove, $3.50.) Novelization of the film about a Vietnam vet who returns to rescue prisoners of war. 12 FLING, by Pamela Beck and Patti Massman. (Dell, $3.95). What follows a married woman's impulsive affair with a handsome stranger. 13 * SUMMER HARVEST, by Madge Swindells. (NAL/ Signet, $3.95.) One family's life in southern Africa. 14 * THE WISHSONG OF SHANNARA, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $8.95.) The battle against evil continues; conclusion of a trilogy. 15 FLOODGATE, by Alistair MacLean. (Fawcett Crest, $3.95.) Terrorists threaten to flood the Netherlands unless Britain leaves Northern Ireland. NonfictionQ General 1 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (S&S/Touchstone, $8.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 2 SON, by Jack Olsen. (Dell, $4.50.) The case of a young psychotic rapist at large in Spokane, Wash. 3 PAST IMPERFECT, by Joan Collins. (Berkley, $3.95.) The tell-it-all autobiography of the actress. 4 IN SEARCH OF EXCELLENCE, by Thomas J. Peters and Robert H. Waterman Jr. (Warner, $8.95.) Lessons from well-run corporations. 5 FIRST LADY FROM PLAINS, by Rosalynn Carter. (Fawcett Gold Medal, $3.95.) Memoirs. 6 THE KENNEDYS: DYNASTY AND DISASTER, by John H. Davis. (McGraw-Hill, $5.95.) The story of a leading Irish-American family from 1848 to 1984. 7 BALLS, by Graig Nettles and Peter Golenbock. (Pocket, $3.95.) The San Diego third baseman tells about his life with the New York Yankees. Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 PENGUIN DREAMS AND STRANGER THINGS, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $6.95.) Cartoons from the syndicated ''Bloom County'' strip. 2 BRIDE OF THE FAR SIDE, by Gary Larson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $5.95.) Cartoons. 3 RAND MCNALLY ROAD ATLAS: United States, Canada, Mexico. (Rand McNally, $5.95.) For 1985. 4 EAT TO WIN, by Robert Hass. (NAL/Signet, $4.50.) A regimen for sports and fitness activities. 5 * THE ONE MINUTE MANAGER, by Kenneth Blanchard and Spencer Johnson. (Berkley, $6.95.) How to increase your productivity. 6 MORE SNIGLET .S, by Rich Hall and Friends. (Collier/Macmillan, $5.95.) More words that should appear in dictionaries, but don't; with cartoons. 7 GARFIELD MAKES IT BIG, by Jim Davis. (Ballantine, $5.95.) Cartoon humor. 8 GROWING UP CATHOLIC, by Mary Jane Frances Cavolina Meara, Jeffrey Allen Joseph Stone, Maureen Anne Teresa Kelly and Richard Glen Michael Davis. (Doubleday/Dolphin, $4.95.) Humor.

title: ART
description: In the field of art-book publishing the most remarkable among recent developments is the new prominence of the exhibition catalogue. In bookstores the exhibition catalogue now ranks with the biographies, the color-plate books and the general surveys that till lately dominated the art shelf. As for the scholarly monograph, it has not been superseded by the exhibition catalogue - John Pope-Hennessy's forthcoming study of Benvenuto Cellini will soon prove that - but it is certainly outnumbered.

title: A HEALTH PLAN FOR AILING CITY HOSPITALS
description: A one-mile walk south on Madison Avenue would take Eugene L. McCabe directly from the front door of the hospital he heads, North General, to the back door of Mount Sinai Medical Center. If Mr. McCabe has not made that trek literally, he has made it figuratively on many recent occasions, seeking aid from his wealthy neighbor in the struggle to keep his small, financially distressed Harlem hospital alive.

title: Official Criticized For Remarks on Noise
description: In a May 12 article about Princeton Airport, Arlene Butler Feldman, director of the state's Division of Aeronautics, was quoted as saying:

title: EXCAVATIONS SHOW FAST CULTURE CHANGE
description: Archeologists have discovered the remains of 10,000-year-old stone buildings in southeastern Turkey that are believed to be among the earliest examples of formal architecture and important evidence of rapid cultural changes when human societies moved from hunting and gathering to farming and living in villages.

title: ELAINE S. KELLOGG IS WED TO PETER POPE
description: The marriage of Elaine Spaulding Kellogg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Roy Kellogg of Stowe, Vt., and Peter Brooke Pope, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Pope Jr. of New York, took place yesterday at the Stowe Community Church. The Rev. Phillip Chase performed the Congregational ceremony.

title: RAIL BARGAIN: MEXICO METRO FOR ONE PESO
description: While the price of nearly everything in Mexico has been soaring, there is still one bargain to be found: a ride on the subway costs one peso. That is four-tenths of a United States cent.

title: IN WALES, A BOOKWORM'S HOLIDAY
description: The welcome mat was out for me at St. Deiniol's, as long as I was not deliberately working to undermine the Anglican religion. It seemed so little to ask. I dismissed every subversive impulse and applied for admission.

title: ELLEN M. BRUZELIUS BECOMES THE BRIDE OF WILLIAM NEVILLE TIFFT IN CONNECTICUT
description: Ellen Maria Bruzelius, the daughter of Mrs. Harmar Brereton of Redding, Conn., and the late Axel Sture Bruzelius, was married in Redding yesterday to William Neville Tifft, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry N. Tifft of New Canaan, Conn., and Marion, Mass. The Rev. Randall U. Giddings performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Social Events
description: Parties, Parties

title: C. N. STOLPER MARRIES CHRISTINA TUCKER
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Christina Cuthbertson Tucker and Charles Nichols Stolper. The Rev. Robert W. Cowperthwaite performed the ceremony.

title: DANCE: VIEW OF FUTURE IN STUDENT PERFORMANCE
description: THE Performing Arts Dancers, who attend the School of Performing Arts, gave the first of two annual dance concerts Friday night and showed off some talent that is sure to make its mark.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BEAUTY AND THE BEAST Written and illustrated by Warwick Hutton. Unpaged. New York: Margaret K. McElderry/Atheneum. $11.95. (Ages 6 and up) THE story of ''Beauty and the Beast'' is among the most thickly plotted of fairy tales. At the same time it is one of the most elemental and emotionally charged. A merchant loses his ships at sea and he and his daughters are reduced to poverty. While trying to salvage his affairs, he becomes lost in a storm. He seeks shelter in a palace where he is well treated at first but soon finds himself an accused man forced to choose between his own life and that of one of his daughters. Crisis follows crisis, all as prelude to the tumultuous central episode of this drama of illusions unmasked, of family strife, forbearance and difficult love.

title: FICTION THAT IS WORLDS APART
description: LOVE ALWAYS By Ann Beattie. 247 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95. ANN BEATTIE has claimed her fictional territory with cool, clever prose and a brilliant eye for detail. In her short stories and two previous novels, ''Chilly Scenes of Winter'' and ''Falling in Place,'' her stance is that of a witty reporter charting the manners of the civilized and the chic among the post-60's generation. Her elegant aloofness alternately charms and maddens, and in the ironically titled ''Love Always,'' her most comic novel thus far, she poses some hard questions about her own art within a structure drolly modeled on the soap opera.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

AIDS TEST: BREAKTHROUGH AND PROBLEM
description: THE licensing by the Food and Drug Administration of a blood test for antibody to the virus thought to be the cause of AIDS marks an important milestone in the research into this dreaded disorder.

title: LISA DEFELICE IS WED
description: At the Bedford (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church yesterday Lisa DeFelice and Ben Berlangieri, graduates of Northeastern University, were married by the Rev. Thomas A. Hughart. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent DeFelice of Bedford and Cranbury, N.J. Her father is senior vice president and general counsel of Rhone-Poulenc Inc., a chemical company in South Brunswick, N.J. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Tullio Berlangieri of Revere, Mass.

title: AT SEASON'S END, THE THEATER LOOKS TO A BRIGHTER TOMORROW
description: Tonight the Broadway theater community will put on black tie and happy faces for its annual spring rite of revelry, the nationally broadcast Tony Awards show. But however much merriment is staged for the benefit of the television cameras, the gaiety is likely to be as forced as that of the cafe-society party scenes in Hollywood movies made during the Depression. While the American theater in general may be entering an artistic boom period - and while the 1984-85 Broadway season offered more than a few artistic triumphs - the street has been unable to halt its galloping case of economic blues. Even as some members of the commercial theater establishment pledged their hearts and purses to worthy theatrical endeavors, they had to face the fact that, for much of the season, the only ''new'' Broadway show to cause a public stampede was Yul Brynner in ''The King and I.''

title: A DAY LATER, ONTARIO CITIES GAUGE LOSSES
description: The day after the tornado, people in this county seat of 45,000 tried today to get on with their lives. In one front yard, a family sat in front of their ravaged house quietly petting the family cat. The afternoon sounds were the tapping of hammers, the buzz of power saws and people shouting across streets about how lucky they were.

title: DANCES COMMISSIONED FOR AMERICAN FESTIVAL
description: Dances by Alwin Nikolais, winner of the 1985 Samuel H. Scripps American Dance Festival Award, and Chuck Davis, David Gordon, Pooh Kaye and Moses Pendleton are among the works commissioned for the festival's 1985 season, which opens on June 12 in Durham, N.C. Featured projects during the six-week festival will be debuts by the Robert Desrosiers Dance Theater of Canada and the G.R.C.O.P., the experimentalist wing of the Paris Opera Ballet, and a salute to the modern dance pioneer Charles Weidman on the 10th anniversary of his death.

title: PATRICK FINE WED TO SUSAN FRENCH
description: Susan Parker French, a daughter of Sarah Winter French of South Salem, N.Y., and Carroll Davies French of Ridgefield, Conn., was married yesterday to Patrick Chilion Fine, a son of Mrs. Lee Calvert Fine of Jefferson City, Mo., and the late Mr. Fine. The Rev. William Fensterer performed the Lutheran ceremony at the Mead Chapel in Waccabuc, N.Y.

title: THE SHOW GOES ON, AFTER ALL
description: MY friends always ask me why I keep the disk in the bedroom where hardly anyone can see it. My answer is that I keep it there so I'll see it when I wake up each morning. The disk we are talking about is a Tony Award, which is presented every year in the first week of June to the best of the year's theater productions. Looking at it now on this warm spring morning, my thoughts go back to a night 30 years ago.

title: THE CONCORDE'S NEW STYLING
description: The Concorde, that high-speed, high-priced trans-Atlantic aircraft for the hasty and the highly paid, recently took a skip around Britain and the North Sea to show off what British Airways has done to its supersonic fleet.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Seattle Mariners, at Yankee Stadium, 2:05 P.M. Finale of a three-game series. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Padres, at San Diego (Television - SportsChannel, 4:05 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 4 P.M.) Atlanta Braves vs. Pirates, at Pittsburgh (Television - WTBS, 1:35 P.M.) College: N.C.A.A. College World Series at Omaha, (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.) Basketball Los Angeles Lakers vs. Boston Celtics, at Inglewood, Calif. The third game of the four-of-seven-game N.B.A. championship series. (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.) Harlem USA vs. I.T.T., 2 P.M., and Coca-Cola/Uptown Chamber of Commerce vs. North General Hospital, 4 P.M. Rucker Pro Summer League doubleheader, 2 and 4 P.M. at the Holcombe Rucker Memorial Playground, Frederick Douglass Boulevard and West 155th Street The 35th annual summer pro league opened with two games yesterday. Golf Ladies P.G.A. Championship, at Kings Island, Ohio, final round. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M.) Kemper Open, at Bethesda, Md., final round. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Soccer Colombia vs. Argentina, at Bogota, World Cup South American Group 1 Game. Each team has won a game in this four-team group that also contains Venezuela and Peru. (Television - Channel 41, 4:30 P.M. live). Running Riverdale Ramble Metropolitan Athletics Congress, 10,000-Meter Open Championship, for men and women, 10 A.M., at Manhattan College Parkway and 241st Street, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. New York City Marathon, request for entry forms at Tavern on the Green, 67th Street and West Drive Central Park, 10 A.M. The New York Road Runners Club will accept one request and one $3 check or money order from every person showing up and process them before the ones received in the mail.

title: DANCE: 'POULENC SONATA'
description: KYRA NICHOLS is one of the glories of American ballet today. But she's a contrary glory - a dancer whose extraordinary control and technical gifts are displayed with a calm whose innocence at times seems almost childlike. In ''Poulenc Sonata,'' performed by the New York City Ballet on Thursday at the New York State Theater, Peter Martins has created a ballet for Miss Nichols that both celebrates and challenges her.

title: DAVID HARTMAN IS ABC'S EVERYMAN
description: David Hartman, the 6-foot 5-inch television host who looks a little like an athletic version of Ichabod Crane, was thinking. He sat in his office and put his big hands together.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Historical Treasures To View and To Buy The Historical Society of the Tarrytowns, organized in 1889, will sponsor its 16th Strawberry Festival fund-raising event at its Victorian headquarters at 1 Grove Street next Sunday from 2 to 5 P.M., with the $4 admission price including both shortcake and beverage, or a choice of plain strawberries to go. The nearby Back Parlor Boutique at 19 Grove will be open for browsing and buying that day during the same period.

title: Keeping Sudan As a Friend
description: Since a military coup toppled President Gaafar al-Nimeiry last month, the Sudan has seemed to Washington a less compliant though still important friend in Africa. In the first high-level visit by an American official since the changeover, Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, paid a call last week to inquire about such unsettling actions as restoring diplomatic relations with Libya, reaching out to the Soviet Union, and emphasizing nonalignment.

title: THE OLDEST 'FRIENDLY TOWN' IN THE STATE
description: FOR Ruby Harris, who lives in the Bronx, past summers in New Jersey are a source of fond memories.

title: CD'S HIGHLIGHT THE VIRTUES AND FLAWS OF FRITZ REINER
description: Making records today is such an expensive and painfully selective kind of enterprise that the people at RCA Red Seal must bless daily the treasury of past performances which lie at their disposal. Engineers and technicians, moreover, have found new ways to make old recordings sound better; and with these skills, the company's Red Seal division is busy cleansing earlier releases through digital and half-speed mastering processes and issuing them on both compact disk and LP.

title: ETHIOPIA ORDERS STUDENTS TO AID RESETTLEMENT
description: The Government announced this week that thousands of Ethiopian college students and teachers have been ordered to spend the summer working with famine victims who have been resettled in the south and west of the country.

title: Motivating
description: Representative Thomas J. Manton wanted the Congressional Record to show that the Woman's National Democratic Club had named none other than Geraldine A. Ferraro as its Woman of the Year for 1984.

title: EISENHOWER AIDE RECALLS THE PAST
description: IT HAS been 40 years since the end of World War II, but to Col.

title: Murray ChassOn Baseball;   UEBERROTH REVIVING GAG RULE FOR OWNERS IN LABOR TALKS
description: Four years after it last played a role, the gag rule on owners has been dragged out and dusted off. Perhaps as a sign of the so-called stressful economic times, though, the maximum cost of violating the rule has been slashed in half, from $500,000 to $250,000.

title: GREEK VOTE TODAY SEEN AS TEST OF SOCIALISM
description: Greek voters are to decide Sunday whether to grant a second term to Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, the Socialist leader, or return to the right-of-center rule that prevailed, as a democracy or dictatorship, from World War II until 1981.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;

JUMPING-OFF POINT FOR NEW THEATER
description: THE American theater, Emily Stevens insists, did not start on Broadway. And given the current state of Broadway, if Miss Stevens, a founder of the Circle in the Square Theater, has her way, Theater (with a capital T) will continue in places like Glen Cove.

title: WITH A SHIPLOAD OF SALT
description: LAST LETTERS FROM HAV By Jan Morris. 203 pp. New York: Random House. $14.95. LIKE the current modes of poetry, travel writing is an art that necessarily partakes of fictional elements but is not supposed to. The great originals, like Herodotus and Marco Polo, freely interpolated whoppers into their travel chronicles. Our contemporaries are less at liberty to spin tales of ''Anthropophagi, and men whose heads / Do grow beneath their shoulders,'' but there are still ways to spice up the raw data of topography without overstepping the bounds of documentary. One simply offers hearsay evidence, as in this poker-faced account -from Jan Morris's most recent travel book, ''Last Letters From Hav'' - of the salt trade that for centuries has been the economic basis of the city's anomalous existence:

title: ADRIENNE BYRNES BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Adrienne Patricia Byrnes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald D. Byrnes of Oradell, N.J., was married yesterday to Thomas Eugene Flanagan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. T. Flanagan of Rye, N.Y. The Revs. James Ryan and Patrick Tarrant performed the ceremony at the St. Teresa of Avila Roman Catholic Church in North Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: MOST OF BURNED ROOSEVELT HOME NOW OPEN
description: More than three years after a fire severely damaged the Franklin D. Roosevelt home here, a white ribbon on its porch has been cut, marking the end of the major stage of a $2 million reconstruction job.

title: SMALL STAFFS
description: To the Editor:

title: GUIDE TO WASHINGTON, PARTY AT NIAGARA FALLS
description: HOW TO VISIT THE CAPITAL, WITH CHILDREN For older children with an interest in military history, why not a tour of the Pentagon? Between May and September, there are 14 tours daily, every 30 minutes between 9 A.M. and 3:30 P.M.

title: LEORA ROSENBERG AND STEVEN LEVY ARE WED IN RYE
description: At Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester in Rye, N.Y., yesterday Leora Mariana Rosenberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Rosenberg of Charlotte, N.C., was married to Steven Mark Levy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley H. Levy of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN SPECIAL INTEREST MAGAZINES;

PUTTING NEW LOOKS ON OLD HOMES
description: A truism of modern life is that affordable homes are hard to find.

title: SMITH EDGES WAITZ IN 10-KILOMETER RUN
description: Women from 19 countries and 40 states tested their running power in the heat at Central Park yesterday morning in the 14th annual L'eggs Mini Marathon.

title: HAS MODERN DANCE LOST ITS IDEALISM?
description: ''I aim to speak the language of humanity, not the dialect of a folk.'' The founding mothers of modern dance in America were prone to making such pronouncements and this statement, typically, came from the mother of them all, Isadora Duncan. Just as typically and in the same interview with The San Francisco Examiner in 1917, Isadora felt compelled to declare where her ''center of inspiration'' lay. As the reporter indicated, she placed her hand on her breast and then on her brow. For Isadora, the source of movement was in the solar plexus. Later, in the 1930's, the phrase ''fall and recovery'' would be identified with the movement principles of Doris Humphrey just as ''contraction and release'' would be identified with Martha Graham.

title: Child-Abuse Deaths Down
description: Fewer New York City children died from abuse and neglect during the first five months of this year than during the same period last year, but the official in charge of child-abuse prevention says he doubts things will get much better soon. ''I have not solved the problem,'' Eric B. Brettschneider, head of the Office of Special Services for Children, said last week. He said he did not think that corrective or preventive action by the city is going to stop the death of children.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: PAUL ORGEL, who made his New York debut at the Merkin Concert Hall Tuesday night, studied at the New England Conservatory of Music and took his master's degree in music at Boston University. He is presently a visiting teacher of piano at Wesleyan University and an affiliated artist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: FORMER FRIEND TELLS OF SPY SUSPECT'S COAST TRIPS
description: A Virginia man said today that John A. Walker Jr., the major suspect in a widening espionage investigation, made frequent trips to California, where Federal agents are now keeping watch on a group of his former Navy colleagues.

title: AN OPTION: 'ACTIVE' SPEAKERS
description: Among the offbeat approaches to loudspeaker design that have lately come to the fore, so-called ''active'' loudspeakers have gained a fair share of attention. The term ''active,'' in this context, means that the speakers contain their own built-in amplifiers, thus dispensing with the customary separate amplifier or receiver. Instead, these speakers are connected directly to a preamplifier. At least four highly regarded companies - Revox, ADS, Meridian and B & W - now offer speakers of this kind, and while it seems unlikely that these designs will spark a widespread trend, their merits have been plausibly argued and audibly confirmed.

title: DANCE EN MASSE
description: Fourteen-year-old James Williams is a jumper, a basketball player known to his Children's Village teammates for his layups, not his pirouettes. That was before James met Jacques d'Amboise.

title: LIFE AND DEATH
description: 'If you don't stop feeding him, he won't die.'

title: RESTAURANT'S MENU FOR BOOK LOVERS
description: THESE days at the Traveler Restaurant in Union, the owner, Martin Doyle, is giving away only 1,000 to 1,500 books a week. By summer, however, Mr. Doyle will give away twice that, and to handle the overflow, he is putting two trailers in a lot outside the yellow-roofed building.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: June 2, 1985 Fiction

title: THE GREEN REVOLUTION BEARS FRUIT
description: While recurring drought and hunger ravage Africa, much of the rest of the third world has reached or is approaching self-sufficiency in food. Indeed, after 20 years of using the new seeds and productive methods of the Green Revolution, many third world countries have become food exporters, altering world trade patterns of crucial interest to the United States.

title: Horse Wins 2d Title
description: Just For Fun won the regular conformation hunter stake today and became the grand hunter champion for the second straight year at the 89th annual Devon Horse Show.

title: The Anxiety of Being A Japanese-American
description: In his article on the effects of the World War II incarceration of Japanese-Americans, Gene Oishi points to several ways nisei can try to deal with their ''basic insecurity'': joining the American Civil Liberties Union, supporting social-program projects such as Kimochi Inc. and, most importantly, accepting the uncomplaining courage of people such as his father, who, despite ''economic ruin and loss of status,'' picked up the few remaining pieces of his life ''as if none of that really mattered.''

title: A POIGNANT MEMORIAL TO INDIRA GANDHI OPENS
description: The official residence of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was opened to the public this week as a national memorial.

title: The Anxiety of Being A Japanese-American
description: Gene Oishi's article stunned me as it must have many other readers who knew of the ''relocation'' and internment of Japanese-Americans, who deplored it but considered it something long past. Now we know that, though the events are over, they are not done with.

title: STATE STEPPING UP FARM-PRODUCT ADS
description: PHOTOGRAPHS of blueberries, corn, tomatoes, peaches, apples and eggs will adorn billboards along roads throughout the state from now through September, and New Jersey, New York and Philadelphia radio stations will carry jingles about the state's produce.

title: Maryland Health Checkups
description: Fifteen barbers have agreed to check customers' blood pressure as well as cut their hair in a program intended to assure that more black men are examined regularly for high blood pressure. Seven barbers trained as ''blood pressure measurement specialists'' are to get certificates next week from the Urban Cardiology Research Center and the University of Maryland School of Medicine. Eight others will soon be certified to take blood pressure measurements, counsel customers and refer them for medical treatment.

title: A COMING TORNADO IN U.S.-SOVIET RELATIONS
description: Sometimes on the Great Plains, you can see a tornado coming from a long way off. This is the situation we face in our relations with the Soviet Union just now. Unless something changes, we are in for a long period of unregulated military competition and consequent higher tensions. Neither country wants it. Both countries will face tough domestic problems as a result. In addition, America will have increasingly difficult alliance problems. But each country thinks it is up to the other to move.

title: SMALL STAFFS
description: To the Editor:

title: DUARTE PLEDGES HELP IN SOLVING SLAYING
description: WHEN John J. Sullivan Jr. of the Bergen County community of Bogota vanished in El Salvador in December 1980, his family was sure that he would soon be found with the help of the United States Embassy there.

title: THE SHORT SKIRT
description: Summer is the season for short skirts. Slim and comfortable, the bright skirts shown here may well presage things to come in the fall.

title: Q AND A
description: Basis for a 'Flip Tax' Question: Our co-op board wants to institute a ''flip tax.'' Must it be a flat percentage, or can it be based on seniority in the building? . . . L. S., Manhattan Answer: In recent challenges to transfer fees, or ''flip taxes,'' courts have held that they must be uniformly calculated for all shareholders without discrimination. Marc Luxemburg, president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, recommends basing them on a dollar amount per share, not seniority. Some co-ops also use a percentage of the selling price or the profit. Sponsor's Right of Access Question: I live in a rent-controlled apartment that is going co-op. Will the sponsor have the right to show it to prospective buyers while I am away for the summer? . . . A. W., Forest Hills, Queens Answer: Martin A. Shlufman, deputy counsel for rent administration for the State Division of Housing and Com-Redinger munity Renewal, says that under Section 2204.2f of the Rent Control Law, a tenant's unreasonable refusal of access to an apartment for the purpose of showing it to a prospective buyer is a ground for eviction. A similar provision exists for rent-stabilized apartments under Section 53E of the Rent Stabilization Code.

title: No. 1 Farmer's Fiscal Condition
description: ''The point is, farmers everywhere are making adjustments,'' Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block said of the financial disclosure statement he made public last week. ''I've made a series of adjustments, I've made more since the first of the year, and I'm not through yet.''

title: APARTMENT PREMIUMS ARE SOARING
description: PROPERTY- and casualty-insurance rate increases - in some cases as much as 400 percent - and a reduction of the number of carriers who cover residential buildings have created consternation among apartment dwellers throughout New York City.

title: Q AND A
description: Question: Where can I get information on climbing Mount Fuji? Is it too difficult for someone of middle age in good health? - J. .A., Rutland, Mass. Answer:''Mt. Fuji and Fuji Five Lakes,'' a four-page booklet that gives information on climbing the mountain, is available free from the Japan National Tourist Organization (630 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10111). It has details on the three major routes to the summit (12,389 feet) and refers to the mountain huts on the slopes, trains from Tokyo (55 miles away) and local hotels. The booklet points out that there are 10 stages to the climb and that most people travel by bus or car to the fifth stage and start climbing there. Depending on the route, it estimates the climbing times from the fifth stage to the top as 4 hours and 20 minutes, 5 hours and 8 hours. (Many people spend the night in one of the huts and resume their climb in the early hours so they can be on the summit in time to see dawn break. The huts are open only in July and August.) Among books that have material on climbing Fuji are ''Japan At Your Feet: A Hiking and Walking Guide'' ($9.95, Peony Press) and ''National Parks of Japan'' ($20, Kodansha), which is essentially a photographic book but does include text on the mountain and climbing it. The books can be ordered from the Traveller's Bookstore (22 West 52d Street, New York, N.Y. 10019).

title: BETHANY HORESEMEN REGAIN OLD TRAILS
description: A LONGTIME privilege is to become a documented agreement Thursday, when the Bethany Horsemen and the South Central Connecticut Regional Water Authority sign papers to officially open the trails around a local reservoir for horseback riding.

title: BRAODWAY AIDING THE HUNGRY
description: CHECKING off celebrity names - ''my list of stars'' - on her yellow pads, collating dates and confirming commitments, organizing meetings with recording and video producers and conferring with her attorney-partner, Susan Edwards, who grew up in Levittown, might just as well be an entrepreneur as an entertainer.

title: BIZARRE EVENTS DESIGNED TO SHOCK
description: THE British playwright Simon Gray is best known in this country for his successful Broadway and Off Broadway productions of ''Otherwise Engaged,'' ''Quartermaine's Terms,'' and ''Molly.'' He is a gifted craftsman, but his plays are filled with characters who are usually discontent with their lot in life and who are often filled with self-loathing.

title: Grand Prix Of Belgium Postponed
description: The Belgian Grand Prix auto race scheduled Sunday has been postponed because the track is considered unsafe.

title: THEY'RE BEHIND BARS, BUT NOT OUT OF BUSINESS
description: Prison inmates may be cut off from most contacts with the outside world, but law enforcement officials are blaming penitentiary gangs for violent crimes - many of them related to drug trafficking - committed in a spreading number of American cities.

title: NOW SOFT-DRINK MAKERS BRACE FOR THE JUICE WARS
description: ''WE got the juice!'' proclaims PepsiCo Inc. in its promotions for Slice, a new lemon-lime soda. With this battle cry, PepsiCo is leading the charge into a new category of sodas: soft drinks with juice. It is a category that analysts predict will become a major segment of the $25 billion soft-drink business over the next few years, as Coke, Shasta, Canada Dry and Perrier turn on the juice, too.

title:
DINING OUT;

A NEON DUCK IS IN THE WINDOW
description: CHAN'S Peking Duck House in Bridgewater is the third restaurant that the Chan family has opened. The first, in nearby Dunellen, burned and was recently rebuilt in a much more elaborate fashion; the second, in Livingston, opened four or five years ago. Now there is one at the Somerville Traffic Circle.

title: 'MOST FUNNY STUFF IS BORN OF PAIN'
description: A couple of years ago, Herb Gardner was strolling in Central Park one day when he noticed two elderly men sitting on a park bench, carefully positioned so they were close enough to talk but not so close as to acknowledge that they were together.

title: FATALISTIC HYMNS TO INFATUATION
description: Bryan Ferry has been writing the same song, with variations, for more than a decade. It's a song about a man in love despite himself - a melancholy guy who's at the mercy of passion, knowing that it can't last and he'll be miserable again in no time. His titles tell the story: ''The Thrill of It All,'' ''Love Me Madly Again,'' ''Can't Let Go'' and - on his new album, ''Boys and Girls'' - ''Slave to Love.'' Love is a pop-song staple, but Mr. Ferry has defined his specialty as narrowly as a laser neurosurgeon.

title: KATHLEEN R. FERGUSON WEDS DAVID CHAPMAN
description: Kathleen Renee Ferguson and David Arthur Chapman were married yesterday in the chapel at Hanover College in Indiana by the Rev. William Crum, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: FOR ABDUL-JABBAR, IT'S A MATTER OF PRIDE
description: At the age of 38, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar says his days as a smooth, slender collegian at U.C.L.A. are ''almost too long ago to remember.'' But as he sat in a hotel suite last Tuesday afternoon and watched a tape of the Boston Celtics' unexpected 34-point blowout of the Los Angeles Lakers in the opening game of the championship series, he was shocked to see what that young player had become.

title: SPIN: A NEW VOICE IN POP MUSIC
description: TWENTY years after his father started publishing Penthouse magazine, Robert Guccione Jr. hopes to make publishing history repeat itself.

title: DECLINING ELMIRA BUOYED BY PLANT REOPENING
description: Like a dozen other idle factories here, the Westinghouse picture-tube plant is an industrial dinosaur. Closed for nine years because of Japanese competition, it sits next to the highway in an area of lost jobs, broken families and fading hope.

title: YOUNGER COLLECTORS
description: There was a time when stamp collecting could be described with some degree of accuracy as the world's most popular hobby. Millions of youngsters were introduced to stamps as a form of education and entertainment. Many youngsters turned collecting into a lifetime hobby.

title: Santos Keeps Crown, Outpointing Acaries
description: Carlos Santos of Puerto Rico retained his International Boxing Federation superwelterweight title tonight with a 15-round decision over Louis Acaries of France.

title: RESTRUCTURING ZONING TO SPUR APARTMENT CONSTRUCTION
description: WINDING through the procedural maze of the city's land-use review system is a proposal that would bring the first significant zoning change in 25 years to medium-density housing districts.

title: U.S. WILL HOLD OUT FOR SOVIET SHIFT IN TALKS ON ARMS
description: President Reagan has concluded that the Soviet Union has hardened its positions on arms control, and he has told American negotiators in Geneva not to show flexibility unless the Russians make new proposals first, according to Administration officials.

title: Maneuvering
description: The post of president of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty is expected to be open soon, and the maneuvering for a replacement has begun.

title: ASHKENAZY AND MEHTA TEAM UP FOR BEETHOVEN
description: Vladimir Ashkenazy has previously recorded the Beethoven piano concertos with Solti and the Chicago Symphony for London Records. Now from the same company comes a recently-made package set of all five, with Zubin Mehta and the Vienna Philharmonic accompanying. It is available simultaneously on LP (411-899-1, LH 4, four disks) and on compact disks. The pairings on the CD's (as in the stereo set) are the Piano Concerto No. 1 and the six Bagatelles of Op. 126 (411 900-2 LH); Nos. 2 and 4 (411 901-2 LH); No. 3 and the ''Andante Favori'' and ''Fur Elise'' (411 902-2 LH); and No. 5 (411 903-2 LH).

title: VCR'S FOR STERO TV IN THE OFFING
description: At press time, final preparations are under way in Chicago for the opening of the Consumer Electronics Show, the biggest trade fair in the field of video and other electronic equipment for the home. New models scheduled to appear in the stores next fall will be unveiled today to dealers and distributors. Acres of the latest video gear will be on display at McCormick Place, Chicago's vast lakeside exhibition hall, much of it kept under wraps until the last minute. But sufficient advance information is available to present a partial preview of the show, which opens this morning.

title: FICTION THAT IS WORLDS APART
description: A PERFECT PEACE By Amos Oz. Translated by Hillel Halkin. 374 pp. New York: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95. THIS, the Israeli writer Amos Oz's most powerful work, is his fourth novel and ninth book to be published in the United States in English translation. The events of ''A Perfect Peace,'' which appeared in Israel in 1982, unfold between 1965 and 1967, from the news of skirmishes near the Syrian border to the Six Day War. The reverberations of these events permeate the book, lending it an atmosphere of continual unease and anticipation, but the clashes Mr. Oz evokes are more of the domestic variety - a generational conflict over the meaning of the Israeli experience itself. In ''A Perfect Peace,'' he examines the disjunctions of history and the ways in which a people -and finally it is more than just the Israeli people to whom he speaks - transcend such divisions.

title: ONEC-RURAL GEORGIA COUNTY NOW HAS FASTEST GROWTH IN U.S.
description: Traffic is in a terrible tangle, the county's sewage treatment plants are near capacity and the court docket is so overburdened that the old downtown movie theater has been turned into a courtroom.

title: MARCOS SAYS HE MIGHT ASK FOR ALLIED TROOPS
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that the Philippines might have to call for military help from its allies to fight Communist rebels.

title: Woman's Ordeal Points Up Hazards Of Construction
description: Critics of Manhattan's building boom often grumble about unimaginative architecture, permissive zoning and threats to the scale of old neighborhoods. There are sometimes physical hazards as well.

title: ON STATE PENSIONS AND APARTHEID
description: IN THE next few months, legislators and Governor Kean must decide whether state pension or annunity investments should be withdrawn from institutions or companies that do business in or with South Africa.

title: PALESTINE NATIONAL COUNCIL: DIFFICULT TO DEFINE
description: Should American officials engage in Mideast talks with a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation, the Palestinians at the table are most likely to be drawn from the ranks of an amorphous body known as the Palestine National Council, according to American and Arab officials.

title: Threat of Moths Eases in 3 States
description: Officials in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware have modified their earlier predictions that a growing gypsy moth population would cause severe damage to the region's forests this summer.

title: EUROPE'S HIGH-STAKES AUTO BATTLE
description: VOLKSWAGENWERK A.G., the West German automobile giant, is negotiating to build all its Polo subcompacts in Pamplona, Spain. To the south, near Saragossa, the General Motors Corporation is now assembling its Opel Corsas for the entire European market, while motor production is being concentrated at Kaiserslautern, in Germany. The Ford Motor Company is shipping transmissions from Bordeaux, France, to assembly plants throughout Europe and discussing joint ventures with Fiat ranging from parts production to a possible merger.

title: On Language;   Whose Oxymoron Is Gored?
description: ONE OF THE LAN-guage's great tropes is on the ropes. Something must be done to save the oxymoron.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Women figure heavily in prime-time viewing statistics and, in case you haven't noticed, the plots of TV movies are noticeably partial to women as their central characters. Among this week's rebroadcasts, for instance, one can find ''based on true story'' portraits of Marva Collins, a Chicago teacher passionately concerned about underprivileged children deemed ''unteachable,'' and Candy Lightner, a Californian responsible for some of this country's strongest legislation against drunken driving. Mrs. Collins is depicted by Cicely Tyson, Mrs. Lightner by Mariette Hartley, and both performances merit attention.

title: Miller and Lopez Share Lead
description: Nancy Lopez bogeyed the 16th and 17th holes today and fell into a tie for the lead with Alice Miller after three rounds of the 31st annual Ladies Professional Golf Association Championship. The two-stroke penalty Miss Lopez received for slow play in the first round Thursday now suddenly looms very large.

title: MAUREEN LOUISE KENNEDY WEDS JAMES PETER MARTIN
description: Maureen Louise Kennedy, a daughter of Mrs. Jerome Kennedy of Roslindale, Mass., and the late Mr. Kennedy, was married yesterday to James Peter Martin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Martin of Riverdale, the Bronx. Charles Leslie, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at the Martha-Mary Chapel of Longfellow's Wayside Inn in Sudbury, Mass.

title: China Premier Off to Europe
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang left for a tour of Britain, West Germany and the Netherlands today, affirming that China's top leadership did not plan a shuffle in the near future. At a news conference, Mr. Zhao said Deng Xiaoping, the top leader, and Hu Yaobang, the Communist Party General Secretary, would keep their posts after a party conference planned for September, when changes in the party leadership are routinely proposed.

title: Third in Family Is Charged With Spying
description: The Government's investigation of a Navy family accused of stealing military secrets for the Soviet Union produced another arrest last week and the prospect of more to come.

title: STEPS TO WEIGH IN THE FACE OF DROUGHT
description: RECENTLY I have read with some amusement editorial ruminations (not in The Times) about ''. . . damming Long Island Sound and making it one big reservoir.'' I am not sure the severity of the current water crisis warrants dragging this blueprint for disaster from its obscurity, but like other ''make work'' projects proposed by the United States Army Corps of Engineers, once suggested they never seem to die.

title: David Byrne: Thinking Man's Rock
description: Within David Byrne's complex lexicon, there exists an undercurrent that harbors, metaphorically, the architectural relationship between human beings and buildings. What is being suggested by the Talking Heads assists in establishing an appropriate structure by which a life can be humanly lived. Mr. Byrne's house is clearly not an ordinary structure. JACK GROVE Canton, N.Y.

title: A DIFFERENT APPROACH TO CLAY
description: ALTHOUGH it is rare to find something really new, the work of Jindra Vikova is a striking departure from approaches to clay that are familiar to Americans.

title: AMERICANS ABROAD Conservative Colors
description: ''Why shouldn't I look like a tourist?'' said the vacationing American in the 1950's New Yorker cartoon. ''I am a tourist.''

title: Robert Coe Dies at 83; Former U.S. Diplomat
description: Robert Douglas Coe, a former American diplomat, died last Sunday in Cannes, France, at the age of 83.

title: DIPLOMTIC BUFFOONERY
description: THE INTERNATIONAL GARAGE SALE By Stefan Kanfer. 224 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $13.95. THE United Nations -what a subject for a great satire! At its founding strong men wept, spoke glowingly of beating weapons into plowshares and vowed never to wage war again. Forty years and umpteen million deaths later, the United Nations is a sputtering travesty. The chance for a spoof of modern peacekeeping, for a ''Dr. Strangelove'' or a ''Catch-22'' of bad faith, terrorism and idiot oratory would seem golden.

title: BLUE JAYS KEEP ON ROLLING
description: Lloyd Moseby hit a homer and drove in three runs, and Damaso Garcia went 4 for 5 in leading the Toronto Blue Jays to an 8-3 victory over the Cleveland Indians today.

title: TWO ATMOSPHERIC CONDITIONS CITED IN STORMS
description: The tornadoes and thunderstorms that battered areas of New York State, Pennsylvania, Ohio, West Virginia and Canada, killing scores of people and causing millions of dollars of damage, were caused by two atmospheric conditions, weather analysts say.

title: ALBANY VOTES LIMIT ON PORNOGRAPHY DISPLAY
description: The display of pornographic materials in establishments where public access is not restricted, such as drugstores and supermarkets, would be banned under a measure passed here this week by the State Legislature.

title: CALENDARS
description: Horse Shows Today - Asbury Hill Farm, Freeville, N.Y. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (607) 257-5573.

title: CAPTIAL OF ALASKA (STILL) IS THRIVING
description: In the three years since Alaskans abandoned a plan to move their capital from here to the Anchorage area, Juneau has boomed with home construction and heavy commercial investment.

title: SPARRING BOUT
description: THE 1985 session of the General Assembly, which began in January with predictions of sharp clashes between the Republican majorities and the Democratic Governor, neared its end last week looking more like a sparring match.

title: N.C.A.A. Indoor Meet To Be in Oklahoma City
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association, which may abolish its indoor track and field championships, has awarded the 1986 meet to the Oklahoma City Myriad.

title: CHEMICAL RUSSIAN ROULETTE
description: AMERICA is living with a chemical nightmare. Chemical companies routinely vent tons of dangerous chemicals into the air as part of their normal operations. We have no idea what many of these chemicals are or what their potential harm to our health and environment may be.

title: Nabobbing
description: Vivid Image Award (Ivy League): to Ralph Nader (LL.B. with distinction, Harvard Law School 1958) for the title of the speech he is to deliver in the capital June 11 to the Harvard Law School Association: ''Harvard Lawyers: Nabobs of Narcissism Wallowing in Complacency?''

title: IN BANGLADESH, TRAGEDY HAS BECOME A TRADITION
description: In 14 years of independence, Bangladesh has experienced frequent catastrophes. Born in a brutal war between India and Pakistan, the country has survived the assassination of two leaders and several coups. Floods, droughts, famine and violent tropical storms are virtually routine.

title: Oldest Police Cadet Graduates on Coast
description: Lewis Ellis, a 53-year-old grandfather who does 100 push-ups a day, graduated from the Police Academy Friday, becoming the oldest rookie police officer in the city's history.

title: PUPILS, 8 to 17, GET A CHANCE AT BALLET
description: Twenty-four pointing toes bound in pink or white ballet slippers traced invisible arcs above the gray hardwood dance floor. Again and again, the long, slender legs swept in unison across the surface scuffed with heel marks.

title: Philadelphia to Raise Fares for Mass Transit
description: It will cost 10 cents more to ride buses, trolleys and the subway-elevated lines in the Philadelphia area beginning July 1, and a quarter more to take a commuter train.

title: BUDDING MARKET
description: New York's flower wholesalers are among the most recent of the groups of tradesmen to be nudged from their traditional territory in Manhattan by rising rents and the demand for midtown office space. But by next spring, construction is expected to be completed on the College Point Flower Market, a new facility to house up to eight wholesalers now situated in the Flower District, in the vicinity of 28th Street and the Avenue of the Americas.

title: Small Staffs
description: We agree in principle with Tom Peters that most corporations could benefit from slimming staffs (''Why Smaller Staffs Do Better,'' April 21). But we caution against concluding that cutting staff to the bone, or across the board, automatically maximizes profitability.

title: EXPLORING THE LEGACY OF ANSERMET
description: Many record collectors feel that stereo recordings from the 1960's are too recent to qualify as ''historical'' disks - a category that, by unspoken definition, is largely reserved for mono recordings and 78 rpm transfers. Of course, as time and technology march on, definitions have to be updated, and ironically, it may take a technological changeover to rid the ''historical'' definition of its technological bias. After all, the real point of separating the historically significant from the commonplace is whether performance styles have changed significantly since the recording was made, and more crucially, whether the reading in question conveys a viewpoint rooted in an earlier era. That yardstick is bound to become increasingly important in the next few years, since record labels transferring their old analog catalogues to the compact disk format will be turning to recordings that, despite their relatively recent vintage, deserve to be considered historical issues.

title: RICHARD PRYOR IN SEARCH OF HIS COMIC GENIUS
description: Watching Richard Pryor as he forces himself to cavort with simulated abandon in ''Brewster's Millions,'' his new comedy directed by Walter Hill, is like watching the extremely busy shadow of someone who has disappeared. The contours of the shadow are familiar but the substance is elsewhere. ''Brewster's Millions'' is another in the series of earnest attempts to tame - to make genteel - one of the most original, most provocative, most unpredictably comic personalities to come onto the American scene in the last 20 years.

title: JANET ANN PHILLIPS WEDS TIMOTHY LORING JOHNSON
description: Janet Ann Phillips, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert W. Phillips of Sag Harbor, L.I., was married in East Hampton, L.I., yesterday to Timothy Loring Johnson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton S. Johnson of New York and East Hampton.

title: SOME TENTATIVE STEPS TO BRIDGE THE 38TH PARALLEL
description: A succession of ''firsts,'' some of them eye-catching, have been registered recently in relations between North and South Korea. Last September, for the first time, convoys of trucks brought relief goods from North to South. Then, North Korean cargo ships, also carrying flood relief supplies, docked at a South Korean port for the first time. Soon after, the two sides opened their first negotiation on possible economic cooperation.

title: FORTUNE-COOKIE AUTHORS ABOUND IN CHINATOWN
description: The last of the moo shu pork is devoured and the fortune cookies arrive: fate in folded wafers. The diners smile to show how little they care -then crack open theirs at once.

title: COURT PANEL SAYS GRENADA PRESS SUIT IS MOOT
description: A Federal appeals court panel Friday upheld the dismissal, on the ground of mootness, of a suit challenging the constitutionality of the Government's barring of reporters from the early stages of the invasion of Grenada in October 1983.

title: Proud Truth Sidelined
description: Proud Truth, who would have been one of the favorites in the Belmont Stakes next Saturday, was found today to have a small fracture in his left front leg and will not race again until the fall.

title: RAOUL DE ROHAN WEDS PATRICIA PRICE IN JERSEY
description: At the Episcopal Church of St. John on the Mountain in Bernardsville, N.J., yesterday Patricia Ann Price and Charles Raoul de Rohan were married by the Rev. Alfred Niese Jr. Margaret Price Weeks was matron of honor for her sister and Blair Villa best man.

title: Toasting
description: Patience is a prerequisite for diplomats, and friends of John Scanlon Sr., a career foreign service officer, could only toast him the other night for the three years he waited in vain to be cleared as the new Ambassador to Poland. Acceptance of his credentials was never granted by the Poles as relations worsened with Washington.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE STUDIO, by John Gregory Dunne. (Limelight, $7.95.) For his report on the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation, John Gregory Dunne held the studio up to a bright light. He wangled permission to sit in on conferences, roamed the lot and followed the activities of 93 people, all named. As a result, ''The Studio'' tells with considerable precision how Hollywood operates. The 1969 book was acclaimed for its delineation of the industry's money-centered ethos.

title: DEATH AND DEBRIS SHATTER A QUIET EVENING
description: Linda Quay's 2-year-old daughter was sitting in her highchair in the dining room when the tornado swirled up out of nowhere Friday evening.

title: PLANS OUTLINED TO ALLEVIATE DELAYS DURING ROADWORK
description: ON the Hutchinson River Parkway, where construction crews are building a new interchange with Mamaroneck Avenue, motorists wind through a temporary detour that frequently slows them down.

title: Electronic Signs Called a Frivolity
description: The thought of my tax money being used to erect electronic traffic advisory signs (May 5) makes my skin crawl. I do not need a sign with a college education to tell me that I'm sitting in a traffic jam.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: WHEN the actress Celeste Holm talks to young people, it's never about the theater.

title: FILM: 'HOLY INNOCENTS'
description: ''The Holy Innocents'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times Sept. 30. The film opens today at the Cinema Studio 1, Broadway at 66th Street. ON a feudal farm in northern Spain, stereotypical images of noble, earthy peasants are made unexpectedly touching in Mario Camus's ''Holy Innocents,'' which focuses on the travails of one peasant family, gatekeepers to the large country estate of a marchioness and her family in the 1960's.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: HOUSING NEEDS RISE ON RTE. 1
description: WHEN the Prudential Insurance Company of America decided in 1976 to build a few office buildings at Princeton University's Forrestal Center on Route 1, it hedged its bets.

title: AFGHAN GUERRILLAS REPORT MAJOR SETBACK
description: Afghan rebels said here today that Soviet forces had attacked guerrilla positions in a strategic valley with tanks, napalm and saturation bombing, forcing the rebels to retreat.

title: '86 Medicare At '85 Rates
description: A freeze on Medicare payments to hospitals has often been proposed, to contain health care costs or to cut the Federal deficit or both. The bottom lines in the Senate and House budget resolutions for the 1986 fiscal year assumed a freeze; President Reagan's first budget for 1986 also called for one.

title: QUEEN MARIE OF RUMANIA
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERSTATE BANKING'S DIFFICULT BIRTH
description: INTERSTATE banking in America is advancing in haphazard, almost accidental steps.

title: COOLING OFF TWO ROOMS FOR THE PRICE OF ONE
description: ALTHOUGH this area has had only a small taste of hot weather thus far this year, no one doubts that there are plenty of hot and humid days and nights still ahead - days and nights when those who own air conditioners will have their machines running full blast in bedrooms and living areas in order to lower the temperature and reduce humidity.

title: Nationwide PCP Ring Broken, Police Report
description: Federal agents and the police say they have broken a ring that annually manufactured and distributed up to $150 million worth of ''angel dust'' - phencyclidine, or PCP - using chemicals stolen from the Eastman Kodak Company.

title:
ART;

LOOKING AT A 'TIME CAPSULE'
description: IN 1935, Edward Hopper painted ''House at Dusk,'' William Gropper finished ''The Senate,'' and Peter Blume was working on ''The Eternal City.'' These, and a good many other landmarks of 20th-century American art, are currently assembled at Hofstra University's Emily Lowe Gallery as part of the school's 50th-anniversary exhibition, ''1935: The Year and the Arts.''

title: A COWBOY OF THE SPACE AGE
description: ONE of these fine days, if you're passing the offices of the Space Structures International Corporation in Plainview, you might notice something unusual on the lawn: a full-scale prototype of a space station.

title: VICTORIAN PARTY
description: ELI WALLACH, the actor, will be quite visible among the guests, and his wife, Anne Jackson, should be, too. But the aromatic ghost who inhabits the Domed Octagon House will probably show up at next Sunday's Victorian Garden Party in its usual form - ''as an exquisite and unidentifiable fragrance.''

title: ANOTHER LOOK AT 'NINE' AND THE TONYS
description: GIVEN the limp lineup of musicals nominated for this last Broadway season's Tony Awards - which will be televised tonight at 9 o'clock on the CBS network, with three musical categories eliminated - and compounded by Broadway's meager musical supply, it appears apt to reappraise ''Nine,'' which won five Tony Awards in 1982.

title: MISS JORDAN HAS NUPTIALS
description: Jennifer Bennett Jordan, an associate in the New York law firm of Lord, Day & Lord, and Henry Crawford Clark, an architect at Butler Rogers Baskett Associates in New York, were married yesterday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read performed the ceremony.

title: CENTER GAUGES CONSUMERS' TASTES
description: AT the Greenwich Opinion Center, your opinion counts. In fact, the Center pays consumers to talk about what they like and what they do not like about products and services.

title: Broccoli Soup With Buttermilk
description: In ''Butter's Sour Milk'' (April 28), Craig Claiborne and Pierre Franey dish up four vegetable soups made with buttermilk. Despite a name that sounds fattening, buttermilk is made from low-fat milk and actually contains less fat and calories than fluid whole milk.

title: CHRISTINA STANLEY BECOMES A BRIDE IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: Christina Stanley, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John A. Stanley of Belvedere, Calif., was married in Worcester, Mass., yesterday to Charles W. Kim Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Kim of Old Field, L.I. The Rev. Ralph Marsden performed the Protestant ceremony at the Greendale People's Church, where the bride's parents were married in 1958.

title: Fairer Taxes and What Else?
description: When first elected, President Reagan proclaimed that the power to tax ''must not be used to regulate the economy or bring about social change.'' Four years wiser, he now proclaims a tax program to achieve nothing less than ''the second American Revolution.'' Such hyperbole aside, Mr. Reagan's proposals point toward significant progress in tax policy. Since its social goals are now acknowledged, the nation can cleanly debate what they should be.

title: GEORGIA'S TWO PARTIES CAN THINK LIKE ONE
description: The emergence of a two-party system in the South is already producing some strange side effects - ''a dizzy spell,'' as one Democrat put it - and nowhere is the confusion more striking than in Georgia. The two parties in this state are acting more like kissing cousins than feuding clans.

title: SMALL BUSINESS IS BIG BUSINESS The following remarks were made by Dr. Irwin Kellner, senior vice president and chief economist of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, at a recent special seminar in Jericho for small businesses.
description: IN order to know where small business is going, it is necessary to be aware of two important facts. One, the United States economy is now in the third year of a broad-based economic recovery. Two, small businesses are the main force behind the nation's economic growth, now representing almost half of our gross national product.

title: The Score Is 1 to O; the Toll Is 38
description: Soccer is not a particularly violent sport, yet it has engendered violence all over the world. Over the past few years British youths have seemed particularly prone to it. Last week, fans of the Liverpool team went on one of the worst rampages in sports history, even before the match began. Thirty-eight people died and 250 were injured as millions of horrified Europeans viewed the mayhem at home on television.

title: GARDENING
description: Gardeners who must justify chores undone on steamy summer days can do so with grace merely by immersing themselves in a good illustrated garden book. Here's a sample of the latest crop. PERENNIALS: How to Select, Grow & Enjoy. By Pamela Harper and Frederick McGourty. 160 pp. (HP Books, Paper, $9.95.) Having recently become obsessed with English perennial plantings, Americans have been forced to fend for themselves; knowledge has been hard to come by, with the few good books on our side of the Atlantic - like Robert Hebb's ''Low Maintenance Perennials'' - long out of print. To the rescue at last is ''Perennials,'' a superb guide produced by the combined talents of Pamela Harper, who is known for practicing what she preaches in Tidewater, Va., and Frederick McGourty, whose showplace nursery is in Norfolk, Conn. Their amiable text first touches upon the design of various perennial settings - including woodland, border or meadow - and then the details of selecting, planting and maintenance. Especially handy are the summary lists of plants for special conditions, such as alkaline soil, or special uses, such as ground cover. Mr. McGourty, the former editor of the respected Brooklyn Botanic Garden handbooks, lends his characteristic presence with such solid specifics as ''plants are . . . set out at least three or five to a kind. Don't plant in rows.'' The remainder of the book is an alphabetical compilation of more than 200 genera, from acanthus to yucca, with detailed cultural tips for each species noted.

title: CHINA ORDERS CHANGES IN ITS EDUCATIONAL POLICIES
description: China has adopted a wide-ranging package of educational policy changes designed to bring schooling more into line with the country's pragmatic economic goals.

title: CHAMPAGNE: THE WINE AND THE COUNTRY
description: The Autoroute de l'Est, which begins in Paris and slices across the flat, windswept landscape of eastern France, is lightly traveled. Parisians, after all, are Latins; like flowers and cats, they turn their faces instinctively to the sun. They have never been overly enamored of the cities of Metz and Strasbourg, to which the autoroute leads, or of the rest of Alsace and Lorraine.

title: South Korea Accepts North's Plan for Talks
description: South Korea's National Assembly decided today to accept a North Korean proposal for preliminary discussions in July that are intended to set up political talks between the legislatures of the two countries.

title: MARY OGDEN MARRIED TO EUGENE WALTER, JR.
description: The marriage of Mary Ellen Katherine Ogden, a registered nurse, enterostomal therapist and continuing education instructor at the Englewood (N.J.) Hospital, to Eugene J. Walter Jr., curator of publications for the New York Zoological Society and editor in chief of Animal Kingdom magazine, took place yesterday at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bogota, N.J. The Rev. Gerald Heinen performed the ceremony.

title: NEW VIEW: BARE BACKS
description: THE latest warm-weather look, the bare back, is daringly pragmatic, just the thing for those who wish to be sartorially up to the minute and well ventilated at the same time. A few questions remain to be grappled with, such as how much back does one reveal.

title: IN BIOTECHNOLOGY, CORDIALITY WORKS, TOO
description: THE scramble for survival in the market for genetically engineered products has led to a search for avenues of cooperation among the competitors.

title: Y'S EXPANSION PLAN CREATES CONCERN
description: THE possibility that the Y.M.C.A. will offer community programs in northern Westchester this fall is being viewed with concern by the northern Westchester Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. and the Mount Kisco Boys Club, both of which are making expansion plans of their own.

title: CONNORS FLARES UP IN 4-SET TRIUMPH
description: Jimmy Connors threatened to quit during a four-set triumph in the third round of the French Open today, then hinted he would not return for the Grand Slam event next year.

title: NATURE & OUTDOORS
description: The year thus far has yielded a satisfying harvest of books on natural history, ranging from an important new series of guides to the flora and fauna of the United States, to more intimate and personal treatments of the plight of the loon and of ways of turning one's own backyard into a harbor for wildlife. The alarming acceleration of the rate of extinction among plant species, especially in the tropical rain forests around the earth's Equator, has led to some books that address larger, more global issues as well. THE AUDUBON SOCIETY NATURE GUIDES Illustrated. 606-671 pp. (Chanticleer Press/Knopf, $14.95 each.) The National Audubon Society's idea was so logical that you have to wonder why no one had done it before. They divided the territorial United States into seven ecological habitats and provided a comprehensive field guide for each. The guidebooks describe the forces that brought each habitat into being and identify the most common forms of plant and animal life to be found there. The result of this marvelous idea is the simultaneous appearance of the Audubon Society Nature Guides, an impressive series of seven books: ''Atlantic and Gulf Coasts'' by William H. Amos and Stephen Amos; ''Deserts'' by James A. MacMahon; ''Eastern Forests'' by Ann Sutton and Myron Sutton; ''Grasslands'' by Lauren Brown; ''Pacific Coast'' by Bayard H. McConnaughey and Evelyn McConnaughey; ''Western Forests'' by Stephen Whitney, and ''Wetlands'' by William A. Niering. Their content varies as widely as the habitats they treat, but in form they are cut to the same useful and sensible cloth.

title: SYNAGOGUE IN FLORIDA DEFIES BLACKLIST ON GROUP OF ISRAELIS
description: A Conservative synagogue in Florida has defied its national rabbinical organization by honoring and giving over its pulpit to one of the 51 members of the Israeli Parliament who voted against the Conservative position on a key issue earlier this year.

title: YOUNG PERFORMERS AT TWO CONCERTS
description: YOUTH will be featured at two unusual concerts this evening: a piano recital at the Westport Town Hall Auditorium, and an orchestral program at the Palace Theater in Stamford.

title: LIZBETH HOEFER BECOMES BRIDE OF C. G. NAUTA
description: Lizbeth Hoefer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Burns Hoefer of Bronxville, N.Y., and Charlestown, R.I., and Cristofer Gene Nauta, the son of Walter Nauta of Chester Springs, Pa., and the late Jill Jones Nauta, were married yesterday. The Rev. Clayton A. Lord Jr. performed the ceremony at the Cross Mills Baptist Church in Charlestown.

title: 'Living Will' for Terminally Ill Passed by House in Hartford
description: The state House of Representatives, in a rare Saturday session, modified and sent back to the Senate a bill giving legal standing to ''living wills'' - instructions by terminally ill people not to be kept alive by medical apparatus.

title: Peru, Avoiding Vote Runoff, Proclaims Its President-Elect
description: Alan Garcia Perez, a Social Democrat, was proclaimed President-elect of Peru today by the Electoral Board after the board accepted a decision by the Marxist candidate, Alfonso Barrantes Lingan, not to contest a runoff.

title: Miami Routs Stanford
description: Greg Ellena and Rusty DeBold each hit two home runs and Chris Hart added another to lead Miami to a record-setting 17-3 victory over top-ranked Stanford in their first round game of the College World Series today.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

FROM SMALL SEEDS
description: THE young writers range in age from 9 to 14, but already they share some syndromes with their older counterparts. They spoke, for instance, of the gratification of putting words on paper (''It feels a lot better when you just get it out''). Of the agony of being blocked at the beginning (''It would be easier if you could just start in the middle''). Of the joys of making it big (''A best seller is what I want'').

title: MARGARET WOERDICH IS WED
description: Margaret Jean Woerdich, a daughter of Mrs. Alan McCree of Union, N.J., and the late George L. Handzo, was married yesterday to Douglas Waller Vreeland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Vreeland of Summit and Mantoloking, N.J. The Rev. Albert Butzer performed the ceremony at St. Simon's-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Mantoloking.

title: The Movers and the Shakers and the Golfers
description: Tennis held center court in the first term of the Reagan Administration. But golf is fast becoming the sport to watch in the second term.

title: CONDOMINIUM PLAN STIRS SMITHTOWN
description: MANY Smithtown residents are fuming over a proposal to convert the former Landing Elementary School into condominiums, and at what they say is the insensitive method used by the Smithtown School District Board of Trustees to push the plan.

title: THE LONGEST WAR
description: VIETNAM The Valor and the Sorrow: From the Home Front to the Front Lines in Words and Pictures. By Thomas D. Boettcher. Illustrated. 495 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. Cloth, $27.50. Paper, $14.95. MANY Americans used the occasion of the 10th anniversary of the fall of Saigon in April to reflect on that most contentious of America's foreign wars, the Vietnam conflict. Now, Thomas D. Boettcher, who served as a press officer for the 834th Air Division in 1968-69, has written a fair and lucid history of 20th-century Vietnam. He begins with the Vietnamese struggle against French colonialism, which culminated in 1954 with the Vietnamese victory at the battle of Dien Bien Phu.

title: RESTORING THE TRADITIONAL BLACK FAMILY
description: WHAT WOULD SOCIETY BE like if the family found it difficult to perform its most basic functions? We are beginning to find out. Half of all marriages in this country end in divorce, and half of all children will spend a significant period with only one parent.

title: WHY SOCCER SERVES AS A VEHICLE FOR FAN VIOLENCE
description: THE truly horrifying thought lingering after this week's death and destruction at the European Cup soccer final in Belgium is that if there were no more soccer, the madmen and their malevolence would still be seeking victims elsewhere.

title: TRAVELING FOR BUSINESS AND PLEASURE
description: LAST winter, a veterinarian fled his Long Island office for a week-long seminar in Acapulco, Mexico, sponsored by the New Jersey Veterinary Medical Association. He spent his mornings in lectures on hematology and clinical pathology, but during the afternoons he went deep-sea fishing, played golf and did some sightseeing.

title: Home From the Hospital
description: The conditions of Babies A,BC,D and E improved last week, and so did that of their mother, Patti Frustaci, the 30-year-old California high school teacher who had the largest multiple birth in American history. Mrs. Frustaci's five surviving septuplets remained in critical but stable condition, afflicted with lung conditions and other complications resulting from their birth, 12 weeks premature, on May 21. Mrs. Frustaci, recovering from a Caesarean section birth and grieving for the loss of two of her infants (one was stillborn and the other died three days later), was allowed to touch her children for the first time in the neonatal intensive care unit. She and her husband, Samuel, later named the babies.

title:
GARDENING;

SOLUTIONS FOR SMALL SPACES
description: MOST suburban gardeners share at least two restrictions on their gardening efforts: limited space and too little time to devote to the task. Both limitations necessitate good planning, if worthwhile results are to be obtained.

title: CYNTHIA GREGORY - 20 YEARS AT THE TOP
description: American Ballet Theater is, to some dancegoers, simply a matter of Cynthia Gregory, one of the company's most popular leading ballerinas. For countless fans, she epitomizes Odile, the most glittering and brilliant black swan ever to seduce the prince in ''Swan Lake.'' Her Sylph floats on a current of air through ''La Sylphide.'' And Miss Julie is captured, in the ballet of the same name, in Miss Gregory's flashing legs, grinding out romance with a stab of a lethal point shoe. In 1965, Miss Gregory left the San Francisco Ballet to join Ballet Theater. On Tuesday, the company will celebrate her 20th anniversary with a gala performance - an unusual honor for an individual dancer. Produced by Donald Saddler with a script by Robert Larkin, the gala will range from slide projections of Miss Gregory as a child to excerpts from 20 of the 70 ballets in which she has danced during her years at Ballet Theater.

title: MEN WITH RIFLES
description: THE BARRACKS THIEF By Tobias Wolff. 101 pp. New York: Ecco Press. $12.50. ''HE said that a barracks thief was the lowest thing there was. A barracks thief had turned his back on his own kind. He went on like that.'' A first sergeant is about to retire, after 20 years of faithful service, and his final Army days have been soured by such a tawdry, disgraceful incident. A month or so later, dressed in garish, ill-fitting civilian clothes, the first sergeant (he has no other name) drives away from his last post without a word or a wave. ''There goes a true soldier,'' remarks a pompous second lieutenant whom the enlisted men usually ignore. This time, however, Philip Bishop listens: ''the lieutenant meant what he said, and I thought he was right.''

title: Dance
description: P.S. 1, the artists' studio complex in Long Island City, is a magical enclave that is always worth a visit in itself. But ''Dance and Popular Culture,'' a festival occurring Saturdays and Sundays through June 23, offers an extra reason. Sunday, Saturday and next Sunday the Double Dutch Jumpropers will perform their intricate, exuberant ''A Touch of Class,'' and there will be pieces by Yvonne Meier and Mark Morris.

title: DARK SIGNS EXIST IN THE U.S., TOO
description: LAST week's tragic riot by British and Italian soccer fans that left 38 dead at the European Cup match in Belgium jeopardizes the future of organized sports throughout the world.

title: Connecticut Troopers Reach a Tentative Pact
description: A tentative three-year contract for more than 900 state police officers was reached today after three days of negotiations, the State Labor Commissioner, P. Joseph Peraro, announced this morning.

title: THE MAN WHO LOVED MISERY
description: DIVIDED SOUL The Life of Marvin Gaye. By David Ritz. Illustrated. 367 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company. $16.95. MARVIN GAYE left his indelible mark on American popular music and those who listened to it, danced to it and romanced to it during a 26-year career that ended April 1, 1984 - one day before he was to turn 45 - when his father shot him dead. Marvin Gay Sr. (young Marvin changed the spelling of his name) was sentenced in November 1984 to five years' probation. The father was a self-ordained minister to a strict Pentecostal sect. Rising from the keyboards and choir of his father's storefront church and from a doo-wop apprenticeship begun in the school halls and on the street corners of Washington, Gaye came to represent sexuality incarnate, pure charm, pained vulnerability and spirituality troubled by the secular world.

title: NEW RELEASES TAP MUSICAL HISTORY
description: Few companies issue recordings simply because the people in charge like the music or the performance. In Sync is one of the few, and its remarkable series of ''Historical Restorations'' from 78 rpm records to cassettes reflects primarily the taste of E. Alan Silver, head of the company.
