In Sync's newest releases in this series provide a fascinating glimpse of those tastes and of a past not too far removed from us, yet redolent of musical history.

title: AMERICANS ABROAD Three and Out
description: Diplomatic pouches are said to be speeding an appropriate message to most political appointees serving as U.S. ambassadors: three years is enough. Exceptions are being made for a few noncareer envoys, like Mike Mansfield in Tokyo and Maxwell Rabb in Rome.

title: EDUCATIONAL PROGRAM MIXES 'LIFE SKILLS' WITH ACADEMICS
description: DRESSED casually in blue jeans and T-shirt, 18-year-old Debbie Fitzgerald stands in front of the class, leading a discussion about environmental policy. Her manner is confident as she fields questions from her classmates seated in chairs around the edge of the room. Most striking is the degree of engagement among them, the attentive hush in the room punctuated only by the exasperated sighs of students waiting to be called on, and an occasional ripple of laughter.

title: ABHORRING A POLICY VACUUM IS CONGRESS'S NATURE
description: In recent weeks, it has sometimes seemed that Robert C. McFarlane, the President's national security adviser, had opened a branch office on Capitol Hill. Before Congress went home for its Memorial Day recess, Mr. McFarlane was spending much of his time negotiating with lawmakers over such issues as deployment of the MX missile, aid to the Nicaraguan rebels and adherence to the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty.

title: 90,000 Argentines Stay In Shelters After Storm
description: More than 90,000 people remained in makeshift shelters today after rains swept the Argentine capital, killing at least 14 people and disrupting public services.

title: CRIME
description: It has been about three years since the last Tony Hillerman book about Jim Chee, the sergeant in the Navajo Tribal Police. Mr. Hillerman's new entry, THE GHOSTWAY (Harper & Row, $13.95), maintains the high standard of its predecessors, starting with ''The Fly on the Wall'' in 1971.

title: NATIONALIST, CAPITALIST, PESSIMIST
description: SUPREME COURT JUSTICE JOSEPH STORY Statesman of the Old Republic. By R. Kent Newmyer. Illustrated. 490 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. $33. AMERICAN historical biography is undergoing a revival. Not so many years ago, the ''life and times'' seemed a second-rate genre for the serious historian. During the past year, however, prizewinning studies of Booker T. Washington, Eugene V. Debs, Cotton Mather and Andrew Jackson have appeared, along with others that enrich our understanding of the past.

title: FUND RAISING: A COMPLEX ART
description: Last June, about 50 prominent Long Islanders were invited to a dinner at the Cold Spring country Club in Cold Spring Harbor to start a $4 million capital fund-raising cmapaign for what will be the first kosher nursing home in Suffolk County.

title: MARGARET J. LOCKHART WED TO W. K. BALZER
description: Margaret Joan Lockhart, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Lockhart of Highland Mills, N.Y., was married there yesterday to William K. Balzer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Balzer of Ballston Lake, N.Y. The Rev. James Griffin performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church.

title: ISOLDE MCNICHOL WEDS JOEL MOTLEY 3D
description: Christ Chapel in the Riverside Church was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Isolde McNicholl, a daughter of Zita McNicholl of Dublin and the late Gerald McNicholl, to Joel Wilson Motley 3d, the son of Judge Constance Baker Motley and Joel Wilson Motley Jr. of New York and Chester, Conn. The Rev. Dr. William Sloane Coffin Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: GROWING PLANTS FOR BETTER HEALTH
description: HORTICULTURAL therapy, or gardening to nurture mental health, is a program being used increasingly by hospitals, nursing homes, retirement centers and mental health institutions to give the disabled and the elderly a physical and emotional outlet.

title: HEAD OF BOSTON CHARITY LOOKS TO NEIGHBORHOODS
description: As the new director of the Boston Foundation, Anna Faith Jones is shaping a $10 million program to help the inner city poor that she promises will reflect ''what neighborhood people want.'' She is acutely aware that she is the first black woman to head a major foundation and that in a city with a record of violence, new statistics show a rise in poverty and hunger, infant mortality, drug and alcohol abuse.

title: Time for a Tariff
description: To the Editor:

title: 'She'd Never Shot Anybody'
description: The police say a woman told them that she shot and killed a trucker who picked her up when she was hitchhiking simply because ''she'd never shot anybody before.'' The woman, Donna Louise Strok, 20 years old, of Romeoville, Ill., was charged with murder Friday and was held on $50,000 bond in the slaying of the truck driver, Marty E. Tune, 22, of Union, Miss. Sheriff Thomas Hodge of Bowie County said Miss Strok admitted shooting Mr. Tune with his own gun after she found it in the sleeping compartment of his truck.

title: Wishing DioGuardi Courage and Wisdom
description: It won't be long before Congressman Joseph DioGuardi [''DioGuardi Offers a Few Surprises,'' May 5] finds himself between a rock and a hard place. How can a fiscal conservative remain in the good graces of a President who has doubled the national debt since he came into office?

title: The Pitfalls of Progress
description: UNTIL RECENTLY, I have been embarrassed by my distaste for approximately 97 percent of everything that passes for progress. This was partly due to a reluctance to ally myself with mossbacks. No sensitive person can fail to wince at the suspicion that the only people who share his dislike for progress are those who have only recently accepted the abolition of slavery, and then only because economists concluded that slavery made for inefficient business personnel.

title: COLLEEN CALLAHAN WED TO ROBERT GOLDWATER
description: Colleen Marie Callahan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter D. Callahan of Quincy, Ill., and Robert Donald Goldwater, a son of Robert A. Goldwater of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Eileen Weitz of West Palm Beach, Fla., were married yesterday in Columbus, Ohio. The Rev. John T. Dittoe performed the ceremony at St. Christopher Roman Catholic Church.

title: DARIEN IS SETTING FOR THE WEDDING OF ANN D. MALEY
description: The marriage of Ann Dwyer Maley, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Wyss Maley of Darien, Conn., to James Harding Shannon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Van Arsdale Shannon, also of Darien, took place yesterday at the Noroton Presbyterian Church of Darien. The Rev. Wiilliam Donovan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Edward R. Danks, pastor of the church.

title: NEEL LANE WEDS ALLISON C. HAYS
description: Allison Christina Hays, the daughter of Anna Jane Hays of New York and Joseph Andrew Hays of Chicago, was married yesterday to Daniel McNeel Lane Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lane of Oklahoma City. The Rev. Hays H. Rockwell performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

title: MY RESERVATIONS ON EATING OUT
description: REMEMBER when eating in a restaurant meant ''going out for a bite?'' - a last-minute decision followed by an evening in which you actually ate what you felt like eating, on the night you felt like eating it.

title: PARABOLAS OF LOVE
description: PLANE GEOMETRY And Other Affairs of the Heart. By R. M. Berry. 189 pp. New York: Illinois State University/ Fiction Collective. 2.95.

title: CASE OF 3 BROTHERS DEPICTS STRUGGLES IN ENFORCING NEW YORK HOUSING LAW
description: Their real-estate companies have been cited, sued and fined for hundreds of code violations, and the Spodek brothers have been singled out by tenants and city officials as examples of one of the difficulties in enforcing New York City's housing code.

title: Cable TV
description: For tastes at opposite ends of the spectrum, cable television has novelty to offer this week: the first-time airings of ''Under the Volcano'' for the serious; and ''Sixteen Candles'' for devotees of fluff.

title: BROOKLYN TECH DOMINATES MEET
description: When Len Malech coached the girls' teams at Brooklyn Tech, the school won 17 Public Schools Athletic League cross-country, indoor and outdoor track and field titles. Last fall, Malech took over the boys' squads from Ed Zarowin, and he had disappointing results in the cross-country and indoor championships.

title: Stand on Drugs Is Called Invalid
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MISS HENDERSON MARRIES A BANKER
description: At St. James' Episcopal Church in Manhattan yesterday Anne Vinton Henderson, a daughter of Mrs. and Mrs. Peter Henderson of Plainfield, N.J., was married to Gregory W. Bauer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Grant W. Bauer of Bay Head, N.J. The Rev. Susan Harriss performed the ceremony.

title: 'TESCO' OPENS EARLY MUSIC FESTIVAL
description: For many observers, Boston is America's first city of early music, and as good an argument as any for its primacy is the fact that the Boston Early Music Festival, growing in fertile ground and nourished by the multifaceted activity surrounding it, has in five years emerged as an international leader in the field. On the eve of the third biennial festival, which opens here Monday, some critics and scholars already call it the best in the world.

title: THERE WILL BE MUSIC IN ABUNDANCE
description: The presentation of significant alternatives in musical programming continues to be one of cable's bounties, a point furthered this week with the arrival of a quartet of offerings - focusing on such names as Arturo Toscanini, Sergiu Celibidache and Richard Strauss.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bridgewater $121,500 22 Flanders Way *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 17-year-old colonial; cathedral *2* ceiling, family room, recently painted; taxes $2,381. Flemington $215,000 6 Brookview Court *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1-year-old colonial; skylights, *2* beamed ceiling, sunken family room; taxes $3,065. Maplewood $93,000 71 Franklin Avenue *2* 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; slate roof, *2* oak woodwork, enclosed porch; taxes $2,569. Palisades Park $203,000 510 Fourth Street *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old colonial; *2* recreation room with wet bar, 2-car garage; taxes $3,089. Passaic $200,000 218 Aycripp Avenue *2* 7-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 80-year-old Georgian; *2* wine cellar, living room with fireplace, den; taxes $4,027. Riverdale $233,000 805 Jason Road *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old split-level; *2* fenced backyard, fireplace; taxes $3,953. OTHER AREAS Baldwin $95,000 965 Schuman Place *2* 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, *2* eat-in kitchen, fireplace, basement; taxes $2,000. Peekskill, N.Y. $110,000 239 Buttonwood Avenue *2* 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old Cape Cod; *2* family room, 1-car garage, 1.5 acres; taxes $3,425. Stamford, Conn. $283,500 147 Skyline Lane *2* 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 27-year-old ranch; *2* newly landscaped,1 acre; taxes $3,200.

title: O'NEIL BUILDS MOMENTUM BY ROLLING WITH THE PUNCHES
description: If the 1985 session of Connecticut's General Assembly was the first skirmish in the 1986 statewide election campaign, as some politicians contend, the Republicans and the Democrats both scored points against the enemy, but the lines ended close to where they had started in January.

title: Coast Man Kills 5 People Then Gives Up to Police
description: A man shot five people to death inside a home in this San Diego suburb, then called the police and asked to be shot before being persuaded to surrender, a police spokesman said.

title: IN SRI LANKA'S HILLS, A GROWING FEAR
description: In the last 10 days, residents of this mountain town say, Government security forces have swept through a previously peaceful Tamil area in the heart of Sri Lanka, rounding up about 100 young men on suspicion of terrorism.

title: A PROGRAM FOR PURCHASING MANAGERS
description: ONE of the most noticeable recent changes in the software industry has been the development of programs far more specialized than those conceivable only a few years ago. The mighty three of business computing - word processors, spreadsheets and data base managers - are certainly not about to be displaced, but the field's greatest innovation is in programs designed for highly focused users.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ARMONK FAIR More than 35,000 people descend on Armonk each year when the Lions Club puts on its old-fashioned family fair in Wampus Park. This year's edition will be open from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Saturday and noon to 6 P.M. next Sunday. There is no admission charge.

title: NONPROFIT GROUPS
description: To the Editor:

title: FLORIO AID SOUGHT
description: WHEN Representative James J. Florio decided not to run again for Governor, his telephone started ringing and has not stopped.

title: 'Steal a Bank, Me Boy'
description: To the Editor:

title: MANGUAGE
description: Walter Block, senior economist at the Fraser Institute in Canada, and a dozen other readers have written to chide us for a recent bit of unintended exaggeration.

title: Sports of The Times;   Strangers at Home
description: IN the litter of empty soda cans and empty dreams, Gregg Thompson had a question burning across his face. The young defender from Minnesota strode across the rudimentary locker room and blurted at the American soccer coach, Alkis Panagoulias: ''When are we ever going to play a home game?''

title: TEACHERS GET A DOSE OF THEIR OWN MEDICINE
description: Karen Sullards, a teacher with a graduate degree and 14 years of experience, who was named a master teacher and freed from classroom duties to help other teachers, had to take a test recently to show that she is qualified to teach. Miss Sullards was one of 25,000 teachers and supervisors in Arkansas who were tested on reading, writing and arithmetic this year in the first such statewide examination in the country.

title: NANCY COLEMAN WEDS PHYSICIAN
description: Nancy Mosler Coleman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin S. Coleman of New York, was married last evening to Dr. Medwin Matthew Mintzis, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Irving Mintzis of New York. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony at the Colemans' home.

title: FLORA DEL PRESTO BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Flora Viviani Del Presto, a daughter of Rose Del Presto and the late Rocco Robert Del Presto of Essex Fells, N.J., was married yesterday to Thomas Edward Feitel, a son of Barbara Feitel of White Plains and the late Donald Feitel of Pelham Manor, N.Y. The Rev. Paul Dinter performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University, from which the couple received M.B.A. degrees.

title: FAMOUS FIRST WORDS: WELL BEGUN IS HALF DONE
description: In the spirit of summer playfulness, The Book Review asked several writers: What is your favorite opening passage in a work of literature, and why? Some recalled their favorites instantly; others pondered the question for a while before choosing. But all these authors revealed a fondness for other writers' enticements, a willingness to be grabbed and held captive from the start. Elmore Leonard Author of ''Glitz.''

title: AMERICA DISCOVERS ALBERT BROOKS
description: After the opening of ''Lost in America,'' Albert Brooks ''took a deep breath and prepared for what I was going to tell my friends was an artistic success.'' A half-dozen other major films had opened on the same date in mid-February, and business for ''Lost in America'' was so poor that two weeks later the film was disappearing from the 10 New Jersey, Long Island and Connecticut theaters where it had been playing, remaining only at Cinema 2 in Manhattan. In Los Angeles, where he lives, Mr. Brooks consoled himself by driving up and down Sunset Strip, gazing up at a billboard advertising his film as ''Opening March 1.'' One day, he was horrified to discover that the sign had been changed to read ''Coming Soon.''

title: KATHERINE F. DANA IS WED
description: Katharine Francklyn Dana, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold G. Dana of Greenwich, Conn., and Sarasota, Fla., was married yesterday to Paul J. Piasecki Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Piasecki of Greenwich. The Rev. Richard F. Van Wely performed the ceremony at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich. The bride, who will retain her name, is with AZ Marketing Services in Greenwich. Mr. Piasecki is a certified public accountant with Bregman & Company in Stamford, Conn.

title: HOUSEKEEPING IN THE WILD
description: TWO ON THE ISLE A Memory of Marina Cay. By Robb White. 183 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $12.95. IN 1937 Robb White and his wife went to live on an island called Marina Cay in the British Virgin Islands. Mr. White's first book about the venture, ''Virgin Island,'' was published in Britain in 1954 and made into a film. Now he has written another book - the same story but with the hindsight of 50 years, plus an epilogue. ''Two on the Isle'' has a grab-you-quick beginning that soon gives way to a relaxed, often amusing account of the trials and joys of setting up housekeeping in the wild.

title: FOR GIVING NUMBERS, HER VOICE IS PERFECT
description: Her tones are clear, her diction flawless, and once you've heard her speak, you aren't likely to forget what may well be the country's most frequently heard voice.

title: Long Island Overcomes New Jersey in U.S.B.L.
description: Ken Orange's rebound basket at the buzzer of a missed 20-foot jump shot by Mike Moses gave the Long Island Knights a 95-93 victory over the New Jersey Jammers in a United States Basketball League game tonight at Hofstra University before 1,466 fans.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN SPECIAL INTEREST MAGAZINES;

THE TALE OF ONE PUBLISHING VISIONARY
description: IN 1975, Wayne Green bought ''this new thing'' called a personal computer. But he could not find any understandable user instructions.

title: The Longest Gig
description: You can call him ''Sporty'' or you can call him ''Thump'' or you can call him ''Judge.'' Any way, you would be helping to trace the prolific career of bassist Milt Hinton, who celebrates his 75th birthday this month. Mr. Hinton played with groups and singers ranging from Mahalia Jackson to Duke Ellington to the New York Bass Violin Choir.

title: Students to Perform
description: Three students from the School of Performing Arts in New York City are among 20 Presidential Arts Scholars of 1985 who will perform at Kennedy Center on June 18 in a free performance. They are Jean Emile, a dance student from Brooklyn, Matthew Sheridan, a theater student from the Bronx, and Justin Page, a music student from Manhattan.

title: DEATH TOLL RISES TO 85 IN TORNADOES IN U.S. AND CANADA
description: The explosive tornadoes that spiraled through Pennsylvania, Ohio, western New York and Ontario, Canada Friday killed at least 85 people and virtually destroyed a half-dozen towns, officials said yesterday.

title: A PUSH FOR LOCAL FARM GOODS
description: CONSUMERS will never be more than a few miles away from fresh farm produce this summer, thanks to a State Department of Agriculture program to promote locally grown goods.

title:
GARDENING;

SOLUTIONS FOR SMALL SPACES
description: MOST suburban gardeners share at least two restrictions on their gardening efforts: limited space and too little time to devote to the task. Both limitations necessitate good planning, if worthwhile results are to be obtained.

title: Workers Nearing Completion Of Walden Pond Restoration
description: State workers have nearly finished a $600,000 project to restore Walden Pond, which 130 years ago inspired Henry David Thoreau to write ''Walden,'' in which he described his philosophy and thoughts on life.

title: U.S.-Soviet Summit Meeting Is Not Likely, Brandt Asserts
description: Willy Brandt, the former West German Chancellor, who has just returned from talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, said today that he doubts there will be a summit meeting this year between Mr. Gorbachev and President Reagan.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: JUDAIC TREASURES The Wadsworth Atheneum, the Hartford Symphony Orchestra and the University of Hartford have collaborated in a program in conjunction with the Smithsonian Institution's traveling exhibition, ''The Precious Legacy: Judaic Treasures from the Czechoslovak State Collections.''

title: SINGING UNSUNG HEROES
description: What, exactly, are orchestrations? Even the most ardent musical-comedy aficionado might not be able to define the term. Many critics either cannot discern or simply do not acknowledge orchestrations and, yet, every musical has them.

title:
ANTIQUES;

AN 'ART FORM' GOING ON BLOCK
description: PIECE by piece within the intimacy of an 18th-century home secluded on seven and a half acres in the Mendham countryside, Judge Burton Pariser and his late wife, Susan, created more than a place to live and raise four children, all of whom are now grown.

title: SUDDENLY, THE BARRIO IS DRAWING BUYERS
description: ON the surface, most of East 105th Street between First and Second Avenues looks unchanged - faded and gray from neglect, fronted on the south side by a long stretch of abandoned buildings, their windows bricked up like blinded eyes. Garbage carpets the sidewalk.

title: BOOKS FOR VACATION READING
description: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the December 1984 Christmas issue. It only suggests high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from The Book Review.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: Journey Into Fear Starring Joseph Cotten and Orson Welles; directed by Norman Foster, 1943 RKO Home Video 68 minutes. $34.95 From the pages of an Eric Ambler thriller, Joseph Cotten and Orson Welles constructed the screen adaptation of this tale of wartime espionage.

title: READING AND NOTHINGNESS, OF PROUST IN THE SUMMER SUN
description: A feeling seems to have arisen that summer is the time for light reading. I don't know where anyone got that idea. The truth about summer is this. There are an enormous number of hours in it -slow hours - and yet, before you know it, somehow it is over. So all you have to do is to start reading Heidegger, say, on the first day of summer. One day you look up and both summer and Heidegger are done.

title: Secular Humanism and Mr. Justice Black
description: To the Editor:

title: FIONA IRVING BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Fiona Irving, a daughter of Flora Miller Biddle of New York and Michael H. Irving of Norwalk, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Benson Wold, a son of Peter B. Wold Jr. of Bottineau, N.D., and Anne Hartung of Minot, N.D. The Rev. Bruce Forbes performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: THE CELTICS' INVISIBLE CENTER
description: IN the National Basketball Association each year, a 7-foot premise always permeates the playoffs.

title: SAYING CUOMO IS VULNERABLE, GOODMAN PONDERS CHALLENGE
description: ''After you get past George Clark and Roy Goodman, there are no Republicans out there knocking Mario Cuomo,'' said George L. Clark Jr., the Republican state chairman, whose role is to ''knock'' the opposition.

title: WILL THERE BE BROWNOUTS THIS SUMMER?
description: WITH the start of the peak season for electricity at hand, experts on Long Island's power situation have a wide variety of opinions about the adequacy of the supply.

title: ATTITUDES THAT SHAPE THE FIGHT AGAINST AIDS
description: IT has been estimated that as many as one million people have been exposed to HTLV-III, the virus that causes AIDS, since the disease was first recognized four years ago. Many believe that its spread to heterosexuals, if not already under way, is in the offing. Nevertheless, Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome still takes its toll primarily among homosexuals, setting it apart from cancer or heart disease. Although Washington says it is doing all it can, there are those who are dissatisfied with the Government's effort, from its investigative priorities to the aid it provides for the counseling of victims. A panel of researchers, physicians and other experts (but no Federal officials) discussed attitudes and AIDS here last week at a symposium held during the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. Excepts follow.

title: Virginia Republicans Nominate Candidate
description: Republicans today nominated Wyatt Durrette, who ran unsuccessfully for attorney general in 1981, as their candidate to oppose Gerald Baliles, a Democrat. in November's gubernatorial election.

title: MISS MCDONALD BECOMES A BRIDE
description: The marriage of Arlene Joy McDonald, a flight attendant for Trans World Airlines, to John Ireland Howe Bigelow, who is to receive a master's degree in arts administration this week from New York University, took place yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: REAPING A HARVEST OF WILDFLOWERS
description: Amaryllis, fine roses, hydrangea and other rarerified flowers may reign as royalty in most cultivated gardens, but it is the sturdy, dogged wildflower, the peasant of the floral world, that enjoys an honorable home in Charlotte, Vt.

title: A LITTLE TOWN AND ITS BIG RED WINE
description: The new castle of the Pope is a romantic ruin overlooking the red-tiled roofs of Chateauneuf-du-Pape, its tiny namesake village in the South of France. From the Gothic arches of this shell of a keep, the panorama sweeps south to Avignon, which was the seat of a series of French Popes from 1309 to 1377. Chateauneuf-du-Pape, 12 miles to the north, was the Pope's country residence, Castelgandolfo to Avignon's Rome.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SUNDAY, JUNE 2, 1985

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN SOUTHBURY
description: FOR nearly three centuries after it was settled in 1673, Southbury was a peaceful farm community. A few vacationing New Yorkers who began invading Connecticut in the 1920's ventured up to its southern border and bought small parcels on the Housatonic River for rustic summer cottages, but most of the town remained untouched by outsiders.

title: MCDOWELL'S SUCCESS A TRIBUTE TO FAITH
description: At age 24, Roger McDowell is everything that a fire-breathing relief pitcher should not be: mild-mannered, laid-back, inoffensive and a polite young man. In the movies, he would be James Stewart, not Humphrey Bogart. He also is a rookie in the big leagues who had an elbow operation last year in the minor leagues.

title: TO DRAW OR NOT
description: Is it really better to make two draws than one victory and one loss? Conservative players seem to think so.

title: KATHRYN MOSELEY BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Kathryn Drew Moseley, the daughter of Mrs. Richard Curtis Miles of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Charles Guy Moseley Jr., and Robert Michael Kristofik, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kristofik of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., were married yesterday. The Rev. Harry Adams performed the ceremony at the Dingletown Community Church in Greenwich.

title: $50,000 Tooth
description: GINA LOLLOBRIGIDA was dining out in Manhattan in 1983 when, she said, she bit into a shrimp and chipped a tooth on a ''brown, pebblelike substance.''

title: ECONOMIC ANALYSTS SEE BIG CHANGES FROM TAX PLAN
description: If the tax plan President Reagan proposed this week becomes law, it will significantly change major features of the American economy, according to analysts who have made initial examinations of the plan.

title: NORFOLK, VA., SEEN AS SPYING TARGET
description: Current and former Federal intelligence agents say the Tidewater area, home to the world's largest and perhaps most sensitive naval complex, is a prime center of spy-recruiting efforts by foreign powers.

title: TERRIFYING FANTASIES THAT AUGURED REALITY
description: There was a difference between Felix Nussbaum (1904-1944) and most of the other victims who died in Nazi concentration camps. He was an artist who managed to leave behind enduring evidence of his existence. But it took more than 25 years for that evidence to come to light, and the facts of his life to be re-established. The details are still emerging. What's extraordinary is that in the last desperate years before his death, hiding out with his wife in a Brussels attic, he produced works of spirit and optimism, along with those of the blackest vision.

title: MISS LEFRAK MARRIED TO KIRK D'AMICO
description: The marriage of Francine LeFrak, president of the Whole Picture Company Ltd. and LeFrak Productions, to Kirk Mason D'Amico, a vice president of RKO Pictures, took place yesterday at the Metropolitan Club in New York. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony.

title: 'LITTLE ANNOYING THINGS' ADD UP IN HOTEL STRIKE
description: Every detail of Edward and Arlene Bishop's visit to New York had been planned for weeks. A car would meet them at Grand Central Terminal and take them to the Plaza Hotel, where a bottle of champagne would be waiting in their room. They would dine that evening in one of the hotel's five dining rooms or, perhaps, ask the concierge to make a reservation at a fine French restaurant.

title: BROOKS CUSHMAN WED TO EDWIN S. CROOKS 2D
description: Brooks Lucas Cushman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John U. Cushman of Charlotte, N.C., was married yesterday to Edwin S. Crooks 2d, a son of Mrs. Edwin S. Crooks of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Crooks. The Rev. Gary Farmer performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Biltmore Forest Country Club in Asheville, N.C.

title: CRANE ACCIDENT LEADS TO THE CLOSING OF 7 CONSTRUCTION SITES
description: New York City officials, carrying out an emergency inspection of 50 construction sites, have ordered seven of them shut down for what they said were violations of building regulations.

title: NUPTIALS FOR MARIE REGAN
description: Marie Celine Regan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Regan of Long Island City, Queens, was married yesterday to Laurence Anthony Berman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Berman of Jackson Heights, Queens. The Rev. John Clermont performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: ICE CREAM FROM YOUR OWN FREEZER
description: BECAUSE I have a very small kitchen, I have never owned an ice-cream maker - neither one that is hand-cranked and uses bags of salt, or a fancy expensive electric Italian model. I have had to make do with ice cream frozen in freezer trays - with varying success.

title: MIDWEST SEARCHES FOR SOLUTIONS TO FARM CRISIS
description: A major Middle West conference on the future of agriculture ended here today with delegates from nearly two dozen states agreeing that the nation's farm financial crisis was going to get a whole lot worse before it really got bad.

title: ART AND THE LIFE OF INDIA
description: WHEN I WENT TO India for the first time, not quite six months ago, I had in my hand the schedule of the Festival of India that will be inaugurated in Washington on June 13 by the Prime Minister of India, Rajiv Gandhi. It is a remarkable, nationwide roll call of events, in which seasoned professionals will do all that can be done to import the importable India. (A selected list of Festival of India activities and their whereabouts appears on page 29.) In any other country, I should have knocked myself out getting ready for it. I should have gone to as many museums, as many churches and as many houses and gardens, great and small, as could be fitted into the day. I should have gone to the theater, to the opera, to the ballet. I should have pestered eminent writers for their opinion on this question or that. I should have ''taken the pulse of the country,'' the way people take the pulse of Italy by going to the horse race in Siena or of England by going to the Henley regatta.

title: MISS GATES PLANS AUGUST WEDDING
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stuart W. Gates of Portland, Ore., of the engagement of their daughter Sarah MacMillan Gates to Clifford Llewellyn Fitzgerald 3d, a son of Virginia H. Fitzgerald of Greenwich, Conn., and Mr. Fitzgerald Jr. of Stamford, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title: PANACHE
description: Another indication, if one is needed, that the Upper West Side in general and the blocks just off Central Park in particular hold some of the city's most expensive residences is the prices of the five apartments in the brownstone being renovated at 23 West 69th Street. When they go on sale next month, the one-bedroom apartments in the new condominium will cost $470,000 and the asking price for the two-bedroom units will be $585,000.

title: ARE THE PALESTINIANS READY TO SEEK PEACE
description: FOR four days in Washington last week, King Hussein of Jordan held forth as an evangelist for peace in the Middle East. He tried to persuade not only the Reagan Administration, but also pro-Israeli Congressmen and the American public that after years of rejecting any talk of a negotiated peace with Israel, the Palestine Liberation Organization, in concert with Jordan, was finally ready to take that dramatic step.

title: Nicaraguans Attacked Patrol, Costa Rica Says
description: Nicaraguan soldiers fired mortars across their southern border, then moved into Costa Rica, killing at least one Costa Rican Civil Guardsman and wounding nine others, Costa Rica charged today.

title: LAST OF THE RED-HOT PRODUCERS
description: WHEN THE ANTOINETTE PERRY (Tony) Awards ceremony begins tonight, Emanuel Azenberg will probably be sitting toward the front of the audience, next to Bernard Jacobs, the president of the Shubert Organization and the most powerful man on Broadway. Afterward, though, Azenberg plans to skip the banquet at the New York Hilton - the epicenter of glitter and glad-handing - and throw a smaller, more modest party of his own.

title: Slaney Sets U.S. Mark
description: Mary Slaney made her 1985 outdoor track and field debut tonight by breaking her own American record in the 5,000 meters before a hometown crowd at the rain-soaked Prefontaine Classic.

title: BASEBALL CLICHES
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW DISKS REVEL IN BACH'S VARIETY
description: The commemoration of J. S. Bach's tercentennial has more or less coincided with the commercialization of the digital compact disk, which may or may not have anything to do with the somewhat surprising fact that in the CD listings in a recent edition of the Schwann catalogue more space was devoted to Bach than to any other composer apart from Mozart. (If you are interested, Mozart won out with 23 1/2 column inches against Bach's 19). In any event, lots of Bach has already been issued on CD and, while there has inevitably been some duplication of popular pieces, there is nothing to match the Baroque overkill represented by the 12 or so CD releases of Vivaldi's ''Four Seasons'' now in the stores. No, the variety of Bach on CD is pretty wide, with vocal, orchestral and solo instrumental works all well represented.

title: PSYCHEDELIC ROCK STAGES A COMEBACK
description: Do you think you might be able to find your old paisley shirts, Nehru jacket, granny glasses and love beads in the back of a closet somewhere? If so, get them out; you're going to be needing them. Psychedelic rock is back, complete with electric sitars, ragalike droning, fuzztone guitars, loopy lyrics inviting you to ''open your mind,'' and song titles like ''Radar Eyes,'' ''Sundown on Venus,'' and ''Euphoric Trapdoor Shoes.'' It's beginning to look like the summer of 1985 will be a replay of the summer of '67 - the ''summer of love.''

title: Psychologist Responds To 'Daughter's Legacy'
description: I was very much touched by ''The Legacy for a Daughter Left Behind'' by Phyllis Seidelman [Opinion Page, May 5] .

title: PROBLEMS FOR MONTAUK PROJECT
description: FOUR years ago, when the conversion of a portion of the former Montauk Air Force Base into a housing development was begun, the project received bipartisan support from East Hampton Town officials. Its success, they said, would signal a renewed commitment by the town to assisting struggling families and could be viewed as the prototype for future efforts.

title: A DENT IN CRIME
description: The number of crimes reported in New York City dropped 5.8 percent during the first three months of this year compared with the same period in 1984, the police department announced last week. Police attributed the decline to an increase in officers on the streets and to a decrease in the number of young people in the age group most likely to commit crimes.

title: Head of the Line
description: Chuck Daly, the head coach of the Detroit Pistons and a former assistant coach for the Philadelphia 76ers, has joined the line of prospects -maybe even moved to the front of it -for the vacancy created by Billy Cunningham's resignation last week. He declared himself interested in the job and schedulded a preliminary interview with the 76ers' general manager, Pat Williams.

title: FLOWERING PLUM - CHINESE MOTIF FOR THE PASSING OF BEAUTY
description: ''Bones of Jade, Soul of Ice: The Flowering Plum in Chinese Art'' is an example of what a first-rate theme show can be. Although its subject is probably too unfamiliar for the title to whet the appetite of more than a handful of Westerners, the flowering plum has been a fruitful, if not a flourishing Chinese artistic motif for centuries. It has inspired and shaped some of Chinese culture's most eloquent ruminations on beauty and loss, renewal and death.

title: Waterway From the Gulf To the Tennessee Opened
description: Secretary of the Army John O. Marsh Jr. today officially opened the 234-mile Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway, ending more than a century of planning and 14 years of construction.

title: A SHARED SUMMER IS A 2-WAY STREET
description: HIS name is Jaime. A first-generation New Yorker, he lived on East 103d Street in East Harlem.

title: THE ESSENTIAL SPIRIT OF PARIS - SIP BY SIP
description: Most visitors to Paris plan their trips the way Napoleon planned the Peninsula Wars. They lay out walking tours, collect bus schedules, check the hours at the museums and book restaurants weeks in advance.

title: A TRIBUTE TO AMERICAN COOKING
description: THE MOVABLE FEAST tomorrow night that will benefit New York's Citymeals-on-Wheels program, which feeds the homebound elderly, promises to be a delectable tribute to American cooking. The black-tie dinner will honor the late James Beard, a resolute champion of native American food. It will also be an ideal opportunity to compare the old and the new -the classic cooking so dear to Mr. Beard's heart and the so-called new American cooking that has evolved during the last 15 years.

title: Arms Negotiators Resume Sparring
description: As Soviet and American arms-control negotiators began their second round in Geneva last week, Max M. Kampelman, the American chief delegate, said his orders provided ''the flexibility that we need to move forward.'' But several factors, including divisions in the Reagan Administration over whether to preserve existing treaties, raised the prospect of new complications.

title: WAY UP NORTH: WHITEFIELD, N.H.
description: When you reach Whitefield, about 20 minutes north of Bretton Woods and that sprawling hostelry called the Mount Washington Hotel, you're in New Hampshire's North Country, closer to Canada than to Concord.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption for a picture that accompanied an article on North Fork tourism last Sunday misidentified Gertrude McCombe and her son, Clark McCombe, of Briermere Farm in Riverhead.

title: JOURNAL OF A FRESH AIR TRIP
description: DANIELLE SMITH of Staten Island brought a pad and pencil on her first visit to Connecticut as a Fresh Air Fund child. In her makeshift journal she recorded the events of her two-week suburban idyll - gathering daisies by the roadside, shopping for fresh produce at an outdoor stand, and, every night without fail, feeding Rolf, the family's yellow Labrador retriever.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing in New & Noteworthy May 19 erred in suggesting that an edition of ''The Woman in White'' by Wilkie Collins was officially connected to the novel's television dramatization on PBS. The tie-in paperback edition is the Signet Classic published by New American Library.

title: The $32 Million Flying Ashtray
description: Poor Caspar Weinberger. Each time the embattled Secretary of Defense raises his head, another absurdly priced piece of military hardware comes winging his way. The $435 hammer. The $1,118 plastic stool-leg cap. The $7,622 coffee brewer. The $16,571 lunch-pack refrigerator.

title: SARAH E. BUTTON MARRIES A LAWYER
description: The marriage of Sarah Elizabeth Button, a daughter of Daniel E. Button of Albany and Rebecca Pool Button of Newark, Del., to Peter Joseph White Jr., the son of the late Mr. White of New York and the late Mary Anastasia White, took place yesterday. The Rev. William Wilson Trumbore performed the ceremony at Old St. Anne's Episcopal Church in Middletown, Del.

title: Chinese Reported To Fend Off Vietnamese
description: Chinese border guards repulsed a regiment of Vietnamese soldiers backed by artillery fire, the official New China News Agency said.

title: THE CROPS MAY CHANGE BUT NOT THE CONDITIONS
description: When the asparagus harvest ended last week and the migrant workers moved on to the radishes, the portable toilets on Rick Buurma's vegetable farm moved with them. ''We don't want the workers to have to walk a long ways from where the work's at,'' Mr. Buurma said. That's an unusual attitude for a farmer to take about his employees, according to state officials and farm labor organizations. On four of every five farms, they say, employers show little concern for the welfare of their workers. Most farms have no toilet facilities at all.

title: MISS MCINERNEY, EDITOR, WED TO NICHOLAS CUNETTA
description: Rosemary McInerney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. McInerney of Paramus, N.J., was married there yesterday to Nicholas Joseph Cunetta, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Cunetta, also of Paramus. The Rev. James Huvane performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Annunciation.

title: Wilmington Plans To Sell City Hall
description: PERHAPS you can't fight City Hall, says the Mayor of Wilmington, Del., but you can sell it.

title: MANHATTAN YOUTHS DESIGNING SPACE EXPERIMENT
description: Jason Thurston just knows he will be a Hollywood discovery some day. He has yet to decide whether it will be as an actor or singer. For now, though, the 12-year-old fuels his talents by participating in school productions and attending glee-club rehearsals daily -except Wednesdays.

title: TERRI A. TIBBATTS WEDS FRANKLIN H. NICHOLS 3D
description: At the United Methodist Church in Bethel, Conn., yesterday, Terri Ann Tibbatts, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Nelson Tibbatts of Bethel, was married to Franklin Hodgdon Nichols 3d, a son of Mr. Nichols Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Louise Newell Nichols. The Rev. Robert T. Johnson performed the ceremony.

title: London Digs
description: To the Editor: In the ''What's Doing in London'' (Travel, April 28) an excellent restaurant, Clarke's at 124 Kensington Church Street, W8, was cited (the area is great for antiques buffs who like to haunt Portobello Road).

title: WHAT'S AHEAD FOR REAGAN'S 'REVOLUTION'
description: THE oratory last week was vintage Ronald Reagan. He summoned Americans to ''a great historic effort'' on behalf of ''America's tax plan'' -his tax plan - to ''lift us into a future of unlimited promise, an endless horizon lit by the star of freedom guiding America to supremacy.''

title: Jersey Theaters And Liquor Sales
description: A new law that allows nonprofit theaters in New Jersey to sell liquor before and after performances - provided the local municipality agrees -is drawing mixed reactions.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: HERITAGE DAYS FESTIVAL Eartha Kitt, the singer, will present a two-hour program next Sunday afternoon as part of the seventh annual Heritage Days Festival in downtown Trenton.

title: TONY NOMINEES WITH STATE ROOTS
description: WERE it not for plays and performances derived from Connecticut theaters, this year's dim Broadway season would have offered even slimmer pickings for prizes.

title: The Kirkpatrick Factor
description: Jeane Jordan Kirkpatrick was impressive as United States delegate to the United Nations because she gave the job her no-nonsense tone (''The Kirkpatrick Factor,'' by Jane Rosen, April 28). Quickly accepted by her colleagues there because her knowledge was at her fingertips, she was an asset to all Americans. Dr. Kirkpatick put the job of United States delegate to the United Nations back on its pedestal. It makes me wonder why the Democrats let her slip through their fingers. TERRY MAYER New York City

title: FEMALE SLEUTHS
description: To the Editor:

title: CONLEY TRIPLE JUMP OF 58-1 3/4 IS FIRST
description: The temperature was 90 degrees in the stands and more than 110 at trackside. The humidity was 82 percent, the sun made it feel hotter, and the wind kept blowing erratically. It was hardly a day for outdoor sitting, let alone triple-jumping.

title: FLUTIE INJURES SHOULDER
description: The Generals won their game against the Memphis Showboats tonight, 17-7, but lost their celebrated quarterback, Doug Flutie, for a month and possibly more.

title: Bypassing Taxes
description: WHEN Jonathan Smith opened a cigarette stand on the Montauk Highway in the Town of Southampton, L.I., buyers got bargains: cigarettes without state taxes. This put Mr. Smith, a Shinnecock Indian, in trouble with the Suffolk County District Attorney's office.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

10 YEARS LATE, VIETNAM PARADE MEANT A LOT
description: WHEN I was a marine in Vietnam, I took a lot of unforgettable walks in rice paddies and jungle canyons. I often slogged through mud while the screams of incoming rounds and shrapnel filled the air.

title: RALLY WILL SEEK SUPPORT FOR ARTS
description: THE newly formed Statewide Coalition for the Arts will hold a rally here at noon Thursday to demonstrate and seek support for a $3.1 million budget increase for the State Council on the Arts and for a proposed $50 million New Jersey Cultural Capital Fund.

title: BALLPLAYERS' NAMES MAY YET SURFACE
description: If last Friday was a critical day for baseball players concerned about indictments by a Federal grand jury in Pittsburgh, next Friday will be critical, too. That is the day when at least six of the seven men indicted on 165 counts of drug violations are scheduled to be arraigned and plead guilty or not guilty.

title: GOOD OLD IDEAS
description: THE SCHOOLS WE DESERVE Reflections on the Educational Crises of Our Times. By Diane Ravitch. 337 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95. WITH the publication of this collection of 21 essays and occasional pieces, all written within the past decade and most within the past two or three years, Diane Ravitch, a professor of education and history at Columbia's Teachers College, moves to the forefront of a small but indispensable band of critics. In these days of near hysteria over the plight of our schools, she has continued to write responsibly and intelligently about what is going on within those institutions, and what can be done to make them better.

title: Jazz
description: June may usually be a month for weddings but this year is a month for notable jazz birthdays. Doc Cheatham, the trumpeter, will be 80 on June 13, and Milt Hinton, the bassist, will be 75 on June 23.

title: HUMILIATING THE U.S.
description: What should the United States do when it undertakes a heavy diplomatic burden on behalf of a supposedly friendly government and that government repays the effort by breaking its word and making American officials look like fools? That is the question raised by South Africa's contemptuous violation of its undertakings to the U.S. on Angola and Namibia.

title: CASINOS TOLD TO INFORM PUBLIC
description: JOHN D. FEEHAN, chairman-designate of the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, says that a planned $750 million housing construction program in this resort city should not only wipe out a lingering deficiency, but also dissipate bickering within the city administration.

title: Los Angeles
description: To the Editor: Granted it's not a mystery, but one book the Scene of the Crime bookstore in Sherman Oaks (''For Shamuses and Gumshoes'', Travel, April 14) should have in stock is ''Chandlertown: The Los Angeles of Philip Marlowe.''

title: Faneuil Hall in Boston Found In Desperate Need of Repair
description: Faneuil Hall, a focus of Boston's historic Freedom Trail, which lures thousands of tourists to the city every year, is in desperate need of repair, according to Federal officials.

title: TALKS AT A HALT
description: Thousands of guests endured shouting pickets and diminished services yesterday at 47 big Manhattan hotels as negotiators broke off talks and the city's first major hotel strike in nearly a half-century got under way.

title: MEXICAN NOTEBOOK
description: We form our impressions of countries we have never visited in haphazard and often unfair ways - from movies, television, newspaper and magazine articles, from comments of friends, from ill-remembered college lectures. Murky images lodge in the backs of our minds, and even fairly intensive preparatory reading sometimes fails wholly to dislodge them. Or at least so it seems to me after spending two weeks in Mexico last winter.

title: NEW BOOK ON DOGS OFFERS GOOD ADVICE
description: For years, canines have guided the blind and more recently have helped the deaf. Sentry and patrol-dog teams are trained for the military. And with concern about crime growing in many parts of the country, German shepherds, Doberman pinschers and Rottweilers are increasingly being used as guard dogs to protect plants, stores and individuals.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Paul Dietzel, the former football coach at Louisiana State, Army and South Carolina, was said to have accepted the post of athletic director at Samford University, a 4,000-student Baptist school in Birmingham, Ala. . . . Bob Wirz, the chief spokesman for the baseball commissioner's office since 1974, has resigned to start his own sports consulting business in Norwalk, Conn. . . . John Kowalski, the coach of the Pittsburgh Spirit of the Major Indoor Soccer League for four seasons, will not be rehired for next season. . . . The last time they played an All-Star Game in Minnesota, Harmon Killebrew, the Twins' slugger, hit a two-run homer and Sandy Koufax of the Los Angeles Dodgers, was the winning pitcher. That was in 1965 when the National League won, 6-5. For this year's game, June 16, Killebrew and Koufax will be the honorary captains.

title: ARTS INSTITUTE OFFERS SUMMER PROGRAM
description: STUDENTS entering the 9th through the 12th grades this fall will have a chance in Montclair Saturday to audition for admission to the Summer Arts Institute, a five-week residential program in the performing, visual and literary arts that will be held on the Rutgers University campus here.

title: CENTRAL AMERICA'S DISPLEASED AND DISPLACED
description: Driven by political persecution, war and economic need, hundreds of thousands of Central Americans have fled their homes. The numbers seem to be growing, causing concern in the region and in Washington. American officials fear that many will eventually slip into the United States, where an estimated one million Central Americans have arrived illegally in recent years.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

LATIN AMERICAN COINS SET AUCTION RECORD
description: Latin American coins from the famous Norweb Collection attracted big prices at a public auction held May 17 and 18 in Dallas. The 850 lots were hammered down for a total of $839,749. A 10-percent buyer's fee charged on every item increased the amount to well over $900,000. This was substantially more than the $750,000 estimate.

title: EXECUTIVES RETIRE TO LIVES FULL OF ACTIVITY
description: FOR those executives who join a Stamford-based international service organization, retirement can be anything but dull.

title: Dance Work Canceled
description: A performance of the choreographer Merce Cunningham's ''Roaratorio,'' scheduled for late June at the Park Avenue Armory, has been canceled because the space will be used for military drills at that time. The Cunningham company is searching for a large, alternate space for performances of the piece, which features 15 dancers and 6 Irish musicians. The score, composed by John Cage, is a musical rendering of James Joyce's ''Finnegan's Wake.''

title: ONE TEEN-AGER, BUT A PAIR OF DIPLOMAS
description: With barely time to pause after her high school graduation today, Catherine Costello will sit among the seniors of St. Thomas Aquinas College Sunday morning to receive a second diploma.

title: THE MOVING FORCE AT N.Y.U.
description: IN THE SPACIOUS DRAWING ROOM OVERLOOK-ing Fifth Avenue nobody is talking about money. Around a mahogany table beneath a marble bust of Aristotle, the conversation on educating public administrators is determinedly high-minded. ''There's the mathematical approach,'' says Thomas W. Moloney of the Commonwealth Fund, ''heavy on cost-benefit analysis, regarding government as a necessary evil. But those who view government as developing human potential are more involved in moral, philosophical and political debate on the role of the manager. Which side are you on?''

title: FARMERS PREDICTING SHORTAGE OF MAPLE SYRUP
description: Pancake eaters will face a shortage of maple syrup by the end of the year, according to farmers in the Northeast who produce most of the nation's supply.

title: ONCE UPON A HORSE, CAMEL OR ELEPHANT: CLASSICS OF TRAVEL WRITING
description: SOME travelers are insatiable readers, some insatiable readers like to travel but are affected by phobia at the thought of bedding down in a motel or shoehorning themselves into plane seats without something to read. Thrillers are soon finished, history and biography come in slab-size tomes that weigh down the luggage. What to take, then, as satisfactory traveling companions?

title: IS THERE A MESSAGE IN AGCA'S MADNESS?
description: The Vatican is well known for extremely discreet diplomacy. But when a Pope is shot publicly in the middle of a crowd in St. Peter's Square, the issues are not easily confined to drawing room chats.

title: SEX IS RIDICULOUS
description: LAUGHING PIG And Other Stories. By Peter Regent. Illustrated by the author. Salem, N.H.: Quartet Books/ Merrimack Publishers Circle. $12.95. THE British penchant for mockery translates well into tales that pierce, in a few swift strokes of the pen, all that is most frail and ridiculous in human nature. British writers excel in this genre, which ranges from the faintly sinister to the outright gruesome and features comedy both black and blue - since nothing, in this particular fictional universe, makes us quite so ridiculous as our sexual proclivities.

title: NEW SRI LANKA ATTACKS REPORTED
description: A senior member of the Government party said today that separatist guerrillas killed at least 50 people Friday in raids on Sinhalese villages in Eastern Province.

title: Joys and Sorrows
description: To the Editor:

title:
SUMMER READING;

POETS AND TENNIS - DROP SHOTS AND TENDER EGOS
description: IF racing is the sport of kings, tennis is surely the sport of poets. Like poetry, tennis has strict rules, requires technical skill and is played to win.

title: 2 NONBELIEVERS, AND WHAT THEY BELIEVE IN
description: Lawrence Hyman and Theodora Trent are pleasant people, easily encountered. The other day, for example, Mr. Hyman was in his kitchen, drinking tea. Miss Trent, meanwhile, had arrived at the beauty parlor to have her nails done. He is an amiable man. She is industrious and generous.

title: LOWER PAY IS A DUBIOUS EXPERIMENT
description: AT first glance, there is much to recommend the Administration's proposal to allow employers to pay youths under the age of 20 a wage of $2.50 an hour instead of the regular minimum of $3.35. It would increase teen-age employment, lower labor costs for many employers, and wouldn't cost the Government anything. But closer inspection suggests that the seriousness of the problem has been exaggerated and that the proposal is likely to be of limited benefit and could even end up increasing poverty and dependency among adults. Given this risk, the proposal should be given a trial only if a mechanism is devised for assessing its full impact. So far, it lacks such a mechanism.

title: Middle Age Catches Indy Champions
description: Danny Sullivan's Indianapolis 500 victory last weekend underscored a changing of the guard that had been going on among the top-line drivers in America's oldest and most prestigious form of motor sport.

title: TOKYO'S HOT NEW BEVERAGE? COFFEE
description: Andreas, my host, and his wife, Michiko, knew about my morning needs.

title: EXPERTS TELL OF SPYING SURGE AND VULNERABLE U.S. SECRETS
description: Never before have so many people been awaiting trial on charges of espionage against the United States, Federal officials say.

title: Seat-belt Vote In Connecticut
description: The Connecticut Legislature last week joined New York and New Jersey in requiring drivers and front-seat passengers to buckle up. The State Senate passed a bill previously approved by the House of Representatives. Gov. William A. O'Neill said he would sign the measure.

title: THE PRIME OF BRUCE JAY FRIEDMAN
description: THE master of black humor -in fact, the man responsible for the term - has mellowed considerably. He's now a country gentleman on the South Fork. With his second wife, Patty, he has a new baby named Molly and a galumphing yellow Labrador retriever named Mel, short for - appropriately enough - Mellow. A couple of cats hang around the Water Mill campsite, too.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: John Cougar Mellencamp: Ain't That America MusicVision 58 minutes. $29.95 A smart, motorcycle-racing hell-raiser from a working-class Indiana background, John Cougar Mellencamp is the most articulate spokesman, after Bruce Springsteen, of an all-American blue-collar sensibility for whom rock 'n' roll isn't just entertainment but a spiritual release.

title: DOING NOTHING? NOTHING DOING
description: I THOUGHT I'd made it clear that I was taking the vacation not to go anywhere in particular unless we felt like it or even to get away from The Office awhile -just to loaf, be a do-nothing, dawdle (which, of course, I couldn't very well do at The Office; they really wouldn't approve).

title: DR. GLORIA WU IS WED TO DR. PAUL J. WANG
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in New York yesterday Dr. Gloria Wu, chief resident in ophthalmology at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, was married to Dr. Paul J. Wang, a resident in internal medicine at Presbyterian Hospital. The Rev. Dr. Paul O. Mellin performed the ceremony.

title: SKILLED WORKERS HELP SOME PLANTS BUCK A TREND AND STAY IN NORTHEAST
description: In a barnlike, sky-blue building on Route 1 here is what sometimes seems a rarity in the Northeast and other old industrial areas: A manufacturing company that has decided to stay put.

title: Beer Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAEL LEON ROZENTAL MARRIES HARLI FAIT DIAMOND
description: The marriage of Harli Fait Diamond, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Diamond of Manlius, N.Y., and Israel Leon Rozental took place yesterday evening at the Eden Roc Hotel in Miami Beach, Fla.

title: VALERIE A. BURNS IS BRIDE OF STEPHEN WINNINGHAM
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Valerie Ann Burns, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John V. Burns of Naples, Fla., formerly of Greenwich, was married to Stephen Meredith Winningham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Winningham of Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. Dr. John Ramsey Bishop performed the ceremony.

title: Kenyan Leader Worried About Population
description: President Daniel arap Moi said today that failure to slow Kenya's annual 4 percent population growth would lead to social and economic upheaval in the East African country.

title: REAGAN GOES PUBLIC WITH HIS TAX PLAN
description: On the positive side of the President's tax plan for individuals are a near doubling of the personal exemption, to $2,000, a maximum 35 percent tax rate and a $4,000 maximum I.R.A. deduction for one-earner families. The plan would cut taxes for Americans who do not itemize, but would curb or eliminate many popular deductions, including those for state and local taxes, entertainment expenses and interest payments. For businesses, the maximum tax rate would be 33 percent, instead of 46 percent, but investment tax credits would be eliminated, bad debt reserves would not be deductible and the oil depletion allowance would be phased out.

title: '80-20' BENEFICIARY
description: When the Elder Craftsman, a nonprofit organization that sells the handiwork of older artists from a consignment shop at 846 Lexington Avenue, faced the end of its lease last year, its board of directors started searching for new space in a less expensive neighborhood.

title: THE ATMOSPHERE OF A BYGONE AGE
description: NAMING a 1980's Westport restaurant after an 1870's New York City political boss who was known for corruption rather than culinary interests, eludes us. But why bother with imponderables? Just relax and enjoy the vaguely 19th-century atmosphere at Boss Tweed - dark paneled walls, ''gas lamp'' lighting, glass panels and vintage pictures.

title: ST. WOLFGANG AND THE DEVIL
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN ATTACKS OPPONENTS OF HIS TAX PLAN
description: President Reagan, portraying special interests as the stumbling block to his tax proposal, said today that a ''strong voice'' was needed to make Congress pass a major overhaul of the Federal tax system.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Fading of the Familiar According to Elizabeth Spencer, school opens up one world for a child and closes another. In ''Mississippi Writers: Reflections of Childhood and Youth, Volume One,'' an anthology of fiction edited by Dorothy Abbot (University Press of Mississippi), Miss Spencer shows a young girl being ''educated'' away from the familiar and into the strange.

title: GRABBING RESPECT 19 FEET UP
description: IN six track meets in the last six weeks, with his father as coach, Joe Dial has pole-vaulted 18 feet 8 inches, 18-9, 17-10 1/2 (the box in which the pole was planted was too deep), 19-1 1/2 (American record), 19-2 1/4 (American record) and 18-6.

title: WASHINGTON WILL HOLD ITS OWN JAZZ FESTIVAL
description: WHEN the Kool Jazz Festival decided to bypass Washington, the city's jazz community rallied itself. The result is the first Capital City Jazz Festival, a three-concert series that will take place Friday and Saturday at the Washington Convention Center. It is one of the rare jazz festivals whose producers, as well as its performers, are black.

title: TAKING AIM AT THE WORLD OF TV
description: Jonathan Reynolds is a playwright with what may be a quixotic goal. He proposes to appeal to intelligent theatergoers the old-fashioned way, by providing an experience that expands the audience's vision instead of reaffirming what it already knows. Mr. Reynolds's new play, ''Fighting International Fat,'' scheduled to open Wednesday at Playwrights Horizons, takes aim at two peculiar American obsessions - the diet industry and television talk shows - in what he describes as a heightened and intensely theatrical fashion. Once again, as he did in his acclaimed 1982 play, ''Geniuses,'' which skewered the movie business, Mr. Reynolds seeks to challenge, even shock his audience by confronting and exposing the narcissism that underlies certain American institutions.

title: Enter Mrs. Isles
description: It wasn't as though the retrial of Claus von Bulow needed any more drama.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: INCOGNITO MOSQUITO, PRIVATE INSECTIVE. By E. A. Hass. Illustrated by Don Madden. Random House. Paper, $1.95. (Ages 8 to 11) His motto is ''No case too small or has too many legs,'' and his story is a sendup of detective fiction for the very young and hip reader.

title: LOOKING AHEAD TO HARD TIMES
description: ACCORDING to state political leaders, the knife with which President Reagan wants to reshape the nation's tax system would cut deepest and most painfully in New York. Many state residents would pay more overall under the Federal tax changes proposed last week by President Reagan, New York politicians contended.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

A DAUGHTER'S DEDICATION TO HER FATHER
description: I OFTEN cry at graduations and weddings. Not because I am especially sentimental, but because they bring back memories of my own hasty wartime marriage and the college diploma I received three months later.

title: Robertson Triggers Yankees' 8-2 Rout
description: True to his word, Andre Robertson did not hit a home run last night.

title: Psychiatry Showing Age and Losing Grip
description: To the Editor:

title: WHY ALICE RODE OFF WITH MR. TOOT
description: THE DEALERS' YARD And Other Stories. By Sharon Sheehe Stark. 214 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $14.95.

title: DISPUTE KEEPS HORSE IN BARN
description: If Win had run in the Red Smith Handicap at Belmont yesterday, those who remembered his running second to John Henry, losing by a neck, in the Turf Classic last fall might have made him the favorite. Instead, the popular New York-bred gelding spent the afternoon in his stall, ready to run but prevented from doing so by an increasingly bitter squabble among his owners.

title: ROBIN MAUTNER IS MARRIED
description: Robin Mautner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Mautner of Hartsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Gary S. Adler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Adler of Elmsford, N.Y. Rabbi Maurice Davis, assisted by Cantor Julian Raber, performed the ceremony at the Brae Burn Country Club in Purchase, N.Y.

title: COOKING
description: The all-American theme in food-related books remains popular this year, and this spring we finally have a comprehensive book on the foods and traditions of the Southwest. Despite the national obsession with fitness, nutrition and weight control, seductive dessert books continue to roll off the presses - two mentioned below deal with making ice cream at home, and a third is on baking. Interest in wines, or at least reading about them, seems not to have waned. One new twist on this theme is that writers are now paying more attention to wine as a companion to food. What follows is a personal sampling from this spring's copious publishing buffet. THE SIMPLE ART OF PERFECT BAKING. By Flo Braker. Illustrated. 506 pp. (Morrow, $24.95.) Anyone interested in the unforgiving art of baking will find this book indispensable. Flo Braker, a veteran cooking instructor based in California whose specialties are American and European baking and pastry making, together with chocolate and sugar working, spent years compiling this lucid and precise guide. Everything the beginner or experienced baker needs is here - tips on equipment and timing, temperatures and chemical reactions, decorating, embellishing and so on. More than just a collection of recipes, this book is written almost as a curriculum for a course in baking. The student is introduced to a type of pastry - say, the genoise, a buttery sponge cake - and told what constitutes a classic version of it and its many variations.

title:
GARDENING;

SOLUTIONS FOR SMALL SPACES
description: MOST suburban gardeners share at least two restrictions on their gardening efforts: limited space and too little time to devote to the task. Both limitations necessitate good planning, if worthwhile results are to be obtained.

title: Inspector Faults Amusement Park
description: The construction inspector of Jackson Township, N.J., said last week that the operators of the Great Adventure amusement park had continued to put up structures without obtaining permits after a fire at the park last year killed eight teen-agers. The testimony from Frank J. McClintic, the inspector, came during the the trial of Great Adventure's operators on charges of aggravated manslaughter in connection with the May 1984 fire.

title: NEW BULLLPEN LETS JAYS DARE MORE AND WIN
description: THE manager lay back in the kind of sun that settles on a ball park in the middle of the afternoon and bakes its empty seats and dusty dugouts. Hours before his players would arrive to shag their flies and take their turns in the batting cage, Bobby Cox sat on the splintery, wooden dugout steps of Chicago's Comiskey Park. And he held out his hand.

title: Still Kicking
description: He may be recovering from a couple of mild strokes, but Woody Hayes, the 72-year-old former Ohio State football coach, doesn't think that means he has to tear up his appointment book. He said he planned to keep a date to serve as grand marshal of a Fourth of July parade.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: FOR THE seventh year in a row, law-enforcement officials in New Jersey used more wiretaps in 1984 than those in any other state, according to a report by the Administrative Office of the United States Courts.

title: CONSERVATORY BRIMS WITH ACTIVITY
description: ALTHOUGH Garrick Ohlsson and a number of other artists bade an affectionate farewell to Michael Pollon in a tribute-concert last month, the retiring director of the Westchester Conservatory does not officially step down until the end of this month. Nor has the school slowed the pace of musical activities in the final days of his 22-year tenure. This afternoon, its Symphony Orchestra welcomes the winners of the conservatory's yearly Concerto Competition, while over the next three weekends, it is the co-host (with Mercy College) of a festival of June Jazz.

title: SEATTLE
description: Seattle has a reputation for gray, somber days, but in spring and summer, when the sun shines for most of its annual 72 days, it is breathtakingly beautiful. The Olympic Mountains to the west and the craggy Cascades to the east are in clear view. The soft air is so sweet that even downtown it smells like a fragrant flower.

title: Why No Outcry About Sabra and Shatila?
description: To the Editor:

title: MOMENT OF TRUTH
description: Seven years ago a Westchester County developer, Allan V. Rose, bought the Skytop Tennis Center, overlooking Interstate 287 just north of Exit 4 near White Plains, with an eye toward developing the property on the corporate-campus strip known as ''Platinum Mile'' as an office facility.

title: A GUIDE TO SOME 1985 GUIDEBOOKS
description: With the summer vacation season at hand, bookstores have sprouted alluring displays of 1985 guidebooks to a broad variety of destinations. Many of the publishers are familiar names: Fodor, Frommer, Fielding, Michelin and the like. Others bear lesser known imprints, and some of the best new guidebooks are more readily available by mail than in most stores.

title: NO DEARTH OF GOOD SEATS IN PHILIPPINE PARLIAMENT
description: Another session of the Philippine National Assembly is under way, but on the floor of the cavernous Parliament building, half of the representatives' plush turquoise chairs are empty and three tiers of gallery seats for the press and public are deserted.

title: The Kirkpatrick Factor
description: When Jeane Kirkpatrick says ''I believe in building American strength and, in measured ways, of using American power - not force, power - in pursuit of our interests,'' she demonstrates the intellectual's skill at equivocation. To claim that the use of ''American power'' is acceptable, while that of American force is not, is to engage in a very old kind of intellectualism: sophistry.

title: MOVIES AND THE PRESS ARE AN ENDURING ROMANCE
description: Like cops, cowboys and combat soldiers, journalists are a staple in American films, their portrayal shifting with the tides of history and public opinion, but their popularity a constant with the people who make movies and the people who watch them.

title: We Need to Know About These Al Smith Charges
description: To the Editor:

title: TURNOUT A KEY TO PRIMARIES
description: VOTER turnout will be one of the keys in the Democratic primary for Governor on Tuesday. With undecided voters accounting for about 30 percent in candidates' polls 10 days before the balloting, their campaign consultants say they do not know what constituencies will vote or which areas of the state will have the heaviest turnout.

title: TO APPLAUD OR NOT TO APPLAUD
description: The pulse quickens; the fiddler's left hand becomes a blur as the pianist's fingers race up and down the keyboard. The momentum builds to the final scale and triumphal chords: Ta tah! Tum Tummmm! The violinist draws a long, intense downbow; with the release his arm flies exultantly into the air.

title: U.S. CITIZENS LOSE PANAMA TAX CASE
description: A Federal appeals court recently ruled that the 6,000 United States civilians who have worked for the Panama Canal Commission in the Canal Zone since 1979 must pay Federal income taxes.

title: OLDEST PRIVATE SCHOOL LOOKS TO FUTURE
description: LIKE other independent schools, Hopkins Grammar Day Prospect Hill School in New Haven is facing critical challenges that will determine its future viability.

title: TOWNS SEEK A DRINKING BAN
description: THE Towns of Hempstead, North Hempstead and Oyster Bay are again seeking to pass ''open container'' laws that would prohibit the unauthorized drinking of alcoholic beverages in public.

title:
DINING OUT;

ITALIAN FARE IN MILLWOOD
description: SPACCARELLI'S is one of those restaurants that should be better than it is. In fact, one wants it to be better if for no reason other than it is the only game in a restaurant-poor town. But from a promising first encounter, a succession of visits found the place increasingly wanting.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

BLACK HISTORY
description: Villa Lewaro, the Neo-Classical Revival-style mansion on North Broadway in Irvington has been associated with many firsts. Built in 1917, it was the home of Sarah J. Walker, America's first black female millionaire. And it was designed by Vertner Tandy Sr., the first black architect to be registered in the State. Now, if some Westchester residents have their way, it could become the county's first black history museum.

title:
TRAVEL ADVISORY;

CASTLES FOR RENT
description: Part of the allure of traveling in Britain is admiring its many stately homes and castles tucked away in small villages in the countryside. These residences need not just be viewed from afar: to sample life as the squire of the manor, travelers can rent historic homes and cottages.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You can't describe devastation like this.'' - Gov. Dick Thornburgh of Pennsylvania surveying tornado damage in Albion, Pa. [1:5.]

title: HOME REMEDIES VS. GADGETS
description: T is gardening time again -with all its pleasures and perils.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: NORTHEAST WHALE-WATCH This is the time of year when humpback whales summer in Northeastern waters and when humans go out in boats to gape at them.

title: JEWISH Y'S EXPAND SERVICES
description: IN addition to the major effort under way to build a geriatric facility with a kosher kitchen in Commack, the Jewish Y's on Long Island are in the midst of a $24 million program to expand services.

title: 300 Youths Are Seized In Clash at Stonehenge
description: More than 300 youths, barred from holding a music festival at Stonehenge, were arrested today after a clash in which vehicles in a convoy were used to ram police vans.

title: Chicago
description: To the Editor: Eugene Kennedy's extremely entertaining political tour of Chicago (Travel, May 5) contains one major error that should be corrected for the historical record. He states that Senator Edward Kennedy ''found anonymity'' in Chicago by staying at a Jewish club, the Standard Club, during the 1968 Democratic Convention, while Mayor Richard Daley tried to draft him for the Presidential nomination.

title: David Byrne: Thinking Man's Rock
description: I am full of admiration for David Byrne's ability to inspire critical acclaim (''David Byrne: Thinking Man's Rock Star,'' by Ken Emerson, May 5).

title: FRESH AIR CAMP FOCUSES ON HOW TO DEVELOP TRUST
description: When the handful of 8- and 9-year-old campers approached the newborn goslings, four mother geese spread their wings and charged.

title: RIDING HOLIDAY IN HAWAII
description: Riding the waves is usually considered the quintessential Hawaiian pastime, but a quite different sort of riding figures almost as prominently in the recreational pattern of the islands. Although it is far from the dusty plains, Hawaii is horse country, and a saddle can be as useful to a visitor as a surfboard.

title: 'GOOD BUG' LABORATORY TO BE DEDICATED
description: STATE agriculture officials say that the $3.3 million Beneficial Insect Rearing Laboratory to be dedicated here Thursday will produce legions of good insects to control those that prey on crops and home vegetable gardens.

title: FINDING VALUE IN STOCKS THAT STUMBLE
description: AMONG the old-school investors who shop for value among depressed stocks, the name Legg Mason Wood Walker Inc. has been gaining attention. The Baltimore firm's no-load mutual fund, since its inception in the spring of 1982, has turned in the best performance in the mutual fund industry, according to Lipper Analytical Services. As of last week, the Legg Mason Value Trust was up over 160 percent.

title: CARGO SHIP OFF SAUDI COAST SET AFIRE IN GULF WAR
description: Unidentified planes attacked a Panamanian-registered ship in the Persian Gulf off the Saudi coast today, killing at least one crewman, salvage executives said.

title: IRISH HORSE IS FIRST
description: Sharannpour, an Irish import with a reputation for being something special, made his second American start a winning one with a powerful 1 3/4-length victory in the Red Smith Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Want to Buy an Airport?
description: In the latest salvo on what to do with Washington's airports, a new study has come up with yet another proposal: Sell them to the highest bidder.

title: Younger Martin Fondly Recalled
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Elm City
description: ONCE New Haven had so many elm trees that they formed thick arches over the streets and it was called the City of the Elms. But that was in Civil War days.

title: BEACHES READIED FOR SEASON
description: WESTCHESTER'S 871,000 people, come summer, may choose to wet their feet in 21 communities with waterfront parks, or at one of four county beaches, five county pools or, for the better-heeled, 21 private yacht clubs and 39 beach clubs and marinas. While almost half of the county's total boundaries run along the Hudson River or Long Island Sound there are only four access points to natural waters that are open to the general public for swimming.

title: A GENIUS OF MEXICAN JEWELRY
description: Borrowing freely from Aztec through Art Deco designs more than a half century ago, William Spratling began reshaping Mexican silver jewelry into a modern style that is rich in leafage, mythological animals, astrological symbols, ranch images and Jazz Age motifs. In the process, he helped transform Taxco from a sleepy mining town in the Guerrero Mountains into a world-renowned silver center.
