title: CREW VOICES REVEAL 30 SECONDS OF TERROR IN RUNWAY MIX-UP
description: When the danger was over, the crew aboard Northwest Airlines Flight 65 burst into nervous laughter. For 30 seconds they had watched another jumbo jet bear down on them, not knowing if they would survive.

title: Voluntarism In Allentown
description: EVER eager to do a good municipal deed, some Boy Scouts in Allentown, Pa., volunteered to paint 100 fire hydrants.

title: Nighttime Series Is Bemoaned
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A WALK ACROSS THE STATE
description: SCHOOLCHILDREN, the elderly, physicians and state officials are among those planning to join Douglas L. Lloyd, the State Health Commissioner, as he walks across the state during the next year.

title: NEW YORK REGION SWEPT BY STORMS
description: A line of severe thunderstorms swept through the New York metropolitan area early yesterday morning, cutting electrical power for many and dropping a half-inch of rain.

title: COMPLEX AWAITS EFFECT OF DROPPING AGE RESTRICTIONS
description: YOU no longer have to be middle-aged to live at Heritage Hills in Somers, a bastion of orderly, childless living -but the young either have not noticed, do not want to move there or cannot afford to.

title: MOSLEM FIGHTING IN BEIRUT EASES, BUT DOESN'T STOP
description: Fighting continued today around three Palestinian settlements in the Beirut area.

title: TROUBLESHOOTER: Stanton D. Anderson;   JAPAN'S TOP U.S. LOBBYIST
description: STANTON D. ANDERSON'S Sunday school teacher was a state senator who taught the boy more than Bible studies: Mark O. Hatfield, now Republican Senator from Oregon, instilled in the youngster a taste - and a skill - for politics that never disappeared. And today the 44-year-old Mr. Anderson wields political power of a sort that would have seemed inconceivable to a Baptist minister's son growing up in Salem, Ore., during World War II.

title: PUTTING A GOOD FACE ON A FLOWER
description: ANYONE can photograph flowers, but to take an exceptional picture of a flower requires a wide range of skills. To achieve success in this area a photographer must know close-up technique, indoor and outdoor lighting, the color rendition of various films, color composition, electronic flash and how to use backgrounds. It is also helpful to have a general knowledge of nature photography and to know a bit about botany.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: The Fabulous Fleischer Folio Walt Disney Home Video 50 minutes. $49.95 ''Seen any good cartoons lately?'' asks Leslie Cabarga, the biographer of Max Fleischer, in introducing this collection of six short cartoons made by the creator of Popeye, Betty Boop and Superman.

title: NASSAU MAY RELAX SMOKING-BAN RULES
description: A PROPOSED Nassau County smoking ordinance that would require that restaurants and businesses set aside 50 percent of their space for nonsmokers appears to be headed for some modification this week.

title: SMALL GRANTS PAY OFF BIG FOR DEVELOPING ARTISTS
description: FOR artists who receive public grants to help further their work, the sense of recognition that accompanies the award can be as important as the money itself.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Tax Rates, Interest Rates If President Reagan's tax revision proposal manages to survive Congress without major changes, it should drive interest rates down to single digits by Election Day 1988. That's the bold prediction of A. Ann Wallace, managing director of Nakagama & Wallace, a New York economic consulting firm.

title: ETHNIC GROUPS CIRCLE THE WAGONS IN SRI LANKA
description: The new Parliament building is a dark, brooding temple-like structure surrounded by a lake and linked to the rest of the nation by only a narrow causeway. When a special legislative session opened recently to debate the rising level of violence in the country, the police closed the causeway, barring entry to the public, to foreign diplomats and to several hundred monks protesting an attack two weeks ago on Anuradhapura, one of Buddhism's holiest shrines.

title: 49 NEW YORK CITY FOOD OUTLETS VIOLATE CODE
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 49 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: CONCERT: FLORILEGIUM SINGS WORKS BY WOMEN
description: BEING a music listener by occupation and not a social historian, concerts categorized by race, nationality or sex fill me with apprehension. Music is either well made or it isn't. Its origin is not a qualitative consideration.

title: AT 10-0, HAWKINS NO LONGER TIMID
description: The biggest success story in baseball this season is probably Andy Hawkins, the ''timid Texan'' of the San Diego Padres, who lost his job as a starting pitcher a year ago because his manager said he pitched ''like a pussycat.''

title: Irving Herschbein Is Wed To Kate Fenner Urquhart
description: Kate Fenner Urquhart, assistant director of communications for the Inmont Corporation in Clifton, N.J., a manufacturer of printing inks and automotive finishes, was married yesterday to Irving Herschbein, director of manufacturing and distribution of Conde Nast Publications in New York. The Rev. Michael Knowles performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Anglican Church in Halifax, Nova Scotia.

title: Quitting on Top
description: It was quite a run while it lasted, and now she has earned a rest.

title: Morgan Guaranty Shifts 2 Key Aides
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, which in recent years has been shifting its focus outside the realm of commercial banking, has named two executive vice presidents to fill investment banking-type positions.

title: I.R.S. GOAL: NO FILING OF RETURNS
description: The Internal Revenue Service says it hopes that by the early 1990's more than half of America's 101 million taxpayers will no longer need to file annual income tax returns.

title: Diesel Soot's Threat to New York
description: Buses and trucks spew 3,000 tons of diesel soot into New York City's air each year. The particles are an especially insidious form of pollution, yet only now are state and Federal regulators taking the first steps to assess the threat.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 3, 1985:

title: LEBANON EXPERIENCES SPUR NAVY TO IMPROVE BATTLESHIP ACCURACY
description: As part of an effort to bring its recommissioned World War II battleships into the modern era, the Navy has begun an extensive program to improve the accuracy of their guns.

title: REAGAN WOULD HAVE PAID 19% LESS
description: The President's tax revision plan has both winners and losers. One of the biggest winners would be Mr. Reagan himself.

title: MINORITY STUDENT AID OFF, STUDY SAYS
description: The number of students from minority groups getting financial aid to attend public colleges was 12.4 percent lower in the 1983-84 academic year than it was in 1981-82, according to a survey made public today by an association of state colleges.

title: Profit Shown By Braniff
description: One year after emerging from bankruptcy proceedings, the new Braniff Inc. has reported its first quarterly profit, earning $1.6 million, or 13 cents a share, in contrast to a $30.6 million loss a year ago.

title: OUTLETS THAT OFFER EXPLICIT SEX TAPES FACING PROSECUTION
description: American communities, trying to deal with the effects of a technology that has moved the pornographic movie from the back street to the shopping mall and corner store, have begun to prosecute shopkeepers who rent videocassettes of sexually explicit films.

title: Rolling at Wollman
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Women Win
description: The University of Washington took the national collegiate women's rowing championship for the fifth year in a row today, crossing the finish six seats ahead of its closest competitors, Wisconsin and Minnesota.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 3, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Science and Technology - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Nabisco Sends Food Issues Up
description: SHARES of food processing companies rose sharply last week after Nabisco Brands Inc. announced that it ''has had exploratory talks with R.J. Reynolds Industries and has reached no conclusion.''

title: FAMILY ROLES AT THE OFFICE
description: ''He was a real kind of Papa Bear figure and he looked upon all of us as his children,'' said a former Newsweek magazine writer, recalling a senior editor. ''I was the bad boy, always, in his mind. The long lunch. Waiting for the last minute to write the story. Fooling around in the halls. Always coming up with some smart remark at exactly the wrong time.''

title: COAST MAN LINKED TO SPY SUSPECTS
description: An employee of a military contractor in California has been implicated in a purported Soviet spy ring, Government officials said tonight.

title: I.O.C. Director Is Under Fire
description: In an unexpected move, the International Olympic Committee asked today for the resignation of Monique Berlioux, its director and chief executive officer for 14 years, according to committee sources.

title: TALKS TO RESUME IN HOTEL WALKOUT
description: Negotiators for scores of New York City's largest hotels and 14,000 striking employees yesterday agreed to resume contract talks today after a weekend of noisy picketing, disrupted hotel services and inconvenience for thousands of guests.

title: DASTARDLY DEEDS IN 'JAMAICA INN'
description: AS a ship is being lured by scheming plunderers to disaster off a treacherous British coast, someone mutters, darkly, that ''it's a dirty night.'' The ship crashes into the rocks, the villains move in to murder the crew because a ship is technically not a wreck until all aboard are dead, and ''Jamaica Inn'' once again begins its journey into mystery, romance, superstition and drunken brutishness. The Daphne Du Maurier story is now a four-hour television movie, the first half of which can be seen on WNEW/ Channel 5 tonight at 8, with a repeat on Thursday at 8. The conclusion will be broadcast at the same times next week.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Elizabeth Voldstad In Piano Recital
description: The pianist Elizabeth Voldstad, who presented an uneven concert at Carnegie Recital Hall Saturday afternoon, was at her best in Robert Schumann's ''Kinderscenen'' (Op. 15). This wonderful collection of vignettes may be played through by most third-year piano students, but it offers extraordinary subtleties, on which one may spend a lifetime.

title: Ex-Aide of ITT Opens A Consultant's Office
description: Edward J. Gerrity Jr., the communications chief of the ITT Corporation who left the company in March after being suspended by management, has opened Ned Gerrity & Associates at One Rockefeller Center, from which he will consult in public relations, advertising and government relations.

title: PERES SETS JUNE 6 FOR LEBANON TROOP PULLOUT
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel said today that Israel would complete its withdrawal from Lebanon by Thursday, the third anniversary of the invasion.

title: BLUE TRIUMPHS IN FIRST START SINCE '83
description: Vida Blue, making his first start in the major leagues since July 1983, combined with the relievers Frank Williams and Mark Davis on a one-hitter today to help the Giants beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 3-1.

title: Debt Downgrading For Peru Is Feared
description: Peruvian officials and American bankers are worried that Peru's foreign debt may be downgraded by Federal regulators when they meet in Washington June 10. A lower credit rating would force banks to set aside reserves against some of their loans to Peru, which would cut into their profits.

title: For Runaways, Free Bus Rides Home
description: The Port Authority Bus Terminal, whose vastness can frighten even seasoned travelers, has been a bit less frightening these last few months to one group that uses it - runaway children.

title: L'Envoi?
description: Cherchez l'homme: Joe M. Rodgers, a Republican loyalist who has raised more than $5 million for the party in the last five years, is rumored to be President Reagan's choice as the next Ambassador to France. If so, it is news to the State Department, which notes that Evan Galbreath remains Ambassador. Mr. Rodgers has not been available lately at his business office in Nashville. ''He's taking French lessons,'' his secretary said.

title: HOW RENTS ARE SET UNDER CONTROL SYSTEM
description: The rent-regulation system in New York City is a patchwork that began in 1942, when President Franklin D. Roosevelt, responding to wartime housing shortages, signed the Emergency Price Control Act, which allowed the imposition of rent control in New York the next year.

title: Pakistan Sentences Rioters
description: Military courts have sentenced 53 people to 15 lashes each and one-year prison terms for taking part in riots last week in which three people died, the newspaper Dawn reported Sunday. Riots broke out in the west side of Karachi, a poor district, after people became infuriated by power cuts and a water shortage during a severe heat wave. Soldiers and riot policemen dispersed thousands of rioters who charged their lines.

title: Sniping Injures 4 On Florida Highway
description: A sniper opened fire on cars traveling on Interstate 95 today, slightly wounding at least four people, the authorities said.

title: Arch Macdonald Dead at 73; Was News Anchor in Boston
description: Arch Macdonald, who worked in news broadcasting in New England for 54 years, died Friday in Glover Memorial Hospital in Needham, Mass. Mr. Macdonald, who had a heart attack May 15, was 73 years old and lived in Needham.

title: Race Cancellation May Draw Penalty
description: The organizers of the Belgian Grand Prix that was scheduled today but canceled because the track surface was unsafe ''face financial penalties and could lose future Grand Prixes,'' according to Jean-Marie Balestre, president of the International Auto Sport Federation.

title: Elder Survives
description: Lee Elder, surviving a nearly disastrous double-bogey on the 18th hole, held off Peter Thomson to post a one-stroke victory today in the Denver Post Champions of Golf seniors tournament.

title: Test for Wagnerians
description: Washington often resembles a marketplace for the short attention span, the capital of communicating by bytes and snippets. There is more than passing curiosity, accordingly, about the community's ability to have a benefit audience of VIP's sit still on June 9 for the nine hours it will take to view a new film, ''Wagner.''

title: REASSESS THE FOCUS OF 'STAR WARS'
description: In spite of deep confusion about its nature and mission, President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative, popularly known as ''Star Wars,'' has gained enough momentum to pose a serious challenge to the future of arms control. The initiative has been questioned and criticized, to be sure, but often for the wrong reasons. We should re-evaluate the focus of the program -and should be very careful about precisely how we do so.

title: Gary Michael Gertzog Wed to Lori J. Swidler
description: Lori Joan Swidler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Swidler of New York and Boca Raton, Fla., and Gary Michael Gertzog, the son of Marvin Gertzog of North Hills, L.I., and Susan Gertzog of New York, were married yesterday. Rabbi Joseph P. Sternstein performed the ceremony at the Helmsley Palace Hotel in New York.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Cecilia Angell, Mezzo-Soprano
description: The mezzo-soprano Cecilia Angell is a performer of passion, charm and honest sentiment. She knows how to communicate and she knows how to get an audience excited, as she did yesterday afternoon at her Merkin Hall recital.

title: Bellamy Criticizes Dumping of Waste
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy said yesterday that her staff, prompted by Sanitation Department ''whistle blowers,'' had found hazardous hospital wastes illegally dumped at the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island Saturday.

title: LOBBYING IN WHITE HOUSE'S BEHALF
description: Linda Chavez, the new chief of the White House liaison office, believes that lobbying is a two-way street.

title: THE LAKERS GET PHYSICAL
description: COACH K. C. Jones's prophecy of danger began to fulfillitself yesterday afternoon with every swoop that James Worthy took downward toward the basket. The Lakers were asserting themselves at home, just as Jones had feared.

title: 400 THRIFT UNITS CALLED EFFECTIVELY UNSOUND
description: The number of savings and loan associations that are effectively bankrupt - but still open - has increased fivefold since 1981, to more than 400, and industry leaders and Government regulators expect most will be forced to close or merge.

title: 'BILOXI' AND 'BIG RIVER' WIN TOP TONY AWARDS
description: Neil Simon's ''Biloxi Blues,'' an autobiographical play by the dominant Broadway dramatist of his generation, and ''Big River,'' a musical created by Broadway newcomers, captured the 1985 Tony Awards last night at the Shubert Theater as best play and best musical of the season.

title: COLLEGE TUITION POLICIES OFFER DISCOUNTS FOR SOME STUDENTS
description: When Laura Hurwitt opened her letter of acceptance from the College of Wooster in Ohio last month, she found that she had been offered an unsolicited scholarship of $1,000 a year. To her father, who heads the breakfast foods division of General Foods, it struck a familiar chord.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Article 023772 -- No Title
description: In a detailed financial statement filed with the United States Bankruptcy Court, United Press International has itemized more than $40 million in debts - including 1,400 pages devoted to unsecured creditors - and assets of about $24 million.

title: Melissa Krasner Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Melissa Rachel Krasner and Rabbi Paul David Kerbel took place yesterday at the Park Avenue Synagogue. Rabbis Judah Nadich, Joseph A. Brodie and Israel C. Stein officiated, assisted by Cantor David Lefkowitz.

title: TREASURY SALES TO TOTAL $20.5 BILLION
description: Treasury financing this week is confined to the bill market, where new issues totaling $20.5 billion will be offered, with maturities in 3, 6 and 12 months. Proceeds will refund maturing bills and raise about $250 million of fresh cash to finance the Federal deficit.

title: VCR's and Disks Now Star at Show
description: The International Summer Consumer Electronics Show opened today, amid a flurry of new evidence that consumers cannot buy video cassette recorders and compact disk players fast enough, and can no longer find much use for home computers.

title: Highs and Lows
description: One little bit of fallout from Pete Rose's pursuit of Ty Cobb is being felt in the baseball-card market.

title: PHILADELPHIA FIRE: LONG-TERM FALLOUT
description: On May 12, Mayor W. Wilson Goode was riding high, and the city's image with him.

title: SKEETER BEST
description: Skeeter Best, a jazz guitarist who played in Earl Hines's orchestra and recorded with Ray Charles and Milt Jackson, died Tuesday at Jacobi Hospital in the Bronx after a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: MUSIC: AT 92D STREET Y, 'LYRICS AND LYRICISTS'
description: ''LYRICS AND LYRICISTS'' celebrated its 15th year at the 92d Street Y on Saturday and Sunday with gala programs that brought back some of the songwriters and singers who have performed in the series.

title: CUOMO TRIES AGAIN ON DRINKING AGE
description: A proposal that Governor Cuomo was unable to get through the Legislature in 1984 - raising the drinking age to 21 - is at the head of his agenda for the closing days of the 1985 legislative session.

title: 20th John Jay Ceremony
description: Houston's Police Chief urged graduates of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice yesterday to commit themselves to bringing ''new visibility and respect'' to their profession.

title: Bridge: Russell Quartet Wins Easily In Reisinger Knockout Final
description: Close battles were the order of the day in the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship last week, but the final round proved to be one-sided.

title: Undocumented Aliens Don't Take Jobs Away
description: To the Editor:

title: ENGLISH SOCCER CLUBS ARE BANNED FROM EUROPEAN PLAY INDEFINITELY
description: Europe's governing soccer association banned English club teams indefinitely from European competition today because of a riot at a match in Brussels last week in which 38 people died.

title: LOPEZ PULLS AWAY TO WIN L.P.G.A. BY EIGHT STROKES
description: Nancy Lopez said she turned her anger and frustration of the last three days into positive motivation for victory today, as she overcame the effects of her two-stroke, slow-play penalty and ran away with the 31st L.P.G.A. championship by a stunning eight shots over Alice Miller.

title: STORM DAMAGE DONE, TOWN TURNS TO REBUILD
description: It was a family affair, more or less.

title: Driver Is Killed In Stock Car Race
description: Stuart Lyndon, a 35-year-old driver from Hastings, New Zealand, was killed today in a crash during the Georgia ARCA 500-kilometer stock car race at Atlanta International Raceway.

title: Sneak Attack on Campaign Finance
description: President Reagan, usually open and honorable in battle, seems suddenly to be acting like a sneak. The issue is public financing of Presidential campaigns, a system that has given him $90 million and given the nation a successful reform. The system has been accepted by candidates, Congress and the public. Yet Mr. Reagan doesn't like it and is trying, under cover of tax reform, to slit its throat.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: New Atlanta Agency: Scali, McCabe/South
description: There is a new agency on the Atlanta scene, Scali, McCabe, Sloves/ South, staffed by three men with both New York and Southern agency experience. But more important, it opened its doors on Friday with a few million dollars in billings.

title: NORTH SEA OIL PRICE DROP SEEN
description: Oil industry analysts expect official North Sea oil prices to drop by between $1 and $1.40 a barrel this week.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SILENT WAGNER? The Nibelungen, creatures of Nordic myth, were made even more immortal by the operas of Richard Wagner. In 1924, the German film maker Fritz Lang took their story, by then seemingly inseparably associated with the operas, and separated it -he made ''The Nibelung Saga,'' which consisted of two films, ''Siegfried,'' part one, and ''Kriemhild's Revenge,'' part two. They constitute today's double feature at Theater 80, at 80 Saint Mark's Place, near First Avenue (254-7400).

title: SHIITES ATTACK PALESTINIANS IN SOUTH LEBANON DURING LULL IN BEIRUT
description: Shiite Moslem militiamen of the Amal movement stormed a Palestinian settlement in southern Lebanon today after a machine-gun clash with armed Palestinians.

title: Fort Worth Man Shot Dead by Gang
description: A gang that the police said was seeking revenge drove through a residential neighborhood early today, firing shotgun blasts that killed one man and wounded nine other people, including two children, the police said.

title: WINNERS AND LOSERS IN TAX PLAN
description: President Reagan's new tax plan is being widely discussed throughout the nation, but proposals to revise the tax code and tighten loopholes are hardly new. ''The time has come'' for tax reform, President Kennedy declared in 1961, and the last two dozen years have seen many attempts to change the tax code. Most recently, President Carter pledged a revision, calling the tax system ''a disgrace to the human race.''

title: VIEWS OF THE CANDIDATES IN THE JERSEY DEMOCRATIC PRIMARY FOR GOVERNOR
description: Toxic Waste Budget Surplus Education Auto Insurance Transportation Zoning xhrrRobert J. Del Tufo (Toxic Wastes) Would prosecute illegal dumpers of hazardous wastes and force chemical companies to pay for cleanups. Would institute a tax on chemical companies for a ''spill fund,'' to be used for cleanups. (Budget Surplus) Would use the money for ''socially desirable purposes,'' including acquiring sites for toxic-waste disposal. Opposes using the money for rebates to taxpayers and says some of it could be put aside to replace services cut by the Federal Government. (Education) Favors setting a minimum starting salary of $18,500 for teachers, but opposes using the state's budget surplus to pay the difference. Rules out using the property tax as a source of financing. Says salaries of teachers already employed would also have to be increased. (Auto Insurance) Argues that the ease of litigation in automobile-insurance cases accounts for the high cost of insurance. Believes that establishing fixed rates of compensation according to the nature of injuries could reduce litigation. (Transportation) Favors using a transportation trust fund rather than floating bonds to finance repairs and road construction. Would place a priority on repair and widening of such roads as Routes 1 and Interstates 80 and 287. Favors encouraging flexible working hours to reduce crowding on the roads. (Zoning) Supports most of the provisions of a bill passed by the Legislature that would enable towns to provide housing for the poor in line with the State Supreme Court decision known as Mount Laurel II.

title: Seabrook Unit Gets Rate Rise
description: The Maine Public Utilities Commission voted Friday to grant a $22.3 million rate increase to the Central Maine Power Company in exchange for the company taking an after-tax write-off of $44.9 million on its investments in four plants, including the troubled Seabrook nuclear power project.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: MONDAY, JUNE 3, 1985

title: SUSPECT SEIZED
description: A housing police officer was shot in both arms last night in a gunfight in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn, but was saved from even more serious wounds by his bulletproof vest, which stopped two bullets, the police said.

title: Nevada Legislature Passes Seat Belt Law
description: The Nevada Senate has given final legislative approval to a bill that requires motorists to wear seat belts. It also directs the state to ask the Federal Government to allow people to drive at speeds of up to 70 miles per hour in return.

title: LONDON EXCHANGE'S KEY VOTE
description: Because of its relatively free regulatory environment, its record as Europe's most active stock market and its pre-eminence in European banking and finance, the City of London has a long lead in the race to dominate international securities trading in the European time zone.

title: Dance Grants Given To Nine Companies
description: The National Choreography Project, a pilot program designed to provide new opportunities for choreographers and new works for American repertory dance companies, has awarded grants totaling $250,000 to nine companies. The grants will support collaborations between each company and a choreographer with whom it has not previously been associated.

title: JAMES A. WOOTEN, DIRECTOR OF '49 AIRLIFT OF YEMENI JEWS
description: James A. Wooten, who as president of Alaska Airlines directed the transport of thousands of Yemeni Jews to the new state of Israel in 1949, died Friday at his home in Orlando, Fla. He was 71 years old.

title: TAX PLAN EFFECT ON MUNICIPALS
description: Municipal bonds, which have attracted more money in recent years from individuals than any other kind of investment security, will survive the proposed Federal tax revisions, though the size of the market would be drastically reduced and local governments might have to develop new financing techniques or raise taxes.

title: REGATTA DOMINATED BY PRINCETON CREWS
description: Princeton dominated the finals of the long-delayed 83d Intercollegiate Rowing Association Championships today, winning the Varsity Challenge Cup for heavyweight eights for the first time in the Tigers' long rowing history.

title: Powder Break Wins at Belmont
description: Powder Break, ridden by Jerry Bailey and carrying 115 pounds, made a strong late run and coasted to a 3 1/4-length victory in the $88,800 New York Handicap for fillies and mares yesterday on the Inner Turf Course at Belmont Park.

title: Welcome Back, Clara Bow To Brooklyn
description: What do Walt Whitman, Clara Bow, Eubie Blake, George Gershwin and Dixie Walker have in common?

title: HOW TAX PLAN'S IMPACT DIFFERS IN VARIOUS STATES
description: A study by one of the nation's largest accounting firms of how President Reagan's tax plan would affect middle-income families shows that New Yorkers would gain less than residents of 47 other states.

title: A STEPPED-UP DRIVE FOR THE RACING DOLLAR
description: COME springtime, the racing world's attention usually turns to New York, where the top horses have returned from winter vacations and the major events await. So far this year, though, the headlines have been coming from across the Hudson River.

title: Selling Conrail
description: The Administration's proposal to sell the Government's 85 percent interest in Conrail to the Norfolk Southern Corporation may be in for a harder look by Congress in light of a counteroffer from a group of 25 investors.

title: Financial Reports Don't Sway Players
description: Baseball's club owners are not convincing the players association that the teams have serious financial problems. If, by the time they conclude their study of the clubs' financial information, the players are still not convinced, the two sides could be farther apart than at any time since talks for a new labor agreement began last November.

title: INDIA TALKS COVER CRISIS IN SRI LANKA
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India met today with President J. R. Jayewardene of Sri Lanka to explore what officials said were terms of a possible negotiated settlement to the increasingly violent ethnic conflict in Sri Lanka.

title: Foundation Denounces U.S. Education Policy
description: The trustees of the Carnegie Foundation today accused the Reagan Administration of threatening to undermine higher education through budget cuts and by depicting students as ''exploiters.''

title: LIBERATION THEOLOGY: 2 SIDES POLARIZE
description: A leading Brazilian theologian who was ordered to withdraw from public life by the Vatican has remained secluded in a Franciscan monastery for the last month, refusing to take telephone calls and turning down invitations to ceremonies organized in his honor.

title: Karen A. Wagner Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Karen Ann Wagner, a financial analyst with the Nynex Corporation in New York, to Dr. Jason Faller, an internist and rheumatologist in practice in Manhattan, took place yesterday at the Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Irving Koslowe performed the ceremony.

title: Disappointment Over Dropouts
description: According to the New York City Board of Education's own figures, 11 percent of high school students dropped out last year, and 42 percent of all students are expected to drop out before graduation. Those figures are intolerable, yet the board's responses give little hope for improvement.

title: OUTDOORS: IN THE SURF IN SEARCH OF BLUEFISH
description: SIX years ago when Eli Ohlhausen of Brooklyn was 11 years old, he went with me to the South Shore of Martha's Vineyard and captured his first bluefish just as the sun was setting.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Dara Norman Stars In 'All Girl Revue'
description: The one indispensable ingredient in building a musical revue around a young actress's amatory and career problems is a star with the charisma a vitality to give a new twist to an old cliche. Dara Norman, the star of ''Cleo Lieberman's All Girl Revue,'' which plays Thursdays through Saturdays at the Ballroom Theater (253 West 28th Street), has an interestingly morose personality, but she lacks the drive and confidence to carry off what is essentially a one-woman show.

title: DIANE MCGRATH LIKELY G.O.P. MAYORAL CHOICE
description: New York City Republican leaders said yesterday that they expected to designate Diane McGrath of Manhattan, a member of the state's Crime Victims Compensation Board, as their candidate for mayor.

title: Corporate Cowboys
description: The problem with rodeos, of course, is that broncs don't have hoods and bulls don't have fenders. So there is no place to stick on decals displaying the names of corporate sponsors, which helps explain why corporate sponsors have generally shunned rodeos in favor of car racing.

title: ARTIST KNOWN FOR WORKS CREATED IN NEVADA DESERT
description: Although the ''Effigy Tumuli'' sculptures are surrounded by lush forests along the Illinois River banks, they descend artistically from a monumental style of art that was created by a sculptor working in the vast deserts of the American West.

title: BLACKMUN SAYS RUTGERS LAW GRADUATES FACE 'EXCITING PROBLEMS'
description: Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the Supreme Court of the United States, speaking today at commencement exercises of the Rutgers University Law School, challenged its 238 graduates to work to improve the world.

title: SO THAT LIFE DOES NOT REMAIN A CLOSED BOOK
description: The National Institute of Education, a Federal office, says that 27 million adults are wholly illiterate and that 45 million more are near-illiterate. Why is this the case? We've had compulsory education for 100 years. How come millions can't read?

title: Buy New York's Last Private Waterworks
description: To the Editor:

title: Labonte Scores
description: Terry Labonte outdueled Bobby Allison for the lead on the 80th lap today, then pulled away to win the NASCAR Budweiser 400 for the second consecutive year.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: How did the Montreal Expos acquire their nickname and what is the team logo supposed to represent?

title: Dr. D. P. Greenwald Wed To Julia Florence Robbins
description: Julia Florence Robbins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael D. Robbins of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Daniel Paul Greenwald, the son of Dr. and Mrs. James H. Greenwald of Olympia Fields, Ill. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in New York.

title: ORDER AND DISORDER
description: Moscow radio, which dominates the air in all languages hereabouts, has had a lot to say about the murderous football riot in Brussels last week.

title: When a Job Changes Into Women's Work
description: To the Editor:

title: GWILYN PRICE, 89, INDUSTRIALIST, DIES
description: Gwilym A. Price, who dropped out of high school to support his widowed mother and went on to became president, chief executive officer and chairman of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, died Saturday in Ohio Valley General Hospital. He was 89 years old.

title: Grist for the Mills
description: The President's tax reform plan, already a sellout at Government bookstores in town as lobbyists and consultants rush to get informed, began settling quickly into the familiar shorthand groove that marks this city's daily habits. Two reporters on Capitol Hill, facing the repetitiousness of Democratic criticism of the plan, have worked out the jotting of ''B#3 P'' and ''B#3 E'' when they hear lawmakers reiterate warnings against ''balancing the budget on the backs of the poor'' and ''balancing the budget on the backs of the elderly.''

title: CONDITION OF PUERTO RICANS IS SAID TO TRAIL OTHER LATINS IN U.S.
description: Puerto Rican leaders and activists gathered here this weekend to discuss a report contending that despite recent political gains, the two million people of Puerto Rican ancestry in the United States are in far worse economic shape than other Hispanic groups.

title: Swiss Rail Station Bombed
description: A bomb exploded in Geneva's main train station at 12.45 A.M. today, breaking windows and knocking down parts of the ceiling but causing no injuries, a police spokesman said.

title: SO THAT LIFE DOES NOT REMAIN A CLOSED BOOK
description: How can we teach children to read?

title: MCENROE VICTOR
description: Henri Leconte upset Yannick Noah, 6-3, 6-4, 6-7, 4-6, 6-1, in the fourth round of the French Open tennis tournament today The match between the Frenchmen had the crowd in an emotional pitch throughout. Noah, the champion in 1983, fought back from two sets down, setting the stage for a dramatic finish. But Leconte, who teamed with Noah to capture the doubles title last year, cut off his momentum in the deciding set. .

title: Voters in East Hampton Back Plan for Park on Grace Estate
description: Residents have approved a plan under which East Hampton would buy 517 acres of the former Grace estate for $6.3 million and use it for a town park.

title: Oklahoma State And Stanford Win
description: Mike DeBenon belted a grand slam homer to key Stanford to a 9-2 victory over Arizona in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's College World Series tonight after Oklahoma State defeated South Carolina, 16-11, in the earlier game.

title: HOMOSEXUAL YALE ALUMNI RETURN TO A MIXED GREETING
description: Throats catching with emotion, a group of old Blues raised their voices in the rousing chorus from Yale's alma mater: ''For God, for country and for Yale!''

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Housing Authority In Tully Hall Benefit
description: It seems only fitting that a group called the New York City Housing Authority Symphony Orchestra should present a benefit concert for the homeless, and, on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, that's just what happened. Karl Hampton Porter led this energetic youthful ensemble in performances of music by Rossini, Handel, Mozart, Verdi, Gershwin and Beethoven, with all proceeds donated to a local organization called the Partnership for the Homeless.

title: Ex-Sudanese Official Faces Trial Over Airlift
description: The former First Vice President of the Sudan will be tried this month for his purported role in the airlift of Ethiopian Jews to Israel, the Middle East News Agency said today.

title: PARATROOPS SAID TO HIT AFGHANS
description: Afghan rebels said today that Soviet paratroops had joined the battle for a strategic valley near the Pakistani border.

title: ANDRETTI IS EASY WINNER
description: Mario Andretti, driving a Cosworth-powered Lola, scored an easy victory today in the Miller American 200 race for Indianapolis-style cars at Wisconsin State Fairgrounds Park.

title: Kosher Pizzas Are Led To Their Promised Land
description: ''Please, Mr. President,'' said the newspaper advertisement, ''let our pizza go.'' And the President did.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Aloha Inc. of Honolulu has elected A. Maurice Myers president and chief executive officer of Aloha Airlines.

title: Dr. A. S. Triebwasser Marries Jamie Reider
description: Jamie B. Reider, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Reider of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Andrew S. Triebwasser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Triebwasser of New York. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik performed the ceremony at the Water Club restaurant in Manhattan.

title: House Indiana Seat Recount Was Unfair
description: To the Editor:

title: IRRESISTIBLE LURE OF THE WATER PROJECT
description: It is a new era of austerity in Washington, conventional wisdom says. Saving money, not spending it, is the order of the day.

title: Hearst Magazines Revamps Management
description: Hearst Magazines has restructured its management.

title: SALVADOR TROOPS RAID STRUCK HOSPITALS
description: Security forces occupied several hospitals before dawn today in an attempt to end a strike that the Government said was being manipulated politically to the benefit of leftist guerrillas. Four Government agents were killed, apparently by other Government forces in the confusion.

title: HOJO LOST, STAR BORN, PLANT SHUT
description: Howard Johnson started his first restaurant in a small patent medicine store in 1925 in Quincy, a city on Boston's southern rim. In the 1950's, as the company bearing his name expanded and the American romance with the automobile grew, the 28 Johnson flavors of ice cream and trademark orange roofs became almost synonomous with long highway trips.

title: Intercontinental Hotels Promotes Its President
description: The Intercontinental Hotels Corporation, a subsidiary of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., has promoted Hans G. Sternik, president and chief operating officer, to chief executive officer of the New York-based international hotel chain.

title: FOR SINDELAR, TOURING GOLFER, THERE'S NO PLACE LIKE HOME
description: GIVE Joey Sindelar the golf courses of the Northeast, where he grew up, and he is at home. He will dig a divot a foot long on the lush bent-grass fairways or hit a ball out of heavy rough 150 yards with a wedge. That is just the way Sindelar wants it, and that is one reason why he still lives in Horseheads, N.Y., near Elmira, where his home has been for as long as he can remember.

title: James C. Burge Dead at 41; Actor Was to Receive Ph.D.
description: James C. Burge, a film and television actor, died Saturday at his East Side home after respiratory failure due to pneumonia. He was 41 years old.

title: Lorillard Chief Is Appointed
description: The Loews Corporation announced that J. Robert Ave, president and chief operating officer of its Lorillard subsidiary, had been named chief executive of the tobacco manufacturing unit. The appointment is effective today.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Quartet Plays Works Of Joseph Jarman
description: In the Art Ensemble of Chicago and on his own, the saxophonist-clarinetist Joseph Jarman has become known as a multimedia jazz composer, writing words, images and stage action into his music. Saturday at Carnegie Recital Hall, however, Mr. Jarman, Akua Dixon Turre on cello, Kafi Patrice Nassoma on harp and Thurman Barker on marimba, glockinspiel and wind-chimes played Mr. Jarman's pieces with as little theatricality as a chamber-music quartet.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report Saturday misidentified an official attending a reopening ceremony at a day care center in the Bronx. City Councilman Michael DeMarco was at the top right. In front of him, waving, was Stanley Simon, Borough President of the Bronx.

title: THE LOFT GENERATION IS COMING OF AGE IN SOHO
description: Six years ago, Diana Ambats was sure her daughter should be enrolled in a program for gifted children. Jessica showed every sign of precocity, except that she did not know what a bedroom was, nor a dining room, for that matter. The Ambats had lived in SoHo since the early days when walls and rooms were antithetical to loft living.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Joe Egg, Then and Now
description: The eponymous heroine - or, more accurately, centerpiece - of Peter Nichols's play ''Joe Egg'' is a devastatingly brain-damaged child, ''a living parsnip.'' She is not a figment of the playwright's imagination. There was a real Joe Egg, his daughter Abigail, who died at 10. When the play was first seen on Broadway, in 1968, Mr. Nichols described her in an interview as ''a meaningless accident.''

title: HONG KONG ADJUSTS TO TRADE RULE
description: Hong Kong apparel makers are examining a number of alternatives to adjust to a tighter textile import rule imposed during the past year by the United States.

title: Washington HQ Peril
description: To the Editor:

title: INJURED FLUTIE OUT UNTIL THE PLAYOFFS Stars 17, Bulls 12 COLLEGE PARK, Md. (AP) -Kelvin Bryant rushed for 104 yards and scored on two short runs to pace Baltimore (9-6-1). His second score, on a 2-yard run with 10:51 left, put Baltimore in front, 17-6. Bryant also scored on a 6-yard run in the second period. Jacksonville fell to 8-7. Invaders 38 Breakers 20 OAKLAND, Calif. (AP) - Bobby Hebert passed to Anthony Carter for two touchdowns in the victory. The first went for 18 yards in the second quarter, the second for 19 in the third. It was the seventh straight victory for the Invaders (11-3-1); Portland fell to 4-11.
description: The Generals confirmed today that Doug Flutie suffered a broken left collarbone in Saturday night's 17-7 victory over the Memphis Showboats.

title: Two Trade Officials Departing
description: Robert E. Lighthizer, Deputy United States Trade Representative, is leaving his post next month to join the Washington office of the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.

title: Iraq Announces Raids On Teheran and in Gulf
description: Iraq said its warplanes made two raids tonight on Teheran and attacked a naval target in the Persian Gulf.

title: ROONEY IS CHARGED BY S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has charged Rooney, Pace Group Inc. with violating antifraud statutes in connection with a 1981 underwriting and has suspended it from conducting such activities for 60 days.

title: UNDOCUMENTED ALIENS DON'T TAKE JOBS AWAY
description: To the Editor:

title: A Girl Is Asphyxiated; Her Mother Is Blamed
description: A young girl was killed and her brother critically injured by carbon-monoxide fumes that filled their home after a car in the garage was left running in a suicide attempt by their mother, the authorities said today.

title: Inmates Battle Deputies In Los Angeles Jail
description: About 65 prisoners armed with broomhandles and cups of bleach fought riot-equipped deputies for three hours today at the Los Angeles County Jail. Three deputies and about 50 inmates were injured, some seriously, officials said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, JUNE 3, 1985

title: Xerox Will Interview Direct Marketing Units
description: The Xerox Corporation, which has been a client of Needham Harper Worldwide for many years, is now looking for a direct marketing agency to add to its roster.

title: Credit Unions Facing a Tax
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S tax proposal gave little solace to the nation's 2,000 largest credit unions. If he gets his way, all credit unions with assets of $5 million or more will have to pay corporate income tax for the first time in the industry's history.

title: EXHIBITION OF DRAWINGS BY 180 ARCHITECTS
description: An exhibition of 216 drawings by 180 contemporary architects from 18 countries is being shown through this Saturday, in a silent auction sponsored by the Architects for Social Responsibility at the Max Protetch gallery. Proceeds from the sale of the drawings, which were contributed by the architects, will go to the national, nonprofit professional organization, which disseminates information about the consequences and costs of nuclear war and armament.

title: Intercity-Bus Subsidy Is a Fraction of Amtrak's
description: To the Editor:

title: R.J. REYNOLDS SET TO PAY $4.9 BILLION IN BID FOR NABISCO
description: R.J. Reynolds Industries, the nation's second-largest cigarette maker, has agreed to acquire Nabisco Brands Inc., the fourth-ranking food company, in a deal valued at about $4.9 billion, the companies announced yesterday.

title: NETWORKS RETHINKING THE MINI-SERIES
description: In 1977 the enormous success of ''Roots'' confirmed the emergence of a new form of television storytelling, the mini-series. The final episode of that 12-hour film earned a 51.1 rating and a 71 share of the audience. Since then dozens more mini-series have been produced, and there have been other striking successes, including ''Holocaust,'' ''Shogun,'' ''The Winds of War,'' and ''The Thorn Birds.'' But this year audiences seemed to lose patience with these multipart programs. ''A.D.,'' ''Space'' ''Hollywood Wives,'' ''Mistral's Daughter,'' ''Robert Kennedy and His Times'' all performed far below network expectations. Now networks and producers are proceeding with a certain amount trepidation and uncertainty in considering the future of this once-popular form.

title: PURCHASERS' INDEX STAGNANT IN MAY
description: After entering the second quarter on a mixed note, the economy turned flat in May, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported yesterday.

title: GREEK SOCIALISTS WIN SOLID VICTORY IN NATIONAL VOTE
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's Socialist Party won a clear victory in general elections Sunday, but its margin over the conservative New Democracy Party was somewhat reduced.

title: Just for Fun Wins Title at Devon
description: Just for Fun became the grand hunter champion for the second straight year Saturday in the 89th annual Devon Horse Show.

title: LONG LOOK BACK BY A LAWYER NAMED FULBRIGHT
description: It was 9 A.M., and former Senator J. William Fulbright was roasting.

title: Catching Up
description: John Stearns continues to be bitten by the bad-luck bug. Stearns, who at age 33 was dropped by the Mets after last season, his chronically ailing right elbow still keeping him from a catcher's role, sought to further his rehabilitation with Cincinnati's Denver farm club this year.

title: RENT CURBS ARE SAID TO FOSTER NEW YORK TENENT INEQUITIES
description: As the State Legislature prepares to renew New York City's rent-regulation system, housing analysts are debating whether the system -begun in 1943 to cure a wartime housing emergency - has become part of the disease.

title: WOMEN AGAINST APARTHEID: FEMINISM CAN WAIT
description: On a day of sun and sadness and defiance, Virginia Ngalo, a large and powerful woman, rose to address a funeral rally and told other women to unite with her in struggling against white domination.

title: Oshkosh Captures Division III Title
description: Wisconsin-Oshkosh won the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division III baseball title today by downing Ithaca, 11-4, and Marietta College, 11-6, in the double-elimination tournament.

title: Harper's Raising Rate Base
description: HARPER'S magazine, which cut its circulation rate base back to 140,000 from 320,000 in 1982 in search of a more affluent audience, will now be raising it for the first time since - to 150,000 with the October issue.

title: NEW MUNICIPAL INDEX TRADING
description: INVESTORS in tax-exempt bonds have always been speculators. Not only have they always gambled that the interest and principal would not be eroded by inflation, but also that they would be able to get a fair price for their bonds if they had to sell them before maturity.

title: MUSIC: 'WALDEN,' BY CHOSET
description: CHARLES CHOSET is a composer who likes to intermingle pop and ''serious'' music in a calculatedly naive style that jams together and simplifies dozens of different idioms. Mr. Choset, whose Christmas oratorio, ''Messiah,'' has enjoyed downtown New York performances for the last four years, has created a new and similar work in ''Walden,'' whose text is drawn from Henry David Thoreau.

title: GUESTS FIND A NEW KIND OF BELLHOP AT HOTELS DURING STRIKE
description: Carl Aster turned from the registration desk at the Sheraton Centre yesterday and saw an agreeable man stacking his load of packing cases on a baggage trolley.

title: 5% More Lawyers in Jersey
description: The number of lawyers licensed to practice in New Jersey rose by more than 5 percent last year, to 25,471 from 24,262 in 1983, according to a report by the Administrative Office of the Courts and the Office of Attorney Ethics. The study found that 15 percent of the lawyers were women, 3 percent were black and slightly less than 1 percent were of Hispanic origin. Fifty-seven percent were between the ages of 30 and 44.

title: C.F.A. Proposes $600 Player Pay
description: The College Football Association's coaches' committee recommended today giving players $600 a year for incidental expenses and funding the allowance by making them pay for their ''complimentary'' tickets.

title: BLUE JAYS TRIUMPH TO SPLIT WITH INDIANS
description: Lloyd Moseby and George Bell hit run-scoring doubles during a four-run first inning today that led the Toronto Blue Jays past the Cleveland Indians, 5-2, in the second game for a split of the first doubleheader in the major leagues this season.

title: Missing Soviet Train Baffles Bureaucracy
description: Soviet efforts to find a missing freight train produced a bureaucratic tangle but not the 28 rail cars, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda complained today.

title: Kanak Parties to Run In New Caledonia Race
description: Two Kanak separatist parties said today that they would take part in regional elections planned by France as a step toward independence for this South Pacific territory.

title: People
description: John H. Glorieux named senior vice president and director of client services at Young & Rubicam/ New York, replacing Eugene O'Sullivan, who is going to Ogilvy & Mather as a senior vice president and group director.

title: SHULTZ ASKS ISRAEL TO BACK TALKS WITH JORDANIANS AND PALESTINIANS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has sent a message to Prime Minister Shimon Peres to seek Israeli backing for projected American talks with a Jordanian-Palestinian delegation as a step toward direct talks with Israel, State Department officials said today.

title: METS' 2 HOMERS SINK PADRES, 7-3
description: The Mets won their first series in San Diego in eight years today when they beat the Padres, 7-3, and scored their fourth victory in five games on a West Coast trip that seemed like an ordeal when it began last week.

title: Computer Memories
description: Abraham Brand, president and co-founder of Computer Memories Inc. in Chatsworth, Calif., resigned on May 23, according to the company. Gary Streuter, who joined the company as executive vice president seven months ago, was appointed president on the day of Mr. Brand's resignation, Irwin Rubin, chairman and chief executive, said. Mr. Streuter previously worked for Altos Computer Systems in San Jose, Calif.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''New York is a city of the poor masquerading as a city of the rich.'' - Dr. George Sternlieb, director of the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University. [B5:3.]

title: VOTE TOMORROW WILL DETERMINE KEAN OPPONENT
description: New Jersey's Democratic voters will go to the polls Tuesday to choose a candidate to oppose Governor Kean in the general election in November.

title: Dr. Beth Schorr Wed To Charles B. Lesnick Weds Dr. Beth Schorr
description: At the North Country Reform Temple in Glen Cove, L.I., yesterday Dr. Beth Susan Schorr, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Schorr of Flushing, Queens, was married to Charles Bernard Lesnick, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Lesnick of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Maurice Weisenberg performed the ceremony.

title: Missouri Searchers Seek 330-Pound Lioness
description: The authorities were searching for a 330-pound lioness that might have been loose in a densely wooded area of southwestern Missouri for as long as two months.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Oakland A's, at Yankee Stadium. Despite outscoring the A's, 31-14, in their four games in Oakland a week ago, the Yankees managed only to split. They won the first and third games, 10-3 and 13-1, but Dave Righetti lost the other two, one by 8-7 on a bases- loaded walk and the other by 2-1 on a leadoff home run by Dwayne Murphy in the 10th inning. (Television -SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Dodgers, at Los Angeles, 8 P.M. The opening game of the 10th season for ABC's Monday night game of the week. Al Michaels and Jim Palmer are in the booth. In their only other series of the season, a week ago at Shea Stadium, the Mets lost the first two games, the latter when Fernando Valenzuela outdueled Dwight Gooden, then won the last two, (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) College: College World Series, at Omaha, Game 7. (Television - ESPN, midnight, tape). Tennis French Open, at Paris. First of five nightly reports. (Television - USA Network, 8 P.M. same-day tape). New York State Championships for Women, at Beach Point Club, Mamaroneck, N.Y., 10 A.M. Alissa Finerman of Scarsdale is the defending champion and top-seeded player. Other Events BOXING: Mike Picciotti vs. Kevin Rooney, 10 rounds, junior middlewights, at the Sands Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City. First preliminary, 7:30 P.M. FOOTBALL: Gamblers vs. Birmingham Stallions, at Houston, 8 P.M. The Gamblers beat Arizona last week but lost their quarterback, Jim Kelly, for three to five weeks with a torn ligament in his right knee.

title: Springsteen Opens Tour At Castle in Ireland
description: To the strains of his hit song ''Born in the U.S.A.,'' Bruce Springsteen opened his European tour before 60,000 fans in a tiny Irish village Saturday.

title: Philippine Journalist Slain at Beauty Pageant
description: Gunmen shot and killed a commentator for a labor-run radio station as he watched his 19-year-old daughter compete in a beauty contest in the central Philippines, officials said today.

title: Account
description: GMFanuc Robotics Corporation, a joint venture of General Motors and Japan's Fanuc, to D'Arcy MacManus Masius/Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: ILLINOIS PROJECT TO TURN MINED LAND INTO SCULPTURE
description: On the shores of the Illinois River here, an unusual collaboration between a sculptor, a mining company, a state agency and a philanthropic group is transforming a forest destroyed by coal mining into one of the world's largest outdoor sculptures.

title: TORNADO WORKERS FIND 6 MORE BODIES
description: Relief workers and volunteers searched for victims, cleared roads and removed debris, set up temporary housing and sought to restore power and telephone lines yesterday to communities in Ohio, Pennsylvania and Ontario, Canada, that were devastated by tornadoes Friday.

title: GLASSON TAKES KEMPER ON 50-FOOT PUTT
description: Bill Glasson, who lost his tour card last year and had to requalify in the fall, rolled in a 50-foot putt on the last hole today to edge Larry Mize and Corey Pavin by one stroke to win the $500,000 Kemper Open.

title: YANKS LOSE, 7-6, TO MOTIVATED MARINERS
description: The Seattle Mariners won a game yesterday Chuck Cottier's way. It would not have been, the first stage at least, George Steinbrenner's way.

title: BANGKOK'S DEPARTMENT STORE BOOM
description: Bangkok, which does few things in moderation, is on a department store binge. By the end of the year, marketing experts say, the city will have 35 to 40 major stores, or malls anchored by big shops, most of them built within the last five years.

title: PITTSBURGH'S NEW SMOKE
description: PAGE by page, copies of the indictment papers were piled atop a counter in the clerk's office at the old Federal Building here last Friday morning. With 111 pages for the 111 counts involving drug-related charges, the grand jury indictment of Dale Shiffman needed a rubber band around it. The indictments against the other six suspected drug dealers were stacked loosely. But when no baseball players were named in those indictment papers, some baseball people sighed.

title: PORT TO HEAR SHIP WHISTLE OF 'LOST ERA'
description: Even before the majestic hull appeared out of the mist at the edge of New York Harbor 50 years ago today, the whistle heralded her arrival: the Normandie, the largest and most opulent ocean liner afloat.

title: Deborah Ruth Lunder, Lawyer, Has Nuptials
description: The marriage of Deborah Ruth Lunder, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Allen Lunder of North Andover, Mass., and Boston, to Dr. R. Alan B. Ezekowitz, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Kalman Ezekowitz of Durban, South Africa, took place yesterday at the Harvard Club in Boston. Rabbi Albert Axelrad performed the ceremony.

title: A LATTER-DAY PATENT MEDICINE SHOW
description: WHO says you can't bring back the good old days?

title: T.W.A.'S TROUBLED STRUCTURE
description: When Carl C. Icahn met with the management of Trans World Airlines early last month to discuss his large stake in the company and his thoughts about its future, he stressed the need to severely curtail domestic operations.

title: ON CORPORATE LADDER, BEAUTY CAN HURT
description: The notion that beauty is only skin deep has been buried many times in the last decade by psychological studies that confirm a pervasive bias in favor of good-looking men and women. Not only are they more socially desirable, they are also expected to have better jobs, better marriages and happier lives, the studies found.

title: Saving the Heritage
description: The Civil War never quite ends for the National Park Service, which has taken its first prisoners in dealing with artifact thieves who plunder historic sites by digging up bullets, buttons and other valuable souvenirs. Two antiquity thieves caught gleaning the grounds of the Battle of Richmond with metal detectors were sentenced to jail terms earlier this year in a precedent that the Park Service hopes will be an effective warning.

title: Michelle Dupre Weds Kenneth J. Lifton
description: Michelle Ann Dupre, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fernand A. Dupre Jr. of Haverhill, Mass., was married yesterday to Kenneth Jay Lifton, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Jay Lifton of New York. Rabbi Allen Press and the Rev. Ronald Hindelang, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Merrimack College Chapel in North Andover, Mass.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Tomoko Shibata And Koichi Aiba
description: East met West in joyous crossfertilization at the Merkin Concert Hall Saturday night when the Bridge Performing Artists, a nonprofit organization of Japanese-American musicians, sponsored a program featuring the soprano Tomoko Shibata and the flutist Koichi Aiba in conjunction with the pianist Gary Kudo, the harpsichordist Ikuko Aiba, the koto player Reiko Kamata and a chamber orchestra.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CROWDS AT VON BULOW TRIAL
description: As the trial of Claus von Bulow nears its end, the crowds are beginning to grow in the halls of the Providence County Superior Court.

title: Brazilian Is Winner Of Van Cliburn Contest
description: Jose Feghali, a Brazilian who first played in public at the age of 5, was named the winner of the Seventh Van Cliburn International Piano Competition today.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS GROUPS GEAR UP TO OPPOSE REAGAN NOMINEE
description: More than two dozen representatives of civil rights organizations are preparing to testify against the nomination of William Bradford Reynolds, the Justice Department's civil rights chief, to be the Associate Attorney General, the department's No. 3 job.

title: LAKERS TROUNCE CELTICS AND LEAD BY 2-1
description: From the onset of the playoffs, the Los Angeles Lakers have denied that their motivation stems from revenge. But they played this afternoon with the kind of fire and emotion that contradicted that assertion.

title: Anne E. Diamond Becomes a Bride
description: Anne Elizabeth Diamond, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Diamond of New York and New Milford, Conn., was married yesterday to Jonathan Edward Diamond, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Diamond of New York. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York.

title: A Banking Markup
description: On Wednesday, the House Banking subcommittee on financial institutions is scheduled to begin to mark up - that is, consider the shape of - legislation to close the limited service bank loophole and to open up regional interstate banking. And Fernand J. St Germain, Democrat from Rhode Island, subcommittee chairman, appears to have left the most controversial issue - whether to phase in nationwide interstate banking - to the subcommittee members.

title: SFN Is Selling TV Station to Cox
description: The SFN Companies agreed yesterday to sell WFTV in Orlando, Fla., to Cox Communications Inc., for $185 million in cash, one year after SFN bought the station, for $125 million. SFN said that it would use the proceeds to pay down its bank debt and to reinvest in other television properties.

title: ITALIAN WITNESS'S MOTHER SLAIN
description: The mother of a Neopolitan crime figure who had turned state's evidence was killed today in a bomb explosion near Naples. The police said the woman, Francesca Pandico, 65 years old, died when a bomb ripped through the hut in Liveri where she and her family had been living since the earthquake of 1980.

title: Building Outlays Up
description: New construction spending rose 1.02 percent in April to an annual rate of $325.7 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: OPEC TO MEET EARLIER: PRICE PRESSURE IS SEEN
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, whose price structure is under increasing pressure because of sluggish demand for oil, moved up its next full meeting by about three weeks, to June 30 from July 22.

title: Skulduggery Suspected
description: Jim Frey, the Chicago Cubs' manager, is not convinced that Mike Scott's success this season is all due to his new forkball. Scott, the Houston Astro pitcher, beat the Cubs, 4-3, Sunday night at the Astrodome and Frey suspects Scott got some help from a piece of sandpaper.

title: 'Ma Rainey' to Close
description: ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom,'' the drama about the classic blues singer by August Wilson, will close after its Sunday matinee performance at the Cort Theater. It will have given 8 previews and 275 performances. Mr. Wilson's drama - directed by Lloyd Richards and starring Charles Dutton and Theresa Merritt - won the best play award this season from the New York Drama Critics Circle. It also was nominated for best play in the Tony Awards.

title: The Reisinger Tournament Recalls Match 4 Years Ago
description: Two members of the foursome that won the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship in Manhattan last weekend had reason to remember an earlier New York occasion.

title: MANY PATRONS OF HOTELS TAKING STRIKE IN STRIDE
description: ''They haven't made my bed, but then I don't make it at home either,'' Sherron Furst of Fort Worth said with a shrug, describing the curtailed maid service at the Windsor Harley Hotel on West 58th Street.

title: CHANCE MAY BE TO BLAME FOR CANCER RATES AT 2 SITES
description: Soldiers and sailors exposed to radiation at two United States atomic test sites in the 1950's are showing higher-than-normal death rates from certain cancers, the National Research Council reported today.

title: WHY COLLEGE IS SO EXPENSIVE
description: College education has come under attack by parents and Government officials who feel that it costs too much. It is true that education is worryingly expensive, but it is costly for a reason -or, rather, a set of reasons - that should make sense to anyone who cares about the future of our country.

title: A Florida Judge Orders Stay on Execution
description: The Florida Supreme Court granted a stay of execution today for a convicted killer scheduled to die Tuesday morning, and considered whether to do the same for a second man scheduled to die at the same time.

title: Banking Venture
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Time Inc., Chemical Bank and the Bank of America said that they had banded together to offer home banking and brokerage services to customers nationwide. After receiving regulatory approval, the new service will initially be available to the 37,000 individual and small-business customers of the home banking services now offered separately by Chemical in New York and by Bank of America in California.

title: F.D.I.C. Issues Bank Ruling
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation tentatively approved rules that would require federally insured banks to operate real estate development and insurance activities through separate subsidiaries.

title: Venezuela Bank Move
description: The Venezuelan Government suspended activities of the privately owned Banco de Comercio today.

title: Sri Lanka Vows to Seek Political End to Conflict
description: The President of Sri Lanka agreed with Indian leaders today that ''immediate steps'' should be taken to achieve a ''political settlement'' to the ethnic conflicts in his nation.

title: Topics;   Strong Opinions Aid to Education
description: For the first time in its 78 years, the board of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching has taken a public position, to express its alarm about proposed cuts in Federal aid to education.

title: HOW CURBS ON USE OF WATER DURING DROUGHT AFFECT RESIDENTS OF JERSEY
description: Limits on water use, including rationing and lesser restrictions, are in effect in New Jersey in 230 communities in 12 counties.

title: A Commemoration For Benjamin S. Rosenthal
description: The Flushing post office from which the late Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal conducted his Queens district business for many years may one day bear his name.

title: Topics;   Strong Opinions Double Reverse
description: Some judges live long enough to see their dissents become law. That has happened again and again to Judge David Bazelon of the Federal Court of Appeals in Washington, now retiring after 35 years.

title: 2 Views On Jobs in Retailing
description: THE need to whittle down large inventories has seriously affected the executive ranks in retailing, according to a survey by Korn Ferry International, the management recruiting firm.

title: MAD MAY ENDS AT LAST
description: THE mad May social season is gone at last, ending not with a spectacular benefit but with disquiet in the ballet world, speculation at the Metropolitan Museum, a Bach fugue somewhere in the background and yet another of Alice Mason's dinners. Just about everybody has had enough.

title: TELEVIDEO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income The company said the loss for the second quarter includes additional provisions of about $1.5 million related to the closing of the Sunnyvale and Puerto Rican manufacturing facilities. In addition results for the quarter and 6 months reflect a pretax loss of $5,975,000 and $17,527,000, respectively, but offset by tax benefits of $5,297,000 for the quarter and $8,763,000 for the 6 months.

title: RATES DROP AND NEAR %-YEAR LOWS
description: Short- and long-term interest rates declined sharply yesterday and are now approaching lows not seen since June 1980.

title: How to Buy an Ounce of Food-Shortage Prevention
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT SHIFTS ON AID FOR REBELS
description: White House officials have told Congress that President Reagan has reluctantly agreed to drop his insistence that the Central Intelligence Agency serve as the vehicle for nonmilitary aid to Nicaraguan rebels, Administration officials said today.

title: Big Board Union Sets Vote on Offer It Opposes
description: The union for workers on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that its leadership opposed a contract proposed by the exchange and that members would vote on Thursday on whether to accept the offer or go on strike.

title: Dynamics Pays Fine to Navy
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, saying it did not want to further damage relations with the Navy, has paid a $676,283 fine to satisfy a finding that it gave illegal gifts to now retired Adm.

title: SUMMER'S BEST SELLERS ABLAZE IN BRIGHT PRINTS
description: Prints have exploded all over the fashion scene, imparting a special liveliness to summer dressing. Leaving their mark on all kinds of apparel from shirts to shoes, they have met with considerable approval from women assembling their warm-weather wardrobes.

title: New York Rent Laws Won't Improve Amid All This Wrangling
description: To the Editor:

title: OFFICIALS SAY REQUESTS FOR ACCESS TO SECRETS OVERTAX INVESTIGATORS
description: So many people are now asking for official clearance to handle ''secret'' and ''top secret'' materials, Government officials say, that it is impossible to investigate the applications adequately.

title: DEMOCRATS IN CONGRESS WANT CONTINUATION OF THE 1979 ARMS PACT
description: As Congress returned from a 10-day recess today, leading Democrats urged the Reagan Administration to continue to comply with the 1979 strategic arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union, warning of a potential backlash if the pact was abandoned.

title: Inquiry Leads Vietnam To Leave Labor Agency
description: The International Labor Organization said today that Vietnam had left the organization.

title: EXPOS TOP GIANTS ON BAD THROW IN 15TH
description: Frank Williams threw wildly to home plate, allowing Randy St. Claire and U.L. Washington to score in the 15th inning, giving the Montreal Expos a 4-2 victory over the San Francisco Giants today.

title: PINCHED SMALL TOWN SUFFERS NEW PAIN
description: Like many residents of this riverbank town, Jerry Miller talks about Wheatland's businesses in the past tense.

title: NEW YORK RUNOFFS ARE CALLED BIASED
description: The law governing runoffs in political primary elections in New York City was called unconstitutional and discriminatory yesterday at the opening of a Federal trial in a suit to overturn the state statute.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 4, 1985

title: 21 Violations Cited In Hospital Death
description: One of 21 infractions listed today in a report on the morphine-overdose death of an 84-year-old man in Auburn Memorial Hospital charges that administrators allowed a nurse to work after three days of in-hospital training.

title: PERPETUAL MOTION?
description: AH, for the ever-filled purse, the layer of golden eggs, the perfect tax shelter.

title: LETTER QUALITY, ALMOST
description: PRINTERS, along with disk drives, are among the few predominantly mechanical adjuncts to personal computing. This helps explain their relatively high cost. Mechanical components with close-tolerance moving parts simply do not allow the economies of scale possible in the manufacture of electronic components.

title: Palmer Will Rest
description: Arnold Palmer, saying ''I'm tired, I need a rest,'' will soon be taking an indefinite respite from competitive golf.

title: MAN (AND CAMERAS) VS. ROCK ON YOSEMITE PERCH
description: There she was, precariously perched near the slippery summit of Lost Arrow Spire, when the boots started getting closer and closer to her face.

title: No Change of Course At Justice Department
description: To the Editor:

title: IMC LTD. ASSESSES FUTURE AFTER DEATH OF SHELDON GOLD
description: ICM Artists Ltd., one of New York's most powerful artists' management companies, is expected in the next few days to make a decision on how it will proceed without Sheldon Gold, who died suddenly a little more than a week ago. The announcement of that decision, however, may not be made for a week or 10 days. In the interim, ICM and the music business in general are assessing what life without the agency's founding leader will be.

title: 'Gilt' Market Makers To Include U.S. Firms
description: The Bank of England said yesterday that it was prepared to recognize 31 firms as market makers in the gilt-edged securities market, the British equivalent of this country's Treasury bond market.

title: In Plain English, Gibberish
description: In 1972 the Nixon Administration laid down the law: Henceforth, it was decreed, the Federal Register was to be written in ''laymen's terms.''

title: Rumanians to Let 1,000 Emigrate to the West
description: West German officials said today that Rumania was planning to let about 1,000 of its citizens leave the country for the West.

title: PHH GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Bleachers Open
description: After an eight-game shutdown caused by rowdyism and extraordinarily organized chanting of obscenities, Jim Campbell, the Detroit Tigers' president, has reopened the bleacher seats at Tiger Stadium. The reopening took effect with Sunday afternoon's game against California, but partly because of short notice -the move was not announced until after Saturday's game - only 2,000 bleacherites were on hand.

title: PROGRESS ON IMPORTS OF OIL PIPE
description: European and American negotiators reported progress today toward resolving a contentious steel dispute.

title: PREMENSTRUAL PROBLEMS SEEM TO BESET BABOONS
description: Biologists studying wild primates in Kenya have found that premenstrual female baboons display symptoms resembling those of premenstrual syndrome in women. In the days just before onset of menstruation, female baboons eat more and are less social than at other times, the researchers discovered.

title: PAUL HARRIS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
CONRAIL GIVE-AWAY
description: On its face, the Reagan Administration's proposed sale of Conrail looks like a bad deal for the taxpayers and a steal for the Norfolk Southern Corporation, the chosen buyer. Beneath the surface, this complex transaction looks even worse - a government giveaway that could severely reduce freight-hauling competition and further damage already hard-pressed industries.

title: F.A.O. Schwarz May Be Sold
description: The Swiss parent of the F.A.O. Schwarz toy stores, which has sold 10 smaller Schwarz outlets, may sell the entire chain, according to Franz Carl Weber, chairman of the Zurich-based company that bears his name.

title: U.S. WILL DROP EFFORTS TO HALT AID TO DISABLED
description: Reversing itself in a dispute with Federal judges and thousands of disabled people, the Reagan Administration announced today that it would generally follow court precedents requiring the payment of Social Security disability benefits.

title: ALASKA MAY REINSTITUTE STATE TAX, OFFICIALS SAY
description: Officials say they believe that by the middle of 1986 Alaska will be forced to reinstitute state income taxes, which were dropped in 1979 when oil wealth flooded the state treasury.

title: GOING OUTSIDE THE U.N.
description: On the 40th anniversary of the signing of the United Nations Charter at San Francisco, the best birthday present we could give the organization would be to relieve it of responsibility for matters beyond its competence.

title: STEPHENS TO DOUBLE CHANCES IN BELMONT
description: Woody Stephens, seeking an unparalleled fourth straight victory in the Belmont Stakes, said yesterday that he would run Creme Fraiche as well as Stephan's Odyssey in Saturday's race.

title: OPERA: 'RHEINGOLD' ON COAST
description: A frenzy of Wagnerism has overtaken this city, promising to transform it into Bayreuth on the Bay for the next three weeks. The San Francisco Opera, climaxing an effort that began in the summer of 1983, last night set in motion the first of this summer season's three week-long ''Ring'' cycles with a performance of ''Das Rheingold.''

title: Sanitation Dept. Artists
description: Vocation and avocation are one for Robert S. Piltch - Sanitation Department planner and self-described surrealist painter.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: IF the air in New York seems sweeter these days, it may be because this is Fragrance Week. It happens every year at this time - by mayoral proclamation, no less - and it entails all manner of special events to make people aware of perfumes, potpourris and such. Mainly, it means that department store shoppers will find themselves bombarded by videos, posters and demonstrations of how perfumes and potpourris are made and how to select a fragrance from the myriad choices. Even the New York Botanical Garden is getting into the act with a display of roses in the Cranford Rose Garden.

title: What Matters to Greece
description: If Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou means what he says, the Greek people have won a handsome victory in Sunday's election.
