Foreign affairs hardly figured in his Socialist Government's successful campaign for a second term: ''It's amazing,'' Mr. Papandreou told The Times's Henry Kamm on election eve, ''The voters want responsible handling, they don't want adventures . . . It is as if these matters have become tiresome.'' As a result, the Prime Minister contends, the United States and Greece's other allies can expect ''calmer seas.''

title: A Church-State Case Transcending Law
description: The conflict between Mayor Koch and Cardinal O'Connor over New York City's power to prohibit discrimination against homosexuals in city contracts should be settled rather than adjudicated. The case goes before the State Court of Appeals today but it really transcends the law. These powerful agents of church and state finally need to decide whether church-affiliated agencies can deliver critical social services without arousing bitterness and without blurring their distinct functions.

title: Testifying by Television
description: It is no longer absolutely necessary to come to Washington to testify before a Congressional committee. Today, for the first time, a panel will take testimony from witnesses who are not in a Capitol hearing room but whose words and images will be transmitted by television from outside the country.

title: A Quiet Victory For Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
description: In contrast to the attention surrounding so many events in his young life, the admission of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to the New York State bar passed last week almost without notice.

title: 4th Coke Plant in China
description: The Coca-Cola Company said today that it had opened its fourth bottling plant in China. The new plant, in Zhuhai, on the southern coast, will bottle Coca-Cola, Sprite and Fanta orange drink. Other Coke plants in China are in Peking, Guangzhou and Xiamen.

title: R.J. Reynolds Sees Profit Dilution
description: J. Tylee Wilson, the chairman of R.J. Reynolds Industries, said yesterday that there would be some dilution of his company's earnings as a result of its proposed $4.9 billion acquisition of Nabisco Brands Inc., but he declined to elaborate.

title: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results for the latest first quarter include sales of $70,376,000 for Miller- Wohl Co. which was consolidated effective June 23, 1984.

title: MERRILL OFFICER JOINS E.F. HUTTON
description: In a move to polish its image, the E.F. Hutton Group yesterday named Robert P. Rittereiser, a well-respected executive vice president at Merrill Lynch & Company, as the company's president.

title: Horn & Hardart's Diversifoods Bid
description: The Horn & Hardart Company, the apparent loser to the Pillsbury Company last month in a takeover fight for Diversifoods Inc., said that it would seek to elect its own directors at a court-ordered meeting of Diversifoods shareholders to be held no later than June 14. The disclosure came in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission by a partnership controlled by Horn & Hardart.

title: King Hussein's Gambit
description: Jordan's King Hussein has persuaded American leaders that if they will help arrange some protective international cover, he is ready to negotiate directly with Israel. That is good news as far as it goes - which is not very far. The King has met Israelis in secret on several occasions and could probably make a deal with them if he were free to pursue his own interests. The protection he needs is against Arabs.

title: Kennedy Gains Final in Baseball
description: Kennedy High School, which has won city championships in football and cross-country, yesterday defeated John Jay High, 7-4, in the semifinals of the Public Schools' Athletic League baseball championships.

title: TENNESSEE BANKER IS GIVEN 20-YEAR JAIL TERM
description: Jacob F. Butcher, a prominent banker and politician in Tennessee, was sentenced yesterday to two concurrent 20-year prison terms for defrauding his banks of as much as $30 million.

title: Afghan Talks Scheduled
description: Talks on the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan will resume in two weeks when representatives from Pakistan and Afghanistan meet in Geneva with a United Nations envoy, a spokesman announced today. The discussions began in 1982, with the last round ending in August 1984.

title: ELDER-BEERMAN STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated for a 10 percent stock dividend paid in January.

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: b-Including income of $540,000 for the quarter and a loss of $6,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,657,000 and a provision of $9.3 million for the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: 4 Hurt in Brooklyn IRT Crash
description: A southbound IRT subway train hit a bumper block at the end of the No. 2 line at Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn yesterday, injuring three passengers and a conductor, the Transit Authority said. The slow-moving train hit the block at 11:22 A.M., according to a Transit Authority spokesman, Bob Slovak. The injured passengers were taken to Coney Island Hospital, where a spokesman said they were treated for minor injuries.

title: RENT IS A FIGHTING WORD AS GUIDELINES PANEL HEARS LANDLORDS AND TENANTS
description: In a hearing marked by booing, hissing and bitter exchanges, landlords seeking rent increases and tenants demanding rent rollbacks appeared before the Rent Guidelines Board yesterday in Manhattan.

title: Korean Says Soviet Bloc Will Compete
description: The South Korean sports minister, Lee Yong Ho, said today he had received assurances that there would be no Soviet-bloc boycott at the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul, despite the absence of diplomatic relations between Communist countries and South Korea.

title: AN APARTHEID FIGHT
description: If a law is enacted forcing state pension funds to get rid of securities in companies doing business with South Africa, Charles D. Breitel said the other day, he would enjoy being the state's Chief Judge again.

title: NIEKRO CONFOUNDS A'S
description: The Yankee starting pitcher did not throw many fastballs last night. When he did, no one questioned him. Just a few hours after they demoted a rookie pitcher for throwing a fastball in the wrong situation, the Yankees beat the Oakland A's last night, 5-2, at the Stadium, because Phil Niekro threw his famous knuckleball until the hitters were looking for nothing else. Then, when it mattered most, he threw a fastball.

title: Chasing McLain
description: Andy Hawkins, who will try to make it 11-0 when he faces Philadelphia at San Diego Stadium tonight, is a couple of weeks ahead of the pace set by Denny McLain in 1968, which was the last time a pitcher won 30 games. Hawkins got victory No. 10 last Thursday, whereas it was not until June 13 that McLain reached the plateau, at 10-2, en route to a 31-6 mark.

title: Doctors Say 2 Septuplets Fail
description: The two weakest of the five surviving Frustaci septuplets encountered additional lung problems today, and doctors downgraded their condition to critical and unstable.

title: Shotgun Joy
description: One change brought by Rod Dowhower, the new coach of the Indianapolis Colts, has been the introduction of a shotgun formation for long-yardage plays, and Mike Pagel, the No. 1 quarterback, could not be happier about it: ''Sure, the defense knows we're going to pass 99 times out of 100 when we're in the shotgun, but when it's third-and-30, who cares? It's better than running a draw or a trap, like we did under Kush.''

title: Kissinger Voices Doubt About Summit Efforts
description: Henry A. Kissinger declared last night that this year ''is not an ideal time for a summit meeting'' between President Reagan and the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: ITALY AND POPE RATIFY A NEW CONCORDAT
description: The Vatican and Italy ratified a historic pact today ending Roman Catholicism as a state religion in Italy.

title: Pumping Congressional Iron
description: Representative Barney Frank weighed 270 pounds when he was re-elected to Congress in 1983. At the age of 43, the Massachusetts Democrat, after a day's work, would relax by having a soda, potato chips and whatever other junk food struck his fancy.

title: 3 Partners Behind Deal To Buy Gulf Building
description: David R. Topping is only 29, and Alexander Vik is just 30, but they are already old hands in the real estate business. And in the last five years they have made ''quite a bit of money'' at it, according to Mr. Vik.

title: CUBANS TURNING OUT RADIO MARTI'S '1950'S SOUND'
description: Few Cubans want to admit they listen to Radio Marti, the new broadcasting service to Cuba that the United States started about two weeks ago. Fewer still want to discuss it.

title: U.S. MILITARY IS TERMED PREPARED FOR ANY MOVE AGAINST NICARAGUA
description: In the last two years, the United States Southern Command, from its tropical hilltop headquarters here, has presided over the establishment of a sophisticated military apparatus in Central America.

title: Apples Fall, 87-76
description: Napoleon Johnson scored 20 points as the New Jersey Jammers handed the New York Golden Apples their fourth straight defeat, 87-76, tonight in a United States Basketball League game at the Westchester County Center. Steve Burtt, former Iona College standout, had 20 points for the Apples.

title: Bird Named Top Player
description: Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics today was named the National Basketball Association's most valuable player, thus becoming the fifth player and first non-center to be named in consecutive years.

title: CHILD ABUSE REVISITED
description: Child abuse has become one of those problems that every so often explodes into headlines, stirs fuss and fury at City Hall where vows are made that this will never happen again and then recedes into the bureaucratic fog until the next scandal erupts six months later.

title: 2d Shift at U.S. Nissan
description: Nissan officials said today that a second shift had been started at the company's plant here for the production of Sentras and light trucks. The plant plans to produce 240,000 vehicles annually by the spring of 1987.

title: DOROTHY WOLFF LEVITT
description: Dorothy Wolff Levitt, a former community coordinator for the Board of Education in Brooklyn and the widow of Arthur Levitt, the State Comptroller for 24 years, died yesterday at New York Hospital. She was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: TURK TRIED IN PAPAL PLOT DENIES BEING AT PLANNING MEETING IN '81
description: The trial of five Turks and three Bulgarians in a purported plot to assassinate Pope John Paul II began its second week today with testimony about an impromptu meeting four years ago.

title: PRESTIGIOUS FORUM SLIDES INTO TROUBLING DECLINE
description: The once-proud titan of American scientific forums - the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science - is in sharp, troubling decline.

title: PARTICIPANTS AND ISSUES IN HOTEL STRIKE
description: Participants - The Hotel and Motel Trades Council, a nine-union coalition representing 25,000 bellhops, housekeepers, clerks, chefs, waiters, bartenders and other employees of 165 hotels in New York City, has struck 46 hotels and says that its workers have been locked out of 2 others.

title: BRITAIN PROPOSES BROAD OVERHAUL OF ALMOST ALL WELFARE PROGRAMS
description: The Government, saying the national social services system had ''lost its way,'' today proposed the most sweeping changes in the cradle-to-the-grave British welfare state since it was designed more than 40 years ago.

title: Beirut Fighting Resumes
description: Fierce battles broke out today in and around three Palestinian settlements in the Beirut area, shattering a two-day lull.

title: Computerland
description: A state judge in Oakland has upheld a jury verdict granting partial ownership of the Computerland Corporation to a group of outside investors and denied a motion by Computerland for a new trial.

title: Keep the Money, They Told the Endowment
description: To the Editor:

title: JUSTICES LIMIT A CITY'S LIABILITY FOR ISOLATED POLICE MISCONDUCT
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that an isolated act of police misconduct cannot ordinarily make a city subject to a damage suit for violating an individual's civil rights.

title: U.S. ROBOT SALES ROSE 71% IN 1984
description: American robot companies had combined sales of $332.5 million in 1984, an increase of 71 percent from $194.4 million in 1983, according to figures compiled by the Robot Industries Association.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CARBON DIOXIDE IN ICE
description: FRENCH scientists, analyzing the air bubbles from a 660-foot-deep ice core they extracted from East Antarctica, have provided the best measure to date of atmospheric carbon dioxide levels in past centuries. Their findings may help scientists predict future increases in carbon dioxide, which could cause a planetary warming through the ''greenhouse effect.''

title: Advocate for the Homeless Protests Reagan Aid Pledge
description: Mitch Snyder, who went on a 51-day hunger strike last year to protest the plight of the homeless in the nation's capital, said today he would deliver a letter to President Reagan complaining that the President has not followed through on a promise to provide a modern shelter.

title: Court Backs States on Health Plans
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that states may require group health insurance plans for private employees to cover specific types of medical care.

title: Icahn Lifts T.W.A. Stake
description: A group led by Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor, has increased its stake in Trans World Airlines Inc. to 32.7 percent of the shares outstanding.

title: Roy Richards Is Dead at 73; Founded Southwire Company
description: Roy Richards, founder, president and chairman of the Southwire Company, died Sunday of cancer at Emory University Hospital in Atlanta. He was 73 years old.

title: SANDINISTAS PRESS ATTACKS ON REBELS
description: Nicaraguan forces appear to be striking more boldly against rebel bases in border areas than they have at any time since the conflict began three years ago.

title: A Soupcon of Elegance Adds To the Joy of Being a Winner
description: Most players like to give the impression that all they are interested in is winning. They seem to think that this is the tough, unsentimental and, hence, proper way of looking at competition (at least, this is how they talk if you ask them).

title: DEMOCRATS IN WESTCHESTER NOMINATE LAWYER TO OPPOSE O'ROURKE
description: Westchester County's Democratic leaders ended a five-month search for a candidate to oppose County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke tonight when they nominated Arthur H. Goodman, a White Plains lawyer.

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $35,952,000.

title: A SONG PLUGGER'S BIGGEST PLAY: HIS RETURN AS BOSS
description: WHETHER it's ''Everything She Wants'' by Wham! or George Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue'' or Elvis Presley crooning ''Love Me Tender,'' it's all music to Freddy Bienstock's ears.

title: Bank Mergers Await Ruling
description: THE Supreme Court is expected to rule soon on the constitutionality of regional banking, and Wall Street analysts say this landmark decision could affect a number of proposed mergers, particularly in New England and the Southeast. The legality of state laws that limit interstate banking to regions has been challenged by Citicorp, the nation's largest bank holding company.

title: U N A CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income c-After a tax credit of $151,000. The latest quarter and 9 months results include a nonrecurring charge of $30,000 from the disposition of two warehouses and the discontinuation of certain product lines.

title: A 4TH SPY SUSPECT WITH TIES TO NAVY IS SEIZED ON COAST
description: A retired Navy radioman was arrested today in San Francisco and accused of joining a spy ring that had smuggled military secrets to the Soviet Union for at least 20 years, the authorities said.

title: SLATER STEEL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including $2.3 million of overfunding in prior years to certain pension funds which was returned to the company. c-After a charge of $16,250,000 from the sale of an investment in Ipsco Inc. d-Net income including a special gain of $198,000.

title: SEGAL TO HEAD FUTURE ARTS FESTIVAL
description: Martin E. Segal, the chairman of Lincoln Center, yesterday announced a plan for an international summer arts festival in New York City, along the lines of major festivals abroad.

title: National Security Council;   Where Anonymous Power Accrues
description: The National Security Council staff does not actually work for the council, that is, the President, Vice President and Secretaries of State and Defense. It works for the national security adviser to the President, now Robert C. McFarlane.

title: THE DANCE: MARGARET BEALS, 'IMPROVISATIONS TO CHOPIN'
description: MARGARET BEALS, a dancer and choreographer, collaborated with Thomas Hrynkiv, a pianist, on Thursday night at the Loft Theater, at 228 West Broadway. The result was an evening of choreographic chamber music. While Mr. Hrynkiv played several works by Chopin, Miss Beals danced solos to them. Both Miss Beals and Mr. Hrynkiv proved to be sensitive artists. Nevertheless, their concert was oddly insubstantial.

title: SCHORR EXPLAINS VIEW OF TURNER
description: Daniel Schorr, the former Turner Broadcasting commentator whose unfavorable comments about Ted Turner's ethics were cited in the CBS filing, yesterday said that he had not expressed his reservations about Mr. Turner's ethics when he was employed by him at CNN because ''it was an internal matter.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: GOSSIP. By Patricia Meyer Spacks. 287 pages. Knopf. $18.95. PATRICIA MEYER SPACKS is a professor of English at Yale whose books include ''The Adolescent Idea,'' ''The Female Imagination'' and various studies of 18th-century literature. Now she has undertaken an anatomy of gossip. As you would expect, it is a learned work, drawing on a wide range of sources. It makes a number of excellent points, and shows considerable skill and sensitivity in its handling of literary texts. It is also somewhat grotesque.

title: NEW SAN FRANCISCO STAR: BRUNNHILDE
description: Nancy Bardoff, an accountant, took seat L125 in the balcony of San Francisco's War Memorial Opera House Sunday to begin more than 60 hours that she intends to spend listening to the music of Richard Wagner this month.

title: HOW TO BUY AN OUNCE OF FOOD-SHORTAGE PREVENTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Vermont Tax Discrimination Barred
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the state of Vermont unconstitutionally discriminated against newcomers to the state by refusing to give them credit for sales taxes they paid on cars they bought out of state and brought with them to Vermont.

title: ABC SPECIAL BY HARTMAN ON FUTURE
description: DAVID HARTMAN . . . The Future is Now'' is amiable, cheerful and almost entirely pointless. Watch Mr. Hartman being avuncular; watch computers doing things you already know they can do. Mr. Hartman, the co-host of ABC's ''Good Morning America,'' has produced his own vanity show. It will be seen on Channel 7 at 10 tonight.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The St. Louis Cardinals placed the catcher Darrell Porter on the 15-day disabled list.

title: HOW TO BUY AN OUNCE OF FOOD-SHORTAGE PREVENTION
description: To the Editor:

title: KOCH TAKES ON A NEW TARGET: TAX BREAK FOR BUSINESS MEALS
description: Mayor Koch yesterday proposed a change in the gastronomic habits of business executives: no more free lunch. Or, to be more precise, no more ''enormously'' expensive deductible lunches.

title: OFFICIALS QUESTION TORNADO WARNING SYSTEM
description: A disaster relief official in Ohio said today that inadequate warning sirens in some towns probably raised the death toll from tornadoes Friday night.

title: A French Hug
description: One of the most recent recipients of the Legion d'Honneur from France is Jack Valenti, who works in Washington as president of the Motion Picture Association of America. As Mr. Valenti tells the story, it wasn't so easy to get the little crimson rosette in his lapel.

title: TUCKER DRILLING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Complex Suits And Jury Trials
description: MARK GELLER has come to understand why many lawyers and judges contend that some suits are too complex for jurors to understand.

title: Mead Data Testing TV On Selling Its Services
description: Mead Data Central of Dayton, Ohio, yesterday began to test the effectiveness of TV advertising for selling the services of its high-priced computer-generated data bases to American businesses.

title: COLUMBUS'S SHIPS: A QUEST FOR FACS IN TIME FOR 1992
description: THE quincentennial is coming.

title: A Disaster Vacancy
description: The Government's No. 1 official for dealing with disasters, Louis O. Giuffrida, is resigning. Mr. Giuffrida, who has been director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency since February 1981, has told the White House that he is leaving the $72,600-a-year post. Mr. Giuffrida, who helped organize civil defense in California when Ronald Reagan was Governor, was in the spotlight in 1982 fending off skeptics and critics after being put in charge of the President's $4.2 billion proposal to ''provide for survival of a substantial portion of the population in the event of a nuclear attack.'' He was in Youngstown, Ohio, yesterday overseeing Government aid efforts to tornado victims.

title: Saints March Home
description: Months of wheeling and dealingfor the New Orleans Saints ended yesterday with the announcement that a $70 million deal will keep the National Football League franchise in Louisiana. ''We have witnessed a major miracle which is the culmination of a series of minor miracles,'' said Gov. Edwin Edwards, who joined the new owner, Tom Benson, the team president, Eddie Jones, and Coach Bum Phillips at a news conference. The former owner, John Mecom Jr., who had said in November that he would not budge from his $75 million asking price, came down over the weekend, Benson said.

title: Bush Becomes a Texan As Residency Is Affirmed
description: Vice President Bush, who long has boasted of being a Texan but who has tried to save on taxes by asserting that his home is in Maine, had his right to vote in Texas affirmed today.

title: CBS ASKS GOVERNMENT TO DENY TURNER'S BID
description: CBS Inc. petitioned the Federal Communications Commission yesterday to deny Ted Turner's takeover bid, saying such a move would lead to the collapse of the company's television network.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;

FUZZY'S GOLF IS FUZZY
description: With a laugh and a towel, Fuzzy Zoeller made golf fun when he won the United States Open championship at Winged Foot last year while suffering from a spinal-disc ailment. Three months later, he needed surgery. And now, after a startling comeback featured by a nine-under-par victory at the Bay Hill Classic three months ago, he's ailing again. And his golf is fuzzy again.

title: Albeck in Center Of Speculation
description: With Kevin Loughery dumped as coach by the Chicago Bulls, speculation on a successor has focused, in part, on Stan Albeck of the Nets. This conjecture has some logic, not only because Albeck was reared in Chenoa, Ill., not far from Chicago, but also because he has just completed an emotionally draining season that included a months-long tug-of-war with Micheal Ray Richardson and various disagreements with Joe Taub, who was both principal owner and team president before selling out recently to a group of minority investors.

title: Coast Chip Maker To Lay Off 1,300
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said today that it would lay off 1,300 employees in the next few months because of the severe slump in the semiconductor industry. The company also said it would cancel a proposed semiconductor wafer fabrication facility near Portland, Ore.

title: Mengel Grand Jury Releases Report
description: The grand jury that investigated the state police killing of Alex Mengel, the man accused of murdering a Westchester County officer, has recommended that the state police improve their methods of transporting and restraining prisoners.

title: CANDID BRITISH FOREIGN SECRETARY
description: Lord George-Brown, a former Foreign Secretary and one of Britain's most colorful political figures in the 1960's, died Sunday. He was 70 years old.

title: GROUPS FILE AGAINST CBS TAKEOVER
description: More than 50 CBS radio and television affiliates, labor unions, and non-broadcast special-interest groups filed petitions at the Federal Communications Commission here today to oppose Ted Turner's bid to take over CBS Inc.

title: Trading in Options on O-T-C Stocks Begins on 4 Exchanges
description: Trading in options on over-the-counter stocks began today at the Chicago Board Options Exchange and the New York, American and Pacific stock exchanges.

title: U.S. SAYS 4TH SUSPECT OFFERED TO ASSIST F.B.I.
description: A Government affidavit depicts Jerry Alfred Whitworth as a troubled, reluctant spy who wanted desperately ''to retire'' toward the end, but was caught in a web he himself helped weave.

title: Ford to Recall 515,000 Cars
description: Ford Motor Company has agreed to recall 515,000 1982 to 1983 Escort and Mercury Lynx cars to correct rear seat belts that can twist and bind, the Government said today. A spokesman for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Roslyn Kaiser, confirmed a report of the Ford recall, first announced by the Center for Auto Safety.

title: METS LOSE ON ERROR IN 12TH
description: The Mets went to great and uncharacteristic lengths tonight to lose a game to the Los Angeles Dodgers in 12 innings that they should have won in nine.

title: Bradlees May Buy Ward Unit
description: Montgomery Ward & Company, the retailing subsidiary of the Mobil Corporation, is expected to announce today that it has agreed to sell its Jefferson Ward discount store division to Bradlees Department Stores, a division of the Stop & Shop Companies. Jefferson Ward, based in Miami, operates 44 stores in the South and the Middle Atlantic States.

title: PARTI QUEBECOIS IS DEFEATED IN 4 BY-ELECTIONS
description: Quebec's governing party, the Parti Quebecois, lost four by-elections today to the opposition Liberal Party and had its majority in the provincial legislature reduced to a single vote.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They haven't made my bed, but then I don't make it at home either.'' - Sherron Furst, a guest at the struck Windsor Harley Hotel in Manhattan. [B3:5.]

title: Pure Motive
description: Bobby Hebert, whose Oakland Invaders were routed by Portland earlier this season, threw for 328 yards and 2 touchdowns Sunday in a 38-20 victory over the Breakers, but he denied that there had been any particular incentive other than Oakland's playoff drive. ''Revenge is for God, not for me,'' he said.

title: C.W. Post Loses in China
description: On a grassless, dusty field in suburban Peking, C.W. Post made baseball history today as the first United States college team to play in China. It also discovered the novice Chinese know how to pitch and steal.

title: Mostek's Chief Resigns In Shift at Technologies
description: Harold L. Ergott Jr., president and chief executive of the United Technologies Corporation's troubled Mostek Corporation subsidiary, has resigned and been reassigned to United Technologies headquarters, a Mostek spokesman said yesterday.

title: Great Plains Talks Held
description: Sponsors of the $2 billion Great Plains synthetic fuels project met with Energy Department and Synthetic Fuels Corporation officials to seek a way to prevent a threatened shutdown of the nation's biggest synthetic fuels plant.

title: 'Hurlyburly' Closes
description: ''Hurlyburly,'' a play by David Rabe about the show business drug culture in Los Angeles, closed after the matinee on Sunday at the Ethel Barrymore Theater. Directed by Mike Nichols, the drama ran for 343 performances.

title: Miss. State Wins In College Series
description: Mississippi State's Will Clark, the second selection in the major league draft earlier in the day, belted a two-run homer and drove in two other runs in leading the Bulldogs to a 5-4 victory tonight over Arkansas in the College World Series.

title: Black Children Lose Ground Against White, Report Says
description: Black children in America have lost ground over the last five years in terms in income, education and employment, according to a report issued today by the Children's Defense Fund, a liberal lobbying group.

title: PILOT STRIKE: ANOTHER STORM CLOUD IN LABOR RELATIONS
description: The confrontation between management and pilots at United Airlines, now entering its third week, illustrates the stern resolve of a number of companies in the United States to attack unions.

title: BRIEFS
description: BMC Industries, an electronic equipment manufacturer based in St. Paul, said it would not pay a dividend for the second quarter. It paid 12 cents a share in the first quarter, when it lost $378,000.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption from The Associated Press yesterday with an article about the Intercollegiate Rowing Association Championships misidentified some competitors. They were, from left, Dave Kuplick and Peter Gibson of Brown University.

title: OLD DODGERS SWING AWAY
description: A story goes that a Brooklyn cabdriver stopped outside Ebbets Field while a game was in progress. ''Hey,'' he called up to a fan in the stands, ''how're the Dodgers doin'?''

title: FORMER ASSEMBLYMAN FERRIS JOINS BROOKLYN BOROUGH PRESIDENT RACE
description: The Democratic primary for Brooklyn borough president became a four-way race yesterday when Joseph Ferris, a former Assemblyman, announced his challenge of the incumbent, Howard Golden.

title: Man Sought in 5 Slayings Blows Up Van, Killing 3
description: A man sought in the slayings of five people opened fire on the police with a machine gun and then detonated explosives in his van today, killing himself and three others, the authorities said today. Three police officers were injured.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
Thatcher to Seek Laws To Curb Soccer Violence
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today announced a crackdown on soccer violence, including moves to ban alcohol at stadiums and extend police powers.

title: Man Slain in Car Shop; The Owner Is Arrested
description: The owner of a Queens automobile body shop was arrested and charged with shooting a man to death in his office in Long Island City yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: ALIENS STAGING HUNGER STRIKE AT DETENTION CAMP
description: Among the lush fields of the Imperial Valley, where summer temperatures top 100 degrees, is a camp where the Government is holding 372 people who sought to enter the country illegally.

title: Lakers Aren't Shy In Battling Celtics
description: Pat Riley, the coach of the Los Angeles Lakers, became Prof. Pat Riley this morning, schooling his pupils in a seminar he called ''Riley 102.'' ''We had a history lesson,'' he said. The course was meant to rekindle memories of last June. The situation then was much the same, and so were the circumstances, with the Lakers leading the Boston Celtics, 2-1, in the championship series after frolicking to a 33-point triumph in Game 3 in a display that made them look invincible and overpowering. They were neither. And the Celtics proved that by become the aggressors and earning the title with victories in three of the next four games.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 4, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Science and Technology - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Connors, Lendl, Navratilova Advance
description: Jimmy Connors, seeking the only major title that has eluded him, moved into the quarterfinals of the French Open tennis championships today with a four-set victory over Francesco Cancellotti of Italy.

title: PUBLISHING: THE RULING AGAINST TONY CURTIS
description: SEVERAL authors have prevailed in court in recent years, after publishers rejected their manuscripts and demanded they return the advance. Last year, for example, a Federal court in New York dismissed a case in which Dell Publishing Company sued an author, Julia Whedon, to recover $14,000 in advances for a manuscript it eventually rejected as unsatisfactory. Recently, however, a Federal appeals court in Manhattan ordered the actor Tony Curtis to repay a $50,000 advance from Doubleday.

title: Assassin's Hearing Delayed
description: Arthur Bremer, who shot Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama at a 1972 Presidential campaign stop in Maryland, has delayed his parole hearing without giving a reason, William Kunkel, chairman of the state Parole Commission, said today. The hearing, Mr. Bremer's first, had been scheduled for Thursday. Mr. Bremer is serving a 53-year sentence. Mr. Wallace, who was paralyzed by the shooting, has said he would not object to Mr. Bremer's release.

title: Turner's Ad Teams Praised
description: IN a town full of media sales representatives, it is rare to hear those for one company singled out as being exceptionally good at their job.

title: Advice on the Air
description: An independent Washington radio station now has two psychiatrists giving advice on the air four evenings a week to people who telephone the station with their problems. The station, WNTR-AM, started operating in September and has had the two doctors on for the last month.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A MILE OF ART The Museum Mile Festival, back for the seventh year, will turn upper Fifth Avenue, between 84th and 105th Streets, into an Appian Way of culture today from 6 to 9 P.M. Not that the stretch, with its 10 prominent cultural institutions, is anything less at other times. But today, as happens once a year, this part of the avenue will be closed to pay homage to these special residents.

title: Stallions Defeat Gamblers, 29-27
description: Danny Miller kicked field goals of 47, 43 and 20 yards, and Cliff Stoudt dove 1 yard for a fourth-quarter touchdown to rally the Birmingham Stallions to a 29-27 victory over the Houston Gamblers tonight.

title: The Navy Is Promised A Refund for Ashtray
description: The Grumman Corporation said Sunday that it would give the Navy full credit for a $659 ashtray and two other aircraft parts whose prices were questioned, but insisted its charges ''accurately reflect'' costs under Government policy.

title: MEESE SAYS HE WILL ADVISE OBEDIENCE ON SPENDING RULES
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d announced today that he would advise Federal agencies to comply with disputed provisions of a 1984 law regulating Federal contracts, pending a ruling by a Federal appeals court.

title: 'TONY AWARDS' ON CBS, LIVE FROM SHUBERT
description: IS Broadway dying, or even dead? The television presentation of ''The Tony Awards'' couldn't seem to care less. Overseen by the husband-and-wife team of Alexander H. Cohen and Hildy Parks - he is the executive producer, she the writer-producer -the telecast is designed as a glossy commercial for the Broadway theater, a commercial that will reach a national audience for possible ticket sales in the future. The overall season may have been a bust but, with typical show-business pluck, the Tonys get out there and put on a happy face.

title: DISSIDENTS' TRIAL IN POLAND RESUMES
description: The trial of three dissidents charged with planning a general strike that never occurred resumed today amid an uproar.

title: Pilots Association Deplores Radio Interference
description: To the Editor:

title: Webster Plans Return
description: Marvin Webster, the Knicks' substitute center who missed the 1984-85 season because of hepatitis, said yesterday that he intended to try to play next season. Webster, looking fit at 240 pounds, 15 pounds less than his normal playing weight, spoke with Dave DeBusschere, who heads the Knicks' basketball operations, earlier in the day, then met with reporters to announce his intended comeback.

title: LATE MAY AUTO SALES DOWN 4.9%
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles slipped 4.9 percent in the last 10 days of May from the 1984 period, the manufacturers reported today. New light-truck sales fell 13.9 percent.

title: DANCE: ROBBINS'S 'FOUR SEASONS' AT CITY BALLET
description: AMONG the New York City Ballet's offerings at its Sunday performances at the New York State Theater were two affectionate looks at the past.

title: Salomon's Stake
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had bought a 5.1 percent stake in Multimedia Inc., for a total of about $45.6 million. Salomon Brothers told the S.E.C. it had bought the Multimedia shares ''in the ordinary course of its business in connection with its arbitrage activities.'' The investment firm purchased 844,869 Multimedia shares between April 1 and May 30, for prices ranging from $52.50 to $58.50 a share. Multimedia became a target for arbitrage when Jack Kent Cooke, a Washington investor, made an offer to buy the broadcasting firm, based in Greenville, S.C.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 4, 1985

title: SENATORS TO OFFER RESOLUTION TO BAR ARMS FOR JORDAN Israeli forces arrested dozens of men in raids on two Shiite Moslem villages in south Lebanon. Page A8.
description: Nearly 70 Senators will offer a resolution Tuesday declaring that advanced military equipment should not be sold to Jordan until it enters into direct negotiations with Israel, aides to the two main sponsors said today.

title: Lawyer in Escape Marries
description: Mary Evans, who as a Tennessee lawyer engineered the prison escape of a convict in 1983, has married the cousin of her ex-husband, court records showed today. Mrs. Evans, 28 years old, was married to William S. Evans of Pompano Beach, 35, on May 24, three months after she was paroled from her term for helping William Timothy Kirk escape.

title: Iowa Re-enters Credit Markets
description: The State of Iowa, which has not issued any debt since 1957 and has not had any issues outstanding since 1977, re-entered the credit markets yesterday with a $452 million issue of tax and revenue anticipation notes due June 30, 1986. The notes were tentatively offered with a yield of 5 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: WHAT NEXT IN GREECE?
description: Greek voters appear to have given Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou a license to continue on the course he set when he became the first leftist leader of his country.

title: GREENWICH HAUNTED BY A BOY'S MURDER
description: Time and again, new clues seemed destined to solve the mystery. ''Let's go,'' Detective Richard Haug would call excitedly to his partner. ''This is the break we've been waiting for.''

title: Arco Begins Debenture Sale
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, which is restructuring its finances, is offering $300 million of 11 1/8 percent sinking fund debentures due in 2015 at a price of 99 5/8 to yield 11.167 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Parks Dept. Sea Patrol
description: Boat owners, beware. The keepers of the land are striking out at the scofflaws of the sea.

title: RENT CURBS CALLED POLITICALLY ENTRENCHED
description: The housing shortage in New York City is in its 43d year of an ''emergency,'' and the legislative response, rent regulation, is as permanent as any economic policy enforced by the city or state.

title: The 410-Year Party
description: People who donate at least $150 to the Women's Campaign Fund have at least 17 options on how to spend this evening. The fund, an organization that raises money to put more women in public office, has arranged 17 dinner parties around town, each with a well-known host and hostess and guests including prominent politicians, public relations executives and journalists.

title: LOUNGING AROUND IN STYLE
description: Loungewear, a category of fashion that includes robes to slip into after you get out of the shower as well as those to wear in the evening when guests are coming for dinner, is receiving increased attention from designers, manufacturers and store executives. Now that blue jeans are no longer the all-purpose, all-hours mode of dressing for a considerable portion of the population, attention is returning to bathrobes, pajamas and caftans. Designers who have made their mark with clothes to be worn outside are turning their attention to those worn inside.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch on May 24 about Medals of Freedom misstated the number awarded posthumously by President Reagan. There were four, including one for Jerome Holland, an educator, ambassador and civil rights leader.

title: VON BULOW STATES HE WON'T TESTIFY
description: Claus von Bulow said today that he did not intend to take the witness stand at his trial here to refute the state's charges that he injected his wife, Martha, with insulin, hoping to kill her, inherit her money and marry his mistress.

title: Union for Meatpackers Declines Hormel's Offer
description: Union members have voted against a proposal to negotiate a new contract with the Hormel Company and a spokesman for the meatpacker said the vote raised doubts about continued operation here.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Oakland A's, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Second game in three-game series. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs.

title: DANCE: TWO NEW CASTS IN COPPELIA
description: THERE isn't much to work with in the characters of Enrique Martinez's production of ''Coppelia,'' but two casts of leads made a nice try in performances presented by the American Ballet Theater on Saturday at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: IRRATIONALITY, FUTILITY AND HUCK'S CENSORS
description: WHEN Mark Twain published the ''Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'' in 1885, the book had missed the previous year's Christmas sales because the protectors of public morals insisted that an ''indecent'' engraving be cut out of the first printing. Even after the offending illustration - a ''lecherous old rascal'' kissing a girl - had been removed, the public library in Concord, Mass., banished the book from its shelves. A Boston reviewer damned ''Huckleberry Finn'' as being ''very irreverent'' (which it was), and called it ''more profitable for the slums than it is for respectable people,'' and ''trash of the veriest sort.''

title: CANCER-KILLING SUBSTANCE MOVES TOWARD HUMAN TESTS
description: A RARE natural substance that has excited international interest because of its apparent ability to destroy cancer cells without harm to normal tissues will probably be tested in humans for the first time this year, scientists report.

title: Florida in Title Fight
description: The University of Florida still regards its 1984 football team as the Southeastern Conference champion and refuses to recognize a decision last week to strip the squad of its first conference title, the school's president, Marshall Criser, said today. Criser told a news conference that he has instructed campus attorneys to review ''every legal option open to us.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., Los Angeles, has promoted Kay M. Isaacson to senior vice president in its market services division.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: BEIRUT ABDUCTORS SEND PHOTO
description: A photograph of a kidnapped American hospital director was received by a foreign news agency here today, along with a statement from his abductors, the shadowy terrorist group known as Islamic Holy War.

title: THE RIGHT TYPE OF WORD PROCESSING
description: ONE rarely sees fistfights among people arguing the merits and demerits of different brands of toothpaste, socks or gasoline. Yet gather a group of otherwise mild-mannered reporters and writers, bring up the topic of word-processing programs, and take cover.

title: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
An Economist Gets Key Rothschild Job
description: Rothschild Inc., a Wall Street investment banking house, announced yesterday that Irwin M. Stelzer, an economist and consultant, had been named one of three managing directors.

title: DOW DECLINES 4.48 ON PROFIT TAKING
description: Profit taking took a bite out of blue-chip prices yesterday on Wall Street, but investors continued to show some interest in secondary, transportation and interest-sensitive issues.

title: N.B.A. to Consider Expansion
description: The National Basketball Association may be expanding. When the owners open their summer meetings June 23 in San Francisco, the agenda will include a plan that would add several teams for the 1987-88 season, Commissioner David Stern said yesterday.

title: 'HOT NEW GAME' IN FINANCING
description: A decade or so ago, when banks and thrift institutions were awash with mortgages, someone hit upon the idea of grouping the mortgages into pools and then selling shares in those pools. The technique gave bankers the cash to write still more mortgages, and it created a new security that ordinary investors could buy and sell.

title: JERSEY AIDES CRITICIZED ON PHOTO-LICENSE PLAN
description: The State Commission of Investigation today criticized key Kean administration officials for ''irresponsibility'' and ''stupidity'' in concealing the name of a prominent Republican contributor from the announcement of a drivers' photo-licensing program he was to conduct.

title: Agreement Is Reached On Shoreham Security
description: The Suffolk County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan, has agreed to drop his complaints about the security of the backup generators at the Shoreham nuclear power plant, the county attorney said today.

title: WHEN TEACHERS CAN'T SPEAK CLEAR ENGLISH
description: WHEN Mark W. Eichin showed up for his course in differential equations at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology this year, he found that his instructor was a Hindustani whose spoken English was ''almost incomprehensible.'' Along with most of his classmates, the freshman stopped attending lectures. ''People just got their assignments and left,'' he recalled.

title: 3 EX-PARK AIDES SAY SAFETY PLEAS WENT UNHEEDED
description: Three former shift managers of the Great Adventure amusement park's Haunted Castle, where eight teen-agers were killed in a fire last year, testified today that their pleas for safety precautions had been rejected by management as too expensive.

title: Analysts Skeptical
description: Oil industry analysts in the United States expressed doubts yesterday that OPEC would be able to keep world oil prices from falling.

title: ISRAELI UNITS RAID LEBANON VILLAGES
description: Israeli forces, backed by the militia known as the South Lebanon Army, raided two Shiite Moslem villages in south Lebanon today, demolishing five houses and arresting dozens of men, It was the third such sweep reported in the last several days in the so-called Israeli security zone. The zone, beginning just south of the mountain village of Jezzin, is an area that the Israelis hope will be controlled in its absence by the South Lebanon Army, which is commanded by a retired Lebanese Army general, Antoine Lahd.

title: Conflicting Rulings On Bid for T.W.A.
description: A federal judge issued a temporary restraining order barring enforcement of a state law passed last week to hinder Carl C. Icahn's bid to take over Trans World Airlines. Earlier, a state judge issued a temporary restraining order barring Mr. Icahn from buying more T.W.A. stock until June 17.

title: TURK'S '80 TRAVELS FIGURE IN PAPAL-PLOT TRIAL
description: Testimony in the trial of eight men accused of plotting the assassination of Pope John Paul II turned again today to the travels of one of the five Turkish defendants, Omer Bagci.

title: 9.9% Stake Bought In Cluett, Peabody
description: A group headed by William Brodovsky, a California lawyer, has notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has acquired or optioned 9.9 percent of the common stock of Cluett, Peabody & Company, a leading apparel producer, and may seek a leveraged buyout of the company.

title: LTX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $384,000.

title: Letter: On Immigration;   Why the Simpson Bill Has No Cosponsor
description: To the Editor:

title: REPORT BY CUBA IS CANDID ON ECONOMIC BURDENS
description: A report by the Cuban National Bank, made public today, disclosed that Moscow pays Havana 10 times the world price of sugar as part of its long-term support for the Fidel Castro Government.

title: NEW, AUTHENTIC EDITION OF FAULKNER NOVELS SET
description: Corrected versions of four major novels by William Faulkner, coming out this November, are expected to clarify some of his themes and fortify his reputation as a careful writer.

title: MORTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $2,030,000. c-After a nonrecurrring charge of $7,181,000.

title: A CHAMPION'S PREDICAMENT
description: Wherever Michael Spinks searches for a meaningful opponent, up or down, the view is similar to Moses' of the Promised Land. The undisputed and undefeated light-heavyweight champion can look all he wants, but he can't touch.

title: Addendum
description: * Young & Rubicam has acquired a majority interest in GSI Advertising, Auckland, New Zealand.

title: STAGE: 'SUBMARINERS,' COMEDY AT HUDSON GUILD
description: THE sailors in ''Submariners,'' a new comedy by Tom McClenaghan at the Hudson Guild Theater, keep trying to frighten one another with tales of submarines that went to the bottom. It is a bit foolhardy of the playwright to conjure up such an image in a play with material that is so fragile, if not flimsy. One sailor, fed up with duty on a nuclear submarine, decides the way to get out of the navy is to pretend he is a homosexual, and another determines his way out is to fake lunacy. So you assume that, this being billed as a comedy by an author with much more naval experience than theatrical, a third will turn out to be really homosexual and a fourth will go bonkers - and they do.

title: Oil Troubles For Russians
description: WHILE the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is trying to put pressure on its members to hold production down, the world's biggest oil producer, the Soviet Union, is struggling to maintain its output.

title: JAPANESE CHIP DUMPING CITED
description: At least one Japanese company is ''dumping'' semiconductors in the United States market, a high-ranking American trade official charged today.

title: MUSICAL EVENINGS
description: The 10th annual Summer Evenings Series at Sarah Lawrence College will begin with performances by the Tokyo String Quartet on June 13 and 14 at 8 P.M. in Reisinger Concert Hall. The Sarah Lawrence Woodwind Quintet will give an outdoor performance before the concert. Reservations: (914) 337-0700, extension 412.

title: 'VAN GOGH IN ARLES' AIDED CITY, MET FINDS
description: Out-of-town visitors to the Metropolitan Museum's exhibition ''Van Gogh in Arles'' last fall spent approximately $223 million on goods and services during their stay in the city, according to a survey commissioned by the museum.

title: FOREST REGENERATION BY FIRE FIZZLES IN ITS COLORADO TEST
description: The Forest Service dropped napalm on its woods near here today in the first attempt in a growing effort to regenerate aging forests through manmade forest fires.

title: MARIEL BOATMEN FACING FINES
description: The United States Government is filing a battery of lawsuits demanding more than $100 million in fines from boat captains who ferried 125,000 Cubans to Florida's shores in 1980, Federal officials said today.

title: DIAGNOSTIC-RETRIEVAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jersey Bonus Increased
description: Offering a $2 million bonus to any horse that won the 1985 Kentucky Derby and a three-race series at Garden State Park was a great publicity gimmick with little risk for the track's owner, Robert Brennan.

title: BOB EVANS FARMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
Momentous Decision
description: Martina Navratilova says she may quit tennis competition at the end of the 1986 tour.

title: Yields Drop Again In Late Trading
description: Interest rates declined yesterday, though at a slower rate than the two previous trading sessions. Since Thursday, yields on 30-year Treasury bonds have fallen to 10.31 percent from 10.69 percent, while the rate for three-month Treasury bills is down to 6.94 percent from 7.18 percent.

title: GOODEN FANS 12, TOPS VALENZUELA
description: They held the big return match here tonight, and this time Dwight Gooden outpitched Fernando Valenzuela, struck out 12 batters, got three hits himself and led the Mets to a 4-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Carroll Report
description: The Milwaukee Bucks are planning to make a lucrative offer to the free-agent center Joe Barry Carroll, The Milwaukee Journal reported. The 7-foot Carroll played in Italy this season after being unable to reach a contract with the Golden State Warriors.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 5, 1985

title: YANKEES ARE FOILED BY THEIR CASTOFFS
description: The long, dry game finally had its moment: Bottom of the ninth, bases loaded, two outs, and the big names in the big trade facing one another, Jay Howell of the A's versus Rickey Henderson of the Yankees.

title: BALLET THEATER: A SURPRISE 'SWAN LAKE'
description: WONDERS never cease.

title: Mexico Drops 427 Agents
description: The Government said today that 427 federal security agents had been dismissed in a continuing campaign against police corruption.

title: DRUG FIGHT BY MILITARY URGED
description: Gen. Paul F. Gorman, the former commander of United States armed forces in Latin America, said today that some specialized units of the armed forces could be used to help block narcotics traffic into the United States.

title: Mortgage Agency Sells Certificates
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation is offering $130 million of 15-year mortgage participation certificates with a coupon of 10 1/2 percent at a price of 99 1/2 to yield 10.33 percent, assuming the 15-year mortgages have an average life of seven years. The yield at yesterday's sale was down from 10.76 percent at a similar offering on May 22.

title: Dormitory Authority Sets Student Loan Issue
description: The New York State Dormitory Authority is financing student loans for the first time, issuing $70 million of tax-exempt bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Loans under the new program will have an effective cost of 12 percent with a 15-year life, and will be available to students at state and city universities as well as 40 private colleges in New York.

title: BELDEN & BLAKE ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bitburg and Leaving Well Enough Alone
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: SETA KARAKASHIAN IN PEIANO RECITAL
description: UNTIL she began to play, everything about Seta Karakashian's piano recital Monday at Merkin Concert Hall was calculated to make a listener's spirits sink. Tiny audience; sub-minimal program listing (does the composer Babagianian have a first name? What are Grieg's ''Six Poetic Tone-Pictures'' pictures of?); no program notes at all.

title: FABRI-CENTERS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: b-Net income.

title: Larchmont Curbs Gardening Noise
description: The Westchester County village of Larchmont has decided to regulate noise levels for gardening equipment in the summer because of complaints by residents that the machines were too loud, village officials said today.

title: Reflections on 40 Years In the Police World
description: In the 40 years since Patrick V. Murphy became a patrolman in Brooklyn, he has walked a lot of different beats.

title: SENATE PANEL BACKS ANTI-APARTHEID BILL
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved legislation today that would ban bank loans to the South African Government and the sale of computers to the military, the police and other agencies that enforce the apartheid system. The vote was 16 to 1. The preliminary approval of the proposal was the strongest Senate action to date against South Africa's policy of apartheid. The margin of the vote suggested that the bill has a good chance of approval in the full Senate.

title: Browns Drop White
description: He was good enough at Southern California to win the Heisman Trophy in 1979, but as a pro, Charles White never quite lived up to his promise. Yesterday, the 27-year-old running back was waived by the Cleveland Browns to make room for more promising players. ''Because of the talent we have at running back, I don't believe Charles has a great chance to contribute to our team,'' said the Browns' coach, Marty Schottenheimer, citing the signing of Kevin Mack from the Los Angeles Express and the drafting of Greg Allen from Florida State.

title: BLACKS FIGHT FOR MARKET NICHE
description: Black producers of hair-care products say these should be robust days. After all, a large percentage of their principal clientele, black consumers, have become more affluent, and are using more hair-care products than ever. Moreover, recent industry figures indicate that blacks individually spend three to four times more on such products than whites - with black spending reaching an estimated total of $2.3 billion last year.

title: HOSTILE QUESTIONS GREET NOMINEE FOR JUSTICE DEPT. POST AT HEARING
description: William Bradford Reynolds, the Reagan Administration's nominee to be Associate Attorney General, today faced hostile questioning from Democratic senators who criticized his stewardship of the Justice Department's civil rights division and charged he had ''sided with the bigots'' in one case.

title: DANCE 'TRISTEZA' HONORS LATE GERMAN PERFORMER
description: FACULTY members and alumni of New York University's Department of Dance and Dance Education offered a concert Friday night at the University Theater, 35 West Fourth Street. Their program was varied, but only intermittently interesting.

title: FORMER PARK EMPLOYEE SAYS STAFFING AT FIRE SITE WAS LOW
description: A former employee of the Great Adventure amusement park testified today that only one worker, rather than the usual five, had been stationed inside the Haunted Castle attraction when it burned and killed eight teen-agers last year.

title: HENNING MAY GET POST WITH CANUCKS
description: Lorne Henning, a member of the Islanders' first two Stanley Cup championship teams and the coach of the team's American Hockey League affiliate in Springfield, Mass., said yesterday that he was close to signing a contract to become head coach of the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Austin Will Not Shift
description: Austin, Nichols & Company, distiller of Wild Turkey bourbon and importer of wine, after a month reviewing its agency situation, has decided to stay with its old shop. And that is Calvillo, Shevack, Goldberg & Partners, formerly Nadler & Larimer, and one of the Mickelberry companies.

title: Former Esty Executive Back to Fill New Post
description: After a nine-year absence, William C. Seaman, 56, is returning to the William Esty Company for a newly created job, executive vice president, director of broadcast communications.

title: Jab for a Job
description: George McPhee begs to differ with the proposition that nothing good ever comes out of a hockey fight. McPhee, the heavily penalized left wing of the Rangers, engaged so ardently in a first-period donnybrook against the Devils at the Garden on March 17 that he was ejected.

title: WHITE HOUSE TELLS NICARAGUA TO STOP 'AGGRESSIVE' MOVES
description: The White House condemned Nicaragua today for what it called ''increased aggressive behavior'' against neighboring Honduras and Costa Rica.

title: THE TENNIS HUSTLER IS BACK
description: Five young women wearing smiles and not much else escorted Bobby Riggs and Vitas Gerulaitis to the lectern on cue. Twelve years ago, these women, who are cheerleaders for the Generals, were approaching adolescence and the women's rights movement was gathering momentum. Twelve years ago, Riggs's escorts all wore shirts that said ''Sugar Daddies,'' and talked as if auditioning for the role of Marilyn Monroe. Until yesterday, it was thought that Riggs had made his final contribution to women's rights and women's tennis.

title: A FEAST IN MEMORY OF JAMES BEARD
description: IT was culinary paradise, the Ninth Avenue food festival raised to gastronomic heights, a chance to sample the wares of 14 chefs, among the best known and most talented in the country. They were collected together Monday evening on the lower plaza at Rockefeller Center for a dazzling culinary tribute to the memory of James Beard and for the benefit of what was one of Mr. Beard's favorite charities, Citymeals-on-Wheels, which brings weekend and holiday meals to the homebound elderly in New York City.

title: First Move at Nuclear Plant
description: The first major phase of the restarting of the undamaged nuclear reactor at the Three Mile Island electric plant is scheduled to begin Thursday evening, and it could begin producing power next Tuesday for the first time in more than six years. Lawyers for Gov. Dick Thornburgh and two antinuclear groups, however, have asked a Federal appeals court to block the move pending a challenged to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission vote that allowed it.

title: GULF & WESTERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $100,000 for the quarter and $1,000,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $23,700,000 for the quarter and $3,500,000 for the 9 months, and a gain of $32,700,000 for the 9 months form the sale of marketable securities.

title: Benjamin H. Oehlert Jr., 75; Former Coca-Cola Executive
description: Benjamin Hilborn Oehlert Jr., a former Coca-Cola executive, died here Sunday at the age of 75.

title: 9 MORE HOTELS ARE STRUCK; UNIONS SAYS SUPPORT WIDENS
description: Nine more New York City hotels were struck yesterday, increasing the total to 55 in the fourth day of the walkout by bellhops, clerks, housekeepers, bartenders and other workers.

title: GETTING THE BEST TABLE: A SCRAMBLE FOR FAVOR
description: IT is 9 on a weekday night at Petaluma and the scene is as hot as a mesquite grill. A tall blond woman in a black jump suit holds a clipboard scribbled with names of customers who are waiting three deep at the bar in this animated new Italian restaurant at First Avenue and 73d Street. Three men in their early 30's, wearing dark suits, white shirts loosened at the collar and expressions of subdued awe, scan the premises.

title: EPA SEEKS SHIFT IN FIGHT ON TOXIC AIR POLLUTION
description: State and local agencies would take over the regulation of many toxic pollutants under a ''national strategy'' announced today by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: WALKER'S EX-WIFE SAYS SHE INFORMED F.B.I.
description: The former wife of John A. Walker Jr. said in an interview today that she informed the Federal Bureau of Investigation of her husband's alleged spying for the Soviet Union, an action that also led to the arrest of her son.

title: Gateway to Brooklyn
description: A 50-foot-high steel arch, its red girders rising five stories above the small plaza at the entrance to the downtown Brooklyn campus of Long Island University, was dedicated yesterday after an 18-year effort to place it there.

title: EPIDEMIC OF NUPTIALS AT MILITARY CHAPELS
description: In the narrow gap between commissioning and reporting for duty, around the end of May and the beginning of June, marriage-minded Air Force Academy graduates parade through the chapel with the precision of the formation march. At least 30 weddings are crammed into five days. One day there were 11, starting at 8 A.M., with times out for tourists to visit the chapel.

title: Gandhi Sees Slim Hope For Bhopal Settlement
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi said in New Delhi yesterday that the chances are slim at present for an out-of-court settlement with the Union Carbide Corporation over the pesticide leak at the company's Bhopal factory last Dec. 3.

title: Trans-Canada Series
description: To the Editor:

title: THE G.O.P. IS FOOLING ITSELF
description: Today, the Republican Party is crowing about the prominent Democrats who have joined the G.O.P. Tomorrow, it may eat crow.

title: U.S. BEGINS EXPORT AID IN GRAIN SALE TO ALGERIA
description: The Reagan Administration, responding to what it calls unfair trade practices by the European Economic Community, today announced the first sale of commodities to a foreign country under its new export subsidy program.

title: Landlord Guilty In Fire Deaths
description: A Superior Court judge today found a Waterbury landlord guilty of criminally negligent homicide in a 1984 fire that killed eight people.

title: The Embassy Cup
description: Without benefit of moat or mob, the capital is enjoying international soccer on a pastoral level these days as 30 embassies and world organizations compete for the Embassy Cup. The competition is taking place on the Mall, near the Lincoln Memorial, with loyalists lolling and picnicking in the shade while teams of embassy clerks and statesmen romp diplomatically.

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The bank is listed on the Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HEART RECIPIENT SUFFERS A STROKE BUT MAKES A DRAMATIC RECOVERY
description: Murray P. Haydon, who was described as the ''perfect'' candidate for the artificial heart when he received it Feb. 17, suffered a stroke late Monday night but made ''a dramatic recovery'' in the hours thereafter, his doctors said yesterday.

title: IN JAPAN, A NEW CACHET FOR AN OLD DRINK
description: MASUKO ITO, who runs a small bar in Yokohama, had no intention of ever selling the stuff. ''It did not fit our shop's style,'' she said, her voice coated with a thin layer of hauteur. But customers kept insisting, and about a year ago Mrs. Ito and her husband, Hiroshi, broke down and finally added it to their drink list. Now, she says, it accounts for about 60 percent of her business.

title: AEQUITRON MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $230,000.

title: Lessons in China
description: Maybe it's jet lag, or perhaps those funny Chinese baseballs, but C. W. Post's championship baseball team, which is on a tour of China to help instruct the locals about the niceties of the game, got another lesson in their national pastime, this time a 4-3 defeat by a Sichuan team. The loss, following a 6-4 seminar conducted by a Peking team on Monday, has produced some consternation among the visitors.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DRAWING ON VENICE The Drawing Center, in SoHo at 137 Greene Street, near Houston Street (982-5266), is a long way in distance and style from Venice's Museo Correr. But the Venetian spirit infuses the center with the exhibition ''Drawings From Venice: Masterworks from the Museo Correr.''

title: MCENROE PRESSED, REACHES SEMIFINAL
description: Playing on his least-favorite surface and in a tournament no American man has won for 30 years, John McEnroe was pressed to reach the semifinals of the French Open tennis championships today. Down by 3-1 in the fifth set, he recovered to overcome a stubborn challenge from Joakim Nystrom of Sweden.

title: CITY STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $666,000. c-After a loss of $143,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $8,000. The company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: Promotion for a Hero
description: Paul Ragonese says he was no hero.

title: POLL SHOWS MOST AMERICANS SEE REAGAN TAX PLAN AS FAIR
description: A broadly based majority of Americans believe President Reagan's proposal on tax revision would treat most people fairly, even though two adults in five say they expect to pay higher taxes if the plan is enacted, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: THE CONSERVANCY CIRCLE HOLDS ITS FIRST MEETING
description: Everyone had a horror story to tell. From her bedroom window, Judith Zabar remembered watching a wrecking ball across the street smash the stained glass windows of a church - which was soon replaced by a high-rise apartment building. Others told of historic buildings removed for ''luxury housing,'' and of beautiful brownstones turned in a twinkling to parking lots.

title: MILITARY CHIEFS FAVOR ABIDING BY SOVIET PACT
description: American military leaders, in a split with Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, have concluded that the United States would probably lose more than it would gain by abandoning the 1979 arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Toxic Dumpers Don't Deserve a Super Bailout
description: To the Editor:

title: Spanish Unions Rally Against Pension Cuts
description: Spain's Socialist-led labor union broke ranks tonight with the Government for the first time by holding nationwide protests against proposed pension changes.

title: F.C.C. Approves Taft-Gulf Deal
description: The Taft Broadcasting Company said it had obtained Federal Communications Commission approval to buy the assets and licenses of five television stations and four radio stations from the Gulf Broadcast Company of Dallas. The deal is still subject to approval by Gulf stockholders, who are to meet on June 19.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Alabama State Docks Department has sold $118 million of refunding revenue bonds to institutional investors through Merrill Lynch. Yields ranged from 6.50 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 10 percent in 1996 and 10.23 percent in 2005.

title: CHARMING SHOPPES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
Analysts' View of Aluminum
description: AT a time when stock prices over all are setting record highs, the investment community shows limited enthusiasm for shares of aluminum producers - a group that typically performs best at the start of an economic expansion cycle. The current cycle is now midway through its third year.

title: CITY AGENCY AGREES TO ALLOW AUTO RACE IN FLUSHING MEADOW
description: The Parks Department and promoters of a Formula One Grand Prix auto race reached an agreement yesterday that all but clears the way for the race to be held in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in September.

title: DURO-TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
PREPARING HOMEMADE BABY FOOD
description: INSTEAD of going to the store for baby food, an increasing number of parents seem to be preparing it at home. Occasionally, such parents ask me to recommend recipes that will keep the children interested in - and eating -their meals.

title: TIT-FOT-TAT DIPLOMACY WITH THE MEXICANS
description: When the Soviet Government restricted the freedom of American diplomats to travel outside of Moscow some years ago, the United States adopted a similar set of restrictions curbing Soviet diplomats' travel outside of Washington.

title: REBOUNDING EDGE SPURRING LAKERS
description: In the two days since the Los Angeles Lakers took a 2-1 lead in the National Basketball Association championship series by routing the Boston Celtics in Game 3, most of the talk here has not centered on basketball. Nothing about fast breaks and defenses, key matchups and coaching strategies.

title: TURNER BROADCASTING TO SHOW SOVIET PROGRAMS
description: The Turner Broadcasting System will soon begin showing news, entertainment and sports programming provided by the Soviet Union, a company official said yesterday.

title: Let Connecticut Turnpike Tollbooths Stay
description: To the Editor:

title: Local Cops Might Be Better Cops
description: Would New York be better policed if all officers had to reside in the city, more directly sharing its burdens and achievements? Six of every ten already do, and seven of ten recruits plan to. Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward wants to make it a rule for all new officers. Phil Caruso, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, thinks the idea is ''theoretically very impressive'' but ultimately ''misleading.''

title: GEODYNE RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company said that losses for the periods were reduced primarily because of a non-cash $250,000 writedown of the carrying costs of the company's oil and gas properties in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1985 compared with a similar $3,200,000 writedown in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1984.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ONE of the earliest lessons children are taught about socially acceptable behavior is that there is a proper time and place for the elimination of body wastes. Somewhere between the ages of 2 and 3, most children learn to control elimination most of the time. While occasional accidents are common and accepted in early childhood, beyond the preschool years incontinence is nearly always cause for humiliation and distress.

title: American League;   Upshaw's Homer Helps Blue Jays Win
description: Willie Upshaw hit a two-run homer to highlight Toronto's three-run fourth inning, and Jim Clancy scattered four hits over eighth innings tonight to lead the Blue Jays to a 9-2 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

title: SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After tax credits of $305,000 for the quarter and $381,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income The company said the latest 6 months' earnings include a gain of $969,000 from the sale in January of a division and the year-ago period's operating and final net figures were restated to reflect a gain of $1.5 million on a change in tax laws affecting the company's domestic international sales corporation.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amax Inc., Greenwich, Conn., said it would close two molybdenum mines in the Colorado Rocky Mountains for nine weeks beginning in July, affecting about 1,200 workers.

title: Bees Besiege Moore
description: Archie Moore fought Muhammad Ali back when Ali was known as Cassius Clay, but now Moore knows what it's like to be stung by a real bee.

title: RECITAL: PIANIST, GREGORY TABOLOFF, PRESENTS DEBUT
description: THE most immediately notable aspect of the pianist Gregory Taboloff's playing is his irrepressible energy. Everything Mr. Taboloff played in his Sunday afternoon debut concert at Carnegie Recital Hall - two miniatures by Scarlatti, Beethoven's Sonata in E flat (Op. 31, No. 3), the first book of Debussy's ''Images,'' Chopin's Scherzo in B flat and Rachmaninoff's ''Variations on a Theme of Corelli'' (Op. 42) - was charged with fresh, bristling spirit.

title: VIOLENCE ON TV SPURS INCREASED ADULT SUPERVISION
description: THE show is violent but the children are determined to watch, so what is a parent to do? Turn off the televised beatings, murders, knives, guns, chains, fires, cars hurtling off cliffs and victims being thrown out of airplanes, or simply turn away? Although definitive links are hard to establish, psychologists and other authorities in the field generally accept that watching violence on television can affect the way children view the world and the way they relate to others, that it can anesthetize their responses to cruelty and suffering or make them excessively fearful.

title: Norman Recalls the High Points
description: TO present awards at Avery Fisher Hall last night for the introductions of Warner Cosmetics' Paloma Picasso for women and Cosmair's Drakkar Noir for men, the Fragrance Foundation made an inspired selection. It chose Norman B. Norman; while he never was in the cosmetics business himself, as an agency man he had many clients that were, Revlon for one. Chanel for another. Shulton for a third.

title: Suspect Given Trial Delay
description: A judge has granted Llewellen G. Fickes, the brother of Senator Paula Hawkins, Republican of Florida, another month to prepare his defense to charges of sexually abusing three girls. Mr. Fickes had been scheduled for trial Monday, but Judge Allen Babineaux of District Court granted an additional 30 days to prepare for the case, a court clerk said.

title: People
description: * Allan D. Kellam and Scott J. Messinger have been appointed senior vice presidents at Ted Bates Advertising.

title: The Fountain of Hammer
description: Armand Hammer, the industrial patriarch, art patron and global optimist, has been asked by the Chinese to share the ultimate in technology, the fountain of youth. The 87-year-old chairman of Occidental Petroleum Corporation smiled at the request from Han Xu, the new Chinese Ambassador, who lifted his glass in a toast the other night at the Corcoran Gallery.

title: Talks Sought by U.S. In United Airlines Strike
description: The National Mediation Board today sent out a call for negotiations to resume Thursday in Washington in the nearly three-week-old pilots' strike against United Airlines.

title: G.&W. Net Increases 49.4%
description: Gulf and Western Industries reported yesterday that net income for the latest quarter rose 49.4 percent, to $53.8 million, or 76 cents a share, from $36 million, or 53 cents a share, reflecting the absence of a $23.7 million charge taken last year for discontinued operations. Revenue increased to $1.2 billion from $1.1 billion.

title: FED BACKS BANK SALE OF PAPER
description: In a major decision that could open the door for a number of money-center banks to enter the commercial paper market, the Federal Reserve Board decided today that the Bankers Trust Company could continue to sell commercial paper.

title: STOCKS LIFTED BY INSTITUTIONAL BUYING
description: Institutional buying late yesterday helped the stock market finish with moderate gains that were big enough to push certain key market indicators back into record territory.

title: Navy Lists General Dynamics' Gifts to Rickover
description: The Navy released today a detailed accounting of more than $67,628 in gifts given by the General Dynamics Corporation to Adm. Hyman Rickover over 16 years.

title: HUMANITARIAN (?) AID TO THE 'CONTRAS'
description: In coming weeks, the Administration will again ask Congress to appropriate funds for the ''contras.'' If, as before, the President cannot marshal enough backing for direct military assistance, he will try to reach a compromise on what is euphemistically being labeled ''humanitarian aid.'' In fact, it would be nothing of the sort -and would at best only postpone the issue of what to do with the contras.

title: Romantic Renewal
description: She grew up in Sussex. He came from Hell's Kitchen. She attended Oxford. He went to N.Y.U. She parachuted into occupied France as a radio operator with British intelligence.

title: BANKAMERICA EXPECTS A BREAK-EVEN QUARTER
