description: In another stunning report of mounting loan losses, the BankAmerica Corporation said yesterday that it expected its operating results to ''be near the break-even point in the second quarter.''

title: THREE DATES, TWO PROMS AND ONE MOM
description: IT is happening all over the country. Parents are being screamed at by children who are casting gimlet eyes over front halls that must be shaped up (like their parents) before the doorbell rings. Little brothers, threatening to sabotage their sister's big evening by appearing downstairs in their underpants, are being strong-armed into broom closets. At the last minute, a zipper breaks. (''God's always dumping on me!'' wails the victim.) Everyone's emotional inner tube is about to pop. It is the night of the prom.

title: DYNEER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FERRI JOINS BALLET THEATER
description: Alessandra Ferri, a principal dancer with the Royal Ballet of Britain, has joined the American Ballet Theater as a principal dancer.

title: A.T.&T., Mercury
description: The Cable and Wireless Company said its subsidiary, Mercury Communications Ltd., had reached agreement with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to provide satellite telecommunications services between Britain and the United States.

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: b-After a loss of $1,657,000 from discontinued operations and a nonrecurring charge of $9,300,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $540,000 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $6,000 for the 6 months.

title: BRUCE CRANE
description: Bruce Crane, chairman of the company that makes the paper used by the United States Treasury, died Sunday at the Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield.

title: NO-PAROLE BILL ADVANCES IN ASSEMBLY
description: For the first time in seven years, the Assembly is expected to bring to a vote this session a bill that would allow some murderers to be sentenced to life in prison without parole.

title: 6 BUSINESS CHIEFS ENDORSE TAX PLAN
description: Six chief executive officers, specially selected to be the first business leaders to testify before Congress on President Reagan's tax revision proposal, endorsed the plan today and said it would benefit not only their companies but the economy as a whole.

title: BITBURG AND LEAVING WELL ENOUGH ALONE
description: To the Editor:

title: SPY INQUIRY GROWS AS 2 DENY CHARGES
description: John A. Walker Jr. and his 22-year-old son, accused of smuggling secret Navy documents to the Soviet Union, pleaded not guilty today to charges of espionage.

title: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 5, 1985
description: Companies

title: FOREST CITY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Philadelphia Revenue Bonds
description: Philadelphia is offering $90 million of gas works revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8.79 percent for bonds due in 2015, through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: Chase in Ohio
description: The Federal Reserve Board said it had approved the Chase Manhattan Corporation's application to convert six savings and loans in Ohio into one consolidated commercial bank, the Chase Bank of Mentor, near Cleveland. The new bank will operate 22 branches in the Cincinnati, Columbus and Cleveland areas.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: SINCE she was 2 weeks old, Sarah Goldstein, now 20 months, has gone along to the tour office of which her mother is a co-owner.

title: FINAL EVENT: OLYMPIC READING
description: Peter Ueberroth, former president of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee, today presented to the International Olympic Committee a copy of his final official report on the Los Angeles Games. The report says the Games, the first to be financed entirely through private funds, made a profit of $215 million by last September - with more money coming in.

title: MEDTRONIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,645,000 for the quarter and $8,648,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $256,000 for the quarter and $1,381,000 for the year. Results for the latest quarter are after a charge of $12,000,000 in part to cover costs associated with discontinuing the Medical Data Systems division.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For me, the battle is over. But prayer will go on in the schools.

title: FOR WINE BUFFS WITH A NEED FOR NEWS, THE INDUSTRY OBLIGES
description: GOOD news for wine lovers who like to stay tuned to the grapevine: newsletters are available free. In states where grapes are grown and wine is made - among them California, New York, Washington, Oregon, Ohio, Idaho, Virginia, Connecticut and Pennsylvania - vineyards mail informative, entertaining newsletters for the asking. A sampling suggests that marketing may not be the sole motive, and that education ranks high.

title: OAKLAND PUBLISHER IN UPHILL STRUGGLE
description: In 1983 a black journalist with a national reputation and no money purchased The Tribune, the unprofitable newspaper based in this ethnically diverse city.

title: ISSUES IN HOTEL STRIKE
description: Participants - The Hotel and Motel Trades Council, a nine-union coalition representing 25,000 bellhops, housekeepers, clerks, chefs, waiters, bartenders and other employees of 165 hotels in New York City, has struck 55 hotels and says that its workers have been locked out of 2 others.

title: Theory of Deduction
description: The Spectrum in Philadelphia is delaying a $25 million renovation plan until Congress acts on President Reagan's tax package, which would eliminate tax breaks for corporations purchasing sports tickets. ''It's on the back-burner until we hear about the tax bill,'' said Ed Snider, who owns the arena and the Philadelphia Flyers hockey team. The tax plan would eliminate sports events as tax-deductible business entertainment, effectively cutting a major revenue source for teams and arenas.

title: JORDAN ARMS CURB CALLED DANGEROUS
description: A resolution was introduced in the Senate today opposing sales of advanced arms to Jordan until the Amman Government actually opened negotiations with Israel. The Reagan Administration immediately criticized the measure as ''a serious mistake'' that could jeopardize prospects for Middle East peace.

title: Not Dad's Fault
description: When Ozzie Virgil Jr. accounted for all the Philadelphia runs with two homers in a 3-2 victory Monday night in San Diego, Ozzie Sr., the Padres' third-base coach, got a little defensive: ''I taught him how to approach hitting when he was a kid, but tonight's not my fault.''

title: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: Results for the latest quarter are after a charge of $3,500,000 related to the Salmonella outbreak associated with the company's Jewel subsidiary in Chicago as well as the closing of Jewel's Hillfarm Dairy. The company said quarter-to-quarter sales figures are not comparable since the figure for the year-ago quarter does not include the acquisition of Jewel Cos. in fiscal 1984.

title: APPLIED SOLAR ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $133,000. c-Net income which includes extraordinary gains of $404,000 for the quarter and $740,000 for the 6 months.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 5, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Science and Technology - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: GILBERT AND SULLIVAN'S 'SORCERER'
description: PUBLIC television's ''Compleat Gilbert and Sullivan,'' another import from Britain, has had a problem in settling on a cohesive style. Too often, it has brought forth something resembling a parody on the parodies, which can get merely silly. However, tonight's installment on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock fares surprisingly well.

title: SYMPHONIE FANTASTIQUE,' LED BY MUTI, ON PBS
description: THE premier difficulty that faces any conductor who leads Hector Berlioz's ''Symphonie Fantastique'' is how to reconcile the composer's wild-eyed Romanticism with his paradoxical bent toward Classical serenity. Anyone who highlights yin at the expense of yang can only hope to reveal one facet of a complex creator.

title: HOW TO RECRUIT A U.S. SPY, IN 3 STAGES
description: Spread over a convention floor here today, military contractors displayed some of the nation's most advanced communications technology.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Oakland A's, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Finale of three-game series and the homestand. Tomorrow, the Yankees began a four-game series in Milwaukee before returning to Yankee Stadium next Monday. (Television -SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Dodgers, at Los Angeles. The Mets wrap up an eight-game road swing and will be home Friday to face the Cardinals. (Television - Channel 9, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 10:30 P.M.) Cubs vs. Atlanta Braves, at Chicago (Television - WTBS, 2:05 P.M.) College: National Collegiate Athletic Association College World Series, Miami vs. Texas, at Omaha. (Television -ESPN, 8 P.M.) Basketball Los Angeles Lakers vs. Boston Celtics, at Inglewood, Calif. The fourth game of the four-of-seven National Basketball Association championship series. (Television - Channel 2, 9 P.M.) Boxing Tyrone (Butterfly) Crawley vs. Charlie (Choo Choo) Brown, 12 rounds, for the vacant United States Boxing Association lightweight title, at Resorts International Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City. First preliminary, 8:30 P.M. Crawley, of Philadelphia, is 18-1 with 6 knockouts. He is the World Boxing Association's No. 1 contender. Brown, another Philadelphian, is 24-4-2 with 17 knockouts. (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M.) Tennis French Open, at Paris. Men's quarterfinals. (Television - USA Network, 8 P.M., same-day tape.) New York State Championships for Women, at Beach Point Club, Mamaroneck, N.Y., noon, semifinals, doubles and singles.

title: TRANSFORMING A WEST VILLAGE WAREHOUSE INTO OFFICES
description: THE area around the newly renovated 117,000-square-foot office building at 96 Morton Street in the West Village does not look or sound much like an office district. Diesel engines roar, trailer trucks rumble over the streets and an air wrench screams as a worker at the tire repair shop on the corner unbolts a wheel from a sanitation truck. Around the corner stands a wholesale meat outlet and across the street are five-story walk-up cooperative apartments.

title: Asset Sale Set By Coca-Cola
description: The Coca-Cola Company said that it would sell about $750 million of its financial assets in its entertainment sector. Thomas E. Gray, a spokesman, said the company had not determined how the funds would be used: ''We're taking a look at reinvesting it into one of our companies.

title: INSPECTORS FIND CODE VIOLATIONS AT 18 MORE SITES
description: City inspectors have found infractions at 18 more construction sites as they continued the emergency inspections ordered after a crane fell and seriously injured a pedestrian last Thursday, officials said yesterday.

title: A Puerto Rican Bishop Named for Washington
description: The first Puerto Rican-born Roman Catholic bishop on the United States mainland was appointed today by Pope John Paul II, who assigned him to be an auxiliary bishop in Washington.

title: MOSCOW IS OPPOSED TO AMENDING 1972ABM TREATY FOR 'STAR WARS'
description: A top Soviet military leader said today that the Soviet Union would oppose any effort to revise the 1972 ABM treaty to accommodate the United States' new space-based defense technologies.

title: HIGH COURT UPSETS MOMENT'S SILENCE FOR PUPIL PRAYER
description: Reaffirming its insistence that ''government must pursue a course of complete neutrality toward religion,'' the Supreme Court today struck down an Alabama law that permitted a daily one-minute period of silent meditation or prayer in the public schools. The vote was 6 to 3.

title: NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
A Lawyer's Visa
description: Kenneth R. Thomas says he can hardly wait to get away from lawyering in the Federal bureaucracy and begin an exotic, escapist vacation this month trekking through northern India. The trouble is he has not yet been able to obtain a visa, and he fears that this is precisely because he is a lawyer and Indian officials are on guard against an invasion of American attorneys looking to exploit the toxic chemical leak in Bhopal.

title: SENATE REJECTS A $1.1 BILLION CUT IN BUDGET OF ANTIMISSILE PROGRAM
description: The Senate tonight rejected an effort to slice $1.1 billion from President Reagan's proposal to build an antimissile shield to defend the United States.

title: The Keeper of the Door And Other House Parts
description: He is a large, rotund man who stands in the rear of the House chamber during joint sessions of Congress and bellows the titles of those entering the chamber, ultimately proclaiming, ''Mr. Speaker, the President of the United States.''

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: CHRIS-CRAFT DROPS WARNER BOARD BID
description: Chris-Craft Industries said yesterday that talks seeking more representation for the company on the board of Warner Communications Inc. had broken off and that its participation in earlier negotiations over a leveraged buyout of Warner had also been ended.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: STUFFED BREAD FOR A PICNIC The stuffed breads made at Bakery Soutine, 106 West 70th Street, would make a happy addition to any picnic. These are loaves of the bakery's French sourdough bread, packed with stuffings such as a boudin blanc - minced veal, chicken and pork sausage with onions - or chunks of smoked turkey with mustard and cheese. The shop also has vegetarian loaves stuffed with broccoli, cheddar and mushrooms, or spinach, mushrooms and sun-dried tomatoes.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SUNRISE WITH SEAMONSTERS:

title: TV Reporter Gets Stay On a 3-Month Jail Term
description: A television news reporter was sentenced today to three months in jail for refusing to identify a source who, with his back turned to a camera, said he saw police officers looting a drugstore.

title: PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
description: b-After a pre-tax LIFO charge of $576,000. c-After a pre-tax LIFO charge of $1,543,000. The company said sales for the year-ago quarter included $6,198,000 from a retail operation that was sold last year.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: LONG recognized by home cooks as easy to prepare and requiring a minimum of time and effort, skinless, boneless chicken breasts are also incredibly versatile. Therein lies the problem: they can be cooked in so many ways - sauteing, frying, boiling and broiling, to name but a few - and they marry so well with so many flavors that the choice may be difficult.

title: L.I. Man, 75, Is Killed as Car Is Hit by a Train at Crossing
description: A 75-year-old New Hyde Park man was killed this morning by a Long Island Rail Road train when he apparently drove his car around the closed gates at a crossing here, officials said.

title: HIS VISIT NEARING, GANDHI FAULTS U.S.
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi said today that he wanted to achieve a ''better understanding'' with the United States, but that American policies in southern Asia, particularly toward Pakistan, were causing serious difficulties for India.

title: MCGRAW-HILL REALIGNS INFORMATION EXECUTIVES
description: McGraw-Hill Inc. announced a number of executive changes on its business and financial information services side yesterday.

title: Accounts
description: * Two new products from Banquet Foods Corp., a division of Conagra Inc., to Foote Cone & Belding/Chicago.

title: ON THE ASSEMBLY LINE OF THE $5 DOLLAR WEDDING
description: The bride wore leotards. The bridegroom was resplendent in a ''Lets Go Mets'' T-shirt. The couple were bound in matrimony in 58.5 seconds, a respectable time indeed for the city's Marriage License Bureau considering it is so early in the June wedding season.

title: Father and Son in Court
description: Two seats apart in the crowded courtroom, the young man and the father he reportedly idolized did not once look at each other.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday about senators' opposition to arms sales for Jordan misidentified John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi. He is a former chairman of the Armed Services Committee. The current chairman is Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona.

title: JAZZ ARTISTS PROMINENT IN U.S. - JAPANESE TRADE
description: THE growing exchange of jazz musicians between Japan and the United States is pointed up by two New York showcases for Japanese jazz musicians -one featuring them with American musicians, the other as leaders of their own groups.

title: G.M. DEAL FOR HUGHES IS REPORTED
description: The General Motors Corporation has bought the Hughes Aircraft Company in a secret bidding contest, insiders said last night.

title: RILLETTES OF FISH? TRADITIONAL DISH SHEDS SOME FAT
description: RILLETTES (pronounced ree-yet) are a delicious French peasant expedient, a simple, time-honored method of potting pork, duck or goose to preserve it. But lately chefs have been taking astonishing liberties with this classic dish that resembles a pate, lightening it and even preparing it with seafood. The creative impulse that has given us seafood pot-au-feu and crayfish minestrone is also being applied to rillettes. They are no longer strictly rich winter fare and could even begin a warm-weather meal.

title: Left Out in Open
description: Arnold Palmer failed to qualify for the United States Open for the second consecutive year. Palmer, one of 55 players competing for seven berths in a secitional qualifier, posted rounds of 77 and 71 for a total of 6-over-par 148. ''I'm a little disappointed that I didn't play better,'' said Palmer, who won the United States Open in 1960.''

title: DEMOCRATS IN JERSEY SELECT SHAPIRO TO FACE KEAN IN FALL
description: Essex County Executive Peter Shapiro yesterday won the Democratic primary for governor in New Jersey to oppose Governor Kean's bid for re-election in November.

title: WINE TALK
description: FOR many years - starting around the end of Prohibition - this country's wine and spirits trades maintained good working relations within the alcoholic beverage industry.

title: Aliens' Hunger Strike Ended
description: The hunger strike by Salvadoran aliens being held at the El Centro immigration facility ended Monday with the release on bond of the seven remaining strikers, who had spent a week without food in protest of alleged mistreatment.

title: Trade Nominee
description: President Reagan intends to nominate S. Bruce Smart Jr. to be Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, the White House confirmed today. Mr. Smart, now chairman and chief executive of the Continental Group, would succeed Lionel H. Olmer.

title: Don't Promote Civil Rights Wrongs
description: William Bradford Reynolds, who has compiled a dismal record as Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights, has been nominated for Associate Attorney General, a promotion. He doesn't deserve it.

title: Auxiliary Bishop Gerald Ryan Of L.I. Diocese Is Dead at 61
description: Bishop Gerald Ryan, auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, died today, apparently of a heart attack.

title: LIBERIANS GET SINKING FEELING ABOUT 'DEMOCRACY'
description: Less than a year ago, this small West African nation began moving toward political change, and in the view of many citizens it promised to be as refreshing as the Atlantic breezes that curl through the sultry climate. But the great expectations have soured into cynicism.

title: South African Homeland Opens an Office in Israel
description: The South African homeland of Bophuthatswana has set up an office in Tel Aviv, embarrassing Israeli officials who fear it could harm relations with black Africa.

title: F.A.A. REPORTS RISE IN NEAR COLLISIONS
description: The number of reported near collisions of aircraft rose to a record 592 last year, the Government said today, and critics immediately called on Congress to investigate whether it had become less safe to fly.

title: JOHN F. M'KAY
description: John F. M'Kay, a retired New York advertising executive, died of cancer Saturday at Glen Cove (L.I.) Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: MOST AMERICANS IN SURVEY OPPOSE AID FOR OVERTHROW OF SANDINISTAS
description: A majority of Americans still oppose help for efforts to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government, but support for that Reagan Administration policy is increasing, especially among the growing number who know which side the United States backs, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: SHOP & GO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
SPY SUSPECT SEEN AS A MAN OF UNFULFILLED DREAMS
description: Jerry A. Whitworth, the retired Navy chief petty officer accused Monday of being a Soviet spy, is described by friends as an ambitious man who dreamed of striking it rich in the stock market but had trouble making a go of it after leaving the Navy.

title: THE GAME OF THE WEEK
description: Chairman: The topic of today's political Game of the Week is what our panel thinks about President Reagan's tax reform plan. Let's begin with Mrs. Springs. Mrs. Springs: Absolutely marvelous! Under the President's plan, everybody helps the country by helping themselves. Not only the rich but the poor pay less and have more to spend, so that there will be more work, more jobs and more money in the Treasury.

title: French Atom Test Draws New Zealand Protest
description: France set off a nuclear explosion today at Mururoa Atoll in the Pacific Ocean, its third of the year at the site. Prime Minister David Lange of New Zealand criticized the test.

title: CLASS AT EINSTEIN GIVEN WARNING ABOUT CONFLICTS
description: Young doctors entering the medical profession face ''a continuing struggle socially and economically,'' the sociologist Dr. Paul Starr told graduates yesterday at the 27th commencement of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx.

title: Commerce Publishing
description: An agreement has been reached by Commerce Publishing of Dallas to acquire all of the assets of California Business News, the Los Angeles company that publishes California Business magazine, a monthly that started as a tabloid in 1965 and now has a circulation of 70,000. Commerce Publishing's magazine is nine-year-old Texas Business, a monthly with a circulation of 48,500.

title: Doyle Dane Acquires London's Paling Ellis
description: In its continuing push to make its health-care-advertising subsidiary international, the Doyle Dane Bernbach Group has acquired Paling Ellis & Associates of London, Britain's third-largest agency of that kind, with billings of $8 million.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adac Laboratories, San Jose, Calif., maker of medical imaging products, has named Johan F. Blokker president and chief executive officer.

title: Davis Helps Cubs Down Braves, 5-3
description: Jody Davis's tiebreaking single in the sixth inning, one of his three hits in the game, and homers by Keith Moreland and Ron Cey led the Chicago Cubs to a 5-3 victory over the Atlanta Braves today.

title: OPEC Price Aid Urged
description: Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, oil minister of the United Arab Emirates, complained today that world oil markets were ''never so difficult'' as now and said members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries were faced with a choice of cutting prices or reducing production.

title: Distinguished Alumnus
description: Even though more than 30 years have passed, Education Secretary William J. Bennett remembered to dress properly yesterday when he visited his former elementary school in Brooklyn.

title: GEARHART INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
DECISION MADE QUICKLY IN FILLING GAP AT MERRILL
description: Things happen fast in the brokerage business, and last week Stephen L. Hammerman, general counsel at Merrill Lynch & Company, was asked to make a quick decision.

title: NICARAGUA AND THE U.S. OPTIONS: AN INVASION IS OPENLY DISCUSSED
description: Reagan Administration officials have begun openly discussing a subject they had previously refused even to speculate about: the possibility that American combat forces might one day be sent into Nicaragua.

title: Ex-Governor Switches Party
description: Former Gov. Edward J. King of Massachusetts, once labeled President Reagan's favorite Democratic Governor, became a Republican Monday to set the stage for a possible third battle with Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, a Democrat, in 1986.

title: BROOKLYN GRADUATES URGED TO AVOID CYNICISM
description: William J. Bennett, the United States Secretary of Education, returned to his native Brooklyn yesterday to address the 60th graduating class of Brooklyn College, urging the more than 2,000 students to avoid cynicism in their lives.

title: GIANT FOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 18
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid June 7.

title: The Case for Military Retirement Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: COMBAT IN PALESTINIAN SETTLEMENT MAY HAVE LEFT IT UNINHABITABLE
description: The destruction in Sabra, one of three Palestinian settlements besieged by Shiite attackers for nearly three weeks, is so extensive that the refugee district may no longer be habitable, according to visitors to the site in the last two days.

title: PLANTIFF IN PRAYER SUIT SAYS THE CASE HURT HIS CHILDREN
description: ''For me, the battle is over,'' Ishmael Jaffree said this morning after learning of the Supreme Court's ruling that struck down an Alabama law that provided for a one-minute period of silent meditation or prayer in the public schools. ''But prayer will go on in the schools,'' he said. ''It just won't go on in any of my children's classes.''

title: TREASURY POST SEEN FOR WALL ST. BANKER
description: President Reagan will name George D. Gould, a Wall Street banker and a former top official of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, to a new Treasury position overseeing domestic banking regulation, Administration sources said yesterday.

title: Toxic Dumpers Don't Deserve a Super Bailout
description: To the Editor:

title: Stolen Renoir Portrait Is Recovered by Police
description: A portrait by Renoir reported stolen in February was recovered yesterday by New York City detectives. Two men who tried to sell the painting to the officers were arrested, the authorities said.

title: COOPER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $48,339,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2,589,000 for the quarter and $4,478,000 for the 6 months.

title: Dominica Elections Slated
description: Prime Minister Eugenia Charles of Dominica, one of the chief architects of the 1983 United States-led invasion of Grenada, today called general elections for July 1 in this Caribbean nation of 80,000 people. The two leading parties have already been campaigning for several months, but legal proceedings against former Prime Minister Patrick John for attempted coups in the early 1980's has divided the opposition, which should help the Charles party.

title: BROADWAY AIRS ITS COMPLAINTS AT CITY HALL
description: Representatives of New York's theaters said yesterday that the high cost of real estate was one of the principal problems facing the industry.

title: ARAPAHO PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: The Unvacancy
description: Louis O. Giuffrida, director of the Federal agency responsible for handling national disasters, is not resigning, according to his office.

title: Toxic Dumpers Don't Deserve a Super Bailout
description: To the Editor:

title:
DISCOVERIES;

TIE-SHAPED TIE RACK, BIG, BRIGHT NECKLACE
Early Line For Football
description: The gridiron guesswork does not begin in earnest until next month, when national magazines begin publishing the experts' views as to which college football teams deserve top-20 rankings. And it will be later still, of course, before publication of the results in the major preseason polls, those administered by the news agencies.

title: MCADOO: MORE TO PROVE
description: The phone call came at 2 in the morning, while Bob McAdoo, as all good 25-point-per-game scorers should be, was asleep in his bed. The caller wanted to know what McAdoo thought about being traded from the Knicks to the Celtics.

title: STAGE: 'VOICE OF TURTLE' IN REVIVAL AT ROUNDABOUT
description: DESPITE the fact that ''The Voice of the Turtle'' ran for 1,557 performances and became one of the most popular of Broadway comedies, the author, John van Druten, was hesitant about reviving it. He felt that it would be extremely difficult to recapture the spirit of the time of its conception.

title: H. P. Schoen, 71, Chief Of the Hartford Group
description: Herbert P. Schoen, a retired chairman and chief executive of the Hartford Insurance Group, died Sunday at St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center in Hartford. He was 71 years old and lived in West Hartford.

title: COOPERBIOMEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a charge of $2,100,000 to cover expenses of closing a plant and relocating manufacturing activity. c-Net income.

title: 1,500 in San Salvador Protest Hospital Seizure
description: About 1,500 workers and students held a march in San Salvador today to protest the Government raids on hospitals two days ago.

title: Candelaria Trade Talk
description: John Candelaria, the Pittsburgh pitcher, has been the subject of trade talks with at least 11 clubs, according to General Manager Joe L. Brown, who said that the 31-year-old left-hander wanted to be traded because of the illness of his son. Brown declined to name the clubs who had expressed interest in Candelaria, who is 1-3 with 7 saves and a 4.44 e.r.a., but the Yankees and the Atlanta Braves confirmed they have expressed inter est.

title: INTEK DIVERSIFIED reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PORTUGUESE COALITION BREAKS UP
description: Portugal's Social Democratic Party told its Socialist partners in the Government today that it was withdrawing from the two-year-old coalition, a Socialist Party spokesman said.

title: Two of Surviving Septuplets Remain in Perilous Condition
description: Two of the five surviving Frustaci septuplets entered their 14th day of life today with only a 50-50 chance of surviving a lung disease that left them in critical condition.

title: COATED SALES reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
VON BULOW JUDGE CURTAILS REBUTTAL
description: The prosecution may present only one more witness in its effort to prove that Claus von Bulow tried to murder his wealthy wife with insulin injections in 1979 and 1980, the judge ruled today.

title: GREENMAN BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted May 29 through June 2 with 1,509 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.

title: Toxic Dumpers Don't Deserve a Super Bailout
description: To the Editor:

title: COUNTY CHIEFS GO TO ALBANY
description: Long Island's two county executives and representatives of the Long Island Lighting Company came to Albany today seeking support for a plan intended to minimize rate increases caused by the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: READINGS MARK ANNIVERSARY OF DEATH OF O. HENRY IN 1910
description: Seventy-five years ago today, O. Henry died in New York at the age of 47, after weeks of despair over his health, his debts and his ability to continue writing.

title: FLIGHT B EVENT OUTDRAWS REISINGER CHAMPIONSHIP
description: While some 140 players, including some of the most famous names in the game, battled last week in the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship in New York, a slightly greater number with slightly lesser ambition fought in the Flight B event, restricted to players with fewer than 1,500 master points.

title: EQUITEC FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
EXCERPTS FROM OPINIONS AND DISSENTS IN SCHOOL PRAYER CASE
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today invalidating Alabama's moment-of-silence law. Associate Justice John Paul Stevens wrote the opinion. Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. joined the opinion and filed a concurring opinion. Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor did not sign the opinion, filing a concurring opinion. Dissents were filed by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and by Associate Justices Byron R. White and William H. Rehnquist.

title: THE COLISEUM SITE: GRAND POTENTIAL INSPIRES LITTLE BUT VISIONS OF HEIGHT
description: Last winter, when the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority and the city jointly issued a request for proposals to redevelop the site of the Coliseum on Columbus Circle, it looked like the building opportunity of the decade for New York.

title: General Cinema Offering Notes
description: The General Cinema Corporation is offering $100 million of 10 3/4 percent subordinated notes due in 1995 at a price of 99 1/2 to yield 10.83 percent through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. At the time of the initial offering, the note yield was 79-hundredths of a percentage point higher than for 10-year Treasury notes.

title: DENTAL WORLD CENTER INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss.

title: SO WEAKLY COUCHED
description: R.J. Reynolds, the cigarette company, is merging with Nabisco, a biscuit-and-crackers outfit. The obvious name for this new corporate monstrosity is Nabuttsco. I have already proposed it to the Committee on Nomenclature, whose couch, Burton B. Barton IV, assures me the suggestion will be given serious consideration.

title: Pressure Backed
description: Cheryl Klein of Medford, L.I., is an 18-year-old freshman discus-thrower at the University of Houston, and she had always heard that the national collegiate outdoor track and field championships were pressure-packed. Now she has firsthand evidence.

title: FRIEDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Shoreham: Undamned? Undammed?
description: In an astonishing reversal, the Executive of New York's Suffolk County, Peter Cohalan, the bitterest enemy of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, has changed sides. Whatever his reasons, Mr. Cohalan's new stance is certainly in the public interest. Now that billions have been wasted on the plant, Long Island is better off using it than losing it. The big question is whether Governor Cuomo and the Suffolk County Legislature can be persuaded to get on with the job of cushioning the economic blow.

title: COHEN RESIGNS FROM THEATER LEAGUE: PRODUCERS CRITICIZE REMARKS AT TONYS
description: Alexander H. Cohen, a prominent producer of Broadway shows and of the annual Tony Awards broadcast, resigned Monday from the League of American Theaters and Producers, Broadway's trade association.

title: WHITBREAD & CO PLC reports earnings for Year to March 2
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $13.4 million for the latest year and $4.4 million for the earlier period. Whitbread Breweries' most significant event of the year was the closure of the Luton brewery which accounted for about half of the extraordinary loss in the latest year. All figures are in U.S. currency and were computed at 1 pound sterling equals $1.28.

title: COOPERVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Implant Patient Is Set To Resume Exercising
description: Murray P. Haydon, the artificial heart patient who suffered a minor stroke Monday, will soon resume his exercise routine, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: Solzhenitsyns Apply For U.S. Citizenship
description: Alexander Solzhenitsyn, the exiled Russian author and Nobel Prize winner, has applied for United States citizenship along with his wife, Natalia.

title: HARTFORD LEGISLATORS AID ROADS AND ADJOURN
description: The Connecticut General Assembly moved toward adjournment tonight after approving the creation of an Office of Inspector General to combat waste and abuse in state government.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 6, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Science and Technology - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CONTROVERSY OVER THE STRIPPING OF A HISTORIC PASADENA HOUSE
description: MOST architectural artifacts sold by dealers were originally rescued from buildings about to be demolished. But the high market value of certain pieces has encouraged some owners to remove salable parts from buildings not in danger of being demolished. In recent years, for example, stained glass windows from Frank Lloyd Wright houses in Chicago were sold by their owners. On June 14, Christie's in New York will auction a number of windows and fixtures taken from Wright's Bradley House in Kankakee, Ill.

title: GARDENING ANGELS IN HARLEM
description: In the block bounded by West 142d and 143d Streets and Frederick Douglass and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevards, the roses are blooming and lilies and pink weigelas are in full flower.

title: Official Resignation
description: Monique Berlioux officially announced her resignation as director and chief excecutive officer of the International Olympic Committee at the committee's annual meeting, in East Berlin. Mrs. Berlioux, 59 years old, who had been its director for 14 years, did not elaborate on her reason for leaving the organization, but she denied that she had been forced from her position. She said her contract through December 1988 would be honored. I.O.C. members expressed the opinion that Mrs. Berlioux lost a power struggle with her only superior, Juan Antonio Samaranch, who has been the I.O.C. president since 1980.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 6, 1985

title: DEMOCRATS DENOUNCE POLICY TOWARD NICARAGUANS
description: Democratic leaders today criticized President Reagan's policy toward Nicaragua and said it was leading the country toward greater military intervention in Central America.

title: City Makes Plans For U.S. Aid Cuts
description: The Koch administration is preparing a wide range of contingency plans to reduce the Mayor's proposed $20 billion city budget to take into account possible cuts in Federal aid, city officials said yesterday.

title: STUDY IS SAID TO SHOW EFFECT OF CANCER CHEMICAL ON GENES
description: Government researchers have found what they believe to be the first direct evidence that a cancer-causing chemical acts directly on genetic material that has the potential to change a normal cell to a cancerous one.

title: HERS
description: WHEN I set out to Bloomingdale's recently to buy a bed, it seemed the sensible thing to do. I had just taken an apartment, my marriage was over and with it, all possibility of future evenings in my familiar king-size bed. But as I stepped off the escalator and found myself facing so many new, exposed mattresses, one of which was being tested by a young couple holding hands and bouncing together, I felt so conspicuously out of place I wanted to turn back.

title: A Pox on the Torpedoes!
description: It was Dr. Thomas Bowdler who cleaned up Shakespeare in 1818 and explained, ''Those words and expressions are omitted which cannot with propriety be read aloud in a family.''

title: CABARET: CAROL WOODS
description: CAROL WOODS, the pop-blues singer who was featured in the Off Broadway show ''One Mo' Time'' and who is currently appearing on Broadway in ''Grind,'' continues to grow as a cabaret performer. In her new act at Freddy's Supper Club (308 East 49th Street), Miss Woods covers a lot of musical territory, from raw barroom blues to vintage Broadway pop tunes, from Cole Porter to Lionel Richie.

title: New U.S. Pacts on Steel
description: The Reagan Administration has signed steel export agreements with three more countries as part of its program to curb the flow of foreign steel into the United States. The new five-year agreements, retroactive to Oct. 1, were reached with Rumania, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, the deputy United States trade representative, Robert Lighthizer, said on Tuesday.

title: WHITE MAN'S LAWYER
description: On June 21, 1963, a tense time in the struggle against racial discrimination in the South, President Kennedy called 244 of the country's leading lawyers to the White House. He asked them to help, and they responded by setting up the Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law.

title: Security Reviews for Spy Suspect
description: The Pentagon disclosed today that Jerry A. Whitworth was twice cleared for his ''top secret'' security rating in the time he is charged with spying for the Soviet Union.

title: Holtzman Bill Calls for Two-Way TV in Child-Abuse Trials
description: To the Editor:

title: CLEANING, FIXING ORIENTAL RUGS
description: ORIENTAL rugs, modern or antique, may eventually present owners with some difficult choices about cleaning and repair.

title: DEMOCRATIC VICTOR IN JERSEY PREPARES: PETER SHAPIRO TO BATTLE A POPULAR INCUMBENT: POLITICAL SUCCESS FROM EARLY AGE
description: When Peter Shapiro graduated from Harvard, with honors, in 1974, he shunned the career paths pursued by many of his friends and headed home to New Jersey.

title: Mobil Corporation
description: The Mobil Corporation is offering $100 million of 8 3/4 percent notes due in three years at a price of 99 5/8 to yield 8.894 percent, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The notes, which are rated Aa-3 by Moody's and AA- by S.&P., initially yielded about a tenth of a percentage point more than three-year Treasury notes.

title: VON BULOW'S MISTRESS TOLD OF PLEA NOT TO TESTIFY ABOUT THEIR AFFAIR
description: When Claus von Bulow was awaiting his first trial in 1981 on charges of trying to murder his wife, he pleaded with his mistress not to testify about their affair, the mistress, Alexandra Isles, told a state prosecutor last week.

title: Which Way Rosty?
description: Farther down the line on the tax-revision front, another expression of strong feelings also seems likely.

title: Tennessee Unit's Revenue Bonds
description: The Tennessee Housing Development Authority is offering $182.46 million of single-family housing revenue bonds through a group of underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: RELIGIOUS BELIEFS CITED AT SANCTUARY HEARING
description: Church workers indicted for helping citizens of Central America flee their countries and come to the United States are acting under centuries-old religious precedents, a Roman Catholic professor and representatives of four Protestant denominations have testified in a Federal court here.

title: WIEBOLDT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
A.T.&T. to Cut 1,650 Positions
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, in a move to cut expenses, said it was eliminating 1,650 positions in its AT&T Information Systems, the marketing arm for its telephone, switching and computer equipment. A.T.&T. said that additional reductions were planned but offered no timetable and did not say how widespread they might be.

title: CUOMO FINDS U.S. SETTLING FOR LESS
description: Governor Cuomo of New York told graduating students at Harvard University today that the United States was becoming a country of ''shrunken aspiration and diminished confidence'' and was no longer upholding the American dream.

title: JEWISH GROUP SAYS BONN SHIFTS POLICY ON EX-NAZIS
description: The World Jewish Congress said yesterday that West Germany had quietly altered a longstanding policy and was refusing to accept some Nazi war criminals who had been ordered deported from the United States for fraudulent entry after World War II.

title: 13 LINKED BY U.S. TO SMUGGLING HEROIN AND HASHISH FOM INDIA
description: Federal authorities said yesterday that they had arrested 13 drug traffickers connected with two unrelated rings that smuggled huge amounts of narcotics into the New York area from India.

title: SPY CASE IS CALLED THREAT TO FINDING SOVIET SUBMARINES
description: Submarine experts said today that as a result of the Walker family spy case, the Navy might have to rebuild portions of the undersea network of sound detectors that are a crucial early warning system against a Soviet nuclear attack.

title: JOHN RINGLING NORTH, OF CIRCUS, DIES
description: John Ringling North, who headed the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus for 30 years until its sale by the Ringling family in 1967, died of a stroke Tuesday in his hotel suite in Brussels while traveling. He was 81 years old and lived in Geneva.

title: SPY SUSPECT'S HALF BROTHER IS IDENTIFIED FROM CODE
description: Government officials identified the half brother of John A. Walker Jr. today as the man described in secret documents with the code name F. But they said he was not involved in the purported Soviet spy ring.

title: POLICE TELL HOW THEY RECOVERED A RENOIR
description: For Detective Thomas Moscardini, the case began with two simple facts. The first was that a painting by Pierre Auguste Renoir, worth about $500,000, had been stolen from the Wally Findlay Gallery, at 17 East 57th Street. The second was that a stolen painting had surfaced in the New York art world, and that someone was looking to sell.

title: PLAY EQUIPMENT, INDOORS AND OUT WHERE TO GET IT BECAUSE some of the larger pieces may be stocked in warehouses, increasing delivery time, you may want to call the store to see if an item is stocked there. Mail order delivery ranges from three days to six weeks. Childcraft, 150 East 58th Street, 212-753-3196, and 155 East 23d Street, 212-674-4754. Mail order only, delivery in five to six weeks. Free catalogue.
description: SUMMER is the season for outdoor play equipment. Classes are out, children are around the house and a home play yard can be a pleasure for both children and parents. Equipping the yard, however, should be done thoughtfully. It is important to choose play pieces that are both challenging and as safe as possible.

title: LAWN WATERING IS BANNED
description: New York City residents and businesses face additional limitations on water use today, including restrictions on the use of water-cooled central air-conditioning and bans on lawn watering and filling swimming pools, city officials announced yesterday.

title: New Citroen Model Set
description: Peugeot, France's leading car manufacturer, has received a Government-subsidized loan of $215 million to develop a new car for its Citroen subsidiary, the company said today. Peugeot will use the money to modernize its plant at Aulnay, near Paris, to produce a new compact Citroen model.

title: Fleischmann Account To MacNamara, Clapp
description: MacNamara, Clapp & Klein is going to be doing the advertising for the 12 brands of the Fleischmann Distilling Company, part of Whitbread, North America.

title: Dart Group May Make Eckerd Bid
description: The Dart Group Corporation said it had purchased 5 percent of the shares of the Jack Eckerd Corporation and was considering making a bid for the whole company.

title: BOOKLET DISCUSSES HEARING PROBLEMS
description: Hearing loss can be slow and subtle over time, but in most cases it can be dealt with effectively once detected.

title: FLUTIE LISTS HIGHS AND LOWS
description: For Doug Flutie the highlights and lowlights of his fast-paced season with the Generals are easy to define.

title: CONNORS REACHES SEMIFINALS
description: Jimmy Connors, after a 55-minute delay caused by a thunderstorm, stopped Sweden's Stefan Edberg, 6-4, 6-3, 7-5, and reached the semifinals of the French Open tennis championships today.

title: EVENTS: DISPLAYS OF ROSES
description: Cranford Rose Garden, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue (Crown Street), 718-622-4433.

title: BMC-I.B.M. Suit
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said BMC Software Inc. had dismissed its antitrust lawsuit against I.B.M. and agreed to the entry of a final judgment in favor of I.B.M. It said BMC filed the suit in August 1984. I.B.M. said the final judgment let stand a December court ruling in I.B.M.'s favor on certain software tie-in claims. It said BMC had dropped the rest of its claims.

title: FIRST LOSS SEEN
description: Wang Laboratories, the computer company, said yesterday that it would dismiss 1,600 employees because of weak sales and would report a loss for the current quarter.

title: HOLLY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 12
Mississippi State Senator Is Convicted of Extortion
description: The President pro tem of the Mississippi Senate, Tommy Brooks, was found guilty Tuesday of attempting to extort $50,000 in exchange for his influence on a horse racing bill.

title: Holtzman Bill Calls for Two-Way TV in Child-Abuse Trials
description: To the Editor:

title: BLOCK DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PASTA & CHEESE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HONOR STUDENT, 17, IS FOUND SLAIN IN MAMARONECK NEAR HER SCHOOL
description: A 17-year-old girl, a high school honor student, was found strangled Tuesday night in a room at a motel along a busy road here, officials said today.

title: ALLIES URGE U.S. TO KEEP '79 ARMS PACT
description: Western European foreign ministers told Secretary of State George P. Shultz today that they would oppose any Reagan Administration effort to abandon the 1979 arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union, American and European officials said.

title: SEAGULL RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Agriculture vs. the Merchant Marine
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: The Tandy Corporation said that it had cut the price of its Tandy 1000 personal computer to $999, from $1,199. The company also introduced peripherals for the computer, including a built-in 10-megabyte Winchester disk drive for $1,199 and an external 10-megabyte drive for $699.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ALL FALL DOWN: America's Tragic Encounter With Iran. By Gary Sick. 366 pages. Random House. $19.95.

title: Would You Want Your Child to Be a Farmer?
description: To the Editor:

title:
TO DIVEST IN SOUTH AFRICA, OR NOT?;

SELL HOLDINGS; PROFIT OTHERWISE
description: Opponents of divestment in South Africa are turning increasingly to the argument that its financial costs outweigh its political and moral benefits. Nothing could be further from the truth. Studies show that universities, cities and states that sold their holdings in American companies doing business in South Africa would not reduce either the value of their investments or the chance that they would appreciate. Indeed, in many cases they actually would improve their portfolios.

title: Congress;   Of Fairy Tales, Wish Lists and Balanced Budgets
description: With Federal deficits threatening to surge past the $200 billion mark this year, talk about balanced budgets might sound more like a fairy tale than a realistic possibility. But a new effort is gearing up to force Congress to act on a Constitutional amendment that would require lawmakers to balance receipts and outlays every year.

title: Copyright Council To Lobby Congress
description: Movie makers, book publishers, songwriters, actors and record companies announced formation today of the American Copyright Council to lobby Congress against efforts to undermine Federal copyright laws.

title: WURLITZER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: SUMMIT OIL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $575,000 for the latest first quarter and $198,406 for the year- ago first quarter.

title: ISRAEL COOL TO HUSSEIN PROPOSAL FAVORED BY SHULTZ
description: Remarks by senior Israeli officials indicate that sharp differences are developing between Israel and the United States over the merits of the latest peace initiative by King Hussein of Jordan.

title: SOUTH AFRICA WARNS IT MAY EXPEL ALIENS IF U.S. INVESTORS PULL OUT
description: A high-ranking official says the Government may expel more than a million black workers if the United States pulls its investments from the country to protest Pretoria's racial policies.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: PLEA BARGAIN FOR 2 MEN FAILS IN DRUG DEATH OF A KENNEDY
description: A negotiated plea agreement that was to avert a criminal trial for two bellmen accused of selling cocaine to David Kennedy before his drug-induced death collapsed today just before it was to have become official.

title: Replay Protested
description: Steve Ehrhart, the general manager of the Memphis Showboats, has asked the United States Football League commissioner, Harry Usher, to order an onfield replay to settle a dispute over a video replay that was used to overrule an official's call -and a Memphis touchdown - in the Showboat's 17-14 loss to the Portland Breakers May 25. The disputed play, a 67-yard punt return in the fourth quarter by Henry Williams, was declared a touchdown, but after the Breakers, protesting that Williams had stepped out of bounds, invoked a video review of the play, Frank Rustich, the press-box official, looked at the tape and ruled that Williams had stepped out of bounds.

title: 3-Year Note Offer By CIT Financial
description: The CIT Financial Corporation is offering $100 million of three-year extendible notes with an initial coupon of 8 7/8 percent at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. After three years investors may redeem the notes at par, or accept a new interest rate and maturity to be announced by the company.

title: IMMUNO NUCLEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Talks Resume In Hotel Strike
description: Negotiators for the opposing sides met for an hour and a half yesterday in an attempt to end the five-day-old strike that now affects 54 hotels in the city. They agreed to meet again this morning at 11 at the New York Athletic Club.

title: A Dog's Life In Paris
description: A rather unusual sidelight to the fervent rivalry between Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert Lloyd has emerged at the French Open, where, if form holds through the semifinals today, they will meet in the women's final Saturday.

title: CLUES TO TOXIC SYNDROME FOUND
description: Scientists said today that they had discovered how some tampons caused the rare but sometimes fatal toxic shock syndrome in menstruating women. The researchers expressed hope that the discovery would lead to the production of generally safer tampons.

title: VARIETIES OF TOWEL BARS
description: TOWEL bars come in many varieties. Baldwin has recently introduced a new line of bath accessories, including towel bars and rings, that come in polished or antique brass, chrome and a combination of brass and acrylic.

title: BRITISH EXCHANGE VOTES WIDER FIRM OWNERSHIP
description: The brokers and dealers who own Britain's Stock Exchange voted today to allow outsiders, including American companies, to own member firms.

title: SENATE VOTE URGES BACKING ARMS PACT
description: The Senate overwhelmingly adopted tonight a compromise resolution urging President Reagan to continue to adhere to the second strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union. But the statement also seems to give approval to a measured move by the Administration to respond to any Soviet violations of the treaty.

title: The Big Shove
description: The Big Shove is a tactic by bureaucrats trying to block the appointment of someone they do not like. The shove doesn't quite knock the enemy off the platform into the path of a locomotive, but it does put him out in the open, vulnerable.

title: THE DANCE: OPENING AT LA MAMA
description: ''SPIRIT RISING'' was an apt name for the program presented by the Urban Bush Women on Tuesday at the opening of its season at La Mama, 74A East Fourth Street. Much of what his black women's theater-dance company performs looks like sheer ritual or a summoning up of spirits from the earth and its inhabitants. But Jawole Zollar, the choreographer and founder of the year-old company, is a true original, blending modern and ethnic dance, new and traditional music, and everyday themes in vibrantly theatrical yet unaffected work.

title: WORKER AT GREAT ADVENTURE CITES DELAY IN REPORTING FIRE
description: An employee at an amusement park attraction where a fire killed eight teen-agers testified today that a locked control-room door had delayed his getting to a telephone to report the blaze.

title: JOHNSON BASKET AT BUZZER EVENS SERIES FOR CELTICS
description: After being embarrassed by the Los Angeles Lakers in the third game of the championship series, the defending-champion Boston Celtics - in particular, Larry Bird - vowed to play better when the two teams met again. They did, and so did Bird, even though he waited until the final period.

title: St. John's Gets Lutheran Star
description: Marco Baldi, the 6-foot-11-inch center from Long Island Lutheran High School who averaged 18 points and 12 rebounds as a senior last season, decided yesterday to accept a basketball scholarship to St. John's.

title: FORGOTTEN BUILDINGS IN U.S. ARCHITECTURE
description: BOOKS on American architecture tend to be heavy on mansions and monuments, light on factories and farmhouses. But with as many pages devoted to ranches and gas stations as to capitols and estates, ''Built in the U.S.A.,'' a recent paperback from the National Trust for Historic Preservation, reveals the remarkable diversity of our nation's architectural treasures.

title: CERTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: VACATION WARNING
description: Promoters offering vacation certificates can make them sound like dream holidays, but the Federal Trade Commission warns consumers to evaluate an offer before paying any money.

title: GANDALF TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
DANCE: CYNTHIA GREGORY GALA CELEBRATES 20 YEARS
description: ON Tuesday night, the Metropolitan Opera House belonged entirely to Cynthia Gregory. The California-born ballerina is now in her 20th year with American Ballet Theater and the company celebrated the anniversary with a gala. Miss Gregory deserved it for, although she once was a teen-aged member of the San Francisco Ballet, she has spent virtually her entire career with American Ballet Theater.

title: Grenada Sets June 27 as Date For 19 Leftists' Murder Trial
description: Grenada's Chief Justice, Sir Archibald Nedd, said today that June 27 had been set for the start of the long-delayed trial of 19 leftists accused of murdering Prime Minister Maurice Bishop.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET CANCEL A DEBATE
description: American and Soviet officials have pulled out of a debate on space weapons that had been scheduled for Friday at the Oxford Union, the debating society announced today.

title: STEPHENS CHASING BELMONT DREAM
description: The litany is heard on backstretches from Santa Anita to Saratoga, wherever Woody Stephens is talking and anyone is there to listen.

title: SEX EDUCATION IS SUBJECT OF 'CURRENTS' ON PBS
description: ALTHOUGH sex education, tonight's subject on Channel 13's ''Currents'' at 8, generates plenty of controversy, not much of it actually exists in the nation's schools. Only three states, Maryland, Kentucky and New Jersey, have made sex education mandatory.

title: Tornado Deaths Put at 88
description: Two more Pennsylvania people have died of injuries suffered in last week's tornadoes, raising the death toll to 88, the authorities said today.

title: Bonds Up in Erratic Trading
description: In erratic trading, bond prices continued to rise yesterday amid speculation that the Japanese Ministry of Finance would ease restrictions that limit, or prohibit, Japanese institutional purchases of Treasury securities.

title: In Mideast, Wickedness Is in the Beholder's Eye
description: To the Editor:

title: Yank Game Rained Out
description: Steady rain forced the postponement of last night's Yankees' game with the Oakland A's at Yankee Stadium, but it did not alter the Yankees' pitching plans for their four-game series beginning tonight in Milwaukee.

title: U.S. MOVE TO SEEK JORDAN ARMS SALE IS REPORTED NEAR
description: The Administration is nearing a decision to ask Congress to provide Jordan with $300 million in additional military credits that will allow it to order F-20 fighter planes and two advanced antiaircraft defense systems, officials of the State and Defense Departments said today.

title: TOWNSPEOPLE SHIELD EX-WIFE OF SPY SUSPECT FROM PRESS
description: The citizens and the police in this Cape Cod village threw a protective shield of Yankee reticence today around Barbara Joy Crowley Walker, who informed the Government of her former husband's alleged spying for the Soviet Union.

title:
TECHNOLOGY;

Robots That 'See' and 'Feel'
description: TWO robots are working together in a manufacturing cell assembling oil pump units for an automobile engine. One uses a remotely mounted television camera to ''look'' at the small castings that are the top and bottom of the pump housing as they move along a conveyor belt. When it recognizes a bottom part, it reaches out, picks it up and places it on a fixture.

title: SUPPORT GROUPS WHEN PREGNANCY FAILS Sources of Aid SHARE is a clearinghouse for support groups for couples who have suffered miscarriage or stillbirth. It lists 328 such groups across the country, of which there are 56 in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, some of which are listed here. description: FIVE years ago, Miriam Lieberman lost a daughter in her seventh month of pregnancy.

title: POPE'S ASSAILANT TESTIFIES ABOUT GUN
description: The man who shot and wounded Pope John Paul II four years ago described to a court here today how, in Vienna, he had bought the gun used in the shooting with the aid of right-wing Turkish terrorist friends.

title: Busy May for United's Rivals
description: Some major airlines reported large increases in traffic and loads on their planes in May, mainly because of the pilot strike at United Airlines, the nation's largest carrier.

title: EPSOM DERBY WON BY CAUTHEN MOUNT
description: Steve Cauthen, riding Slip Anchor, led from start to finish today to capture the 206th Epsom Derby, becoming the first American jockey to win the British flat-racing classic in 78 years.

title: MIZLOU PROGRAMMING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DANCE: 'ANDREW JACKSON,' GIVEN BY 1,200 STUDENTS
description: AMERICAN history was never like this. Perhaps it should have been, for ''Andrew Jackson and the Battle of New Orleans'' managed to make the War of 1812 seem fun.

title: Iran and Iraq Report Attacks on Capitals
description: Iraq said its warplanes attacked Teheran again today, reportedly killing 2 people, and Iran said its latest missile attack on Baghdad killed 86 and wounded 132.

title: Pressure Points
description: Excerpts from the diary of Victor Ross, a 33-year veteran of the Bureau of Traffic Operations:

title: Mellon Bank Sues Sharon
description: The Mellon Bank said yesterday that it had filed two suits against the Sharon Steel Corporation seeking $33 million in missed interest payments on Sharon's debentures. Mellon's announcement came one day after Sharon said that it was close to agreement on a sweetened offer to swap some of its debentures for notes and common stock.

title: IN-HOUSE DISPUTE: DRUNKEN-DRIVER BUMPER STICKER
description: When Becky Titus and Elliott Metcalfe made plans to marry this spring they thought the biggest problem facing them was what to do with their pets.

title: Citicorp in Belgian Deal
description: Citicorp, the biggest American bank holding company, has acquired a 70 percent stake in Banque Sud Belge, Belgium's 10th-largest bank, the companies said today. Citicorp already owns Famibanque in Belgium, the country's fourth-largest bank.

title: Henning Rejects Offer
description: Lorne Henning, the former Islander assistant, said today he had rejected the head-coaching job with the Vancouver Canucks.

title: MARIA DAHLIN
description: Maria Dahlin, who was graduated from Barnard College last month, died Saturday in an automobile accident in Stockholm.

title: REAGAN CRITICIZES NICARAGUA ANEW
description: President Reagan said today that the Soviet Union was providing ''hundreds of millions'' of dollars in arms and equipment to Nicaragua, and vowed that the United States would repel attempts by Communists to impose their will in Central America.

title: A Horse Is a Horse Is a Therapeutic Horse
description: Marlin, an undersized 9-year-old wearing a riding helmet, jumps high into the air and manages to land belly-down across the saddle of his horse, Wendy. He swings his leg over his mount's broad back, adjusts the stirrups and, sitting very tall, leads a parade of eight children and eight docile horses slowly around the riding ring.

title: Gandhi Meets Mubarak
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India met with President Hosni Mubarak today after his arrival in Cairo, his first stop on a five-nation tour that will take him to Europe and the United States.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''The President has no plans to use U.S. military forces in Central America, period.''

title: STALLONE ON PATRIOTISM AND 'RAMBO'
description: ''The strongest feelings a man has,'' said Sylvester Stallone, whose new film, ''Rambo: First Blood Part II,'' is breaking box-office records across the country, ''are his religion, his feelings for his loved ones and his love for his country. And if you don't have men willing to die for their country, you don't have a country.''

title: Peru in Debt Payment
description: Peru has paid its creditor banks $10 million in overdue interest, a New York banker said Tuesday. Peru is more than six months behind in interest payments on its foreign debt of about $14 billion, and is said to be concerned that United States Government regulators will lower its credit rating when they meet Monday.

title: Mexican Engineer, 33, Selected as Astronaut
description: Mexico has chosen as its first astronaut a 33-year-old engineer who will be aboard the United States space shuttle Challenger in a flight scheduled for November.

title: PAPANDREOU HOPES FOR BETTER TIES WITH THE U.S. IN HIS SECOND TERM
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, in his first news conference after his re-election Sunday, expressed hope today for improved relations with the United States.

title: US ELECTRONICS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., Los Angeles, has appointed Gregory C. Crews president and chief executive officer of its Market Services division in New York City.

title: RE-USING ARCHITECTURAL ARTIFACTS: THE OLD IS NEW AGAIN WHERE TO LOOK FOR ARTIFACTS
description: FIFTEEN years ago, buying parts from old buildings about to be demolished - mantels, light fixtures, stained-glass windows and columns - for use in the home was something of a novelty. But today, with some 20 architectural salvage stores in major cities across the United States, and six in the New York area, the practice amounts to a small industry and a popular design approach for both professionals and amateurs.

title: SILVAR-LISCO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: 'INTERCOM' ASKS QUESTION: CAN PEOPLE TRUST THE MEDIA
description: THE most equivocal thing about ''Can the People Trust the Media?'' is the title. Robert MacNeil does not tell us whether the people can or not. Forgive him for that. Mr. MacNeil, the co-anchor of the ''MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour,'' has something to say about journalism, and none of it is self-serving. He will be seen on Channel 13 at 10:30 tonight.

title: G.M. TO ACQUIRE HUGHES AIRCRAFT IN $5 BILLION BID
description: The General Motors Corporation, in an ambitious diversification into aerospace and high technology, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Hughes Aircraft Company for more than $5 billion in cash and stock.

title: NICARAGUA REPORTS IT SHOT DOWN 2 COPTERS RAIDING FROM HONDURAS
description: The Government announced today that Sandinista troops had shot down two unidentified helicopters that had entered Nicaraguan air space from Honduras.

title: HOW SALES HELP THE INSTITUTIONS
description: The sale of the Hughes Aircraft Company will enable the Howard Hughes Medical Institute to spend at least $200 million a year on medical research, more than doubling its current outlays, Dr. Donald S. Fredrickson, president of the institute, said yesterday.

title: PRIZE IN STRUGGLE IN UTAH IS REGION ONCE SCORNED
description: John N. McComb explored southern Utah in 1859 and reported back that he could not ''conceive of a more worthless and impractical region.''

title: Norman Macleod Dead at 78; Author of Novels and Poetry
description: Norman Macleod, who established the Briarcliff Quarterly magazine and the Poetry Center at the 92d Street Y, died after a long illness on Tuesday at the University Nursing Center in Greenville, N.C. He was 78 years old.

title: MONEY SAID TO HAVE REPLACED IDEOLOGY AS MAIN SPY MOTIVE
description: ''Money is the dominant reason'' Americans now choose to spy for the Soviet Union, according to Stansfield Turner, a former Director of Central Intelligence.

title: Ahead of Time
description: With three steals Tuesday night against Houston, Vince Coleman, the human blur who is posing as a rookie for the St. Louis Cardinals, raised his season's total to 39, and that is more than any of 16 entire major league clubs have been able to achieve.

title: 33 Die as Iraqi Jets Raid Iranian Cities
description: Iranian troops struck nine miles into Iraq today, and Iraqi air raids on Teheran and other cities killed at least 33 people, the Iranian press agency said.

title: SCREEN: MICHAEL LANDON'S AUTOBIOGRAPHICAL 'SAM'S SON'
description: ''SAM'S SON,'' which was written and directed by Michael Landon, is about two things: Mr. Landon's father and Mr. Landon's hair. In the former capacity, Eli Wallach does a good job of turning a character too often described as ''a dreamer'' into a warm and substantial man. Gene's mother is played by Anne Jackson, who nags him a lot and affects Mama Portnoy-type humor in paying keen attention to her son's bathroom habits.

title: STAGE: GARDNER'S 'I'M NOT RAPPAPORT'
description: NO one can accuse Herb Gardner of betraying his convictions to keep up with changing times. Almost 25 years after his first Broadway success, ''A Thousand Clowns,'' he is still writing roughly the same play - the comedy about the cranky but endearing New York eccentric who refuses to capitulate peacefully to the crass workaday world. Mr. Gardner's new variation on the theme, now available in an attractive production at the American Place Theater, is titled ''I'm Not Rappaport,'' and there's a valor to it. During much of this playwright's career, nonconformity has been fashionable, but these days, it's not. Mr. Gardner, like his on-stage heroes, stubbornly continues to say what he thinks.

title: VOLCKER AND NEVELSON HONORED BY HARVARD The Federal Reserve Board chairman made an unusually strong attack on greed and inflation. Economic Scene, page D2.
description: Harvard University awarded honorary degrees to Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and nine other people, including the sculptor Louise Nevelson, at its commencement today.

title: Panel on Aging Should Study Bus Service
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM: 'PERFECT,' GYM AND JOURNALISM
description: If Alan Pakula's fine film adaptation of ''All the President's Men'' can be said to mark the beginning of a new kind of journalism film, James Bridges's ''Perfect,'' suggested by a piece in Rolling Stone magazine by Aaron Latham, may mark the absolute, idiotic end.

title: OFFICIAL SAYS SPYING ARRESTS ARE 'THE TIP OF THE ICEBERG'
description: A high-ranking Government official said today that he expected ''at least another four or five'' arrests in connection with a spy case that has been described as the most damaging in 30 years.

title: LABOR PEACE REIGNS IN JAPAN, AND UNIONS WITHER
description: The Labor Ministry issued a little-noted report the other day, saying that strikes had cost the average Japanese employee only 15 minutes and 50 seconds of work time in each of the last three years.

title: ARCH PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company changed its name from Sparkman Producing Co., effective yesterday.

title: SL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted.

title: Circus at Battery Park
description: Battery Park will be a circus for the next seven Fridays, starting today, with free workshops in juggling, acrobatics, clowning and other circus skills from 11 A.M. to 2 P.M. Juggling will be today's subject taught by Eff Collins and Luanne Dietrich, former members of the Bond Street Theater Coalition. Each session will repeat the previous week's program, while adding another activity.

title: Pennsylvania Fire Kills Five
description: Five people died in an apartment house blaze in East Pittsburgh today, including a frightened woman who resisted rescue attempts and was too scared to step out her window onto a ladder, officials said. ''I had my hands on the lady through the window.'' said Fire Chief Sam Stiles. He said he could not squeeze through the window to get the woman, Bertha L. Gilbert, 41 years old, because he was wearing protective clothing and equipment.

title: SCREEN: 'THE GOONIES,' WRITTEN BY SPIELBERG
description: QUICK: what do George Washington, Abraham Lincoln and Martin Sheen have in common? You'd have to be a kid to know the answer, or at least be tuned in to the very particular wavelength on which ''The Goonies'' plays. Made under the aegis of Steven Spielberg, and crammed with every pop cultural artifact from Mad Magazine to Michael Jackson's sister, ''The Goonies'' doesn't even pretend to court the grown-up set. So there may be those who share the sentiments of the ''Goonies'' character who declares, ''I feel like I'm babysitting, except I'm not getting paid,'' but that hardly matters. There isn't a child in America who won't want to see ''The Goonies'' this summer.

title: UNIVERSAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I sometimes think it's more difficult to get an American Express card than a security clearance.'' - Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware. [D18:6.]

title: East River Savings Sale
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the New York State Banking Department yesterday approved the sale of the East River Savings Bank to Alvin Dworman, a New York real estate developer.

title: QUINONES CITES DUTY OF THE CITY TO TEACH HOMOSEXUAL PUPILS
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones said yesterday that the New York City Board of Education had sponsored a school for homosexual adolescents because it was the only way to provide them with the education that state law requires.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Shea Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Opener of four-game weekend homestand series that includes the season's first doubleheader on Sunday. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 8 P.M.) Yankees vs.

title: A Novel Takes Off
description: This is the story of Bob Weiss, a novelist, who recently moved from Washington to Greenwich Village, a spot well known for its hospitality to writers.

title: Gencorp President To Add Chief's Post
description: Gencorp Inc., the tire, broadcasting and aerospace company, yesterday named its president, A. William Reynolds, to the added post of chief executive officer, effective Aug. 1.

title: MCI Settlement
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said it had reached an agreement with the Bell Atlantic Corporation, including a cash payment to MCI in settlement of antitrust claims. MCI said that the agreement reduced Bell Atlantic's liability in two antitrust suits filed by MCI against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the Bell system and various independent telephone companies. MCI also announced agreement on a series of business relationships, including arrangements for Bell Atlantic's seven local operating companies to perform long-distance billing services for MCI.

title: Olympic Confidence
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee, said yesterday he had been assured by the Soviet Union and other Soviet-bloc nations that they were planning to participate in the 1988 Olympic Games at Seoul, South Korea. There had been indications that the Soviet bloc contemplated a similar boycott of the Seoul Games because South Korea has no diplomatic relations with any Communist country.

title: HANDLEMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid May 10.

title: Philly Joe Jones Quintet
description: The drummer Philly Joe Jones and his quintet will play the music of Tadd Dameron tonight at 9 and 10:30 at the Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street near East Third Street (505-5660). The group includes Clifford Jordan on tenor saxophone, Walter Bishop Jr. on piano, Don Sickler on trumpet and Larry Ridley on bass. Tickets are $8 ($6 for students and the elderly).

title: Address Unknown
description: Rhode Island may be small and thickly settled, but not so much so that it doesn't have people living in the middle of nowhere. Ask where they live, and they'll tell you: ''half a mile down the road'' or ''a stretch in from the highway.''

title: Decision Due
description: The Joint Review Committee, a three-member panel of physicians established by baseball's joint drug agreement last year, is expected to decide on Monday whether Alan Wiggins is fit to rejoin the San Diego Padres. The second baseman, who missed a game and then checked into a drug treatment program in April, says he's put his drug problems behind him and is ready to resume his career.

title: FIRM HAND GUIDES KENNEDY TO THE TOP
description: When Neal Baskin became the head baseball coach at Kennedy High School in the Bronx 12 years ago, his goal was simple and direct: He wanted to win immediately.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE SEVEN DAY CIRCLE. The History and Meaning of the Week. By Eviatar Zerubavel. 206 pages. The Free Press. $16.95 DAYS, months and years were given to us by nature, but we invented the week for ourselves. There is nothing inevitable about a seven-day cycle, or about any other kind of week; it represents an arbitrary rhythm imposed on our activities, unrelated to anything in the natural order. But where the week exists - and there have been many cultures where it doesn't - it is so deeply embedded in our experience that we hardly ever question its rightness, or think of it as an artificial convention; for most of us it is a matter of ''second nature.''

title: 'BYE, NATIONAL PARKS
description: The national parks are as sacred to most Americans as the flag, motherhood and apple pie, but unlike those other symbols of our national psyche, the National Park System is in imminent danger.

title: Table-Hopping
description: Is eating out in? Or is it out?

title: HAUNTED CASTLE MANAGER SAYS HE REPORTED PERILS
