description: The day manager of the Haunted Castle testified today that for several days before a fire took eight lives at the amusement park attraction he had referred to the castle in reports as the ''Haunted Heap.''

title: THORNS IN THE ROSES
description: The roses are blooming deliciously along all the main avenues. And with the warm weather, people look well enough in bright summer clothes. There is still some flair in this city, which once took pride in being called the ''Paris of the East.''

title: How the 1040 Has Grown
description: There is more than one way to look at current proposals for tax simplification. Consider:

title: What's a Mother to Do? Go Out and Play Soccer
description: The score was 1-1. The fans were going wild. It was a tough match between the reigning four-time league champions and a team of gutsy upstarts. Several players had taken spills. One had punched another in the chest in retaliation for being kicked in the leg. Red-faced and shouting from the sidelines, the coach of the top-ranked and now threatened team berated his players: ''You're doing too much sissy kicking!''

title: D'LITES OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to April 3
description: b-Including tax credits of $180,000 for the quarter and $436,000 for the year. c-Including a tax credit of $126,000 for the quarter and year.

title: RECYCLING PROJECTS MEET HARD TIMES
description: The residents of Boulder, Colo., and nearby Longmont were so diligent last year about putting out their bundled newspapers, glass bottles and aluminum cans that the area's recycling program turned a $34,000 profit.

title: MADONNA AND HER CLONES
description: She uses only one name, but no matter. Only those who have been residing on the planet Jupiter for the last several years need to ask Madonna who? Rock's hottest female star, whose hits include ''Borderline,'' ''Material Girl'' and ''Like a Virgin,'' is in New York for performances at Radio City Music Hall and Madison Square Garden.

title: HAROLD O. WARREN Jr.
description: Harold O. Warren Jr., retired managing editor of Family Circle magazine, died of cancer May 15 in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Lear Fan Files For Chapter 7
description: Lear Fan Ltd. has filed for Chapter 7 liquidation proceedings in United States bankruptcy court, listing assets of $7 million and liabilities of $475 million. The company closed its operations last week.

title: Reporter Is Spared Jail As Witness Volunteers
description: A reporter was spared three months in jail for contempt today when the source she refused to identify came forward and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors.

title: Hayes Wins School Title
description: Javier Vasquez drilled a two-run single to right field in the seventh inning as Cardinal Hayes snapped the 16-game victory streak of Mt. St. Michael, 5-2, to capture the New York City Catholic High School Athletic Association baseball championship yesterday at Yankee Stadium.

title: Dow Climbs 6.72, to 1,327.28
description: Stock prices, again hitting record levels, rose moderately yesterday as General Motors and reborn technology stocks paced the climb.

title: NATIONAL TECHNICAL SYSTMES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
THE MUSEUM SCENE: NO TIME FOR DOLDRUMS
description: IF anyone asks whether New York's museums are taking it easy now that summer's near, the answer is ''Not so as you'd notice.''

title: CIRCUS CIRCUS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CANADIAN IMPERIAL BANK OF COMMERCE reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Burger King Plans Saturation Campaign
description: In about a week, the answer to the important question ''Where's the beef?'' is going to be amended to read, Burger King. That's when the Pillsbury subsidiary will introduce a bigger Whopper, bigger even than Wendy's burger, which inspired the ''Where's the beef?'' campaign.

title: NEW LIFE FOR A PROBLEM PLANE
description: Buried among 200 pages of the 1986 military programs bill that the House of Representatives will debate this month is a Congressional instruction that is rare in the annals of Air Force procurement. It calls for direct competition between two warplanes - the General Dynamics F-16 Falcon, of which the Air Force has already acquired more than 1,300, and Northrop's F-20 Tigershark, a plane that nobody has bought so far.

title: Blues and Rock Concert
description: The Leroi Brothers, a blues band from Austin, Tex., will headline a triple bill with two rock bands, the Reducers and the Rattlers, on Saturday at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place at East 15th Street (477-3728). Live music begins at about 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $10.

title: Book Fair Footnote
description: To the Editor:

title: PARTY LOCALES SHIFT AS HOTEL STRIKE GOES ON
description: As the New York hotel strike continues, the number of shifts, postponements and cancellations of banquets, conferences, testimonials, parties, weddings, dinner-dances and receptions is increasing. Guests and organizers of events say either that they are afraid of confrontations with pickets or unwilling to cross picket lines. Theaters, private clubs, banquet and catering halls as well as hotels not being struck are being used for functions.

title: Police Exhibit and Tour
description: The world of cops and robbers is the topic of a walking tour tomorrow sponsored by the New York City Department of Records and Information. Joseph Vito, a former police captain, will lead walkers past Lower Manhattan sites that figured in police and criminal activities, including the former Tombs prison, the old Police Headquarters at 240 Centre Street, the new headquarters at 1 Police Plaza and the courthouses at Foley Square.

title: Court Upholds Pistol Contract
description: A court today rejected Smith & Wesson's suit to block a $56.7 million Pentagon contract for 9-millimeter pistols. Federal District Judge Frank H. Freedman said the gun maker failed to show that the Defense Department had acted illegally in awarding the contract to Beretta U.S.A.

title: ANIXTER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,690,000 for the quarter and $1,557,000 for the 9 months.

title: REAGAN AFFIRMS BASIS FOR HANOI TIES
description: President Reagan said today that Washington would not normalize relations with Hanoi until the Vietnamese accounted for all missing American servicemen and ended the occupation of Cambodia.

title: Chinese Offshore Field
description: The first oilfield in the South China Sea will start commercial production in June 1986, and output could reach 4.9 million barrels annually, People's Daily, the Communist Party newspaper, said today.

title: ARGENTINE DEBT RATING TESTED
description: Argentine officials and American bankers are scrambling to avert a downgrading of Argentine debt next Monday, which could cut into bank profits and scuttle a long-delayed package to reschedule the country's foreign debt.

title: BALDI IN MIDDLE FOR REDMEN
description: St. John's got the help it needed in the middle for next season when it recruited Marco Baldi, the 6-foot-11-inch center from Long Island Lutheran High School. Baldi, who announced his decision Wednesday, said he chose St. John's over Southern Cal and Maryland ''because it offered an opportunity to play right away.''

title: Britain Refuses Asylum For Nigerian Fugitive
description: The Government refused today to grant asylum to a fugitive Nigerian politician who was the victim of a bungled kidnapping attempt hear last year.

title: GIRL 'VERY SICK'
description: One of the five surviving Frustaci septuplets died today of a severe lung disease that has afflicted the infants since birth.

title: 4TH TAX BRACKET, FOR RICH, IS HINTED
description: In the first hint of what may be a budding Democratic strategy on tax legislation, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee suggested today that his committee might favor a tax rate for wealthy Americans higher than the 35 percent rate proposed by President Reagan.

title: Shell Development
description: The Shell Oil Company said it would spend about $500 million to develop its Green Canyon oil discoveries in the Gulf of Mexico, about 150 miles southwest of New Orleans. Development of its oil and natural gas finds will require the construction of the world's tallest offshore platform, Shell said. The Royal Dutch/Shell Group affiliate did not disclose its estimates of reserves in the area.

title: Books: Bypass Surgery
description: BYPASS: A Cardiologist Reveals What Every Patient Needs to Know. By Jonathan L. Halperin, M.D., and Richard Levine. 295 pages. Times Books. $16.95. EACH year about 200,000 coronary-bypass operations - the introduction of a transplanted blood vessel that shunts blood across diseased arterial tissue - are performed in the United States, making it the nation's most common major surgical procedure. It is also among the most expensive (if one leaves out the experimental artificial heart), siphoning some $5 billion annually from the public for support of this dramatic surgical assault on America's leading killer, heart disease. Are these operations necessary? Is the social cost of carrying them out worth it? These questions among others are addressed in ''Bypass,'' a refreshingly candid and fast-moving review of the state of affairs on the cardiac frontier by the cardiologist Jonathan L. Halperin of Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York and Richard Levine, a New York Times editor.

title: Europe Views U.S. Grain Aid
description: America's new crop export subsidies are too small to be effective and will not force the Common Market to quit subsidizing food sales abroad, Europe's top farm trade official said today. He is Franz Andriessen, Agricultural Commissioner of the European Economic Community.

title: 3 MILE ISLAND PLANT GETS CLOSE U.S. SURVEILLANCE
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission began a round-the-clock watch this morning at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant's Unit 1 reactor as utility workers prepared for its operation for the first time since an accident crippled its twin more than six years ago.

title: Hutton Officers Subpoenaed
description: Top officials of E. F. Hutton & Company were subpoenaed by a House Judiciary subcommittee today to testify at a June 19 hearing on the company's $4.35 billion fraudulent check writing scheme. The subcommittee on crime also subpoenaed documents from Hutton and records of banks that were defrauded by the leading brokerage firm.

title: Marijuana Ingredient Wins Drug Approval
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today that it had approved a new drug containing the active ingredient in marijuana, which has been shown to alleviate severe nausea and vomiting suffered by cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.

title: E.P.A. TO GIVE 341 SCHOOLS ASBESTOS FUNDS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it would give $45 million in grants and loans to 341 schools around the country to help them deal with asbestos hazards.

title: KOCH, IN SHIFT, WANTS PRIVATE CITIZENS ON POLICE REVIEW BOARD
description: Mayor Koch made an abrupt policy reversal yesterday and endorsed an effort to include private citizens on the Police Department panel that investigates complaints about police brutality.

title: TALKS IN GENEVA PRIORITY OF NATO
description: NATO foreign ministers stressed today that differences over existing arms treaties and space weapons should not be allowed to interfere with the Geneva arms talks, Western European officials here said.

title: How Estimates Of Profits Vary
description: ALTHOUGH this has been a volatile year for stocks, one constant has remained. Security analysts have steadily been cutting their estimates of corporate earnings for 1985.

title: AZNAVOUR'S BACK IN TOWN AND SINGING AT CARNEGIE
description: ''Something I never say is 'in the old days,' '' Charles Aznavour observed the other day. ''If you're not trying to step back, if you go with the times, every day is your day.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on May 29 about Ethiopian Hebrew congregations in New York City misidentified the rabbi who said he had been inspired by a visit to a Harlem congregation.

title: Close the Murder Gap
description: In New York's Legislature, death-penalty politics follows a familiar script: Supporters persuade a majority of the legislators to pass a bill restoring capital punishment. The Governor vetoes it. The pro-death forces, lacking the votes to override, withdraw, vowing victory next session.

title: CITY GAS CO OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JAYS WIN IN 12 ON HOMER, 2-0
description: Buck Martinez hit a two-run home run off Aurelio Lopez in the 12th inning tonight as the Toronto Blue Jays, whose Jimmy Key lost a no-hit bid three innings earlier, beat the Detroit Tigers, 2-0, in the opener of a four-game series.

title: WHITSON, YANKS STAY IN SLUMP
description: Away from Yankee Stadium and the ridicule that has hounded him there, the troubles of Ed Whitson continue.

title: DR. MORTIMER GENAUER
description: Dr. Mortimer B. Genauer, retired chief of anesthesiology at St. Vincent's Medical Center of Richmond, died of a heart attack yesterday at the hospital, on Staten Island. He was 77 years old and lived in Grimes Hill, S.I.

title: SOME VERY SPECIAL GUIDES ON A MUSICAL PASSAGE TO INDIA
description: THE classical music of India is the oldest unbroken musical tradition in the world, a body of compositional materials and guidelines for individual expression and improvisation that has been passed down from guru to disciple since before recorded history. This weekend, two concerts will give New Yorkers a chance to hear some leading exponents of this age-old tradition.

title: Sweetening the Cider
description: To the Editor:

title: Editor Arrested in Bid For Interview in Case
description: An editor for The New York Times, John W. Finney, was arrested today by the West Dennis police on charges of trespassing as he was trying to arrange an interview in connection with the Walker family spy case.

title: RESORTS BID FOR T.W.A. IS RUMORED
description: Resorts International Inc., the hotel and casino operator, has joined the bidding for Trans World Airlines, a company that is seeking to avoid the clutches of Carl C. Icahn, according to Wall Street sources.

title: NEW TRIAL ORDERED FOR A MAN FEIGNING VIETNAM SYNDROME
description: The state's highest court today ordered a trial for a robbery suspect who tried to avoid prison by falsely contending that he was suffering from Vietnam stress syndrome. In fact, he had never served in Vietnam.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Fluke Fishing Picking Up
description: Margate, N.J.:Bluefish are abundant and the larger ones, 10 to 12 pounds, are about seven to eight miles offshore.

title: Wartime Mine Kills 4 in Riga
description: Three boys and a 77-year-old woman were killed in an explosion apparently caused by a World War II antitank mine in Riga, according to the newspaper Sovetskaya Latviya. The boys, aged between 7 and 12, were apparently playing with the mine, the paper said. The incident occurred on May 27.

title: ON WNYC, MCGOOHAN STARS IN 'THE PRISONER'
description: As reruns get under way in earnest at this time of the year, WNYC-TV is reaching further into the past than most stations in an effort to find viable programs. It has grabbed ''The Prisoner,'' a 17-part series made in the 60's by ITC Entertainment of Britain, a commercial organization.

title: By Friendly Beanball
description: Tim Birtsas, Oakland's young left-hander, displayed a wicked knuckle curve in shutting down the Yankees the other night.

title: Spinks Now 27-0
description: Michael Spinks knocked down Diamond Jim MacDonald three times before stopping the courageous but outclassed challenger at 1:30 of the eighth round tonight to retain his undisputed light heavyweight title.

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: GERICAULT DRAWINGS AT THE MORGAN LIBRARY
description: WE still tend to think of Theodore Gericault (1791-1824) as a one-painting artist. When his name comes up, our minds flash to ''The Raft of the Medusa,'' an immense extravaganza that melodramatically depicts a ghastly cargo of shipwreck survivors on a makeshift raft. The masterpiece of his short career, it overshadows all his other work in size and in the grandiose intensity of its composition.

title: Federal Support Keeps Social Services Equal
description: To the Editor:

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE invasion of the pastel pasta makers may be under way. First it was Mezzaluna at Third Avenue near 74th Street (212-535-9600), the colorful Italian cafe the size of a studio apartment that serves sprightly pumpkin tortellini, green cannelloni and tortellini with pink sauce.

title: ONE IS A SURPRISE
description: Eleven 3-year-olds, including a gelding, a reformed ''rabbit,'' a last-minute surprise and a recent maiden, were entered yesterday for the 117th Belmont Stakes at Belmont Park Saturday.

title: Columbia Report
description: Columbia Pictures Industries, a subsidiary of the Coca-Cola Company, has declined comment on published reports that it is negotiating to buy Embassy Communications Inc., the movie and television production company co-founded by the producer Norman Lear. Trade reports have said that Columbia would pay $250 million for a controlling interest in Embassy.

title: VERSATILE ACTOR-DANCER
description: Raymond Serrano may turn up one night on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House as a mad old crone intent on separating a pair of 19th-century lovers in American Ballet Theater's ''Sylphide.'' The next night he is the seething Rasputin in Kenneth MacMillan's ''Anastasia.'' '' And tomorrow afternoon, Mr. Serrano will defend the family honor as the angry, driven Tybalt in MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet.''

title: THIRD WORLD, THIRD WAY
description: In recent years, American foreign policy in the third world has been based on a despair of the center. There is no third way, we concluded, between the extremes of Fascism and Communism. But we may have been wrong.

title: NORTHWEST TELEPRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in January.

title: MUSIC: IN SAN FRANCISCO, WAGNER'S 'SIEGFRIED'
description: It is a fair question to ask any director of a new production of a familiar opera: What are you trying to say to us that hasn't been said before? In regard to Wagner's ''Ring,'' that is an especially stern request simply because for a century and more this cycle has been the subject of more interpretative debate than any work but the Bible. In other words, if all a new production does is replace worn sets and costumes, its importance is severely limited.

title: 2 SENATORS URGE REAGAN TO CUT ACCESS TO SECRETS
description: Two Senators today proposed a sweeping overhaul of Government security procedures to limit access to official secrets and speed background investigations of individuals in sensitive jobs.

title: ATCO LTD reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: There were no share earnings in the prior year because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: Sator Sought After
description: Assistant coaches usually keep one eye open for a head coaching job, but Ted Sator of the Philadelphia Flyers is a National Hockey League assistant with both eyes open.

title: Dining Out Guide: Restaurants With Views
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. BEEKMAN HOTEL, Top of the Towers, First Avenue at 49th Street (355-7300) -

title: 900 GRADUATES AT YESHIVA HEAR TALK INOUYE
description: Senator Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii, addressing more than 900 Yeshiva University graduates, urged the Reagan Administration yesterday to reject plans to sell F-20 fighter planes and two advanced antiaircraft systems to Jordan.

title: Sipe at Risk
description: Brian Sipe, the Jacksonville Bulls' quarterback who underwent shoulder surgery on Wednesday, his second such operation in three months, has been advised to give up football or face the risk of permanent damage and a life of pain.

title: SENATE ROLL-CALL ON AID TO REBELS
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate approved an amendment today that would authorize nonmilitary aid to the Nicaraguan rebels:

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $302.1 million, to $213.75 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: CAGLE'S INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $528,000 and a tax credit of $280,000. c-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $257,000.

title: 17 ARE ACCUSED OF MONEY LAUNDERING IN PUERTO RICO DRUG INVESTIGATION
description: The United States Justice Department charged 17 bankers today with 57 counts of conspiring to defraud the Government and failing to report cash transactions over $10,000.

title: DECA ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
CUOMO AT N.Y.U. RITES
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday extolled the virtues and opportunities of life in New York to thousands of students, faculty members and visitors who assembled in bright sunshine in Washington Square Park for New York University's 153d commencement.

title: Chantey Sing-Along
description: Life at sea was not always easy, but it was musical.

title: UNITED TOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income c-After losses from discontinued operations of $69,624 for the quarter and $234,574 for the 6 months and tax credits of $182,429 and $334,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday FOLK-ROCK FROM ENGLAND Contemporary interpretations of traditional English folk tunes will be on the program when three well-known English folk-rock groups join forces for a triple-bill concert tonight. Steeleye Span, one of Britain's most popular folk-rock groups of the 1970's, mixes acoustic and electric music, drawing on traditional folk songs and poetry for its source material and featuring the vocals of Maddy Pryor. Renaissance, another popular group in Britain, will perform an entirely acoustic program for this engagement. Despite some changes in personnel, Fairport Convention continues to perform its electric versions of traditional tunes, as well as original material. The concert gets under way at 8 o'clock in the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 74th Street on the Upper West Side. Tickets are $14.50 and $17.50. The information number is 787-1477.

title: Whales and Poetry
description: In its checkered history, the United Nations General Assembly Hall has played host to a staggering selection of speakers. On Wednesday night, in what observers say was a historical first, a pod of Russian beluga whales added their voices to the cacophonous chorus.

title: S.M.U Fights Back
description: Southern Methodist University is apparently not going to accept a National Collegiate Athletic Association proposal to impose sanctions on the school's football program for engaging in illegal recruiting practices. Bob Hitch, the S.M.U. athletic director, would not comment, but according to The Dallas Times Herald, school officials have decided to mount a stiff challenge, including a possible lawsuit testing the validity of the N.C.A.A.'s enforcement procedures, rather than accept the findings and recommendations of the N.C.A.A.'s committee on infractions.

title: Illinois Student Wins National Spelling Bee
description: Balu Natarajan, a 13-year-old eighth grade student from Bowling Brook, Ill., won the 58th annual Scripps Howard National Spelling Bee Thursday, by correctly spelling the word milieu.

title: Blame Television
description: The record books are a little hazy on the matter, but it is believed that Wednesday night marked the first time that a boxing match at an Atlantic City casino was ever delayed because of rain in Omaha. It was television, of course, that was responsible.

title: Silver Lining
description: Met fans who are growing miffed at the way George Foster has been stranding all those runners in scoring position won't take much solace from this, but the fact is that things could be worse. Take Wednesday night's game at Detroit, where Larry Herndon went to bat three times with the bases loaded and failed to advance even one of those nine runners. Herndon escaped the postgame glare, though, as the Tigers were still able to beat Seattle, 5-2.

title: DANCE: FINIS JHUNG WORKS CHAMBER BALLET U.S.A.
description: THE Chamber Ballet U.S.A., founded and directed by Finis Jhung, returned Wednesday night to the Symphony Space, 95th Street and Broadway, with the first of two programs that run through Sunday.

title: DANNERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
HAROLD PRINCE QUITS THEATER LEAGUE
description: Harold Prince, one of the most prominent Broadway directors and producers of the last 30 years, resigned Wednesday from the League of American Theaters and Producers. In a statement issued yesterday, Mr. Prince accused the league, Broadway's trade association, of paying too little attention to rising ticket prices and labor costs.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IN the Bronx Zoo's new Jungle World, the rare proboscis monkey, the 750-pound Malayan tapir and the black leopard, none of them night owls, were preparing for bed Wednesday when 850 human beings showed up, cocktails in hand. Some had old-line names such as Astor, Roosevelt, Phipps and Frelinghuysen, and many wore pith helmets and bush jackets, dresses with exotic animal prints, British colonial uniforms and infinite variations on a jungle theme.

title: U.S. Presses New Nerve Gas
description: The Defense Department's chief civilian authority on chemical warfare issued a plea to the House of Representatives today to approve funds for new nerve gas weapons.

title: FORT LEE GROUP BUILDING PALISADES CONDOMINIUMS
description: More than 10 years have passed since the Centex Homes Corporation built the high-rise condominium project called Winston Towers on the Hudson River waterfront, just over the Fort Lee line in Cliffside Park.

title: Those Dirty Ashtrays
description: Like the missing strawberries aboard ship in the novel-play-film ''The Caine Mutiny,'' the mystery of the Navy's $659 ashtray will not subside. In a ''Dear Cap'' letter, Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona has asked Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger for a ''full report'' on whether the Secretary was justified in publicly disciplining three naval officers after the embarrassing news about the purchase of the exorbitantly priced aircraft ashtrays.

title: MCCANN AND CUCCI CAMPAIGN IN JERSEY CITY'S MAYORAL RACE
description: Mayor Gerald McCann occasionally broke into a trot as he tried to shake the hands of all of the potential voters directed into his path on Bergen Avenue and brought out of their homes by his aides.

title: GENOVESE DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 24
MCGUIGAN'S TITLE BOUT SIRES IRELAND
description: Such is the appeal of Barry McGuigan, the Irish boxer who fights under the slogan ''Let McGuigan do the fighting,'' that 12,000 fans from both sides of the border are coming from across the Irish Sea to cheer him here as he tries to take the world featherweight title from Eusebio Pedroza of Panama on Saturday night.

title: 'New Television,' Channel 13 Series
description: Viewers given to constant laments that television consists of little more than sit-coms, mini-series, old movies and sports might find some justification for revisionism on Channel 13 starting Sunday night.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Airman on Trial Over Secrets
description: Senior Airman Paula A. Wilderman, 22 years old, is being court martialed at Luke Air Force Base on charges of selling secrets to an undercover agent posing as an employee of the Rockewell International Corporation. Officials said the case does not involve foreign governments. Military lawyers appointed to defend the woman said she is charged with giving classified information to unauthorized persons and possessing drug paraphernalia.

title: NAVRATILOVA, LLOYD ADVANCE TO FINAL
description: Experience overcame youth today in the French Open tennis championships as Martina Navratilova, seeded No. 1, and Chris Evert Lloyd, seeded No. 2, advanced to the singles finals over younger opponents.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM: NIXON TALE, 'SECRET HNOR'
description: A dapperly dressed, fictional character named Richard M. Nixon, played by Philip Baker Hall, who sort of resembles the former President of the United States but certainly isn't a lookalike, comes into his wood-paneled study carrying a small wooden box, later revealed to contain a gun. He pours himself a brandy and, for about 10 seconds, remains settled comfortably in a chair in front of the fire.

title: Discover Charts a New Path
description: ''RIGHT now we are the most interesting thing going on in this building,'' said James B. Hayes, publisher of Discover magazine, in his 17th-floor office in the Time-Life Building. ''We're digging ourselves out of a hole and it's tough. But it's one hell of a lot of fun trying.'' And the magazine is not alone in its efforts. Top corporate management, having suffered the loss of face and cash attendant with the closing of TV-Cable Week, is committed to the revival of the science magazine. Henry A. Grunwald, the editor in chief of Time Inc., is personally taking a hand in its editorial repositioning, and even made a pitch for advertising at the recent meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: The company said the latest quarter and 6 months results include 9 cents a share from the sales of securities.

title: Thomas Cook Travel Acquires a Chairman
description: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation said yesterday that James Woodward, president of its Official Airline Guides Inc. subsidiary, had been named to the additional post of chairman of Thomas Cook Travel U.S.A., a unit Dun & Bradstreet acquired in March.

title: POP: MADONNA SINGS AT RADIO CITY
description: MADONNA'S rise from obscurity to the top of the pop charts has been so rapid that her current concert tour, which arrived at Radio City Music Hall last night for a three-performance engagement, is the first chance her fans have had to see her in the flesh. And seeing her, cheering her on, and singing along with her hits was just what the night's exuberant crowd seemed to have come for. It was evident that they had not come primarily to listen to her sing.

title: EXHUMED BODY IN BRAZIL SAID TO BE MENGELE'S
description: The Brazilian police today exhumed the remains of a man who was said to have died here six years ago and who the police say could be the long-sought Nazi death camp doctor, Josef Mengele.

title: People
description: John M. Otter, director of national broadcast, and Laura Silton, general manager of local broadcast, have been elected senior vice presidents at McCann-Erickson.

title: Cornrowing
description: Americana, from slavery to celebrity: The rows-of-corn hairdo is a symbol of black cultural pride plagiarized lately by style merchants into Minerva-like coiffures sported by such whites as the actress Bo Derek.

title: ROTHKO AT THE GUGGENHEIM
description: ''MARK ROTHKO: Works on Paper,'' at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, makes us feel as if we were inside Rothko's studio watching him build and coax and fret. It is the first major exhibition of works on paper by an artist who was at ease with paper and knew how to feed and stoke it so that it could swell with light. The exhibition is also something of a mini-retrospective that encourages us to reflect again upon one of the most difficult and complex of the Abstract Expressionists.

title: Decorum at the Forum
description: That was a terribly short-sighted thing Scotty Stirling did Wednesday night at the Forum. Acting in the interests of public image and good sportsmanship, Stirling told both coaches to lay off the goonery and the woofing that went on in last Sunday's game.

title: HITACHI LTD reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Results were converted at the rate of 250 yen equal $1.

title: Storage Area Explodes At Army Weapons Depot
description: A storage facility believed to contain TNT exploded tonight at the Lexington-Bluegass Army Depot near Richmond, a spokesman for the depot said.

title: Required Reading;   By Famous Last Words
description: Excerpts from Volume 14 of ''Foreign Relations, 1952-54,'' a State Department compilation of newly declassified Government documents from the Eisenhower Administration, many relating to the activities of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles:

title: PARAGUAYAN PUTS OFF BONN VISIT
description: President Alfredo Stroessner has postponed a trip to West Germany scheduled for July, West Germany's Ambassador to Paraguay said today.

title: NATIONAL MINE SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Net income.

title: TAX PLAN IS FOUGHT IN ALBANY
description: President Reagan's plan to end deductibility of local taxes would force states and municipalities to cut their own taxes and programs and to rely on the Federal Government to meet social needs, top Republican legislators said today.

title: PONDEROSA INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CONOLOG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
TRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The latest quarter and 9 months' results include a provision of $18 million for realignment of TRE's semiconductor equipment operations. The provision had a net after-tax effect of $1.31 a share.

title: BASE TEN SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: A SAMPLER OF WRITING BY THE COUNTRY EDITOR
description: Years ago, The Gazette used to give details concerning refreshments. Our reports would tell what was served at almost every gathering of ladies, gentlemen, Boy or Girl Scouts, members of this or that fraternity, and so on. But there was altogether too much jealousy concerning the various collations, and we kept getting complaints that the whipped cream had been omitted from the fruit salad cup in the Ladies' Social Circle report, or that The Gazette had seemed to favor the patty shells of the Degree of Pocahontas over the lettuce sandwiches of the Occidental Chapter, Daughters of Plutarch. After a while we became sick of this, and made an office rule that all refreshments should be treated alike. They would all be ''delicious'' in our columns, and never anything else, more or less. This worked pretty well, but ultimately the profusion of delicious refreshments was somewhat wearying, and we legislated further. Now refreshments are served, so far as the paper is concerned, and we do not characterize them. they must stand on their own feet. - From ''Country Editor,''

title: Sakharovs Have Been Taken From Home, Relatives Assert
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and dissident, and his wife have ''been removed involuntarily from their apartment'' in Gorky, the Soviet city where they are in internal exile, according to the Sakharovs' relatives in the United States.

title: 6,000 Salvadorans End A Monthlong Strike
description: About 6,000 Social Security workers ended a monthlong strike today after the Government freed two jailed labor leaders.

title: Drugs Seized in Malaysia
description: The Johore state police chief said today that drug-control officers detained 1,850 people, including 23 officials, and confiscated large amounts of drugs between January and May.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in Business Day on Wednesday listing sales of black-owned hair-care companies incorrectly labeled the figures. They were in thousands of dollars.

title: ANOTHER JOHNSON STEALS SHOW
description: Earvin (Magic) Johnson of the Los Angeles Lakers and Dennis Johnson of the Boston Celtics have more in common than last names. Both are talented point guards for excellent teams. And they are also very close friends.

title: Madge West, an Actress, 93; Made Theater Debut in 1897
description: Madge West, an actress who studied under David Belasco and whose career extended from the early days of Broadway to recent television commercials, died on May 29 at her home in Memphis from complications following a fall. She was 93 years old.

title: Talks Resume Today In City's Hotel Strike
description: After a one-day break, negotiations are to resume this morning in an attempt to end the strike against 55 hotels in New York City.

title: Citicorp Seeks Argentine Role
description: Citicorp would be willing to take over a failed bank in Argentina under certain conditions, Citicorp's chairman, John S. Reed, said today.

title: St. John's Performance
description: I Giullari di Piazza, the New York performance troupe that has been recreating the music, dance and street theater of Southern Italy in a series of spring concerts at St. John's Church in the Village, 224 Waverly Place, over the last month, will present three performances this weekend of ''L'Ammor Folle,'' a 16th-century Neapolitan commedia dell'arte farce.

title: Eckerd Rebuffs Dart Overture
description: The Jack Eckerd Corporation said that the ''secret accumulation'' of its stock by the Dart Group Corporation was unsolicited and unwelcomed, and it added that the drugstore chain was not for sale.

title: HOSPITAL STRUCK BY 151 INTERNS AND RESIDENTS
description: After completing their morning rounds, interns and residents at Interfaith Medical Center in Brooklyn began a strike at the center's two sites yesterday morning in a dispute over pay and the future of their union.

title: U.S. Jury Deliberates In Suit on Klansmen
description: A Federal jury began deliberations today in the civil suit alleging that law-enforcement officials failed to protect demonstrators at a 1979 rally against the Ku Klux Klan in which five people died.

title: EAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 20
CITY IS BESIEGED ONCE MORE IN EFFORT TO PLACE HOMELESS
description: The cards pinned to their lapels read ''New York Begins in Maspeth,'' but as the people of Maspeth, Queens, turned out by the busload yesterday to fight a proposed shelter for the homeless, they spoke of their fears rather than their hope.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 7, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Science and Technology - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. >ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Population Award Presentation Ceremony - 6 P.M. >TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Still No Policy in Nicaragua
description: President Reagan's yearlong haggling with Congress over how to parse aid to the rebels attacking Nicaragua continues. The Senate has again voted for ''humanitarian'' subsidy; the balkier House votes again Tuesday. And how, asks the President, pounding the table for emphasis, can this passel of politicians ever agree on the tricky details of foreign policy? Good question.

title: Internorth Terms
description: Internorth Inc. said that it had agreed to sell several of the Houston Natural Gas Corporation's pipelines and gathering facilities to meet Federal Trade Commission requirements on its previously announced $2.3 billion merger with Houston Natural. As a result of the agreement, Internorth said that it had accepted for payment the 58 percent of Houston Natural's outstanding shares that have been tendered under its $70-a-share offer. The offer expires today unless extended.

title: KERKORIAN MAKES OFFER FOR REST OF MGM GRAND
description: Kirk Kerkorian, the Las Vegas financier who controls 70 percent of the stock in MGM Grand Hotels Inc., today offered to purchase all of the remaining shares for $126 million in cash.

title: BROADWAY
description: ''IT is not your ordinary musical,'' said an early information sheet sent out about a proposed Broadway show named ''Teddy and Alice.'' Maybe it is and maybe it isn't, but it will not have its unveiling on Broadway. A long excerpt of the show will be telecast Sunday at 4 P.M. on WNYC-Channel 31 on an hourlong pilot called ''Be An Angel.''

title: Mexican Is Indicted In Death of 2 Americans
description: Rafael Caro Quintero, who has been jailed on charges of murdering a United States narcotics agent, has been indicted in the murders of two other Americans who apparently crashed a private party, the United States Embassy said today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table of bank account rates in Business Day yesterday carried incorrect figures for the Bank Rate Monitor Index. The index for money market accounts was 7.28 percent and for six-month certificates 7.83 percent.

title: ARMS CONTROL AND THE RUSSIANS: BATTLE ON COMPLIANCE HEATS UP
description: A fight is heating up between the Reagan Administration and its critics over possible Soviet cheating on strategic arms control agreements and what to do about it.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Burns & Roe Inc., an engineering and construction company with headquarters in Oradell, N.J., has elected W.R. Cobean Jr. executive vice president.

title: EDUCATION'S ROLE AFFIRMED
description: Dr. Hanna Holborn Gray, president of the University of Chicago, told 234 doctoral graduates of the City University Graduate School yesterday that the pessimism inherent in recent reports questioning the direction of higher education conjure up a nonexistent ''golden age'' of progress in American universities.

title: YOUTH SEIZED IN SLAYING OF MAMARONECK GIRL, 17
description: A New Rochelle youth was arrested today and charged with strangling a 17-year-old girl whose body was found at a motel here.

title: Blauvelt 'Robin Hood'
description: A musical production of ''Robin Hood,'' based on the light opera by Reginald DeKoven, will be presented this weekend at the South Orangetown Middle School on Van Wyck Road in Blauvelt, N.Y. Written by Nancy Ponder, it features students and members of the community.

title: Rates Rise After 4-Day Slide
description: Interest rates on short- and long-term Treasury securities rose modestly yesterday, after falling sharply the previous four days.

title: SOME ISRAELIS STAY BEHIND IN LEBANON
description: Israel began withdrawing the last of its combat soldiers from Lebanon today but left behind several hundred so-called military advisers in a security zone along its northern frontier, military sources here said.

title: FIREFIGHTER HONORED AT CITY HALL FOR RESCUING WOMAN AND CHILD
description: There were times, James A. Sollami said yesterday, when he used to think of the danger of being a firefighter and wonder why he was one.

title: Bradford Fire Toll Is Now 55
description: Another badly burned victim of the fire at a Bradford soccer stadium has died, bringing the death toll to 55, officials said today. The death was announced on the second day of a public inquiry at Bradford City Hall into the cause of the May 11 disaster.

title: WEINBERGER SAYS HE'LL CUT BACK ON PEOPLE WITH SECURITY ACCESS
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the Pentagon would reduce the number of people who had access to secret information so as to foil spy rings like the one John A. Walker, a retired Navy warrant officer, is accused of running for 18 years.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 7, 1985

title: SCHWITTERS AT THE MODERN
description: THE retrospective exhibition of Kurt Schwitters at the Museum of Modern Art is right there where it should be, in that Schwitters in his stricken and penurious last months was supported by a no-strings grant from the Modern. It is also well timed, in that although Schwitters is by any standard a well-known artist, he has nothing like the great name that he deserves.

title: AUCTIONS
description: DECORATIVE arts of the 20th century - furniture, stained-glass windows, Tiffany lamps, bronze vases and post-World War II glassware - are commanding increasingly high auction prices, with the result that more major works are showing up at public sales.

title: Bridge: Knockout Events Increase In Popularity and Duration
description: Those who plan the schedules of major tournaments have recently recognized the great popularity of knockout team events. These are no longer provided only for the top experts who are seeking major national titles, but for the large number of good players who want something more challenging than the customary Swiss team events.

title: The 'Self-Deception' Of the Palestinians
description: To the Editor:

title: Hearing in House
description: An official of the Department of Transportation told a House panel today that no new legislation was needed to protect carriers, such as Trans World Airlines, during the time it takes the department to investigate whether an individual is fit to hold a certificate to operate an airline.

title: NEW YORK JOINING JERSEY TO COMBAT SALES-TAX EVASION
description: New York and New Jersey announced yesterday an agreement intended to thwart an estimated $100 million a year in tax evasion by businesses and customers who avoid sales taxes by sending purchases out of state.

title: San Antonio Offer Of Sewer Bonds
description: San Antonio is offering $85 million of prior lien sewer system revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8.85 percent for bonds due in 2010 through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.

title: LEBANESE SHIITE THREATENS ISRAEL OF ITS SECURITY PLANS IN THE SOUTH
description: The leader of the Lebanese Shiite Moslem militia said today that he would join forces with Palestinian guerrillas if Israel kept troops in southern Lebanon and continued to insist on retaining a security zone north of its border, both of which the Israelis have said they will do.

title: Democrats Try to Turn Swords Into Swords
description: Ever since President Reagan's landslide re-election last fall, Democrats in the House of Representatives have been on the prowl for ways to shake their negative image, especially the Republican contention that they are ''soft on defense.''

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: OASES OF TRANQUILITY IN BUSTLING CITY
description: THE notion of a public garden has come a long way since the 17th century, when European royalty first designed them to entertain their subjects. Today's New Yorkers don't even have to leave the city to meditate in a Japanese tea house, to stroll through a hemlock forest, to enjoy hundreds of varieties of blooming roses or to sunbathe next to Claes Oldenburg's Geometric Mouse.

title: CARDS OFF AND RUNNING IN '85
description: The St. Louis Cardinals streak into town tonight with baseball's foremost track team and scoring ensemble, and they will confront the Mets this weekend with the offense that has produced the best batting average, the most hits, the most runs and the most stolen bases in the National League.

title: Unocal Offer
description: The Unocal Corporation said the final count of common shares in its exchange offer for a $72-a-share package of senior secured notes was 151,021,000 shares, including 23.7 million shares tendered by Mesa Partners II, the investment group headed by T. Boone Pickens. Unocal said it had accepted 59.3 million shares for exchange under the provisions of the offer and the May 20 agreement settling its takeover battle with Mr. Pickens. After the offer, Unocal will be left with about 116 million common shares outstanding and about $4.16 billion in new senior notes.

title: Khmer Rouge Said to Kill 28
description: Khmer Rouge guerrillas said today that they had killed 28 Vietnamese soldiers and wounded 34 in an attack on a Vietnamese base in southwestern Cambodia. The Khmer Rouge radio, monitored in Bangkok, said the battle took place Monday near Koh Konglue in Koh Kong province. Khmer Rouge claims cannot be independently verified, and are often regarded as exaggerated.

title: BANKER'S NOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
Control Data to Idle Plants for 2 Weeks
description: The Control Data Corporation, responding to declining orders, said yesterday that it was consolidating two of its disk drive assembly plants near Minneapolis and that it would idle 29 other facilities throughout the country for two-week periods, beginning next month. The company said the move would result in the temporary layoff of ''several thousand'' employees.

title: Reds' Success: Reasons Why
description: The Reds, hanging in so much tougher than anybody had reason to expect, will play a twilight-night doubleheader against San Diego this evening, opening a four-game weekend battle for first place in the National League's Western Division. How has Cincinnati been doing it?

title: SENATE WOULD AID NICARAGUA REBELS WITH $38 MILLION
description: The Senate approved an amendment today that would authorize $38 million in nonmilitary aid over two years to the Nicaraguan rebels. The vote was 55 to 42. The vote attached the aid package to a bill outlining programs for the State Department.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 7, 1985

title: AQUINO WITNESS IS SHARPLY QUESTIONED
description: Defense lawyers representing the military men accused in the 1983 assassination of the opposition leader, Benigno S. Aquino Jr. began an assault today on the credibility and character of the prosecution's key witness.

title: HOUSE, 203-202, REDUCES FEDERAL WATER PROJECTS
description: The House of Representatives today cut the appropriation for water projects by $99 million, a cut that could affect 31 projects across the country.

title: ENGLISH TEAMS GET AWAY-GAMES BAN
description: The governing body of world soccer today banned English professional teams indefinitely from world competition anywhere outside England because of the Brussels soccer riot last week.

title: FIGHTING THE LAST WAR
description: The Senate is about to confirm William Bradford Reynolds as Associate Attorney General -his reward from President Reagan for seeking, as head of the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division, tax advantages for segregated private schools; trying to weaken the Voting Rights Act; leading the Administration's attack on affirmative action programs, and continuing to fight the last war against busing to achieve school desegregation.

title: Morgan Stanley Aide Active in Hughes Sale
description: During his nine years at Morgan Stanley & Company, Bruce D. Fiedorek, 34, a managing director in the firm's mergers and acquisitions department, has played a major role in some very big deals, including the Du Pont Company's $7.3 billion purchase of Conoco Inc. in 1981. But the $5 billion sale of the Hughes Aircraft Company to the General Motors Corporation, a transaction that was announced on Wednesday, is in a class by itself, he said.

title: Mobile Phone Dumping
description: The Commerce Department said today that it had made a preliminary ruling that cellular radio mobile telephones from Japan were being sold in the United States at unfairly low prices. Importers must post bonds or cash deposits to offset the dumping margins, the department said.

title: Nathan Hale a State Hero
description: A bill designating the Revolutionary War patriot Nathan Hale as the state hero was signed by Gov. William A. O'Neill today, the 230th anniversary of Hale's birth in the Connecticut town of Coventry. On Sept. 21, 1776, the 21-year-old Hale, disguised as a Dutch schoolmaster, was captured by the British during a spy mission. Tradition holds that just before he was hanged, he said, ''I only regret that I have but one life to lose for my country.''

title: Miami, Arkansas Survive in Series
description: Ric Raether, Miami's relief ace, held off Oklahoma State to preserve a 2-1 College World Series victory tonight.

title: A New Role
description: Sam Rutigliano, dismissed last season as coach of the Cleveland Browns, has signed on as a television football analyst with N.B.C.

title: Pizza Inn Restaurants Selects Marschalk
description: The Houston office of Marschalk, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has been selected as agency by the Pizza Inn Restaurants, a Dallas-based chain of fast-food outlets.

title: MEESE TO CHALLENGE DECISION ON CRIME PANEL
description: The Justice Department said today that it would seek further review of a Federal appellate court panel's decision that the membership of two Federal judges on President Reagan's Commission on Organized Crime was unconstitutional.

title: AGCA SAYS BULGARIA ABETTED A TERRORIST GROUP IN TURKEY
description: The Turkish terrorist who shot and wounded Pope John Paul II testified today that members of the Turkish underworld, working with the Bulgarian authorities, helped finance terrorism to undermine Turkey's civilian Government in the late 1970's.

title: HOUSE OF FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
By Great Lakes Pipe To Parched East Coast
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman, 64, Slain in Home
description: A 64-year-old woman was found stabbed to death in her Harlem apartment last night, the apparent victim of a robbery. Police officers discovered the body of the woman, Francise Clayton of 282 Manhattan Avenue, at 9 P.M. The police believe she was attacked when she opened her door.

title: BUILDING 83: SCHOOL FOR NAVY'S RADIO OFFICERS
description: At the United States Naval Training Center here, in a nondescript three-story building marked 83, John A. Walker Jr. and Jerry A. Whitworth taught radio communications and formed a friendship that the Federal Bureau of Investigation says led to one of the largest spying cases in recent memory.

title: VANDALS MAR DEBUT OF NEW IRT CARS
description: The first new train on the West Side IRT subway line in more than 20 years had not finished a full trip before vandals sprayed paint all over it and tried to kick out its windows.

title: BRIEFS
description: Aetna Life and Casualty Co. said it had tentatively agreed to acquire the remaining 13 percent of Federated Investors Inc., for one million Aetna common shares.

title: There Is No Free Advice
description: Be advised that the Federal Government paid $71 million last year to get otherwise free advice from an array of more than 1,000 Federal advisory committees consisting of 25,162 appointees, ''the fourth arm of Government,'' as it is called by President Reagan.

title: NOMINEE WITHDRAWS EFFORT TO HEAD CIVIL SERVICE ANEW
description: Saying he faced the near certainty that he would not be confirmed by the Senate for a second term as head of the Office of Personnel Management, Donald J. Devine asked today that his name be withdrawn.

title: How to Tell Ohio From North Carolina
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Basic Justice' in Poland Is in Danger, Glemp Says
description: Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Roman Catholic Archbishop, said today, a day before a dissident trial resumes, that human rights and ''basic justice'' were threatened in Poland.

title: NICARAGUAN SAYS AN ATTACK BY U.S. WOULD BE DEFEATED
description: The Nicaraguan Defense Minister said today that if the United States ever invaded Nicaragua, its forces would be defeated by ''a very mobile, very irregular form of armed resistance.''

title: ROOKIE SOUTHPOW TIES BURNS FOR LEAD
description: For the last two years Russ Cochran was the only left-handed golfer on the PGA Tour, which has not had a southpaw winner since New Bob Charles of New Zealand won the 1974 Greater Greensboro Open. But now there is a left-handed rookie, Ernie Gonzalez, to keep Cochran company.

title: Little Johnny Scott
description: The singer Little Jimmy Scott will perform tonight and tomorrow at Sutton's, 403 West 145th Street (283-9523). Sets begin at 10:30 P.M. and 12:30 and 2:30 A.M. There is an $8 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Saluting Flutie
description: The effort of press agents to make public-relations hay out of good deeds performed by their star-athlete clients is one that has long been familiar, of course. But when Doug Flutie attended a benefit dance not long ago for a New Jersey high school girl who had been blinded by an attack of diabetes, he did not say a word about it. And so the effect that his visit had on those directly involved might never have been known to anyone else, except that one of his acquaintances, without Flutie's knowledge, passed along the following letter:

title: Even the President Is Not Above the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sensible, Not Sensational, School
description: The story sounds sensational: The New York City Board of Education sets up a special school for homosexual students, apparently the first in the nation. In reality it's somewhat less of a story: A community group with a homosexual orientation is running an education program for a small number of students. It's a reasonable and constructive project.

title: ASTRONOMERS FIND NEW EVIDENCE OF BLACK HOLE IN THE MILKY WAY
description: Two groups of scientists have reported the strongest evidence so far that there is a supermassive black hole in the center of the Milky Way galaxy.

title: SHOPWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
Across the Hudson
description: New Jersey's continuing identity crisis brought a cry from the heart the other day as Representative Frank J. Guarini of Jersey City rose up in the House to complain that a Government building, the New York Bulk and Foreign Mail Center, was actually as Jersey-based as the New York Giants.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: AFFORDABLE French restaurants are as rare as air-conditioned subway cars these days. And when you find one that is as charming and enterprising as Montrachet, a seven-week-old venture in TriBeCa, there is ample reason to celebrate.

title: HENRY BEETLE HOUGH IS DEAD AT 88
description: Henry Beetle Hough, former owner and publisher of The Vineyard Gazette in Edgartown, Mass., on the island of Martha's Vineyard, and the weekly's editor for the last 65 years, died yesterday at his home in Edgartown. Mr. Hough, who had been in failing health in recent months, was 88 years old.

title: ALASKA BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SHOPSMITH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Shop Early
description: If you want to root the Indianapolis Arrows into the World Series, you'd better send your season ticket orders in now. By the time they get around to forming a team, all the seats may be gone.

title: Invitation to the Mansion
description: To mark the rescue that followed last week's crane collapse on Third Avenue, Mayor Koch is having a picnic tomorrow at his home. Here is the invitation: ''Nothing has stirred this City and brought out its best as did the enormous tragedy on May 30, 1985, when a crane toppled and trapped Brigitte Gerney, one of the most courageous people I have ever met.

title: EXPERTS SKEPTICAL OF REPORTS THAT MENGELE DIED IN 1975
description: Investigators from the United States, West Germany and Israel left hurriedly for Brazil yesterday to check into assertions that Josef Mengele, the fugitive Nazi death-camp doctor, may have drowned there six years ago and been buried in a cemetery outside Sao Paulo.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: AFTER having made two films in lower Manhattan, Susan Seidelman is ready to travel.

title: PRETORIA CURB: BUSINESS VIEW
description: If they become law, the sanctions against South Africa contained in a bill that passed the House of Representatives on Wednesday would probably lead many American companies to sell their operations there, business executives said yesterday.

title: BOTH SIDES IN THE VON BULOW CASE MAKE FINAL APPEALS TO THE JURORS
description: The lawyers for Claus von Bulow and for the State of Rhode Island made their final appeals today to the jurors who will decide if Mr. von Bulow tried to kill his wife, Martha, with insulin injections.

title: Volcker's List Of Worries
description: PAUL A. VOLCKER, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, delivered an address at the Harvard commencement yesterday, sounding, as he himself put it, ''like a central banker reverting to type - preaching to others about their responsibilities.'' But he did not apologize for this.

title: States' Bond Yields Low But Demand Is Heavy
description: New issues of high-grade state bonds - generally regarded as the safest, but lowest-yielding, of tax-exempt bond issues - are selling with yields that are the lowest since May 1983 and that are close to levels last seen in late 1980.

title: BEIRUT MEDIATION REACHES DEADLOCK
description: Negotiations to end three weeks of fighting for control of three Palestinian settlements in Beirut have reached a deadlock, authorities here said.

title: JOBLESS RATE IN JERSEY REACHES A 15-YEAR LOW
description: New Jersey's unemployment rate dropped last month to the lowest level in 15 years, as the number of people employed in the construction industry there reached the highest level in 50 years, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: RATE RISE SENDS DOW DOWN 10.86
description: The stock market yesterday took its biggest tumble since early May as Wall Street investors, seeing a rise in interest rates, decided it was time to take some profits.

title: Lear Family Bids
description: The Lear family and other investors said yesterday that they would seek the rights to build the Learfan 2100 aircraft, which was designed by the late William Lear. Lear Fan Ltd., the company that had been trying to develop the innovative aircraft, filed for liquidation under Chapter 7 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code Thursday.

title: VISUAL GRAPHICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $160,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and year. The net income for the latest quarter and year includes $547,000, or 33 cents a share, of nonrecurring gains resulting from the phaseout of manufacturing operations, principally the sale of real property and associated machinery and inventory disposals. The net for both year-ago periods includes gains of $172,000, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and $275,000, or 17 cents a share, for the year from liquidation of LIFO inventories.

title: YANKS FAIL IN 10
description: The hard times continue for Doug Sisk. The 27-year-old Met pitcher, who in only one season has fallen sharply from the ranks of the league's top relievers, gave up five earned runs last night as the Mets lost a 13-inning game to the St. Louis Cardinals, 7-2.

title: HEAD OF P.B.A. ASSAILS REVISION OF POLICE BOARD
description: The head of the police officers union said yesterday that adding private citizens to the police review board would cause tremendous morale problems, and he vowed to fight any change in court.

title: Langston Is Injured
description: Mark Langston, the left-hander who led the American League in strikeouts as a rookie last season, was placed on the 21-day disabled list by the Seattle Mariners yesterday after a doctor verified that a tendon in his left elbow was strained against the Detroit Tigers Wednesday night. Langston, whose elbow was hurt in the fourth inning and had to leave the game, was examined Thursday in Columbus, Ga., by Dr. James Andrews, an arthroscopic surgeon, who prescribed three weeks of rest for the 24-year-old pitcher. . . . Jose Cruz, the left fielder for the Houston Astros who started only one of the last 11 games because of a dislocated toe, was told to sit out this weekend's series against San Francisco.

title: NATIONAL PARK SERVICE HEAD TO BATTLE OVERCROWDING AND ENCROACHMENT
description: William Penn Mott Jr., the new head of the National Park Service, came to the nation's first park here at Yellowstone with a vow that he would protect and expand the park system even it meant raising fees and sometimes closing the gates because of overcrowding.

title: THE LEGACY OF A CITRUS FREEZE
description: The Florida citrus industry weathered its fourth severe winter freeze in the last five years far better than was initially expected, losing only about 14 percent of its anticipated harvest, according to commodities analysts and government and industry officials.

title: Job Training Is Key to Parole Success
description: To the Editor:

title: DURHAM GROUP TO OFFER A NEW 'CARMEN' OUTDOORS
description: Durham, N.C., is an inspired hybrid; it seems composed of equal parts Theodore Dreiser, Erskine Caldwell and Ann Beattie. A factory town built on tobacco (Liggett & Meyers and American Tobacco have their headquarters there) Durham is also the home of Duke University, one of the most distinguished - and wealthiest - educational institutions in the country. The restaurants list quiche as well as hush puppies; the arch sophistication of northern academic communities is here co-mingled with a distinctive Southern grace.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in New York Day by Day yesterday about a novel manuscript that blew off a balcony misidentified the writer. He is Bob Reiss, not Bob Weiss.

title: LA-Z-BOY CHAIR CO reports earnings for Year to April 27
ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10. 1. The ''Ring'' cycle is being performed by the San Francisco Opera this summer, and the city has erupted in a frenzy of Wagnerism. 2.

title: SMEAL AND GOLDSMITH FIGHT FOR LEADERSHIP OF NOW
description: The decision by Eleanor C. Smeal, once president of the National Organization for Women, to challenge her successor, Judy Goldsmith, for leadership of the 250,000-member organization has led to a spirited campaign that is now moving into high gear.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, JUNE 8, 1985

title: CLINI-THERM CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NAVY DOCUMENTS REPORTED FOUND IN SUSPECT'S HOME
description: Two confidential documents, one of them describing Navy contingency plans for Middle East hostilities, were found in the home of California man accused of participating in a Soviet spy ring, the authorities said today.

title: REAGAN BARS A 4TH TAX RATE
description: President Reagan today rebuffed the suggestion that his tax proposal calling for three tax rates of 15, 25 and 35 percent be changed to create a fourth tax rate of 40 percent for earners with high incomes.

title: JAZZ: DOC CHEATHAM MARKS HIS 8OTH BIRTHDAY WEEK
description: Doc Cheatham, the jazz trumpeter and singer who will be 80 years old on June 13, is celebrating the occasion this week through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, where he has been leading his quartet on Sunday afternoons for the past five years.

title: Ralston Purina
description: Ralston Purina & Company and Forstmann, Little & Company said they had ended plans for the sale of Ralston's Foodmaker Inc. subsidiary.

title: Choice by Cuomo For Power Chief
description: Richard M. Flynn, a New York City lawyer and son of a former Democratic national chairman, is Governor Cuomo's choice to head the State Power Authority, the Governor's office confirmed today.

title: Syracuse U. Liable For Arena Taxes
description: A judge ruled today that Syracuse University should pay a partial assessment on the Carrier Dome, its 50,000-seat covered arena.

title: Tyner-Carter Duo
description: The pianist McCoy Tyner and the bassist Ron Carter are at Lush Life, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (228-3788), through tomorrow. Sets: 9, 11, 1 A.M. tonight; 8:30, 10:30 P.M. tomorrow. $12.50 cover, $6 minimum.

title: LEVITZ FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Diversifoods Bid Is Fought
description: Jesart Partners, in which the Horn & Hardart Company is principal, has filed suit in Federal court in Nebraska seeking to bar the Pillsbury Company's tender offer for Diversifoods Inc., an Illinois-based restaurant company.

title: SUPREME EQUIPMENT & SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $64,000 for the quarter and $281,000, for the 9 months. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $1,079,000 for the quarter and $2,183,000 for the 9 months.

title: CITY G.O.P. PRESENTS TICKET THAT INCLUDES 2 NEWCOMERS
description: The Republican citywide ticket, made up of two political newcomers and one veteran politician, was introduced yesterday on the steps of City Hall, a Democratic preserve for most of this century.

title: A LATIN BEAT ENLIVENS CITY BALLET PARTY
description: For most of the evening Oscar de la Renta's temporary grape arbor, suspended over a temporary dance floor, provided the New York City Ballet's Annual Spring Gala with a setting befitting the staid foxtrots of the swing-band era that the band was playing.

title: ...And Touch Someone Else
description: Is America ready for competitive long-distance telephone service? Economists think so but so far consumers aren't cooperating. Customers are starting to be offered a choice between A.T.& T. and its new competitors, but they won't choose. The Federal Communications Commission's newly announced system for assigning customers to long distance companies should solve the problem. If not, it may be necessary to rethink the logic of deregulating the service.

title: JOBLESS RATE AT 7.2% IN MAY, FOURTH MONTH IN ROW
description: The nation's unemployment rate stood at 7.2 percent in May, the fourth consecutive month at that level, the Labor Department reported today.

title: BELMONT HAS IMAGE PROBLEM
description: If the owners and the trainers of the favorites in the 117th Belmont Stakes look grim as their 3-year-olds go to the post today at Belmont Park, it is because they may have more to lose with a defeat than they have to gain with a victory. The absence from the field of 11 of Spend a Buck, the Kentucky Derby and Jersey Derby winner, means that whoever wins will still not be considered the top 3-year-old around, and another defeat may permanently doom the reputations of the losers.

title: SUPER FOOD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: Share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in December 1984.

title: SPORTS SATURDAY
description: Baseball Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. Ed Lynch goes for the Mets as they cling to first place in the National League East. (Television -SportsChannel, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Brewers, at Milwaukee. (Radio - WABC 770, 2:30 P.M.) Cubs vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Chicago. (Television - Channel 4, 3:15 P.M.) College: N.C.A.A. Division I College World Series at Omaha. (Television -ESPN 7 P.M.) Boxing Eusebio Pedroza vs. Barry McGuigan, 15 rounds for Pedroza's W.B.A. featherweight title, at London. Pedroza, from Panama, the longest reigning champion in any division currently fighting, is 39-3-1 with 24 knockouts and is seeking his 20th successful title defense. McGuigan, a native of Ireland who is 26-1 with 23 knockouts, is expected to have a large number of fans from both sides of the Irish border. (Television - Channel 7, 4:30 P.M.) United States vs. Venezuela. (Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M., tape from yesterday.) Golf $500,000 Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic, at Westchester Country Club, Harrison, N.Y. Third round, 9 A.M. (Television - Channel 2, 3 P.M., live) Ladies P.G.A. McDonald's Championships, at Malvern, Pa. Third round (Television - USA Network, 4 P.M., live) PGA Senior Tour Champions Classic, at Sparks, Nev. (Television - ESPN, 2 P.M.) Harness Racing Yonkers Trot, at Yonkers Raceway, 8 P.M. Workaholic, Master Willie and Another Miracle are the favorites in the three $88,168 divisions. The top three finishers in each final come back for a sixth race final worth $176,336 and the first leg of the trotting triple crown for 3-year-olds.

title: GRADUATES OF L.I.U. URGED TO OPPOSE THE ARMS RACE
description: Justice Francis T. Murphy Jr. of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court yesterday urged 900 graduates of Long Island University's Brooklyn campus to oppose the arms race and to fight poverty.

title: Reynolds Vote Delayed in Senate
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee decided today to put off a vote scheduled for next week on the nomination of William Bradford Reynolds as Associate Attorney General. Instead, it asked Mr. Reynolds to return for more questioning.

title: The President Calling
description: President Reagan, who likes to give people good news, has gradually established a practice that produces both joy and anxiety among senior State Department officials waiting for promotions.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about public gardens gave an incorrect time for lectures at the Cloisters. ''Flowers in Tapestry and Cloister'' will be presented today at noon and 2 P.M.

title: THE YOUNG AND UGLY
description: LESS THAN ZERO. By Bret Easton Ellis. 208 pages. Simon & Schuster. $15.95. This is one of the most disturbing novels I've read in a long time. It's disturbing because the 20-year-old author draws a knowing portrait of adolescence that is almost entirely defined by hard drugs, kinky sex and expensive clothes. And it's disturbing because these kids - who are as young as 13 and 14 - are not only living a life out of a Harold Robbins novel, but have also acquired, at their brief age, a cynicism that makes, say, James Dean in ''Rebel Without a Cause'' seem like a Pollyanna.

title: Hail the Local Artist
description: Sometimes it seems that the painting of artists from the Washington area is hard-to-find pentimento, obscured by the works of famous painters from elsewhere in the nation and the world whose art is constantly imported for exhibitions in the capital's museums. The Phillips Collection, however, is to show the work of three local artists: two painters, Thomas Downing and Simon Gouverneur, and a sculptor, Christopher Gardner. The exhibition starts today and lasts until Sept. 8.

title: BRITISH RESTAURANTS: A DELIGHTFUL TOUR
description: Reasonable wine prices, fresh sweet butter and professional dining-room service. Those should be a few of the givens in the best restaurants. And the British do a good job of providing them.

title: SPY SUSPECT DESCRIBED AS 'SWEET,' 'MOUSY' AND FAR DIFFERENT FROM BROTHER
description: On May 24, while Federal agents were breaking up the concrete floor of John A. Walker Jr.'s house seeking evidence of espionage, the quiet family life at the suburban home of his brother, Arthur, his wife and their three children was crumbling, too.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article on the Style page yesterday about the New York hotel strike's effect on social events cited a dinner for the Long Island Jewish Hospital scheduled for Sunday. It has now been canceled. Those who hold tickets for other events in struck hotels are advised to consult sponsoring organizations for the latest information.

title: Conciliation in New York City Housing Court
description: To the Editor:

title: BELMONT'S MUSICAL SADDLES
description: When the horses, one by one, enter the starting gate for the 117th Belmont Stakes today, Chief's Crown will move into the No. 1 post with Angel Cordero Jr. perched atop him. Not far away, Don MacBeth, who had ridden Chief's Crown to six consecutive victories prior to the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, will be approaching the gate on Cutlass Reality, but part of his heart will still be aboard the bay colt in the No. 1 post.

title: KEY SUSPECT DIES
description: Three skeletons were found among ''piles of bones'' today at a ranch used by a survivalist who apparently swallowed a poison pill while being questioned by the police.

title: CUBA HOPES TO CASH IN ON WEST'S WANDERLUST
description: Though this is the off-season for tourism in the Caribbean, several scheduled flights and more than a dozen charters are arriving in Cuba every week with vacationers from Canada, Mexico and Western Europe.

title: Did Hitler Say It?
description: To the Editor:

title: JUDGE EXPELS A POLE FROM COURT AGAIN
description: One of three Polish dissidents on trial charged with fomenting unrest was ousted from a Gdansk courtroom today for the sixth time in the last five days.

title: Bulgarian-Soviet Accord
description: The Bulgarian party Todor Zhivkov, signed an agreement today on economic cooperation with the Soviet Union until the year 2000. The accord was signed after talks in the Kremlin with the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, according to Tass, the official Soviet press agency. Mr. Zhivkov is the third East European leader to sign such an accord with Moscow in the last three months.

title: INTECH INC reports earnings for 16 wks to March 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $2,000 for the quarter and $8,000 for the year. c-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $21,000 for the quarter and year.

title: TRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The latest third quarter and 9 months' results include an $18 million provision for realignment of TRE's semiconductor equipment operations, compared to a similar provision of $10 million for the year-earlier quarter and 9 months. The $18 million provision had a net after-tax effect of $1.31 a share.

title: The Birth of the Kennedy Half-Dollar
description: To the Editor:

title: INTEREST RATES ARE UP SHARPLY
description: Interest rates rose sharply yesterday after the Commerce Department announced a larger-than-expected increase in the number of employed workers during May.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday about Senate approval of nonmilitary aid to Nicaraguan rebels described Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware incorrectly. Although Senator Biden is a member of the Foreign Relations Committee, the ranking Democrat is Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island.

title: CROWN BOOKS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Ready to Sign Up
description: ''W hat number do you dial?'' Bernard Deutchman, principal of Norman Thomas High School in Manhattan, asked the students assembled in the auditorium yesterday.

title: SIX IN DRUG CASE ENTER NOT-GUILTY PLEAS
description: Baseball crept into court for a second time today as six defendants in the Pittsburgh drug case pleaded not guilty to charges involving cocaine sales over a five-year period. The seventh man indicted last week has not been scheduled for arraignment.

title: Strike Is Voted At Big Board
description: Trading floor and other clerical workers at the New York Stock Exchange have voted to walk off the job Tuesday in what would be the first strike at the Big Board since 1948.

title: STATEX PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $34,000 for the quarter and $240,000 for the 6 months. c-Net losses.

title:
PATENTS;

Dental Implant Gains
description: Dr. Leonard I. Linkow, who has made more than 10,000 dental implants, got his 10th patent this week. Patent No. 4,521,192 provides for immediate installation of an artificial tooth support in a jawbone portion that has become oversized because of a faulty prior implant or another cause. Dr. Linkow practices in New York, and is a clinical professor at the Temple University School of Dentistry in Philadelphia.
