title: New Civil Liberties Director
description: Norman Siegel, a civil rights activist, has been named executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union. He replaces Salvador Tio, who left the 25,000-member organization to pursue political ambitions. In a statement, Mr. Siegel said, ''We intend to immediately and dramatically expand the base of the civil liberties support throughout the state of New York.''

title: U.S. STUDY DETAILS EMPLOYMENT SHIFT
description: The Labor Department today provided its first detailed look at how far the nation's economy has shifted away from manufacturing jobs since the recession.

title: SENATORS MODIFY BILL ON REBEL AID
description: The Senate today approved an amendment that would bar the use of Federal funds for activities against the Nicaraguan Government that violate international law or the Charter of the Organization of American States.

title: AEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Canine on the IRT
description: No one ever figured out where it came from. But passengers on a downtown IRT express train leaving the West 72d Street station one morning this week suddenly became aware of a very young, medium-sized, very frightened, mixed-breed dog lying at their feet.

title: VISIONTECH reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
SIMCO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
EASTERN AIR YOUTH PASS
description: Eastern Airlines said today that it was offering young people a restricted $399 pass that allows them to take up to eight flights anywhere on Eastern's United States system. Each ''Youth Pass'' is valid for 30 days, and the overall offer is in effect until Sept. 30. The fare applies only to passengers between the ages of 17 and 25, and the passengers must take flights leaving between 7 P.M. and 7:59 A.M. In addition, reservations can be made only within three days of departure.

title: TRIAL BEGINS IN ROOFTOP SLAYING OF DRAMA STUDENT
description: A prosecutor in the murder trial of Emmanuel Torres told a jury yesterday that Caroline Isenberg had been stabbed to death on the roof of her apartment building after Mr. Torres became enraged when she resisted his sexual advances.

title: Pitcher Investigated
description: National League President Chub Feeney said yesterday he planned to ''instruct our umpires to scrutinize Mike Scott's pitching'' following the complaint that the Houston Astros' right-hander was using sandpaper to doctor baseballs. Jim Frey, the manager of the Chicago Cubs, had sent a letter to Feeney, enclosing a piece of sandpaper that Frey said was found on the mound during the Cubs' 10-8 victory on May 26 in Chicago. Feeney acknowledged that ''it would be very dificult to investigate'' the incident but said, ''We're certainly going to be watching Mr. Scott.''

title: Looking West
description: Pitching in Cleveland before sparse crowds and amid equally sparse national news media attention, Bert Blyleven quietly achieved career victory No. 199 Thursday night with a five-hitter against Seattle. The question now is whether he will still be wearing the Indians uniform when No. 200 comes his way.

title: AILEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: b-Net loss.

title: AS DROUGHT HITS JERSEY, '81 WATER PLAN STALLS
description: In mid-1981, at the end of the last severe water shortage in New Jersey, state officials said they had a plan in place to prevent similar crises through the next century.

title: APPEALS COURT AWARDS $472,190 TO MEESE FOR HIS LEGAL EXPENSES
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia today awarded $472,190 to Edwin Meese 3d to help him pay legal fees and expenses that he incurred in successfully defending himself against charges of misconduct before his confirmation as Attorney General.

title: Good Pickings
description: When Jim Acker of the Toronto Blue Jays got credit for the victory by pitching only one inning Thursday night after Jimmy Key had shut out Detroit for 10, he summed up matters by saying, ''I feel like a buzzard.''

title: Zamir Chorale Concert
description: The Zamir Chorale's 25th anniversary benefit concert will be held at Alice Tully Hall tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. with a program that includes music by Bach, Brahms, Bernstein, Bloch, Copland and Salomone Rossi as well as works by the Israeli composers Tzvi Avni and Yechezkai Braun. Tickets are $10, $15 and $25. Information: 362-1911, 362-3335 or 362-6633.

title:
PATENTS;

A Method To Identify Microbes
description: A UNITED STATES company has received a patent for a method of identifying microbes. Patent No. 4,521,512 was granted this week to Dr. Robert E. Silman, a British physician who conducts research at St. Bartholomew's Hospital Medical College in London.

title: Hail Nathan Hale
description: Intelligence with a capital I is always analyzed one more time when a good spy story is unraveling in the capital. Investigators round up their usual sources for tips and try to set up secret meetings with retired spies.

title: LATEST RESCUE IS GREETED WARILY
description: Last-minute financial rescues of Argentina, and thereby of its creditor banks, are hardly new. Nor have they been very long-lived. This time, too, many analysts remain deeply wary of the prospects of any new agreement between Argentina and the International Monetary Fund.

title: Letter: On Rent Regulation;   Decontrol Would Intensify Segregation
description: To the Editor:

title: HAROLD S. MINER
description: Harold S. Miner, the president from 1957 to 1978 of CARE, the nonprofit international aid and development agency, died of cancer Thursday at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 92 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: DELTAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
In the Booth
description: Tim McCarver heads back to the ABC broadcasting booth for a second season Monday night, freed once a week of duties with the Mets under his new four-year contract with them. He again teams with Don Drysdale to form the B squad for the network's weekly baseball telecast, which means he'll be at Montreal to cover the Cubs' visit while the A team - Al Michaels and Jim Palmer, to be joined the week after next by Howard Cosell - is at Yankee Stadium for Toronto-New York. It wasn't many months ago that McCarver was talking to the Expos about their managerial post and to the Cardinals about the role of general manager - ''I guess I lead the league in preliminary talks,'' he says - but now he acknowledges: ''The longer you stay in the booth, the less the chances are you'll go back to the game.''

title: Daly Report
description: The 76ers have offered Coach Chuck Daly of the Detroit Pistons the head-coaching job of the Philadelphia club, according to a published report.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: STEWART & STEVENSON SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Weekender Guide yesterday on ''The Shooting of Dan McGrew'' located Public School 29 in an incorrect district. It is in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn.

title: Mary Kay Buyout
description: Mary Kay Cosmetics Inc. said that it had appointed three outside directors to a special committee that would evaluate the leveraged buyout offer proposed by Mary Kay Ash, the company's founder, and some of its officers. The management group is offering a package of cash and subordinated debt that it values at $18.15 a share for each of the company's 21 million shares outstanding. Analysts have valued the offer at between $15 and $16 a share.

title: Max Ways Dead at 79; Retired Fortune Editor
description: Max Ways, a retired editor at Fortune magazine and foreign correspondent for Time magazine, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Police Look for Link In 2 Hotel Slayings; Special Unit Formed
description: Police officials said yesterday that two women slain in hotels on West 54th Street in Manhattan may have been killed by the same person, and that they had established a special force of detectives to investigate the cases.

title: IDENTIFYING BODIES: USING DENTAL EVIDENCE
description: An examination of the teeth, even a single tooth, could produce an identification of the exhumed body said to be that of Josef Mengele if dental records of the Nazi doctor are sufficiently detailed, specialists in forensic pathology said yesterday.

title: First Federal Building Is Named for a Black
description: A Federal office building was named today in honor of Dr. A. H. McCoy, a black civil rights activist.

title: HUSSEIN'S BID FOR TALKS: ALREADY A SOURCE OF ISRAELI CRITICISM OF U.S.
description: A senior State Department official said recently that his ''nightmare'' was that the Palestine Liberation Organization would agree to all the conditions set by the United States for recognition by Washington, provoking a new crisis in American relations with Israel.

title: RESTAURANT MANAGEMENT SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to May 12
DON'T HURL WRESTLING OUT OF THE RING
description: Lord knows, they've been wanting to ban things from the very beginning.

title: CARL KARCHER ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to May 17

PATENTS;

Pressurized Helium Used in Heating System
description: A compact electric fluid heater that employs pressurized helium gas was patented this week by Harry J. Scanlan of New York and Leif Liljegren of Oakland, N.J. It is recommended as a hot water heater for residences, apartments, hotels and office buildings.

title: U.S. STEPPED UP MOVES ON CURRENCY
description: The United States intervened on currency markets six times this spring, buying $580 million worth of West German marks, Japanese yen and British pounds to try to drive down the dollar, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: LORRAINE E. YOUNGER
description: Lorraine E. Younger, a longtime Harlem community worker and a former executive director of the community center of St. Philip's Episcopal Church at 208 West 134th Street, died of a heart ailment Thursday at the Harlem Hospital Center. She was 62 years old and lived at 2171 Madison Avenue, near 135th Street.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I feel like I'm standing against a cellophane wall getting shot at from both sides'' - President Reagan, on the pressures to modify his tax proposal. [35:6.]

title: STRIKE AT HOTEL MAKES DOORMAN'S JOB DELICATE
description: Raymond W. Bonner stood in the middle of Fifth Avenue, holding an umbrella close against his shoulders, flagging cabs toward the entrance of the Plaza Hotel. When a taxi pulled in, Mr. Bonner hurried to help a guest with her luggage, gingerly stepping through puddles at least ankle deep.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SATURDAY, JUNE 8, 1985

title: NORDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,082,000.

title: Fred Marshall of Minnesota House Member for 14 Years
description: Fred Marshall, who served seven terms in the United States House of Representatives, died Wednesday. He was 79 years old and had suffered from heart problems and Hodgkin's disease in recent months.

title: Self-Help for New York's Port
description: Through the mediation of the Port Authority, longshoremen and shippers have agreed to cut the cost of moving container cargo through New York and New Jersey. That provides a welcome boost for a troubled port.

title: DANCE: BALLET THEATER'S 'QUIXOTE'
description: American Ballet Theater performed an operetta Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, yet not a note was sung. Rather, this was the season's first performance of ''Don Quixote,'' a ballet that can be called a choreographic operetta.

title: Price-Sales Stock Ratio
description: MENTION the words ''price-earnings ratio'' and individual investors usually know that it deals with the relationship between a corporation's market price and its earnings per share. Daily newspaper stock tables list this indicator, brokers discuss it regularly with their clients and the ratio has become a widely used measurement of how investors regard a company.

title: Stephen Draper Dead at 79; Theatrical Agent For 40 Years
description: Stephen Draper, a theatrical agent, died of a heart attack Wednesday in his New York office. He was 79 years old.

title: QUEENS COMMUNITY AND ITS ARTISTS REACH DETENTE
description: Under no circumstances should one step up to the bar at Chick's in Long Island City, among the beer-swigging factory workers, and order an avocado-and-brie on pita bread with a natural papaya juice to wash it down.

title: STATE UNIVERSITY IN CONNECTICUT GETS NEW CHIEF
description: Trustees of the University of Connecticut today appointed Dr. John T. Casteen 3d, Virginia's top education official, as the university's 11th president.

title: DUMBER ALL THE TIME
description: When President Reagan finishes tax simplification he ought to have a crack at phone simplification. The telephone bill has gotten more complicated than Form 1040, and if you want a new phone installed these days your best bet is to retain a lawyer and an engineer.

title: City Told to Provide Worker Job Setting That's All White
description: This city may have to find an all-white job setting for a city employee because he says he has a mental problem that makes him fear working with blacks.

title: ADVANCED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Parents Keep Vigil For One of Septuplets
description: Patricia and Samuel Frustaci kept vigil today for Bonnie Marie, the most critically ill of their four surviving septuplets.

title: FORECASTERS AND THE TAX PLAN
description: As economic forecasters subject President Reagan's tax proposals to the scrutiny of their forecasting models, they are drawing far less optimistic conclusions about the plan's potential impact on the economy than the White House has suggested, Based on their preliminary computer runs, several leading forecasting firms have concluded that economic activity could fall by one percentage point in the first year, a significant drop for an economy that some expect to grow by only 2 to 3 percent. In later the years, the growth rate is expected to revive, but, at best, the tax plan is seen as a ''wash,'' neither helping nor hindering the economy over all.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Aluminum Co. of America, Pittsburgh, said it was reducing primary aluminum production by 11,000 tons a year.

title: LUTHERAN MINISTER IS DEFROCKED AT STORMY MEETING
description: To shouts of ''crucify him,'' a militant Lutheran pastor who defied his church and the state while agitating for the unemployed was defrocked today. He was arrested minutes later for disrupting the convention that voted to take the action.

title: MICROFRAME INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DAIRY MART CONVENIENCE STORES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a pretax loss of $145,000.

title: Judge Upholds Deadline In Zimbabwe Elections
description: A judge today ruled against extending the nomination deadline for the 80 seats designated for blacks in the 100-seat National Assembly.

title: N.L.R.B.: Thunder Against Thunder
description: When he became chairman of the National Labor Relations Board two years ago, Donald L. Dotson declared flatly that the ''pendulum'' on the board had swung ''too far to the left,'' and he served notice that he intended to return it ''back toward the middle.''

title: JURY IN VON BULOW CASE BEGINS ITS DELIBERATIONS
description: A 12-member jury today began deliberating whether Claus von Bulow is guilty of twice trying to kill his wife, Martha, an heiress, with injections of insulin. Deliberations, interrupted by lunch, began shortly before noon and continued until 4 P.M., when the jury retired for the night.

title: M/A/R/C INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
ARGENTINA SAYS IT HAS I.M.F. ACCORD
description: President Raul Alfonsin said today that Argentina had ''completed in a satisfactory manner'' work on a long-awaited agreement with the International Monetary Fund.

title: WESTWAY: A TALE OF TWO CITIES
description: Once upon a time, and a long time ago it was, people built highways through the centers of cities. Stop! cried Congressmen. Stop! You dislocate families, you dislocate businesses, you ruin the environment and fill it with noise and pollutants, you slice up neighborhoods, you destroy communities. Instead, said Congressmen in a distant place called Washington, bury your highways - cover them with parks and housing. Your Federal Government will create the landfill, and the builders of houses on the new land will pay back the money.

title: PALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
NEW DISCOS CATER TO YOUTHS WHO REJECT ALCOHOL
description: Since it opened earlier this year, the Let's Dance discotheque has been packed on Friday and Saturday nights with hundreds of teen-agers dancing to blaring rock music.

title: SUTCLIFFE RETURNS AND HURLS 5-HITTER
description: Rick Sutcliffe, backed by Jody Davis's home run, came off the disabled list today and pitched a five-hitter as the Chicago Cubs defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 1-0. When the Mets lost to the Cardinals tonight, Chicago moved into a first-place tie with New York in the National League East.

title: Nicolas Moufarrege, Writer Artist, Exhibition Organizer
description: Nicolas Moufarrege, an artist, writer and exhibition organizer, died of pneumonia Tuesday at the North Central Bronx Hospital. He was 36 years old.

title: For Turkish-Armenian Study of a Shared Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: NCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SANDINISTA FAULTS VOTE TO AID REBELS
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra has condemned the Senate vote to authorize $38 million in nonmilitary aid to anti-Government rebels as ''a vote in favor of crimes against the Nicaraguan people.''

title: FOR TURKISH-ARMENIAN STUDY OF A SHARED TRAGEDY Other Side of the Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Old Preserve, New Challenge
description: Celebrations this summer will mark the 100th anniversary of New York State's unique Forest Preserve, about 4,000 square miles of state-owned land in the Adirondacks and Catskills. With remarkable foresight, the 1885 law prescribed that such land (then about 1,100 square miles) would be ''forever kept as wild forest lands.

title: Adams Wins City Title
description: Lenny Diblasi completed a stirring four-run seventh-inning comeback with a single to left field yesterday, giving John Adams a 6-5 victory over John F. Kennedy in the Public Schools Athletic League championship game, at Yankee Stadium.

title: CHOCK FULL O'NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $20,000 for the quarter and $75,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $85,000 for the quarter and $261,000 for the 9 months.

title: Judge Seeks Bhopal Plan
description: The American Red Cross was asked yesterday to develop a substitute plan for distributing $5 million in emergency aid from the Union Carbide Corporation to victims of the Bhopal gas plant disaster because the Indian Government has turned down an earlier aid plan.

title: HAM ADS ATTACK DECEPTION
description: ''SOMETHING'S not kosher in the ham business,'' read the full-page ads that have been appearing in newspapers around the New York area since early June. A series of radio and television ads repeat the same theme.

title: MCENROE, CONNORS ELIMINATED IN PARIS
description: For different reasons, neither John McEnroe nor Jimmy Connors was ready today for his semifinal match in the French Open tennis championship. Their opponents, Mats Wilander and Ivan Lendl, were more than ready, and so they advanced in straight sets to Sunday's final of the Grand Slam tournament.

title: 32 Indians Are Killed In a Police Battle
description: Police forces from two of India's northeastern states battled each other for four hours Thursday in a dispute over a border fence, leaving 32 dead and 50 wounded and sending 25,000 villagers fleeing, the authorities said today.

title: EX-N.A.A.C.P. SPOKESMAN
description: Henry Lee Moon, the retired public relations director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center after a long illness. He was 84 years old and lived in Queens.

title: AMERICAN HELIOTHERMAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Progress Is Reported In Hotel Strike Talks
description: Progress was reported yesterday in talks to reach an agreement in the week-old New York City hotel strike.

title: Appeal for T-Shirts
description: People are not being asked to take the shirts off their backs exactly, but almost.

title: MENGELE'S SON LINKED TO MAN BURIED IN BRAZIL
description: The son of Josef Mengele, the long-sought Auschwitz death camp doctor, apparently visited the man whose body was exhumed here Thursday, the Brazilian police said today. The police have said the body may be Dr. Mengele's.

title: OFFICIALS SAY THEY EXPECT REAGAN TO ADHERE LARGELY TO ARMS PACT
description: Administration officials say they believe President Reagan will decide in favor of continued overall adherence to strategic arms control treaties, but will also agree to limited and measured deviations in response to purported Soviet violations of the pacts.

title: TRIANGLE MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Ethnic Republicans
description: The Republican National Committee is still licking its chops over the Reagan landslide last year and is now emphasizing that the President's victory reflected his increased popularity among ethnic groups. In a committee leaflet, ''Talking Points,'' intended to help the faithful with their proselytizing, these ethnic groups are reported to have given the President a higher percentage of their vote: German/ Austrians, 67 percent in 1984, up from 57 percent in 1980; English/Scottish/ Welsh, 70 percent, up from 59; Irish Protestant, 62 percent, up from 54; Irish Catholic, 56 percent, up from 49; Polish and other Slavic, 51 percent, up from 39; Italian, 58 percent, up from 50; Scandinavian, 62 percent, up from 53, and Hispanic, 44 percent, up from 37.

title: Barge Orchestra's Chief Faces Boating Violations
description: Robert Austin Boudreau, founder and director of the American Wind Symphony Orchestra, which gives performances on a barge, was arrested Thursday on Coast Guard charges arising from his operation of the vessel.

title: Iraqi Jets Bomb Teheran And Other Iranian Cities
description: Iraq said 27 of its warplanes made three attacks today on Teheran for the third day in row.

title: COUNCIL SEEKS $84 MILLION IN ADDED SPENDING
description: The City Council yesterday called for adding $84 million in spending to Mayor Koch's proposed $20 billion budget and for cutting the commercial rent tax by $35 million.

title: EX-OFFICIAL SAYS POLICE HAVE CUT EFFORTS TO FIGHT CORRUPTION AND BRUTALITY
description: A former high-ranking New York City police official asserted yesterday that corruption and brutality have resurfaced in the Police Department because of a ''relaxation of tough controls'' by top commanders.

title: Wesray in Buyout Of Western Auto
description: The Wesray Capital Corporation, the investment firm headed by former Treasury Secretary William E. Simon, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Western Auto Supply Company from the Beneficial Corporation in a leveraged buyout valued at about $300 million.

title: CONSULTANT SAYS HE PROPOSED SPRINKLERS FOR PARK ATTRACTION
description: A fire-protection consultant for the Great Adventure amusement park near here testified today that he advised park officials in 1979 to install a sprinkler system or fire and smoke alarms in their Haunted Castle attraction.

title: MUSIC: DENNIS KOSTER, GUITAR
description: There are not many guitarists who include both classical music and flamenco in recital programs, but Dennis Koster is one who does. At Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday night, he played Bach, Mozart and Paganini, and flamenco composed or arranged by Sabicas and himself. Mr. Koster's versatility was further demonstrated by his having made the arrangements of Mozart's Fantasy in D (K. 397, originally for piano) and Paganini's Grand Sonata in A (originally for guitar accompanied by violin).

title: HADCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-Net income.

title: LAUNDERING SCHEMES TRACED TO PUERTO RICE
description: The arrest on Thursday in Puerto Rico of 17 individuals, including a prominent savings and loan president, on charges that they conspired to help launder drug money opens a new front in the Federal Government's efforts to attack organized crime by tracking its cash flows.

title: Panel in Connecticut Outlaws 'Ladies Nights' in Bias Ruling
description: The state human-rights commission has ruled that ''ladies night'' promotions discriminate against men, Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman said today, and Connecticut bars and nightclubs are being told to discontinue them.

title: Philanthropists' Party
description: The paper streamer read, ''Five Banner Years: Thank You Barrie,'' but in spite of Central Park breezes, it had a stubborn sag. So Marshall A. Robinson, president of the Russell Sage Foundation, climbed a ladder and fastened the ends to the ornate wood portico of the landmark building called the Dairy.

title: HIGHLAND SUPERSTORES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company went public in May and year-ago first quarter results are pro forma.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 33. 1. This ''Brunnhilde'' mannequin in a store window is part of a display in an American city that has temporarily been transformed into Bayreuth on the Bay. Identify the city and explain. 2. A sweeping overhaul of an institution known as the ''nanny state'' would affect almost every household in a foreign country. What institution is it? 3. Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinerger announced a measure intended to foil spy rings like the one John A. Walker Jr., a retired Navy warrant officer, is accused of running for 18 years. What is the measure? 4. Twenty students are enrolled in a highly unusual high school in Greenwich Village. What kind of school is it? 5. When the only thing known about a candidate is the way he or she looks, voters of both sexes tend to choose (attractive men/unattractive men) and (attractive women/unattractive women), according to recent studies of the effect of physical appearance on political elections. 6. If things go as planned, by mid-August the assets of the Howard Hughes Medical Institute will exceed those of the Ford Foundation, currently the nation's wealthiest private philanthropy. What are the circumstances? 7. In a foreign country, the police exhumed the remains of a man whom they say could be the long-sought Nazi death camp doctor, Josef Mengele. What country is it? 8. New York and New Jersey have devised a plan intended to thwart businesses and customers who avoid sales taxes by sending purchases out of state.

title: Kean's Counsel to Quit Post
description: W. Cary Edwards, Governor Kean's chief counsel, said today that he planned to leave the post by the end of the year. Mr. Edwards, 40 years old and a former Assemblyman from Oakland, said he told Mr. Kean when he was appointed to the $70,000-a-year position four years ago that he would leave at the end of the first term.

title: CONCERT: Y CHORALE PERFORMS
description: With all the attention that has been bestowed upon Bach, Handel and Scarlatti in this, their tricentennial year, we must be grateful for Amy Kaiser's devotion to the cause of the lesser-known German composer Heinrich Schutz, born four centuries ago this year.

title: West Germans Seem Relieved Paraguayan Postponed Visit
description: The West German Government reacted with apparent relief today after the President of Paraguay postponed a state visit here that was planned for next month.

title: Apparent Israeli Support
description: Israel tonight appeared to throw its full backing behind the South Lebanon Army, telling the commander of the United Nations troops in Lebanon that Israel would only seek the return of kidnapped United Nations soldiers if the United Nations secured the release of captured S.L.A. troops.

title: Off to Buffalo
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro's signals that she will run for United States Senate next year grow stronger by the day. Today, for example, the Queens Democrat will forsake her Fire Island beach home for Buffalo, and a party celebrating Joseph F. Crangle's 20th anniversary as Erie County Democratic leader.

title: AMF Merger Curb Is Barred
description: A Federal judge has issued a preliminary injunction barring AMF Inc. from enacting proposed anti-takeover provisions intended to thwart a hostile takeover bid from Minstar Inc., the Minneapolis company controlled by Irwin L. Jacobs, the financier.

title: CBS Riding High On N.B.A. Finals
description: While the Celtics and the Lakers have been speeding up and down the court in an effort to do each other in, the ratings for the CBS telecasts of the two clubs' championship series have been hurtling in another direction - straight up.

title: RUSSIANS RAM A CAR AND DETAIN 3 BRITONS IN EAST GERMANY
description: Soviet soldiers rammed a parked car carrying three British officers on a reconnaissance mission in East Germany, then detained them for five hours after searching the vehicle, the British military command said today.

title: SEARCH IN BAVARIA LED TO EXHUMATION
description: Several tips, including a letter from Paraguay, spurred the West German authorities last week to search a house in Josef Mengele's hometown in Bavaria, where they found documents placing the long-sought Nazi death camp doctor in Sao Paulo, Brazil, officials and investigators close to the case said yesterday.

title:
PATENTS;

Appliances Operated By Voice Commands
description: The Whirlpool Corporation, Benton Harbor, Mich., received a patent this week for a voice control system to be used with home appliances, such as automatic clothes dryers.

title: APPEALS COURT BLOCKS RESTARTING OF A REACTOR AT THREE MILE ISLAND
description: A Federal appeals court today blocked the re-opening of a nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island next week and agreed to hear arguments on whether the Nuclear Regulatory Commission acted improperly when it voted to let operations here resume.

title: With Babies for All
description: Riddle: how is government like an infant?

title: CONCERT: PENDULUM
description: It was appropriate that Pendulum opened its concert Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall with a Chick Corea tune. The pianist Jim Hodgkinson and the vibraphonist Ted Piltzecker, faculty members at the Aspen Music Festival in Colorado, have modeled their partnership on duets by Mr. Corea and the vibraphonist Gary Burton.

title: MALTBIE POSTS NEAR-RECORD 63
description: Roger Maltbie was still partying at the home of a newspaper executive at 1 o'clock this morning, and he got less than five hours' sleep before teeing off at 7:50. Yet he proceeded to shoot an eight-under-par 63 in the second round of the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic, one shot off the Westchester Country Club's West Course record of 62.

title: CITY'S BILL FOR ROME TRIP BY MAYOR TOTALS $15,442
description: Mayor Koch's trip to Rome last month to attend the elevation of Archbishop John J. O'Connor to Cardinal cost the city $15,442, according to city officials.

title: Detective Can Exercise Skill At or Away From the Table
description: A bridge detective has many opportunities to pinpoint nonviolent crimes and misdemeanors at the bridge table, from minor incompetence up to full-scale cheating. But he can exercise his talent away from the table.

title: RAMBIS HELPS LAKERS HUSTLE TO 3-2 LEAD IN FINAL
description: Looking at the statistics from tonight's contest, it would appear that that the 36 points by Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the 33 by James Worthy and the 26 points and 17 assists by Earvin (Magic) Johnson were the primary reasons that the Los Angeles Lakers earned a 120-111 victory tonight that gave them a 3-2 lead and placed them on the verge dethroning the defending champion Boston Celtics. But the Lakers believe otherwise. Their hero was Kurt Rambis. When measured with numbers, the contributions of the fourth-year power forward with the thick, black-rimmed glasses and no jumpshot didn't really amount to much. He scored only 7 points, adding 9 rebounds, 3 assists and 2 steals in 27 minutes. But those figures don't reflect his biggest asset: desire.

title: On Show at Pier 84
description: To the Editor:

title: COSBY WEIGHS STAKE IN ABC STATION
description: Bill Cosby, whose new situation comedy on NBC became the top-rated show of this past television season, is looking into becoming an owner of a small piece of one of NBC's competitors. Mr. Cosby and Joe Zingale, partners in Cozzin Communications, have had preliminary discussions with officials at Capital Cities Communications about buying WXYZ-TV, a station owned by ABC in Detroit, Mr. Zingale said yesterday.

title: HCW INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
School-Bus Driver Held On Intoxication Charge
description: A school-bus driver was arrested today on charges of drunken driving while he took children home from school, the police said.

title: Car-Bomb Explodes In Peruvian Capital
description: A blackout plunged Lima into darkness tonight and a car packed with explosives blew up near the palace where President Raul Alfonsin of Argentina was attending a ceremony with President Fernando Belaunde Terry of Peru.

title: GAC LIQUIDATING TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bombed House's Owner Barred From Returning
description: City officials proceeding with the rebuilding of the west Philadelphia neighborhood destroyed in the confrontation with the radical group Move have said they would not allow Louise James, the owner of Move's fortified house, to return.

title: IMPERIAL SAID TO REJECT 2 HOWARD JOHNSON BIDS
description: The Imperial Group of London, owner of the Howard Johnson lodging and restaurant chain, has turned down a joint offer of $400 million in cash for the big American chain from the Marriott Corporation and Prime Motor Inns of New Jersey, hotel sources said yesterday.

title: 4-Nation Peace Tour
description: Leonard Bernstein will lead an international summer tour of concerts called the ''Journey of Peace,'' beginning with a performance Aug. 1 in Athens. The tour will include stops in Hungary, Austria and Japan, and will feature performances by the European Community Youth Orchestra and choirs from each of the countries visited. Eiji Oue will share the conducting chores with Mr. Bernstein.

title: 'Singin' in Rain' Postponed
description: ''Singin' in the Rain,'' a musical adapted by Betty Comden and Adolph Green, based on their 1952 film, has postponed its opening until June 20. Directed and choreographed by Twyla Tharp, the play will continue in previews at the Gershwin Theater.

title: 8 FOUND LIABLE IN SLAYING AT ANTI-KLAN RALLY IN 1979
description: A Federal jury today found eight people liable for damages in the wrongful death of one of five leftist demonstrators killed at a rally against the Ku Klux Klan in 1979. Those found liable were five Klansmen and Nazis, two Greensboro police officers and an informer for the police, who was also a Klansman.

title: AGCA REJETS QUERIES ON BULGARIANS
description: Mehmet Ali Agca, asserting that he felt threatened by the secret services of Bulgaria and the Soviet Union, told a court here today that he would not answer specific questions about purported Bulgarian involvement in a conspiracy to assassinate Pope John Paul II.

title: New Rankings
description: After stopping Diamond Jim MacDonald in a title defense Thursday night, Michael Spinks found a new way of saying that he is head and shoulders above everyone else in the light-heavyweight division: ''I'm not number one, I'm number zero.''

title: WHAT IS SO RARE AS A DAY IN JUNE? A TAXI IN MANHATTAN.
description: Mayor Koch's latest plan to reform New York City's taxicab industry proves that when it comes to serving cab riders, the Mayor has moved backward faster than a cab in midtown traffic can inch forward.

title: PUBLISHERS, IN SHIFT, BACK SOVIET FAIR
description: The Association of American Publishers, which two weeks ago repudiated its own committee responsible for staging an exhibit of American books at the Moscow Book Fair in September, has now decided that no changes are necessary in the 313 books chosen for the fair.

title: Pitt Seeks Blackouts
description: The University of Pittsburgh, citing a sharp decline in attendance last season, is seeking to limit local and regional telecasts of home games this coming fall. ''You can't give away something for free and then expect people to pay for it,'' Dean Billick, the associate athletic director, said yesterday, echoing athletic officials at other schools who fear that the proliferation of regional telecasts will cause a permanent decline in attendance.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: IN MEMORIAM Ulysses S. Grant was a boy from the Middle West who became a general, with a crucial role in bringing the Civil War to an end, and later President of the United States. He ended his days in New York City just 100 years ago and 1.5 million people reportedly came to his funeral, which lasted eight hours.

title: U.S. WINS NATO BACKING FOR GENEVA EFFORT
description: The United States negotiating efforts in the Geneva arms control negotiations won strong backing today from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: RAVAGING WILDFIRES' BURN 10,000 ACRES IN NORTHERN FLORIDA
description: Gov. Bob Graham, warning that the state again faces the ''grim prospect of ravaging wildfires,'' today ordered the National Guard to help fight two wildfires that have burned almost 15,000 acres in Madison County in the state's panhandle, where more than 20 other fires were burning.

title:
PATENTS;

Simplifying Form Of DNA Molecule
description: One of the week's patents of interest to scientists covers simplification of the double helix - strands of DNA that contain the basic genetic codes of life - into single or shortened double strands.

title: Home State Units
description: The First National Cincinnati Corporation said it had reached an agreement in principle to buy 10 Ohio offices of Home State Savings Bank from the American Financial Corporation's Hunter Savings Association subsidiary for undisclosed terms. It said five branches are in Cincinnati, one in Middletown and four in the Dayton area. All will become federally insured full-service commercial bank branches.

title: Pope to Visit Australia
description: Pope John Paul II will visit Australia next year, Deputy Prime Minister Lionel Bowen of Australia said today. He said the Pope had accepted an invitation from Prime Minister Bob Hawke and the country's Roman Catholic bishops to visit in November 1986.

title: T.W.A. Stock Up
description: Trans World Airlines' board met yesterday, reportedly to study a buyout offer from Resorts International.

title: TURNING PARKS INTO PIT STOPS
description: This one's a beaut. This is the kind of deal that gives deals a bad name. They're trying to turn a large section of a nice park in Queens into an auto race track. And the deal makers are very close to succeeding. Let's hear a great big vrooom for the masterminds of this one.

title: MORTON GELLER
description: Morton Geller, a certified public accountant and lawyer, died of cancer yesterday at New York Hospital.

title: ENERGY-POOR BULGARIA TURNS TO ATOM POWER
description: Severely lacking in deposits of coal, oil and hydropower potential, this country is turning more and more to nuclear power plants for its energy needs.

title: NEW CASSETTES: OFFBEAT HITCHOCK, TV'S BELLAMYS
description: Lifeboat Starring Tallulah Bankhead, William Bendix, John Hodiak, Walter Slezak; directed by Alfred Hitchcock, 1944 Key Video 96 minutes. $59.98 Though not the sort of film that won Alfred Hitchcock his reputation as a master of stylish suspense, ''Lifeboat'' is nonetheless an exercise in film-making expertise.

title: CABARET: CAROL FREDETTE
description: CAROL FREDETTE cut through a broad segment of cabaret repertory at Fat Tuesday's, where she sang last Sunday. The common thread that carried her through Brazilian music, the wry wit of Bob Dorough and Dave Frishberg, songs by Cole Porter, Cy Coleman and the movie team of Mack Gordon and Harry Warren was a strong sense of involvement.

title: Recent Sales
description: Cliffside Park $135,000 399 Aurora Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 56-year-old colonial; *2* fenced yard, patio, basement apartment; taxes $1,473. Mountainside $247,500 1370 Chapel Hill *2* 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 19-year-old ranch; slate entrance *2* hall, cathedral ceilings, picture window; taxes $3,720. Paterson $69,800 16 Dey Street *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 75-year-old colonial; *2* modernized kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $1,298. Scotch Plains $215,000 7 Greensview Court *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-year-old colonial; family room, *2* fireplace, skylight, cathedral ceiling; taxes $4,295. South Orange $192,500 134 Irving Avenue *2* 8-bedroom, 3-bath, 60-year-old colonial; leaded *2* glass, parquet floors, deck; taxes $4,728. Westfield $312,000 11 Hawthorne Drive *2* 4-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 47-year-old colonial; *2* 4-zone heat, central air-conditioning, library; taxes $4,447. OTHER AREAS Central Islip, L.I. $74,000 22 Split Cedar Drive *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old high ranch; *2* dining room, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300. Westport, Conn. $237,500 17 Indian Hill Road *2* 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 85-year-old barn; *2* pegged floors and skylights; taxes $2,212. Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. $132,000 50 Farrington Road *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 55-year-old frame colonial, *2* family room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,587.

title: GHONCHEH SIROSSI IS MARRIED
description: In the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York yesterday Ghoncheh Sirossi, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Azar Houshang Sirossi of Seattle, formerly of Teheran, Iran, was married to Allen Dulles Jebsen, a son of Clover Dulles Jebsen of Lloyd Neck, L.I., and the late Jens Henrik Jebsen. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth O. Jones performed the ceremony with the assistance of the Rev. Avery Dulles, a Roman Catholic priest and cousin of the bridegroom.

title: ARGENTINE LEADER INSTITUTES PERON-STYLE FOOD HANDOUTS
description: Juan Peron's populist Government handed out bread and cider to the masses in the 1940's. Nowadays, President Raul Alfonsin, who routed the Peronists 18 months ago, is distributing flour, sugar and corned beef hash.

title: GIVING CHILDREN SUMMER JOYS
description: TWELVE-YEAR-OLD Monique Long of the Bronx would like to continue to live in the city when she grows up. But after vacationing for eight summers on Long Island, she has decided she would like a country vacation home, too.

title: THE COURT'S NEW LINE ON RELIGION ISN'T SO NEW
description: The Supreme Court did more last week than strike down one state's effort to put prayer back in the public schools. In declaring unconstitutional Alabama's ''moment of silence'' statute, the Court signaled an unexpected about-face in its approach to the relationship between church and state. The principle that ''government must pursue a course of complete neutrality toward religion'' - less than prominent in recent Supreme Court opinions - emerged as the centerpiece of the analysis. Furthermore, the 6-to-3 majority placed firm restraints on the notion, dominant in recent rulings, that ''accommodation'' of religion is an appropriate, perhaps even necessary goal of Government policy.

title: AMY L. KATZ, LAWYER, MARRIES IRVING SCHER
description: The marriage of Amy Lyn Katz, a senior counsel of Revlon Inc. in New York, and Irving Scher, a partner in the New York law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges, took place yesterday at the Manhattan home of Ellen and Paul Victor. Rabbi Benjamin Kahn performed the ceremony.

title: NEW LONDON GETTING COURT
description: EASTERN Connecticut could get its first United States District Court, in New London, as early as next fall.

title: PEW CHARITABLE TRUSTS EXTEND REACH
description: The Pew Charitable Trusts, seven family foundations with combined assets of nearly $2 billion that have for decades poured millions of dollars into Philadelphia-area charities, are developing a new image.

title: Gunslingers Are Paid
description: All members except one of the financially troubled San Antonio Gunslingers received their paychecks and a $500 bonus Saturday from owner Clinton Manges.

title: THE DANCE: BALLETFORE
description: BALLETFORE lived up to its reputation as a model chamber ballet company in a performance on Thursday at Theater of the Riverside Church. The Balletfore choreographers and dancers are good storytellers, and the stories unfolded with the aid of colorful, inventive sets and costumes in just the right proportions for the Riverside's intimate house and small stage.

title: MASTER WILLIE WINS
description: Tonight's running of the $440,840 Yonkers Trot turned out to be a family outing.

title: LUSTY DREAMERS IN THE SUBURBAN JUNGLE
description: GREASY LAKE & Other Stories. By T. Coraghessan Boyle. 229 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: FEMINISTS RALLY ON ABORTION
description: Feminists rallied today in cities around the country to protest the Roman Catholic Church's stand against abortion and birth control, squaring off against abortion foes in Boston and chastizing the Pope in Washington.

title: Why Tampons Cause Toxic Shock Syndrome
description: The mystery of why some tampons caused the rare but sometimes fatal toxic shock syndrome in menstruating women was reported solved last week.

title: LIVES OF NOISY DESPERATION
description: CAPTAIN MAXIMUS By Barry Hannah. 101 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95.

title: PHYSICIAN IS WED TO MISS MAYNARD
description: Elizabeth Sprague Maynard, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin P. Maynard of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married there yesterday to Dr. Peter Taylor Gordon, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert S. Gordon Jr. of Kensington, Md., and Quonochontaug, R.I. The Rev. Donald S. Bitsberger performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer.

title: WITHOUT PROTFOLIO
description: ROOSEVELT TO REAGAN A Reporter's Encounters With Nine Presidents. By Hedley Donovan. 332 pp. New York: A Cornelia & Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LIMELIGHT. By Terence Feely. (Morrow, $15.95.) Take Alexis Colby of ''Dynasty.'' Change her dark, short curls to a veil of golden locks, her upbringing from lofty to low, and make her a tad more wicked.

title: IS CLASSICAL MUSIC THRIVING OR DYING?
description: Critics who periodically undertake to describe the State of Music, to use the term given currency a generation ago by Virgil Thomson, must be forgiven if they rarely appear to agree. Music, after all, is a fantastic Fafner-like creature that can change shape even as we try to describe it. The multifarious stuff we lump under the unsatisfactory term Classical music may appear to one critic as a simple diversion, to another as a quasi-religion. It can function for various people at various times as a time filler, as a hobby, as a trade, as an entrepreneurial venture, as academic make-work, as therapy, as an obsession. Music, in other words, is a country of many States, often overlapping and sometimes in direct conflict with one another.

title: PRACTICE DOESN'T ALWAYS MAKE PERFECT IN RETRIALS
description: The second trial of Claus von Bulow supports the view of legal experts that retrials in criminal cases almost always differ in content from the first attempt to do justice.

title: Miller Gains 5-Shot Edge
description: Alice Miller scored 5 birdies on the front 9 and coasted to a 4-under-par 68 and a 5-stroke lead after 3 rounds of the $400,000 L.P.G.A. McDonald's golf tournament today.

title: SHOREHAM DRILL: WHAT WILL IT PROVE?
description: SOMETIME this summer, the Local Emergency Response Organization, the Long Island Lighting Company's nuclear evacuation crew, may get a chance to audition before an audience of Federal officials to show how it would handle an accident at the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station.

title: THE WISDOM OF LOTTE HEINOTZ
description: PRIMA DONNA A History. By Rupert Christiansen. Illustrated. 367 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95. DEMENTED The World of the Opera Diva. By Ethan Mordden. Illustrated. 310 pp. New York: Franklin Watts. $16.95. A SIDE from badly, there are two ways for an aria to be sung. It can be done phonetically, so to speak, with all, or anyway most, of the right notes sung correctly and in a technically adequate, totally uninteresting, unmoving way. On the other hand, there are opera singers touched with vocal hubris, whose singular, even perverse vision and style enliven scenes, illuminate the music and otherwise touch off audience raptures. Outside in or inside out. Appropriately, these different strategies mark two recent books that train spotlights of unequal brightness on the many-splendored world of prima donnas - a culturally endangered species, one might argue, although any self-respecting diva would surely rather die than admit even the possibility of extinction.

title: Changing Positions Decent Switch
description: Should not independent civilians have the power to investigate complaints against New York City's police? City Hall has studiously avoided that question since the Lindsay administration tried an independent board for 10 months until it was voted down in a traumatizing public referendum. Complaints are now reviewed by an in-house Police Department committee.

title: Couple Found Guilty In '84 Midwest Murder
description: A man accused in a 1984 six-state crime spree was convicted today of the murder of a 15-year-old girl. Another jury had convicted his girlfriend in the same crime.

title: EXCERPTS FROM COMMISSION OF INVESTIGATION REPORTS ON RELEASE OF INMATES
description: Following are excerpts from reports by members of the State Commission of Investigation concerning the court-ordered release in 1983 of 600 prisoners from the Rikers Island jail. The first report is by the chairman, David G. Trager, and Commissioners Edward R. Korman and Charles J. Hynes; it was written by Mr. Hynes. The second report is by Commissioners Earl W. Brydges Jr. and Bernard C. Smith, and was written by Mr. Smith. The third report is by Commissioner Thomas J. Culhane Mr. Hynes's Report The commission's investigation clearly shows that New York requires and deserves a criminal-justice system which thinks with one mind, speaks with one voice and acts with one purpose.

title: WORDS FOR A WORLD
description: HAD I A HUNDRED MOUTHS New & Selected Stories 1947-1983. By William Goyen. Introduced by Joyce Carol Oates. 275 pp. New York: Clarkson N. Potter/ Crown Publishers. $15.95.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN CORPORATE ALUMNI GROUPS;

XEROX -- CAMARADERIE AND NETWORKING
description: XEROX-X, a nine-month-old organization of former Xerox ''managers and above,'' has one overriding purpose: Help members improve their business and career prospects by sharing information and expertise. Sure, the group's inaugural gathering in Dallas last November included its share of festivities - a ''hoedown'' dinner, golf and tennis, and a Dallas Cowboys game. But through it all, the focus was professional.

title: Skeleton Crew
description: STEPHEN KING'S fiction, at its best, is equivalent to the post-Expressionist art found in the tiny galleries of Manhattan's East Village, where painters, sculptors and collagists often turn to the aggressive headlines of tabloid newspapers for inspiration. What erupts in their work is an apocalyptic world, at once magnetic and repulsive, in which good howls at evil, nature runs headlong into technology, humor provides life's one grand escape and ''control'' is a word with little meaning.

title: MANY-FACED, CONTRADICTORY, ANCIENT SICILY
description: Few places in the world are as underrated as Sicily. To many people, and perhaps especially to Americans, Sicily is the land of the Mafia, of poverty, of women in black shawls and taciturn men, of violence and clans and uncertainty. But the fact is that Sicily may be the most attractive, most culturally privileged place in the complicated, recently established country called Italy.

title: DON'T TURN YOUR BACK ON THIS BOOK
description: SKELETON CREW By Stephen King. 512 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95.

title: Nominee Gets A Grilling On Civil Rights
description: William Bradford Reynolds, nominated to be Associate Attorney General, did not have an easy time of it last week in the Senate Judiciary Committee. He was roundly criticized, mostly by Democrats and members of organizations unhappy with his record as head of the Justice Department's civil rights division.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ROUBLES IN WORDS, KOPEKS IN FIGURES: And Other Stories. By Vasily Shukshin. Translated by Natasha Ward and David Iliffe. (Marion Boyars/Scribners, $14.95.)

title: MANHATTAN SCHOOLS PUT YOUNGSTERS AT THE CHESSBOARD
description: The players huddled over the chessboard, locked in a combat of logic and calculation.

title: The Dangerous Season on the Potomac
description: Now placid, now tumbling, the Potomac River wends its way through the Maryland and Virginia countryside into the nation's capital, past the Lincoln and Jefferson Memorials and on, cutting a channel of natural beauty that lures thousands upon thousands of visitors to its banks each year.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: BASEBALL

title: WHY N.F.L. TEAMS DO NEED 49 MEN
description: WE cannot understand the logic of the National Football League owners voting, 19-9, to reduce the active rosters from 49 players to 45 players for the 1985 season. Citing economic hard times as the reason for the cutback is penny-wise and pound-foolish. This move will have a significant effect on the quality of the game. We question this move and totally disagree with any economic justification for it.

title: 'LINKAGE' IS STUDIED AS AID TO CITY HOUSING
description: AFTER years of luring developers, four Connecticut cities are now searching for ways to cope with the resulting booms.

title: The Soup-and-Fish
description: In his essay ''Come as You Are'' (On Language, May 5), William Safire solicited the assistance of his Lexicographic Irregulars in ascertaining the derivation of the term ''soup-and-fish'' when used to designate white tie and tails.

title: The 'Nanny State' In Question
description: When Sir William Beveridge issued his report on Social Insurance and Allied Services in 1942, it marked the start of a social revolution in Britain. With the war's end and the advent of a Labor Government, every British citizen ''from the cradle to the grave'' was included in one of the most comprehensive social security systems ever devised. Last week, hard times and a Conservative Government that does not share Beveridge's faith in state intervention caught up with the plan.

title: LIGHTING UP THE OUT-OF-DOORS
description: IN recent years, more and more homeowners in this area have learned the benefits of installing outdoor lighting -for security reasons, for increased safety and for purely esthetic reasons.

title: Random Testing Called Vital Tool
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MANY COLLEGES SAY 'VALE' TO VALEDICTORY TALKS, BUT SOME KEEP THE CUSTOM
description: Kelly A. Walsh, who from the time she was a freshman at Boston College hoped to speak at her commencement, was one of two seniors chosen to represent the 1,200 graduating students this year.

title: YOUTHFUL-OFFENDER PROGRAM WINS AWARD
description: THE young people who participate in Yorktown's unusual program call it the ''chain gang,'' but the Westchester Municipal Planning Federation calls it ''innovative'' and gave it one of its annual achievement awards.

title: GROUP COUNSELS VICTIMS OF HAIR DISEASE
description: GLORIA DeMARCHIS was 12 years old when she began to lose her hair. She showed her mother the small areas of baldness on her scalp, and her mother quickly took her to the family doctor, who prescribed ultraviolet light treatment. Gloria was told she had ringworm, and the light treatment would make it go away.

title: CRIME
description: James McClure is the South African writer who attracted a good deal of attention in 1972 with ''The Steam Pig.'' The book introduced Tromp Kramer and his Bantu partner, Mickey Zondi, both of the South African police. Five adventures followed, and now, after almost four years, comes the seventh, THE ARTFUL EGG (Pantheon, $13.95).

title: DESPITE DROUGHT, JERSEY CAN'T EASE ITS CAMPAIGN AGAINST THE MOSQUITO
description: Lawrence Ferchak scooped an inch of water from a drainage ditch filled with garbage and discarded tires across the New Jersey Turnpike from Newark International Airport and found inside the cup five squiggling bugs that looked like tiny tadpoles.

title: WHAT LEBANON MEANT
description: Three years after Israeli forces entered Lebanon, all but the willfully blind know that the war exacted a terrible price from both invaded and invaders. Lebanon paid in destruction, death, intensified communal chaos. Israel paid in heavy military casualties, economic drain, loss of national confidence.

title: LITTLE MUSEUM IN NEW YORK EMBRACES ALL HUMANITIES
description: The three students crowded around the computer screen to select from a list of possible survivors to occupy a lifeboat.

title: FAN'S PLEA: HELP ME, HELP MY INDIANS
description: AN OPEN LETTER to Baseball Commissioner Peter Ueberroth:

title: THE MODERN FAMILY STIRS IMPASSIONED DEBATE
description: What is happening to the American family?

title: FOR BRIDES, THEME AND VARIATIONS
description: THIS is the height of the wedding season, so it is hardly a surprise to see a profusion of wedding gowns. Even less surprising, but warmly reassuring, is the constancy of this romantic attire - full skirts, puff sleeves, lace and taffeta.

title: ALEUTS FEAR FOR SEAL KILL AS SENATE CONSIDERS TREATY RENEWAL
description: The 750 Aleuts on the Pribilof Islands have their backs to the wall again as some animal rights organizations seem near victory in a campaign to block the killing of fur seals.

title: THE CHOICE
description: I read ''The Choice'' with a sense of deja vu. While I admire Lieut.

title: 8 IN KLAN TRIAL TOLD TO PAY LAINTIDDS $390,000
description: Three of 16 plaintiffs in the civil lawsuit arising from deaths and injuries at a 1979 rally against the Ku Klux Klan today were awarded almost $400,000 in damages by a six-member Federal jury.

title: 2 SOVIET ASTRONAUTS LINK CRAFT MANUALLY USING A NEW DEVICE
description: Two Soviet astronauts used a new distance-determining device today to dock their Soyuz T-13 spacecraft with the Salyut-7 space station, according to the official press agency Tass. It was the first reported instance of a manual docking in the Soviet space program.

title: CHASING THE BAD PAPER AT THE BORDERS
description: The popular image of illegal aliens entering the United States has them wading across the Rio Grande or crossing the border hidden in the trunk of a car. But many arrive by plane at American airports, where they present fraudulent documents and may receive no more than a cursory inspection before losing themselves in a land of 238 million people.

title: THE MIGHT OF MACHU PICCHU
description: It is 6:30, at the dawn of the summer solstice. At Machu Picchu the sun beats back its own shadow, bringing to light the violent red, enduring green and deliquescent gold of the Andean site's long and enigmatic history.

title: Jazz
description: In June, 1978, a ''salute to women in jazz'' was organized by Nobuko Cobi Narita and the Universal Jazz Coalition and was scheduled to be presented for four nights at CasaBlanca 2, the site of one of New York's most celebrated jazz clubs, Birdland. It was both a triumph and a disaster. After the first two nights, the owner of the room decided to change the contract to terms that Miss Narita could not meet and when musicians and audiences arrived on the third night, they found themselves locked out. So the performances on the last two nights were put on outside the club on the sidewalks of Broadway with electricity supplied by an adjoining parking lot, instruments sent over from the Sam Ash Music Stores and folding chairs borrowed from Roseland.

title: SURGEON IS WED TO ABBY HARRIS
description: Abby Meryl Harris, a daughter of Dr. Joseph T. Harris of Metuchen, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla., and Betty Harris of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Bruce Andrew Seideman, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Seideman of Hewlett, L.I. Rabbi Joel Zion of Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., performed the ceremony at the Hotel Pierre in New York.

title: Capital Gains Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD WAR I FORESHADOWS 'THE SHOOTING PARTY'
description: Though he was only a child at the time, Alan Bridges vividly recalls a certain book, containing photographs of what was then known as the Great War. He remembers leafing through it hundreds of times, transfixed by its sepia images.

title: Texas, Miami Are Finalists
description: Billy Bates led off the bottom of the tenth inning with a triple and scored on Doug Hodo's third single of the game to give Texas an 8-7 victory over Arkansas in the College World Series tonight.

title: THE CELTIC BOYS
description: WELCOME to Boston. It's a small city, perfect for walking, sight-seeing and dining. Maybe you could even do a little shopping before you go home to L.A.

title: THEATER: FOOD AND TALK IN 'INTERNATIONAL FAT'
description: IN his last play, ''Geniuses,'' Jonathan Reynolds gleefully savaged the mega-hit machismo of Hollywood whiz kids. The playwright, who had served a term writing ''Apocalypse Now'' for Francis Coppola, knew the full comic panoply of his subject, on camera and on location. Having also toiled as a talent coordinator on television talk shows, he has now turned his satiric eye on the idiocies of the small screen, as represented by Shep Bradley Diedricksen, the host of ''At Large in Depth.''

title: SECRETS POSE RECURRING LEGAL PROBLEM IN SPY TRIALS
description: In seeking to prove its charges that a group of United States naval personnel acted as a spy ring for the Soviet Union, the Government will face a recurring problem: how to prove a defendant betrayed national security secrets without publicly disclosing more secrets in the process.

title: Headliners;   A Date in Court
description: Perhaps only Katherine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy could have made a film version of the story of Becky Titus and Elliott Metcalfe. She was elected a county traffic judge last year in Sarasota County, Fla.

title: ACTING OUT CULTURE
description: ISLANDS OF HISTORY By Marshall Sahlins. 180 pp. Illinois: University of Chicago Press. $22.50.

title: MISS WARREN WED TO G. G. GURNEY
description: Constance Lyman Warren, a daughter of Caroline W. Warren of Rye Brook, N.Y., and Henry P. Warren 3d of Delray Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to George Goodyear Gurney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert R. Gurney Jr., of Roxbury, Conn., and New York. The Rev. Richard F. Van Wely performed the ceremony at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: MODERN ECHOES OF THE PAST
description: AT THE TIME NEW YORK'S GREAT PREWAR apartment buildings were designed, maids' rooms, butlers' pantries and laundry rooms were generally considered standard. These shoe-box-sized spaces tended to meander along the rear of the apartment, usually facing alleys or dreary courtyards.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PAYBACKS. By Christopher Britton. (Donald I. Fine, $16.95.) Midway through this mystery story about the Marine Corps in 1971, Mike Taggart tries to explain to his wife why, as the defense attorney in a murder trial, he is so obsessed.

title: MISSION TO RUSSIA, JUNE 1944
description: FORTY-ONE years ago, World War II was on the march through much of the world. The Axis capital of Rome had just fallen to the Fifth Army of the United States. On beaches renamed Utah and Omaha in northern France, more than 100,000 soldiers, sailors and airmen surged forth at dawn in Operation Overlord, one of the largest military maneuvers in history. Ultimate target: Berlin. The date was June 6, 1944, and the day would become forever known as D-day.

title: Reagan on Religion
description: President Reagan is not a regular church-goer, but he is at ease discussing religion and sometimes he even seems to tweak the nose of Providence.

title: Iran Says It Launched 'Massive Attack' on Iraq
description: Iran said it bombarded Iraqi territory today in ''a massive attack'' in retaliation for Iraqi air raids, and Iraq said its warplanes raided targets in five Iranian towns.

title: Post Wins in China
description: C. W. Post College of Long Island beat the Sichuan provincial baseball team here today, 8-3. The Americans are 3-2 in their six-game tour. Ron Lupo struck out five and walked three in going the distance.

title: CONDOMINIUM PLAN UPHELD BY COURT
description: The State Court of Appeals has upheld a lower-court decision allowing the real-estate developer Harry Helmsley to sell as condominiums, without city approval, 800 rental units in Manhattan built on land cleared under a Federal urban-renewal program.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN GLEN COVE
description: IN Glen Cove, construction crews seem to be everywhere these days, laying pipe, clearing lots and hoisting steel beams to forge a new commercial role for this Nassau County community.

title:
ART;

'REGIONALISM' EXAMINED THROUGH BENTON AT HUDSON MUSEUM
description: AS Americans try to understand in depth how this country attained its preeminence as art capital of the world, neglected art movements that contributed to that rise are being re-examined. One of these movements is ''regionalism,'' which flourished in the 1930's and early 1940's, and one of its best-known practitioners was Thomas Hart Benton of Missouri. Benton is the subject of a substantial retrospective at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers through July 7.

title: VONNEGUT, IN POLAND: 'SPIRIT OF SOLIDARITY LIVES ON'
description: Two American writers, Kurt Vonnegut Jr. and William Styron, visited Poland in late March. They met with dissident writers (including members of the disbanded PEN Club, or writers association) and Solidarity leaders, and Mr. Vonnegut was interviewed by the underground newspaper Tygodnik Mazowsze.

title: TANK'S PROSPECT FACES LIFE ON FARM
description: The joys of anticipation for a second victory in the Triple Crown series came to a stunning end yesterday for Gene Klein and his wife, Joyce. Their 3-year-old colt, Tank's Prospect, the Preakness winner, damaged the suspensory muscle in his right leg in the Belmont Stakes and failed to finish. The injury, Klein said, will end the colt's racing career.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: AT LEAST one person is offering a flicker of hope to conservationists and those communities faced with having to comply strictly with the State Supreme Court's Mount Laurel II decision.

title: ALPINE EXPRESS
description: To the Editor: The Q&A column of the Travel section has twice mentioned the Trans-Alpine Express train ride.

title: CASTING HISTORY IN BRONZE
description: ON a raw November day last year, after 200,000 veterans had massed in Washington and after President Reagan had addressed an assemblage of dignitaries and after a bronze sculpture in tribute to those who had served in Vietnam had been unveiled at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, one of those veterans approached Joel M. Meisner of Huntington.

title: The Sequoia
description: The wayward voyage of the Sequoia back to home dock as the Presidential yacht may soon be complete. The 105-foot-long wooden vessel had steamed forth to ease the cares of Presidents since Herbert Hoover.

title: Synagogue Vandals Get Terms in Prison
description: Three teen-agers who pleaded guilty to painting anti-Semitic slogans on a Manalapan synagogue and plowing a bulldozer into one of its walls have been sentenced to prison terms in the Monmouth County Jail.

title: EVERYTHING OLD IS NEW AGAIN
description: I HAVE been shopping for prom gowns with my daughter and guess what. Scarlett O'Hara is alive and well and living in the hearts of designers of teen-age clothes and in the hearts of the girls themselves. In dressing room after dressing room, I have been zipping up oceans of taffeta, flounces of organza and tiers of something that pretends to be satin.

title: MARIE CLAIR FLORENCE WED
description: Marie Clair Florence, a daughter of Mary Ellen Gates of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Murray Florence of Winnipeg, Manitoba, was married yesterday to Scott Leonard Young, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Young of Saddle River, N.J. The Rev. Charles Cowell performed the ceremony at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Irvington, N.Y. Mrs. Young is the floor manager for the Discount Corporation and Mr. Young is a partner of Y & B Futures, both members of the New York Futures Exchange.

title: PLANNING FOR TAX SIMPLIFICATION
description: PRESIDENT Reagan's proposed tax revision has many middle-class taxpayers apprehensive about the possible loss or diminution of such cherished tax shelters as real estate limited partnerships and Clifford trusts.

title: DOWNTOWN PLAINFIELD REVIVING
description: WHEN the Teppers and Steinbach's department stores in downtown Plainfield closed with nine months of each other in 1977, it looked like the end of the city's central business district.

title: CHILDRENS BOOKS
description: THE SWEENEYS FROM 9D Written and illustrated by Ethel and Leonard Kessler. 56 pp. New York: Macmillan. $9.95. (Ages 6 to 9) MOTHERS who work and children who come home from school to empty homes are such an accepted part of contemporary society that they are now appearing in stories for even the youngest readers.

title: LAW RESTRICTS USE OF CAMPAIGN GIFTS
description: Political contributions may no longer be converted to personal use under a measure signed into law this week by Governor Cuomo.

title: ANNE TILNEY HAS WEDDING
description: The marriage of Anne Cutler Tilney, a daughter of Dr. Robert W. Tilney Jr. of Far Hills, N.J., and the late Anne Cutler Williams Tilney, to John Taylor Terry Brune took place yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Gladstone, N.J. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Wiliam H. N. Brune of Englewood. Fla., and the late Mr. Brune. Canon John R. Morrow performed the ceremony.

title: ISLAND BLOOMS FOR 'PICK YOUR OWN'
description: THE first Riverhead strawberries of the season were on the stands two weeks ago. But usually the farmers who open their fields on a pick-your-own basis wait longer, to give the crop a chance to develop so there will be ample ripe fruit. Pick-your-own started about a week ago at farms in western Suffolk and the Riverhead area. Farther east, the berries should be ready about now.

title: BERRA HIT PROVIDES 13-INNING VICTORY
description: A long day followed the long night, but this time, things worked out better for the Yankees.

title: NEW CASSETTES: OFFBEAT HITCHOCK, TV'S BELLAMYS
description: Robert Klein: Child of the 50's, Man of the 80's Thorn EMI Video/HBO 60 minutes. $29.95 What makes this cassette so roll-on-the-floor-and-bite-the-carpet funny? Well, part of it is the audience - this 1984 performance was recorded live before a savvy, responsive crowd at New York University.

title: MEDIATION CHIEF MIGHT NAME PANEL IN HOTEL STRIKE
description: Citing mounting economic losses in the New York City hotel strike, the chairman of the State Mediation Board said yesterday that he would appoint a panel to recommend settlement terms if negotiations fail to end the walkout by tomorrow.

title: THE TRUTH BEHIND THOSE TAG SALES
description: ON the heels of daffodils and dogwood, summer is coming fast, and from now on there will be a burst of tag, yard, garage and moving sales. No matter what you call them, they add up to huge accumulations of furniture, tools, books, children's and adults' castoff clothing, pots and pans, all kinds of games and puzzles (sometimes with pieces missing), radios, television and so on.

title: THREATENED WORLD OF IMAGINATION
description: VIDEO stores are springing up all over the country. Even food markets have sections set aside for videotapes. Libraries have free video lending. In the mail, I am bombarded with advertisements for tapes: ''Rent One Movie, Get Second Movie Free,'' ''Half Price All Rentals From Our Children's Selections.'' These ads remind me of bargain basement or drugstore specials also printed on leaflets. There is a tawdriness in the display, thus cheapening the phenomenon of the movies.

title: MA BELL'S BREAKUP
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;

BEFORE YOU SPRAY, DO SOME HOMEWORK
description: THERE is an astonishing amount of variation in the regulations governing the use of pesticides, from one part of the country to another.

title: WHERE THE SUN RISES FIRST
description: Exploring Hokkaido, one is hard-pressed to find majestic shrines or packed cities or to encounter the painstaking attention to protocol that is such a distinctive feature of mainland life in Japan. Instead, life in the country's chilly north has a rough edge, manners are a bit unrefined and the land stretches on and on.

title:
TROUBLE IN LONG-DISTANCE;

AFTER THE BREAK-UP: MORE REGULATION
description: THE current turmoil in the telecommunications industry provides several prominent examples of how the benefits promised by the advocates of economic deregulation have failed to materialize.

title: MINERS' STRIKE IN 9TH MONTH IS A TEST OF UNION STRATEGY
description: A coal war is being waged in the mountains here and across the Tug River in Kentucky, one in which the levels of hostility and violence are reminiscent of union-management battles early in this century.

title: Quebec Party Loses Its Punch
description: The prospect of an independent Quebec once frightened Canada's nine other provinces. Last week, however, the Parti Quebecois, which caused the fright by gaining power in 1976, hardly seemed scary.

title: Sri Lanka's Population Boom Adds to the Island's Troubles
description: To the Editor:

title: UNITED PARCEL EXTENDS ITS REACH
description: SINCE last Monday, even the Havasupai Indians living at the base of the Grand Canyon are able to receive next-day delivery of letters via the United Parcel Service. Under a complicated plan devised by the company in case the need ever arises, a U.P.S. driver with an urgent letter will drive 50 miles on a dirt road from Valentine, Ariz., to the rim of the canyon. He will then hand over the letter to a mule-train operator who, for a $35 charge to U.P.S., will transport the letter on its rocky final leg. The price of the letter to the sender is the standard fee: $8.50.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: FICTION 1 ''. . . AND LADIES OF THE CLUB,'' by Helen Hooven Santmyer. (Berkley, $5.95.) Life in an Ohio hamlet, 1868-1932. 2 FULL CIRCLE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.50.) The relationship of a mother and daughter is altered by the changing values of the past 40 years. 3 THE WHEEL OF FORTUNE, by Susan Howatch. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A wealthy Welsh family haunted by an ominous heritage. 4 THE WALKING DRUM, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $3.95.) A young man from Brittany sets out to free his father, enslaved in 12th-century Asia. 5 MISSISSIPPI! by Dana Fuller Ross. (Bantam, $3.95.) The ''Wagons West'' series reaches the post-Civil War South and New Orleans. 6 LINCOLN, by Gore Vidal. (Ballantine, $4.95.) A fictionalized account of the Civil War Presidency. 7 TENDER IS THE STORM, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $3.95.) A New York heiress's passionate encounter with an Arizona rancher in the late 19th century. 8 POSSESSIONS, by Judith Michael. (Pocket, $4.50.) A woman discovers the truth about her husband after he disappears. 9 THE HAJ, by Leon Uris. (Bantam, $4.95.) An Arab's experience in the bloody wars of the Holy Land. 10 DEEP SIX, by Clive Cussler. (Pocket, $4.50.) One man copes with a sinister Asian shipping family and an even more threatening Soviet plot. 11 RAMBO: First Blood Part II, by David Morrell. (Jove, $3.50.) Novelization of the film about a Vietnam vet who returns to rescue prisoners of war. 12 * THE AQUITAINE PROGRESSION, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $4.50.) A lawyer finds himself caught in a conspiracy to take over the world. 13 THE MODIGLIANI SCANDAL, by Ken Follett. (NAL/Signet, $3.50.) A ''lost masterpiece'' and dirty dealings in the international art world. 14 ROLE OF HONOR, by John Gardner. (Berkley, $3.95.) James Bond leaves Government service to become a private spy. 15 * SUMMER HARVEST, by Madge Swindells. (NAL/ Signet, $3.95.) Thirty years of one family's life in southern Africa. Nonfiction General 1 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (S&S/Touchstone, $8.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 2 IN SEARCH OF EXCELLENCE, by Thomas J. Peters and Robert H. Waterman Jr. (Warner, $8.95.) Lessons from well-run corporations. 3 SON, by Jack Olsen. (Dell, $4.50.) The case of a young psychotic rapist at large in Spokane, Wash. 4 THE KENNEDYS: DYNASTY AND DISASTER, by John H. Davis. (McGraw-Hill, $5.95.) The story of a leading Irish-American family from 1848 to 1984. 5 FIRST LADY FROM PLAINS, by Rosalynn Carter. (Fawcett Gold Medal, $3.95.) Memoirs. 6 PAST IMPERFECT, by Joan Collins. (Berkley, $3.95.) The tell-it-all autobiography of the actress. Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 PENGUIN DREAMS AND STRANGER THINGS, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $6.95.) Cartoons from the syndicated ''Bloom County'' strip. 2 BRIDE OF THE FAR SIDE, by Gary Larson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $5.95.) Cartoons. 3 RAND MCNALLY ROAD ATLAS: United States, Canada, Mexico. (Rand McNally, $5.95.) For 1985. 4 EAT TO WIN, by Robert Hass. (NAL/Signet, $4.50.) A regimen for sports and fitness activities. 5 * THE ONE MINUTE MANAGER, by Kenneth Blanchard and Spencer Johnson. (Berkley, $6.95.) How to increase your productivity. 6 GARFIELD MAKES IT BIG, by Jim Davis. (Ballantine, $5.95.) Cartoon humor. 7 GROWING UP CATHOLIC, by Mary Jane Frances Cavolina Meara, Jeffrey Allen Joseph Stone, Maureen Anne Teresa Kelly and Richard Glen Michael Davis (Doubleday/Dolphin, $4.95.) Humor. 8 MORE SNIGLETS, by Rich Hall and Friends. (Collier/Macmillan, $5.95.) More words that should appear in dictionaries, but don't. Illustrated. 9 AAA NORTH AMERICAN ROAD ATLAS 1985. (American Automobile Association/Random, $5.95.) Maps and traveling advice.

title: CAN MCCANN BREAK 'SOPHOMORE JINX'?
description: ONE OF the most difficult government jobs to hold on to in New Jersey is that of Mayor of Jersey City, and on Tuesday Mayor Gerald McCann faces an uphill fight to win a second term.

title: PAPER LOSES LIBEL LAWSUIT BY EX-EDITOR
description: In an unusual libel action, a jury has found that the Kansas City Star Company defamed the newspaper's former outdoor editor in published articles and awarded the former editor $275,000 in damages.

title: Tanglewood's Bird Problem
