description: Officials at Tanglewood, the summer home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, have turned to inflatable owls in hopes of ending a half century of accompaniment by choruses of baby starlings. Twenty-four of the plastic predators have been painted to resemble great horned owls, which prey on baby starlings, and hung from the eaves of the shed, where the orchestra performs.

title: THE BAD SEED OF BAD SCIENCE
description: IN THE NAME OF EUGENICS Genetics and the Uses of Human Heredity. By Daniel J. Kevles. 426 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

NECESSITIES OF A 'GRADUATION KIT'
description: WHEN our college senior was home recently, we took the first step toward pushing her out of the nest: we bought her (gasp!) a Business Suit. Over the years there have been swim-team suits for swimming, leotards and ballet-shoes for dancing, soccer cleats for field sports, et cetera and et cetera. Every activity had its ''uniform.'' Like parents everywhere, we tried to provide her with the necessary equipment for success. The Suit represents the first item of the ''Graduation Kit,'' or what we feel is necessary to get her pulled together to face life-after-dependence.

title: The Long Goodbye
description: Jacob F. Butcher, a prominent Tennessee financier and politician, never hesitated to think big.

title: $472,190 for Meese's Trouble
description: The progress of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to the Department of Justice was interrupted last year by the inquiries of a special counsel into allegations of impropriety, centering on charges that as Presidential counselor, Mr. Meese had helped get Federal jobs for people who provided him financial assistance. Last week, he got some Federal assistance himself, $472,190 worth, to help pay legal fees and expenses he incurred in his successful defense.

title: SYRIANS WALK AWAY FROM ARAB MEETING IN DISPUTE ON ARAFAT
description: Syria walked out of an emergency Arab League council meeting shortly after it opened tonight in a reported dispute over a speech by Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader.

title: 7 Charged in Port Protest
description: Seven people were removed from a Brooklyn approach to the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge yesterday afternoon and charged with disorderly conduct during a protest against plans for a new Navy port on Staten Island. The protestors, who oppose the possible stationing of nuclear weapons in the port, sat down and refused to move from Fort Hamilton Parkway, the police said.

title: WHO WROTE 'HAMLET'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Far Away Game
description: American football bears little resemblance to Australian football, a derivative of soccer and rugby that also manages to resemble basketball by incorporating dribbling in its kick-and-catch format. Australians haven't had much opportunity to see the American game.

title: A SUBURB RECALLS ITS NEW DEAL MISSION
description: To most passing motorists, Greenbelt is just another exit on the Capital Beltway, and only a short distance from the off ramp are the shopping malls, office complexes and other trappings of prosperous American suburbia.

title: STAGE FOR MUSICALS LOOKS PAST INFANCY
description: CONNECTICUT performers who previously played only in local productions are now getting the chance to share the stage with professionals in musicals produced by a New London theater group.

title: REAGAN'S TRAVELING TAX SHOW
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN was where he likes to be last week, on the road for causes he believes in, stumping for his partisans. The two-day Sunbelt swing, Mr. Reagan's second out of Washington in as many weeks, was intended to promote his tax revision plan. Intended added benefits, to three endangered freshman Senators elected in the first Reagan landslide from traditionally Democratic states, were Presidential fundraisers on their home turf.

title: FOR PETER SHAPIRO THE HARD PART IS JUST BEGINNING
description: Essex County Executive Peter Shapiro defeated four opponents last week to claim the Democratic nomination for Governor of New Jersey. Now comes the hard part. He has to figure out a way to defeat Thomas Kean, one of the most popular incumbents in state history.

title: 'Fistic Nobodies' Fatten Records
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SANDINISTAS ARE SHOWING SURPRISING STAYING POWER
description: The Government has erected a new billboard directly opposite the main entrance to the American Embassy. The text is that of a note sent by Nicaraguan patriot Augusto Cesar Sandino to the United States Marine captain who demanded his surrender in July 1927. ''I have received and understood your communication of yesterday,'' Sandino wrote. ''I will not surrender, and I await you here. I want a free country or death. I am not afraid of you. I count on the patriotism of those who are with me.''

title: NEW CASSETTES: OFFBEAT HITCHOCK, TV'S BELLAMYS
description: Tchaikovsky's 'Pique Dame' A Bolshoi Opera production Corinth Video 102 minutes. $69.95 This ''Pique Dame'' is not a theater performance but the richly produced Soviet film.

title: Hungarians Voting, And They Have a Choice
description: Hungarians voted today in parliamentary and municipal elections under a new law requiring at least two candidates for each seat.

title: THEATER: 'MAN WHO KILLED BUDDHA'
description: ''THE MAN WHO KILLED THE BUDDHA'' begins with Kenji, a wisely simple young Japanese provincial in quest of spiritual enlightenment, becoming a disciple of the Buddhist master Misou Roshi, a religious hustler of the Old East. Kenji hopes to catch the Buddha the way he caught a fish with his bare hands when he was 11 years old. He spends the next 19 years polishing the Buddha's image, despite the inconvenience of not being able to see it, and thereby gains a reputation as a saint.

title: A Not-So-Grand Prix
description: New York's Flushing Meadow Park was once the Valley of Ashes, its ugliness memorialized by F. Scott Fitzgerald in ''The Great Gatsby.'' Though the ashes are gone, what remains is a flat tract surrounded by freeways that is only lightly used. The inferior soil is subject to flooding. Two world's fairs have left temporary buildings behind. Once-pleasant walkways have sunk into the ground. The lake's rowboat concession is inactive.

title: PLAYGROUND DESIGNS TEST CHILD CREATIVITY
description: CLAY MORRISON scurried up a bank of tires, grasped a pole and slid down. Without pause, he headed over to jump onto his tire basket swing, with his dog, Cashew, in pursuit.

title: Doctors and Their Dilemma
description: New York State health officials last week established an emergency referral service to insure that ''necessary medical services will not be denied'' to patients whose doctors have refused to treat them because of a dispute over medical malpractice insurance. Some obstetricians in Buffalo, Syracuse and Albany have decided not to deliver babies or perform high-risk surgery rather than pay sharply higher insurance rates, according to the officials.

title: THEATER GROUP SETS 3 SHOWS
description: UNDER a dark-blue tent pitched on the rolling lawn of Harrybrooke Park in New Milford, the age of Elvis, hot rods and duck-tail haircuts will be recalled beginning Friday night as Connecticut Stage Inc. opens its second summer season with a production of the rock-and-roll musical ''Grease.''

title: THE CITY OPERA RECORDS 'CANDIDE'
description: Hard on the heels of the recent ''West Side Story'' issued by Deutsche Grammophon, another Leonard Bernstein theater piece is being recorded as a full-fledged opera - this time by an opera company. The New York City Opera's soloists, chorus and orchestra taped their Hal Prince production of ''Candide'' during the last week of May for New World Records.

title: HOME IS A HAVEN FOR CELTICS
description: Through the years, stories have been passed along by players and coaches about how the Celtics used the small, dingy dressing rooms in antiquated Boston Garden for psychological advantage.

title: Aiming for No. 1
description: Chicago may be the Second City, but if Mayor Harold Washington has his way, it will soon be the ''sports capital of the nation.'' That is the prize the mayor dangled in front of the city's investment community Friday when he announced a proposal for an ''All-Chicago Sports Center,'' with facilities for baseball, football, hockey and soccer teams.

title: NICARAGUA REBELS MAY ISSUE CHARTER
description: The Nicaraguan rebels, under prodding from the Reagan Administration, are expected to make a new effort next week to project a more democratic image, according to Administration officials and Congressional sources.

title: Destination Yugoslavia
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz is quite taken, within the bounds of diplomacy, with Milka Planinc, the Prime Minister of Yugoslavia. ''She's a world-class leader,'' Mr. Shultz said after she conferred with him in a meeting that went on for three hours, ended with a stately embrace and included an invitation to visit Yugoslavia that Mr. Shultz instantly accepted.

title: OFF BEATEN TRACK
description: For decades, the West Side between Houston and Canal Streets has been an industrial neighborhood where printing and graphic arts companies have congregated. But recently, as the traditional boundaries of the financial district have been pushed to the west and north, office uses by companies in other businesses have begun to expand.

title: MISS ANGERS WED TO JEFFREY N. COE
description: Mary Catherine Angers, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Paul Angers of Red Bank, N.J., was married there yesterday to Jeffrey Norling Coe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Griffin Coe of Rumson, N.J. The Rev. John J. Angers, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at St. James Roman Catholic Church.

title: NEW DEMOCRATIC GOVERNORS SEEK BLEND OF RIGHT AND LEFT
description: According to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the state of ''Taxachusetts'' no longer exists.

title: WHY N.F.L. TEAMS DON'T NEED 49 MEN
description: IN 1958, the Baltimore Colts and New York Giants met in what was described at the time as ''The Greatest Game Ever Played,'' the Colts winning the National Football League championship, 23-17, in sudden-death overtime at icy Yankee Stadium.

title: A TOP GRADUATE'S LONG WAY UP
description: FIFTEEN years ago, Lisa Vice was on the fast track to nowhere. She was a high school dropout, a runaway, an unwed mother and a welfare recipient. Even her last name seemed to work against her.

title: NJ TRANSIT STUDIES ROLE VIS A VIS BUSES
description: UNDER pressure from the Reagan Administration, transit officials in New Jersey are re-evaluating their relationship with the state's private bus companies.

title: DANCE: THE BEARDEN TROUPE
description: IT was one of those evenings of participatory hoots and hollers on Friday, when the Nanette Bearden Contemporary Dance Theater performed at the Theater of the Riverside Church. It was unfortunate that the audience couldn't get up to dance, however, for the company could have used some capable performers.

title: AIR ATLANTA'S BUOYANT FOUNDER
description: WHEN he was growing up in Atlanta, Michael R. Hollis recalled recently, the black community abided by 12 commandments, not the standard 10. The 2 homemade commandments were ''thou shalt own thy own home'' and ''thou shalt send thy sons and daughters to college.'' All five of the Hollis children attended college, with Michael, the youngest, graduating from Dartmouth and the University of Virginia School of Law.

title: DEE MCHUGH BECOMES BRIDE OF J. F. LEARNED
description: Deirdre Ann McHugh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Nevin McHugh of Larchmont, N.Y., was married there yesterday to John F. Learned, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kevin G. Learned of Fitchburg, Mass. The Rev. William V. Reynolds performed the ceremony at St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church.

title: U.S. Envoy, Leaving Thailand, Says He Expects India Post
description: John Gunther Dean, who has been Ambassador to Thailand for the last three years, left Bangkok this week saying he expected to become the Ambassador to India within the next few months.

title: STAE BENEFITS SEEN IN TAX PLAN
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S plan to end the deduction of real-estate taxes from Federal income-tax returns could create an exodus of businesses and residents from New York to New Jersey, according to Alan Greenspan, who was chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers under Gerald R. Ford.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: SHOPPING AROUND FOR TRIP INSURANCE
description: An important reality about travel insurance is that sometimes you may think you are covered when you are not. It is essential, therefore, that you understand a policy's limitations and exclusions before you sign up. Most travel insurance is riddled with restrictions. Sometimes, to comply with varying state regulations, what is offered in one place is not offered in others, or rates for similar coverage differ substantially.

title: NEW AMERICAN ISSUES
description: The United States Postal Service will issue over 70 stamps in 1985 with a total face value in excess of $24.50. A quick check of the records reveals no single year in which a higher total face value was issued.

title: ALISON BUTLER MARRIED TO FREDERICK J. GEYER
description: At the Episcopal Cathedral Church of St. Paul in Boston yesterday Alison Butler, a daughter of Peter L. Butler of Boston and the late Marjorie A. Butler, was married to Frederick J. Geyer, a son of Carol Geyer of Dorchester, Mass., and the late Frederick J. Geyer. The Very Rev. Thomas B. Kennedy, Dean of the cathedral, performed the ceremony.

title: OUTDOOR ART WELCOMES THE SEASON
description: THE refreshing sound of running water in recirculating fountains is greeting visitors at two galleries in northern New Jersey that are featuring seasonal shows.

title: Up to Speed In Queens
description: Hard by the Long Island Expressway in Queens, where motorists consider themselves lucky to reach the speed limit, drivers in low-slung, single-seat racers will be roaring through twisting turns at 100 miles per hour. Under an agreement reached last week by the Parks Department and auto racing promoters, an annual Formula One Grand Prix race will be held in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

title: TEAM CHEMISTRY IS METS' CATALYST FOR SUCCESS
description: HOW do the Mets do it?

title: OMAHA IS A STOP ALONG THE ROAD TO THE MAJORS
description: WILL CLARK combines the boyish good looks and hustle of a Fred Lynn with the confidence of a, well, Reggie Jackson. And Clark, the Mississippi State first baseman and the star of the College World Series, likes to talk. He is a newspaper reporter's dream.

title: H. G. BRAUER WED TO CLIE MADEIRA
description: Carolyn Coxe Madeira, a daughter of Mrs. Rufus C. Finch Jr. and Harry R. Madeira of Northeast Harbor, Me., was married yesterday to Henry George Brauer, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Earle W. Brauer of New York and Westport, Conn. Justice William S. Silsby of the Maine Appellate Court performed the ceremony at the Jordan Pond House in Seal Harbor, Me.

title: All That Relatives Mean to Children
description: I recently read a wonderful article about the services for grandparents in divided families at the Scarsdale Family Counseling Service [''Grandparents and Divorce,'' Feb. 24] . It aroused many thoughts of my own personal experiences, which I would like to relate.

title: DOUGLAS M. ELY WED TO SARAH B. SELBY
description: Sarah Burneson Selby, a daughter of Dr. Talbot R. Selby of Richmond and Marjorie W. Selby of Bon Air, Va., was married in Washington yesterday to Douglas Michael Ely, the son of Michael E. C. Ely and Cynthia S. Ely, both of Washington. The Rev. John C. Harper performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square.

title: CAMPUS SURVEY GIVES FEMALE TEACHERS CAUSE FOR CONCERN
description: In addition to the familiar problems of sex discrimination in hiring and promotion, women in teaching may have new cause for concern. A study released last week indicates that college students, particularly men, regard female teachers as less worthy than male teachers.

title: Dartmouth Professor Drops Libel Suit Against Newspaper
description: A Dartmouth College music professor has dropped a two-year-old libel suit against a conservative student newspaper that called his course ''the most outrageous'' on campus and described him as a ''used Brillo pad.''

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: The Good Food Guide 1985 #600 pages. Consumers' Association. Paperback, $16.95. Egon Ronay's Lucas Guide 1985 #805 pages. St. Martin's Press. Paperback, $13.95. It will come as no surprise to anyone who has been to Britain lately that culinary guidebooks have joined volumes designed to guide visitors to stately homes, flower gardens and the London theater scene.

title: A Soviet Air Bungle Almost Costs a Ship
description: A Soviet Air Force pilot on a bombing test almost sank the ship monitoring his performance because of an air traffic control error, the Soviet aviation journal Aviatsiya i Kosmonavtika said today.

title: PARIS AS A STATE OF MIND
description: ''If one of us dies,'' the husband told his wife, ''I shall move to Paris.'' - Sigmund Freud The young man entered Paris to a blare of strumpets; the old man enters it to the measured gurgle of good cheap red wine taken by the tourists in immoderation, by the Parisians in steady nonintoxicating drafts to the obbligato of Parisian bread and Parisian cheese, the exquisite conglomeration, along with all the arts and all the humanities, the boulevards, the fountains, the museums, the music, and the self-possession, and the arrogance (always the arrogance), and the never quite wholly faded gloire - the conglomeration encrusted in a magic that is nowhere else and always there. The magic of this one city. Imagine the end, either end, of a car on the Paris Metro. There are two aluminum grab-poles running from floor to ceiling, about four feet apart across the width of the car. It's between rush hours but the car is well filled, with many mothers with children. A drama is about to be enacted, a drama that belongs to Paris alone.

title: 2 Drown and 4 Are Missing In Canoe Accident in Jersey
description: A 33-year-old man and his 5-year-old son drowned, two adults were missing and a 3-year-old boy was rescued yesterday after a canoe overturned on the Navesink River in Rumson, N.J., the state police said.

title: COMPROMISE NEAR ON '79 ARMS PACT
description: President Reagan planned today to resolve a sharp dispute between Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and Secretary of State George P. Shultz on whether the United States should adhere to a six-year-old strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union that has never been ratified.

title: SCIENCE FICTION AND SPORTS WILL BRIGHTEN SUMMER FARE
description: The competition is keen: barbecues and beaches and Shakespeare in the Park.

title: Q & A
description: Question:We plan on traveling in August from France to Guernsey in the Channel Islands and then to England, and will be taking a car. How can we obtain information on schedules for car ferries operating between the islands and France and England? - V. F., Stamford, Conn. Answer:For car ferry schedules from St.-Malo, France, to the Channel Islands, write to Townsend Thoresen Ferries, Post Office Box A, Saltillo, Pa. 17253 (814-448-3945 or 800-458-3606). The company represents - and makes reservations for - Emeraude Ferries, which operates daily between St.-Malo and St. Helier, Jersey, and St. Peter Port, Guernsey. The crossing to Jersey takes about 1 hour and 45 minutes and to Guernsey 2 hours and 45 minutes. The one-way fares to Guernsey are from about $52 to $85 for a car, depending on length, and about $22 a passenger. (Townsend Thoresen Ferries also represents several other services, including Condor Hydrofoils, which carries passengers only between St.-Malo and the Channel Islands.) Sealink, the shipping company that operates car ferries between the Channel Islands and England's south coast, is represented by BritRail (630 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017; 212-599-5400). The BritRail office, which can supply schedules and makes reservations, advises travelers to book well ahead because of the route's popularity among British vacationers. Sealink has daily service between Jersey and Guernsey and Weymouth (by day and overnight) and Portsmouth (overnight). The trip from Guernsey to Weymouth takes about 8 1/2 hours and to Portsmouth about 10 hours.

title: BIG PLANS FOR A SMALL TOWN
description: WHEN Peter J. Fioretti looks at the northernmost point of Lake Hopatcong, to the spot known as Glasser, he sees cottage condominiums, a dockside bar, a tennis court and a bustling restaurant with live entertainment.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: HELLO, GOVERNOR? HERE'S a phone number anyone living on Long Island should write down: 1-800-535-5414. People who dial that toll-free number on Wednesday evening may get a chance to talk directly to Governor Cuomo.

title: PANEL IN CONFLICT OVER JAIL RELEASE
description: After a 16-month inquiry, the State Investigation Commission yesterday issued widely conflicting reports on the events leading to the release of 600 prisoners from Rikers Island in 1983 and on changes that should be made in the criminal-justice system.

title: WEDDINGS: SOMETHING OLD IN NEW SETTINGS
description: ON Memorial Day weekend, Debra J. Depue and Jason R. Mayers Jr. were married under a canopy of blue sky in the flowering splendor of the Frelinghuysen Aboretum in Morris Township.

title: TIGHT BUDGET, EASY MONEY
description: How would the Federal Reserve Board -- Washington's most independent economic actor -- react if the Senate and the House manage to reduce the Federal deficit for fiscal 1986 by $25 billion to $35 billion?

title: GERMAN AWAITING MENGELE EVIDENCE
description: The West German prosecutor in the Josef Mengele case said yesterday that there was now ''a certain probability'' that the fugitive Nazi death camp doctor had lived and perhaps died in Sao Paulo, Brazil, but that he was awaiting the results of further investigation and tests.

title: PEKING HOSPITAL TAKES BACK PRE-1949 NAME
description: In a gesture symbolic of China's drive to broaden its scientific ties with the West, a Peking hospital and an associated medical college have been given back the names they had when they were financed by the Rockefeller Foundation before the Communist revolution in 1949.

title: No Headline
description: SUSAN HALLETT will not be at the White Plains Hotel Tuesday when the organization she heads is honored at the annual luncheon of the Westchester Council on Crime and Delinquency. She will be at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, where, since 1974, she has been serving a 25-year-to-life sentence for murder.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: ANNO'S ITALY. Written and illustrated by Mitsumasa Anno. Philomel. Paper, $5.95. (All ages) A paperback edition of the 1978 book in which the well-known Japanese artist leads a wordless tour of Italy.

title: RUSSIAN RARITIES ON NEW DISKS
description: Russian symphonies other than those by Tchaikovsky, Prokofiev and Shostakovich get short shrift from orchestras outside the Soviet Union. Occasionally Rachmaninoff, Scriabin, Borodin, Gliere and Miaskovsky are represented. But who in the West has heard those by Alexander Glazunov and Mikhail Ippolitov-Ivanov? Well, a few of them can now be sampled through two LP releases (although a couple have been recorded before). Glazunov's First, Fifth and Eighth Symphonies are played by the Bavarian Radio Symphony under Neeme Jarvi (Orfeo S 093842 H, two disks), and Ippolitov-Ivanov's First Symphony is played by the Singapore Symphony under Choo Hoey (Marco Polo, 6.220217).

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ALEXIS DE TOCQUEVILLE: Selected Letters on Politics and Society. Edited by Roger Boesche. Translated by James Toupin and Roger Boesche. (University of California, $24.95.)

title: VON BULOW JURORS HEAR TRNSCRIPT
description: A jury weighing whether Claus von Bulow twice tried to kill his wife with insulin injections deliberated for five hours today without reaching a verdict.

title: LEARNING DISABLED FIND EXTRA HELP AT YESHIVAS
description: No matter how hard he tried, Daniel Plaut kept losing his place in the page of the Talmud that was spread out before him.

title: COHALAN AND POWER POLITICS
description: PETER F. COHALAN'S shift from unflagging opposition to the operation of the Shoreham nuclear plant to favoring putting it ''on line'' proved once again that political considerations are at the heart of governmental decisions.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: ARMY TO CELEBRATE Five thousand soldiers will pass in review, parachutists will drop from the sky and warplanes will streak overhead at Fort Dix Friday afternoon to celebrate the Army's 210th birthday.

title: Pan Am Flight Forced To Return to Kennedy
description: A Pan American World Airways flight bound for Tokyo was forced to turn back half an hour after takeoff from Kennedy International Airport yesterday morning because an engine failed.

title: Conference for Black Women In Politics Is Led by Chisholm
description: Led by former Representative Shirley Chisholm, black women from across the country are holding the first national meeting of a group dedicated to organizing black women as a force in politics.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN CORPORATE ALUMNI GROUPS;

G.E. -- A QUASI-PLACEMENT SERVICE
description: FOR two years, Jack Trout was an advertising copy writer for General Electric, living near G.E. headquarters in Schenectady, N.Y. Toward the end, he had had about all he could take of that locale and, he recalls, one thing preoccupied him: ''How do you get sprung from Schenectady? You have to have somebody to call.''

title: THE LAST OLE
description: THE DANGEROUS SUMMER By Ernest Hemingway. Introduction by James A. Michener. Illustrated. 228 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $17.95.

title: One Nation Indivisible
description: To the Editor:

title: Cable TV
description: This is an interesting cable week for movie buffs, with some surprises. On Saturday, SelecTV (WHT) is showing a double version of ''You Can't Take It With You.''

title: The Long Arm of The Tax Collector
description: New York and New Jersey, which have been feuding over Federal money, sewage, Westway and even football and baseball teams, united last week against a common foe: tax evaders. Under a plan announced by the states' top tax officials, shoppers will no longer be able to evade sales tax by having their purchases shipped across the state line.

title: IS INDIA'S ECONOMIC MIRACLE AT HAND?
description: INDIA has come alive, imprinting itself on the American mind through the celluloid images of ''Jewel in the Crown'' and ''A Passage to India.'' The exotic has been reinforced by the outsized disaster that overwhelmed the impoverished in Bhopal, as well as by the assassination of Indira Gandhi and the violence that followed it.

title: 18 Still in America's Cup Race
description: All of the original 10 United States yachting syndicates that challenged for the America's Cup last year remain as official contenders for the 1987 Cup match. There are signs, however, that there may be a reshuffling among weaker yacht club efforts during an international challengers meeting beginning tomorrow in Porto Cervo, Italy.

title: 'EVITA' CONQUERS AGAIN ON THE ISLAND
description: UNDER Ruth Mitchell's creative direction, the Westbury Music Fair's physically awkward center-stage arena has been turned into an Argentine oyster holding the pearl ''Evita.''

title: LEBANON MILITIA FREES 4 CAPTIVE FROM U.N. FORCES
description: The commander of the South Lebanon Army, Gen. Antoine Lahd, today ordered the release of 4 of the 23 Finnish soldiers of a United Nations force held hostage by his Israeli-backed militia, and he termed the move a ''good-will gesture.''

title: TWO VINTAGE SHOWS ARE RESHAPED FOR NEW LIFE ON BROADWAY
description: Choreographers have been a major influence on Broadway dance. George Balanchine brought the discipline of classical technique to show dancing in ''On Your Toes.'' Agnes De Mille integrated dance with theater in ''Oklahoma!,'' And Jerome Robbins made the choreographer as important as the director in shows such as ''The King and I'' and ''West Side Story.'' But it has been 21 years since Broadway welcomed ''Fiddler on the Roof,'' staged by Mr. Robbins, the last great musical to have been directed by a choreographer from the concert stage.

title: The Public Makes Apartheid Policy
description: The urge to punish South Africa for apartheid is now palpable throughout the United States. Americans want to destroy this abhorrent structure of racism or disown its sponsors' claimed kinship with Western culture. Most Americans want to do business with South Africa only to the extent that this can undermine the Afrikaners' hateful doctrines.

title: 7 COUNTY STUDENTS TO VIE IN DALLAS
description: ''I DIDN'T think I had a chance,'' said Raymond Bancroft, a 14-year-old artist from White Plains, ''but I did it, I won, and the rest is history.''

title: Vietnam Warns U.S. Over Issue of Missing
description: Vietnam's official radio said today that United States hostility ''would only do harm to efforts seeking Americans missing in action'' in the Vietnam War.

title: Bowling Ball Death Verdict
description: A woman accused of beating her male companion to death with a bowling ball was convicted early today of voluntary manslaughter.

title: ARMS CONTROL'S FUTURE IS IN DOUBT, AND SO IS ITS PAST
description: The whole process of arms-control negotiations, past, present and future, was in question last week. Soviet and American delegates were pecking away in Geneva, but no breakthroughs could be sighted. Indeed, the life of the last breakthrough, the unratified SALT II treaty of 1979, hung by a thread as President Reagan made his decision this weekend on future American compliance.

title: ATLANTIC CITY CASINO PATRONS MOSTLY FROM 150-MILE RADIUS
description: Casinos, in business here for seven years, still rely as much on New Jersey and the New York and Philadelphia metropolitan regions for gamblers as they did originally.

title: MOST IN POLL FOUND TO FAVOR IMPORT LIMIT TO PROTECT JOBS
description: Most Americans think trade with other countries costs jobs in the United States, and they consider restrictions on imports a good idea even if it means less choice among the products they can buy, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: HISTORY AND ANTIQUES Visitors to the Van Alen Antiques Festival from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Saturday in Kinderhook will get more than a browse through the merchandise for their $3 admission fee (free to children). Organizers of the 13-year-old show have engaged members of the 12th Albany Militia and their wives and children to entertain customers with a re-eneactment of a Revolutionary War encampment, complete with military drills, outdoor cooking and camp-craft demonstrations.

title: METHODS AND AIMS POINT TO A NEW BREED OF SPY
description: While unraveling what may be the largest espionage ring in United States history, Federal officials say they have discovered a new breed of spy.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

PROMOTING OUR STATE ABROAD
description: FOR THE first time in 71 years, the United States has become a debtor nation. Our record foreign-trade deficit has endangered the future economic health of the country.

title: BOOMLET PROTEST
description: To the Editor:

title: Talking Maintenance;   Handling Tardy Payments
description: CREATING a system that will induce condominium and co-op owners to pay their monthly charges on time has never been easy, because nobody likes to go after a neighbor. And that neighbor knows it, which fosters even more tardiness.

title: WHEN TECHNOLOGY OUTPACES NEEDS
description: THE promise of personal computing in business is great. In partial fulfillment of that promise, word processing and spreadsheets have become not only accepted professional implements, but tools upon which everyday commerce depends. Other modern electronic applications, however, seem to have had a more difficult time establishing their credentials.

title: BASEBALL TEAM BEING SOUGHT FOR STAMFORD
description: A REAL-ESTATE executive wants to bring minor league baseball to Stamford, an idea many in Stamford endorse. What has not found favor is the executive's choice of playing fields: Cubeta Stadium.

title: Huge Wildfire in Florida Burns Up 21,000 Acres
description: Firefighters using bulldozers and helicopters fought a 12-mile-long wildfire today that threatened homes in north-central Florida and burned up to 21,000 acres in four days.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MY MOTHER'S KEEPER. By B. D. Hyman. (Morrow, $17.95.) The most recent daughter of a celebrity to create a scandal by writing a best-selling memoir of her mother is 38-year-old B. D. Hyman.

title: THE DRAG FROM DEBT
description: There may be a new weak spot ahead for the economy: the sagging growth of consumer installment credit. The growth of such credit earlier this year, was attributed by analysts to an unusually large tax effect.

title: SESAME PASTE
description: IT IS PERHAPS A COMMON-place to say that the American kitchen has become the most adventure-filled room in the house during the last decade.

title: PAMELA SELVAGE WED IN RIVERSIDE
description: Pamela Claire Selvage, the daughter of Patricia Carlin Selvage of Darien, Conn., and J. Preston Selvage of Lighthouse Point, Fla., was married yesterday to Charles Dolan Reilly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Reilly Jr. of Westford, Mass. The Rev. Vincent J. O'Connor performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: PROJECT ON WAVES WINS AWARD
description: FOR Beth Meyerand, a junior at Glastonbury High School, spending time at the beach has meant more than getting a tan and going swimming. It prompted her to experiment with using waves to create energy. For that, she won the most prizes given at the recent International Science and Engineering Fair in Shreveport, La.

title: THE BUSINESS OF COMEDY
description: IN THE 17TH FLOOR OF the RCA building, the comedian Billy Crystal of NBC's ''Saturday Night Live'' is in an office thinking funny about the film critics Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert. Both are to be included the following night in a segment in which Crystal -playing a popular character he created, an unctuous Hollywood charmer named Fernando -will interview them.

title: Dragnet by Peru Police Gets Two Suspects in Lima Blasts
description: Over 1,000 people were detained and two were charged today in connection with a blackout and two car-bomb explosions here during a visit by the President of Argentina, the police said.

title: CAYTHA SOLING AND MICHAEL GENTIS EXCHANGE VOWS
description: Caytha Ann Soling, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Soling of New York, and Michael Irwin Jentis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Jentis of Livingston, N.J., and Lauderhill, Fla., were married last evening. Rabbi Mark Goldman performed the ceremony in the grand ballroom of the Plaza Hotel in New York.

title: Baltimore's Place For Squeegee Kids
description: THE Baltimore City Council, which split along racial lines this spring over a proposal to outlaw ''squeegee kids,'' the young people who provide unsolicited windshield washings at traffic lights, has agreed upon a compromise.

title: City Selects Developer For Brooklyn Pier Site
description: The Lazar Group, a development and management company in the New York metropolitan area, has been selected by the city to build a $35 million project that includes restaurants and shops on a new 500-foot pier in Sheepshead Bay in Brooklyn.

title: Changing Positons Chairman Performer
description: Martin E. Segal, who claims to have been a high-school dropout, has announced that this, his fifth year as chairman of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, will be his last. This time, however, Mr. Segal will be no dropout.

title: The Bubbly Business
description: It is the season of weddings, graduations - and thus, of champagne. ''Nothing matches the rise in retail sales of real champagne, by which I mean the sparkling wine produced only in the Champagne region of France,'' said Marvin R. Shanken, publisher of Impact, a wine and spirits trade journal.

title: GO-GO MUSIC BRINGS A FRESH BEAT TO SUMMER DANCING
description: Washington was the first major city in the United States with a predominantly black population, and it has long been an important center for black music. Washington's Howard Theater was a leading stop on the East Coast's black theater circuit for decades, comparable in importance to Harlem's Apollo. In the 1950's, Washington was the hometown or headquarters for a glittering array of black talent, including Ruth Brown, Billy Stewart and, during a significant early period in his career, Marvin Gaye. But in the 60's, when Detroit, Chicago, Memphis and New Orleans were regional centers with their own distinctive brands of soul music, and performers from near and far flocked to New York and Los Angeles to take advantage of their cosmopolitan recording and club scenes, Washington was left behind. The city's most ambitious performers took their talents elsewhere, and there was never a ''Washington Sound'' to compete with the Memphis Sound and Motown's ''Sound of Young America'' -until now.

title: LEBANON'S CHRISTIANS HAVE HIT BOTTOM
description: AFTER 10 years of civil war, the fortunes of Lebanon's embattled Christians appear to have reached their lowest ebb.

title: McGimpsey Captures British Amateur Golf
description: Garth McGimpsey of Northern Ireland defeated Graham Homewood of England, 8 and 7, and won the British Amateur golf title today. The final had been scheduled for 36 holes.

title: FIELD NOTES ON THE PSYCHOLOGY OF FAMINE
description: A two-hour drive down a winding track leads to this dusty bush village hidden among the thorn trees and flat-topped acacias. Several hundred Afar nomads can be seen, tending their camels or just milling about. The Afar are among the tribes most severely affected by the African drought and famine, but this particular group appears relatively healthy. The men still possess their long, curved daggers. Some have rifles too and wear bullet-filled bandoliers across their chests. Women who are married wear a sort of scarf over their plaited and beaded hair. All the women are bare-breasted.

title: WITH GANDHI DUE IN U.S., JOINT SPACE VENTURE IS SET
description: The United States and India are scheduled to announce a joint space effort next week that will include the launching of an Indian astronaut in 1986 along with American astronauts, Administration officials said today.

title: WHY BEST SELLERS SELL BEST, AND OTHER PUBLISHING SECRETS
description: IT was described by its publisher as a sexy ''Forsyte Saga,'' a modern-day ''Moll Flanders,'' a real page-turner and a great read.

title: THE CHOICE
description: The article on women officers shows that the military learned nothing from Vietnam, and the same ticket-punching careerists run the armed forces.

title: CATHERINE E. GEKAS IS WED
description: Catherine Elizabeth Gekas, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George G. Gekas of Riverside, Conn., was married in Stamford, Conn., yesterday to Richard Warren Henderson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Henderson of Indialantic, Fla. The Very Rev. George Poulos performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Church of the Archangels.

title: Verbatim: CBS Strikes Back
description: 'In the reporting of news, (CBS) should be free from outside pressures and influences. The CNN organization has chosen not to maintain a strict policy of independence - either from advertisers, corporate management or government.' rrCBS Inc., rrin a petition to the Federal Communications Commission asking that the agency reject a proposal by Ted Turner, chairman of Turner Broadcasting System Inc. and operator of Cable News Network, to acquire control of CBS.

title: DOROTHEA B. JESSER MARIES DANIEL STEVEN MAPES
description: Dorothea Benn Jesser, a daughter of Dorothea Coogan Jesser of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., and Benn W. Jesser of Nantucket, Mass., and Daniel Steven Mapes, a son of Mr.and Mrs. David J. Mapes of Minocqua, Wis., were married yesterday. St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Chapel in Magnolia, Mass., was the setting for the ceremony performed by the Rev. Vincent McKiernan, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Howard Keeley, a Baptist minister.

title: Coptic Cairo
description: To The Editor: Marylin Bender's recent article on Coptic Cairo (Travel, April 21) brought back fond memories of my adventures in old Cairo. An alternate way to reach the old city is to take the ferry, which has a stop near the major hotels along the Nile.

title: AMISH AIDING A SMALL TOWN IN REBUILDING
description: A week after tornadoes destroyed houses and farms, hundreds of Amish volunteers from at least three states streamed into this tiny town today to help rebuild it.

title: MAUREEN A. RYAN AND C. C. SMITH, A BROKER, MARRY
description: In the chapel at the Convent of the Sacred Heart in New York yesterday Maureen Anne Ryan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James V. Ryan of Rye, N.Y., was married to Christopher Conroy Smith, a son of Mrs. Joseph A. McManus of Rye and the late Walter J. Smith. The Revs.

title: VACANCY SIGNS
description: The recent New York hotel strike is not the only problem for the $40 billion lodging industry. Another is the construction of new hotels nationwide is running at a 13-year high -- twice the growth rate of demand for rooms, according to Daniel R. Lee, senior analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;

SOAP DIRECTOR RETURNS TO THE STAGE
description: UNTIL he signed on to direct the Clifford Odets drama for the Long Island Stage, Norman Hall hadn't really taken a close look at ''The Country Girl'' in 30 years; not since he directed Brian Donlevy in a New England summer-stock production in the mid-50's.

title: ANGELA VORDER BRUEGGE OF SOTHEBY'S MARRIES FRED L. HUDSON 3D, A BROKER
description: Sarah Angela Vorder Bruegge, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Martin Vorder Bruegge of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Fred Lennox Hudson 3d, a son of Mrs. Paul Berger Kopperl of New York and Lenox, Mass., and Mr. Hudson Jr. of Ridgefield, Conn., were married yesterday. Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Michael the Archangel in Greenwich, Conn.

title: CUBS DEFEAT PIRATES TO TAKE OVER FIRST
description: Chris Speier drove in four runs with a homer and a single and Jody Davis cracked a pair of doubles and drove in two runs today to lead Steve Trout and the Chicago Cubs to a 7-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: LOOKING FOR A GOOD ARGUMENT
description: IS argument returning to the novel? I don't mean generational feuds or emotional scuffling between the sexes but argument with some metaphysical meat on its bones. In the past several years, novels by Cynthia Ozick, Umberto Eco and the late John Gardner have unabashedly pondered what the literary critic Lionel Trilling called ''the great issues with which the mind has traditionally been concerned: whence and whither, birth and death, fate, free will, and immortality.'' Trilling felt that in neglecting these issues, mid-20th-century fiction had suffered a loss of emotional power. This may be putting the case too strongly; impassioned dialogue about ideas, however, has not exactly been a staple of the contemporary novel.

title: I.M.F. Rescues Argentina Again
description: Argentina, the banking world's biggest problem child, last week reached another agreement with the International Monetary Fund that will give it breathing space to get its finances in order, or perhaps to sink deeper into financial chaos.

title: PENDANT SAFEGUARDS THE AGED
description: SEVENTY-NINE-YEAR-OLD Rose Gagliardi of White Plains lives alone in a four-room apartment just a few doors down from her daughter, Betty LaManna. Mrs. Gagliardi suffers from high blood pressure and occasional dizzy spells, a condition that used to cause anxiety for both herself and her family when Mrs. LaManna wasn't nearby.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: MUSIC IN MINNESOTA, ANDALUSIAN TRAIN
description: Vienna Invades Minneapolis (For a Month) For anyone who cannot make it to Vienna in midsummer, there is always Minneapolis in mid-July. The magnet is the Minnesota Orchestra's Vienna Sommerfest, a potpourri of mostly music, with a topping of other Viennese attractions, from beer and wurst to strudel and sachertorte, with some movies and dancing thrown in. This year's Sommerfest, the sixth, begins July 17 and ends Aug. 10; it is built around the theme ''Vienna and the Virtuoso.''

title: Inconsistency on Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: A NATIVE TREE THAT BEARS UNUSUAL FRUITS
description: This year I'm going to plant a banana tree in my yard here in New York State. Well, it's not exactly a banana, but a pawpaw, which is known as the ''poor man's banana,'' the Indiana banana, the Michigan banana, or whatever state the pawpaw happens to be growing in.

title: PANEL QUESTIONS POLICY ON DISABILITY BENEFITS
description: Members of Congress and state officials say there are still serious problems involving eligibility for the Social Security disability program despite changes announced recently by the Reagan Administration.

title: BROOKLYN TENANTS' RENOVATIONS SPARK RENT DISPUTE
description: THE landlord of 10 buildings in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn has been accused by the State Attorney General and 35 of his tenants of initiating a renovation program using the tenants' labor merely to get higher rents for what might be considered ''new apartments'' under the rent-stabilization law.

title: Graduate Is Only 66 Years Late
description: WALTER PENN SHIPLEY JR. has been active in the Alumni Association of Haverford College for more than half a century, serving 20 years as the chairman of the fund-raising drive for the class of 1919, as an organizer of its 50th reunion and as a member of the Corporation of Haverford College, the all-Quaker body whose Board of Managers controls the liberal-arts school in Haverford, Pa., outside Philadelphia.

title: COUNTY CONTEST CITES 3 PLAYS
description: IF anyone is wondering, ''Where are the new plays coming from?'' - and everyone concerned or connected with the theater is - the answer is not restricted to the young playwrights' festivals that seem to be popping up nationwide.

title: SUMMARY OF '85 ASSEMBLY SESSION
description: Following are some of the major issues dealt with by the 1985 regular session of the General Assembly, which adjourned last week:

title: SUMMER PHOTOGRAPHY SAFEGUARDS
description: SUMMER is the best of times and the worst of times for photography. While nature shows off with spectacular color, the season's heat, dust and humidity can wreck a camera or destroy the delicate balance in the chemistry of film.

title: MAINE RECALLS A YANKEE DIVA
description: No novelist would dare invent the circumstances of Lillian Nordica's life. Nordica, born Lillian Norton of Farmington, Me., where her home has been turned into a museum, was America's first diva - a dazzling figure who blazed through Bayreuth, St. Petersburg, Covent Garden and New York at the turn of the century, sharing, and often commanding, the stage with such luminaries as Caruso, Melba, Patti and the De Reszke brothers.

title: WESTPORT READINGS HELP DEVELOP PLAYS
description: IT started as a series of seminars encompassing virtually all facets of theater. Jason Robards, Jane Alexander and George Grizzard participated, and so did the producers Elliot Martin and Burry Fredrik, among others.

title:
INVESTING;

RECORDS ASIDE, IT'S A DULL STOCK MARKET
description: COMPARED with the heady moves of the bond market in recent weeks, the stock market has seemed downright tame. While the Dow Jones industrial average has set new highs, it has done so in fits and starts, and investors have not shown much enthusiasm or conviction. ''I don't see any decisive movements in either direction,'' said Laszlo Birinyi, analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: BRANFORD PLANS TOWNWIDE FESTIVAL
description: SUMMER traditionally brings small clusters of people to the Branford Green. One weekend, the crowd comes for a folk music concert. Another features a road race or a strawberry festival. The events are organized by separategroups.

title: JAPAN
description: To The Editor: I was pleased to see John David Morley's article (''Glimpsing Japan's Hidden Face,'' Travel, May 12) the day after I returned from a trip to Japan. His impressions corroborate my own. I quote from my travel notes:

title: ARKANSAS BALKS AT EXTRADITION IN NEW YORK CASE
description: The Governor of Arkansas and the Queens District Attorney are involved in a dispute over the extradition of a former preparatory-school student, Catherine Nicole Cowan, who was indicted in New York in 1984 on drug-trafficking charges.

title: PRIME INGREDIENT IN TASTY MOZZARELLA APPETIZERS: FRESHNESS
description: IT seems that all it takes to prepare an appetizer these days is to put out a platter of fresh mozzarella cheese and sliced tomatoes, scatter fresh basil leaves over it, grind some pepper and drizzle extra-virgin olive oil on the top. Some good bread should be served on the side.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN CORPORATE ALUMNI GROUPS
description: THIRTY years ago Ted Stanley, who today runs a direct mail company in Norwalk, Conn., was one of dozens of eager young recruits toiling in Procter & Gamble's brand management program at the company's Cincinnati headquarters.

title: THE CHOICE
description: Creating an environment in which women feel they can reach their potential is not the primary role of the military.

title: FIRST BIG F.A.A. CONTRACT TO BE LET IN SOUTH JERSEY
description: AFTER more than three years of planning, the Federal Aviation Administration is ready to begin replacing its 20-year-old computerized ground-guidance systems and to upgrade equipment for weather forecasting and landing aids, among other vital auxiliary flight services.

title: MARY FILBIN MARRIES
description: Mary Margaret Filbin, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Malvin William Filbin of Houston, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Lamar Beach, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lamar Beach of Sanford, N.C. The Rev. Justin Hennessey and the Rev. Gerard Benson officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in Manhattan. The bride, who will keep her name professionally, is a vice president and divisional merchandise manager at Bergdorf Goodman in New York. Mr. Beach is a vice president of sales and marketing for Hampshire Hosiery in New York.

title: S. LEAH WASSERBERGER WED TO JOHN MAKSIM
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York yesterday, S. Leah Wasserberger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George D. Wasserberger of New York and Chilmark, Mass., was married to John Maksim, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Maksim of Garden City, L.I. Msgr. George Bardes performed the ceremony.

title: ANGOLAN REBEL REJECTS PARTIAL CUBAN WITHDRAWAL
description: The leader of the insurgents who seek the overthrow of the Marxist Government of Angola says he has rejected an American compromise proposal for the withdrawal of some of the Cuban soldiers in the country.

title:
GARDENING;

BEFORE YOU SPRAY, DO SOME HOMEWORK
description: THERE is an astonishing amount of variation in the regulations governing the use of pesticides, from one part of the country to another.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Black Landscape In 1832, when she was 13, Queen Victoria began to keep a journal. In ''Queen Victoria in Her Letters and Journals,'' edited by Christopher Hibbert (Viking), she records her royal impression of a coal mining area in the Midlands.

title: 10TH ANNIVERSARY FOR 'SUMMER EVENINGS'
description: NEATLY filling the period between the end of the regular concert season and the opening of the county's big summer musical festivals at Caramoor, Lyndhurst and the State University of New York at Purchase, is ''Summer Evenings at Sarah Lawrence,'' which is about to celebrate its 10th anniversary.

title: (NYT/Alan Zale)
description: IT took Democratic leaders three minutes last Monday to settle a five-month-old question: who could they name to run this fall against County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke?

title: Four More Years For Papandreou And Uncertainty
description: The Reagan Administration was definitely not rooting for Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou and his Socialist Party in Greece's elections last week. But enough Greeks were in their camp to give them four more years of power, albeit with a reduced majority in Parliament.

title: ROYALS MOVE TO TOP
description: Mark Gubicza and Dan Quisenberry combined on a five-hitter tonight to lift the Kansas City Royals into first place in the American League West with a 4-1 victory over the California Angels.

title: Brown-Bagging it
description: IT was known as the brown-bag or B.Y.O.B. (bring your own bottle) bill - state legislation to allow New Yorkers to take wine or beer to restaurants that did not have liquor licenses. The bill was introduced in the Legislature because the State Liquor Authority warned last year that brown-bagging was illegal and that it would prosecute restaurants where violations occurred.

title: THE EMBATTLED ARAB INTELLECTUAL
description: EACH ARAB COUNTRY HAS ITS SYMBOL OF INTELLECTUAL MALAISE.On a sunny, warm morning in January, Mahmoud Mohammed Taha was publicly hanged in the main square of Kober Prison, near Khartoum. His crime was ''heresy.'' Mr. Taha, 76 years old, had distributed a pamphlet that opposed the way in which Islamic law was being implemented in Sudan. The amputations, lashings and other harsh punishments of criminals had distorted the spirit of Islam, he argued, and had damaged Sudan's international standing.

title: DR. BENTLEY WEDS DAVID H. LEHMAN
description: At St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Wianno, Mass., yesterday Dr. Bettina Taft Bentley and David Harris Lehman were married by the Rev. Raymond W. Webster 2d, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Richard J. Mallone, a Roman Catholic priest.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

THE SOUTH IN SOFT FOCUS
description: In the 1920's and early 30's, Doris Ulmann (1882-1934) traveled by limousine from New York City to photograph the rural poor of Appalachia and the Deep South. Despite her means, she used an outmoded box camera, refusing to purchase such modern equipment as a light meter or a mechanical shutter.

title: FRESH AIR FUND'S BRONX-AMISH LINK
description: It was not the trees, the sun, the fields or the cows that endeared the South Bronx boy to rural life. It was the hard, hand-blistering work required for maintaining a farm.

title: ONE-FAMILY HOUSES FOR EAST HARLEM
description: FOR the last quarter-century, East Harlem has been characterized by a declining population as residents fled the neighborhood's continuing decay, and by an increasing amount of vacant land - the visible effects of that decay.

title: 'YOU PERSEVERE'
description: HOW do you ask people for money for a good cause?

title: MISS SICULAR IS A BRIDE
description: Patricia Ann Sicular, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon H. Sicular of Sands Point, L.I., and Delray Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. Robert D. Haar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Haar of Fair Lawn and West End, N.J. Rabbi Eugene Lipsie performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, L.I.

title: CONCERT: CONCORDIA
description: CONCORDIA, a young chamber symphony 45 players strong, played an intriguing program of ''Music from the American Melting Pot'' under its founder and conductor Marin Alsop at Alice Tully Hall Friday. The idea is a nice one, thoughtfully worked out. Not only were the composers an assortment of refugees and immigrants or their descendants, but each piece was achieved by musical melting and stirring: opera with jazz; the 18th century with the 20th; swing with ''classical'' strings; modern dissonance with folksong.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

A PORTRAIT OF A FATHER AS A HOUSE PAINTER
description: IN retrospect, back in the 1930's, fathers were strange creatures in contrast to the fathers of today. At least the fathers I knew were strange. Fathers back then did not play tennis or golf, jog, or grill red raw meat on backyard barbecue spits. A father seen riding a bicycle in those distant days would have been quickly certified for the funny farm.

title: GROUPS ON L.I. TAKE CENSUS OF BIRDS ON ENDANGERED LIST
description: The small colony of least terns was in an uproar as biologist Michael Scheibel, an expert on endangered species, stepped gingerly through their Shell Beach nesting area here.

title: Shedding Light On the Black Hole
description: Two groups of scientists reported last week that they are more convinced than ever that there is a hole in the middle of our galaxy, the Milky Way.

title: THE FRAGILE MONTH OF MAY FLIES BY
description: ''HELLO,'' said the laconic recorded voice on the telephone. ''We're happy to inform you that this is your lucky day.'' I heard something about buying resort property in Newport before hanging up the receiver.

title: CONSERVATIONISTS CELEBRATE 20 YEARS
description: DR. Harold Leonard has been described as ''the gentlest of souls,'' a man who, when he retired from his periodontal practice, looked forward to the simple joys of tending his own garden. But in 1965, a Scarsdale Audubon Society meeting turned the organization's 78-year-old president from someone who ''never raised his voice,'' according to Susan A. Reed, into ''the letter-writin'est, battlin'est man in Westchester.''

title: TENDING THE CAPITAL'S PARKS
description: Each year, when the 10 regional directors of the National Park Service come before the House Appropriations Commitee to petition for more funds, the chairman of the committee invariably calls upon Jack Fish with the same refrain: ''And what do you have for us this year, Mr. Impressario?''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE LIFE INSURANCE GAME. By Ronald Kessler. (Holt, $16.95.) The images of insurance companies - towering rocks, alert Minutemen, open umbrellas - are designed to convey safety and protection.

title: G.M. RETOOLS ITS OUTLOOK AND ITS ASSEMBLY LINES
description: A research engineer at General Motors' Technical Center once grumbled to a visitor that the specifications for the first practical industrial robot were developed there in the early 1960's, but nothing had come of it. At that time, the company was rich and complacent and not interested in something as seemingly risky as high-technology robotics. ''The attitude then was, 'We make cars, not tools,' '' he said.

title: Photography
description: It's only a slight exaggeration to say that the focus in photography has shifted in the last year from those who make images to those who collect them. Perhaps it is a signal that the medium has finally achieved its rightful niche in the world. Or perhaps lately there hasn't been all that much excitement generated by photographers. In either case, there's no arguing over its beneficial impact: it has brought into the public eye pictures of enormous beauty and art-historical value.

title: TOWNS STUDY JOINT TRASH PLAN
description: THE Towns of Huntington and Smithtown, whose landfills are just 500 feet apart, are talking about a joint effort to dispose of their garbage.

title: CUBA EXPANDING ACTIVITY IN AFRICAN NATIONS
description: Despite persistent objections from the United States Government, Cuba is expanding its activities in Africa, and Cuban officials say it is unlikely that their combat troops in Angola will be leaving in the near future.

title: JINSEY DAUK WEDS STEPHEN H. KIESLING
description: Jennifer Gledhill Dauk and Stephen H. Kiesling were married yesterday at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn., by the Rev. Lawrence MacColl Horton, assisted by Canon Frederick Brunson, an Episcopal priest.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: MASSACHUSETTS SLOWDOWN A campaign against Massachusetts speeders by police cars, some of them unmarked, and by radar teams began last week on Interstate 93, resulting in 891 summonses, nine times normal, in its first five days.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: AUGUST PEOPLE. By Ralph Graves (Doubleday, $16.95.) Charles Winderman - ''Ah-boo'' to family and close friends (from the poem ''Abou ben Adhem'') - is the patriarch of the Winderman clan, which assembles each August at an unnamed East Coast island.

title: WHY REFERENCES AREN'T 'AVAILABLE ON REQUEST'
description: Last month, a memo came down from the eighth-floor personnel department at the Southmark Corporation in Dallas. Henceforth, it read, manages are not to talk to anyone calling to ask about former Southmark employees, regardless of who the caller is or how wonderful or terrible the former employee was. The policy was firm: dates of employment and job titles only. No opinions.

title: LONG-TIME U.S. WORKERS FEEL THE EDGE OF COST CUTS
description: For the last 18 of her 40 years, Barbara Roberts has worked in the mess hall of the Marine Corps Logistics Base here. She made salads and served food to the soldiers and expected to do much the same until retirement after 35 years as a Federal employee.

title:
ON LANGUAGE;

A Toast To White Bread
description: DESCRIBING THE EF-fect of softened violence in a movie called ''The Dirty Dozen: Next Mission,'' John Corry, a New York Times television critic, wrote, ''It may be a white bread war. . . .''

title: MCGUIGAN TAKES TITLE FROM PEDROZA
description: Barry McGuigan, the pride of the Irish, won the World Boxing Association's featherweight title tonight in a unanimous decision over Eusebio Pedroza, ending the Panamanian's seven-year reign as champion.

title: U.N. SAYS FAMINE WORSENS IN SUDAN
description: The famine in 19 African countries continues to worsen, according to a United Nations report issued this week. In the Sudan alone, the number of victims will reach 11.5 million, or more than half the population, by the end of the year, it said.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE PROMISED LAND, by Mary Antin. (Princeton, $12.50.) In 1912 Mary Antin published the story of her and her parents' migration from Polotsk, a town in the Jewish Pale of Russia, to Boston. Her book is divided between her Russian and American experiences. An unsigned review in The Times commented: ''In the moving, vividly interesting pages of her autobiography, Mary Antin has presented the case of the Russian Jew's American citizenship as it has not been presented before. And she has made a unique contribution to our modern literature and to our modern history.'' THE MAN WHO CRIED I AM, by John A. Williams. (Thunder's Mouth/Persea, $8.95.) The story in the fourth of John A. Williams's 17 books revolves around Max Reddick, a black news magazine writer who has also been a White House aide, an expatriate in Europe and friend of a Richard Wright-like figure. The chilling climax involves his discovery of the plan for America's ''final solution'' to ''the Negro problem.''

title: TALL IN THE SADDLE
description: LONESOME DOVE By Larry McMurtry. 843 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title:
ANTIQUES;

A RESTAURANT WHERE EVERYTHING BUT THE FOOD IS OLD AND FOR SALE
description: IT MAY seem like another version of ''The Odd Couple,'' but Kitchen Caboodle-Nancy Gilbert Antiques, a dual business housed in an old carriage repair shop on Main Street, is a combination that seems to work.

title: Reds' Davis Not Ready for Majors
description: ERIC DAVIS batted only .224 in his 57-game trial with Cincinnati last season, but the rest of his performance - 10 home runs, 30 runs batted in, 10 stolen bases - provided the Reds with a glimpse of what they thought the young outfielder could produce in the immediate future. They were wrong, though, and they acknowledged their mistake by returning Davis to the minors last week.

title:
DINING OUT;

HEARTY CHINESE WITH HARMONY
description: WHAT distinguishes an accomplished Chinese restaurant from a mediocre one is not only the range of its offerings but also the distinctiveness of its dishes and the ability to keep them that way year after year. Dozens of restaurants offering Chinese cuisine have opened in the county since Hunan Manor settled in seven years ago, but few of them can boast of maintaining kitchens as dependable as Hunan Manor's. Unlike a recent spate of Chinese restaurants (many of them incorporating the word Wok in their name and many of them offering quality comparable to our western fast food chains) that serve up bland or unsubtle fare, one dish indistinguishable in appearance and flavor from the next, Hunan Manor delivers the promised goods, harmonious, hearty, home-style dishes with character, prepared as hot and spicy or as mild as your palate pleases. Simply make your preference known.

title: DEVELOPERS TROUBLED BY REAGAN TAX PLAN
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S proposed tax revisions would cause radical changes in the business of commercial real estate in the city, professionals in the field agree. But they see as the greatest threat his proposal to eliminate deductions on Federal income-tax returns for city and state taxes.

title: The Choice
description: As a woman graduate of the United States Military Academy in May, I read with interest Esther B. Fein's article ''The Choice'' (May 5). Many of the feelings and concerns expressed by the three women officers are shared by my classmates and me.

title: TIME VINDICATES FRANCIS BACON'S SEARING VISION
description: The retrospective exhibition of paintings by Francis Bacon at the Tate Gallery in London is not an event about which I shall pretend to be objective. Among the many thousands of exhibitions that I have seen on business and for pleasure, none is more vivid to me than the first sight of Bacon's ''Three Studies for Figures at the Base of a Crucifixion'' at the Lefevre Gallery in London in April 1945. They are in every book on Bacon. They are the predestined point of departure for every retrospective exhibition of his work. They have been described a thousand times. But, when seen at first hand, they still startle.

title: HOW ONE HOUSEHOLD WITH 2 PH.D.'S CAN GENERATE INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL IDENTITY PROBLEMS
description: IN June 1982, after what seemed an eternity of concept-stalking and footnote-juggling, my wife, Vasda, received her Ph. D. from New York University. End of story? In some ways, just the beginning.

title: SECT ORDERED TO STOP SHELTERING TEEN-AGERS
description: A self-styled Christian sect that operates a carpet-cleaning service from residences on the West Side of Manhattan and in Brooklyn has been ordered to stop taking any more teen-agers into the homes, authorities said yesterday.

title: A SELECTIVE GUIDE TO SUMMER CELEBRATIONS
description: The following is a selective list of summer dance festivals and events. It is national in scope but concentrates on the Northeast, beginning with New York City. NEW YORK CITY ART IN THE ANCHORAGE - Ongoing series of performances and visual-arts exhibits at the anchorage, located underneath the Brooklyn Bridge on the Brooklyn side, through June 30. Susan Marshall and Dancers will perform June 26-27. (Creative Times at Art in the Anchorage, Cadman Plaza West at Front Street, Brooklyn, N.Y. Phone: 718-571-2206) ART ON THE BEACH - The seventh annual Creative Times series of performances and visual-art exhibitions at the Battery Park City landfill on the Hudson River will open on July 2. This season, there will be 10 collaborative projects involving over 30 visual and performance artists and new music composers. Concerts are given on Wednesdays and Sundays at 6:30. (Through Sept. 13) (Art on the Beach, Chambers and West St., New York, N.Y. Phone: 571-2206) BATTERY DANCE COMPANY -This modern-dance troupe of New York's financial district will again give free concerts accompanied by the West Side Brass Quintet at the South Street Seaport, Aug. 16 through Sept. 13. On Aug. 20 they will appear at the Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park. (Battery Dance Company, 380 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10013.

title: Maine Museum Commissions Potato Sculpture for Festival
description: The Bowdoin College Museum of Art has commissioned two artists to create a series of potato sculptures as part of the Maine Festival starting in late July, according to the museum's curator, John Coffey.

title: CUOMO ANGERED BY REAGAN AIDE
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday attacked Patrick Buchanan, the White House communications director, for implying at a news conference Friday that high-tax states are ''neo-socialist'' governments attempting to ''redistribute the wealth.''

title: COPTIC CAIRO
description: To the Editor: In her article on Old Cairo's Coptic Museum and churches, Marylin Bender notes that adjacent to St. Sergius Church is the centuries-old Ben Ezra synagogue. She adds that, according to its sexton, the synagogue and its notable collection of manuscripts are being restored.

title: OFFSPRING OF G.M.-TOYOTA MARRIAGE
description: It is longer ago than I like to remember, but I did have some pleasant young days in New Zealand, in the Navy, on my way to Antarctica and operation Deep Freeze. There were good people and good times and all of that, and it is worth dwelling on. But what we will think about here are those interesting cars.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: A Polish Omen That's Bad for Historians
description: To the Editor:

title: Basques Suspected in Blast
description: A bomb exploded today near a beachfront hotel outside Valencia, and the police said it may have been part of an anti-tourism campaign by Basque separatist guerrillas. No one was hurt, and there was no damage. The police said warnings had been received by telephone before the blast.

title: 'MACK AND MABEL' IN A REVIVAL
description: SOME musicals make it instantly, and then one wonders why. Others, like ''Mack and Mabel,'' do not, and that is a wonder, too.

title: WHITE-COLLAR CRIME: BOOMING AGAIN
description: THE business news lately has been reading like a drawn-out Hollywood script of corruption: Old line manufacturers exposed cheating the Pentagon. Venerable banks caught laundering money. A securities firm found fraudulently kiting checks. Once-respected businessmen and former government officials indicted - and jailed - for insider trading and fraud.

title: PUERTO RICO
description: To the Editor: My wife and I read with great interest Jorge Heine's article ''Puerto Rico's Quiet Edge'' (Travel, March 31) as we have made many visits to the area over the years. We found his article extremely informative, even for part-time residents.

title: PennDot: Second Thoughts on Aged
description: PENNSYLVANIA'S Department of Transportation has decided to rescind an April 17 order that 80 ''paratransit'' companies cut the fares they charge the elderly under a taxi program subsidized with proceeds from the state lottery.

title: TARA STACOM, BROKER, WED
description: Tara Irene Stacom, a daughter of Matthew J. Stacom of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Claire P. Stacom, was married yesterday to Paul Allan Nussbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Nussbaum of Tamarac, Fla. Rabbi David Greenberg performed the ceremony in the library of the Villard House at the Helmsley Palace Hotel in New York.

title: HAVARD OARSMEN END YALE CUP STREAK
description: Harvard's varsity heavyweight crew initiated what it hopes will be a new winning streak in the oldest intercollegiate sporting event in America, capturing the 120th rowing of the ''The Boat Race'' today against its ancient rival, Yale.

title: CORRECTION
description: In last week's About Westchester column, on a conference for young authors and illustrators, nine lines of type were inadvertently dropped during production.

title: WAR HEROINE'S ROLE IS ACTRESS'S MISSION
description: ''HANNAH SENESH'' may be what is commonly called a one-woman show, but in an uncommon coup de theatre the actress Lori Wilner, who is 23 years old, plays two women: the title character, from the age of 13 to 22, and her own mother, Catherine, who appears in the first and last scenes.

title: ASSEMBLY ADJOURNS: SET BIGGEST TAX CUT EVER
description: TAX cuts, concerns about drunken driving and problems with Connecticut's criminal justice system dominated the 1985 session of the General Assembly, which adjourned last Wednesday.

title: A Public School For Homosexuals
description: The first public school program in the United Staes designed for homosexual adolescents has been operating in New York since April 1, it was reported last week. Twenty students, from 14 to 19 years old, are attending classes at the Washington Square United Methodist Church in Greenwich Village. All are school dropouts or truants.

title: RECALLING HOW RADIO SURVIVED THE ARRIVAL OF TV
description: While Lucy and Ralph Kramden and Uncle Milty are among those who have been honored with well-publicized salutes at the Museum of Broadcasting, the nine-year old museum has never presented an exhibition devoted solely to radio. But don't touch that dial: The situation is likely to change very soon.

title: DEBATE IS GROWING OVER MEDICARE AID
description: The Reagan Administration is resisting directives from a Federal district judge and from Congress to increase Medicare payments for hospitals that serve large numbers of poor people.

title: Plans to Expand America's Parks
description: The new head of the National Park Service promised last week to protect and expand the park system even if it meant raising fees and sometimes closing the gates because of overcrowding. Moreover, William Penn Mott Jr., who was appointed last month by Secretary of the Interior Donald J. Hodel, called for more protection of the parks against encroaching development and for the purchase of new parklands.

title: YES, THERE IS LIFE SOUTH OF 25A
description: IT happened at a party in Northport. I was eating runny Brie and mangoes with our friends' neighbors when I learned some astonishing truths. I learned that the people next door had the tackiest garbage in town on large-scale trash collection day.

title: Patrick
description: Apart from Ron, Tip and Cap, the tall young man known as Patrick may be the only celebrity able to maintain single-monicker identity in the capital. The foregoing group is, respectively, the President, the House Speaker, the Secretary of Defense and the primary draft choice of the New York Knicks basketball team, Patrick Ewing. ''Patrick,'' as hand-scrawled in the window of the downtown ticket office of the Washington Bullets basketball team, is enough said since he was the seven-foot-tall pillar of the Georgetown University team for the past four years. The sign, trying to cash in on Patrick's approaching first autumn as a professional, seems plaintive as much as crass: ''Three times at the Capital Centre!''

title: LIMITS ON DRINKING AT GAMES DEBATED IN ALBANY
description: The introduction of a bill in the Legislature to restrict the drinking of alcohol at stadiums and arenas has set off an emotional debate throughout the state, particularly between fans and stadium operators.

title: Strong Candidate
description: Bernie Bickerstaff, a Washington Bullet assistant, says he may be in line to take over the Seattle SuperSonics.

title:
GARDENING;

BEFORE YOU SPRAY, DO SOME HOMEWORK
description: THERE is an astonishing amount of variation in the regulations governing the use of pesticides, from one part of the country to another.

title: Spy Investigation: The Plot Widens
description: Whenever it bags a spy, the Justice Department tends to talk about its prowess in counterintelligence. But in the case of the Walker family, accused of selling Navy secrets to the Soviet Union, the Government's investigation may have begun only after the prime suspect's former wife turned him in.

title: LOCAL TV NEWS IS MAKING A COMEBACK
description: A YEAR ago, when Newsday dropped its cable-television news show, the prospects for Long Island television news seemed bleak. But now local television news is making a strong comeback.

title: MIDDLE-INCOME OPTION
description: No one shopping for a home in New York City needs to be told that it is not easy to find anything newly built that is affordable to a family with an income below $50,000 a year. But such houses have begun to appear in various locations through the sponsorship of the New York City Partnership, a nonprofit organization of business and civic leaders.

title: Sports Promoter Sentenced For Fraudulent Tax Scheme
description: A sports promoter has been sentenced to four years in prison and fined $5,000 for involving a former coach for the Philadelphia Flyers hockey team and two players on the Philadelphia Eagles football team in a fraudulent tax shelter, , according to a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service.

title: 2 TAIWANESE JOURNALISTS SAID TO CONDUCT JAIL HUNGER STRIKES
description: Two imprisoned Taiwanese journalists have been on hunger strikes since April and plan to ingest nothing but small amounts of liquid until the Government releases its political prisoners, according to a New York-based press group.

title: BALLOON DIPLOMACY IS HEADED FOR POLAND
description: THE tensions between the United States and Poland are great, but Harvey Hubbel of Newtown thinks he can ease the strain, from the basket of a hot-air balloon.

title: GIGI ROONEY, L. J. WEIL JR. ARE MARIED
description: Jean Clare Rooney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis C. Rooney Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Leon Jerome Weil Jr., the son of Ambassador and Mrs. Weil of New York and Katmandu, Nepal. Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan, assisted by the Rev. Mark Connelly, performed the ceremony at St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church.

title: YANKEE PRODUCTS ON THE LONDON STAGE
description: Its critics often accuse the New York theater of being abjectly reliant on imports from London. What they don't always recognize is that the traffic across the Atlantic is by no means one-way. In which city can you currently find Charlton Heston in ''The Caine Mutiny Court Martial'' and Constance Cummings in ''The Glass Menagerie,'' along with ''42nd Street,'' ''On Your Toes,'' ''Little Shop of Horrors'' and several other more or less American musicals? In which city, had you traveled there a week ago, could you have seen Jack Gilford in canary waistcoat and red bow tie, paying peppy tribute to the laid-back lyrics of the late Yip Harburg? In which city is the public currently scrambling for tickets for a major revival of ''Guys and Dolls,'' and another of Tennessee Wiliams's ''Sweet Bird of Youth,'' with Lauren Bacall in the lead? The answer is London, not New York.

title: HAMLET AT THE OFFICE
description: IT'S spring, and that means that Long Island's newest crop of college graduates is about to hit the job market - bright-eyed, rosy-cheeked and determined to make a mark in the world.

title: PAIGE D. WILLIAMS MARRIED TO ROBERT CHARLES HEBERT
description: The Congregational Church of New Canaan, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Paige Deacon Williams and Robert Charles Hebert.

title: SHORTWAVE RADIOS THAT PUT THE WORLD IN YOUR HANDS
