description: Schools's out and the dollar is high - a combination that sends a sizable segment of the American population swarming over the globe from Perth to Pilsen and from Ischl to Ise, with stops in between. Along the way, travelers often find themselves far from the nearest newsstand that carries newspapers in English; and even if they manage to make out what it says in the local press, the only news of the United States may be a bit of Hollywood gossip at the bottom of an inside page. Those who regard home as the navel of the world have been known to develop a sort of psychic vertigo under such circumstances. One remedy is to keep in touch with America by shortwave.

title: CONDOS PLUS
description: Until it was sold in 1981, Barton's Candy Company, one of the largest manufacturers of kosher chocolates, operated from two neighboring buildings on DeKalb Avenue in Brooklyn. Vacant since then, both structures are being now being recycled.

title: BIG SPRING RUNOFF, NEW WATER BATTLE
description: A twice-normal spring runoff in the Rio Grande has conservationists afraid that bald eagle roosts and pre-Columbian Indian ruins will be flooded in order to store water for Texas and New Mexico irrigators.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The so-called ''round pound'' seems to be gaining strength. The British Royal Mint recently introduced a third variant of this small, thick one-pound coin and mint officials report that public acceptance is showing steady improvement.

title: Civil Convictions In Greensboro
description: After two criminal trials, state and Federal prosecutors had failed to obtain convictions against any of those who participated in the killing of five members of the Communist Workers Party in Greensboro, N.C., in 1979. Last week, in a judgment in a civil suit, those who were injured and the families of those who died when Ku Klux Klansmen and members of the American Nazi Party attacked a Communist rally accomplished part of what the prosecutors had not.

title: JAIL REVIEW
description: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke voiced satisfaction last week that ''reasonable action'' had been taken by the county's Commissioner of Correction to prevent future jail breaks at the County Jail in Valhalla.

title: CREME FRAICHE GIVES STEPHENS 4TH BELMONT IN ROW
description: Woody Stephens, who had trained three consecutive winners of the Belmont Stakes, outdid himself yesterday by sending out the entry of Creme Fraiche and Stephan's Odyssey to run 1, 2, half-a-length apart in that order, in the 117th Belmont.

title: SOCIAL LEGISLATION ADVANCES IN TEXAS
description: The Texas Legislature has concluded what many lawmakers consider one of its most extraordinary sessions in years.

title: VAN CLIBURN REFLECTS ON THE PAST AND A POSSIBLE FUTURE
description: After nearly 30 years, the memory has not faded: the curly-haired young pianist who seemed to be all elbows, wrists and neck and who dazzled Russian audiences at the 1958 Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow returned home to a ticker-tape parade. Van Cliburn's victory was a political event as much as a musical one, and over the next two decades, millions would turn out to gape at the boy wonder who had beat the Russians on their own ground and proved that cultural exchange was not a one-way street.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

CHILDREN HAVE A RIGHT TO LIVE DRUG FREE
description: THE Westchester Children's Association has been concerned with the problems of chemically involved and chemically dependent young people for many years. It has sponsored several countywide conferences, financed programs in critical areas in the county and helped to establish parent support groups in many towns. Recently, the association consolidated its thoughts, drew on its experience and issued a position statement on the ''Use of Alcohol and Other Drugs.''

title: NEW GROUP TO AID FEMALE CANDIDATES
description: A COMMITTEE has been formed to offer financial help to female candidates for state office who support economic, political, educational and social parity issues of concern to women.

title: SUSAN E. TROEGER BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Susan Elaine Troeger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis R. Troeger of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Jeffrey Fulcher Thompson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Webb Thompson of New Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Roland M. Jones performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: RIGHTS VS. GOALS
description: A MATTER OF PRINCIPLE By Ronald Dworkin. 425 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $25.

title: NEW CASSETTES: OFFBEAT HITCHOCK, TV'S BELLAMYS
description: The Best of 'Upstairs, Downstairs' Vols. I and II, starring Gordon Jackson, Angela Baddeley, Jean Marsh; John Hawkesworth, executive producer Thorn EMI Video 50 minutes each. $29.85 each Of all the quality mini-series to come out of British television, none generated a more loyal and enthusiastic following than the toney soap opera entitled ''Upstairs, Downstairs.'' Beginning in 1903, in the well-appointed and rather aristocratic Bellamy household, the programs explored the separate but symbiotic worlds of masters and servants with a clear eye for telling detail and a sure nose for splendid little melodramas. It may come as a bit of shock to realize that the programs got underway - at London Weekend TV, not the BBC - way back in 1971. But fans will be delighted to discover that they wear marvelously well.

title: OFFICE POWER RARE FOR WOMEN
description: AT a time when women across the country are assuming power in business, they are still few and far between in the boardrooms of Long Island corporations. In fact, there are so few women prominent in the upper echelons of the large companies on the Island that analysts say they have no statistics; women seldom register as even an asterisk in business surveys.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: AT THE age of 25, Douglas R. Heir of Cherry Hill is a proven champion at overcoming adversity.

title: A Blow to the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: AT THE ARBORETUM

title: AFTERMATH OF A DISPUTE
description: Whatever general issues are raised by the bitter dispute through which Lincoln Kirstein has recently reaffirmed his authority as president of the School of American Ballet, a new problem now stands to affect the school and the company with which it is affiliated, the New York City Ballet.

title: Power Shortage?
description: To the Editor:

title: And Another Gives Up
description: Donald J. Devine, up for a second four-year term as head of the Office of Personnel Management, had an even rougher time. ''I can count the votes, and I don't believe I can be confirmed by this committee,'' he told the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee Thursday morning.

title: Congress Plays Its Own Cards On South Africa
description: It might be impossible to prove cause and effect, but the thousands of people who have been demonstrating against South Africa's racial practices could at least claim a connection between objectives and outcome last week. In the House and in the Senate Foreign Relations Committees, large bipartisan majorities voted for penalties against South Africa.

title: S.R.O. Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Poisoning Feared In 15 Cases in Illinois
description: Fifteen people were treated for apparent food poisoning in a suburban hospital, and a restaurant where they had bought food has been closed by the owner, the authorities said.

title: LOW MARKS FOR EXECUTIVE HONESTY
description: FOR years, capitalists themselves have been trusted far less than the free enterprise system they run, but much of the public's distrust was based on the principle of caveat emptor. Today, the distrust of business executives goes far deeper. The consensus is that most corporate executives are not honest, that white collar crime is frequent, that most such criminals get away with their crimes and that even those who are convicted receive lenient punishment.

title: LLOYD SCORES UPSET OVER NAVRATILOVA
description: Chris Evert Lloyd had not beaten Martina Navratilova in a Grand Slam tennis tournament since 1982, but she got some compensation by defeating her keenest rival in the French Open final today, 6-3, 6-7, 7-5.

title: U.S. CAPITAL GAINING REPUTATION AS ITS ILLICIT DRUG CAPITAL AS WELL
description: The purest, strongest heroin in the country is available to the 15,000 addicts of this city, where the nation's top law-enforcement officials work to combat drug trafficking around the world, The strong heroin is killing more people than ever: Nine died over one weekend in March and three died one night in May. Street sales are growing despite a police crackdown. Washington officials are concerned that the city is getting an image as the heroin capital of the world.

title: A Garageful of Greed
description: KELVERTON WANT-ed to accuse me of greed. I could see that, and it angered me that he was holding back.

title: G.M. DIVERSIFIES WITH HUGHES DEAL
description: G.M.'s acquisition of Hughes Aircraft for more than $5 billion helps the auto maker diversify, while giving it access to technology that it can use in its core car and truck business. The deal also lets G.M. put to good use some of the excess cash from its recent record earnings. The proceeds from the sale of Hughes Aircraft, the largest deal outside the oil industry, will make the Hughes Medical Institute the largest private philanthropy. Ford and Boeing, the losing bidders, are likely to seek other high-technology partners: Ford is reported to be looking at Sperry.

title: HEALTH CHIEF EASES STAND ON DOCTORS' INVESTMENTS
description: THE state's Commissioner of Health has unexpectedly withdrawn a proposal to set rigid ethical standards for doctors who invest in profit-making ventures related to their practices.

title:
ART;

MIXING MEDIA AT ISLIP SHOW
description: IN spite of occasional grumbling about the time, effort and expense involved in entering juried competitions, artists seem to be responding in ever larger numbers to these opportunities on Long Island. The current show at the Islip Art Museum attracted nearly 500 entries, of which 91 were selected by a jury of three: Claudia Gould, program coordinator of Public School 1 in Long Island City; Nancy Princethal, an associate curator at the Whitney Museum, and Amei Wallach, a Newsday cultural columnist and art critic.

title: Ban Is Upheld on L.I. Flights
description: A Federal judge here has upheld the Town of Islip's temporary ban on New York Air flights to Boston and Orlando, Fla., from Long Island-MacArthur Airport in Islip. Officials of the town, which owns the airport, sought to block new commercial flights while they complete a study of ways to lessen noise from the jets.

title: WORTH THE WORK
description: FROM now until fall, those who relish the flesh of the Atlantic blue crab will be prowling bays and sounds, tidal rivers and salt ponds in quest of their prey.

title:
RECORDINGS;

RAVEL'S SONGS ARE INTERPRETED BYU SIX VOCALISTS
description: Economy of expression is a much acclaimed virtue in French music. Consider the case of Maurice Ravel, an exquisite craftsman, a master of small forms and a stranger to prolixity. He wrote art songs from his early youth until his untimely death in 1937, yet his total output in 44 years does not average out to more than one song per year. What a natural recording project: Ravel's entire song oeuvre in one easily accessible volume -a mere trifle in this age when record companies bravely undertake all the Haydn symphonies, all the Bach cantatas and everything by Brahms. And yet, even the Ravel centenary in 1975 failed to produce such an anthology. Now, however, it has finally come about, accomplished by BMI's Paris branch after more than two years of recording activity.

title: MISS TAYLOR IS MARRIED TO J. M. FLUMERFELT JR.
description: The marriage of Margaret Creighton Taylor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Huntington Taylor of Westfield, N.J., to John Molyneux Flumerfelt Jr., the son of Dr. Flumerfelt of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and the late Mary Hamm Flumerfelt, took place yesterday. The Rev. Michael Lee Barlowe performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Westfield.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THERE is little doubt that modern communications has made our water-girt home a tight little island, indeed. Long Island folk get the word from television stations, from radio stations that inundate us with not only words but music, and from CB radios, perhaps not as pervasive as they were several years ago but still spreading the word about the police car lurking around the next bend on the expressway, or the tie-up, as permanent and as floating as a blood clot, that is blocking the Southern State.

title: 'PRIZZI'S HONOR' TAKES A COMIC VIEW OF DEADLY LOVERS
description: Early last year John Huston discovered a copy of Richard Condon's novel ''Prizzi's Honor'' in his office, where it had been sitting since its publication in 1982. Luckily, the book jacket mentioned that Mr. Condon lived in Dallas, and the author had a listed telephone number there. Mr. Huston and the producer John Foreman called him and learned that the film rights remained unsold. Mr. Huston then showed the book to Jack Nicholson, who saw it as ''a French New Wave archetypical love picture between two killers -you know, deadly but lovely.''

title: DIGGERS CONFIDENT OF FINDING 28 CUSTER TROOPS
description: After 109 years, archeologists say they believe they know where to find the remains of 28 soldiers who died with Lieut. Col. George Armstrong Custer in the Battle of the Little Bighorn.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SUNDAY, JUNE 9, 1985

title: EFFECTS OF TAX PLAN
description: SIX tax proposals by President Reagan, if passed, could change how money is raised for commercial projects, who develops them and how profits are taxed:

title: RITUALS
description: WOULD YOU LIKE THIS opened now?'' the waitress asked about our wine.

title: GROUP WARNING OF INDOOR AIR
description: HAVING implemented a means of accurately measuring exposure to indoor air pollution, scientists and engineers will begin next week to promote a greater awareness of its health dangers.

title: 4 Killed in Philippine Battle
description: Three militiamen and an attacker were killed when about 100 Moslem guerrillas raided a village in the southern Philippines on Thursday, the military said today. A spokesman said a three-hour gun battle followed the raid in Balo Mabaw on Olutanga Island, about 50 miles southwest of here.

title: TO CUT MILITARY SPENDING
description: The momentum of the Reagan Administration's military buildup finally has been slowed. Congress has made clear that the once sacrosanct defense budget must bear a portion of the deficit-cutting burden. With the overall spending level chosen, the crucial process of deciding what and where to cut begins. How these reductions are made will affect the shape and direction of national security policy for the rest of this century.

title: ARE THE WHITNEY'S SATELLITE MUSEUMS ON THE RIGHT COURSE?
description: Moving onward and - it is hoped - upward with the visual arts, the ambitious Whitney Museum has recently revealed expansion plans on more than one front. It will build a $37.5-million extension to its main facility on Madison Avenue; and it will colonize yet another corporate lobby - the new headquarters of the Equitable Life Assurance Society going up on Seventh Avenue at 52d Street - with a satellite museum. What's more, early in 1986, its Downtown branch - established 12 years ago in part as a project to help develop young curatorial talent -- will relocate in a new office building on Maiden Lane, seat of the Park Tower Realty Corporation, a New York-based developer.

title: Philadelphia's Baby Gorilla
description: Officials of the Philadelphia Zoo are celebrating the birth of a one-foot-long, three-pound gorilla born last week to Snickers and John, 17-year-old African lowland gorillas. ''We are delighted and tickled by this birth since the captive population of these animals, though increasing, is not yet secure,'' said Dietrich Schaaf, curator of mammals at the nation's oldest zoo.

title: SAILING SOUTH TO THE LAND OF THE PENGUIN
description: As our ship rolled and pitched in the frigid waters south of Cape Horn, I wondered what had lured me some 8,000 miles from home to a heaving sea at the bottom of the world. Then a companion called out ''black-browed albatross,'' and I remembered. Instantly, I focused my binoculars on the snowy white bird, with its seven-foot wingspread. Its dark, striking brow seemed to twist into a frown, as if the creature were puzzled to see several pairs of human eyes following its drifting, gliding movements.

title: Cape Cod Rangers Look for Modesty
description: ONCE again, naked drama seems to be in prospect for the Cape Cod National Seashore, where, a spokesman says, rangers will insist this summer that bathers be properly if not nattily attired.

title: MISS KAPOTES MARRIED TO DR. ALI HOMAYUNI
description: Alexandra Kapotes, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles N. Kapotes of Manhasset Hills and Southold, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Ali Reza Homayuni, a son of Mrs. Khosro Homayuni and the late Dr. Homayuni of Lake Success, L.I. The Rev. Nicholas Magoulias performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Greek Orthodox Church in Hempstead, L.I. He was assisted by the Rev. Christopher Metropulos.

title: HERNANDEZ: CONSUMMATE PRO WITH THE INTENSITY OF AN ARTIST
description: THE STREET crackled from the heat of cars stuck in traffic. A fire hydrant was open. Teen-agers stalked the cars with their cleaning sticks. The street was packed, and in Rusty's van the ballplayers talked about other ballplayers.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HOLD THE DREAM. By Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Readers who made ''A Woman of Substance'' a giant best seller will set off an epidemic of deja vu if they buy this bloated sequel to the saga of Emma Harte, the Yorkshire lass who overcame Edwardian sculleryhood and scandal to emerge as one of the world's richest women and the mother of five supporting characters.

title: R. K. BIGGERS JR. AND SISSY CARGILL EXCHANGE VOWS
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Martha Lyons Cargill, a daughter of William S. Cargill of Marbella, Spain, and Mrs. Harris E. Russell of Southport, to Reeve Kelsey Biggers Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Biggers of Redding, Conn. The Rev. Jennings Matheson performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Robert L. Ficks 3d.

title: Political Action Units Reported to Quadruple
description: The number of political action committees donating money to candidates for office in New York quadrupled to 325 between 1978 and 1984, a civic group has reported.

title: Nature and Law
description: THE way the Village Court of Kenmore in upstate New York saw it, Stephen Kenney was growing noxious weeds in front of the house that he and his wife, Emelie, were renting.

title: ON THE WATERFRONT, GOOD SEAFOOD
description: IN response to the common complaint about the scarcity of fine seafood restaurants in a seaside region like the Hamptons, there is now the Coast Grill in the Noyack-North Sea section of Southampton Town. One of the dining rooms overlooks the docks of the Peconic Marina and Wooley Pond.

title: DANCE: TO STRAVINSKY
description: ON the face of it, it was just an ordinary night with the New York City Ballet on Wednesday, and yet the evening was magical. The company has been dancing with tremendous spirit and style, and that heightened vitality was at work in performances of Balanchine's ''Stravinsky Violin Concerto'' and ''Divertimento From 'Le Baiser de la Fee.' ''

title: The Sailboat Addiction
description: I have been surrounded by sailing all my life (''The Sailboat Addiction,'' by Terence Smith, About Men, May 5). I'm a sailor, my husband is an addicted sailor and my father is a sailor and sailmaker.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN CORPORATE ALUMNI GROUPS;

TIME -- PART OF THE CORPORATE CULTURE
description: RALPH P. DAVIDSON, chairman of Time Inc., was having lunch with a British businessman in London when he mentioned he would be returning to New York the next day to address the Time-Life Alumni Society. His dining companion was astonished.

title: Real Estate Inequity
description: To the Editor:

title: EMILY M. BATESON AND T. C. COOPER ARE WED ON L.I.
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., Emily Moffat Bateson, a daughter of Mrs. Adams H. Nickerson of New York and Cold Spring Harbor and the late E. Farrar Bateson, was married yesterday to Thomas Curtin Cooper, a son of Malcolm E. Cooper and the late Marion Curtin Cooper of Dorset, Vt. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony.

title: SHOES FOR EVERY SPORT
description: GIVEN THIS AGE OF SPECIAL-ization, it is not surprising that plain old-fashioned sneakers are more often seen at discos than at athletic events. Sports shoes are now technologically engineered to encourage proper movement, to improve performance and, perhaps most importantly, to deter injury.

title: CAROLE M. SONNENFELD WED TO T. F. GEITHNER
description: Carole Marie Sonnenfeld and Timothy Franz Geithner, 1983 graduates of Dartmouth College, were married yesterday at his parents' summer home in East Orleans, Mass. The Rev. Thomas Keehn, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated.

title: UKRAINIAN RESURGENCE IN EAST VILLAGE
description: When the Ukrainian National Home was destroyed by fire last fall, some feared it would be a major setback for one of the most cohesive ethnic communities of New York.

title: THE BAPTIST SCHISM
description: PASTOR GEORGE H. Gaston came home to Houston from the annual meeting of the Southern Baptist Convention last summer feeling that his congregation had been slapped in the face. At the meeting, a resolution had been passed condemning the ordination of women as deacons and ministers, basing its action on passages in the Bible. Several years before the convocation, and after prayer and consulting the Scripture, Willow Meadows Baptist Church had ordained three women deacons and one woman chaplain in the traditional Baptist way, by a vote of the congregation.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: FANCIFUL HISTORY Something a little old and different will be on stage at the Palace Theater in Stamford today when ''Americana'' is presented at 3 P.M. Billed as an allegorical opera, it has been revamped from an 18th-century masque performed in the South in 1798.

title: COGENERATION CAN CUT ENERGY COSTS
description: MOST Americans may believe that the energy crisis is over. The fact is, however, that New Jersey is still in the midst of a very real energy crisis - a crisis of price - for the state's energy is among the costliest in the nation.

title: RESETTING SHOREHAM'S CIRCUIT BREAKER
description: A nuclear power plant is a complicated device, full of wires and pipes and radioactive rods of nuclear fuel. But nothing on the inside of the Shoreham nuclear plant could be more complicated or generate more heat than what has been going on outside the plant in recent days.

title: DINAH L. BUECHNER WEDS A. G. VISCHER
description: The marriage of Dinah Louise Buechner, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Frederick Buechner of Rupert, Vt., and Anthony Guy Vischer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony P. Vischer of Basel, Switzerland, took place yesterday at the First Congregational Church of Manchester, Vt. The Rev. Jerome Hevey performed the ceremony.

title: KATE K. JOHNSON BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Kate Knapp Johnson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Broaddus Johnson Jr. of Bedford, N.Y., was married yesterday to the Rev. Douglas Stephen Phillips, a son of Gail W. Phillips of Van Nuys, Calif., and Jeanne Phillips of Sunbury, Pa. The Rev. Jack Silvey Miller performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Mount Kisco, N.Y., where the bridegroom is the associate minister.

title: Franey, Trautmann Win 2 Events Each
description: Kathy Franey and John Trautmann capped sparkling outdoor seasons today with double victories at the New York State high school track and field championships here.

title: WEINBERGER TO SEEK A 3% RISE IN BUDGET FOR 1987
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger says he will seek at least a 3 percent increase in the military budget for the fiscal year 1987 on top of an increase to make up for inflation. That budget is now being fashioned in the Pentagon.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

DESIGNATED DRIVER
description: In a decade of designer labels, the latest status symbol just might be a little white and red button reading D.D. The letters stand for Designated Driver, and on June 20 about 50 restaurant and bar owners will be meeting with County Executive O'Rourke and the Commissioner of Public Safety, Anthony M. Mosca, and others to find out how they may become part of Westchester's County Designated Driver Program.

title:
DINING OUT;

ATLANTIC CITY'S ITALIAN-STYLE SECRET
description: ATLANTIC CITY is a study in contrasts.

title: TENNIS PLAYERS SHARE FRUSTRATIONS
description: LEWIS, a 16-year-old tournament tennis player from the north Bronx, complained for years about getting nervous before important meets and acting ''stupid'' on the court.

title: THE CABLE MAKERS' LOSING BATTLE
description: THE soaring arches of the Brooklyn Bridge represent Frederick A. Paulson's brightest hopes for the future. But they also serve as painful reminders of how far his industry has slipped since its robust past.

title: CASE ON RESIDENCY AND SCHOOLS HALTED
description: A STATE judge Wednesday dismissed first-degree larceny charges against four Hartford region parents accused of illegally sending their children to Bloomfield public schools.

title: TERRENCE G. O'CONNOR IS WED TO MISS POITRAS
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in Manhattan yesterday Catherine A. Poitras, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Poitras of Fresno, Calif., was married to Terrence Gregory O'Connor, a son of Diane H. O'Connor and the late Terrence Edward O'Connor of Basking Ridge, N.J. The Rev. William Guido performed the ceremony.

title: Argentina Is Reported Close to I.M.F. Accord
description: Argentina has virtually completed negotiations with the International Monetary Fund on a new loan program to replace the one suspended by the fund in February, a source close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: CALENDARS
description: Horse Shows Today - Avon Lions Club, Avon, N.Y. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (716) 226-8425. Today - Greenwich, Greenwich, Conn. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (203) 438-6175. Today - Stony Brook, Stony Brook, L.I. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (516) 725-1953. Today - Underwood Hospital, Woodbury, N.J. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (609) 235-5623.

title: THE BALLET: BUJONES AND HARVEY IN 'DON QUIXOTE'
description: FERNANDO BUJONES and Cynthia Harvey led American Ballet Theater's version of ''Don Quixote'' Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House with gusto and flourish. Merrymaking is what Mikhail Baryshnikov's staging of this Russian staple is all about.

title: REPORT WARNS OF THREATS TO NATION'S PARKS
description: The National Park system is ill equipped to cope with the human development now gnawing at park borders or with the decay of the parks' natural and cultural resources, according to a report issued today by the Conservation Foundation.

title: RICHARD BAKER MARRIES HEATHER ANN BALDWIN
description: At St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Scarborough, N.Y., yesterday Heather Ann Baldwin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Baldwin of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married to Stuart Richard Baker, a son of Elisabeth Koch-Baker, also of Briarcliff Manor, and Stuart D. Baker of New York and Water Mill, L.I. The Rev. Paul F. M. Zahl performed the ceremony.

title: MIKHAIL TAL BLUNDERS TO VICTORY
description: In recent years, Mikhail Tal of the Soviet Union has developed a penchant for giving lesser opponents chances for spectacular victories over him, but the 48-year-old former world champion has become a genius at surviving.

title: Not at Your Service
description: New York City hotel workers were on strike last week for the first time in more than 50 years, leaving guests in many cases to haul their own bags, empty their own trash cans and serve their own meals. The Hotel and Motel Trades Council, which represents 25,000 bellhops, clerks, housekeepers, bartenders and other workers, struck 55 hotels and said workers had been locked out of 2 others.

title: Wall St. Rescue
description: THE Federal Hall National Memorial on Wall Street, built in 1842 on the site where George Washington was sworn in as President and the Bill of Rights was passed by Congress, has been called the Parthenon of New York by admirers. But by and large the columnar building has been a forlorn monument, grimy and overshadowed by skyscrapers, the Stock Exchange and the excitement of the nation's leading financial district.

title: LABOR CHIEF LOOKS BACK ON LIFE'S WORK
description: JOHN J. DRISCOLL, the state's top labor leader for the past 24 years, said he wanted to set things straight about why he is retiring next September.

title: TOP LACROSSE CLUB VIES FOR U.S. TITLE
description: THIS afternoon, in Baltimore, a group of Long Island lacrosse players will find out if they have the best club in the country.

title: FLYING EYE CLINIC HELPS THE CHINESE
description: More than 200 of northern China's most skillful eye specialists watched closely recently at the Peking airport as a Manhattan doctor performed a cornea transplant, an operation rarely done in China, using a cornea donated by a Houston man.

title: Votes in Congress;   Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BRETT: From Bloomsbury to New Mexico. By Sean Hignett. (Franklin Watts, $22.95.) Dorothy Brett (1883-1977) is probably best known as a minor figure in the Bloomsbury circle, but she comes into her own in this fascinating biography, which reads at times like a Barbara Pym novel (although perhaps more farcical).

title: AMY DENNIS, BANKER, WEDS BRET E. RUSSELL
description: Amy Marie Dennis, the daughter of Richard Paul Dennis of Chicago and the late Mrs. Dennis, was married yesterday to Bret Evan Russell, the son of Mark Evan Russell of La Jolla, Calif., and the late Mrs. Russell. The Rev. Peter Jacobs, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Snuff Mill at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

BRONCK'S HOUSE
description: It is only a warehouse on 132d Street near Lincoln Avenue in the Bronx, but to 28-year-old Brian G. Andersson of Yonkers it is home.

title: RUSSIAN POETS, BETWEEN THE LINES
description: The Soviet Union is apparently on a cultural offensive. For the first time since Mikhail S. Gorbachev's assumption of power, major Soviet culture heroes have arrived in the United States: the poets Yevgeny Yevtushenko and Andrei Voznesensky. Mr. Yevtushenko is possibly the world's most famous living poet; Mr. Voznesensky is widely considered to be the greatest living poet of the Russian language. In the Soviet Union, both recite their verse to audiences of thousands.

title: THE CHOICE
description: I was disappointed that the article on women in the military overlooked our United States Coast Guard Academy, in New London, Conn., where women have been matriculating since 1976 and have been serving as officers in the only one of our military services that does not restrict their activities because of possible combat roles.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: OTHERWISE ENGAGED: The Private Lives of Successful Career Women. By Srully Blotnick (Facts on File, $17.95.) For the last 27 years, Srully Blotnick, a research psychologist and the author of ''The Corporate Steeplechase'' and other books, has followed the lives of some 3,000 American women who are well above average in terms of income, education and professional achievement.

title: Much Heat, Little Light on Rents
description: For New York City's landlords and tenants, the rites of spring are performed before the Rent Guidelines Board. At two rowdy public hearings last week, the groups renewed their annual battle over whether and by how much rents on rent-stabilized apartments should be increased.

title: New Federalism Is a Victim of Reagan Tax Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: BANKS TRIPLE JUMP IS 2D BEST IN HISTORY
description: Willie Banks is America's most celebrated triple jumper ever - an American record-holder, two-time Olympian, three-time national champion, world ranked since 1975 and perennial cheerleader for his event. But he says he is not receiving the respect he should, and today he did something about it.

title: IMPACT ON AREA ALREADY FELT
description: IMPLEMENTING the $9 billion air-traffic control modernization program at the Federal Aviation Administration's Technical Center here is expected to yield not only jobs for South Jersey, but also new educational opportunities, and legislators and schools are already seeking to become involved.

title: A COOK'S NOTEBOOK ON DINING IN DELHI
description: When I first arrived in New Delhi about 15 years ago the first restaurant I visited was the Moti Mahal. I noted then that it was one of the most intriguing restaurants in town (or anywhere in the world, I added), a place where ''guests may go into the primitive kitchen and watch the foods being cooked.''

title: Social Events;   Indoors and Out
description: Because the New York hotel strike was continuing when this column was prepared, those interested in events scheduled for hotels should check with the sponsoring organization to see if changes have been made. Partying at the Pierre June 10 - The Helen Keller Services for the Blind provides training, counseling and rehabilitation for the blind throughout the New York metropolitan area, including a summer camp for children and a comprehensive Braille library. The Manhattan League is a voluntary group that raises money for Services for the Blind through benefits, including its 10th Annual Iris Ball, scheduled for the Pierre starting with cocktails at 7 P.M. followed by dinner and dancing. Tickets for the black-tie event, $175 from 718-522-2122. Rollicking at Roseland June 10 - World Hunger Year was established 10 years ago to inform Americans about the scope, causes and remedies of hunger. An anniversary celebration will be held from 8 P.M. to 1 A.M. at the Roseland Ballroom, 239 West 52d Street, with Count Basie supplying the music. The actor Roy Scheider is scheduled to give a brief talk. Snacks are available at the cash bar. Tickets, $50 at the door or from Chargit, 212-944-9300. Academy's Centennial June 10 - The American Academy of Dramatic Arts has been training actors for 100 years, and a dinner-dance celebration with entertainment by many famous graduates is scheduled for the Plaza starting with cocktails at 6:30 P.M. Robert Redford will present a life achievement award to another academy graduate, Jason Robards.

title: My Empire State For a Ladybug
description: ROBERT C. WERTZ, a State Assemblyman from Smithtown, L.I., is trying once again to correct what he says is an oversight. New York, it seems, has a state tree, a state flower, a state bird and even, thanks to Mr. Wertz's efforts, a state animal, the beaver.

title: METS BEATEN 3D TIME IN A ROW
description: The Mets' teamwide batting slump has begun to reach critical proportions. Like the drought in the New York area this spring, the Mets' power shortage is no longer regarded as an aberration.

title: No Headline
description: A Hungarian immigrant has told the Brazilian police that a man who identified himself as the Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele lived with her family in Brazil between 1961 and 1974 and died here in 1979, according to testimony made public today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It shows that a majority of Americans think we're being taken to the cleaners.'' - Mark A. Anderson, a trade analyst for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., on survey of attitudes toward imports. [40:1.]

title: MORE LONG ISLANDERS ACQUIRING HANDGUNS
description: MORE Long Islanders are applying for licenses that will allow them to carry handguns, and the police say most applicants probably will receive them.

title: Job Market In Turmoil
description: For the fourth straight month, the Labor Department reported last week, overall unemployment has been in a steady state, at 7.2 percent. But the stability of the gross figure for May veiled the turbulence in the national labor market detailed in another report, on employment patterns since the 1980-82 recession.

title: THE SOUP-AND-FISH
description: If William Safire really knew his Bertie Wooster, he would not describe formal dinner attire as ''a soup-and-fish,'' but ''the soup-and-fish'' or, better, ''the full soup-and-fish.'' EUGENIE SCHOMER New York City

title: A.T.&T. STILL HAS TOO MUCH CLOUT
description: THE breakup of A.T.&T. is heading down a path that could lead to the remonopolizing of the telecommunications industry. While the Federal Communications Commission has shown in recent actions an awareness of the problems the industry faces, it still needs to take steps to insure that competition will become a reality.

title: GOODBYE TO JOE BOB AND ALL THAT
description: For 30 years Yankee writers have come down to Texas, looked around at its glittery oil-boom cities and pronounced that rough-and-tumble Texas was becoming more like the rest of the United States - a rising tide of accountants and, lately, wine bars and croissants. It was enough to make any real Texan tug on his silver buckle, climb into his pickup and head off to the ranch at 85 miles an hour.

title: ANOTHER WAY OF LOOKING AT THE BRAIN
description: THE YOUNG MAN HAD BEEN DRIVING on a New England road when the car ahead of him stopped short. In the resulting accident, his head was rammed against the windshield. Apparently suffering only minor bruises, he was treated at the emergency room of a nearby hospital and released. But within days he began to hear voices; within months, he had lost his job, been diagnosed as schizophrenic and admitted to a mental hospital. None of the usual antipsychotic drugs seemed to help. When he was transferred to a Boston psychiatric hospital, doctors referred him to Dr. Frank H. Duffy, a neurologist at the Harvard Medical School and Children's Hospital.

title: SHIITE CHIEF SETS TERMS FOR FREEING MILITIAMEN
description: The leader of the Shiite Moslem movement Amal put forward his terms today for freeing 11 militiamen of the South Lebanon Army whose capture Friday led to the reprisal seizure of Finnish soldiers of the United Nations peacekeeping force.

title: DIBIAGGIO REFLECTS ON UCONN
description: LAST week, as he reflected on his tenure as president of the University of Connecticut, Dr. John A. DiBiaggio said that he considered the institution, which he had headed for six years, to be in ''better circumstances now then it has been in some time.''

title: VARIETY SPICES SUMMER DANCE AGENDA
description: VARIETY is the theme of dance activities this summer, with ballet, modern and jazz ensembles offering workshops and concerts from classical to avant-garde in parks, theaters and city squares throughout the state.

title: GHANA'S WOMEN MAINTAIN THEIR CORNER ON THE MARKETPLACE
description: To the market women of this tropical West African country, the sale is everything. Their eyes dart back and forth, scouring the crush of higgledy-piggledy stalls and people for someone who looks willing to spend a little cash. They compete vociferously for attention. Once they attract some interest, they persuade with gilded flattery and hard bargaining.

title: PUSH TOURISM, CASINOS URGED
description: THE director of the state's Divison of Travel and Tourism, Victoria D. Schmidt, is hoping that Atlantic City's casino industry will ''openly support'' a statewide effort to develop tourism.

title: THIS TIME, ETHIOPIANS LEAVE CAMP WILLINGLY
description: For the second time in two months, famine victims have begun an exodus from the relief camp here in the Gondar region of Ethiopia.

title: HOW TO LEARN FROM YOUR EDSELS
description: INNOVATION AND ENTREPRENEURSHIP Practice and Principles. By Peter F. Drucker. 277 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95. CALVIN COOLIDGE exaggerated when he said ''The business of America is business.'' But business is a large part of the business of America. And it is a part about which most of us know little. Most take it for granted as a vending machine that pours out a flow of goods and services whenever we put our quarters in the slot. There is now a vocal minority that regards business as a crusade, conducted by saintly heroes who are carving their way into the Holy Land of economic growth for the benefit of the unappreciative masses. Still another minority looks on the whole business community as a den of thieves.

title: Cauthen Rides Winner Of the Epsom Oaks
description: Three days after his winning ride in the Epsom Derby, Steve Cauthen rode the filly Oh So Sharp to victory today in the Epsom Oaks, the fourth of England's five classic flat-racing events.

title: CO-OP CONVERSIONS QUICKENING NEAR FOR TRYON PARK
description: ENGRAVED in Jacob Haberman's memory is the day in July 1983 that he bought the former St. Elizabeth Hospital, at 689 Fort Washington Avenue in the Fort Tryon Park section of Washington Heights, at auction for $1.7 million.

title: The Backpacking Weekend
description: I enjoyed very much your Home Entertaining issue on the summer weekend (May 5). But you have missed one of the best weekends of all -the backpacking weekend, and the wonderful meals it entails.

title: Q AND A
description: Evictions in a Conversion Question: Can a nonpurchasing tenant be evicted from an apartment in a rent-stabilized building that was recently converted to cooperative ownership in a noneviction plan? . . . L. K. G., Manhattan Answer: Like a tenant in a rental building, a renter in a building converted under a noneviction plan can be evicted for nonpayment of rent, violating the lease or creating a nuisance, according to Martin A. Shlufman, deputy counsel for rent administration in the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. However, a nonpurchasing tenant in a noneviction conversion cannot be evicted merely because the owner wants the apartment for his own use and occupancy or for that of a member of his immediate family. Courts have been split on whether a tenant can be evicted for nonprimary residence in plans accepted for filing after July 20, 1982. Getting a Lease Renewed Question: We had a one-year lease from August 1982 to July 1983 on our rent-stabilized apartment. We have asked several times for a renewal, but the landlord always avoided the issue. How can we get a lease to assure our security? . . . J. F., Manhattan Answer: ''No lease, no increase,'' says Errol Brett, a lawyer who represents tenants, colloquially para-Redinger phrasing the Rent Stabilization Code, which says landlords are entitled to rent increases for a one- or two-year lease renewal. You can file a complaint for failure to offer a lease at the Division of Housing's district rent office at 2 Lafayette Street, N.Y. 10007.

title: Swiss Wins Tour Stage, But Hinault Holds Lead
description: Urs Freuler of Switzerland won the 21st and next-to-last leg of the Tour of Italy cycling race today.

title: Article 038810 -- No Title
description: ON Capitol Hill and in the traveling White House, the issue of Central America generated strong emotions and conflicting opinions last week as Congress and the President struggled for control of United States policy. ''We really do stand at a rather critical juncture in Central American policy today,'' said Representative Lee H. Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who heads the House Intelligence Committee. ''The question is whether we want to fund a war in Central America.''

title: THE CHOICE
description: I served as an officer in the Navy from 1972 to 1975. There are very few of us who served as officers when I did.

title: POWERFUL, MYSTERIOUS FIGURES BY TERENZIO
description: IN the later works of his 1981 retrospective at the William Benton Museum, Anthony Terenzio was concentrating on interiors devoid of figures and painted in rich, if restrained, colors. One or two of these are included in the artist's show on view at the New Britain Museum of American Art through June 30, but otherwise his subject is now figures, standing alone in limbo, and he has reduced his colors to black, white, grays and browns, with occasional touches of blue, green and yellow.

title:
GARDENING;

BEFORE YOU SPRAY, DO SOME HOMEWORK
description: THERE is an astonishing amount of variation in the regulations governing the use of pesticides, from one part of the country to another.

title: THEY CAN THINK, BUT CAN THEY DREAM?
description: THE COGNITIVE COMPUTER On Language, Learning, and Artificial Intelligence. By Roger C. Schank with Peter G. Childers. 268 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley Publishing Company. $17.95. THE KNOWLEDGE MACHINE Artificial Intelligence and the Future of Man. By Donald Michie and Rory Johnston. 300 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $16.95.

title: Mengele Search Leads to a Grave
description: Pursuing a West German tip, the Brazilian police last week uncovered circumstantial evidence, including the remains of a man buried as ''Wolfgang Gerhard'' in Sao Paulo in 1979, which suggested that Josef Mengele, the missing Nazi death camp doctor, may be dead.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Weeks This Last on Week Fiction Week List 1 HOLD THE DREAM, by Barbara Taylor 2 4 Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Continuing the family saga begun in ''A Woman of Substance.'' 2 THE CIDER HOUSE RULES, by John Irving. 4 3 (Morrow, $18.95.) Life in a Maine orphanage earlier in this century. 3 JUBAL SACKETT, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, 1 3 $16.95.) In this forerunner to the 17-volume Sackett saga, a restless explorer scouts the 17th-century American wilderness. 4 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom 3 12 Clancy. (Naval Institute Press, $14.95.) A Lithuanian submarine driver defects to the United States with the Soviet Union's most advanced nuclear secrets. 5 CHAPTERHOUSE: DUNE, by Frank Herbert. 6 8 (Putnam, $17.95.) A new world rises from the Old Empire's ashes in this volume of the ''Dune'' series. 6 IF TOMORROW COMES, by Sidney 5 20 Sheldon. (Morrow, $17.95.) A young woman destroys the crime lords who got her an undeserved prison term. 7 THINNER, by Richard Bachman. 7 15 (NAL Books, $12.95.) In this pseudonymous novel by Stephen King, a lawyer's body mysteriously wastes away. 8 THE CLASS, by Erich Segal. 9 7 (Bantam, $17.95.) What happened to five members of the class of 1958 after they left Harvard Yard. 9 INSIDE, OUTSIDE, by Herman Wouk. 8 12 (Little, Brown, $19.95.) A traditionalist Jew's quest for identity in glittery contemporary America. 10 QUEENIE, by Michael Korda. 11 8 (Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The glamorous career of Dawn Avalon, whose life was not unlike that of the late Merle Oberon. 11 THE LONELY SILVER RAIN, by John D. 12 10 MacDonald. (Knopf, $15.95.) A yacht's disappearance, a debutante's murder and other puzzles Travis McGee must solve to save his life. 12 A CREED FOR THE THIRD MILLENNIUM, 13 5 by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A man and a woman set out to salvage a spiritually exhausted America in the not-too-distant future. 13 FAMILY ALBUM, by Danielle Steel. 10 14 (Delacorte, $16.95.) A married couple with five children cope with the crises of contemporary America. 14 GLITZ, by Elmore Leonard. 14 18 (Arbor House, $14.95.) The escapades, romantic and melodramatic, of a cop who needs a rest after being shot in Miami. 15 PROOF, by Dick Francis. 14 12 (Putnam, $16.95.) A young wine merchant gets caught in a scam involving murder and vengeance. Nonfiction 1 A PASSION FOR EXCELLENCE, 2 5 by Tom Peters and Nancy Austin (Random House, $19.95.) Ways to achieve distinction in management. 2 IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca 1 32 with William Novak. (Bantam, $19.95.) The rise of the automobile executive from immigrants' son to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler. 3 SMART WOMEN, FOOLISH CHOICES, 3 10 by Connell Cowan and Melvyn Kinder. (Clarkson N. Potter, $13.95.) Two clinical psychologists analyze the successes and failures of modern women in looking for acceptable men. 4 MY MOTHER'S KEEPER, by B. D. Hyman. 4 4 (Morrow, $16.95.) A portrait of the actress Bette Davis, by her daughter. 5 LOVING EACH OTHER, by Leo 5 41 Buscaglia. (Slack/Holt, $13.95.) Suggestions for ''setting our priorities right in order to enjoy life to the fullest.'' 6 MOUNTBATTEN, by Philip Ziegler. 15 2 (Knopf, $24.95.) The authorized biography of the British diplomat, naval hero and royal counselor. 7 BREAKING WITH MOSCOW, by Arkady N. 6 15 Shevchenko. (Knopf, $18.95.) The autobiography of the highest-ranking Soviet official ever to defect. 8 CONFESSIONS OF A HOOKER, by Bob Hope 11 4 with Dwayne Netland. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Memories of more than 50 years of golfing, by the comedian. 9 THE SOONG DYNASTY, by Sterling 8 8 Seagrave. (Harper & Row, $22.50.) The tangled lives of Charlie Soong and his six children, who shaped much of China's modern history. 10 ONCE UPON A TIME, by Gloria 7 6 Vanderbilt. (Knopf, $16.95.) Memories of the first 17 years of a ''poor little rich girl.'' 11 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel 11 133 Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse and drawings by the author. 12 THE COURAGE TO CHANGE, by Dennis 9 17 Wholey. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) Conversations with two dozen men and women, many of them celebrities, about their problems with alcoholism. 13 THE BRIDGE ACROSS FOREVER, by 10 40 Richard Bach. (Morrow, $16.95.) The author of ''Jonathan Livingston Seagull'' tells of his search for love. 14 METAMAGICAL THEMAS, by Douglas 3 R. Hofstadter. (Basic Books, $24.95.) Essays on many topics by the author of ''Godel, Escher, Bach.'' 15 THE HEART OF THE DRAGON, by 1 Alasdair Clayre. (Houghton Mifflin, $29.95.) Companion volume to the PBS television series on China.

title: REPORT URGES COLLEGE TUITION AID FOR THOSE JOINING A POLICE CORPS
description: A police corps in which college students receive tuition aid in exchange for a promise to serve for several years on their local police forces would be an effective way to increase police manpower while holding down costs, according to a federally financed study.

title: NAHIDA NAAYEM IS WED
description: The marriage of Nahida Naayem, a daughter of Tatiana Naayem of New York and the late George Naayem, to Dr. Stephen Eskeland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Per Eskeland of Great Kills, S.I., took place yesterday at the Old Westbury (L.I.) Gardens. The Rev. Daniel Mercaldo, senior pastor of the nondenominational Gateway Cathedral in Oakwood, S.I., performed the ceremony.

title: WHO WROTE 'HAMLET'?
description: To the Editor:

title: BLAKE GARDNER IS WED IN WASHINGTON TO DOUGLAS GREGORY COOK, A LAWYER
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square in Washington, Joan Blake Gardner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wendell Gardner of Washington and Southampton, L.I., and Douglas Gregory Cook, the son of Mrs. William Batten of Newport, R.I., and Charles Edward Cook of Providence, R.I., were married yesterday. The Rev. John Harper performed the ceremony.

title: HIGH-PROFILE PROSECUTOR
description: THE WOMAN CANNOT BELIEVE IT: SHE IS IN THE same elevator as Rudolph Giuliani, the Federal prosecutor for Manhattan. ''You're Rudolph Giuliani,'' she says. ''Oh, I can't believe it. You're the one in the papers - with the mob.'' She is staring. ''Oh, this is a thrill.''

title: The Unmaking of a Democrat
description: The political pendulum for a former Massachusetts Governor, Edward J. King, swung last week from Democratic to Republican. The change of allegiance represented no great ideological shift, however.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article and a caption last Sunday about a group of seventh-graders in Manhattan who are designing an experiment for the space shuttle misidentified a City College instructor who is helping them. He is Joseph Grossfield.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of erroneous information supplied by the publisher, a review May 26 of Truong Nhu Tang's ''Vietcong Memoir'' misidentified a co-author. David Chanoff is a freelance writer who has taught in Harvard University's summer school program.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on May 19 about a conference conducted by the NAACP Legal Defense Fund on employment and education among blacks misstated the approximate number and age range of young black males who die each year in homicides. According to statistics provided at the conference, about 2,000 black males between the ages of 10 and 19 are killed each year.

title: Bush on the P.L.O.
description: In his role as a reiterater and underliner of Administration attitudes, Vice President Bush reassured a meeting of influential Israeli educators and American Jewish leaders that the United States has not changed its official policy on the Palestine Liberation Organization. Mr. Bush gave his reassurances in New York on Wednesday at a ceremony marking the establishment of a chair in foreign relations in the Vice President's name at the Bar-Ilan University in Ramat Gan, Israel. Unless the P.L.O. ''recognizes Israel's right to exist,'' he said, ''the United States will neither recognize nor negotiate with the P.L.O.''

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Shoes for Everyone, Plus Modifications Tru-Form Shoes, established in New Rochelle in 1955 as a factory, retail store and executive offices, has a second county store along Central Avenue with a Scarsdale address and six additional stores (Manhattan, two stores in the Bronx, Garden City, L.I. Nanuet, N.Y. and Stamford, Conn.). Major sales are announced to a mailing list twice a year, sometimes with $5-off coupons on purchases of more than $20, and the sale area in each store has footwear at 30 to 50 percent off. The Manhattan shop has five workmen to fill custom-made shoe orders - the only branch to offer this service.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: BALLOONS and children may be a familiar spring item, but on May 24 a new message was hovering in the air at the Glenfield School in Montclair, where 100 helium balloons containing messages of peace written by sixth- , seventh- and eighth-graders celebrated the school's becoming an official Peace Site. (A Peace Site is a place - it might be a school, a church or a community organization - that has dedicated itself to the promotion and study of peace activities).

title: SPOTTING A SIGNAL
description: Ill winds on one continent do not usually blow favorably on another, but they have done so in a bridge context. India recently suffered a severe disappointment when it lost the right to stage the 1985 world team championship. The Indian government would not provide the required guarantee to admit any possible participating country.

title: Ma Bell's Breakup
description: To the Editor:

title: FUND RAISING: NEED GROWS AS GOVERNMENT AID LAGS
description: ''PEOPLE don't give to causes,'' said Howard Katz, director of development at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center. ''People give to people.''

title: WALKER STARTED BAR NEAR CAROLINA NAVY PORT
description: Almost 20 years ago, when John A. Walker Jr. is said to have begun spying for the Soviet Union, he bought a house here and converted it into a small bar that would have been suitable for that purpose.

title: Broadcast TV
description: In the season of rebroadcasts, the game of catching up can have its rewards. One of the more sumptuous is ''The Life of Verdi,'' the six-part series returning to public television's ''Great Performances'' on Friday at 9 P.M. on channels 13 and 49.

title: BACK HOME IN INDIANA
description: The ancient glacier that rolled down the Midwest, flattening the land that eons later became rich farmland and industrial center, stopped on the northern edge of what is now Indiana's Brown County. The county's name is one of the greatest misnomers on the American map. Through all seasons the area is a study in layered hillsides that form wide, multicolored vistas under misty, blue-gray horizons. Natural beauty and simple rural life in such towns as Beanblossom, Gnaw Bone and Nashville are Brown County's constant celebrations.

title: SAN FRANCISCO
description: The roses are in full bloom in Golden Gate Park. Richard Wagner is casting his spell at the Opera House. The Golden Gate Bridge, as usual, is getting a fresh coat of the red-orange paint that seems to blend so beautifully with the colors of sunset. Herb Caen, the popular columnist for The San Francisco Chronicle, is still trying to convince people not to say ''Frisco.'' And on Fisherman's Wharf, the few fishermen who are still there are asking again: Where have the crabs gone?

title: COMEDY FOR THE RADIO
description: ON the sixth floor or a Bridgeport office building, four people are crowded into a small recording studio, listening to a tape for the fifth time.

title: ACADEMY ON BACH COMING TO RUTGERS
description: THE Aston Magna Foundation for Music will come to Rutgers University for the first time next Sunday for a cross-disciplinary academy called ''J. S. Bach and His World.'' It will run through July 6. The academy, under the direction of the harpsichordist-musicologist Raymond Erickson (not to be confused with Raymond Ericson, the former New York Times critic), is the seventh such residential summer academy sponsored by the Massachusetts-based foundation.

title: MIXED USE ON 6TH
description: For decades, that part of the Avenue of the Americas below 42d Street has served almost exclusively as a commercial throughfare inhabited by small office concerns and light manufacturing companies.

title: LEGISLATORS WEIGH PROPOSAL TO MODERNIZE AIRPORT
description: A REPORT that proposes a new passenger terminal, new hangars, a new taxiway and other facilities at the Westchester County Airport appears to be winning substantial support among county legislators.

title: PATRICIA RUBIN TO MARRY DOUGLAS SACKS
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy Rubin of Stamford, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Patricia Ann Rubin to Douglas Lowell Sacks, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Sacks of New Haven and West Brattleboro, Vt.

title: About Men;   Taking It
description: IN 1944, AT THE AGE OF 11, I HAD polio. I spent the next two years of my life in an orthopedic hospital, appropriately called a reconstruction home. By 1946, when I returned to my native Bronx, polio had reconstructed me to the point that I walked very haltingly on steel braces and crutches.

title: LAURA FERGUSSON IS WED
description: The marriage of Laura Hill Fergusson to Robert Johnston Plumb 3d, the son of Mrs. John L. Kelsey of Rumson, N.J., and the late Mr. Plumb Jr., took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. A. Carter Fergusson, in Gladwyne, Pa. The Rev. David B. Watermudler of the Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony.

title: CAROLYN W. DAVIS BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Carolyn Woodbury Davis, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen E. Davis of Glen Ridge, N.J., was married yesterday to Matthew Forbes Erskine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Linwood Mandeville Erskine of Worcester, Mass. The couple exchanged their vows after the manner of the Society of Friends in the Montclair (N.J.) Friends Meeting.

title: A HOME OF GUNS FIT FOR A KING
description: Isolated in seas of computerized mass production there stand in the Western World a few citadels where products are made by hand and whose workers approach their duties with the dedication of medieval craftsmen. Purdey's, the London gunmakers, is one.

title: KATHLEEN VAN HATTEN WED TO KENNETH SCHLINGER
description: Kathleen R. Van Hatten, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Van Hatten of Carmel, Ind., was married yesterday to Kenneth B. Schlinger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Israel Schlinger of Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Steven Klein performed the ceremony at the Davenport Club in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Elisabeth Joy Ronis Is Wed To Philip John Hawthorne
description: Elisabeth Joy Ronis, an independent art consultant, and Philip John Hawthorne, a freelance film maker, were married yesterday.

title: Russians Said to Break Siege by Afghan Rebels
description: A Soviet armored column smashed through the last guerrilla lines and relieved the besieged Afghan border town of Barikot after two weeks of fierce fighting, rebel officials said today.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: AMY'S EYES By Richard Kennedy. Illustrated by Richard Egielski. 437 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $13.50. (Ages 8 and up) EVEN coastal sailors who cruise only in local waters know the feeling, upon letting go the mooring line, that anything might happen. The sea holds in wait for us not only its magnificence and fateful changes of weather but also our own capacity for wonder - for magic and mystery - and vulnerability as well. This is the feeling out of which Richard Kennedy has created ''Amy's Eyes,'' his 17th work for young readers. But the book is not just for the young - this rich, exuberant story wittily draws together several different literary traditions in ways that are pleasing to an adult.

title: ITALIANS SET TO VOTE ON WAGE INDEXING
description: By some accounts, it is little more than a trivial issue, involving something like 50 cents a day for the average worker.

title: NEW CASSETTES: OFFBEAT HITCHOCK, TV'S BELLAMYS
description: Don Quixote (Kitri's Wedding) Mikhail Baryshnikov's production performed by the American Ballet Theater, featuring Mr. Baryshnikov and Cynthia Harvey Thorn EMI Video/HBO 86 minutes. $39.95 This live performance in 1983 from the Metropolitan Opera House, preserved in amber on videotape, also preserves our image of Mr. Baryshnikov's dancing at its peak.

title:
ANTIQUES;

PAPERS AND POSTERS OF BYGONE ERA
description: OFFERED at auction in Wethersfield next Saturday will be Revolutionary War and other 18th-century documents and letters, including many by signers of the Declaration of Independence.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

MISSING CHILDREN: THE SEARCH GOES ON
description: CINDA PALLETT, who is 17 years old, ''arrived'' on Long Island recently.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FOUR WAYS OF COMPUTING MIDNIGHT. By Francis Phelan. (Atheneum, $15.95.) ''Dear Anne Francis,'' begins an anonymous letter at the start of this novel.

title: DANCE: 13 BY SIMONNE
description: TO her credit, Julia Simonne appears to be a ballet choreographer sincerely interested in contemporary music. All 13 works that she choreographed for the program called New Music/New Dance, presented Wednesday night at the Harkness Center for Dance, were to pop and symphonic music of the 20th century.

title: SOVIET RESEARCH SHIP TRAPPED IN ANTARCTIC ICE
description: The Soviet Union has dispatched one of its giant icebreakers to Antarctica to free a research vessel trapped with 53 aboard in thickening and shifting winter ice.

title: Maltbie Ties Burns for Lead In Soggy Westchester Golf
description: Roger Maltbie dropped a five-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole today to gain a tie for the lead with a struggling George Burns after three rounds of the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic golf tournament.

title: RAHAL WINS SECOND LEG
description: Starting from the fourth pole position, Bobby Rahal averaged 84.363 miles per hour today in posting a 2.444-second victory over John Watson in the second leg of the Inernationl Race of Champions.

title: A FRUSTRATED SEAMAN IN CLERICAL GARB
description: He sounds salty enough, this square-jawed cleric with a ruddy, wind-whipped face.

title: FELLINI: MASTER OF AGELESS COMEDY
description: When you think of Federico Fellini, what are the images that first come to your mind?

title: A TROVE OF COLONIAL RICHES
description: A goodly representation of Colonial Williamsburg's major period furnishings - in storage for more than six years and in some instances never exhibited - are among the 8,000 American and English 17th- through 19th-century antiques now on view in its new DeWitt Wallace Decorative Arts Gallery.

title: ENLISTING THE COMPUTER AS AN ARTISTIC AID TO ORCHESTRAS
description: It must be a rare concertgoer who hasn't occasionally wondered how and why orchestral programs are put together. Why that Liszt tone poem and that Mozart concerto? Why that version of that particular Bruckner symphony?

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

FOSTERING HOPE
description: PURA BOUZA does not think she would survive in a nursing home. At 81 years of age, she has silky white hair and tiny bones and skin like tissue paper. She also has a clear idea of what she does and does not want. ''I could not stand a nursing home,'' she said firmly. ''It would be too sad.''

title: 'Snake-Oil Man' at the Belmont
description: AS a morning rain muddied the Belmont track yesterday, a horseplayer said, ''Brennan's gone too far this time, he's even seeding the clouds.'' And when a helicopter hovered down under the dome of gray clouds and landed in the grassy infield, another horseplayer said: ''If his International Thoroughbred Breeders stockholders see him, he's in trouble. His stock is down to my hat size, 6 7/8.''

title: RACHEL SCHACHTER BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Rachel Susan Schachter, a daughter of Drs. Joseph and Judith S. Schachter of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to Jonathan Toll Edelson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Marshall Edelson of New Haven.

title: ISRAEL IS STILL CALCULATING ITS LOSSES FROM INVASTION
description: ISRAEL last week passed the third anniversary of its invasion of Lebanon by not completely withdrawing as planned. While the Israelis largely ignored the anniversary, they could not ignore the chain of events that the Lebanon invasion set in motion. The latest peace initiative by King Hussein of Jordan, the apparent moderation of Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and the rise of the Shiite Moslems in Lebanon were all unintended results of the invasion, and Israel will be wrestling with them for months to come.

title: BIKINIS AND THE NAKED TRUTH
description: CALL it a fad, call it a passing fancy, but the fact is that the bikini is back.

title: FISH TO BE USED TO CONTROL MOSQUITOES IN A TEST IN SUFFOLK
description: A NEW method of mosquito control for Long Island will be tested this summer at the 200-acre Seatuck National Wildlife Refuge on Great South Bay in the Town of Islip.

title: THE FOLGER THEATER IS ALIVE AND CLICKING
description: John Neville-Andrews calls it ''the war of 1985'' and, having weathered the battle, he is planning to expand the activities of the Folger Theater. As its artistic producer, he would like, quite simply, for the Folger ''to become the nation's foremost classical theater,'' the American equivalent of the Royal Shakespeare Company.

title: RETURN TO JAPAN
description: To the Editor: Marylin Bender's marvelous recounting of her return to Japan (''The Second Time Around,'' Travel, May 5) after an absence of 25 years brought back fond memories of a similarly nostalgic trip my wife and I made recently.

title: 23 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY CITY
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 23 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: HOMECOOKING IN A COUNTRY STORE
description: THERE is often a wide chasm in restaurants between elegant dining and fast foods. In Ridgefield, that gap has been filled by several small homestyle restaurants where you can eat homecooked food (or the next best thing) in unpretentious surroundings at fairly modest prices.

title: BEFORE AND AFTER HEART SURGERY
description: BYPASS A Cardiologist Reveals What Every Patient Needs to Know. By Jonathan L. Halperin and Richard Levine. Illustrated. 295 pp. New York: Times Books. $16.95.

title: HENRY BEETLE HOUGH
description: One of the most interesting things about journalism in America is that so many of its memorable characters have been country editors. From Tom Paine to Mark Twain, William Allen White of Kansas and Elmer Davis of Indiana, and the Baltimore crowd from Henry Mencken to Russell Baker, it was, in a funny way, the hicks from the sticks who took over the big-city crowd.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TO BEAR ANY BURDEN: The Vietnam War and Its Aftermath in the Words of Americans and Southeast Asians. By Al Santoli.

title: BAROQUE SPIRIT OF A PLACE AND ITS PEOPLE
description: Within the space of about 10,000 square miles, the island of Sicily offers the possibility of the perfect trip - perfect in that the scenery varies while the driver need travel minimum distances. The same landscape will change, depending upon the time of day and the vagaries of the light. And there may not be any other area in the world where one can confront so much history in such a limited space.

title: JAZZ: COHEN AND JAMES PLAY
description: UNLIKE most jazz groupings of piano and bass, the pianist Mark Cohen and the bassist Stafford James not only think of themselves as a team rather than as a pianist with accompaniment but the predominant voice in the duo is Mr. James's bass.

title: Judaism's Prospects for Survival in Cuba Are Improving
description: To the Editor:

title: VOTERS IN HOBOKEN TO CHOOSE A MAYOR TOMORROW
description: Voters in this Hudson County community will go to the polls on Tuesday, for the second time in a month, to choose a mayor.

title: Rumanians Accused
description: An unusual accusation of sacrilege has been directed against the Government of Rumania by critics who charge that a gift shipment of Bibles was pulped. ''This is a sign of the total contempt for religion that the regime practices,'' said Alexander Havadtoy, who identified himself as pastor of the Calvin United Church of Christ in Fairfield, Conn., adding that he was born in Rumania.

title: ANGELS WIN AND RETAKE LEAD
description: Ron Romanick and Donnie Moore combined on an eight-hitter and Bob Boone singled in a run in the fourth as the California Angels edged the Kansas City Royals, 1-0, and regained first place in the American League West.

title: Team Owners Split On Tax Plan Effect
description: Although many sports executives, including three major-league commissioners, initially predicted a severe impact on teams if President Reagan's proposed tax plan is adopted, other sports executives have more recently expressed optimistic reactions.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is probably the most satisfying championship for me. Celtic pride was in this building, but there was a little Laker pride, too.''

title: Thanks for the Memorial
description: With sentiments as simple -sometimes as moving - as those etched on the monument, people have been thanking New York in the month since the Vietnam Veterans Memorial was dedicated. Some excerpts from their letters:

title: HE'S 'JUST AN ORDINARY GUY'
description: EVERY so often during dinner, Salevaa Atisnoe, his 484 pounds bursting from beneath a blue-and-white kimono with a multicolored sash, would stretch his arms across the leather ledge of the semicircular booth. As a sumo wrestler, 21-year-old Salevaa Atisnoe, known as Konishiki to his Japanese idolaters, had his black hair tied in a topknot. And now, after having turned a platter of fried shrimp into an endangered species, he stretched across the booth again, as if he were a spreading chestnut tree.

title: NEW SPIRITUAL UNITY PRAISED AT HEBREW UNION GRADUATION
description: The chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America praised the growing cooperation between the Reform and Conservative branches of Judaism yesterday and urged new graduates of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion to help extend the ''nascent sense of spiritual oneness of the Jewish people.''

title: Unsoaking the Rich
description: President Reagan wants to give money earned as capital gains even more favorable tax treatment than it already receives. That will stimulate investment, he contends, particularly in new ventures. Maybe so, but it's still a terrible idea no matter how the current flurry about high tax rates for the rich turns out.

title: Quaker Oats Sells Its Agency
description: THE agency competition is over.

title: BARBED WIRE UP AT STONEHENGE IN BATTLE TO PREVENT FESTIVAL
description: The chairman of the National Trust says his group is determined to prevent a pop festival from being held at Stonehenge despite plans for one by members of Britain's counterculture, whose attempts to reach the area recently led to battles with the police.

title: Still Trying to Help
description: David Koch is getting frustrated.

title: RELIVING PERILS OF '61 OPEN
description: I WAS in the clubhouse after the final round of the '61 Open 45 minutes before Gene Littler was. We played the double rounds on Saturday in those days. I was just off the lead at the start of the day, and I shot 69 in the morning to pick up a little ground. I was back in contention going into afternoon.

title: Big Board Union's Head Sees a 'War of Nerves'
description: Back in the 1940's, John Kelly said, he thought seriously about joining the priesthood. ''I didn't have any problem with the vows of poverty and chastity,'' he added in a telephone interview. ''But I couldn't handle the obedience angle.''

title: 4 Plastic Trash Cans Cost the Navy $561
description: Navy officials, already under fire for paying $659 for an ashtray, spent $140.25 apiece for four plastic brown trash cans and $99.50 for a silk plant, a Congressman says.

title: Dr. Katherine Moss Marries in Rochester
description: Dr. Katherine Moss, a psychiatrist, and Dr. Jefferey Lowengrub, a pediatrician, who will both become residents this month at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, were married yesterday at Temple B'rith Kodesh in Rochester. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Robert Eisen, assisted by Rabbi Sheldon Kilimnick and Rabbi Jerome D. Folkman, the bride's grandfather.

title: MORE WOMEN ARE GAMBLING
description: About a third of the nation's 12 million compulsive gamblers are women, according to Arnold Wexler, vice president of the National Council on Compulsive Gambling. Studies published recently indicate that by the year 2000, women may account for half of the Americans with the affliction.

title: 80 CAMP OUT, WAITING FOR CONDOMINIUM OFFER
description: More than 80 people were camped out last night along Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn Heights, some of them since Thursday, waiting for a chance to buy moderately priced condominiums.

title: C.I. Fontes Wed To Lisa Aronson
description: Lisa Shepard Aronson and Carlos Isidoro Fontes were married yesterday at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Shepard Gerard Aronson of Tappan, N.Y., parents of the bride. Rabbi Leonard B. Troupp performed the ceremony.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Over his first two seasons in the major leagues, how does Don Mattingly of the Yankees compare with another left-handed throwing and batting first baseman of considerable ability almost 70 years earlier, George Sisler?

title: LAKERS ERASE THE PAIN
description: Pat Riley did not get much sleep Saturday night. He had too many distractions: the haunting memories and images that everyone who had been a part of the Los Angeles Lakers' organization in the last 26 years had to endure. But, instead of counting sheep, the 40-year-old coach pondered more pleasant thoughts.

title: FAMILY WITH MANY TROUBLES AT CENTER OF ESPIONAGE CASE
description: At the center of what the authorities have called one of the major spy rings in American history is the troubled family of John A. Walker Jr. It was family ties, the Federal Bureau of Investigation says, that helped Mr. Walker obtain some of the classified information he sold to the Soviet Union. And it was family turmoil, punctuated by a divorce nearly a decade ago, that apparently led to his arrest.

title: Fame in Utica
description: Last year Ken Brett appeared in a television commercial for Lite Beer from Miller, and the script was tailor-made for a former pitcher so peripatetic that he had played for 10 teams in a major league career of 14 seasons. The commercial was set in a bar, where a disoriented Brett, trying to figure out which town he was in, offered a couple of mistaken guesses to his drinking partners and then, with a grimace born of some dread, said, ''Utica?''

title: KOREAN CARS SEEK U.S. NICHE
description: With its first foray into the United States car market less than a year away, the Hyundai Motor Company is a company in a hurry, pushing its workers to improve the way they build cars.

title: LANGER AT HOME ON PGA TOUR
description: IN a country where winter sports are important and soccer is supreme when the snow melts, Bernhard Langer was unusual. While his friends went off after school to play soccer, Langer headed to one of the few golf courses in West Germany to learn a sport few of his countrymen cared about.

title: STAGE: REGIONAL WORK OPENS FESTIVAL AT JOYCE
description: THE AMERICAN THEATER EXCHANGE, a summerlong festival of plays culled from the country's more prestigious resident theaters, is potentially one of the season's brighter developments. While regional productions are now routinely imported to Broadway and Off Broadway, New Yorkers see only a small sample of the total out-of-town output - and that sample tends to favor those works presumed to have the widest audience appeal.

title: Carol E. Goulian Becomes a Bride
description: Carol Ellen Goulian, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Levon M. Goulian of New Milford, N.J., was married yesterday to Victor Edwin Stewart, a son of Mrs. Harold C. Palmer of New York and Indian Wells, Calif., and the late George James Stewart. The Rev. Arnak Kasparnian performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Armenian Church in Tenafly, N.J.

title: MIAMI AND TEXAS TO PLAY FOR TITLE
description: Don Rowland scored on an unearned run in the bottom of the eighth inning, and then the reliever Ric Raether snuffed a ninth-inning rally as the Hurricanes defeated Texas, 2-1, and forced a final game in the College World Series semifinal tonight.

title: Fans at Yonkers Upset
description: Irate fans at Yonkers Raceway littered the winners' circle Saturday night with beer and race programs, and a bettor won $16,800 after a parimutuel machine was said to have malfunctioned before the fourth race.

title: OUTDOORS: FLY FISHING FOR SALMON IN CANADA
description: A HALF-MILE downstream in the cloud-filled valley of the Restigouche River I saw, through rain-blurred glasses, the canoe from which Pierre Lutz of Redding, Conn., was fly fishing for Atlantic salmon go ashore.

title: BRAZIL MAY ACCEPT HELP IN NAZI CASE
description: The Brazilian authorities have reluctantly agreed to allow United States and West German experts to work with them in determining whether the Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele died here in 1979, a source close to the investigation said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some editions of Sports Pages on Thursday, about the Mets-Dodgers game Tuesday night, inaccurately described the performance in the eighth inning by Dwight Gooden of the Mets.
