With the bases loaded, he struck out one batter on three pitches, got the next batter to foul out on the first pitch, then struck out the next batter on five pitches.

title: U.S. Charters Thrift Unit
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said Friday that it had chartered a new Federal mutual savings association to take over the business of the Southern California Savings and Loan Association, which was found insolvent.

title: REVAMPED REDS CONTEND IN WEST
description: IT was late Friday afternoon, an hour before the doubleheader that would begin the biggest series the Cincinnati Reds had played in at least four years, and Pete Rose, the player-manager, watched as the first of 38,000 people found their seats in Riverfront Stadium.

title: PENTAGON ADOPTS STEPS TO IMPROVE QUALITY OF MILITARY MEDICAL CARE
description: The Department of Defense has instituted what the military and civilian medical authorities describe as strict new measures to eliminate substandard care at military hospitals.

title: Woodward's Loses Officer in Bid Fight
description: Six weeks ago, Grant Woodward MacLaren, the 52-year-old president of Woodward's Ltd., was declared the successor to Charles Woodward as chairman and chief executive officer of the Canadian retailing giant as part of the company's pending sale to the Cadillac Fairview Corporation. Mr. Woodward, 61, intended to retire. But last Friday Mr. MacLaren ended his dealings with Cadillac and resigned as president and a director after a dispute with his cousin, Mr. Woodward, over an unexpected, competing proposal for the Vancouver company made by Cambridge Shopping Centres of Toronto.

title: DANCE: PRINCETON BALLET
description: Princeton is not the only New Jersey city that the Princeton Ballet calls home. The company also gives regular engagements in Trenton and this week was in residence at New Brunswick's George Street Playhouse.

title: HEAVY TAX-EXEMPT BOND SCHEDULE
description: The only Treasury financing scheduled this week is today's regular sale of new bills due in three and six months. Government securities dealers do not expect any auctions of Treasury notes or bonds until June 19, when a two-year issue is expected, followed in the last week of the month by a major financing consisting of notes due in four and seven years, as well as 20-year bonds.

title: STAGE: A ONE-ACT PLAY, 'NORTH OF PROVIDENCE'
description: IN ''North of Providence,'' Edward Allan Baker takes a painful domestic crisis and transforms it into a one-act play of emotional depth and conviction. His play is the most impressive in Series C of the Ensemble Studio Theater's continuing Marathon of one-acts. To balance the evening, ''North of Providence'' is followed by a delirious cartoon by Shel Silverstein called ''One Tennis Shoe.''

title: JURIST APPEALS TO GRADUATES TO AID COURTS
description: The Chief Judge of the New York State Court of Appeals, Sol Wachtler, called on graduates of Benjamin Cardozo Law School to defend the judicial system against calls for an end to plea bargaining and other moves to make the courts tougher on defendants.

title: Cynthia Frisch Weds Peter Stephen Scully
description: Cynthia Joy Frisch, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alan J. Frisch of New York and Ashley Falls, Mass., was married yesterday to Peter Stephen Scully, a son of Mrs. Peter M. Scully of Orange, Conn., and the late Mr. Scully. Dr. Paul Migliore, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony at the Frisch home in Ashley Falls.

title: FARRELL IS TO BUY RADIO AIR TIME IN BID FOR MAYOR
description: Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., who is seeking the Democratic mayoral nomination, will begin a modest radio advertising campaign tomorrow in an effort to increase his visibility and solidify his base among blacks.

title: PRIZES CLIMAX TOKYO FILM FESTIVAL
description: This city's first foray into the world of international film festivals ended today, after weathering charges of censorship and withstanding a pace that included the showing of more than 100 movies in 10 days.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline in Weekend on Friday for a film review of ''The Goonies'' incorrectly indicated authorship of the screenplay. It was written by Chris Columbus and based on a story by Steven Spielberg.

title: A LAW SCHOOL HEARS CUOMO AT CEREMONY
description: Governor Cuomo urged new graduates of the New York Law School yesterday to maintain standards of social responsibility in their legal careers and to use the law ''as an instrument of social justice.''

title: A New Chance With India
description: When Rajiv Gandhi arrives in Washington tomorrow for his first visit as India's Prime Minister, there will be ample reason for good will. There are no real quarrels between the most populous and the most powerful of the world's democracies - no hard disputes over territory, trade or ideology. Yet for all the good will, a granule of sour suspicion will linger in the air, the legacy of a long-strained relationship.

title: MORE HOTEL TALKS TODAY
description: Talks in New York City's 10-day-old hotel strike were scheduled and abruptly called off without explanation last night, but a union spokesman said a new round of negotiations set for today would take place.

title: IT'S HISTORIC, 'JUST LIKE '55'
description: KAREEM ABDUL-JABBAR remembered it as if it were yesterday: ''You always remember important things,'' he said.

title: RIGHETTI AWAITS HIS NEW ORDERS
description: By now it should be clear that Dave Righetti has become more than just a pitcher to the Yankees. He has come to be a symbol of different Yankee eras, a tool with which Yankee managers make their imprint.

title: COMPUTER MAKERS IN A SEVERE SLUMP
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc., a maker of computer chips, celebrated last Christmas with typical Silicon Valley flamboyance - a $700,000 employee Christmas party featuring entertainment by the rock group Chicago and a 50-piece orchestra.

title: Donna Lee Smith Marries James E. Gerb in Peekskill
description: Donna Lee Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard J. Smith of Peekskill, N.Y., and Delray Beach, Fla, was married yesterday to James Edwin Gerb, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Maurice Gerb of Lynbrook, L.I. Rabbi Joshua Hammerman officiated at the Colonial Terrace in Peekskill.

title: FOR 36 BOB JOSEPHS, A DAY OF CAMARADERIE, PICNICKING AND SELF-CELEBRATION
description: There were a great many Bob Josephs in Brooklyn yesterday.

title: STEPHEN'S UNLIKELY COUP
description: Three hours after Woody Stephens had sent out Creme Fraiche and Stephan's Odyssey to run one, two in the Belmont Stakes Saturday, more than 50 celebrants were still swilling beer and champagne outside the stables, slapping the winning trainer on the back and shaking their heads at his feat of sending out a fourth consecutive winner of the final leg of the Triple Crown. That streak, though, was only part of what was so remarkable about the race.

title: NEW ZEALAND TRIES FREE-MARKET STAND
description: New Zealand has been thrust into the international spotlight in recent months because of its acute case of nuclear allergy: The Government of David Lange refused in February a port call by a United States naval vessel unless it was assured that the ship carried no nuclear arms, an assurance that Washington would not give.

title: BREWERS' 3 HOMERS SINK YANKEES, 9-4
description: The big week is here, and the Yankees are not ready. Key hitters are slumping, the pitchers are rattled, but one thing at least is in their favor: The Yankees will be at home.

title: Miller Romps to Her 3d Victory on a 68
description: Alice Miller today became the first golfer to win three L.P.G.A. events this year when she captured the $400,000 McDonald's Championship by eight strokes.

title: Big Florida Fire Contained
description: Up to 300 firefighters, including National Guard troops who dropped water from helicopters, managed to keep a 26,500-acre blaze within fire lines today.

title: Bojangle's, Red Lobster Set New Ad Campaigns
description: Two restaurant chains are breaking ad campaigns next Monday that will be offering consumers alternatives to the heavily advertised hamburger pushers.

title: Smoke in a High Place
description: To the Editor:

title: Elliott Edges Gant In Pocono Race
description: Bill Elliott, taking advantage of a series of late caution flags, charged into the lead 11 laps from the end and held off Harry Gant to win the Van Scoy 500 Grand National stockcar race today.

title: TOO MUCH, TOO LITTLE
description: The world has reached an absurd impasse on food supplies. Of all the crazy problems people have created for themselves, nothing seems so preposterous as the maldistribution of the essentials of life. Last year, taxpayers in the U.S. and Europe provided $36 billion in subsidies for farmers, $19 billion in the U.S. and $17 billion in the Common Market, according to Maurice Williams, head of the U.N.'s World Food Council.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Science Times last Tuesday about teachers who speak foreign-accented English incorrectly described an instructor of differential equations at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Hindustani was his native language; it is not a nationality.

title: PRISCILLA FEINBERG WEDS
description: Priscilla Dawn Feinberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen J. Feinberg of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Paul Bauersfeld, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Bauersfeld of Scarsdale, were married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in Yonkers. Rabbi Abraham Klausner and the Rev. Francis J. Melican, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. Mrs. Bauersfeld graduated magna cum laude from Brown University in May. Mr. Bauersfeld is a senior engineering student at the Rochester Institue of Technology.

title: THE BUSINESS OF GETTING INVITATIONS
description: ''This is the only city I know where you send all the invitations to the office,'' says Adrienne Arsht, a Washington business executive whose husband, Myer Feldman, served in the Kennedy Administration and practices law here.

title: CONCERT: DE TARANTO AT THE PIANO
description: IT was billed as a concert by ''Marcel De Taranto and Friends,'' and on Wednesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall it was Mr. De Taranto's friends who saw him through.

title: CHANGE SET FOR SQUASH
description: Professional squash rackets competition with the ''soft'' ball used in most other countries will have its United States debut here this week at the United States Pro Softball Squash Championships.

title: A Half-Century of A.A.
description: Doctor Bob's nightmare ended 50 years ago today when he took his last drink.

title: RATES DECLINE WITH ECONOMY
description: A cardinal rule in the credit markets is that bad news for the economy is good news for the bond market.

title: BANK CRISIS HURTS GOVERNOR OF OHIO
description: The banking crisis in Ohio is on its way to resolution with the state's decision to sell the failed Home State Savings Bank to a Cincinnati institution, but the political fallout goes on.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Medical Communications Co. of North Brunswick, N.J., a division of ST&L Associates Inc., an advertising firm, has named Emile Nerlinger president.

title: FAST-FOOD CHAINS ARE SHORT OF HELP
description: Employers in the fast-food restaurant industry report they are having growing difficulty finding people to fill jobs, even at wages above the Federal minimum of $3.35 an hour, according to a survey by the private Bureau of National Affairs.

title: LEBANON MILITIA BRIEFLY DETAINS FRENCH COLONEL
description: The Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army seized a French Army colonel who was negotiating for the release of 21 kidnapped Finnish United Nations soldiers today, but it later released him unharmed, a United Nations spokesman said.

title: 2 Die in the Crash of a Plane In Fog on Upstate Golf Course
description: A twin-engine airplane flying through heavy fog early today crashed at an upstate golf course, killing the pilot and co-pilot, the state police said.

title: EQUAL AIR TIME FOR THE DANGERS OF ALCOHOL
description: To the Editor:

title: Restless in West Wing
description: A spell of restlessness may be understandable in the workaholic life of Edward J. Rollins, the Republican field marshal who managed President Reagan's re-election campaign.

title: HOUSE TAX HEARING: EYE ON MAIN ST.
description: In the first full week of Congressional hearings on tax legislation, the question raised more often than any other about President Reagan's tax proposal was whether the plan would be too generous to the wealthy and not favorable enough to the broad middle class.

title: LESSONS OF THE '75 FISCAL CRISIS
description: Today marks the 10th anniversary of the creation of the Municipal Assistance Corporation - one of several crucial developments in the effort to save New York City from bankruptcy a decade ago. As we celebrate, it is worth pondering how it all happened and whether we can apply the lessons learned to the financial crisis facing our nation today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE LOVER. By Marguerite Duras. Pantheon. 117 pages. $11.95. ''WHAT I'm doing now is both different and the same. Before, I spoke of clear periods, those on which the light fell. Now I'm talking about the hidden stretches of that same youth, of certain facts, feelings, events that I buried,' Marguerite Duras says at the beginning of her latest novel, ''Sometimes, I realize that if writing isn't all things, all contraries confounded, a quest for vanity and void, it's nothing. That if it's not, each time, all things confounded into one through some inexpressible essence, then writing is nothing but advertisement.''

title: Still the Same Old Weed
description: Imagine the teen-ager eager to embark on that rite of passage, the first cigarette, who's told to ''take a pouch instead of a puff.'' Chances are that kid is going to think that chewing tobacco, and tobacco snuff, which the user sucks or ''dips'' inside the lower gum, are healthful alternatives to smoking.

title: A LOOK AT 2 SITCOMS AT TED TURNER'S WTBS
description: ''SAFE AT HOME'' and ''Down to Earth'' are a couple of situation comedies deserving little more than a passing nod except that they represent a sizable chunk of the original weekly programming to be found on WTBS, the superstation owned by Turner Broadcasting System. And, of course, Ted Turner, the brash and aggressive owner of TBS, is making a takeover bid for CBS. His programming record is of far more than passing interest.

title: Lotus-Dataspeed
description: The Lotus Development Corporation, a computer software company based in Cambridge, Mass., said Friday that it had reached a definitive agreement for the previously announced acquisition of Dataspeed Inc. The transaction, valued at about $6.5 million, would broaden the Lotus product line. Dataspeed developed Modio and Quotrek, two products that use FM sideband radio waves to provide securities quotations to customers with the proper receivers.

title: Fewer Households Held Affected by Crime in '84
description: Violent criminals or thieves victimized about one in four households last year, the lowest proportion since 1975, the Justice Department said today.

title: Swiss, in 2-to-1 Vote, Reject Tighter Rules for Abortions
description: Swiss voters today rejected a proposal that would have severely limited abortions and banned some contraceptives.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Miss Grossman Weds Andrew Greene
description: Caroline Ann Grossman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence K. Grossman of Westport, Conn., and New York, and Andrew Gilbert Greene, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack C. Greene of Mill Neck, L.I., were married yesterday. Rosalie Ann Danbury, a justice of the peace, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents in Westport.

title: THE HUMANA BUILDING IN LOUISVILLE: COMPELLING WORK BY MICHAEL GRAVES
description: There are few skyscrapers, even in this decade of startling towers, that have been as awaited as the architect Michael Graves's design for the new headquarters here of Humana Inc., the private health-care company. The Humana Building is the largest and most ambitious work so far of an architect whose career has taken off with astonishing speed in the last few years, with such projects as the Portland Building in Portland, Ore., the San Juan Capistrano Library in southern California, the new museum for Emory University in Atlanta and the recently announced expansion for the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York.

title: Guarding the Price Index
description: With trading to begin next week in futures contracts on the Consumer Price Index, the Labor Department has strengthened security measures to guard against leaks. The new contract, to be traded on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, is the first based on a general-purpose figure produced by the Federal Government.

title: Joffrey II Troupe Gets New Director
description: Richard Englund, former director of the American Ballet Theater II company, has been named to direct the Joffrey II Dancers.

title: IMPROPER USE OF BALLAST CITED AT HEARING ON SINKING OF RIG
description: When an oil-drilling barge capsized in a calm channel last month, killing 11 men aboard, its ballast system was being used improperly, according to testimony at a Coast Guard hearing.

title: PALESTINIANS IN HILLS BOMBARD SHIITES ATTACKING BEIRUT SETTLEMENTS
description: Palestinian guerrillas in the hills east of Beirut bombarded positions of Shiite fighters who were attacking three Palestinian settlements south of the Lebanese capital today.

title: 4TH SEPTUPLET DIES AFTER 19 DAYS OF STRUGGLING WITH LUNG TROUBLE
description: Bonnie Marie Frustaci, the weakest of the four surviving Frustaci septuplets, died today in her parents' arms after a 19-day struggle with a lung ailment, hospital officials said.

title: Catching Up
description: Ned Fowler, who resigned as basketball coach at Tulane amid the gambling and recruiting scandal there, was relaxing at his New Orleans home these days, pondering business offers that, he reports, have come his way from the fields of insurance, banking and public relations. ''There are a lot of carryover assets after being a college basketball coach,'' Fowler said.

title: 'YIN AND THE YANKEE'
description: AN amusing account of the fight against bureaucracy - a losing one even in this case involving a powerful individual in a Communist country - is told in the documentary, ''The Yin and the Yankee,'' on WNET/Channel 13 at 10 P.M. today.

title: Miss Fetner Wed Dr. J. E. Sherman
description: The marriage of Randi Fetner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Fetner of Greenwich, Conn., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to Dr. John E. Sherman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard J. Sherman of New York, took place yesterday. Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz performed the ceremony.

title: JIHAN SADAT SHOCKED BY CHANGES IN EGYPT
description: Jihan Sadat has come home to Egypt after a five-month sojourn in the United States. In many respects, the widow of President Anwar el-Sadat says, she has returned to a different land.

title: COURT RULING ON WIVES DEVIDES EGYPT
description: The abolition of a women's rights law last month by Egypt's Supreme Court has touched off a furious debate here and put the Government of President Hosni Mubarak in a politically awkward position.

title: WILANDER TOPPLES LENDL IN 4-SET FINAL
description: Mats Wilander said before the French Open final today that he would not play exclusively from the baseline, and he was as good as his word as he won the title from an ineffective Ivan Lendl.

title: A PLOT FOR TV: GETTING TOUGH WITH ADOLESCENTS
description: Many of the most popular recent theatrical feature films, such as ''The Breakfast Club,'' have championed rebellious teen-agers against abusive or uncomprehending parents. But parents will have their day in ''Toughlove,'' a movie for television about a controversial but popular movement that urges parents to get tough with abusive teen-agers.

title: Home in Milwaukee
description: The reason he left the Mets midway through the 1983 season, he said, was that he could no longer bear the frustration of managing in a circumstance ''that had no daylight.'' In fact, George Bamberger recalled, ''after that experience I never thought I'd ever want to manage again.''

title: Minneapolis Agency Is Top Award Winner
description: The 64th annual awards night of the Art Directors Club was held Friday and the star of the show could easily have been its location, the historic Puck Building at the corner of Houston and Lafayette Streets. After all, if the committee had decided on booking a hotel ballroom, as it has in most past years, the event might not even have been held because of the hotel workers' strike.

title: MOYNIHAN AND LAUTENBERG OPPOSE E.P.A. CHANGE
description: Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Frank R. Lautenberg said yesterday that they would introduce legislation to block the Environmental Protection Agency from delegating to the states the regulation of many toxic air pollutants.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ANGOLA'S CHILDREN OF WAR
description: There had been rain in the night, unseasonal showers, and so the gray blankets were laid out to dry around huts of pale straw that, evidently, had leaked.

title: Secession Bid Urged In Western Colorado
description: Larry Polich, Mayor of this town in western Colorado, says he thinks the area is neglected by state officials and that he wants it to secede and become a state.

title: Mayor Must Not Name Medical Examiner
description: To the Editor:

title: Lynn Radlauer Is Wed
description: At the Falmouth (Mass.) Jewish Congregation yesterday Lynn Miriam Radlauer and Edward Mark Lubell, who received M.B.A. degrees Thursday from Harvard University, were married by Rabbi Robert Goldstein.

title: IN VERDANT LARCHMONT, A BATTLE OVER GARDEN NOISE
description: For Glynne Woolfenden, a writer, the neighborhood just hasn't been the same since ''those snarling monsters'' moved in.

title: STANLEY ABRAMS, LED MUSEUM
description: Stanley Abrams, president of the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum, died Thursday at University Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Technical Case For Bonds
description: TECHNICAL analysts at brokerage firms typically devote their talents to interpreting the stock market. But they occasionally venture onto the treacherous shoals of the bond market.

title: New York Rudeness
description: A woman flagged an M-2 bus as it leapfrogged down Fifth Avenue and asked the driver if it went as far as 42d Street.

title: COUPLE WILL FACE A GERMAN INQUIRY ON AID TO MENGELE
description: The West German prosecutor investigating the disappearance of the Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele said today that he would soon begin a judicial inquiry to determine if the former manager of the Mengele family's farm machinery company and his wife had obstructed justice.

title: Cosmos Triumph
description: Two well-known internationals, playing their first soccer game at Giants Stadium, scored goals 4 minutes apart tonight and led the Cosmos to a 2-0 victory over Sporting Club of Lisbon before a crowd of 15,724.

title: Paul S. Newman, Writer, Is Wed to Carol Wernick
description: The marriage of Carol Wernick, the project coordinator of youth leadership for the New York City Board of Education, to Paul S. Newman, a writer of industrial films and audio-visual presentations, took place yesterday at the bridegroom's home in New York.

title: 22 More Bodies Feared Buried at California Site
description: As many as 22 more bodies may be buried around a cabin where the authorities have already found the remains of three people, the police said today.

title: MUSIC: CHARLES Aznavour
description: WATCHING Charles Aznavour in the first show of a five-night stand at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday, one felt the excitement of confronting not just a legendary singer but a great veteran athlete going through his paces with a flawless precision. By exhibiting a special physical intensity and timing, the diminutive 61-year-old French-Armenian singer succeeded in making a very familiar game seem fresh and exhilarating.

title: Summer Jobs Program
description: To the Editor:

title: Robin Alyce Niad Is Wed To Charles Hammerman
description: At Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I., yesterday Robin Alyce Niad and Charles Daniel Hammerman, May graduates of Washington University in St. Louis, were married by Rabbi Sol Roth.

title: Conflicts of Parents
description: Amid the Senate debate last week over life and death, revolution and democracy in Nicaragua, a question arose about graduation.

title: BIG SHIPS, BAD BEARS, BUSY SKY
description: Alaska has always attracted tourists, but the pace has picked up in the jet age, which has created a major demand for cruise ship staterooms on trips through the Inland Passage.

title: F.A.A. Revamping Reporting Of Near Collisions in Midair
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has revamped its method of reporting near collisions in midair, acknowledging that hundreds of reports from pilots were never counted in recent years.

title: B'NAI B'RITH SAYS GROUPS TRY TO HINDER ANTI-NAZI ACTIONS
description: The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith released a report yesterday charging various organizations with a campaign to obstruct Justice Department action against Nazi war crime suspects.

title: Oscar Cohen, Former Official Of Anti-Defamation League
description: Oscar Cohen, a former program director for the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, died of a stroke Saturday at New York Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 10, 1985: *2*MONDAY Bunker Hill Inc Interco Inc First Int'ste Bncp Materials Research Hospital Corp Am *2*TUESDAY Chesapeake Corp Hubbell (Harvey) Cox Commun Premier Industrial Emery Air Freight Riblet Products Fleetwood Enter Shaklee Corp Fluor Corp Toro Co House of Fabrics *2*WEDNESDAY Nicor Inc Southern New Engl Tel *2*THURSDAY Acco World Corp National Fuel Gas Adams Express Petrol & Resources Basix Corp Supermarkets Gen'l General Signal Corp Trinity Indust Mony Mtge Invest *2*FRIDAY Abbott Labs May Dept Stores Ames Dept Stores Ohio Art Co Illinois Tool Wks *2*SATURDAY Wolverine World Wide

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 10, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Institute for Training and Research meeting of presidents of General Assembly - 3 P.M.

title: ROPING IN POLITICAL ADVANTAGES ON TAXES
description: President Reagan is trying to harness a political force that Republicans call ''new populism'' to drive his tax revision proposal across the finish line. Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d defines it as ''anti-big government, pro-market and pro-fairness.''

title: FOR TWO GENERALS, SPECIAL ASSIGNMENTS
description: HERSCHEL WALKER needs 33 yards and Ron Reeves needs to survive. Those two, the noted halfback and the nondescript quarterback, represent two ends of the spectrum for the Generals, who play the Jacksonville Bulls at Giants Stadium tonight.

title: G.&W. SETS SALE OF UNIT TO WICKES
description: Gulf and Western Industries has agreed to sell its consumer and industrial products group, which includes clothing licensed under the Calvin Klein, Liz Claiborne and Jonathan Logan labels, to the Wickes Companies for $1 billion in cash, plus the assumption of $90 million in long-term debt, the two companies said today.

title: Italians Vote on Pay Policy
description: Italians began two days of voting today on a referendum to reverse a pay cut, imposed by the Government last year, that affects 20 million employees. Prime Minister Bettino Craxi, a Socialist, has said he will resign immediately if the referendum succeeds. It is sponsored by the Communist Party.

title: REAGAN DECISION ON ARMS ACCORD EXPECTED TODAY
description: President Reagan has decided that the United States will continue to honor provisions of a six-year-old, unratified strategic arms agreement with the Soviet Union but with modifications to take account of perceived Soviet violations of the accord, Administration officials said today.

title: Bank Takeover By Hong Kong
description: The Overseas Trust Bank Ltd., which collapsed Thursday, was taken over Friday by the Government, which promised to safeguard depositors and creditors and said the closure of the British colony's fourth-largest bank apparently was the result of ''major fraud.''

title: ABDUL-JABBAR LEADS WAY
description: At the age of 38, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar did today what no other Laker was able to accomplish in eight previous attempts over 26 years - he led his team to victory over the Boston Celtics in the championship round.

title: Equal Air Time for the Dangers of Alcohol
description: To the Editor:

title: Secretive Debt Reviewers
description: It is a secretive group of nine top Federal bank examiners who refuse even to say where they meet and who never divulge anything publicly. Three times a year, they pass judgment on the creditworthiness of major third world and other countries.

title: SSC&B: Lintas Fills Key Posts
description: Spencer Plavoukos, newly arrived at the top of SSC&B: Lintas USA with the title of chairman and chief executive, has in turn raised two associates to new heights.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: OF TREES, LITTER AND THE CITY'S BUDGET
description: The seven volumes of Mayor Koch's $20 billion executive budget spill forth an endless succession of numbers stretching from one computer-generated page to the next.

title: Melissa Vernick Marries
description: Melissa Jo Vernick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Vernick of Albertson, L.I., and Jeffrey Lee Shangold, a son of Mrs. David Feld of East Meadow, L.I., and the late Alvin Shangold, were married yesterday. Rabbi Norman Kahan performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai in Roslyn, L.I. The bride is an account executive with William Esty & Company. Her husband is an accountant with Arthur Young & Company in New York.

title: U.S. DEBUT FOR A STAR FROM BRAZIL
description: It's not every singer who can make her United States debut with two concerts at Carnegie Hall. But the Brazilian singer Gal Costa, who is performing there tonight and tomorrow, comes to New York with an international reputation. She has had hit singles since 1968 in Brazil, where she usually performs in 10,000- and 15,000-seat arenas; she has also toured Europe and Japan. For fans of Brazilian music around the world, her voice is synonymous with tropicalia, the style that revolutionized Brazilian pop by embracing - and transforming -rock-and-roll.

title: Briefcase
description: The Federal Reserve has deferred by a month, until July, a long-awaited updating of its index of industrial production. Among other things, the base will be moved forward 10 years, to 1977, and new breakdowns will be published for the chemical industry.

title: F.B.I. MAN CALLED KEY TO SPY TRIAL
description: An idiosyncratic former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation is expected to offer crucial testimony early this week in the trial of a Soviet emigre couple accused of conspiring with him to pass secret intelligence documents to the Soviet Union.

title: SUCCESS OF COLUMBIA'S DRIVE SENDS GOAL UP TO $500 MILLION
description: Columbia University has increased the goal of its five-year fund-raising campaign to $500 million from $400 million, President Michael I. Sovern has announced.

title: BEWARE OF AIDING THE 'CONTRAS'
description: The President has won the Senate's support for a renewal of ''nonmilitary'' aid, through the Central Intelligence Agency, to the Nicaraguan ''contras.'' No one should be deceived by the word ''nonmilitary.'' If the House should agree, this money will be used to pay for everything short of weapons and bullets, and the rest of the needed funds will be sought in other places it would be embarrassing to explore. The Senate has voted for continued war by the C.I.A. against the Nicaraguan Government. The House should reverse this vote, on the simple and fundamental ground that this ''covert'' operation will not work.

title: CENTRAL BANKERS' DEREGULATION WARNING
description: Central bankers want governments to take a more cautious approach to financial deregulation, warning that the fast-changing structure of modern markets makes it harder to control inflation and could lead to instability and a premature recession.

title: MENGELE'S DEATH DOUBTED IN ISRAEL
description: Israeli Nazi hunters said today that they still believed Josef Mengele was still alive somewhere in Latin America, despite reports from Brazil that his remains may have been found in Sao Paulo, Brazil.

title: Cancer Hearings Boycotted
description: Senate hearings this week into whether cancer is caused by nuclear fallout are being boycotted by the National Association of Radiation Survivors, 5,000 widows and survivors of nuclear tests and cleanups. The association feels the hearings are predisposed to play down complaints from such citizens as Reason Warehime, the association chairman, who participated in the Nagasaki bomb cleanup and who has lung cancer, according to the group's director, Dorothy Legarreta. Instead of testimony, the association will make its statement at the Washington Project for the Arts, in the form of portraits of 30 members.

title: Changing Chairs
description: He has been one of the last bastions of amateurism in professional tennis, the local barber or businessman who once a year climbs to his perch above the court and serves as the umpire at his city's annual Grand Prix tournament. Already an endangered species because of a program of certification established in 1979 by the Men's International Professional Tennis Council, the amateur chair umpire has now been marked for extinction.

title: Nancy Carol Marks Is Married to Steven J. Silver
description: Nancy Carol Marks, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan D. Marks of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Steven J. Silver, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Silver of Larchmont, N.Y. Rabbi Marjorie Yudkin performed the ceremony at the Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Allan Kornblau, a Lawyer, Is Married to Lenore Rons
description: The marriage of Lenore Rons, a lead analyst in the data processing area at the Irving Trust Company, and Allan I. Kornblau, a partner in the New York law firm of Parente & Kornblau, took place yesterday.

title: Mobile Home Chapter 11
description: The Commodore Corporation, a leading producer of mobile homes, announced yesterday that it and a subsidiary, Commodore Home Systems Inc., would file for reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Code today. Commodore, based in Syracuse, Ind., said it is possible that other subsidiaries may file under Chapter 11 proceedings as well.

title: CURRENCY TRADERS EDGY
description: AN unusual nervousness has recently gripped the foreign currency cash, futures and options markets. Whether this development was caused by or was the result of recent actions by major global financial houses to sharply limit their exposure in foreign exchange dealings was not clear, according to market analysts.

title: British Bank System
description: Nonprofit building societies, which have monopolized Britain's home mortgage business, would be able to incorporate into profit-making enterprises listed on the Stock Exchange and to engage in many banking activities, under a Government proposal.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: MONDAY, JUNE 10, 1985

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, JUNE 10, 1985

title: ARID WEST REALIZING WATER IS A SALABLE CROP
description: For more than a century Westerners have fought over water, stolen it, occasionally killed for it. Now, in a challenge to the traditions of the West, they are starting to broker it like crude oil, fresh oranges or bushels of corn.

title: BONN OFFER IN '64 ON MENGELE REPORTED
description: The Nazi hunter Simon Wiesenthal asserted yesterday that the West German Government tried in 1964 to pay Paraguay to extradite Josef Mengele.

title: An Airman Acquitted Of Selling Information
description: An airman was acquitted today of selling classified information to an undercover investigator posing as a representative of a major military contractor.

title: Sound Housing Needs Sound Planning
description: Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch are seeking mortgage credit to fix a New York housing shortage that has been years in the making. Since the state Constitution limits borrowing to build housing, they have filed the equivalent of a 10-year, $1.2 billion loan application with three public corporations.

title: Hindu-Moslem Clashes Leave 20 Dead in India
description: At least 14 people were burned to death today and six others were killed in the western state of Gujarat in continuing Hindu-Moslem clashes over an affirmative action program for underprivileged groups.

title: SLOWER GROWTH AT THRIFT UNITS
description: FOR thrift institutions, 1984 was the year of sizzling growth. Some small institutions grew tenfold and dozens of the very largest expanded by more than 25 percent. Regulators and some industry officials became understandably worried.

title: Bridge: L.I. Player Appreciates Gift At His 90th Birthday Party
description: If you count years of participation, bridge players have a great advantage over those who engage in more active pursuits. Competitively speaking, except for the rare case, swimmers are finished at 25, tennis players at 40 and golfers at 50.

title: DRUG MADE ON SPACE SHUTTLE NOW BEING TESTED IN ANIMALS
description: A New Jersey pharmaceutical concern has begun the first animal tests of a superpure medicine made in space that holds the promise of helping millions of people by the end of the decade.

title: U.S. TRIES TO TRACK DOWN INCOME SAID TO BE MOTIVE IN SOVIET SPY CASE
description: While the Government asserts that John A. Walker Jr. spied for the Soviet Union for the purpose of making money, Federal investigators are still trying to determine how much he may have received for his activities.

title: RECITAL: 'CONTRASTS' FOR PIANO
description: CHAIM FREIBERG'S piano recital at Merkin Concert Hall Wednesday night was not particularly marked by style or technical poise, but it did bring us Tzipora Jochsberger's ''Contrasts'' - 16 short teaching pieces for children.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Los Angeles Soccer Killing
description: Bystanders pounced on a gunman Saturday as he was reloading his pistol after killing one man and wounding two others in a crowded park after a soccer game, the police said today. They said Angel Nunes Gudino, 24 years old, shot Mario Guerra, 23, of Van Nuys, in the chest and twice in the neck, killing him, then shot another man in the buttocks and a third in the leg. The angry crowd then beat up the assailant and turned him over to police.

title: OPERA: 'CARMEN' IN PLAZA
description: It had been humid and cloudy all this afternoon, but by evening, the skies had cleared and no rain dampened the Durham Arts Council's premiere outdoor staging of Bizet's ''Carmen.'' This engaging production, modeled on the ''street opera'' endemic to Montepulciano, Italy, will receive four more performances next week.

title: PAINFUL DECISIONS AT HANNA
description: So far, the 1980's have not been the brightest decade for the M. A. Hanna Company and Robert F. Anderson, its chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Dunlop Slazenger Goes To McCann-Erickson
description: For the third time this year, McCann-Erickson, one of three international agency networks run by the Interpublic Group of Companies, has received a major multinational assignment.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. This is New York's first meeting of the season with the high-flying Blue Jays, who have the best record in baseball. For the Yankees, this is the beginning of a tough stretch against American League East rivals; the Detroit Tigers and the Baltimore Orioles are next. (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M. Radio -WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Phillies, at Philadelphia. Opener of a seven-game, seven-day road trip to Philadelphia and Montreal. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Football Generals vs. Jacksonville Bulls, at Giants Stadium, 7 P.M. The Generals shipped Brian Sipe to the Bulls at the beginning of the season to make room for Doug Flutie, and now both quarterbacks are out with injuries. The Generals need a victory to clinch a playoff berth. Their halfback, Herschel Walker, is 33 yards away from the 2,000-yard mark and needs only 139 yards to break the pro football one-season record of 2,105 set by Eric Dickerson of the Los Angeles Rams in 1984. (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M. Radio - WMCA 570, 7 P.M.) Squash Inaugural United States Pro Softball Squash Championships, at the Park Place Squash Club, 25 Park Place, across from City Hall Park, 10 A.M. to midnight. This is the first American professional championships using the slower softball and the official 21-foot court, which is 2 1/2 feet wider than the squash racquets courts.

title: FOR INDIVIDUALS, FILING MAY BE SIMPLER RITUAL
description: For some, the ideal vision of a simpler tax system is nothing short of a tax code streamlined to the point where every American could file a return no bigger than a postcard.

title: HELPING THE ILL TO COPE
description: ELAINE MARTIN of Warren, N.J., stood by her swimming pool and watched as her husband, Jonathan, shouted for help. Momentarily forgetting the illness that had atrophied the muscles of his upper torso, he had dived in. ''I walked to the edge,'' she recalled, ''and said: 'I suggest that you kick like hell. I just had my hair done.' ''

title: MEXICO ENCOUNTERS PROBLEM OF GROWTH
description: After coming close to economic collapse in 1982 and enduring two years of rigid austerity intended to bring its finances into balance, Mexico is now plagued by a new problem: growth.

title: Von Bulow Jury Rehears Key Testimony of Maid
description: Jurors in the attempted murder trial of Claus von Bulow today reheard key testimony that helped convict him three years ago as they weighed whether he twice tried to kill his wife with insulin injections.

title: Turkish Cypriots Re-Elect Leader
description: Rauf Denktash, who led the Turkish Cypriot move to declare an independent state in the north of this divided island two years ago, was re-elected President of the breakaway republic today.

title: IN ADIRONDACKS, A NIGHT FOR SOME FIDDLING AND SOCIALIZING
description: Toward evening, when fishbowl-sized servings of strawberry shortcake began appearing on tables at Peggy Morrill's Lumberjack Restaurant on Route 28, talk lingered over common sense and a night's fiddling.

title: DANCE: CITY BALLET
description: MATINEES are for exciting debuts by fine young dancers - or so it seemed Saturday at the New York State Theater when several of the New York City Ballet's members stepped into new roles.

title: THE NEW TOWNSEND HARRIS HIGH KEEPS OLD GOALS
description: In 1942, Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia ordered the closing of Townsend Harris High School as a ''nonessential educational unit.''

title: 25 Independents Win In Hungarian Elections
description: Twenty-five independents won seats in the 387-member Hungarian Parliament in the most open elections since the Communists took power at the end of World War II, according to results released today.

title: Miss Avery, Therapist, Marries Scott R. Smith
description: Wendy Wintage Avery and Scott Reed Smith were married yesterday by the Rev. Allen Wells, a Unitarian minister, in an outdoor ceremony at the Riverdale Country School in Riverdale, the Bronx, where the bridegroom is director of admissions and chairman of the scholarship committee.

title: Accounts
description: Egypt Air to AC&R Advertising, a subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide.

title: ARGENTINA DEBT MOVE AWAITED
description: Federal bank regulators meeting in Washington today could downgrade Argentina's foreign debt ratings, bankers believe. Such a move might require the banks to set aside substantial reserves against their loans to the South American country and thereby cut into their profits.

title: Ralph Schneider, 86; Ex-Clothing Executive
description: Ralph D. Schneider, founder of the Broadstreet's chain of menswear stores and former president of the retail division of Botany Industries, died of cancer Saturday at Long Beach (L.I.) Memorial Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Long Beach.

title: OPEC'S PRICING PREDICAMENT
description: A continuing worldwide oversupply of crude oil, lower oil demand in the second quarter and increased oil production by the industrial nations have combined to precipitate yet another pricing and production crisis for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Arrest Ends Learfan Revival
description: A man who pledged to revive the Learfan jet project after the Lear Fan company had filed for liquidation was being held in jail this weekend following his arrest for violating parole after a fraud conviction.

title: We Need People to Keep All Those Secrets
description: To the Editor:

title: CUBS SWEEP PIRATES SERIES
description: Leon Durham's run-scoring double and a two-run single by Chris Speier keyed a four-run rally in the sixth inning today that led the Chicago Cubs past the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5-1, for a four-game sweep.

title: 78 Are Reported Killed As Iraq Raids Iran Camp
description: At least 78 people were killed and more than 120 were wounded today in an Iraqi air raid on a Kurdish refugee camp in northwest Iran, the Iranian press agency said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BEST OF TASTE It may be that art or it may just be the theme ''Starved for Art: The Art of Dining Out'' that starts one salivating in the show on view in the Visual Arts Museum, the ground-floor gallery of the School of Visual Arts, 209 East 23d Street (679-7350).

title: Search Pressed After 3 Die in Kayak Accident
description: The search continued for several hours today for a possible survivor of a boating accident that left three people dead and led to the dramatic rescue of a 3-year-old boy by a 13-year-old speedboat operator, the police said.

title: HOUSTON'S SPANISH ACCENT GETS MORE PRONOUNCED
description: El Mercado del Sol, a 17-acre shopping center billed as ''the nation's largest Hispanic theme festival center,'' has opened in Houston.

title: New York Nonchalance
description: On the downtown IRT local yesterday morning, mothers were tending squirming children in their church clothes and weekend workers were rubbing the residue of Saturday night from their eyes.

title: ADVERSARIES IN HOTEL STRIKE: CALM UNDER PRESSURE
description: It angers Vito J. Pitta, the president of the striking Hotel and Motel Trades Council, that there are some who he says look down on the housekeepers, maids, waiters and busboys he represents.

title: MALTBIE WINS TITLE ON 4TH PLAYOFF HOLE
description: Roger Maltbie birdied the last two holes of regulation to join Ray Floyd and George Burns in a sudden-death playoff, then sank a 9-foot birdie putt on the fourth extra hole to win the $90,000 first prize in the 19th Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic.

title: PROTOCOL OF CALLS FROM DISTANT SPACE
description: An encounter with Allan E. Goodman can be unsettling.

title: 'Sisterfire' Festival
description: Other 30 individual performers and companies will appear in ''Sisterfire,'' an open-air festival celebrating women artists, on June 22 and 23 at Takoma Park, Md., just outside Washington.

title: U.S. Said to Withhold Visa for Former Rebel
description: Two Democratic Congressmen said today that the Government was withholding a visa for a former Nicaraguan rebel leader to influence the debate in Congress over aid to the insurgents.

title: REAGAN STATEMENT ON ARMS ACCORD
description: Following is the text, issued today by the White House, of a statement by President Reagan on United States and Soviet compliance with the 1979 treaty limiting strategic arms:

title: Let Hotel Families Have the Refrigerators
description: To the Editor:

title: Law Schools' Decline Continues for 3d Year
description: Applications to the nation's law schools have fallen for the third year and have dropped 20 percent since 1982, the Law School Admission Council said today.

title: Berle Has Heart Surgery
description: Milton Berle, the comedian, underwent quadruple bypass heart surgery today, four days after he was admitted to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center complaining of fatigue.

title: F.A.A. Revamping Reporting Of Near Collisions in Midair
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has revamped its method of reporting near collisions in midair, acknowledging that hundreds of reports from pilots were never counted in recent years.

title: AGED APES SHOW NO DECLINE IN LEARNING ABILITY
description: GOOD news about the effects of old age on primates has emerged from study of the two most aged chimpanzees in captivity. Bula and Gamma, females in their mid-50's living at the Yerkes Regional Primate Research Center in Atlanta, recently repeated some learning tests they had taken more than two decades earlier.

title: NOT SO NEAT A WAR
description: For United States military forces, an invasion of Nicaragua would be ''like falling off a log,'' says an intelligence officer. And an official of the Army's Southern Command estimates that it would take only two weeks to gain control of 60 percent of the Nicaraguan population.

title: Yale Medical School Gets $8 Million Gift
description: The Yale University School of Medicine today said it had received its largest gift ever, $8 million to build a library addition.

title: MIDEAST TALKS WILL BE USEFUL ONLY...
description: The State Department apparently believes that Arabs and Israelis are making progress toward peace -that King Hussein of Jordan is ready to negotiate on terms that would be acceptable to the United States and Israel. In fact, there is little ground for optimism.

title: Music Group Sends Supplies to Ethiopians
description: The first plane full of food, medicine and clothing bought with royalties from the ''We Are the World'' hit single and album is on the way to drought victims in Ethiopia and the Sudan.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS BANKING MERGERS LIMITED TO REGIONS
description: The Supreme Court, upholding the idea of community-based banking, ruled today that regional banking zones were valid under both Federal law and the Constitution. The vote was 8 to 0.

title: Trouble for Cuomo's Copter
description: A state executive helicopter, ferrying Governor Cuomo from Albany to New York City, was forced to make an emergency landing this morning at the Sky Park Airport, a small private airport near this Dutchess County community, because of a drop in oil pressure, said a spokesman, Martin Steadman, who was with the Governor. A state police helicopter was dispatched to take over the flight.

title: ON E. 44TH ST., CONSTRUCTION NEVER CEASES
description: Once upon a time, 650 people lived peacefully in twin apartment buildings that faced each other across East 44th Street, just a glance away from the grass and flags of the United Nations.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. The Yankees, with problems in the starting rotation, send out the struggling Ed Whitson, who is 1-6, as they contemplate moving Dave Righetti back into the rotation.

title: Ingenious Teachers
description: Eleven municipal workers have been engaging in highly irregular work practices, according to an audit by the City Comptroller's office.

title: Regent Air Gets U.S. Approval
description: The Regent Air Corporation, the financially troubled luxury airline that so far has largely operated as a charter service, has received approval from the Transportation Department to become a scheduled carrier. J. Roger Faherty, Regent's chairman, president and chief executive, said the airline had sought certification as a scheduled carrier since 1983. Mr. Faherty added that, in light of the Transportation Department's action, the airline would introduce a marketing program and complete its $6 million to $8 million financing plan.

title: TRITON GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Comparable figures are not available because the company's fiscal year-end was changed to Jan. 31 year from May 31. c-After an extraordinary gain of $2,769,000, or 4 cents a share.

title: NAVY CHECKS ITS SECURITY APPARATUS
description: The Office of Naval Intelligence has assigned a team of 35 people to search, here and at every ship and duty station where John A. Walker Jr. served, for the answers to two critical questions, according to Navy officers.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Alaska Airlines, based in Seattle, has elected Gus Robinson president and chief operating officer.

title: STERLING EXTRUDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
TOROTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: MERITS AND MISCONDUCT
description: Back in 1982 a Federal judge, Thomas Griesa, threw out a go-ahead permit that the Army Corps of Engineers had issued for Westway and ordered the corps to start again on its process of deliberation, this time obeying all the applicable Federal laws.

title: 21 More Rabbis in a Protest At Soviet Embassy Are Held
description: The police arrested 21 rabbis today as they chanted and prayed outside the Soviet Embassy to protest what one organizer called ''an ongoing, silent holocaust'' in the Soviet Union.

title: ENDURING TRIPLE A AND A PAINFUL LOSS
description: The amenities are not up to major league standards, Jeff Kunkel said, but Triple A is still a cut above the 17-hour bus trips he made after signing his first professional contract with the Texas Rangers and beginning an apprenticeship in the lower reaches of baseball's farm system. Just two years after leaving Rider College in New Jersey as a No. 1 draft choice, Kunkel has already seen the best and worst that baseball has to offer and is waiting for another opportunity to become the Rangers' shortstop.

title: PROSECUTOR SEEKS DUTCH EVIDENCE IN PLOT ON POPE
description: The prosecutor in the trial here of eight men accused of conspiring to kill the Pope flew to the Netherlands today to seek information about a Turk arrested there last month with a weapon and a forged passport.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The case was quite rightly conducted as a medical matter. There was no crime.''

title: CITY STORES POST A SLIM SALES RISE
description: Sales in May at New York's City's largest department stores rose by an average of 1.1 percent from the period a year ago, continuing the disappointing trend that has been evident for almost a year, a monthly spot-check found last week.

title: FURS BY GALANOS START WITH MINK
description: The James Galanos fur show started off quietly enough, if you can call a black sheared mink coat sashed in red and collared in Persian lamb quiet. It emphasized mink, the workhorse of the fur wardrobes. Luminous pale mink and gleaming near-black mink. Mink with sable collars. Mink with chains dipping in front connecting metal buttons. Almost-ankle-length mink coats worn with wool trousers or flung open to show a knee-baring satin skirt. Mink so supple the coats could be belted without looking bulky.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ART OF THE CARIBEES The arrival of Columbus signaled not only the discovery of a new world for Europe but also the loss of an old one for the people who inhabited what are now known as the Americas. The developed civilizations of the Aztecs, the Incas and the Mayans were swept away in the tide of colonization. And the ancient traces of other peoples widely but more sparsely scattered through the hemisphere are even more difficult to come by.

title: Topics;   Empty Insults, and Pools Water on the Brain
description: City Hall, trying to cut New York City's water consumption to 1.1 billion gallons a day, about 200 million gallons below present levels, has ordered water-cooled air conditioning systems shut between 8 and 10 A.M.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SWEETNESS AND POWER. The Place of Sugar in Modern History. By Sidney W. Mintz. 274 pages. Illustrated. Viking. $20. BECAUSE the associations of sugar are predominantly pleasurable, most of us find it hard to grasp how significant a part it has played in the history of the past 300 or 400 years. Unlike iron, say, or gold or cotton or wheat, it somehow doesn't seem quite ''serious'' enough for a starring role. Yet it has sustained empires, its social influence and economic impact have been immense, and it has also been, as Sidney W. Mintz says, ''one of the massive demographic forces in world history,'' responsible for the uprooting, resettling and as often as not the enslaving of millions of people employed in its cultivation.

title: WEATHER ALERTS CITED AS CUTTING TOLL OF TWISTERS
description: A National Weather Service study team said yesterday that warnings by its forecasters and prompt action by local officials had minimized the death toll from tornadoes that killed 76 people in Ohio and Pennsylvania on May 31.

title: LEBANESE MILITIA AND U.N. FORCE AT A STANDOFF IN HOSTAGE DISPUTE
description: The hostage dispute between an Israeli-backed militia and the United Nations force in southern Lebanon remained deadlocked today. Twenty-one Finnish soldiers from the United Nations force are being held by the Israeli-backed militia, the South Lebanon Army, and 11 South Lebanon Army troops are in the hands of the Shiite militia known as Amal.

title: MAPPING TECHNIQUE PRODUCES IMAGE OF MAGMA CHAMBER NEAR YOSEMITE
description: Three-dimensional mapping of molten rock beneath the area east of Yosemite National Park in California has confirmed the existence there of a chamber filled with magma, or molten rock, that is at least eight miles wide and six miles deep. The aim was twofold: to assess the likelihood of volcanic eruptions there, near the Nevada border, and to evaluate the site's potential as an energy source.

title: Big Gap in May In Japan Trade
description: Japan rang up a $3.41 billion trade surplus with the United States in May, second only to April's record $3.46 billion, as Japanese car exports topped levels a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Bloomsday
description: Stately, plump and other-shaped Washingtonians are going to take turns reading Joyce's ''Ulysses,'' all of it, aloud, for two days and one night, starting June 16, which is Father's Day to some, Bloomsday to others, including the local theatrical impresario Herbert S. Guggenheim of Pleasant Dream Productions, who has arranged for a series of people to read the entire novel at Herb's on P Street NW, where the food offered will include some of Leopold's favorites, kidneys and liver and bacon and gorgonzola, while one of the readers is none other than Kevin Dowling, a third secretary of the Irish Embassy and, finally, Mollie Bloom's words will be spoken by the local actress Joan Durante, and yes they will yes Yes.

title: When the Gringos March Into Central America
description: To the Editor:

title: Kentucky Agency Bonds Are Priced
description: A $314.6 million issue of Kentucky Turnpike Authority bonds was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 9 1/4 percent for interest-bearing bonds due in 2008 through underwriters led by the Cranston Securities Company, Columbus, Ohio.

title: ICM NAMES INTERIM LEADERS
description: Lee Lamont and Marvin Schofer have been named executive vice presidents of ICM Artists Ltd. and are to share leadership of the prominent artists management company at least over the next few months.

title: The Lebanon Hostage Who Was Forgotten
description: To the Editor:

title: Army's Critic Shifting
description: One of the most prominent uniformed critics of how the Army fought the Vietnam War is retiring from the Army after 38 years, to become a writer for U.S. News & World Report.

title: CUOMO TERMS TAX PLAN 'A RIP-OFF,' NOT REFORM
description: Governor Cuomo told a Congressional hearing in Manhattan yesterday that President Reagan's tax-simplification plan was ''a rip-off dressed up as reform.''

title: Early Start for Redmen
description: St. John's, which reached the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Final Four last season, is expected to join the National Invitation Tournament's preseason event in the fall. ''It is a very good idea, but we have to go through proper channels,'' said Coach Lou Carnesecca. The new tournament will be divided into four regions, possibly with St. John's, Auburn, West Virgina and Navy playing at the East site in Hartford.

title: Death in Uganda Disputed
description: A rebel Uganda group accused the Uganda Army today of murdering a senior rebel officer sent to Kampala, the capital, in April as a peace envoy.

title: ARE SERVICE CONTRACTS WORTHWHILE?
description: A SERVICE contract for a computer is very much like a life insurance policy for its owner; one is betting against one's hopes that there will never be a need to take advantage of it.

title: 5 Children Drown In Closed Pool in Gary
description: Five children searching for frogs in a closed public swimming pool waded into the deep end and drowned as they tried in vain to climb the pool's slimy walls and floor, the police said.

title: EAGLETON SEEKS HEARINGS ON CBS TAKEOVER BID
description: Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri, plans to introduce legislation this week that would compel the Federal Communications Commission to hold extensive hearings on a bid by Ted Turner to take over CBS, an aide to the Senator said yesterday.

title: Charles Le Maire, Costumer For Broadway andHollywood
description: Charles Le Maire, a three-time Oscar-winning costume designer who also created wardrobes for Broadway musicals of Florenz Ziegfeld and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, died Saturday. He was 88 years old.

title: OEA INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SWEEPING INSURANCE CHANGES MAY INCREASE BUSINESS COSTS
description: The insurance industry has initiated sweeping changes that promise higher costs or less coverage for most American businesses and public agencies, insurance experts say.

title: SIZZLER RESTAURANTS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
ARMS TREATY: ISSUE PUT OFF
description: President Reagan's decision today to continue honoring the unratified 1979 arms limitation pact, despite purported Soviet violations, has set the stage for even tougher decisions on compliance later on.

title: Minstar Extends AMF Tender Bid
description: Minstar Inc., which is embroiled in a takeover battle with AMF Inc., said that it had extended the expiration date for its $23-a-share tender offer for 12 million shares, or 43 percent of AMF, to 5 P.M. today. Minstar said the offer was already oversubscribed, noting that about 15.9 million shares have been deposited, including 3.8 million tendered subject to guarantees of delivery.

title: Indian Dance Programs
description: Four forms of Indian dance will be performed in Festival of India, a weeklong celebration of Indian music, dance and theater that opens Sept. 10 at Alice Tully Hall.

title: A PUSH FOR PAY-PER-VIEW TV
description: The cable television industry feels under siege. It is facing growing competition for viewer attention from the boom in video cassette recorders, and as fewer new cable systems are built, it is having trouble wooing and holding on to new subscribers.

title: Treasury Securities Mixed
description: Interest rates on Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with rates rising for Treasury bills due in less than a year but falling slightly for longer-term notes and bonds.

title: Weinberger Holds Talks With Japanese Official
description: Defense Minister Koichi Kato of Japan discussed the defense of Pacific sea lanes around Japan and other issues today with Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, the Pentagon said.

title: C.&W. Gets Sterling Brands
description: Cunningham & Walsh, a Mickelberry company, has gotten a pair of assignments from the Sterling drug empire, for which it first started working in the early 1960's.

title: Dueling Budget Plans In Congress
description: The House approved freezing budget authority at its 1985 level and then allowed for an increase for inflation plus 3 percent in 1987 and 1988. The Senate allowed for an increase in budget authority in 1986 to cover inflation and then the same 3 percent increases in 1987 and 1988. In both cases, projected spending in 1986 increases because of the outlays to pay for contract commitments, especially on weapons systems, made in previous years. Over three years, the House plan reduces projected spending $22 billion more than the Senate. The House budget authority figure for 1985 reflects a special one-time pay absorption that is not counted in calculating the freeze level in 1986.

title: Eckerd Sues Dart On Stock Purchase
description: The Jack Eckerd Corporation said yesterday that it had filed a lawsuit seeking to stop the purchase of more of its stock by the Dart Group Corporation.

title: NEW LOANS NEAR FOR ARGENTINA
description: The International Monetary Fund and about a dozen countries prepared today to make more than $1.6 billion of credits available to Argentina, based on fresh austerity pledges expected from it.

title: CUBS TOP EXPOS; STREAK AT 5
description: Ryne Sandberg had a two-run single and Keith Moreland added a game-winning single tonight to highlight a three-run eighth inning that helped the Chicago Cubs defeat the Montreal Expos, 5-4, for their fifth consecutive victory.

title: ARTHRITIC MICE BRED AS NEW WINDOW INTO HUMAN DISEASE
description: MEDICAL researchers have found an experimental model they have long sought, a laboratory animal that naturally develops a disease resembling rheumatoid arthritis.

title: RICKOVER TELLS LEHMAN HE GAVE AWAY GIFTS
description: Hyman G. Rickover, the retired Navy admiral who was censured last month for accepting gifts from the General Dynamics Corporation, said in a letter released today that he had given away most of the gifts. He again denied that they had affected his duties as head of the Navy's nuclear submarine program.

title: Passing Career
description: The Jacksonville Bulls arrived Sunday evening for their game against the Generals last night, but, after checking into a hotel near Giants Stadium, Brian Sipe didn't stay long. Soon he was chatting with friends at a bar on Manhattan's East Side, where he bumped into a reporter he knew.

title: DOCTORS IN BRAZIL CITE MENGELE CLUE
description: Brazilian forensic experts studying human remains suspected to be those of the Nazi death camp doctor Josef Mengele said today that they had found a pelvic abnormality that could help identify the body.

title: 'AMICABLE' RESIGNATION BY COACHMAN PRESIDENT
description: C. Ray Johnson has resigned as president and chief operating officer of Coachmen Industries, a major producer of recreational vechicles. He cited philosophical differences with the company's chairman and chief executive officer, Thomas H. Corson.

title: ITALY AFTER THE SOCCER HORROR: SCATTERED ANTI-BRITISH DEEDS
description: British and Italian officials say they are concerned about scattered anti-British violence in Italy in the aftermath of a riot at a soccer match in Brussels 12 days ago that left 38 people dead and hundreds injured.

title: Long at Shortstop
description: When Shawon Dunston was demoted to the minor leagues for more seasoning not long ago, Larry Bowa seemed to have clear sailing ahead as the Chicago Cubs' regular shortstop.

title: PANSOPHIC SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Hong Kong Bank Charges
description: The police said today that a fourth official of the Overseas Trust Bank, which failed last week, had been accused of conspiracy to defraud.

title: NEWSLETTER SETBACK FOR S.E.C.
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Securities and Exchange Commission had no authority to block the publication of stock market newsletters on the basis of past misconduct by a newsletter's publisher.

title: REAGAN SAYS U.S. WILL KEEP ABIDING BY '79 ARMS PACT
description: President Reagan, saying he was prepared to ''go the extra mile'' to obtain mutual restraints in nuclear weapons, formally announced today that the United States would continue to honor provisions of the second strategic arms limitation treaty of 1979.

title: MUCKRAKER AT WORK
description: MICHAEL M. THOMAS has become something of a pariah among New York's powerful upper echelons. His magazine articles are said to have indulged in gratuitously cruel people-bashing, and enthusiasm for his best-selling financial novels has been underwhelming.

title: Firebreak Is Widened Around Blaze in Florida
description: Hundreds of firefighters used bulldozers today to widen a 50-mile firebreak around a blaze burning on 26,500 acres of timberland and brush in Florida's Panhandle.

title: ITALIANS VOTE AGAINST A PROPOSAL FOR PEGGING PAY TO COST OF LIVING
description: Italian voters have rejected a Communist-sponsored proposal designed to overturn a key element of the Government's economic policy, results of a referendum today and Sunday showed.

title: Topics;   Empty Insults, and Pools Name-Calling
description: During his later years as F.B.I. Director, J. Edgar Hoover seemed to mistrust sociologists and called them ''so-called sociologists.'' A listener once gibed that sociologists are so called because that's what they are, but for Mr. Hoover, the modifier made the term truly pejorative.

title: DESPITE HEAD START 'ACHIEVEMENT GAP' PERSISTS FOR POOR
description: THE historic goal of preschool and remedial programs for students from low-income families has been to close the achievement gap separating them from children of higher-income families.

title: Ketchum President In New York Named
description: Thom Miller, 36 years old, has been running the Ketchum Advertising/ New York for about three years as executive vice president and chief executive officer. Well, top management at Ketchum Communications down in Pittsburgh has finally loosened up and bestowed the New York president's title on him.

title: PREP SCHOOL NEWSPAPER SPARKS NICARAGUA DEBATE
description: For the 600 students at the Kent School, the debate over American aid to Nicaraguan rebels has taken on special significance.

title: Cyclone Death Toll Climbs
description: The bodies of three more victims of last month's cyclone have been found, bringing the total recovered to 2,540, the authorities said today. Some 4,882 are officially listed as missing from the storm on the Bay of Bengal on May 24 to 25.

title: LIFE SENTENCES WITHOUT PAROLE GAIN IN ALBANY
description: A bill that would allow some murderers to be sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole was passed by the Assembly tonight after five hours of impassioned debate.

title: Revco Charge
description: Revco D.S. Inc. said it expects to take a write-down of about $35 million, or $18 million after taxes, on video game cartridges, computer peripherals and other merchandise for the fourth quarter ended June 1.

title: Color This Party . . .
description: Does ''sky blue'' mean that Liberal hopes are pie in the sky? Could there be a more rock-ribbed color than ''granite'' for Conservatives? And will ''cherry'' assuage Republicans who would not want to be called pink - or, worse, red?

title: ITT's Future Seems Unclear
description: LAST month the ITT Corporation had a showdown with its chief antagonist, Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor. The scene was the annual meeting of the company's shareholders in Savannah, Ga., and little was at stake except publicity.

title: Now, the Ultimate Threat: 'Skunk Wars'
description: To the Editor:

title: GENERAL CINEMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,047,000 for the quarter and $3,000 for the 6 months.

title: McGuigan Hailed
description: Barry McGuigan flew home to Belfast, Northern Ireland, and was given the sort of welcome reserved for war heroes, after taking the World Boxing Association featherweight title from Eusebio Pedroza in London. He told the enthusiastic well-wishers at the airport that he enjoyed ''making people happy, and if I have managed to do that, it is terrific.''

title: SECURITY TAG SYSTYEMS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
INVESTIGATORS TURN ATTENTION TO MENGELE FAMILY CONTACTS
description: Growing indications that the son and perhaps other relatives of Josef Mengele may have kept in touch with the fugitive Nazi doctor over the years have focused the attention of investigators on the tight-lipped Mengele family.

title: Company Fitness Programs
description: HEALTH care has become a growth industry, and joggers and bicyclists are everywhere. When trends such as these converge, interesting job vistas can be spotted - in this case in fitness programs for company employees, sometimes known as ''wellness'' programs.

title: HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,078,000 for the quarter and $1,883,000 for the 9 months.

title: STEIN JOINS RACE TO BE PRESIDENT OF CITY COUNCIL
description: Citing his 17-year record in public office, Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan yesterday formally announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for City Council President.

title: LAST ISRAELI COMBAT OUTFITS PULL OUT
description: Israel withdrew the last of its combat forces from southern Lebanon today, leaving behind an undisclosed number of patrols, advisers and observers, Israeli military sources said.

title: AUTO RACE PLAN FOR QUEENS GETS 2 NEW SETBACKS
description: A plan to build a Grand Prix auto racing track in a Queens park and hold the first race there in September was put in doubt yesterday when a national auto racing official said he did not think that the park could be readied in time and a city agency put off a vote on the proposal.

title: Iran Attacks Baghdad; Iraqi Planes Bomb Cities
description: An explosion rocked Baghdad today as Iran reported launching a missile strike on the Iraqi capital, the third such attack in the last 16 days.

title: A Closing by Swift
description: The Swift Independent Packing Company said that it would close its Hereford, Tex., beef plant on Saturday.

title: First Interstate Rejects Marine
description: The First Interstate Corporation of Wisconsin said that its board had rejected an offer from the Marine Corporation to acquire 90.9 percent of First Interstate in an exchange of stock valued at about $111 million.

title: Driver in Accident That Killed A Times Editor Goes to Prison
description: The driver of an automobile that killed Seymour Peck, an editor of The New York Times Book Review and the paper's former culture editor, shortly after midnight New Year's Eve, surrendered yesterday to begin a prison sentence of one to three years, the Manhattan District Attorney's office said.

title: Big Board View Of Allis Move
description: The New York Stock Exchange has advised the Allis-Chalmers Corporation that, according to the exchange's interpretation of its shareholder approval rules, the company's conversion of debt to equity last month should have had prior shareholder approval. Allis-Chalmers said that the exchange would ''technically commence delisting proceedings,'' but that its stock would continue to trade while the exchange completed a review of its shareholder approval policies.

title: WHY WE MUST NEGOTIATE SPACE WEAPONS AT GENEVA
description: To the Editor:

title: $41 Million Issues For Dallas County
description: A $41 million financing for Dallas County, Tex., was offered yesterday through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.

title: DEVELOPING 'CRISIS' SEEN IN COSTLY TREND TOWARD BID MACHINES
description: BIG machines that push back the frontiers of science are becoming so large and expensive that they are starting to overwhelm laboratory budgets, distort the process of project evaluation by the Federal Government and threaten the pace of progress, according to science policy experts.

title: OPERA: 'RING' FINALE IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: A great deal has been made, while the San Francisco Opera's new ''Ring'' has been unfolding, of the effort Nikolaus Lehnhoff's production makes to return to staging ideas that we associate with Wagner's own period. Horned helmets, sets inspired by 19th-century painters, a palpable dragon, and so on. To an extent, that is true, though as the final work in the cycle, ''Gotterdammerung,'' showed on Saturday evening, the director's vision is anything but constricted to traditional Wagnerian practices.

title: AGE, PAY CELTICS CONCERNS
description: The Los Angeles Lakers boarded the team bus yesterday for the airport and their trip to the White House, with a small contingent of autograph seekers and diehard Boston Celtic fans looking on.

title: DRESS BARN INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Crown Zellerbach Corp., the San Francisco-based paper products company, said that 77 percent of its shareholders had approved management's slate of board members, according to the final report from election inspectors.

title: Phone Link to London
description: British Telecom P.L.C., once Government-held and now publicly owned, announced today that it would create a new ''hot line'' telephone link between businesses in London and New York. The service will be operated in partnership with TRT International Inc. of the United States.

title: Do-It-Yourself Vision Test
description: British scientists have invented a device that makes it possible for viewers to check their own vision.

title: Required Reading;   Dropping In on Reagan
description: Excerpts from a recent issue of The Busby Papers, a political analysis by Horace W. Busby, a former aide to President Johnson:

title: U.N. Aide Going to Israel
description: Brian E. Urquhart, Under Secretary for Special Political Affairs, will arrive in Jerusalem on Tuesday as part of a United Nations effort to win the release of the 21 Finnish soldiers.

title: MENGELE'S SON TO BREAK SILENCE ON FATHER'S FATE
description: Rolf Mengele, son of the Nazi death camp doctor Josef Mengele, will issue a statement soon about his father's fate, breaking the family's longstanding refusal to discuss Dr. Mengele's disappearance, his secretary said today.

title: INDUSTRY FEARS A SUMMER FILM GLUT
description: For Hollywood, summer begins during the last week of May, when the first summer movies trickle into theaters. This year, summer will bring a flood - 45 films, up 25 percent from last year -and the movie industry is afraid that for many movies, the chance of box-office success will be washed away in the deluge.

title: A KEY ITEM IN HOUSING PLAN IS RESISTED IN ALBANY
description: A key element of a new plan to build and rehabilitate 75,000 apartments in New York City was described by legislative leaders today as unlikely to pass this year.

title: Metro-North Fails Injury-Claim Test
