description: An undercover investigation using a bogus doctor, Donald Mallard, found that the Metro-North Commuter Railroad did not adequately check injury claims before settling them, according to a report released yesterday.

title: Series Rainout
description: The championship College World Series game scheduled for tonight between Miami and Texas was postponed because of rain. The game was rescheduled for Tuesday night at Rosenblatt Stadium. The Hurricanes beat Texas, 2-1, Sunday night to force a showdown in the double-elimination event.

title: PANEL SUGGESTS ROLE OF CYCLAMATE IN CANCER MAY BE AN INDIRECT ONE
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 -

title: Lotus to Drop Visicalc Sheet
description: The Lotus Development Corporation, whose best-selling 1-2-3 computerized spreadsheet displaced the pioneer in the field, Visicalc, said that it had decided to end production of the Visicalc program.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: KNITWEAR goes in and out of fashion. Sometimes it takes a back seat to woven materials, but with this year's return to narrower, more figure-hugging clothes, knits are in the spotlight.

title: P. Peter Sheppe Dies; Executive of Time Inc.
description: P. Peter Sheppe, the corporate secretary and a vice president of Time Inc., died Saturday in New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 52 years old and lived in Scarsdale.

title: Administration Rejects T.W.A. Plea on Icahn
description: The Reagan Administration refused today to get involved in Carl C. Icahn's hostile takeover bid for Trans World Airlines, saying it did not want to be drawn into an airline management dispute.

title: HEART PATIENT RECOVERING
description: Murray P. Haydon, the artificial heart patient who suffered a mild stroke last week, now spends less time on a breathing support device than he did before the stroke and has recovered fully, a spokesman at Humana Hospital Audubon here said today.

title: AN OUSTED RUSSIAN APPEARS IN PRINT
description: Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, who was ousted last September as Soviet Chief of Staff, has reappeared in print, having written a book urging vigilance against the United States.

title: HARPER & ROW PUBLISHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,878,000 for the quarter and $1,162,000 for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,137,000.

title: WEST POINT-PEPPERELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 25
ADVANCE CIRCUITS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 25
PRESBYTERIANS CONSIDER SHIFT IN STAND FOR ABORTION RIGHTS
description: The Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.), whose member churches voted to support abortion rights before the Supreme Court did in 1973, is to consider a serious challenge to that stand at its annual convention here.

title: GANDHI, DUE IN U.S. TODAY, STILL HAS PROBLEMS AT HOME
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, due in the United States on Tuesday, continues to enjoy popularity at home. But some of his associates are frustrated at the slow pace of progress in solving India's problems.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CALIFORNIA (AL) - Designated for release or assignment Tommy John, pitcher.

title: MIDEAST TALKS WILL BE USEFUL ONLY...
description: Though prospects for Middle East peace talks seem to have brightened since President Reagan's meeting with King Hussein of Jordan, a big obstacle is Israel's refusal to sit at the table with the Palestine Liberation Organization - a moral stance that defeats Israel's own long-term objectives.

title: Why We Must Negotiate Space Weapons at Geneva
description: To the Editor:

title: BIGGER CUTS URGED IN SENATE BUDGET
description: Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, asked the Senate today for additional cuts in Federal spending as House and Senate conferees prepared to meet Tuesday to try to assemble a compromise 1986 budget.

title: Big Board, Union Meet
description: A Federal mediator, Rosemary LeBoeuf, called a meeting last night between representatives of the union representing trading floor workers and the Big Board in hopes of averting a strike today.

title: Help for the Teen-Age Recession
description: Though overall employment has risen handsomely for most of the last two years, employment among teen-agers has barely risen at all. That's the strongest argument for the American Conservation Corps, once again beginning to work its way through Congress.

title: METS' RALLY COMES TOO LATE
description: By itself, the Mets' ninth inning wasn't so bad. With two down, Gary Carter hit a home run over the left-field fence. Then Danny Heep singled and John Christensen hit the next pitch over the left-field fence for his first home run in the big leagues.

title: SEAGRAM CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes dividend income from E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. of $37,568,000 for the latest quarter and $33,413,000 for year-earlier period.

title: FATIGUE FACTOR PLAYED DOWN
description: In the 16 years since a National Basketball Association champion has successfully defended its crown, teams have blamed injuries, trades and even inflated egos for their demise.

title: Lyme Disease and Dogs
description: The bacteria that cause Lyme disease, the tick-borne infection that sometimes causes severe arthritis in humans, may infect dogs as well. Scientists of the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station at West Haven have detected antibodies to the bacteria in more than a quarter of dogs tested in regions of the state where the disease in humans is more commonly found.

title: OLDEST ACTING SCHOOL FETES ITS 100TH BIRTHDAY
description: It was, after all, the centennial gala of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts, the oldest acting school in the English-speaking world, so why not a few, or even more than a few, touches of glamor?

title: AN OUTFIELD PILEUP WRECKS THE METS
description: They call them ''the breaks of the game,'' those freakish occurrences that often determine the outcome of a game. A ground ball hits a pebble and skips over a fielder's outstretched glove. A long fly ball hits the foul pole and caroms fair for a game-winning home run. On Sunday at Shea Stadium, Terry Pendleton, the St. Louis Cardinals' third baseman, was the beneficiary of such an uncanny play, and it helped the Cardinals to an 8-2 victory over the Mets in the second game of a doubleheader.

title: THERMAL PROFILES reports earnings for Year to March 31
Winning Writer From Alternative School
description: After trying and failing at two public high schools, Aimee Rivera enrolled at an alternative school in Queens for troubled students and emerged as an award-winning poet and playwright.

title: Another Bumper Wheat Crop Is Forecast for U.S.
description: The Agriculture Department forecast today another bumper wheat crop for the nation this year and another increase in grain production worldwide.

title: Jury Being Picked For Stewart Trial
description: Jury selection began in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday for the trial of six transit police officers charged in connection with the death of Michael Stewart, a 25-year-old Brooklyn man who died in September 1983 after what prosecutors have said was a beating by transit officers.

title: EIL INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Stocks Edge Down in Slow Session
description: Stock prices generally fell yesterday as trading volume tumbled to a two-week low. Only blue-chip issues escaped from the retrenchment that began late last week.

title: COACH WHO GOES BY BOOK REACHES TITLE GAME
description: A veteran lineup, with a senior at every position but designated hitter, started for Cardinal Hayes last Thursday, when the Cardinals defeated Mount St. Michael, 5-2, for the Catholic High Schools' Athletic Association baseball title at Yankee Stadium.

title: Varying Views Of Heads-Up Play
description: This is another story about Babe Herman. In its rudimentary form, it started circulating in the late 1920's, and it survives to this very day, having long ago become a cherished part of the lore that makes baseball so special.

title: ISRAEL PROPOSES 5-POINT PLAN AS ALTERNATIVE TO HUSSEIN'S
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres proposed an alternative today to King Hussein's recent peace initiative, offering a five-point plan that he said would lead to an international conference on the Middle East within three months.

title: WALKER SETS RUSHING MARK
description: Herschel Walker broke through three tacklers and ran away from a fourth on a spectacular 55-yard run for a touchdown tonight in the third quarter. That was the first of two big plays for the Generals, who defeated the Jacksonville Bulls, 31-24, and qualified for the United States Football League playoffs.

title: FRIEND OF SPY SUSPECT LOSES JOB
description: A close friend of John A. Walker Jr., who has been charged with espionage, has been dismissed from her job at the Norfolk Police Department, her attorney said tonight.

title: WHERE THE CAPITAL IS DOWN HOME
description: Each morning in the nation's capital, in the elegant dining rooms of the fine hotels, the Hay Adams, the Mayflower and the Jefferson, the power brokers can be observed meeting over grapefruit and croissants, speed-reading the newspapers for their required daily dose of new information.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municiapl Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FROST & SULLIVAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
MANTLE'S SWING WORKS IN BOOTH
description: Dizzy Dean never recovered from his scrape with the English language. When the fastballer-turned-announcer described someone who ''slood'' into second base, teachers' associations were so irate that good ol' Diz was finally dismissed as a baseball announcer.

title: COURT RULING CALLED BLOW TO BIG BANKS
description: The nation's biggest banks were dealt a blow yesterday by the Supreme Court's decision to authorize regional interstate banking, a ruling that allows banks in many states to merge while allowing them to keep the biggest banks out. Ultimately, it could lead to a fundamental restructuring of the American banking industry.

title: SIHANOUK URGES THE U.S. TO HELP SET UP COALITION
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk appealed to the United States today to use its ''great influence and prestige'' to help Cambodia establish a coalition government of Communists and non-Communists under international guarantees.

title: SAMPLE BAZELON VIEWS
description: The right-wrong test, which considers knowledge or reason alone, is an inadequate guide to mental responsibility for criminal behavior. An accused is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act was the product of mental disease or mental defect.

title: EXPERTS TESTIFY THEY URGED ALARMS FOR HAUNTED HOUSE
description: Two fire-prevention engineers testified today that after six successive inspections, they recommended that smoke alarms or sprinklers be installed in the Haunted Castle at the Great Adventure amusement park.

title: West German G.N.P.
description: The gross national product of West Germany fell 1 percent in this year's first quarter from the last quarter of 1984, the Government said today. Severe winter weather was blamed. The G.N.P., however, was up four-tenths of 1 percent from a year earlier.

title: VON BULOW JURY ISSUES ACQUITTAL ON ALL CHARGES
description: Claus von Bulow was acquitted today of twice trying to kill his wealthy wife, Martha, with insulin injections that the state had charged were the cause of her falling into two comas.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary on May 21 of John Martin, dance critic of The New York Times from 1927 to 1962, omitted his survivors. They are Albert L. Lloyd, a nephew, and Elizabeth A. Lloyd, a grandniece.

title: Architecture Quarterly Wants to Grow in U.S.
description: Admittedly, architectural development in the third world is not everybody's intellectual cup of tea, which is probably why a magazine called Mimar that covers the subject has but 1,700 circulation in the United States out of a worldwide circulation of 6,700.

title: Private Insurance For Banks Debated
description: Despite the failures of privately insured savings and loan institutions in Maryland and Ohio, a number of conservative thinkers continue to urge private deposit insurance for both commercial and thrift institutions.

title: Municipal Bond Futures Will Be Traded Today
description: Trading in municipal bond futures contracts will begin today at the Chicago Board of Trade, amid widespread predictions that the new contract will attract heavy trading from securities dealers and speculators.

title: Cuomo's Countermove
description: People in Washington who think a lot about national politics assume that Governor Cuomo of New York is going to make a grab for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1988. So they are not surprised when the Governor speaks out on a national issue, or chooses to joust with Republican ideologues like Patrick Buchanan, the White House communications wizard.

title: JUDGE TO RULE IF CYANIDE OR BAD HEART WAS KILLER
description: Was Stefan Golab murdered by the ''callousness'' of the company he worked for, as prosecutors said in closing arguments today? Or did he suffer a heart attack, as the defense contended?

title: LORIMAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-After and extraordinary charge of $2,550,000.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 11, 1985

title: FOTOMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
The U.N. Today
description: June 11, 1985 SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on Namibia at 10:30 A.M.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 11, 1985

title: An Alternative To the Bypass
description: HEART disease, by far the leading cause of American deaths, cost employers at least $2.1 billion last year just counting health-benefit payments for heart bypass surgery. And that is only the beginning. Many of those patients who return to work, after at least 10 weeks of rest, are still weak. The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company reported last month that only 11 percent of its employees who had a bypass at age 55 or under were still actively employed five years later.

title: U.S. Seeks Protective Order
description: The Government asked Federal District Judge Alexander Harvey 2d today to issue a protective order in the Walker spy case to prevent the disclosure of sensitive documents. Under the order, anyone from the defense would need clearance from the court security officer before getting access to classified Navy documents.

title: Auto Renters Lured With Lower Prices
description: Travelers to many domestic destinations can expect to pay lower rates for rental cars this summer than they did last summer. Price cuts by the country's major car rental agencies reflect, experts say, both the increasing competitiveness of the $3.9 billion industry and the growing importance of the leisure travel market.

title: SOUTHERN BAPTISTS MOVE TO HEAL RIFT
description: Presidents of 37 state Baptist conventions agreed to a 10-point peace plan today that is aimed at ending the doctrinal and political strife in the Southern Baptist Convention, the nation's largest Protestant denomination.

title: TRANSLATING BASEBALL INTO CHINESE
description: When C. W. Post's baseball team opened a six-game exhibition series with Chinese squads here last week, something happened that the American players didn't expect: They lost.

title: Texas Instruments
description: The Navy has awarded Texas Instruments Inc. a $462.1 million contract to make more than 1,500 high-speed anti-radar missiles, the company announced. The latest contract follows a $60 million contract received in March. The program could have a total value of more than $5 billion, Pentagon officials said.

title: SHIRLEY RESURFACES, WINS
description: Perhaps it only seemed as if Billy Martin and Bob Shirley were not enjoying the best of relationships. Maybe it was just a coincidence that Shirley became a forgotten man the day Martin became the Yankees' manager six weeks ago.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: WALESA TELLS POLISH COURT 3 DISSIDENTS ARE INNOCENT
description: Lech Walesa, wearing a T-shirt imprinted with the banned name of his outlawed Solidarity labor union, testified in Gdansk today that three of his colleagues on trial for fomenting disorder were not engaged in illegal activities when they attended a meeting he convened in February.

title: Chess: First '85 Interzonal Tourney Won by Yusupov, a Russian
description: Artur Yusupov, a 25-year-old Russian grandmaster, won the first of the 1985 Interzonal Tournaments, which comprise the second stage of qualifications to challenge for the world championship, in Tunis, Tunisia. Yusupov's winning score was 11 1/2-4 1/2.

title: Alfa Romeo Campaign:Phase 2
description: FOR over a year, Alfa Romeo North America, the importer of the Italian motor cars, has been pushing the product with some unusually graphic ads that gave much attention to the logotype and to ''Alfissimo!'' - a word created for the occasion. It was supposed to mean great to look at and tremendous to drive.

title: STATE MEDIATION CHIEF APPOINTS HOTEL STRIKE PANEL
description: The chairman of the State Mediation Board named a five-member panel of private citizens yesterday to recommend terms for a settlement of the 11-day-old New York City hotel strike. The panel will have subpoena power but its decisions will not be binding.

title: ABC'S 'SAM' IS INSPIRED BY AN ERICA JONG BOOK
description: WHENEVER you see the word ''pilot'' in the program listings these days, it can usually be interpreted as ''stay away.'' These are the shows that did not make the fall schedule, and the reasons are generally obvious. This being television, however, there are exceptions. Once in a while there is a rejected pilot that looks at least as promising as those that were accepted for production. Take, for instance, ''Sam,'' a likable mutt of a sitcom that can be seen on ABC this evening at 9:30 o'clock.

title: ARTIST IN GREENWICH VILLAGE FOUND STRANGLED IN HER LOFT
description: A 39-year-old artist active in community and cultural affairs was found strangled late Sunday night in her Greenwich Village loft, the police said.

title: Keeping the Arms Lid On, Barely
description: President Reagan has reached the right decision in postponing a clear American violation of the SALT II missile limits next fall. He will ''plan'' to deactivate and dismantle one old-fashioned Poseidon missile submarine when a more potent Trident goes to sea. That buys six months for arms control negotiations. It also buys the time the President would need to prove that the United States is not primarily to blame if they should fail.

title: Tandem Products
description: Tandem Computer Inc. said it was introducing five products that would allow customers to use Tandem networks to link users of a variety of incompatible personal computers, work stations, terminals, facsimile devices and local area networks. It said one new product was for electronic mail, filing and distribution, while another links International Business Machines Corporation PC's into Tandem distributed networks. Two products are for text editing and formating, and the fifth is for moving images and pictures electronically.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a technical error, a front-page picture in some copies yesterday, with an article about the detention of a French colonel in Lebanon, appeared without a caption. The picture showed Gen. Antoine Lahd, commander of the South Lebanon Army, whose forces seized Col. Jean-Michel Blemdjian.

title: FILM SOCIETY PAYS TRIBUTE TO FELLINI
description: ''It's no longer a name, but a word,'' said Donald Sutherland. ''It's in the dictionary.''

title: STONEHENGE PLAN MAY RESTRICT ACCESS
description: British archeologists are planning radical new measures to improve the preservations and display of Stonehenge, Europe's premier prehistoric monument, whose increasingly squalid state has been an embarrassment for years.

title: A SOVIET CRAFT IS SET TO DROP VENUS PROBES
description: A Soviet spacecraft hurtling toward a rendezvous with Halley's Comet today approached the planet Venus and the first of its appointed tasks. If all goes as planned, it will deploy a capsule tomorrow containing an atmospheric balloon probe and a landing craft. Soviet officials have called the atmospheric tests, which were developed together with French scientists, ''fundamentally new experiments.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: The veteran Czechoslovak defenseman, Miroslav Dvorak, is retiring from the Philadelphia Flyers, General Manager Bobby Clarke said.

title: Books: Fibs and Foibles
description: VITAL LIES, SIMPLE TRUTHS: The Psychology of Self-Deception. By Daniel Goleman. 287 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95. JUST as the eye has a blind spot of which we are ordinarily unaware, says Daniel Goleman, so the mind has blind spots: we blank out - we ignore or forget -certain kinds of experience and are not even aware of doing so. The eye's blind spot is a minor oddity; the mind's blind spots are anything but. For the ways in which we hide painful, anxiety-provoking or embarrassing truths from ourselves profoundly affect our personalities and behavior.

title: Peete Out of Open
description: Calvin Peete, plagued by back problems for much of the year, withdrew from the United States Open, which begins Thursday. After completing last week's Westchester Classic with two rounds of 75, he said he planned to see his physical therapist in Washington.

title: FAILED COAST UNIT GIVEN A MANAGER
description: James C. Schmidt, the president and managing officer of the Great American First Savings Bank of San Diego, has 28 years of experience in the thrift industry, and every year of it will probably come in handy during the next few weeks.

title: U.S. CALLS 11 TOXIC AIR POLLUTANTS BIGGER THREAT INDOORS THAN OUT
description: Eleven common toxic air pollutants pose a greater hazard in an average home than they do in the air around the plants where they are produced, a new study by the Environmental Protection Agency has reported.

title: F.A.A. Says 2 Pilots Used Radios for Harassment
description: The Government has begun action against two pilots who it says illegally used their radios ''to harass nonstriking United Airlines pilots.'' The enforcement action could result in loss of the pilots' licenses or more severe penalties.

title: Burford's Own Case
description: There is a clear logic involved in the invitation of Anne McGill Burford to speak tomorrow at a meeting of the Senior Executives Association of the Environmnetal Protection Agency. Mrs. Burford is officially gone from Government environment circles, but not forgotten. In 1983, she was forced to resign as the agency's administrator in the midst of charges of mismanagement of Federal toxic waste removal programs.

title: ZACCARO REALTY LICENSE LIFTED
description: The State of New York has suspended the real-estate broker's license of John A. Zaccaro for 90 days, effective Aug. 1, officials said yesterday.

title: MAGAZINES FOR CHILDREN ADDRESS SERIOUS TOPICS
description: SIX years ago a group of history buffs created Cobblestone: The History Magazine for Young People, published monthly for 8- to 14-year-olds. One year later, Cobblestone Publishing Inc., in Peterborough, N.H., started a quarterly called Classical Calliope: The Muses' Magazine for Youth. Last month it added a teacher manual, Cobblestone Companion. With history and the classics well served, anthropologists recently became envious and persuaded the publishers to create a new magazine, Faces: The Magazine About People.

title: UAL PLANS PENSION ASSET MOVE
description: UAL Inc., adding to its protections against an unwanted takeover, today announced a plan to recapture about $962 million in ''excess assets'' of United Airlines employee pension plans.

title: SOFTWARE FOR SMALL-SCALE PUBLISHING
description: I HAVE often wondered how many writers started small neighborhood newspapers in their youth. It sometimes seems as if almost all of us did.

title: Padre Gets Clearance
description: Alan Wiggins, the San Diego Padre second baseman, was declared ''ready to resume play from a medical standpoint'' yesterday by a panel reviewing his drug problems. But the team president, Ballard Smith, stood by his decision not to reinstate Wiggins this season.

title: AN 8TH AMERICAN IS KIDNAPPED BY BEIRUT GUNMEN
description: The dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut was kidnapped by unidentified gunmen Sunday night as he drove from the Beirut airport.

title: Border Dispute Draws Indian Troops to Area
description: Paramilitary troops were deployed today at the border between two states in northeast India. Recent clashes between rival police forces there have left 50 dead and scores wounded.

title: People
description: Koichi Mizuno has been named president of Dentsu Inc., New York.

title: $100 Deposit for a Wreck
description: Every year, 3,000 stolen and abandoned cars are dumped in city parks, usually in the dead of night, making towing a major responsibility of the Parks and Recreation Department.

title: PANEL ON PBS DEBATES PRESS ROLE DURING WAR
description: ''THE MILITARY AND THE MEDIA: The Correspondent Under Fire'' gives us distinguished journalists, former Government officials and military men in a debate: How should the press cover a war? It is a rich, ripe question, never satisfactorily answered on the program tonight. The debate, which will continue next Tuesday and on June 25, will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock.

title: Tommy John's Exit
description: Tommy John was designated for release or assignment by the California Angels yesterday. John, who turned age 42 last month, had a 2-4 record and a 4.70 earned-run average.

title: FROM ONE GARDEN TO ANOTHER
description: On Sunday, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar was not happy to find out the Lakers were not going home right away. His head extending high above the crowd of reporters, he asked a team official, ''Aw, man, why not?''

title: Fluor-McDonnell
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it and the Fluor Corporation had signed an agreement to jointly seek airport projects in China. It said that Fluor China would join McDonnell Douglas China Inc. to pursue all phases of airport projects from planning a complete new facility to designing and supervising improvements at existing sites. It said that the work would include feasibility studies, engineering and design and construction management.

title: Harry Mayrock, 67, Chairman Of M. Fortunoff Store Chain
description: Harry Mayrock, chairman of the M. Fortunoff of Westbury Corporation, the department-store chain, died Saturday at his home in Old Westbury, L.I. He was 67 years old. Born in Brooklyn, Mr. Mayrock was a founder of the Mayrock Silver Company and joined the Fortunoff family company after his marriage to Marjorie Fortunoff.

title: IN CANADA'S WEST, PIONEERS RELIVE AN OLD ANGUISH
description: A few years ago, an armed forces colonel came around to propose that Archie Nicolas and his neighbors join in re-enacting the battle of Batoche, which ended the Northwest Rebellion of 1885. It was the last battle in which Canadians fought and killed each other, ''I advised him against it,'' said Mr. Nicolas, whose great-grandfather fought on the losing side. ''I said, 'Do you want to revive the whole thing? There's still a lot of bitter feelings here.' ''

title: MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY DETAILS OFFER TO INDIAN BOARD
description: The American Museum of Natural History will offer $7.5 million a year to help operate the Museum of the American Indian if the two museums agree to merge, according to Thomas D. Nicholson, the director of the Natural History museum.

title: GROWING UP IN SWIMSUIT BUSINESS
description: Most women worry too much about how they look in a swimsuit - when they go to a beach or a pool they should concentrate on having fun.

title: New ITT Sale Of Europe Assets
description: The ITT Corporation, continuing its sweeping divestiture program, said that it planned to sell about $100 million more of its European holdings within a year.

title: EDGAR SCHMUED
description: Edgar Schmued, chief designer of the P-51 Mustang fighter plane that was credited with destroying 5,000 enemy aircraft in World War II, died here June 1.

title: BARD AND BOTSTEIN: A COLLEGE SUCCESS
description: When Ann E. Lewinson, a junior at Bard College, wanted someone to look over a paper she had written on Hegel's philosophy, she thought immediately of Leon Botstein - who happens to be the president of the college.

title: I.B.M.-NIPPON COMPUTER LINK
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, apparently seeking to augment its role in Japan, has reached an agreement with Nippon Telegraph and Telephone that allows users of Japan's computer networks to communicate with I.B.M. machines, a Nippon official said yesterday.

title: Bob Prince, 68, Broadcaster For the Pittsburgh Pirates
description: Bob Prince, the voice of the Pittsburgh Pirates for nearly three decades and one of baseball's best-known play-by-play announcers, died today of cancer. He was 68 years old.

title: 2D AERIAL SURVEILLANCE CASE ACCEPTED
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Federal Government can arrange for aerial surveillance of an industrial plant, to check for pollution, without first obtaining a search warrant.

title: ARBITRARY ARBITRATION
description: To the Editor:

title: JOHN E. PANCOAST
description: John E. Pancoast, former director of the Portland (Me.) Museum of Art, died of a kidney disease Saturday at the Maine Medical Center in Portland.

title: SHREWD DEFENSE ATTORNEY: THOMAS PHILLIP PUCCIO
description: When public prosecutors switch to private law practice, they often increase their incomes handsomely while decreasing their public exposure. For Thomas P. Puccio, however, this has been only partly true.

title: Latest Thing in Trucks
description: In Washington there is always a rush to put a new Government catch-phrase to work in the private sector. Yesterday a truck hauling a load of dirt along MacArthur Boulevard in Northwest Washington bore upon its side the company name ''Star Wars Evac.''

title: SPOKESMAN FOR LIBERALS WATCHES TIDE FLOW OUT
description: David L. Bazelon sat by a window that looks out on the Capitol Dome, where praise and scorn for his rulings once echoed, and talked about what has made him tick as a judge.

title: Two Faces of Poland
description: General Jaruzelski's Warsaw regime speaks softly to the West of amnesties and reconciliation. To Poles, that same regime constantly speaks with the big stick of repression.

title: Bridge: Overcall of One No-Trump Can Be Dangerous Venture
description: A player who opens one no-trump vulnerable and finds himself left in that contract with a worthless dummy is likely to fail by several hundred points. He could not know that he would have been better off if he had passed with his 17 or so high-card points and is entitled to some sympathy.

title: JUDGE NULLIFIES COHALAN OREDR ON ATOM PLANT
description: A state judge today voided an order by the Suffolk County Executive directing the county to participate in emergency evacuation planning for the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Heating Oil Prices Hit Lowest Level Since '78
description: Heating oil futures prices slumped in thin trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Prices for August deliveries fell below 67 cents, the lowest level for heating oil contracts since 1978.

title: MADISON APPOINTS NEW CHIEF
description: Madison Resources Inc., an exploration and oil producing company, said yesterday that Stanley R. Rawn Jr. had been named chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Nuclear Weapon Test Is Set
description: A major nuclear weapon test with an explosive force equivalent to that of 20,000 to 150,000 tons of TNT has been scheduled for 6 A.M. Wednesday at the Nevada test site.

title: Turks Debating New Bill To Extend Police Power
description: Turkey's Parliament began debating a bill today to give the police sweeping new powers.

title: 100 YEARS AND TONS OF TAFFY LATER...
description: IT'S gooey and chewy and excessively sweet.

title: 'THE LOST WEEKEND' ALBUM
description: IT'S a rock-and-roll tradition.

title: WALKER'S EX-PARTNER SAYS AGENCY USED LIE TESTS FOR SAILOR CLIENTS
description: Sailors trying to clear themselves of drug charges often went to the detective agency run by John A. Walker Jr., the man accused of recruiting spies for the Soviet Union, his employees say.

title: Leucadia Seeks Bigger Stake
description: The Leucadia National Corporation, rebuffed in two bids to influence National Intergroup Inc., asked regulators for authority to more than double its 9 percent stake in the company.

title: AGCA SAYS HE HEARD SOVIET AIDE PAID MONEY TO HAVE POPE KILLED
description: The Turkish terrorist who shot and seriously wounded Pope John Paul II four years ago testified today that an order to assassinate the Pope had come from the Soviet Embassy in Bulgaria.

title: Supreme Court;   On 'Stirring Up Litigation'
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger has for years traveled the lecture circuit complaining about the burden that the growing number of lawsuits places on the court system. Last month a majority of the Supreme Court had its say on that issue in a new opinion, from which the Chief Justice dissented, and its perspective is distinctly different.

title: Sinatra Fans Clogging the Circuit
description: The lines in front of Carnegie Hall were as clogged as ever yesterday when tickets for Frank Sinatra's September engagement went on sale.

title: McDonnell Pacts
description: The Navy awarded the McDonnell Douglas Corporation $440.4 million in two aircraft production contracts for the fiscal year 1985, the Defense Department said. The awards include $375 million for 80 F/A-18A aircraft and four TF/A-18A aircraft, and $65.4 million to the company's McDonnell Aircraft Company unit for 32 AV-8B Harrier II aircraft.

title: Physical Causes Of Mental Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: FOCUS OF '76 RIGHT TO DIE CASE
description: Karen Ann Quinlan, who slipped into a coma 10 years ago and became the center of a national debate on the definition of life and the right to die, died yesterday at a nursing home in Morris Plains, N.J. She was 31 years old. Miss Quinlan died at 7:01 P.M. in her room at the Morris View Nursing Home, with only her mother, Julia Quinlan, at her bedside. Her father, Joseph Quinlan, had been in the room most of yesterday.

title: PRESS RUMANIA ON RIGHTS
description: President Reagan has recommended renewal of Rumania's most-favored-nation status -that is, nondiscriminatory treatment on im 358.8,0,128.8,2,184,0,450.8,2>ports - for another year. Congress ought to hinge approval of his request on human rights improvements.

title: Addenda
description: * Hill & Knowlton, public relations, to open an office in Stamford, Conn., July 1.

title: U.S. RELEASES 4 AND EAST BLOC 25 IN SPY EXCHANGE ON BERLIN BRIDGE
description: The United States today released four East Europeans imprisoned on espionage charges in exchange for 25 Western agents who had been held prisoner in East Germany and Poland, State Department officials announced.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL MONTREAL (NL) - Waived Doug Flynn, infielder. Recalled Al Newman, infielder, from Indianapolis of American Association.

title: BEIRUT HIJACKERS DEMAND DEPARTURE OF PALESTINIANS
description: A Jordanian airliner carrying 74 people, including two Americans, one a professor at the American University of Beirut, was hijacked today by gunmen thought to be Shiite Moslems.

title: USING INSIDE DATA HELD NO BAR TO SUING BROKER
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that investors did not lose the right to file suit for securities fraud simply because they themselves might also be guilty of violating Federal securities law.

title: Tofutti Campaign By Campbell-Ewald
description: Tofutti, the soybean's answer to ice cream, is going to be getting its advertising backing from Campbell-Ewald's New York office.

title: U.S. Steel Cancels Sale of a Division
description: The United States Steel Corporation said that it would not sell its agrichemicals division to that unit's management in a leveraged buyout plan that was announced in February. U.S. Steel announced that the parties had been unable to conclude a definitive agreement, saying only that ''negotiations contemplated in a previously announced letter of intent had been terminated.''

title: Preferred Shares Of Harnischfeger
description: The Harnischfeger Corporation, which is accumulating money to finance a major acquisition, is offering two issues of preferred stock through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: N.R.C. REJECTS SHOREHAM TESTS AT LEVEL OF 5%
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today refused a request by the Long Island Lighting Company to begin testing the Shoreham nuclear plant at up to 5 percent of its capacity.

title: Iraqi Air Raids Kill 41; Iran Hits Border Towns
description: Iraqi warplanes attacked the Kurdish town of Sardasht in northwestern Iran today, and Iran said 41 people were killed and 51 were wounded.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: BASEBALL

title: STAGE: JEROME KERN TRIBUTE OPENS
description: AFTER more than half a dozen productions of Jerome Kern musicals in the first five months of this Kern centenial year, a potpourri of Kern songs drawn from both his stage and film scores has arrived at the Harold Clurman Theater as ''ladies and Gentlemen, Jerome Kern.'' Except for a couple of Kern's earliest efforts, the songs will probably be familiar to most listeners.

title: SYRIA FINDS IT ALSO LACKS KEY TO LEBANESE PEACE
description: Syria's efforts to impose its own order on Lebanon have bogged down in that country's intractable feuds, according to diplomats and Lebanese, Palestinian and Syrian sources here and in Beirut.

title: Travels Pro Bono
description: Capital lawyers say the cutback in Government support for legal services for the poor is coming home to roost. The District of Columbia Bar, accordingly, is preparing an elaborate appeal to its more prosperous members for greater pro bono publico contributions - charity work.

title: Union Pact At Big Board
description: The union representing New York Stock Exchange workers called off a scheduled strike yesterday morning after all-night negotiations with a Federal mediator produced a tentative new contract. The 1,300 members of the union, Local 153 of the Office and Professional Employees International Union, will vote on the proposed contract next week.

title: Travels With Garn
description: Back from the ultimate junket, Senator Jake Garn, the first lawmaker in space, told members of the space subcommittee of the ''absolutely incredible'' and ''absolutely limitless'' future he senses for space. ''We vastly underfund the space program,'' the Senator testified, his enthusiasm in full orbit.

title: Evidence Is Found In Artist's Slaying
description: Detectives said yesterday that they had found some evidence but were still seeking a motive for the slaying of a 39-year-old artist who was found strangled Sunday night in her Greenwich Village loft.

title: SOVIET DROPS WEATHER BALLOON INTO AIR OF VENUS
description: A planetary weather balloon began sending data on the clouds and winds of Venus today after being dropped into the planet's atmosphere by Vega-1, the Soviet spacecraft on its way to a rendezvous with Halley's comet.

title: Freddie Mac's $1 Billion Swap
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, yesterday announced an agreement to exchange $1 billion of mortgage participation certificates for an equal amount of home mortgage loans originated by the Home Owners Federal Savings and Loan Association, a Boston thrift intstitution with assets of $933 million.

title: ELECTRO AUDIO DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-After a gain of $266,000 on the exchange of notes and debentures. c-Net income which includes a tax credit of $415,000.

title: ECLIPSING A RECORD IN RUN TO DAYLIGHT
description: As the tailback in the New Jersey Generals' I-formation, Herschel Walker takes his position seven and a half yards behind the center. That is deep, as far back as a place-kicker goes when attempting a field goal.

title: PAYLESS CASHWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 25
LONDON HOUSE INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
Reading as a Vanishing Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Peking Reports Shuffle In Top Military Posts
description: Peking has appointed new officers to senior positions in regional military commands, the Government reported today.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: SENATORS VIEWING SOVIET SPY EFFORTS
description: Prompted by the widening Navy spy case, the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence announced today that it had begun a comprehensive investigation of Soviet espionage efforts against the United States.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Wild Fennel for Sale Wild fennel has not been available commercially in this part of the country, although it is said to grow like a weed all over California. Now Dean & DeLuca has arranged for regular shipments of wild California fennel and is selling it at the shop, 121 Prince Street (near Greene Street). The fresh herb costs $2.50 a bunch, which is a little over a pound.

title: C 3 INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a charge of $6.8 million for writedowns of obsolete inventory which was partially offset by a gain of $1.3 million related to the sale-leaseback of the company's corporate headquarters.

title: Kean Seeking Reforms In Motor Vehicles Unit
description: Governor Kean announced the end of New Jersey's 79-year-old patronage system for awarding franchises to motor-vehicle agents and called for the end of the mandatory photo driver's licenses.

title: Hu Feng Is Dead at 83; Chinese Literary Critic
description: Hu Feng, a celebrated writer and literary critic who championed artistic freedom in China in the 1950's only to be jailed and purged, has died of cancer, the New China News Agency reported today. He was 83.

title: Vilas May Quit
description: Humiliation is a risk in sports, but when it strikes, the reactions are not always the same. Take Guillermo Vilas, for instance.

title: Crayons Apparel In Debut
description: IF you were making what you considered kicky and fun items of apparel for girls and young women from their teens through early 20's, where would you advertise?

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: AS easily as a remembrance of favorite dishes past, a recognition of good food prices present can become the theme of this food column. So it is that I am writing about filet mignon, a cut of beef that many people consider to be the ultimate in flavor, texture and leanness - but an admittedly expensive ultimate.

title: Marcos Says Martial Law Could Be Reimposed
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he would reimpose martial law in the Philippines if rebel insurgency turned into fighting in the streets.

title: Travels With an Escort
description: Platonic companionship for sale:

title: Chase Ohio Appoints President
description: Richard C. Bittenbender 2d was named president of Chase Bank of Ohio yesterday, as the Chase Manhattan Corporation formally became a part of the Ohio banking community, opening 22 commercial bank offices.

title: North American Philips Stock Falls
description: The North American Philips Corporation, a New York-based electrical equipment company, led the list of the biggest losers on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday as its shares dropped $6.625, to $35.75 in heavy trading.

title: Second Victim Dies of Burns From a Ruptured Steam Line
description: A second victim of a ruptured high-pressure steam line at Southern California Edison's Mohave Generating Plant in Nevada, one of 15 severely burned, died of injuries today, officials said.

title: CITY REPORTS AN ACCORD WITH UNIFORMED GROUPS
description: City negotiators said yesterday that they had agreed on the terms of a new contract with the unions representing police officers, firefighters and other uniformed workers.

title: Ralston-Purina Opens Blues Suit
description: The National Hockey League violated antitrust law by preventing Ralston Purina Co. from selling the St. Louis Blues to Canadian investors who planned to move the franchise to Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, a jury was told today at the start of the company's $60 million lawsuit against the league.

title: JUDGE AND PROSECUTORS AT ODDS ON VON BULOW TRIAL
description: Judge and prosecutors in the Claus von Bulow case blamed each other today for the fact that the jury that acquitted him Monday did not hear some evidence that was presented three years ago. In that trial, Mr. von Bulow was convicted of trying to kill his wealthy wife.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The order to kill the Pope began at the Soviet Embassy in Sofia.'' -Mehmet Ali Agca. [A15:1.]

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 12, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Subcommittee on Petitions - 10:30 A.M.

title: NEW ERA FOR OUTBOARD MARINE
description: Charles D. Strang's love affair with outboard motors began in the 1930's, when he was a boy growing up on the South Shore of Long Island, cheering on a local racer named Benny Levy and his mahogany boat, the Baby Sink.

title: Health and Federal Leadership
description: Until very recently, the bankruptcy of Medicare was considered imminent. Now it has been avoided, at least for several years . . . Blue Cross is refunding premium money to the Federal employees and their employers . . . Hospitals compete for patients by offering fancy meals and amenities.

title: TED TURNER FORMS A SOCIETY TO PRODUCE 'GLOBAL TV PROGRAMMING'
description: Ted Turner, the Atlanta broadcasting entrepreneur, announced yesterday the formation of the ''Better World Society,'' an organization that will produce ''global television programming'' about the environment, nuclear arms control and overpopulation.

title: WEALTH OF BARGAINS FROM BORDEAUX
description: NO, your eyes do not deceive you. You read the advertisement correctly: 1982 Petrus, $2,100 a case, $185 a bottle. That's the going price for this famous Bordeaux red wine. Does that mean Bordeaux prices are very high? Does it mean that this is not the time to buy Bordeaux? The answer to both these questions is an uneqivocal yes, and an unequivocal no.

title: TRADITION REIGNS AS PRINCETON U. CONFERS DEGREES
description: Few Princeton University graduates knew what Andrew Feldherr was talking about yesterday when he delivered the traditional salutatory oration in Latin.

title: Hotel Strike Talks To Resume Today
description: Negotiators for the opposing sides in the 12-day-old hotel strike met for an hour and a half yesterday, but adjourned with no apparent progress toward a settlement, according to a state mediator, William Glinsman.

title: Western Air Lines Reviewing Its Agency
description: Western Air Lines confirmed yesterday that it was reviewing its relationship with Doyle Dane Bernbach, Los Angeles, that only began last year.

title: FANS OF OLD COKE SAY THE NEW IS NOT IT
description: Seven weeks after the Coca-Cola Company changed its longtime recipe, many frustrated Coke drinkers are complaining that the new taste is just not the real thing.

title: THE NEW YORK WHATS
description: I had just said ''Madonna who?'' when The New York Times landed on the doorstep. ''You've got to be kidding,'' said the kid to whom I had just said ''Madonna who?''

title: PHILADELPHIA INQUIRY ON BOMBING BY POLICE TO BEGIN TODAY
description: With Mayor W. Wilson Goode's political reputation in the balance, a commission investigating the city's May 13 assault on a radical group will hold its first public meeting Wednesday, William H. Brown 3d, the chairman, said the commission would concentrate on why the Mayor had not avoided the crisis and how his administration managed or mismanaged it.

title: GREAT AMERICAN STANDARDS UNDER SIEGE
description: MY problem in matters of food is that I am a purist.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 12, 1985

title: Bridge: Teams With 5 or 6 Players Used for Knockout Events
description: In national knockout events that call for 64 deals on 5 or 6 consecutive days, stamina is a factor. Nearly all teams employ five or six players, permitting some rest, rather than the minimum of four.

title: POLAND RESTS CASE AGAINST 3 ACTIVISTS ON TRIAL ON GDANSK
description: The prosecution in the Gdansk trial of three political activists urged a five-year sentence today for one defendant and four-year terms for the other two. All are charged with fomenting unrest.

title: WOMEN ASSESS PROGRESS
description: More than 100 women in politics, business and the professions took inventory at a recent meeting in Stamford, Conn., assessing the changes the women's movement has made in their lives and the remaining hurdles.

title: 21 Are Killed in Israel As Train Hits School Bus
description: Seventeen children and four adults were killed today when a train collided with a school bus at an unguarded crossing south of Haifa. Seventeen other children were hospitalized.

title: The Dangerous Age
description: New Jersey, Connecticut, Massachusetts and Pennsylvania have all raised the age for alcoholic drinking to 21. That makes New York, where the age remains at 19, a dangerous holdout. It lets 19-and 20-year-olds from surrounding states drive into New York to purchase liquor. After an evening of drinking, they are hardly in condition to drive back.

title: Draft Security
description: The scheduled appearance of Patrick Ewing at Tuesday's draft, where the Knicks will officially make him the No. 1 selection, has caused the league to institute a security measure.

title: CBS PRESENTS 'ALL-STAR SALUTE TO FORD'S THEATER'
description: When the occasion offers an opportunity not only for publicly contributing to a worthy charitable cause but also for an enviable ''photo opportunity,'' a stampede of politicians is inevitable. So the ''All-Star Salute to Ford's Theater,'' on CBS at 8 o'clock this evening, has an audience that includes everybody from President and Mrs. Reagan and Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill Jr. to what a network release describes as ''key Congressional leaders and top representatives of American business and industry.'' The bill of entertainment adds up to a kind of pretentious vaudeville.

title: REAGAN LETTER PRESSES LATIN REBEL AID
description: President Reagan pressed his campaign for renewed aid to the Nicaraguan rebels today by promising to consider resuming direct talks with the Government in Managua.

title: 3 CANCER RESEARCHERS WIN $130,000 AWARDS
description: Three scientists who have made important contributions to cancer research and diagnosis were named winners yesterday of the General Motors Cancer Research Foundation prizes for 1985.

title: VERSES CARRY 'SOUND OF SOBBING' FROM VIETNAM
description: As a young man he wrote love poems. His friends used to borrow them to impress their sweethearts.

title: THE DANCE: CHEN TROUPE AT SCHONBERG
description: Chen and Dancers presented work on Saturday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater that included lyrical abstractions, a piece for dancers and bicycle seats and bells, and a homage to Mott Street. The company of nine, headed by the compelling Dian Dong, had a notable clarity of attack and an understated, attractive way of presenting itself. But nothing caught fire on this program.

title: STOCK PRICES IN MODERATE RETREAT
description: Blue-chip issues joined the rest of the market yesterday in a retreat that sent stock prices moderately lower on slightly increased volume.

title: Topics;   Outcasts The Crime of Mercy
description: The new military rulers of the Sudan apparently consider compassion a crime. They have jailed and are now trying the country's former Vice President, Omar Mohammed el-Tayeb, for aiding the airlift to Israel of some 10,000 Ethiopian Jews from Sudanese refugee camps.

title: Albeck May Quit Nets' Job
description: Ever since the Nets were eliminated in the first round of the playoffs, Stan Albeck has insisted that he would return next season as coach. Now, it appears he may not.

title: Market Place;   A Fresh Look At Grumman
description: IF it could happen to the Hughes Aircraft Company, why not the Grumman Corporation? Apparently such thinking inspired the buying mania that pushed the stock of Grumman, the Long Island aerospace contractor, sky-high yesterday. It rose $3.50, to $33.75, as 572,700 shares changed hands in soaring consolidated volume.

title: COMA TRIAL: AFTER HOOPLA
description: In the news media center here, amid a litter of discarded newspapers and abandoned coffee cups, reporters who covered the two-month trial of Claus von Bulow reflected today on what most regard as a very peculiar experience.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municiapl Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Not Tall Enough
description: Anyone waiting for the return of the ''World's Tallest Building'' title to Manhattan will have to keep waiting. Whatever structure rises at Columbus Circle will not wrest this distinction from Chicago.

title: Rally for Lakers Halted
description: Festivities honoring the Los Angeles Lakers for winning the National Basketball Association championship were cut short today because of heat and the crush of a crowd of about 6,000 at a City Hall ceremony.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: The Lord George-Brown They Remember
description: To the Editor:

title: RECITAL: DEBUT BY THE PIANIST
description: The pianist Jill Timmons, who made her New York debut Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is a sensitive musician and a particularly accomplished miniaturist. Miss Timmons was at her best in short works by Debussy, Ravel and William Bergsma; her playing was graceful, lyrical, detailed and intimate.

title: PRICE COMMUNICATIONS IN PACT FOR LAW LOURNALS
description: A company headed by Robert Price, a former New York Deputy Mayor, has agreed to buy The New York Law Journal, the daily chronicle of legal activities in the New York metropolitan area, and its weekly companion publication, The National Law Journal, for $20.5 million.

title: STAGE: 'THE TEMPEST,' IN HARTFORD
description: Mark Lamos's production of ''The Tempest'' begins with a shower of sound and lightning. The storm quickly subsides and we are entreated to enter Prospero's peaceable kingdom. In Michael H. Yeargan's set design, the island idyll becomes a hull-like interior moored in space. The feeling of tranquillity is endemic to the director's approach to Shakespeare's farewell play. When Prospero lays down his magic staff, one is left with an image not of fulfillment but of forbearance. He has made his treaty with the real world and has decided to terminate a noble experiment.

title: U.S. COURT TO REHEAR APPEAL OF LIBEL AWARD IN MOBIL CASE
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia agreed today to reconsider a decision reinstating a $2 million award to the former president of Mobil Oil in his libel suit against The Washington Post.

title: Times Co. Broadcast Chief
description: Frank Roberts, executive vice president and general manager of WREG-TV in Memphis, has been named president of The New York Times Company's broadcasting group, it was announced yesterday by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the company's chairman.

title: WILEY, JOHN & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $350,000.

title: Publisher Is Elated By S.E.C. Victory
description: Christopher L. Lowe freely admits he is a convicted felon, found guilty of kiting checks and tampering with evidence related to his handling of an investment client's funds. Three years ago, he says, he served four months in jail.

title: COLLINS FOODS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Year-ago results exclude a nonrecurring charge of $800,000 for the quarter and a nonrecurring gain of $3.2 million, or 24 cents a share, for the year.

title: 2 AGENCIES DIFFER ON HOW TO CUT MILK PRICES
description: The Cuomo administration released two reports today recommending sharply conflicting ways to lower milk prices in New York City, which are often far higher than those in other parts of the state and in New Jersey.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Saturday about a protest outside the Soviet Mission to the United Nations erroneously listed three public officials among those arrested. Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. of Manhattan, and City Councilmen Archie Spigner of Queens and Noach Dear of Brooklyn participated in the protest but were not arrested.

title: AIRLINE MEALS: ARE THEY ALL THE SAME?
description: AIRLINE meals. The food you love to hate. So frequently the subject of jokes that even airline personnel acknowledge its shortcomings. On a United Airlines flight in April from La Guardia Airport to Denver, a flight attendant announced that there were three entree choices and then added: ''Please don't be upset if your first choice is not available. They all taste the same anyway.''

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: OPERA: 'MANON LESCAUT,' THE MET IN CENTRAL PARK
description: THE Metropolitan Opera opened its 19th ''Met in the Parks'' season last night to unseasonably cool breezes, but not a sign of rain. Discouraging forecasts and a few drops in the afternoon, though, kept many opera lovers home: Only 15,000 to 20,000 gathered on Central Park's Great Lawn, according to official estimates - about a quarter of the crowd that heard ''Rinaldo'' there last summer.

title: FORBES 11, KREMLIN 10 IN FABERGE EGG RACE
description: Malcolm Forbes, the magazine publisher, yesterday paid $1.76 million for a bejeweled Easter egg, created in 1900 by Faberge for Czar Nicholas II.

title: WOMEN'S NEAR-LIBERATION
description: Outwardly, women are doing fine, as more and more of us are accepted into what was once a male world. A subtle shade of sex- ism continues to thrive, however -and women aren't doing nearly enough to combat it.

title: AMERICAN SOFTWARE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
IRWIN TOY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chubb Corp., Warren, N.J., has elected Dean R. O'Hare executive vice president.

title: Turkey Airline Offering
description: Turkey will announce the details next month of a plan to sell the shares of the state-owned Turkish Airlines to the public, a senior Government official said today.

title: VALUE OF FARMLAND MAKES A STEEP 12% DROP
description: United States farmland plummeted 12 percent in value in the last year, a drop so steep that it delayed the release of the information as statisticians double-checked their figures, the Department of Agriculture says.

title: No Homecoming For Cartwright
description: After an inglorious tenure in Kansas City, you're now the Sacramento Kings, and you've got an idea: What better way to stir up interest than to bring in a local kid to play for your team, especially if he's a former hero, a hometown player who made good?

title: FOR DEEP FRYING
description: DEEP frying is a precise method of cooking that requires strict attention to temperature, timing and the size of ingredients. Anyone who has tried to make french-fried potatoes at home probably has learned that if the oil temperature is too low the potatoes will come out limp and soggy; too high and they burn. This applies to other deep-fried foods, too.

title: CUOMO AND LEADERS NEAR AGREEMENT ON BILL TO CURB MALPRACTICE PREMIUMS
description: Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders are nearing agreement on a measure designed to curb rapidly rising premiums for medical malpractice insurance, key legislative and gubernatorial aides said today.

title: SENATE BATTLE IS SHAPING UP ON LIFE-SENTENCE MEASURE
description: Warren M. Anderson, the State Senate majority leader, said today that the Senate would not consider during this session a bill to allow the sentencing of murderers to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

title: CONDUCTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,008,000 for the quarter and $1,071,000 for the 6 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $113,000 for the quarter and $170,000 for the 6 months.

title: FOR HOT SUMMER DAYS, EASY DISHES EVEN A COOK CAN LOVE
description: AS June warms up, many cooks begin stipulating what they will and will not put up with by way of summer cooking chores. Predictably, their lists are long on short-order dishes, but short on imaginative ones. The desire not to rely on elaborate preparation, not to spend hours tending a hot stove, leaves them perilously close to not cooking at all. To their families, the prospect is a dismaying one of endless barbecues punctuated by pasta with the same old sauce.

title: Merrill Lynch
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said that it was discussing with A. B. Giles & Cresswell, a London jobber firm, the possibility of acquiring a 29.9 percent stake in Giles.

title: The Presidency;   Rethinking a Tax-Plan Strategy
description: As President Reagan departed on a two-day swing through the Sun Belt last Wednesday, he faced the challenge of a rush of issues all vying for Presidential attention and comments. Mr. Reagan met the challenge by firing what amounted to a verbal shotgun that scattered the Presidential emphasis in a number of directions.

title: 2 JERSEY MAYORS DEFEATED IN RUNOFFS
description: Voters in Jersey City and Hoboken turned their Mayors out of office yesterday after bitter runoff campaigns that centered on the effects of recent redevelopment in the neighboring Hudson County cities.

title: India-Carbide Talks Planned
description: After a two-month lapse, negotiations are to resume Monday between Indian Government and Union Carbide officials on a possible out-of-court settlement to compensate victims of the poison gas leak in Bhopal, India, last Dec. 3.

title: Belushi Case Judge Holds 2 Reporters in Contempt
description: A judge in the murder case of John Belushi, the actor, found two reporters in contempt of court and sentenced them to jail today for refusing to testify about an interview with the defendant, Cathy Evelyn Smith.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WHERE WATER COMES TOGETHER WITH OTHER WATER. By Raymond Carver. 130 pages. Random House. $13.95.

title: Silent Bats
description: The decline in National League hitting this season is a bit of a mystery, all right, but it is very, very real. Through the first quarter of the season, the 12 teams collectively were batting .242, a decline of 15 points from the first one-fourth of 1984, and only once in the last decade and a half has their start been anywhere near as slow. That was in 1972, when the average after the first 40 games was .246.

title: CLINICAL DATA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TAX SHIFT UNDER FIRE IN SENATE
description: The Senate began public scrutiny of President Reagan's tax revision proposals today, and the reception was much less enthusiastic than in the House of Representatives.

title: THE BIG WINNERS ON TAXES
description: Amid the loud outcries from smokestack industries, high-tax states and other special interests that stand to be hurt by President Reagan's tax revision plan, Wall Street analysts and tax specialists have been scouting the economic terrain to pin down those who stand to benefit handsomely under the plan.

title: Apparent Drop in U.S. Catholic Population May Well Be Growth
description: To the Editor:

title: ROYAL INTERNATIONAL OPTICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in March 1985.

title: KIT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Bombarding Buchanan
description: Patrick J. Buchanan, the White House communications director, hit more than one raw nerve when he said at a news conference Friday that the Reagan Administration's new tax proposal would benefit the ''traditional'' family; that is, one in which the wife stays home to take care of the children.

title: BODY IS MENGELE'S HIS SON DECLARES
description: The son of Josef Mengele, the Nazi death camp doctor, said today he had ''no doubt'' that the skeleton exhumed from a grave in Brazil five days ago was that of his father.

title: A Mistrial on Charges In Fire That Killed 15
description: A Superior Court judge declared a mistrial today when a jury was unable to reach a verdict after deliberating more than eight days in the arson-murder trial of a handyman accused of starting a fire in a rundown hotel here that killed 15 people.

title: PANTRY PRIDE INC reports earnings for 12 wks to May 4
description: b-Includes tax credits of $335,000 for the 12 weeks and $2,477,000 for the 40 weeks, a gain of $275,000 for the 40 weeks on Chapter 11 debt reduction and a net gain of $218,000 for the 40 weeks on the termination of a pension plan. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $128,000 for the 12 weeks and $765,000 for the 40 weeks, tax credits of $1,482,000 for the 12 weeks and $3,628,000 for the 40 weeks and a gain of $1,150,000 for the 40 weeks on Chapter 11 debt reduction.

title: BUDGET UNIT CHIEF IN HOUSE FORESEES NEED FOR TAX RISE
description: The chairman of the House Budget Committee, a Democrat, said today that in addition to about $50 billion in spending cuts, a tax increase would be necessary to bring the Federal budget deficit down near $100 billion.

title: Sea, Sand and Silence
description: Something radical is happening to summer at two beaches beloved by New Yorkers. Special radio-free zones have been created at Jones Beach in Nassau County and Orchard Beach in the Bronx.

title: Comeback On 'Chitlin Circuit'
description: Before desegregation, blacks in America had to rely mainly on a string of theaters set up around the country for stage entertainment.

title: FRENCH CHEFS ARE UP IN ARMS OVER NO-SHOW RESERVATIONS
description: FOR some tourists, a visit to France without dining at a fine restaurant would be as unthinkable as passing up the cathedral at Chartres or the Eiffel Tower. Yet the number of people who reserve a table and fail to show up is increasing, acccording to some of France's top chefs, some of whom are asking for deposits when they accept reservations.

title: Burroughs Plants
description: The Burroughs Corporation, the Detroit-based computer company, announced it would close a plant here and an engineering facility in Orlando by Oct. 31. The two closings will involve transfers or layoffs of 600 employees in the Coral Springs encoding and imaging division and 150 workers in the Orlando engineering section beginning next month, company officials said. The closings are part of a yearlong consolidation.

title: Interest Rates Post Moderate Decline
description: Interest rates fell moderately late yesterday as traders remained optimistic that rates would continue to decline. Even though there were no concrete developments - other than good investor demand - prices rose sharply in the last two hours of trading.

title: YOUNG RUNAWAYS GET FREE BUS RIDES
description: At the age of 16, Tina Lane ran away from her Indianapolis home, only to end up working nine-hour days in a fast-food restaurant, barely making ends meet and unable to afford bus fare home. But she was reunited with her family, one of 4,000 young people who, in the last year, have taken advantage of Trailways' free trips home for runaways.

title: STORAGE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Storage Technology said that the net loss figure for the latest quarter reflects a loss of $16,191,000 due to the cumulative effect, from prior periods, of a change in the company's revenue recognition policy.

title: Overdone Investor Protection, Undone
description: Can the Securities and Exchange Commission forbid publication of a newsletter for investors, in the name of protecting consumers? No, says the Supreme Court. There is a surer protection for consumers - their freedom to receive a variety of financial information without Government censorship. The Court decision, unanimous, is as welcome as it is wise.

title: SELIGMAN & LATZ INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
NAVY ORDERS CUT OF 50% IN ACCESS TO SECURITY DATA
description: The Navy will halve the number of people who have access to restricted information because of the spy case involving John A. Walker Jr. and three others, the Secretary of the Navy said today.

title: POP: AMBITIOUS DEBUT FOR BRAZIL'S GAL COSTA
description: THE finest singers, classical and popular, bring every note a certain kind of grace. For all the technique involved, phrases seem to pour forth with the ease of conversation; the voice blithely defies every law of physics.

title: ULTRASYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
I.M.F. APPROVES ARGENTINE PLAN FOR NEW LOANS
description: The International Monetary Fund announced today that it had reached agreement with Argentina on an austerity program that opens the door for up to $1.2 billion of loans to Buenos Aires by next March 27.

title: WHITSON A SUCCESS IN A YANKEE FAILURE
description: Ed Whitson, booed at the start of the evening and cheered near the end, kept calling the game a turning point in a season of misery. But his performance last night at the Stadium might have been nothing more than a morale builder.

title: Paine Webber Is Censured
description: The New York Stock Exchange and the Chicago Board Options Exchange announced today that Paine Webber Inc. had been censured and fined $15,000 by each exchange for taking positions in stocks and options in the General Motors Corporation before the securities firm had released a research report on G.M. three years ago. The exchanges said that at the time of the trading, the firm knew about the imminent release and contents of the report.

title: CRENSHAW GETS OUT OF THE DEEP ROUGH
description: Ben Crenshaw's game deteriorated so much after he won the 1984 Masters 14 months ago that he said: ''I was almost at my wit's end. My whole life was with no direction. The way I was going, I might not win anything again, let alone play well in something like the Open. I needed some help.''

title: BID FOR WARNER AMEX GAINS WITH SWEETENER
description: Time Inc. and Tele-Communications Inc. moved a step closer to success yesterday in their bid for Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc. They won the approval of the American Express Company, co-owner of Warner Amex with Warner Communications Inc., which said it had signed a definitive agreement for the sale.

title: PRESBYTERIANS AFFIRM ABORTION RIGHTS POLICY
description: After a strong effort by anti-abortion forces, Presbyterians reaffirmed their support for abortion rights tonight at a meeting here.

title: Slaney, Budd Make Up
description: Mary Slaney says she has ''made up'' with Zola Budd, the young South African-born runner who collided with her in the Olympic 3,000 meters last summer. Mrs. Slaney told a British magazine, ''I don't want Zola, or any other kid, to go through the pain and traumas I had when I was young.''

title: Bowman Steps Down
description: After 17 seasons with 3 teams, and with 718 victories and 5 Stanley Cups, Scotty Bowman has decided to turn over his coaching duties to someone else. He named Jim Schoenfeld, a former Sabre defenseman and captain, to take over the Buffalo job , and added that he would concentrate on his jobs as general manager and director of hockey operations.

title: Diversifoods Stock
description: A Federal judge in Omaha issued an order restraining the Pillsbury Company from purchasing any stock tendered by shareholders of Diversifoods Inc. until a court hearing next Monday.

title: Miami Wins College Series
description: Greg Ellena had four hits tonight to pace a 14-hit attack that carried Miami of Florida to a 10-6 victory over Texas in the championship game of the College World Series.

title: Wiggins Poses Problem
description: Alan Wiggins has been given a clearance by baseball's joint review board to resume his career after two suspensions for drug abuse, but Ballard Smith, the Padre president, is sticking to his decision not to allow Wiggins to return to the Padres this season -if ever.

title: REPORT OF MENGELE DEATH IS NOT THE FIRST
description: In his up to 40 years on the run, Josef Mengele has been reported to have died many deaths.

title: HOTELS TO ADD REFRIGERATORS FOR HOMELESS
description: An association representing 40 hotels that house homeless families has agreed to place about 1,000 refrigerators in rooms that do not have them, under an agreement reached with the Koch administration yesterday.

title: Panel Should Recognize Threat of Pornography
description: To the Editor:

title: ECONOMISTS URGE TAX PLAN CHANGE
description: Leading economists, including former top advisers to President Reagan and President Ford, told Congress today that they had found major faults in the President's tax plan. They urged changes in several of its most important provisions.

title: 'Big River' Enjoys A Big Jump in Business
description: Business for ''Big River'' jumped by $96,000 - or 60 percent - in the week after the musical won seven Tony awards, according to the show's box-office records.

title: BRAZIL IS SEEKING PROOF ON MENGELE
description: The Brazilian police said today that they still wanted scientific proof that the Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele died here in 1979 despite his son's statement earlier today that his father was dead.

title: Harlem Dance Theater Sets Opening Benefit
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem will open its two-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday with a benefit performance. Nancy Reagan is honorary chairman of the benefit, which includes performances of George Balanchine's ''Stars and Stripes'' and the company's popular Creole ''Giselle.''

title: PARK FIRE AN ACCIDENT, BOY TESTIFIES
description: A 14-year-old boy testified today that he saw another boy accidentally start an amusement-park fire that killed eight teen-agers last year.

title: BOWNE & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * BASF America Corp. has signed contracts, valued at close to $20 million, to build a floppy-disk plant and a plant to make TDI, a polyurethane foam component, in China.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 12, 1985

title: FUNDAMENTALIST RE-ELECTED HEAD OF SOUTHERN BAPTISTS
description: Fundamentalists today took firm control of the Southern Baptist Convention, the largest Protestant denomination in the United States, by re-electing the Rev. Charles F. Stanley of Atlanta as the national president.

title: CAPITAL SPENDING PLANS CUT
description: Businesses plan to increase their spending for expansion and modernization this year by less than expected earlier, the Commerce Department said today.

title: REAGAN'S TAX PLAN IS UNFAIR
description: What started as a movement for a flat tax has turned into a proposal for a ''flat-earth 248.4,0,128.8,2,1 28.8,0,128.8,2,588.8,0>tax.'' That label is suitable because President Reagan's program ignores social realities - much as individuals who proclaimed the world was flat ignored scientific truth.

title: Continental Airlines Called Safe by Agency
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today declared Continental Airlines a safe airline, although it said a detailed inspection of the carrier disclosed sloppy record-keeping and 20 safety violations.

title: Lorimar Expected To Buy Bozell
description: Late yesterday afternoon Lorimar, the California production company, called a press conference for today.

title: Kupchak Made It Back
description: The final word on the basketball season comes not from the Birds and the Magics but from a man who shot only 1 for 5 in the last game of the season, playing on a repaired knee that had once suffered the worst injury doctors had ever seen.

title: 20% Interest Sold In Kiewit-Murdock
description: Peter Kiewit Sons' Inc., the Omaha-based construction and mining company, has purchased David H. Murdock's 20 percent equity interest in Kiewit-Murdock Inc., an investment company formed last year to acquire the Continental Group, the packaging company based in Stamford, Conn.

title: BIG BOARD, LONDON TIE DISCUSSED
description: The New York Stock Exchange and London's Stock Exchange announced yesterday that they had set up a study group to examine the creation of a common trading system that could lead to broad trading links between the two exchanges.

title: THEATER: 'ODD COUPLE,' A REMIX AND REMATCH
description: IF you're willing to wait patiently until Act II, Scene 2 of the new Broadway version of ''The Odd Couple,'' you'll discover that there is at least one good reason why Neil Simon has revised, if not exactly improved, his funniest play.

title: Youth Held in Child's Death
description: A teen-ager was charged today with murdering a 5-year-old girl who was thrown from a 13th-story window after what appeared to be a sexual assault at a bleak West Side housing project, the police said. Johnny Freeman, 17 years old, of Chicago, was charged with murder in the death of Shabanna McCann.

title: Dozens of Counts Voided In Molestation Case
description: A judge dismissed 64 of 208 child-molesting charges today against the founder of the McMartin Pre-School and two other defendants, saying there was not enough evidence to substantiate them.

title: Travels With Kirkpatrick
description: In the Washington atlas, the path from Iowa to New Hampshire is the Early Momentum Trail, the route between the first two Presidential tests where aspiring candidates are to be found racing like rockets or plodding like prairie schooners. The trail turns out to be bustling this early with the travels of Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the Reaganite star and neophyte Republican who spoke at party dinners in Des Moines Friday night and Manchester Monday night.

title: THEY LABOR IN FOOTHILLS OF ACADEME
description: As ways of life go, there is hardly much to recommend it. The hours are long, the anxiety constant, the pay negligible, the work tedious and the job prospects, at best, uncertain. But each year 250,000 college and university graduates commit themselves for perhaps as long as another decade to this emotional and intellectual endurance test.

title: GEORGE BUSH AT 61
description: Vice President George Bush is a busy man these days, lucky even if he can find an evening to celebrate his 61st birthday today. He's involved in everything from the struggle between the Senate and the House over the budget to the controversy over the control of nuclear weapons.

title: T.W.A. Reply Due
description: Resorts International Inc. expects to hear whether Trans World Airlines Inc. will accept its takeover bid within ''24 hours,'' a source close to Resorts told the Reuters news agency yesterday.
