Wall Street sources said the T.W.A. board reviewed Resorts' offer of $22 a share last Friday. Separately, American Airlines confirmed reports that it had taken an informal look at T.W.A. But Lowell Duncan, an American spokesman, said the airline had decided not to make an offer.

title: Tax Fairness: What Is It?
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN has declared the aims of his proposed revision of the tax system to be ''fairness, growth and simplicity.'' Of the three goals, fairness is the hardest to define objectively.

title: Alfonsin Appears Willing to Make Cuts
description: As some Argentine officials signed a new agreement with the International Monetary Fund in Washington today, others here announced an 18 percent devaluation of the peso, the largest since June 1981.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Richard Todd, the quarterback who is now a free agent, said he had turned down an offer to join the Generals as a game-by-game replacement for the injured Doug Flutie. . . . Joe Barry Carroll of the the Golden State Warriors became a free agent Monday, and has received an overture from the Dallas Mavericks. But he plans to check with other clubs before signing an offer sheet. . . . Steve Ovett, the British runner who was stricken with a viral infection at the Olympics and has not raced since, said he would return to competition Friday in the 3,000 at a team competition against the United States in Birmingham, England. . . . Doug Flynn, the former Met infielder, was waived by Montreal so that he could obtain an unconditional release. . . . Jack Van Berg, who won the Eclipse Award as the nation's top thoroughbred trainer in 1984, and W. Burlington Cocks, long a leading steeplechase trainer, have been elected to the Racing Hall of Fame.

title: MENGELE CASTS SHADOW ON A BAVARIAN TOWN
description: To many people, the signs along the roads leading to this Bavarian town have an accusatory tone: ''Mengele-Gunzburg.''

title: DREAMS AND DETAILS: STAGING A TRADITIONAL JUNE WEDDING
description: Ann Marie Blachetta met Joseph Leone five years ago at the Argo Bowling Lanes. She was 15, a high school sophomore. He was an older boy, 17.

title: Debt Issues
description: * BP Capital B.V. is issuing $50 million (New Zealand) of 16 percent Eurobonds, due in 1988, at par through underwriters led by Credit Suisse First Boston

title: U.S.C. Expels 17 Students
description: The University of Southern California has expelled 17 students, suspended six and frozen the records of 17 others on charges of involvement in a pay-for-grades scheme, a university official said Monday.

title: AS GANDHI ARRIVES, U.S. SEES BETTER RELATIONS
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India arrived here today amid expressions of optimism within the Reagan Administration that he would would adopt ''a more balanced posture'' in relations with the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: RICHTON INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $431,000 and extraordinary income of $3,108,000.c-Net loss which is after a tax credit of $174,000 and a loss of $481,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net loss which is after income of $170,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Home Run Helps Adams Take Title
description: The odds against John Adams winning the overall city high school baseball championship yesterday seemed long. The Spartans had entered the sixth inning trailing, 2-0, and Victor Garcia, one of the best pitchers in the city, was on the mound for Cardinal Hayes.

title: Michael Belson, 42, Is Dead; Former Assistant Prosecutor
description: Michael Belson, a former first assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, died of a heart attack Saturday while visiting in Westhampton, L.I. He was 42 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: STUART DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: Sales figures exclude leased department sales.

title: CUBE RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss.

title: Fiberglass Yams Yield 300 Pounds of Cocaine
description: Federal drug agents huddled inside a steamy warehouse Monday and marveled at the latest smuggling technique: cocaine stuffed inside fake fiberglass Colombian yams.

title: U.S. WEIGHS ALLIED ROLE IN MIDEAST PEACE TALKS
description: The Reagan Administration is considering the possibility of organizing a Middle East peace conference of European and Asian allies as a compromise to meet the concerns of Israel and Jordan, Administration officials said today.

title: UGANDA TORTURE CHARGES BACKED
description: A human-rights group charged yesterday that Ugandan civilians continue to be unlawfully detained and systematically tortured by troops and security forces of the Government of President Milton Obote.

title: Topics;   Outcasts The Name is Baum
description: Somewhere over the rainbow is a land called Oz, discovered by an American writer named L. Frank Baum (1856-1919). Children loved his Oz books, 14 of them, but one of Oz's wizards has evidently cast an evil spell, so that while Dorothy and Toto have come to life for youngsters everywhere, their creator has been rendered invisible.

title: SOVIET SAYS REAGAN IS GRADUALLY ENDING PACT
description: The Soviet Union said today that President Reagan's statement pledging continued adherence to the 1979 arms treaty confirmed his intention to destroy the entire system of arms-control accords.

title: Asarco Stake
description: Weeks Petroleum Ltd. and Bell Resources Ltd., two companies controlled by the Australian investor Robert Holmes a Court, increased their stake in Asarco Inc. to 3,493,800 common shares, or 11 percent of the New York-based mining concern's shares outstanding. Mr. Holmes a Court, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, said that between May 22 and June 10, he bought 353,900 Asarco shares for prices ranging from $23.875 to $25.25 a share, or a total of $8.6 million.

title: METS LOSE AGAIN, BY THE MOST AMAZIN' SCORE
description: The Philadelphia Phillies blasted the Mets into the baseball record books tonight with a hammering offense that produced 27 hits and 26 runs and plunged the Mets to the worst defeat in their often checkered 23-year history.

title: 'VIDEO FROM RUSSIA'
description: LAST year, an American film maker, Dimitri Devyatkin, took his cameras to the Soviet Union and talked to people in the streets of six cities - Moscow, Kiev, Kazan, Ulyanovsk, Leningrad and Volgograd. The result, ''Video From Russia: The People Speak,'' can be seen tonight at 8 on cable television's Arts and Entertainment network.

title: POLICE CRITICIZED BY SOUTH AFRICAN
description: The report of a judicial inquiry into the the killing of 20 black demonstrators last March 21 accused the South African police today of fabricating its version of events so as to justify police action in opening fire on the marchers.

title: THEATER BENEFIT FOR MEN'S WEAR ADWARDS
description: IT was time for the men's wear industry to preen a bit Monday night. Everyone got done up in black tie, or creative facsimiles, and hied over to the Fashion Institute of Technology to find out who had received the sixth annual Cutty Sark Men's Fashion Awards.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: A 34-year-old woman had been suffering for 10 years from recurrent fevers, sore throats, fatigue, joint pains, depression and headaches, although no medical reason could be found for her symptoms. Her persistent inability to think straight and concentrate on tasks forced her to resign from her university faculty position.

title: '84 PAY FOR NEW YORK CONSTRUCTION JOB: $308,651
description: State investigators are looking into widespread featherbedding practices at New York City construction sites that led to wages of $308,651 last year for one construction worker at Battery Park City.

title: Vic Tanny, Health Club Owner And Body Builder, Dies at 73
description: Vic Tanny, a body builder and health club pioneer, died Tuesday after suffering a stroke several months ago. He was 73 years old.

title: VOTE IN ASSEMBLY
description: Following is the roll-call vote by the State Assembly Monday night on a bill to allow the sentencing of some murderers to life in prison without the possibility of parole. The bill was approved 99 to 47 with 4 members not voting.

title: MARKETING OF MCGUIGAN NOW IN SIGHT
description: It's rare to find a good fighter these days. It's even rarer to find a good fighter with a marketable personality. Larry Holmes, Marvelous Marvin Hagler, and now Donald Curry, were accomplished champions before they became acknowledged stars.

title: Manufacturers Hanover Plans Special Preferred
description: The ability to sell money market preferred stock with low dividend yields is attracting many companies, just as lower interest rates have spurred the issuance of corporate notes and bonds.

title: State Dept. Aide Nominated
description: The White House said today that President Reagan had nominated a career diplomat, Rozanne L. Ridgway, to succeed Richard R. Burt as Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs. Mr. Burt is reported to be a candidate to succeed Arthur Burns as the Ambassador to West Germany. Miss Ridgway, 49 years old, has been the Ambassador to East Germany since 1982.

title: Office Look In Jersey Is Residential
description: GRAND AVENUE, a major thoroughfare in Englewood, N.J., that is zoned for both commercial and residential development, has recently become a favored site for small office projects. While most of them have been contemporary in design, a major exception is Patriot Centre, a 16,000-square-foot office complex at 205 Grand Avenue, just north of Route 4.

title: How Veiled Subsidies Pay for Intercity Buses
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. OFFICIAL SAYS EX-LEADER OF SUDAN COVERED UP FAMINE
description: A United Nations official asserted today that that president Gafaar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan had deliberately suppressed information about the developing famine in his country, allowing the situation to develop to crisis proportions.

title: 13 Illegal Aliens Are Held
description: Thirteen illegal aliens, most from Bangladesh, were being held today at a detention center after their boat drifted ashore here. The aliens, 11 from Bangladesh and two from Sri Lanka, left the island of Bimini in the Bahamas with the goal of reaching Miami, but their 23-foot boat had engine trouble, the Border Patrol reported.

title: Puns
description: It probably didn't help matters any that one of the police officers who made the arrest was named Robert Fortuna.

title: HIGH COURT UPHOLDS VOIDING OF STOUFFER CONVICTION
description: New York State's highest court yesterday affirmed a trial judge's ruling setting aside the verdict in the case of Luis Marin, who was convicted of setting a fire at the Stouffer's Inn in Westchester County in 1980 in which 26 people died.

title: CIRCUIT RESEARCH LABORATORIES reports earnings for Year to March 31
Giants Top Braves in 18th on Brenly Hit
description: Bob Brenly's two-out single in the 18th inning scored David Green from second base and gave the San Francisco Giants a 5-4 victory tonight over the Atlanta Braves. It was the longest game ever played in Atlanta, running 4 hours 40 minutes.

title: Storage Posts Loss
description: The Storage Technology Corporation yesterday reported a loss of $29.6 million for the first quarter, an increase over its $16.6 million loss a year ago. Revenues fell 9.7 percent, to $161.9 million, from $179.4 million. Ryal Poppa, the chairman, said losses may continue through the rest of the year, but ''we anticipate that our results will improve progressively because of continuing reductions in our cost of doing business.''

title: JOHN WILLIAM KISER Jr.
description: John William Kiser Jr., a retired businessman, died Saturday at his home in East Hampton, L.I. He was 65 years old.

title: Elie Wiesel Places Emphasis On Those Who Aided Mengele
description: Elie Wiesel, chairman of the United States Holocaust Council, said yesterday that the fate of Josef Mengele was secondary to the issue of who helped him escape apprehension after the war.

title: SUMO EMBODIES ANCIENT RITUALS
description: For the last week or so the enormous, exotic, kimono-clad figures of sumo wrestlers have been in the news and on television. On Friday these Japanese colossi will get down to serious business in Madison Square Garden. For two nights and on Sunday afternoon they will try to push each other out of a ring that measures 15 feet in diameter.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about the formation of a panel to recommend terms for a settlement in the New York City hotel strike misidentified one member. He is Louis L. Levine, a former State Industrial Commissioner.

title: UNLIKELY TROIKA HOLDS BALLET THEATER REINS
description: Eyebrows went up all over the dance world when Mikhail Baryshnikov, artistic director of the American Ballet Theater, announced last summer that the company was acquiring two key administrators.

title: RADYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: NICARAGUAN OFFERS TO LIFT SIEGE LAW
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua has offered to lift the three-year-old state of emergency in his country if the United States halts its efforts to aid anti-Sandinista guerrillas and resumes talks with the Nicaraguan Government.

title: JUSTICES VACATE DEATH SENTENCE, CITING JURY'S ROLE
description: The Supreme Court today set aside a death sentence imposed by a Mississippi jury, ruling 5 to 3 that the prosecution had improperly led the jurors to believe the State Supreme Court, and not the jury itself, was ultimately responsible for sending defendants to their death.

title: COLEMAN IS A MAN IN A HURRY
description: When Greg Coleman hears about the fuss being made over Vince Coleman, he chuckles, struck by the notion that his cousin has done so well and isn't even playing his best sport.

title: Travels With Bush
description: Through a glass blankly: The prompter has been one bit of campaign technology heretofore missing in Vice President Bush's undeclared candidacy for the Presidency. But now he has begun using the device, which reflects the printed text of a speech on a clear glass panel that is angled so his audience sees him, not the words he is reading. Mr. Bush's role model, President Reagan, is the acknowledged virtuoso of the device and can make an invisibly scrolling speech seem like fresh words newly come to his mind.

title: SCREEN: 'WHITE ELEPHANT'
description: Riding in a Mercedes and carrying a small, tidy architectural model, a British industrialist arrives in Ghana, where he hopes to orchestrate the building of a fully-automated plastic furniture factory. The project will pollute a holy lake and destroy the only local industry, but the industrialist regards these obstacles as small. However, he is not in the region long before he falls, quite literally, under its spell. And all of his assumptions about the superiority of his own way of life begin to crumble.

title: GORBACHEV URGES PLANT RETOOLING
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, said today that the Soviet Union must modernize its economy to expand consumer goods and services and to support the military spending necessitated by ''imperialism's aggressive policy.''

title: EX-F.B.I. AGENT, ACCUSED OF SPYING, TESTIFIES
description: Richard W. Miller, the first agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation ever charged with spying, was granted immunity today as he took the witness stand to testify at the trial of two Soviet emigres accused as co-conspirators in espionage.

title: Peru Denies Payment
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ILLUSTRATED LETTERS It must have been thrilling to have written to Henri Matisse or Pablo Picasso, eagerly opened the reply envelope, and discovered that the letter was illustrated - with a Matisse or Picasso. That experience can be re-created by a visit to the Pierpont Morgan Library. In the current exhibition, 40 original illustrated letters by authors, musicians and artists, from the library's own holdings, are on display.

title: China Restricts Banks
description: China is not ready to let foreign banks set up branches outside Peking and the southern special economic zones, the People's Bank of China president, Chen Muhua, said today.

title: MIDWIVES FACING LOSS OF INSURANCE
description: THE problems that doctors across the country are having with malpractice insurance are also being felt by nurse-midwives. About a third of the 2,500 in practice have been notified that they will soon lose their malpractice insurance, meaning that they might have to give up their profession unless another insurer will cover them for professional liability.

title: JAPAN'S 'SECRET' WEAPON
description: With American corporations' almost sycophantic admiration of Japanese business techniques, it is interesting that what may well be the most subtle, but most powerful, weapon in Japan's management arsenal has gone largely unnoticed.

title: Obese Jersey Sex Offender To Be Paroled in December
description: A sex offender whose brief release from prison in 1982 because of his obesity set off a furor is to be paroled Dec. 17 after serving 3 years of a 15-year sentence.

title: Lance Bank Deal Seen
description: The Calhoun First National Bank of Calhoun, Ga., whose chairman is former Budget Director Bert Lance, agreed in principle yesterday to be sold to the First Railroad and Banking Company of Augusta, Ga., a top official of First Railroad said.

title: GO-BETWEEN TELLS OF TRIPS TO BRAZIL
description: A man identified as an intermediary between Dr. Josef Mengele in Latin America and the Mengele family in West Germany said today that he had carried letters to the fugitive Nazi death camp doctor, but not money, as far as he knew.

title: 26 Held in Bay State Protest
description: At least 26 people were arrested today at a sit-in in an Internal Revenue Service office here to protest Reagan Administration policies in Central America. Tax agency officials said they called the police after about half of a group of 50 people entered the office in the Mohawk Mall this morning and refused to leave.

title: U.S. Tests Nuclear Device
description: A nuclear device with an explosive force of 20 to 150 kilotons of TNT was detonated underground today at the Nevada Test Site, according to the Department of Energy.

title: Centurions Remain Exclusively Male
description: The Century Association takes its name from the fact that its membership was originally limited to 100 men.

title: BancTexas Group
description: BancTexas Group Inc. said it had sold its 19.5 percent condominium interest in Thanksgiving Tower/BancTexas Plaza, Dallas, to Thanksgiving Zane May Associates for $61 million. In addition, BancTexas said it had signed an eight-year lease and four 10-year renewal options with the buyer and would keep its existing bank operations in the building. Alan M. May and Paul Zane Pilzer of Dallas are general partners in the company that is buying the building.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When asked what I thought should be done if the people were guilty, I said I thought they should be shot, though I supposed hanging is the preferred method.'' - Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, discussing those who spy in peacetime. [B8:5.]

title: MENGELE 'DOUBLE' CALLED FERVID NAZI
description: An Austrian emigrant who is said to have given his identity card to the fugitive Nazi Josef Mengele in Brazil was a fervent admirer of the Third Reich who adorned his Christmas trees with swastikas, according to sources in the Austrian town of Graz, where he died.

title: PHILADELPHIA PANEL PICKS STAFF
description: The commission investigating the city's May 13 assault on the headquarters of the radical group Move appointed its senior staff members today and said it would start public hearings on the confrontation in mid-July.

title: Philippine Party Picks Candidate for President
description: The largest opposition party in the Philippines today selected Salvador H. Laurel, a former Senator, as its presidential nominee.

title: The Leaven the Elderly Add to a Community
description: To the Editor:

title: HONOR FOR NIKOLAIS, DANCE PATRIARCH
description: ''I wish I were in a kitchen where I could cook,'' Alwin Nikolais said tonight as he peered out over the heads of the capacity audience at Page Auditorium at Duke University here. A ripple of laughter greeted Mr. Nikolais, who was there to receive the ''Sammy,'' or 1985 Samuel H. Scripps American Dance Festival Award, at the start of the six-week summer festival.

title: Topics;   Symbolic Statements Whose Hero?
description: Over the years, Connecticut's lawmakers have proclaimed a State Bird, a State Insect, a State Animal, a State Flower, a State Tree, a State Mineral, a State Song and a State Ship - respectively, robin, praying mantis, sperm whale, mountain laurel, white oak, garnet, ''Yankee Doodle'' and the U.S.S. Nautilus. Now there is a State Hero, too.

title: JOHN SAYS HE CAN STILL PITCH
description: Tommy John saw it coming. The former pitching star for the Yankees, Los Angeles Dodgers and Chicago White Sox was placed on the ''designated for assigment list'' on Monday by the California Angels.

title: OPERA: MAGIC CIRCLE
description: THE Magic Circle Opera Repertory Ensemble declares unexceptionable, even laudable goals: ''individual development, company ensemble, and the evolution of new works in English for the operatic stage.'' And the company's program of short pieces Saturday at Manhattan School of Music disclosed a distinctive ensemble style, consistent through the varying music of seven collaborating composers. Doubts about its methods, though, arose early and proved hard to shake.

title: Connors Falls to Qualifier
description: Mike DePalmer of Knoxville, Tenn., who advanced by qualifying, swept top-seeded Jimmy Connors out of the $250,000 Queen's Club tournament today. DePalmer, ranked 87th in the world, recovered after dropping his service in the first game to storm to a 7-5, 6-3 victory in only 70 minutes.

title: MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income. Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted and adjusted for a 4 percent stock dividend payable July 1, 1985.

title: NO PROGRESS MADE IN BUDGET TALKS
description: Conferees from the House and the Senate ran into the first snag in their effort to work out a compromise budget plan when they failed to agree today on new user fees and a cut in a key energy program.

title: Fat Cats I
description: The Cosmos Club, in a mansion behind a high iron fence on Embassy Row, is one of the best places in Washington to play power-broker, to grimace across a very dry Gibson at the folly of a whippersnapper, to steeple the fingers judiciously over demitasse, to harrumph a bore to silence, over brandy.

title: Dow Sags 7.50 as I.B.M. Casts a Pall
description: Another gloomy profit forecast from the International Business Machines Corporation tripped up the rest of the stock market yesterday, sending Wall Street to its fourth consecutive loss.

title: ANDERSON BALKS
description: Governor Cuomo announced today that he had reached an agreement with the legislative leaders on a measure designed to curb rapidly rising medical malpractice premiums.

title: IN NORTH KOREA: POLEMICS OF PAST DISCARDED
description: As the train from China crosses the Yalu River, there is no mistaking the legacy of war. A hundred yards downstream stands a second bridge, with all six supports on the North Korean side of the river missing, blown away by American bombing.

title: WEINBERGER BACKS DEATH PENALTY FOR ESPIONAGE ACTS IN PEACETIME
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that a way should be found to execute people who passed military secrets to hostile powers in peacetime.

title: HOW ABOUT CAPITAL GAINS?
description: President Reagan insists his new tax reform program is fair. Yet he rejected the recommendation of his own Treasury Department to end what some regard as the most flagrantly unjust feature of the tax system: taxation of capital gains at a fraction of the rates imposed on wages and salaries. The original Treasury plan proposed taxing the two equally, but Mr. Reagan turned thumbs down.

title: Reed to Acquire Xerox Subsidiary
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that its R. R. Bowker Company would be bought by Reed Holdings Inc., a Wilmington, Del., subsidiary of Reed International P.L.C. of Britain. The deal revokes an agreement reached in April under which the unit would have been bought by the American subsidiary of International Thomson Organization Ltd.

title: CORRECTION
description: A music listing in The Guide Sunday gave an incorrect date for the singer Tim Strong's engagement at the Silver Lining, 349 West 46th Street. He will perform Friday.

title: Mere Mortals Make Managers
description: The longtime conventional wisdom about becoming a good major league manager, of course, is that it helps if you weren't too good when you played the game. The conventional understanding as to the reason for this is that having performed at the level of a superstar - a Frank Robinson, say - you can't really begin to understand the trials of players who are merely mortal.

title: Saudi Refinery Output
description: A new refinery at Saudi Arabia's port of Jubail began loading its first oil aboard a tanker today for export amid the world supply glut. The refinery is owned 50-50 by the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Petromin, the Saudi state oil organization.

title: BRAJDAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $5,423,759 for the quarter and year in connection with the company's reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. c-Net loss. Shares outstanding reflect the exchange of one share of Brajdas stock for 29.412 shares of Micro-Z stock, effective March 24, 1984, as part of the company's reorganization plan.

title: WARNING SIGNALS FOR THE METS
description: There are a few ways the Mets may choose to handle the fallout from the 26-7 pummeling they suffered Tuesday night in Philadelphia in what was easily the most revolting development of the season. It also was a game that evoked memories of the Mets' sometimes wild and wacky past.

title: THEATRE: REVIVAL OF 'DAMES AT SEA'
description: In the theater, revivalism is a risky business, as memories grow dimmer and shows fade like wallpaper on last season's summer stock set. Such is not the case with ''Dames at Sea,'' which is as fresh as it was in 1968 when it began its journey into popular musical mythology.

title: Transactions
description: TUESDAY BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Signed Rafael Palmeiro, outfielder.

title: NETS, JUST IN CASE, SEARCH FOR NEW COACH
description: Stan Albeck's resignation as coach of the Nets to take the same job with the Chicago Bulls grew more imminent today as the Bulls said they would decide by Thursday whether to offer him the job.

title: Offer Is Made For Lee Wards
description: A group of investors led by the executive vice president for specialty retailing at General Mills Inc. is seeking to buy Lee Wards Creative Crafts Inc., one of the company's retail chains, and may also seek another of the company's retail divisions.

title: BROWN-FORMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings for the latest periods reflect the repurchase by the company of 3.7 million of its shares.

title: ARGENTINA PAYS PART OF ITS DEBT
description: Argentina paid $250 million in overdue interest yesterday to its creditor banks around the world, as the United States and other governments prepared to lend Buenos Aires an additional $450 million or so.

title: Fingerprinting Experts Press Mengele Inquiry
description: Brazilian and West German police officers today worked on fingerprints found on documents here that should help determine if the Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele lived and died in Brazil.

title: TEEN-AGE PREGNANCY: SOLUTIONS ELUSIVE
description: Although each year more than a million American adolescents become pregnant, parenthood among unwed teen-agers was not a burning national concern until a few years ago. It is now.

title: Chiat Wins Grand Effie; D.D.B. Gets 11 Golds
description: Chiat/Day might have won the Grand Effie, along with two Gold Effies, among the annual awards for effective advertising given out last night at the New York Hilton by the New York Chapter of the American Marketing Association, but Doyle Dane Bernbach won 11 golds itself and three of its subsidiaries each got a gold.

title: FINNS SAY CAPTORS HAVE BEEN 'NOT BAD, NOT GOOD'
description: The Israeli army took foreign correspondents for a visit today to 21 Finnish soldiers of the United Nations who are being held hostage near here by an Israeli-supported militia.

title: Operating Chief Leaves Datapoint
description: The Datapoint Corporation, the financially troubled computer maker controlled since March by Asher B. Edelman, said yesterday that John C. Butler, who joined the company as chief operating officer last month, ''is no longer associated with the company.''

title: 4 SEIZED IN DRUG SALES AND KILLINGS IN HARLEM
description: Four members of a Harlem gang that deals in heroin and routinely kills competitors have been arrested on murder, drug and conspiracy charges, the Manhattan District Attorney said yesterday.

title: Rebellion Afoot In Transit Depots
description: The Sneaker Rebellion began yesterday.

title: EX-F.B.I. AGENT DESCRIBES HIS AFFAIR WITH EMIGRE
description: Richard W. Miller, the first agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation ever charged with espionage, told a hushed courtroom today how he became sexually involved with a Soviet emigre with whom he is accused of conspiring to pass secret intelligence documents to the Soviet Union.

title: PEP BOYS-MANNY, MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: Share earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split payable July 15, 1985.

title: BROAD DROP IN INTEREST RATES SPURS HOPE FOR THE ECONOMY
description: Americans are enjoying the lowest interest rates they have seen in five years or more. Mortgage rates are down. Car loan rates are down. The cost of business borrowing has fallen. Even the Treasury Department's borrowing costs have plunged.

title: BANCTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Including a gain of $405,000 on the sale of land.

title: Finances and Teen-Agers
description: The Reagan Administration finally found a labor union to support its proposal for a lowered minimum wage for teen-age workers in summer jobs, called the Youth Employment Opportunity Wage Act. The Labor Department has said that 400,000 summer jobs would be created for workers between 16 and 19 years old if the minimum hourly wage for them was reduced to $2.50 from $3.50.

title: Article 049811 -- No Title
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. agreed in principle last night to be acquired by the Texas Air Corporation, parent of Continental Airlines and New York Air, for $793.5 million, according to sources close to the companies.

title: NAVY MEN MET WALKER AT FLORIDA AIRFIELD, MECHANIC REPORTS
description: Several times this spring, an aviation mechanic and his wife here say, the man identified in newspapers and on television as John A. Walker Jr., who has been accused of leading an espionage ring that sold Navy secrets to the Soviet Union, flew alone into a small airfield here.

title: Vampire Label Unfair To Porphyria Sufferers
description: To the Editor:

title: DATARAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a net charge of $2,009,000 for costs related to the discontinuance of certain product lines. c-Net income.

title: ANDERSEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: b-Including equity in loss of joint venture of $12,000.

title: TAX PLAN CRITICIZED BY LABOR
description: Leaders of organized labor today called the Reagan Administration's tax plan unfair to workers and too generous to corporations and wealthy individuals.

title: COST OF MISSILE DEFENSE PLAN SEEN AS CLIMBING
description: A non-Government analyst estimates that a proposed defense against intercontinental nuclear missiles could cost $90 billion by 1994 but might cost even more and face delays.

title: SPAIN AND PORTUGAL SIGN MARKET PACT
description: Spain and Portugal signed a treaty today admitting them to the Common Market. But the occasion was marred by a series of attacks attributed to Basque terrorists that killed four people in Spain.

title: FLAGS, POLES AND MORE
description: TOMORROW is Flag Day.

title: Papandreou to Visit U.S. For U.N. Anniversary
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, elected last week to a second term, will visit the United States later this year for the first time since assuming power in 1981.

title: ROLL-CALL VOTE IN HOUSE
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 248 to 184 by which the House of Representatives today approved $27 million in nonmilitary aid for rebels seeking to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government. A ''yes'' vote was a vote for the aid. A ''no'' vote was a vote against it. Voting ''yes'' were 73 Democrats and 175 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 177 Democrats and 7 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House.

title: 11 OLD BOYS MEET AT U.N., 'THE MIRROR OF THE WORLD'
description: ''There was no south, there was no north, no east and no west - just the 11 apostles,'' Paul J. F. Lusaka, current President of the General Assembly, said as he surveyed the scene with satisfaction.

title: Robert Berrellez, an Official Of ITT in the 1970's, Is Dead
description: Robert Berrellez, a former official of International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation who was once an Associated Press correspondent, died today. He was 65 years old. Mr. Berrellez, who suffered a brain hemorrhage about two weeks ago, died at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles.

title: YANKEES LET DOWN BY FAULTY RELIEF
description: It seemed as if someone had turned down the volume in the Yankee clubhouse. Billy Martin grabbed a beer and walked quietly across the room toward his office. Rich Bordi sat on a stool near his locker and stared at the floor. Dave Righetti spoke, but his words were virtually inaudible.

title: ANNE FRANK'S WORLD: A NEW GLIMPSE OF AN ERA
description: The smile of Anne Frank - perhaps as much as her famous diary - has become a symbol of the power of the human spirit over evil.

title: Article 048855 -- No Title
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that the Reagan Administration would ask Congress for $101.6 million to increase to 21 the number of regional drug enforcement groups trying to break up narcotics trafficking. There are now 13 such groups.

title: MARS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
APPLIED CIRCUIT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $288,000. c-Net loss which is after a tax credit of $257,000. d-Net income. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Certel Inc. in November 1984.

title: Minoxidil's Hair-Raising Struggle Goes On
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics;   Symbolic Statements Broadway Bug
description: Robert C. Wertz, a New York State Assemblyman from Smithtown, L.I., has been trying for six years to get the ladybug declared the State Insect. ''Everybody's always loved the ladybug,'' he says.

title: 12 Cases Are Confirmed Of Legionnaires' Disease
description: A dozen cases of legionnaires' disease have been confirmed among 350 people who attended a church dinner in suburban Detroit, health officials said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Apollo Computer Inc., Chelmsford, Mass., has elected to its board James P. O'Neill, a partner of Regional Financial Enterprises of New Canaan, Conn.

title: REV UP, NEW YORK, HERE COMES GRAND PRIX AUTO RACING
description: To the Editor:

title: Polygram President Optimistic
description: During his youth, Guenter Hensler said he harbored dreams of a career as a pianist.

title: Drop in Yields Slows
description: The drop in interest rates on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds slowed in the latest week, according to figures compiled for the week ended yesterday.

title: Mozambique Insurgency Topic of African Meeting
description: The growing insurgency in Mozambique and possible ways to combat it were discussed here today by Mozambique's President, Samora M. Machel, in a one-day meeting with his closest allies, President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania and Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe.

title: JACK ARMSTRONG, NAMESAKE FOR 1930'S RADIO HERO DIES
description: Jack Armstrong, an Air Force colonel whose name was bestowed on the ''All-American boy'' of the 1930's radio series, died Monday after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

title: HEAD OF I.B.M. IS GLOOMY ON PROFITS
description: The head of the International Business Machines Corporation retracted a two-month-old prediction today that I.B.M. would post ''solid growth'' this year. It was the latest and most serious indication that the computer industry's downturn was worsening.

title: Going Good
description: Three success stories - so far, at least - among three pitchers who formerly worked in New York:

title: CONCERT: BRETTA LUNDELL
description: BRETTA LUNDELL did not start from strength Monday in her recital at Merkin Concert Hall (129 West 67th Street): the three Handel arias she sang wanted lightness, clarity and trills that they didn't get. But strength aplenty was in store.

title: Merger Canceled
description: The Southwestern Energy Corporation said it and the Mustang Fuel Corporation had ended their merger agreement, which was announced just 15 days ago. Under terms of that agreement, Southwestern would have acquired Mustang, a closely held company, in an exchange of stock valued at about $200 million. Southwestern said the merger had been abandoned because of its concern about the outcome of Mustang's rate approval applications before the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.

title: THE POLITICS OF ADOPTING CITY BUDGET
description: At one point in the city's unusually protracted budget negotiations this week, as Mayor Koch's $20 billion budget proposal made its way through a gantlet of elected officials struggling to replace his fiscal imprint with their own, somebody asked who, at that moment, held the budgetary ball.

title: TRAK AUTO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
The Leaven the Elderly Add to a Community
description: To the Editor:

title: A CRITIQUE ON PBS OF VIETNAM SERIES SETS OFF A DISPUTE
description: A Public Broadcasting Service program that will offer a conservative group an unusual chance to criticize the network's prize-winning series on Vietnam has touched off a dispute over whether PBS has given in to pressure from the Reagan Administration.

title: Vote at National
description: National Intergroup Inc. said today that the Leucadia National Corporation's bid last week for four seats on its board was defeated by a margin of nearly 2 to 1. Leucadia, a New York insurance and financial services company with a 9 percent stake in Intergroup, said it wanted board representation to promote a plan to sell the company's assets.

title: BEIRUT HIJACKERS FREE TRAVELERS, BLOW UP JET
description: A two-day hijacking of a Jordanian airliner ended at the international airport here today when the assailants, believed to be Shiite Moslems, released the 66 passengers and crew members unharmed, blew up the plane and escaped.

title: SCIENTOLOGISTS SCALE BACK PROTESTS OVER PORTLAND JURY VERDICT
description: The Church of Scientology moved back a step yesterday in its demonstrations against a jury verdict in Portland, Ore., that assessed $39 million punitive damages against the founder of Scientology and two of its church corporations.

title: Owners' Proposal Rejected by Players
description: The labor negotiators for major league baseball players, not unexpectedly, rejected the owners' comprehensive proposal for a new basic agreement yesterday, leaving the two sides farther apart than ever.

title: PILOTS AND UNITED IN TENTATIVE PACT TO END WALKOUT
description: United Airlines and its 5,000 pilots have reached a tentative agreement to end the pilots' 26-day-old strike, the National Mediation Board announced yesterday.

title: LAMP SCULPTURES OF OCEAN LINERS
description: LIKE many others, Egan Sagik, left, had a special fondness for the great ocean liners, even though he had never traveled on any of them. But because he was also an artist who loved miniatures and was adept at putting together houses from paper kits, he decided to translate the romantic image of the steamship into a series of lamp sculptures.

title: Technology;   Laser Process For Uranium
description: IT is billed as the state-of-the-art technology in uranium enrichment - a step forward that will create jobs, help restore the United States Government's dominance in uranium sales and possibly reduce energy costs for thousands of households and businesses.

title: 8 1/4% Bond Yield Offered by Texas
description: Texas yesterday offered $175 million of general obligation bonds with a maximum yield of 8 1/4 percent for bonds due in 2007 through underwriters led by Citibank.

title: 'The Iceman Cometh' Set for Kennedy Center
description: In what is practically a revival of a memorable 1956 run at New York's Circle in the Square Theater, the American National Theater will present ''The Iceman Cometh'' by Eugene O'Neill at the Kennedy Center this summer.

title: Golf Illustrated
description: Family Media, a magazine publisher, has acquired Golf Illustrated, a quarterly with single-copy circulation of around 40,000. And, since it already owns World Tennis, that brings its sports publications to two and makes it an appropriate time to start a new division called Family Sports Media. Now the company has eight titles.

title: Most Rates Up by End of Day
description: Interest rates were mostly higher yesterday, as early morning declines were reversed during afternoon trading.

title: AGCA ASSERTS SOVIET ORDERED RADIO FREE EUROPE BOMBING
description: The Turkish gunman who shot Pope John Paul II testified today that the Soviet Union had commissioned right-wing Turkish terrorists to blow up an American-financed radio station in West Germany that broadcasts to Eastern Europe.

title: JORDAN ARMS AID MEETS RESISTANCE
description: The Reagan Administration was under heavy political pressure today to postpone any action to sell advanced arms or to seek additional economic and military aid for Jordan, Administration and Congressional sources said.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: A CHANCE TO END THE IRAN-IRAQ WAR
description: The bloody war between Iran and Iraq, now more than halfway through its fifth year, is widely perceived as an ugly but permanent fixture on the international scene. The inability of either nation to score a decisive military victory, combined with the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's rejection of peace except on his own terms, seems to portend an interminable conflict that will end only when he or the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, dies or is overthrown.

title: Plane With 223 Loses Panel but Lands Safely
description: A Trans World Airlines jet carrying 223 people landed safely Tuesday after a 125-pound aluminum panel fell off one wing, the authorities said.

title: Senate Aide Named
description: Senator Bob Dole today named a former aide to President Reagan as deputy sergeant-at-arms, making her the first black woman to serve in the high Senate staff position. Mr. Dole, the majority leader, announced the choice of Trudi Morrison, former associate director of the White House's Office of Public Liaison.

title: MUSIC: BOYS CHOIR OF HARLEM
description: THE Boys Choir of Harlem is a testament to discipline, high standards and commitment.

title: Wiggins Speaks Up
description: At his first news conference since his second treatment in three years for drug problems, Alan Wiggins, the Padre second baseman, said he was ready to play ball anywhere in the major leagues, but that he preferred to play in San Diego because he had a home in the city. Ballard Smith, the Padres' president, has insisted that Wiggins is finished in San Diego because of his drug problems, and there have been reports the Baltimore Orioles have been looking to acquire him.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 13, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Subcommittee on Small Territories - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Experiment Fails
description: Having undergone minor eye surgery in late April, Fred Lebow, the 53-year-old president of the New York Road Runners Club, was advised by his doctor not to jog or engage in any other kind of exercise for a couple of weeks. To Lebow, who had averaged 40 miles of running a week for the last 15 years, this was a bit like being advised not to breathe.

title: MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Including share of loss in joint venture of $103,000 for the quarter and $214,000 for the 6 months. c-Including share of loss in joint venture of $37,000 for the quarter and $92,000 for the 6 months.

title: SIGMAFORM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
STUDY DISPUTES IDEA ON CANCER PATIENTS' ATTITUDES
description: The popular idea that a positive mental attitude helps fight disease is disputed by a new study showing that social and psychological factors do not affect the survival of gravely ill cancer patients.

title: Walton Looking
description: He is 32 years old, his career has been marred by injuries and retirement can't be far off. Before he calls it quits, however, Bill Walton of the San Diego Clippers is determined to play for a winning team, and the Clippers, he has apparently concluded, don't have what it takes.

title: Lester Irving Cooper Is Dead; Produced TV Documentaries
description: Lester Irving Cooper, a television documentary producer for more than 30 years, died of cancer last Thursday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 66 years old.

title: Showbiz Pizza Time Names New Top Officer
description: The Brock Hotel Corporation said yesterday that Richard M. Frank, who is executive vice president of the S&A Restaurant Corporation, will become president of Showbiz Pizza Time Inc., a restaurant chain in which Brock has a controlling interest.

title: At the Carlyle, Picket-Line Civility
description: The guest from England needed a cot in her room at the Carlyle Hotel. As she would customarily do, she mentioned her request to an employee whom she has known for many years.

title: THE BEST PART OF THE SEASON
description: For many basketball fans, the best part of the season begins in June, with the commencement of summer leagues throughout the country. While the regular winter season offers excitement in a relatively structured setting, summerball offers what one scout calls ''basketball without bars.''

title: Bowditch Wins Pro Squash Title
description: Top-seeded Steve Bowditch of Australia defeated Dale Steiner of Canada last night to win the first United States Pro Softball Squash championship at the Park Place Squash Club in Manhattan.

title: METS GET SOME REVENGE IN 18-HIT BEATING OF PHILS
description: On the day after the debacle, the Mets regained a measure of dignity tonight, but it wasn't easy.

title: A.M.C. Plants to Close If Deadline Is Not Met
description: The American Motors Corporation today told the United Automobile Workers that a new three-year contract with two Wisconsin locals must be completed by June 28 or the company would take steps to shut the plants down.

title: JURY FINDS BOAT THIEF GUILTY IN 1974 PACIFIC ISLAND MURDER
description: A man described by his attorney as ''a boat thief but not a murderer'' has been convicted of killing a wealthy San Diego woman in 1974 on an isolated South Pacific island.

title: Deaver Looks Back After a Month Away
description: For 52 months, each time President Reagan walked out to begin a formal news conference, an aide handed him a scribbled note. After a quick peek, the President moved on stage before the cameras with a smile or a jaunty stride, the tension broken.

title: ELECTRO AUDIO DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-Including a gain of $266,000 for the quarter and 9 months from a note and debenture exchange. c-After a charge of $271,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. d-Net income including a tax credit of $415,000.

title: Minoxidil's Hair-Raising Struggle Goes On
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS NATIONAL INTERSTATE BANKING
description: The House Banking Committee mustered a strong majority today to approve a bill that would usher in nationwide interstate banking after five years of regional interstate banking.

title: On Nixon's Rehabilitation of Nixon
description: From his estate in Saddle River, N.J., Richard M. Nixon is reaching toward Washington in what associates say is a quiet but steady effort to construct an image as a wise adviser on current foreign and domestic issues.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: REAGAN-GANDHI TALKS TOUCH ON ARMS
description: President Reagan warmly welcomed Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India to the White House today, saying the United States sought to ''broaden the understanding and deepen the cooperation'' between the two nations.

title: JEWELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
PRESBYTERIANS END INDIANAPOLIS CONVENTION
description: The Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) ended its 197th General Assembly here today after reaffirming its support for abortion rights, efforts to harbor Latin Americans as refugees and divestment in South Africa.

title: ANALOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
NICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SAFECARD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Mazda Agrees To Labor Pact
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation pledged today that it would hire union workers at its new automobile assembly plant in Flat Rock, Mich.

title: Friend of Suspect Protests Dismissal From Police Force
description: A friend of John A. Walker Jr. said Tuesday that she knew nothing about charges that the retired Navy officer's spied for the Russians and said she had been unfairly dismissed from the city police force because of her ties with him.

title: POLAND IS CRACKING DOWN ON ACADEMIC FREEDOM
description: The Government has announced proposed steps to curb academic freedom, and today the Minister of Higher Education defended them as necessary retreats forced by the ''antistate'' and ''antisocialist'' activities of some university circles.

title: GENTEEL HYPE AT THE OX RIDGE HUNT CLUB
description: The horse set began to gather here this week dressed like English gentry but yearning for mass appeal.

title: BRIDGE: RETIRED STAR DEMONSTRATES THAT HE HASN'T LOST SKILLS
description: One of the game's greatest figures emerged briefly from retirement to compete in a recent regional knockout team event in Toronto.

title: FIRST CITY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income including extraordinary credits of $716,000 for the quarter and $1,179,000 for the 6 months.

title: AGENT SAYS JOHN WALKER RECRUITED BROTHER AS SPY
description: Arthur J. Walker was recruited as a spy for the Soviet Union in early 1980, a month before he found a job here with a private Navy contracting concern from which he has admitted taking classified documents, a Federal agent testified today.

title: ABRAMS BEGINS ANTITRUST INQUIRY TO EXAMINE RISING PRICE OF BEER
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams said today that he had begun an investigation of the state's beer industry, subpoenaing the records of more than a hundred brewers and distributors to determine if the way beer is distributed is in violation of antitrust laws.

title: DANCE: CHAMBER BALLET
description: FINIS JHUNG'S Chamber Ballet U.S.A. is a likable little company with an extroverted style, and on Sunday afternoon at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street, its dancers looked particularly fresh.

title: U.S. VOICES HOPES ON 1979 ARMS PACT
description: The State Department said today that it did not accept as ''definitive or final'' the negative Soviet response to President Reagan's decision to abide by the terms of the 1979 strategic arms agreement at least until the end of the year.

title: Wither Weaver?
description: The hottest topic of conversation in Baltimore centers on whether or not Edward Bennett Williams, owner of the Orioles, can persuade Earl Weaver to end his retirement and return to the team he managed for 14 1/2 years. Weaver, who has been in Baltimore visiting his step-daughter, met with Williams at the lawyer's Washington office yesterday, but there was no immediate word about the status of their talks.

title: PRIEST IS CHARGED IN VON BULOW CASE
description: An indictment unsealed here today charges that a Roman Catholic priest lied in a sworn statement he gave in 1983 to help Claus von Bulow get a new trial on charges of trying to kill his wife with insulin injections.

title: NEW SUMMARY
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 13, 1985 International The House voted aid to the rebels seeking to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government. The representatives voted 248 to 184 to send the rebels $27 million in nonmilitary aid over the next nine months in an action marking a major victory for President Reagan. [Page A1, Columns 4-6.] President Reagan praised India and warmly welcomed Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi to the White House, saying the United States sought to ''broaden the understanding and deepen the cooperation'' between the two countries. [A3:4-6.] North Korea still has wide damage from the Korean War nearly 32 years after the armistice. The country is tightly sealed, but a few American reporters are being allowed in for brief visits, and officials guiding them seem anxious not to make too much of the war. For North Korea, the policy marks a major change. [A1:3-5.] National United Airlines and its pilots agreed tentatively to terms for ending the pilots' 26-day-old strike, the National Mediation Board announced. The pact provides for a two-tier pay scale under which newly-hired pilots would initially receive much lower pay than those now employed. [A1:3.] Import curbs on shoes were recommended to President Reagan by an advisory panel that called for a a five-year program that would lead to price increases for both imported and domestic shoes. [A1:1-2.] A peacetime death penalty for people who sell military secrets to a hostile power may be restored. Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said a panel had been formed to determine whether the Uniform Code of Military Justice should be changed to allow the execution of military officials for spying in peacetime.

title: PASSES $27 MILLION PACKAGE
description: The House of Representatives voted today to send $27 million in nonmilitary aid over the next nine months to rebels seeking the overthrow of the Nicaraguan Government.

title: OHIO PLANT FOR HONDA CAR ENGINE
description: The Honda Motor Company said today that it would begin to make automobile engines in Ohio late next year, becoming the first Japanese-owned car company to produce major components in this country.

title: SKI TRAIL PLANNER OPENS BUSY SEASON
description: Even the most stalwart skiers forget about snow and skiing and ski trails by the time the trees are covered with leaves. Not so for Steve Bushey. This is the time of year he begins serious planning for next season's ski treks.

title: Gov. Edwards's Trial Delayed
description: Federal District Judge Marcel Livaudais refused today to give lawyers for Gov. Edwin W. Edwards of Louisiana any more information about the racketeering charges against him and seven other people, but he agreed to delay the trial until Sept. 17. Mr. Edwards and the others had been scheduled to go on trial Aug. 12, charged with scheming to profit by selling the approvals they got from the state for hospitals and nursing homes. James Neal, the lawyer for Mr. Edwards, requested the names of people who are not identified in the indictment but are mentioned as having talked to the defendants about hospital projects.

title: A MEDICAL TURNING POINT
description: The case of Karen Ann Quinlan symbolized the ethical problems posed by the development of life-sustaining treatment that could prolong a life that was bereft of virtually everything that made life meaningful.

title: BRIEFS
description: COMPANY BRIEFS

title: 'FABRICATED TO JUSTIFY'
description: Why is Congress, including numbers of Republicans, in such outraged revolt against President Reagan's policy on South Africa? Administration officials say the whole thing puzzles them. If they mean that, here is a clue.

title: WATERING PLANTS DURING DRY SPELLS
description: GREEN plants must have a sure supply of moisture to thrive. A lettuce plant requires about nine inches of rainfall in its lifetime, and some trees can transpire up to 100 gallons of water each day.

title: Gretzky Honored
description: Wayne Gretzky collected his sixth straight Hart Trophy as the National Hockey League's most valuable player but said that the honor was dampened somewhat by a rule change that virtually eliminates four-on-four skating situations. The change calls for teams to remain at full strength when coincidental minor penalties are assessed.

title: Visitors From India
description: Mohammad Rafiq, a 10-year-old magician, was tired today when he got back from a trip to Mount Vernon.

title: CARDIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $397,400 for the quarter and $534,300 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $150,900 for the quarter and $313,600 for the 6 months.

title: Why Mengele Matters
description: Does it really matter whether some bones and teeth are the remains of Josef Mengele? Forensic studies may or may not confirm his son's claim, suspiciously convenient, that the Nazi criminal died six years ago in Brazil. They will not resolve the wider question: Why keep hunting for the old men who once ran Hitler's murder machine?

title: Judge Takes Leave Amid Allegations
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Queens has temporarily stepped down from the bench, saying he was doing so because of newspaper stories that Federal authorities were investigating allegations that he had taken bribes to influence cases.

title: TECHNODYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-Net loss The year-ago 9 months' net includes a pre-tax gain of $1,829,000 on the sale of a subsidiary. The company is 81.5 percent owned by Electro Audio Dynamics Inc.

title: Midland Joins Rate Cut
description: The Midland Bank cut its base lending rate today to 12.5 percent, from 12.75 percent, joining the three other big British banks - Barclays, Lloyds and National Westminster.

title: THOUGHTS FOR A FATHER'S GIFT
description: FOR a child, a Father's Day gift usually involves making a decision in the men's department - playing it safe with a striped tie, or taking a risk with Hawaiian shorts. But for a mother, the best gifts are found outside of stores.

title: THE DANCE: 'CINDERELLA'
description: MARIANNA TCHERKASSKY and Danilo Radojevic were a well-matched pair of young lovers on Tuesday at the Metropolitan Opera House, where the American Ballet Theater presented ''Cinderella.'' This production, created by Mikhail Baryshnikov and Peter Anastos and danced to the Prokofiev score, tells its story for the most part by filling the stage with stock madcaps and swirling corps dancers in a wide variety of costumes.

title: CONTROL DATA ENDS PLAN TO SELL FINANCIAL UNIT
description: The Control Data Corporation said yesterday that it had abandoned plans to sell its Commercial Credit Company financial services unit.

title: Death Sentence Is Imposed For Killing Jersey Policeman
description: A 22-year-old auto mechanic tonight became the first person in New Jersey sentenced to death for killing a police officer since the state reinstated capital punishment.

title: Sacramento Unit Revenue Bonds
description: The Sacramento Municipal Utility District in California is offering $200 million of revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8.71 percent for 8 5/8 percent bonds due in 2010 offered at a price of 99 1/4 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: SEPTUPLETS EVOKE QUESTIONS ON DRUG
description: A little over three weeks ago a 30-year-old California woman gave birth to septuplets in what will apparently go down in record books as the largest mutliple birth in American medical history.

title: COUNCIL AND ESTIMATE BOARD IN BUDGET PACT WITH KOCH
description: The City Council and the Board of Estimate, facing a threatened veto by Mayor Koch, agreed in principle last night to adopt his proposed $20 billion budget without adding a penny in additional spending.

title: ROBOT MAKER FINDS A NICHE
description: The market for robotics is small and the number of companies fighting for the business is large. The Japanese have been dominant and profits few.

title: SUSPECT ARRESTED IN SLAYING OF GREENWICH VILLAGE ARTIST
description: A 38-year-old drifter was arrested yesterday on charges of murdering a Greenwich Village artist who had met and counseled him at a Bowery agency while training to be a social worker.

title: Wheeling to Seek Payment Waiver
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation said that, because of its deteriorating financial condition, it would be unable to make its $5 million pension fund payment due July 31. The Pittsburgh-based company, which filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in April, said it would ask the Internal Revenue Service for a waiver of the payment.

title: North Carolina Agency In $450 Million Offering
description: The North Carolina Municipal Power Agency No. 1 is offering $450 million of bonds with a maximum yield of 9.55 percent for 9 1/2 percent bonds due in 2019 that were offered at 99 1/2 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: HERS
description: A GREAT many years ago, when I was no more than 7, my parents took me to a family get-together so that distant relatives who had not seen me since my infancy could have that pleasant opportunity. One of the guests, apparently delighted by my growth, walked over to me, grabbed me by my chin and said, ''Honey, do you know who I am?'' I told her I didn't and asked what seemed to me to be the natural follow-up question, ''Don't you know who you are?''

title: PRODUCER MAY GET BEAUMONT POST
description: Bernard Gersten, a veteran producer on Broadway and in the noncommercial theater, is expected to be appointed today as executive producer of the Lincoln Center Theater Company, which operates the Vivian Beaumont and Mitzi Newhouse Theaters.

title: 3 TEEN-AGERS SLAIN IN BROOKLYN
description: Three teen-agers were shot to death and a fourth was wounded last night in a Brooklyn grocery store, according to the police. The police believe that the killer was the proprietor, who fled the scene.

title: AN ANGLOPHONE'S GUIDE TO THE THICKETS OF FRENCH
description: IF you ask a Frenchman to join you in a game of Trivial Pursuit, make sure there are no misunderstandings, since in French ''trivial'' means vulgar or rude (''dire des trivialites'' is to talk smut). On the other hand if he confesses that he has been making ''des coups de telephone abusifs,'' it may not be quite as bad it sounds - he has simply been taking undue or unauthorized advantage of the telephone, probably making personal calls from the office.

title: Banking on Congress
description: While Congress dawdles, the courts are stifling expansion of America's banking system. Last month, the Federal Court of Appeals in Atlanta ruled against the spread of unregulated banks that offer only limited services. This week the Supreme Court approved regional bank mergers that exclude outside banks. This chaos cries out for a national policy. Only Congress can supply it.

title: NUTRI-SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $724,000 for the quarter and $1,028,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,836,000 for the quarter and $2,791,000 for the 9 months.

title: EXPOS DEFEAT CUBS, HALTING STREAK AT 6
description: David Palmer and two relievers combined on a five-hitter tonight as the Montreal Expos ended the Chicago Cubs' six-game winning streak with a 2-0 victory.

title: Of Percy and Women
description: He hasn't been a member of the Senate since January, but Charles E. Percy is still highly visible among the movers and shakers in Washington. The former Republican Senator from Illinois, who was defeated by a Democrat, Paul Simon, in November, is president of Percy & Associates, a Washington-based consulting firm that specializes in international relations and trade. Mr. Percy, who had been chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, is also chairman of the Institute of International Education, an organization working on cultural and educational exchanges between the United States and other countries.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 13, 1985

title: PANEL ASKS CURB ON SHOE IMPORTS TO BOLSTER AILING INDUSTRY IN U.S.
description: The Government's International Trade Commission recommended to President Reagan today that he grant the American shoe industry five years of protection from imports.

title: ITALIAN VOTE: BALANCE TIPS
description: The victory of Prime Minister Bettino Craxi's Government in a referendum Monday marked an important shift in the balance of political power in Italy and the twilight of a period of Communist assertion, Italian political leaders say.

title: Body of Rafter, 12, Is Found in River
description: Scuba divers found the body yesterday of a 12-year-old boy who drowned when a raft he and two friends were floating on capsized in the East River Tuesday afternoon, the police said.

title: TRADITION REIGNS IN OFFICE FURNITURE AR CHICAGO SHOW
description: One might have expected to hear Tevye, the dairyman in ''Fiddler on the Roof,'' shouting ''Tradition!'' around every corner, as office-furniture buyers, architects, designers and space planners made their way through the showrooms in the Merchandise Mart here at Neocon 17, the National Exposition of Contract Furnishings.

title: 60 Soldiers Leave Grenada; Last of U.S. Invasion Force
description: The United States has withdrawn its last invasion troops from this Caribbean island, ending its nearly 20-month presence with a ceremony at the Point Salines International Airport.

title: HIGH-PAY CONSTRUCTION REPORTED RAISING HOUSING AND OFFICE RENTS
description: The huge current investments in construction - and the huge risks they entail - have made entrenched featherbedding extremely profitable for some members of powerful building trades unions but inflationary for tenants of new apartments and offices, experts say.

title: HIGH SCORES LIKELY IN U.S. OPEN TODAY
description: Few sub-par rounds are expected in the 85th United States Open championship that starts at the Oakland Hills Country Club Thursday.

title: AFTER DELAYS, OPENING IS SET FOR BARNEYS WOMEN'S STORE
description: THE long-awaited Barneys New York store for women finally is set to open next February. It will have 70,000 square feet of selling space and will be in a row of brownstones on 17th Street east of the main store on Seventh Avenue.

title: PACO PHARMACEUTICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 11
Key Rates
description: * Municiapl Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Berle's Condition Fair
description: The comedian Milton Berle was cracking jokes with hospital employees and doing ''just splendidly'' two days after major open-heart surgery, hospital officials said Wednesday. The condition of the 76-year-old television and film star was upgraded from serious to fair Tuesday, one day after he underwent a four-hour quadruple-bypass heart operation. He was hospitalized last Thursday complaining of fatigue, and tests revealed cardiovascular disease.

title: WILD AGAIN TICKLES CLOCKER
description: ''How's Wild Again doing?'' a handicapper asked a clocker at Belmont Park yesterday morning. ''Still got four legs screwed on?''

title: ART IS A NEW GOVERNMENT TOOL FOR BUSINESS AND DIPLOMACY
description: In a midtown art gallery, a collection of contemporary Peruvian paintings is displayed in a main hall while in a back room a film for tourists shows rich scenes of the Incan city of Machu Picchu, the deep canyons of the Colca River and the vast colonial monastery in the mountain town of Arequipa.

title: COLLINS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income including tax credits of $144,000 for the quarter and $350,000 for the 6 months.

title: Scott Paper Issues Total $200 Million
description: The Scott Paper Company offered two issues of debt securities Tuesday totaling $200 million through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Mr. and Mrs. Quinlan's Legacy
description: When she was four weeks old, a baby girl named Mary Anne Monahan was adopted by Julia and Joseph Quinlan of Morris County, N.J. They christened her Karen Ann. Karen Ann Quinlan lived for 31 years, the last decade of which entailed nothingness for her and an extraordinary ordeal for her parents.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: PLANS for new, single-family American homes characteristically lag years behind changes in the living habits of the American family. Not until the mid-1930's, for example, did servant quarters drop out of most house plans - even though servants had begun to disappear from the middle class family by World War I. ''The New American House'' - a traveling exhibit that opened Tuesday at the the Graduate Center of the City University of New York at 33 West 42d Street - addresses the new sociological facts of today's household. In an open competition last year for architects and designers, the Minneapolis College of Art and Design asked for house plans that would accommodate the contemporary American family. The New York show presents 25 winning and notable designs.

title: A.T.& T. Sees Earnings Gain
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it expected earnings in the second half of 1985 to improve over the first half, which has not yet ended.

title: Arkansas Families Home After Tank Car Blasts
description: The last of the 900 families forced from their homes when a freight train derailed, caught fire and set off explosions, were allowed to return home today after the flames died.

title: UNION TO PROTEST U.P.I. PLAN FOR CURB ON PAY AND BENEFITS
description: United Press International has proposed a wage freeze and benefit cuts that company officials say would save millions of dollars and help assure the news agency's survival. A union official has denounced the proposal as ''ultimate hardball.''

title: Antiapartheid Activists Report a Plot on Tutu
description: A group of black leaders charged today that a group of whites had been plotting to kill or kidnap Bishop Desmond Tutu, the Nobel Peace Prize winner, and 13 other antiapartheid activists in the next four days.

title: DR. EDWARD I. GOLDSMITH
description: Dr. Edward I. Goldsmith, a professor of surgery and an attending surgeon at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, died of leukemia Tuesday at the hospital.

title: Thanks, Gary
description: After a shaky start with San Diego this season, LaMarr Hoyt is now on track, riding a five-game winning streak that has put his record at 7-4 and his earned run average at 3.13. And, he says, he owes it all to the Mets - specifically to a game at Shea Stadium on May 20, in which, having been shelled for eight runs by St. Louis in his previous start, he loaded the bases in the first inning with no one out and then fell behind in the count to Gary Carter, 3-0.

title: HEAD OF JEWISH THEOLOGICAL SEMINARY RESIGNS
description: Dr. Gerson D. Cohen, the chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary, who ''with great pride'' last month ordained the first woman to be a Conservative rabbi, announced yesterday that he would step down from the post as soon as a successor could be named.

title: GIRL TELLS COURT ABOUT ESCAPING FUN HOUSE FIRE
description: The sole survivor of a group of nine teen-age patrons sobbed today as she testified about how she had become separated from the others in the Haunted Castle when it caught fire at the Great Adventure amusement park last year.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Phillies, at Philadelphia. Finale of the four-game series. (Television - SportsChannel 7:30 P.M. Radio -WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.).

title: AGE OF ENTREPRENEURS
description: THE entrepreneurial spirit grows, but what does this mean? Will the new entrepreneurs save us all, or are they merely harbingers of an upcoming age of greed? ''Currents,'' the Channel 13 series that looks at social change, examines the new entrepreneurs, and on balance finds in their favor. The program, ''Minding Your Own Business,'' at 8 tonight, is an intelligent piece of work.

title: SCITEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Thai-Vietnamese Clash
description: Thai forces today battled 400 Vietnamese troops who crossed into Thailand in pursuit of Cambodian guerrillas opposing Hanoi's occupation of their country, military sources said.

title: Finances and Football
description: After the Reagan landslide, in which only Minnesota and the District of Columbia went for Walter F. Mondale, there was talk among local Democrats of putting out bumper stickers reading ''Don't Blame Me. I'm From D.C.'' It never happened, but now with a hot tax issue abroad in the capital, a sticker is beginning to appear, saying ''Reagan's Tax Plan: One for the Gyper.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SECRECY AND DEMOCRACY: The CIA in Transition. By Stansfield Turner. 304 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $16.95 M ORE than one Congressman has described the Central Intelligence Agency as a ''rogue elephant.'' The institution that Adm. Stansfield Turner found when he was appointed Director of Central Intelligence in 1977 more nearly resembled a somewhat geriatric Missouri mule.

title: JUDGE APPROVES TEAMSTER ACCORD WITH DISSIDENTS
description: In a settlement approved today by a Federal district judge, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and a group of dissidents agreed to allow part-time union members to vote on national contracts and elections.

title: Coleco Reassesses Its Video Games
description: Coleco Industries is assessing its continuing commitment to the video game business, company executives told the annual meeting. Arnold C. Greenberg, the chief executive, said no timetable had been set for a decision on continuing or dropping the Colecovision products or on whether the software for the games would continue to be produced if hardware production was discontinued.

title: San Francisco BBDO Names New President
description: A bicoastal creative type has been corraled to be the new president of the BBDO office in San Francisco.

title: Bird's Cure
description: Medical specialists differ over the cause of the sore elbow that has been bothering Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics since before the playoffs.

title: GET READY TO OBSERVE MAY AS SPEECH MONTH
description: President Reagan signed legislation today designating Mat 1985 as Better Hearing and Speech Month. That's right, May 1985. A White House statement said Congress passed the measure June 4 and that it was received at the White House on June 7.

title: 3 Defendants Silenced, Polish Lawyer Asserts
description: A defense lawyer in the Gdansk trial of three dissidents said today that the court had wrongfully silenced the defendants.

title: THREE RARE HEMLOCKS ON DISPLAY
description: THREE rare, old and large specimens of Sargent's Weeping Hemlock (Tsuga canadensis f. pendula) will be featured at a reception at Marders nursery in Bridgehampton, L.I., this Saturday. Peter Del Tredici, assistant plant propagator at the Arnold Arboretum, will give an informal lecture on the trees.

title: THE FREE SPIRIT OF HIGH-JUMPING
description: Eleven weeks ago, Dennis Lewis high-jumped 7 feet 8 inches.

title: JUDGE IN PRESCHOOL SEX CASE DISMISSES 125 MORE COUNTS
description: A judge today dismissed at least 125 more counts of child molestation in the McMartin Preschool case for lack of evidence, but all seven defendants remained charged with crimes.

title: RISING FEAR OF HURRICANE ON U.S. COASTS
description: Unparalleled development along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts has increased the likelihood of enormous losses from a hurricane, according to emergency planners in several states.

title: HARVEY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: b-Including tax credits of $48,000 for the latest first quarter and $13,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: What Can Be Done About Mom and Dad
description: To the Editor:

title: LATIN TRADE SURPLUSES SHRINK
description: Even as bankers celebrate Argentina's success in reaching a new accord with the International Monetary Fund, they are growing concerned over another, more worrisome development affecting both that country and some of its neighbors: dwindling trade surpluses.

title: Israel Halts Canal Project
description: Israel has abandoned plans for a $1.5 billion project to produce hydroelectricity through a canal between the Mediterranean and the Dead Sea, Energy Minister Moshe Shahal said today. Jordan and other Arab countries had protested about the plan, which proposed a 100-mile canal through the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip. Mr. Shahal said at a news conference he had given the order to abandon the project because of lack of funds.

title: Elizabeth Lindsay Becomes Bride of Karl Kuhnke
description: Nancy Elizabeth Lindsay, a daughter of Alvin Francis Lindsay Jr. of New York and Mrs. Donald William Polzin of Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Karl Helmuth Kuhnke of Henley-on-Thames, England, a son of Ingeborg Kuhnke of Malente, West Germany, and the late Karl Hellmuth Kuhnke. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Westchester 0-6
description: Joe Dawson had a game-high 28 points to lead five double-figure scorers as the Connecticut Colonials handed the Westchester Golden Apples their sixth consecutive defeat without a victory, 104-98, in a United States Basketball League game Tuesday night at Westchester County Center. Jim Bostic and Loews Moore each had 22 points for the Apples, who led at halftime, 52-49. Connecticut (3-3) then went on a 6-0 spurt, moving in front, 55-52, and never trailed.

title: Rev Up, New York, Here Comes Grand Prix Auto Racing
description: To the Editor:

title: NUCLEAR REACTOR NEAR TOLEDO CLOSED IN ACCIDENT
description: A nuclear reactor near Toledo suffered an accident Sunday morning similar to the early stages of the one at Three Mile Island six years ago, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said yesterday.

title: GRACE SAID TO BID FOR ALTMAN CHAIN
