description: W. R. Grace & Company, a large chemical company with restaurant and retail holdings, is reportedly making a bid for a stake in B. Altman & Company, the seven-unit department store chain based in New York.

title: SCHWARTZ BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $58,553 for the latest quarter and $19,000 for year- earlier period.

title: SOUTHERN BAPTISTS' FEUD GOES ON DESPITE CREATION OF 'PEACE PANEL'
description: A fragile effort to make peace among feuding Southern Baptists threatened to come apart tonight amid charges of illegal voting, controversial parliamentary rulings and the leadership style of the denomination's president.

title: New Agency's Name Has a Familiar Ring
description: There is a new ad agency in town called Steinbrenner, Muller, Marshall and the first-named partner is no kin of you-know-who.

title: THREE D DEPARTMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and 9 months' nets include a provision of $400,000 from the discontinuance of the company's wholesale jobbing operations.

title: AMERICAN BUILDING MAINTENANCE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: HOW-TO books on outdoor maintenance, the home water supply and built-in storage units are some of the new publications that should be of interest to do-it-yourselfers.

title: JOHNSON REMINDS METS, 'DO NOT FORGET'
description: When the deed was done and the Philadelphia Phillies had knocked out their 27 hits and scored their 26 runs, the Mets withdrew to the silence of their locker room. They sat on wooden stools and waited as Manager Dave Johnson closed the door, stood in the center of the room and said, without yelling or snarling:

title: BROOKLYN GARDEN PROGRAM
description: Children's Garden, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, 718-622-4433.

title: BLISS. A T & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $52,888.

title: China President Plans To Visit U.S. in July
description: China and the White House announced today that President Li Xiannian would visit the United States in July. It will be the first official United States tour by a Chinese President.

title: U.S. Envoy to Austria Will Resign This Year
description: Helene A. von Damm, the United States Ambassador to Austria, has informed President Reagan that she intends to resign at the end of the year, the White House said today.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Advertising;   Lorimar To Acquire Bozell
description: IN January 1986, there should be another $1 billion agency in the wonderful world of advertising, and its name will be Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

title: SINGLE MOTHERS ARE THE TARGETS IN MARRIAGE FRAUD
description: THE financial plight and emotional needs of women who are raising children alone have made them a popular target for the growing number of foreigners seeking a partner for a ''green card'' marriage, according to leaders of single-parent organizations and the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

title: Fat Cats II
description: Unofficially and jocularly they are known as the fat cats of the Democratic Party. But the Democratic National Committee, understandably more deferential, calls the group its National Finance Council.

title: SMOKELESS TOBACCO STUDY
description: A panel of Government scientists is preparing a comprehensive report on whether snuff and chewing tobacco are health hazards, a decision likely to influence whether warning labels should be required on the increasingly popular products.

title: Orators Hall of Fame
description: The Orators Hall of Fame is not one of the better-known halls in the land, and there are reasons. The hall is situated in Cleveland Heights, Ohio, at the headquarters of its creator, the International Platform Association, which concerns itself with public speaking.

title: Parolee Arrested In Bronx Robbery
description: A 33-year-old Manhattan man on parole in the 1973 killing of an off-duty police officer has been arrested on charges of committing a robbery on a Bronx street.

title: Market Place;   High Returns On Drug Issues
description: WHAT William J. Hayes calls his ''big bet'' on major drug stocks has paid off handsomely for the portfolio manager of the Fidelity Select Health Care mutual fund. So far this year, its total return of 45.2 percent ranks as the best performance among 818 mutual funds monitored by Lipper Analytical Services.

title: SAKHAROV WHEREABOUTS AN ISSUE
description: Travelers from Gorky say there is no sign of anyone living in the apartment of Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner.

title: KEAN SIGNS 4 BILLS RESTRICTING PLACES SMOKING IS PREMITTED
description: Governor Kean today signed bills regulating smoking in the work place, in supermarkets, on public transportation and in restaurants.

title: SECT ABUSE CHARGE DISMISSED
description: Vermont's last child abuse charge against a member of the Northeast Kingdom Community Church was thrown out of court today, five days before it was scheduled to go to trial.

title: INEXPENSIVE TOUCH OF CLASS FOR RENTED APARTMENTS HOW TO KEEP COSTS DOWN
description: HAVING the knack of walking into a junk shop and emerging with a treasure is a talent. So is being able to fashion yards of leftover fabric into balloon window shades or to create a dimensional effect by outlining the ceiling moldings with brown grosgrain ribbon and a $1.99 bottle of gold paint.

title: AT BEIRUT AIRPORT, HIJACKING IS AN INSTITUTION
description: Beirut International Airport is the home of the hijacker.

title: Chip Market Is Still Sluggish
description: Sluggish conditions in the semiconductor market continued in May, the Semiconductor Industry Association said today, citing a a key gauge of the industry's performance that it said fell from already low levels.

title: EATON VANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
PUZZLING SOVIET RERUN
description: This is a period of uncertainty and groping in superpower relations, a crossroads where small steps can be decisive for future directions. There are some discomfiting parallels in Washington and Moscow.

title: Advanced Micro Sets 4-Day Week
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc., a major manufacturer of semiconductors, said yesterday that it expected an operating loss for its fiscal quarter ending this month, and that it would place most of its 8,000 domestic employees on a four-day workweek over the summer.

title: FILM: 'PRIZZI'S HONOR' BY HUSTON, WITH NICHOLSON
description: LIKE Woody Allen's ''Purple Rose of Cairo,'' the only other great American movie of 1985, John Huston's ''Prizzi's Honor'' delivers a kind of high most commonly associated with controlled substances, or with works of art of liberating imagination.

title: New Chief Named For Josephson Unit
description: Josephson International Inc. said yesterday that William M. Lendman had been named president and chief executive of Herzfeld & Stern Inc., the investment bank and brokerage subsidiary that has been losing money steadily since Josephson bought it in January 1984.

title: ALEXANDER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
GULTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 25
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $317,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $336,000.

title: People Express Makes 2 Offerings
description: People Express Airlines is offering two issues of equipment trust certificates totaling $125 million through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Moderate Quake in Alaska
description: A moderate earthquake that jolted Mount McKinley and the rest of the Denali National Park apparently cause no damage, officials say. The quake Wednesday registered 4.7 on the Richter scale of ground motion and was centered about 10 miles south of the park, which is between Anchorage and Fairbanks, said John Sindorf of the Alaska Tsunami Warning Center.

title: Albeck and Bulls Reach Agreement
description: In a move that had been expected for several days, Stan Albeck said last night that he has ''agreed in principle'' to become head coach of the Chicago Bulls.

title: PORT AUTHORITY BACKS FERRY TO JERSEY
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday endorsed a plan for commuter ferry service between Hoboken, N.J., and lower Manhattan.

title: SCHOOL IN JERSEY ORDERS STUDENTS TESTED FOR DRUGS
description: Mandatory tests for drug use will be conducted on all students at a small regional high school here starting next September.

title: PATRONS ENTERED HAUNTED HOUSE AS FIRE BURNED
description: The Great Adventure amusement park continued to admit patrons to its Haunted Castle attraction even as it was burning, according to testimony today in Superior Court.

title: REDMEN TOP FIELD FOR N.I.T.
description: The field for the first preseason National Invitation Tournament was announced yesterday at Madison Square Garden, ending months of speculation and putting into motion what could develop into one of the country's strongest preseason tournaments.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 14, 1985 SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 3:30 P.M. on renewal of United Nations Force in Cyprus. Meets at 10:30 A.M. on Namibia. GENERAL ASSEMBLY Subcommittee on Petitions - 10:30 A.M.

title: THIS 'GROWTH' RECESSION
description: IS the United States economy slouching toward recession? Since the first half of 1984, when the gross national product, adjusted for inflation, soared at an annual rate of 8.6 percent, growth has slowed to a crawl. Real G.N.P. rose at an annual rate of only 1.6 percent in the third quarter of 1984, perked up to 4.3 percent in the fourth quarter and then slowed down to seven-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter of this year, yielding an average growth rate of just 2.2 percent for the last three quarters.

title: THE CAST OF RESTAURANTS NEARBY
description: Along with the blossoming of quality Off Broadway productions on Theater Row has appeared a cast of diversified restaurants and bars where you can stop for a drink or a bite before curtain time.

title: Persistent Giver Gets His Way
description: While one Mr. Koch was holding a news conference this week to announce that the city had reached an agreement with the owners of 40 welfare hotels to provide 1,000 refrigerators for pregnant women and mothers with newborn babies, another Mr. Koch was celebrating his own small victory along the same lines.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: FOR years Spanish cuisine in New York was considered merely a minor ingredient in the great Latin stockpot of foods from Mexico, Argentina, Cuba, Chile and Central America. The recent emergence of several restaurants offering authentic Spanish dishes is slowly changing that misperception. When I heard about a promising new place in the West Village owned by a chef from Asturias on Spain's northwestern coast, I couldn't get there fast enough.

title: LILCO TO BE TOLD TO ABSORB PART OF A-PLANT COST
description: The Long Island Lighting Company will be barred from passing on to its customers nearly one-third of the cost of its new Shoreham nuclear power plant, the chairman of the State Public Service Commission said yesterday.

title: End of the Road
description: Harold Carmichael, the record-setting receiver who failed to find a secure berth after the Eagles released him a year ago, returned to Philadelphia yesterday to announce his retirement from footall and to begin a new career as a travel agent there. ''I love Philadelphia,'' said the 35-year-old Carmichael. He set a National Football League record by catching at least one pass in 127 consecutive games, and also set Eagles' records for most career catches (589), most yardage (8,978) and most touchdowns (79).

title: 30 Held in Marriage Frauds
description: Thirty people have been charged in what officials called a multimillion-dollar ring that arranged fraudulent marriages for aliens seeking to gain legal residency in the United States, the authorities said today. Since 1982 hundreds of aliens, mainly Haitians, paid $2,500 to $5,000 for a marriage, officials said. The new residents also became eligible for Federal and state aid, including welfare and unemployment compensation.

title: Jobless Filings Decline
description: New applications for unemployment insurance benefits declined 28,000 in the week ended June 1, to a seasonally adjusted 367,000, the Labor Department said today. The number of people collecting benefits under regular state programs totaled 2,546,000 in the week ended May 25, the latest period for which that figure was available.

title: PROGRAMMING & SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
STRAWBERRIES ARE RIPE AND PICKABLE
description: A week earlier than normal, strawberries are now ready for picking at farms close to the New York metropolitan region.

title: LIFE OF 'MENGELE' EMERGING: MUSIC, TV AND FEW VISITORS
description: The man identified by associates here as Josef Mengele, the long-sought fugitive Nazi war criminal, led a reclusive life for nearly two decades in and around Brazil's largest city, according to neighbors, friends and a housemaid who says she loved him.

title: RETAIL SALES FELL 0.8% LAST MONTH
description: Retail sales in May sagged eight-tenths of 1 percent from April, the sharpest drop since last summer, the Commerce Department said today.

title: A Promotion At Edelman
description: Richard Edelman has been named president of Daniel J. Edelman Inc., public relations, as his father, the founder, relinquishes the title but retains the chief executive's job. The son will be 31 years old tomorrow.

title: DIRECT ACTION MARKETING reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Large Contingent From the East
description: They were led by the yokozuna (sumo grand masters). The ozeki (those of the second-highest rank) followed a few steps behind, and the sekitori (journeyman wrestlers) brought up the rear.

title: Boeing Jet Order
description: The Boeing Company said it had received a $110 million order from Braathens S.A.F.E., a Norwegian airline, for six 737-200 twin jets powered by the United Technologies Corporation's JT8D-17A Pratt & Whitney engines. The company said the airline would standardize its fleet with 737-200's, selling its two Boeing 767's and four other planes.

title: George L. Chandler, 86, Dies; Film Actor Who Headed Guild
description: George L. Chandler, an actor who succeeded Ronald Reagan to become the 10th president of the Screen Actors Guild, died Monday of complications following cancer surgery. He was 86 years old.

title: Work of Black Artists
description: ''Close Connections: Where We At,'' an exhibition of artwork by black artists, opens today in the Cork Gallery at Lincoln Center, Avery Fisher Hall.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the signing of a treaty admitting Spain and Portugal to the Common Market misidentified Giulio Andreotti. He is Foreign Minister of Italy.

title: I.B.M. Moves PC Unit Office
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, drawing its personal computer operations into ever-tighter orbit, said yesterday that it was moving the leadership of its Entry Systems division to Montvale, N.J., nearer the headquarters of other I.B.M. divisions.

title: 40 Drown in Boat Accident
description: Forty people drowned when a boat traveling from the Ivory Coast to Ghana sank last week, the Ghana news agency reported today. One of the 35 survivors said the boat was overloaded when the accident occurred, the news agency said in the report monitored here.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S CORN BELT: A HARVEST OF BITTERNESS
description: The sun dies quick and early in this, the African winter, and the great estates of the continent's richest corn belt surrender to darkness and cold.

title: CARME INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a loss of $291,388 from discontinued operations. c-Net income.

title: 3 ACTIVISTS SPEAK IN A POLISH COURT
description: Three political activists charged with fomenting unrest made their final statements in a Gdansk courtroom today. The trial judge said he would pronounce sentence on Friday.

title: Military Contracts
description: The Grumman Corporation won a $126.7 million Navy contract for 24 F-14A Tomcat aircraft for the fiscal year 1985, the Defense Department said. It said the Navy had also awarded $71 million to the General Electric Company for material and services for 188 F404-GE-400 engines. Also, a division of the General Motors Corporation received Army contracts totaling $30.2 million for transmissions, and White Engines Inc. of Canton, Ohio, received $33.1 million from the Army for engines.

title: SOLAR AGE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company was formerly the Solar Age Manufacturing Corp.

title: ASKS ECONOMIC AID
description: The Administration announced today that it would seek a $250 million increase in economic aid to Jordan as a show of support for what it said were King Hussein's efforts to move toward peace negotiations with Israel.

title: COMMONWEALTH FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Senate Unit Approves Additional '85 Funds
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee today approved a $13.4 billion supplemental budget for the current fiscal year, including $38 million in aid to Nicaraguan rebels, which President Reagan supports, and expensive water projects, which Mr. Reagan has opposed.

title: THEATER: 'BOB BERKY'
description: IT has taken two years for the second New York International Festival of Clown Theater to arrive in town. During the interval, the sponsors, If Every Fool Inc., have gathered clowns, mimes, jugglers and jokers from around the world. The festival opened in Westbeth Theater Center this week with ''An Evening with Bob Berky,'' a collection of Mr. Berky's favorite sketches and improvisations. One-third of the ''Foolsfire'' team of clowns, he can easily hold an audience in thrall, solo.

title: Melvin Block Is Dead at 57; Headed Trial Lawyers Group
description: Melvin Block, a lawyer and former president of the New York State Trial Lawyers Association, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Massapequa Park, L.I. He was 57 years old.

title: Officials Recall Cheeses After Link to 28 Deaths
description: Health officials today linked two cheeses to more than 80 illnesses that resulted in 28 deaths and stillbirths since April. A statewide recall was ordered and the factory was closed.

title: WALTERS STARTS U.N. TENURE ON THE OFFENSIVE
description: Lieut. Gen. Vernon A. Walters made his debut in the Security Council today and delivered a scathing attack against what he called the misrepresentation of American policy by some delegates.

title: HAPPENSTANCE BENEFITS CREME FRAICHE
description: Rhoman Rule, who beat Creme Fraiche by eight lengths in the Everglades at Hialeah in March, finished ninth in the Kentucky Derby and missed the rest of the Triple Crown races. But indirectly, Rhoman Rule enabled Creme Fraiche to win the Belmont Stakes last Saturday.

title: MATH BOX INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
AGCA, SAYING HE'S JESUS, BROADENS HIS TALE
description: Mehmet Ali Agca, the key prosecution witness in the trial of eight people accused of conspiring to kill Pope John Paul II, today linked the purported plot to two other cases.

title: BRIDGE: ECHOES OF OLD CONTROVERSY HEARD FROM TWO LAWYERS
description: Two echoes have been heard recently from an old controversy, the dispute involving Dr. Richard Katz and Larry Cohen of Los Angeles.

title: LEADER'S DOUBLE EAGLE IS FIRST EVER IN '85 OPEN
description: Tze-Chung Chen of Taiwan today became the first golfer in history to make a double eagle during a United States Open championship. To do it, he holed a 3-wood from the fairway, 255 yards out, on his second shot on the par-5 second hole at Oakland Hills Country Club.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. This is the Yankees' first meeting with the Tigers, who have not gotten off to the fast start that helped them to the World Series last October. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Expos, at Montreal, 7:30 P.M. Dwight Gooden goes for victory No. 10. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Braves vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Atlanta (Television - WTBS, 7:35 P.M.) Boxing Jose Quinones, champion, vs. Arthur Anthony Holt, middleweights, 12 rounds, at the Felt Forum. First preliminary, 7:30 P.M. On the undercard are two 10-round bouts: Enrique Sanchez vs. Jose (Pepe) Vasquez, junior featherweights, and Dennis Jackson vs. Kevin Isaac, cruiserweights. Isaac, from Brooklyn (14-7-2) is returning to the ring after a five-year absence. Golf United States Open, at Oakland Hills Country Club at Birmingham, Mich., second round. (Television - ESPN, noon and 4 P.M., live, and Channel 7, 11:30 P.M. to midnight, tape) Ladies P.G.A. Rochester International, at Pittsford, N.Y., second round. L.I.G.A. Amateur Championships, at Huntington (L.I.) Country Club, 8 A.M. The first day of match play. Sumo Wrestling Grand Sumo Tournament, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. The ancient sport of emperors opens in New York for the first time. Track and Field USA/Mobile Outdoor championships, at Indianapolis. Opening day. There are only two finals today, the women's 4 x 800 meter relay and the women's 10,000 meters.

title: DOW PLUMMETS BY 16.24, TO 1,290.10
description: Stocks tumbled yesterday for their third decline in a row, hurt in part by lingering fallout from a projection of lower profits at I.B.M.

title: U.S. DRAFTING OVERTIME PAY CODE TO COVER STATE AND CITY WORKERS
description: In a move that could mean higher earnings for hundreds of thousands of public employees, Labor Secretary Bill Brock is preparing to issue new regulations requiring state and local governments to meet Federal wage and hour standards, Labor Department and Congressional sources said today.

title: L.I. Man Admits Bribing City Aides
description: A partner in a Brooklyn hardware concern pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to paying bribes and kickbacks to about 20 employees of the City Housing Authority.

title: CML GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
Such Sniping, Such Stuff
description: Not an Administration job goes by that does not stir some sniping between factions of the Reaganite family. The sharpest rhetorical elbows lately are being thrown about for the job of Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, the post to be vacated when Elliot Abrams becomes Assistant Secretary for Inter-American Affairs.

title: GOLDEN SEEKS 3D TERM AS BOROUGH PRESIDENT
description: Borough President Howard Golden of Brooklyn announced his candidacy for a third term yesterday, saying he had led the borough to recovery and growth.

title: ART: RICHARD ZIEGLER, AT 94, MAKES SOLO HERE
description: RICHARD ZIEGLER has most likely set a record by having his first New York solo at the age of 94. With well over 100 works, the show is large enough to occupy the exhibition spaces at Goethe House, 1014 Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, and the Alex Rosenberg Gallery, 20 West 57th Street.

title: Computerland Lays Off 128
description: The Computerland Corporation, the world's largest computer-store franchiser, said that it had laid off 128 of its 1,011 domestic corporate employees as a result of a general slowdown in the computer retailing industry.

title: AMERICAN ELECTROMEDICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
OPPENHEIMER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BROADWAY
description: ''It should be pronounced ''Pahk yo'r Cah in Hah'vid Yahd,'' and that is, in fact, the subtitle of Israel Horovitz's new play.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: JEREMY KAHN played ''I'll Take Manhattan'' on a piano set up among a forest of lilies, white birches, wild asparagus and rambling roses and more than 1,500 people roamed among the Picasso, Moore and Rodin bronzes in the Museum of Modern Art's Sculpture Garden. They ate fresh strawberries and sliced Virginia ham and drank California champagne Wednesday night to mark a revival of a museum tradition, its ''Party in the Garden.'' Until 1979 this welcome to summer had been an annual event, discontinued while an apartment tower rose above the museum and its garden.

title: Strong Nicaragua, Weak Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 14, 1985

title: Addenda
description: Cahners Publishing Co., Newton, Mass., part of Reed International P.L.C. of London, has acquired Physicians' Travel and Meeting Guide, a quarterly.

title: Weaver Renamed to Manage Orioles
description: The Baltimore Orioles, making a move that was more typical of the Yankees, yesterday dismissed Joe Altobelli as manager and brought back Earl Weaver, in retirement the last two years, for the remainder of the current season.

title: INDUSTRIALISTS SAY PLAN IMPERILS JOBS
description: Representatives of capital-intensive industries told a House panel today that the cutbacks in investment incentives in President Reagan's tax plan, proposed as a way to pay for tax cuts for individuals, could cost many of those individuals their jobs.

title: BY T. O'NEILL, MILLIONAIRE
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House of Representatives, is about to join the growing list of high-priced Washington literary properties. The bidding for his autobiography is expected to be completed today, but by the time it adjourned last evening the price offered was said to be near $1 million.

title: Fanny Farmer Chain Goes to Marschalk
description: The Fanny Farmer Candy Shops, that great American sweets tradition that is owned by Poulain, a French food company, has decided to give its advertising to Marschalk, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Coffee Seen as Posing Heart Risk to Women
description: Women who drink four or more cups of coffee a day have more cholesterol and could be at greater risk of heart disease, a University of California study shows.

title: Leniency Sought in Killing
description: Gov. Bob Graham said today that he would seek a prompt clemency hearing for Roswell Gilbert, 75 years old, who was sentenced to life in prison for killing his terminally ill wife. Mr. Gilbert was convicted of first-degree murder May 9 after he admitted he killed his wife, Emily, 73, who was suffering from Alzheimer's disease, by shooting her in the head. The Gilberts' neighbors said she had begged him for death.

title: DIVERSIFIED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,620,000 for the quarter and 6 months and tax credits of $1,677,000 for the quarter and $1,964,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $54,000 for the quarter and $124,000 for the 6 months and tax credits of $97,000 for the quarter and $134,000 for the 6 months.

title: RUBENS WORK IS BURNED
description: A painting by Peter Paul Rubens worth almost $2 million was set afire and destroyed today at the Kunsthaus Museum here, where it was on display.

title: AQUINO DEFENDANTS WIN A KEY RULING
description: The court trying 26 people in the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. ruled today that earlier, self-damaging testimony by the armed forces chief of staff and seven other soldiers was not admissible as evidence.

title: Genex-Searle Pact Won't Be Renewed
description: The Genex Corporation said G.D. Searle & Company does not intend to purchase L-phenylalanine from it after Oct. 31, when deliveries under the current contract will be completed. The chemical is used in making the artificial sweetener aspartame, which Searle sells as Nutrasweet.

title: STUDY REPORTS BLOOD PRESSURE DRUGS ARE SAFE
description: Long-term use of antihypertensive drugs to control high blood pressure is safe and effective, and older patients appear to have a lower rate of adverse reactions than younger ones, a study has found.

title: Miami Printing Set For Herald Tribune
description: The International Herald Tribune, published in Paris for almost 100 years, will print a limited number of copies in Miami for United States and Latin American distribution, starting early in 1986, according to Rolf D. Kranepuhl, its advertising director.

title: FILM: 'SECRET ADMIRER'
description: TO be absolutely fair about it, ''Secret Admirer'' may have sounded marginally funny at the one-sentence-story-idea stage. A high school boy gets an anonymous love letter from a classmate, and the letter accidentally falls into many sets of wrong hands, creating various romantic misunderstandings. Compared with the full-length screen version, which opens today at the Movieland, this account at least has the advantage of being brief.

title: Product Introductions
description: New products in the package goods area reached all-time heights last month, according to the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News newsletter, which spotted 235 of them, up from 226 in May 1984 and from the paltry 183 in April of this year.

title: SPECIAL BIPARTISAN PANEL TO STUDY PENTAGON BUYING
description: The White House will soon announce the forming of a high-level commission to investigate the way the Pentagon buys weapons, Administration officials said today.

title: 202 DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The share earnings are fully diluted.

title: COAST CHILD-ABUSE CASE AT KEY POINT
description: One of the longest legal proceedings in Los Angeles County's courts, the case involving allegations of child abuse at a nursery school, appears to be nearing a turning point after more than 14 months of often bizarre testimony and courtroom behavior.

title: SOVIET DRIVE: NEW URGENCY
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in a major speech on the economy this week, offered the most detailed insight to date on what he had in mind for the future. And he gave notice that he meant business.

title: A CONSENSUS ON REBEL AID
description: After months of debate on Capitol Hill, and countless meetings between members of Congress and White House officials, the outline of a consensus on United States policy toward Nicaragua has now emerged.

title: Lisbon Coalition Ends; Premier Offers to Quit
description: The Social Democrats quit the coalition Government today in a dispute over economic policy and presidential elections. Mario Soares, the Socialist Prime Minister, offered to resign.

title: CHINA TO GET U.S. BOOKS
description: In a further opening of China to Western ideas, books published by American university presses will be exhibited simultaneously in six Chinese cities for a week beginning Nov. 5.

title: Stepping Up
description: Aaron Pryor, the International Boxing Federation junior welterweight champion, will be stepping up in weight in the fall, according to Don King. The promoter said yesterday he has signed the undefeated 140-pound champion to challenge undefeated Davey Hilton of Canada for the Continental Americas welterweight crown sometime in September in Montreal. King also said he was expecting Larry Holmes and Michael Spinks to join him in Las Vegas this weekend to sign for a title fight some time this fall.

title: 76ers Hire Guokas
description: Matt Guokas, who spent the last four seasons as an assistant to the Philadelphia 76ers' head coach, Billy Cunningham, has been chosen as Cunningham's successor, according to a club spokesman, who said the official announcement would be made today. The decision to promote Guokas, one of only two candidates, was made after the other candidate, Chuck Daly, the coach of the Detroit Pistons, found himself priced out of consideration. The Pistons had told the 76ers that they would insist on a first-round draft pick as compensation for letting Daly out of the last year of his contract, and the 76ers decided that was too high a price.

title: Della Femina Gets Hayes Microcomputer
description: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners has filled its computer category and the new client is Hayes Microcomputer Products of Atlanta, which a spokesman described as a leader in the personal computer retail modem market.

title: At Long Last, Marriage
description: After a courtship of 50 years, Patric Farrell and Elsa de Brun are getting married.

title: The Best Students Money Can Buy
description: To the Editor:

title: HELEN OF TROY CORP reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-Net income. Results are for a two-month fiscal year. The company changed its year- end to Feb. 28 from Dec. 31.

title: Race-Walks in the Park
description: Fathers and other family members can go the distance Sunday in two Central Park race-walks sponsored by the East Side Track Club.

title: Persistence Pays Off For Georgia Bank Head
description: Charles B. Presley, chairman and chief executive of the First Railroad and Banking Company of Augusta, Ga., got something he had wanted for a long time on Wednesday, when the bank holding company said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Calhoun First National Bank, which is headed by Bert Lance, the former United States budget director.

title: AUDIO-VIDEO AFFILIATES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
HUBBARD REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including gains on the sale of real estate of $28,053 for the quarter and $54,831 for the 6 months. c-Including gains on the sale of real estate of $723,411 for the quarter and $1,237,381 for the 6 months.

title: INTEREST RATES MOVE LOWER
description: Interest rates were mostly lower yesterday, as credit market participants digested a host of developments that provided conflicting clues about the likely course of interest rates.

title: Canada Seeks Investments
description: The Canadian Finance Minister, Michael H. Wilson, yesterday invited American business to invest in Canada, declaring that ''for too long, Canada has been overly defensive about the role of foreign investment.''

title: Pirates Out For Jersey Bid
description: The chairman of the New Jersey Sports and Expositon Authority said yesterday that two groups of investors had inquired about buying the Pittsburgh Pirates and moving the team to New Jersey. If that is their plan, there is a major obstacle, according to the Pirate official in charge of selling the team.

title: EXPOS OVERCOME CUBS AND PASS METS
description: Andre Dawson, Terry Francona and Hubie Brooks drove in two runs each tonight to lead the Montreal Expos to a 9-7 victory over the Chicago Cubs. With the victory, the Expos moved ahead of the Mets into second place in the National League East, two games behind Chicago. New York trails by 2 1/2 games.

title: NOEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
APPALACHIAN OIL & GAS reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: Results for the prior year have been restated for the reevaluation of certain assets.

title: TCA CABLE TV INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
MORTGAGE GROWTH INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for 12 wks to May 4
description: b-Including tax credits of $137,000 for the latest 40 weeks and $449,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Readings of 2 Plays
description: The actor Len Cariou will play the part of a ghost writer in a dramatic reading of ''Day Six,'' a play by Martin Halpern, this weekend at the St. Ann Center, 157 Montague Street, Brooklyn Heights.

title: Tax Plan Squeezes Public Education
description: To the Editor:

title: ACME GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $54,000 for the quarter and $111,000 for the 6 months.

title: Wet Days in Ohio
description: Rain was so scarce several weeks back that for the first time in major league history, not a single game was postponed in the month of April. But it has been inflicting some minor havoc with its belated appearances recently, particularly out in Ohio.

title: Iraq Reports Attacks On 9 Towns in Iran
description: Iraq reported ''devastating'' air raids on nine Iranian towns and cities Wednesday night and today, and Iran said 37 people died and 75 were wounded in the attacks.

title: LUBY'S CAFETERIAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including net gains of $160,000 for the latest quarter and $550,000 for the year-ago quarter from the sale of land.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municiapl Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THOMAS CLEARS ANOTHER HURDLE
description: Heroin addiction, O.K. The managerial disputes and broken hands, O.K. But Pinklon Thomas refuses to talk about the surgery to repair the damage to the retina of his right eye.

title: Gersten Named to Post At Lincoln Center
description: Bernard Gersten, a longtime theatrical producer, has been appointed executive producer of the Lincoln Center Theater Company, which operates the Vivian Beaumont and Mitzi Newhouse Theaters.

title: GRIFFIN TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
BARBARA WALTERS TO MARRY
description: Barbara Walters said yesterday that she and Merv Adelson, the chairman of Lorimar Inc., would be married in the late fall.

title: BILL ON PRONOGRAPHY OPPOSED
description: Two officials of Women Against Pornography tore down a brown paper wrapper that had covered two enlarged photographs of nude women tied with ropes yesterday. The photos, they said, had appeared in the December issue of Penthouse.

title: IMPLICATIONS OF SPY CASE RIPPLING INTO 2 OTHER SERVICES AND NATO
description: The implications of the spy case involving Navy secrets spread today across the Air Force and Army in the United States and American allies in Western Europe, according to spokesmen for the military services.

title: FUSING YEVTUSHNEKO'S VERSE AND WINTER'S MUSIC
description: ''I always thought that music was the highest genre of art,'' the Russian poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko said the other day. ''Then when I met Shostakovich and we became friends, he said that in his opinion poetry was the highest. I asked him why, and he said because poetry contains music inside itself. Poetry, he said, is music with explanation.''

title: BOOK PLACES NUCLEAR WARHEADS IN 26 STATES
description: A new book says nuclear arms are deployed or stored in 28 states and that New York has 1,900 warheads, the second highest number of any state.

title: INTERTRANS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Diner's Journal
description: LOUISIANA crayfish - also known in the Deep South as crawfish, crawdaddy, creekcrabs, mudbugs, freshwater lobsters and yabbies - have become one of the most important culinary contributions from Dixie since barbecued ribs. Chefs around town have been chartering daily one-way flights for these sweet little crustaceans that come from Louisiana and they are serving them in a variety of traditional, and untraditional, ways. Abe de la Houssaye, the chef at Texarkana, who hails from the self-proclaimed ''crawfish capital of the world,'' Breaux Bridge, La., is organizing a crawfish festival at the restaurant that will run from Friday, June 28, to Sunday, July 7.

title: ADMINISTRATION BACKS INTERSTATE BANKS AGAIN
description: In the face of strong bipartisan opposition from a panel of United States Senators, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker reaffirmed today the Reagan Administration's support for legislation that would lead to nationwide interstate banking.

title: U.N. Panel Questions Lebanese Militiamen
description: Eleven militiamen of the South Lebanese Army being held by the Shiite Amal forces told a United Nations panel today that they did not wish to be sent back to the the area controlled by the militia, an informed source said tonight.

title: Ex-Premier in Belgium Faces Trial in Forgery and Tax Case
description: Former Prime Minister Paul Vanden Boeynants must stand trial on 48 charges of forgery and tax evasion, the Court of Cassation, Belgium's highest appeals court, has ruled.

title: Here Comes Cuomo
description: The plot for the tax-revision struggle should thicken earlier Wednesday when Governor Cuomo comes down from New York to challenge President Reagan's plan, in particular the provision that would eliminate the Federal deduction for state and local income taxes. The National Press Club luncheon that will be his setting has been sold out for two weeks. An audience of 450 can be reliably expected to ask about a subject some consider as inevitable as taxes: Mr. Cuomo's eventual candidacy for President.

title: TESTIMONY ON ARGENTINE JUNTA
description: An official in the Carter Administration testified tonight that a former Argentine military official told her that members of the Argentine Army and Air Force carried out torture during the Government's counterinsurgency campaign in the late 1970's.

title: BROOKLYN GROCER IS SOUGHT IN KILLING OF 3 OVER A SODA
description: The police searched yesterday for the proprietor of a small Brooklyn grocery store who fled Wednesday night after three teen-agers were shot to death and a fourth was wounded in a dispute over payment for a can of soda.

title: Weary Ripley Calls It Quits
description: When the USA/Mobil outdoor track and field championships begin today at Indianapolis, Dan Ripley, who not so long ago was among this country's very best pole-vaulters, will be far away, at his southern California home. At age 31, with no big announcement, with little fanfare of any kind, Ripley has more or less retired from a career in which he ascended 18 feet 1 inch or higher every year from 1975 to 1984.

title: Comings and Goings
description: He's still not happy with his game, but Guillermo Vilas, the Argentine tennis star, says he's not quitting the tour, as he had indicated he might. ''I was misunderstood,'' he said.

title: PLAYERS OFFERED AID ON SALE OF PIRATES
description: Is the baseball players' union ready to go into the franchise broker business?

title: The Rosty Pac
description: The law rather than modesty prevents him from calling it the ''Rosty Pac'' for easy identification.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: THE two-day sellout run of Robert Altman's ''Secret Honor'' at the Thalia last week has led to an extended engagement for the film at the Embassy 72d Street, where it opened on Wednesday. ''So maybe it'll play for four days instead of two,'' said Mr. Altman, nonetheless sounding quite cheerful about the film and its prospects. ''Secret Honor,'' Mr. Altman's screen version of a one-character play by Donald Freed and Arnold M. Stone, was filmed in seven days last February at a cost of $350,000 and was financed by the director himself. Mr. Altman had also been distributing the film, which played briefly in Chicago, Los Angeles and several other cities, where it was enthusiastically received. But he had not, on his own, been able to find any New York theater to show it.

title: LEOPOLD BLOOM DOFFS HIS DERBY FOR A READ-IN
description: JOYCEANS rejoice Sunday. It is the anniversary of the day in 1904 when Leopold Bloom took his epic walk through Dublin in James Joyce's ''Ulysses,'' and flights of actors will gather at Symphony Space at Broadway and 95th Street to read from that novel and other works of Joyce between 1 and 5 P.M. in the ''Bloomsday on Broadway IV'' celebration.

title: John Williams Lecture
description: The author John Williams will speak about writing tonight at 6:30 at the Studio Museum in Harlem 144 West 125th Street. Mr. Williams is a professor at Rutgers University and wrote ''!Click Song'' and ''The Man Who Cried I Am.''

title: GETTY DONATES $25 MILLION TO BRITAIN'S NATIONAL GALLERY
description: John Paul Getty 2d is donating $25 million to Britain's state art collection at the National Gallery, a gallery spokesman announced today.

title: SCREEN: 'D.A.R.Y.L.'
description: If there is a subtext to ''D.A.R.Y.L.,'' and I'm not entirely sure there is, it's that one should always be kind to a computer, because a computer might be somebody's brother.

title: U.S. CHIP MAKERS TO ASK AID
description: Domestic producers of semiconductors, the leading edge of this country's high-technology sector, will ask the Government Friday to make Japan end alleged restrictions against buying American semiconductors.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Creamer In Another Merger
description: THE Creamer Inc. merger last year with Humphrey Browning MacDougall to form HBM/ Creamer has not curbed an insatiable appetite to acquire, as an announcement yesterday by Harold L. Strauss, vice chairman and acquisition specialist, proves.

title: People
description: Jill Boker has been appointed publisher of Art & Auction magazine.

title: THEATER ROW: SMALL STAGES HAVE BIG SEASON
description: THERE'S not much glamour surrounding Theater Row, a short strip on West 42d Street between 9th and 10th Avenues. Its buildings are small and devoid of decorative chic. But the strip does have one thing going for it - it provides some of the most interesting and challenging theater in the city.

title: DINING OUT GUIDE: FATHER'S DAY
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: A SPANKING BREEZE AND YOU BEFORE THE MAST
description: THE CLEARWATER, the boat whose name is the message, is a 106-foot reproduction of the sloops that made the 19th-century Hudson River a highway for commerce, ''apple cider and pumpkins, strawberries and corn,'' as the song says, not to mention cement, furs and machinery.

title: WORLD CONTAINER reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-There were no comparable results for the year-ago periods because the company went public in August 1984.

title: Calculation Standard Set on C.M.O. Yields
description: Major participants in the mortgage securities market have agreed on a standardized method for calculating the yield of collateralized mortgage obligations, the Public Securities Association announced yesterday. The association represents securities dealers and banks in the government, municipal and mortgage securities markets.

title: Oral-B Laboratories Going to Chiat/Day
description: Chiat/Day in San Francisco has picked up a client in nearby Palo Alto. It is Oral-B Laboratories, maker of Oral-B toothbrushes, the worldwide leader in toothbrush sales; Oral-B Dental Floss and Super Floss, and Oral-B Zendium Toothpaste.

title: T.W.A. TO BE SOLD TO TEXAS AIR CORP. FOR $793.5 MILLION
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the Texas Air Corporation, which owns Continental Airlines and New York Air.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday EARTHLY DELIGHTS IN DANCE Moving Earth, the dance company headed by Kei Takei, an avant-garde dancer and choreographer, performs this weekend at La Mama E.T.C. The program will feature ''Light, Part 20'' and ''Light, Part 21,'' both choreographed by Miss Takei, and ''Evocations,'' which was choreographed by Miss Takei and designed by Tetsu Maeda. Performances at La Mama E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street, are at 7:30 P.M. Tickets are $12 tonight and Saturday and $10 on Sunday. Information: 475-7710.

title: ETHIOPIA CANCELS PLANS FOR A CAMP
description: Ethiopian authorities have abruptly canceled plans to construct a new relief center for famine victims that was to be built in northern Ethiopia by a team of 14 Israeli volunteers.

title: Laundering Penalties Sought
description: The Reagan Administration proposed tough new laws today that would impose stiff fines and imprisonment of up to 20 years for anyone involved in money laundering activities.

title: Let Public Power Be Truly Public
description: Dams on rivers subject to Federal regulation produce $5 billion worth of electricity each year at virtually no cost. Who should benefit?

title: REAGAN, IN JERSEY, DEFENDS TAX PLAN
description: President Reagan, in a spirited response to critics of his tax plan, said today that the proposals do not favor one state over another and would not harm taxpayers in high-tax states such as New York.

title: FINALLY, MOSES GETS SOME COMPETITION
description: At age 19, Danny Harris is close to ruling his world. Since his first 400-meter hurdles race 15 months ago, he has run the race 28 times, with 25 victories and three second places.

title: Paine Webber Is Still Bullish
description: DESPITE the recent ragged action of stock prices, Paine Webber Inc. is taking a basically bullish stance on market prospects. ''The sharp drop in interest rates provides the underpinnings to sustain the next leg of the bull market,'' said Edward M. Kerschner, chairman of the firm's investment policy committee.

title: SERVO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Security for Gandhi
description: An extra measure of concern over security is discernible for the visit of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India. State Department corridors buzzed all of Wednesday with rumors of a bomb that in truth was merely a messenger's misplaced package. At the White House, tourists stared wonderingly at a long drop-cloth-like veil of dense white canvas that barred Mr. Gandhi's arrival and welcome at the North Portico from the sightline of outsiders.

title: 10 Killed in Botswana In South African Raid
description: South African soldiers staged a cross-border raid into Botswana early today against what it said were guerrilla targets.

title: ELBIT COMPUTERS reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Elbit Computers is a subsidiary of Elron Electronics Industries Ltd.

title: D'ARCY SEEKS A NEW MERGER
description: When D'Arcy MacManus Masius, the nation's 12th-largest advertising agency, completed a merger with a small New York shop called de Garmo Advertising in 1980, it thought it had solved its problems.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $2.37 billion, to $216.12 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: COTY FASHION AWARDS DISCONTINUED
description: The Coty American Fashion Critics' Awards have been terminated. The announcement to discontinue the awards, which since 1942 have honored American designers, was made yesterday at a meeting of the board of trustees.

title: MERRY-GO-ROUND ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 common stock split paid on June 29, 1984.

title: Shoot Again
description: Walt Frazier, who owns the United States Basketball League's Atlanta franchise, which begins plays next year, showed up for a television interview with Jerry Girard on WPIX the other night to do a little public relations work.

title: HOMECRAFTERS WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: G.M. TO INVEST $170 MILLION IN WESTCHESTER PLANT
description: Executives of General Motors, ending years of uncertainty, said today that they planned to keep their automobile-assembly plant here open in return for a complex set of Federal, state and local incentives.

title: MINNESOTA INQUIRY IN SEX CASE OPENS
description: At first the Scott County Attorney faced an inquiry on whether she should have charged 25 people with sexually abusing dozens of children in the little Minnesota town of Jordan. Now the investigation is focusing on whether she acted improperly in dropping the charges.

title: ARO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Countess Karolyi Dies; Husband Led Hungary
description: Countess Katalin Karolyi, known as ''the Red Countess'' for espousing the socialist views of her husband, a former Hungarian President, has died in France, the national news agency reported today. She was 93 years old.

title: Nabisco Stock Rise Queried
description: Two Senators asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to investigate possible insider trading in the stock of Nabisco Brands Inc. before its proposed takeover by R. J. Reynolds Industries was announced June 1. Senators Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, and Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, said in a statement that they were concerned by the 15-point rise in Nabisco stock between May 24 and May 31.

title: A Not-Bad Bargain With City Labor
description: Both sides regard the new wage settlement for New York City's uniformed forces as ''not bad.'' Both sides are right, though the city probably came out a little worse.

title: Verbeek Healing Well
description: Pat Verbeek, center for the New Jersey Devils, suffered a deep cut in his left thumb in a farming accident last month, the team said yesterday, and underwent six and a half hours hours of microsurgery to reattach the top half of the thumb, which was nearly severed. Max McNab, the general manager, said that Verbeek is recovering nicely and is optimistic he will be in training camp. Verbeek, who is 21 years old, injured the thumb while working on a fertilizer truck at his home in Sanria, Ontario.

title: ADMINISTRATION REPORTED SET TO BACK NEW IMMIGRATION BILL
description: The Reagan Administration plans to support a new immigration bill that would delay amnesty for illegal aliens until a Presidential commission certified that the United States had better control of its borders.

title: Meadow Road Favored
description: Meadow Road, a 5-year-old Swedish horse who has won eight of nine starts this year against top European competition, was installed yesterday as the early favorite in the first annual Statue of Liberty Trot Monday night at the Meadowlands. He drew the rail for the opening leg of the two-part international competition, a $135,000 mile-and-a-half race.

title: SEIS PROS IND reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: SWEDLOW INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes nonrecurring after-tax income of about $300,000, or 24 cents a share.

title: Even Radicals Have Rights
description: State and Federal criminal trials ended in acquittals of gunmen charged with shooting down five members of the Communist Workers Party in Greensboro, N.C. Now, six years after the event, a civil jury has awarded $400,000 in damages to some of the victims and survivors. The recompense for the victims may be limited as well as late, but this is no time to complain about inadequate justice. The acquittals set back American principles of law and civil rights; the civil verdict goes a long way to reassert them.

title: THE SENATE'S GRASS OFTEN LOOKS GREENER
description: As an institution, the Senate may not be what it used to be. But it is still a powerful lure to members of the House, many of whom risk their political fortunes to get to the more prestigious side of the Capitol.

title: CANADA SUPREME COURT VOIDS MANITOBA'S LAWS IN ENGLISH
description: The Supreme Court of Canada declared today that all laws established by the province of Manitoba in English since 1890 were invalid because they had not been enacted in French as well.

title: MONY MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a charge of $2,186,000 for the quarter and a gain of $85,000 for the year from the sale of investments. c-Including gains of $311,000 for the quarter and $804,000 for the year from the sale of investments and a $1.3 million writedown for the quarter and year of equity investment.

title: Friends Again
description: For several years, Mayor Koch and the Rev. Donald S. Harrington have exchanged heated words. Earlier this week, the temperature was changed to warm.

title: Winans Case Meeting Held
description: The judge in the R. Foster Winans securities fraud and conspiracy case called a special meeting of the defense and prosecution attorneys yesterday. He said he wanted to discuss implications to the credibility of the prosecution's chief witness, Peter N. Brant, stemming from Mr. Brant's involvement in a related matter.

title: TELCO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Resulted primarily from the company's previously announced inventory writeoff of about $7.5 million. c-Net income d-Includes an extraordinary credit of $121,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: LET'S FIRM UP THE BORDERS
description: As Congress again prepares to debate the immigration reform bill, the issue of amnesty for illegal aliens residing in this country will be a bone of contention.

title: CHANNEL 13 REJECTS VHF-SWAY IDEA
description: The board of trustees of WNET/ Channel 13, the New York metropolitan area's major public television station, has rejected any effort to exchange the station's channel for cash and a channel with a weaker signal, John Jay Iselin, the station's president, said yesterday.

title: Max Roach Quartets
description: The drummer Max Roach will lead his Double Quartet - the Uptown String Quartet plus a jazz quartet -in concert tonight at the Henry Street Settlement's Harry DeJur Playhouse, 466 Grand Street (598-0400). Shows begin at 7 and 8:30 P.M.; tickets, which are $5, go on sale at 6:30.

title: Jay Barney, Actor, Dies at 72; Appeared Often on Broadway
description: Jay Barney, an actor who performed in more than 20 Broadway shows, including ''Eugenia'' and ''The Immoralist,'' died of cancer on May 19 at Lehigh Valley Hospital Center in Allentown, Pa. He was 72 years old and lived in New York City and in Columbus, N.J.

title: MEMORY DISORDER SEEN AS CLUE TO BRAIN'S FUNCTION
description: A rare brain disorder that leaves its victims perfectly normal except that they can no longer consciously recognize familiar faces - including their own in a mirror, spouses, children, lifelong friends, the family dog - has shed new light on how normal brains work, according to a recently completed study.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: GERMANY TODAY. A Personal Report. By Walter Laqueur. 231 pages. Little, Brown. $16.95. FRANZ ALT is a famous figure on West German television, one of a small group of political commentators who enjoy a far wider following in the Federal Republic than any of their colleagues in the press. Some time ago, he brought out a book in support of the German peace movement that, according to Walter Laqueur in ''Germany Today,'' ''contained virtually nothing that had not been said many times before by other writers.'' Within a few months, however, it had sold more than 600,000 copies in hard cover; as the work of a television personality, it attracted greater interest than the political writings of Heinrich Boll or Gunter Grass or any of their fellow literati.

title: IS THIS WAR NEEDED?
description: Is Nicaragua, one of the poorest countries in this hemisphere, so great a threat to its neighbors and ultimately to the United States that President Reagan may have to use U.S. troops to overthrow its Marxist Government?

title: Storage to Cut 500 Employees
description: The Storage Technology Corporation said it would reduce its work force by an additional 500 employees, adding that the affected employees would be notified on June 18.

title: Article 051873 -- No Title
description: After nearly a week of hectic negotiations, the City Council and the Board of Estimate prepared yesterday to adopt a $20 billion city budget that expands city services - including putting 2,250 more police officers on patrol - without raising taxes.

title: U.S. AND INDIA DOUBTFUL ON ANY ARMS DEAL SOON
description: Reagan Administration officials affirmed today that the United States was willing to sell arms to India, but did not expect any transactions soon in view of India's military ties to Moscow.

title: LANGER BIOMECHANICS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Asians in U.S.
description: ''Mitsuye and Nellie,'' an award-winning documentary on second-generation Japanese and Chinese Americans, will be shown tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. at the Henry Street Arts for Living Center, 466 Grand Street.

title: Ekaya at Sweet Basil
description: The pianist Abdullah Ibrahim, also known as Dollar Brand, will lead his septet Ekaya, featuring the alto saxophonist Carlos Ward and the drummer Ben Riley, tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. tonight and tomorrow; 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. Sunday. There is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: The Bleeding of Nicaragua
description: Some face has been saved and backsides have been protected, but those are not good enough reasons for the House's change of heart about supporting the undeclared war against Nicaragua. After narrowly opposing all forms of aid to the ''contra'' rebels in April, the House now favors $27 million in ''nonmilitary'' help over the next nine months. Since the Senate has voted $38 million for a longer period, President Reagan has won a major political battle. The likely result is that the real battle will drag on, inconclusively.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: MOVERS INCLUDED IN CHARGES OF BID-RIGGING AND PAYOFFS
description: Seventeen people, including executives of four moving and storage companies, were charged yesterday with participating in racketeering activities that included bid-rigging on a contract to move government offices in the New York City area.

title: TRANSMATION INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $62,300.

title: Mets Plummet To Third Place
description: The Mets fell into third place tonight for the first time in five weeks when the Philadelphia Phillies rallied to beat them, 5-4, on a two-run home run by Glenn Wilson off Jesse Orosco in the eighth inning.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY: NEW WORK IN COLOR BY CALLAHAN
description: IT'S admirable, though not surprising, that at the age of 73 Harry Callahan continues to make photographs as he has for the last 47 years, by following his own peculiar path through the thicket of the medium's formal possibilities. What is surprising is how good these new photographs are. His ideas about photography may have matured with the years, but his eyes seem to maintain their restlessness and sense of wonder.

title: 2 JUDGES REMOVED BY NEW YORK'S TOP COURT
description: The state's highest court today removed from office a Nassau County judge who had tried to fix traffic tickets. It also ousted a town justice in Orange County who had harassed an Iranian defendant during the hostage crisis.

title: Xerox China Pact
description: The Xerox Corporation announced that it had signed a five-year contract to produce a telecopier facsimile machine in China.

title: Dangerous Experiment
description: To the Editor:

title: 158 COMPANIES TO CLEAN UP BIG OHIO TOXIC DUMP
description: Under an agreement filed today in Federal District Court in Cincinnati, 158 companies promised a cleanup of the Chem-Dyne waste dump in Ohio, a large-scale toxic waste site.

title: FOR THE GANDHIS, A RUSH OF PARTIES
description: The pomp and glitter of a state visit were combined this week with the inauguration of a major cultural event, and the result was a merry-go-round of luncheons, dinners, receptions, concerts and trips to galleries and musuems.

title: Basque Group Says It Killed 4 in 3 Attacks
description: The Basque separatist organization E.T.A. took responsibility today for the deaths of four people in terrorist attacks the previous day.

title: Police Suspend 5 In Bronx Assault
description: Five probationary police officers have been suspended in connection with the assault of an employee of the police union during a dispute in a Yankee Stadium parking lot, the police said yesterday.

title: C.B.G.B. THROWS PARTY TO PAY FOR RENT RISE
description: HILLY KRISTAL tells his own version of an all-too-familiar story: His small business in an up-and-coming neighborhood will shortly feel a severe squeeze from a new lease that triples the rent. Mr. Kristal's premises are a stucco-and-plaster storefront where the Bowery meets Bleecker Street, at 315 Bowery, on ground level below a 600-bed flophouse. The floor tilts differently every few steps; the illumination is in shades of krypton and neon. Its full name: C.B.G.B. and O.M.F.U.G., which initially stood for ''Country, Bluegrass, Blues'' and ''Other Music for Uplifting Gourmandizers.''

title: FORMER EMPLOYEE SHOOTS 3 IN NASSAU FACTORY, KILLING 2
description: A disgruntled former employee walked into a furniture factory here this afternoon and shot three workers, two fatally, after accusing them of taking his job.

title: Feet, Don't Fail the U.S.
description: For two years Footwear Industries of America has tried mightily to draw Congress's attention to the American sole.

title: Record for Consolidated
description: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company said today that one of its gas wells had set a production record for the Gulf of Mexico. It said one of the four wells on the East Cameron 299 block flowed more than 100 million cubic feet during a 24-hour period, adding that this was the largest daily production rate recorded in the files of the Interior Department. The previous record was 83 million cubic feet.

title: THREE WEEKENDS OF EARLY MUSIC IN CONNECTICUT
description: The Connecticut Early Music Festival is ideally planned for any unfortunate New Yorkers who are not on vacation during June; everything happens on the weekend. Three weekends, to be precise, each neatly arranged into a 7 P.M. Friday cruise with music on the S.S. Sabino in Mystic Harbor, a Saturday program at the Noank Baptist Church at 8 P.M. and a Sunday concert at the Harkness Chapel of Connecticut College in New London at 6 P.M.

title: BURROUGHS AND SPERRY IN TALKS
description: The Burroughs Corporation and the Sperry Corporation said yesterday that they had begun merger talks that if successful would create the world's second-largest computer company.

title: JETRONIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding for the year-ago first quarter have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid July 2, 1984.

title: AT LEAST 5 BODIES FOUND AT SIERRAS TORTURE SITE
description: The remains of a fifth body were reported found today at a remote Sierras retreat that is the focus of an investigation into what officials fear were multiple torture-slayings.

title: ORTEGA SAYS VOTE IN HOUSE FORCES NICARAGUA TO SEEK MORE ARMS AID
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra, reacting to a House vote on Wednesday, said today that he would lift a five-month-old moratorium on arms imports.

title: Emhart Group
description: The Emhart Corporation said it would sell its Hill Store Equipment Group to the Jepson Corporation's Emerson Quiet-Kool affiliate for $60 million. Emhart said it expected to close the deal later this month. Hill manufactures store fixtures in the United States and Canada.

title: UNITED PILOTS DELAY VOTE ON PACT
description: Leaders of the pilots' union yesterday delayed ratification of a tentative agreement to end the pilots' four-week-old strike at United Airlines pending the outcome of negotiations with the flight attendants.

title: BEAMON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
EX-U.S. AGENT TESTIFIES OF A JAMES BOND FANTASY
description: Richard W. Miller testified today that he was acting out ''a James Bond kind of fantasy'' last year when, as an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, he became sexually involved with a Russian woman now accused of being a Soviet spy. The relationship, Mr. Miller said, ''just sort of came with the territory.''

title: Amalgamated Bank
description: Stiller and Meara, the husband-wife comedy team, will continue doing the advertising for the Amalgamated Bank of New York even though the bank has switched its advertising account to Muller Jordan Weiss from Jim Johnston Advertising. Billings are about $1 million.

title: Middle South Plant Ruling
description: Residents of Mississippi, Arkansas and parts of Missouri were told that they will have to bear the brunt of paying for a completed $3.5 billion nuclear power plant that will not be needed until the 1990's.

title: Custer's Really Last Stand
description: Civilization is massing ominously along the borders of Custer's last stand, according to warnings being received in Washington by National Park Service officials. Some of their own people at the historic Montana site are urgently advising going ahead with the Federal purchase of a strip of land that would link the separate parcels of the Custer Battlefield National Monument, which, like the Battle of Little Big Horn 109 years ago, is in two pieces five miles apart.

title: GANDHI, IN A SPEECH TO CONGRESS, CALLS FOR NONALIGNED AFGHANISTAN
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India, addressing a joint meeting of Congress, said today that India sought independence and a nonaligned status for Afghanistan.

title: MILTON POPPER
description: Milton Popper, a lawyer who was active in politics in Nassau County, died yesterday at his home in Long Beach, L.I., after suffering a stroke. He was 79 years old.

title: AUCTIONS
description: EIGHT 500-year-old polychrome picture bowls, excavated near Snowflake, Ariz., after 1900, are among a group of American Indian art works to be auctioned at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street, next Friday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. and Saturday at 10:15 A.M.

title: Pipeline to Pros
description: Whether or not Vince Coleman eclipses Rickey Henderson in the record books this year, he has made sports history - at least in Jacksonville, Fla.

title: Persico Relative Is Found Dead
description: A body believed to be that of the son-in-law of Carmine Persico, the reputed head of the Colombo organized crime family, was discovered wrapped in plastic bags in the trunk of a car in a Brooklyn parking lot yesterday, a police official said.

title: Wanted: Ideas for High-Tech Development
description: To the Editor:

title: DART GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $2,166,000, or $1.25 a share.

title: EXCERPTS FROM GANDHI SPEECH TO JOINT MEETING OF CONGRESS
description: Following are excerpts from an address by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India to a joint meeting of Congress today:

title: Duo at Lush Life
description: The pianist McCoy Tyner and the bassist Ron Carter will perform tonight through Sunday at Lush Life, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (228-3788). Sets are at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M. tonight and tomorrow, 8:30 and and 10:30 P.M. Sunday; there is a $12.50 cover ($10 Sunday) and a $6 minimum.

title: LIFE IN HOUSTON: GOOD, BAD, EVERYTHING GROWS
description: It is already high summer in Houston and the city's legion of gardeners have a look of serious intent.

title: Otis Rush at Tramps
description: Otis Rush will sing and play Chicago blues tonight and tomorrow at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077). Sets begin at about 9:30 P.M. and midnight; there is a $9 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: ASHTON-TATE reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
ON MR. GORBACHEV AND PETER THE GREAT
description: Few people, in the Soviet Union or the West, question the need for Mikhail S. Gorbachev to initiate significant economic reform. Much less certain is how far he will go - and what will be the consequences for Soviet relations with the rest of the world.

title: EXTRA PAY CALLED A COST OF BUILDING IN CITY
description: The hiring of unneeded workers at construction sites is part of the ''cost of building'' in New York City, an executive for an international real-estate development company testified yesterday.

title: NEW SUMMARY
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 14, 1985 International More U.S. economic aid to Jordan is planned, the Reagan Administration announced. It said it would ask Congress to approve a $250 million increase in economic aid to Amman as a show of support for King Hussein's peace efforts. [Page A1, Column 6.] Rajiv Gandhi, addressing Congress, said India backed independence and a nonaligned status for Afghanistan. The Prime Minister's comments were welcomed by United States officials. [A1:4-5.] The man said to be Josef Mengele, the long-sought Nazi death camp doctor, led a reclusive life for nearly 20 years in and around Sao Paulo, Brazil, according to neighbors, friends and a housemaid. They portray the man as an authoritarian, cultivated figure who tended sick animals, never publicly discussed politics and disparaged black people. [A1:5-6.] National Texas Air will buy T.W.A. for $793.5 million. The acquisition of Trans World Airlines by the Texas Air Corporation, which owns Continental Airlines and New York Air, would create the nation's second biggest airline network, after United. [A1:1.] The Senate, backing purer water, voted 94 to 0 to renew and strengthen the Clean Water Act, allocating $18 billion - three times the amount asked by President Reagan - for grants and loans over the next nine years to construct water treatment plants. [A1:2.] A key toxic waste site will be cleaned under a court agreement accepted by 158 companies. Under the accord, the concerns that dumped chemicals into the site, the Chem-Dyne dump in Ohio, will clean up the contaminated water table below it, a process expected to take at least 10 years and to cost about $12 million.

title: ACTING CHIEF OF L.I.R.R. TO STAY IN POST
description: Bruce C. McIver, acting head of the Long Island Rail Road and a former chief labor negotiator for New York City and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, has been named president of the railroad, the M.T.A. announced yesterday.

title: He's Earl Weaver Again
description: Until now, Earl Weaver had resisted for more than two seasons the temptation to sneak a smoke in the dugout runway between innings. As recently as late April, when George Steinbrenner was losing patience while the Yankees were losing games with Yogi Berra as manager, the principal owner sounded out Earl Weaver before anointing Billy Martin for the fourth time. Earl Weaver wisely knew better than to be interested.

title: First City Ferry Was a Rowboat
description: In their glory days soon after the turn of the century, dozens of ferryboats steamed across New York Harbor, carrying hundreds of thousands of commuters every day.

title: Trio at the Vanguard
description: The guitarist Kenny Burrell and his trio will perform tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is an $8.50 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: ARGENTINE BANKS CLOSE TO AWAIT AUSTERITY PLAN
description: The Argentine Government tonight declared a bank holiday for Friday, and officials said that President Raul Alfonsin would address the nation then to announce ''economic and social measures'' to control inflation.

title: V BAND SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: POP-SOUL: MISS SARAH DASH
description: ALTHOUGH Sarah Dash is the least-known graduate of Labelle, the seminal 1970's rock-soul trio that included Patti LaBelle and Nona Hendryx, she is no shrinking musical violet. Miss LaBelle, of course, went on to cultivate the explosive theatricality of a soul-music version of Judy Garland, while Miss Hendryx has excelled in her forays onto the cutting edge of funk.

title: KEWAUNEE SCIENTIFIC EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in January.

title: New York's Executive Order 50 Is About Equal Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: Ball Corp., Muncie, Ind., said it had reached a tentative agreement with Anheuser-Busch Cos. on a five-year extension on Ball's can supply contract for Anheuser-Busch's brewery in Williamsburg, Va.

title: Conductor Has Captain To Pilot Concert Barge
description: The barge Point Counterpoint II, a floating concert stage, sailed out into Lake Michigan early today, released by the Coast Guard after a week of argument over whether the vessel is a passenger ship, as the Coast Guard says, or a yacht, as Robert A. Boudreau, its captain, maintains.

title: U.S. Needs to Show Good Faith to Jordan
description: To the Editor:

title: TSI INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HONOR STUDENT, 17, IS KILLED BY POLICEMAN ON WEST SIDE
description: A police officer on plainclothes duty shot and killed a 17-year-old youth on an Upper West Side street Wednesday night, and the circumstances of the death were disputed yesterday by the police and the victim's family.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We stand for a political settlement in Afghanistan that insures sovereignty, integrity, independent and nonaligned status, and enables the refugees to return to their homes in safety and honor.

title: MARTIN SAYS YANKS LACK BASIC TRAINING
description: Two nights ago, Billy Martin sat at his desk and tried unsuccessfully to absorb a second consecutive extra-inning loss to the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Amax Inc., the minerals and energy company based in Greenwich, Conn., said Donald H. Wilkinson had been named president of the Amax Magnesium Corp., a unit of its metals group.

title: SURVIVAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: SENATE, 94 TO 0, REBUFFS REAGAN ON WATER FUND
description: The Senate voted unanimously today to renew and strengthen the Clean Water Act, allocating $12 billion more than President Reagan had recommended in his budget proposal.

title: ART: REVIVAL OF STILL LIFE FROM ITALY AND SPAIN
description: ONE good thing about the present decade is that it has witnessed the rehabilitation first of Italian still life and more recently of Spanish still life. Both were overdue. Fifty years ago, Italian still life was believed in this country to rank very low in the hierarchy of Italian painting, while Spanish still life was the preserve of a happy few. Still life as an autonomous mode of painting of a high order was thought to have got under way in the Netherlands in the 17th century and in France in the 18th century, and thereafter to have been brought to perfection by Courbet and Manet, Cezanne and Matisse, Picasso and Braque.

title: Senate Backs Fed Nominee
description: The Senate confirmed the nomination of Martha Romayne Seger today for a full 14-year term as a governor of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: ENTREPRENEUR OF TEXAS AIR
description: When historians look back on the airline industry. Frank A. Lorenzo, the president of the Texas Air Corporation and the chairman and chief executive of Continental Airlines, is likely to emerge as one of the pivotal figures in the era of deregulation, just as Juan Trippe, the founder of Pan American World Airways, is regarded as the pioneer in establishing international aviation.

title: AMERICAN SOLAR KING INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $891,099 from the reversal of a tax credit. c-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $708,222. d-Net loss after a charge of $2,605,661 from an accounting change. Year-ago revenues have been adjusted for accounting changes.

title: ADACORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
