description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $103,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $355,000 for the year. c-Net income including an extraordinary gain of $55,000. d-Including an extraordinary gain of $345,000.

title: 'PORTRAIT OF THE PRESS' BY CHANCELLOR ON NBC
description: What is journalism? It's a job, for one thing, and if it's not always practiced fairly, accurately and according to canons of good taste, blame the practitioners, not the profession. ''A Portrait of the Press, Warts and All, by John Chancellor,'' an NBC ''White Paper'' tomorrow night, tells us why. Mr. Chancellor is modest and engaging, and so is his report.

title: NIKOLAI I. ESHLIMAN, RUSSIAN PRIEST, DIES AT 57
description: The Rev. Nikolai I. Eshliman, a Russian Orthodox Church priest who was suspended from his priestly duties for writing a devastating critique of the church in 1965, died Saturday night after a serious illness, it was announced today. He was 57 years old.

title: INFORMATION INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Including gains from discontinued operations of $424,938 for the latest year and $26,070 for the prior year.

title: New-Car Sales Up 15.5% in Early June
description: Despite a lack of manufacturers' incentive programs and a gradual softening in consumer confidence, sales of new automobiles showed surprising strength in early June. Domestic car makers said sales rose 15.5 percent in the first 10 days of the month.

title: Chrysler Plant
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would break ground this month for a $160 million expansion of its assembly plant in Sterling Heights, Mich.

title: THE CLEARWATER TO DOCK AT CROTON
description: The sloop Clearwater will be docked at the eighth Great Hudson River Revival this weekend in Croton Point Park at Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: CDI CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including a gain of $450,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and year from a tax refund.

title: PRIVACY FETCHING HIGH PRICES AT JERSEY DEVELOPMENT
description: Things seldom seem rushed in this genteel community of manicured lawns and wooded lanes about an hour northwest of New York City. Like the shallow, winding stream from which the town takes its name, events seem to unfold slowly and deliberately, as though hastiness, along with nosy neighbors and tacky lawn ornaments, were considered bad form.

title: One Septuplet Is Able To Breathe Without Aid
description: One of the three surviving Frustaci septuplets is breathing on her own, the first of the tiny babies able to function without a respirator, a hospital official said today.

title: Clore Sells Stake In Gulf Resources
description: Alan Clore, former chairman of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation, said that he had sold his 20.3 percent interest in the company to two British investors for about $30.5 million. Mr. Clore also said that he would resign from the board of the Houston-based company. The investors, David and Frederick Barklay of London, and two of their associates will be named to the board.

title: GANDHI EMERGES FROM THE LONG SHADOWS OF HIS ANCESTORS
description: In his first visit to Washington as the leader of India, Rajiv Gandhi has in the eyes of American officials quietly and firmly removed the shadow they felt had been cast over the relationship with the United States by his mother, Indira.

title:
Your Money;

Leases Popular In Municipals
description: OVER the last decade or so, municipal bonds have become a popular investment among individuals, spurred by the growth of unit investment trusts and mutual funds consisting of these securities. Now another type of tax-exempt security, the municipal lease, is beginning to make an increasingly greater impact on the public.

title: EASING BY FED IS SEEN
description: Fresh evidence of a weak economy and low inflation sent interest rates plummeting yesterday and led many economists and traders to predict that the Federal Reserve would soon ease monetary policy and encourage lower interest rates.

title: PILOTS AT UNITED END 29-DAY STRIKE
description: United Airlines pilots approved a tentative agreement Friday night ending their 29-day strike against the nation's largest carrier, shortly after flight attendants returned to their jobs without a back-to-work agreement.

title: Florida Company Sold
description: The Senior Corporation said today it had been sold for $141 million to a corporation owned by the William Lyon Company, a California home builder, and the J.D.H. Realty Company.

title: Hearing on Abuse Cases In Minnesota Is Delayed
description: A commission that is to decide whether a prosecutor should be removed from office over her handling of child sex abuse cases in Jordan, Minn., reversed itself today and decided to delay the hearing.

title: EX-MET TERRELL STOPS YANKEES COLD
description: The Mets considered him expendable, a pitcher they could afford to trade and still be contenders in the National League East this season. Walt Terrell simply figured it was a chance to fulfill a dream.

title: Rabbi Convicted For Role in Melee
description: A rabbi charged with assault and rioting stemming from a melee between a group of Hasidim and the police in Brooklyn in 1983 was acquitted of those charges yesterday but found guilty of obstructing government administration by a jury in Criminal Court in Brooklyn.

title: Holland Tunnel Work To Close Some Lanes
description: New-York City-bound lanes of the Holland Tunnel will be closed at night beginning Monday, when a $78 million overhaul of the tunnel's ceiling is scheduled to begin, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Minor Musings On Met Mania
description: Is there defensive help at Tidewater?

title: SEAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $129,000 for the quarter and $258,000 for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary gains of $135,000 for the quarter and $222,000 for the 6 months.

title: SALES AND INVENTORIES POSTED APRIL INCREASES
description: Sales and inventories of manufactured goods rose in April, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: VIDEO SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
An MX Shootout
description: C ynics who despair of the MX debate's ever getting beyond hypotheses about chaos to some heartfelt sentiments in the here and now should sample some of the knock-down, drag-out views that have been exchanged lately by Senator Malcolm Wallop and the Friends of the Earth.

title: The Pace Setter
description: Owen Gill, the running back from Iowa, has been signed by the Seattle Seahawks to a five-year pact that, depending on who is doing the talking, is worth either $320,000 a year on average (his agent's account) or something closer to $220,000 a year (what the club hints at). Either way, it's not a bad contract, and that's significant to each of the following:

title: CBS BRISTLES AT REMARK IN NBC'S PRESS 'PORTRAIT'
description: A statement made by John Chancellor, the NBC News correspondent, in ''A Portrait of the Press, Warts and All,'' a documentary to be shown tonight at 10 o'clock on NBC, has irked Edward M. Joyce, president of CBS News.

title: RCM TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CHARVOZ-CARSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $496,000.

title: PASSENGERS TELL OF FEAR IN THE AIR
description: ''First thing we noticed were these people shouting and running and that's when we knew we were being hijacked,'' said Irma Garza, one of 19 people who arrived here from Beirut today after being released from a hijacked Trans World Airlines flight.

title: MUSIC: 'JORURI,' AT OPERA THEATER OF ST. LOUIS
description: For the Japanese, ''Joruri'' is both a name from history and a dramatic art form. It is also the title of the new work by Minoru Miki and Colin Graham that played Wednesday night at the Opera Theater of St. Louis.

title: WASHINGTON POST HOLDING CABLE TALKS
description: Capital Cities Communications is negotiating to sell its cable television systems to the Washington Post Company for about $375 million, both companies said yesterday.

title: City-Owned Site Sought for Offices
description: The Koch administration yesterday announced a proposal to build a 16-story office building on city-owned land in Brooklyn Heights that is now a parking lot.

title: LITTLE URGE TO COMPETE
description: It is the most important track and field meet in the United States this year, but several outstanding athletes are missing. It qualifies the most successful athletes for seven international meets, but not everyone is interested.

title: More Drug Tests
description: In Connecticut, where jai alai is an established sport, state gaming officials say they know of no drug or alcohol abuse.

title: EX-AGENT SAYS HE CANNOT RECALL GIVING CREDENTIALS TO SPY SUSPECT
description: Richard W. Miller admitted today that he told the authorities he had given his Federal Bureau of Investigation credentials to a Soviet woman accused of conspiring to spy with him. But he said he did not know whether he had actually given her the documents.

title: Italian Premier Backs France's 'Eureka' Plan
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi of Italy said today that his country would seek to cooperate with a French-sponsored high technology program, but would not rule out participating in President Reagan's program on research into space-based weapons.

title: Two Advocates for Homeless Are Arrested at White House
description: Mitch Snyder, who staged a hunger strike last year until President Reagan promised to assist his efforts to aid the homeless, was arrested today as he sat in a chair outside the White House waiting to meet with the President.

title: Panel Is Wary on Gains Tax
description: Several members of the House Ways and Means Committee expressed sentiment today for disallowing preferential capital gains tax treatment under President Reagan's tax revision plan for certain types of assets, such as gold, works of art, antiques and other collectibles. Some members also suggested that Congress might increase the holding period to one year, from six months.

title: 'CYCLE OF VIOLENCE' IS ASSAILED -- RELATIONS SAID TO REACH A LOW
description: The United States ordered the recall of its Ambassador from Pretoria today to protest South African military raids into neighboring Botswana this morning and into Angola last month.

title: Illinois Relatives Pray For Hijacking Victims
description: Prayer services were held here today for the pastors of three local Roman Catholic Churches and more than 20 of their parishioners who were among those aboard the T.W.A. jet hijacked over Athens.

title: Nevada Ghost Town Bombed by Navy Jet
description: A Navy jet dropped several 500-pound bombs a mile from a practice range, scoring a direct hit on a ghost town that is eligible for listing as a national landmark, officials said Thursday.

title: BURLINGTON COAT FACTORY WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
Cuomo Names 5 For M.T.A. Posts
description: Governor Cuomo has nominated an N.A.A.C.P. official to replace Carol Bellamy on the 14-member board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Paul Silas, the former San Diego Clipper coach, said he had withdrawn as a candidate to replace Willis Reed as basketball coach at Creighton University, where Silas had starred, and would continue his business interests in New York. . . . Joe Barry Carroll, the free-agent center from Golden State, has signed an offer sheet from the Milwaukee Bucks, giving the Warriors 15 days to match the offer of five years at more than $1 million a year or lose him. . . . Mike Norris, the Oakland pitcher who has been battling drug and alcohol problems, started the comeback trail with a lively step Thursday night in California when he pitched six innings for the Class A Modesto A's, holding Stockton to two hits. . . . Jean Ratelle, who was a Ranger from 1960 through the first 13 games of the 1975-76 season, Gerry Cheevers and Bert Olmstead were named to the Hockey Hall of Fame yesterday.

title: BSD MEDICAL (CO) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
GUINNESS SEEKS BELL SCOTCH
description: Arthur Guinness & Sons P.L.C., the London and Dublin-based brewer with diverse retailing and publishing interests, bid just under $400 million today for Arthur Bell & Sons P.L.C., one of Scotland's largest whisky producers.

title: Hints From Holmes
description: It is by no means official yet, but Larry Holmes may attempt to tie Rocky Marciano's record of 49-0 on Friday the 13th of September against the undisputed and undefeated light-heavyweight champion, Michael Spinks.

title: F.B.I. SCRUTINIZED APPLICANTS TO THE BAR, DOCUMENTS SHOW
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation and an prominent lawyers' organization secretly exchanged information about bar applicants for four decades, according to newly disclosed F,B.I. documents.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week.

title: FIRE ENGINEER CRITICIZES LACK OF ALARMS AT PARK
description: An official of the National Fire Protection Association testified today that sprinklers or smoke alarms might have prevented the loss of life in a fire that killed eight youths in an amusement-park fun house near here last year.

title: Walter Johnson Dies; A Historian of Politics
description: Dr. Walter Johnson, a teacher of American political history who was editor of eight volumes of Adlai E. Stevenson's papers, died yesterday at the Memorial Medical Center in Ludington, Mich., of complications arising from a stroke he suffered two weeks ago. He was 69 years old and lived in Pentwater, Mich.

title: BOHEMIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $320,000 for the quarter and $844,000 for the year and a gain of $43,000 for the quarter and year on the disposal of marine construction equipment. d-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,715,000, a gain of $3,657,000 on the disposal of marine construction equipment and a charge of $2 million for cancellation of a timber contract.

title: HELDOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Pickpockets' Scourge
description: Jane Rothchild is an amateur pickpocket spotter.

title: CORRECTION
description: The first paragraph of a Washington dispatch on Thursday about a new analysis of the cost of a proposed defensive space-weapons program incorrectly described the portion of the program that was analyzed. The analysis was done solely on research, development and testing for the program.

title: CORRECTION
description: A roll-call listing in Metropolitan Report on Wednesday, on the New York State Assembly vote to mandate life imprisonment without parole, misidentified Edward Griffith. He is a Democrat from Brooklyn.

title: METROCARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
THE POLISH REGIME CALLS IT JUSTICE
description: I went to Poland last month to try to observe the trial of three Solidarity leaders, Adam Michnik, Bogdan Lis and Wladyslaw Frasyniuk. I had been to Poland twice before, once during the heady days before martial law, but my experience this time was deeply revealing for me.

title: COASTAL INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Underground: Not-So-Stainless Steel
description: The first new train in 20 years on New York City's Seventh Avenue subway line hadn't been in service a day before its gleaming stainless steel cars were streaked with graffiti. By the end of its first week, the train had been defaced seven times and needed replacements for five broken windows at a cost of $1,300.

title: LIFETIME COMMUNITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $50,711 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: RELATIVES CONCERNED OVER FATE OF THE SAKHAROVS
description: The stepchildren of Andrei D. Sakharov said today that they were alarmed by the apparent disappearance of the Soviet dissident and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, from their apartment in the Volga River city of Gorky.

title: INSTALLMENT DEBT RISES
description: Americans took on $8.27 billion more in installment debt than they paid off in April, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: U.S. Condemns Soviet For Its Policy on Jews
description: The Soviet Union is pursuing a ''tragic and needless'' campaign against Jews that threatens to block improvement in American-Soviet relations, Bernard Kalb, the State Department spokesman, said today.

title: Wrong Grand Jury Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: WARNING: FIREWORKS AHEAD
description: AS the Fourth of July approaches, the Government is warning consumers about mail-order fireworks kits that it says are unsafe and often injure young people who wind up mixing powerful explosives in their own homes.

title:
PATENTS;

Improved Way Devised To Make Nuclear Fuel
description: The General Electric Company, in San Diego, received a patent this week for an improved method of manufacturing nuclear fuel.

title: PASSENGER KILLED
description: Gunmen commandeered a Trans World Airlines jetliner with 104 Americans and 49 other people aboard yesterday and forced it to fly on a twisting course from Athens to Beirut to Algiers, then back to Beirut, where one passenger was shot to death, and again to Algiers.

title: Rate Hopes Send Dow Up by 10.86, to 1,300.96
description: The stock market scored its first advance in a week yesterday as investors, once again convinced that interest rates would move lower, scrambled to buy recently devalued equities.

title: MEGADATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
IN ATHLETIC SHOES REEBOK LEADS THE PACK
description: Some call them sneakers. Others refer to them more accurately as athletic shoes. They may have been designed for running, tennis, basketball or aerobics, but they are just as often worn for simply walking the streets of New York.

title: Police Hunt Continues In Slayings at Grocery
description: Detectives searching for the Brooklyn grocer who is a suspect in the shooting deaths of three teen-agers and the wounding of a fourth Wednesday night said yesterday that they had made little progress in finding the man.

title: OVER THE BIG-POWER CHASM
description: The long impasse between the Soviet Union and United States may possibly now be resolved. The unfolding of recent events may make the time right and ripe. An opportunity has arisen that will enable the present antagonism to suddenly melt into a cooperative spirit.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municiapl Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MOSCOW EXPELS AN AMERICAN DIPLOMAT AS A SPY
description: An American diplomat who Moscow says was caught in the act of spying is being expelled from the Soviet Union, the Tass press agency said today.

title: A WOLF, A BOMB SHELTER AND A TRIP TO REMEMBER
description: Never mind that a classmate kept pulling Alexis Gonzalez's hair or that Tommy Faglon thought the most interesting thing about Albany was the State Museum's stuffed wolf. History, of sorts, was being made here.

title: WHAT'S REALLY BIG NOW? TINY VEGETABLES
description: The vogue in vegetables is one of youth. Baby eggplants are very big nowadays. Baby bok choy, baby beets, baby curly endive and baby leeks are prized. The thing about baby leeks is that they look like onions. Baby onions look strange.

title: A FORMER EMPLOYEE IS ARRAIGNED IN SLAYING OF L.I. FACTORY WORKERS
description: A 29-year-old former employee of a furniture factory was arraigned this afternoon in Nassau County District Court on charges of fatally shooting two men at the plant yesterday after accusing them of causing him to lose his job.

title: Bridge: Experts, if Lacking in Luck, Can Get Lesson in Humility
description: That genial dustman, Alfred P. Doolittle, sang about the importance of ''a little bit of luck.'' And bridge players can agree with him.

title: QUINLAN FUNERAL IS A QUIET FAREWELL
description: A mass of the Resurrection steeped in the themes of biblical sustenance and devotion of friends was celebrated in this country hamlet today for Karen Ann Quinlan.

title: U.S. BISHOPS, IN FACE OF CRITICISM, BACK DRAFT OF LETTER ON ECONOMY
description: The hotly debated effort by the nation's Roman Catholic bishops to draft a pastoral letter on the United States economy faced some of its most demanding critics today: the bishops themselves. But their criticism was generally limited to the document's form rather than its content.

title: LOSS SEEN
description: Apple Computer Inc., battling a fierce downturn in personal computers as well as problems in its own ranks, said yesterday that it was laying off 1,200 employees, more than a fifth of its work force.

title: SUICIDE CAR BOMB KILLS 23 AT ARMY POSITION IN BEIRUT
description: Two suicide bombers crashed a car loaded with explosives into a Lebanese Army position in West Beirut today, killing 23 people and wounding 36, the state radio said.

title: Some Heroes of African Famine Relief
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: NORTHSTAR MINERALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $78,200.

title: Israel Inflation Eases
description: Israel's monthly inflation rate slowed sharply in May, but officials took little comfort from the result, saying the economy was showing no signs of improvement. The Central Bureau of Statistics said today that prices rose by 6.8 percent in May, compared with a gain of 19.4 percent in April.

title: DANCE: 'IN MEMORY OF ...,' A NEW ROBBINS BALLET
description: Jerome Robbins has choreographed a moving ballet titled ''In Memory of . . . '' and it is about a young woman, personified with piteous beauty by Suzanne Farrell, who comes to terms with her own death.

title: POLICE SAY OTHERS SAW STUDENT ATTACK OFFICER
description: The police said yesterday that they had found witnesses who corroborated a plainclothesman's account of being assaulted before he fatally shot a 17-year-old Harlem youth outside Morningside Park Wednesday night.

title: HALIFAX ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a net loss of $212,116 from discontinued operations. c-Net income including net income from discontinued operations of $19,217.

title: Inviting Insult
description: The San Francisco Giants are batting .213, the worst average in the majors, which helps explain why they have been shut out nine times, the worst total in the majors, and why through Thursday's play they had scored only 6 runs in 82 innings. Further, their record against San Diego, whose Dave Dravecky and Goose Gossage blanked them Thursday night, was 1-4 entering last night's game at Candlestick Park.

title:
PATENTS;

Filter for Mobile Phone is Aid to Fine-Tuning
description: A microwave filter for mobile telephones, patented this week for AT&T; Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J., makes fine-tuning in the factory easier, cheaper and more reliable.

title: CONTAMINATED CHEESE TIED TO 29 DEATHS
description: Thousands of pounds of cheeses were being removed today from stores in 13 states after health officials found that bacterial contamination had caused 29 deaths and stillbirths in California.

title: HANDWRITING EXPERTS SAY LETTERS FOUND IN BRAZIL WERE MENGELE'S
description: Two American handwriting experts said tonight that they had positively identified letters found in Brazil as having been written by Josef Mengele, the fugitive Nazi war criminal.

title: O'Neill Considers a Publisher
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Speaker of the House of Representatives, is expected to announce a decision today on a publisher for his autobiography.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: 1. It is the Faberge Cuckoo Egg. With the purchase of the egg, Malcolm Forbes surpassed the Soviet Government and now owns more of the eggs than any other collector.

title: RAPID AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including a gain of $73,966,000 on the sale of operations sold and an extraordinary charge of $4,015,000. c-Net loss including income from discontinued operations of $3,160,000 and an extraordinary charge of $18,317,000. Year-ago results have been restated for the sale of Lerner Stores Corp.

title: INTERPHASE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FINAL PLEAS OFFERED IN MAINE'S LAWSUIT AGAINST SEARS STORES
description: Final arguments were presented today in Maine's consumer lawsuit against Sears, Roebuck & Company. The state contends the retailer sells extended maintenance warranties that illegally duplicate warranties already required by law.

title: Japan Growth Sluggish
description: Declining exports and sluggish private investment practically stalled Japan's economy in the first three months of 1985, the Government reported today. Japan's gross national product grew only one-tenth of 1 percent from January through March, which was the final quarter of Japan's fiscal year. The economy grew 2.4 percent from October to December, and for the full fiscal year, the economy grew at a 5.7 percent rate after inflation, the highest since 1972.

title: MIXED VIEW IN BRITAIN ON U.S. ARTS FESTIVAL
description: Some art exhibitions remain and a handful of artists and performers are still touring Britain, but the American Festival, a monthlong celebration of American art and culture billed as the largest such event ever mounted outside the United States, has ended without fanfare.

title: 5 INDICTED FOR VIOLATING MACHINE-GUN RESTRICTIONS
description: Five people connected with three different companies have been indicted on Federal firearms charges in what officials said today was a new approach to restricting the availability of illegal machine guns and silencers around the country.

title: BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for 16wks to May 18
description: b-Including a tax credit of $310,000. c-Net loss.

title: PROLER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Sperry Said to Get Burroughs Offer
description: Directors of the Burroughs Corporation made a formal offer yesterday to buy the Sperry Corporation, according to sources close to the negotiations.

title: U.S. Issues: Shift by Japan
description: The Japanese Ministry of Finance said this week that, for the first time, zero coupon Treasury issues may be bought by Japanese investors.

title: CUOMO'S ROLE IN U.S. TAX-PLAN FIGHT
description: Governor Cuomo says he perceives ''a perverse syndrome: that what is bad for New York is good for the nation.'' He says he is also aware that, to many people, he personifies New York.

title: LILCO WINS FEDERAL BOARD'S APPROVAL FOR LOW-POWER TESTING AT SHOREHAM
description: The Shoreham nuclear power station was authorized yesterday to begin tests at up to 5 percent of its full power output, a crucial step in the efforts of the Long Island Lighting Company to put the plant into commercial operation.

title: ODETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $301,000.

title: CORRECTION
description: The headline yesterday on a Washington dispatch about a new book on nuclear arms in the United States misstated the number of states in which the book says such arms are deployed or stored. It is 28, not 26.

title: Medical Error Reported At Coast Army Hospital
description: A woman being treated for a miscarriage at Madigan Army Medical Center was accidentally injected with a formaldehyde solution instead of a painkiller, The Seattle Times has reported.

title: PENTAGON TO DISMISS AUDITOR
description: The Department of Defense said today that it would obey an order of the Merit System Protection Board and dismiss Charles O. Starrett Jr., the Pentagon's chief civilian auditor. The Pentagon said he would be dismissed Monday.

title: PRODUCER PRICES UP ONLY 0.2% IN MAY
description: Prices at the producer level remained in check last month, with a rise in energy prices all but offset by sharply lower food costs, the Labor Department reported today.

title: A PENNSYLVANIA FAMILY THAT LOST ITS FARM IS WORKING NOW TO FIND ITSELF
description: Sometimes on weekends, out of sheer longing, Gary and Cheryl Matulevich drive their 1972 Dodge Dart out to the dairy farm where until lately they helped supply milk for New Yorkers and lived what they considered a hard-working but happy life.

title: HOUSE PANEL OPENS INQUIRY ON U.S. EFFORTS TO COMBAT SPYING
description: The House Select Committee on Intelligence has begun an investigation of the spy case against John A. Walker Jr. and of American counterintelligence efforts, officials said today.

title: SUMMER IN SUBWAYS: COOLER, BUT NOT COOL ENOUGH
description: Although New York City transit officials are promising to put more air-conditioned buses and subway cars into service this year, they say most passengers can expect many hot, sweaty rides.

title: Rangers Narrow List to 5
description: The National Hockey League's annual amateur draft, which takes place here Saturday afternoon, continued to be upstaged today by the Rangers' pursuit of a new coach. Craig Patrick, the Ranger general manager, said that he had trimmed the list of coaching candidates to five names - from about 20 interviewed - and that he would like to name his new man next week.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LOOKING UP

title: Halfway Out of a Uranium Imbroglio
description: Enriching uranium as fuel for nuclear reactors is a $2 billion-a-year business run by the Department of Energy. By miscalculating markets and mismanaging technology, the department has run the business into the ground. Last week, in his first major decision as Secretary of Energy, John Herrington took the hard steps needed to restore competitiveness. But Congress needs to focus on some awkward features of his plan.

title: SOURCE OF PRIDE NOW A SOURCE OF LIVERPOOL SORROW
description: ''You'll Never Walk Alone,'' says the wrought-iron motto over the gates of the Liverpool soccer club. After Brussels, that sense of shared euphoria has been replaced by other emotions: shock, chagrin and anger.

title: HE DESCRIBES HIJACKING PLOT
description: The Greek police tonight arrested a 21-year-old Lebanese Shiite Moslem who they said confessed to helping plan the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines airliner with 153 passengers and crew members aboard.

title: Sculptor-in-Residence For Stockbridge Estate
description: A sculptor-in-residence program has been established at Chesterwood, the former summer estate of the artist Daniel Chester French, by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and the National Trust for Historic Preservation.

title: UNIVERSITY PATENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
DELAY IN T.W.A. DEAL SEEN TO PROTECT ICAHN
description: Even if the Department of Transportation gives speedy approval to the proposed acquisition of Trans World Airlines by the Texas Air Corporation, the deal will not take place until December, in order to placate Carl C. Icahn, sources close to the transaction said yesterday.

title: ALL SEASONS RESORTS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: EFFECTS FROM BACTERIA: THEY APPEAR RANDOM
description: The infection caused by bacteria linked to multiple deaths or stillbirths among consumers of two locally made cheeses seems to strike randomly, with some cases progressing rapidly from flu-like symptoms to death and others producing mild symptoms or none at all, public health officials say.

title: Female Panda Gets Hormone Treatment
description: Concerned about the failure of the National Zoo's pandas to mate this year, zoo officials said today that they had begun giving the female, Ling-Ling, hormone treatments to try to bring her into heat.

title: Ex-Housing Aide Gets Prison Term
description: A former project superintendent for the City Housing Authority was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to a year and a day in prison and restitution of an undertermined amount of $30,000 he extorted in bribes and kickbacks from suppliers.

title: MUSIC: ROBERT DEGAETANO IN PIANO RECITAL
description: Should Bach be played on the modern piano? If the results are as exciting as those produced by Robert deGaetano Wednesday night at the Merkin Concert Hall (129 West 67th Street), the answer is an unqualified yes.

title: CLAYTON SILVER MINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
3 IN POLAND SENTENCED TO PRISON FOR PLANNING A STRIKE
description: Three political activists were sentenced today to terms ranging from two to three and a half years after being found guilty of fomenting civil disorder by planning a 15-minute strike. The strike never took place.

title: U.N. Can Still Achieve Its Goal of Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Spend the Hughes Billions
description: General Motors will pay $5 billion for Hughes Aircraft, making the seller, the Howard Hughes Medical Institute, probably the world's largest private philanthropy. The institute will spend $200 million a year for medical research. Spending it well won't be easy.

title: The Unkindest Cut
description: On the 18th green, as his 16-foot putt slowly dropped into the cup to save a par, the applause hailed Jack Nicklaus as if he had won another United States Open instead of having shot 73 after a 76 in the opening round. Hearing the ovation, the Golden Bear waved his putter and forced a smile that was as much grimace as grin.

title: U.S. SAYS ITS POLICY 'IS NOT TO GIVE IN'
description: The Reagan Administration, involved in its most serious hijacking crisis since taking office, said today that it would not yield to demands made by the terrorists aboard the plane.

title: Conserving Water On Broadway
description: Your night on the town begins with a three-minute shower that barely gets you wet. You pass by great fountains that are still and parched.

title: MENGELE'S SON SAID TO GIVE FATHER'S DOCUMENTS TO MUNICH WEEKLY
description: The son of Josef Mengele has given a Munich-based weekly hundreds of photographs, letters and some 30 pounds of documents depicting the Nazi war criminal's life on the run in South America, an editor for the magazine disclosed today.

title: ONE LAST CHANCE FOR MIKE WEAVER
description: Pulling the rug from under Mike Weaver is an old trick that even his new dog, Kayo, has learned.

title: Upbeat Assessment By a Japanese Visitor
description: On his last full day in the city yesterday, the Governor of Tokyo, Shunichi Suzuki, received an honorary degree at City University and then went for a helicopter ride.

title: A Career of Power and Anonymity
description: ''In a world of appearance, Sam Hughes is the real thing,'' said Roger G. Kennedy, director of the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History. ''He is among the last of the wholly disinterested, highly competent, flexibile utility-infielders for the democratic process.''

title: ARGENTINA PLANS A NEW CURRENCY AND STRINGENT CURBS ON ECONOMY
description: President Raul Alfonsin announced an ''economy of war'' tonight to bring the country's extraordinarily high inflation rate to a standstill.

title: U.S. to Cut Off Cuban Immigration
description: The Reagan Administration said today that as of Tuesday it would not allow any more Cuban immigrants into the United States.

title: L.I. Needs Conservation, Not Shoreham
description: To the Editor:

title: Glenn Seeks Third Term
description: Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, announced as expected today that he would run in 1986 for a third Senate term. Mr. Glenn won re-elction by more than a million votes in 1980. The former astronaut failed in his bid to win the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: BONN SPOKESMAN QUITS AMID INQUIRY ON TAXES
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's personal spokesman abruptly quit his job today because of an investigation over his possible tax evasion.

title: METS LOSE IN 9TH AS BULLPEN FAILS
description: For eight innings tonight, it was the kind of reunion the Mets might cherish. Gary Carter came home to cheers from 35,422 fans in Olympic Stadium, and got on base five straight times. Dwight Gooden pitched eight innings of six-hit ball and struck out 11 batters. And the Mets went into the bottom of the ninth leading the Montreal Expos, 4-3.

title: SURGING RED SOX DEFEAT BLUE JAYS, 4-1
description: Dennis Boyd scattered 11 hits in his sixth straight complete game and Mike Easler drove in two runs with a double and a single tonight as the streaking Boston Red Sox beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 4-1.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They kept yelling 'Down! Down!' in Arabic. One of the stewardesses translated for us.

title: ANADITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a provision of $900,000 for costs expected to be incurred in fulfilling certain backlog obligations at the company's Anacast division. c-Net income including a gain of $1,190,000 representing a government waiver of a previously accrued rental.

title: CHARTING A COURSE FOR MARCO BALDI, 18
description: The school bell rings in a turn-of-the-century mansion on a wooded 32-acre estate, a setting that is not quite what Marco Baldi envisioned last September when he came to New York to finish his high school education and continue his lessons in the ''city game.'' The progress he has made on the basketball court at Lutheran High School has enabled the young man with the explorer's name to chart a new course for his countrymen.

title: ACAPULCO Y LOS ARCOS RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $22,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $112,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Desegregation Ordered In Kansas City Schools
description: A Federal district judge today ordered that an $87.7 million desegregation plan involving voluntary student transfers between the Kansas City and suburban school districts be carried out to bring racial balance to the city schools.

title: AMID SHOW OF FORCE, A CAIRO MARCH IS POSTPONED
description: Islamic fundamentalists today postponed a march to demand the imposition of Islamic law in Egypt, in the face of an overwhelming show of force by President Hosni Mubarak's Government.

title: L.I. JUDGE BARS TESTING FACULTY FOR DRUG ABUSE
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that a Long Island school district may not force 23 teachers seeking tenure to have their urine tested for traces of drugs.

title: Death of a Regular
description: Every neighborhood coffee shop is an informal community whose members are known less by their names and occupations than by their habits. Such a place is the Utopia Restaurant at 267 Amsterdam Avenue, just off West 72d Street.

title: She's a New Yorker
description: To the Editor:

title: SATURDAY, JUNE 15, 1985
description: International

title: Circle K to Buy Shop and Go Inc.
description: The Circle K Corporation, a Phoenix-based company with about 2,660 convenience stores in 23 states, said it had reached definitive agreement for the acquisition of Shop and Go Inc., which operates about 450 convenience stores in Florida and Georgia. Circle K said it would pay $166 million in cash and common stock for Shop and Go, with acquisition of 80 percent of Shop and Go's stock through a tender offer of $16.50 a share in cash. The remaining 20 percent of the Shop and Go stock would be acquired in exchange for Circle K stock.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: American Telephone and Telegraph Co.'s third Telstar 3 communications satellites will be launched Monday aboard the space shuttle Discovery. The satellite will beam voice, data and video services throughout the United States and Puerto Rico.

title: Iran Says It Hit Baghdad With a Missile
description: Iran said it hit Baghdad with a long-range missile early today, hours before a 15-day Iraqi moratorium on bombardments was due to take effect.

title: EAGLE CLOTHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $120,000 for the quarter and $999,000 for the 9 months. c-Including extraordinary credits of $202,000 for the quarter and $751,000 for the 9 months.

title: MILITIA IN LEBANON TO FREE HOSTAGES
description: The Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army agreed today to release the 21 Finnish soldiers of a United Nations unit whom it has been holding hostage for a week, United Nations and Israeli military sources said.

title: PARTIAL LIST OF THOSE ON JET
description: Following is a list of crew members and some of the 145 passengers aboard T.W.A. passenger jet that was hijacked today, as compiled from T.W.A. officials and freed passengers. The first 8 were reportedly among those booked on the hijacked flight, and the final 19 were among those released. T.W.A. has not made public the names of passengers still on the plane:

title:
Patents;

Medicine Release in Body Aided
description: OFFICERS of the Liposome Company, Princeton, N.J., which manufactures microscopic lipid spheres that deliver drugs to specific points in the body praised the granting this week of the first product patent ever issued in their field, called lipsomology.

title:
PATENTS;

Dental Implant Can Go Into Jawbone or on Top
description: The modular dental implant patented this week by Dr. Larry R. Ashkinazy of New York should, he says, serve as another set of teeth.

title: Books of The Times;   Romance in the South
description: LOOKING FOR BOBBY. By Gloria Norris. 259 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: FITNESS MAGAZINE EXPLOSION
description: If it involves moving a muscle, there is probably a magazine for it.

title: 3 EXECUTIVES CONVICTED OF MURDER FOR UNSAFE WORKPLACE CONDITIONS
description: In what many lawyers called a landmark decision, three company officials were found guilty of murder today in an employee's death from cyanide poisoning.

title: KENAI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $306,000 for the latest first quarter and $500,000 for the year- ago first quarter.

title: PRAB ROBOTS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: PUBLISHING: HOUSE STAYS WITH BOOK ON MENGELE
description: Whether or not that body exhumed in Brazil turns out to be Josef Mengele - and despite the new information to be published by a German magazine about the Nazi war criminal's years in South America - Donald I. Fine said last night that his publishing house plans to publish as scheduled ''The Last Nazi: The Life and Times of Dr. Joseph Mengele,'' by Gerald Astor.

title: Special Consideration
description: Arnold Palmer, who has been taking some time off from the golf tour after failing to qualify for the United States Open, has turned down an offer of a special exemption that would have allowed him to play in the British Open next month. In a letter notifying tournament officials that he would not play this year, Palmer, a two-time winner of the British Open, who has been off his game in recent months, said he appreciated the exemption and hoped to take advantage of it in the future, ''if I can get my game to perk up.''

title: Rubens Burned as Protest
description: A young West German who destroyed a $2 million Rubens painting said his act was a protest against environmental pollution, the police said today.

title: AMF AGREES TO OFFER BY JACOBS OF $24 A SHARE
description: Ending nearly two months of sparring, AMF Inc., the leisure equipment maker, and Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, said yesterday that they had reached a definitive agreement for Mr. Jacobs to acquire the company.

title: Public Debt Sale For Conair Buyout
description: The Conair Corporation, which makes hair dryers and other personal care products, has arranged the first leveraged buyout to be financed through the public sale of debt securities, rather than a privately arranged bank loan, according to investment bankers at Bear, Stearns & Company. The financing calls for Leandro P. Rizzuto, chairman and founder of the Edison, N.J., company, to sell $190 million worth of debt securities through a new company that he owns.

title: MACGREGOR SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $459,000 for the quarter and $1,369,000 for the 9 months. c-Including extraordinary tax credits of $280,500 for the quarter and $716,600 for the 9 months.

title: 16 ARE REPORTED KILLED AS COMMANDOS STRIKE AN INSURGENT 'CENTER'
description: South African commandos attacked Gaborone, capital of neighboring Botswana, early today to strike at targets that South Africa described as the nerve center of the insurgent African National Congress.

title: EXPLOITING THE HOMELESS
description: The owners of the 50 or so welfare hotels that house New York City's homeless families have offered us a new case study in greediness.

title: Of Debt and Stern Stuff
description: The Citizens for a Debt-Free America refuse to be discouraged just because the nation is more than one and three-quarter trillion dollars in the hole. The group has been working like Sisyphus since 1961 to reduce the national debt, which as of the first week in June was $1,776,831,008,783.23.

title: Datapoint Spinoff
description: The Datapoint Corporation said that its board had authorized spinning off its domestic customer service division as a separate public company. Datapoint said its shareholders would receive one share of the new company's stock for each share of Datapoint common owned. The company said that the spinoff would require a favorable tax ruling from the Internal Revenue Service or an opinion from counsel that the spinoff will be a tax-free transaction.

title: Professors Censure 4 Colleges
description: The American Association of University Professors censured four institutions today for faculty cutbacks and other actions that it contends violated the principles of academic freedom and tenure.

title:
PATENTS;

Fatty Acid Compound Utilized in Heart Tests
description: A heart-testing compound was patented this week for the Department of Energy under a contract with the Union Carbide Corporation.

title: BANANA QUEMOY AND MATSU
description: If you follow the news only casually you probably think Nicaragua is the greatest problem facing the world today. Scarcely a day seems to pass without the President warning, clarifying, challenging, denying, declaring, invoking or issuing this, that or the other about Nicaragua.

title: SATURDAY, JUNE 15, 1985
description: International

title: Stargell Returns
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates, faced with declining attendance, mounting financial losses, an uncertain future and the worst record in baseball, reached into the past yesterday to get some glory back in Pirate uniform. They called Willie Stargell out of retirement to serve as first-base coach and provide instant inspiration for a dispirited team.

title: NEW PAPERBACK BOOKS: THREE TO CHEER COOKS
description: There seems to be no let up in the number of cookbooks published each year. Are there people who actually cook from them or are most of them simply read in bed at night?

title: Search for Bodies at Site On Coast Is Intensified
description: Investigators formed a human chain today to search a self-styled survivalist's property where the remains of five people have been found along with human bones and the teeth of small children.

title: SELIGMAN & ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Reagan News Conference
description: President Reagan will hold a nationally televised news conference Tuesday evening, the White House announced today.

title: VON BULOW TRIAL: QUESTIONS PERSIST
description: Claus von Bulow's acquittal Monday on charges of trying to kill his wife, Martha, with insulin injections completed a process of inquiry that began four years ago when Mrs. von Bulow fell into a coma from which she has not recovered.

title: Colombian Is Held On Drug Charge
description: A 33-year-old Colombian national was ordered held without bail today after Customs agents seized 44 pounds of cocaine valued at more than $5 million on a cargo ship at Port Newark.

title: The Convertible Submachine Gun Boondoggle
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN SEES LATIN AMERICA MOVING TOWARD DEMOCRACY
description: President Reagan said today at a Flag Day ceremony that Communist ''bullying tactics'' in Central America had only bolstered the determination for freedom.

title: GOING NORTH
description: O ur new man in Ottawa is expected to be Thomas M. T. Niles, a career Foreign Serivce officer who has worked in Moscow and Brussels and is now Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian Affairs.

title: Regional Bank Merger
description: The Bank of New England, based in Boston, and the CBT Corporation, the Connecticut bank holding company, whose intention to merge led to the regional banking decision handed down last Monday by the United States Supreme Court, said yesterday that they had completed their merger. The agreement between the banks to merge was the first made under a regional compact that allowed New England-based bank holding companies, but not those from New York or other states outside the region, to acquire local banks.

title: How the Administration Interprets Equal Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Girl Who Wouldn't Stand For Salute Gets Apology
description: Susan Shapiro, the high school student who caused a controversy last year when she refused to stand and recite the Pledge of Allegiance, received a public apology today from her school's teacher association.

title: CHEN LEADS OPEN BY ONE AFTER A 69
description: Tze-Chung Chen, who posted the first double eagle in United States Open history Thursday, got through the first six holes at Oakland Hills Country Club today in two under par without hitting one of the five driving fairways in that stretch. That is just not the way to show proper respect for the supposedly awesome courses reserved for Open championships.

title: THOR ENERGY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Turn Those Motors Off
description: To the Editor:

title: Met to Exhibit Engravings
description: A major retrospective of the 16th-century Italian engraver Giorgio Ghisi will open June 18 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82d Street. Ghisi, who worked mostly in France, is noted for his engravings of works by Michelangelo, Raphael, Correggio, Giovanni Battista Bertani and Giulio Campi. About 75 prints from the museum and other collections are in the show; they will be on display through Sept. 1.

title: Rockwell Starts Additional Layoffs
description: The Rockwell International Corporation has begun laying off between 300 and 400 of its 7,000 workers from its space operations facility in Downey, Calif., after the National Aeronautics and Space Administration discontinued a portion of the company's work on spare parts for the space shuttle.

title: MY FATHER, THE DELI MAN
description: ''I'm a deli man,'' my father used to say when people asked how he made his living. Proudly, he'd add, ''I have my own store.''

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT FELL 0.1% IN MAY
description: The output of the nation's industrial sector fell in May for the second consecutive month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The news provided new evidence that economic activity has not picked up since the slow first quarter and added to fears that it would remain sluggish throughout the year.

title: A VICTORY GREETS WEAVER IN RETURN
description: Earl Weaver's first day back on the job was much like his last day on the same job two and a half years ago, without the tears. More than 100 reporters packed into the Hit and Run Club at Memorial Stadium to hear Weaver's first public comments since he agreed Thursday to succeed Joe Altobelli as the Baltimore Orioles' manager.

title: Sales-Tax Income Up in Connecticut
description: The chief of economic and revenue forecasting for the budget office of Gov. William A. O'Neill said state sales-tax receipts for April were 12.4 percent higher than those for April 1984.

title: HALLWOOD GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $504,000 for the quarter and $1,245,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $217,000 for the quarter and $563,000 for the 9 months.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers, at Yankee Stadium, 4:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 4 P.M.) Mets vs. Expos, at Montreal. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Astros vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Houston. (Television - Channel 4, 1:15 P.M.) Braves vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Atlanta. (Television -WTBS 7:35 P.M.) Mariners vs. Kansas City Royals, at Seattle. (Radio -WCBS 880, 9:50 P.M.). Boxing Pinklon Thomas, champion, vs. Mike Weaver, 12 rounds for the World Boxing Council heavyweight championship, at Las Vegas, Nev. This is the first defense for the undefeated Thomas (25-0-1 20 knockouts) since he won the title from Tim Witherspoon. Weaver (27-10-1, 18 K.O's), a former World Boxing Association champion, is ranked No. 1 by both the W.B.A. and the W.B.C. (Television - HBO 9 P.M., live.) Football Generals vs. Invaders, at Oakland, 8 P.M. Both teams have already clinched playoff berths. This game is a pure matchup of the league's No. 1 rushing team, the Generals, and the No. 1 team in defense against the rush, the Invaders, who have allowed just 95.0 average yards rushing per game. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M. Radio - WMCA 570, 8 P.M.) Golf United States Open, at Oakland Hills Country Club at Birmingham, Mich., third round. (Television - Channel 7, 2 P.M. to 6 P.M., live.) Rochester International, at Pittsford, N.Y., third round L.I.G.A. Amateur Championships, at Huntington (L.I.) Country Club, quarter- and semifinals of match play.

title:
SCOUTING;

Age-Old Problem
description: The Orlando Renegades lost their first 6 games this season but have managed to win 4 of the 10 since then, an improvement that Coach Lee Corso attributes largely to a change at quarterback, where Reggie Collier has been installed. The problem with the guy Collier replaced will strike a familiar chord in Giant fans. ''Jerry Golsteyn,'' Corso says, ''didn't have enough mobility for our young line.''

title: Employers Found Guilty of Murders
description: In what is believed to be the first decision of its kind, an Illinois judge last week found three corporate officials guilty of murder in the death of an employee who inhaled cyanide on the job.

title: PRINCETON FOSTERING WOMEN'S STUDIES
description: Three years ago Princeton University became one of the last major schools in the country to establish a program in women's studies.

title:
FILM VIEW;

MUSCLEBOUND MOVIES LEAVE LIFE UNEXAMINED
description: ''Saturday Night Fever'' was the film in which John Travolta expressed all of his character's hopes and ambitions on the dance floor.

title: ALAN SUTHERLAND KURTH WED TO SANDRA MCKEE
description: Sandra Blair McKee, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh S. McKee of Englewood, N.J., and Shelter Island, L.I., was married yesterday to Alan Sutherland Kurth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Kurth of Andover, Mass. The Rev. James Steele performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Englewood.

title: MERGER REJECTED
description: A proposition that would have merged the Rye Neck and Rye City School Districts into a single new Rye City School District was defeated last Tuesday by voters in Rye City but approved by the voters in Rye Neck. A merger cannot take place if voters in either community reject the proposal, according to state law.

title: BRADLEY SHOOTS A 67 FOR 5-STROKE LEAD
description: Pat Bradley shot a five-under-par 67 today to take a five-stroke lead after three rounds of the $255,000 Rochester International golf tournament.

title: Social Events;   Parties In and Out of Port
description: Liberation June 17 - The Simon Wiesenthal Center will honor American soldiers who liberated European Jewry at a black-tie dinner at 6 P.M. at Roseland, 239 West 52d Street. Honored guests will include both liberating soldiers, such as Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin, and survivors, such as Mr. Wiesenthal, of such Nazi concentration camps as Wobbelin, Buchenwald and Dachau. The Wiesenthal Center has a New York office and is based in Los Angeles. Tickets, from $300, from Mark Young at 212-889-2244. Under the Cantilever June 17 - The Lobby Gallery Associates of the Whitney Museum of American Art will hold a Spring Breeze Ball at the museum at 9 P.M. The event, appropriately, will be held on the museum's lower level, where the cantilevered design by Marcel Breuer provides protection from the elements. Tickets, $65, from 212-570-3641. Dress: ''creative black-tie,'' as the invitation puts it. A Cornucopia June 18 - ''By the Sea,'' an art sale and benefit for the exhibition and performance series organized by Creative Time, will begin at 6:30 P.M. at Christie's, the auction house, at 502 Park Avenue (59th Street). Amanda Burden and Gordon Davis are co-chairmen of the event, which will raise funds for artists' fees for the organization's ''Art on the Beach,'' ''Art in the Anchorage'' and other projects. Biscotte Garnie, a performance group of caterers from Brussels, will serve the hors d'oeuvres and entertain. More than 80 artists have contributed works for the silent auction. Creative Time supports new work for public presentation in vacant spaces of historical and architectural interest throughout New York City.

title: BISHOPS' LETTER ON ECONOMY GETS 'NEW LIFT'
description: The chairman of the committee that is drafting the Roman Catholic Bishops' pastoral letter on the American economy said today that the four-year-old project got a ''new lift'' from the two days of discussion here.

title: FIRST SIGNS OF FALL
description: Even before summer officially arrives, autumnal sweaters begin appearing on store counters. This year, many of them will be closely fitted and sinuous, and available in a variety of lengths.

title: FREED HOSTAGE SAYS HIJACKER STRUCK HER AS SHE KNELT IN JET
description: A woman held hostage aboard the hijacked Trans World Airlines jetliner said here today after her release in Algiers that one of the hijackers struck her on the back of her neck while she was kneeling near her seat.

title: IN AND OUT OF WORK
description: THAT'S LIFE By William Herrick. 228 pp. New York: New Directions. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $9.95. WILLIAM HERRICK'S latest book is neither a traditional novel nor a collection of stories, but a loosely-connected assortment of oral reminiscences, letters, telephone conversations and anecdotes spanning three generations of a remarkable Jewish-American family. ''That's Life'' begins during the Great Depression with the accidental death of Eli Miller, a hard-working roofer, whose fall from a housetop leaves his family destitute. In desperation, Eli's 15-year-old son Max decides to leave home to find work. ''Mom was frying a small piece of stale bread in a pan with some chicken fat she got from a neighbor. . . . I gazed around the kitchen. Dingy, poor. I was just another mouth to feed - what did they need me for?''

title: THE BUMPY ODYSSEY OF 'JUNO'S SWANS'
description: IT hasn't been easy gliding for ''Juno's Swans'' from the time the play had its premiere at the PAF Playhouse in Huntington just seven years ago.

title: Barcelona
description: To the Editor: Your recent article on the Gaudi architecture in Barcelona (Travel, May 12) was quite interesting to read since we had attempted to gain entrance to several of the buildings while we were in Barcelona last August.

title: ESTABLISHING A SCHOOL OF THEIR OWN
description: The class is self-taught, two teachers learning to start their own school. They know now that life is a tutorial, that in whim and ambition and discontent, there are many, many lessons.

title: THE END OF THE QUINLAN CASE, BUT NOT THE ISSUE IT RAISED
description: In a way, the death of Karen Ann Quinlan last week marked the end of the beginning of a painful passage into a new era of medical technology and ethics. No one knows precisely where science, medicine and technology will lead as they continue to conquer old maladies and extend life as well as control and shape the creation of new life. But a look at the advances and agonies of just the past 10 years indicates that drastic social changes may come a lot more quickly than many people realize, and than most governments are prepared to handle.

title: HARVARD CREW WAITS FOR TITLE
description: Although a protest by Princeton delayed the official announcement, Harvard was named the winner of the 1985 national championship in collegiate rowing today. The Crimson varsity heavyweight eight won by 47-hundredths of a second, or 3 feet.

title: Airline Food
description: To the Editor: In ''Airline Food: Flights of Fancy'' (Travel, May 26), Fred Ferretti persuades readers that the meatiest bone to nibble in flight is the funny bone.

title: 'Just Signing Checks'
description: It is a familiar story in boxing, which doesn't make things any easier for Matthew Saad Muhammad. The former World Boxing Council light heavyweight champion, has become the sport's latest rags-to-riches-and-back casualty.

title: CAROLYN A. LESH WEDS S. H. ROWLEY, REPORTER
description: Carolyn Agnes Lesh, a former foreign correspondent for The Associated Press and United Press International and a Washington reporter for Time magazine, was married yesterday in Chicago to Storer Hastings Rowley, a national correspondent for The Chicago Tribune. The Rev. George Hull performed the ceremony at St. Chrysostom's Episcopal Church.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: OFF THE BOOKS: The Rise of the Underground Economy. By Philip Mattera. (St. Martin's, $25.) To cope with a declining living standard and reduced social services, workers are slipping - or getting pushed -into an underground economy now estimated at 10 percent of the gross national product.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Votes in Congress table last Sunday incorrectly described the second vote listed for the Senate. It was an amendment to a State Department authorization bill.

title: Chemical Lawns
description: THIS lawn chemically treated.

title: Judge Stays Sex Abuse Trial For an Appeal on Testimony
description: Judge Paul Turner of Superior Court has delayed proceedings in a sexual abuse case to allow prosecutors to appeal a ruling barring children from testifying through closed-circuit television.

title: FROM WILLIAMSBURG'S ATTIC
description: Colonial Williamsburg is in some parts looking increasingly like a museum. The DeWitt Wallace Decorative Arts Gallery, which opened last week, brings to three the number of museums in this restored town, which served as the capital of Virginia from 1699 to 1780. The new museum is notable for the way its collection of 8,000 objects is displayed, not in period settings but in a space more typical of traditional art museums.

title: AIRLINE FOOD
description: To the Editor: I was pleased to see ''Airline Food: Flights of Fancy.''

title: Poland Sentences Three Dissidents
description: Poland's hope for better relations with the West to help revive its economy keeps colliding with its concern over internal dissension. Last week, repression won out.

title: NEW CANCER DRUG IS CALLED PAINLESS
description: A new drug that promises treatment without pain for tens of thousands of cancer patients was announced today by British scientists.

title: JAMES SHERWIN IS WED TO HIROKO YOSHIKAWA
description: The marriage of Hiroko Yoshikawa, co-principal of the Princeton (N.J.) Community Japanese School, to James T. Sherwin, vice chairman of the GAF Corporation in Wayne, N.J., took place in New York yesterday. The ceremony at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine was performed by the Very Rev. James Parker Morton, dean of the cathedral.

title: ELIZABETH WOOD BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Elizabeth Barnes Wood, a daughter of Elizabeth Norris Andrews of Newtown Square, Pa., and Charles Randolph Wood of Haverford, Pa., was married yesterday to Christopher Marc Isles, a son of Elene de Saint Phalle of New York and Naples, Fla., and the late Philip Henry Isles of New York and Sands Point, L.I. The Rev. Rudolph A. Moore, assisted by the Rev. Warren Haynes, performed the ceremony at St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

A STRATEGY FOR NEW PUBLIC POLICIES
description: IT IS time to develop a new public agenda for the new New Jersey.

title: Giving Two Visiting Russian Poets the Cold War Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: J. W. BLUM WED TO SARA COWARD
description: Sara Lamborn Coward, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Mortimer Coward of Essex Fells, N.J., and Edgartown, Mass., and Jay William Blum, a son of Mrs. J. Robert Blum of Essex Junction, Vt., and the late Mr. Blum, were married yesterday. Msgr. Edward T. Fleming performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in Roseland, N.J. He was assisted by the Rev. Cornelius J. O'Neill, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Dr. David St. George, an Episcopal priest.

title: PROFILES IN COURAGE
description: In reversing its position last week and approving aid to the Nicaraguan ''contras,'' the House of Representatives told us something important about American politics. Demagogic anti-Communism is as effective as ever. Members of Congress would rather vote for a cynical policy that they know will not work than be seen as ''soft on Communism.''

title: CHINESE CUISINE, HOME-STYLE
description: A DECADE or so ago, if you wanted to make Chinese food at home, you had to make a trip to Chinatown to get the necessary ingredients. This is no longer true. Sichuan peppercorns, oyster sauce, hot chili sauce, water chestnuts, baby pickled corn, fresh bean sprouts and even wonton wrappers are now available in many local supermarkets and specialty stores.

title: ELBOWING IN THE VOTE IN JERSEY CITY
description: Voting may be a duty, a privilege and a responsibility, but, for thousands of Jersey City residents, last week it became a chore.

title: TASTE OF COLUMBUS AVE. IN JERICHO
description: PARTS of the Island begin to resemble Manhattan's Columbus Avenue as stylish and casual restaurants such as the Great American Cafe in Jericho continue to open. They represent the suburban clones of the latest dining trend.

title: Experiments In the Garden
description: Because Vaux-le-Vicomte is one of my favorite gardens, I recognized immediately the debt that landscape designer Tori Thomas owes it in at least one of the versions of her garden (''Experiments in the Garden'' by Carol Vogel, May 12). It is reassuring to realize that her experiment is no frantic attempt to be different, but, rather, that it is rooted in tradition.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: BINNIE J. THOM has always wanted to see the world. And if the 33-year-old East Windsor resident gets lucky, she'll be doing it from outer space.

title: YALE ENDS PROJECT ON THOMAS MORE
description: A quarter of a century after a group of scholars here began editing the vast ''Yale Edition of the Complete Works of Saint Thomas More,'' the project is grinding, prematurely, to a close.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN COPENHAGEN
description: The good news about Copenhagen this summer is that there is none, or not much at any rate. True, Tivoli has a new roller coaster. The raffish side of the Nyhavn is a bit less raffish, the porn shops fewer and a mink jacket can be bought for $2,300. But what really matters is that Copenhagen remains the city that everyone expects it to be. Its charm is that everything, or most of it, is crammed into a small maze of streets, canals and bridges, all within easy walking distance.

title:
POSTINGS;

VICTORIANS ON HUDSON
description: Within the historic district of Windle Park in Tarrytown, an area distinguished by its Victorian structures, developers are constructing a condominium community that will blend in with the prevailing architectural style.

title: ON KEEPING TRACK WITH A GARDEN JOURNAL
description: Keeping track of a garden in a diary is not a purely poetic exercise. But the journal that a gardener keeps shouldn't be a cold scientific report, either. Both the trouble with and the delight of gardening is that it fuses art and science. A well-kept garden journal should do the same.

title: TERRY R. BEESLEY TO BE MARRIED JULY 13
description: Terry Ruth Beesley and Howard Phipps 3d plan to be married July 13 in Geneva, where the future bride's father, J. Alan Beesley, is Canadian Ambassador and representative at the United Nations office.

title: EAST HEATS UP AS JAYS LOSE
description: The Boston Red Sox scored two runs on a pair of two-out, bases-loaded walks by Gary Lavelle in the bottom of the eighth inning to rally for a 7-5 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays tonight.

title: PARENTS REFLECT ON TEEN-AGE SUICIDE
description: THE Harts and Spoonhours share a tragedy. Each family had a teen-age son who took his own life. Now the two families are speaking out about their experiences with suicide, in the hope that the knowledge could prevent other teen-age deaths.

title: ALIASES OF A SLEUTH
description: To the Editor:

title: SOCIAL WORKER WINS STATE AWARD
description: MILDRED KIBRICK remembers very clearly the incident that convinced her the decision to become a social worker was the right one.

title: CANDIDATES EMERGING FOR SEATS ON BOARD
description: COUNTY Democratic and Republican leaders were putting the finishing touches last week on their slates for election to the 17 seats on the County Board of Legislators.

title: A Page From Truman
description: There is no shortage in the capital of proposals for reducing waste in spending for military items and programs. One of them comes from Representative Timothy E. Wirth, a Colorado Democrat, who wants a new Truman Commission. The original Truman Commission, established in 1941 at the urging of an obscure Senator from Missouri, saved the Government billions and got Harry S. Truman going on his way to the White House. Mr. Wirth has proposed legislation to create a similar commission, one with investigative but not legislative powers to look into the price of screw drivers, ash trays, fighter planes and missiles.

title: AFTER 46 YEARS, HOLLYWOOD REVISITS OZ
description: Returning anywhere after 46 years is hazardous. Even the most ordinary past sets psychological land mines for the present. Returning to Oz - that Technicolor world of dancing Munchkins over the rainbow, of ruby slippers and winged monkeys and the Wicked Witch of the West - is a booby trap of immense proportions.

title: SUPPORTERS OF REACTOR CITE ACCORD IN MAINE
description: Supporters of the Seabrook nuclear reactor say that a recent decision by regulators in neighboring Maine may be a model for resolving disputes in other states that jeopardize the project.

title: BUSINESS PROVIDES A SENSE OF SECURITY
description: THE little room sits high above Long Island Sound and offers a view reaching 75 miles on a clear day. Soft breezes blow through the windows, and Mozart plays softly on the radio. The atmosphere is serene, yet every ring of the telephone is a potential signal of distress. This is I.C.S., a central monitoring station wired to thousands of alarm systems in homes, businesses and offices in the metropolitan area.

title: ATLANTIC CITY CASINOS FACE UNCERTAIN PERIOD
description: Trump's Castle Hotel and Casino will open on Monday as the seven-year-old casino industry here is facing a period of uncertainty.

title: FILLING THE PANTRY AT REYNOLDS
description: TWO weeks ago, on the day his company announced it had agreed to buy Nabisco Brands Inc., and would become the nation's largest consumer products concern, J. Tylee Wilson, chairman and chief executive of R.J. Reynolds Industries Inc., went to a White House benefit for Ford's Theater in Washington.

title: LEGHOLD: BAN MUST STAY INTACT
description: ON April 27, a 10-year legislative battle culminated in the realization of Public Law 1984, Chapter 37, which bans all types of steel-jaw leghold traps in New Jersey.

title: Random House Wins O'Neill Book's Rights
description: Random House emerged yesterday as the winning bidder for the right to publish the autobiography of Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House of Representatives.

title: Jazz
description: It has been so long since George Wallington has been heard playing piano in New York that he may be unknown to the current generation of jazz fans. Mr. Wallington was one of the prime movers in be-bop during its seminal decade in the 40's - a close colleague of Charlie Parker, Dizzy Gillespie and Max Roach - but he left the jazz world in 1960 to settle in Florida. He will return to New York as a pianist for the first time since then to play at the Kool Jazz Festival next Saturday at Carnegie Recital Hall at 5:30 as part of the festival's daily solo piano series.

title: Interstate Banking Curbs Upheld
description: The revolution in banking has brought forth non-bank banks, bailed-out banks and regional banks but, for the time being, not interstate banks, at least in an unfettered form.

title: TWO STAR TURNS
description: In reporting a major team event the bridge journalist often searches in vain for a deal that will show the brilliance of the winners in play or defense. A deal that demonstrates both of these elements, by two partnerships playing in different rooms, is a very rare event indeed. But it occurred last month in the Cavendish Club team event in New York City, which brought together many of America's top-ranked stars and a handful of visiting experts.

title: Scandinavia Feels Tremor
description: The strongest earth tremor felt in Sweden this century shook the southern part of the country and parts of Denmark today, the Danish Geodetic Institute said. The tremor, measured in Sweden at 4.2 on the Richter scale, occurred at 2 A.M. (9 P.M. Friday, New York time) and lasted 10 to 15 seconds.

title: DR. P. E. HOPPER, VETERINARIAN, WED TO MICHELLE DUNE
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan yesterday Michelle Anna Dune, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steve Charles Dune of New York, and Dr. Patrick Elliott Hopper, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony W. Hopper of San Francisco, were married by the Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley.

title: AUDIO-VIDEO RECEIVERS GIVE A HINT OF THE FUTURE
description: To speak of the marriage of audio and video, as is often done these days, may be a little premature, considering that the two are not even firmly engaged yet. True, the notion of combined audio-video ''entertainment centers'' for the home is eagerly embraced by companies lusting after ways to hike a sales ticket, and quite a few such ''total systems'' are now being launched, with RCA, Pioneer, Denon, NEC and Sony in the forefront. But public response to these elaborate A/V (audio-video) installations has remained hesitant.

title: AT CONTROLS OF T.W.A. FLIGHT: 'CALAM AND PROFESSIONAL' PILOT
description: It was only earlier this year that Capt. John L. Testrake decided - after more than 30 years of co-piloting and piloting domestic flights for Trans World Airlines - that he would bid for international flights and then retire in two years.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: 'DAMES AT SEA'

title: LUCY OLDRIN AND ROBERT HERZ JR. MARRY IN DARIEN
description: The marriage of Lucy Royer Oldrin to Robert Theodore Herz Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herz of Darien, Conn., took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John Oldrin, parents of the bride, in Darien. The Rev. Lawrence Horton, pastor emeritus of the Noroton Presbyterian Church of Darien, performed the ceremony.

title: A FATHER'S VENTURE
description: THE REVERSE-CHARGE call from my son gently, apologetically, informed me that he couldn't register for the new term as a junior at St. John's College in Santa Fe, because the school had yet to receive a tuition down payment of $1,500. Barred from classes, he was now a ''nonperson,'' he said.

title: Donating Organs In New Jersey
description: The New Jersey Assembly has passed unanimously and a Senate committee is expected this month to consider a bill that would require a change in the design of the driver's license to provide space on the back for organ-donor information.

title: Pope Criticizes Poland For Trial of Dissidents
description: Pope John Paul II, beginning a three-day journey through northeastern Italy, today criticized the sentences handed out to three Polish activists Friday in a trial in Gdansk.

title: THAIS PLANNING TO MEET TOMORROW ON CAMBODIANS
description: Faced with problems of disease, crime and overcrowding in refugee settlements along the Cambodian border, Thai officials are planning to meet Monday to discuss the future of Cambodians driven into this country by the Vietnamese offensive last winter, officials said today.

title: U.S. SAID TO SEND COMMANDO SQUAD
description: The United States has reportedly sent a commando unit to the Mediterranean to be ready to storm the hijacked Trans World Airlines plane if deemed necessary. But American officials said today that they were counting on Algeria and the Red Cross to bring about a nonviolent resolution of the crisis.

title: LANGUAGE AND LIFE SURRENDERED
description: ETERNITY'S WOODS By Paul Zweig. Postscript by Galway Kinnell. 65 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press/ Harper & Row. Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $7.95. IN his third and final collection of poems, Paul Zweig - who died last year of cancer at the age of 49 - speaks with the quiet intensity and authority of someone who is standing on just this side of the grave. These are the tender, melancholy poems of a man talking intimately about his life, still tethered to earth but already on the edge of what he calls ''eternity's woods.'' What Zweig once wrote about Whitman is true in a modest but nonetheless genuine way for himself as well - in these last poems, he has tried to step outside the institution of literature in order to speak to us as a man.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ALFRED NORTH WHITEHEAD: The Man and His Work. Volume One: 1861-1910. By Victor Lowe (Johns Hopkins, $27.50.) Alfred North Whitehead (1861-1947) spent the second half of his long professional life as a philosopher, writing, among other things, ''Science and the Modern World'' and ''Process and Reality.''

title: Lou Gehrig And the Stickball Boys
description: How in the world could Lou Gehrig be left out of the stickball company! [''For These Boys of Summer, the Game Is Stickball,'' May 5.] Lou's dad bought him a catcher's mitt and Lou was only 6 years old.

title: JENNIFER BRAINARD WED IN HARTFORD TO WILLIAM PHILIP
description: Jennifer Cameron Brainard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edwin Brainard Jr. of Hartford, was married there yesterday to William Van Ness Philip, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Van Ness Philip of New York and Bedford, N.Y. The ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church Cathedral was performed by the Rev. Stephen Gushee, Dean of the Cathedral, assisted by the Rev. Thomas Gariepy, academic dean of Saybrook College of Yale University.

title: MARISSA HOLMBERG IS A BRIDE
