description: Marlissa S. Holmberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Einar A. Holmberg of Oradell, N.J., was married yesterday to John Evans Westerfield, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Westerfield of Winnetka, Ill. The Rev. Herbert Anderson performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York. Mrs. Westerfield is an assistant vice president of the European American Bank. Mr. Westerfield received an M.B.A. degree from Harvard University this month and is to join Morgan Stanley & Company as an associate.

title: ATHENS DISCLOSES A HIJACKER DEAL
description: The Greek Government today gave in to the demands of hijackers of an American airliner and freed an associate who had been in Greek custody in exchange for the release of eight Greek passengers.

title: Protect This Insurance Triumph
description: Some 700,000 New Yorkers buy life insurance from the Savings Bank Life Insurance Fund, and no wonder. It's cheap, uncomplicated and sold without high-pressure tactics.

title: CHURCH GETS $20 MILLION FROM A CONGREGATION
description: The 600-member congregation of a church here has given a trust fund of $20 million, earned from oil-field royalty certificates, to the North American Unitarian Universalist Association.

title: INTRODUCTION TO THE WORLD OF MEN'S WORK
description: NOT long ago I faced the task of moving my father-in-law's small business from one downtown location to another. The move would be hard, dirty physical work, not the sort of thing one expects to enjoy. Yet I found several reasons for looking forward to it.

title: JOANNE C. DUNNE BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Joanne Carroll Dunne, a daughter of State Senator John R. Dunne and Mrs. Dunne of Garden City, L.I., was married there yesterday to Thomas Cuff Murphy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward P. Murphy, also of Garden City. The Rev. Charles A. Lennon performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: On the Envoy Front
description: President Reagan is expected to confirm in the next few weeks that his choice for the next Ambassador to Portugal is Frank Shakespeare, who is now chairman of the Board for International Broadcasting. The President is also expected to confirm that he wants former Senator James L. Buckley of New York to replace Mr. Shakespeare on the broadcasting board, which oversees the operations of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty. Mr. Buckley is now president of the two Government stations, which broadcast to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.

title: SHOULD FAIRFIELD SHUT ITS DOORS?
description: The elderly woman in a T-shirt and Bermuda shorts pulled her grocery cart up short outside a supermarket in this quiet community of white-steepled churches and clapboard houses. Virginia Hodgkinson wanted her to sign a petition asking town officials not to allow construction of a new office park on 56 acres of open fields on the north end of town.

title: DAMAGES REFLECTED IN DEATH OF FETUS
description: A woman whose baby was stillborn as a result of prenatal testing cannot collect damages for her emotional distress, the state's highest court has ruled.

title: MISS MCGOLDRICK BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn., yesterday Marguerite Emily McGoldrick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. McGoldrick of Darien, was married to Kevin Christopher Lippert, the son of Dr. Ernest L. Lippert of Toledo, Ohio, and Maureen Lippert of Toronto. The Rev. Edward J. Howley performed the ceremony.

title: Overtime on Rails
description: THE Metro-North Commuter Rail Division of the New York Metropolitan Transportation Authority had a slight problem last year: overtime for conductors, whose pay normally averaged $31,549 a year. By November, the highest paid conductor, with overtime, was earning close to the $105,000 salary of the line's president.

title: THE U.S. CAN OFFER SOME 'STRAWS' TO HELP GET MIDEAST TALKS GOING
description: After some initial hesitation, the United States has accepted the burden of an active intermediary role in the Middle East peace process. The prospects are somewhat murky, to say the least, and it would be foolhardy for Washington to offer up ultimate solutions now. But we must grasp at the straws we have been offered and do what we can to encourage negotiations toward an interim arrangement premised on full autonomy for the West Bank and Gaza.

title: CAUTHEN'S SUCCESS AMAZES BRITAIN
description: STEVE CAUTHEN rode two winners here last Wednesday, but the 25-year-old Kentuckian's 65th and 66th trips to the winner's circle since the British horse-racing season began in mid-March were regarded as scarcely worth noting by sportwriters and fans. They were still buzzing about his double victory earlier this month in the prestigious Derby and Gold Seal Oaks at Epsom and looking forward to his likely challenge this week to the legendary Lester Piggott's record of riding eight winners in the Royal meeting at Ascot.

title: 'HE HAD TO BE GUILTY'
description: THE AIRMAN AND THE CARPENTER The Lindbergh Kidnapping and the Framing of Richard Hauptmann. By Ludovic Kennedy. 438 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: MUSIC: BLUES BY KOKO TAYLOR
description: IN Chicago, blues fans take for granted the kind of set Koko Taylor and the Blues Machine delivered Thursday at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street. Here in New York, however, Mrs. Taylor's barnstorming voice and her band's stinging backup are a rare pleasure.

title: RUSSIAN SPACECRAFT LANDS ON DARK SIDE OF VENUS AND DIGS IN
description: A Soviet space module carrying instruments from the United States landed today on the dark side of Venus and began drilling into soil in temperatures of more than 840 degrees Fahrenheit to determine the composition of the planet.

title: A GROUP FOR DUAL-DOCTOR FAMILIES
description: Five years ago, David and Esther Nash were newly married, just out of medical school and facing problems they did not expect.

title: Fathers, Earnest and Pathetic
description: When they're thought about at all, unwed teenage fathers are generally thought of as sexual hit-and-run artists, young rakes who love 'em and leave 'em - and their children - to the welfare rolls. Sadly, the stereotype is often true. But social-service workers have lately begun to recognize another type of teen-age father in the inner city.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a schedule change by the Light Opera of Manhattan, the Notes on Music column on page 25 of the Arts and Leisure section today carries an outdated report about the company's summer season. It will open with Rudolf Friml's ''Vagabond King'' on July 3 at Norman Thomas High School, 111 East 33d Street.

title: CHEN INCREASES HIS HEAD AT OPEN
description: Tze-Chung Chen continued setting records with heroic shots and deadly putting today despite a steady, cold rain as the 26-year-old from Taiwan increased his lead to two strokes in the 85th United States Open.

title: THROUGH THE AGES WITH WINE ARTIFACTS
description: The Psalms tell us that wine ''maketh glad the heart of man.'' This theme is one of several explored in the delightful, thoroughly absorbing exhibition ''Wine Celebration and Ceremony'' now at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design, 2 East 91st Street, through Oct. 13.

title: EVALUATING MUSEUM QUALITY
description: ''THE criterion is quality,'' said Ulysses Dietz, curator of decorative arts at the Newark Museum. ''That means not only technical excellence, but also distinctive design.''

title: Olympic Bid To Anchorage
description: The United States Olympic Committee today designated Anchorage as the American city that will bid for the 1992 Olympic Winter Games.

title: REPUBLICANS IN ALBANY PRESENT ENERGY PACKAGE
description: A package of legislative proposals on energy, including one for the sale of tax-exempt industrial development bonds to help finance the Shoreham nuclear plant, has been proposed by leaders of the Republican-controlled Senate.

title: MOTHER TERESA SET FOR VISIT TO UCONN
description: THE visit of Mother Teresa to Connecticut this week can be traced to the charity visits of a Norwich dentist to the steamy slums of Port-au-Prince, Haiti.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: RAGTIME: Its History, Composers, and Music. Edited by John Edward Hasse. (Schirmer/Macmillan, Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $17.95.) Originally the art of piano ''professors'' in dusty Middle Western saloons, ragtime is now the business of college professors, and this anthology is full of research, analyses and lists, with an undertone of disagreement about what the word ''ragtime'' actually means.

title: SEASIDE VILLAGE IN DENMARK
description: The merest mention of Dragor is guaranteed to bring a quick smile to the faces of most residents of Copenhagen. For it is to this small, coastal village, a scant eight miles south of Copenhagen's Town Hall Square, that they troop - summer, fall, spring and winter - to buy smoked fish and eels at the harbor, to walk along the beach or through the narrow cobbled alleys, and to have a hearty lunch.

title: A Mile Hike To Stonehenge
description: In prehistoric times, it is thought, Stonehenge was used for religious rites. More recently it has been the scene of pop-music rites, which have sometimes ended in clashes between British policemen and hundreds of youths.

title: KEY MAN IN MENGELE CASE: ROMEU TUMA
description: Sensitive to the dangers of bruising national pride, the Federal Police Chief here, Romeu Tuma, insisted from the start of the investigation that Brazilian authorities would determine whether a body exhumed June 6 was that of the Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SUNDAY, JUNE 16, 1985 International

title:
GARDENING;

FRESH VEGETABLES ALL SEASON LONG
description: IN addition to the pleasures that one may derive from growing one's own vegetables, there are advantages in being able to harvest the freshest possible produce just outside the kitchen door.

title: HAMMOND HONORED
description: The Northern Westchester Center for the Arts bestowed an arts award on Natalie Hays Hammond, 81-year-old artist and founder of the Hammond Museum and Stroll Gardens in North Salem, at the center's yearly benefit held last Sunday night at the museum. Miss Hammond, who is hospitalized, was unable to attend, so the award, presented by former Lieut. Gov. Alfred B. DelBello of Waccabuc, was accepted by a friend and supporter, Louise Hyde of North Salem.

title: LIFE WITH FATHER: ON THE BEACH...
description: WHATEVER the weather, I will spend a good part of today at West End Beach 2. Just as I did last Father's Day, I will run two miles (along the shore), body surf in the ocean and sit on the sand, dreaming and planning.

title: DRUNKEN DRIVING IS UNDER ATTACK
description: IN the past year, the police in Connecticut have been looking harder for drunken drivers, and they have been catching more.

title: Hijackings Overshadow Peace Moves
description: There were further peace efforts in the Middle East last week, but they were all but forgotten in the drama involving a TWA airliner under constant threat of being blown up by its Moslem Shiite hijackers. One passenger was killed in the Beirut airport.

title: NEW ANTHOLOGIES BURNISH THE SONDHEIM REPUTATION
description: There are delicious ironies in the fact that the music of Stephen Sondheim, far more than that of any other active theater composer, is being anthologized on disk with an almost obsessive thoroughness. Here is a composer who has prospered almost oblivious to the pop-rock onslaught of the last 25 years. That onslaught, which has increasingly affected the mainstream of Broadway theater music, has produced a new generation of popular songwriters for whom composing means ''writing records'' rather than songs. Mr. Sondheim has never composed the sort of pop-rock music that has become the economic foundation of the record industry. His elegant, yearning Old World melodicism looms more and more as magnificent anachronism. Yet at the same time, it is largely through records - RCA's original cast albums of Sondheim shows, of the revues ''Side by Side By Sondheim'' and ''Marry Me a Little'' and a recent Whitney Museum tribute, ''A Stephen Sondheim Evening - that his music continues to draw an audience in search of a genuinely adult popular music.

title: Policing Himself
description: Soon after the Tulane point-shaving scandal hit the headlines back in April, Mike Krzyzewski, the Duke basketball coach, called his team together to discuss the Tulane incident. It was, Krzyzewski believes, the right thing for a concerned coach to do.

title: ETERNAL TRUTHS AMONG THE STRAWBERRIES
description: FOR 12 months of the year I struggle with words and abstractions and the society of humankind, but for the month of June, I also attempt to reckon with a more wild and demanding force: the kingdom of strawberries.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: CHAUTAUQUA SOVIET TALKS Audiences aren't shy when they get to query speakers at Chatauqua, the more than century-old cultural, intellectual and recreational complex near Jamestown in upstate New York. So question-and-answersessions there are likely to be lively Monday through Friday at what is described as the first Soviet-American conference open to the American public.

title: Guilty Plea Is Entered In Tainted Meat Case
description: The owner of a Chester County pet food company has pleaded guilty to charges that he sold meat from diseased, dying or dead cattle to a wholesaler who then resold it to state hospitals, schools and military facilities.

title: KOREAN DMZ: GAZING SOUTH, ANOTHER VIEW
description: For a Westerner, there is a strangeness about entering the demilitarized zone between the two Koreas from the Communist side.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption on April 28 accompanying ''Strategies for Avoiding the Crowds in Europe'' misidentified a city scene. The photograph was of a square in Lille, France.

title: FROM SIND TO GILGIT
description: TO THE FRONTIER By Geoffrey Moorhouse. 285 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $17.95.

title: LESLIE A. O'BRIEN BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Leslie Anne O'Brien, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Philip O'Brien of West Hartford, Conn., was married in New York yesterday to Kenneth Charles Williams, the son of Col. Robert Williams, U.S.A.F., retired, of Redington Beach, Fla., and the late Mrs. Williams. The Rev. Nicholas R. Reid performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer.

title: SOME FINE PRINT IN THE TAX PLAN
description: NOW that tax professionals have taken a closer look at President Reagan's tax proposal, they are revising their initial grim predictions regarding vacation homes.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN HAVERSTRAW
description: SCHOONERS no longer haul Haverstraw's famous bricks to ports the world over. For a hundred years, brickmaking was the lifeblood of this Rockland County village on the Hudson, 30 miles up river from Manhattan. But the industry died during World War II and years of economic decline followed.

title: DOCUMENTS ON LOWENSTIEN
description: To the Editor:

title: Make Contractors Adhere to Rules
description: The fraud committed by defense contractors and other corporations doing business with the Government is a national disgrace and an assault against the American taxpayer.

title: STATE POLITICAL PARTIES ARE PLAYING A NEW ROLE
description: To the Editor:

title: DOCUMENTS ON LOWENSTEIN
description: To the Editor:

title: BARCELONA
description: To the Editor: Your fine focus on Barcelona provides an excellent guide to Gaudi's wonders, but omits another magical site that music lovers and architecture buffs will want to discover.

title: LANGUAGE EXPERTS QUERIED
description: THE votes are in: The noun gridlock is a winner, the transitive verb commentate is a loser.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: A Nos Amours Starring Sandrine Bonnaire, Dominique Besnehard, Maurice Pialat; directed by Mr. Pialat, 1984. (R) RCA/Columbia Home Video 99 minutes.

title: MISS ARLOW WEDS MORTON AARONSON
description: The marriage of Susan Alissa Arlow to Morton Cass Aaronson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence C. Aaronson of Old Westbury, L.I., took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Arlow of Great Neck, L.I., parents of the bride. Rabbi Stephen Pinsky performed the ceremony.

title:
POSTINGS;

JACKSON SQUARE STEPS
description: German developers are planning a condominium complex overlooking Jackson Square Park in Greenwich Village in the 19th-century style characteristic of the residential and commercial buildings of the neighborhood.

title: A TEST OF STAYING POWER FOR AMERICANS IN LEBANON
description: For the few Americans left in Moslem-dominated West Beirut, life is not easy. Seven are being held by Moslem groups. The civilian toll rises daily as rival militias constantly battle each other with small arms and artillery. Yet many of those who were packing last week were thinking only of summer holidays abroad and were prepared to return in the fall.

title: NEUROSCIENCES UNIT CELEBRATES 10 YEARS
description: WHEN neurologists and neurosurgeons discuss CAT and PET, they are not talking about the small, furry variety. They are referring to coaxial tomography and positron emission tomography scanners, computerized diagnostic devices that are used to examine the brain.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: THERE is something for just about everyone on this year's summer bookshelf.

title: MAMARONECK MOTEL IS FOCUS OF DEBATE
description: FOR the last two years, Vincent's Motel, where earlier this month a 17-year-old high school student was found murdered, has been a source of concern and complaints among residents here.

title: GRANTS INSPIRE CUTS IN HOSPITAL COSTS
description: A PROGRAM that has saved Manchester Memorial Hospital patients $2 million in charges is expanding hospitals in Norwich and Middletown this year.

title: Democrat Bids Reagan Reduce Military Waste
description: Saying the Pentagon budget was ''locked into a go-go cycle of spend, spend, spend,'' Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan asked President Reagan today to make a Father's Day pact to cut waste and fraud in the military budget.

title: RON HOWARD GOES FROM HOT ACTOR TO HOT DIRECTOR
description: ''Hey, Richie, how you doin'?'' a U.C.L.A student calls across the restaurant to Ron Howard.

title: TCHAIKOVSKY INSPIRES AN OFFBEAT BALANCHINE BOOK
description: Among the books concerning George Balanchine that have been published since the great choreographer's death two years ago, the most curious and most interesting is ''Balanchine's Tchaikovsky'' by Solomon Volkov (Simon and Schuster. $19.95) Mr. Volkov, a Soviet musicologist who emigrated to the United States in 1976, ran into a certain degree of controversy in 1979 with the publication of''Testimony: The Memoirs of Dimitri Shostakovitch.'' His claim that these memoirs were based on fresh conversations by himself with the late Soviet composer was doubted in some quarters and their authenticity as such was not accepted by Shostakovitch's son when he too arrived in the West a few years ago.

title: Happy Anniversary
description: The planning has been almost perfect. To mark the 20th anniversary of Medicare and Medicaid, the Federal Government and the State of California are to hold a conference in Los Angeles Wednesday through Friday.

title: GREAT NECK TV SHIFT DEBATED
description: AN attempt by Cablevision to buy the cable television franchise currently held by Cox Communications in 15 North Shore villages has so far met with a chilly reception from officials of the Great Neck Cable Commission and the North Shore Cable TV Advisory Committee.

title: Massachusetts Checking Bars
description: Massachusetts has developed a new tactic in its war against drunken driving.

title: RECITALS MARK SUMMER DEBUT
description: SUMMER must really be here!

title: AIRLINE FOOD
description: To the Editor: Fred Ferretti's article on airline food encourages me to share a technique I use whenever making a flight reservation.

title: FLOODING VEXES LAKE HOMES
description: WATERLOGGED residents around Lake Ronkonkoma face a long wait while officials attempt to develop a flood relief plan.

title: Co-op Eviction Exemptions
description: Question: I live in a rent-stabilized apartment with my 12-year-old daughter, who is handicapped. If the building is converted to a co-op on an eviction plan, will I be permitted to stay as a tenant because of her handicap? . . . F. G., Manhattan Answer: The law does not allow the parents of a dependent child who is disabled to be considered eligible for an exemption, says Martin A. Shlufman, deputy counsel for rent administration in the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. Bills have been introduced in the State Legislature at the request of the New York State Advocate for the Disabled, a state agency, to extend the exemption to parents of disabled children and to include disabled people who may be employed. For more information write: New York State Advocate for the Disabled, Agency Building 1, 10th floor, Empire State Plaza, Albany, N.Y. 12223. Rights to the Roof Question: Can rent-regulated tenants in a non-eviction co-op use the roof? . . . M. H., Manhattan Answer: If a rooftop facility was provided for tenant use before the conversion, the conversion cannot take away Redinger any rights, services or amenities a tenant had, Mr. Shlufman said. If the co-op installed a roof garden, then the use could be limited to shareholders. Owner-Occupancy Eviction Question: After my daughter's divorce, she sold half her Manhattan brownstone and retained two floors, one of which is rented to an elderly couple and is either rent-controlled or -stabilized. She has remarried and has a stepson who lives with her in a one-bedroom apartment.

title:
GARDENING;

FRESH VEGETABLES ALL SEASON LONG
description: IN addition to the pleasures that one may derive from growing one's own vegetables, there are advantages in being able to harvest the freshest possible produce just outside the kitchen door.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AMERICA ENTERS THE WORLD: A People's History of the Progressive Era and World War I. By Page Smith. (McGraw-Hill, $29.95.) Advanced students of American history might dismiss this massive (1,089 pages) seventh volume of Page Smith's ''People's History'' of the United States as a superficial summary.

title: Wearing Furs
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE THREE ROMES. By Russell Fraser. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $17.95.) The legacy of Rome did not die with its fall, but lived on with Constantinople and then Moscow; each city in turn sought to rule the world and found a new heavenly order.

title: AMID FEAR AND CONFUSION ON PLANE, 'YOU COULD HEAR THE GUNS RATTLING'
description: By late afternoon, the Trans World Airlines jetliner parked on the steaming runway was ''a complete mess,'' Pamela Rice recalled later, ''with scraps of food and junk all over.''

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: NEW OLD HOSPITAL IT'S official: All the signs have been changed, the new stationery distributed, and everyone notified. Long Island's oldest hospital now has the newest name.

title: ON BOXING
description: THEY ARE YOUNG welterweight boxers so evenly matched they might be twins - though one has a redhead's pallor and the other is a dusky-skinned Hispanic. Circling each other in the ring, they try jabs, tentative left hooks, right crosses that dissolve in midair or turn into harmless slaps. The Madison Square Garden crowd is derisive, impatient. ''Those two! What'd they do, wake up this morning and decide they were boxers?'' a man behind me says contemptuously. (He's dark, nattily dressed, with a neatly trimmed mustache and tinted glasses. A sophisticated fight fan. Two hours later he will be crying, ''Tommy! Tommy! Tommy!'' over and over in a paroxysm of grief as, on the giant closed-circuit television screen, middleweight champion Marvelous Marvin Hagler batters his challenger, Thomas Hearns, into insensibility.) The young boxers must be conscious of the jeers and boos in this great cavernous space reaching up into the $20 seats in the balconies amid the constant milling of people in the aisles, the smells of hotdogs, beer, cigarette and cigar smoke, hair oil. But they are locked desperately together, circling, jabbing, slapping, clinching, now a flurry of light blows, clumsy footwork, another sweaty stumbling despairing clinch into the ropes that provokes a fresh wave of derision. Why are they here in the Garden of all places, each fighting what looks like his first professional fight? What are they doing? Neither is angry at the other. When the bell sounds at the end of the sixth and final round, the crowd boos a little louder.

title: U.S. to Honor Salt II Treaty Up to a Point
description: After a long debate within the Government, President Reagan said last week that the United States would continue to abide by the unratified 1979 strategic arms limitation treaty known as SALT II. He still thinks the treaty and its 1972 predecessor, SALT I, are flawed, Mr. Reagan said, but his decision is intended ''to foster an atmosphere of mutual restraint conducive to serious negotiation'' with the Russians in Geneva.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;

BUCKWHEAT NOODLES: JAPAN'S FAST FOOD
description: Generalizing about the national character is a favorite pastime of the Japanese. Most of them say that as they get older they revert to a more Japanese way of doing things, things like wearing kimono at home and eating the plainest kinds of food. They prefer not the attenuated mannerism of kaiseki cuisine - the spare but extensive sequence of dishes served before the tea ceremony - - or the cloying richness of sukiyaki but the simplicity of green tea poured over rice flavored with a few bits of seaweed; or the purity of transparent, fatless slivers of raw flounder; or the nutty flavor of buckwheat noodles, called soba, with the refreshing bite of wasabi, the green horseradish that accompanies sashimi and is dabbed on sushi.

title: TOO IMPORTANT FOR GENERALS?
description: COUNSELS OF WAR By Gregg Herken. 409 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Insights Into Self-Deception
description: In his article ''Insights Into Self-Deception'' (May 12), Daniel Goleman is really saying: There is no absolute truth; there are only facts, from which each individual makes his own reality, his own truth, in a way that suits his needs at the time. If his perception of reality enables him to cope more happily and successfully in his world, that is to be desired, not denigrated.

title: PORT JEFFERSON, IRKED BY TEEN-AGE CROWDS, ASKS PARKING BAN
description: PORT JEFFERSON is seeking to limit parking on Main Street to discourage crowds of teen-agers that have made the area one of Long Island's most popular spots for young people.

title: SUMO COMES TO THE GARDEN WITH A SCREAM AND A SPLAT
description: Form followed function in the first sumo tournament ever held in New York. Thirty-four of Japan's best sumo wrestlers displayed their heft and art to about 13,000 customers Friday night in Madison Square Garden. When it was over, the grand champion (or yokozuna) Chiyonofugi emerged the winner, and Japan's only other active yokozuna, Takanosato, was the runner-up. Immediately beneath them were the ozeki Asahio (an ozeki is ranked just under yokozuna) and the audience favorite, the 490-pound Konishiki from Hawaii.

title: DR. SUSAN PRESBY WEDS
description: Dr. Susan Presby Weds At Temple Israel of the City of New York yesterday Dr. Susan Presby, a psychologist, and Bruce Kodish, a physical therapist, were married by Rabbi Martin Zion. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Samuelson of Boca Raton, Fla., was widowed. She has two children. Mr. Kodish is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Kodish of Mount Lebanon, Pa.

title: T. C. AND THE EX-MONSTER
description: WHEN he arrived at Oakland Hills earlier in the week, Tze-Chung Chen was provided with a copy of the United States Open program, as all the golfers in the tournament were. Every so often since then, usually as his motel in the evening, he has glanced at the 446-page book. But only at certain pages.

title: YOUTH-EXCHANGE GROUPS WOO L.I.
description: A STRONG effort to recruit high school students to study abroad, as well as families to be hosts to foreign students, has been aimed at Long Island in recent months. The area's social and economic factors are ideal for such recruiting, say spokesmen for several large youth exchange programs.

title: SEED BIENNIALS NOW FOR BLOOM NEXT SUMMER
description: Why not a renaissance for biennials? After all, biennials are close to perennials and offer the same substance and form to enhance a flower border.

title: CHOIR IS FORMED FOR DISABLED YOUTHS
description: ''I'M planning ahead - projecting into the future,'' said Barbara Baker, program coordinator, recreation specialist and music therapist at the South East Consortium, a voluntary, nonprofit corporation that provides therapeutic recreation programs to youths and adults with physical, developmental, emotional or learning disabilities whose recreational needs have not been met by traditional municipal programs.

title: SIMPLE TIPS FOR PAINLESS PAINTING
description: PAINTING is one chore that almost everyone tackles at one time or another. It is also a task that often requires as much time for cleanup after the job is done as is spent in actually putting the paint on. That's why knowledgeable do-it-yourselfers soon learn that wise planning, coupled with some simple tricks of the trade, can help to make cleaning up a lot less messy and time-consuming. Here are some pointers:

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: Kodak Pocket Guide to Nature Photography #112 pages. Simon & Schuster. $5.95. Kodak Pocket Guide to Travel Photography #112 pages. Simon & Schuster. $5.95.

title: Clippers File Suit
description: When the Los Angeles Clippers obtained Marques Johnson in a six-player trade with the Milwaukee Bucks last September, they did not know that the highly regarded forward had spent some time in a drug rehabilitation center in Minneapolis the year before. When the Clippers did find out about the treatment -and concluded that the Bucks had known about it and improperly withheld the information - they filed a protest with David Stern, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, but asked him to disqualify himself from ruling on the matter because of his involvement with the N.B.A. lawsuit in connection with the Clippers' move from San Diego to Los Angeles.

title: Ever on Guard
description: Marshall Nikolai V. Ogarkov, the former Soviet Chief of Staff, has long advocated that the Soviet Union remain vigilant against the United States. He has promoted the need to keep the Soviet military at the forefront of technological innovation, whether in conventional arms, electronics or nuclear weaponry.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: First, a confession. Although I am a great admirer of Frank Herbert's Dune saga, I approached the most recent installment with some trepidation. Fearful that Mr. Herbert could not sustain the narrative excitement indefinitely, I dreaded having to inform the legions of Herbert fans that the inevitable decline had set in. I am happy to report that the sixth Dune novel, CHAPTERHOUSE: DUNE (Putnam, $17.95), is a worthy addition to this durable and deservedly popular series.

title: HOUSTON'S CREDIT RATING IS CUT BUT REMAINS HIGH
description: Standard & Poor's Corporation has cut this city's credit rating on over $1 billion worth of pending and outstanding general obligation bonds, citing the city's ''weak economic performance during the recent recession and its slow recovery'' as well as the lack of a rise in sales tax revenue.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

TAKING THEIR MEASURE
description: JULIET POPPER said she was shy. She said she wasn't sure she wanted to perform a song she had written. ''Oh don't announce me,'' she begged the piano player as a hush spread over happy hour in Tuttles in the White Plains Hotel. ''Don't announce me.''

title: BIRDS AT THE BAY
description: AMONG the most abundant shore birds that depend on Delaware Bay in the spring are the sanderling and the common and semipalmated sandpipers.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on page 1 of the Business section last Sunday about corporate ethics incorrectly described the charges against the Bank of Boston. In February the bank pleaded guilty to failure to report to the Federal Government $1.2 billion of cash transfers with foreign banks and was fined $500,000.

title: MISS SLUSSER HAS WEDDING
description: Wendelin Margaret Slusser, a member of the class of '86 at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, and James Douglas Bruce, a film maker, were married yesterday. Msgr. James G. Wilders performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title:
GARDENING;

FRESH VEGETABLES ALL SEASON LONG
description: IN addition to the pleasures that one may derive from growing one's own vegetables, there are advantages in being able to harvest the freshest possible produce just outside the kitchen door.

title: A NEW PRESCRIPTION: SNIFF AN APPLE A DAY
description: THE smell of apple pie rekindles a warm spot inside many people. The scent of mulled cider can evoke thoughts of home on a chilly winter day.

title: West Germany Loses To Mexico in Soccer
description: The Mexican national team defeated West Germany, 2-0, today at an exhibition match at Aztec Stadium, marking the first Mexican victory over West Germany in soccer.

title: THE BIG SHOREHAM QUESTION: WHO RUNS SUFFOLK?
description: SUFFOLK County Executive Peter F. Cohalan and the 18-member County Legislature are engaged in a no-holds-barred clash over who holds the ultimate power in county government.

title: LEFT BANK OF THE SUBURBS
description: ''Are you pro-bamboo or anti-bamboo?''

title: IN AN ILLINOIS TOWN, THE HIJACKING HITS CLOSE TO HOME
description: The hijacking of a 727 aircraft loaded with American tourists was a world away from this rural Illinois town today but very close to the lives of St. Margaret Mary Church on the hill.

title: 19 FREED HOSTAGES FLOWN TO FRANCE
description: The 17 women and 2 children freed in Beirut Friday from the hijacked Trans World Airlines flight began another leg of their odyssey today as they flew to Paris to join about 25 others who were released from the hijacked aircraft in Algiers late Friday night and this afternoon.

title: A LESSON IN IMPROVEMENT
description: In West Germany, the favorite form of chess is team competition.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: When Croydon Hall, a private academy in Middletown Township, Monmouth County, closed in 1975 - a victim of inflation and declining enrollment - local historians felt the loss as well.

title: MAYORAL ELECTION STIRS SAG HARBOR
description: IN most communities, the announcement that someone is running for a local office does not cause much commotion. But when George Butts Jr. declared last month that he was running for Mayor of Sag Harbor, it created a stir. It will be the first time since 1979 that the incumbent, Mayor Fred Runco, has had a challenger.

title: NEW YORK GROUP FIGHTS MANDATED PRISON TERMS
description: The Correctional Association of New York has renewed its appeal for the abolition of the state's mandatory sentencing laws, citing 21 cases that it says show that many convicts are forced to serve prison terms whose length even their prosecutors and judges feel is unwarranted.

title: WILL COLLEGE SPORTS REFORM BE BUSINESS AS USUAL?
description: FOR the first time since the 1920's, there seems to be general agreement about the need for reform in intercollegiate sports. Opinions offered from many different perspectives acknowledge that recent scandals show a basic dislocation between the stated goals of college sports and its actual operation. The fact that so many different sources are calling for change might suggest that there is unanimity and that all agree that educational concerns should be restored to a predominant position. However, a close look at recent proposals gives reason for pause.

title: Tobacco Smoke Does No Harm
description: Norman Conn's arguments in support of workplace smoking restrictions [''Speak Up Against the Smokers,'' May 12] are as familiar as they are deficient. Mr. Conn refers to the claimed hazards of tobacco smoke in the air and the asserted added expense companies assume by hiring smokers.

title: YOUNG RECORD COMPANY FORGES AHEAD
description: In September 1980, a small Minneapolis-based record company called Pro Arte opened up its doors. The timing wasn't exactly ideal for the launch of a new label: Many of the larger and seemingly more firmly established labels, suffering under the weight of the recession, were firing employees and curtailing their production schedules, but Pro Arte forged blithely ahead with a line built largely on material licensed from German Harmonia Mundi, Seon, Supraphon and other European labels, along with a few local productions and European co-productions to fill out the mix. At the time, Pro Arte did have some corporate muscle behind it - it was a subsidiary of American Can/Pickwick, the company that had been successfully marketing the Quintessence mid-price reissue line for several years.

title: CELEBRATING HERSELF
description: THE EARLY DIARY OF ANAIS NIN Volume Four 1927-1931. With a preface by Joaquin Nin-Culmell. Illustrated. 502 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $29.95.

title: U.S. MAYORS AT PARLEY VOICE DOUBTS ON REAGAN TAX PLAN
description: Mayors of some of America's larger cities, meeting for the first time since President Reagan submitted his budget and tax proposals, charged today that he was advocating a ''conceptual change'' in Government that would fall particularly hard on urban centers with large concentrations of poor members of minority groups.

title: NEW YORK FOOD OUTLETS CITED FOR VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 61 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE DESTROYING ANGEL: Sex, Fitness & Food in the Legacy of Degeneracy Theory, Graham Crackers, Kellogg's Corn Flakes & American Health History. By John Money.

title: LAKE CHAMPLAIN FOUND TO BE POLLUTED BY PCB'S
description: Lake Champlain, a center of tourism in northern New York, is polluted by PCB's, a hazardous chemical, according to the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: Koch Wins on Budget Limit
description: Mayor Koch took away the allowance he traditionally gives to the City Council and the Board of Estimate during negotiations last week over the 1986 budget. But he then agreed to exchange some of their pet projects for his own. In the end, after a long week of occasionally frenzied negotiations, the Mayor managed to keep the cost of running the city for the fiscal year beginning July 1 at $20 billion.

title: WRITING WAS AS DANGEROUS AS LIFE
description: SELECTIONS FROM GEORGE ELIOT'S LETTERS Edited by Gordon S. Haight. 567 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $25.

title: WASHINGTON, RIPE FOR DISASTER
description: ALL FALL DOWN America's Tragic Encounter With Iran. By Gary Sick. 366 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: OPERA: AMERICAN ALLEGORY
description: IN 1798, less than a generation after the American Revolution and before its achievements had been securely consolidated, an ''Allegorical Masque'' recounting the colonies' secession was performed in Charleston, S.C. It was published in 1802 as ''Americana, or, a New Tale of the Genii.'' The author is unknown, the music lost, but the text is not without a curious charm, and Neely Bruce's new score for it (with libretto reworked by Tony Connor) evinced its own quirky appeal Friday in a concert version at Symphony Space.

title: LESLIE A. OSBORNE IS MARRIED
description: Leslie Anne Osborne, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard de Jongh Osborne of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Samuel Richard Coleman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John M. Coleman of Easton, Pa. The Rev. Edward Dougherty performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Princeton Roman Catholic Chapel.

title: BALLET: 'QUIXOTE' RECAST
description: American Ballet Theater's production of ''Don Quixote'' received another pleasant performance on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. And one of the dancers who contributed most to the jollity was Deirdre Carberry, who made her debut as the ballet's heroine, Kitri.

title: Lilian Behan Wins Title In British Amateur Golf
description: Lilian Behan, a groom at the Curragh racecourse in Ireland, won the women's British Amateur Golf Championship today, beating Claire Waite of Britain by one hole in the final.

title: 2 TEST SURVIVAL ON A SAILBOARD
description: The coastal waters of the New York metropolitan area are setting the stage for yet another attempt by maritime adventurers to set a world record. This time, two men want to become the first to cross the Atlantic Ocean by sailboard. But rather than trying to break a speed record, their objective is survival. Two Frenchmen set sail from Sandy Hook, N.J., yesterday. They plan to re-create the record-breaking voyage taken by the 185-foot schooner Atlantic in 1905. At that time, the Atlantic sailed 4,000 nautical miles to the southwest coast of Britain in 12 days. The two men said they will be pleased if they make the crossing in 30 days.

title: LO, SOLLY COMETH
description: AFTER GOLIATH By R. V. Cassill. 209 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $14.95.

title: EXPLORING THE WILD ADIRONDACKS
description: At 6 P.M. the car is heading north, bound from city to mountains.

title: LYNN M. SARAJIAN PLANS AN OCTOBER MARRIAGE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Ahnert of Bushkill, Pa., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Ahnert's daughter, Lynn Margaret Sarajian, to Raymond Price 3d, a son of Mrs. Price Jr. of Stroudsburg, Pa., and the late Mr. Price. An October wedding is planned.

title: CLAIRE M. LIBIN, ARTIST, MARRIES DEREK LYNCH
description: Claire Milah Libin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Libin of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Derek James Lynch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Lynch of Califon, N.J. Town Justice Sheppard Frood performed the ceremony at the Libin home in East Hampton.

title: THE LONG ROAD TO STEREO TV
description: A gap of worrisome width is opening up between the makers of home video equipment and the broadcasting industry. Many of the new VCR's and television sets introduced at the Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago earlier this month (slated to show up in the shops this fall) are equipped for stereo sound. This, of course, is all to the good; but it puts this new gear in the position - as one observer remarked - of being ''all dressed up and no place to go.'' These VCR's and television sets are definitely ready for the future, but the future is slow in coming, at least in this country.

title: STAY-AT-HOME DAD IS FATHER OF THE YEAR
description: COA Schwab is 8 years old and a Boston Celtics fan, just like his father, 32-year-old Brian Schwab.

title: SUSAN SCARF HAS WEDDING
description: Susan Margaret Scarf, a daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Herbert Eli Scarf of Hamden, Conn., and Richard Wade Johnson, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Rollin M. Johnson of Northampton, Mass., and New York, were married in New Haven yesterday. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman and the Rev. Christopher Carlisle, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Dwight Memorial Chapel at Yale University.

title: SHRIVER IN FINAL WITH NAGELSEN
description: In an all-American semifinal round today, the defending champion, Pam Shriver, defeated Elise Burgin, 6-4, 6-2, and Betsy Nagelsen battled back to defeat Sue Mascarin setting up Sunday's final in the Edgbaston Cup women's international tennis championships.

title: CHEAP PARISIAN CHIC
description: The boulevards of Paris, heavy with luxurious designer shops, tend to be, more than anything, a kingdom for window shoppers. There are few people able to afford high-fashion Parisian clothing. The ones who can't leave smudge marks on windows and walk on. There is a way around the high prices though: a shopping expedition to Reciproque, a popular store for secondhand clothes in the 16th arrondissement.

title:
POSTINGS;

WINSTON'S CONDOS
description: Though the facades of two small buildings on the west side of Fifth Avenue just south of 56th Street have been saved by a landmark designation, the building at the corner, housing Harry Winston Jewelers, is going to be demolished and replaced by an 18-story tower.

title: SHINNECOCK BRACED FOR '86 U.S. OPEN
description: THIS summer will be busier than usual at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club as the club gears up to be host to the United States Open tournament for one week in June 1986 - an event expected to be a major boon to the East End's economy and tourism.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HAPPY FATHER'S DAY While it's true that not as much is made of Father's Day as Mother's Day, attention is occasionally paid to the man of the family, and not just by buying him power tools, after-shave lotion and ties. Several groups have scheduled special events devoted to dad today. For example, the Baffa Symphony Orchestra and Chorus offers ''Stars and Stripes'' as a Father's Day tribute. Featuring Richard Rodgers's ''Victory at Sea'' and other works by American composers, the concert is at 4 P.M. at Our Lady of the Snow Church, Blue Point Avenue in Blue Point. Tickets are $5, or $3 for students and the elderly.

title: GOVERNMENT WAS THE SOLUTION
description: FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT His Life and Times: An Encyclopedic View. Edited by Otis L. Graham Jr. and Meghan Robinson Wander. Illustrated. 483 pp. Boston: G. K. Hall & Company. $27.50. A CARING SOCIETY The New Deal, the Worker, and the Great Depression. By Irving Bernstein. Illustrated. 338 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $22.95.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: IN THE early 1970's, Hackensack's Middle School was one of the first in the state to have its own student-run television studio and station, WHBE (for Hackensack Board of Education). Over the years, it has improved its stature and equipment, and its programs can now be seen countywide through a cable-television access channel.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;

FROM EASTMAN HOUSE, A HISTORY BEGINNING WITH DAGUERRE
description: The exhibition ''Images of Excellence'' at the I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art, Madison Avenue at 56th Street, through July 27, is one of the most important exhibitions of photographs ever to be seen in New York City. The 200 photographs in this exhibition cover the history of photography from its introduction in 1839 down to the present day, and since they are drawn from the collection of the International Museum of Photography at George Eastman House in Rochester, N.Y., they cover it with an authority and thoroughness that probably could not be duplicated by any other institution.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;

ENSEMBLE 'HAS BACH, WILL TRAVEL'
description: AS far as Samuel Baron and his eight colleagues in the Bach Aria Group are concerned, there's no such thing as too much Bach - even in this year of Bach's tricentennial celebration.

title: DONNA M. TUTHS WEDS GEORGE MANDES
description: The marriage of Donna Marie Tuths, a daughter of Evelyn Svete Tuths of Rockville Centre and Southampton, L.I., and the late Dr. Philip M. Tuths of Valley Stream, L.I., to George James Mandes, the son of James Mandes of Bristol, Conn., and Ellen A. Mandes of Wallingford, Conn., took place yesterday at the chapel of the Choate School in Wallingford. The Rev. Thomas Fusco performed the ceremony.

title: Dispute Over Youth's Death
description: A 17-year-old Harlem youth was shot and killed by a plainclothes police officer on the Upper West Side one evening last week. Police officials said the youth, who graduated two weeks ago from an elite preparatory school, was involved in an apparent robbery attempt. But the family contended that he would not have committed such a crime and called the shooting unjustified.

title: THE CATSKILLS CAST THEIR QUIET SPELL
description: From the top of Slide Mountain, the Catskills can seem almost impressive. To the north, undulant hills swell gradually toward the flat-topped summits of West Kill and Hunter mountains, which dominate the horizon and divide the watersheds of Esopus and Schoharie creeks. These and a handful of other mountains in Greene and Ulster Counties constitute the ''high peaks'' of the Catskills, but one must suspend judgment to confer on them such lofty status. Early settlers in this region often used the term ''hills'' in describing these worn-down summits 100 miles north of New York City, and for a time the name ''Blue Hills'' vied with ''Catskills'' before the latter (whose etymology is obscure) won out.

title: PRESSURES OF REGULATION SQUEEZE ALASKA FISHING
description: Pat Millard has spent half his 32 years as a commercial fisherman in the salmon-rich waters of southeastern Alaska, and he worries about the way things are going.

title: A CORPSE AT THE DOORSTEP
description: THE ASSAULT By Harry Mulisch. Translated by Claire Nicolas White. 185 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $13.95.

title:
ANTIQUES;

A BIT OF HISTORY TAKES TO THE ROAD
description: THE closing of the Route 22 westbound lanes here for several hours on June 29 is expected to be offset somewhat by pedestrian traffic on hand to witness a bit of local history on the move.

title: Security Council Extends Mandate of Cyprus Unit
description: The Security Council voted unanimously today to extend the mandate of the United Nations peacekeeping force in Cyprus, amid signs of new obstacles blocking mediation efforts by the Secretary General.

title: IN SEARCH OF BARGAINS AT A CUSTOMS AUCTION
description: ''Lot No. 327: one compact-disk player,'' the auctioneer called. ''Do I hear $100?''

title: Inhospitalities The Republican
description: Q.: Who are the only two Republicans to be elected Mayor of New York City in the last 52 years? A.: Fiorello LaGuardia and John Lindsay. Q.: Who wants to be the next one? A.: Diane McGrath, a member of the New York State Crime Victims Board, and obviously a person of some courage.

title: Florida Keys
description: To the Editor: Two points might be added to Jon Nordheimer's poetic remarks on driving through the Florida Keys in the article ''On the Road From Sea to Sea'' (Travel, April 21).

title: WHY THE MINI-SERIES IS LOSING FAVOR
description: Now it is the turn of the mini-series to take a drubbing. When the ratings fall short of expectations, trust the average network executive to panic. Less than a year ago, the situation comedy was being buried forever because so few new ones, most of them dreadful, were being accepted by the public. Then, this season, along came ''The Cosby Show.'' The sitcom is solidly back in favor. So, in recent months, the analysts have been training their sights on mini-series, several of which have disappointed the network statisticians. Included among the culprits are productions ranging from more ambitious projects such as ''A.D.,'' ''Space'' and ''Columbus'' to the trashy glitter of ''Mistral's Daughter,'' ''Hollywood Wives'' and ''Lace II.''

title: GOOD REASONS TO BE A TEACHER
description: TO my considerable astonishment, I recently suggested to our son that he might enjoy teaching. In spite of the fact that I have inveighed for years, publicly and privately, against low teachers' salaries, negative public attitudes toward education, against teachers who demonstrate only a shop-steward mentality, there I was, after 16 years of teaching, encouraging my child to enter the very profession I have bewailed and denigrated.

title: THE NORMANDIE'S END
description: To the Editor:

title: Redesigning Human Bones
description: As someone who is actively involved in the design of total hip prostheses, I read with interest Herbert Burkholz's article ''Redesigning Human Bones'' (May 5). The article faithfully conveyed the status of the major breakthroughs that are occurring in orthopedics.

title: MOM'S COMMAND HANGS ON TO WIN
description: Mom's Command, the speedball who lasted a mile to win the Acorn Stakes 15 days ago, stretched her early speed an additional furlong yesterday to win the $233,000 Mother Goose Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at Belmont Park.

title: PILOT CHIEFS BACK UNITED CONTRACT, ENDING WALKOUT
description: The 29-day strike of 5,000 United Airlines pilots ended early yesterday when a tentative agreement was ratified by union leaders. The airline announced that it would be back to full operation in three to four weeks.

title: FORMULA ONE'S 2-RACE SEASON
description: Alain Prost of France will be trying for his third victory in five races today as the Formula One auto-racing circuit starts its annual North American swing with the running of the Labatts Canadian Grand Prix in Montreal. Prost drove his TAG-Porsche-powered McLaren to victory in the season-opening race at Brazil in April, and last month won the Monaco Grand Prix for the second year in a row.

title: Free to Spy Another Day?
description: Even John le Carre might have had trouble dealing with last week's scene on a bridge linking West Berlin to East Germany. It was ''the biggest spy swap'' in memory, according to an American official, and it took a bus to handle the crowd.

title: CATHERINE ELLIOTT BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Catherine Story Elliott, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Kindred Elliott Jr. of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Patrick John Mitchell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradford W. Mitchell of Doylestown, Pa., were married yesterday. The Rev. Hugh McManus performed the ceremony at Mount Mercy Roman Catholic Chapel in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Keeping Soccer From Slipping
description: To The Sports Editor:

title: GRADE CROSSING PLANS READIED FOR MINEOLA
description: AT 2:18 A.M. on March 14, 1982, at a Long Island Rail Road grade crossing on Herricks Road in Mineola, an onrushing train collided with a van with 10 teen-agers inside.

title: ...AND BUILDING A LEADER'S ROOTS
description: Governor Cuomo made the following remarks in a talk last month at John Glenn High School in Elwood.

title: A CHANNEL WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: ''Our programming is for what we call the lifelong learners,'' John S. Hendricks was saying the other day. ''People who maintain a curiosity about the world, and who want to come away from a program enriched as well as amused.''

title: Redesigning Human Bones
description: The ''quiet revolution'' in prosthetics that Herbert Burkholz described could be displaced by the not-so-quiet revolution in health financing. Controlling costs has become the dominant theme in health-care policy.

title: A Gandhi Stand Cheers U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration welcomed Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India to Washington last week with modest expectations: better relations but no big change in India's even-handed policy toward the United States and the Soviet Union. The meetings with President Reagan and others were described as relaxed and friendly, and Mr. Gandhi's call for an independent and nonaligned Afghanistan came as a pleasant surprise.

title:
DEPRECIATION: THE TAX PLAN'S HIDDEN ISSSUE;

THE PROPOSAL STRIKES A FAIR BALANCE
description: DID President Reagan capitulate to big business in his treatment of depreciation in his proposed tax-simplification plan? Is accelerated depreciation necessary or desirable as an investment incentive? Neither question is susceptible to a simple yes or no answer. Clearly, however, the President's proposal for reforming depreciation policy is a significant improvement over the existing Accelerated Cost Recovery System - although a step backward from the first Treasury proposal. It provides badly needed flexibility and removes the arbitrariness that has made accelerated depreciation a vulnerable political target.

title: Blyleven Stays Put
description: Bert Blyleven picked up his 200th career victory Friday night as he led the Indians to a 6-1 decision over the Oakland A's, but the 34-year-old pitcher has lost his chance to get out of Cleveland, at least for the time being. Blyleven, who for a year has been asking the Indians to trade him, appeared on the verge of getting his wish, and the Toronto Blue Jays, the Minnesota Twins, the St. Louis Cardinals and the California Angels expressed interest.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE MOSLEY RECEIPT. By Kenneth Royce. (Stein & Day, $15.95.) Spider Scott, a former ''cat burglar of distinction'' turned government agent who figures in Kenneth Royce's series of espionage novels, burrows away on another thankless mission for British intelligence in this smartly crafted formula thriller.

title: Merger Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ: THE JVC FESTIVAL
description: DAVE GRUSIN, the successful film composer, record producer and keyboardist, has been a key figure in the development of a Latinized, funk-inflected jazz-fusion style organized around the ensemble playing of leading session musicians. Instead of free improvisation and the expression of individual personality, the genre revolves around tightly coordinated group performances on electric instruments. Intense Latin-funk grooves take precedence over melodic invention in pieces whose rigidly syncopated rhythms are pointedly augmented by the instrumentation.

title: KATHARINE BOWING MARRIED TO EDWIN DAVIS COYLE
description: The marriage of Katharine Nash Bowring, the daughter of Ann Street Bowring of New York and William Boyd Bowring of Chatham, Mass., to Edwin Davis Coyle took place yesterday in Christiansburg, Va. The Rev. David Augustus Elliott 3d, a cousin of the bride and an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James Temple Coyle.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Fiction 1 ''. . . AND LADIES OF THE CLUB,'' by Helen Hooven Santmyer. (Berkley, $5.95.) Life in an Ohio hamlet, 1868-1932. 2 FULL CIRCLE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.50.) The relationship of a mother and daughter is altered by the changing values of the past 40 years. 3 THE HAJ, by Leon Uris. (Bantam, $4.95.) An Arab's experience in the wars of the Holy Land. 4 DEEP SIX, by Clive Cussler. (Pocket, $4.50.) One man copes with a sinister Asian shipping family and an even more threatening Soviet plot. 5 THE WHEEL OF FORTUNE, by Susan Howatch. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A wealthy Welsh family is haunted by an ominous heritage. 6 * LINCOLN, by Gore Vidal. (Ballantine, $4.95.) A fictionalized account of the Civil War Presidency. 7 THE WALKING DRUM, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $3.95.) A young man from Brittany sets out to free his father, enslaved in 12th-century Asia. 8 MISSISSIPPI! by Dana Fuller Ross. (Bantam, $3.95.) The ''Wagons West'' series reaches the post-Civil War South and New Orleans. 9 TENDER IS THE STORM, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $3.95.) A New York heiress's passionate encounter with an Arizona rancher. 10 POSSESSIONS, by Judith Michael. (Pocket, $4.50.) A woman discovers the truth about her husband after he disappears. 11 THE MODIGLIANI SCANDAL, by Ken Follett. (NAL/Signet, $3.50.) A ''lost masterpiece'' and dirty dealings in the international art world; first published pseudonymously several years ago. 12 RAMBO: First Blood Part II, by David Morrell. (Jove, $3.50.) Novelization of the film about a Vietnam vet who returns to rescue prisoners of war. 13 THE AQUITAINE PROGRESSION, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $4.50.) A lawyer finds himself caught in a conspiracy to take over the world. 14 SUMMER HARVEST, by Madge Swindells. (NAL/ Signet, $3.95.) Thirty years in southern Africa. 15 * THE WISHSONG OF SHANNARA, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $8.95.) The battle against evil continues in the Four Lands; conclusion of a fantasy trilogy. Nonfiction General 1 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (S&S/Touchstone, $8.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 2 IN SEARCH OF EXCELLENCE, by Thomas J. Peters and Robert H. Waterman Jr. (Warner, $8.95.) Lessons from well-run corporations. 3 SON, by Jack Olsen. (Dell, $4.50.) The case of a young psychotic rapist at large in Spokane, Wash. 4 FIRST LADY FROM PLAINS, by Rosalynn Carter. (Fawcett, $3.95.) Memoirs. 5 PAST IMPERFECT, by Joan Collins. (Berkley, $3.95.) The tell-it-all autobiography of the actress. Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 PENGUIN DREAMS AND STRANGER THINGS, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $6.95.) Cartoons from the syndicated ''Bloom County'' strip. 2 BRIDE OF THE FAR SIDE, by Gary Larson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $5.95.) Cartoon humor. 3 RAND MCNALLY ROAD ATLAS: United States, Canada, Mexico. (Rand McNally, $5.95.) For 1985. 4 THE SILVER PALATE GOOD TIMES COOKBOOK, by Julee Rosso and Sheila Lukins with Sarah Leah Chase. (Workman, $11.95.) Recipes from the owners of a Manhattan gourmet food shop. 5 THE ONE MINUTE MANAGER, by Kenneth Blanchard and Spencer Johnson. (Berkley, $6.95.) How to increase your productivity. 6 EAT TO WIN, by Robert Hass. (NAL/Signet, $4.50.) A regimen for sports and fitness activities. 7 MORE SNIGLETS, by Rich Hall and Friends. (Collier/Macmillan, $5.95.) Words that should appear in dictionaries, but don't. With cartoons. 8 GARFIELD MAKES IT BIG, by Jim Davis. (Ballantine, $5.95.) Cartoon humor. 9 * AAA NORTH AMERICAN ROAD ATLAS 1985. (American Automobile Association/Random, $5.95.) Maps and traveling advice. 10 * SNIGLETS, by Rich Hall and Friends. (Collier/ Macmillan, $5.95.) Newly minted words.

title: Art
description: No public space in the city is immune from the attentions of the Organization of Independent Artists, an enterprising group that seeks settings outside of galleries and museums to display the work of its members. The fairly new campus (1983) of the Borough of Manhattan Community College,at 199 Chambers Street, with its frontage on the Hudson River, poses a special challenge, and the group has taken the bait. Eight of its sculptors have joined in ''Sculpture at Borough of Manhattan Community College'' (through Oct. 20), an indoor-outdoor show that puts these architectural works in the context of one of the city's largest and most ungainly buildings (its size approximates the Empire State Building turned on its side).

title: PBS Will Air Vietnam Rebuttal
description: On June 27, Channel 13, New York's public television station, will carry a two-hour response to the award-winning series on the Vietnam war that it and many other public stations carried in 1983.

title: A NEAR MISS IN OHIO HARKENS BACK TO THREE MILE ISLAND
description: Government investigators are still trying to determine exactly what went wrong, but they agree that last Sunday's events at the Davis-Besse nuclear plant in Oak Harbor, Ohio, were strikingly similar to the accident at Three Mile Island in 1979.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CANOE RACES The Connecticut Canoe Racing Association championships will be held at 1 P.M. today on the Shetucket River, starting from Lauter Park, Willimantic. Approximately 100 open canoes and downriver kayaks will compete in the 14-mile, flatwater course with one portage around Scotland dam. Registration costs $6 for nonmembers and will be held from 11:30 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. The phone number is 456-0558.

title: A Friend Of the Dogwoods
description: As a native of Fairfield, I was pleased and proud the fine article, ''Fairfield Celebrates Its Dogwood Trees'' [April 21] .

title: STATE POLITICAL PARTIES ARE PLAYING A NEW ROLE
description: To the Editor:

title: 18 MONTHS LATER, IT'S STILL HARD TO FIGURE DEREGULATION
description: Once again, Americans are learning the cost of deregulation in the telephone industry. As 90 million households and 5.7 million small businesses get their telephone bills this month, they will discover that they are paying a $1 ''subscriber line charge.'' The monthly charge, to be paid for every line going into a home or business, was introduced with relatively little protest. Even those who argue that deregulation is doing more harm than good in the telephone industry acknowlege that the extra $1 won't force large numbers of people to give up their telephone service.

title: Man and Woman Guilty Of Killing 2 in Kansas
description: Jurors convicted a man and a woman today of kidnapping and murdering two workers at a grain elevator Feb. 13 in a crime spree in which four people died.

title: DANIEL G. GILLIAN WED TO CYNTHIA A. LAWLER
description: Cynthia Ann Lawler, a daughter of Mrs. William C. Ridgway 3d of Sea Bright, N.J., and Fishers Island, L.I., and Edward E. Lawler 3d of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Daniel G. Gillan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Gillan of Smithtown, L.I., were married yesterday. The Rev. Edward Wisneski performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church on Fishers Island.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: IN THE ATTIC By Hiawyn Oram. Illustrated by Satoshi Kitamura. Unpaged. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $10.95. (Ages 3 to 5) WHAT'S INSIDE? The Alphabet Book. By Satoshi Kitamura. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95. (Ages 3 to 5) ARTHUR, a furious black-haired, white-faced child, was the protagonist of Hiawyn Oram and Satoshi Kitamura's first book, ''Angry Arthur.'' When his mother told him to turn off the television, Arthur turned on a tantrum so world-shaking that it destroyed the planet and made the universe tremble. This was Max minus the Wild Things; a neat variation on a contemporary picture-book theme.

title:
POSTINGS;

S. BRONX REVIVAL
description: In the late 70's, eight square blocks of dilapidated housing in the University Heights section of the South Bronx were condemned by the city and the structures have been gradually demolished over the years.

title: INSIGHTS INTO SELF-DECEPTION
description: There are limits to the advantages of cognitive psychology. A person may be aware of an alcoholic father, a nagging mother, a hypochondriac wife, an ungrateful son, and yet choose to dwell upon a redeeming attribute. Who is to fault such trade-offs, and who among us is without cracks and shadings? HELEN KRANTZ Hempstead, N.Y.

title: MISSING DAD
description: IT is Father's Day, and this year I don't have a father. So many years have gone by, and for every one of those years the day has been acknowledged with a card. I can still remember hand-fashioning those construction-paper labors of love in my elementary school years. Then, later, when I evolved into a mature young lady, I ventured out into the world of Hallmark, picking and choosing until I had discovered the perfect verse, the ideal picture.

title: MISS DISERENS WED TO J. E. TAYLOR JR.
description: The marriage of Deborah Fairbanks Diserens and James Edward Taylor Jr. took place yesterday in the garden at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Diserens Jr., in Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. Arthur W. Hargate, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Dr. and Mrs. J. Edward Taylor of Bala-Cynwyd, Pa.

title: AIRLINE FOOD
description: To the Editor: I love oxymorons. I am adding Fred Ferretti's ''airline food'' to a collection that includes ''military intelligence,'' ''Long Island Expressway'' and many others.

title: Anti-Sandinistas Try To Change Their Image
description: A leader of Nicaragua's political opposition said here today that a coalition of anti-Government forces had adopted a ''code of conduct'' to insure civilian control of its military arm and to soften its identification with the regime of the deposed Nicaraguan dictator, Anastasio Somoza Debayle.

title: Fraternities, Where Men May Come to Terms With Other Men
description: To the Editor:

title: LISA KIMMELL, AN ARTIST, WED TO ANDREW N. WHITE
description: Lisa Deitch Kimmel, the daughter of Arnold Kimmel of New York and Lakeville, Conn., and the late Lois Deitch Kimmel, was married in Lakeville yesterday to Andrew Newhall White, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. White of Lakeville.

title: LYDIA SWEETSER WED TO WILLIAM G. GOLLNER
description: Lydia St. Laurent Sweetser, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Sweetser of Minneapolis, was married yesterday to William Guy Gollner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Guy Gollner of Bronxville, N.Y., and Stratton, Vt. The Rev. Thomas Tobin performed the ceremony at St. John the Baptist Roman Catholic Church in Westport Harbor, Mass.

title: MISS LANG WEDS R. H. LANDSMAN
description: Sandra Lang, a daughter of Mrs. Andrews Madden Lang of Shrewsbury, Mass., and Washington, and the late Mr. Lang, was married yesterday to Robert Henry Landsman of New York and Delhi, N.Y., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Alexander Landsman of Tamerac, Fla. The Rev. Paul Milz, a Presbyterian minister, performed a nondenominational ceremony at the bridegroom's home in Delhi.

title: CUOMO SENTENCING PLAN ASSAILED
description: Signs that Governor Cuomo is pressing harder for his criminal sentencing package than many legislators expected have touched off a strong opposition campaign.

title: HIGH SCHOOL WELCOMES ELDERLY
description: WHEN the term ends Wednesday, officials at Princeton High School will be able to look back on a program that began amid controversy but has proved even more successful than its advocates had hoped for. The program, Learning in the Classroom, puts the elderly in high school classes with people half a century and more their junior.

title: AN OUTPOURING OF BACH DISPLAYS VARIED ARTISTRY
description: As nice as it is to be celebrating J. S. Bach's 300th birthday, it is hard to escape the feeling, when faced with new and repackaged versions of everything from the Brandenburg Concertos to ''The Art of Fugue,'' that one has Bach coming out of one's ears.

title: Living with Toxic Chemicals
description: In some ways, according to a report issued last week, breathing the air at home may be more dangerous than breathing it in the vicinity of the plants where toxic pollutants are produced.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: The Song Remains the Same Featuring Led Zeppelin; directed by Peter Clifton and Joe Massot, 1976 Warner Home Video 137 minutes. $39.98 Fast-forward controls were invented for productions like this video cassette, which is built around Led Zeppelin's 1973 concerts at Madison Square Garden.

title: A NOVICE PLAYWRIGHT FINDS INSPIRATION IN HER HERITAGE
description: Tomorrow evening at 9, when public television's American Playhouse series presents Genny Lim's ''Paper Angels,'' the story of Chinese immigrants who landed on Angel Island will finally reach thousands of people. It is a story that lay untold and forgotten until nine years ago when Miss Lim and two other Chinese-Americans decided to try to piece together a missing part of their heritage.

title: WHAT WILL ALL THESE MUSICIANS DO?
description: Every generation has its handful of great performers. They appear in equal numbers regardless of intellectual climate, economic health or the systems of education which reared them.

title: Philadelphians Defend the Stoop
description: Is a Philadelphia row house a Philadelphia row house if it doesn't have a stoop or a screen porch on which to pass a summer's eve?

title: MILITANT MOSLEMS TAKE THE OFFENSIVE
description: Islamic fundamentalists, faced with an overwhelming display of force, lost a battle here last week, canceling a march they had planned to demand the immediate imposition of Islamic law, or sharia. More than 1,000 heavily armed riot police laid siege to the Noor Mosque in central Cairo as a holy day of prayer was transformed into a sharp test of wills between the fundamentalists and the Government of President Hosni Mubarak.

title: OVERHAUL ASIDE, CONGRESS TALKS OF TAX INCREASES
description: THERE was a new note of discord in the capital last week, struck once again by taxes. As President Reagan campaigned for tax redesign, Congressional leaders began talking about the need for a tax increase to control the Federal deficit.

title: Q&A
description: Question:Where can I get information on chartering a sailboat, with crew and chef, in the Caribbean? Do you have to book a year in advance? - D. A. D., Far Rockaway, N.Y. Answer:Vacationers should approach one or more of the many companies that represent boats available for charter. The smaller boats, often 44 feet long, generally have a skipper and a mate who acts as cook. On the bigger boats there are additional crew members. The rates charged include the crew, cook, all provisions and docking charges. It is rarely necessary to make reservations as far as a year in advance, unless one particular boat is wanted around the busy Christmas period.

title: Bringing In the Yacht
description: If God had meant his flock to stay afloat He would have given it a yacht. The Washington National Cathedral is trying to sell a gift yacht this summer, the 72-foot Anore, which was a donation from a rich believer of nautical pursuits. She sleeps six souls plus crew and should return in excess of $500,000 to the cathedral if providence is anywhere within the yacht broker's estimate.

title: LYNN CAMPBELL WEDS TODD KELLEY ANDERSON
description: Lynn Ann Campbell and Todd Kelley Anderson were married yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Osterville, Mass. The Rev. W. Raymond Webster 2d performed the ceremony.

title:
ART;

PRINT SHOW BECOMES A TRIBUTE
description: THE death of Donn Steward, the master intaglio printer who 10 years ago established the Huntington Township Art League's printmaking workshop, came only a few days before the opening of an exhibition of monotypes by workshop members.

title: The Von Bulow Melodrama Ends In Acquittal
description: The final chapter in a mystery melodrama of wealth and passion was written last week when the jury in Claus von Bulow's second trial found him not guilty of attempting to kill his wife. Mr. von Bulow had been convicted in 1982 of twice causing his wife, Martha, to fall into a coma with injections of insulin. That verdict was overturned on appeal.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: More than 40,000 Nicaraguan Roman Catholics cheered Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo today as he pledged to work ''to consolidate a stable peace in the entire Central American region.'' The new Cardinal said: ''We do not accept violence as a path to peace. Christianity is our peace.''

title: IT'S WISE TO CHECK RECORDS
description: AMONG the more esoteric provisions governing the use of a piece of property are its restrictive covenants - private contractural conditions placed upon the use of land by a prior owner. The covenants are recorded on the land records and normally bind all subsequent buyers.

title: 100-Mile Run Won by Yeter
description: Cahit Yeter, who withdrew last year because of injuries, won the 100-mile run yesterday at Shea Stadium.

title: LOOKING AHEAD AT UCONN
description: BEFORE John T. Casteen 3d takes over as president of the University of Connecticut on Aug. 1, he plans to do some research. He will start ''working on how to go about doing that job,'' he said, by talking with officials from other public universities who have attained the kind of goals he wants to reach at UConn.

title: BUSINESS CLIMATE: HOW IT IMPROVED
description: NEW JERSEY'S new rating as first in the Northeast in the quality of its manufacturing climate is considered a milestone in its changeover from smokestack to high-technology industry.

title: Protecting Ferns
description: FOR 15 years, Burlington County in New Jersey had planned a $5.5 million, 2.2-mile road to relieve traffic near the County College in Pemberton Township, but just when all problems seemed resolved, the Lygodium palmatum got in the way.

title: A BARREN PROSPECT FOR WHEAT
description: FRED DWYER stepped out of his pickup truck, looked across his wheatfields, which stretched as far as he could see, and squinted into the midday sun to watch three big red combines cut broad swaths through the golden grain.

title: THE BERKSHIRES AT THEIR SUMMER PEAK
description: It is the most seductive of images. You are sitting on a vast greensward, surrounded by the makings of an elegant picnic. A virtuoso performance of Vivaldi drifts through the warm night air as, in the distance, the hills of the Berkshires melt into a violet blur.

title: LOOKING BACK, EVERYDAY THINGS RECALL FATHER
description: I SIP coffee from a mug with POP emblazoned across it, and I think of him. I drive into the garage, see the X on the wall, and I think of him. I slip the string around the doorknob to keep the door open, and I think of him. He died four years ago, and I'm reminded of him each day. Considering my father's personality, this is surprising.

title: MERGERS SEEN AT AREA BANKS
description: BRIAN J. WOOLF, the State Banking Commissioner, expects as many applications for interstate bank mergers to be filed in the next six months as have been filed in the last two years.

title: Senate Approves Clean-Water Bill
description: Since 1981, when spending authority for the Clean Water Act expired, members of Congress have been haggling between themselves and with the White House over whether and how to renew it. Last week, the Senate performed a minor miracle, passing 94 to 0 a bill that pleased state water control authorities, business groups and environmental organizations - that is, all parties except the Reagan Administration.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A TOUCH OF THE OTHER. By Clare Morgan. (Victor Gollancz/David & Charles, $14.95.) In a puckish parody of illicit romance, Wankel, a poet with a crooked tooth and a shortish neck, pursues and is pursued by Suzie, bespectacled member of London's Green Street Writers' Circle, a birdlike woman whose ankles are too narrow for her big feet.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Charles White, the running back released by the Cleveland Browns last week, plans to meet with John Robinson, the coach of the Los Angeles Rams, tomorrow, but when he arrives for the job interview he won't need an introduction. Robinson was White's coach at Southern California when the running back won the Heisman Trophy in 1979. . . . Ernie Calverley, the former basketball player and coach at the University of Rhode Island, will retire at the end of the month as the school's associate director of athletics for men.

title: EVOKING THE QUIRKY GENIUS OF FAULKNER
description: This season, Eminent Authors have stalked our stages in a variety of theatrical guises. Literary incestuousness reached a kind of apex at the Public Theater as T. S. Eliot told tales about Virginia Woolf while, on a nearby stage, Virginia Woolf returned the favor. As played by Edward Herrmann, Eliot was a character in Michael Hastings's ''Tom and Viv,'' Woolf (Kate Nelligan) in Edna O'Brien's ''Virginia.'' As the plays converged, one waited for Mr. Herrmann to appear, uninvited, at one of Miss Nelligan's Bloomsbury soirees.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Practical Traveler column last Sunday about travel insurance, an incorrect toll-free number was given for the Travelers Insurance Companies. The correct number is 800-243-3174.

title:
ART;

PAINTERS SHOW OFF NEW TRENDS AT SILVERMINE SHOW
description: FROM a mixed-bag competition such as the 36th Art of Northeast U.S.A. Exhibition of Painting, Drawing and Sculpture, at the Silvermine Guild Center for the Arts through Friday, it is difficult to draw conclusions of much moment or substance.
