title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Korean Delicacies, Japanese Lunch The Oriental Food Mart in the Edgemont-Scarsdale section of Central Park Avenue provides takeout Korean specialties marinated or cooked on the spot, as well as imported packaged foods.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LESS THAN ZERO. By Bret Easton Ellis. (Simon & Schuster, $15.95.) There seems little joy in the world of Bret Easton Ellis, unless it's the delight he takes in christening his creations: names like Blair, Kim, Chris, Lee and Lindsay, which suggest in their androgyny the indifference of most of the characters about the sex of their bed partners; and names like Rip, Spit, Spin, Finn, Fear, Dead and X, which suggest the drugged stupor in which these people conduct their lives.

title: CABARET: MISS MCCORKLE
description: DURING the past two or three years, Susannah McCorkle seemed to have reached the level of a distinctive and polished cabaret singer that she had been striving to achieve for the better part of the decade. During those earlier years, there was almost constant evidence of improvement - in her delivery, in her interpretation, in the balance of her performances and in the range of her repertory.

title: Entrepreneurs In Wilmington
description: Whatever the fate of heavy industry and high technology, the entrepreneurial spirit lives on in the Northeast. Baltimore and New York have their traffic-light squeegee wielders, of course, and now Wilmington, Del., the cradle of the Du Pont dynasty, has spawned ''gas lads.''

title: GENDER AND LITERATURE
description: To the Editor:

title: Botswana Denounces Raid by South Africa
description: Botswana's President said today that he was seeking a United Nations Security Council debate about a raid on this capital city in which South African troops killed 16 people.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Just put yourself in the hostages' position today. Think how they are thinking.

title: BIZARRE PLOT MARKSK 'VERONICA'S ROOM'
description: IN Ira Levin's play ''Veronica's Room,'' a young woman, out on a date with a man she has just met, is stopped by an elderly Irish couple and asked to do an unusual favor for them. Are these kindly, soft-spoken people the gentle, caring folk they seem to be, or is something sinister going on?

title: N.F.L. Cutback Ill Conceived
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: DANCE: HISTORY LESSON IN A BALLROOM SURVEY
description: THE Court Dance Company of New York waltzed its way through American history on Friday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater.

title: Giving Two Visiting Russian Poets the Cold War Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: WAITING FOR THE OTHER SHOE TO DROP
description: HOUSING would be shelter, not tax shelter if President Reagan's tax program is passed, say residential real-estate professionals who have scrutinized the 461-page proposals known as Treasury II.

title: ARGENTINES FACE LIFE WITHOUT PESO
description: Argentines were forced to begin thinking today in australs, their new currency, instead of pesos, and their reaction was one of outrage, hope and bemused resignation.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: INDEPENDENCE DAY IN BOSTON, HALLEY'S COMET CRUISES
description: 90 Ways To Celebrate The 4th of July Spread across six days including the Fourth of July, more than 90 attractions -from free concerts to cruises, fireworks, a parade, chowderfest, clambake, assorted tours and nautical events - are scheduled this year for the annual waterfront celebration that is the Boston Harborfest.

title: PATRICIA WALTON WEDS
description: Patricia Walton of New York, director of education and training for Prescriptives Inc., a cosmetics company, was married yesterday to David Silver of New York and Amagansett, L.I., an owner and chief executive officer of the Regency Bedspread Corporation.

title: COULD NORA COOK? PORTRAIT OF THE WIFE OF THE ARTIST
description: JAMES JOYCE set ''Ulysses'' on June 16, 1904, because, many believe, it was the day he first went out with Nora, the girl who became his wife. The date has become sacred to Joyceans as ''Bloomsday,'' but Nora Joyce herself has been treated with less reverence. She has had a bad press. It is hard to think of any other great man's wife who has gone into history with such a reputation for total and self-satisfied incompetence. Nora, if we believe what we read, could not spell. She could not punctuate. She could not, according to many, write at all. Her inadequacy adds frisson to the mystery of Joyce. Her, with Him? And the heart of the story of the chambermaid who ran off with the artist is that Nora, nee Barnacle, was a terrible housekeeper, that she could not even cook.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE state's proposed Threatened Plant Species and Habitat Act is long overdue, according to some conservationists. More than two dozen states have adopted legislation to protect their plants.

title: A MENU WITH IMAGINATION
description: FANS of the chef Jonathan Walker may already have discovered his new restaurant, Park Place Cuisine in Avon. It is just a few miles west of Hartford and the Wadsworth Atheneum, where Jonathan's was a favorite dinner and Sunday brunch spot.

title: Hand to Hand
description: Is it better to give than to receive? Hyman O. Rickover, the retired Navy admiral, thinks so. In a letter made public last week, Admiral Rickover argued that passing gifts along removes potential improprieties in receiving them.

title: OPERA: 'WOODLANDERS,' A ST. LOUIS PREMIERE
description: Two of the four productions in this spring's Opera Theater of St. Louis season are new works - Minoru Miki's ''Joruri,'' given on Wednesday, and Stephen Paulus's ''Woodlanders,'' performed on Thursday.

title: WALKER GETS 209
description: The Generals lost a game tonight to the team with the best record in the United States Football League, the Oakland Invaders, but the defeat did no damage to the losers' playoff status.

title: Cable TV
description: Just in time for Father's Day, when the family is as likely as it may ever be to defer to his taste in viewing, HBO has scheduled a movie calculated by subject matter to appeal to Dad.

title:
ART;

A QUARTER CENTURY OF DI SUVERO WORK
description: MARK DI SUVERO is one of the most celebrated sculptors of his generation, a generation that built on and extended the concepts of abstract expressionism. As such, he is the perfect choice to be given a 25-year retrospective in commemoration of the 25th season of the Storm King Art Center. Storm King, as is becoming increasingly known, is a motherlode of outdoor sculpture, much of it gigantic, comprising 200 well-manicured and landscaped acres in Mountainville, N.Y. The show will run through October.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times Magazine on June 2, about John Brademas, the president of New York University, misidentified the chancellor of the State University of New York. He is Clifton R. Wharton Jr.

title: CHINAGLIA'S TEAMS STRUGGLING
description: With his team in Rome relegated to the Second Division in the Italian League and his Cosmos without a league, Giorgio Chinaglia appears more like a defeated Roman gladiator now.

title: Inhospitalities Cold Comfort
description: They call themselves the Association of Innkeepers, conjuring up an image of bucolic hospitality. Actually they are a newly organized group of 40 hotels charging New York City exorbitant rents to house homeless families.

title: AIRLINES AND RESIDENTS CAUSING TURBULENCE FOR MACARTHUR AIRPORT
description: ALTHOUGH no longer in its infancy, Long Island MacArthur Airport is still suffering growing pains.

title: NEWLY ACTIVE UNIONS A CHALLENGE FOR EL SALVADOR
description: Pursuing the difficult road to democratization in the midst of war against guerrillas, El Salvador faces dilemmas that test its fragile political structures. The latest is posed by the reawakening of trade unions that, in this country, have existed as much for political as economic ends.

title: BUCHANAN LABELS CUOMO A 'REACTIONARY' LIBERAL
description: Patrick J. Buchanan, the White House director of communications, accused Governor Cuomo today of ''unbuttoned bellicosity,'' calling him a ''glib, fast-talking lobbyist for a reactionary liberalism that would kill tax reform in its crib.''

title: FRESH AIR FUND OFFERS OFF-SEASON ADVENTURES
description: When autumn's cool evenings begin to overtake summer's balmy days here, leaves ignite into a fiery melange of orange and red. In winter, skiers use narrow deer paths set above mountain streams that swell in spring, completing the seasonal cycle.

title: AN EXODUS FROM THE TIMBERLANDS
description: IN the 1970's, the Northwest's timber business was on a roll. But by 1983, profits at the seven largest forest product companies had fallen 55 percent from the 1979 level, the industry's last good year. Now, with costs continuing to soar and prices plummeting, no one is ''making enough profit to justify their investment in the land,'' said Harold Mayhew, a securities analyst in Portland, Ore..

title: JOYS AND PERILS OF A GOLF OUTING
description: GOLF, legend has it, is a gentle game, a leisurely pastime played in a sylvan setting with amiable companions.

title: IN THE FOOTSTEPS OF THE CRUSADERS
description: The Latin Kingdom of Jerusalem, the name by which the Crusaders' rule over the Holy Land is commonly known, lasted from 1099, when the Crusaders ''rescued Jerusalem from the yoke of the infidel,'' as one contemporary account put it, to 1291, when the city of Acre was retaken by the Moslems. At its zenith the kingdom stretched from Beirut to Elath, from the Mediterranean to the Jordan and beyond.

title: DO GOUNOD DISKS PRESAGE A REVIVAL?
description: As most people nowadays remember charles Gounod (1818-93) for his operas ''Faust,'' ''Romeo et Juliette,'' and perhaps ''Mireille,'' it may be surprising to learn that many of his French and English contemporaries, Camille Saint-Saens chief among them, believed Gounod's ultimate fame would rest upon his religious works. Indeed, Gounod the young romantic nearly entered the priesthood, while the faintly theatrical piety of his maturity led him to furnish the study of his Paris house with a pipe organ embellished with a medallion of Christ's head, and a mantlepiece carved with scenes from the Passion. Through music he expressed his fervor by writing 23masses, a Requiem and over 100 shorter sacred pieces. Moreover, the close ties he enjoyed with Victorian English audiences, who placed him next to the beatified Mendelssohn in their esteem, yielded two large-scale oratorios, ''The Redemption'' and ''Mors et Vita,'' composed for the Birmingham Festivals of 1882 and 1885. Unhappily, with the exception of the well-known St. Cecilia Mass and the even more famous ''Ave Maria'' (infamous to the snobs), this rich legacy has been neglected for almost a century. It is to be hoped, therefore, that several new recordings of sacred Gounodiana will prove to be the start of a trend.

title: WAGNER'S LIFE IS IN HIS ART
description: While sitting through a rather concentrated week of Wagner recently, I was continually struck by how far the wheel of interpretation has turned in a few years. When Wieland Wagner began the postwar revival of his grandfather's operas, his aim seemed to be to cleanse the works of all literal meanings by staging them as abstract, mythic dramas. He put Wagner's works before us as pure art objects, as if they had been set down by some disembodied genius, as remote from us as Homer. Especially in the ''Ring,'' the individuality and personality of characters was minimized in favor of overriding symbolism. Because decor was stark and generally dimly lighted, an eerie feeling of detachment was generated. We could watch a Wieland ''Ring'' much as we might view an abstract impressionist painting, imposing on it whatever meanings we happened to prefer at the moment.

title: SHUBERT THEATER PLANNING A 'FAIL-SAFE' SEASON
description: A RECORDING of Ethel Merman singing ''Everything's Coming Up Roses'' boomed through the Shubert Theater in New Haven recently when officials announced the upcoming season's attractions. But the theater's acting general manager, Judith Lisi, was not quite so optimistic.

title: BIRD SMUGGLING IS ON THE RISE
description: DURING the past decade, efforts to smuggle protected species of wild birds, or their eggs, into this country have intensified, according to Jerome Smith, deputy chief of the division of law enforcement of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.

title: MISS MCCREA, ACTRESS, WEDS JEFFREY M. KROLIK
description: The marriage of Christine Eleanor McCrea, a daughter of Mrs. Robert C. Atkinson of Hatboro, Pa., and Francis B. McCrea of Doylestown, Pa., to Jeffrey M. Krolik took place yesterday in Glenside, Pa. The Rev. Samuel Appel, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Grey Towers on the Beaver College campus. Mr. Krolik is the son of Mary Stuart of New York and Richard Krolik of Washington.

title: Wright at the Mike
description: Representative Jim Wright of Texas prefers the Big Band sound and dreamy fox-trotting, but he is not above a round of hosannas in the cause of advancing choral art in the great state of Texas. The Schola Cantorum, a classical choral group from Fort Worth, will make its Kennedy Center debut next week with Mr. Wright, the House majority leader, at center stage.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

HISTORIC LESHER HOUSE RECALLS A BYGONE ERA
description: A small, ramshackle house in Victor, Colo., will soon be transformed into an important numismatic museum. The house was once the residence of Joseph Lesher, a numismatic entrepreneur of the early 20th century and it now is being restored as a repository for the fascinating tokens he produced.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: GAFFER SAMSON'S LUCK By Jill Paton Walsh. Illustrated by Brock Cole. 119 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95. (Ages 9 to 11).

title: STREAMLINING THE FEDERAL COURTS
description: Sadly, but certainly, our Federal court system runs the terrible risk of being perceived as an incomprehensible morass - much as we perceive our Federal tax laws. And just as President Reagan has struck a sympathetic chord with his plan to revise the tax code, so too must we make a bold and sweeping effort to restructure our Federal courts and recalibrate Federal jurisdiction.

title: Recent Sales
description: Budd Lake $111,000 9 Brookside Drive *2* 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 12-year-old Tudor; new kitchen, *2* wall-to-wall carpeting, 1-car garage; taxes $2,533. Garfield $94,600 560 Midland Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 60-year-old colonial; *2* new kitchen, family room, 2-car garage; taxes $1,259. Leonardo $83,000 8 Flomar Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, older Cape Cod; *2* deck, patio, pool; taxes $1,327. Pine Brook $326,250 68 Windsor Drive *2* 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 2-year-old colonial; master-bedroom *2* suite with 2 skylights and double Jacuzzi; taxes $3,528. West Orange $103,500 1 Cecil Lane Place *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year old split-level; *2* central air-conditioning, vinyl siding; taxes $2,646. Wyckoff $292,500 305 Windham Court *2* 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old ranch; family room *2* with fireplace and bar, deck; taxes $3,842. OTHER AREAS Levittown, L.I. $111,000 23 Trapper Lane *2* 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old ranch; *2* eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,000. Yorktown Heights, N.Y. $141,000 3008 Hickory Street *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 14-year-old raised ranch; *2* family room, eat-in kitchen, deck; taxes $3,497. Bethany, Conn. $80,000 445 Amity Road *2* 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 37-year-old frame house; *2* hardwood floors, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,128.

title: LIBRARY TO EXPAND ITS STACKS
description: The New York Public Library will undertake its first expansion of the book stacks of the Main Library, at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street, under a 1986 capital projects budget nearly double that of the current year.

title: AMERICA'S RETREAT FROM PROTECTIONISM
description: TOMORROW marks the day in 1930 that Congress passed the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act, the highest import levy in American history. This single act provoked a wave of retaliation, forced Europe to suspend debt repayments and caused world commerce to dry up. Is the United States once again poised for such wide-spread protectionism?

title:
INVESTING;

THE 'NEW' G.M. MAY STILL BE ROADBOUND
description: DESPITE the hoopla and excitement generated by the General Motors Corporation's proposed acquisition of Hughes Aircraft, G.M., in the eyes of many analysts, remains an auto company. And that is precisely why they are not optimistic about the near-term prospects for the giant auto maker's stock. Auto issues will ''probably underperform the market,'' for the remainder of the year, said Joseph S. Phillippi, an analyst with E.F. Hutton & Company in New York. In fact, Ford and Chrysler may offer more value. G.M. is selling at about $74 a share, with a price/ earnings ratio of about 6. Ford, at $45 or so, sells at 2.9 times earnings and Chrysler, at about $36, has been trading at about 2.5 times earnings.

title: Broadcast TV
description: If they so chose, feminists could point with pride to a succession of home-screen Hollywood performances on Saturday. There are five in a row, marking career breakthroughs or highlights for Deborah Kerr, Olivia de Havilland, Rita Hayworth, Jane Fonda and Carole Lombard.

title: 5 for Retardation Panel
description: President Reagan appointed three people to the President's Commission on Mental Retardation on Friday and reappointed two people already serving on the panel. The five are Dorothy Corbin Clark, a Utah nurse, who was reappointed; Martha Lois Eargle, a South Carolina real estate executive; Madeline B. Harwood, a Vermont lobbyist and nurse, reappointed; Dr. William Kerby Hummer of Los Angeles, and U. Yn Ryo, a professor of medicine at the University of Chicago.

title: HIJACKERS RELEASE OVER 60 FROM JET IN ALGIERS AIRPORT
description: The hijackers who forced a Trans World Airlines jet to make a terror-filled journey back and forth across the Mediterranean released more than 60 passengers and crew members in Algiers yesterday and 3 more today, but they set an ominous new deadline for those still held hostage.

title: PUSHING AMERICA OUT OF CHIPS
description: JUST a summer ago, the makers of computer chips rode atop the high-tech world. To supply parts for a seemingly insatiable computer industry, giants like Texas Instruments and Mostek raced to retool their plants for a new generation of memory chips. And three Silicon Valley stalwarts, National Semiconductor, Advanced Micro Devices, and Intel, spent hundreds of millions of dollars adding plant capacity - sure of a quick payback.

title: LESTER CROWN BLAMES THE SYSTEM
description: A BLACK limousine pulled up at the curb of the General Dynamics Corporation's suburban Washington office one day last week. A tall, trim man who had recently turned 60 emerged and took the elevator to Suite 1000, a warren of offices devoted to advancing the government interests of one of the world's most powerful arms manufacturers.

title: ON THE ALTAR OF 'OVERLORD'
description: FALL FROM GRACE By Larry Collins. 475 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: DODGERS SHUT OUT ON 3 HITS
description: Pedro Guerrero hit his third home run in five times at bat and Orel Hershiser pitched his seventh career shutout today with a three-hitter in the Los Angeles Dodgers' 3-0 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: DANCE: NIKOLAIS PIECE OPENS FESTIVAL
description: Alwin Nikolais, the winner of the 1985 Samuel H. Scripps American Dance Festival Award, got this year's festival off to a fine start with a provocative program of new and recent works on Thursday at Duke University's Page Auditorium. The program opened with a salute to Terry Sanford, former Governor of North Carolina and retiring president of the university, and his wife, Margaret Rose. The six-week, Durham-based festival has been dedicated this summer to Mr. Sanford, one of its chief supporters, in tribute to his ''innovative intelligence, sense of adventure, and loving and committed spirit.''

title: RITA BOLGER WED TO RONALD CIMA
description: The Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Haworth, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Rita Mary Bolger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Bolger of Oradell, N.J., to Ronald Prence Cima, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Cima of Silver Spring, Md. The Rev. Joseph W. Nealon performed the ceremony.

title: CENTER FOR AIDS CHILDREN SET
description: A center for the care of infants and children with AIDS is to be established in the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center using $400,000 approved last week in the city budget that begins July 1.

title: UPPER EAST SIDE INSTITUTIONS FEAR DOWNZONING
description: THE Ramaz School, a Jewish parochial school on the Upper East Side, put up an eight-story building at 60 East 78th Street in 1980 that was designed to accommodate two more stories whenever the school had the need and the money to build them. But now a proposal to downzone the area is threatening the school's right to add the extra floors as well as the school's initial investment of more than $50,000 to make the structure expandable.

title: A BENCHMARK CASE ON COMPARABLE PAY
description: NEARLY 10 years ago, the state of Washington asked Norman D. Willis & Associates, a Seattle consulting firm, to study whether the state was guilty of sex-based discrimination in setting salaries for state employees. The firm found that indeed, it was.

title: MURDER FOR THE MILLIONS
description: NUTCRACKER Money, Madness, Murder: A Family Album. By Shana Alexander. 444 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $17.95. AT MOTHER'S REQUEST A True Story of Money, Murder and Betrayal. By Jonathan Coleman. Illustrated. 624 pp. New York: Atheneum. $19.95.

title: GREEKS BEARING GUNS
description: TEN DAYS TO DESTINY The Battle for Crete, 1941. By G. C. Kiriakopoulos. 408 pp. New York: Franklin Watts. $18.95.

title: A DISSENTING VOICE ON TRANSFERRING AIR RIGHTS
description: ON the City Planning Commission, as on any other reviewing body, independent thinking leads to dissenting opinion.

title: OUTLOOK BRIGHTENS AT CANDLEWOOD STAGE
description: MARLENE DIETRICH adorned its stage. Jerry Lewis did his act there, too.

title: COMPOSER READIES PREMIERE IN MOSCOW
description: JOE RAPOSO has won four Grammy Awards, an Oscar nomination and has seen an original commissioned work of his performed by the Boston Symphony Orchestra. He has arranged concerts for Fred Astaire, written songs for Frank Sinatra and has collaborated with Richard Rodgers. The work the composer said he was most proud of, however, is a song he recently wrote to commemorate his 5-year-old son's graduation from nursery school.

title: LETTING THE PC PLAN THE PROJECT
description: THE personal computer software industry is often compared with book publishing, but a closer analogy might be magazine production. Most programs are, after all, an ongoing series of releases. These updates are always making their way to the marketplace, either to correct errors in previous versions of a program or to add various features for which users have discovered a need.

title: LITERARY STANDOFF
description: THE POST-MODERN AURA The Act of Fiction in an Age of Inflation. By Charles Newman. With a preface by Gerald Graff. 203 pp. Evanston, Ill.: Northwestern University Press. Cloth, $18.95. Paper, $7.95. IN this long, intense essay on postmodernist fiction, the critic and novelist Charles Newman argues that the contemporary novel in America is obsessed with a ''phony dualism between Formalism and Realism.'' By ''Formalism'' he means the postmodernist urge to make the subject matter of fiction the nature of fiction itself. Writing becomes a continuous exploration of the conditions of writing; tale telling disappears; the novel pursues the idiosyncratic, trying to undercut the complacency of a reading audience saturated, as Mr. Newman puts it, by electronic information. Formalists produce a literature of situation and not of character, a catalogue of discrete experiences that add up to a condition rather than a set of relations or a developing state of mind. The realists, by contrast, develop the humanistic legacy of modernism and are the positivists of fiction - didactic, caught in the bourgeois moralism that the formalists, to Mr. Newman's mind, so inadequately attack.

title: PUTTING OLD VIEWS OF INDIANS TO REST
description: SHATTERING the myths and stereotypes surrounding American Indians is a full-time goal of Karen Coody Cooper, the creator of several educational programs that attempt to put those misconceptions to rest.

title: IN THE SWIM OF THINGS
description: SWIMMING SEEMS TO suit nearly everyone. After walking, it is America's most popular form of exercise. Babies can be introduced to water at an early age, and it is a sport that can be continued late into life. A superb conditioner, it uses all of the body's major muscles. Only cross-country skiing surpasses swimming in terms of aerobic benefits. In addition to cardiovascular improvement, swimming builds endurance and improves flexibility, especially of the shoulders and ankles. Swimming is also one of the safest sports. Unlike other aerobic activities, it does not put stress on the weight-bearing joints or the spine. Those who cannot perform other sports because of orthopedic or arthritic problems find swimming a comfortable exercise that often relieves stiffness and pain. People with back problems, however, are advised to avoid the butterfly stroke; the breast stroke can also aggravate backache.

title: Closing the Egg Gap
description: There are not likely to be any limitation talks in the race between the Soviet Union and Malcolm Forbes, the magazine publisher. Mr. Forbes went one up on the Russians last week with his bid for an Easter egg, encrusted with gold filigree and pearls, created by Faberge for Czar Nicholas II. The publisher paid $1.76 million for the eight-inch-tall egg and now owns 11 of the 54 eggs that Faberge made for the imperial family.

title: National Symphony Names New Director
description: The National Symphony has named Stephen Klein as executive director, succeeding Henry Fogel, who has taken a similar position at the Chicago Symphony.

title: 38 FILMS FOCUS ATTENTION ON ELIZABETH TAYLOR THE ACTRESS
description: For most of her life, Elizabeth Taylor, the screen actress, has been upstaged by Elizabeth Taylor Hilton Wilding Todd Fisher Burton Warner, the ultimate celebrity. Millions of people who have never seen ''Father of the Bride,'' ''Giant'' or ''Butterfield 8'' are inveterate fans of that private career Miss Taylor has acted out in public - her fabled acquisitions both mineral and animal, her illnesses and resuscitations, the fluctuations which time and a hearty appetite have imposed on that legendary form. Despite four decades of hard work on sound stages throughout the world, Miss Taylor's image has been most decisively shaped by her status as the paparazzi's often unwilling pet.

title: I'M LOST IN THE CORWDS OF THE WIDE OPEN SPACES
description: I CAN'T get off Long Island. I am mired in lines - car lines, food lines, bank lines, post office lines. I thought that when we moved out here there would be more room than in New York. Everyone else must have believed that, too. And they all moved into my neighborhood.

title: FOR MEADOWLANDS, 2,800 HOUSING UNITS
description: MILL CREEK in the Secaucus Meadowlands is a shallow ribbon of fresh water that twists and turns back on itself so severely on its way to the Hackensack River that, in places, it nearly winds into a complete loop.

title: TODD TORRANCE WED TO A. T. TURRENTINE
description: Lucie Todd Torrance, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Torrance Jr. of Woodbury, Conn., was married there yesterday to Alexander Thomas Turrentine, a son of the late James L. Turrentine and the late Elizabeth McN. Turrentine of Stamford, Conn.

title: ANNE CHRISTINE DONOVAN IS THE BRIDE OF JAMES LESLIE BODNAR, AN ARCHITECT
description: At St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford, N.Y., yesterday Anne Christine Donovan, who received an M.B.A. degree June 6 from Harvard University, was married to James Leslie Bodnar, an associate partner with Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, architects in New York. The Rev. Francis C. O'Hare, cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: 'A ROLE MODEL FOR ALL OF US'
description: ''IT HAS made a real difference to the students,'' said Merle Rose, the creative-writing teacher at Princeton High School. ''Marcia Conn has become a role model for all of us.''

title: WHY JAPAN IS COMING TO 'SILICON FOREST'
description: A slew of Japanese electronics companies are building in the Vancouver, Wash.-Portland, Ore., area. And although regional officials like to say that the area's lifestyle attracted the Japanese, the reasons for the moves seem rooted in more profit-oriented concerns.

title: CHICKEN IN CLAY
description: TWO OF THE MOST COLORFUL AND theatrical dishes I know are of Chinese and/ or Italian origin. Their preparation is based on the same technique, with a chicken wrapped (sculptured, if you prefer) in raw clay and baked until done. I first dined on this ''beggar's chicken'' in Hong Kong several decades ago, and the waiter explained the dish's origin. It seemed that a penniless rogue once made off with a fine fat fowl from a rich man's coop. He took his loot in a bag to the river's edge and prepared a roaring fire for roasting. Just as the ashes became ready, he glanced up a hill and noticed the long arm of the law approaching. He hastily scooped up mud from the river bank and enclosed the chicken, feathers and all, to disguise it. He plopped the chicken in the ashes. After an hour or so, the police departed and the thief removed the package from the fire. When he cracked the clay and removed it, the feathers came off as well. The remaining prize, so the legend has it, was delectable.

title: GAIL P. CUSHMAN, A MUSEUM DIRECTOR, WEDS L. G. ROSE
description: Gail Powell Cushman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Haskell Cushman of Marblehead, Mass., was married yesterday to Lawrence G. Rose, a son of Sidney Rose, also of Marblehead, and Mrs. Harry Corman of Weston, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Randall Niehoff, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Cushman home.

title:
GARDENING;

FRESH VEGETABLES ALL SEASON LONG
description: IN addition to the pleasures that one may derive from growing one's own vegetables, there are advantages in being able to harvest the freshest possible produce just outside the kitchen door.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: AUTO RACING Nascar Michigan 400, at Brooklyn, Mich. The Grand National Champion, Bill Elliott, is the defending champion in this race, the mid-point of the 30-race circuit. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Formula I Canadian Grand Prix, at Montreal (Television - ESPN, 12:50 P.M.) Cart Portland Oregon 200 (Television - ESPN, 5 P.M.) #24 Hours of LeMans, France, second and final 12 hours. Baseball Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers, at Yankee Stadium, 2:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Expos, at Montreal (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) Braves vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Atlanta (Television - WTBS, 2:05 P.M.) Boxing Edwin Rosario vs. Frankie Randall, 10-round lightweight bout in London. Rosario is the former World Boxing Council champion from San Juan, P.R., who has knocked out two 1985 opponents to raise his record to 22-1 with 19 knockouts. Randall, undefeated in 23 professional fights, has 19 knockouts. (Television - Channel 4, 4:30 P.M.) Golf U.S. Open at Birmingham, Mich., Final round coverage. (Television - Channel 7, 2 P.M. to 6:30 P.M.) L.P.G.A. Rochester International, at Pittsford, N.Y. Final round. Soccer Cosmos vs. Lazio of Rome, at Giants Stadium, 7 P.M. Giorgio Chinaglia, the president and owner of both clubs, has to have mixed emotions about this game. Argentina vs. Colombia, at Buenos Aires. Argentina currently leads the World Cup group with 3 victories and 6 points, with Colombia and Peru tied for second.

title: MAYORAL CANDIDATE UESTIONS
description: THE PRESENT mayoral election is shaping up to be a rather dull contest. Here's an idea that might liven things up: talk about sports.

title: Richard Dangerfield
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missourri, has been whining like Rodney Dangerfield lately in making a virtue of second billing in the Bradley-Gephardt proposal for changing the tax code.

title: STARVING THE STATES TO FEED BUSINESS
description: A funny thing happened on the way from the Treasury Department's original tax plan to President Reagan's. Big, capital-intensive companies, such as General Electric, Boeing and Dow Chemical, which are paying no taxes, got back hundreds of billions of dollars in tax savings through restoration of accelerated depreciation schedules. By returning to the original Treasury plan, Congress could find more than enough tax revenues to retain the deduction for state and local taxes, make the tax reform truly ''revenue neutral'' and preserve the general principles of tax reform.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Another Lift for Incomes Personal income continues to climb, says Robert J. Genetski, senior vice president and chief economist of Chicago's Harris Trust and Savings Bank. But whether the new money means a stronger economy remains a matter of doubt. The added income could flow into savings, rather than into consumer spending, he said.

title: COLONIAL FIGURES ON NEW ISSUES
description: Although the pace is expected to slow soon, new issues continue to pour forth from the United States Bureau of Engraving and Printing. Latest editions include a commemorative, postal card and postage due stamp.

title: 'A GREAT SPECTATOR' HELPS SELL SPORTS
description: WHEN it comes to sports, said Dolores C. Kelly of Rockville Centre, ''I don't possess the skills to be a great participant, but I'm a great spectator.''

title: Herzog Offers Plan for Both Sides
description: IF anyone had listened to Earl Weaver in the spring of 1981, baseball might not have had a 50-day strike later that year. Weaver, then - as now - managing the Baltimore Orioles, came up with a solution to the dispute between the players and owners over professional compensation for lost free agents, and it was a plan that had so much merit the players might have accepted it.

title: Bid to Protect American Shoes
description: American shoe makers have long complained of unfair competition from foreign manufacturers, especially Taiwan and South Korea. A year ago the Government's International Trade Commission rejected the industry's pleas for special protection.

title: Marathon to Norman
description: Don Norman of Pittsburgh finished first today in the ninth annual Grandma's Marathon along Minnesota's North Shore. Norman, who finished third in last year's race, broke the tape in Duluth with an unofficial time of 2 hours 11 minutes 9 seconds.

title: WHY TELEVISION'S BUSINESS PROGRAMS HAVEN'T TURNED A PROFIT
description: ANYONE waiting for a lunchtime partner at New York's ''21''

title: PLAN TO SAVE SHORE BIRDS STIRS INTEREST
description: NEW JERSEY has become the focus of a program that not only would protect migratory shore birds that rely on Delaware Bay as a spring stopover, but also would serve as the basis for an international effort to save these birds from mounting dangers along their travel routes.

title: WORLD'S FAIRS
description: To the Editor:

title: YANKEES LOSE, 10-8, AND FALL BELOW .500
description: George Steinbrenner sat there stoically, his eyes riveted on a game that kept getting worse. By late in the day, the Yankee owner had seen his team rally three times, fall agonizingly short three times and finally lose its fourth consecutive game, 10-8, to the Detroit Tigers.

title: ITEMS COLLECTED BY SLOANE ON SALE IN LITCHFIELD
description: ERIC SLOANE, a Connecticut artist who wrote admiringly about the way Americans lived 100 or more years ago, the tools they made and used, and the folk craft they created, was himself an almost compulsive collector of Yankee artifacts.

title: ABOARD THE KOWLOON LOCAL
description: Commuter trains are normally the most prosaic of railroads, but in Hong Kong even the commonplace suburban local hums with an exotic Anglo-Chinese tone, typical of the unique blend of influences in the British colony.

title: HOSPITAL STRIVES TO REDUCE NOISE
description: HOSPITALS exist to facilitate the care of the sick and injured. And among the most frequent instructions given by doctors is that patients receive bed rest and quiet.

title: JEANINE M. WHALEN WED
description: Jeanine M. Whalen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George V. Whalen of Nanuet, N.Y., was married there yesterday to James R. Blumenfeld, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Blumenfeld of New City, N.Y. The Rev. Edmund Netter performed the ceremony at St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: A Swiss corporation will be allowed to build a warehouse and office near private homes in Briarcliff Manor, but instead of storing 2,700 gallons of potentially toxic chemicals, as planned, it may only keep 15 gallons on the premises under a unanimous decision by the Briarcliff Manor Village Board.

title: The Importance Of Being Ordinary
description: THE RICH AND FA-mous may be rich and famous, but at least they are ordinary, which is good because think how hard it would be to put up with them if they were extraordinary.

title: Kiting Checks
description: To the Editor:

title: Ice-Cream Parlor Supervisor Dies in Columbus Ave. Fight
description: An employee of an Italian ice-cream parlor on Columbus Avenue fatally stabbed the kitchen supervisor during a dispute in front of the shop yesterday morning, according to the police.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BOSOM OF THE FAMILY. By Evelyn Harter. (St. Martin's, $14.95.) Evelyn Harter's first novel focuses on Mohan, an Indian from a Brahmin family, who is studying in the United States.

title: INJURED LEWIS FAILS TO GAIN 100 FINAL
description: Carl Lewis is track and field's most celebrated athlete, the winner of four Olympic gold medals last summer and the national 100-meter title in 1981, 1982 and 1983. Tonight, in the USA/Mobil outdoor championships, he became an also ran.

title: WORDGAME CHAMPS
description: I BEGAN TO SCRATCH my head one day last winter when a football coach started to praise his players.

title: THE SKILLFUL USE OF OUTDOOR LIGHT
description: LIGHT, often, is as important as the subject of a picture. In an Ansel Adams photograph a special light -the photography critic Nancy New-hall called it ''the eloquent light'' -has been discovered and recorded on film. No photographer has been able to achieve success without a talent for using light.

title: NEW WEAPON AGAINST THE GYPSY MOTH
description: TOO frequently, we forget to be grateful for the miseries that did not materialize. Nuclear holocaust has not happened, yet.

title: CITY REVITALIZING SHEEPSHEAD BAY
description: NEW YORK CITY is moving ahead with a $33 million project to redevelop the Sheepshead Bay waterfront in Brooklyn with boutiques and restaurants while maintaining the salty atmosphere of an active fishing village. This month, it named the Lazar Group as developer and said the project would be completed in time for the summer season of 1987.

title: South Africa Crosses the Line
description: South African commandos struck at African National Congress representatives in the neighboring country of Botswana last week, killing at least 16 people. The United States protested by recalling Ambassador Herman Nickel from Pretoria, and State Department officials said relations were at the lowest point since President Reagan launched his policy of ''constructive engagement'' with South Africa five years ago.

title: WHY THE MARKET IN AMERICAN SECRETS SEEMS TO BE BOOMING
description: In a gesture that may have been the rough equivalent of putting bars on the window after the safe has been emptied, Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. said last week that he hoped to reduce by half the number of Navy personnel given access to Government secrets and to use lie-detectors to ferret out spies.

title: JOHN INGALLS WED TO MISS WILLIAMS
description: The marriage of Kathleen McConnell Williams to John Sumner Ingalls, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Lewis Ingalls of Binghamton, N.Y., and Tucson, Ariz., took place yesterday in Tulsa, Okla. The Rev. Ralph U. Taylor, the chaplain of the Holland Hall School in Tulsa, of which the bride is an alumna, performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Pettigrew Williams.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: INNOCENCE ABROAD NO MORE
description: After a morning of viewing Impressionist paintings at the Grand Palais in Paris and a fine lunch at which we enjoyed both the food and the 10-cent franc, my wife and I boarded the Metro for the subway ride to our next stop. We didn't get there. Instead, we wound up at the familiar American Express office behind the Opera, joining a long list of people in our predicament. My pocket had been picked on the subway.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: PRESIDENTIAL ECONOMICS: The Making of Economic Policy From Roosevelt to Reagan and Beyond, by Herbert Stein. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) The author was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers during the Nixon Administration. He writes on the actual role of the professional economist in making national economic policy and what that role should be. Last year Leonard Silk said here that Mr. Stein's is a ''temperate and thoughtful book'' whose author is ''humble and balanced about what economists do and do not know'' and whose ''diagnosis of Reaganomics, without being polemical, is devastating.'' THE BURNT ONES, by Patrick White. (Penguin, $6.95.) Patrick White's 1964 collection of 11 short stories preceded by nearly 10 years his Nobel Prize in Literature.

title: THOMAS KNOCKS OUT WEAVER
description: Pinklon Thomas, displaying a right-handed complement to his fine left jab, scored a one-punch knockout of Mike Weaver at 1 minute 42 seconds of the eighth round tonight to retain the World Boxing Council title and establish himself as the finest heavyweight champion this side of Larry Holmes.

title: CITY'S YOUNGSTERS LEARN TO SOW AND HOE
description: The members of Myrna Traverso's kindergarten class stood bent over a furrow in the dry earth, each pair of hands clutching a seed peanut. There was scraping, patting and a bit of pushing, and spring planting at Public School 83 in East Harlem was under way.

title: SPURRING DANCE TROUPES TO TAKE RISKS
description: ''There are two kinds of anxiety for me,'' the choreographer David Gordon amiably confessed last fall: ''The kind that says you're in the wrong place, get out of here, and the kind that says you're uncomfortable and this is great.''

title: JAZZ: JAPANESE ARTISTS
description: AN ensemble of 10 Japanese jazz musicians and 10 Americans celebrated the sister-city relationship of New York and Tokyo at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening in a concert that demonstrated to an American audience the high level of Japanese jazz musicianship.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: PIECES AND PRINTS Westchester residents who have not strolled through the sculpture gardens at the Pepsico Headquarters in Purchase should make a point to do so. There are few places where works of vastly disparate styles by such major artists as Alexander Calder, Henry Moore, George Segal, Auguste Rodin, Joan Miro, Louise Nevelson, Max Ernst, Isamu Noguchi, David Wynne, Claes Oldenburg and numerous others are displayed so harmoniously - in a garden specifically designed for them.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: The Intel Corporation has chosen Rutgers, the State University, to receive its new general-purpose super microcomputer and other systems and services and a grant worth more than $4.3 million.

title: ON NOT GETTING THERE FROM HERE
description: Before my first trip to Europe, my grandfather, who was then a very confident 82 and is now a very opinionated 1OO, poured me a glass of wine and gave me the following instructions: Over there, don't believe anything until three people have told you the same thing. I not only found this advice invaluable for getting around Europe that summer, it has proven useful for traveling in other parts of the world as well. Nowhere, however, has my grandfather's advice been more useful than in his native Italy, where a remarkable enthusiasm to assist foreigners is sometimes overshadowed by a lack of reliable information.

title: A REGIONAL REPORT: THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST
description: Pink salmon and green trees were once the gold of the Pacific Northwest. But now fishing and lumber have lost their luster. And while the fishing slump is troublesome, the problems with lumber, which has traditionally brought in nine times the revenues of fishing, are devastating.

title: Arkansas to Extradite Drug Case Defendant
description: The Governor of Arkansas, ending a dispute with the District Attorney of Queens, said yesterday that he had agreed to extradite a former preparatory-school student who was indicted in New York in 1984 on drug-trafficking charges.

title: MISS RIDGWAY IS A BRIDE
description: The marriage of Sheridan Elizabeth Ridgway, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lynn S. Ridgway of Armonk, N.Y,, to Gustaf Henry Peterson Jr. took place yesterday at the First Church of Round Hill (interdenominational) in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. John Olofson Jr. performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is the son of Jane Mulligan Peterson and Mr. Peterson, both of Armonk.

title: The Glory Of Carnegie Hall
description: To the singers of the New York Choral Society, Samuel Freedman's words rang as clear and true as if they had been sounded in that acoustically perfect hall. It's not just the acoustics, nor even the history, that makes the hall unique. Mr. Freedman strikes a resonant note when he cites the audience as special; what he terms ''egalitarian,'' we think of as ''unstuffy.''

title: An Owner's Plea
description: To the Editor:

title: Pittsburgh Plan Seeks To Create 41,000 Jobs
description: A $1.9 billion economic recovery plan was unveiled here Friday by city and county officials and the presidents of the University of Pittsburgh and Carnegie-Mellon University.

title: STATES OPPOSE BURNING OF TOXIC WASTE IN GULF
description: Federal plans for commercial incineration of hazardous waste on ships in the Gulf of Mexico are stirring opposition along the Gulf Coast. Only Florida backs the proposal.

title: PRINCETON STUDENTS ASK CHANGES IN FEDERAL AID TO COLLEGIANS
description: A group of students majoring in public affairs at Princeton University had a rare chance this spring to recommend changes in a Federal policy that affects them - student aid.

title: CORRECTION
description: An introduction and a headline last Sunday with excerpts from three reports on the 1983 release of prisoners from the Rikers Island jail misidentified the writer of the report that proposed formation of a single New York State criminal-justice department. He was David G. Trager, chairman of the State Commission of Investigation; Charles J. Hynes was among those who drafted it.

title: REAGAN DEFENDS JUSTICE DEPT. NOMINEE AS OPPOSITION RISES
description: President Reagan today defended William Bradford Reynolds, his nominee for Associate Attorney General, as ''a tireless fighter against discrimination.'' Senate aides say, however, that they no longer regard his confirmation as a certainty.

title: GOODBYE, DAD, AND THANKS
description: MY FATHER died unexpectedly 11 years ago, not giving me a chance to say goodbye or thank you. And so there are still moments when I half expect him to answer the phone, recommend a book or be snoozing in his faded brown chair after a Thanksgiving dinner.

title: SEARCH FOR MAN GOES ON IN ATTACK ON OFFICER
description: Detectives continued searching yesterday for a man identified by witnesses as an accomplice in an attack on a plainclothes officer Wednesday that resulted in the fatal shooting of a 17-year-old Harlem youth.

title: COSTS OF INTERNATIONAL DEBT HIT HOME FOR THE ARGENTINES
description: Gerardo Silva, a 39-year-old blue collar worker, stared blankly at his visitor. ''The fund?'' he asked. ''I don't know anything about the fund, but we can't make any more sacrifices.'' His wife, sewing a pair of pants already almost beyond repair, looked up from her work. ''We can barely eat now.''

title: ENGLISH INTO ENGLISH
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: Normandie: Her Life and Times By Harvey Ardman. 435 pages. Franklin Watts. $22.95.

title: WATERY ROGUERY
description: AN INNOCENT MILLIONAIRE By Stephen Vizinczey. 369 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $17.95. THE second novel by the author of ''In Praise of Older Women'' is a rare accomplishment, a contemporary adventure told with style, wit and wisdom.

title: NEW STATE PLAN TO HELP HOMELESS
description: STATE housing officials have found a new source of aid for communities trying to help the growing number of homeless people.

title: COUNTDOWN ON FOR SHUTTLE'S SPACE ARMS TEST
description: The countdown began today for a weeklong mission of the space shuttle Discovery that will include the first shuttle experiment to develop weapons for President Reagan's proposed shield against nuclear missiles.

title: NORTH GOING THE RIGHT WAY
description: This golf season is a critical one for him, Andy North acknowledged. ''If I had played like I did last year,'' he said, ''I might have thought about getting into something else.''

title: WHY WE STICK OUR HEADS IN THE SAND
description: VITAL LIES, SIMPLE TRUTHS The Psychology of Self-Deception. By Daniel Goleman. Illustrated. 287 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: Keeping the Peace In Woodside, Del.
description: While cities and towns all over the Northeast are competing for such assets as industrial parks and foreign trade zones, the Town Council in Woodside, Del., is trying to keep things just the way they are - and were.

title: Many Fine Teachers Of Ballet in State
description: In your article about the Stamford ballet school taught by Carol Sumner [''Stamford School Aims for the Top,'' May 19] , the author allowed a young student to make an unwise statement. It is presumptuous to state that Miss Sumner is ''the best in Connecticut . . . the only one who teaches the right technique . . .'' A 15-year-old is hardly an authority on who is the best ballet teacher in Connecticut and the statement should not have been included.

title: NETS EXPECT COACH TO BE NAMED SOON
description: On the day after the Nets were eliminated from the playoffs this spring, Stan Albeck leaned against a wall in a hallway at Byrne Meadowlands Arena and commented on his two-year tenure as coach: ''The number one thing we brought to the franchise is stability,'' he said. ''When I first came here, I'd never seen a more jittery bunch of players. Continuity is the most important thing.''

title: FIERY FOODSTUFFS AT POINT-BLANK RANGE
description: WHAT began with a boast turned into a duel - a high-noon showdown between two tough-talking law officers.

title: NORTHERN ETHIOPIA CRISIS SAID TO WORSEN
description: The senior Red Cross official in Ethiopia said today that the famine had grown ''much worse'' in parts of the country where Government troops and rebel forces remain in conflict.

title: Six Steps to Promote Public Ridership
description: I read, with great interest, your article ''Plans Outlined to Alleviate Delays During Roadwork'' [June 2] , which discussed the massive roadwork planned to unfold in the county during the next five years. And, I was interested in noting that the county intends to ''encourage greater use of public transportation.''

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: Hackensack, incidentally, is where F. Scott Fitzgerald went to preparatory school - he attended Newman Academy in 1911 before going on to Princeton University - and Bergen County is where his spirit was resurrected last Sunday at a ''Great Gatsby party'' to benefit the John Harms Englewood Plaza for the Performing Arts.

title: STILL LIFES BY SPAIN'S GREAT MASTER
description: Close on 400 years ago, a Spanish painter, no longer young, went into his studio in the Carthusian monastery in Granada, Spain, and looked long and closely at a distinctly uncharismatic vegetable. That vegetable - known in English, where known at all, as a cardoon - forthwith became the protagonist in an image, the like of which had never quite been seen before in European art. In so-called ''reality'' the cardoon looks like psychotic celery, with thorns, bristles and spikes to protect itself, But its proportions are grand, its color unexpectedly subtle, and its profile both suggestive and ambiguous. As raw in character as in fact, it is not a vegetable to mess with.

title: BAND LEADER PREPARES YEARLY SUMMER SERIES
description: Sometime in the late 1920's, George Seuffert Jr. recalls, the composer John Philip Sousa told a teen-age friend and student, ''You know, I don't think there's any chance that you would be anything except a musician.'' Mr. Seuffert, the teen-ager, has not looked back since, except to savor the comment.

title: THE SAFETY NET HAS SHRUNK BUT IT'S STILL IN PLACE
description: IT IS HARD EVEN TO THINK THE word hunger while sitting in a typical American kitchen with a freezer and other appliances gleaming as they do in the pages of a Sears catalogue, but in just such a kitchen, in Peoria, Ill., the wife of a laid-off worker at the slumping Caterpillar Corporation described how she sometimes takes only a little food on her plate at dinner, then plays with it as if she isn't really interested in eating. The point of the stratagem, Sally Sawatzki explained, was to get her children to eat more without letting them guess she was denying herself for their sake. And what, I asked, did she do after they left the table?

title: A WOMAN'S PLACE, THEY SAY, IS IN THE GYM
description: The separate but unequal athletic facilities for members of the House has long been a thorny issue.

title: SOUNDS: BOW GAMELAN
description: CLANGING, popping, crunching, honking, booming, Bow Gamelan made an industrial-strength racket Wednesday night at Creative Time's Art in the Anchorage program, under the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Vital Difference Between State and Local Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: CHURCHES DEBATE ROLE AS SANCTUARY
description: A number of churches in the New York metropolitan region are considering giving sanctuary to refugees from civil conflict in El Salvador and Guatemala, in open defiance of Federal law and the Reagan Administration.

title: VERBATIM: NO SMOKING
description: 'These bills mark a gret step foward for the state in the fight to insure each resident a healthy environment. Each year we spend millions of dollars to find a cure for cancer and to treat emphysema, lung cancer and many other diseases whose primary cause is smoking.'

title: TALKING WITH MAN'S BEST CRITIC
description: AMERICAN poets often complain that they have no audience, but I think I have a solution, one that will provide a loyal, sympathetic and discriminating body of readers. All the poet has to do is get a dog. In ''Talking With the Animals'' (Morrow), the latest of many such studies, Bill Thomas asserts what most dog lovers already know: That your dog can read you better than most people can. He's far more sensitive than any human being to the tone of your voice. What's more, according to Mr. Thomas, he can smell what you're saying. Try to find an ordinary reader or reviewer who can tell you how your poems smell.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: A new park-and-ride lot has been opened at the Exit 91 ramp of the Garden State Parkway in Brick Township, Ocean County. In providing 215 free spaces for riders of NJ Transit's Toms River-New York bus route, it replaces an unpaved lot in another section of Brick Township.

title: New Jersey Symphony Names Music Director
description: Hugh Wolff, the 31-year-old associate conductor of the National Symphony Orchestra, will become the music director and principal conductor of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra on Sept. 1.

title: DOUBLE-BREASTED ELEGANCE SUITS THEM
description: IT seems appropriate on Father's Day to note the increasing number of well-dressed young men, in the smooth, classically tailored sense, about town these days. They are the ones in impeccably fitted double-breasted suits and ties with discreet patterns. The tips of folded handkerchiefs peek out of their breast pockets, their trousers are cuffed and their shoes are English in style. Surely, Dad would approve.

title: FROZEN ON BROADWAY
description: Contrary to its unrelentingly blazing insistence, Times Square does not have a face. It is movement. There may be no place in New York as elusive or evasive, as impossible to capture in a frozen landscape or portrait.

title: House Bows On Nicaragua
description: A renewal of official American help to Nicaraguan rebels fighting the Sandinista Government became certain last week. Enough Democratic Congressmen had a change of heart to reverse the House's opposition in April and pass a bill, 248 to 184, calling for $27 million in nonmilitary aid for the so-called contras. Although it was less generous and more restrictive than the package approved by the Senate the previous week, the House measure represented a striking victory for the Reagan Administration, which had worked for almost a year to restore support for those portrayed by the President as ''freedom fighters.''

title: Iraqi Capital Is Rocked By Deafening Explosion
description: A deafening explosion shook Baghdad early today. The Iraqi Government made no comment about the blast, but Iran reported it had launched a missile at the Iraqi capital.

title: Investigation Begins At Coast Cheese Plant
description: Investigators looking for the source of bacterial contamination that has caused at least 29 deaths and stillbirths began dismantling equipment today at a factory of the Jalisco Mexican Products Company.

title:
DINING OUT;

A FRENCH ACCENT IN NEW HOPE
description: UTTERLY charming but very expensive are the words that best describe La Bonne Auberge in New Hope, Pa. The 200-year-old stone house - it started life as a farmhouse - was used as a clubhouse for Village II, a condominium complex, before being transformed into a restaurant 13 years ago.

title: A LASTING WRIGHT LEGACY
description: FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT CAN BE CELE-brated as a great maker of flowing space, or as a bold experimenter in new building technologies, or as a crusader who sought to bring the values of architecture within reach of the common man. Wright, the protean genius of 20th-century architecture, was all of those people. Even more, though, he was an architect who sought out the underlying nature of a place and who struggled to express that nature in a way that would be altogether his own.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Spits at Shooting Star ''The Book of Rewards and Punishments,'' a chinese classic that dates originlly from the fourth century A.D., offers among other things a definition of a thoroughly wicked man. It is quoted in ''The Heart of the Dragon,'' edited by Alasdair Clayre (Houghton Mifflin).

title: SALE KEEPS PUBLIC LAND RURAL
description: FROM the bottom-line point of view, an auction here of five former privately owned farms totaling 608 acres was a loss: around $350 an acre in taxpayers' money. Still, it was a success of sorts.

title: UNRULINESS AN UGLY PASTIME FOR SOME BASEBALL FANS
description: On a quiet night at Yankee Stadium, a beer vendor did not want to climb the steps to where a fan sat in an upper row of the upper deck. So the fan came down and punched him in the nose. At field level, along third base, a 13-year-old boy snatched a bag filled with $126 worth of Yankee trinkets. Near the left-field corner a concession worker at a hot dog stand scrapped with a teen-ager who climbed atop the counter and reached into the cash drawer. And in right field, another vendor was punched by another fan who argued that he had not had too much to drink.

title: SAFETY THROUGH SOBRIETY: NEW APPROACHES
description: THE present campaign to reduce the incidence of alcohol-related automobile accidents creates an opportunity to re-educate the public about alcohol use. Establishing new behaviors regarding drinking will permit families of the coming generation to meet a critical challenge to our society.

title: Westchester Escapee Seized While Walking Dog in Bronx
description: A man who escaped from the Westchester County Jail in May was captured in the Bronx Friday while walking his dog, the county police said.

title: UNPREPARED FOR THE MALPRACTICE MALICE
description: NOBODY said medicine would be easy. I entered it with my eyes open. The decision to do so lay somewhere in my psyche. It fit; it described multiple components of myself: a need to ''pay back,'' to be responsible, to problem-solve, earn respect, demonstrate integrity, and gain security.

title: Let Public Servants Serve the Public
description: Thank you for the article by Fred McMorrow entitled ''Another Car, Another Traffic Jam - Indoors'' [About Long Island, April 28] , which chronicled his experiences trying to get a car registered at the Department of Motor Vehicles in Westbury.

title:
ART;

INNOVATIONS AND CONTRADICTIONS
description: WHEN abstract shapes appear to find their own boundaries and set their own momentum, the resulting paintings can be quite engaging. This is the general spirit of recent work by Natalie Suchotine of Jericho, whose first solo exhibition is currently at the B. J. Spoke Gallery in Port Washington.

title: The Deficit. Remember the Deficit?
description: Reality has begun to intrude on the discussion of Federal budget deficits. This healthy illumination makes the problem even more difficult than it appeared last month. It also forces attention back to raising taxes - with or without tax reform.

title: 2 ELECTIONS TOLL BELL FOR HUDSON MACHINE
description: IF THERE were any doubts that the old days and ways are gone in Hudson County politics, the defeat of two incumbent Mayors last week should dispel them.

title: Holmesian Settee
description: To the Editor:

title: ENTER GYNOCRITICISM
description: THE NEW FEMINIST CRITICISM Essays on Women, Literature, and Theory. Edited by Elaine Showalter. 403 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $22.95.

title: B & B's
description: To the Editor: As a fairly seasoned traveler and admirer of almost everything British (especially the exquisite countryside and the cities), I must take great exception to the portion of Nora Magid's article ''London in a Fog'' (Travel, May 19), which berates the bed-and-breakfast experience.

title: WHERE NAZI REFUGEES FOUND THE CLIMATE TO THEIR LIKING
description: IF forensic experts prove that a body exhumed here 10 days ago is that of the Auschwitz death camp doctor Josef Mengele, as his son, Rolf, affirmed last week, the most-wanted Nazi would have lived in South America for 30 years without being caught. If the bones are not his, Dr. Mengele could still be at large.

title: HA! HA! AMONG THE TRUMPETS
description: EMINENT VICTORIAN SOLDIERS Seekers of Glory. By Byron Farwell. Illustrated. 367 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $17.95.

title: 48 COLLEGES SEE SCIENCE SUPPORT
description: Forty-eight colleges renowned for turning out future lawyers, physicians, corporate executives and government officials, have banded together to publicize and seek support for a role for which they are less known: the production of scientists.

title: MILES DAVIS
description: FOR MANY YEARS OF MY LIFE, MILES DAVIS WAS MY ULtimate culture hero: artist, cool man, bad dude, hipster, clear as daylight and funky as revelation. His influence and effect on the music called jazz and its players is still somewhat astonishing.

title: LEBANON MILITIA FREES 21 FINNS IT HELD 8 DAYS
description: The Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army today freed the 21 Finnish soldiers of a United Nations unit whom it had been holding as hostages for eight days.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WAR CRIES OVER AVENUE C. By Jerome Charyn. (Donald I. Fine, $17.95.) ''Avenues A, B, C, and D form a dirty appendage to Manhattan . . . these Alphabet Blocks have become Indian country, the land of murder and cocaine.'' Well, sort of. This novel is too amiable for murder, except of the comic-book variety - lots of Eeech! and Yuch! but not a great deal of pain. In fact, the novel is remarkably like a comic book - I mean the kind with pictures - in tone, in lively vernacular and juxtaposition of disparate elements. It is sort of about Sarah, a pockmarked woman from Bayonne, N.J., who becomes a nurse in Saigon, South Vietnam, and then den mother to a band of misfits in an abandoned synagogue on the lower east side of a city vaguely like New York. But the book isn't really about Sarah; rather, it contains her every so often. And it contains her boyfriend, Howie, who learns magic from Vietnam's Montagnards (called ''yards'' here) and is left by the war pulling shrapnel from his hair, addicted to poison. And it contains the various machinations of an omnipotent C.I.A.-like agent called The Preacher. Or is he K.G.B.? Or are they different? And do they perhaps both work for a super-agency run by a publisher in New York? We are not asked to believe any of this. It's just so many alphabet blocks thrown together - a few mild jokes about Henry James and his critics (who here are thugs for the super-agents), some surprising transpositions (the black market currency in Ho Chi Minh City is Mont Blanc pens), a few James Bond-like exploits and a lot of friendly, slangy writing.

title: The $323,378 Hardhat, and Other Tales
description: The high cost of land, labor and financing have helped make construction in New York City the most costly in the country. So have some startling expenses for employees who don't work, state investigators disclosed last week. Featherbedding practices allow some supervisors to make hundreds of thousands of dollars in overtime even while absent from the work site, officials of the State Commission of Investigation said.

title: N.H.L. Holds Day Of Dreams for 252
description: Kent Nilsson left Calgary for Minnesota. Mark Hunter departed Montreal for St. Louis. And a couple of hundred starry-eyed teen-agers, one of them named Gretzky, became part of National Hockey League teams today in the league's annual amateur draft.

title: NATURE WATCH
description: MOLE CRAB Emerita talpoida Size: Male, to one inch; female, larger.

title: NAILING HUSBANDS TO THE WALL
description: THE DITTO LIST By Stephen Greenleaf. 358 pp. New York: Villard Books. $16.95.

title: Death Penalty Vs. Life Penalty
description: It was hardly surprising that both houses of the New York State Legislature passed a bill reinstating the death penalty this year, and that the Governor vetoed it, and that the lawmakers were unable to override his veto (the Senate succeeded, but the Assembly fell nine votes short). This has been the pattern over the past several years, first under Gov. Hugh L. Carey and then Governor Cuomo.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Mozart's 'Magic Flute' A Glyndebourne Festival Opera production, featuring Benjamin Luxon, Felicity Lott, Leo Goeke, May Sandoz and Thomas Thomaschke, with Bernard Haitink conducting the London Philharmonic Orchestra; 1978 Video Arts International 164 minutes. $79.95 The presenters call this ''The Magic Flute,'' but as it is sung in German (with English subtitles) it really should be called ''Die Zauberflote.''

title: MAHLER AND BRUCKNER ARE INTERPRETED ON CD'S
description: Mahler's Seventh Symphony in E minor has always been one of his most enigmatic. In his program notes to a splendid new compact-disk recording of the work by the Chicago Symphony under Claudio Abbado (DG 413 773-2, two disks), Donald Mitchell offers some interesting ideas as to its meaning. He points out that the two ''night'' pieces, which make up the second and fourth movements, were composed first, and then Mahler created the first, third and fifth movements around them. The ''night'' pieces flank a scherzo, which, with its ''shadowy'' marking, continues the nocturnal theme. The first movement uses a somber version of the last movement's theme, while that finale becomes a celebration of the sunlit key of C. Thus the symphony moves from dark to light. (It is significant that when Mahler first conducted the work himself, he included in the program Wagner's Overture to ''Die Meistersinger,'' which is another hymn to the key of C.) The recording is superb. The orchestra is at its extraordinary best, and Mr. Abbado has a flair for giving phrases a subtle inflection and smoothing out tempo transitions without breaking the forward impulse of the music. The complex yet transparent orchestration has both clarity and a richly varied texture, with the important motives suitably stressed. In its CD version, this recording is surely the best to be had.

title: TALK BIG, THINK SMALL
description: On the two major issues before the United States Government today - the control of the budget and the control of nuclear weapons - President Reagan has recently been trying to avoid a break with the Congress and the Russians.

title: INSIGHTS INTO SELF-DECEPTION
description: One of the cornerstones of science is the Parsimony Principle: Given two explanations for a phenomenon, start by accepting the one that requires fewer assumptions. Unfortunately, Mr. Goleman's examples do not meet this test.

title: SUMMERFARE EVENTS REFLECT CHANGES BY NEW DIRECTOR
description: T HERE will be no youngsters dressed as animals parading onto the grounds of the State University of New York at Purchase next month when Pepsico's Summerfare opens its sixth season, but Cleopatra will be lowered by construction crane onto a stage resembling a bombed-out Middle Eastern hotel.

title: BATTLE OVER LEGAL SERVICES MAY NOW BEGIN IN EARNEST
description: It was a milestone week for the Federal Legal Services Corporation. The Senate confirmed President Reagan's nominations of eight men and three women as directors of the controversial body, which distributes Federal money to provide free lawyers for poor people in civil cases. Now, observes Clinton Lyons, director of a legal aid lawyers' group called the National Legal Aid and Defender Association, after years of Administration attacks on the program, Reagan appointees ''are going to have to produce a concrete vision of what it ought to be.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Recalled Juan Agosto, pitcher, from Buffalo farm club and optioned Bryan Little, infielder, to Buffalo.

title: Housing Delays
description: To the Editor:

title: RALPH SHAPEY RETURNS
description: When Ralph Shapey assumes the position of Distinguished Professor of Music at Queens College's Aaron Copland School of Music this fall, he will be returning to New York after a 21-year absence. During this period he has built up a substantial reputation as one of the most talented, independent and outspoken of American composers. And through his work as a conductor and organizer he has come to be closely associated - indeed, almost synonymous - with contemporary music in the Chicago area. Mr. Shapey, who received a no-strings-attached ''genius'' award from the MacArthur Foundation in 1982 - the first composer to be so honored - has been teaching at the University of Chicago since 1964.

title: THE CHANGING FACE OF SUMMER THEATER
description: As television has become the primary medium for featherweight comedy, the most enterprising and successful summer theaters have turned to more demanding material. Massachusetts's Williamstown Theater Festival, for example, has become a traditional summer nesting spot for such celebrated stage actors as Blythe Danner and Edward Herrmann. Actors are eager to stretch themselves in unfamiliar roles and straw-hat audiences seem just as hungry for fresh theatrical experiences.

title: BEACON FALLS, REMEMBERING, HELPS OUT
description: THE evening news showed homes leveled, families without food or electricity, bodies on the street. The scenes were from Pennsylvania, where several towns last month were devastated by tornadoes.

title: MISS LEBS WEDS A. G. HANDLELMAN
description: Kathy Lebs, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dale Lebs of Arcadia, Calif., and Albert Gresser Handelman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Handelman of New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Noel Vore performed the ceremony at the Neighborhood Unitarian Church in Pasadena, Calif.

title: TOWNLEY MCELHINEY BECOMES BRIDE OF KELLY SCOTT SHAW, BANK EXECUTIVE
description: At St. James' Episcopal Church in New York yesterday Helen Townley McElhiney, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Watkins McElhiney of Bethesda and Annapolis, Md., was married to Kelly Scott Shaw, the son of Mr. and Scott A. Shaw of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Ann Brewster Jones, assisted by the Rev. Susan C. Harriss, performed the ceremony.

title: TOP DRAFTEES PRESSURED BY FULL-COURT SCRUTINY
description: ONLY Patrick Ewing has been certain of his future in the days leading up to Tuesday's National Basketball Association college draft. The 7-foot Georgetown center has been aware for more than a month that minutes after the proceedings begin at 1 P.M., at Felt Forum, Commissioner David Stern will announce, ''New York selects Patrick Ewing of Georgetown.''

title: TUMBLING METS FALL TO EXPOS IN 9TH
description: Only 24 hours after they lost in the ninth inning and fell into third place, the Mets lost in the ninth inning again tonight and fell into fourth place for the first time in more than a year.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: MY VERY FIRST BOOK OF NUMBERS. Written and illustrated by Eric Carle. Thomas Y. Crowell. Paper, $2.95.

title: TRENTON: A LEIPZIG SEMI-RETROSPECTIVE
description: THE 22 paintings by Mel Leipzig now on view at the State Museum represent only the last 12 years of a career that began in the late 1950's. Nevertheless, they sum up the accomplishment that has put him among the top New Jersey realists, along with Robert Birmelin and George Segal.

title: WRITING: CAN IT BE TAUGHT?
description: Can it but by more writers per annum than anyone has time to read. Whatever the demand for their product, the supply of able American poets, novelists, and short-story writers has not declined in the second half of this century. An annual national poetry competition, for the Walt Whitman Award, a few years back received 1,475 manuscript volumes of verse from which to select and publish one winner; a poetry magazine with 520 subscribers may receive 10,500 poems from 1,875 contributors in a single year. The fiction and poetry editors of the few American large-circulation periodicals that still publish fiction and poetry are comparably deluged, as are the directors of the nation's better-known graduate programs in creative writing. Lots of literature out there.

title: CONDUCTOR IS NAMED
description: THE New Jersey Symphony Orchestra last week announced the appointment of Hugh Wolff as conductor and music director.

title: U.S. FRUSTRATED IN EFFORTS TO COUNTER SOVIET SPYING
description: American counterespionage forces are finding themselves understaffed and overwhelmed in trying to combat increasingly advanced and diversified Soviet intelligence operations in the United States, according to senior Government officials.

title: LINDA RODD WED TO RORY MILLSON
description: Linda Ellen Rodd and Rory Oliver Millson were married yesterday at the Terrace at Butler Hall of Columbia University in New York by Judge Solomon Katz of the Civil Court of New York. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Rodd of Atlanta, and Mr. Millson is a son of Dr. Fay Millson of Cape Town, South Africa, and the late Harry Millson.

title: FOR FATHERS AND SONS, A TIME TO LIVE, A TIME TO DIE
description: WE ARE sons first, then fathers. For a while, we are both. It is a measure of that line of life's impermanence, but also our immortality.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE SNOW GODS. By Herbert Burkholz. (Atheneum, $19.95.) Some people read novels for the same reason others ski - the scenery. In this long book about three generations of a skiing family, the backdrops seem more important than the tortured and improbable twists of plot.

title: Cliffhanger
description: CRUMBLING bluffs along the Mississippi River were endangering homes in a historic area of Natchez, Miss., last fall, with one antebellum mansion, Weymouth Hall, perched eight feet from the edge of a 100-foot-high bluff.

title: 'BROADWAY JOE' IS NOW 'BOARDWALK JOE'
description: IF ''Bells Are Ringing,'' the 1956 Jule Styne-Betty Comden-Adolph Green musical at the Claridge Hotel-Casino, is being presented and promoted as a Joe Namath vehicle, do not fault Mr. Namath.

title: THE POCONOS BEYOND THE BILLBOARDS
description: Ever since World War II the Poconos - the Pocono Mountains of northeastern Pennsylvania - have suffered from a reputation for gaudiness brought on by ''couples' retreats'' and ''honeymoon hideaways,'' most hidden only by the huge signs that tout them. If mirrored ceilings, pink satin sheets and heart-shaped bathtubs are your idea of bliss, you're probably already a Pocono regular (or should be).

title: Bank in Wisconsin Fails, First in State in 10 Years
description: The 104-year-old Strong's Bank, of Dodgeville, closed Friday, the first Wisconsin bank to fail in 10 years, the State Banking Commissioner, Richard Galecki, said today.

title: The Glory Of Carnegie Hall
description: Samuel G. Freedman's article ''The Glory of Carnegie Hall'' (May 19) was well received by those of us who travel from the provinces, where music halls parade as other settings on off nights. The splendor of Carnegie Hall and its brilliant acoustics are unmatched in the United States.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: U.S. Plans Military Exercise
description: The Defense Department said today that United States and Canadian forces would hold an air defense exercise Sunday over North America. Jet fighters from the North American Air Defense Command, a joint United States-Canadian military organization, will try to intercept bombers from the Strategic Air Command.

title: CALENDARS
description: HORSE SHOWS Today - Ox Ridge Charity, Darien, Conn. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (203) 438-6175.

title: HOLMES AGREES TO FIGHT SPINKS
description: Even as he was wrapping up the final negotiations today for Larry Holmes's 49th fight - a meeting against Michael Spinks sometime in September - Don King was planning No. 50 -perhaps a Hawaiian Five-O.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''On a scale of 1 to 10, measuring progress from the current system toward an ideal, stable, growth-oriented tax system, the President's plan is probably a 3.''

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Weeks This Last on Week Fiction Week List 1 THE CIDER HOUSE RULES, by John Irving. 2 4 (Morrow, $18.95.) Life in a Maine orphanage earlier in this century. 2 HOLD THE DREAM, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. 1 5 (Doubleday, $17.95.)Continuing the family saga begun in ''A Woman of Substance.'' 3 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy.
