(Naval Institute Press, $14.95.) 4 13 A Lithuanian submarine driver defects to the United States with the Soviet Union's most advanced nuclear secrets. 4 JUBAL SACKETT, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, 3 4 16.95.)In this forerunner to the 17-volume Sackett saga, a restless explorer scouts the 17th-century American wilderness. 5 CHAPTERHOUSE: DUNE, by Frank Herbert. 5 9 (Putnam, $17.95.) A new world rises from the Old Empire's ashes in this volume of the ''Dune'' series. $ 6 IF TOMORROW COMES, by Sidney Sheldon. 6 21 (Morrow, $17.95.) A young woman destroys the crime lords who got her an undeserved prison term. 7 THINNER, by Richard Bachman. (NAL Books, 7 7 $12.95.) In this pseudonymous novel by Stephen King, a lawyer's body mysteriously wastes away. 8 INSIDE, OUTSIDE, by Herman Wouk. 9 13 (Little, Brown, $19.95.) A traditionalist Jew's quest for identity in glittery contemporary America. 9 THE CLASS, by Erich Segal. (Bantam, $17.95.) 8 8 What happened to five members of the class of 1958 after they left Harvard Yard. 10 A CREED FOR THE THIRD MILLENNIUM, 12 6 by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A man and a woman set out to salvage a spiritually exhausted America in the not-too-distant future. 11 QUEENIE, by Michael Korda. (Linden Press/ 10 9 Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The career of Dawn Avalon, whose life resembles that of Merle Oberon. 12 FAMILY ALBUM, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, 10 9 $16.95.) A married couple with five children cope with the crises of contemporary America. 13 THE LONELY SILVER RAIN, by John D. 11 11 MacDonald.$15.95.) A yacht's disappearance, a debutante's murder and other puzzles Travis McGee must solve to save his life. 14 A CATSKILL EAGLE, by Robert B. Parker. 1 (Delacorte, $14.95.) In his 12th case, the private eye Spenser joins hands with Federal agents. 15 THE HOUSE OF THE SPIRITS, by Isabel Allende. 1 (Knopf, $17.95.) A Chilean woman seeks to cope with the disaster, violence and despair that beset her male-dominated family. Nonfiction 1 IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca 2 33 with William Novak. (Bantam, $19.95.) The rise of the automobile executive from immigrants' son to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler. 2 PASSION FOR EXCELLENCE, by Tom Peters 1 6 and Nancy Austin (Random House, $19.95.) Ways to achieve distinction in management. 3 SMART WOMEN, FOOLISH CHOICES, by Connell 3 11 Cowan and Melvyn Kinder. (Clarkson N. Potter, $13.95.) Two clinical psychologists analyze the successes and failures of modern women in looking for acceptable men. 4 MY MOTHER'S KEEPER, by B. D. Hyman. 4 5 (Morrow, $16.95.) A portrait of the actress Bette Davis, by her daughter. 5 LOVING EACH OTHER, by Leo Buscaglia. 5 42 (Slack/Holt, $13.95.) Suggestions for ''setting our priorities right in order to enjoy life to the fullest.'' 6 CONFESSIONS OF A HOOKER, by Bob Hope 8 5 with Dwayne Netland. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Memories of more than 50 years of golfing, by the comedian. 7 MOUNTBATTEN, by Philip Ziegler. 6 3 (Knopf, $24.95.) The authorized biography of the British diplomat, naval hero and royal counselor. 8 BREAKING WITH MOSCOW, by Arkady 7 16 N. Shevchenko. (Knopf, $18.95.) The autobiography of the highest-ranking Soviet official ever to defect. 9 THE HEART OF THE DRAGON, by Alasdair 15 2 Clayre. (Houghton Mifflin, $29.95.) Companion volume to the PBS television series on China. 10 THE COURAGE TO CHANGE, by Dennis Wholey. 12 18 (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) Conversations with two dozen men and women, many of them celebrities, about their problems with alcoholism. 11 ONCE UPON A TIME, by Gloria 10 7 Vanderbilt. (Knopf, $16.95.) Memories of the first 17 years of a ''poor little rich girl.'' 12 THE SOONG DYNASTY, by Sterling Seagrave. 9 9 (Harper & Row, $22.50.) The tangled lives of Charlie Soong and his six children, who shaped much of China's modern history. 13 ''SURELY YOU'RE JOKING, MR. FEYNMAN,'' 13 by Richard P. Feynman. (Norton, $15.95.) A Nobel laureate in physics recounts his curious misadventures inside and outside his profession. 14 THE BRIDGE ACROSS FOREVER, by Richard Bach. 13 41 (Morrow, $16.95.) The author of ''Jonathan Livingston Seagull'' tells of his search for love. 15 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel 11 134 Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse and drawings by the author.

title:
DINING OUT;

REVISITING AT CAPRICCIO'S
description: THE view is one in a million, the service gracious and efficient, the ambience warm and relaxing; the menu is short enough to inspire confidence in the kitchen's ability to deliver what it promises, the dishes familiar but prepared with a perceptible dab of inventiveness. Of the scores of one-star restaurants in the area, Capriccio's may be one of the three we look forward most to revisiting. However, an absolute, unemotional judgment - one that excludes the charm of the waiters and the maitre d'hotel, the beautiful plants played off against dark Tudor rafters, the glassed-in veranda with a stunning view of the great East Branch Reservoir - would have to take into account the parts of this production that lack a certain measure of finesse one expects at these prices. The chairs were plain and not particularly comfortable. And don't expect culinary Everests; the dishes, with a few exceptions, were uninspired.

title: URBAN BUILDING TRENDS LEND BOSTON AN ODD MIX
description: This city was once called the cradle of liberty, but now it might more appropriately be called the cradle of the new urbanism. Here, thrown together like the layers of ancient history that preoccupy the archeologist, is evidence of virtually every trend that has characterized the redevelopment of the American city over the last generation.

title: THE UNWRITTEN CODE THAT STOPS POLICE FROM SPEAKING
description: The ''blue wall'' is an unwritten code of New York City's Police Department, but the consequences of violating it are so clear to most officers that the code might as well be chiseled over the entrance to the Police Academy. ''If they mark you as a 'rat,' you're finished on the job,'' a police officer, who asked for anonymity, said of the code of silence that prosecutors believe has restrained officers from implicating fellow officers. ''It means that no one talks to you, that your family gets obscene calls and every day you have to wonder if someone is going to be a little slow in backing you up in a life or death situation.''

title: TEXAS AIR-T.W.A.: WILL THE DEAL FLY?
description: Texas Air's purchase of T.W.A. for $793.5 million is a personal coup for Frank A. Lorenzo, Texas Air's chief. The purchase, valued at $23 a share, would give Texas Air a vast network of east-west routes to add to the mainly north-south business of its New York Air and Continental units. And it adds T.W.A.'s lucrative European destinations to Continental's Far East routes without cumbersome negotiations with governments. But other airlines will probably protest, and the Government may try to quash the deal as well. Analysts also note Mr. Lorenzo's penchant for trimming costs by forcing wage cuts on unions. The sale keeps T.W.A. from Carl C. Icahn, who had offered $19 a share.

title: FOREIGN STUDENTS MUST PAY THE FREIGHT
description: At the Patrice Lumumba People's Friendship University on the outskirts of Moscow, 5,000 students from 105 countries study alongside young Russians training for positions as third-world advisers. The non-Russians are among an estimated 50,000 foreign students in the Soviet Union, most of them from developing countries and virtually all on Soviet Government scholarships.

title: TAX EFFECT ON FAMILY ASSESSED
description: The assertion last week by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d that ''the median-income family'' in every state would be better off under the Reagan Administration's tax plan is not borne out by an analysis of Government statistics.

title: SOUTH AFRICA TO IMPOSE A NEW ADMINISTRATION ON NAMIBIA TODAY
description: With much fanfare, but with no elections, a new administration is to be installed on Monday in this South African-controlled territory. The move is seen by many as an effort to erode the support enjoyed by insurgents in the north who have been fighting South Africa's control for the last 20 years.

title: CONSUMER REPORTS BOOKS EXPANDS
description: Consumer Reports Books, until now available mainly to subscribers of Consumer Reports magazine, will soon be available in book stores and other retail outlets. With 16 commissioned book salesmen plus distribution by Harper & Row, the restructured book company has also moved its editorial office from Mount Vernon, N. Y., to midtown Manhattan, where it soon plans to publish about 25 titles a year.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PHOTO ALBUM Dom Pedro II, who was Emperor of Brazil from 1831 to 1889, majored in government but he minored, enthusiastically, in photography. He was such an ardent amateur that he propelled the new art to a position in Brazil more advanced than that in any other country south of our border. This is just one of many background items that emerge from the photographic exhibition ''New World Africans: 19th-Century Images of Blacks in South America and the Caribbean,'' now on view in the ground- floor gallery of the New York Public Library's Schomberg Center for Research in Black Culture, 515 Lenox Avenue, at 135th Street (862-4000).

title: Ex-Wife of Murder Suspect Asks Immunity From Charges
description: The former wife of a suspect in numerous murders at a remote mountain compound has received death threats and will say nothing more about the case to police until the authorities grant her immunity from prosecution, her lawyer said today.

title: JAPANESE-AMERICAN REOPENS QUESTION OF WAR INTERNMENT
description: Court proceedings in which a Japanese-American will seek overturning of his conviction for defying Government internment orders in World War II open Monday in the same Federal courthouse where he was sentenced in 1942.

title: VENEZUELA AWAITS PHONE WORK BIDS
description: This country's state-owned telephone concern has asked nine international companies to submit bids on the biggest telecommunications contract in the nation's history.

title: NEW YORK MIDDLE CLASS FACING BIGGER TAX BITE
description: President Reagan in a speech in New Jersey last week reasserted his belief that his tax plan would not hurt taxpayers in ''high-tax'' states such as New York. But neither the President nor his lieutenants have ever denied that many New Yorkers would face a big tax increase.

title: MEESE'S LIKELY CHOICES: YOUNG AND CONSERVATIVE
description: Many of the top jobs at the Justice Department have been vacant for months and speculation has been growing about what kind of team Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d wants. But Mr. Meese has been keeping his cards close to the vest.

title: Songbirds at the End of the Ecological Chain
description: To the Editor:

title: ELDERLY ALCOHOLICS: FINDING THE CAUSES AND CURES
description: ''Many elderly people use drink as self-medication for depression and loneliness,'' said Dr. Michael L. Freedman of the New York University Medical Center. ''Alcohol is one of the few substances one can buy for this without a prescription. Of course, it does provide some initial relief - but in the long term, alcoholism makes you more depressed.''

title: THE REAL QUINLAN ISSUE
description: More than nine years after the New Jersey Supreme Court granted her parents permission to disconnect Karen Ann Quinlan's mechanical respirator so that she could die ''with grace and dignity,'' and after years of ''defying'' the experts who testified she could not survive without that apparatus, she is dead. It is plain the landmark case will still be debated. What troubles me is that the central issue has escaped attention.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 17, 1985: *2*MONDAY Horizon Bancorp Rykoff-Sexton Rochester Tel Corp *2*TUESDAY Anderson Greenwood Fed'l Paper Brd Bell Atlantic Firestone Tire Brunswick Corp Roper Corp CPC Int'l Upjohn Co Citicorp Walbar Dyneer Corp *2*WEDNESDAY Affiliated Public Stone & Webster Inc American Tel & Tel Tidewater Inc Bank of Virginia United Jersey Banks Carolina Pwr & Lt Valspar Corp Flightsafety Int'l Vestaur Secur National Svce Indust Woodstream Corp *2*THURSDAY Air Pdts & Chem Nynex Corp Central Maine Pwr Southern Cal Edison Dow Chemical Stevens (J P) & Co Ennis Bus Forms Swift Independent Excel Industries Tektronix Inc First Boston Inc Texas Oil & Gas Insilco Corp *2*FRIDAY CTS Corp Rogers Corp General Cinema Southeast Banking Kaiser Cement Tasty Baking Penobscot Shoe

title: Engelhard Officer Named to New Post
description: The Engelhard Corporation, which in February 1984 underwent a major restructuring, announced that Cyrus H. Holley, who has served as president of the company's specialty chemicals division, has been named to the new post of executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Emily M. Altman Marries Alan Heaps
description: Emily Marice Altman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David R. Altman of New York and Long Valley, N.J., was married yesterday to Alan A. Heaps, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Heaps of Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Joel E. Soffin performed the ceremony at the Altman home in Long Valley.

title: Toxic Air and the E.P.A. Tortoise
description: Each year America's chemical plants vent or leak billions of pounds of hazardous gases into the air. New attention was focused on the toxic seepage by the accident at Bhopal, India, last year, in which 2,000 people were choked to death by poisonous fumes. But even that disaster has not budged the Environmental Protection Agency into decisive action, and Congress is stretching to fill the void.

title: BRADLEY TAKES AN OPTION TO SUCCESS FOR MARINERS
description: THERE'S a new name these days among the batting leaders in the American League, and his teammates and coaches think it's a name that may be near the top for a few more years.

title: SHRIVER ROMPS IN ENGLISH RINAL
description: Pam Shriver took just 43 minutes to crush a fellow American, Betsy Nagelsen, 6-1, 6-0, today and capture a $125,000 women's tennis tournament.

title: PRESIDENT ISSUES A VEILED WARNING
description: President Reagan today warned Moslem Shiite hijackers ''for their own safety'' to free the American hostages on a Trans World Airlines jet in Beirut as well as the passengers removed Friday night to an undisclosed location.

title: Synthetic Fuel Discretion
description: Having had its original $14.9 billion appropriation chopped to $8 billion last year, the Synthetic Fuels Corporation has decided that discretion is the better part of valor. The ''comprehensive strategy report'' to Congress that its board of directors is expected to approve Tuesday asks for no more money.

title: Bush to a 'Few Key People'
description: It sounds like the heroic prologue of the latest film in the Star Wars saga: ''I feel the time has come for me to gather our team together, rekindle the torch and renew our crusade.'' No, the empire is not striking back, but George Bush, after five years at the side of President Reagan, the jedimaster of Republican politics, is striking out on his own with a new campaign organization called the Fund for America's Future.

title: REV. ALFRED L. BECK
description: The Rev. Alfred L. Beck, a Lutheran pastor from Huntington, L.I., and a former church official, died Thursday while visiting relatives in Norristown, Pa. He was 68 years old and had been suffering from cancer.

title: COMMENCEMENT THEMES HEW TO NEWS
description: This year's commencement speakers who attacked policies of the Reagan Administration ranging from trade to civil rights to disarmament were countered by others, often Administration officials, lauding a new patriotism and national pride.

title: Ferraro Says D'Amato Did Not Fight Tax Plan
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro, who is considering an election challenge to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, criticized the Senator yesterday for what she called his failure last fall to oppose a Treasury Department tax plan to end the Federal income-tax deduction for state and local taxes.

title: WNET DRAMA LOOKS AT ANGEL ISLAND
description: LIKE Ellis Island on the East Coast, Angel Island in San Francisco Bay was a clearing house for immigrants in the first decades of this country. Both facilities have become symbols of the oppressed being welcomed into the golden new land of opportunity. Many of their realities, however, were a little more complicated, considerably less sentimental. ''Paper Angels,'' an hourlong drama on WNET/13 tonight at 9, considers the Angel Island experience from the vantage point of a several Chinese men and women, a mere handful plucked from the lists of 175,000 who passed through between the years of 1910 and 1940.

title: Well, They Have the Taste
description: There is an esthetic pork barrel carefully watched by members of Congress and it has a special resonance.

title: RALLY LETS RED SOX SWEEP BLUE JAYS
description: Dwight Evans's sacrifice fly capped a four-run eighth inning today as the Boston Red Sox rallied for a 7-6 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays that completed a four-game sweep of the American League East leaders.

title: 21 Seized in Los Angeles In Curfew Crackdown
description: The police arrested 21 juveniles in a weekend crackdown on curfew violators in the city's busiest nightclub district.

title: Henry Zupnick Weds Judith Zerden, Lawyer
description: At the Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel in Riverdale, the Bronx, yesterday Judith C. Zerden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Zerden of Brooklyn, and Henry D. Zupnick, a son of Prof. and Mrs. Elliot Zupnick of Riverdale, were married by Rabbi Irving Greenberg, the bridegroom's uncle, and Rabbi Shlomo Balter.

title: JOURNEY OF FLIGHT 847: A LOGBOOK OF TERROR
description: Since Trans World Airlines Flight 847 was hijacked Friday morning after a stop in Athens on a flight from Cairo to Rome, it has flown four times between Beirut and Algiers. Following is a chronology of those flights and the local times that they occurred: xhrrFriday 10:10 A.M. Flight 847 leaves Athens for Rome with 145 passengers and eight crew members. Two men, each with a 9-millimeter pistol and a hand grenade, hijack the plane and force the pilot to fly to Beirut. The hijackers are later identified by an accomplice captured in Athens as members of a Shiite Moslem group known as Islamic Holy War. 11:55 A.M. The plane lands at Beirut International Airport after the pilot, whose request is at first denied, tells the controller that passengers are being beaten and a hijacker has pulled the pin on a grenade. 1:30 P.M. The plane leaves Beirut for Algiers after the hijackers read their demands, which include the release of more than 700 Shiites captured by Israel in Lebanon. The hijackers release at least 17 women and 2 children and the plane is refueled. 3:30 P.M. The plane, after at first being refused permission to land, touches down at Houari Boumediene International Airport in Algiers for refueling. The hijackers threaten to ''execute'' the remaining passengers unless Israel releases the 700 Shiites. 8:15 P.M. After the hijackers release at least 21 passengers, the plane heads back to Beirut. xhrrSaturday 2:20 A.M. In Beirut the controller refuses to turn on the runway lights, but relents after the pilot says the plane will run out of fuel.

title: . . .and the Greengrocer
description: Five days after his family arrived on the Lower East Side from Sicily in 1936, Salvatore Ferrante, then 11 years old, went to work.

title: THOMAS IS CLEARING THE AIR
description: A brilliant light, color it pink, shone on the dark and dank heavyweight division Saturday night. Pinklon Thomas knocked out Mike Weaver with one beautiful right hand, defended his World Boxing Council title and established himself, if not as the true champion, as clearly the best of what often has been a slovenly collection.

title: 3 Hurt as Tornado Hits Hilton Head Trailers
description: A tornado raked a South Carolina trailer park yesterday, while showers and thunderstorms pushed along the Atlantic Coast and the threat of more rain figured into plans for the space shuttle launching in Florida.

title: McClain Takes Horse Grand Prix
description: McClain, ridden by Leslie Burr Lenehan, won the $35,000 Laurent Perrier Grand Prix for the United States Equestrian team show-jumping championship today at the Merrill Lynch-Ox Ridge Charity Horse Show. Mrs. Lenehan, from Westport, Conn., piloted the 11-year-old gelding faultlessly around the jump-off course in the time of 24.774 seconds.

title: The Bookseller. . .
description: At the Isaac Mendoza Book Company, they count their volumes in the tens of thousands, their anniversaries by the score and their remaining days on two hands.

title: DOUBTS INCREASE OVER FUTURE OF U.S. LAND-BASED MISSILES
description: A political bargain that limits deployment of the MX missile, as well as problems with the planned Midgetman missile, have cast new doubt on the future of land-based missiles in the country's nuclear arsenal, according to Pentagon officials and members of Congress.

title: Nicaraguan Medical Tam Free After 'Contra' Captivity
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: BRONX ARTS ENSEMBLE IN 'FALL OF HOUSE OF USHER'
description: EDGAR ALLAN POE'S ''Fall of the House of Usher'' may have the germ of an effective opera in it, but a master's hand, bold and subtle, would be required to put its people on the stage in flesh and blood without dispelling the haze that half shrouds them in the story. Debussy might have been able, but he stacked the cards against the success of his abandoned attempt with his preliminary choices in shaping the libretto. So have the librettist Robert Kornfeld and the composer Russell Currie in ''A Dream Within a Dream,'' their ''Usher'' opera that was presented Saturday at the Lehman Center by the Bronx Arts Ensemble.

title: CHEN STUMBLES AND NORTH CAPTURES U.S. OPEN
description: Andy North had not won a tournament since taking the 1978 United States Open and did not seem destined to win today in the final round of the 85th Open - not unless something happened to Tze-Chung Chen, who led by four shots with 14 holes to go at Oakland Hills Country Club.

title: Jackson Urges Action
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson urged President Reagan yesterday not to allow the United States Ambassador to return to South Africa until a plan to end apartheid had been formulated.

title: CHRIS MULLIN SCORES WITH CAVS' COACH
description: Subject: One-on-one game.

title: WHITE HOUSE TO REBUT CRITICS
description: Patrick J. Buchanan, who recently took charge of White House communications, is setting up what he calls a ''response desk'' to reply when the President is attacked by his critics.

title: Elizabeth Easton Wed to James Traub
description: Elizabeth Wynne Easton, a daughter of Joan K. Easton of New York and William L. Easton of New York and Wainscott, L.I., and James Stuart Traub were married yesterday. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin S. Traub of New York and Greenwich, Conn.

title: The Return Of Sutcliffe
description: RICK SUTCLIFFE wasn't supposed to be pitching for the Cubs tonight against the Mets. But he is.

title: SHUTTLE IS READY TO BEGIN MISSION
description: The space shuttle Discovery is set for Monday's mission, the first in the history of space flight to include crew members from three countries. On board will be five Americans, a Frenchman and a Saudi Arabian prince.

title: F.D.I.C. Stalls on Repayment
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said over the weekend that it would not immediately reimburse 11 financial institutions that had deposited funds in the Strong's Bank of Dodgeville, Wis., which failed on Friday.

title: SHIRLEY OUTDUELS TIGERS BY 2-1
description: Bob Shirley stood passively in front of his locker and answered the same questions over and over again. He wanted to take a shower, to change into street clothes and spend the remainder of Father's Day with his three sons. Instead, he waited patiently and answered every question.

title: Shift in Economic Policy Seen
description: As they watch interest rates tumble, some economists say that the policy mix governing the American economy is changing significantly, with important ramifications.

title: METS END 1-6 TRIP WITH A 7-2 LOSS
description: Deeper and deeper went the Mets today, spinning almost out of control as they again lost to the Montreal Expos, 7-2, and the numbers tell the tale: They lost three straight to the Expos this weekend and six times in seven games on their worst trip in more than two years.

title: Required Reading;   Effects of Detente
description: Excerpt from an address, ''The Global Information Revolution and the Communist World,'' by Walter R. Roberts of the Board for International Broadcasting at Kennan Institute for Advanced Russian Studies in Washington, June 12:

title: SLAIN MAN'S BODY SENT TO SPAIN FOR IDENTIFICTION
description: The body of the passenger from the hijacked airliner who was killed Saturday in Beirut arrived tonight at an American air force base near here, American officials said.

title: BLACKS QUESTION U.S. MOTIVES IN VOTE FRAUD TRIAL
description: Twenty years ago, on a cold and drizzly day, Albert Turner was at the head of a column of civil rights marchers who were clubbed down by the Alabama police as they attempted to enter this old city.

title: Guadeloupe Rebel Chief Escapes From Jail
description: The suspected leader of a group fighting for the independence of French overseas territories escaped from jail in Guadeloupe today, the public prosecutor said.

title: SILESIAN EXILES JEER KOHL SPEECH
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl insisted to a Silesian exile organization today that West Germany had no claims on the territory of Poland and would not raise them in the future.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: DIRECT INFLATION HEDGE ON CONSUMER INFLATION
description: When the Chicago commodity exchanges introduced financial futures a dozen years ago, they revolutionized the global money market by affording investors and dealers in Government and private debt issues the ability to hedge their portfolios and trading risks.

title: Nell Scovell, Writer, Marries Thomas Jonah Tisch
description: The marriage of Helen Vivian Scovell to Thomas Jonah Tisch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence A. Tisch of New York, took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin E. Scovell, parents of the bride, in Newton, Mass. Rabbi Philip Hiat, assisted by Rabbi Jacob Neusner, performed the ceremony.

title: DIFFICULT ROAD AHEAD FOR ARGENTINA
description: The Argentine economy and its intractable inflation problem has toppled governments and ruined the political careers of a slew of bright financial ministers for more than four decades.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: When Spend a Buck won the Kentucky Derby last month, he did so from the No. 10 post position with the No. 9 on his saddlecloth. Why didn't the numbers correspond?

title: ROCK: PETTY IN CONCERT
description: CLASSIC rock and roll that extends and deepens traditions established in the 60's and early 70's may be a slowly vanishing breed of music. But its most dedicated practitioners continue to produce a guitar-based electric music that is a ruminative, visceral expression of populist feeling.

title: JAPANESE WOMEN SPEAK OUT ON NEW TV NEWS PROGRAMS
description: Two newscasts that are capturing the attention of Japanese viewers feature young women who freely air their own opinions. That's something uncommon among Japanese in general, let alone females, in this male-dominated society.

title: CROWD FLIPS OVER SUMO FINAL
description: Chiyonofuji, the grand champion, or yokozuna, of sumo wrestling, won the three-day sumo tournament yesterday afternoon in Madison Square Garden. It was the first official sumo tournament ever conducted in New York, and a crowd of some 14,000 cheered the wrestlers on.

title: HEADED SMALL-BUSINESS UNIT
description: Wendell B. Barnes, who saw the Small Business Administration through its infancy in the Eisenhower Administration, died of a heart attack Tuesday at a hospital near his home in Walnut Creek, Calif. He was 75 years old.

title: FIRST 100 DAYS OF GORBACHEV: A NEW START
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev may have had little or nothing to do with the recent release of the film ''Agoniya.''

title: U.S. SAYS IT HAS LITTLE INFORMATION ABOUT PASSENGERS TAKEN OFF JET
description: Administration officials said today that they had little information about the fate of at least 6 passengers who were reportedly removed from the hijacked Trans World Airline jet in Beirut on Saturday.

title: Mengele Investigators Return to Brazil Grave
description: Brazilian and West German police investigators returned today to the grave of a man believed to be Josef Mengele to search for missing bones and other evidence needed for a positive identification of the long-missing Nazi doctor who friends and family say drowned in 1979.

title: Blood Doping Is Banned
description: The United States Olympic Committee today unanimously passed a resolution outlawing the practice of ''blood doping.''

title: The Better to See With
description: Nine days ago, the Belmont Stakes was run for the 117th time, and that obscured an only slightly younger anniversary at the track. June 8 also was Cohen Johnston's 80th birthday and began his 67th year of renting and storing binoculars for everyone from railbirds to railroad barons at Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga.

title: 42D ST. PROPOSED TO BE 1-WAY TO CARS
description: The city's Transportation Department is proposing to make 42d Street a one-way, westbound thoroughfare for automobiles, with bus lanes in both directions, to expedite traffic for the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center on the West Side.

title: DESERTERS IN SWEDEN: AN ODD LITTLE 'V.F.W. POST'
description: One day a few years ago, as David Smith was driving the No. 52 bus here, a Swedish passenger and a Yugoslav immigrant got into an argument. The driver stopped the bus and tried to break it up.

title: CUBS STILL CAN'T PULL SWITCH TO NIGHT
description: CHICAGO

title: IN WEARY CRISIS ROOM, PHONES KEEP FLASHING
description: On the seventh floor of the State Department, in a large conference room around the corner from the Secretary's office, a dozen officials have kept a round-the-clock vigil on developments in the hijacking crisis.

title: Watch It, Conrail, Here Comes Norfolk Southern
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW SOWETO CLASH MARS OBSERVANCE OF 1976 UPRISING
description: Police and army units in armored vehicles used tear gas and rubber bullets in this vast and bleak township outside Johannesburg today to disperse thousands of black people commemorating the ninth anniversary of an uprising.

title: OUR ALLEGED U.N. FRIENDS
description: Now that Lieut. Gen. Vernon A. Walters has taken his seat as America's chief delegate at the United Nations, he will need to cast an eye over his shoulder. Many of our so-called friends there still get away with murder in the way they treat us.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They pushed and shoved me and had a grenade in front of my face and pushed me to the back.

title: Susan Lu Is Married To James G. Reichek
description: At Temple B'nai Or in Morristown, N.J., yesterday Susan Peng-Yu Lu, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Si-Ming Lu of Whippany, N.J., was married to James G. Reichek, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton A. Reichek of Parsippany, N.J. Rabbi Z. David Levy performed the ceremony.

title: Wheeler Putting Ads Into Middle of Traffic
description: By now, we all know the unwritten law in America that places free of advertising may not exist. It is not always easy to enforce this law, so sometimes foreign forces must be imported to help fill the void.

title: MAY CANCEL GAMES
description: Disappointed by the small attendance at their first three exhibition games this spring, such as tonight's crowd of 8,677 that saw a 2-1 loss to Lazio, the Cosmos will meet Monday to decide whether to continue the schedule of international matches.

title: Advanced Micro Slump Dooms Christmas Bash
description: Last Christmas, to celebrate what had been a stunning year, Walter J. Sanders 3d, chairman and chief executive of Advanced Micro Devices Inc., threw a $700,000 party for his employees. But with the semiconductor industry mired in what some analysts consider to be its worst slump ever, the lights will be out next December.

title: STUDENT DIED OF STOMACH WOUND
description: An autopsy yesterday found that the graduate of a preparatory school who was killed outside Morningside Park Wednesday night died as the result of a bullet wound to the stomach, according to the city's chief medical examiner.

title: CARDS BEAT CUBS FOR SWEEP
description: Tom Lawless drew a bases-loaded walk to force in one run and Ozzie Smith squeezed home another in the fourth inning today to lead the St. Louis Cardinals past the Chicago Cubs, 5-2, for a sweep of their three-game series.

title: AN 8 FOR CHEN TO REMEMBER
description: WITH two shots, Tze-Chung Chen went from the sublime to the ridiculous as no other golfer in the United States Open ever has.

title: AS HE SEEKS A 4TH TERM, MORGENTHAU CONFRONTS FIRST SUSTAINED CRITICISM
description: For Robert M. Morgenthau, it was an unusual way to spend an evening.

title: FLORIDA AIDES LURE FUGITIVES IN HIDING BY PROMISING GIFTS
description: Nearly 3,400 fugitives wanted for various crimes, including murder, rape, robbery and assault, were lured out of hiding by Federal and local law officers around Florida in a secret operation that promised free trips and other prizes, officials said today.

title: Chilean Military Lifts State of Siege
description: Chile's military Government said today it is lifting a seven-month state of siege and ending censorship.

title: THE CHURCH AND THE POOR
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops, who became strongly identified with nuclear disarmament through a pastoral letter two years ago, are now trying to take a similarly strong position on the issue of poverty in the United States.

title: SHOULD CAR MILEAGE LIMITS BE KEPT?
description: Ten years ago, when Congress imposed mileage standards on Detroit's automobile companies, the average American-made car could go 14.2 miles on a gallon of gasoline that cost 62.2 cents. Since then the price of gasoline has almost doubled. And if Detroit had met the mileage standards, fuel economy would have almost doubled, too.

title: HOSTAGES' LETTER TO REAGAN
description: Following is the text of a letter to President Reagan today said to come from American hostages on board from the hijacked T.W.A. plane at the Beirut airport. The handwritten letter says it was signed by 32 American passengers, but there were only 29 names on it.

title: DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM AT THE MET
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem is no stranger to miraculous-seeming victories in the face of struggle. But the company, founded in 1971 by Arthur Mitchell and Karel Shook to increase the nearly nonexistent black participation in American ballet, has had new reason for pride, as well as sorrow.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: MONDAY, JUNE 17, 1985

title: RELEASE OF SHIITES IS CALLED POSSIBLE
description: The Israeli Government would be willing to ''consider'' a request from the United States, if one is made, for Israel to free the more than 700 Lebanese Shiites it is holding in exchange for the American hostages being held on board the hijacked Trans World Airlines jetliner in Beirut, an Israeli source very close to the decision-making process here said late tonight.

title: Talks Continue On Sperry Deal
description: Merger talks continued over the weekend between the Sperry Corporation and the Burroughs Corporation and, although no announcement was issued, a Sperry spokesman said the two companies could release a statement today.

title: Sudan Aide Faces Trial
description: Oliver Battali Albino, who was sent home from Saudi Arabia and dismissed as Labor Minister here after Saudi authorities at the Jidda airport said they found a ''commercial quantity'' of pills in Mr. Albino's possession Thursday, will stand trial for trying to smuggle stimulant pills into Saudi Arabia.

title: New York's Life-and-Death Struggle
description: New Yorkers New York State has lacked a punishment for first-degree murder, and for years Republicans have blamed that gap in the law on bleeding-heart Democratic governors. Now it's a Democratic Governor's turn to blame the Republicans, and well he should.

title: BANKS TRIPLE JUMPS TO WORLD RECORD
description: Willie Banks, an extrovert who encourages spectators to clap when he triple jumps, gave them extra reason to clap tonight. He broke the world record by jumping 58 feet 11 1/2 inches.

title: ART: IN VIENNA FESTIVAL EXHIBITIONS, THE CITY'S GREAT, AND DARK, PAST
description: Great cities - and quite small towns, for that matter - are in the business of covering up at festival time. Salzburg forgets the Archbishop who was so odious to Mozart. Edinburgh forgets the martyrs who were hanged from poles in the 17th century. Bayreuth forgets the Nazis.

title: 'BUT WE HAVE NO CHOICE'
description: Following are excerpts from an exchange today between the pilot of the hijacked Trans World Airlines jetliner and the Beirut airport control tower as the plane returned here for a third time:

title: OUTDOORS: FISHING IN EUROPE WITH TIES TO THE PAST
description: MANY Americans will be going to Europe to find a time and place to fish this year. Their fishing may be rewarding.

title: 'MY SON'S GAY. THAT'S ALL RIGHT.'
description: In September 1981, my son Elliot, a singer and guitarist, wrote me: ''I don't want to keep this from you any longer. In case you wondered why I have been secretive and retreated from the family, I'm going to tell you: I am gay and have been all of my life.''

title: PAT BRADLEY WINS FIRST TITLE SINCE '83
description: Pat Bradley survived rain, two lightning delays and a late charge by Nancy Lopez today to score her first victory since 1983 by winning the $255,000 Rochester Invitational golf tournament.

title: JURORS IN RAPE TRIALS STUDIED
description: When jurors render a verdict in a rape trial, they often do so on the basis of the victim's demeanor, reputation, social life and appearance, according to a new study of jurors' attitudes.

title: No on Local Cops
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil Links Shoes to Debt
description: Brazil's Minister of External Relations, Olavo E. Setubal, told the United States on Friday that a curtailment of shoe imports, as recommended by the International Trade Commission, could make it ''increasingly difficult'' for Brazil to pay the interest on its $100 billion of foreign debt.

title: CHICAGO ACTOR ADJUSTS TO 'ORPHANS' DEMANDS
description: Kevin Anderson has not gotten to see a lot of New York since he arrived here from Chicago two months ago, and that is not only because of the tangle of hair that curls over his eyes. Most of his time is spent at the Westside Arts Theater on West 43d Street, where he is playing in ''Orphans,'' or at home, in a sublet Chelsea apartment, where he recovers from the exhausting role.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: DOING LAPS TOWARD KEMP PRESIDENTIAL CAMPAIGN
description: The Buckley name is usually associated with conservatism, Yale, erudition and novels. Now it is also linked to a Republican Congressman from Buffalo who wants to be President.

title: The Nazi Hunters Deserve to Be Remembered
description: To the Editor:

title: Encouraging Activism
description: A new public service ad campaign with world peace as its goal was unveiled over the weekend at a meeting in Atlanta of the Unitarian Universalist Peace Network. Davidoff & Partners of Fairfield, Conn., has contributed to the multimedia effort to encourage activism. The message on posters will be: ''Say Your Peace. Join. Write. Call. Talk. Meet. March. Vote. Nag. Scream.''

title: BRISK CORPORATE BOND SALES LIKELY
description: Treasury financing this week is confined to the bill market and a sale of two-year notes on Wednesday, but many investment bankers expect brisk activity in the corporate market as issuers take advantage of interest rates that are the lowest in five years.

title: ECONOMIC POLICIES ASSAILED IN KOREA
description: The South Korean Government is coming under fire for policies that some say have led to a marked slowdown in economic growth.

title: HOSTAGE'S FAMILY PRAYS AND BURIES HIS FATHER
description: As the family of the flight engineer on hijacked Trans World Airline Flight 847 gathered yesterday to pray for his safe release, it was also preparing to bury his father.

title: Minuteman Missiles Tested
description: Two unarmed Minuteman 3 test missiles were launched early today from the California coast, an Air Force spokesman said. After flights of about 30 minutes the unarmed warheads of the missiles were tracked to their targets in Kwajalein Missile Range 4,200 miles southwest of here, the spokesman said.

title: AT WORK: PROBLEMS OF COUPLES
description: FOR years it was dogma among corporate personnel executives that it was unwise to allow couples to work for the same company. The specter of nepotism, special favors to relatives, would create too much tension, it was argued.

title: MEETINGS ON BHOPAL RESUMING
description: As negotiations resume today on claims from last December's gas leak disaster in Bhopal, India, both sides are far apart on monetary damages, emergency relief for victims is uncertain and there are continuing disagreements among victims' lawyers, sources familiar with the case said.

title: A MULTITUDE OF WASHINGTONS
description: Sometimes the nation's capital takes itself so seriously that it seems there could be only one Washington in the United States, if not the whole universe.

title: Special Pitch
description: Al Goldis, the Eastern supervisor of scouting for the California Angels, got what he was looking for - 14 of the things he was looking for, as a matter of fact - in baseball's amateur draft a couple of weeks ago. It was Goldis who was responsible for that number of the Angels' 26 selections, including the big prize, the team's first-round pick, Willie Fraser.

title: AFTER FIRE, BROOKLYN CHURCH STARTS TO REBUILD
description: For the last seven months, the memories of the fire were so painful that Gwendolyn Simpson would not walk by the charred ruins of the historic Janes United Methodist Church.

title: GENERALS SQUANDER WALKER'S 209 YARDS
description: Herschel Walker added 209 rushing yards, escalating his season record to 2,338 with a game to go. But the Generals needed more Saturday night against the Oakland Invaders. The Generals lost, 34-29, in a game that was not as close as the score.

title: Jessica Anne Pressler Married in Englewood
description: Jessica Anne Pressler and Anthony K. Modafferi 3d were married yesterday at the home in Englewood, N.J., of the bride's parents, Judge Sylvia B. Pressler of the Appellate Division of the Superior Court in New Jersey and David A. Pressler. Rabbi H. Philip Berkowitz performed the ceremony.

title: Market Place;   I.B.M. Stock Still Favored
description: THE International Business Machines Corporation sent shivers through the stock market last Wednesday when it indicated that profits for the first nine months of 1985 would drop below results in the comparable period last year. It made investors wonder whether Big Blue was a good buy.

title: NEW BATTLES BREAK OUT IN BEIRUT
description: A pitched battle broke out today between Palestinians and Shiites in and around one of three besieged Palestinian settlements in southern Beirut. The latest fighting came within minutes of the return of the hijacked Trans World Airlines plane to the Beirut International Airport.

title: IRENE KITTLE KAMP, EDITOR WHO WROTE FOR STAGE AND FILMS
description: Irene Kittle Kamp, a screenwriter and playwright who had been an editor at magazines in New York, died of a heart attack Saturday at her Los Angeles home. She was 74 years old.

title: Cheese Pasteurization Not Faulted in Outbreak
description: Pasteurization was performed correctly at a plant that made a Mexican-style cheese linked to 29 deaths or stillbirths from a bacterial infection, a state health official said today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ON WRITING AND POLITICS, 1967-1983.

title: FOR AGED, PROBLEM DRINKING IS ON THE RISE
description: New research findings suggest that alcoholism among the elderly is a more serious problem than previously believed.

title: The Quiet Passings Of Three Little Shops
description: Above all else, this is a mercantile city. Often lost in the fortissimo of the big businesses, however, are the notes sounded by the small ones, the flutists who compete with the orchestra.

title: U.S. Ends Oil Export Ban
description: President Reagan on Friday lifted a ban on exporting United States crude oil to Canada, saying it would increase energy trade between the two countries without diminishing domestic oil supplies.

title: DOMESTIC VIOLENCE AND ITS HIGH COST
description: ''BATTERED Wives, Shattered Lives'' examines a truly important subject.

title: RANGERS WAITING FOR COACH AND DRAFTEE
description: The Rangers left here today with a Swedish center on their minds but without a coach in their hands.

title: Jane Bloom Is Married To Bruce Lovett Hertz
description: Jane Laura Bloom, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Bloom of Los Angeles, and Bruce Lovett Hertz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Hertz of Pompano Beach, Fla., were married yesterday. Rabbi Mark Z. Somerstein performed the ceremony at Le Chateau in South Salem, N.Y.

title: Italy's President Says He Won't Run Again
description: President Sandro Pertini of Italy said today that he would not run for re-election this month, the Quirinal Palace said.

title: ALUMNI OF A-BOMB PROJECT RECALL SECRECY, AND LITTLE THINGS
description: After 40 years, the memories of the men and women meeting here this weekend went back to little things.

title: ALBORETO WINS CANADIAN GRAD PRIX
description: Michele Alboreto of Italy beat his Ferrari teammate, Stefan Johansson of Sweden, by 1.957 seconds today to win the Labatt Canadian Grand Prix and take the Formula One driver lead.

title: Sharannpour Wins Another in Stretch
description: Sharannpour, who made a late move on a soft course to win the Red Smith Handicap 16 days ago, made an identical sretch run yesterday to win the $238,000 Bowling Green Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: The Kitchen Outfitter. . .
description: ''My motivation was to make some things that were exciting and beautiful,'' Esther Westby said. ''I think I was very successful.''

title: Football Over Ice
description: It may come as a surprise to learn that they play American-style football in Finland. It should not come as such a surprise to learn that they don't play it very well. Not yet anyway.

title: GUNMEN NEGOTIATE AS HOSTAGES URGE CAUTION FROM U.S.
description: The hijackers of a Trans World Airlines jetliner forced it yesterday to fly for a third time to Beirut, Lebanon, where negotiations began on the release of more than 30 hostages on the plane and up to 10 more who had been spirited away to an unknown location.

title: COACHING OF AGCA IN ITALY CHARGED
description: A major organized crime figure who turned state's evidence in Italy has said that Mehmet Ali Agca, the convicted assailant of Pope John Paul II, was coached in prison by the Italian secret services to say that the shooting of the Pope in 1981 was commissioned by the Bulgarian security service, and thus, the Soviet Union.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 17, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Subcommittee on Petitions - 10:30 A.M.

title: FREED PASSENGER RECOUNTS BEATING
description: An Australian girl freed by the hijackers of a T.W.A. jet described today how the gunmen assaulted an American serviceman before killing him, kicking him over and over until ''they had broken all his ribs.''

title: TAX IS OUT, WILDLIFE IN, GUNS BLAZE
description: When the Tennessee General Assembly voted last year for a new tax on amusement and entertainment events, the people who run county fairs in the state were aghast.

title: FOR CUBAN-CHINESE, THE TWAIN MEET
description: The Loos speak Spanish, Chinese and English at home, celebrate the Chinese New Year and listen to Latin music. Jesus Loo usually eats Chinese vegetables and fish, while his wife and children prefer beefsteak, fried plantain and black beans.

title: Centel Changes Involve Ex-Apollo Astronaut
description: John P. Frazee Jr. has been named vice chairman of the Centel Corporation. He steps into the newly created post behind Robert P. Reuss, Centel's 67-year-old chairman and chief executive officer. Succeeding the 40-year-old Mr. Frazee as president of Centel Communications is James A. Lovell Jr., a former astronaut and an executive vice president of the parent. Mr. Lovell, 57, will retain the latter post as well. Mr. Frazee and Mr. Lovell have also been added to Centel's board of directors.

title: Open Roads Calling
description: It's enough to make a warren-rooted bureaucrat cry or at least press his nose longingly against the office window. There is an anthropologist in town, Matt T. Salo, studying a most enviably liberated group of Americans, those who have ''the freedom to choose when and where to work and live.'' They are the Roms, the Romnichels, the Ludars, the main brances of American gypsies whom he has tracked in field and at crossroad and now is documenting through Federal archives under a study grant provided by the Smithsonian Institution. Dr. Salo will give a Smithsonian lecture on his wanderings next month, attempting to explain why the stigmatized gypsy group seems able to avoid such modern ills as poverty and family breakdown, not to mention office boredom.

title: Orren B. Weisberg Weds Harry S. Falk in Princeton
description: The marriage of Orren Beth Weisberg and Harry Stephen Falk, both members of the class of '86 at the Brooklyn Law School, took place yesterday at the Hyatt Regency in Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Edward Feldheim performed the ceremony.

title: CUOMO ASSAILS REAGAN POLICY
description: Governor Cuomo said today that the Reagan Administration had created a government of ''shrunken aspirations,'' and he urged graduates of Stanford University to use their political power to build a ''real shining city on a hill with room for everyone.''

title: Washington Watch;   Rostenkowski Stand on Trade
description: WHEN Dan Rostenkowski speaks out on trade issues, people listen. One reason is that he rarely addresses the subject publicly. Another is that he is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, which handles most trade legislation and is now inundated with protectionist bills.

title: 2 Airlines' Passengers Get Guides From Taff
description: Thomas A. Fadrhonc, born in the Netherlands of Czech parents, came to this country a decade ago at age 23 to get a graduate degree. He was bitten by the entrepreneurial bug at one of his first three employers - SmithKline & French; Needham, Harper & Steers or Trans World Airlines.

title: Needham Unit Buying Public Relations Board
description: Needham Porter Novelli, the Washington-based public relations subsidiary of Needham Harper & Steers, announced Friday that it is completing negotiations to acquire the Public Relations Board in Chicago.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Cubs, at Shea Stadium, 8:05 P.M. This is the first of a four-game series and the first meeting of the season between the two teams. The Mets have slumped and are now chasing not just the Cubs, but the Expos as well. (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. Orioles, at Baltimore. Billy Martin meets up with his old nemesis, Earl Weaver, as the Yankees meet the Orioles for the first time this season. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 7:30 P.M.) Football Gamblers vs. San Antonio Gunslingers, at Houston. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.) Harness Racing The Meadowlands, 8 P.M. The $135,000 Statue of Liberty Invitational Trot kicks off the Grand Circuit Historic Track weeklong series that was originally run at Goshen, N.Y. Proceeds will go to the reconstruction of the Statue of Liberty. In the field of 12 from 9 countries is Meadow Road of Sweden, the early 3-1 favorite. The Acorn Trot for 2-year-old fillies drew 33 candidates and has been split into three divisions, each worth $58,470. (Television - MSG Network, 12:40 A.M.) Yonkers, 8 P.M. Closing night. Roosevelt in Westbury, L.I., reopens tomorrow night. Tennis Eastern Clay Court Championships for Women, at Orienta Beach Club, Mamaroneck, N.Y., 10 A.M. Opening round singles. Alissa Finerman from Scarsdale, N.Y., the winner of last week's New York State Championships for women, is the top-seeded player in this tournament.

title: Bridge: Revelations Come Gradually During the Course of a Game
description: Any bridge deal can be regarded as a journey of discovery. You know 13 cards at the start and in the bidding learn something about the other hands. Your stock of information makes a quantum jump when the dummy appears, and you then find out more and more until the complete distribution of 52 cards is revealed.

title: How to Find Western Water: Sell It
description: The desert cities of the American Southwest face a dry future. Developing new water resources costs more every year, yet the Federal Government is increasingly unwilling to foot the bill. Happily, the Environmental Defense Fund has devised a way out of the dilemma: give irrigation authorities a chance to profit from conservation of surplus water. At least one big irrigation authority wants to try. What's needed now is Federal encouragement. Arid southern California is running out of water. Things will get even worse at the end of the decade when the Central Arizona Project is finished, permitting Arizona to divert enough water from the Colorado River to support the entire city of San Diego.

title: WORDS OF GOD AND EVIL
description: A quarter of a million people gathered in Paris Saturday night to hear a rock concert dedicated to opposing racism in France.

title: PAUSE URGED IN SHIPMENTS TO ETHIOPIA
description: United Nations officials in Ethiopia have advised Western nations not to send new shipments of food to this country until more of the supplies now in ports and warehouses have been moved to relief centers.

title: Leah Rosovsky Becomes a Bride
description: Leah Rosovsky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Rosovsky of Newton, Mass., and David Spindler McIntosh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius A. McIntosh of Middletown, Ohio, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. Rabbi Neil Kaminsky performed the ceremony.

title: GOLDMAN'S RISE IN REAL ESTATE
description: In January 1983, John Whitehead, then the co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, was puzzled over the lack of progress in his firm's real estate business, recalls Martin Bucksbaum, one of the country's major shopping center developers.

title: Loan Guarantee for Chile
description: Clyde H. Farnsworth

title: SAUDIS CITE LOW MAY OIL OUTPUT
description: Saudi Arabia's crude oil production in May fell even lower than rumored and caused the country to suffer a severe shortfall in both oil revenues and natural gas supplies, Saudi Arabia's oil minister said in an interview being published today in an oil industry newsletter.

title: Stephen Bruce Young Wed To Anne Rachel Schulson
description: At Congregation Shearith Israel in New York yesterday Anne Rachel Schulson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman A. Schulson of New York, was married to Stephen Bruce Young, the son of Mrs. Richard S. Young of Swampscott, Mass., and the late Mr. Young.

title: MAJOR QUAKE NEAR INDIAN POINT IS CALLED UNLIKELY
description: Measurements of geologic stress near the Ramapo Fault, which passes close to the Indian Point nuclear reactors at Buchanan, N.Y., indicate that the fault is unlikely to cause a major earthquake, geologists report.

title: FOR PASSENGERS IN ALGIERS, PRAYERS AND TEARS
description: ''Lord hear our prayer,'' murmured the little circle of Americans, meeting this morning in the lobby of a strange hotel in a city few had ever expected to see. Some were sobbing, and others had their arms around each other.

title: OPERA: 'IDOMENEO' BY MOZART, IN ST. LOUIS
description: If the Opera Theater of St. Louis had done nothing else of worth this year, reminding us of Mozart's ''Idomeneo'' and its splendors would have been enough.

title: John Y. Brown Sr., 85; Father of Ex-Governor
description: John Y. Brown Sr., a prominent defense attorney and father of former Gov. John Y. Brown Jr. of Kentucky, died of pneumonia today at Humana Hospital Audubon, where he had been treated since June 5. He was 85 years old and had been paralyzed from the waist down since he was hurt in an automobile accident in December.

title: Topics;   Pet Projects Marine Motorists
description: For New Jersey commuters to New York, who now brave 35-minute tunnel delays or packed PATH cars, there's good news and no news.

title: NICARAGUA SET TO SIGN DEBT PAYMENT ACCORD
description: The Government of Nicaragua is scheduled to sign an agreement today in New York with its commercial bank creditors from around the world. The pact would give Managua more time to pay back its debts, and as a sign of good faith the Government said it would make a payment of $3 million today to its creditors.

title: Afghan Rebels Report 140 Killed in Bomb Blast
description: About 140 people were killed when a bomb planted by Afghan rebels wrecked a large building in Mazar-i-Sharif in northern Afghanistan, guerrilla sources said today.

title: HIJACKERS TOOK AWAY PASSENGERS WITH JEWISH NAMES, PURSER SAYS
description: The purser of the hijacked Trans World Airlines plane said last night that the gunmen who commandeered the jetliner ordered her to collect passengers' passports and give them those passports with Jewish-sounding names, but that she did not single out any names.

title: JONATI MAVOA
description: Fiji's Minister of Foreign Affairs and Tourism, Jonati Mavoa, died in New Zealand today after a fall on Friday night that left him unconscious. Mr. Mavoa, 65 years old, had served in several ministerial posts since 1967 and was among the legislators who took part in the constitutional conference leading to Fiji's independence in 1970.

title: Advertising;   Harrah's Gambling On TV Ads
description: ''GAMBLING'S fun if not somewhat anxiety-filled,'' said George Lois, who could have been talking about the ad agency business. But he wasn't, because on Friday morning the chairman of Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK, in the company of Richard Gershon and Dale Pon, had his mind very much on gambling and their new client - Harrah's Marina in Atlantic City. Its multimedia advertising campaign starts today in New York and Philadelphia.

title: Brain-Death Definition Is Urgently Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Neighbors of Radicals Face Stress After Fire
description: Neighbors of the radical group Move who endured months of tension and a day of horror have handled the emotional stress well, but they may face psychological problems in the future, mental health officials say.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * ADAC Laboratories, San Jose, Calif., has named Johan F. Blocker president and chief executive officer.

title: Taking Notes to Europe
description: Soon after he learned that he was being designated Ambassador to the European Common Market, J. William Middendorf 2d, the millionaire diplomat and closet orchestral composer, heard something special in the air, a variation on ''Ode to Joy,'' he humbly recalls. He began writing it down. The result is ''Overture for a United Europe,'' a symphonic piece ready for downbeat once he arrives in Brussels. Mr. Middendorf has written dozens of concertos, marches and symphonies to mark various facets of Government service, including ''The Lollipop March.''

title: Topics;   Pet Projects Customer Service
description: Owners of dogs and cats are apt to complain to their friends about them. ''Melanie's so neurotic,'' they say. ''Fifi's so fussy.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, JUNE 17, 1985

title: LOBBYISTS FOR THE ARTS MAPPING A NEW ALBANY STRATEGY
description: When Nelson A. Rockefeller was Governor of New York the arts world did not need an Albany lobbyist. The Governor translated his cultural enthusiasms into wads of governmental money.

title: HOSPITAL STRIKE IN BROOKLYN INCREASES WORK FOR DOCTORS
description: The 12-day walkout by interns and residents at the Interfaith Medical Center in Brooklyn has forced nonstriking physicians to work longer hours than usual, but state health officials say they have found no faults in medical care.

title: The Big Cold Lure
description: The capital is a press agent's dream, and there is no end to the attempts to lure members of Congress into the role of patriotic, parochial shills. This week, the International Association of Ice Cream Makers is returning to town and reaching beyond Abscam tolerances to dispense 2,500 gallons of free ice cream under the very noses of the legislatorsand their staffs in the courtyard of the Russell Office Building on Capitol Hill.

title: Catching Up
description: When the Mets finally gave up on Tim Leary and traded him to Milwaukee last winter, General Manager Frank Cashen continued to describe him as ''a pitcher with unlimited promise.'' Unlimited, and also unfulfilled.

title: 20 DOWNHILL YEARS
description: The more you study the wealth of statistics and analyses now available on recent American elections, the more one particular conclusion seems warranted - that the Republican Party has virtually claimed the Presidency as its own, winning it in four of the last five elections - three times by landslides -and in 6 of 10 since World War II.

title: EQUION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After tax credits of $436,419 for the quarter and $2,286,007 for the nine months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $195,305 for the quarter and $518,381 for the nine months and tax credits of $686,566 for the quarter and $1,397,051 for the nine months.

title: UNITED AIRLINES SET TO BUY HERTZ FROM RCA IN $587 MILLION DEAL
description: UAL Inc., the owner of United Airlines, agreed yesterday to buy the Hertz Corporation, the world's biggest car-rental company.

title: THEORY OF PYRAMID STAR DIMS
description: SCIENTISTS have always scoffed at the supernatural qualities sometimes ascribed to the Great Pyramid at Giza, but many have accepted the notion that a sophisticated knowledge of astronomy guided the Egyptians in building it. It turns out, however, that even that belief is probably a myth.

title: Gamblers Clinch Berth in Playoffs
description: Todd Dillon passed for four touchdowns and ran for another as the Houston Gamblers clinched a United States Football League playoff spot with a 49-21 victory over the San Antonio Gunslingers tonight.

title: RIGHT AND LEFT, FRENCH POLITICS IS TURNING CHURLISH
description: The image most commonly displayed on the front pages of newspapers here these days shows three middle-aged political leaders - a former President and two former Prime Ministers - standing shoulder to shoulder, their mouths open as they sing the stirring strains of ''Marseillaise,'' France's national anthem.

title: WILLIAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The share earnings for 1984 have been adjusted to reflect a 6 percent stock dividend paid Aug. 31, 1984.

title: DEAL PROVIDES MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES
description: For UAL Inc. the acquisition of the Hertz Corporation is the latest in a series of transactions aimed at making it a more formidable travel company.

title: Congress;   A Wildcatter Drills for Power
description: In early 1981, when Dave McCurdy was a newly minted member of Congress, he went to the White House with a group of senior colleagues to discuss the budget with President Reagan. The Oklahoma Democrat recalls his surprise when the other lawmakers just listened respectfully and declined to ask the President any tough questions.

title: POWER TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Reflects a loss of $494,000 by Power Test Realty Co. c-Net loss.

title: HIGH COURT CLOSES RELIGION CASE WITH A TIE VOTE
description: The Supreme Court brought an inconclusive end today to one of the religion cases on its docket, while accepting two similar cases for the term beginning next fall.

title: NEW CENTURY PRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
600 BURIALS ARE DELAYED AT 10 STRUCK CEMETERIES
description: More than 600 unburied bodies have accumulated at 10 New York metropolitan cemeteries since a cemetery workers strike began May 11, a state official said yesterday.

title: CAMBRIAN SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
The Hostage Tangle
description: We hope we're wrong, but it looks as if it will take time to free the last 43 of the hijacked Trans World Airlines passengers, now held somewhere in Beirut. They have become the prisoners of powerful interests in three societies. President Reagan's effectiveness in arranging their release depends on how well he can resist impatient demands for force or hasty resort to ransom.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Alliance Capital Management Corp. said Lawrence S. Harris would join the company as senior vice president and head of its Fixed Income Group.

title: Safety Code Sought
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India called today for a ''well-defined code of conduct'' for multinational corporations to prevent industrial accidents such as the one at Bhopal, India, last year in which more than 2,000 people were killed when poison gas leaked from a Union Carbide plant. He made his remarks at the annual conference of the International Labor Organization.

title: EWING MEETS AN OLD HERO
description: Pro basketball's present met its future for the first time yesterday morning when Kareem Abdul-Jabbar reached out to shake the hand of Patrick Ewing as the two crossed paths at the Grand Hyatt Hotel.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article June 4 about groups petitioning the Federal Communications Commission to deny Ted Turner's bid to take over CBS incorrectly included one group. The American Legal Foundation filed comments with the commission supporting the takeover bid.

title: 4 Phone Units Ask Inquiry
description: Four small competitors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked the Federal Communications Commission today to investigate a series of ''issues'' they contend are ''threatening to prevent a successful transition'' to competition in the long-distance business.

title: LESTER EUGENE DENONN
description: Lester Eugene Denonn, a Manhattan lawyer for 45 years and a scholar of philosophy, died June 12 at New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital in Manhattan.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A Washington dispatch on page 1 Sunday reported that a letter to The New York Times by Patrick J. Buchanan, the White House director of communications, criticized Governor Cuomo for his position on President Reagan's tax program. Mr. Buchanan gave the letter to a Times reporter with the understanding that it could be used as the basis for a news article. The article should have explained the circumstances under which Mr. Buchanan made the letter available. Letters addressed to The Times that contain news are sometimes used as the basis of articles rather than published in the columns of the editorial page devoted to letters to the editor. Page D1

title: GOALS KEEP BANKS JUMPING
description: Last summer's Los Angeles Olympic Games should have provided wonderful moments for Willie Banks. They were being held in the city where he lived. His family and friends were there to see him win the triple jump, and he was the favorite.

title: L.I. Man Charged In Tax-Fraud Case
description: A Long Island accountant was charged yesterday with 53 counts of mail fraud in connection with the filing of false New York State sales tax returns by operators of gasoline stations in the metropolitan area, according to Federal officials.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 18, 1985

title: PAPAL TRIAL IN ROME MAY CALL RACKETEER
description: A court here today put off a decision on whether to question a confessed racketeer about his assertion that members of the Italian secret service, working with organized crime leaders, prodded the Turkish gunman who shot Pope John Paul II into implicating Bulgaria and the Soviet Union in the shooting.

title: WEAVER LOSES IN BIG WAY
description: When Earl Weaver announced his decision to return as manager of the Orioles last Thursday, he conceded that, for all his baseball experience, the toughest adjustment would be catching up with changing times.

title: SATELLITE ORBITED
description: The crew of the space shuttle Discovery roared into orbit today to help develop arms for President Reagan's proposed shield against nuclear missiles, to launch satellites and to perform a variety of experiments.

title: Sharing the No. 1 Spot
description: Chris Evert Lloyd and Martina Navratilova were jointly named the No. 1-seeded players today for the All-England Tennis Championships next week, the first time in the 63-year history of seedings at Wimbledon that organizers were unable to designate a pre-tournament favorite.

title: AMCAST INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
NOTES ON FASHIONS
description: WILLI SMITH introduced his very first collection of accessories last week at an informal breakfast in his showroom. Models wrapped themselves in headbands, multiple scarves and belts, snapped on button earrings and tossed bags over their shoulders. But the designer doesn't expect anyone to wear all the accessories at one time. His idea is just the opposite. ''I wanted to do something simple but still fun,'' he said. ''I can never find anything to accessorize my clothes. Things are either too overdesigned or too precious for my taste.''

title: PIVOTAL FIGURE IN THE BEIRUT CRISIS: NABIH BERRI
description: His sudden propulsion into the vortex of the hijacking drama has confirmed what Beirut watchers have known all along - that Nabih Berri, a soft-spoken, mild-mannered, 46-year-old lawyer is perhaps the most powerful man in Lebanon.

title: POWERFUL NEW DATA BASE SOFTWARE
description: THIS seems to be the year when data bases are really coming into their own in personal computing. Ease of use and more flexibility are being built into many of the programs.

title: Goodrich Sets Announcement
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company said yesterday that it planned a ''significant'' announcement today, and some reports speculated that it might be planning to take a big write-off in connection with its polyvinyl chloride operations.

title: Hughes Employee Enters Guilty Plea
description: A former Hughes Aircraft employee, one of 10 southern California aerospace employees arrested in April for receiving kickbacks in the awarding of Defense Department subcontracts, pleaded guilty today in Federal District Court.

title: IRAN'S HOTAGES: WORRISOME PARALLELS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they hoped to prevent the plane hijacking from turning into ''another Iran,'' a hostage crisis that proved embarrassing for the United States.

title: Hitler Remark on Armenians Reported in '39
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM MARKS ITS 10TH
description: ''It's like going to the graduation of your first child,'' said Cicely Tyson last night. ''I'm so very, very proud.''

title: FORCED RETIRING AT 60 BARRED
description: The Supreme Court, in a decision with broad implications for the enforcement of the Federal law against age discrimination in employment, ruled today that airlines may not force flight engineers to retire at age 60. The vote was 8 to 0.

title: RESEARCH SUCCESS MARKS RECENT DAYS FOR 'STAR WARS'
description: If a beam of green laser light flashes up from Hawaii to the space shuttle Discovery as scheduled on Wednesday, it will be the most prominent experiment yet conducted as part of President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative program to develop a defensive shield against nuclear missile attacks.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS WARY AS MILITARY BILL COMES UP
description: As the House prepares to debate the military program bill this week, Democrats are walking a fine political line, seeking to convince voters that they are strong on defense but tough on wasteful military contractors.

title: Jackson Hopes to Aid In Freeing Hostages
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said here today that he was working to see if he could help win the release of the hostages in Beirut.

title: Sinclair to Sell British Unit
description: The British newspaper owner Robert Maxwell disclosed today that he had agreed to take over the home computer company of the British inventor Sir Clive Sinclair in a deal valued at about $15.2 million.

title: NERO EMERGES AS RUTHLESS BUT LESS BAFFLING
description: THE young Emperor Nero became known as one of the worst Roman rulers by ordering his mother's death, persecuting Christians and Jews and committing other cruel and bizarre deeds. And, of course, it has also been suggested that he even gave a musical recital, with himself as sole performer, while Rome was ablaze with a fire he had caused.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bob Shirley, who escaped the bullpen to become the Yankees' stopper last week, yesterday became the first pitcher this year to be named Player of the Week by the American League. Shirley (2-1) won both of his starts last week, allowing only two earned runs and 10 hits in 15 Y innings. . . . Jim Lynam, the former head coach of the Los Angeles Clippers, has been hired by the Philadelphia 76ers as an assistant coach. . . . Kevin MacConnell, a spokesman for the Atlantic 10 Conference, said the conference had voted to do away with the three-point field goal in basketball. . . . Cliff Johnson, designated hitter for the Texas Rangers, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right knee yesterday to remove cartilage and to smooth rough edges on the kneecap.

title: Moody's Cuts ITT's Rating
description: The senior debt and subordinated debt rating of the ITT Corporation, affecting $1.3 billion in debt securities, has been lowered by Moody's Investors Service, it was announced yesterday.

title: SKYLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and year's earnings include a gain of $66,000 on the sale of a facility. The prior year earnings include a gain of $579,000 from the sale of a facility.

title: Crocker Bank Case Appealed
description: The Crocker National Corporation said that two shareholders had filed an appeal with the Delaware Supreme Court seeking to reverse a settlement of shareholder litigation against Crocker and Britain's Midland Bank, which recently acquired Crocker.

title: NATIONAL ISSUES COMPLICATE NEW YORK HOTEL STRIKE TALKS
description: Some of the issues remaining in the New York City hotel strike involve difficult money matters, but labor experts say others involve a national labor-relations climate in which industries are changing and corporations are seeking to gain strength against unions.

title: There Is a Better Way to Tax Life Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 in Stewart Case Aid in Arrest
description: Two transit police officers on trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan in connection with the death of Michael Stewart helped capture a suspected purse-snatcher during a luncheon recess yesterday, the police said.

title: BETTER CLEARANCE STEPS NOT ENOUGH, EXPERTS HINT
description: The General Accounting Office told Congress today that improved security clearance techniques would probably not have uncovered the spy ring the Government says was run by John A. Walker Jr. ''Looking at all the usual indicators - drug abuse, alcoholism, financial -they probably wouldn't have been detected,'' said Bill W. Thurman, deputy director of the G.A.O.'s national security division. Mr. Walker, his son, Michael, his brother Arthur, and a longtime friend, Jerry A. Whitworth, all now or formerly in the Navy, have been accused of smuggling secret documents to the Russians. All had clearance to handle such documents.

title: Barnaby Comic Strips To Be in Book Form
description: Barnaby, Mr. O'Malley, Gus the Ghost and Gorgon the talking dog -all characters from the syndicated ''Barnaby'' comic strip originated by Crockett Johnson - are scheduled to return to paperback book form in November, when Ballantine Books publishes 2 of a scheduled 12 titles.

title: Hutton Fills Post Of Treasury Chief
description: E.F. Hutton & Company said yesterday that Paul J. Beehler, an independent cash management expert and consultant, had been named senior vice president for treasury operations.

title: CULLINET SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Jan. 21.

title: Lawyer Is Slain In Harlem Office
description: A man burst into a Harlem law office yesterday afternoon and opened fire with a handgun, killing a 76-year-old lawyer who was conferring with a client.

title: FOGERTY AND TURNER IN TWO MUSIC SPECIALS
description: IN its search for original material to supplement movie schedules, pay-cable has been notably successful with music specials covering everybody from Elvis Presley to Elton John. Tops among the current crop are Showtime's ''John Fogerty's All Stars'' and Home Box Office's ''Tina Turner: Private Dancer.''

title: BURROUGHS AND SPERRY END TALKS
description: Merger talks between the Burroughs Corporation and the Sperry Corporation were called off yesterday after Sperry said it wanted more time to consider Burroughs's offer.

title: AN ART HISTORIAN AND AUTHOR
description: Patrick J. Kelleher, an art historian, teacher, author and former director of the Princeton University Art Museum, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Princeton. He was 67 years old.

title: Hoping for a Miracle
description: Jack Lambert, the Pittsburgh Steelers linebacker, says it is premature to consider retirement, but admits it will take ''a miracle'' to return for his 12th season in the National Football League. ''I figure if I'm good this week and behave myself, maybe I'll get rewarded and get it,'' said Lambert, who will be 33 in July.

title: 'Singin' Re-delays Opening
description: The opening of the Broadway musical ''Singin' in the Rain,'' scheduled for Thursday, has been postponed a second time. ''We are going to put changes in and rehearse until it's ready to open,'' said Maurice Rosenfield, a producer.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He wanted to live in the greatest country in the world and take advantage of all its freedom, but he didn't want to be loyal to it.

title: Absolution for $7.50
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CROSSTOWN There are any number of ways to look at 42d Street. One way is to look at the famous main stem itself.
