Another is to go into the mall of City University Graduate Center, at 33 West 42d Street, and enjoy an artistic representation of the thoroughfare from First to Eleventh Avenues.

title: Newfound Indian Art To Join Exhibition
description: Two sculptural pillars and three crossbars dating from the first to the fifth centuries A.D. will be added to an exhibition of art from India at the National Gallery of Art in Washington today.

title: TERAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Earl, Billy and the Gangs
description: You gotta have heart, and wheels, if you live in Washington and want to see the Yankees play baseball in person. Washington hasn't had major league baseball since 1972, so fans must travel to Baltimore, or farther, to attend a game. The Baltimore Orioles run special buses to Baltimore, and a ticket office in the capital is promoting this week's Yankee-Oriole series with a carefully nonpartisan slogan: ''See Earl vs. Billy.''

title: Gates Learjet President Quits
description: Bermar S. Stillwell has resigned as president and chief operating officer of the Gates Learjet Corporation and James B. Taylor has been elected to replace him, the company announced today.

title: Alois Mertes Is Dead at 63; Bonn Foreign Ministry Aide
description: Alois Mertes, a Minister of State in the West German Foreign Ministry who favored close relations with the United States, died of a stroke on Sunday, a Ministry spokesman said. He was 63 years old.

title: A FAMOUS FORTUNE ENTAGLES FAMILY IN A BITTER FIGHT OVER BEQUEST
description: At the time of their marriage in 1971, J. Seward Johnson and his third wife, Barbara Piasecka, were by any standard the unlikeliest of couples.

title: 30th Death Held Linked To Contaminated Cheese
description: County officials reported another death today in an outbreak linked to bacteria-contaminated cheese, bringing the toll to 30.

title: Aid and Sanctimony Do Not Mix
description: Hungry Africa may be hungrier because of a quarrel between the United States and a dozen members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. At issue is which should contribute how much to the valuable International Fund for Agricultural Development. All agree that the fund significantly helps small farmers, especially in Africa, where it spends nearly half its budget. The Administration approves the program but is seriously thinking about withholding support if OPEC countries don't contribute more.

title: WALKER BROTHER AND CALIFORNIA MAN INDICTED ON ESPIONAGE CHARGES
description: A Federal grand jury charged today that Jerry A. Whitworth, a retired Navy enlisted man, was paid more than $328,000 over six years to sell secrets to the Soviet Union.

title: Reagan's Conference To Be on TV Today
description: President Reagan's news conference will be broadcast live at 8 P.M., Eastern daylight time, on the CBS, NBC and ABC television networks, and on CNN, the Cable News Network. In addition, some local affiliates of PBS may carry the half-hour address, either live or as a taped-delayed broadcast. In New York City, for example, WNET/Channel 13 will broadcast the news conference at 11 P.M.

title: SLAIN PASSENGER WAS A NAVY DIVER
description: The passenger killed by the hijackers in Beirut on Saturday was identified today as Robert Dean Stethem, a 23-year-old Navy diver whose home was in Waldorf, Md.

title: DATAPOWER INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $258,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net income

title: Dow Declines 2.57 as Trading Slows
description: Oil stocks teamed up with technology issues to push the stock market lower yesterday in the slowest session since April.

title: SANDINISTAS SEIZE LAND OF A CRITIC
description: The Nicaraguan Government has confiscated properties belonging to one of its most outspoken critics, Enrique Bolanos Geyer, president of the country's principal business federation.

title: KETTLE RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: MEXICO CUTS A KEY OIL PRICE
description: Mexico, a key ally of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, reduced the price of its heavy crude oil yesterday by $1.50 a barrel, to $24.

title: GENERAL AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-Reflects a loss of $50,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. c-After a tax credit of $80,000.

title: HBO FILM CALLED UNFAIR TO FORMER CBS OFFICIAL
description: A Home Box Office docudrama about the broadcasting career of Edward R. Murrow, a CBS News correspondent from the 1930's to the 60's, has drawn criticism from current and former officials of CBS News about the portrayal of Dr. Frank Stanton, CBS's former president.

title: High Cost of Theater
description: To the Editor:

title: EAGLE-PICHER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Rush-Order Dispatches
description: You might call Rickey Parkey a young man in a hurry. And if you did, you wouldn't get an argument from anybody who has seen him in action during the last six months.

title: THERE IS A BETTER WAY TO TAX LIFE INSURANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: John H. Tinker Jr., 79, Advertising Executive
description: John H. Tinker Jr., an advertising executive who created advertisements for clients ranging from the Ford Motor Company and its Model A to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and his 1966 re-election campaign, died Friday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 79 years old.

title: President to Be Chief At White Consolidated
description: White Consolidated Industries yesterday named Ward Smith, president and chief operating officer, to succeed Roy H. Holdt, chief executive officer since 1976, when he retires at the end of the year.

title: Capacity Use Down By 0.4%
description: The nation's factories operated at 80.3 percent of capacity in May, down four-tenths of a percentage point from April and the fifth decline in the last six months, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: Rates Floating On Citicorp Notes
description: The Citicorp Banking Corporation, a unit of Citicorp, is issuing $250 million of 12-year, floating-rate notes on the Eurobond market through underwriters led by the Citicorp Investment Bank, previously Citibank International Bank Ltd.

title: Harry H. Platt Is Dead at 83; Lawyer and Labor Arbitrator
description: Harry H. Platt, a lawyer and labor arbitrator who decided the landmark case on residency requirements for Detroit police officers, died Saturday in Oakland, Calif. He was 83 years old and had recently moved to California from the Detroit area.

title: DO 'WHAT IT TAKES' FOR HOSTAGES, A FREED PASSENGER URGES REAGAN
description: An American hostage freed from the hijacked Trans World Airlines jetliner in Beirut for medical reasons arrived here today, exhausted and grim, and urged that President Reagan do ''ever what it takes'' to free the remaining passengers.

title: MEDICAL ELECTRONICS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: ARMAND HAMMER HAS MEETING WITH GORBACHEV
description: Armand Hammer, the industrialist, said today after a meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev that negotiations were under way on the time and place of a meeting with President Reagan.

title: Goldmark to Join Newspaper Group
description: Peter C. Goldmark Jr., the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, who announced last year that he intended to leave the post, will become a corporate vice president with the Times-Mirror Company in August.

title: MACPHAIL DEFENDS PAY PLAN
description: Before proposing the average payroll plan that the players flatly rejected last week, negotiators for baseball's club owners considered other salary plans but rejected them as ''too inflexible and too radical,'' the negotiators disclosed yesterday. The most developed of those plans, they said, centered on a series of salary ranges based on major league service.

title: THE CROOKS ARE IN CHARGE
description: We nurture a belief in this country that government and powerful private institutions can right almost any wrong. But in the corrupt construction industry in New York - especially Manhattan, where billions of dollars are at stake - it is a fantasy, an illusion. The crooks are in charge and no one is willing to take them on.

title: Jobs Found In Racing Industry
description: HORSE RACING is big business in the United States and Canada. The betting at tracks totaled about $8.1 billion in 1984, up from $5.27 billion 10 years earlier, according to Christopher N. Scherf, director of the service bureau of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations, Lake Success, L.I.

title: Tenneco
description: Tenneco Inc. said it plans to announce a ''major acquisition'' at a news conference today.

title: Seat Belts and Pedestrians
description: Statistical evidence indicates that seat belts save the lives of many drivers and front-seat passengers. But a recent survey of automobile accidents in Britain suggests that drivers who wear seat belts may represent a new menace to pedestrians and bicyclists.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: COLLECTED LETTERS 1911-1925. By Bernard Shaw. Edited by Dan H. Laurence. 989 pages. Illustrated. Viking. $45. GEORGE Bernard Shaw was generally careful with his money, but not where postage stamps were concerned; in the course of his career he must have laid out - in today's terms -something like $50,000 on them. For three-quarters of a century letters streamed from his pen or typewriter at the average rate of 10 a day, and ''Collected Letters'' is very much a misnomer (though a pardonable one) for the splendid selection of his correspondence that Dan H. Laurence has been editing over the past 30 years. The latest volume, the third of what will eventually be four, contains nearly 600 letters, some of them the length of moderate-sized pamphlets; it probably represents not much more than a hundredth part of his epistolary output during the period it covers.

title: Gallstones and 'Senility'
description: Gallstones can cause mental confusion and physical deterioration in elderly people that is commonly mistaken for senility, British researchers have found. The team, from Freeman Hospital in Newcastle-upon-Tyne, studied six patients in their 80's who were hospitalized because of serious physical or mental deterioration in recent weeks or months.

title: Out-of-Town Officers Call In Sick More
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW LIFE FOR BRITAIN'S MOVIE HOUSES
description: How can you get people back into movie theaters after they've settled down with video cassettes and television?

title: DIVI DIVI HOTELS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
BRINKMAN, L D reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Reflects losses from discontinued operations of $4,267,000 for the quarter and $4,551,000 for the nine months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $11,000 for the quarter and $348,000 for the nine months. d-Net income.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: MAYORS STRESS 'NEW LOCALISM' IN REBUILDING CITIES
description: A new strategy for rebuilding America's old cities is emerging among the nation's mayors. It is a strategy based on resignation to drastically reduced Federal aid and on more reliance on local independence and initiatives.

title: A BLEAK QUARTER FOR 1ST CHICAGO
description: The First Chicago Corporation said today that it would merely break even in the second quarter because of a $107 million reserve being established to shore up a Brazilian banking affiliate.

title: N.R.C. Aide Stays Shoreham Ruling
description: A decision authorizing low-power operation of the Shoreham nuclear power plant on Long Island was temporarily stayed today by a Nuclear Regulatory Commission official.

title: 4 NEW YORK BANKS FACE FINES BY U.S. IN CASH VIOLATIONS
description: The Treasury Department is expected to announce on Tuesday fines against at least four major New York City banks for failing to report thousands of large cash transactions in recent years, banking sources in Washington and New York said today.

title: CHINESE WRITER STUDIES JEWISH ROOTS
description: Qu Yinan could barely contain her excitement as she watched Rabbi Joshua Stampfer wash his hands in preparation for a Jewish Sabbath meal.

title: 'LET ME INTRODUCE...'
description: THE cheerful, ruddy face is vaguely familiar. So is the hearty laugh. And that's not surprising. Regardless of whose enormous party is in progress, if Milton Goldman is there, he's introducing himself and everybody in sight.

title: Iran Rejects Iraq's Bid To Stop Raids on Cities
description: Prime Minister Mir Hussein Moussavi of Iran has rejected Iraq's unilaterally declared halt to attacks on cities, saying fighting would continue, Iran's official press agency said today.

title: NICHOLS, S E INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
U.S. MUSICIANS IN DROUGHT BID
description: Members of U.S.A. for Africa, the group of American pop musicians whose recording ''We Are the World'' has raised about $50 million for famine relief projects, said today that they planned to address what they said were basic misconceptions held by the American public about famine in Africa.

title: TALES OF MARTIN
description: Last Thursday, Billy Martin said something he didn't say. It is not the first time. Actually, he said something he wished he hadn't said, or wished he hadn't said it to who he said it to (the press), because he didn't like what was made of what he said, or what was made of what he said he didn't say.

title: NEWBERY ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PRESIDENT ESTABLISHE PANEL TO REVIEW MILITARY SPENDING
description: President Reagan, acting in the wake of Congressional and public concern about waste in the military, today formally announced that the Administration was forming a bipartisan commission for a broad review of Pentagon procurement.

title: Planner Is Ad Team's Latest Star
description: FOR about a year Ogilvy & Mather, New York, has been using account planners in its advertising development. Norman Berry, the Briton who is president of the office and responsible for the introduction, has judged the system a success and yesterday was ready to talk, as were Jennifer Stewart, head of planning and research, and Douglas J. L. Richardson, director of planning development, both equally British.

title: Mary L. Potter Weds Justin Stanford Colin
description: Mary Lee Potter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Byron Potter of Oklahoma City and Boulder, Colo., was married yesterday to Justin Stanford Colin, the son of Mrs. Albert H. Colin and the late Mr. Colin of New York. Justice William C. Thompson of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Manhattan home of Frederick William Richmond, the former Democratic Representative from Brooklyn.

title: Plea of Not Guilty In Cocaine Case
description: A Philadelphia caterer pleaded not guilty today to 16 counts of cocaine distribution in a Federal case that has involved major league baseball players as witnesses, and his attorney demanded that authorities turn over ''any tape recordings made with ballplayers'' during alleged transactions with his client.

title: Silver Snails
description: The Project on Equal Education Rights is soliciting denunciations of individuals and organizations deemed to be slow to ban sex discrimination.

title: Alcohol and Migraines
description: Researchers in London have identified a series of chemicals in alcoholic beverages that may account for the migraine headaches that are touched off by alcohol in some people. The chemicals, which are especially plentiful in red wine, the worst offender for migraine sufferers, inhibits an enzyme called PST that deactivates phenols.

title: SCIENCE STUDIES THRIVE AT SMALL COLLEGES
description: MOST undergraduates go through four years of college without ever being invited to take part in the scientific research of their professors, and certainly few undergraduates ever become co-authors of journal articles with their teachers. Experiences of this sort are usually reserved for graduate students working toward doctorates at large research universities.

title: Pinton Quits Cosmos
description: The Cosmos were still operating as of last night, although Peppe Pinton had submitted his resignation as the team's managing director earlier in the day.

title: Flutie Improves
description: The Generals yesterday elevated Doug Flutie's status from ''out'' to ''doubtful'' for Sunday's home game against Birmingham. According to league policy, the doubtful classification means that he has a 25 percent chance of playing in the next game in the opinion of the trainer or team doctor.

title: AS BEIRUT DRAMA UNFOLDS, REPORTERS SCRAMBLE TO FILL THE GAPS
description: By about 4:30 A.M. last Friday, when word reached the Washington headquarters of United Press International that a Trans World Airlines jetliner had been hijacked, the bureau had already been racked with worry for several hours.

title: POLICE UPHELD ON OBSCENTIY EVIDENCE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the police do not need a warrant to buy presumably obscene books or magazines for use as evidence against the seller.

title: LEVI STRAUSS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflects a charge of $24,500,000 for plant closings.

title: PENRIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
29 Firms On London Dealer List
description: The Bank of England said today that 29 firms had confirmed their intention to become primary dealers in British Government securities when Britain adopts its new trading system late next year. Eleven of them are linked with American banks or securities dealers.

title: Maximum Yield Is 9 3/8% On Grand River Bonds
description: A $225.9 million issue of revenue bonds from the Grand River Dam Authority in Oklahoma was priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 9 3/8 percent, through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: Chess: The Old Caro-Kann Defense Appears Less Redoubtable
description: For years now, the Caro-Kann Defense has epitomized the solid and eminently practical - if totally unglamorous - ambition of achieving a draw with the black pieces.

title: 2 BIG BANKING MERGERS PLANNED IN SOUTHEAST
description: In a sign of the ferment in regional banking after a landmark ruling by the Supreme Court last week, two mergers were announced yesterday that would create two new banking giants in the Southeast.

title: LIFE, DEATH AND THE RIGHTS OF HANDICAPPED BABIES
description: IS the treatment of severely handicapped newborn infants an issue of civil rights and discrimination? Doctors, nurses, social workers, and other medical professionals told the United States Commission on Civil Rights last week that it was not. Federal officials and spokesmen for some groups representing the handicapped gave the opposite view.

title: Demise of a Mailbox
description: The corner looked strangely bare.

title: Adviser in Iran Crisis Says He Backs Reagan
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski, national security adviser during the Iranian hostage crisis, said today that it would be unwise for the Administration to let the hostage crisis fester, but he said he believes that President Reagan is handling the situation correctly.

title: Earnings Off For Brokers
description: The average retail stockbroker earned about $64,000 last year, a drop of more than 22 percent from the nearly $83,000 earned in 1983, the Securities Industry Association reported yesterday.

title: ENNIS BUSINESS FORMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BOND INTEREST FALLS FURTHER
description: Interest rates continued to fall in the bond market yesterday, along with some shorter-term rates. The declines came as some oil prices slipped and investors demonstrated an ever stronger conviction that the Federal Reserve is likely to cut its discount rate before the weekend to bolster the nation's sagging economy.

title: Levi's Profit Rises 40.2%
description: Levi Strauss & Company reported earnings of $32.1 million, or 86 cents a share, for the second quarter ended May 26, up 40.2 percent, from the $6.4 million, or 17 cents a share, for the same period last year. Sales in the latest quarter amounted to $615.7 million, down from $659.8 million for the same period last year.

title: Bear, Stearns Appoints Fixed-Income Strategist
description: Stanley Diller, an academic economist who in 1976 founded a financial strategies group at Goldman, Sachs & Company, has left the firm to join Bear, Stearns & Company as senior vice president and fixed-income strategist.

title: REAGAN'S UNTRUTHS ABOUT MANAGUA
description: President Reagan has won another round in the battle over United States policy in Central America: After yet another major debate about whether to fund the ''contras,'' Congress changed its mind and voted last week to support aid to the anti-Sandinista guerrillas. How are we to account for this capitulation? History offers an unsettling clue.

title: WARSHIPS SET SAIL; U.S. SEEKS TO END SPECULATION IT WILL ACT
description: United States Navy ships and a Marine amphibious unit were moving toward Lebanon today in response to the hijacking of Trans World Airlines Flight 847 and the continued detention of more than 40 Americans. But Reagan Administration officials said the movements did not reflect a decision to attempt a rescue or military reprisal.

title: PROSECUTION AT TRIAL OF 2 EMIGRES ENDS ITS QUESTIONING OF EX-AGENT
description: The prosecution today ended five days of questioning of Richard W. Miller without directly asking the former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation whether he had ever passed classified documents to two Soviet emigres.

title: FOR SOME FAMILIES, JOY; FOR THE OTHERS, FEAR
description: There were cheers and applause, tears and emotional embraces as, one by one, 11 of the released hostages from Trans World Airlines Flight 847 met friends and relatives at Logan Airport in Boston yesterday. But elsewhere around the country, a long wait continued.

title: U.S. Judge Bars Data In Suit on Internment
description: A Federal district judge refused today to allow Justice Department attorneys to introduce thousands of pages of evidence in a trial examining the legality of the internment of Gordon Hirabayashi and other Japanese-Americans in World War II.

title: Accounts
description: Bass Exports to Stan Merritt Inc. for beer from Britain.

title: Fare Discounts Set by United
description: United Airlines today announced a series of marketing promotions aimed at winning back customers following settlement of the 29-day strike by the airline's pilots.

title: Salvador Soldiers Move Hundreds in Rebel Zone
description: The Salvadoran Army said today that it was evacuating hundreds of people from a region in northern Morazan Province where troops began an offensive against leftist rebels.

title: DIGITECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
WATER PROJECTS IN '85 MONEY BILL SPUR VETO THREAT
description: President Reagan will veto supplemental appropriations for this fiscal year because of water projects approved by the full House and by the Senate Appropriations Committee, Administration officials said today.

title: CONTROL OF TV ADS IN ELECTIONS URGED
description: Legislation was introduced in the Senate today to regulate television advertising that directly or indirectly attacks candidates in Federal election campaigns.

title: SENTENCING REPORT CHALLENGED IN SUIT
description: Mayor Koch and several county executives filed suit in State Supreme Court in Manhattan today, challenging a report by a special legislative commission that proposed new guidelines for sentencing convicted criminals.

title: BILL ADDS TAX ABATEMENTS TO EXTENSION OF RENT RULES
description: A housing bill combining extension of rent regulations with tax abatements that New York City officials complained would cost millions of dollars was introduced today by State Senate Republicans.

title: CHILD-CARE AIDES NOW FACE SUSPENSION FOR PAST CRIMES
description: Mayor Koch and his Human Resources Commissioner yesterday reversed their policy and ordered that any child-care worker who had been convicted of a serious crime be suspended without pay pending a review of the case.

title: Veteran for Hire
description: Jan Scruggs, the man who for six years ran the organization that built the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, is looking for a job. ''I'm looking for a new cause,'' he said.

title: MCCORMICK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,000,000, or 8 cents a share, on the sale of property. c-Includes a gain of $22,200,000, or $1.77 a share, on the sale of property.

title: PIRATES HALT EXPOS' STREAK
description: Tony Pena drove in three runs with a two-run home run and a single tonight, powering the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 5-2 victory over Montreal. The defeat put an end to Expos' five-game winning streak.

title: Joe and Jane College
description: New York City, a great college town?

title: 30 INDICTED BY U.S. ON COCAINE COUNTS
description: Thirty people, including three dentists, two lawyers, two stockbrokers and several businessmen, have been indicted on Federal charges of operating a cocaine ring that distributed as much as $5 million in sales a month, the United States Attorney's Office said today.

title: GREECE COMES UNDER CRITICISM FOR INADEQUATE AIRPORT SECURITY
description: The Greek Government has come under sharp criticism by international aviation authorities for what they say is its failure to take adequate security measures at its airports.

title: Judge Promoted; Off Murder Case
description: Sybil Hart Kooper, a State Supreme Court justice, was appointed yesterday by Governor Cuomo to the court's Appellate Division. The promotion had the result of removing Justice Kooper from the trial in State Supreme Court of a man charged with killing 10 people in a house in Brooklyn last year.

title: Coca-Cola to Buy 2 Television Units
description: The Coca-Cola Company announced yesterday that it had reached definitive agreements to acquire the television production companies, Embassy Communications and Tandem Productions, for cash and stock amounting to $485 million.

title: REPUBLIC RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
EQUAL PAY IS NOT NEEDED FOR JOBS OF COMPARABLE WORTH, U.S. SAYS
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ruled unanimously today that Federal law does not require employers to give men and women equal pay for different jobs of comparable worth.

title: Navy Reserve Officer Is Slain Aboard Ship
description: A Navy Reserve officer was stabbed to death aboard the U.S.S. Miller while the frigate ship was on duty in the Atlantic Ocean, officials said today.

title: Yakety-Yak
description: Novo Bojovic of the Invaders is known around the United States Football League not only for being a pretty fair place-kicker but also for having a bit of a mouth, a guy who will try to bait opponents in the pregame drills. As such, he was in top form before his team took on the Generals last Saturday night at Oakland, and, by coincidence, he thereby did his team some good.

title: MUSIC: WESTERN WIND GROUP
description: THE Western Wind Vocal Ensemble has developed a loyal following and, one would guess, a thriving career with its combination of interesting music and smooth stage presence. One is reminded of the Canadian Brass, an instrumental group of similar size that also adds smart looks and running patter to the business of making music.

title: STAGE: RUSSIAN POETS AT CARNEGIE
description: SPECTATORS at Carnegie Hall made a journey Sunday night into an exotic land: the wildly emotional world of Russian poetry.

title: The Price of Supermarket Clarity
description: The growing use of laser scanners to speed shoppers through supermarket checkouts has stirred a movement in New York and New Jersey to require food outlets not to abandon price tags on most individual items. For the time being, such a law seems like a sound precaution.

title: HOUSE VOTES STRONGER CLEAN DRINKING WATER ACT
description: The House of Representatives voted today to renew and expand the Safe Drinking Water Act. The voice vote was unanimous. Among the amendments adopted by the House was a sweeping provision requiring the Environmental Protection Agency to decide in the next three years whether and how to regulate a list of over 60 water pollutants. Since the law was enacted in 1974, the agency has provided standards for controlling 22 pollutants.

title: Many Questions, One President
description: There are times when even a President of the United States has a hard time getting a word in edgewise.

title: Shiites and Palestinians Sign Cease-Fire Accord
description: Shiite and Palestinian leaders signed a Syrian-sponsored cease-fire accord late today intended to end the monthlong battle for three Beirut refugee settlements, Syrian officials announced.

title: STOP & SHOP COMPANIES reports earnings for 16wks to May 25
ISRAELIS SAY U.S. MUST ASK IF IT WANTS SHIITES RELEASED
description: Israeli officials stressed again today that, unless the Reagan Administration made a public appeal, they had no intention of releasing more than 700 Lebanese Shiite detainees in exchange for more than 40 American hostages.

title: COGENIC ENERGY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Thrift Unit Insurance Bar
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has stopped granting Federal deposit insurance approval for new state-chartered savings and loan associations in California, Texas and Florida pending agreements with officials in those states on more stringent state control.

title: Trade Deficit Up in Quarter
description: The deficit in the nation's broadest measure of foreign trade grew in the first quarter of 1985, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Bridge: Reaching a Wrong Contract Can Hold Unusual Rewards
description: Everyone would like to bid accurately to the right contract. But there can be compensations in reaching the wrong contract: it can offer opportunities for skillful play that would not have existed otherwise.

title: DEVELOPER IN PERMIT DISPUTE AGREES TO IMPROVE ESPLANADE
description: The City Planning Commission said yesterday that Harry Macklowe, the real-estate developer, had agreed to spend up to $4.3 million to renovate part of the East River esplanade because he had modified an East Side apartment building without city approval.

title: Well-Financed Campaign
description: He may be a novice as a candidate, but the former Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development certainly knows how to get - and spend - money.

title: CONTINENTAL HEALTHCARE SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $30,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Envoy to Bonn Named
description: President Reagan said today that he will nominate Richard Burt, an Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian Affairs, to be the United States Ambassador to West Germany. Mr. Burt's nomination to succeed Arthur Burns, the former Federal Reserve chairman, had been expected for some time.

title: PRETORIA INSTALL REGIME IN NAMIBIA
description: Policemen wielding riot sticks charged demonstrators in a black township here today as South Africa handed over limited powers to a new, multiracial administration in this former German colony.

title: Of Bigger Legislation and Better Chances
description: It is a notion that is easy to dismiss, contrary as it is to most experience.

title: 'LATCHKEY CHILDREN' DO AS WELL AS OTHERS
description: CHILDREN who care for themselves after school until their parents return from work show no significant differences in social and psychological functioning when compared with children who attend day care centers or go home to parents, a recent study suggests.

title: DIFFERENT CULTURES SEEK TO RESOLVE ETHICAL ISSUES OF MEDICAL PROGRESS
description: IN a variety of ways reflecting their own differing cultures, doctors, lawyers, patients and their relatives around the world are slowly coming to grips with the agonizing ethical, legal and personal dilemmas posed by modern medical advances.

title: New York, New York
description: Two Mayor Koches will visit the capital July 1 to entertain and edify members of the National Press Club of Washington.

title: CLABIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $531,000. c-Net loss.

title: STATE ASSEMBLY BACKS RISE TO 21 IN DRINKING AGE
description: The State Assembly voted tonight to raise the legal drinking age to 21 from 19. The vote was 89 to 59.

title: PILOTS UNION OBJECTS TO QUEENS STATDIUM PROPOSAL
description: The proposed domed stadium in Queens would pose a safety hazard for planes using La Guardia Airport, according to the Airline Pilots Association.

title: Passing the Death Penalty Buck
description: How popular would capital punishment be if each person favoring it were asked to throw the switch? Polls show that a majority of Americans support the general idea of the death penalty. But experienced defense attorneys and prosecutors know that jurors faced with the final decision about an individual defendant find it much harder to make. It's unfair to the accused to make that decision seem easier than it really is, as the Supreme Court recently made clear.

title: ADOLFO'S FALL SHOW: ELEGANCE IN BLACK
description: Black is the color of the majority of styles in Adolfo's fall show, but do not for a moment believe that the mood of dressing next season will be sober. The black suits, sweaters and long skirts for evening, as well as the knitted day dresses, are awash with glitter.

title: New I.B.M. Model
description: The International Business Machines Corporation is expected to announce a desktop version of its System/36 minicomputer tommorrow, along with several modems - which communicate data over telephone lines - and a new terminal. The desktop System/36 is expected to pose a significant challenge to other minicomputer makers, including the Digital Equipment Corporation and Wang Laboratories Inc. It is part of an effort to bring many of I.B.M.'s medium-sized computers down to a desktop machine format.

title: New Times Ad System
description: The New York Times has introduced a computerized system that permits an advertising agency to transmit classified advertising to the paper from a personal computer. Lance R. Primis, senior vice president for advertising, said yesterday that an advertising agency ''will no longer need to bother sending paper insertion orders by mail or messenger - the ad is the order.'' The system was developed at the request of the Miller Advertising Agency and The Times said that it expected other advertising agencies to be using the system by the end of the year.

title: Defining Terms
description: Ever wonder what a manager means when he calls on his struggling team to ''regroup'' against the opposition?

title: UNIVERSITY GENETICS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Key Rates
description: * Municiapl Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SPECTRUM CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Theater Money Shifted
description: For a while, it seemed as if the curtain was about to rise on Frederic S. Papert's long-running dream of a National Theater Center on Times Square.

title: Raymonde Paul, 81, Lawyer And President of Foundation
description: Raymonde I. Paul, a lawyer specializing in international cases who was the president of the C. Michael Paul Foundation, died of a heart attack Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 81 years old and also had a residence in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: 'La Cage aux Folles' Set for Washington
description: A touring production of the musical ''La Cage aux Folles,'' starring Peter Marshall and Keene Curtis, is to open on Sept. 10 at the National Theater in Washington.

title: THIS COUNTRY'S TRADE OUTLOOK
description: In 1979 Congress strengthened the Commerce Department's role in international trade. The Reagan Administration put Lionel H. Olmer, a former Navy intelligence operative and Motorola executive, in charge of it as under secretary.

title: SYSTEMS ASSURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CITY BALLET: 'LIEBESLIEDER WALZER'
description: WATCHING George Balanchine's ''Liebeslieder Walzer,'' a ballet about love, is almost as exciting as falling in love. The performance it received by the New York City Ballet on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater could easily have made one fall head over heels in love with this work, to music by Brahms for two pianists and four singers.

title: Williams Rebounding
description: John (Hot Rod) Williams, the former Tulane Basketball star accused in a point-shaving scandal that helped end Tulane University's basketball program, says he is doing his best to overcome his troubles. ''A lot of people thought I'd fold over,'' Williams said. ''A lot of people thought I'd go in the corner and hide. Why should I go in the corner and hide? I don't have any reason. Life doesn't stop with one thing. You're always going to have problems in life.'' The 6-foot-10-inch center, who is playing for the Rhode Island Gulls in the new United States Basketball League, has pleaded not guilty to charges of sports bribery and conspiracy to commit sports bribery. The scandal at Tulane, followed by Ned Fowler's admission that, while head coach, he had made cash payments to several Tulane players, prompted the university's president, Eamon Kelly, to shut down the basketball program. It also prompted National Basketball Association Commissioner David Stern to issue a recent memo indicating that Williams - who, until the scandal, was considered an almost certain first-round N.B.A. pick - could be a risky choice in Tuesday's draft. Williams's teammates on the Rhode Island Gulls have supported him. ''He's got talent, and I can't imagine him ever wanting to jeopardize that chance,'' one teammate, Bobby Reitz, told The Times-Picayune of New Orleans in an article published Sunday. Kevin Stacom, the Gulls' coach, said: ''He's a low-key worker and a strong person, not some slick, fast-talking kid.''

title: AN ACTOR BLOOMS IN A TERRORIST TALE
description: It was the kind of role an actor waits a lifetime for, and Brian Cox knew it. ''The reason I became an actor was to play a part like this,'' he says.

title: Priorities Set
description: It happens in the minor leagues too: Frank Verdi, whose 21-year career as a manager in the bushes has produced 1,333 victories, was dropped by the parent Baltimore club yesterday as the pilot at Rochester, where the Red Wings were battling a nine-game losing streak. The Orioles have not offered the 59-year-old Verdi another position, and so he'll be busy job hunting. ''I'm too young and too broke to retire,'' he said.

title: ABC 'ARMY' COVERS THE ANGLES AT OPEN
description: If you have never been to a golf match, why bother? Golf, because of its panoramic quality and unwieldy number of players, is perhaps the one sport better captured by television cameras than by the spectator who is there in person.

title: DATA GENERAL TO LAY OFF 1,300
description: Two of the nation's leading makers of minicomputers, the Data General Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company, became the latest victims of the prolonged computer slump yesterday, saying that slow sales were forcing them into major cutbacks.

title: Cliffhanger
description: Dwayne Murphy explains why he was particularly tickled when his two-run homer in the ninth gave the A's a 3-2 victory over Cleveland: ''I love dramatics.''

title: Renault Plans Cutbacks
description: The chairman of Renault, Georges Besse, has confirmed plans to cut the state-owned concern's French work force by more than 20 percent by the end of 1986. The reduction is widely regarded as only the first step in Mr. Besse's strategy to turn around what was once the symbol of success in French nationalization.

title: OPEN: MORE A LOSS THAN A TRIUMPH
description: No matter how Tze-Chung Chen of Taiwan tries to forget his collapse, and no matter how much Andy North of Wisconsin enjoys his victory last weekend, the 85th United States Open will be known as the one Chen lost with a horrendous quadruple-bogey 8 on the fifth hole. It wiped out the four-shot lead he had over North with only 14 holes to go.

title: METS TIGHTEN RACE IN EAST
description: It may not have exactly been the long-awaited battle for first place but, as main events go, it wasn't too shabby: Ron Darling outpitched Rick Sucliffe before 41,986 roaring fans, Gary Carter once more supplied the game-winning home run and the Mets snapped out of their four-game losing streak last night with a 2-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: MUSINGS INSPIRED BY AN AMTRAK RIDE
description: Almost everyone has a maiden aunt. I didn't have one in the legal sense, but in reality I had one of the best kind. Her name was Ella Anderson - I called her Pud. Her father had been an engineer on the Chesapeake & Ohio. Pud, who had worked as a cashier in a restaurant, was from Staunton, Va., and thought of herself as a lady of the Old South.

title: Bud Light Wins Clio For Best TV Campaign
description: At the annual Clio Awards ceremony at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center last night, the award for the best national television campaign went to Bud Light beer. And not only the agency, Needham Harper Worldwide, but also the production company, Pytka Productions, and the music house, Klaff/ Weinstein Music, raked in statuettes.

title: BRIEFS
description: Allied Corp., Morris Township, N.J., said it had extended the expiration date of its tender offer to purchase up to 22 million shares of common stock of the Signal Cos. for $45 a share in cash to midnight June 28.

title: Perseverance Is Path To Peace in Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: GUILTY OF DISAPPOINTMENT
description: FOR at least the past two millennia, people have looked upon Halley's Comet as an omen of things like the sack of Jerusalem and the Norman Conquest. There is no telling what the comet may have in store for us this time around, but one possibility is that it will put a whole generation of kids off astronomy. Take the case of little Johnny. Johnny is a bright lad who has done so well with girls by encouraging them to look up at the night sky that he decides to become an astronomer. Naturally, he plans to observe Halley's Comet, and to that end he cajoles his parents into buying him an outrageously expensive telescope. Even more important, he arranges to do his observing far enough from the light-polluted skies of Manhattan that he stands a chance of seeing the dim comet.

title: PASSENGERS TAKEN FROM HIJACKED JET, LEBANESE REPORTS
description: More than 30 people from a hijacked Trans World Airlines jet, most of them Americans, were reportedly taken off the plane yesterday in Beirut, but the prospects for the release of those hostages and another group said to have been taken off earlier remained uncertain.

title: FRENCH SOCIALIST TAKES A CONSERVATIVE STAND
description: ''IN war, you are not allowed to put on the enemy's uniform, but that's what Chevenement is doing,'' said a staunch conservative.

title: Meadow Road Breaks Record
description: Meadow Road, a Swedish horse, lowered by four seconds the world record for trotters going a mile and a half to win the inaugural $135,000 Statue of Liberty Trot tonight at the Meadowlands.

title: Law Agencies Assemble In Mass Murder Inquiry
description: Investigators from around California were called to a meeting today to try to sort out the widespread investigation into the feared mass killings of as many as 25 victims in the Sierra foothills.

title: Why Do Athletes Need Anthems?
description: To the Editor:

title: WORD ABOUT PROCESSORS
description: A CRYPTIC reference was made here recently about a word-processing program that is attracting a devout following among some reporters and editors. The program is XyWrite II+ - but whoa! Before the stampede starts, pause a moment for a few thoughts in general about word-processing software.

title: DAUGHTER SAYS JOHN WALKER PRESSED CHILDREN TO BE SPIES
description: Laura Walker Snyder, the daughter of John A. Walker Jr., says her father used intimidation and emotional manipulation to try to recruit her and her brother as spies.

title: Business-Form Outlook Bright
description: WHILE computer manufacturers are mired in a virtual recession, the business-forms industry is enjoying a boom. In a sense, Wall Street analysts say, this phenomenon reflects the split personality of the economy.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 18, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Subcommittee on small territories meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: LEBANESE SHIITES: ONCE DOWNTRODDEN, NOW POTENT
description: The latest hostage crisis in the Middle East illustrates the extent to which Lebanon's one million Shiite Moslems, once downtrodden, have moved to the center of power in this country.

title: FIRSTS FOR JOHN PAUL: VENICE, AND A GONDOLA
description: He has, it seems, traveled everywhere and by almost every known means of transport. But even Pope John Paul II had never had a weekend like the one just past.

title: Bombers Begin Sentences
description: Two young men who said they bombed three abortion clinics to save unborn babies surrendered at a Federal prison today to start serving 10-year sentences. Mathew Goldsby and James Simmons, both 21 years old, were convicted in April after a nine-day Federal trial of making and setting off the bombs that destroyed one Pensacola clinic and heavily damaged two others.

title: OFFICIAL RECALLS CODE VIOLATIONS AT THEME PARK
description: A state official testified today that a sprinkler system would have put out the fire in an attraction at the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park last year that killed eight teen-age patrons.

title: NEW PLAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Revenue figures for the nine months were not given.

title: Frank Zappa's Son To Appear in Film
description: Dweezil Zappa, son of the rock performer Frank Zappa, will appear in the film ''Pretty in Pink,'' which stars Molly Ringwald.

title: EARLY DATA ARRIVE FROM PROBE ON VENUS
description: The gray stone corridors of the Space Research Institute resounded with unfamiliar footsteps Saturday morning, as an international team of planetary scientists gathered to catch the first returns from a robotic spacecraft plunging headlong into the atmosphere of Venus, 66 million miles away. Among the roughly 100 participants were representatives from eight European nations and the French Ambassador, who together with their Soviet hosts concentrated on the computer display projected onto the conference-room wall.

title: Bishops in Ohio Support Boycott of Campbell
description: Roman Catholic bishops in Ohio announced support today for a boycott of Campbell Soup Company products, in an attempt to pressure the company into approving collective bargaining for farm workers.

title: FIGHT AGAINST TUBERCULOSIS RUNS INTO DIFFICULTIES
description: THE battle against tuberculosis seems to be faltering, according to a recent report by the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta and newly published research.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 18, 1985

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Met Museum To Display 'Princely' Art
description: ''Liechtenstein: The Princely Collections,'' a major exhibition of artwork and other items, will open in October at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: LEXICON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Ward to Sell Part Of Jefferson Unit
description: Montgomery Ward & Company, a subsidiary of Mobil Corporation, said in Chicago that it had agreed to sell the 18-store Northern division of its Jefferson Ward discount-store chain to Bradlees, the discount-store division of Stop & Shop Companies. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: TEXAS PRISON CHIEF QUITS AFTER A YEAR
description: Thirteen months after he was tapped by Texas to reorganize its troubled prison system, Raymond K. Procunier resigned today as director of the Texas Department of Corrections, saying, ''I just ran out of gas.''

title: Whither Detente?
description: Detente, once the catchword in American-Soviet relations, is a rather ignored concept these days in Washington, given the way the Reagan Administration seems to view Moscow and its policies.

title: DANCE: 'QUIZOTE' BY BALLET THEATER
description: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER ended its spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday with two performances of ''Don Quixote,'' one of its most popular ballets. It was danced with crisp technical brilliance in the evening by Cheryl Yeager, as Kitri, and Danilo Radojevic, as Kitri's fiance, the jaunty barber Basilio, and in the afternoon with a gentler and more human touch by Martine van Hamel and Kevin McKenzie.

title: NETS ARE 'CLOSE' TO HIRING MASSIMINO
description: Bernie Mann, president of the Nets, said yesterday afternoon that the team was ''close'' to reaching an agreement with Rollie Massimino to become the new head coach.

title: Mubarak Goes to Sudan; First Visit Since Coup
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt visited the Sudan today for the first time since the coup against Gaafar al- Nimeiry, and said he never would extradite the ousted Sudanese President, the Egyptian press agency reported.

title: ARGENTINA EXTENDING BANK HOLIDAY 2 DAYS
description: Officials of Argentina's central bank today extended the nation's bank holiday until Wednesday to give people more time to adjust to the complexities of the Government's anti-inflation program.

title: Federated Issue
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. is issuing $100 million of 10 1/8 percent Eurobonds due in 1995, at a price of par, through underwriters led by Goldman Sachs International. The company said proceeds from the sale of the bonds, which are non-callable, would be used to reduce short-term indebtedness.

title: RYKOFF-SEXTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
TOUGHER PEER REVIEW OF DOCTORS URGED
description: The president of the American Medical Association has called for the nation's doctors to police their colleagues better, especially in the area of exorbitant incomes.

title: OTTAWA RIGHTS PARLEY ENDS WITHOUT A REPORT
description: A major international conference on human rights ended here today with the 35 participating nations failing to agree on a final report after six weeks of closed meetings.

title: Goldome Buys Bankers' Funding
description: The Goldome Realty Credit Corporation, a subsidiary of the Goldome Savings Bank, said that it had purchased the Bankers' Funding Corporation from the American National Bank unit of the Central Pacific Corporation.

title: FEDERATED GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split. Results for the latest period are for 13 weeks.

title: Iran Hostage Pledge By Reagan Recalled
description: Reporters at President Reagan's news conference today referred to comments he made at a White House ceremony Jan. 27, 1981, honoring Americans who had been held hostage in Iran. Mr. Reagan said then: ''Let terrorists be aware that when the rules of international behavior are violated, our policy will be one of swift and effective retribution.

title: REYNOLDS APOLOGIZES FOR SENATE TESTIMONT ERRORS
description: William Bradford Reynolds, President Reagan's nominee for Associate Attorney General, apologized four times today to the Senate Judiciary Committee for giving inaccurate or possibly misleading testimony about his record on civil rights.

title: CONCERT: JOHN DENVER
description: JOHN DENVER appears to have a reached a critical turning point in his career.

title: Landlord Gets 30 Days In Rundown Apartment
description: A neurosurgeon has been ordered to move from Beverly Hills for 30 days to one of the rundown apartments he owns after failing to improve them as the court had ordered.

title: A DISSIDENT CALLS POLAND FASCIST
description: A Polish dissident says the Gdansk trial in which he and two other Solidarity activists were sentenced to prison terms showed that ''fascism has knocked on the doors of Polish homes.''

title: Market Place;   Technology Stocks of Israel
description: IS Israel the new Japan of high technology? Analysts who recently visited the country believe that there may indeed be a Silicon Valley in the land of milk and honey.

title: REAGAN REJECTS TAX INCREASE
description: President Reagan tonight firmly ruled out any increase in taxes, renewing his longstanding pledge against a tax increase as a deficit reduction step.

title: BANK CUT PRIME RATE TO 9 1/2%
description: The nation's major banks cut their prime rate half a percentage point yesterday, to 9 1/2 percent. This is the first time the benchmark lending rate has been below 10 percent since 1978.

title: Allied Plans To Add Stores
description: The Allied Stores Corporation plans to open 25 new department stores from 1985 through 1989, with emphasis on expanding the larger, most successful divisions, Thomas M. Macioce, chairman and chief executive officer, said at the annual meeting yesterday.

title: 'Rambo' Strengthens Its Lead at Box Office
description: ''Rambo: First Blood Part 2'' led at the box office over the weekend for the fourth consecutive week, while a new release, ''Prizzi's Honor,'' starring Jack Nicholson and Kathleen Turner, opened a strong fourth.

title: SLAIN STUDENT IS EULOGIZED AT MEMORIAL
description: Edmund E. Perry, the 17-year-old Harlem honor student who was shot outside Morningside Park last Wednesday, was remembered at a memorial service last night as a sensitive, intelligent, caring young man who was killed, as one speaker said, ''by the people we pay to protect us.''

title: AVIALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: All figures are in U.S. dollars and are translated at the rate of 252 yen equals $1.00, the Tokyo foreign exchange market rate as of April 30. The latest quarter results include a foreign currency exchange loss of $11,028,000, compared to a foreign currency exchange gain of $4,865,000 for the year-earlier period. The latest 6-month period included a foreign currency exchange loss, compared with a foreign currency exchange gain for year-earlier period. The share earnings are per American Depositary Share and each depositary share equals one share of common stock.

title: SAUDI PRINCE ON SPACE VOYAGE: SULTAN SALMAN AL-SAUD
description: A nephew of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, Prince Sultan Salman al-Saud is not only the first Arab to fly in space, but also the first member of royalty. From his vantage point aboard Discovery, 220 miles above the earth, he hoped to be the first Moslem to see the sliver new moon yesterday, marking the end of Ramadan, the holiest month of the Moslem year.

title: Lessons Learned At Prep School
description: The idea is to help struggling high school students stay in school by giving them summer scholarships to nine prestigious prep schools across the Northeast. Some recipients, though, have learned as much about race relations as reading and math.

title: About Incontinence
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: A DETAILED ACCOUNT OF MENGELE'S LIFE
description: The Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele had never met his son Rolf until a ski holiday in Switzerland in 1956 when the boy was 12 years old, according to information supplied to a Munich magazine by the son himself.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Kraft Inc., Glenview, Ill., a Dart & Kraft unit, said it had completed its acquisition of Westman Commission Co., a Denver-based food service distributor. Terms were not disclosed.

title: FALCON PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
Sixth Body Found on Coast
description: Investigators unearthed a sixth body today at a survivalist's mountain compound where they already had found 45 pounds of human bones in their search for clues to the fate of 22 missing people. The remains were discovered under two feet of dirt, a sheriff's deputy said. More than 700 pieces of evidence have been removed from the property where sheriff's deputies believe Leonard Lake, 39, and Charles C. Ng, 24, took some of the missing people.

title: Bridge: A Skillful Inference Solves Mystery of the Club Queen
description: In one form of a famous problem, three intelligent men with crosses chalked on their foreheads try to infer the color of their own cross. The solution hinges on the behavior of a competitor in a hypothetical situation.

title: NETS ARE EXPECTED TO SIGN MASSIMINO
description: Bernie Mann, the Nets' president, said today that he expected to sign Coach Rollie Massimino of Villanova on Wednesday to a contract that will make him the team's new head coach.

title: Captors 'Nice People,' Greek Folk Singer Says
description: A Greek singer who was freed today by Shiite Moslem gunmen said he serenaded the hijackers of a Trans World Airlines jetliner and described them as ''nice people'' who gave him a birthday cake.

title: GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 19
description: b-Net loss, which includes a gain of $1,826,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Johnson's French Deal
description: The French sugar and paper group Beghin-Say is forming a company with Johnson & Johnson to market pharmaceutical products and toiletries in France, Beghin-Say's president, Jean-Marc Vernes, said today. The new company, to be called Beghin-Say Johnson & Johnson, will be exclusively a sales and marketing operation for selected products made by the two companies.

title: 3 Lebanese Convicted in Italy On Plastic-Explosives Charge
description: A court convicted three Lebanese citizens today of smuggling plastic explosives into Italy in an operation the prosecution linked to a terrorist group in Lebanon, court officials said.

title: UNITED TELECONTROL ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
Police Attendants Held for Extortion
description: Two police attendants were arrested yesterday on charges of extorting money from crime suspects by threatening to delay or interfere with their arraignments, according to a spokesman for the special state anticorruption prosecutor, William Dowling.

title: AN ONION NOT DESTINED FOR CASSEROLES
description: THIS town in southeastern Washington and the island of Corsica would seem to have little in common. But there's an onion that links them together. Pete Pieri, a young Frenchman with the memory of sweet Italian onions he'd tasted in Corsica and dreams of making his fortune farming them in America, headed west at the turn of the century. He carried onion seed to Walla Walla, where he'd heard of opportunities from French and Italian farmers already established there. Pieri planted the seeds and with the first tender shoots of that long-ago spring in Walla Walla, sweet onion was born.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Pinetop Perkins Plays, Piano at the Lone Star
description: The 72-year-old pianist Pinetop Perkins, who spent 12 years with the Muddy Waters Blues Band, was the main attraction Sunday at the Lone Star Cafe, 61 Fifth Avenue. He was a special guest with the Mojo Blues Revue, organized by the guitarist-singer George Jr. Mr. Perkins sings in a light, conversational tone; his piano-playing distills Chicago style from boogie-woogie to rocking blues.

title: DESPITE PEACE ACCOD, BEIRUT FIGHTING GOES ON
description: Artillery and rocket exchanges between armed Palestinians and Shiite militiamen erupted today despite a cease-fire agreement worked out late Monday between Palestinian and Shiite combatants fighting for control of three Palestinian settlements here.

title: T.W.A. SAYS ATTENDANTS TRIED TO DISSUADE THE HIJACKERS ON NAMES
description: Flight attendants aboard the hijacked Trans World Airlines jet in Beirut tried but failed to dissuade hijackers from separating passengers thought to be Jewish from the others, according to T.W.A. spokesmen in New York.

title: RETAIL DEALERS TO SELL I.B.M. MINICOMPUTER
description: Intensifying its effort to combine personal computers with more sophisticated office equipment, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would begin selling a new version of its leading minicomputer through some computer retail stores.

title: Train Crash in Egypt Kills 30
description: At least 30 people were killed in a head-on collision between a passenger train and a freight train on Monday night, police sources said today. Witnesses said 10 of the 13 cars of the passenger train caught fire in the collision at Isna, north of Aswan in Upper Egypt.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Chicago Cubs at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The K's will be out at Shea as Dwight Gooden looks to pick up his 10th victory and add to his major-league-leading strikeout total of 116. (Television -- SportsChannel 7:30 P.M. Radio -WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Orioles at Baltimore. Last of a three-game series. Ed Whitson looked good in his last outing, but his teammates didn't and Whitson failed to pick up a much-needed victory. He is 1-6 with a 5.37 e.r.a. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 7:30 P.M.) Boxing Mark Breland vs. Dario DeJesus, welterweights, at Totowa (N.J.) Ice World, Route 46 and Union Boulevard, Totowa. First preliminary 8 P.M. This eight-rounder is the fifth pro fight for Breland, fighting at Ice World to keep active. The Olympic gold medalist finally scored a knockout in his last fight, against Vince Dunfee in May. DeJesus is 14-8-3 with 7 knockouts. On the undercard, Tracy Harris, the adopted son of the former heavyweight champion Floyd Patterson, makes his pro debut in a four-round junior lightweight bout against Sean Dynda, of Pittsburgh. Golf Women's Amateur Public Links Championships, at Flanders Valley Golf Course, Flanders, N.J. Opening round of stroke-play qualifying. This is the tournament for bona fide public course players. Heather Farr is the defending champion. Other Events BOWLING: PBA Seattle Open, final (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.) HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt 8 P.M. $100,000 New York Sire Stakes.

title: TENNECO TO BUY GAS PIPELINES
description: Tenneco Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase pipelines and other natural gas holdings from the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company for about $500 million in cash and assumed debt.

title: HUMANA INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
9 Latin Nations Divided On Contadora Talks
description: A new round of Central American peace talks among nine nations began today with officials divided on whether their efforts can resolve the region's conflicts.

title: PEKING REPLACES 9 TOP GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS
description: Deng Xiaoping's drive to rejuvenate the upper echelons of China's bureaucracy gathered momentum today with the replacement of nine Government ministers, about a fifth of all officials holding ministerial rank.

title: AMF Deadline
description: Minstar Inc. has extended to July 8 the expiration date of its offer for 12.5 million shares of AMF Inc., the diversified leisure products company.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Kenny Loggins Offers Folk and Pop Funk
description: Endowed with a sunny, boyish charm and an exceptional melodic fluency, Kenny Loggins has remained a pop star for longer than most of his contemporaries who jumped aboard the folk-pop bandwagon of the early 70's. One way he has continued to prosper has been by skillfully adapting his music to accommodate changing mainstream tastes.

title: BILL ON TV TAKEOVERS IS INTRODUCED
description: The Federal Communications Commission would be required to hold extensive hearings whenever a national television network was the subject of a hostile corporate takeover, under legislation introduced in the Senate today.

title: U.S. AGENCY CRITICIZED ON ITS FLUORIDATION PLAN
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, which wants to nearly double the maximum permissible amount of fluoride in drinking water, has come under fire from those on both sides of the issue.

title: Letter: On Shoreham;   An Argument for Public Power
description: To the Editor:

title: A DROUGHT COMMERCIAL ON A SOGGY DAY
description: The filming of some public-service commercials that will urge residents of drought-stricken New York to conserve water was postponed yesterday because of rain.

title: FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: b-Net loss. Results for the latest six months include a pre-tax gain of $574,000 on the sale of a store.

title: HOMELESS CHILDREN FOUND IMPAIRED
description: A study of children living in shelters for the homeless found that more than half those older than 5 were seriously depressed and most said that they had suicidal thoughts.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC ISSUES
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference last night in Washington, as recorded by the New York Times:

title: PARENTS AND EXPERTS SPLIT ON SPANKING
description: SUSAN WRIGHT of Cambridge, N.Y., gives her three children, aged 1 to 5, a ''firm whack on the bottom'' when they misbehave because, she says, ''It is important for a kid to know who is the boss.''

title: Conticommodity
description: Conticommodity Services Inc., in a formal response, denied charges by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission that it had participated in a complex international scheme with the Hunt brothers of Texas to manipulate the silver futures market in 1979 and 1980. In its 24-page filing, Conti either denied the charges or said it did not have enough information or was unable to obtain the information to respond to the complaint. The Hunts have called the charges against them baseless.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend Friday about picking strawberries gave an incorrect telephone number for the Blue Jay Orchards in Bethel, Conn. The number is (203) 748-0119.

title: Cosmos to Continue Play
description: Coach Ray Klivecka of the Cosmos said today that the team would continue to operate, but was reorganizing its ownership - probably to exclude Giorgio Chinaglia.

title: Nets Are Getting International Look
description: The Knicks weren't the only team in the metropolitan area with big plans yesterday. But the plans that the Nets had going into the collegiate draft weren't as easy to execute as those of their neighbors across the Hudson, who used the No. 1 pick to select the day's most coveted prize, 7-foot center Patrick Ewing.

title: QUAKER GROUP CITES 'BRUTAL REPRESSION' AT A FEDERAL PRISON
description: There is ''an emerging pattern of brutal repression'' at the maximum security Federal prison at Marion, Ill., a Quaker service organization asserted today.

title: Keeping a Voice in South Africa Through Stock Ownership
description: To the Editor:

title: Murchison Debt Meeting
description: The former owner of the Dallas Cowboys football team, Clint Murchison Jr., will meet Wednesday with a committee representing his creditors to start negotiating for financial reorganization, his attorney said today.

title: C.&W. Is Assigned New Beecham Billing
description: Cunningham & Walsh, a Mickelberry company that already serves Beecham Inc., has been assigned that company's Beecham Home Improvement Products subsidiary.

title: Magazine Ad Pages Off 7.6% in May From '84
description: The magazines that belong to the Publishers Information Bureau were collectively down 7.6 percent in advertising pages in May from the same month last year, to 13,305 pages.

title: Slaney Victor In Canada Mile
description: Mary Decker Slaney failed to keep her vow to break the world record in the mile, but still easily won the event tonight at the Harry Jerome International Track Classic.

title: 'NO BUILDING PERMIT NEEDED' NOTE DISPUTED AT HAUNTED CASTLE TRIAL
description: A state building official testified today that he had found no evidence that Great Adventure Inc. or its parent company, the Six Flags Corporation, had ever applied for the building permit required for a fun house in their Jackson Township amusement park.

title: ORDERS ANTIHIJACKING STEPS; 3 MORE TWA HOSTAGES FREED
description: President Reagan, vowing that the United States would never give in to terrorists, called tonight on Lebanese Shiite hijackers to release their American hostages without conditions.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: SOMEONE once observed that if the onion were not so abundant, if it were relatively rare, it would be more sought after and costly than caviar. Undoubtedly, that is an exaggeration, but the thought that the most readily available items are often the least appreciated reminds me of flounder, which is one of the most abundant fish in American waters. Yet, it is seldom in demand.

title: SHIRLEY IS UNFAZED BY NEW CELEBRITY
description: Bob Shirley sat in the hotel lobby this afternoon, joking with his Yankee teammates as they passed by.

title: U.S. Adds $15 Million To Grasshopper Battle
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block declared an emergency today in response to possibly the worst grasshopper outbreak in this nation's history and provided an additional $15 million to control the infestation in the West.

title: 'St. Elsewhere' Series Will Touch on Famine
description: NBC's ''St. Elsewhere,''a hospital drama series, will touch on the issue of world hunger next season through the experiences of three of its producers, who said they went to Ethiopia expecting a depressing story but found ''an uplifting one.''

title: Hinckleys' Mission
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: NEW PLAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Mere Tinkering With College Sports
description: After so many college sports scandals, you'd think a convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association would be riveted on reform. But the agenda for a New Orleans meeting this week looks more like an exercise in damage control.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 19, 1985

title: BSD MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Judge Increases Award to Lawyers
description: A Federal judge has added $1.4 million to the amount awarded in January to more than 80 lawyers and law firms that represented Vietnam veterans and their relatives who claimed harm from Agent Orange, the chemical defoliant.

title: First Jersey Sets Changes
description: First Jersey Securities Inc. said yesterday that it would put into effect the 25 recommendations made by a court-appointed financial consultant. The New York-based securities firm agreed to hire Benjamin L. Lubin, president of the Securities Industry Management Corporation, to review its 35-office national business and the treatment of its 500,000 customers as part of the firm's settlement of a Securities and Exchange Commission complaint.

title: CSP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
REV. HERMAN F. REISSIG
description: The Rev. Dr. Herman F. Reissig, pastor emeritus of the First Congregational Church of Old Greenwich and a writer on religion and social issues, died Sunday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital after a long illness.

title: Short-Term Rates Continue to Tumble
description: Short-term interest rates slid sharply yesterday, further bolstering the market's belief that the Federal Reserve is engineering lower interest rates to reinvigorate the economy.

title: CORRECTION
description: A recipe in The Living Section last Wednesday accompanying an article on easy dishes for summer listed an incorrect amount of white wine to be used in making shrimp with tomato and dill. The correct amount is a quarter cup.

title: STAGE:'LISBON TRAVIATA,' TALE OF TWO OPERA FANS
description: TERRENCE McNALLY'S new play, ''The Lisbon Traviata,'' begins as a comedy about a diehard pair of opera enthusiasts; it ends as an impassioned dramatic equivalent of grand opera. The play (at Theater Off Park) is a long step away from such wry McNally comedies as ''Bad Habits.''

title: WINE TALK
description: CHATEAU HAUT-BRION, one of the five so-called first growths of Bordeaux, this month is celebrating the 50th anniversary of its purchase by the Dillon family of America. On July 27, a gala party at the chateau will celebrate this period in Haut-Brion's long and distinguished history.

title: PBS 'CELEBRATION FOR BACH AND HANDEL' TONIGHT
description: THERE is probably little danger that any television viewer, even one who has never darkened the door of a concert hall, is still unaware of the 300th birthday observations for Bach and Handel. Still, there's nothing like a solid performance of some of their best music to remind us why they're worth remembering. Anyone who for whatever reason lacks opportunities to hear it in performance might want to tune in tonight at 8 to the PBS ''Celebration for Handel and Bach,'' a production of WHYY-TV in Philadelphia.

title: Clear Instructions
description: ''The train on the local tracks will be making express stops only,'' the voice intoned over the loudspeakers in the West 72d Street IRT station - clearly.

title: CLASSIC DUO GETS A NEW SUMMER TWIST
description: SOUP and a sandwich, for many people, is the most comforting meal imaginable. On a cold winter night, with the wind dashing sleet against the windowpanes and a crackling fire burning on the hearth, there is nothing more satisfying than a bowl of hot soup, accompanied by a hearty sandwich, preferably made of toasted bread.

title: An Eye for Talent
description: Lynn Snyder, a 43-year-old administrator with a sharp eye for coaching talent, has been named athletic director at Oregon State, filling a post that has been vacant since Dee Andros was transferred to a new fund-raising position in February after a decade in the job. Snyder, a former associate director of athletics at Illinois, has been athletic director at Marshall University in West Virginia since 1979. Marshall's sports information director, Mac Yates, noted two of Snyder's hiring successes - Rick Huckabay, the basketball coach who led Marshall to the Southern Conference championship in each of his two seasons on the job, and Stan Parrish, the school's first-year football coach whose team turned in its first winning record (6-5) in 20 years last fall.

title: Ontario Conservatives Lose Confidence Vote
description: Ontario's Governing Conservative Party was defeated today after more than four decades in power.

title: PAY 'N PAK STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
BIRDFINDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After tax credits of $300,000 for the quarter and $868,000 for the nine months. c-Net loss.

title: Chrysler Accord Seen on Gulfstream
description: The chairman of the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation said today that he expects an agreement to be signed Wednesday for the Chrysler Corporation to acquire the aircraft manufacturer.

title: WOMEN HOPE FOR A CIVIL NAIROBI FORUM
description: ORGANIZERS of and participants in an international forum on women's issues next month in Nairobi, Kenya, expressed their hopes yesterday that the meeting would be free of the heated political confrontations that have marked two previous gatherings.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET OPEN TALKS ON AFGHANISTAN ISSUE
description: The United States and the Soviet Union opened talks here today on Afghanistan, the latest in a series of discussions on regional issues.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ANNE FRANK Anne Frank was a German-Jewish teen-ager whose family fled to the Netherlands to try to escapt the Nazis. They were hidden in a secret annex to her father's business and captured and shipped off to a German death camp, where she died in the spring of 1945, only a few months before V-E Day.

title: THE NEW HATCHET MAN
description: We haven't had a really provocative political hatchet man around the White House since Spiro Agnew, but with the appointment of Patrick J. Buchanan as President Reagan's director of communications, the old noisy tradition may not be lost.

title: AGCA DENIES DEAL WAS MADE TO IMPLICATE SOVIET
description: Former Italian intelligence officials and the Turkish gunman Mehmet Ali Acga denied today that Mr. Agca had been involved in a deal to concoct testimony implicating Bulgaria and the Soviet Union in a conpiracy to kill Pope John Paul II.

title: England and Direct Mail
description: One of this country's most successful raisers of funds for political candidates and causes has sent a team to London to test whether direct-mail techniques that have proved effective on the hectic American electoral scene will also work in the more sedate parliamentary atmosphere of England.

title: Judge Suspended in Peru During Massacre Trial
description: A trial arising from the massacre of eight Peruvian journalists came to an abrupt halt today after the presiding judge was suspended from the case.

title: PLAY: 'SALE' BY GURKOFF
description: ''FOR SALE,'' a forlorn first play by Jeffrey Gurkoff, which opened last night at Playhouse 91, takes place in sub-sitcom suburbia. A spineless young couple (Craig Wasson and Katherine Cortez) allow themselves to be abused by the wife's blowhard father (Wayne Tippit).

title: SRI LANKA AND REBELS ANNOUNCE A CEASE-FIRE
description: The Sri Lanka Government announced today that separatist guerrillas had agreed to a cease-fire, the first in more than two years of fighting.

title: ENZO BIOCHEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SHUTTLE LOFTS SATELLITE FOR ARAB LANDS AND P.L.O.
description: With a Saudi Prince cheering them on, fellow crew members of the space shuttle Discovery today successfully launched a communication satellite for a consortium of 21 Arab countries and the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: S.E.C. GOVERNMENT SECURITIES RULES
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission decided today on the proposals it would recommend to Congress for regulating the Government securities industry if Congress should pass regulatory legislation. The vote was 3 to 1.

title: COMPUTER DEPOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: b-Net income.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 19, 1985

title: BODIES IN MEXICO HELD TO BE AMERICANS
description: The police today unearthed the bodies of two men they believe to be American citizens who disappeared from Guadalajara last January. Authorities said the men had been killed after being mistaken for informants by drug traffickers.

title: OVERTURES TO SOLDIERS TO SPY FOR SOVIET BLOC SAID TO RISE
description: The Army says there has been an increase in reports of attempts by Soviet and other Eastern European intelligence services to recruit American soldiers as spies.

title: REPUBLICAN CANDIDATE PRESSING BID TO BE MAYOR
description: In a city that is almost unfailingly Democratic, Diane McGrath, the Republican-Conservative candidate for mayor, seems unfailingly optimistic about her candidacy.

title: Jersey Hospital Bonds Are Priced
description: An $87 million issue of Mountainside Hospital revenue bonds for the New Jersey Health Care Facilities Finance Authority was tentatively priced at par yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Not Your Usual Tour
description: Washington is a tale of two cities.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Rossini and Prokofiev By the Naumburg
