description: The Naumburg Orchestra's outdoor summer season is as notable for its ambience and fresh air as for its music. And so on Saturday night in Lincoln Center's Damrosch Park, passing airplanes, ambulances and exploding firecrackers nearby joined easily with this program of Rossini, Prokofiev, Persichetti and Haydn.

title: HOUSTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about 29 firms interested in becoming primary dealers in British Government securities incorrectly reported the number of primary dealers in United States Government securities. There are 36 such dealers, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: STATE SENATE APPROVES LIMIT ON DOCTORS' INSURANCE COSTS
description: The State Senate this evening approved legislation designed to restrain the rapid rise in malpractice insurance premiums that doctors must pay.

title: ISRAELIS READY TO MEET RED CROSS ON CAPTIVES
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres said today that Israel would be ready to receive a representative of the International Committee of the Red Cross to discuss ways of resolving the Beirut hostage crisis.

title: BLUE JAYS LOSE 6TH IN ROW
description: Ray Burris pitched a seven-hitter and Paul Molitor homered as the Milwaukee Brewers handed the Toronto Blue Jays their sixth straight defeat, 4-1.

title: U.S. Envoy Given Protest
description: Greece lodged a strong protest today over a State Department announcement earlier in the day warning American citizens of the dangers ''of air travel to, through or from Athens.''

title: MATERIAL SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CONCERT: EARLY MUSIC
description: Handel's ''Acis and Galatea'' is not an opera but a masque; though it can be staged attractively, concert room performance suits it well. The Connecticut Early Music Festival gave it in a chapel at Connecticut College here Sunday, to prolonged applause and a standing ovation. The audience thus showed itself as discriminating as the Festival's directors. This was as fine a model as one is likely to encounter for authenticity of Baroque performing style, and almost as fine a demonstration that fastidious scholarship need not interfere with - indeed, may enliven - dramatic involvement, characterization and musical expressiveness.

title: SMD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $878,198 for the quarter and year. c-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $31,663 for the quarter and year. The latest fourth quarter and year discontinued operations figures include an after-tax gain of $838,757, or 45 cents a share, from sale of buildings and equipment.

title: ALINE B. AUERBACH
description: Aline Buchman Auerbach, a writer on child care and an executive with the Child Study Association, died Saturday at her home on East 84th Street.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 19, 1985 SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 11 A.M. on situation in Namibia.

title: Housing Starts Fell 14% in May
description: Housing starts fell a surprisingly sharp 14 percent last May, to an annual rate of 1.66 million units, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: U.S. in Shift On Chile Loan
description: The Reagan Administration, in a policy shift that immediately touched off Congressional criticism, voted today in favor of a loan to Chile by the World Bank.

title: IRAN HOSTAGES DESCRIBE THE TRAUMA
description: Some of the Americans held hostage for 444 days in Iran said yesterday that while they may have been better prepared than those being held in the current Beirut crisis, there is really no way one can prepare for the fear of the actual event.

title: SUN CITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
PICO PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Despite Justice Dept., Affirmative Action Is Alive
description: To the Editor:

title: CHURCH ROLLS RISE AFTER A DECLINE
description: Church membership rose slightly less than 1 percent in 1983, ending the long decline in membership in mainline denominations, the National Council of Churches said today.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Sashimi to Go Individual servings of sashimi, the Japanese raw fish appetizer, are available at the new Food Emporium at the Avenue of the Americas and 13th Street. Each attractively presented tray has 6 1/2 ounces of raw fish, including tuna, fluke, sea trout and surimi, the Japanese fish paste that is molded to look like crab. The trays cost $7.99 each. One tray would do for two people as a first course, but for a main course, count on a tray for each person.

title: 'PA-TRICK, PA-TRICK'
description: For the Knicks, the New Year arrived yesterday - the first day of Patrick Ewing's first year. Toot horns, bang pots, put on silly hats, toast the future.

title: MICRON TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
description: b-Net income

title: 'WORKIN FOR PEANUTS,' HBO 'FAMILY' DRAMA
description: THERE is something unusual about some of the hour-long dramas Home Box Office has been acquiring for its periodic ''Family Playhouse'' series. These productions, aimed at young audiences, tend to tackle grimmer, or at least less soothing, realities than the average family entertainment. They are made in Canada, and they focus on lower-middle-class families, complete with worries about unemployment and painful personal tensions. Middle-class comforts are scarce. This is certainly not the glossy world of instant solutions of ''Charles in Charge'' or ''Family Ties.''

title: NO TAX FAVORITISM FOR CORPORATIONS
description: This nation prides itself on free enterprise, but we really practice tax socialism. Some investments and businesses are taxed heavily, others lightly and still others not at all - in fact, the tax code subsidizes some.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MIGRAINE. Understanding a Common Disorder. By Dr. Oliver Sacks. 270 pages. University of California Press. $17.95.

title: HOUSE VOTES BAR ON BUYING MX OVER NEXT YEAR
description: The House of Representatives voted tonight to bar the purchase of any additional MX missiles next year and to limit deployment of the intercontinental weapon to a total of 40.

title: New Yorker Publisher Adds Title of President
description: Steven T. Florio, 36 years old and publisher of The New Yorker, has been additionally named president of New Yorker Magazine Inc. He replaces J. Kennard Bosee, 65, who left last month.

title: Shift at U.S. Tobacco
description: The U.S. Tobacco Company announced that Nicholas A. Buoniconti, a senior vice president, had been named president and chief operating officer.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Berkshire Gas Co., Pittsfield, Mass., has named Scott Robinson president and chief operating officer.

title: Who First Used the Words 'Secular Humanism'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Hosptial Issue Of $103.6 Million Is Set
description: A $103.6 million issue of hospital revenue refunding bonds for the Jacksonville Health Facilities Authority in Florida was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 8 7/8 percent for bonds due in 2015 through underwriters led by Underwood, Neuhaus & Company.

title: BRENNER COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Desperately Seeking Truman
description: ''Down at Curtiss-Wright at the airplane plant in Ohio, they were putting defective motors in planes, and the generals couldn't seem to find anything wrong. So we went down, myself and a couple other Senators, and we condemned more than four or five hundred of those engines. And I sent a couple of generals who'd been approving, who'd okayed those engines, to Leavenworth, and I believe they are still there. I certainly hope so.''

title: Pirate Offers
description: When Daniel M. Galbreath, president of the Pittsburgh Pirates, tested the waters over the weekend by dropping his demand that the prospective new owners agree to keep the franchise in Pittsburgh, he thought it might cause some ripples among bidders. How right he was.

title: The Robes of Justice Swirl (for Decorum)
description: Lawyers in Judge Richard Feder's courtroom wore flowing, knee-length black robes Monday in an experiment planned to bring dignity and decorum to Dade County Circuit Court.

title: WHO FIRST USED THE WORDS, SECULAR HUMANISM?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE OUTDOORS HAS ITS ATTRACTIONS-AND INFECTIONS VARIED SOURCES OF RABIES MOSQUITOES: DANGER SIGNALS
description: TO most of us, mosquitoes and ticks are just seasonal annoyances, the price we pay for enjoying the outdoor pleasures of summer. But these bloodthirsty creatures can be more than just ordinary pests. They are the bearers of serious illness, vectors for encephalitis, Rocky Mountain spotted fever and Lyme disease.

title: With the Wits
description: Toiling behind the scenes in Washington, uncredited and often unpaid, is a corps of writers believed by leaders of their respective parties to be humorous. Any time a prominent politician, from President Reagan on down, is invited to speak to a press dinner or submit to self-immolation at a roast, these anonymous wits are sent scurrying into their files to freshen up some sure-fire material.

title: NEW YORK RAISING ITS DRINKING AGE TO 21 IN DECEMBER
description: The minimum legal drinking age in New York State is rising from 19 to 21 on Dec. 1.

title: 'The Dream Is Alive'
description: The Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum is the most popular tourist attraction in the capital, and one of its most popular features, the giant-screen motion picture theater, is about to premier a new space film, the fourth in a series that has played to capacity audiences totaling 14 million since 1976.

title:
HOSTAGES IN LEBANON: ANOTHER AGONY REMEMBERED;

FREED HOSTAGE TELLS OF SAILOR'S DEATH
description: One of the released passengers held aboard the Trans World Airlines jet said one of the stewardesses aboard the plane warned them of the impending execution of another passenger.

title: TOP MILITARY FIGURE
description: Marshal Kirill S. Moskalenko, who helped develop the Soviet strategic missile forces, died Monday, Soviet television said today. He was 83 years old. In an obituary signed by Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other members of the political and military leadership, Marshal Moskalenko was praised for his long and varied service.

title: Fight in Doubt
description: It was a fairly far-fetched idea to begin with - a fight in Canada on Sunday between 41-year-old Joe Frazier, the former world heavyweight champion, and Robert Cleroux, a onetime Canadian champion, who is 47. When Regis Levesque, a promoter, proposed the idea, both boxers accepted, but Canadian sports authorities were less enthusiastic.

title: PLAY BY POPE TO GET TV PREMIERE
description: A drama about the Nazi oppression of Poland written by Pope John Paul II when he was a 20-year-old philosophy student will be given a live television premiere next month in Italy.

title: 140 OTHERS STUDIED
description: The Treasury Department today announced fines against four major New York City banks and said that the Internal Revenue Service was investigating 140 other banks for possible criminal violations of the Bank Secrecy Act.

title: U.S.-SOVIET ACCORD ON FARMS SIGNED
description: The Under Secretary of Agriculture, Daniel Amstutz, said here today that the Soviet Union and the United States had agreed to resume agricultural cooperation broken off after Soviet forces swept into Afghanistan in late 1979.

title: LEARNING TO KEEP KNIVES SHARPENED
description: IF you ask a chef to identify the most indispensable utensils in his kitchen, chances are excellent he will answer, ''My knives.'' Good-quality, sharp knives make easy work of such tasks as trimming meat and seafood for the grill, shredding cabbage for coleslaw and preparing vegetables for a stir-fry. On the other hand, a dull knife is not only inefficient but also dangerous. It forces you to use excessive pressure to cut, thus greatly increasing the chances that the blade will slip.

title: HOT YANKEE BATS BEAT ORIOLES, 6-4
description: Rickey Henderson continued to be a veritable one-man wrecking crew against the Orioles as he led the Yankees to a 6-4 victory here tonight before 33,794 fans at Memorial Stadium.

title: BASTIAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $150,000 for the quarter and $2,150,000 for the nine months.c-After an extraordinary gain of $642,000.

title: PRIME CUT PUSHES DOW 6.38 HIGHER
description: Stocks generally rose yesterday, in response to a half-point reduction in the prime rate by the nation's major banks. Some important technology issues, however, failed to participate in the upturn.

title: T.W.A. Deal Has Opposition
description: The T.W.A. Employees Committee said yesterday that employees were expressing strong opposition to the Texas Air Corporation's proposed purchase of Trans World Airlines and that a possible buyout of the airline through an employee stock ownership plan was still being considered.

title: ART: ARRAY OF PICASSO IN MONTREAL
description: The first thing to be said about ''Pablo Picasso:

title: UNITED'S STRATEGY QUESTIONED
description: United Airlines dazzled the airline world with its agreement last month to acquire the Pacific division of Pan American World Airways. Hardly was the ink dry before it announced an ambitious restructuring of its pension fund assets that will provide nearly $1 billion to finance corporate expansion. And then, after finally fighting through a costly pilots' strike, this week it announced the purchase of the Hertz Corporation, a company that many saw as a natural extension of the company's travel business.

title: President Quits At Miniscribe
description: Roger Gower, who joined the Miniscribe Corporation as president and chief executive scarcely seven months ago, resigned yesterday from the company, which makes disk drives. The resignation is effective June 30.

title: 'CBS REPORTS' TACKLES PROBLEMS OF TERRORISM
description: WHAT is terrorism? How should we respond to it?

title: 8 People Die in Plane Crash As Craft Hits Colorado Peak
description: Eight people on their way to a banquet honoring a law firm associate died when their twin-engine aircraft crashed near the top of 11,970-foot Windy Peak, the authorities said today.

title: Head of Disney Channel Announces Resignation
description: James P. Jimirro, creator and president of the Disney Channel, the family-oriented cable television service of Walt Disney Productions, resigned unexpectedly yesterday.

title: AN HONOR FOR ADVOCATE FOR THE CITY'S HOMELESS
description: Robert M. Hayes had spent most of last Thursday at Camp La Guardia, the city shelter for 1,000 homeless men, when he returned to his office at the Coalition for the Homeless late in the afternoon to find ''the usual 60 or so phone messages.''

title: Policeman Charged With Murdering Wife
description: A decorated Roselle policeman was arrested today on charges he murdered his wife with cyanide after falsifying her will and a divorce decree and secretly marrying his 19-year-old mistress of five years.

title: Chevron-Olympia
description: The Chevron Corporation said it had given Olympia & York Developments Ltd. an additional two days to make its final decision on its proposed $2.18 billion purchase of Chevron's holdings in Gulf Canada. The agreement between the two companies, which has been extended to tomorrow, allows Olympia & York to withdraw from the proposed deal if it is not satisifed with certain legal and tax matters. A Chevron spokesman said that he believed Olympia & York needed more time to get an assessment from the Canadian Government of the deal's tax implications.

title: Herman & Rosner Gets $5 Million in Billings
description: Herman & Rosner Enterprises, the agency in the Kaufman Astoria Studios in Queens, has acquired three accounts in the last month with total billings of $5 million, according to Harvey Herman, chairman and creative director.

title: OFFICER IN HIT-AND-RUN DISMISSED
description: The Police Department has dismissed a probationary officer who, together with a sergeant and another officer, was indicted last month in connection with the hit-and-run accident on Park Avenue that killed one pedestrian and injured another.

title: Mother Teresa Ill
description: Mother Teresa, the Nobel Peace Prize winner, who was scheduled to visit the University of Connecticut Wednesday, canceled her trip because of a sudden illness, school officials said today. Mother Teresa, a 75-year-old Roman Catholic nun, founded the Missionaires of Charity in Calcutta, India. She was scheduled to receive an honorary degree from the university and visit the health center's patient-care areas.

title: Film on Space Trips At History Museum
description: For those who haven't been guests aboard the space shuttles Challenger and Discovery but would like to do the next best thing, ''The Dream Is Alive,'' a new short film made during three space voyages last year, will open June 26 at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street.

title: AFRICAN GOSPEL RADIO: DOSES OF BIBLE AND MEDICINE
description: An outbreak of measles was claiming young lives in a rural area of this tropical West African nation. Deaths mounted, but the local people refused to have their children vaccinated out of fear that the medicine was a poison more deadly than the disease.

title: Chief Executive Named at Scripps
description: Scripps Howard, the privately held communications company, said yesterday that Lawrence A. Leser had been elected president and chief executive.

title: Donna Reed Loses Bid for 'Dallas' Role
description: The actress Donna Reed lost a bid today to regain her role as Miss Ellie on the hit prime-time series ''Dallas'' when a judge refused to halt production of the series.

title: FOR ORGANIZED COOKING
description: A GOOD cook is an organized cook. In my opinion, this maxim embraces having necessities, such as proper utensils, close at hand; having herbs and spices neatly arranged and clearly labeled, and having recipes, if you are using them, clearly written in a logical sequence.

title: Judge William M. Taylor Dies; Presided Over Dallas Busing
description: William M. Taylor, the Federal district judge who presided over the Dallas school desegregation case for more than a decade, died Monday at the age of 76.

title: Luncheon With the Mayor For Women Only
description: Mayor Koch faces opponents who are women in both the primary and general elections, so he might be inclined to brag about his supporters who are women. But yesterday he lunched quietly with 220 of New York's most prominent women at a private gathering at Tavern on the Green.

title: LIFEGUARDS SCARCE AS GLAMOUR FADES
description: Lifeguards, long considered among summer's more glamorous figures, are in critically short supply in the New York metropolitan area this year.

title: AGENCY, RESISTING MAYOR, WON'T SUSPEND EMPLOYEE
description: Board members of a Head Start program on the Upper West Side said yesterday that they had defied a new city rule and had refused to suspend an employee who has a criminal conviction.

title: Alabama Utility Buys Solar Plant
description: The first sizable electricity-generating plant using solar panels coated with amorphous silicon will be supplied to the Alabama Power Company by the Chronar Corporation of Princeton, N.J., the companies announced.

title: VOTES ON NEW DRINKING AGE
description: ALBANY, June 18 - Following are the roll-call votes in the State Assembly and the Senate to raise the minimum drinking age to 21 from the current 19:

title: JIM WALTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Scali, McCabe, Sloves Gets Equitable Product
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves, an Ogilvy Group subsidiary, received an assignment from the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.

title: Cummins Will Cut 2,200 in U.S.
description: Citing a ''rapid reduction'' in demand for its truck engines, the Cummins Engine Company said today that it would reduce its United States work force by 2,200 employees, or 8.6 percent, over the next few weeks.

title: College Bound
description: It's not that Jim Abbott isn't flattered, because he most certainly is. It's just that he has always wanted to play for the University of Michigan, where he will enroll next fall on a baseball scholarship, and besides, he believes that a pro career is very far in his future - ''just a wild fantasy right now,'' he says. And so thanks, but no thanks, go to the Toronto Blue Jays, who selected him in the recent amateur draft.

title: Church Worker Wins Retrial in Alien Case
description: A Federal appeals court today overturned the conviction of Stacey Lynn Merkt, a religious worker who was arrested while driving two illegal aliens from El Salvador down a remote country road in Texas.

title: Baseball Drug Tests Are Set
description: Commissioner Peter Ueberroth informed baseball club owners yesterday that the first drug tests under his mandatory program would be conducted next month.

title: Economic Scene;   Is Reagan A Keynesian?
description: WAS the economic recovery of 1983-84 the result of the Reagan Administration's supply-side policies or of the Keynesian stimulus resulting from big budget deficits?

title: Judge Ponders TV Rule In Molestation Case
description: More than 400 volumes of transcripts from the McMartin Pre-School molestation case were given to a Los Angeles County Superior Court judge Monday after prosecutors challenged a ruling that could eliminate most of the charges against the school's former teachers.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: High Cost of Change To Future Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN DECISION TO ABIDE BY ARMS TREATY PRAISED
description: Lieut. Gen. Brent Scowcroft, an adviser on nuclear arms policy to the White House and Congress, today praised President Reagan's decision to continue to comply with the unratified 1979 strategic arms limitation treaty as useful for American nuclear weapons policy.

title: Seabrook Finds New Investors
description: The owners of the Seabrook nuclear plant said today that new investors -which are not utility companies -had been found to buy shares of the plant from utilities forced to withhold or stop payments on the project. Utilities in Maine and Vermont are under regulatory orders to end their involvement in the project.

title: BAYSWATER REALTY & CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income Year-ago results include gains on the sale of real estate equity investments of $459,657 for the quarter and $540,257 for the nine months.

title: THE WARRENS OF SHIITE SHANTYTOWNS: A MOST LIKELY PLACE FOR THE CAPTIVES
description: The most likely places for the American hostages to be held are in the sprawling shantytowns around Beirut's International Airport.

title: Check Box to Pay National Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: Arms Teams Meet in Geneva
description: United States and Soviet negotiators discussed defense and space weapons for three and a half hours today, a United States statement said. Details of the substance of the meeting, which took place at the United States arms control offices, were kept secret under the confidentiality agreement between the two sides.

title: Mr. and Mrs. Lawmaker
description: A husband-and-wife team of legislators could be in the offing in Queens.

title: CIGARETTE SALES DROP 8% IN '83
description: Cigarette sales dropped in 1982 for the first time since 1969 and fell again by nearly 8 percent in 1983, a Federal Trade Commission study issued today shows.

title: SPAIN, SPURNING HIJACKERS, WILL TRY GUNMEN
description: Spain is going ahead with the scheduled trial Wednesday of two Lebanese gunmen despite demands by hijackers holding American hostages in Beirut that the two be freed, Spanish officials said today.

title: AGREEMENT ON SUPPLEMENTAL APPROPRIATIONS MEASURE CALLED NEAR
description: The Reagan Administration's budget director and the chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee said this evening that they expect to resolve their differences over the water projects in the supplemental appropriations bill, thereby avoiding a Presidential veto.

title: DANCE: HARLEM TROUPE AT THE MET
description: DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM'S first season at the Metropolitan Opera House got off to a gala start on Monday night. There was a festive ceremony and a bit of razzledazzle. Even more importantly, there was much serious dancing.

title: 12 Nations to Aid Argentina
description: Argentina will receive an interim loan of $483 million from the United States and 11 other governments to help it pay the back interest on bank loans until the International Monetary Fund fills the gap, the Treasury Department announced today.

title: SATELLITE HAS STRONGER SIGNAL
description: Arabsat is a powerful satellite with solar panels that measure nearly 70 feet from tip to tip.

title: ANDERSON JACOBSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $2,200,000 from sale of real estate. c-Includes a $5,300,000 payment for settlement of arbitration and a pre- tax gain of $5,800,000 from sale of real estate.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: METS GET BOOST FROM LYNCH
description: Maybe it was the memory of last summer, when the Chicago Cubs whacked them seven times in a row and dumped them out of the pennant race. Maybe it was the memory of last week, when the Philadelphia Phillies stomped them, 26-7, and they lost six times on a seven-game road trip.

title: CASCADE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FACES BEHIND FAMOUS CASES
description: JAGDISH RAI CHADHA, now a citizen of the United States, lives a quiet life in a San Francisco suburb with his wife and two daughters. Few of his neighbors and co-workers know that because of him, the United States Congress can no longer exercise the legislative veto, a 50-year-old practice used to block special actions taken by the President or Federal agencies.

title: GREAT AMERICAN MANAGEMENT & INVESTMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
U.S.-SOVIET SESSION ON '72 NAVAL ACCORD CANCELED
description: For the first time in the 14-year life of a Soviet-American agreement on preventing dangerous incidents at sea, naval officers from the two nations have failed to hold their annual meeting.

title: U.S. HAS A PLAN FOR THE RED CROSS TO ARRANGE THE RELEASES OF SHIITES
description: The United States has asked the Red Cross to find out Israeli plans for the release of 700 Lebanese Shiites whose return has been made a condition by hijackers for freeing 40 American hostages, the White House said today.

title: T.W.A. LIST OF THE HOSTAGES
description: Following is a list of the passengers and crew members from the hijacked Trans World Airlines jetliner still being held in Beirut, as made public in New York yesterday by T.W.A. officials:

title: EAGLE TELEPHONICS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
U.S. SAYS ISRAELIS TOOK MORE SHIITES
description: A combined force of Israeli troops and Christian-led militiamen swept into a south Lebanese village today and seized 19 Shiite men, a United Nations spokesman announced.

title: Honeywell Sees Decline in Quarter
description: Honeywell Inc., citing weakness in industrial and computer markets, said that it expected its second-quarter earnings to ''decline sharply'' from the period last year.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There seems to be more respect for next fall's scripts for 'Dynasty' and 'Dallas' than there is for U.S. contingency plans.'' - Michael I. Burch, Pentagon spokesman. [A14:1.]

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,006,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,784,000 for the quarter and $5,178,000 for the nine months. The company said results for the latest quarter and nine months reflect an accounting change.

title: Short Odds
description: In Britain. where they bet on everything, the public bookies have posted odds for Wimbledon, and notwithstanding Chris Evert Lloyd's status as co-top-seeded woman with Martina Navratilova, there is quite a spread between them on the board: Miss Navratilova at 2-5, Mrs. Lloyd at 7-2.

title: HOLTZMAN ISSUES NEW RULES FOR ARRESTS MADE OFF DUTY
description: District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn yesterday issued new guidelines to her staff for identifying and handling cases in which off-duty police officers make arrests.

title: Real Estate;   Law Firm As a Buyer, Not Renter
description: CONSTRUCTION crews worked through the Father's Day weekend to finish up in time for the official opening last night of the 275,000-square-foot building at 100 Maiden Lane. The property had been purchased and was renovated by the 193-year-old law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, which occupies 155,000 square feet and plans to lease the rest to other law firms.

title: MAJOR REFOCUSING AT GOODRICH
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company yesterday announced a major restructuring that will make it smaller, less dependent on commodity businesses such as tires and vinyl and - the company hopes - more profitable.

title: Required Reading;   Military Waste
description: Excerpts from remarks by Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado, on the House floor, June 17:

title: Civil Rights Is Not a Shell Game
description: As Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights, William Bradford Reynolds has failed his obligations to the law and the victims of discrimination. He has used his position to try to reverse decades of hard-won advances, contending disingenuously that he merely opposes quotas and other controversial remedies. Now he has confessed that he has also been less than candid in advising Congress at several crucial points.

title: LIMITS ON URANIUM IN RESEARCH REACTORS OPPOSED
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission's staff has urged it to back away from a proposed rule that would force universities and commercial enterprises to abandon the use of bomb-grade uranium in research reactors.

title: TWO VETERANS OF NAVY PLEAD NOT GUILTY TO SPYING
description: Jerry A. Whitworth, a retired Navy enlisted man, pleaded not guilty today to charges that he sold secrets to the Soviet Union. The authorities assert he was part of a spy ring run by John A. Walker Jr. Wearing a suede jacket, blue slacks and checkered shirt, Mr. Whitworth stood before Magistrate Frederick J. Woelflen, his hands clasped behind his back. The plea was entered for him by the magistrate.

title: U.S. TELLS TOURISTS ATHENS AIRPORT HAS HIGH RISK
description: The State Department, on direct orders from President Reagan, warned American travelers yesterday that there was a high risk of exposure to terrorism on flights using Athens International Airport. Athens was the boarding point of the men who hijacked a Trans World Airlines jet last Friday.

title: Colombian Found Guilty In Cash Laundering Case
description: A Colombian financier today was found guilty on all seven counts in what the Government says was a $57 million money-laundering scheme.

title: 25 WILL RECEIVE MACARTHUR AWARDS
description: The MacArthur Foundation has named 21 men and four women to receive awards ranging from $155,000 to $600,000 over the next five years so they can be free to ''pursue whatever they believe is important and relevant.''

title: NEW ALBUM BY CLINTON ABOUT WAR
description: LEAVE it to George Clinton to make an album about war and nuclear proliferation that happens to be one of the year's best dance records. Mr. Clinton's ''Some of My Best Jokes Are Friends'' (Capitol Records) is scheduled for release Friday; soon afterward, clubs and radio stations should begin pulsating with ''Double Oh-Oh'' and ''Bullet Proof,'' which insists ''The whole world's on red alert.''

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: STUDY CITES GAPS IN FEDERAL SPENDING
description: Increased military spending and cuts in domestic programs in the last four years have significantly increased the gap between the amounts of taxes that go from individual states to the Federal Government and the amounts that come back to them in Federal spending, a new study shows.

title: Spy Trial of 2 Emigres Is Recessed For a Day
description: The trial of Svetlana and Nikolay Ogorodnikov, who are accused of spying with the help of a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent, was recessed today until Wednesday while lawyers for the Soviet couple and the Government held private discussions with the judge.

title: NATHAN'S FAMOUS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $261,000 and gains of $257,000 on the sale of property and $15,000 from insurance proceeds. c-Includes a tax credit of $353,000 and a gain of $310,000 in insurance proceeds.

title: STAGE: 'RABBONI,' ON JESUS AND SATAN
description: THEATER has, from its origins, served as a means of transmitting a message, of drawing attention to a theme - social, political or religious - that has gripped the sensibilities of the playwright. The better sort of the message-drama genre has usually recognized that preachment alone is not enough; that theatrical values can be more effective than the message.

title: CHEEZEM DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
DRAFT A TALL STORY, WITH EWING AT TOP
description: The National Basketball Association draft belonged to the centers yesterday. Seven centers, six of them 7-footers, were among the first 17 players taken. Four more centers were among the first eight selections on the second round.

title: George Stevens, Writer And Ex-Publisher, Dies
description: George Stevens, a longtime book publisher, writer and former editor of the Saturday Review of Literature, died Saturday at Doylestown (Pa.) Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Doylestown.

title: Wiggins to Las Vegas
description: At least one aspect of the Alan Wiggins dispute has been resolved.

title: West Germans Protest At Embassy in Managua
description: Some 40 West Germans occupied the West German Embassy here today to press demands for the release of a West German woman said to have been kidnapped by Nicaraguan insurgents.

title: THE WRONG WAY TO PROTECT SECRETS
description: Revelations about the scope and duration of the alleged Walker spy ring make it clear that our system for protecting vital secrets needs a major overhaul. It is thus distressing to see how quickly some officials have seized upon the case to resurrect two long-discredited ideas: the death penalty and random use of lie detectors.

title: CABLE TV INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 9.50-10.00 ** Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FOR PARTY PLANNING AND FUN IN THE SUN
European Tariff Plans
description: The European Economic Commission is putting together a package of restructured import tariffs on some electronics goods, the commission vice president, Karl-Heinz Narjes, said today.

title: N.J. Transit Planning To Hold Line on Fares
description: N.J. Transit fares will not increase next year, the agency announced today.

title: Advertising;   The Radio Ad Bureau Workshop
description: EVERY year the Radio Advertising Bureau and the Association of National Advertisers team up to present an annual workshop whose keynote speaker is generally a top agency creative director, who had not been thinking much about radio until he accepted the invitation to speak. So he (or she) decries the lack of attention being paid to radio. It's an annual event.

title: Pentagon Bars Reports On U.S. Deployments
description: The Pentagon tried today to choke off information about the movement of United States military units in response to the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines jet, saying the reports could hamper efforts to protect or free the hostages being held by Shiite Moslem gunmen.

title: Control Data Has Rating Cut
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday that it had lowered the rating on $2.5 billion of debt of the Commercial Credit Company. It also downgraded the rating on $34 million of Control Data Corporation debt.

title: CUBS, NOW 0 FOR 7, TALK LIKE WINNERS
description: The numbers are almost horrifying for a club that led the division not too long ago: seven consecutive losses, three runs in 35 innings, four extra-base hits in seven games.

title: Generals Block For Their Man
description: Eric Dickerson has had his say, so now let the Generals have theirs.

title: COWTOWN, U.S.A., HESITANTLY GIVES WAY TO HIGH TECHNOLOGY AND CULTURE
description: The annual Fort Worth Chisholm Trail Ride has been held for nine years now, and it has become one of this Texas town's bigger social events. But a tea party it is not.

title: JAPANESE TV RECORDS A MURDER
description: The head of a gold company being investigated for deals that were purportedly improper was stabbed to death today by two men who broke into his house in full view of television crews, the police said.

title: MICROPRO INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Security Pacific Bank
description: The Security Pacific Corporation said yesterday that George F. Moody, president of the holding company and its principal subsidiary, the Security Pacific National Bank, had been named chief executive of the bank. Mr. Moody, who is 55 years old, succeeds Richard J. Flamson 3d. Mr. Flamson remains chairman and chief executive of the parent company, which has assets of $45 billion and is based in Los Angeles. Security Pacific National Bank has assets of $39.1 billion. The corporation also announced that Robert H. Smith, 49, vice chairman of the holding company and the bank, had been named chief operating officer of the bank.

title: AEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago share earnings figure is after preferred stock dividend requirements of 10 cents a share.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IT was at 74th Street and Broadway; Miguel Diaz securely locked his brand-new bicycle to a parking meter. Then Mr. Diaz, a personal fitness trainer, went off to make house calls. It was four hours before he returned to retrieve the bike. It wasn't so much the discovery that the bike was gone that startled Mr. Diaz; the really big shock was that the parking meter was gone too.

title: On Curbing Dial-a-Porn
description: Several years ago, Congress and the Federal Communications Commission began receiving an avalanche of letters, petitions and phone calls demanding immediate action against so-called dial-a-porn telephone services.

title: THE QUEEN GAMBIT
description: An ashtray, a coffeepot, a toilet seat . . .

title: NAVY DEPOT IN JERSEY: CONCERN AND COMPLACENCY
description: A train carrying tons of munitions moves slowly from its guarded enclosure here and snakes its way for 12 miles to a rendezvous with Navy ships on the Raritan Bay.

title: Choice by Rangers
description: After a five-month search for a replacement for Herb Brooks as head coach, the Rangers called a news conference for today at which they are expected to end that search by naming Ted Sator to the job.

title: FAMILY QUARRELED OVER SPY SUSPECT
description: The family drama in the Walker spy case continued to unfold today as the daughter of John A. Walker Jr. described how she and her mother decided to turn him in to Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: SKY-MARSHAL PLAN DRAWS CRITICISM
description: Security experts found little merit yesterday in President Reagan's proposal for expanding the sky marshal force for use on international flights.

title: KINDER-CARE LEARNING CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 7
description: b-Reflects losses from discontinued operations of $52,899 for the quarter and $184,065 for the nine months. c-Reflects a loss of $626,802 from discontinued operations and a gain of $1,480,000 on disposal of assets. Year ago results were restated to reflect results of discontinued operations. Per share figures reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective Sept. 4, 1984.

title: GOODEN HURLS CROWD-PLEASER
description: The Mets served the piece de resistance last night to 51,778 fans in Shea Stadium, their largest crowd in eight years: Dwight Gooden and his renowned ''heater.'' And the 20-year-old strikeout star responded by pitching them to a 1-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs, a sizzling six-hitter with nine strikeouts that sent the Cubs to their eighth straight defeat.

title: Money Fund Yields Fall
description: There has been no letup in declining interest rates on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds over the last two months. For the week ended yesterday, rates moved even lower.

title: CHARLES V. McADAM
description: Charles V. McAdam, co-founder and board chairman of the McNaught newspaper syndicate, died Saturday of a heart attack in Bal Harbour, Fla., where he made his home.

title: Iranian Troops Stage A Raid Into Iraq
description: Iran said its troops mounted a three-pronged hit-and-run raid across the border with Iraq today, killing or wounding more than 250 Iraqi soldiers. Iraq said it had crushed the attack.

title: Keach to Discuss Cocaine
description: Sometimes, Congressional committees try to attract attention to worthy subjects by having celebrities testify.

title: HERS
description: LAST week, in a gesture of detente, I visited my former husband, from whom I had just been divorced. I found him, at the peak of his hay fever season, sitting on the deck of the gray colonial we had once shared, holding a box of Kleenex and sneezing. We chatted amiably about legal and domestic matters, occasionally throwing each other tentative smiles.

title: Cosmos Deal Called Near
description: Coach Ray Klivecka of the Cosmos said late today thaT he had been told by Joseph Berardo, one of the club's minority owners, that ''95 percent of the deal with Warner Communications had been completed for him to take over control of the club.''

title: Social Security Agency Is Still Kicking the Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: FALWELL IN DEBATE ON NUCLEAR WEAPONS
description: PRIME Minister David Lange of New Zealand lays on righteousness; the Rev.

title: Capital Gains Are Earned on After-Tax Money
description: To the Editor:

title: PROBLEMATICAL SEARCH FOR CINDERELLA
description: ONE of the most curious touches in the original scenario for Prokofiev's ''Cinderella'' comes when, after finding Cinderella's slipper, the prince rushes around the world in search of her. The scenario does not simply require him to dash about excitedly. It allows for the inclusion of vignettes showing him in foreign lands.

title: ONCE A WEEKLY RITUAL, BEANS NOW A RARITY
description: There was a time when a turn-of-the-century doggerel said a lot about Boston. And this is good old Boston, The home of the bean and the cod Where the Lowells talk to the Cabots And the Cabots talk only to God.

title: NATIONAL SERVICE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
COMPUTER NETWORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STAGE: 'BROADCAST BABY'
description: ''A BROADCAST BABY,''

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE GENERAL INSTRUMENT CORPORATION-Frederick Shuh, senior vice president, bought and exercised option of 11,259 shares giving him directly a balance of 47,317 shares.

title: U.S. WARNS SHIITES ABOUT BECOMING GLOBAL 'OUTCASTS'
description: The Reagan Administration warned Lebanese Shiite leaders today that if they failed to release 40 American hostages unconditionally, they would become international ''outcasts'' deprived of future American help.

title: POLAND BIDS WALESA STOP CRITICIZING
description: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder, said today that he had been told by the Gdansk prosecutor to stop criticizing Government policies or face unspecified measures.

title: Bridge: Ultramodern Systems Bring Oddities and Recriminations
description: Hypermodern systems in which bad hands must bid and good hands must pass create weird results.

title: Breland Is Hot at Ice World
description: ''It's a nice place,'' said the ringside judge a few years back, ''except my feet get cold.''

title: A Familiar Face, a Familiar Problem
description: Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island recalls that when he was Secretary of the Navy about 15 years ago, he once answered a telephone call from Deputy Secretary of Defense David R. Packard and discovered, with a twinge of embarrassment, that he had stood up from his desk at the sound of his boss's voice.

title: CHOOSING A CAREER AS A HORTICULTURIST
description: FOR the professional horticulturist the hours are long, the work sometimes muddy and the pay not proportionately rewarding. Yet increasing numbers of young people are venturing onto the path that leads to gardening careers.

title: NBC OFFERS 'BIGSHOTS,' ABOUT RUSSIAN EMIGRES
description: THE talent that has gone into ''Bigshots in America'' makes the deplorable result all the more disheartening. The stars are Joe Mantegna, winner of a Tony Award for ''Glengarry Glen Ross;'' Christine Baranski, winner of a Tony Award for ''The Real Thing,'' and Keith Szarabajka, seen in the film ''Missing.'' The producer is Lorne Michaels, long the guiding force behind ''Saturday Night Live.'' The director is Jim Burrows, one of the creators of ''Cheers.'' If this had been a Broadway-play project, I would have invested before the formal auditions. However, ''Bigshots in America'' is a television situation comedy, which can be seen on NBC tonight at 9:30 o'clock. For good reason, the potential series is not on the network's fall schedule.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. Finale of the four-game series that has helped revive the Mets. The two teams will meet again for three games in Chicago's Wrigley Field beginning next Tuesday. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050.) Yankees vs. Tigers, at Detroit. Opener of a four-game weekend series. With Willie Hernandez, the Cy Young Award winner, picking up successive saves, Detroit took the first two of the three-game set in Yankee Stadium last weekend. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WABC 770, 7:30 P.M.) Braves vs. Houston Astros, at Atlanta (Television - WTBS, 7:35 P.M.) Boxing Tony Anthony vs. Jesse Ferguson, 12 rounds, heavyweights, at Resorts International Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City. First preliminary, 8:30 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M.) Golf Georgia Pacific Atlanta Classic, opening round, at Marietta, Ga. Tze-Chung Chen of Taiwan will try to erase the memory of his final-round collapse in the United States Open last Sunday. He and the other two Open runners-up - Dave Barr and Denis Watson - are entered in this tournament. Ladies P.G.A. $250,000 Mayflower Classic, at Indianapolis. United States Golf Association Women's Amateur Public Links Championships, at Flanders Valley Golf Club, Flanders, N.J. Tennis Eastern Clay Court Championships for Women, at Orienta Beach Club, Mamaroneck, N.Y., singles semifinals, 1 P.M. Nassau/Suffolk Clay Court singles Championships for men, at Old Field Tennis Club, Greenlawn, L.I., 2 P.M. Other Events BASKETBALL: Springfield Fame vs.

title: CONCEPT INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $616,000 for the quarter and $717,000 for the nine months and tax credits of $324,000 for the quarter and $504,000 for the nine months.

title: HEAD START UNIT YIELDS AND SUSPENDS WORKER
description: The board of a Head Start program on the Upper West Side reversed itself last night and voted to suspend without pay an employee who has a criminal record, as the city had demanded.

title: Father Shot Dead At Day-Care Unit
description: A 25-year-old Manhattan man was shot and killed yesterday in the lobby of a building in Washington Heights minutes after taking his 4-year-old son to a day-care center in the building, the police said.

title: XUAN THUY, HANOI ENVOY AT PARIS TALKS, DIES
description: Xuan Thuy, vice chairman of Vietnam's National Assembly and North Vietnam's chief diplomat at the Paris peace talks that led to the withdrawal of American forces from Vietnam, died Tuesday in Hanoi, according to a report on Radio Hanoi Wednesday. He was 73 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 20, 1985

title: EX-F.B.I. AGENT TESTIFIES ON EARLY BUREAU INQUIRY
description: Richard W. Miller, the first F.B.I. agent in history to be charged with espionage, was investigated twice on other charges before his arrest Oct. 2, he testified today in Federal District Court.

title: U.S. Panel Dismisses Efforts To Bar Shoreham Operations
description: A Nuclear Regulatory Commission appeal board today dismissed as ''without merit'' motions by New York State and Suffolk County to stop the Shoreham nuclear power plant from beginning low-power operations.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday on a rise in church membership in the United States incorrectly described the 219 denominations counted by the National Council of Churches. Roman Catholics were included in the total membership figure of 140,816,385.

title: Dow Slides 7.39 in a Mixed Market
description: Fearful of surprisingly high growth in today's gross national product estimate from the Government, Wall Street traders turned cautious in the final hour yesterday, selling blue-chip issues but hanging onto secondary stocks.

title: A Policy Man
description: Ralph C. Bledsoe is about to become the man to see in the Reagan Administration for people who want to have a say on domestic policy.

title: TURNER DEFENDS BID FOR CBS
description: Ted Turner, the Atlanta cable and broadcast entrepreneur, vigorously defended the financial viability of his bid to take over CBS, in a filing to the Federal Communications Commission made public yesterday.

title: A Congress Party Chief Is Shot Dead in India
description: Unidentified gunmen shot and killed a Moslem leader of the governing Congress Party as he rode a rickshaw through a crowded street, domestic news agencies reported.

title: JUSTICES REBUFF SKI MONOPOLIST
description: The Supreme Court today upheld a $7.5 million antitrust judgment against a company found to have monopolized downhill skiing at the Aspen, Colo., ski resort. The vote was 8 to 0.

title: NEW MATH, ARGENTINE STYLE
description: Argentina's banks reopened today after three holidays, and its citizens stood in lines that snaked around entire downtown blocks, waiting to pay bills, ask questions, sort out accounts and withdraw money for expenses.

title: Police in Colorado Seize Arsenal of 3 New Yorkers
description: The police in this tiny mountain community have seized about $15,000 in weapons and ammunition from a 21-year-old man and two teen-age boys from New York City.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: DIGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Reflects a loss of $3,969,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations for the quarter and the nine months. c-After an extraordinary gain of $3,258,000, or 82 cents a share, related to the collection of insurance proceeds for the quarter and the nine months. The year-earlier periods were restated.

title: London Futures Plan
description: The London International Financial Futures Exchange said today that it would add trading months in Eurodollar, sterling currency and short sterling interest-rate futures.

title: A CHANGING FOCUS FOR A CRAFT FAIR IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: This is the 20th anniversary of the granddaddy of all major crafts fairs, the ACC Craftfair West Springfield, which will open to the public here Friday and run through Sunday. The fair has been somewhat of a movable feast: it is now at its fourth location and on its third name. Last year it moved here to the Eastern States Exposition fairgrounds, but from 1973 to 1983 it was known as the Rhinebeck Fair because of its location in Rhinebeck, N.Y. From 1968 to 1972 it was known as the Northeast Craft Fair and was held in Bennington, Vt.. It all began in Stowe, Vt., where in 1965 a volunteer group of northeastern craftsmen banded together to set up a marketing outlet for their wares.

title: CORPORATION FOR ENTERTAINENT & LEARNING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of 3 cents a share. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of 4 cents a share.

title: Chicago Railroad
description: The Chicago and North Western Transportation Company will reduce its work force by about 13 percent, or 1,500 workers, over the next three years, its president, James R. Wolfe, told the company's annual meeting. He said the reduction was part of a program intended to save about $60 million. Mr. Wolfe said the company's second quarter ''should be better than the first,'' when it lost 80 cents a share. He also said the company was considering diversifying outside the rail business because Federal approval of a railroad acquisition would take two years and the company wanted to use its tax-loss carry-forwards more quickly than that.

title: 4 S.I. Youths Held In Attack on Bus
description: Four youths were arrested Tuesday night in connection with an attack on a city bus that was taking students home from classes at New Dorp High School on Staten Island last Thursday, the police said yesterday. They said the attack appeared to have been racially motivated.

title: FOR A HARVEST OF SURPRISES, PLANT LILIES
description: EVERY garden needs a few surprises, plants that pop up seemingly from nowhere yet are pleasing. Lilies can surprise. Until they bloom, their existence is quietly tolerated. But when the petals open, there are rewards.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE PLACE TO BE Sutton Place extends only from 53d to 59th Street, near the East River. It is residential, quiet and rich, seemingly a world away from the hubbub of First Avenue, a block west. It has a history of gracious living, as you can learn in three walking tours this evening.

title: PENWEST LTD reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-No per share figure was reported for the year-ago nine months because the company was a unit of Univar Corp. for a portion of that period.

title: CONCERT: 'RIGOLETTO'
description: ON paper, the second of the Metropolitan Opera's two free opera-in-concert offerings for New York City parks this year didn't look all that promising. But with a few key cast shifts, the third performance, Tuesday night on Central Park's Great Lawn, turned out to be really first-rate. And the 30,000 attendees who showed up on this cool but lovely evening gave every sign of appreciating what they heard.

title: GAMMA BIOLOGICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
8 Colombia Policemen Ambushed by Guerrillas
description: The police said today that guerrillas had ambushed and killed eight policemen patrolling near the Venezuelan border and that 10 bombs had exploded in cities on the eve of a strike.

title: Army Agrees to Reassess Plan to Test Deadly Agents
description: The Army will do an environmental impact study of a proposed $1.4 million testing chamber for deadly chemical and biological agents at the Dugway Proving Ground in Utah, a spokesman confirmed Tuesday.

title: HUNT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday on awards by the MacArthur Foundation incorrectly described a past position held by Morton Halperin, one of the award recipients. He was Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense in the Johnson Administration.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Morrissey and Smiths At the Beacon Theater
description: ''Last night it was the tomboys, tonight it's the poetic librarians,'' said Steve Morrissey, the lead singer and lyricist for the Smiths, about the audience at the Beacon Theater Tuesday night. Through songs that speak very directly but poetically about the pain of life and the difficulty of making emotional contact with others, Mr. Morrissey has created for himself the mystique of someone who is almost too sensitive to live.

title: BRITISH TELECOM PLC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-No per share figures were given for the year-ago periods because the company went public in December 1984. Share earnings represent American Depository Receipts, which equal 10 shares of British Telecom ordinary stock. The latest quarter net income includes a provision of $186,000,000 for deferred taxes and latest year net includes a provision of $663,000,000 for deferred taxes. All figures are translated into U.S. dollars using an exchange rate of $1.24 to the pound, the rate prevailing on March 31, 1985.

title: RESTORING DAMAGED MOLDING
description: WOODEN molding seen on doors and inner sides of window frames rarely rates a second glance, but when this form of adornment appears on furniture it can be a different story. Molding is the decoratively-shaped band that borders a flat surface, its profile catching light and shade, furthering the embellishment. The various molding styles were created by the Greeks but are known by Latin names: cyma recta, cyma reversa, caveto, scotia.

title: ALBANY TACKLES THORNY MALPRACTICE INSURANCE ISSUE
description: Sometime in the next week or so, lawmakers here expect to pass legislation intended to stem the rising premiums paid by physicians in New York for malpractice insurance.

title: ITALY CAPTURES A TOP TERRORIST
description: Italy's most-wanted terrorist was arrested today, the police announced. She is Barbara Balzerani, said to be the last member of the Red Brigades executive council still at large.

title: BILLING ERRORS COST TRANSIT AUTHORITY MILLIONS
description: The Transit Authority has failed to collect - and probably cannot recover - as much as $100 million from the city, state and Federal Governments, transit officials said yesterday.

title: TRIPS TO ATHENS ARE BEING CANCELED
description: Tourists, athletes, a cruise line and Pan American World Airways canceled or altered planned trips to Greece yesterday after President Reagan's warning about security problems at the Athens airport and general unrest in the Middle East.

title: COLLECTING MARBLES ISN'T JUST CHILD'S PLAY
description: ''WHEN I showed people the marbles I kept in my jewelry box, they laughed,'' said Beverly Brule, of Marble Collectors Unlimited in Northboro, Mass. ''A couple of years ago, when you asked an antique dealer for marbles, they dragged out a slab of marble for you. Now, they recognize them as true collectibles. If they don't have any to sell, they don't laugh anymore.''

title: SECURITY COUNCIL FAULTS SOUTH AFRICA ON NAMIBIA
description: The Security Council called today for ''appropriate measures'' against South Africa unless it complied with United Nations efforts to establish an independent South-West Africa.

title: Suicide in Police Car Chase
description: A man shot the Police Chief, stole his patrol car and killed himself early today when the police chased him, officials said. The suspect, Benefacio Rodriguez, 27 years old, was found dead in the stolen patrol car 15 miles from here, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol said. The Police Chief, John Juvenile, was in critical but stable condition.

title: Chrysler Deal for Gulfstream
description: The boards of the Chrysler Corporation and the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation said yesterday that they had approved the acquisition of the aircraft manufacturer by Chrysler for $19 a share, or $637 million. The purchase will be financed by $310 million in cash and the issuance of $327 million of notes.

title: Resolute Speaker
description: The circumstance before the pomp was a bit roiled.

title: Turk, Refused a Swiss Visa, Shoots a Consul in Istanbul
description: An irate Turk who had been denied a visa to enter Switzerland shot a Swiss consul today.

title: People
description: Alain Rousset and Michael H. Popernik each was named senior vice president and chief financial officer/ worldwide of HCM, a joint venture of Young & Rubicam and Havas Conseil of France.

title: DOMINO'S PIZZA INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
CALENDAR: PARK WALKS, SEASIDE GARDENING
description: Quilt Lectures, New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, 2 Columbus Circle, 212-581-2474.

title: Monaco Yacht Race Set
description: Prince Albert of Monaco joined Mayor Koch and city port officials yesterday to announce plans for a transatlantic yacht race from Monaco to New York dedicated to the memory of the Prince's mother, Princess Grace. The race is scheduled to begin Oct. 13 in Monaco and end in New York Harbor.

title: PATTY DUKE SEEKING ACTORS GUILD PRESIDENCY
description: Patty Duke has announced that she will be a candidate for the presidency of the Screen Actors Guild, and today it appeared that she would get the official endorsement of the guild's nominating committee.

title: A Humbling Game
description: This is an event in which bad is good, and by that standard Angelo Spagnolo of Fayette City, Pa., had a very good day. He lost five-dozen golf balls as he carded a 185-over-par 257 - including a 66 on the par-3 17th hole, where he put 27 balls into the water - to win (lose) a tournament to determine the Worst Avid Golfer in America. ''I used to bowl,'' he said, ''but my scores were so bad I took up golf, and now my golf scores are higher than my bowling scores.'' Jack Pulford was the runner-up, 49 shots off the pace, with a 208. Joel Mosser was next with a 192 and Kelly Ireland finished way back (ahead) with a 179. Par for the Tournament Players Course at Ponte Vedra, Fla., is 72. Ireland set the tone for the tournament, sponsored by Golf Digest magazine, on the first stroke of the day, smashing a 15-foot tee shot that landed in the second row of the bleachers. But after seven hours of play, all he could show for his round was a trophy inscribed ''1st Worst.'' Spagnolo got the one for ''Worst-Worst.'' . . . In Flanders, N.J., a serious golf event involving 120 competitors began: the United States Golf Association Women's Public Links Championship. Sue Billek of Provo, Utah, shot a par 72 to lead the field after the first round of the 36-hole qualifier for match play. Miss Billek, who was born in New York City and spent her childhood in Lake Hopatcong, N.J., balanced three birdies and three bogeys over the 5,484-yard Flanders Valley Golf Club course and led Cindy Schreyer of Athens, Ga., and Danielle Ammaccapane of Phoenix by one shot.

title: 'MENGELE' BOOKS REPORTED SEIZED
description: A magazine editor said today that four notebooks said to have been written by the Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele had been impounded by the Frankfurt prosecutor's office.

title: HOUSE APPROVES A BILL TO BLACKLIST FOREIGN AIRPORTS DEEMED UNSAFE
description: The House and Senate, venting their frustration over the hijacking drama in Beirut, swiftly passed measures today to improve airport security, and members of Congress lined up with additional proposals to toughen safeguards against air piracy.

title: Nantucket Gas Truck Leaks
description: A propane gas leak in a delivery truck forced more than 400 island residents from their homes Tuesday for nearly three hours, officials said.

title: David Eaton Conducts The City Symphony
description: The New York City Symphony, or at least its name, has a history dating back to the 1920's. To judge by its concert under David Eaton in Alice Tully Hall Monday, the current incarnation finds its place among the several capable but not particularly distinctive ensembles of freelancers that play regularly in this town.

title: STAGE: 'VAMPIRE LESBIANS OF SODOM'
description: IN Charles Busch's ''Vampire Lesbians of Sodom'' and the accompanying ''Sleeping Beauty or Coma'' the legitimate stage, if that's what it can be called in this case, may have found the answer to ''The Rocky Horror Picture Show.'' One can imagine a cult forming. Costumes flashier than pinball machines, outrageous lines, awful puns, sinister innocence, harmless depravity - it's all here. And it is contagious; this kind of campy show that transforms everything it touches attracts audiences that could take over and finish the performance if the cast walked out in the middle.

title: FUROR IN JAPAN OVER TV MURDER
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone joined other Japanese today in expressing dismay that a group of journalists had stood by and taken photographs while two men bayoneted a businessman to death.

title: MEDDLING CHARGED BY SOUTH AFRICA
description: President P. W. Botha denounced what he termed Western double standards toward his country today, and said South Africa could solve its problems without ''international meddling'' in its affairs.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 20, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: France, the Magazine
description: Anew magazine, in English, for Americans, is being published by the French Embassy.

title: Oilfield Stocks' Outlook Weak
description: THE computer industry is not the only sector that is drawing negative comments and lowered earnings estimates on Wall Street. Consider, for example, the plight of the oilfield services group that was flying high back in the boom period of energy prices.

title: Jumper Loses 'E' for Effort
description: Last Sunday, when Willie Banks became the first American in three-quarters of a century to set a world record in the triple jump, there was some confusion regarding his predecessor, who was identified in a number of news reports as Dan Ahearne.

title: Pitchers Continue To Baffle Pitchers
description: If you have the feeling that hitters are in a mass slump this season, especially in the National League, you are right. Now, the only question is why.

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL DENIED ABSOLUTE IMMUNITY
description: The Supreme Court today rejected the Reagan Administration's argument that an attorney general is absolutely immune from suit for violating an individual's legal or constitutional rights in the name of national security.

title: Steelers Waive Johnson
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers said that the veteran defensive back Ron Johnson had cleared waivers and was a free agent. Johnson, a first-round draft choice from Eastern Michigan in 1978, said ''I'll sit tight for a while and see if I get any calls from other teams.

title: CITIZENS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Earnings per share of series A common stock were 50 cents and $2.30 for the latest quarter and year, respectivley, and 44 cents and $1.99 for the year-ago quarter and year, respectively. c-Earnings per share of series B common stock were 50 cents and $2.30 for the latest quarter and year, respectively, and 47 cents and $2.13 for the year-ago quarter and year, respectively. Series A earnings per share for the year-ago quarter and year have been adjusted for subsequent stock dividends.

title: MAINE ACTS TO REVIVE BIRD LANDS
description: Maine is spending millions of dollars to preserve thousands of tiny islands along its coastline - the homes of many migrating seabirds.

title: EVIDENCE IS SAID TO POINT TO MENGELE IDENTIFICATION
description: The Brazilian official in charge of the Josef Mengele investigation said today that ''all experts are coming to the same conclusion'' and that he hoped to have an announcement by the end of this week.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A SHORT HISTORY OF A SMALL PLACE. By T. R. Pearson. 381 pages. Linden/Simon & Schuster. $16.95. UNLIKE the blood of aristocrats, that remarkable Southern gift for talk seems to get thicker as it gets passed down through the generations since William Faulkner. One of the many places it has coagulated is in this first novel by T. R. Pearson, ironically (given its length) called ''A Short History of a Small Place,'' which recounts yet again the decline of Southern nobility and the rise of the riffraff, but in a voice that makes it all seem slapstick and zany, as if Quentin Compson had stepped in a bucket of paint on his way to the Charles River and Benjy the idiot had run off and joined the pro golf tour.

title: Courage Acknowledged
description: ''I couldn't leave New York without coming to see you.''

title: MAYORS BID CONGRESS AMEND TAX PROPOSAL
description: In an unusual display of bipartisan unity, the nation's mayors today urged Congress to amend President Reagan's tax plan to allow continued deduction of state and local taxes and to retain the tax-exempt status of municipal bonds.

title: CURB IN REACTOR PERIL ORDERED
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today ordered its staff to make regulatory changes aimed at limiting the dangers of using bomb-grade material in research reactors at universities and commercial enterprises.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Ford Ratings Up
description: The Ford Motor Company and Ford Motor Credit Company's senior long-term debt was raised to A from A- by the Standard and Poor's Corporation, affecting about $5.5 billion of debt securities.

title: Lessons on Avoiding Alcohol in Alcohol City
description: When it comes to strong drink, the nation's capital is the nation's capital.

title: NAVY HEART SURGEON CHARGED IN 4 PATIENT DEATHS
description: The former top heart surgeon at the Navy's flagship hospital will face a general court-martial on charges of involuntary manslaughter in the death of four patients, the Pentagon said today.

title: COLLEGE HEADS SEEK TO CONTROL ATHLETICS
description: Stiffer penalties for recruiting violations and tighter control of athletic department budgets will be at the top of the agenda Thursday when the National Collegiate Athletic Association opens a two-day special convention here on ''integrity and economics'' in intercollegiate athletics.

title: Strength and Comfort
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Army Rescinds Order Grounding 61 Copters
description: The Army, attributing an April 21 helicopter accident to human error, today lifted an order that had grounded its fleet of giant Chinook helicopters since May 4.

title: Truck Driver Guilty in Crash
description: A Canadian truck driver was convicted of criminally negligent homicide in the deaths of three Michigan residents who were killed last year when the truck he was driving rammed their car from behind on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway. A State Supreme Court jury on Tuesday also convicted the truck driver - John Brownell, 36 years old, of Windsor, Ontario, on charges of driving with bad brakes and at an imprudent speed. He faces up to four years in prison.

title: Not Wagnerian
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: U.S. and Soviet Hold 2d Day of Afghan Talks
description: Talks on Afghanistan between United States and Soviet officials went into a second day today with officials declining to comment on them.

title: ALFRED V. TAYLOR
description: Alfred V. Taylor, an official at social service agencies for more than three decades, died Saturday. He had suffered a stroke at his summer home in Ocean Bay Park, Fire Island.

title: Not Publicity, Notoriety or Even Site Makes a Sculpture Great
description: To the Editor:

title: CIRCUIT CITY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
FROM RUGS TO GLASS AND MORE
description: IT was, as David and Christine Van Der Hurd, left, admit, ''quite a switch.''

title: REAGAN VIEW: CARTER ECHO
description: By establishing as his ''primary goal'' the safe return of American hostages held in Lebanon, President Reagan has turned to a policy of restraint along the line followed by Jimmy Carter in the Iranian hostage crisis, foreign policy and Congressional officials said today.

title: EGYPTIAN AUTHOR DEFIES TRADITION
description: Laila Abou-Saif sees the book on the shelves of bookstores and, although the cover bears her picture and the pages her words, she feels strangely detached from ''A Bridge Through Time,'' her memoirs.

title: COMPLEX PARALLELS
description: While the holding of 40 American hostages by Lebanese Shiite militants inevitably invites comparison with the Iran hostage crisis, the drama being played out in Beirut has, if anything, an even more complex political background.

title: English Jazz Sextet At Eddie Condon's
description: An English sextet called Hefty Jazz, led by the trumpeter Keith Smith, was at Eddie Condon's Monday and Tuesday running the kind of gamut that one rarely hears a jazz group cover in this country.

title: CAPITAL GAINS ARE EARNED ON AFTER-TAX MONEY
description: To the Editor:

title: Official Moves Up At Marine
description: Marine Midland Banks announced yesterday that Thomas F. Donovan, a senior executive vice president since 1980, had been named vice chairman of the holding company and of its principal subsidiary, Marine Midland Bank.

title: OTHER MOVES IN THE DRAMA
description: Reagan Visits a Family -President Reagan unexpectedly met with the family of an American hostage in Indianapolis after a speech. Page A16.

title: DANCE: ASIAN SENSIBILITY
description: ELEANOR S. YUNG and her Asian American Dance Theater, which performed on Friday at Pace University's Schimmel Center, are at their best when they are at their simplest.

title: Police to Replace Highway Phones
description: The old and often inoperative emergency telephones along city highways will be replaced by new cellular telephones that cost less and are easier to maintain, the Police Department said yesterday.

title: Judge Dissolves Multimedia Order
description: Circuit Judge C. Victor Pyle Jr. dissolved a temporary restraining order against Multimedia Inc., saying Jack Kent Cooke should present his complaints about the company's recapitalization plan at a shareholders' meeting.

title: India, Carbide Trade Charges
description: Even as negotiations continued in private, Indian Government and Union Carbide officials yesterday exchanged their most hostile public statements yet concerning responsibility for the gas leak tragedy in Bhopal, India.

title: YANKEES PUMMEL ORIOLES
description: Playing perhaps their most inspired baseball of the season, the Yankees concluded a three-game sweep of the Orioles e tonight with a 10-0 victory before a crowd of 37,470 at Memorial Stadium.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 20, 1985

title: FOR SOME, CITY AUCTION OF HOUSES IS CHANCE TO COME HOME TO HARLEM
description: Marie and Robert Richardson grew up in Harlem, raised their two daughters in the Bronx and Chappaqua, N.Y., and, after their youngest, Kim, finished college last year, moved to an apartment in Guttenberg, N.J. Now they want to complete a circle by ''coming back home'' to Harlem, Mrs. Richardson said, and buying a brownstone that ''could be a legacy to our children.''

title: REAGAN VIEWS ON HOSTAGES, PRE-1985
description: President Reagan has commented several times in the past on the holding of American hostages, most often during the crisis in Iran at the end of the Carter Administration. Here are excerpts from some of his comments.

title: Afghan Rebel Says His Men Put a Bomb Under Army Post
description: A prominent Afghan rebel commander has reported that his men tunneled under a large army post in Herat Province, near the Iranian border, and blew it up, his party said today.

title: RANGERS PICK SATOR, THEIR FIRST CHOICE
description: The long hunt that began with Ted Sator ended with Ted Sator, and as a result, the Rangers, finally and officially, have their successor to Herb Brooks.

title: '81 HUTTON STAFF REPORT TOLD OF BANK OVERDRAFTS
description: A House subcommittee released today an internal E.F. Hutton document addressed to George L. Ball, the firm's former president, and other high Hutton officials in 1981 informing them that a number of regional offices were making big profits by the heavy use of bank overdrafts.

title: Pepsi Problem at Coke Plant
description: A Coca-Cola employee who received a three-day suspension for drinking a Pepsi on the job was returned to work after one day and told he would not miss any pay. Charles Edwards, general manager of the Coca-Cola bottling plant where the employee, Dexter Gooden, works, said the layoff was an ''overreaction'' by a supervisor. Mr. Edwards said, however, ''It is against our policy for employees to drink competitive products on our property.''

title: COAST PARLEY ON MEDICARE AND MEDICAID OPENS AMID PROTESTS
description: A national conference on the future of Medicare and Medicaid opened here today after complaints led to special fee arrangements for the poor and the elderly so they could attend.

title: RANSBURG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Includes a provision of $2,500,000 as a reserve for restructuring debt related to the divestiture of the company's Glas-craft division.

title: JEWISH MUSEUM TO EXPAND
description: The Jewish Museum unveiled plans yesterday for a permanent multi-media exhibition in one or more new buildings that would trace 4,000 years of Jewish history. Without losing the museum's identity as an institution rooted in religion, the expansion would turn it into a museum with an international focus and scope.

title: State Water Rationing Order Lifted for One Town in Jersey
description: State officials have lifted a water rationing order for this Morris County town, but they warned that it would take more significant rainfall before the restriction would be eased in the 92 other affected communities.

title: MAX & ERMA'S RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to May 12
description: b-Net loss.

title: FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $903,579 for the quarter and $1,659,889 for the year, and tax credits of $48,100 for the quarter and $177,100 for the year. c-Net income, which reflects a loss of $63,944 from discontinued operations. d-Reflects a loss of $517,021 from discontinued operations.

title: Bureaucracy;   Office of Environment and Budget
description: It was, in a way, like the ballplayer dictating the rules of the game to the umpire.

title: RED CROSS DENIES IT IS NEGOTIATING
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that it could carry out any agreement to exchange the United States hostages in Beirut for more than 700 Lebanese Shiite prisoners in Israel, but that it could not act on a United States request that it determine Israel's plans for releasing the Lebanese detainees.

title: BIG BOARD FORMS UNIT TO SPOT ILLEGAL TRADES
description: Saying that a jump in corporate mergers has brought an increase in ''questionable'' trading, the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it was forming a new unit to crack down on illegal trades.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 9.50-10.00** Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: WALKER'S LINE LITTLE KNOWN
description: The linemen blocking for Herschel Walker have identified with his remarkable feats this season, even though they realize that many fans watching Walker do not know their names.
