title: READER'S DIGEST CAMPAIGN
description: THE new high command of the secretive Reader's Digest Association, which has $1.4 billion in annual sales, is throwing open its windows to the public with a $1 million corporate ad campaign, the first in the Digest's 63-year history.

title: NAHAMA & WEAGANT ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Next Stop, Morocco
description: Thomas A. Nassif, deputy assistant secretary of state for Near Eastern and South Asian affairs, is expected to be the next United States Ambassador to Morocco. Mr. Nassif, a lawyer from California who was the State Department's deputy chief of protocol before being named a deputy assistant secretary, has been nominated by President Reagan to succeed Joseph Verner Reed Jr. Mr. Reed is expected to be reassigned, as a deputy delegate to the United Nations.

title: Socialist International Shuns President's 'Star Wars' Plan
description: The Socialist International today rejected President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative and similar space-based missile defense systems and urged countries not to take part in these projects.

title: A Lawyer's Viewpoint
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Sports Pages yesterday with an article about the National Basketball Association draft misidentified the player with Benoit Benjamin and Patrick Ewing. It was Wayman Tisdale of the University of Oklahoma.

title: New Mexico Offering Tax Refunding Bonds
description: New Mexico offered $262.4 million of severance tax refunding revenue bonds in serial form yesterday through underwriters led by E.F. Hutton & Company. Underwriters offered the bonds with tentative yields ranging from 4.80 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 6 3/4 percent in 1990, 7.20 percent in 1992 and 7.60 percent in 1994.

title: No Big Deal
description: Just as ticked off as Corrales are the majority of high school football coaches in southwestern Pennsylvania, where, if you said that schoolboy football is a matter of life and death, you would be understating matters.

title: SENATE REPUBLICANS OFFER NEW BUDGET PLAN
description: Republican Senate conferees proposed a compromise budget plan this evening that would protect the poor from a freeze on Social Security increases and add more than $1 billion for other aid programs.

title: NICARAGUA FAULTS AGENDA AT PARLEY
description: Nicaraguan representatives today rejected an agenda for the latest round of Central American peace talks, and a session of the negotiations was cut short.

title: EDWARDS, A G SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CUOMO WARNS WHITE HOUSE
description: Governor Cuomo of New York said today that Patrick J. Buchanan, the White House communications director, was turning tax revision into an ''ideological'' debate that could alienate key Congressional Democrats whose support is crucial to passage of President Reagan's tax plan.

title: DECONCINI TO OPPOSE REYNOLDS NOMINATION
description: A pivotal Senator announced today that he would oppose the nomination of William Bradford Reynolds to be Associate Attorney General, even as the White House stepped up lobbying to save the nominee on the eve of a vote by the Judiciary Committee.

title: ISRAELIS LAUD REAGAN STAND AGAINST YIELDING TO TERROR
description: Israeli officials said today that they welcomed President Reagan's uncompromising approach to dealing with the Beirut hijackers.

title: Mistaken Opposition To the N.L.R.B.
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., is toying with a misguided proposal by advocating the repeal of the National Labor Relations Act, a statute once thought to constitute a bill of rights for workers.

title: The Magna Cum Laude Coach
description: In his inaugural address as the New York Rangers' 20th coach, Ted Sator talked about ''direction, guidance and discipline'' and the value of ''surface tension,'' befitting a magna cum laude graduate of Bowling Green in health and physical education. But after 45 years of the Rangers being unable to win the Stanley Cup, he was quickly asked his timetable for being the magna cum leader of a team that would win the silver chalice that now resides in Gretzkytown.

title: Test for Maxwell
description: The Los Angeles Clippers have made no secret of their interest in Cedric Maxwell, the Celtics' forward, and on Tuesday they had their team physician examine Maxwell's ailing left knee. Afterward, the club said that although the knee was not as strong as the right one, it could probably be rehabilitated.

title: Long Way Down
description: He has never been a manager known for taking it real easy on his team.

title: Bad Cheese Suspected In 42 Deaths in 2 States
description: The number of deaths in two states linked to a bacteria that has been found in a Mexican-style cheese reached 42 today, and officials around the nation investigated whether other deaths had been caused by the tainted product.

title: NATIONAL LUMBER & SUPPLY reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Year-ago results are for the three months ended March 31 because the company changed its fiscal year-end.

title: FIREWORK HAZARDS DISPLAYED IN WASHINGTON
description: The United States Consumer Product Safety Commission set off a series of explosions today about 200 feet from the Washington Monument in a demonstration of the dangers of fireworks and illegal mail-order fireworks kits.

title: Lilco Bonds Set To Yield 13.30%
description: The Long Island Lighting Company is offering $225 million of 13 1/4 percent general and refunding bonds due in 1995 through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: Harvester Plans Receivables Sale
description: The International Harvester Company said that its finance subsidiary, the International Harvester Credit Corporation, had retained Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company to help the finance unit market about $1.2 billion in wholesale and retail notes receivable.

title: A.T.&T., QUOTRON DEAL LIKELY
description: Entering a crowded but growing market, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is expected to announce today that it is joining with Quotron Systems Inc. to provide up-to-the-minute financial information and data-processing abilities to stockbrokers and other investors.

title: MAYS, J W INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results for the latest quarter include real estate tax refunds of $247,369. Results for the latest nine months include real estate tax refunds of $297,803 and results for the year-ago nine months include a gain of $1,488,939 on the sale of property and a real estate tax refund of $536,783.

title: BELLAMY'S BACKERS ARE PRESSURING FARRELL TO DROP MAYORAL CHALLENGE
description: Supporters of City Council President Carol Bellamy are making a strong effort to persuade Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. to drop out of the Democratic mayoral race. The move comes amid increasing signs of disenchantment with Mr. Farrell among his early supporters and sponsors.

title: IT'S TIME FOR THE DEMOCRATS TO BE TOUGH-MINDED
description: For much of the last decade, the Democratic Party has spoken with a multitude of conflicting voices on foreign policy. Unable to reconcile the differences between the left and right wings of our own party, we have created the impression that we are too divided to govern. If Democrats are going to regain the confidence of the American people and recapture the White House, we will have to develop a new - and more tough-minded - consensus on foreign policy.

title: A.T.&T. Controller
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it had named C. Perry Colwell to the position of controller. The appointment is effective July 1.

title: Chase Promotes 3 To Vice Chairman
description: Three of Chase Manhattan Corporation's 14 executive vice presidents were promoted to vice chairman yesterday and became members of what the bank calls its top management team. They are Robert R. Douglass, Arthur F. Ryan and Anthony P. Terracciano.

title: DODGERS END HAWKINS'S STREAK AT 11
description: Andy Hawkins's 11-game winning streak ended tonight. Pedro Guerrero started a four-run Dodger rally against Hawkins in the seventh inning with his 14th home run, and Los Angeles went on to beat the San Diego Padres, 5-1.

title: E.P.A. Proposes a Ban On Fungicide for Food
description: The Environmental Protection Agency proposed Tuesday that the fungicide captan be banned from use on food because the chemical produces tumors in mice and rats.

title: PLAN FOR CRIME DATA OVERHAUL
description: A Justice Department study group reported today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation's crime statistics were seriously flawed, and it recommended substantial changes in how they are collected and published.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
MULLIN MAKING A TOUGH MOVE
description: It's a feeling that occurs every year at this time, and it affects each of the league's 23 teams. It's called postdraft euphoria. The players feel it, too, because it's a time when lifelong dreams of happiness and riches are finally realized.

title: WHISTLING AS A FULL-TIME CAREER
description: One fall day many years ago, a young man with music on his mind was sitting in a seventh-grade reading class in Ardsley High School. He cannot now recall the exact circumstances that distracted him, but it must have been the kind of day or the kind of class that sets the mind to wander.

title: BEIRUT CEASE-FIRE PERMITS RESCUE OF THE WOUNDED
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross began a major rescue operation today to evacuate people wounded in recent fighting in two Palestinian refugee settlements in the Beirut area.

title: Tax Code Described As 'Enemy'
description: President Reagan, in a strong defense of his proposed Federal tax overhaul, said today that the current tax system had ''become public enemy No. 1'' for middle-income Americans.

title: U.S. COURT BACKS COMPANY RIGHT TO MOVE AWAY TO NONUNION PLANT
description: In a decision with far-reaching implications for organized labor, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled Tuesday that companies are permitted to move operations from a union to a nonunion plant in order to cut labor costs, unless a contract specifically prohibits such transfers.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day June 12 about the the sale of The National Law Journal incorrectly described a competing publication. The competitor is Legal Times, a weekly that covers legal matters throughout the nation.

title: SCREEN: WATERGATE AND NIXON
description: ONCE again, almost 11 years after Richard M. Nixon resigned the Presidency in disgrace, the intensity of interest that many Americans felt for one of their most durable but unlikely political leaders has been freshly revived by ''Secret Honor,'' a 90-minute, one-actor film, with an added dimension of fiction that does not seem at all out of place.

title: AFTER THE WHITE WALL: ELABORATELY PAINTED ROOMS
description: IN the late 19th century, the pale colors and discreet ornamental plaster and wood work that characterized many houses gave way to boldly patterned wall decoration. Today history seems to be repeating itself with a second period of vivid and elaborate decorative wall painting. While the white wall that typified modern interiors was challenged several years ago by soft post-modern colors and painted details, even post-modern interiors pale in comparison to these newer rooms, some of them like painted Cineramas - total, wraparound visual environments.

title: Of Friends and Assets
description: As a Senator, Bill Bradley of New Jersey prefers to be known as a fiscal and tax expert and almost never refers to his past professional life. But other people do it for him. Representative Jack Kemp, a former Buffalo Bills quaterback who is now a tax expert himself, recently introduced the Senator as ''the former depreciable asset of the New York Knicks.''

title: STAGE: 2 LONDON PLAYS TOUCH ON STALINIZATION
description: In a London season dominated by lustrous stagings of the classics, ''Pravda'' is the single new play that everyone wants to see and debate. What's beyond debate is the epic size of the production and its ambitions. Billed as a ''Fleet Street comedy,'' this ironically titled work parades over 30 characters across the National Theater's vast Olivier stage. ''Pravda'' aspires to be nothing less than a ''Front Page'' for its time, and, in its malevolently funny first act, it actually succeeds.

title: QUINONES 'REPORT CARD' NOTES GAINS BY SCHOOLS
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones said yesterday that the New York City school system was making ''progress in serving its students'' but still faced many barriers to further improvement.

title: Bloom Is Getting More Gaines Work
description: It was a fun group, a happy group, that met for breakfast at the St. Regis Hotel yesterday, all members of the staff of the Bloom Agency of New York. And they were made all the more so by the antic home movie that caught each of them in some silly situation at the office.

title: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
ANXIOUS KIN OF HOSTAGE ARE CONSOLED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan met unexpectedly today with the family of one of the American hostages in Beirut after promising that he would not ''cave in'' to the demands of terrorists and ''reward their grisly deeds.''

title: U.S. SEES THE PRESS HELPING HIJACKERS
description: A Pentagon spokesman said yesterday that a majority of the news organizations were providing information that might be useful to the hijackers of the Trans World Airlines plane.

title: HOUSE VOTES FUNDS TO RENEW OUTPUT OF NERVE WEAPONS
description: Under strong pressure from the White House, the House of Representatives approved funds today for the production of new chemical weapons, ending its 16-year moratorium on such spending.

title: Synthetic Fuel Curb Voted
description: A House subcommittee voted today to abolish the Synthetic Fuels Corporation and set up a much smaller program in the Energy Department.

title: Westinghouse Bid
description: TSC Inc. said that the Westinghouse Electric Corporation had offered to buy it for $13.50 a share and that the TSC board had recommended approval of the offer. TSC, which is engaged in research and development of advanced military radar systems and sonar and infrared sensor systems, has about 1.6 million shares outstanding.

title: Interest Rates Rise In Profit Taking
description: Reversing course, interest rates jumped yesterday as traders took profits following the recent exuberant rally.

title: NEW IDEAS FOR FANS
description: KEEPING cool will be easier this summer with two new types of fans that have just arrived in city stores. Ventilore by Softwind is a tiny white fan that fits into any light socket.

title: SURVIVAL FIGURES ON CANCER ARGUED
description: Figures that appear to show some lung cancer victims survive longer now than 20 years ago may be inaccurate because the disease is spotted sooner and patients are monitored longer before death, a new study suggests.

title: PARENT CONCERN DENIES RESPONSIBILITY IN PARK FIRE
description: The president of the Six Flags Corporation testified today that safety decisions were a local responsibility of each of the corporation's nine amusement and theme parks around the country.

title: SUZANNE FARRELL DANCES IN HARMONY
description: Death and transfiguration are the themes of ''In Memory of . . .,'' Jerome Robbins's latest creation for the New York City Ballet. And balletgoers seem agreed that one of the things that makes this choreographic elegy especially poignant is Suzanne Farrell's performance in its central role.

title: AGCA IMPLICATES AN ITALIAN BEING HELD IN NEW YORK
description: Mehmet Ali Agca said today that a businessman wanted for involvement in Italian political and financial scandals had visited him in jail and urged him to implicate Bulgaria in a purported plot to assassinate Pope John Paul II.

title: SEX CHARGES AGAINST PRIEST EMBROIL LOUISIANA PARENTS
description: The admission by a Roman Catholic priest that he sexually abused 37 children entrusted to his care has aroused a deep sense of betrayal and shame in this small rural community in southwestern Louisiana.

title: F.B.I. REPORTS 15 CONTACTS FOR WALKER WITH RUSSIANS
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has identified at least 15 meetings or ''contacts'' between John A. Walker Jr. and Soviet intelligence agents since 1977, according to documents the F.B.I. released recently.

title: 2 LEBANESE GUNMEN GET A SPEEDY TRIAL IN SPAIN
description: Two confessed Lebanese gunmen whose freedom is a subsidiary demand of the airliner hijackers holding American hostages in Beirut admiited in court today that they had shot and wounded a Libyan diplomat here last September.

title: RENT RULES ARE EXTENDED FOR 2 YEARS
description: Rent regulations covering a million apartments in the New York metropolitan area were extended for two years under a bill passed tonight in the Legislature and signed by Governor Cuomo.

title: Chesebrough to Sell Its Health-Tex Unit
description: Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Health-Tex division to a management group headed by Robert A. Breakstone, a group vice president and former president of the children's wear manufacturer, in a leveraged buyout. Terms were not disclosed.

title: WD-40 CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
LABATT, JOHN LTD reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-After a $19,700,000 writeoff of surplus of obsolete bottles. The company is listed on the Montreal and Toronto stock exchanges.

title: Hunts Deny Silver Charges
description: The Hunt brothers of Texas today formally denied charges by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission that they illegally manipulated the silver futures market in 1979 and 1980.

title: Urban Wildflowers
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: HARD WORK DRIVES GIBSON TO SUCCESS
description: He considers batting practice part of his workday, not a time to socialize or cater to the early arrivals among the fans. On a recent afternoon at Yankee Stadium, Kirk Gibson was working hard, trying to punish the baseball instead of simply make contact. Big and strong and sporting the unshaven look that makes him more menacing, the Detroit Tiger outfielder growled to the batting-practice pitcher to put the ball over the plate and chastised himself for smashing two pitches in the dirt at his feet.

title: GROMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
QUIRK SEEN
description: Americans' personal income declined five-tenths of 1 percent in May, but the sharp drop was attributed to unusual factors that had put the April figure at an artificially high level, the Commerce Department said today.

title: HUSSEIN CALL HIJACKERS THE 'SCUM OF THE EARTH'
description: King Hussein of Jordan today condemned the hijacking of the T.W.A. jetliner and other acts of air piracy by Shiite Moslems as a betrayal of Islam and the Arab people. He called for ''collective action by all civilized nations to stop such dastardly acts of terrorism.''

title: Other Americans Held in Lebanon
description: Seven other Americans, in addition to the passengers and crew members of the Trans World Airlines jet hijacked last Friday, are being held hostage in Lebanon. These are the seven.

title: Degree Plan For Dropouts
description: Spurred by the success of a pilot program at Northeastern University, 11 colleges announced yesterday that they had formed a national consortium to offer degrees to former college athletes who left school without graduating.

title: Natural Gas Is an 'Unsootable' Fuel
description: To the Editor:

title: More Fine Print for the Disabled
description: It looked, at last, like a sensible capitulation to humanity and reason. The Reagan Administration announced it would abandon ''nonacquiescence'' -ignoring legal precedent - in decisions about granting Federal benefits to the disabled.

title: Eckerd Denies Merger Rumor
description: The price of the Jack Eckerd Corporation's stock rose yesterday in heavier-than-normal trading as rumors circulated that the drugstore chain might be seeking ways to fight off the advances of the Dart Group Corporation, including a merger with another company.

title: Mobile Phones Falling Short
description: CELLULAR mobile telephone service, which is just getting started in most cities, is already showing signs of inadequacy.

title: Citicorp Seeks To Enter Illinois
description: Citicorp promised to construct ''a significant building in Illinois'' if the Legislature agrees to open the state to interstate banking in two years.

title: Marijauna Legalization Appears to Lose Support
description: Public support for the legalization of marijuana is slipping, according to the latest Gallup Poll. The poll indicated that a steady growth in the number of those favoring legalization has reversed itself since the mid-1970's.

title: Southern Pacific
description: The Southern Pacific Transportation Company said it had reached a voluntary coordination agreement with Burlington Northern Inc. allowing each railroad to act as a marketing agent for the other. Southern Pacific, a subsidiary of the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation, said the agreement would simplify interline shipping arrangements for customers of the two railroads.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Abacus Real Estate Finance Group of Wellesley, Mass., has promoted Evan L. Weston to senior vice president of its Boston regional office.

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BRIEFS
description: Colonial Commercial Corp., Valley Stream, L.I., said it was exploring the disposition of its position in Monroc Inc., a producer of sand, gravel and concrete products, and Big Smith Inc., a producer of work clothes.

title: Financial Deposits
description: Financial Corporation of America said it had gained $107.7 million in deposits during May but had lost $2.45 billion in deposits for 1985 to date. In its monthly report, Financial Corporation listed total deposits of $17.88 billion as of May 31, down from $23.77 billion at the same time last year.

title: Washington State Site for RCA Seen
description: The RCA Corporation is expected to announce at a news conference Thursday that it plans to build a new $200 million high-technology manufacturing plant in the state of Washington, according to state government sources involved in the negotiations for the new plant.

title: PUEBLO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 18
description: b-After a tax credit of $495,000. c-After a tax credit of $361,000 and a gain of $663,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: A Death Lamented
description: What led to Edmund E. Perry's death is a matter of dispute. What is beyond question is the effect of his death on his Harlem elementary school.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think we'd all be dead men if they did because we are continuously surrounded by many, many guards.'' - Capt. John L. Testrake, talking about the possibility of an American rescue attempt. [A1:5.]

title: And for University Reform
description: Time is also running out on the sound reform that would give the state university the management flexibility everyone seems to agree it needs. Five months have passed since an independent commission called attention to the stifling overregulation of the university.

title: CHILDREN OF THE DISABLED FACE SPECIAL PRESSURES
description: AS a baby, Elyse Jenkins was told to pick up her toys. It was more important for her than for most children because her father is blind. When she learned to cross streets at the age of 5, she learned for two, always alerting her father to curbs and broken pavement. Now 19 years old and a freshman in engineering at Columbia University, she goes home every Saturday to the Bronx to read the mail aloud to her father and type his correspondence.

title: Plan for Lights At Wrigley Gains
description: A plan to let the Chicago Cubs play night baseball at Wrigley Field if they make the National League playoffs received preliminary approval today in the Illinois General Assembly.

title: ASSAD, IN MOSCOW, CONFERS ON MIDEAST ISSUES
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria met today with Mikhail S. Gorbachev in talks that appeared to be centered on American-backed peace moves in the Middle East and the continuing strife in Lebanon.

title: BALLET: 'TROY GAME'
description: Robert North's ''Troy Game'' is one of Dance Theater of Harlem's happiest dances.

title: Briton Dies on Matterhorn
description: A British climber fell 2,100 feet to his death during an attempt to scale the eastern side of the Matterhorn, Switzerland's most famous mountain, the police said today. A spokesman said the man's identity would be withheld until his family was informed.

title: LASER TEST FAILS TO STRIKE MIRROR IN SPACE SHUTTLE
description: Pentagon scientists today tried to bounce a laser beam off the space shuttle Discovery but failed because ground controllers sent instructions to the shuttle in nautical miles instead of feet, twisting it out of position for the experiment.

title: RENTAL CARS: RIVALRY FIERCE
description: UAL Inc., the parent company of United Airlines, knows about head-to-head competition, pricing, promotional wars and the value of winning the allegiance of the business traveler. In acquiring Hertz from RCA, as UAL agreed to do earlier this week, the company is going to have to put the skills it learned in the rough-and-tumble of the deregulated airline industry into another cutthroat business: car rental.

title: CANADIAN FARM FOLKWAYS: LAND IS LOST TO BANKS
description: When the Hutterite colony at Star City auctioned off 3,349 acres of fertile black soil recently, it was taken as proof that hard times were upon Canada's farmers.

title: TV Math From Those Who Brought Us Big Bird
description: ''Sesame Street'' helped children to read. ''3-2-1 Contact'' makes science less scary. And now, from the ever-restless Children's Television Workshop, comes ''The Math Series.''

title: Who Will Drive Cabs?
description: To the Editor:

title: LOCAL TRACES FOUND IN WATER AT U.S. COMPLEX
description: Unsafe levels of lead have been found in the water supply of the Federal Plaza complex in lower Manhattan, and officials said yesterday that they would test employees' blood for possible poisoning.

title: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $460,000, or 4 cents a share, from the reversal of deferred taxes.

title: The Hard Way
description: The latest Scandinavian sports rage is American-style football, and to see how well they have mastered the alien sport, a team of Swedish all-stars invited Bethany College of Kansas to send its football team to Stockholm for an exhibition game on Tuesday.

title: Paine Webber Names Head of New Bond Unit
description: To increase its involvement in municipal bond underwriting for major entities in New York, Paine Webber Inc. announced yesterday that it had formed a special unit within its municipal investment banking division, the New York Finance Group. The unit is believed to be the first of its kind at any investment bank.

title: New York's Unfinished Business;   Still Time for Truth in Sentencing
description: Governor Cuomo's effort to reform New York's criminal sentencing process remains barely alive in the Legislature, having been abandoned by district attorneys. Their defection is based on reasons of narrow interest that ought not to prevail.

title: HOUSTON SURGEONS USE LASER TO CLEAR CORONARY ARTERIES
description: Surgeons at the Texas Heart Institute in Houston have used lasers for the first time in the United States to remove plaque blocking the flow of blood through coronary arteries, they said yesterday.

title: U.S. RAID WOULD DOOM HOSTAGES, T.W.A. PILOT WARNS IN INTERVIEW
description: As the American hostage crisis entered its sixth day, the captive pilot of a hijacked T.W.A. airliner issued a warning that any United States rescue attempt would be futile.

title: Rent Control Creates New Kind of Serfdom
description: To the Editor:

title: BOMB AT FRANKFURT AIRPORT KILLS 3 AND WOUNDS 42
description: A powerful bomb ripped through an international departure lounge of the Frankfurt Airport this afternoon, killing three people and wounding 42, according to the police. There was no immediate claim of responsibility.

title: WILDFLOWERS AS ART IN A CHICAGO PARK
description: A meadow of pink primroses and white daisies, yellow coreopsis and blue phlox is not what Chicagoans ordinarily expect to see in the shadow of this city's highest skyscrapers. But early in May, 47 varieties of wildflowers began blooming in downtown Chicago in oval flower beds the size of two football fields.

title: Blast Kills 4 in France
description: An explosion at a munitions depot killed four bomb specialists here today. Officials said the exact cause of the blast in the former naval arsenal building was not immediately known.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ONCE a novelty used only by hobbyists and artisans, clear sheets of acrylic are now widely used in the home as a glazing material and for making decorative accessories.

title: A Chance Missed?
description: President Reagan, who found it so easy to attack Jimmy Carter over Iran, now knows something about the frustrations of power in a hostage crisis. But in the course of adjusting to reality he may have missed the chance to free the passengers of T.W.A. Flight 847 at the lowest possible price.

title: Geneva Arms Session Held
description: American and Soviet negotiators on strategic nuclear weapons met today at the American side's offices for almost two and a half hours, a statement issued by the United States said. Details of the meeting were not made public, under an agreement to maintain confidentiality. There are two other working groups in the talks, on space and defense weapons and on intermediate-range nuclear forces.

title: Trip Is Off
description: Among the Americans whose summer plans have been affected by the Beirut hostage incident and Washington's concern over the level of security at the airport in Athens are 11 whose names will be very familiar to basketball fans. Each is an officer or a player representative in the National Basketball Players Association, and all were to have flown out of New York next Thursday for a nine-day union-sponsored trip to Greece and two games against the Greek national team.

title: 3 Acquitted in Slaying Of Hawaii Official's Son
description: A jury in state court today acquitted three Honolulu men accused of taking part in the 1975 killing of Charles Marsland 3d, 19 years old, son of the current city prosecutor, Charles F. Marsland Jr. The prosecution's chief witness in the case was Ronald K. Ching, 36, who testified that he shot young Marsland twice in the chest with a shotgun at close range.

title: Twisting Reagan's Tail
description: There's been a strong temptation all week to throw President Reagan's bluster straight back at him, and it boiled over at his news conference Tuesday. As a candidate he suggested repeatedly that Jimmy Carter had handled the Iranian hostage crisis like a wimp, and after his election he warned terrorists worldwide that real men don't eat quiche. ''We hear it said that we live in an era of limit to our powers,'' he said in welcoming the Iran hostages home. ''Well, let it also be understood, there are limits to our patience.''

title: Nets to Introduce Coach
description: Three days after losing their head coach, the Nets will get a new one today. At a news conference scheduled for 1:30 this afternoon, the Nets are expected to name Rollie Massimino of Villanova to replace the departed Stan Albeck.

title: ISRAELIS DEADLOCK ON A LAND DISPUTE
description: Officials of Prime Minister Shimon Peres's coalition Government were deadlocked today over whether to comply with a demand by Egypt to submit a land dispute to international arbitration.

title: DAUGHTER FELT PRESSURE TO SAVE WALKER
description: Laura Walker Snyder waited three years to tell the authorities about suspicions that her father, John A. Walker Jr., was a spy because her family wanted her to keep quiet to protect him, she said in an interview broadcast today.

title: BOMB IN NORTHERN LEBANON IS SAID TO KILL 31
description: A car bomb exploded today in Tripoli, Lebanon's second largest city, and initial police reports said 31 people were killed and more than 50 were wounded.

title: VERTIPILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
description: b-After a tax credit of $5,000.

title: PIANO RECITAL: BRACKEEN PLAYS JAZZ
description: JOANNE BRACKEEN set out to dazzle listeners - and dazzle them she did - in her solo piano concert Wednesday at Carnegie Recital Hall. Her powerful, two-fisted playing has absorbed all the major modern jazz piano styles, notably those of McCoy Tyner, Chick Corea, Bill Evans, Herbie Hancock, Bud Powell, Keith Jarrett, Randy Weston and even a little bit of Cecil Taylor; her improvisations whiz around the keyboard, undaunted by harmonic complexity or high speeds.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 21, 1985

title: MOREHOUSE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
The U.N. Today
description: June 21, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FILM: A NEW 'OZ' GIVES DOROTHY NEW FRIENDS
description: ''RETURN TO OZ,'' which opens today at Radio City Music Hall, is the work of ingenious technicians who seem either not to know what gave the original film its magic, or not to care. Instead of the ''Wizard of Oz'' sequel that its title suggests, ''Return to Oz,'' directed and co-written by Walter Murch, is more of a grim variation.

title: Showing Warsaw Carrots and Sticks
description: The sentencing last week of three Solidarity leaders - Adam Michnik, Bogdan Lis and Wladyslaw Frasyniuk - to prison terms of two and a half to three and a half years for ''disturbing the public order'' has again called attention to the unresolved political situation in Poland. For Americans, the sentences raise difficult questions about our policy toward Poland - about whether or not we should use sanctions and other retaliatory measures to demonstrate our disapproval. But before we react with new retaliatory measures, we ought to step back and assess our long-term interests in Poland.

title: F.B.I. CHECKING RECORDS OF 41,000 U.S. WORKERS
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is checking the records of 41,000 employees of the Department of Health and Human Services in an attempt to detect workers who may try to steal Government money by computer, officials said today.

title: MARQUEST MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Year to March 30
Star Wars and the Magic Mountain
description: The ''Star Wars'' strategic defense program has gotten off to a rocky start. Its first test on board the space shuttle sent the craft right through a 10,023-mile-high mountain. That's a bad augury for a defense system that must work perfectly the first time it's used.

title: SCREEN: 'COCOON' OPENS
description: ''COCOON'' begins by dwelling upon the shuffleboard, the medical supplies, the sudden forgetfulness and the forced good cheer that are the stereotypical accouterments of old age. It observes these things with a delight that the audience can share, since it will go on to describe the miracle by which a group of Florida retirees escapes their fate. The magical reversal by which an elderly man suddenly finds himself break-dancing is only one such turnabout the movie offers. ''Cocoon'' is a film in which extraterrestrial aliens come to Earth in the form of neatly dressed tourists, and one in which a beautiful young creature can slip off her skin to reveal an even more radiant inner being.

title: Ad Council Chairman
description: James H. Rosenfield, senior executive vice president of the CBS Broadcast Group, has been elected chairman of the Advertising Council, which since World War II has united the media, ad agencies and advertisers as the advertising industry's public service contribution. He is the first TV network executive to hold the post.

title: BROADWAY
description: STEVE SHAGAN, the best-selling author and script writer, has finished his first play, an offbeat comedy that may or may not be called ''Africa.'' The action takes place in Los Angeles within a 36-hour time span, and the leading character is a screen writer, once in demand, who is writing three scripts simultaneously in his apartment above Sunset Boulevard.

title: A WHO-WHERE-WHEN OF EVENTS AT THE FESTIVAL
description: Today 5 P.M. Carnegie Recital Hall. Marian McPartland, solo piano. Sold out. 8 P.M. Avery Fisher Hall. Miles Davis.

title: F.A.O. SCHWARZ SOLD TO CALIFORNIA DEVELOPER
description: F.A.O. Schwarz, the 22-store retailer whose lavish toys and games have delighted children and their indulgent parents for more than a century, is being acquired by the Christiana Companies, a California real estate developer and investment company. Christiana will be Schwarz's third owner in 11 years.

title: GENCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Stiffer Penalties Expected
description: Despite a few objections, members of the National Collegiate Athletic Association are expected to pass a series of proposals Friday that would permit the association to hand out stiffer penalties to colleges and coaches violating regulations.

title: SMITHSONIAN ACTS ON AFRICAN STOCKS
description: The Smithsonian Institution has decided to sell investments in companies doing business in South Africa that do not adhere to an anti-discriminatory code of conduct. The decision, made Monday, was announced today.

title: ART: JAPANESE AND THE SUPERNATURAL
description: AS they are in earthly matters, the Japanese are very inventive about the other world.

title: PACKWOOD SEES TAX PLAN SHIFT
description: Senator Bob Packwood, chairman of the Finance Committee and the most influential Senator on tax matters, said today that he expected President Reagan to modify his tax revision plan to make it more favorable to middle-income taxpayers.

title: JEM RECORDS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FRANKFURT BOMBERS NOT KNOWN
description: The Frankfurt police said today that they were following several leads in the bombing of the city's international airport but that they still had no indication of who might have set off the explosion.

title: Dow Up 2.35 as Stocks Close Mixed
description: Wall Street stock prices closed mixed yesterday as investors debated the pros and cons of a Government report that the economy improved during the second quarter.

title: Funds Assets Climb
description: Assets of money market mutual funds increased $2.72 billion in the week ended yesterday, to $218.84 billion, the Investment Company Institute said.

title: 8 Charged With Indecency
description: An undercover operation by the state police to reduce homosexual activity at rest stops on the Merritt Parkway near Greenwich and New Canaan has resulted in the arrests of eight men this week, the authorities said. Lieut. Kenneth Kirschner of the state police said the men had been arrested on charges of public indecency. He said the investigation would continue through the summer.

title: PRISON EXPANSION PLAN SET IN ALBANY
description: A plan to authorize the State Urban Development Corporation to build two new maximum-security prisons and to expand five other prisons has been agreed on by key lawmakers and the Governor's office, according to aides to Governor Cuomo and the lawmakers.

title: BEATRICE COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Diner's Journal
description: ONE of the best chicken sandwiches in town is rustled up at the new Cafe Montana, the latest grand grillery to appear on the Upper West Side. Situated in the Montana, a new apartment building at Broadway and 88th Street, the cafe is a cheerful, two-level restaurant with a tiled open kitchen (of course), plum-colored walls, Art Deco sconces and, in the upstairs dining room, tall windows affording a sweeping view of renascent Upper Broadway.

title: G.N.P. RISE PUT AT 3.1% IN QUARTER
description: The nation's economic activity is expanding in the second quarter at a moderate annual rate of 3.1 percent, after having virtually stalled in the first quarter, the Government said today.

title: Topics;   As the Smoke Clears De-escalation
description: New Yorkers have a special reason to welcome the victory of Anthony Cucci over Gerald McCann in Jersey City's raucous mayoral election: Westway. Just as the court fight over the project is ending, funding has been threatened by New Jersey Congressmen angered at New York City's attempts to block Federal development money for their state.

title: Bridge: A Recent Bibliography Fills Large Gap on the Bookshelf
description: A gaping gap in bridge literature has concerned bridge literature: There has never been a serious bibliography, apart from one limited to British publications.

title: SENATE PASSES $13.5 BILLION IN SUPPLEMENTAL 1985 APPROPRIATIONS
description: The Senate late tonight approved a $13.5 billion supplemental appropriations bill for 1985, including $250 million in economic aid for Jordan. Approval came on a voice vote.

title: Strawberry Festival
description: Strawberry shortcake, stone soup and musical entertainment will be served Sunday at the Beacon Sloop Club's free Strawberry Festival in Riverfront Park, Beacon, N.Y. Stone soup is a potpourri of vegetables, grains and seasonings, and those planning to attend are asked to bring ingredients to add to the pot.

title: Quartet at Henry Street
description: The trumpeter Cecil Bridgewater will lead a quartet tonight at 7 P.M. at the Henry Street Settlement Playhouse, 466 Grand Street (598-0400). Tickets are $5.

title: IDLE WILD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
7 REPORTED KILLED IN NEPAL BOMBINGS
description: Five bombs exploded at Government buildings, the royal palace and a hotel today, killing at least seven people in what is believed to be the first major terrorist attack in this Himalayan kingdom.

title: WILDERNESS EXPERIENCE reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income after tax credits of $9,000 for the quarter and $15,000 for the 6 months.

title: HACH CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After relocation costs of $76,000 for the quarter and $274,000 for the year and a gain of $389,000 from the sale of a building.

title: EX-AGENT 'MAY HAVE FAKED' TESTIMONY AT ESPIONAGE TRIAL
description: Richard W. Miller, saying ''it gets pretty tiring sitting up here answering questions,'' admitted today that he ''may have faked'' an answer he gave to a prosecutor in the the trial of an emigre couple who are charged with conspiring with him to spy for the Soviet Union.

title: INTERNATIONAL TELDATA II reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Argentina Goes Straight
description: Like a ravaged addict suddenly deciding to go clean, Argentina's Government last week swore off printer's ink and resolved to print and spend no more money than it collects. Higher taxes, slashed programs and wage and price controls will reduce living standards by 30 percent in just a few weeks. That is the hard meaning of what bankers euphemistically call putting one's house in order.

title: SPORTO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Sony Broadcast Picks Lord, Geller
description: Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein has a thing about quality clients. It likes them very much.

title: Gretzky'll Pass
description: When Dwight Gooden pitched the Mets to a 1-0 victory over Chicago at Shea Stadium on Wednesday night, Wayne Gretzky, in town to receive yet a couple of more awards, was among the 51,778 fans. After the game, Gretzky visited the locker room, where people were marveling at Gooden's celebrated fastball and his 125 strikeouts, tops in the majors. Gretzky was introduced to Ron Gardenhire, the reserve shortstop, who shook hands and asked, ''How would you like to face that heater?'' And the Great Gretzky, though once a baseball prospect himself, winced and replied, ''No, thanks, I'll stick to my job.''

title: Market Place;   Trying to Spot Bank Targets
description: FOR the better part of a year, regional banks have constituted one favorite area for trying to spot possible takeovers. In turn, this has done wonders for the prices of many regional bank stocks, making them one of the best-performing sectors of the equity market.

title: SWISS OFFER TO HELP OBTAIN RELEASE OF U.S. HOSTAGES
description: Switzerland said today that it had offered to help obtain the release of the American hostages in Beirut, and called on the Shiite militia leader Nabih Berri to free them on humanitarian grounds.

title: FOSTER'S SLAM HELPS METS SWEEP PLUMMETING CUBS
description: It was, said George Foster, ''a vendetta.'' It was, said Gary Carter, ''big time.'' It was, said Dave Johnson, ''probably the biggest series we'll have all year.''

title: SUPPRESSION OF EVIDENCE IN 1943 CITED
description: The Government suppressed evidence when it argued in 1943 that the Supreme Court should uphold the conviction of a Japanese-American citizen, a lawyer who represented the War Department then testified today.

title: ISRAELIS APPEAR ANGERED BY SUBTLE U.S. PRESSURE
description: Israeli leaders, angered by what they perceive to be subtle American public pressures to give in to the hijackers, affirmed today that they would make no concessions unless asked to do so officially by the United States.

title: CHURCH SANCTUARY WORKER GETS 2-YEAR TERM
description: A Federal district judge today sentenced the former director of a refugee center to two years in prison for hiding a Nicaraguan in her car trunk at a border check point.

title: VILLAGE VOICE IS BOUGHT BY CHAIRMAN OF HARTZ
description: The Village Voice, the outspoken liberal weekly that has been owned by Rupert Murdoch since 1977, was sold yesterday to Leonard Stern, a wealthy businessman.

title: Geneva Arms Talks Go On
description: The American and Soviet arms teams on medium-range missiles negotiated for just over two hours today, an American statement said. It gave no details, in keeping with the two sides' agreement to a news blackout for this second round of talks. No information on the date, location or subject of the next meeting was given.

title: ART: TRIBUTE TO MILLET AT THE IBM GALLERY
description: ''JEAN-FRANCOIS MILLET'' at the IBM Gallery, Madison Avenue at 56th Street, is a reduced version of an exhibition that was initiated by the Boston Museum of Fine Arts. Drawn almost entirely from that museum's holdings, it was shown first in Boston and later toured five cities in Japan. Even at something less than its original size, it is a remarkable tribute not only to a major French 19th-century painter but also to the good judgment of the Boston collectors who by 1889 had acquired more than 155 paintings, pastels and drawings. Not to covet something by Millet, at that date, was to be not quite a proper Bostonian.

title: Uganda Opposition Deputies Assail Human Rights Abuses
description: Uganda's opposition deputies walked out of Parliament today to protest the Government's record on human rights, witnesses said.

title: Jake Butcher Gets Tax Term
description: Jake Butcher, the former banking entrepreneur who twice ran for Governor of Tennessee, was sentenced to 14 years in prison today for not reporting $38.5 million in income on tax returns from 1978-82.

title: For Want of a Horse
description: If in 1988 the Democrats are to regain a Presidency that has become almost a Republican office, which must come first - changes in party policy, or a winning candidate?

title: ALL THIS JAZZ
description: THREE of the legendary stars of jazz over the last four decades - Dizzy Gillespie, Miles Davis and Ella Fitzgerald -will share the spotlight this evening as the annual 10-day Kool Jazz Festival gets under way. Mr. Davis and his band will be at Avery Fisher Hall, Miss Fitzgerald at Carnegie Hall and Mr. Gillespie and his quintet will inaugurate a festival moonlight cruise on the Hudson River.

title: COUNCIL UNIT PASSES MEASURE LIMITING GRAFFITI DEVICE SALES
description: Legislation restricting the sale of spray paint was passed, 4 to 0, by a City Council committee yesterday in the city's latest attempt to curb graffiti.

title: Of Faith in Pepper
description: In the sometimes eccentric world of Congress, Representative Claude Pepper remains a phenomenon. He was elected to the Senate from Florida in 1936, before many current members of Congress were born.

title: MESSGAES AND EXCERPTS FROM NEWS CONFERENCE: 'PUT ASIDE FEAR, ANGER AND INSULT' TO RECTIFY WRONGS, THE HOSTAGES URGE
description: Following are excerpts from statements yesterday by American hostages from the hijacked Trans World Airlines jetliner, as provided by ABC News. The first five statements were delivered in tape recordings, and the subsequent statements were made in a news conference in Beirut, Lebanon.

title: TOP S.I. OFFICIALS IS SAID TO FACE CONFLICT CHARGES
description: The city's Department of Investigation has concluded in a report that Ralph J. Lamberti, now the Borough President of Staten Island, engaged in a conflict of interest when he helped a former business partner who was seeking to develop a shopping center on city-owned land, according to members of the Koch administration.

title: FINANCIAL NEWS NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Coal Shipping Guidelines
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission yielded to critics of deregulation today and abandoned a proposal that would have allowed railroads to raise prices for shipping coal by as much as 15 percent a year above inflation without regulatory approval.

title: COACHING SALARIES ZOOMING
description: In 1965, Jack Ramsay gave up a $10,000-a-year coaching job at St. Joseph's College in Philadelphia to become general manager of the Philadelphia 76ers. He is now the coach of the Portland Trail Blazers, having spent 20 years in the National Basketball Association.

title: SPY SUSPECT'S EX-WIFE TELLS OF WARNING HIM SO HE COULD FLEE TO SOVIET
description: Barbara Walker, the former wife of John A. Walker Jr., who is charged with spying, says she sent him a warning after she turned him in to the Federal Bureau of Investigation on the assumption that he would flee to the Soviet Union to avoid prosecution.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In our minds and to a man we condemn hijacking or terrorism of any sort or nature, regardless of the perpetrators or the circumstances.

title: Wilhelmenia Fernandez In Film on Channel 13
description: Curious are the interactions between old and new modes of performance. Wilhelmenia Fernandez is a young American opera singer of the old-fashioned sort. She studied at the Juilliard School and is industriously building a career for herself as a lyric soprano. But in 1981, she almost accidentally, to hear her tell it, got the role of the iconic opera singer in the French film ''Diva.'' Her appearance as a legendary star has propelled her ''real'' career. And now that career is being further helped by the electronic media, this time in a half-hour documentary titled ''Diva in Concert,'' to be seen tonight at 10:30 o'clock on Channel 13.

title: Bodies in Mexico Grave Identified as Americans'
description: Two bodies found in a shallow grave near Guadalajara have been identified by relatives as those of two missing United States citizens, the official news agency Notimex said today.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Year-ago results do not include nonrecurring net merger costs of approximately $18.1 million.

title: IVY PRESIDENTS CONFER ON DIVESTITURE
description: Investment in corporations doing business in South Africa, a matter of growing concern on the nation's campuses, was a prime topic of discussion for the Ivy League presidents this week as they gathered at an upstate mountaintop retreat for their semiannual meeting.

title: ALLEGHENY BEVERAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,027,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $992,000 for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $24,000. d-Results for the previous year are not available because of a change from the calendar year ended Dec. 31 to a fiscal year ended March 31. Results for the year-ago fourth quarter have been restated to reflect the sale of two subsidiaries which were reclassified as discontinued operations.

title: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
INTERNATIONAL CLINICAL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
P.L.O. Can't Speak For Palestinians
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics;   As the Smoke Clears Health Tax
description: Congress doubled the Federal excise tax on cigarettes to 16 cents a pack in 1983 mainly to raise revenue.

title: Ex-Admiral Hired By Toledo Edison
description: The Toledo Edison Company has turned to an outsider with a wealth of experience in nuclear power to head its nuclear program in the wake of an incident at one of the company's power plants.

title: MORE CORPORATIONS ARE OFFERING CHILD CARE
description: A rapidly growing number of American employers are providing some form of child-care assistance to workers. More than 1,800 companies are now doing so, compared with 600 in 1982, according to a study announced yesterday by the Conference Board, a nonprofit business research organization in New York.

title: How to End the Gulf War
description: To the Editor:

title: Olympia Deadline
description: Olympia & York Developments Ltd. said it had obtained an extension of the deadline by which it could withdraw from its proposed $2.18 billion purchase of a 60.2 percent stake in Gulf Canada Ltd. from the Chevron Corporation.

title: SINATRA SEEKS LIST OF PAPERS PRINTING 'DOONESBURY' COMIC
description: Lawyers representing Frank Sinatra have demanded a list of the names of newspapers that published a ''Doonesbury'' cartoon strip satirizing Mr. Sinatra from the distributor of the comic so they can seek retractions.

title: COMMANDO SQUAD IS TRAINED TO KILL WITH FULL 'SURPRISE, SPEED, SUCCESS'
description: If the United States were to attempt a military rescue of the Beirut hostages, it has a counterterrorism unit that might be used. Its members are trained to force entry into and ''clear'' a room in less than seven seconds, usually by putting two pistol bullets into each terrorist's head.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Montreal Expos, at Shea Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Opener of a three-game weekend series. The Mets' fortunes have changed considerably since last weekend, when they were swept by the Expos in a three-game series in Montreal. The Mets turned themselves around with four straight victories over the Cubs and have a chance to overtake Montreal for first place. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. Tigers, at Detroit. Second game of a four-game series, with the Yankees' Rickey Henderson on a hot streak that has thrust him into the American League batting lead. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WABC 770, 7:30 P.M.) Reds vs. Atlanta Braves, at Cincinnati, twilight-night doubleheader (Television - WTBS 6 P.M.) Golf Women's Amateur Public Links Championships, at Flanders Valley, Golf Club, Flanders, N.J. This United States Golf Association championship begins match-play format today, with the 32 qualifiers competing. There are two rounds today, a quarterfinal round tomorrow and the semifinals and finals on Sunday. Georgia Pacific Atlanta Classic, second round, at Marietta, Ga. Ladies P.G.A. Mayflower Classic, at Indianapolis, second round. P.G.A. Senior Tournament Players Championships, at Cleveland, second round. Other Events BASKETBALL: New Jersey Jammers vs. Connecticut Colonials, at Paterson State, Wayne N.J., 8:05 P.M. (Television - MSG Network, 8 P.M.). FOOTBALL: Renegades vs. Los Angeles Express, at Orlando, Fla. Both teams are out of the playoff picture. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.) HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt Raceway, 8 P.M. The Meadowlands, 8 P.M. The Historic Cup for 3-year-old trotting colts and geldings has been split into two divisions; Bon Sport and Flak Bait are the favorites in the first division, and Master Willie and Piggvar are the favorites in the second division.

title: COMEDY, A LA CINEMAX AND SHOWTIME
description: WHILE comedy has become a staple of some pay-television services, the results can be laughable for very different reasons. Witness two current specials: Cinemax's ''Martin Mull Presents the History of White People in America, Part I'' and Showtime's ''Joan Rivers and Friends Salute Heidi Abromowitz ... Almost Live From Caesar's Palace.'' Martin Mull is a seemingly mild-mannered actor-comedian who has been seen in television situation comedies like ''Fernwood 2-Night'' and movies like ''Mr. Mom.'' He specializes in the kind of poker-faced lunacy that made ''Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman'' so endearing. This time around (tomorrow at 4 P.M.), serving as writer and performer, Mr. Mull presides as a genial host for a ''documentary'' investigating the personality and habits of the basic white person or, more precisely, the white Anglo-Saxon Protestant person. His ''journey into whiteness,'' directed by Harry Shearer, was inspired by such minority explorations as ''Roots'' (''Who could ever forget Ben Vereen as Chicken George,'' he asks with an envious gleam in his eye).

title: Dining Out Guide: Chinatown
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. HOOLOK CORPORATION RESTAURANT, #54 East Broadway (226-0969) -

title: SILLS LEADS WITH 65
description: Tony Sills, forced to overcome serious physical difficulties to play golf, shot a seven-under-par 65 today to take the first-round lead in the Atlanta Classic.

title: Head Start Custodian Allowed Back on Job
description: The city's Human Resources Commissioner yesterday reinstated a custodian who works at a Head Start program on the Upper West Side, less than a day after the program's board reluctantly agreed to suspend him.

title: AGCA SAYS HE TRIED TO BLACKMAIL U.S. FOR RELEASE
description: Mehmet Ali Agca testified today that a letter he sent to the American military attache in Rome in 1983 was designed to blackmail the United States Government into helping him obtain release from prison.

title: Polish Minister Visits Italy
description: Foreign Minister Stefan Olszowski of Poland arrived here today for a two-day official visit to Italy and an audience with Pope John Paul II. No official agenda was announced, but the recent conviction of three Solidarity activists in Poland on charges of inciting unrest was likely to be raised by the Italian side, Foreign Ministry sources here said.

title: ECHLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Health-Tex Buyer Back On Familiar Ground
description: When Robert A. Breakstone was made president of Chesebrough-Pond's Inc.'s Health-Tex division in 1978, ''he took what had been a good operation with some problems and turned it into a powerhouse,'' said Joseph H. Kozloff, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. When Mr. Breakstone was promoted last year to be a group vice president of the parent company and relinquished day-to-day control of the business, Health-Tex, which makes children's apparel, ''promptly fell apart,'' Mr. Kozloff said.

title: LEGISLATURE STILL FACING MANY ISSUES ON HOUSING
description: Although the state's basic rent-regulation laws were extended for two years Wednesday night with great fanfare, a host of housing issues remain to be addressed by the Legislature. And time is getting short.

title: CULTURAL FESTIVAL TO OPEN IN ATHENS
description: With fireworks on the Acropolis and with such political leaders as President Francois Mitterrand of France in attendance, Athens will be inaugurated Friday night as the ''cultural capital of Europe'' for 1985.

title: HEAD OF HOUSE PANEL LOSES VOTE ON TOXIC WASTE CLEANUP PROGRAM
description: The legislative struggle over the future of the toxic waste law boiled over today as a House subcommittee rejected a bill introduced by its own chairman to enlarge and strengthen the waste cleanup program.

title: Suit Charges Conspiracy In Coal Mine Explosion
description: A lawsuit filed today charges that the Pittston Company conspired with two supervisors and a state official to hinder enforcement of safety regulations at a mine where seven miners died in a 1983 methane explosion.

title: Lawyers, Lawyers, Lawyers
description: It is not a development for which either the legal profession or the general public has been noticeably clamoring, but it looks as though Washington has more lawyers in private practice this year than it did in 1984. At any rate, the annual census conducted by the weekly tabloid the Legal Times shows that the 25 largest firms in the capital have grown by 175 lawyers, or about 7 percent, since the same count a year ago.

title: The Shoe Tax Beckons
description: The U.S. International Trade Commission, yielding to pressure, recommends quotas that would reduce imports of shoes sharply and drive up their price. President Reagan must now decide whether consumers should finance this remedy, saving American jobs at an annual cost of $50,000 each.

title: CONDOMINIUMS RISE IN FLATLANDS AREA
description: Four years ago Sidney Steinberg and Anthony Clemenza were renovating vacant loft buildings as apartments on lower Broadway in Manhattan. They did 32 units in Nos. 710, 722 and 620 Broadway, selling finished, full-floor apartments.

title: A Wrong Signal On Birth Control
description: Fifteen years ago, the United States was accused of espousing population control as a means of keeping developing countries weak and subjugated. Ironically, now that many have accepted the need to control population growth, the United States may change its tune.

title: DIOCESE UPHELD OVER ABORTIONS AT TWO CLINICS
description: In a legal victory for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Albany, the state was ordered by an appeals court today to reconsider its permission to let two Planned Parenthood clinics provide abortions.

title: A PASTA WAR MAY BE AT HAND
description: In an echo of the Chicken War of the 1960's between Europe and the United States over poultry exports, the White House fired a shot today in what threatens to become the Pasta War, having grown from what started out as a skirmish over citrus.

title: ARCHITECT CASTIGATES WHITNEY PLAN
description: In an acceptance speech to the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects for its 1985 Medal of Honor, the architect Abraham W. Geller last night condemned the proposed addition to the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: FILM: BY SATYAJIT RAY
description: NO matter what the particular story, no matter what the social-political circumstances of the characters, the cinema of Satyajit Ray (the ''Apu'' trilogy, ''The Music Room,'' ''Distant Thunder'' and ''The Chess Players,'' among others) is so exquisitely realized that an entire world is evoked from comparatively limited details. Thus his latest film, ''The Home and the World,'' adapted from the novel by the Nobel laureate Rabindranath Tagore, manages to be something that might be called a sweeping chamber-epic.

title: File It Under 'A,' If You Please
description: His name is Brad Arnsberg, and if you're a New York baseball fan you might want to write it down. Only two years after the Yankees plucked him from the amateur draft, he has become ''the best pitching prospect in the organization,'' in the opinion of Barry Foote, his manager at Albany-Colonie of the Class AA Eastern League, who has an abundance of supporting data.

title: Dynamics Offers A Cut-Rate F-16
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, in a bid to protect its hold on the Pentagon's biggest jet fighter program, offered today to sell the Air Force a stripped-down version of its F-16, at a sharply reduced price.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: THEY LOVED AND LOST
description: The Nets, who wooed with all their heart -or much of it - were left standing at the altar yesterday.

title: 'Boat People' Reach Japan
description: A group of 90 Vietnamese refugees arrived in the southern Japanese city of Sasebo today aboard the American tanker Ranger, which picked them up off a boat in the South China Sea last week, the Foreign Ministry said.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF STATEMENT BY SPEAKES ON ATTACKS IN SALVADOR AND FRANKFURT
description: Following is a transcript of a statement in Washington by Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network:

title: NO U.N. TRIP FOR GORBACHEV
description: A United States official here confirmed today that Mikhail S. Gorbachev had decided against attending the United Nations General Assembly this fall.

title: Coke-Flavor Suit Rejected
description: Federal District Judge Walter McGovern, who said he liked the taste of Pepsi-Cola today rejected a lawsuit filed to force the Coca-Cola Company to change its new taste back to its original 99-year-old formula. After the hearing, Gay Mullins, the president of Old Cola Drinkers of America, said the organization would file a suit within 30 days to restore the old Coke flavor. ''Today's suit was just to change the labeling, not to change the new Coke back to old Coke,'' he said.

title: Working Profile: Christopher J. Matthews;   He Who Speaks for the Speaker
description: Christopher J. Matthews tries vainly to keep a poker face and to contain his pride of authorship. A buoyant six-footer, he hovers above Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., who sits at his desk reading a statement to reporters at the start of a news conference.

title: Hold Back in Anger
description: President Reagan admits that he pounded a few walls in frustration over the Beirut hostage crisis. It is important to understand that sometimes national frustration has to be endured for the sake of lives, as the hostages themselves are having to endure fury in silence.

title: Weyerhaeuser
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company said it had frozen the pay of its 9,000 salaried employees and was making plans to lay off more workers as the company reorganized. A spokesman, Tom Ambrose, said that salaries would be frozen at June 1 levels and that layoffs of both executives and salaried workers were expected. In the last three years, employment at the wood products company has dropped by 3,000, to about 37,800.

title: Santa Fe Buyback
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation said its board authorized the company to purchase up to 30 million of its shares, which would have a current market value of about $900 million.

title: The Smithsonian Is Going Underground
description: The Smithsonian Institution, the nation's vast, exquisite curiosity shop, is burrowing three stories under the Mall to create two new museums that will extend its pursuits still further beyond the attic treasures of America.

title: Paul Colin, 92, Dead; Noted French Posterist
description: Paul Colin, one of the most influential 20th-century French posterists and theater designers, died Tuesday at his home in Nogent-sur-Marne. He was 92 years old.

title: Andrews Still Out
description: William Andrews, the Falcons' All-Pro running back who missed the 1984 season after suffering a serious knee injury in preseason practice, said he would probably have to skip this year's training camp and might even miss the 1985 season. ''I'm very encouraged about the progress I've been making, but it's kind of up in the air for this season,'' he said after a medical examination in Atlanta. . . . The Dallas Cowboys, hungry for help at wide receiver, have signed world-class sprinter Mel Lattany to a contract.

title: Fan Favorite
description: Dave Winfield of the Yankees has a wide margin in the fan voting for outfielders on the American League's all-star team. The latest figures show Winfield with 320,066 votes, followed by Reggie Jackson of the California Angels, with 263,472, and Fred Lynn of the Baltimore Orioles, with 237,207. . . . Tony Armas, the Boston Red Sox outfielder who tore a calf muscle on Sunday, was placed on the 15-day disabled list, and Marc Sullivan, a catcher who had been out with a pulled chest muscle, was reactivated.

title: SCREEN: DOCUMENTARIES ON HORROR
description: FILM students, plus anyone interested in the vagaries of film production, may not want to miss the double bill opening a two-day run at the Thalia today.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: DINO DE LAURENTIIS, the movie producer turned restaurateur, boldly proclaimed three years ago that ''There really are no Italian restaurants in the United States,'' implying that he would enter the food business to show New Yorkers what authentic pasta tasted like. Two years and an expensive flop later - the late and lavish DDL Foodshow failed both as a food emporium and a restaurant - Mr. De Laurentiis found himself dining on ''crow Parmesan.''

title: How to End the Gulf War
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 9.50-10.00 ** Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Business News Program Ends
description: Business Times, the daily morning cable news program on ESPN, will go off the air today. Despite the program's critical acclaim, its owners said they had been unable to raise the financing necessary to continue the program, which was broadcast from 6 to 9 A.M.

title: POLICEMAN IS GUILTY OF KILLING WOMAN AFTER CAR ACCIDENT
description: A 56-year-old police sergeant was convicted of second-degree manslaughter yesterday for fatally shooting a woman in the back last December in a dispute over an auto accident.

title: French Civil Servants March
description: Thousands of French civil servants marched through Paris today to protest Government plans that union leaders say could cost as many as 50,000 jobs.

title: New Unicef Ads Stress Privation
description: People who get visions of well-scrubbed youngsters selling greeting cards when they hear the name Unicef are in for a rude awakening when they are exposed to the TBWA Advertising campaign for the international organization.

title: MASSIMINO TURNS DOWN NETS JOB AT LAST MOMENT
description: An emotional week of soul-searching finally ended for Rollie Massimino early yesterday morning when he informed the Nets that he was rejecting their lucrative offer to become the new head coach.

title: Salute to Sims
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has recommended that Robert B. Sims, a retired Navy officer with high-level public affairs experience, be named official spokesman for the Pentagon. If President Reagan agrees, as is expected, and the Senate confirms Mr. Sims as Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs, he would succeed Michael I. Burch, who is leaving the Government for private industry. Mr. Sims retired from the Navy as a captain and previously served in the Pentagon as deputy chief of information for the Navy. Most recently he has been spokesman for the National Security Council, with the title Deputy Press Secretary.

title: Reciprocity
description: The skirmish was local but the setting was national:

title: Septet at Basil
description: The pianist Abdullah Ibrahim, also known as Dollar Brand, will lead his septet Ekaya, featuring the alto saxophonist Carlos Ward and the drummer Ben Riley, tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. tonight and tomorrow; and 10, 11:30 and 1 A.M. on Sunday. There is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: FORMAL LINK OF STEPS BARRED
description: The Reagan Administration has told several friendly governments that if the 40 American hostages are freed unconditionally by the hijackers in Beirut, Israel will follow with the release of the 766 detainees, Administration officials said today.

title: NAVY SPY CASE IS TO BE PROSECUTED IN THREE CITIES
description: The four Navy men accused of spying for the Soviet Union will be prosecuted in three cities, the Justice Department said today.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: SIDNEY LUMET watched the 1984 election campaigns without realizing that his next project would be ''Power,'' a film about political consultants, media coverage and behind-the-scenes electoral machinations. But when he saw a screenplay by David Himmelstein, a Maine newspaperman who had covered the New Hampshire primaries, he was eager to become involved.

title: Fannie Mae Issue
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, announced yesterday that it will price a $250 million issue of mortgage-backed securities next Tuesday. It is the first sale of such securities from Fannie Mae's portfolio since early 1984. David O. Maxwell, chairman, said: ''Lower interest rates this year have given us an opportunity to accelerate financial restructuring, reducing the corporation's exposure to interest rate increases by lengthening the maturity of debt and shortening the maturity of assets.''

title: FOR NEW CHINESE ENVOY, A PARTY ABOARD THE QE2
description: It was not an accident that Han Xu, China's Ambassador to the United States, chose a reception and a luncheon in his honor, a forum provided by the China Institute in America, for his first public appearance in New York before an American audience. He said with a broad smile yesterday: ''My predecessor made that choice and I make the same choice because you are a force for Sino-American mutual understanding and friendship.''

title: Contractors Investigated
description: The Pentagon is investigating 45 of the nation's military contractors, including 9 of the top 10, concerning allegations that include bribery, kickbacks and bid-rigging, according to Defense Department documents.

title: A CATSKILLS DELIGHT: UPPER BEAVERKILL
description: If you have been nurturing a desire to fish private club waters on a hallowed trout stream, there is a way to approximate that experience on the Upper Beaverkill in the Catskills.

title: NEW 'VAUDEVILLIANS' TRANSFORM CLOWNING
description: THE image of clowns, along with magicians, jugglers, mimes and other circus-oriented performers, is changing rapidly as ''new-wave vaudevillians'' like Bill Irwin, Avner Eisenberg, Bob Berky, Whoopi Goldberg, Penn & Teller and the Flying Karamazov Brothers win adult theater audiences. These performers blend clown techniques, character comedy and various styles of movement theater into theatrical hybrids for which labels have yet to be invented.

title: MASSMUTUAL MORTGAGE & REALTY INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, the Food Notes column in The Living Section on Wednesday omitted part of a book title. The book is ''Commonplace Book of Cookery'' by Robert Grabhorn and is published by the North Point Press of Berkeley, Calif.

title: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE 0.2% IN MAY
description: Inflation slowed to two-tenths of 1 percent in May as grocery prices fell for a third month and a springtime surge in fuel costs abated, the Labor Department reported today.

title: CPU COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: The company is listed on the Boston Stock Exchange.

title: PLAYERS EXPRESS DISMAY
description: Rollie Massimino's rejection of the Nets created disappointment among their players yesterday. Several thought his credentials as a tough-minded college coach might have helped them recover from their lack of success last season.

title: PHILADELPHIA ROUNDUPS INCENSE PUERTO RICANS
description: A series of police roundups in a Puerto Rican neighborhood after the slaying of a white officer has added heat to the bitter debate over the way the city's police officers are said to treat members of minority groups.

title: APPREHENSION AT THE VOICE, AGAIN
description: At The Village Voice offices at Broadway and 13th Street, the news that Leonard Stern, chairman of Hartz Mountain Industries, will buy the 30-year-old weekly was met with apprehension by the 120-member editorial staff.

title: 4 AMRINES SLAIN IN A REBEL RAID IN SAN SALVADOR
description: In what officials viewed as evidence of a return of urban terrorism to El Salvador, 13 people, including four off-duty United States marines and two American businessmen, were shot dead at a San Salvador restaurant Wednesday night.

title: RED SOX PULL TOGETHER AND PROSPER
description: As far as home runs go, this one did not go all that far.

title: Duquesne Expels 2
description: Two Duquesne University basketball players have been expelled after being acquitted of rape charges. The players, Gregory Harrison, 20, of Lynn, Mass., and Eric Compton, 19, of Long Beach, L.I., had been charged in the case along with two teammates, Ronald Stevenson, 20, of Pittsburgh and Emmett Sellers, 20, of Newark.

title: SHIITE CONFIRMS SEPARATION OF 'ZIONIST' PLANE HOSTAGES
description: A senior aide to Nabih Berri, the Shiite leader, said today that six to ten hostages were taken off the Trans World Airlines plane early Saturday because the hijackers suspected them of having ''Zionist connections.''

title: SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: SPAIN ARRESTS DOZENS AS VIOLENCE FLARES DURING NATIONWIDE STRIKE
description: Dozens of people were arrested today as much of Spanish industry and transportation was shut down by a one-day general strike called by Communist-led unions.

title: Steinbrenner's Gag Rule
description: George Steinbrenner has apparently decided he will have the first, last and only word on the Yankees.

title: VOLCKER REBUKES MARTIN ON 3D-WORLD DEBT IDEAS
description: In a highly unusual public controversy, Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, chastised Prestin Martin, the board's vice chairman, yesterday for remarks he made to reporters Wednesday about the third-world debt situation. Mr. Martin had suggested that consideration be given to a number of long-term proposals to help ease the debt burden of developing countries, including having banks convert part of their loans to such nations into equity investments in third-world enterprises.

title: THE LADYBUG AFFAIR: WHAT'S IN A NAME?
description: The ladybug, that glossy red beetle with black spots that is so fond of the the rose-eating aphid, is the leading contender to be enshrined as the state insect.

title: Engine Fails on Pan Am Jet
description: A Pan American World Airways jetliner flying here from Los Angeles with more than 300 people aboard was diverted to a landing in Scotland today after an engine ''disintegrated,'' a spokesman for the airline said. The Boeing 747 landed safely at Prestwick Airport, near Glasgow, said the spokesman, who gave no other details of the incident.

title: C.A.A. Seeks Cure For Strategy Erosion
description: There is a malady in the marketplace and Canter, Achenbaum, Associates, a marketing consulting firm, has put a name on it - Marketing Strategy Erosion.

title: Dominique Bigar Weds William Melville Kahn
