description: Dominique Anne Bigar, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Bigar of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to William Melville Kahn, the son of Evelyn Kahn Biderman of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Melville Kahn. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan.

title: TWO BIG-BAND LEADERS AFFIRM TIES TO TRADITION
description: TWO big bands are playing in the Kool Jazz Festival this weekend - both led by musicians who, 10 years ago, were considered absolutely avant-garde. Yet as their careers have unfolded, both the tenor saxophonist David Murray and the trumpeter Lester Bowie have reaffirmed their connections with jazz tradition - connections that were there all the time. Both musicians might better be considered avant-gutbucket, as they work to give new structures the kick and the emotional directness of the finest jazz from every era.

title: Asbestos Health Claims
description: An out-of-court plan to process thousands of asbestos-related health claims has been set up by 50 asbestos companies and insurers, the concerns said yesterday.

title: The Proper Mix
description: Chicago's climb to the top of the American League's Western Division has been abetted by a road revival. The White Sox were only 6-14 away from Comiskey Park before departing on a recent trip, in which they proceeded to go 8-5.

title: Elite Will Meet
description: Sebastian Coe, Steve Cram and Steve Ovett, Britain's leading middle-distance runners, will be competing together for the first time since the Olympics when Britain takes on the United States today at an invitation meet in Birmingham, England.

title: FLORIDA GULF REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
COAST STARS ENGAGE IN A STRONG RIVALRY
description: While the older handicap horses in the East have been plagued by form reversals and upsets, the best in the West have been embroiled in one of the best rivalries in years. Precisionist, Greinton and Lord at War are so far above their competition that they scared away all but one challenger in the Californian two weekends ago and are likely to meet only two others in the $500,000 Hollywood Gold Cup Sunday.

title: IN DEARBORN, 10,000 SHIITES GO ABOUT THEIR BUSINESS, WITH SOME UNEASE
description: In one corner of the town where Henry Ford made the $5-a-day wage a way of life, the signs above the stores are printed in Arabic and English. The minarets of the three mosques stand in the shadow of automobile factory smokestacks, and clerks born in Lebanon sell Michigan lottery tickets.

title: ISRAELIS SAY NOT ALL 766 PRISONERS ARE SHIITES
description: Israel said today that of the 766 detainees whose release the Beirut hijackers are demanding, only 570 are Shiite Moslems.

title: S.E.C. Files Charges Against Price Waterhouse
description: Moving against one of the Big Eight accounting firms, the Securities and Exchange Commission accused Price Waterhouse and three of its partners today with conspiring to inflate the 1980 and 1981 sales and earnings of AM International, a company that makes duplicating machines and other office equipment.

title: Definitions
description: Mayor Koch, at a news conference this week, had praised President Reagan's handling of his news conference on the hostage crisis.

title: CO-FOUNDER OF ART COLLECTION
description: Marjorie Acker Phillips, who with her husband created the first major museum of modern art in the United States, the Phillips Collection in Washington, D.C., died of pulmonary failure on Wednesday at her home on Foxhall Road. She was 90 years old.

title: HIJACKING VICTIM BURIED AT ARLINGTON CEMETARY
description: Robert Dean Stethem, the Navy diver who was killed by Shiite terrorists in Beirut, Lebanon, last week, was buried today with full military honors at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: RISKY STAND ON TAX PLAN
description: Governor Cuomo of New York has picked a fight that few Democratic leaders in Washington are eager to join, at least publicly. He has taken on a popular President on a popular issue, tax revision, and in doing so he is risking not only his political capital but that of his party as well.

title: ARMADA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 21, 1985

title: Couple Arrested In Actress's Death
description: A Bronx couple was arrested Wednesday night and charged with the murder of an unemployed actress who was fatally injured while trying to recover her stolen purse on West 43d Street last Friday, the police said.

title: The War of Words With Speakes
description: Sharp exchanges between reporters and Government spokesmen are nothing new. But the exchanges between the White House press corps and Larry Speakes, President Reagan's spokesman, have been notably sharp, even acidic and personal at times of national or international tension.

title: AMREP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to give effect to a 25 percent stock dividend paid in November 1984.

title: JOHN BOULTING, 71, FILM MAKER
description: John Boulting, the British film maker whose dramatic and satirical films done in conjunction with his twin brother, Roy, made a name for them as writers, directors and producers, died of cancer Monday at his home in Sunningdale, Berkshire, England. He was 71 years old.

title: Angotti, Thomas Wins General Computer
description: The six-month-old Angotti, Thomas, Hedge agency has just won its fourth account, the General Computer Company of Boston, for which it will advertise Hyperdrive.

title: Occidental Selling 25% of Libya Stake
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it would sell a 25 percent interest in its oil operations in Libya to the national oil company of Austria.

title: GREECE URGES AMERICANS TO IGNORE REAGAN'S TRAVEL WARNING
description: Greece appealed to Americans today to disregard President Reagan's warnings against travel to this country.

title: NWA Debentures
description: NWA Inc., the parent company of Northwest Airlines, is offering $160 million of 7 1/2 percent, 25-year, convertible subordinated debentures, at par, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Ex-Admiral Russell S. Berkey; Veteran of Two World Wars
description: Russell S. Berkey, a retired four-star admiral and one-time commander of Navy forces in the Far East died Monday at the age of 91.

title: GRACE PERIOD VOTED FOR SERVICE AGENCIES THAT DEFY BIAS RULE
description: The Board of Estimate voted last night to provide a six-month grace period before halting city financing for Roman Catholic social service agencies that refuse to comply with a city policy barring discrimination against homosexuals.

title: Of Faith in the I.R.S.
description: The Internal Revenue Service's failure to get income tax refund checks to taxpayers on time is apparently going to cost the Government more than $200 million in otherwise unnecessary interest payments, contributing further to the mounting Federal deficit.

title: STAGE: 'COST OF LIVING,' AN IMPORT FROM FRANCE
description: DOMINATING the set of ''The Cost of Living'' are several picture frames without pictures. It was surely not the intention of the designer, Eugene Brogyanyi, to criticize the play, but by the second act of sporadically engaging action, those empty rectangles seemed to be making a comment on the proceedings. The intriguing frame of the play's opening scene is not matched by what follows.

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $3.8 million for the quarter and $8.8 million for the year. c-Net income. d-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $7.8 million for the quarter and year.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: QUESTION: You are a princess - perhaps a baron - and many of your best chums are leaving town for the summer. What do you do?

title: Canucks Replace Coach
description: Tom Watt, the former coach of the Winnipeg Jets, was named head coach of the Vancouver Canucks, completing the replacement of his former mentor, Harry Neale, who was dismissed as coach and general manager last month. The appointment was announced by the other replacement, Jack Gordon, a former assistant general manager under Neale who was named general manager.

title: Reagan Tax Plan Encourages Divorce
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ: MAXINE SULLIVAN SINGS
description: DURING the Kool Jazz Festival, which begins tonight, Fat Tuesday's is offering what it bills as ''Kool Combinations.'' The first, ''A Tribute to the Cotton Club Era,'' combining the singer Maxine Sullivan with the quintet led by the tenor saxophonist Scott Hamilton, runs through Sunday.

title: NORWEGIAN EX-DIPLOMAT GETS 20 YEARS FOR SPYING
description: Arne Treholt, a 42-year-old former diplomat once regarded as a rising star in Norwegian politics, was convicted today of spying for the Soviet Union and Iraq and sentenced to 20 years in prison.

title: Senate Approves $50 Million For C.I.A. Security Measures
description: The Senate today approved $50 million for the Central Intelligence Agency for enhanced security measures abroad.

title: Article 068531 -- No Title
description: The House of Representatives tonight approved $2.5 billion for continuing research on President Reagan's proposal to build a space-based shield against intercontinental missiles.

title: No Need to Move
description: Don't worry about dashing out in a bathrobe and moving the car tomorrow morning.

title: SENATE JUDICIARY PANEL POSTPONES ACTION ON REYNOLDS NOMINATION
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today postponed a vote on the nomination of William Bradford Reynolds to be Associate Attorney General after it became clear that he would not win an endorsement from the panel.

title: Getting Away
description: After his Orioles had aggrieved the Baltimore faithful with some thoroughly impotent play for a third straight night, the manager was asked if he was glad to see the Yankees leave town. And Earl Weaver, packing his bags for his own road trip, replied: ''I'm glad we're leaving.''

title: Hauling by Stealth
description: Breaking the early morning quiet, a city garbage truck pulled away from the hotel. A moment later, the police patrol car that had been waiting nearby followed.

title: John Gilbert Silents
description: Three silent films featuring John Gilbert will be shown this weekend at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street.

title: JAYCEE WOMEN TO DISBAND
description: The United States Jaycee Women have decided to disband because most of the group's members have joined the formerly all-male Jaycees.

title: THE SCREEN: 'LIFEFORCE'
description: ABOUT 30 seconds into Tobe Hooper's ''Lifeforce,'' two things become clear: that this film is going to make no sense, and that Mr. Hooper's directorial work on ''Poltergeist'' may indeed have been heavily influenced by Steven Spielberg, who wrote and co-produced that film. ''Lifeforce'' shows off Mr. Hooper's way with a whirling mass of protoplasm, just as ''Poltergeist'' did. But its style is shrill and fragmented enough to turn ''Lifeforce'' into hysterical vampire porn.

title: MENGELE WRITINGS DEPICT A GROUCHY AND EMBITTERED OLD MAN
description: Letters and notebooks said to have been written by the Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele offer a picture of a grouchy, unhappy and embittered old man, grumbling to his son that he does not hear enough from him, spinning out Darwinian racial theories and muttering about Communism and the decadence of Western European societies.

title: San Antonio Bond Issue May Yield Up to 8.70%
description: The city of San Antonio yesterday offered $41.74 million of general obligation improvement bonds through an underwriting syndicate led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: From Albany, Government by Party Caucus
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Says Blue Law Is 'Blatantly Invalid'
description: A Superior Court judge today declared an Ocean City ordinance prohibiting Sunday openings of certain businesses ''blatantly invalid'' and prohibited the resort community from enforcing it.

title: NEGOTIATIONS ON AFGHANISTAN RENEWED IN GENEVA
description: Foreign Ministers of Pakistan and the Soviet-backed Government in Afghanistan, meeting Thursday under the auspices of the United Nations, opened a fourth round of secret negotiations here on a political settlement of the Afghan conflict.

title: SHUTTLE PUTS OUT A 'BLACK HOLE' DETECTOR
description: The crew of the space shuttle Discovery used the craft's mechanical arm today to place in space an X-ray observatory that will search for a massive ''black hole'' that may be hidden at the center of the Milky Way.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday A SALUTE TO THE SOLSTICE Today marks the summer solstice, and an all-day salute to the sun sponsored by the New Wilderness Foundation begins at dawn in Central Park's East Meadow. Sunrise events scheduled from 5:30 to 8:30 A.M. include an opening ceremony at the United Nations to launch the departure of 100 runners toward the East Meadow, songs, dances and chants, a tai chi meditation, and a ''sacred unity pipe ceremony'' led by a member of the Otter Clan of the Anishinabe Nation. From 8:30 A.M. until 12:15 P.M. a series of activities will be repeated every hour, including appearances by the Bali-Java Dance Theater, the Asian American Dance Theater and music for homemade instruments. A solstice fanfare for 30 trumpets and 15 dancers will herald high noon at the East Meadow. A variety of afternoon events will culminate in a sunset reprise of the solstice fanfare, the Grand Buddha Marching Band, the Ketjak Chanting Chorus and Ramayana Dance-Drama, an ''American Midsummer Sermon'' by the Bread and Puppet Theater and a Grand Solstice Participation Processional, among other festivities. The whole celebration is free. The East Meadow is near Fifth Avenue at 97th to 99th streets. Information: 807-7944.

title: Economic Scene;   Examining G.N.P. Vigor
description: THE just-released ''flash'' report of the gross national product, showing that the economy has moved up at a 3.1 percent annual rate in the second quarter, said to the markets that there is life in the expansion yet.

title: Homosexuals Protest Foster Parent Policy
description: An all-night protest against state foster parent policy by more than a dozen homosexuals outside the office of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis broke up about noon today after the Governor agreed to meet with them.

title: Coffee Record Seen
description: World coffee production could rise to a record 99.1 million bags in 1985-86, up 8 percent from last season's revised output of 91.8 million bags, the Agriculture Department said today. A bag of green, unroasted coffee weighs about 132 pounds. The previous world record for coffee production was 98.1 million bags in 1981-82.

title: JAPAN'S PRESS SEARCHES ITS SOUL OVER TV MURDER
description: For a few days, Kazuo Nagano was the most closely watched man in Japan.

title: AUCTIONS
description: THE Beatles' yellow Rolls-Royce, a 19-foot-long limousine decorated with psychedelic motifs and flowers framed in red scrollwork, is the star attraction in an auction of rock-and-roll collectibles June 29 at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street. The Phantom V automobile, purchased by John Lennon in 1966 and decorated a year later by him and a mystic friend, goes on view tomorrow at the gallery.

title: Al Smith's Reputation Will Survive Charges
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY DROPS PLAN TO BUILD SHELTER AT A QUEENS SITE
description: The Koch administration, facing community opposition, yesterday dropped plans to build a shelter for the homeless in an industrial section of Maspeth, Queens.

title: STATE CONSULTANT LINKED TO MOBSTERS BY OFFICIALS
description: A former union leader who law-enforcement authorities say is linked to an organized-crime group is working as a $20,000-a-year labor consultant by the State Battery Park City Authority.

title: MET WILL ELIMINATE ITS NATIONAL TOUR AFTER 1986
description: The Metropolitan Opera announced yesterday that it would abandon its century-old national tour after next year.

title: Encouraging Messages From the Upper West Side
description: While they were learning about immigration to New York in their social studies class, fourth graders at P.S. 163 on West 97th Street read about newly arrived Korean manicurists trying to survive on the Upper West Side of Manhattan without friends or English.

title: WESTWOOD ONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Top Rhode Island Judge Appears Before Panel
description: The Chief Justice of the Rhode Island Supreme Court appeared briefly today before an ethics panel investigating his friendships with criminals.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: JOURNEY TO THE FORBIDDEN CHINA. By Steven W. Mosher. 180 pages. Illustrated. The Free Press. $17.95.

title: Blues at Tramps
description: The blues singer Charles Brown will perform tonight and tomorrow at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077). Sets begin at about 9:30 P.M. and midnight; there is a $9 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Five Plead Innocent To Vote Fraud Charges
description: Five people, including Spiver Gordon, a national director of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, have pleaded not guilty in Federal Court here to charges of vote fraud. Three activists are on trial in Selma on similar charges.

title: ART: THE FURNITURE OF DIEGO GIACOMETTI
description: THE exhibition of Diego Giacometti's furniture at the Marisa Del Re Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, is handsome and instructive. It is the first one-man show this 82-year-old Italian-Swiss artist has had, and it is installed with exceptional care. It also contains enough representative work to suggest why his knobby, elegant, superbly proportioned objects have steadily grown in reputation during a period in which efforts to blur the distinction between art and craft have been distinguished more by their insistence than by their success.

title: 7 Killed by Indian Army During Banned Parade
description: Indian soldiers opened fire today to disperse Moslems throwing rocks at a Hindu religious procession in Ahmedabad, killing seven people and wounding 20.

title: TOLL IN TRIPOLI BLAST IS SAID TO RISE TO 75, WITH 100 WOUNDED
description: The number of casualties in a car-bomb explosion in the northern Lebanese port of Tripoli rose to 75 dead and more than 100 wounded, the state-run Beirut radio reported today.

title: Muse Merger
description: Stockholders of Muse Air unanimously approved a proposed merger with arch-rival Southwest Airlines, a combination deemed vital to Muse's survival. At a news conference after the company's annual meeting, Muse's chairman, Lamar Muse, said he was ''cautiously optimistic'' that the Department of Transportation would approve the merger.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Blood Pressure Centers Inc. said it might have to close its one remaining blood pressure diagnosis and treatment center, in Massapequa, L.I., and cease operations because it has been unable to raise needed capital.

title: Officials Seek Inquiry On Tainted Cheese
description: Los Angeles County supervisors voted today to seek a grand jury investigation of the illnesses and deaths linked to tainted Mexican-style cheese.

title: EX-CELL-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Chip Maker Posts a Loss
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation, hurt by the slumping demand for computer chips, reported yesterday that it had a loss of $2.7 million in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1985, compared with earnings of $24.4 million, or 28 cents a share, in the 1984 quarter.

title: 40 REMAINING HOSTAGES: A DIVERSE GROUP UNITED BY THE RANDOM NATURE OF THEIR PLIGHT
description: They come from Illinois, Florida, Vermont, Kansas, Texas, Virginia, California, Massachusetts and Indiana.

title: MEASUREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
NEW YORK AREA COSTS INCREASE 0.3%
description: Paced by higher shelter costs, consumer prices for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area increased by three-tenths of 1 percent in May, the regional Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Riegel-Pamplin
description: The Riegel Textile Corporation said it had agreed in principle to be acquired by a unit of the R. B. Pamplin Corporation, a privately held concern based in Portland, Ore.

title: Money Supply Up; Bonds Fall
description: An unexpectedly sharp $4.8 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply touched off a steep drop in bond prices late yesterday and a jump in interest rates.

title: E.F. Hutton Responds To Memo
description: The E. F. Hutton Company said today that an internal memorandum it had submitted to a House subcommittee in the form of one document was actually two memoranda, prepared at different times between late 1981 and early 1982. Hutton made the disclosure in contesting charges by the subcommittee that the memorandum showed that top management at the firm knew of an extensive bank overdraft scheme in 1981.

title: The Day's Developments
description: Hostage Separation Confirmed - A Berri aide confirmed that 6 to 10 hostages had been held separately, suspected of having ''Zionist connections.'' Page A6.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL DETROIT (AL) - Traded Duane James, minor league right-handed pitcher, to Texas for Frank Tanana, left-handed pitcher.

title: EXPLORING THE 'NEW WORLD VOYAGES'
description: Four hundred years ago, in the summer of 1585, a fleet of English colonists navigated the treacherous shoals of the Outer Banks off what is now North Carolina and came ashore at Roanoke Island. A reconnaissance party had reached the island the year before, but this represented England's first attempt to colonize America.

title: Moving Up
description: He may not have experience as a head coach, but Bernie Bickerstaff, the Washington Bullets' assistant who was named coach of the Seattle SuperSonics, has the kind of confidence he will need in trying to rebuild a 31-51 team. His appointment, Bickerstaff said, marks the beginning of a ''new era'' of basketball in Seattle. ''This is the job I wanted,'' added the 41-year-old coach, who spent 12 years as an assistant under three National Basketball Association coaches in Boston and Washington.

title: GREAT ADVENTURE'S SISTER PARK INSTALLED SPRINKLERS
description: The president of the Six Flags Corporation testified today that the company's Missouri subsidiary had installed sprinklers in an amusement park fun house although the Six Flags subsidiary in New Jersey decided not to.

title: LIGHT-UNBENDING MIRROR TEST A SUCCESS, ASTRONOMERS SAY
description: Astronomers from California and Arizona said today that they have successfully tested a mechanism to correct the atmospheric light distortion that blurs telescope images, a device similar to one the astronauts on the shuttle Discovery were unable to properly test Wednesday from space.

title: Chris-Craft TV Deal Off
description: Chris-Craft Industries said yesterday that it had postponed indefinitely its plan to transfer two television stations to United Television Inc.

title: Hotel-Strike Litter
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch Wednesday from Larnaca, Cyprus, on the possible whereabouts of the American airline hostages incorrectly described a reported link between the Central Intelligence Agency and a car-bomb explosion in Beirut last March that killed 80 people. According to Reagan Administration and Congressional sources the explosion was the work of people who had been hired by a Lebanese counterterrorist team that had been recruited by the C.I.A. But the sources said the bombing had been carried out without the knowledge of the C.I.A., and the C.I.A. affirmed this in a statement May 13.

title: Big Bluefish Plentiful
description: 1Margate, N.J.:Although large numbers of small bluefish are no longer along the beaches, 12- to 14-pounders are numerous offshore. Mako sharks are being taken with regularity. Shore fishermen are catching a few large striped bass at night during the early stages of the falling flood tide and good catches of small weakfish are being made at the same time. The fluke in Margate Bay are plentiful and larger than they were last year at this time. Barnegat, N.J.: Party-boat anglers are doing well both day and night with bluefish in the 4- to 9-pound range while chumming offshore. Seaside Park, N.J.: The bluefish action off the Barnegat Inlet jetty has slowed, but those fish are still being taken on metal jigs in the morning and bait at dusk. Point Pleasant, N.J.: Party boats are making two half-day trips in the ocean for fluke, and night bluefishing is under way. #2 Sea Bright, N.J.:Weakfish up to 12 pounds have moved against the beach and into the bay. Bluefish are everywhere, 2 to 7 pounds close to shore, up to 14 pounds farther out. Fluke quite plentiful in Raritan Bay and a few large stripers, one more than 40 pounds, have been caught in the surf recently.

title: Pullman-Peabody
description: The Pullman Company said it had agreed to merge with the Peabody International Corporation, exchanging 1.65 Pullman shares for each Peabody share, making the transaction worth about $115.5 million.

title: CREDO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
INACTION ON PROBLEM DOCTORS SPURS DOUBTS ABOUT MILITARY CRACKDOWN
description: When the Navy said Wednesday it would seek formal censure of the second-ranking officer overseeing its hospitals ashore, it was the fourth time in three years that a high-ranking military medical officer was called deficient in cracking down on incompetent or problem doctors.

title: Advertising;   Push for Outdoor Revival
description: AS far as out-of-home media go, here is the picture as seen by Martin J. Mullany, president of Out-of-Home Media Services: Cigarette advertising is stagnant, liquor advertising is slipping, food advertisers are beginning to show an interest and the use by certain Japanese auto makers might reawaken the TV-smitten Detroit crowd.

title: YANKEE WILD PITCH ENDS LATE COLLAPSE
description: Typically, Dave Righetti offered no excuses. He simply talked quietly, unemotionally, about a period that has been the most difficult in his young pitching career.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD UP 14.7% TO A RECORD
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest soared 32.4 million shares, or 14.7 percent, in the month ended June 14, to a record 253 million shares.

title: U.N. Council Condemns South African Foray
description: For the second time in two days, the Security Council condemned the actions of the South African Government, this time for an incursion into Angola.

title: LEVESQUE, QUEBEC SEPARATIST, QUITTING AS PROVINCE'S LEADER
description: Rene Levesque, who took the province of Quebec to the brink of separation from the rest of Canada, resigned tonight as head of the party he founded 17 years ago.

title: KILLER OF OFFICER GETS 32 1/2 YEARS IN PRISON TERMS
description: A 19-year-old Brooklyn man convicted of murdering a transit police officer with her own gun last September was sentenced yesterday to serve 25 years to life in prison for the killing.

title: FDP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Reagan Names Chief For Office of Personnel
description: In a move designed to end a dispute over leadership at the Office of Personnel Management, President Reagan today named Constance Horner as its new director.

title: Two Seized in Nassau In Rape-Slaying Case
description: Two men were indicted and arrested today in connection with the rape and killing of a Long Island girl last year, the Nassau County District Attorney's office said.

title: Q T & T INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss after a writeoff of loan of $181,376 and a tax credit of $24,601. c-After a writeoff of loan of $181,376 and a tax credit of $266,038.

title: Thanks, Guys
description: When Andy Hawkins of the Padres finally fell, to the Dodgers, after an 11-0 start, he gave a farewell address to all the sportswriters who had become a part of his traveling party: ''I'm never going to forget this streak.

title: Beatrice Net Off 20%
description: The Beatrice Companies today reported a 20 percent drop in net income, to $58 million, or 59 cents a share, for its first quarter ended May 31, from $72 million, or 76 cents a share, in the quarter a year ago. The company attributed the decline to ''unallocated purchase cost amortization and interest expense'' resulting from its $2.7 billion acquisition of Esmark Inc. last summer. Sales for the quarter increased 39 percent, to $3.07 billion, from $2.21 billion a year earlier, but the 1984 figure does not include Esmark's results.

title: ATTACK ON A SCHOOL BUS REVIVES S.I. RACIAL TENSIONS
description: They hid baseball bats, tire irons and chains in the bushes. They rendezvoused after school, 30 teen-agers in all. And then, the police say, the group of white Staten Island students attacked a bus - shattering windows and terrifying the black and white students on board - all in a scheme planned as revenge against a black teen-ager who turned out not to be there.

title: RHODEN STARS AS PIRATES BEAT EXPOS, 2-1
description: Rick Rhoden pitched a three-hitter over seven innings and drove in the winning run with a double as the Pittsburgh Pirates edged the Montreal Expos, 2-1, tonight.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Air Express International Corp., Darien, Conn., announced that Joseph N. Berg had resigned as president, chief operating officer and a director.

title: HONDURAN ARMY KILLS AMERICAN
description: An American citizen was shot and killed by a Honduran Army patrol near the Salvadoran border, a United States Embassy spokesman said today. A Honduran military spokesman said the American was shot Wednesday when he tried to flee from a border patrol that had asked him for identification.

title: FEARS FOR AMERICAN UNIVERSITY RISE: CAN IT SURVIVE THE BEIRUT VIOLENCE?
description: Another category of Americans in Beirut besides airline passengers has lately suffered assaults from a deadly and apparently dedicated force.

title: NICARAGUAN REBELS PLAN BIG GROWTH
description: The leaders of a newly formed Nicaraguan rebel group said here today that they intended to double the size of anti-Sandinista guerrilla forces and that they expected to receive humanitarian assistance from the United States to aid the rebel fighters.

title: A Rembrandt Reported Damaged in Leningrad
description: A Rembrandt masterpiece at Leningrad's Hermitage museum, the ''Danae,'' was damaged by a vandal on June 15, according to reports from Leningrad. Neither the extent of damage nor the motive of the lone assailant, who was arrested, was known today.

title: ROWE FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
USENCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
A Student's Legacy
description: When he graduated yesterday, Lloyd Walker left something of value at the Bronx High School of Science.

title: SWEDISH LEADER FOR 2 DECADES
description: Tage F. Erlander, who was Sweden's Prime Minister from 1946 to 1969 and a major architect of its social welfare state, died early yesterday in a hospital in the village of Huddinge, seven miles southwest of Stockholm. He was 84 years old. The cause of his death was not immediately disclosed, but doctors said he was suffering from cardiac insufficiency and minor pneumonia when he entered the hospital June 9.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Nick Polano was removed as coach of the Detroit Red Wings and named an assistant general manager. The Red Wings said they would name a new coach Monday. . . . Dan Schatezeder, the Montreal Expos' left-hander, has been sidelined indefinitely with an inflamed shoulder, which forced him out of the 2-1 loss to the Pirates Thursday night.

title: U.S. 'Friendship Flier' Locked Up in Soviet
description: An American who brought his light airplane to Moscow on an officially approved ''friendship flight'' spent his three days here locked in a hotel because he arrived without a visa.

title: No Headline
description: LAKE MILLS, Wis. -

title: INFOTECH MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15. 1. The shuttle was in the wrong position because instructions from the ground controllers were in nautical miles instead of feet. 2. 570. 3. Associate Attorney General. His record on civil rights. 4. Patrick J. Buchanan, the White House director of communications, made the remarks about Governor Cuomo in response to the Governor's comments about President Reagan's tax revision plan. 5. The Metropolitan Opera will cancel its national tour after 1986. 6. They worked at Los Alamos, N.M., on Project Y, as the Manhattan Project was known then, to build the first atomic bomb. 7. The austral, a new currency, is worth $1.25, or 1,000 old pesos. 8. West Germany. El Salvador. 9. On his way to a disastrous quadruple-bogey eight on the fifth hole, Chen struck his ball twice on the same shot, an error that also cost him a penalty stroke. 10. Baked beans. 11. An agreement on preventing dangerous incidents at sea. Moscow canceled the meeting after the Pentagon decided that in retaliation for the killing of an American officer by a Soviet soldier in East Germany in March, the trip to the United States by Soviet naval officers should be shortened and shorn of all the usual social engagements. 12. The House approved funds for the production of chemical weapons and voted against the purchase of any additional MX missiles next year. 13. The exhibition was chosen by Jacqueline Picasso, the artist's widow, from her private collection. 14.

title: THE CROOKS ARE IN CHARGE (2)
description: That the construction industry in New York is corrupt has not been in question for many moons. Recent disclosures by the State Investigation Commission about the diseased web of featherbedding, bid-rigging, kickbacks and mob control of some unions are merely the latest reminders that the sun rises in the morning.

title: Letter: On Copyright;   Originality and the Nation Case
description: To the Editor:

title: DOW SOARS BY 24.75, TO 1,324.48
description: Stock prices soared to near-record levels yesterday on Wall Street, largely because of a new wave of takeover speculation in food stocks as well as professional trading connected with the expiration of stock index options.

title: SEMTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
G.M. FINANCING
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would offer a 9.9 percent retail financing program on front-wheel-drive luxury cars from today through July 31. G.M. said the progam would apply to the Olsmobile 98 Regency, Buick Electra and Park Avenue, and Cadillac Seville and Fleetwood models.

title: New York City Acts Against Child Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: CARTER CALLS ON AMERICANS TO GIVE REAGAN 'OUR FULL SUPPORT'
description: Former President Jimmy Carter called on Americans yesterday to ''give President Reagan our full support and encouragement.''

title: GREECE DEFENDS ITS ACTIONS IN T.W.A. HIJACKING
description: Greece gave its European neighbors a report today on its actions in the Beirut hijacking, including a defense of its airport security and its decision to free a confederate of the Lebanese hijackers in exchange for Greek and other hostages aboard the commandeered American jet.

title: Books of The Times;   Tales of Lost Ways
description: THE COLLECTED STORIES. By William Humphrey. 371 pages. Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $19.95.

title: 400 STAGE PROTEST OF YOUTH KILLING
description: More than 400 people chanted, sang and listened to speeches by candlelight last night outside a police station in Harlem to protest the killing last week of a 17-year-old Harlem honors student by a police officer.

title: COPING WITH A SHORTAGE OF COACHES
description: Without a coach, the high school tennis team here faced serious peril - until Myra Saunders, a player's mother, came to the rescue.

title: MEESE SAYS U.S. CONCURS ON MENGELE
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that the Justice Department believed that a body recently exhumed in Brazil was that of the Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele.

title: Officer Faces Driving Charge
description: A police officer, arrested last night in the Bronx on a charge of driving while impaired by alcohol, was suspended from duty without pay until he faces a Police Department hearing, the police said. The officer, George Rafferty, 24 years old, has served on the force for three and a half years and is assigned to the 52d Precinct. He was arrested at the intersection of Mosholu Parkway and Webster Avenue at 7:20 P.M., a department spokesman said.

title: U.S. AFFIRMS WARNING AS ATHENS EVENT OPENS
description: As an international cultural festival opened yesterday in Athens, the State Department stood by its warning to all American travelers that ''an above-average potential for terrorist activity exists'' at the Athens airport.

title: COSMOS ABANDON SCHEDULE, PLANS
description: The Cosmos are finished playing soccer this summer - and maybe forever.

title: EASTGROUP PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including gains on the sale of investments of $69,000 for the quarter and $4,290,000 for the 6 months. c-Including gains on the sale of investments of $11,788,000 for the quarter and $13,577,000 for the 6 months.

title: STAODYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
description: b-Net income

title: LASER BEAM HITS 8-INCH TARGET IN SPACE
description: A blue-green laser beam, flashing up from a mountaintop in Hawaii, locked onto the spacecraft Discovery today in what a Pentagon scientist called a ''very successful'' first shuttle experiment to help develop weapons for President Reagan's proposed shield against enemy missiles.

title: COMAIR INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
Praying in Public Schools and in Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: SEARCHING FOR THE PERFECT APRICOT
description: New Yorkers, who pride themselves on the availability of the very best of everything, have to contend with the fact that they don't have the best apricots. The best have been ripened on the tree, not en route to market, and since apricots come from at least 3,000 miles away, they cannot be picked at the peak of perfection. As a result, finding an apricot worthy of its name on the East Coast can be an exercise in frustration.

title: Linda Wells, Editor, Weds Britton Jones, a Treasurer
description: The marriage of Linda Wells, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne Wells of St. Louis, to Britton Jones, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Jones of Bedford Hills, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Edward Salmon performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: DANCE: KEI TAKEI GROUP IN 'LIGHT' PARTS 20 AND 21
description: Thanks to Kei Takei's company, Moving Earth, there was new ''Light'' and more Wednesday night at La Mama E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street.

title: BEACH TO OPEN AFTER DELAY
description: The Lake Sebago beach in Harriman State Park in Haverstraw, N.Y., will open today, according to Kenneth G. Kreiser, superintendent of the New York section of the Palisades Interstate Park Commission. The opening had been postponed because of a shortage of lifeguards. Mr. Kreiser said that 17 lifeguards had passed qualifying tests Thursday and that 3 lifeguards had transferred from upstate parks, giving the beach its full complement.

title: CONCERT: NED ROTHENBERG, SAXOPHONIST, SOLO AND IN TRIO
description: Ned Rothenberg is obviously devoted to the saxophone, but sometimes, hearing him play it, you might assume that he despised its natural tone. This is because Mr. Rothenberg, being an experimental musician as well as a saxophonist, mercilessly explores the outer reaches of the instrument's tonal possibilities and, when performing, spends much of his time demonstrating the resultant atypical sonorities.

title: PROTEST ON TOP RANKINGS
description: Officials of the Women's Tennis Association said today that they would lodge a complaint over the decision to list Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert Lloyd jointly as the No. 1-seeded players for the Wimbledon tennis championships next week.

title: UTAH POWER SALE
description: The Utah Power and Light Company said it had agreed to sell one-fourth of its Hunter 3 generating unit to Nevada Power for $135.3 million. According to the terms of the agreement, Nevada will begin receiving a 100-megawatt share of the 400-megawatt unit's output on Jan. 1, 1988. Nevada Power agreed to pay one-fourth of the costs and improvements at the plant, the statement said.

title: DAVIS QUITS MURDOCH'S TV DEAL
description: Marvin Davis, the wealthy Denver oilman, said yesterday that he was pulling out of the highly publicized deal in which he and Rupert Murdoch were to acquire six television stations from Metromedia Inc.

title: SENATE ACCORD COULD END 9-YEAR DEADLOCK ON WATER PROJECTS
description: Senate Republican leaders today announced an agreement that could end a nine-year deadlock on water projects - local governments would share their cost and user fees would be imposed.

title: PRAYING IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS AND IN CONGRESS
description: To the Editor:

title: ZOO BRINGS JUNGLE TO BRONX - GIBBONS, TAPIRS AND ALL
description: After six years of preparation, the Bronx Zoo dedicated its dramatic $9.5 million indoor Jungle World exhibit yesterday - a re-creation of steaming rain forests, with gibbons swinging from vine to vine, open-mouthed crocodiles drowsing in the sun and birds screeching high above the trees.

title: U.S. Officials Identify Man Shot in Honduras
description: The United States citizen who was shot by a Honduran military border patrol near the border with El Salvador was identified Friday as a 41-year-old welder from Queens.

title: POMPADOURS AND PARTS: EDUCATING BARBERS
description: In this commencement season, Frank Bucaria, an instructor at the Atlas Barber School, is telling his graduating students that they are the hope of the barbering future - now and, yes, into the 21st century.

title: SIHANOUK FINDS CAVIAR AND KIM IL SUNG MIX WELL
description: As Prince Norodom Sihanouk tells it, his friend came to him one day and said, ''You've lost a country, the least we can do is to build you a house.''

title:
PATENTS;

IMPROVED SPECTROMETER FOR REMOTE SENSING
description: James B. Breckenridge and Fred G. O'Callaghan of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in California have been granted patent 4,523,846 for improvements to a spectrometer for remote sensing of geology, agriculture and the atmosphere.

title: WINNEBAG0 INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
CORRECTION
description: A list of the 40 American airline hostages yesterday gave one name twice and omitted another. It should have included Richard P. Herzberg, an insurance salesman from Norfolk, Va.

title: Warning on Pirates
description: Commissioner Peter Ueberroth said yesterday that he would veto any attempt to move the Pittsburgh Pirates to another city and warned cities in search of franchises not to ''raid other communities.'' He met with Mayor Richard Caliguiri and a group of corporate leaders to discuss ways to keep one of baseball's oldest franchises in Pittsburgh. ''I would not approve the sale if outside groups want to move it to another city,'' Ueberroth said at a news conference at Three Rivers Stadium.

title: INTERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
description: b-Including tax credits of $3,391,000 for the quarter and $4,284,000 for the 6 months, a nonrecurring restructuring and consolidation cost of $2,418,000 for the quarter and 6 months, equity in losses of and reserve for possible losses on advances to unconsolidated company of $1,630,000 for the quarter and $2,902,000 for the 6 months and a gain on the sale of an investment of $1,805,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income.

title: The Law, Believe It or Not
description: Out of the universe of laws, ordinances and statutes ratified in the legislative chambers at all levels of government in the United States, more than 2,000 can safely be described as archaic, ludicrous and strange. Many have been ultimately repealed, but some, still dormant, are technically legally binding.

title: Letitia B. Last Marries James P. Fiore in Newport
description: Letitia Blake Last, the daughter of James R. R. Last of New York and Newport, R.I., and the late Marnie D. Last, was married in Newport yesterday to James Patrick Fiore, a son of Mrs. Edward T. Valentino of Smithfield, R.I., and Anthony T. Fiore of New York. The Rev. Everett H. Greene performed the ceremony at All Saints Chapel of Emmanuel Episcopal Church.

title: LEVESQUE OUT, QUEBEC PARTY'S FUTURE IS CLOUDED
description: The Parti Quebecois, which has governed Quebec for the last nine years, confronted an uncertain future today after the resignation of its founder, Rene Levesque.

title: Nevada Brush Fires Burn 76,000 Acres
description: A fire that has charred an estimated 57,000 acres of brush land burned out of control today near Winnemucca in north-central Nevada, the authorities said.

title: A PROPOSED ANTISPYING LAW PRODUCES AN OUTCRY IN JAPAN
description: Japan's governing party, saying that a crackdown on spies is long overdue, has submitted legislation authorizing the death penalty for anyone convicted of espionage that ''severely endangers national security.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Living Section on May 22 on frozen desserts incorrectly described the fat content of one brand. Tofutti contains 10 to 12 percent vegetable fat, while 51 percent of the calories in Tofutti's wildberry supreme and chocolate supreme flavors are derived from fat.

title: OIL CHARGES DISMISSED
description: Most of a $300 million price-fixing suit against six major oil companies by the City of Long Beach and the State of California has been dismissed by a Federal judge.

title: EXCERPTS OF SPEECH TO N.C.A.A. GROUP
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by Dr. John W. Ryan, president of Indiana University and chairman of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Presidents' Commission:

title:
PATENTS;

MODIFIED WARHEADS RAISE DESTRUCTIVENESS
description: The Ford Aerospace and Communications Corporation, Detroit, has patented modification of the warheads (missiles or projectiles) that carry long rod penetrators designed to maximize their destructiveness.

title: HIJACKING DRAMA DRAWS VIEWERS TO NEWS SHOWS
description: Television viewing appears to have increased in the week since Lebanese Shiites hijacked a Trans World Airlines jet and took 40 Americans hostage.

title: SALVADOR REBELS ACKNOWLEDGE RAID
description: A Salvadoran guerrilla group took responsibility today for a sidewalk attack at a restaurant here Wednesday night in which 13 people were killed, including 4 United States marines and 2 American businessmen.

title: 'Singin'' to Open July 2
description: ''Singin' in the Rain,'' the Broadway musical now in previews at the Gershwin Theater, will open on July 2. The musical is directed and choreographed by Twyla Tharp. The show was originally scheduled to open on June 13 and then June 20, but both opening dates were canceled by the producer to allow for more work on the production.

title: K-TEL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $102,000 for the quarter and $1,644,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,385,000 for the quarter and $8,524,000 for the 9 months.

title: Contaminated Milk in Texas
description: More than 42,000 gallons of milk contaminated with penicillin have been recalled from the shelves of 7-Elevens and other convenience and grocery stores in three metropolitan areas in Texas. Oak Farms Dairies, which is owned by the Southland Corporation, the parent company of 7-Eleven, said it recalled the milk from stores in Dallas-Fort Worth, Waco and Temple as soon as the contamination was discovered.

title: Vietnam to Seek Change In Setting Wage Levels
description: Vietnam's leaders have called for an end to large state subsidies and ''bureaucratic centralism'' for setting wages and prices, the Vietnam press agency reported today.

title: THE BIG PROTEIN GRAB
description: If the President's tax bill is enacted in the form he wants, one of its first results presumably will be an exodus from New York.

title: No Bodies Found in Hunt For Human Sacrifices
description: Investigators said they had found ''various ritualistic emblems'' but no bodies today as they dug in remote fields and woods in search of possible human remains of a satanic cult's sacrifices.

title: COAST PAPER FOR TIMES CO.
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire The Santa Barbara News-Press, a California evening daily and Sunday morning newspaper. Terms were not disclosed.

title: JAPAN SATELLITE, HUGHES IN DEAL
description: The Japan Communications Satellite Company, a joint venture between two Japanese trading houses and the American satellite maker Hughes Communications, has signed a $300 million contract to purchase two communications satellites from Hughes, an official of the Japanese company said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is our scientific opinion that this exhumed skeleton belongs to Josef Mengele.'' - Romeu Tuma, federal police chief of Sao Paulo. [1:1.]

title: KOCH BACKS S.I. BOROUGH LEADER DESPITE THICS - VIOLATIONS REPORT
description: Mayor Koch yesterday came to the support of the Staten Island Borough President, Ralph J. Lamberti, who is accused in a Department of Investigation report of violating the City Charter by mixing personal business with his official duties when he was deputy borough president.

title: Uganda Rebels Said to Kill 9
description: Suspected anti-Government rebels killed seven Ugandan Army soldiers and two policemen in separate incidents, the Roman Catholic newspaper Munno said today. Rebels issued a general warning in April that they were stepping up their activities throughout Uganda because of the general elections scheduled for later this year.

title: RIO GRANDE DRILLING reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
HIJACKER OF NORWEGIAN JET GIVES UP FOR BEER
description: An armed man who wanted to see the Prime Minister hijacked a Norwegian jetliner with 120 people aboard today, but surrendered later in exchange for beer, the police said.

title: SCIENTISTS DECIDE BRAZIL SKELTON IS JOSEF MENGELE
description: American, Brazilian and West German scientists announced jointly today that a skeleton recently exhumed from a graveyard near here was unquestionably that of Dr. Josef Mengele.

title: AN EXOTIC BET WITH STRINGS
description: Having taken almost six months to act on a proposal that should have been passed in a day, the Legislature is expected next week to approve pick-six betting in New York. The bet requires the selection in advance of six consecutive winners on the card, with 75 percent of the pool carried over to the next day if no one picks six.

title: RELEASE FOR RETARDED WOMAN
description: A mildly retarded woman who was kept illegally in a state mental institution for 29 years has been ordered released in 120 days by a Federal judge who said the case ''should make no one feel proud.''

title: MODULINE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VENDORS OF FOOD FACE NEW LIMIT ON STREET SALES
description: The New York City Council voted yesterday to widen restrictions on food peddlers in the congested streets of midtown Manhattan and to extend similar limits to crowded sections of lower Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens.

title: RHODE ISLAND CHIEF JUSTICE, UNDER ORDER, TAKES A LEAVE
description: The Chief Justice of the Rhode Island Supreme Court, under orders from a state ethics commission, today agreed to step down from the bench for four months and to be censured for bringing his office ''into serious disrepute'' through his friendships with men identified as active in organized crime.

title: ON TOUR, PHILHARMONIC WARMS TO THE OVATIONS
description: Everyone in the New York Philharmonic agreed: This was not like playing New York.

title: TWO RIGHTS GROUPS CONCEDE GUNMAN KILLED STARVING DEER
description: Two animal-rights groups agree that 34 of the 35 white-tailed deer killed by a sharpshooter last winter to reduce the herd at Crane Reservation were in poor shape and many of them may have been starving.

title: Jessica Amelar Is Wed To Harris D. Leinwand
description: At the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue in New York yesterday Jessica Rose Amelar and Harris D. Leinwand, both lawyers, were married by Rabbi Louis C. Gerstein.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: VOICE OF THE HOSTAGES: ALLYN BLAIR CONWELL
description: Friends and relatives of Allyn Blair Conwell say they are not surprised he has been chosen as spokesman for the American hostages in Beirut.

title: PANATECH RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Results for the prior year are from a research and development business that is no longer being pursued.

title: PENOBSCOT SHOE CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: HONEYMOON OVER FOR SOME
description: An unofficial ballot listing early candidates, based on statistics through Thursday night, for the sophomore-jinx-of-the-year award:

title: CONTRACTOR CASES LISTED BY PENTAGON
description: The Pentagon is investigating 45 of the nation's military contractors, including 9 of the top 10, concerning allegations that include bribery, kickbacks and bid-rigging, according to Defense Department documents.

title:
PATENTS;

AVALVE USED TO ANALYZE PARTICLES OF COMETS
description: A valve designed for use in chemical analysis of comet particles has been patented for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: TWO NAVY OFFICERS REPORTED CLEARED
description: Two senior Navy officers who were relieved of their command over the purchase of $659 ashtrays and other high-priced spare parts have been found blameless in a subsequent investigation, according to Congressional and Navy sources.

title: GLENN SEEKS A SINGLE PRIMARY IN U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CAMPAIGN
description: Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, called Tuesday for a national Presidential primary election day, with all of the country's polls to open and close at the same time.

title: ARAB GROUP ASSERTS IT PLANTED BOMB IN FRANKFURT
description: A group calling itself the Arab Revolutionary Organization says it was responsible for a terrorist bombing at Frankfurt International Airport Wednesday that killed 3 people and wounded 42.

title: Prison Term for Garrett
description: Carl Garrett, the former running back, was convicted of sexually assaulting a 12-year-old girl in Denton, Tex., and was sentenced to nine years in prison. Following the verdict by an all-white jury, Garrett, who is black, insisted that he was innocent and suggested that he was a victim of racism.

title: Tanana Comes Home
description: Frank Tanana, who was traded by the Texas Rangers for a minor leaguer this week, should get a major-league welcome when he makes his first start Sunday in a Detroit Tiger uniform against the Yankees on Sunday. Tanana, a three-time all-star, grew up in Detroit and starred for Catholic Central High School before being drafted by the California Angels in 1971.

title: DATAMETRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $45,200 for the quarter and $91,300 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $136,200 for the quarter and $259,100 for the 6 months.

title: NICHOLS INSTITUTE reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May.

title: EX-AIDE AT PARK SAYS HE ASKED ABOUT A PERMIT
description: A former employee at the Great Adventure amusement park in Jackson Township testified today that a local official had indicated to him that no building permit was needed for a fun house installed at the park in 1979.

title: SCRAPPY YOUNG COLFER TEES OFF AS PROFESSIONAL
description: She was just a little kid then, not yet 5 feet tall, a 12-year-old competing against much older golfers in her hometown of Phoenix. But Heather Farr was humiliated. In her first golf tournament that wasn't strictly for children, she finished dead last.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SATURDAY, JUNE 22, 1985 International The importance of not yielding to the demands of the hijackers holding 40 Americans hostage in Beirut was agreed on by Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel and Secretary of State George P. Shultz. They discussed the hostage crisis on the telephone in the first high-level Israeli-American contact since the Athens-to-Rome T.W.A. flight was hijacked last Friday. [Page 1, Column 6.] Moslems held an anti-American rally at Beirut airport, chanting ''Death to America'' and ''Death to Reagan.'' They were cheered by the hijackers of the T.W.A. jetliner there. The march was organized by the pro-Iranian Shiite group called the Party of God. The hijackers are believed to be members of that group. [1:5.] A skeleton exhumed in Brazil was unquestionably that of Dr. Josef Mengele, American, Brazilian and West German scientists announced jointly in Sao Paulo. [1:1.] U.S. Marines were the main target of a sidewalk attack in San Salvador Wednesday, Salvadoran guerrillas said in taking responsibility for the shooting that killed 13 people including four United States Marines and two American businessmen. [3:4.] National A slaying at the State Department took place on the seventh floor, near the office of Secretary of State George P. Shultz. A 20-year-old man, identified as Steven Doster, of Alexandria, Va., shot his mother to death with a rifle and then killed himself with the same weapon. His mother, Carole Doster, 44, was a secretary in the office of Edward Derwinski, the State Department counselor.

title: Escaped Prisoner Back After 28 Years
description: A man who escaped from a state prison 28 years ago was found living a few miles away and was sent back to finish his term, prison officials said today.

title: BELLAMY FACTION WINS COURT RULING
description: A state judge ruled yesterday that a Liberal Party faction supporting City Council President Carol Bellamy has the authority to name the party's nominee for Mayor. Liberal supporters of Mayor Koch said they would appeal the decision.

title: INDIAN IMMIGRANTS PROSPER AS OWNERS OF MOTELS
description: As the sun sinks over a pine forest, Jayram Patel sits at the front desk of his brick motel, awaiting the weary travelers who pull off busy Interstate 75.

title: INDICTMENTS IN SUGAR CASE
description: fourteen individuals and 13 companies have been indicted on charges of illegally diverting more than 88 million pounds of foreign sugar into the domestic market, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: TEXT OF EXPERTS' REPORT
description: Following is the text of the preliminary report by American experts who took part in an investigation into whether remains exhumed in Brazil are those of Josef Mengele, the Auschwitz death camp doctor:

title: UNITED STOCKYARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Year-ago results are pro forma because the company was spun off from Canal-Randolph Corp. on June 1, 1984.

title: DELTA DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $209,000 for the latest year and $33,000 for the prior year.

title: HOSTAGES IN LEBANON: Remembering Theodore Roosevelt;   SHULTZ AND PERES AGREE TO OPPOSE SHIITES' DEMANDS
description: As the Beirut hostage crisis entered its eighth day, Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel and Secretary of State George P. Shultz agreed on the importance of not yielding to the demands of the hijackers holding 40 Americans hostage in Beirut, the State Department said.

title: CASH BONUSES AS C.D. LURES
description: CASH bonuses to bank depositors have come and gone in recent years, particularly in New York City, where the search for a bargain is a preoccupation, if not an occupation, of many men and women. And this is one of those times when many such bonuses are available to those who open certificates of deposits at banks and savings and loan associations.

title: PRITZKERS IN DEAL TO ADD CONWOOD
description: The Pritzker family of Chicago, adding another company to its business empire, announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Conwood Corporation, a maker of smokeless tobacco products, for $36 a share, or a total of $400 million.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Argo Petroleum Corp., Santa Monica, Calif., said it had voted against the sale to TCPL Resources U.S.A. Ltd. of an 80 percent interest in the Frankel B. Lease in the Sespe field, Ventura County, Calif.

title: LAST-HOUR FIREWORKS FROM OPTIONS, FUTURES
description: It was what Wall Street called the ''double witching hour'' between 3 and 4 P.M. yesterday, as arbitragers and institutional traders had their final opportunity to close out both June stock-index options and futures positions. The activity gave a strong boost to the Dow Jones industrial average and volume on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: PRESIDENTS GAIN N.C.A.A. BEACHHEAD
description: ''This wasn't a convention,'' said Hoke Smith. ''It was an invasion.''

title:
PATENTS;

ELECTRONIC Security DOOR UNIT
description: AN electronic door security system, which admits visitors after they have been viewed and talked with, was patented this week. Hundreds of the systems have already been installed in office buildings, homes and even government offices in this country and abroad.

title: HOSTAGES IN LEBANON: Remembering Theodore Roosevelt;   1,000 SHIITES RALLY AT BEIRUT AIRPORT
description: Hundreds of Moslem demonstrators chanting ''Death to America' and ''Death to Reagan'' held a mass rally at the international airport here today, where they cheered the hijackers of the T.W.A. airliner.

title: IMPORTS WITHOUT WARRANTY
description: WHILE the United States dollar remains strong, shoppers in this country are being offered a wide array of imported goods at bargain prices. But some of those products are bringing forth a host of new consumer complaints.

title: New Jersey's False Flap Over Drugs
description: The uproar over the proposal by New Jersey's Becton Regional High School to test each of its 500 students for drug use is overblown. The testing is not necessarily a civil rights outrage - and neither is it an effective way to fight drugs.

title: SCRUGGS - LEFTWICH TO WORK FOR GOODE
description: Yvonne Scruggs-Leftwich, who resigned as State Housing Commissioner, said today that she would join the staff of Mayor W. Wilson Goode of Philadelphia.

title: D'ARCY PLANS MERGER WITH BENTON & BOWLES
description: D'Arcy MacManus Masius and Benton & Bowles, the nation's 12th- and 14th-largest advertising agencies, respectively, said yesterday that they would merge.

title: BLUE JAYS EXTEND RED SOX SLUMP
description: Lloyd Moseby singled three times and drove in two runs, and Willie Upshaw hit a home run tonight to lead the Toronto Blue Jays over the Boston Red Sox, 7-2.

title: Sally Keil Is Married To Sean J. McCarthy
description: Sally Van Wagenen Keil, a psychotherapist and writer, and Sean James McCarthy, general manager of the information systems group for Time, Inc., were married yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton, Dean of the Cathedral, presided.

title: THE NIGHT THEY DRESSED TO DINE AT ZABAR'S
description: It was only a few minutes after she had sampled a small wedge of Brie and nibbled at a salad of sun-dried tomatoes, buffalo mozzarella cheese and vinegared asparagus that Judy Auchincloss looked up from the more than 400 cheeses stacked up around her in Zabar's and asked, ''Can I have a David's Cookie?''

title: ARCO SETS PACT TO SELL STATIONS
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell more than 400 of its gasoline stations in eight states and the District of Columbia to the Shell Oil Company. Neither company would disclose the financial terms of the agreement, which they said had yet to be compeleted.

title: HENDERSON STAYS HOT AS YANKS GO COLD
description: Suddenly, the Yankees' momentum has turned. A three-game sweep in Baltimore has now dissolved into a two-game losing streak here. Rickey Henderson remained a staple in the offense, but Phil Niekro wobbled through a rough sixth inning, and the Detroit Tigers took a 6-4 decision tonight before a crowd of 47,499.

title: KIN OF 'OTHER HOSTAGES' SEE A CHANCE TO INCREASE EFFORTS FOR THEIR CAUSE
description: Relatives of ''the other hostages'' -the six or seven Americans who have spent the last three months to one year in captivity in Lebanon - generally hope the high level of attention focused on the hijacking of Trans World Airlines Flight 847 will help their own cause.

title: AZTEC MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: N.C.A.A. APPROVES STIFFER PENALTIES
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today overwhelmingly approved the strongest sanctions it has ever enacted against colleges and coaches who violate rules governing recruiting, amateurism, academic standards and ethics.

title: Caviar and Birthday Cake
description: Her nails were painted scarlet.

title: Some Ways to Avoid Swimming Accidents
description: To the Editor:

title: VIDEO SUPERMARKETS ON RISE
description: The video cassette rental industry, initially staked out by small entrepreneurs who saw a chance to cash in on a new business, is now seeing a burst of activity in big video supermarkets.

title: SURGING METS ARE FIRST AGAIN
description: The Mets kept rolling last night, won their fifth straight game and swept back into first place when they rallied to defeat the Montreal Expos, 6-3. And the winning pitcher was the much maligned, often booed and newly shelved Doug Sisk, who hadn't won in two months.

title: Credit the Hospitals For Containing Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: SPECIAL SUBGROUP OF HOSTAGES REPORTED
description: A Trans World Airlines official said today that the Beirut hijackers had specifically sought to create a separate group of hostages comprising United States military personnel, Greek nationals and passengers with Jewish-sounding names.

title: Deborah Regan, a Painter, Weds Douglas L. Edwards
description: At the United Presbyterian Church in Belvidere, N.J., yesterday Deborah Sanford Regan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John MacVeigh Regan of New York, was married to Douglas Leslie Edwards, a son of Mrs. Martin Seibel of Asbury, N.J., and John L. Edwards of East Blue Hill, Me.

title: MAN KILLS MOTHER AND HIMSELF AT STATE DEPT.
description: A young man shot and killed his mother and himself today on the seventh floor of the State Department, about 100 feet from the office of Secretary of State George P. Shultz, officials reported.

title: For Working Singles
description: The Smithsonian Institution is taking a modest step into the business of providing whereabouts for people who need people. Its Resident Associate Program, which has lectures and workshops on almost everything, is going to put on what it calls ''Ecosystems at Work . . . Tour Especially for Working Singles.''

title: GAMES PROSPER
description: Among the fallout from the multimillion-dollar surplus generated by the Los Angeles Olympics has been a change of outlook within the International Olympic Committee about the size of the Games program.

title: 2 PLEAD NOT GUILTY IN RAPE - SLAYING
description: Two Long Island men were each held in $750,000 bail today in Nassau County Court after they pleaded not guilty to the rape and killing of a Lynbrook teen-ager last November.

title: Jazz at the Mansion
description: Hot licks and hot dogs were served up on the lawn at Gracie Mansion yesterday, celebrating the annual 10-day Kool Jazz Festival, which began last night.

title: NETS PUSH SEARCH FOR COACH
description: The annual National Basketball Association meetings begin tomorrow night in San Francisco, where discussions will take place on expansion, the return to a balanced schedule, rule changes and other league matters. For the Nets, the weeklong meetings could be the place they find their new coach.

title: OFFICIAL AT U. OF MARYLAND TO HEAD QUEENS COLLEGE
description: A high-ranking academic administrator at the University of Maryland will be the new president of Queens College, according to college officials.

title: UNOCAL LAWSUIT
description: The Unocal Corporation said that it would comply with an order by the Interior Department to post a $100 million bond by next Wednesday for damages sought by the Federal agency in a year-old lawsuit against the company. A Federal judge in Anchorage has set a hearing date for September in the case, which Unocal is contesting. The Interior Department has accused Unocal of undervaluing natural gas it produced from the Kenai gas field for eight years, beginning in 1977.

title: Twins Drop Manager
description: Billy Gardner, the manager of the skidding Minnesota Twins, was dismissed yesterday and replaced by Ray Miller, the pitching coach of the Baltimore Orioles. For the 57-year-old Gardner, whose club is in next-to-last place in the American League West after losing 20 of its last 25 games, the midseason switch is a familiar one.

title: MOREHOUSE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BOMBS IN CHILE RESULT IN BLACKOUTS FOR 9 MILLION
description: Bombs planted by saboteurs damaged five electrical transmission towers in Chile's central valley overnight, cutting electricity to at least nine million people in the region, the Government said today.

title: BRUNSWICK-ICO
description: The Brunswick Corporation said that the merger of ICO Inc. and a Brunswick subsidiary would not be completed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, JUNE 22, 1985

title: JERSEY LIMITS ON WATER LEAD TO DECLINES IN USE
description: Businesses and residents in the six northeastern New Jersey counties that are under state orders to curtail their water use are reducing consumption, according to officials of many of the concerns and some of the water companies.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Thursday on travel to Greece in the aftermath of the Beirut hijacking misidentified a professional basketball official. The official, Larry Fleisher, is the general counsel of the Players Association of the National Basketball Association.

title: EDWIN MEESE JR. DIES AT 88: FATHER OF ATTORNEY GENERAL
description: Edwin Meese Jr., the father of United States Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, died today of liver cancer, Myron Meese, one of four surviving sons, said. He was 88 years old.

title: Henning to Coach Stars
description: It took two no's to get a yes, but the Minnesota North Stars have finally found a coach who likes them as much as they like him.

title:
PATENTS;

SHOES TO SUSPEND PERSON BY THE FEET
description: Strong and comfortable shoes to hold a person suspended vertically, feet up and head down, have been patented by S. Morgan Barber, a retired businessman at Lake San Marcos, Calif.

title: BOSTON DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: MULTIMEDIA PLAN
description: Multimedia Inc. said that the Federal Communications Commission had granted its approval to the company's recapitalization plan.

title: HALE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $2,211,000 for the latest year and $1,333,000 for the prior year.

title: Scouting;   RUNNING BATTLE
description: Edwin Moses's injured right knee has not improved, which means, the world's best 400-meter hurdler says, that he will not run his first race of the year until August at the very earliest.

title: KEY THREAT SEEN IN TERRORISTS' USE OF ATOM BOMBS
description: Specialists on terrorism and nuclear arms say that terrorists could obtain nuclear explosives with relative ease and that it may be only a matter of time before they do so.

title: BUFFALO ZOO TO SET YOUNG EAGLE FREE
description: A seven-week-old golden eagle born at the Buffalo Zoo will be released in the wilds of the Adirondacks next week, zoo officials said today.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday, and an accompanying transcript, reported President Reagan's call on Western nations to step up their efforts to curb international terrorism.

title: Paul Segal Is New Head Of Architects Group
description: Paul Segal, a partner in the Manhattan architectural firm of Paul Segal Associates, was inaugurated as president of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects at the chapter's annual meeting on Thursday.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 17 1. A laser beam shot from Hawaii missed the target mirror on the space shuttle Discovery, as the diagram illustrates, because a simple human error turned the mirror 180 degrees in the wrong direction. What was the error? 2. Of the 766 detainees whose release the Beirut hijackers have demanded, (235/570/750/766) are Shiite Moslems, according to the Israeli Defense Ministry. 3. At his confirmation hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee, William Bradford Reynolds apologized repeatedly for giving inaccurate or possibly misleading testimony about his record. For what position has President Reagan nominated him and what record is it? 4. A ''glib, fast-talking lobbyist for a reactionary liberalism.'' Who made this remark, to whom was he referring, and what were the circumstances? 5. After next year music lovers in Atlanta, Boston, Cleveland and Minneapolis will no longer be able to attend a series of performances that have been an annual event in those cities each summer. Explain. 6. At a 40th anniversary reunion, 700 former co-workers gathered in New Mexico to reminisce about their two years of isolation. In what work did they engage? 7. The austral made its debut in Argentina at 1,000-to-1. Explain. 8. Three civilians were killed in one terrorist incident. Six Americans were killed in another terrorist incident. In what countries did the incidents occur? 9. The collapse of Tse-Chung Chen at the United States Open golf tournament was caused by an extremely rare mistake.

title: U.S. CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL AMERICAN LEAGUE - Lifted three-game suspension of Bert Blyleven, pitcher, of Cleveland Indians.

title: VARO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income The latest year's results include income from a one-time reduction in taxes on its domestic international sales corporation of $1,757,000, or 39 cents a share; an inventory writeoff of $3.2 million, a total of $632,000 in amortization of software development costs and an accrual of $1 million for a 2-year management transition that was provided for in the fourth quarter.

title: WHITE INDUSTRIES
description: White Consolidated Industries said it was combining the operations and management of its four major brands of home appliances. It said key operating groups of its Frigidaire unit in Dayton, Ohio; its Gibson unit in Greenville, Mich., and its Kelvinator and White-Westinghouse units in Pittsburgh would be moving to Columbus, Ohio.

title: BOND PRICES OFF FOR THIRD DAY
description: Bond prices dropped sharply yesterday for the third consecutive day as expectations of a cut in the Federal Reserve's discount rate faded.

title: CHARITY - A MATTER OF DEDUCTION
description: President Reagan's proposals to reform the Federal income tax system are far less threatening to charitable contributions, and the thousands of institutions and causes that benefit from those contributions, than the original tax plan submitted by the Treasury Department last year. Gifts will remain fully deductible for those who itemize, and gifts of appreciated property, such as stock, would continue to be largely deductible at full market value. There remains, however, one major flaw in Mr. Reagan's plan: His proposal to deny the deductibility of charitable contributions made by taxpayers who do not itemize.

title: Pamela Courtney Franzheim Marries
description: Pamela Courtney Franzheim, a daughter of Barbara Franzheim Dror of New York and Kenneth Franzheim 2d of Houston, was married yesterday to Whitney Tower Jr., the son of Mrs. John Train of Bedford, N.Y., and Mr. Tower of New York. The Rev. Andrew J. Mullins performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: REAGAN SAYS U.S. RESTRAINT HAS LIMITS
description: President Reagan said here today that the United States would continue to show restraint in the aftermath of recent terrorist acts, but he warned that ''no one'' should doubt America's resolve to counter such attacks.

title: INITIO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-After an extrardinary tax credit of $205,500.

title: Bridge: Difficult Choice Can Result From Two Balanced Hands
description: When a partnership has two balanced hands, the decision whether to play in an eight-card major-suit fit rather than no-trump may be very close.

title: EX-AGENT CALLS DOCUMENTS LOAN FORM, NOT SECRET PAPERS
description: Richard W. Miller, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, testified today he was carrying a loan application, not classified documents, when he got into the car of a woman accused of conspiring with him to spy for the Soviet Union.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Montreal Expos, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Tigers, at Detroit, 4:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 4 P.M.) White Sox vs. California Angels, at Chicago. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M. Minnesota Twins vs. Texas Rangers, at Minneapolis. (Radio - WCBS, 8:20 P.M.) Boxing Donald Curry vs. Pablo Baez, 10 rounds, junior middleweights, at Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City. First preliminary, 3 P.M. Curry is 22-0 with 17 knockouts and is the World Boxing Association welterweight champion. He is trying to move up in weight class, and this is his second fight as a junior middleweight. Baez is 17-12-1 with 15 knockouts. (Television - Channel 7, 4:30 P.M.) Football Showboats vs. Arizona Outlaws, at Memphis. The Showboats are in the playoffs but the Outlaws are out. (Television - ESPN 8 P.M.) Golf Georgia Pacific Atlanta Classic, at Marietta, Ga., third round (Television -Channel 2, 4:30 P.M.) Ladies Professional Golf Association Mayflower Classic, at Indianapolis, third round (Television -ESPN, 3:30 P.M.) P.G.A. Senior Tournament Players Championship, at Cleveland, third round. Harness Racing Roosevelt Raceway, 8 P.M. With 22 of the nation's top 3-year-olds entered, the Messenger Stake will be the richest ever, $485,560, and the field has been split into three elimination heats: the sixth and seventh races with a nonbetting race in between. The Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television -MSG Network, 12:50 A.M.) Monticello, 7:30 P.M. Thoroughbred Racing Belmont Park, 1 P.M.
