Ziggy's Boy is the early favorite in the $75,000-added Hill Prince for 3-year-olds at a mile and a sixteenth on the turf.

title: Rose's Stand Criticized
description: If there is a baseball strike this summer, Pete Rose, the Cincinnati Reds' player-manager, may be the only major league manager whose salary will stop. That's the word from the Reds' owner, Marge Schott, who expressed dismay that Rose has been outspoken in support of the players' demands and joined other Reds in voting to authorize a strike.

title: Impaired Rape Victim Is Allowed an Abortion
description: A judge today authorized an abortion for a 35-year-old woman suffering from a brain disease who was raped while she was strapped to a bed in a convalescent hospital, and became pregnant.

title: Athens Festival Opens
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France and Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece tonight inaugurated the six-month reign of Athens as ''Cultural Capital of Europe.''

title: GENERAL FOODS SURGES $10.75 ON MERGER TALK
description: Persistent takeover rumors pushed up the stock of the General Foods Corporation by $10.75 in heavy trading yesterday, to $82.375. The rumors were that Philip Morris Inc. was considering making an offer of nearly $5 billion for the food company.

title: U.N. Security Council Assails South Africa
description: For the third time in three days, the Security Council condemned the South African Government today, this time for a recent military attack on neighboring Botswana.

title: 2 INSTITUTIONS HAIL NEW STAFF HOUSING
description: The Rockefeller University and the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center broke ground yesterday for a 36-story residence for faculty and staff members, realizing a vision that dates from the 1920's and John D. Rockefeller Jr. Mr. Rockefeller decided in those years to move the Sloan-Kettering center from Central Park West and 106th Street to the area around the Rockefeller University in hopes of fostering cooperation between the two institutions.

title: U.N. OFFERS HELP ON WINNING HOSTAGES' RELEASE
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said today that the United Nations had ''presented many ideas to the American authorities'' on how it might help win the release of the American hostages in Beirut.

title: FALLING SPACE JUNK LIGHTS SKY
description: A large chunk of debris from the launching of a Soviet satellite plunged back to earth and set off a startling red, green and blue midnight display over the Northeastern United States.

title: Unfair Treatment of Ex-Cancer Patients
description: For former cancer patients, the good news is that the survival rate is now nearly 50 percent. The bad news is that they face workplace discrimination - and the hope is that legislation can remedy this problem.

title: CARDINALS GAIN SHARE OF FIRST
description: The pitcher Kurt Kepshire doubled and scored two runs, and Jack Clark slugged a three-run triple, leading the St. Louis Cardinals to a 7-5 victory over the Cubs tonight and a share of first place in the National League East with the Mets. Chicago continued to stagger, dropping its 10th straight.

title: 3 MEN ON COAST FACE ILLEGAL EXPORT CHARGE
description: Three men have been charged by a Federal grand with illegally exporting to Czechoslovakia sophisticated technological equipment that could be used for military purposes.

title: John Stacks Wed To Carol Ruane
description: The marriage of Carol Cox Ruane of New York, a psychotherapist in private practice, to John Fultz Stacks, deputy chief of correspondents for Time magazine, took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. John Mellin performed the ceremony.

title: NORTH HILLS ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Make Voting Easier
description: Politicians regularly extol every citizen's right to vote, but where is their fervor when it comes to making that right easier to exercise? Despite a strangulating congestion in the New York City election system last year, the State Legislature has so far passed only one substantive reform, killed others and, with adjournment only days away, is keeping others up in the air. There's enough time left to act; is there enough will?

title: REPORT CRITICIZES INACTION ON REACTOR
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission delayed for almost six years forcing improvements at a nuclear power plant in Ohio that it knew was vulnerable to a failure like the one at Three Mile Island, according to a report made public by a House subcommittee today.

title: Spare a Dime?
description: The varieties of panhandling in the capital run the modern gamut. There is a silent man in a wrinkled business suit and tie who simply holds out his hat like a Depression-era still photo.

title: At Sea
description: Nancy Reagan is preparing to spend the night of July 16 aboard the aircraft carrier the America somewhere off the coast of Virginia. She was invited to visit the warship by the Secretary of the Navy, John F. Lehman Jr., who is to accompany her when she arrives by helicopter on the America's flight deck. Mrs. Reagan is to talk to the sailors about the Navy's program for dealing with drug problems, one of her major concerns.

title: Action Grants
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ALL'S FAIR Twenty years after the 1964-65 New York World's Fair played Flushing Meadow Park, shades of the big exposition are once again in public view in nearby Flushing, Queens. ''The Mighty Fair'' is a large exhibition in a small space that displays artifacts, photos, documents and a videotape that will recall great sights and events of the billion-dollar extravaganza.

title: Shipley to Lead Drive
description: Walter V. Shipley, chairman and chief executive officer of the Chemical New York Corporation, has been elected chairman of the Lincoln Center Consolidated Corporate Fund Drive and will join the center's board of directors, a spokesman for Lincoln Center has announced. Mr. Shipley replaces Willard C. Butcher, chairman and chief executive officer of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: Therese Kiley Weds Roger Charles Kahn
description: Therese Ellen Kiley and Roger Charles Kahn were married yesterday at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. John Andrew.

title: 125 REPORTED ARRESTED IN NEPAL AFTER SERIES OF TERRORIST BOMBINGS
description: Scores of arrests were reported today, the day after five bombs exploded in this Himalayan city of temples, killing 7 people and wounding 24.

title: ''Grind'' to Close Tonight
description: ''Grind,'' the musical with book by Fay Kanin, music by Larry Grossman and lyrics by Ellen Fitzhugh, and set in a burlesque house in 1933, will close after tonight's performance at the Mark Hellinger Theater.

title: S.E.C ALLOWS BID BY TURNER
description: Ted Turner won the Securities and Exchange Commission's permission today to offer high-interest securities for CBS Inc. stock, but his $5.4 billion network takeover bid must still obtain approval from two other agencies.

title: UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA REJECTS BID TO RID ITSELF OF AFRICA HOLDINGS
description: The Regents of the University of California today cast aside a proposal to divest the university of its $2 billion in holdings in companies doing business with South Africa and instead voted to create a nine-member advisory committee to recommend a course of action.

title: U.S. PLANS TO CLOSE SHLTER REAGAN SAID WOULD BE A MODEL
description: The Federal Government announced today that it would close a Washington shelter for the homeless that President Reagan had vowed to turn into a ''model'' facility.

title: Shufflng the Deck
description: Edward P. Djerejian is to leave the State Department, where he is the deputy spokesman, to go to the White House, where he will be deputy press secretary for foreign affairs. Mr. Djerejian, a career Foreign Service officer, has been No. 2 spokesman at State, assisting No. 1, Bernard Kalb.

title: MONOLITHIC MEMORIES INC reports earnings for 12 wks to June 9
HOSPITAL SUPPLY BID BY BAXTER
description: The American Hospital Supply Corporation, the nation's largest distributor of medical equipment, said yesterday that it had received a $3.6 billion acquisition offer from one of its chief competitors, Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc.

title: Unsolicited Support
description: The Carol Bellamy campaign for mayor is disavowing one supporter - a wizened man wearing an Uncle Sam suit, playing a flute and looking for campaign contributions.

title: Quake Shakes Greek Island
description: A moderate earthquake shook the Aegean island of Euboea early today, but no damage or casualties were reported. The Athens Seismological Institute said the earthquake occurred at 3:15 A.M. local time and measured 4.4 on the Richter scale, signifying that it could have caused moderate damage in a crowded area. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph.

title: The Sham of Namibia
description: South Africa has produced yet another surrogate regime for South-West Africa, or Namibia, the former German colony whose independence it has long and illegally blocked. The excuse for the last five years has been the presence of Cuban troops in Angola, Namibia's other neighbor. The reality is that South Africa has all the while been stirring up civil war in Angola to make sure the leftist Angolan regime will have to keep its Cuban protectors.

title: U.S. JUDGE LIMITS SPY CASE COMMENT
description: A Federal judge today sharply limited the public statements that attorneys and investigators may make in connection with the espionage case of John A. Walker Jr. Mr. Walker, a former Navy communications expert, is accused of leading a spy ring that sold classified information to the Soviet Union.

title: HOSTAGES IN LEBANON: The Course of Events;   8 DAYS OF MIDEAST TERROR: THE JOURNEY OF FLIGHT 847
description: This is the story of the hijacking of Trans World Airlines Flight 847 up to this point, as told by those who have been freed so far. Those who spoke withheld some details, and some said they were doing so because Federal authorities had warned them that the remaining hostages could be jeopardized by their remarks.

title: BALLET: HARLEM DANCE THEATER IN TRIPLE BILL OF DIVERSE STYLES
description: The styles were different in the three ballets presented by the Dance Theater of Harlem on Wednesday at the Metropolitan Opera House, where the company performs through June 29. But the program had a compelling sense of unity to it, for a very compelling reason. This is a company whose dancers seem to bring great inner reserves of emotion to bear on everything they perform.

title: FAULTY EQUIPMENT FOUND IN PLANT THAT MADE TAINTED CHEESE
description: Leaky equipment and faulty pasteurization were found at a plant that made contaminated cheese believed responsible for the deaths of 43 people since March, officials said today.

title: What's Wrong With the Housing-Voucher Scheme
description: To the Editor:

title: AGENCY ASKS F.B.I. TO CHECK WORKERS
description: A study by the Department of Health and Human Services of 46 people recently convicted of computer crimes against the Government has determined that one-quarter of the 46 had previous felony convictions.

title: STAGE: A 'DISNEY' ROUNDUP
description: Yesterday morning's debut performance of ''The Magical World of Disney,'' the new stage show at Radio City Music Hall, was greeted with ear-splitting approval by an invited audience of nearly 6,000 schoolchildren. They squealed and clapped their way through an exuberant, colorful Disney roundup that happens to be a good deal cheerier than ''Return to Oz,'' the new feature on the Music Hall's screen.

title: BRAKES FAULTED IN JET CRASH
description: A failure in the braking system caused an Air Force jet to crash off the runway after landing April 20 at the Wilkes-Barre-Scranton International Airport, killing a four-star general and four others aboard, the Air Force said today. The general was Jerome F. O'Malley, 53 years old, commander of the Tactical Air Command, the Air Force branch that oversees fighter-plane operations in the United States. Also killed were his wife, Diane, 52, and three crew members.

title: DRIVE ON HEART DISEASE AIMED AT U.S. WORKER
description: Aiming to reach ''unmatched numbers of workers,'' the American Heart Association today launched a program called Heart at Work that will enlist employers to encourage people to stop smoking, to eat wisely and to exercise regularly.

title: TRIAL IN ROME: AGCA'S 'DOUBLE GAME'
description: The trial of eight men accused of conspiring to assassinate Pope John Paul II heard more conflicting testimony the other day from Mehmet Ali Acga. The subject was the question of how many other gunmen were in St. Peter's Square on the day Mr. Acga shot and wounded the Pope.

title: CHANGE IN FLOATING CURRENCY RATE SETUP BARRED
description: The United States and 10 other wealthy nations today announced modest revisions of the world's monetary system.

title: PALMER LEADS
description: Arnold Palmer, refreshed by a two-week rest, shot a five -under-par 67 for a one-stroke lead over Don January Thursday in the first round of the $240,000 Senior Tournament Players Championship.

title: OF POLITICS AND FEDERAL EMPLOYMENT
description: Almost a decade ago, agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation began questioning the friends, former teachers, associates and neighbors of Harry Kenneth Clark, a resident of the Washington area who was attending a local college and working part time as a book shelver at the Library of Congress.

title: GIDEONS UNIT AGREES TO HALT BIBLE DISTRIBUTION IN SCHOOLS
description: The Gideons International has agreed to stop handing out Bibles in Iowa public schools as part of a settlement of a Federal suit that challenged the practice under the principle of separation of church and state.

title: MAYOR REQUESTS THAT RESTAURANTS VOLUNTARILY SET UP NO-SMOKING AREAS
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that his administration had asked the city's 15,000 restaurants to impose restrictions on smoking voluntarily.

title: HOSTAGES IN LEBANON: On Second Thoughts;   THE QUANDARY FOR ISRAEL
description: Israel finds itself in a quandary over how to respond in the Beirut hostage crisis, and Israeli experts on terrorism say they believe it is an indirect result of the Government's decision last month to trade 1,150 prisoners, most of them Palestinians, for 3 Israeli prisoners of war.

title: Freebie
description: There are people in Washington full of passionate intensity on the subject of Government giveaways. The Library of Congress remains unfazed, however, printing things it deems worthy and sometimes giving copies away to anybody who writes in.

title: REPORTED CHOICE OF G.O.P. ADVISER AS ARCHIVIST IS PROTESTED
description: Some prominent archivists say they are concerned that President Reagan may appoint a former political adviser to head the National Archives.

title: 10,000 Poles Reported To Sign Petition
description: A prominent dissident said today that more than 10,000 Poles had signed a petition calling for the release of three Solidarity activists who were convicted last week for organizing a national strike.

title: DOCTORS' WALKOUT IN BROOKLYN ENDS By The Associated Press
description: Interns and residents voted unanimously yesterday to return to work at Interfaith Medical Center in Brooklyn.

title: MARTIN VOICE OF YANKEES
description: George Steinbrenner confirmed yesterday that he had issued a gag order to Yankee employees, saying he wanted Manager Billy Martin ''to do all the talking for the team.''

title: German Sees the U.S. In Shift on 'Star Wars'
description: One of West Germany's most vigorous supporters of President Reagan's ''Star Wars'' plan says the United States is no longer interested in getting its European allies involved in the missile defense system.

title: THE REDISCOVERY OF SILVER LAKE
description: THERE'S a giant white deer that has for decades run through Silver Lake, the county's 236-acre natural preserve in Harrison. At least that's what some people say.

title: CYNTHIA PURCELL AND GEORGE TRAPNELL ARE MARRIED
description: Cynthia Hunter Purcell and George Hann Trapnell were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. John W. Bishop, assisted by the bridegroom's brother, Judson B. Trapnell, chaplain of the New York Foundling Hospital.

title: SHUTTLE CONDUCTS COMMERCIAL TESTS
description: One of the significant tasks of the weeklong mission of the space shuttle Discovery has nothing to do with launching satellites, looking for massive stars at the center of the Milky Way or conducting experiments for President Reagan's proposed space shield against enemy missiles.

title: 329 Lost on Air-India Plane After Crash Near Ireland; Bomb Is Suspected as Cause
description: LONDON, June 23 -- An Air-India Boeing 747 plunged into the sea off the Irish coast today, apparently killing all 329 people on board, and an Indian official said an explosion was believed to have caused the crash.

title: Bomb Wounds 2 in Ulster
description: A bomb packed in a canvas bag exploded in a parking lot in Banbridge as policemen were trying to evacuate the center of the town, and two officers were slightly wounded by flying glass, the police said today. They said a person who had seen two men leave the bag in the entry of a building carried it to the center of the parking lot and called the police.

title: Inside Information Whistle Power
description: ''We're looking for whistle-blowers, not undercover agents, people willing to stand up and sound the alarm.'' So wrote Sanford Russell, inspector general of New York's Metropolitan Transit Authority, in a recent letter to the agency's 68,000 employees.

title: LIBRARIES PURSUE PROJECTS FOR LEARNING DISABLED
description: WHEN 10-year-old Stephen Coughlin agreed last December to portray the part of Chang in the Chinese folk tale ''Tikki Tikki Tembo,'' he had no idea that he would still be telling the story in June.

title: Rhode Island Officials Bid Censured Judge Quit
description: Two Rhode Island state senators, the minority leader, Jonathan Farnum, and Robert Motherway, called today for the resignation of Chief Justice Joseph A. Bevilacqua of the state's Supreme Court, who was censured Friday for fraternizing with underworld figures.

title: JULIA VALENTINE IS WED TO WILLIAM S. KEARNS
description: At the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York yesterday Julia Tedesco Valentine, widow of Drayton Valentine, was married to William Stanley Kearns, an architect in private practice in New York. The Rev. David S. Shew performed the ceremony.

title: FROM TWO MOST ENGLISH MEN
description: THE LYTTELTON HART-DAVIS LETTERS Correspondence of George Lyttelton and Rupert Hart-Davis. Volume Two 1956-57. Edited, with an introduction, by Rupert Hart-Davis. 226 pp. Illinois: Academy Chicago Publishers. $14.95.

title: THE MYRIAD PROBLEMS OF GEORGE BALL
description: ONCE the Wunderkind of Wall Street, George L. Ball, now 46, is finding the going much tougher in middle age. He is still a work machine - logging 50,000 air miles a month and keeping a workaholic's schedule from dawn to dusk and beyond. But, success has proved elusive. The firm he heads - Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. - has rolled up multi-million dollar losses that have staggered Wall Street. And, Mr. Ball himself continues to be dogged by the check-kiting scandal that took place at E.F. Hutton & Company during his five-year tenure as Hutton's president.

title: HUGH WOLFF TAKING ORCHESTRA'S PODIUM
description: THE board of directors of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra formally announced last week the appointment of Hugh Wolff as the orchestra's new music director.

title: Bangladesh Troops Rescue Flood Victims
description: Troops have been called out in eastern and northern Bangladesh to rescue about 100,000 people marooned by monsoon floods, officials said today.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

INTO A LANDSCAPE
description: IT looks like a series of pictures within a picture. The big view is a landscape: a watercolor, perhaps, of an inlet on a warm and muggy morning. Grayish water laps onto a tiny beach the color of crushed clam shells. Tan marsh grass rises out of mud flats. Behind the marsh and beach are tiny green poison ivy plants and, behind them, tall dark oaks that cut the sunlight in shafts.

title: Obstruction Ahead: No Guidelines
description: I have read the article regarding the roadwork in our county [''Plans Outlined to Alleviate Delays During Roadwork,'' June 2] . Having been a passenger and driver on our roads for the last 30 years, I was fascinated by the prospect of more winding in and out of construction, or on the roads after they have been reconstructed.

title: POETS AND TENNIS
description: To the Editor:

title: Lesson of Hijacking Is That the U.S. Is at War in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: BAROQUE MUSIC AT SUNSET ALONG THE MYSTIC
description: ORDINARILY, salt water and sacbuts don't mix.

title: BROWSING THE FRENCH FLEA MARKETS
description: It was horn-handled knives that introduced me to the great French world of used objects. I wanted a set of 12, old ones, preferably with heavy-gauge stainless steel blades engraved with the name of some long gone restaurant, to go with my silver-plated forks and spoons, which were bought at auction on the Rue Drouot in Paris. You don't find ancient horn-handled knives in department stores, of course, so the search for them took me to the world of itinerant fairs and flea markets that are a kind of national passion among the French.

title: MISS KEEHN, JOHN LEWIS RE MARRIED
description: The marriage of Elisabeth Keehn to John Jasper Lewis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Lewis of Wilmette, Ill., took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Silas Keehn, parents of the bride, in Winnetka, Ill. The Rev. James E. Avery, chaplain of Northwestern University and a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony.

title: HOSTAGES IN LEBANON: Where Safety is Taken Seriously;   SURVEY FINDS SECURITY AT AIRPORTS USUALLY SERIOUS, SOMETIMES NOT
description: Airport security varies widely around the world, but a review of procedures shows that in general those practiced in developing countries tend to be lax while those in North America and the Communist bloc tend to be stringent.

title:
ABOUT LONG ISLAND;

A LIFETIME OF MEMORIES AND JUNK
description: WITH the kids out of the house now, we have been considering moving into a one-bedroom apartment in Manhattan because our seven-room suburban house is too small.

title: PHILHARMONIC CANCELS STOP IN GREECE ON BASIS OF WARNING ABOUT AIRPORT
description: The New York Philharmonic, here on a European tour, said today that it had canceled performances in Greece, scheduled to begin Sunday, because of a State Department warning against flying into Athens.

title: CORNWALL
description: To the Editor: The article on the South West Peninsula Coast Path (Travel, May 26) brings back fond recollections to one who has often tramped along the rugged rim of Cornwall.

title: HELEN B. BARTLETT EXCHANGES VOWS WITH A. C. HASS
description: Helen Buck Bartlett, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Leffingwell Bartlett of Washington, was married there yesterday to Anthony Cecil Hass, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Hass of Washington and New York. The Rev. Daniel W. Morrissey, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Dahlgren Chapel of Georgetown University Courtenay Lyndon Valenti was maid of honor.

title:
SHOULD THE U.S. TAX FOREIGN GASOLINE?;

IMPORTS COULD KILL THE REFINING INDUSTRY
description: IN 1984, United States oil refiners closed almost one million barrels a day of refining capacity because of competition from imported refined petroleum products. With the world oil market soft and new refineries coming on stream in the Middle East, the United States can expect imports of refined petroleum products to increase and more domestic refineries to close unless the Government enacts a higher tariff, a quota, or both. As a matter of national security, the nation must have sufficient refinery capacity to meet its needs in an emergency.

title:
ART;

HOME-FRONT ART FROM THE WAR YEARS
description: THIS year, the 40th anniversary of the end of World War II, we have seen various scholarly and popular studies of aspects of life in wartime America. Certainly it is not out of order to remind people that American art was alive, well and very much in ferment, in spite of the termination of the New Deal patronage programs, public indifference or hostility and the lack of a commercial market.

title: FLOWERS CUT A SWATH
description: FASHION designers must be spending more time lately in the garden. There or in a chintz emporium. How else to explain the profusion of floral prints seen these days on stylish women all over town.

title: 4 HOUR 'DEAD
description: MARTIN WASKOSKY was at the wheel of a taxicab in Seattle on Dec. 11 when it plunged off a steep embankment and struck a carport, the top of a parked car and the deck of a house. He was pronounced dead at the scene at 2:30 A.M.

title: Airliner Arriving From Beirut Is Inspected at Cairo Airport
description: Egyptian authorities, seeking to prevent any possible hijacking, cordoned off a Lebanese airliner with armored vehicles, marksmen and special police units when it flew in from Beirut today.

title: AUTO THEFT ON THE RISE AT THE MALLS
description: SHOPPERS at the Green Acres Mall in Valley Stream have been plagued by a wave of car thefts.

title: JEROME STRELOV IS WED TO MISS MANOCHERIAN
description: Kimberly Diana Manocherian, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Manocherian of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jerome John Strelov, the son of Anne Strelov of New York and the late Jerry Strelov. The Rev. Donald Harrington performed the Unitarian ceremony at the Plaza hotel.

title:
ON LANGUAGE;

BAYBUH,BAYUH....
description: WHERE'ER YOU walk,'' wrote Alexander Pope -Handel later put it to music -''cool gales shall fan the glade,/ Trees, where you sit, shall crowd into a shade;/ Where'er you tread, the blushing flow'rs shall rise,/ And all things flourish where you turn your eyes.''

title: RIGHTS GROUPS PUT EMPHASIS ON PROTECTING GAINS
description: It is not business as usual for civil rights groups these days. They still negotiate, demonstrate, boycott and sue, but officials say the energy they once put into attempts to improve the status of black Americans is now aimed at preserving improvements already achieved.

title: THE WORLD OF GROOMS, HOT WALKERS AND JOCKEYS
description: What is a horse race? A hope, a dream, a business, a coming together of people from disparate backrounds. ''Nothin' but a Horse Race,'' an imaginative hourlong documentary on WNEW-TV, looks at America's newest racetrack, Garden State Park in Cherry Hill, N. J., and finds excitement. Why not? The camera stares down the chute; horses break from the starting gate; even a race with nags look good. There may be a finer television picture in sports, but what could it possibly be? Meanwhile, no matter how diligent the effort to make horse racing renounce its ancient ambiance (promoters call Garden State ''the race track of the 21st century'') there clings to it an old-fashioned raffishness. The documentary tip-toes around much of this, but fortunately some intrudes. ''Nothin' but a Horse Race'' can be seen on Channel 5 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: COLLEGE PRESIDENTS ARE TAKING CONTROL
description: Presidents of major colleges and universities have said for years that they did not have the time to deal with their large, income-producing athletic departments. They said they had to depend on coaches, athletic directors and athletic department staff members to run a clean shop.

title: BOB DYLAN BRINGS BACK THE PERSONAL TOUCH
description: Bob Dylan's ''Empire Burlesque'' makes a fine first impression. Its music, the blues-rock-gospel amalgam that Mr. Dylan has been polishing though the 1980's, has drive and definition. Its lyrics, meanwhile, reveal that Mr. Dylan has left behind his proselytizing, born-again Christian phase - which resulted in some of his worst verse - and that he's willing to write about people again instead of mystical and rhetorical abstractions.

title: The Death of Edmund Perry
description: Leaders of New York City's black community assert that the killing of Edmund Perry, a black honor student shot by a white officer, is another terrifying example of police brutality. The police and prosecutors insist that the facts of the case do not support such a charge. For more than a week, however, they have provided few facts.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: AN EXCESS OF LOVE. By Cathy Cash Spellman. (Delacorte, $16.95.) Constance and Elizabeth FitzGibbon, high-born sisters, are drawn into the cause of Irish independence by the men they love.

title: ELLEN REDMOND IS MARRIED
description: The marriage of Ellen Margaret Redmond, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aiden J. Redmond of East Islip, L.I., to Edward Joseph Farrell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Farrell of Oakdale, L.I. and New Symrna Beach, Fla., took place yesterday. Msgr. John Fagan performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Church in East Islip.

title: MARGARET GRAHAM MARRIES
description: Margaret Emily Graham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip K. Graham of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to Christopher J. Weglarz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Weglarz of New Milford, N.J. Msgr. Frederick Valentino performed the ceremony at St. James Roman Catholic Church in Red Bank, N.J. Her father is vice president and assistant treasurer of the Fiduciary Trust Company of New York. The bridegroom's father is a vice president with the New York architectural firm of Ferrenz, Taylor, Clark & Associates.

title: SUBTERRANEAN I
description: Passengers on the Washington Metro subway are accustomed to the public address system drily informing them what stop is coming up, which side the doors will open on and nothing more. But when Jack Weaver is the engineer, on the Yellow Line from Gallery Place to Alexandria, the audience is not limited to such spartan fare.

title: HAVANA, LONG GRAY, GETTING A FACELIFT
description: Along the oceanfront boulevard in downtown Havana workmen are scraping the facades of Colonial-style buildings, getting them ready for fresh coats of paint. Heavy Russian paving machines are resurfacing some of the streets and new traffic signals are being installed.

title: NEW CASSETTES: ROSTAND, MAUGHAM AND ELTON JOHN
description: Painters Painting A film by Emile de Antonio, 1972 New Video Independent 116 minutes. $79.95 First issued in 1972, ''Painters Painting'' took rank immediately as a classic of eavesdropping.

title:
ANTIQUES;

A PORTRAIT OF ENGRAVER IS MISSING
description: A SMALL portrait of Amos Doolittle, one of the earliest copper engravers in America, has been stolen from the Museum of the New Haven Colony Historical Society, 114 Whitney Avenue. Doolittle is known for his four scenes illustrating the battles at the start of the Revolutionary War.

title: TOWNS FINDING IT DIFFICULT TO GET AFFORDABLE INSURANCE
description: IN Connecticut, home of the so-called insurance capital of the world, many towns are finding that they can not get insurance this year or that it is so costly they almost cannot afford it.

title: VIRGINIA HINRICHS IS WED IN DARIEN
description: Virginia Lee Hinrichs, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Hinrichs of Darien, Conn., and Stephen Wilcox Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Thompson Miller of Roswell, Ga., were married yesterday. The Rev. Kevin D. Bean performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, assisted by the Rev. Francis Virgulak, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: CURRY STOPS BAEZ TO STAY UNBEATEN Speical to The New York Times
description: Exercises in greatness are not always competitive or dramatic, as Donald Curry showed again today. He especially showed poor Pablo Baez, a tough welterweight who was outboxed, outpunched and simply outclassed in a nationally televised bout at the Trump Casino Hotel that was mercifully stopped at 1 minute 40 seconds of the sixth round by Referee Larry Hazzard.

title: THE ECONOMY PICKS UP THE PACE
description: HERE is one way to view the economy:

title: Vermin
description: WHETHER a home is in the city or the country, it can be attacked by animal, bird or insect pests that cause structural damage, decay and unsightly conditions.

title: NEW CENTER IN BRONX ASSISTS ELDERLY WITH VISION PROBLEMS
description: Glaucoma threatened Julia Hagans for many years, but she was still unprepared for the time when she could see only shadows.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DAEMON IN LITHUANIA. By Henri Guigonnat. Translated by Barbara Wright. Illustrated by Erika Weihs. (New Directions, Cloth, $14. Paper, $7.95.) Nothing is quite what it seems in this macabre, merry little tale.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: MANSIONS ON FILM When Monica Randall, historic preservationist from Long Island, investigated the remains of Castle Wilderstein, one of the Hudson Valley's stately homes in Rhinebeck, she found the 96-year-old owner, Daisy Suckley, reduced to living in front of the dining room fireplace. ''She couldn't afford to heat 36 rooms,'' said Miss Randall. ''But she said: 'my grand-daddy built this house. I was born here and I'm gonna die here.' '' The house was eventually preserved by local residents who bought it, restored it and established a foundation to maintain it.

title: REVIVING A DORMANT 6TH AVE. STRIP
description: THIRTY-SIX years ago, Sidney Bernstein and the late Monroe Lawrence got together and built a six-story, general-use office building at 875 Avenue of the Americas, on the northwest corner of 31st Street.

title: BEHIND THE SCENES AT THE SAVOY
description: Leaving the elevator, I almost tripped over the kneeling figure of Willy Bauer, general manager of the Savoy. The panjandrum of that prestigious London hotel is hardly the sort you expect to find inspecting a tiny burn in the carpet, but in stooping to conquer he has practiced just about every trade in the business. ''I don't care who does the job,'' Mr. Bauer said in his self-assured, deliberate way. ''I expect it to be done.''

title: LEELANAU
description: To the Editor: Realizing there is so much to do in the Leelanau Peninsula (Travel, May 26), I still must point out one major attraction the author missed - a trip to the Manitou Islands by boat. My family has been going to North Manitou since 1898.

title: ISRAEL AND U.S. APPARENTLY RESOLVE SOME DIFFERENCES ON HOSTAGE CRISIS
description: After a week of tension and virtual noncommunication between Israel and the United States, Israeli officials indicated today that the two countries seemed to have patched up at least some of their differences over the Beirut hijacking.

title: BROADCAST TV
description: After taking an ungainly tumble in recent weeks with a laborious adaptation of C. P. Snow's ''Strangers And Brothers,'' public TV's Masterpiece Theater regains its customary composure on Sunday evening at 9 on Channel 13 and 49, with a rebroadcast of the 10-part serial ''The Citadel.'' Don Shaw's fine teleplay is adapted from the 1937 A. J. Cronin novel that became an international best seller even as it infuriated the medical establishment.

title: LINDA RAMSEY ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Ramsey of Carson, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter, Linda A. Ramsey, to Theodore M. Steiner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Steiner of Middletown, N.J. Miss Ramsey graduated from the University of Southern California and its Law School. Her fiance is a graduate of the University of Maryland.

title: AFTER 5%: SHOREHAM QUESTIONS PERSIST
description: WITH the question of whether the Shoreham Nuclear Power Plant should be licensed for testing at 5 percent of full power headed toward the Federal courts, an answer to the larger question of when, if ever, the $4.2 billion plant will operate commercially still may be far away.

title: Votes in Congress;   Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: HOUSE

title: AT THE UNITED NATIONS
description: United Nations Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, is a stamp collector. In a recent interview, he discussed the role of philately and the United Nations Postal Administration (U.N.P.A.) as instruments in achieving the organization's goals. Mr. Perez de Cuellar also noted the benefits of philately in individual character development as well as in promoting understanding among nations.

title: DIRECTOR USES HARTFORD STAGE AS A BLANK CANVAS
description: In his five years as artistic director of the Hartford Stage Company, Mark Lamos has pursued a course of stubborn individualism. He has approached his regional theater, he says, as ''a canvas'' for his directorial creativity. As he says, ''In a six-play season, you have six shots at reinventing the extraordinary.''

title: REACHING OUT TO SOMEONE WITH AIDS
description: George Whitmore's article ''Reaching Out to Someone With AIDS'' (May 19) both touched and angered me. My husband is a mild hemophiliac who needs a blood-concentrate product, Factor VIII, to help him stop bleeding.

title: LEONORE COPELAND IS MARRIED
description: Leonore Copeland, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lammot Copeland Jr. of Wilmington, Del., was married yesterday to Dr. David Francis Panno, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Francis V. Panno of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Adam Lewis performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church, in Greenville, Del.

title: COSMOS CHRONOLOGY
description: 1970 - Franchise awarded to Warner Communications by the North American Soccer League for $25,000 and team started operations in l971, playing home games at Yankee Stadium. 1972 - Played first game at Hostra University Stadium in Hempstead, L.I., in May; captured first N.A.S.L. title. 1975 - Signed Pele, June 10. He played his first game at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island five days later. 1976 - Signed Giorgio Chinaglia, who became the league's career leading scorer and president of the team.

title: AN IMMIGRANT'S SON BUILDING A CITY
description: THE secret of real estate? ''Buying future development.''

title: THREE INSTRUMENTALISTS
description: MOST of the music that Moises Knoll - a young Venezuelan pianist who studied in Caracas and later at the Juilliard School - chose for his Sunday afternoon debut concert at Carnegie Recital Hall were not originally conceived for the piano.

title: BOYER IS STICKING TO CYCLING IN U.S.
description: The Tour de France starts Friday, but Jonathan Boyer, the first American ever to ride in the bicycle race, will not be there.

title: MAN'S INHUMANITY TO WOMAN
description: BEYOND POWER On Women, Men, and Morals. By Marilyn French. 640 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: CHINA HOMECOMING By Jean Fritz. Illustrated. 143 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $12.95. (Ages 10 and up) BOOKS about contemporary China all too often have the same flaw: the events their authors chronicle were experienced through the distorting medium of official Chinese guides and interpreters. One feels the blunting presence of official China in the guise of those assigned to shepherd the foreign guests through their China experience. Such books are filled with paragraphs and sentences that begin ''Then, we were told that . . .'' or ''When we were taken to . . .''

title: Giving Help For Head Injuries
description: ''Seeking Help for Head Injuries'' [May 19] describes the plight and frustrations in obtaining effective treatment for head injuries in New York. That problem has recently been addressed by the development, and licensing by New York State, of the Center for Rehabilitation.

title: OPERA INSTITUTE TO HOLD 'ROLE WORKSHOP'
description: UNDER the auspices of the New School for the Arts here, the New Jersey Opera Institute will hold its first ''role workshop'' this summer.

title: VOTER CHOICE BRINGS SOME UPSETS IN HUNGARY
description: Hungary is conducting an experiment in competitive politics that has produced a spectacular crop of electoral upsets and other public signs of dissatisfaction with the way the country is run, according to Western diplomats in Budapest.

title: CARAMOOR CELEBRATES ITS 40TH SEASON OF SUMMER CONCERTS
description: CARAMOOR, the jewel of Westchester's summer music season, begins its 40th annual festival in Katonah this Saturday at 8:30 P.M., and even though a decided sense of deja vu hovers over both the roster of artists and much of the programming, the glorious ambience of the Rosen estate continues to make concertgoing there a very special joy.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

TRAVEL TO KENYA
description: Ten years ago in Mexico City, the United Nations proclaimed the Decade of Women and declared peace, equality and development as goals. The decade's end will be marked beginning July 15 in Nairobi, Kenya, when government representatives from around the world present official positions. Simultaneously, outside the main hall, members of non-governmental organizations, craftsmen and artists will hold parallel meetings.

title: SUSPENSION RESCINDED
description: The three-game suspension of the Cleveland Indian pitcher Bert Blyleven was rescinded Friday, according to team officials. The American League president, Bobby Brown, ordered the suspension after Blyleven, on April 28, made obscene gestures to fans while leaving the field in the eighth inning of a game the Indians eventually lost.

title: WHERE POKER CHIPS MEET CLAM OPENERS
description: Carmen Maggio strolls the aisles of his glittering, aromatic emporium, his mind probing ahead of him, searching for the next merchandising coup that will lure customers to his front door.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ARTISTS' COLONY John Tarrant, a Westport writer, and his wife, Dorothy, volunteered to put together a book for the Westport-Weston Arts Council in observance of Westport's sesquicentennial celebration this year. Titled, ''A Community of Artists: Westport-Weston 1900-1985,'' the soft-cover volume chronicles, among other things, those years before and during World Way II when a colony of artists thrived in the area.

title: ITALIAN COOKING RENAISSANCE
description: The gratifying renaissance in Italian cooking continues apace, especially in the north and especially in the countryside. It has even acquired a kind of manifesto, drawn up by Franco Colombani, the gentle, self-effacing but fiercely committed proprietor of Il Sole, south of Milan. In his barn, Mr. Colombani brews the best vinegar I have ever tasted, aging it for nine years in a succssion of barrels made of different woods - juniper, myrtle, cherry, oak and chestnut. He is that kind of perfectionist. He has also started an association of like-minded restaurateurs, who have agreed to follow several precepts, the most important of which are ''to limit the number of dishes on the menu'' and ''not to invent just for the sake of it, not to play games, and not to slavishly follow fashions.'' He and his friends are at the forefront of what many Italians are now calling the cucina genuina.

title: BOOM SENDS U.S. ON VACATION TRAIL
description: Buoyed by a prosperous economy, a strong dollar and stable gasoline prices, Americans are setting off for vacations in what are expected to be record numbers this summer, industry specialists say.

title:
CAMERA;

MIRROR LENSES TAKE THE LONG VIEW
description: ALL telephoto lenses are not the same. In a normal telephoto lens light travels straight through to the film plane. But in a mirror lens, light is reflected back and forth off mirrors - similar to the process in an observatory telescope - before it reaches the film. To the naked eye, the mirror lens appears to be short and wide rather than long and narrow, but it does almost everything the longer telephoto lens can do.

title: WOODLAND PLANTS ADAPT TO A NEW LIFE IN BROOKLYN
description: Per-Olof Odman is a study in contrasts. He is a native of Stockholm who, at the age of 26, retired with a pension from the United States Marine Corps. A nature lover, he settled in Vinegar Hill, a commercial section of Brooklyn, where his charming backyard garden lies in the shadows of glum factories. So it should not be surprising that the most successful plants in his city-enclosed landscape are the wild flowers that thrive in woodlands.

title: China
description: To the Editor:

title: RHUBARB, VEGETABLE THAT POSES AS FRUIT
description: THE tomato may be a fruit that masquerades as a vegetable, but in revenge, there is rhubarb, a vegetable that is used as a fruit. The rosy, green-tipped stalks seasonally available in early summer are almost exclusively a dessert ingredient. In Colonial times rhubarb was known as pieplant.

title: Recent Sales
description: Cresskill $132,500 24 Brookside Avenue *2* 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 36-year-old Cape Cod; *2* deck, aluminum siding; taxes $1,813. Fair Haven $150,000 85 Spruce Drive *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 31-year-old split-level; new kitchen, *2* fireplace in living room, family room; taxes $3,152. Manalapan $137,000 238 Union Hill Road *2* 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 7-year-old colonial; central *2* air-conditioning, 3-zone heat, deck; taxes $3,141. Morristown $128,000 12 Knollwood Road *2* 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old split-level; basement *2* recreation room, new kitchen floor; taxes $2,127. Scotch Plains $134,000 1587 Lambert Mill Road *2* 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old colonial; *2* skylight in kitchen, den; taxes $2,408. Springfield $107,000 303 Hillside Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 32-year-old ranch; recently repainted, *2* extra kitchen in basement; taxes $1,579. OTHER AREAS Madison, Conn. $84,500 11 Birch Lane *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 12-year-old ranch; family room *2* with fireplace, laundry room, office; taxes $1,168. Bedford, N.Y. $285,000 Baylis Lane *2* 6-bedroom, 3-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in *2* kitchen, family room, den, 4.29 acres; taxes $5,554. Nesconset, L.I. $155,000 5 Cleveland Street *2* 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-month-old high ranch; *2* dining room, eat-in kitchen, den, skylights; taxes $3,000.

title: MENGELE TRAIL: CLUES OF PAPER, THEN OF PEOPLE
description: An intercepted letter to prison, documents that were supposed to have been destroyed but were not, and a coded datebook were key clues that led the West German and Brazilian authorities to a little country graveyard and the unraveling of one of the great mysteries left over from World War II.

title:
DINING OUT;

CARE AND SPLENDOR IN BEDFORD
description: NO bistro this. A fortune must have been paid for the decorator who ordered dusty pink for the clapboard, cream for the shutters and brass for the rail at the steps of Bistro 22 and then darkened, shaded and spotlighted those colors within to suggest the tans and mauves of elegant Park Avenue. And he was worth every penny. In restaurant decor, exaggeration for effect, just enough so that diners perceive it but not so much that it advertises its commercial function, is a rare gift, indeed.

title: CREIGHTON'S NEW COACH
description: Creighton University has apparently ended it's month-long search for a baskeball coach to replace Willis Reed. Tony Barone, a Bradley University assistant coach, said yesterday that he had accepted the job. And, according to WGN, a radio station in Chicago, the school will hold a press conference tomorrow to announce the move.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: A $5 MILLION, yearlong restoration of the Summit Hotel, a 150-room brick Tudor mansion in Summit that was once a luxurious refuge for wealthy people suffering declines in their fortunes during the Depression, is expected to be completed in November.

title: Sports of The Times;   THE YEAR OF THE GAG: A STUDY IN CONTRASTS
description: ON the Mets, a gag is a clubhouse laugh enjoyed by a team fighting for first place. On the Yankees, a gag is what George Steinbrenner has stuffed into the mouths of his front-office people on their treadmill. More significant than the standings, even more significant than the attendance, each team's definition of the word ''gag'' is all anybody has to know these days about the difference between New York's two major league franchises.

title: We Need to Work With the Rest of the Hemisphere
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMP: SOME THINGS CHANGE, SOME DON'T
description: SUMMER is for romance, roses, sunburn, swimming, mosquito bites and tomatoes.

title: FRESH AIR FAMILY WELCOMES ANNUAL VISITOR
description: In the summer, the Hackley School, a cluster of stone buildings reminiscent of a gothic castle set in the softly rolling hills of Tarrytown, becomes an idyllic setting for a summer camp, with its swimming pool, tennis courts and bounty of nature.

title: PIRANESI PRINTS IN STAMFORD AND A HISTORY OF PHOTOS IN NORFOLK
description: TWO art events not to be missed are an exhibit of Piranesi prints in the gallery at Stamford's Palace Theater of the Arts, at 61 Atlantic Street, and a show of vintage photographs at the Norfolk Public Library, both of them closing June 30.

title: TORONTO RUNNER WINS: DIXON FINISHES SIXTH
description: Rod Dixon of New Zealand ran into shoe problems today, allowing Jerry Kooymans of Toronto to pull away from two other front-runners and win the St. Andrew's 10-kilometer road race in course-record time.

title:
GARDENING;

DRY SPELL BRINGS GOOD AND ILL FOR PLANTS
description: EACH season has its own particular characteristics when it comes to its effects on the garden. This season is no exception.

title: NOVELTY IN SUMMER THEATER
description: FOR a change, novelties abound to spruce up the state's summer theater season, which otherwise offers mostly musicals, lightweight comedies and a smattering of new plays.

title: STRUGGLING TO RESPECT THE RASPBERRY
description: EVERY year when raspberries are in season, I experience profoundly mixed emotions.

title: VIENNA'S AVAN-GARDE IN ITS FINAL BLAZE OF GLORY
description: From time to time there comes to the fore - here, there, everywhere - a group of artists who want to make over the whole world in their own image and will settle for nothing less. Not only do they want to give us paintings and sculptures that will supersede all others, but they plan to dress us, furnish and decorate our houses, design our knives and forks, fit us out with new luggage, revolutionize our jewelry, give our children a new set of toys and keep us in scissors, ashtrays, purses, canes and bottle-stoppers. They also want to have a decisive hand in the look of our offices, our hotels, our restaurants, our automobiles, our subway stations, our post offices and our savings banks. In fact they will do everything for us except do up our buttons.

title: Stephanie A. Shapiro Weds T. W. Waldron
description: Stephanie Ann Shapiro and Thomas William Waldron, both reporters for The Evening Sun in Baltimore, were married yesterday at the Present Day Club in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Wallace M. Alston, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: MEMPHIS ON CHARLES ST.
description: A 20-story condominium-apartment building designed to reflect the iconoclastic Memphis design movement will soon rise on the southeast corner of Charles and Washington Streets at the western edge of Greenwich Village.

title: WESTWAY FOES FOCUS ON SHIFT IN IMPACT STUDY
description: Westway opponents have stressed changes in a Federal environmental statement as they complete their evidence in a trial to determine whether a judge should continue to block construction of the highway and development project.

title: LOSS, DISCOVERY AND OTHER URGENIES
description: ACROSS THE MUTUAL LANDSCAPE By Christopher Gilbert. 91 pp. Port Townsend, Wash.: Graywolf Press. Cloth, $14. Paper, $6. SINGING By Dennis Schmitz. 55 pp. New York: The Ecco Press. Paper, $7.50.

title: SPY SUSPECT, CONVICTED OF BURGLARIES AT 17, WAS WARNED BY JUDGE
description: John A. Walker Jr., who is accused of spying for the Soviet Union, was convicted of burglarizing four businesses around Scranton, Pa., along with another youth, when they were both 17 years old, according to an article published today in The Scranton Times.

title: PARK SERVICE OBJECTS TO CARTER HISTORIC SITE
description: The National Park Service, objecting to a proposed Jimmy Carter National Historic Site, said today it was considering a new policy that would bar memorials for former Presidents until after their deaths.

title: THE QUIET HEART OF KURASHIKI
description: People come to Japan for the first time with romantic visions of rustic wooden houses, graceful gardens and refined good taste. And most find that dream shattered after a first glimpse of downtown Tokyo, with its nondescript concrete buildings, pinball arcades and nightly celebration of neon.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE MODEL COMPANY TOWN: Urban Design Through Private Enterprise in Nineteenth-Century New England. By John S. Garner. (University of Massachusetts, $22.50.)

title: STRIKE'S EFFECT ON HOTELS CALLED SLIGHT
description: The strike against 53 hotels in New York City has apparently been more an inconvenience to visitors than a serious blow to the industry, according to officials concerned with the dispute.

title: VICTIMS WITH A GUILTY SECRET
description: I DIDN'T SAY GOODBYE By Claudine Vegh. Translated by Ros Schwartz. With an afterword by Bruno Bettelheim. 179 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $14.95. IN 1942 the Vichy Government sent its first convoy of French Jews to the German death camps. More than 75,000 were deported during the next two years; most did not come back. The children who were left behind in hiding learned quickly not to talk about the deportations, never to ask why they occurred or when their parents would return. For most the silence has been endless, the French psychiatrist Claudine Vegh writes. As adults they do not discuss the war: ''It is taboo.''

title: HOSTAGES IN LEBANON: A Week of Tension;   U.S. WARNS SHIITES OF CONSEQUENCES ON THE HOSTAGES
description: The United States has stepped up efforts to persuade the Shiite Amal leadership that failure to release 40 American hostages quickly and without conditions will severely damage the Shiites and Lebanon itself, Administration officials said today.

title: JUDGE KAUFMAN TERMS CRIME-UNIT ROLE A DUTY
description: When Judge Irving R. Kaufman opens three days of hearings tomorrow on gambling and organized crime, he will be acting in an extrajudicial role that he believes judges have a duty to play.

title: A TREASURY OF VOICES, FROM GALLI-CURCI TO LILY PONS
description: On William Seward's glass-top reading table lay a bit of timber perhaps a foot and a half long, irregularly studded with nails, old and well-worn. ''I often think that if there were some way we could extract the sound from this,'' he mused, ''then we would hear something indeed.''

title: ISRAEL'S DEFENSE FORCES
description: The morale of Israel's armed forces is heavily dependent on a factor that occupies only a minor part of Drew Middleton's analysis: the use of the army for defense as opposed to partisan political ends (''Israel's Defense: As Good As Ever?'' May 19). The invasion of Lebanon, initiated on June 6, 1982, resulted in the most demoralizing and internally questioned war in Israeli history.

title: MARIAN MCPARTLAND ON PIANO
description: AN expressive serenity and a classical sense of how the elements of jazz pianism ought to be balanced are the artistic hallmarks of Marian McPartland who, at 65, remains a pillar of genteel jazz taste. Miss McPartland, who opened the Kool Jazz Festival's afternoon piano series on Friday, offered a program that included an obscure Duke Ellington piece and a Teddy Wilson song as well as several standards and two original impressionistic jazz compositions.

title: 'No Doubt' It's Mengele
description: ''There is absolutely no doubt it is him.'' With those words, Dr. Lowell Levine, an American forensic expert, pronounced one of the century's longest manhunts at an end.

title: CRIME
description: The last time we left the British antiques dealer Lovejoy, in ''Firefly Gadroon,'' he was in custody and headed for jail. Apparently he got out of trouble. Or maybe he served time. The new Lovejoy adventure - PEARLHANGER by Jonathan Gash (St. Martin's, $14.95) - contains no mention of the results of the antihero's previous escapade, so we may never know.

title:
RESPONDING IN LEBANON AND ELSEWHERE;

DON'T HIT BACK
description: Henry A. Kissinger and the terrorism experts are arguing for strong retaliation against the Lebanese Shiite hostage-takers. The question they don't ask is: After retaliation, what then?

title: WHICH MISS ELLIE?
description: Will the real Miss Ellie please stand up? The actress Donna Reed, who signed a three-year contract last fall to play the matriarch of the Ewing family on the television series ''Dallas,'' contended in a Los Angeles courtroom last week that she was Miss Ellie. But Lorimar Productions argued that Barbara Bel Geddes, who has replaced Miss Reed, had the right to play the part.

title: LESLIE DINGLE HAS WEDDING
description: Leslie Rodgers Dingle, the daughter of Mrs. Silas Llewellyn Warner of Gladwyne, Pa., and David Howard Dingle of New York, was married yesterday to Frederic Carrere, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Georges Carrere of Toulon, France. The Rev. James Squire, chaplain of the Episcopal Academy in Merion, Pa., performed the ceremony at the Warner home.

title: NORTH KOREA ALTERS ITS TONE, IF NOT ITS GOALS
description: Up in the hills to the north of this city, at the back of a narrow valley, lies the tomb of a 14th-century king, Guang Min, where the only sounds are those of cuckoos. Along the valley floor, and in flatter country to the south and east, travelers drive for miles between emerald-green rice paddies tended by weathered peasants. Here, a few miles north of the demilitarized zone, visitors are offered an extended look at rural life. After a lull of several years, this tightly sealed country is opening its doors to American journalists. The message is one of peace and reconciliation. In this area where war between North and South Korea would start, almost the only soldiers in sight have rolled up their pants to work alongside the peasants.

title: THE MARRIAGE THAT I THOUGHT WOULD LAST FOREVER
description: I ALWAYS imagined that we'd grow old together, he and I. And when the slim flecks of gray highlighted his sideburns, I smiled to myself and said how distinguished he was!

title: 'Right to Die' Case Law in New Jersey
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SUNDAY, JUNE 23, 1985 International

title: Headliners;   Johnsons v. Johnson
description: There may not have been enough closets in the homes owned by the family of J. Seward Johnson Sr. for all the skeletons brought forth by a bitter fight over his will. The heir to the Johnson & Johnson health-care fortune died two years ago, leaving his third wife, Barbara Johnson, the bulk of his estate, valued at between $400 million and $1 billion. Mr. Johnson's six children (all by previous wives) were virtually ignored.

title: A LOOK INSIDE BASEBALL'S CONTRACT NEGOTIATIONS; OWNERS: 'FINANCIAL PROBLEM'
description: BASEBALL'S collective bargaining agreement between the Major League Baseball Players Association and the club owners expired last Dec. 31. Representatives of both sides in the ongoing negotiations were interviewed recently by editors and reporters of The New York Times about the issues and the possibility of another baseball strike. In 1981, the players struck for 50 days. Following are edited transcripts of the interviews.

title: TIPS FOR TAKING A COMPUTER ALONG
description: Who would have thought that computers, which once occupied whole rooms, would shrink to the size of a suitcase -indeed, to no larger than a notebook? Yet, with scientists able to etch thousands of circuits onto a fingernail-sized sliver of silicon, growing numbers of travelers are taking computers on trips with them. They are using the machines for letter writing, note taking and calculating.

title: DUTCH BIRTHDAY PARTY, MAINE WOODS GETAWAY
description: Frisian City Celebrates 700th Birthday When a city reaches the ripe old age of 700, no single day can encompass a birthday party.

title: JOHN HUSTON - A MASTER OF HIS ART
description: Six years ago John Huston made one of his occasional appearances as an actor, playing with witty, benign self-assurance a rude, incredibly wealthy character called ''Pa'' Kegan in William Richert's screen adaptation of Richard Condon's melodramatic satire, ''Winter Kills.'' It seemed then that Mr. Huston, a man of robust humor with a profound appreciation for the seriously absurd, was born to collaborate with a writer of Mr. Condon's very particular, manic imagination.

title: N.F. REASONS ARE SELF-SERVING
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 50 YEARS FOR MOMS'S FILM DEPARTMENT
description: The idea was launched at a party given by Mary Pickford and Douglas Fairbanks Sr. at Pickfair, their estate, where the guests included such luminaries of the film world as Samuel Goldwyn, Charlie Chaplin, D. W. Griffith, Walt Disney, David O. Selznick, Mack Sennett, Ernst Lubitsch and Mervyn LeRoy.

title: MUSIC, MUGGINGS AND A CURE FOR CANCER
description: ARDABIOLA A Fantasy. By Yevgeny Yevtushenko. Translated by Armorer Wason. 123 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $11.95.

title: WRITING PLAYS IS AN ACT OF FAITH
description: Honoring Pulitzer winners is a good idea. But, I'm afraid, it's not enough. We need more than honor. More about that later. You cannot honor Pulitzer winners without honoring the entire community of writers for the theater. There are magnificent plays and importatnt writers who have slipped through the Pulitzer net. Furthermore, prize-winning plays do not come strictly from individuals. It takes all of us, working carefully, obstinately, in good faith. . . all of us, working full time to produce the two or three plays which will survive from any given season in this country. And although we write our plays alone, we are not alone in writing them. It is one of our few consistent comforts to know that other dramatists, people we respect and cherish, are just as depressed as we are.

title: THE COUNTRY BOY WHO PUT MARK TWAIN INTO SONG
description: Roger Miller had never read ''Huckleberry Finn'' until he was asked to write the score for the musical adaptation that became ''Big River.'' But when the composer of ''King of the Road'' finally opened the Mark Twain classic, he was overcome with language and imagery that swept him back to his rural Oklahoma childhood.

title: REACHING OUT TO SOMEONE WITH AIDS
description: With respect to Dr. Altman's article ''How Contagious Is AIDS?'', I feel it is important for the word ''contagious'' not to have been used in the title or in the article.

title: VENTURING INTO A BLACK HOLE OF NEW MEXICO
description: It is not given to everyone to fall knee deep into 17,500-year-old bat droppings (carbon dated), and time has not dimmed my memory of the occasion.

title:
GARDENING;

DRY SPELL BRINGS GOOD AND ILL FOR PLANTS
description: EACH season has its own particular characteristics when it comes to its effects on the garden. This season is no exception.

title: COGNITIVE SCIENCE LOOKS AT HOW THE MIND FUNCTIONS
description: As the space shuttle Discovery orbited the earth this week, scholars from 50 North American universities gathered at Vassar College to discuss ways of teaching about mankind's final frontier: the inner space of the human mind.

title: L.I.R.R. ELECTRIFIES, RESIDENTS COMPLAIN
description: ONE Friday afternoon last April, Brian Bofill, a 28-year-old engineer from Bethpage, picked up a newspaper, flipped through its pages and came across a two-column legal notice placed by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: RACHEL L. KENZIE WEDS JOHN KING
description: The marriage of Rachel Langley Kenzie, who received an M.B.A. degree this month from Harvard University, to John Patrick King, a consultant with Bain & Company in Boston, took place yesterday at Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in Snyder, N.Y. The Rev. Daniel J. Palys performed the ceremony.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: COMMODORE PERRY IN THE LAND OF THE SHOGUN. By Rhoda Blumberg. Lothrop, Lee & Shepard. $13. (Ages 9 and up) A large-format history of the arrival of the United States Navy in Japan in 1853, handsomely illustrated with period prints.

title: HOSTAGES IN LEBANON: A Week of Tension;   SHIITE TELLS U.S. NOT TO USE FORCE
description: The Shiite Amal militia leader, Nabih Berri, warned today that any military action by the United States over the hijacking crisis could endanger the lives of the hostages.

title: Q and A
description: Long-Distance Service Question: I live in a 27-unit apartment building that has always had a resident superintendent. Recently he was replaced by a part-time janitor who lives three blocks away. Is this legal? . . . W. R. C., Manhattan Answer: Frank A. Dell'Aria, assistant commissioner for code enforcement in the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, says he believes three blocks is too far away for a superintendent to live. Article 22 of the Housing Maintenance Code requires owners of buildings with nine or more units to provide janitorial services by someone who lives either in the building or within a block or 200 feet. Furthermore, his name address, apartment number and telephone number must be posted prominently in the building. If you wish to complain, call 960-4800; an inspector will be sent to verify the facts and a violation could be filed. Wait for the Wedding Question: Must my fiancee's landlord add my name to her rent-stabilized lease? . . . R. R., Manhattan Answer: A fiance does not have the right to be added to the lease, but Mr. Shlufman says the state division's policy is Redinger that a spouse does have that right as a member of the tenant's immediate family. At the next lease renewal following the wedding, ask the owner to add your name; if he refuses, file a complaint with the state division. Sabbatical Sublet Question: I live in a rent-controlled apartment. I have been granted a year's sabbatical for travel and will be out of the country.

title: MARINES' KILLERS WILL NOT ESCAPE, REAGAN PROMISES
description: In a voice choking with emotion, President Reagan pledged today to bring to justice the killers of four American marines killed Wednesday in San Salvador.

title: As Socialist as Reagan
description: To the Editor:

title: Lesson of Hijacking Is That the U.S. Is at War in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: JEANNE-MARIE PHILLIPS IS MARRIED IN SYOSSET
description: The marriage of Jeanne-Marie Phillips, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Hess Phillips of Syosset, L.I., to Warren Lee Jervey, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward D. Jervey of Radford, Va., took place yesterday. The Rev. John Martin performed the ceremony at St. Edward Confessor Roman Catholic Church in Syosset.

title: We Need to Work With the Rest of the Hemisphere;   They Dare to Disagree
description: To the Editor:

title: FANS BACK PADRES
description: San Diego Padre fans apparently agree with the club's treatment of the second baseman Alan Wiggins.

title: More Accountability, Please
description: ''Now these are the laws of the Navy, unwritten and varied they be; and he who is wise will observe them, going down in his ship to the sea.'' So began - and ended, as I recall - a long, somewhat rambling poem of ruling principles all plebes once learned at the Naval Academy.

title: NEW CASSETTES: ROSTAND, MAUGHAM AND ELTON JOHN
description: Of Human Bondage Starring Leslie Howard, Bette Davis, Reginald Denny, Kay Johnson, Frances Dee; directed by John Cromwell, 1934 Prism 83 minutes. $19.95 The Hollywood legend persists.

title: FRAUD INQUIRY AT GUARD UNITS
description: Army investigators and Federal officials have begun an inquiry into allegations of payroll fraud by members of some Army National Guard units in New York City, state and military officials said yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We and the Salvadoran leaders will move any mountain and ford any river to find the jackals and bring them and their colleagues in terror to justice.'' - President Reagan. [1:2.]

title: SUSAN HOFFMAN MARRIES BARRY BUTTERFIELD, DESIGNER
description: Susan Duane Hoffman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Carr Hoffman of Darien, Conn., and East Dorset, Vt., was married yesterday to Barry Jay Butterfield, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norvell Butterfield of New York. The Rev. Walter L. Pitman, a Congregational minister, officiated at the bride's home in Livingston, N.Y.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AMERICAN SWASTIKA. By Charles Higham. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Recent reports about Klaus Barbie, Josef Mengele and neo-Nazi activity in the United States have put Nazis of all sorts very much in the news.

title: NEWCOMER TO POLITICS CHALLENGES VERGARI
description: PAUL W. PICKELLE, the Scarsdale lawyer and former prosecutor who is seeking to unseat Carl A. Vergari as Westchester District Attorney this year, said last week that he was planning a two-part election campaign: ''first get people to know me, then focus on the issues.''

title: PERSHING SQUARE TRIUMPHS
description: Pershing Square, driven by Bill O'Donnell, overtook the 3-5 favorite, Dragon's Lair, in a final 10 yards tonight to set a track record of 1:55 2/5 in winning the $482,560 Messenger Stake at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: WHO WILL CONTROL SPENDING ON ROADS?
description: LESS than a month into his term as Commissioner of the state's Department of Transportation, Roger Bodman is staring down the legislative gun barrel. It is a classic political confrontation. The issue: Who will control the spending of more than $700 million in road- and bridge-repair funds in the fiscal year that begins July 1 - a week from tomorrow.

title: MICKEY MOUSE IN OKLAHOMA
description: FUNNY MONEY By Mark Singer. 222 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: REYNOLDS MOUNTS A NEW DEFENSE OF HIS TENURE AS THE RIGHTS CHIEF
description: William Bradford Reynolds is fighting back against the latest criticism from senators opposing his nomination to become Associate Attorney General.

title: THE MAJOR ROAD PROJECTS
description: THESE are some of the major maintenance and construction projects that will affect traffic next month and in and August. Bridgeport: Rehabilitation of Interstate 95 bridge on the Connecticut Turnpike over the harbor and reconstruction of Housatonic Avenue.

title: THE SELLING OF LONG ISLAND: PRICE OF PROGRESS IS TOO HIGH
description: SUBTRACT a hundred years from Long Island's history and enter a vanished world: a rural economy, an abundance of natural resources, main streets not yet choked with traffic, a pristine and unspoiled landscape. Life's pace is slower, more relaxed. The land is fertile -richly green and giving. In that fragile balance between man and nature, the delicious luxury of space still prevails.

title: House Votes To Pare Down MX Program
description: At one point last week, during the House's latest skirmish over the MX missile, Representative Vic Fazio, Democrat of California, said the debate ''brings to an end a system that never had a home.'' Something of an overstatement to be sure, but the House eventually voted to bar the purchase of any additional MX's next year and to limit the overall program to 40 missiles.

title: REACHING OUT TO SOMEONE WITH AIDS
description: As a volunteer on the National Gay Task Force's Crisisline who answers questions about AIDS from callers across the country, I am always encouraged to see accurate and responsible reporting of the facts about the syndrome, such as Lawrence K. Altman's article ''How Contagious Is AIDS?'' (May 19). What I find even more encouraging is George Whitmore's profile of Jim Sharp and Edward Dunn.

title: ON TOLSTOY, RACINE AND READING BY THE LIGHT OF THE BOOK
description: I READ at night. I've never been able to read except at night. When I was a child, I also read at night, in the dark of the siesta that empties the city like night itself. I got the habit from my mother, who said without further explanation that one should read in the off hours. So reading took the place of sleeping during the siesta, just as, later, it took the place of sleeping at night. I never read instead of writing or talking with someone or being bored. I realize this with sudden pleasure - I never read out of boredom. I never heard anyone say ''If you're bored, read a book'' in my mother's house.

title: BLIND SKATER AIMS FOR THE TOP
description: TO Ann Wasserman of Long Branch, ice skating and skiing have long been two of life's greatest pleasures.

title: RANDI GOLOMB IS WED
description: Randi Faye Golomb, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Golomb of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Roger Cunningham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Cunningham of Paducah, Ky. Rabbi Arnold Turetsky performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, N.Y.

title: DR. KENNA WED TO A PSYCHIATRIST
description: Dr. Margaret Alene Kenna, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Kenna of Woodbridge, Conn., and Dr. Richard Allan Houser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry William Houser of Waretown, N.J., were married yesterday. The ceremony at the summer home of the bride's parents in Madison, Conn., was performed by Judge E. Ernest Oberst, retired, of the Probate Court of Cheshire, Conn.

title: FIRST LOVE AND LASTING SORROW
description: THE LOVER By Marguerite Duras. Translated by Barbara Bray. 117 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $11.95.

title: EMILY A. PEARSON WED TO CHRISTOPHER FISHER
description: Emily Ann Pearson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank W. Pearson of Newport, R.I., was married there yesterday to Christopher Agnew Fisher, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Agnew Fisher of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Raymond McNicholas performed the ceremony at Salve Regina Roman Catholic Chapel.

title: PROPERTY TAX CALLED KEY ISSUE IN G. M. PACT
description: OF the many Government-inspired inducements offered to General Motors to keep it in Westchester County, probably none was more unusual or contributed more to the success of the effort, according to officials involved, than an agreement reducing the plant's local property taxes.

title: ...AND THE ANIMAL KINGDOM TAKES IT ALL IN
description: Susan Bookatz was cooking dinner at home in Fairfax County, Va., when a frisky bear, about five feet tall, trotted up to her open kitchen door. Her husband, Samuel, who had spotted a smaller bear in their yard that day, saved his dinner and his wife by slamming the door on the uninvited guest.

title: FESTIVAL HONORS COLEMAN
description: WITH the Fourth of July approaching, the listings over the next fortnight are filled with American music, including jazz, gospel, folk and theater offerings, along with the classics.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Weeks This Last on Week FICTION Week List 1 SKELETON CREW, by Stephen King. 1 (Putnam, $18.95.) Twenty-two tales of horror set in contemporary America. 2 THE CIDER HOUSE RULES, by John Irving. 1 5 (Morrow, $18.95.) In this pseudonymous novel by Stephen King, a young lawyer finds his body mysteriously wasting away. 8 CHAPTERHOUSE: DUNE, by Frank Herbert. 5 10 (Putnam, $17.95.) A new world rises from the Old Empire's ashes in this volume of the ''Dune'' series. 9 INSIDE, OUTSIDE, by Herman Wouk. 8 14 (Little, Brown, $19.95.) A traditionalist Jew's quest for identity in glittery contemporary America. 10 THE CLASS, by Erich Segal. 9 9 (Bantam, $17.95.) A man and a woman set out to salvage a spiritually exhausted America in the not-too-distant future. 12* FAMILY ALBUM, by Danielle Steel. 12 16 (Delacorte, $16.95.) A married couple with five children cope with the crises of contemporary America. 13 QUEENIE, by Michael Korda. 11 10 (Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The tangled lives of Charlie Soong and his six children, who shaped much of China's modern history. 12 THE HEART OF THE DRAGON, by Alasdair 9 3 Clayre. (Houghton Mifflin, $29.95.) title: SAN DIEGO-GOUND
description: Trumaine Johnson has apparently agreed to buy out the remainder his contract with the Arizona Outlaws of the United States Football League.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: VINTAGE POPULAR ARTS What's new in popular arts? What's old is what's new, that's what. In other words, history's way of repeating itself carries over into the popular arts as ''residents'' of the Old Bethpage Village Restoration, Nassau County's living mid-19th-century museum, prove today. From 1 to 5 P.M., during their ''19th-Century Popular Arts Weekend,'' they wll demonstrate such ''now'' crafts as rug weaving, leather working and basket making; do some pre-Civil War dancing, accompanied by fiddle music and the Village Brass Band, and, via the Eighth Annual Historical Exhibition of Long Island Horticulture, even show off the spring vegetables, plants and fruits that flourished locally way back then. The restoration is on Round Swamp Road, and admission is $3, $2.50 for Nassau residents, and $1.50 for children.

title: MARGARET E. WILLARD IS WED
description: At the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York yesterday Margaret Eugenia Willard, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Josiah Willard of New York, was married to Peter John Bailey, a son of James Bailey of Fort Myers Beach, Fla., and Mrs. Joseph Palmer of Las Vegas, Nev. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony. The bride's father, who is retired, was a partner in the New York law firm of White & Case. Mr. Bailey's father, who is also retired, was a vice president of the American Express Company.

title: PRISCILLA THURBER BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Priscilla Anne Thurber, a daughter of Mrs. A. Edward Thurber Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., and the late Mr. Thurber, was married there yesterday to Gregory Mark Burton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Burton of Brentwood, L.I. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the cermony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church.

title: THE NEED TO COMMUNICATE IN A WORLD THAT DOES NOT LISTEN
description: The Prinzhorn Collection of the Art of the Mentally Ill is by far the most influential collection of its kind. It contains drawings, paintings and sculptures by institutionalized, mostly German-speaking, mental patients. Most of the works were done between 1880 and 1920, when there was an unprecedented curiosity about human experience that functioned outside the established conventions of the industrial world. Those were the years when Gauguin went to Tahiti and Conrad sent Marlow to the Congo, when Ensor peeled off the surface of domestic life and found suspicion and delusion, when radical artists reinvented themselves with the help of tribal art and when Freud established how much is buried inside us that we can at best only partially understand.

title: NOTABLE OPERATIC VOICES OF THE PAST SING OUT ONCE AGAIN
description: There's no doubt about it -the vocal reissue business is booming. In addition to the occasional release on a major label like RCA or CBS, many small record companies have sprung up throughout the world, catering to the voracious appetites of collectors by transferring scratchy old cylinders and 78's to LP - and, we may suppose, eventually to CD as well.

title: STATE'S DEFENSE JOBS ARE NOT THAT SECURE
