description: LAST April 29, United States Representative Stewart B. McKinney, Republican of Westport, proposed an alternative to the Reagan Administration budget proposal for the 1986 fiscal year. Such alternatives as Mr. McKinney's are vitally important to attack the record Federal deficit and to prevent massive military-spending increases and wholesale elimination of a number of social programs.

title: AMBIANCE AND GOOD VALUE IN DERBY
description: WHEN we learned that Olde Birmingham was located in an 1893 bank building in downtown Derby, visions of another ''theme'' restaurant flashed through our heads. Menus disguised as passbooks, waiters wearing green eyeshades, consideration given to every ''themed'' detail - except possibly the food.

title: CELLULAR PHONES: THE BIG PAYOFFS ARE STILL ON HOLD
description: A few years ago, when Tom Guzek drove from his home office in Boston to his company's regional office in New York, there was little else to do but glance at the scenery. Now his car is equipped with a cellular telephone, and, said Mr. Guzek, a regional manager for an electrical supply firm, ''I'm on the phone constantly. What used to be dead time away from the office, is now productive time.''

title: Vendetta?
description: To the Editor:

title: REBUILDING GOING WELL IN 2D YEAR OF ROAD PLAN
description: THIS summer, drivers hurrying through the midnight gloom of the Connecticut Turnpike will find the monotony broken at the Mianus River bridge in Greenwich by a yellow sign flashing in movie-marquee letters, ''Construction Ahead.''

title: WIMBLEDON: PREDICTABLE BUT NO. 1
description: THE tidbits of controversy preceding the tournament, the slick grass courts and traditional tennis whites that are reminiscent of another era and the inevitable player complaints about the intrusive gossip- oriented British tabloids, all add to Wimbledon's mystique and some say charm, as well as make it perhaps the most predictable of the major championships.

title: 9 Die as Trailer Truck Rams Car in Arkansas
description: A tractor-trailer, apparently without brakes, barreled down a steep hill and rammed a packed station wagon, killing nine people and setting off a fire that destroyed three downtown stores, police said today.

title: BUYING BRITISH
description: The boom in English antiques - and the decorative arts and paintings that traditionally go well with them -continued at this year's Grosvenor House Antiques Fair. The bazaar, which ended its 10-day run here yesterday, offers some of the finest British wares sold annually on either side of the Atlantic and is viewed as a barometer of the British antiques market. Once again Americans carried away many, but far from all, of the treasures offered by the 85 dealers represented here.

title: RUIN AND RENEWAL IN BENGAL
description: THEY SPEAK ONE OF THE GREAT LITERARY languages of Asia. They embraced Western concepts and forms long before their neighbors, then pioneered resistance to colonial rule. Their conversation, when it is not indulging in witty, often spiteful gossip, tends to be intensely political. And their politics - usually passionate, seldom middle-of-the-road - tend to be nationalistic and radical. They proudly defy stereotypes - including these - and yet retain a national character that evokes tenderness and admiration. All these things need to be set down before you say where they live and who they are, because once you mention Bangladesh and Calcutta - place names that have become synonymous with calamity and third-world misery - the Bengalis become objects of pity.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Culture or Couture?

title: COLLEGE DEAN LABORS TO SAVE CARROUSEL
description: ON WEEKDAYS, Dr. Floyd Moreland is associate dean of research and graduate programs and a professor of Greek and Latin at the City University of New York.

title: Editors' Note
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: THE DEBUT
description: IT was 8 o'clock at night, and in about an hour he would enter the ring for his first professional prize fight. It was a significant night, not just for him but for his famous father, too.

title: THAI RETAINS HIS TITLE IN CONTROVERSIAL DRAW
description: Sot Chitalada of Thailand survived two knockdowns by Gabriel Bernal of Mexico to gain a 12-round draw today and retain his World Boxing Council flyweight title.

title: Lesson of Hijacking Is That the U.S. Is at War in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: ART
description: While John James Audubon is familiar to all those who seek out the natural world, he is also known to many good artists. His monumental study ''Birds in North America,'' completed in 1838, has been of consistent interest to artists who combine a passion for nature with a strong feeling for color and composition.

title: JANE AUSTEN'S NIECE
description: To the Editor:

title: PATRICIA MOORE WEDS DANIEL FORMOSA
description: Patricia Anne Moore, president of Moore & Associates in New York, and Daniel John Formosa, a partner in the New York industrial design firm of Davin Stowell Associates, were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York by the Rev. Anthony Dalla Villa. Colleen Moore Evans was matron of honor for her sister and Jeffrey Joseph Formosa best man for his brother.

title: THE POWER OF HELLS CANYON
description: At night by the shores of the Snake River, the rushing water has a curious effect, blocking out even the memory of automobile traffic, ringing telephones and portable stereos. The wild river, looming canyon walls and a canopy of stars transport the setting to a time before man began changing the world around us.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: DIZZY IN JERSEY CITY Dizzy Gillespie, the legendary jazz trumpeter and composer, will perform Saturday evening at Liberty State Park, Jersey City. Appearing with him will be James Moody, saxophone and flute; Richie Cole, alto saxophone; Mickey Tucker, keyboard; Earl May, bass, and Eddie Gladden, percussion.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: A SMALL group of waterfront buildings set back off Brigantine Boulevard in Brigantine, just north of Atlantic City, houses an unassuming organization with sometimes gargantuan goals - the Marine Mammal Stranding Center.

title: ELEANOR S. DONOHUE WED TO JAMES MOORE
description: Eleanor S. Donohue and James S. Moore were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Divine Compassion in White Plains by the Rev. Hugh F. McGovern.

title: DEBORAH ANNE ARMOUR IS ENAGED TO A BANKER
description: The engagement of Deborah Anne Armour to Jerome Mandelbaum has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Armour of Springfield, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Boris Mandelbaum of Rego Park, Queens, and the late Margery Mandelbaum.

title: SHOPPERS' HAUNTS AROUND THE WORLD
description: Many countries have their own version of the flea market. The goods and the language may differ but what most have in common are variety -from antiques to plain junk - bargain hunters, serious collectors and a certain amount of haggling. Here are reports on some outstanding ones:

title: Q & A: IS NEW ACTION NEEDED ON PORNOGRAPHY?
description: THE Attorney General's Commission on Pornography set to work last week with two hearings in Washington, beginning a year-long investigation of the multibillion-dollar sex industry. It is the first such inquiry since a Presidential commission concluded in 1970 that there was no direct link between sexually explicit material and sexual exploitation. In appointing the 11-member commission last month, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d suggested that technological changes, particularly the home-video explosion, was bringing too much pornography into American homes. The commission, he said, would have to devise new ways to control it. Civil liberties groups contend that the commission was formed with censorship as its goal. They have attacked Mr. Meese's choice as chairman, Henry E. Hudson, the chief prosecutor for Arlington County, Va., who was commended by President Reagan two years ago for having all but banished pornography in his suburban Washington area. In an interview last week with Philip Shenon of the Washington bureau of The New York Times, Mr. Hudson defended the commission and described its mandate. Excerpts follow.

title: WHO CREATED ROGER ACKROYD?
description: AGATHA CHRISTIE By Janet Morgan. Illustrated. 393 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: GUIDRY SHUTS OUT TIGERS, 4-0 ON 4 HITS
description: If he could, Ron Guidry would turn back the clock seven years and recapture the magic of an incredible season.

title: DRUG AID FOR AGED STALLED IN ALBANY
description: The Legislature is unlikely to reach agreement this session on a plan to help elderly people pay for prescription drugs, key lawmakers said this week.

title: THE HIGHLANDS: ROYAL RETREAT
description: A late summer trip to the Scottish Highlands when the heather is in bloom is enough to make anyone's heart soar. But to hike during any season through the bald-topped Cairngorm Mountains, valleys of the River Dee where pink-tinged salmon dart, to spot a golden eagle circling in the sky or to flush a protective grouse hen from its nest on the moors, to see herds of red deer grazing high above the timber line is a special kind of holiday for a nature lover. Especially if one is a guest at Mar Lodge, a 77,500-acre estate owned and maintained by an English family in understated style and elegance.

title: CARLTON ON DISABLED LIST
description: Steve Carlton, the Philadelphia Phillies left-hander, was placed on the disabled list for the first time in his 20-year major league career today because of an injury to his pitching shoulder.

title: PICKING OUR FIGHTS
description: THIS WAR CALLED PEACE By Brian Crozier, Drew Middleton and Jeremy Murray-Brown. 307 pp. New York: Universe Books. $17.95.

title: 4 Pakistanis Die in Gunfight
description: A policeman and three bandits were killed and two policeman were wounded in a gunfight in Karachi on Thursday, the police said today.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Fiction 1 FULL CIRCLE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.50.) The relationship of a mother and daughter is altered by the changing values of the past 40 years. 2 ''. . . AND LADIES OF THE CLUB,'' by Helen Hooven Santmyer. (Berkley, $5.95.) Life in an Ohio hamlet, 1868-1932. 3 THE HAJ, by Leon Uris. (Bantam, $4.95.) One man's experience in the wars of the Holy Land. 4 THE WHEEL OF FORTUNE, by Susan Howatch. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A wealthy Welsh family haunted by an ominous heritage. 5 DEEP SIX, by Clive Cussler. (Pocket, $4.50.) One man copes with a sinister Asian shipping family and an even more threatening Soviet plot. 6 * LINCOLN, by Gore Vidal. (Ballantine, $4.95.) A fictionalized account of the Civil War Presidency. 7 TENDER IS THE STORM, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $3.95.) A New York heiress's passionate encounter with an Arizona rancher. 8 THE WALKING DRUM, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $3.95.) A young man from Brittany sets out to free his father, enslaved in 12th-century Asia. 9 MISSISSIPPI! by Dana Fuller Ross. (Bantam, $3.95.) The ''Wagons West'' series reaches the post-Civil War South and New Orleans. 10 POSSESSIONS, by Judith Michael. (Pocket, $4.50.) A woman discovers the truth about her husband after he disappears. 11 THE MODIGLIANI SCANDAL, by Ken Follett. (NAL/Signet, $3.50.) An early work, first published pseudonymously, about a ''lost masterpiece'' and dirty dealings in the international art world. 12 RAMBO: First Blood Part II, by David Morrell. (Jove, $3.50.) Novelization of the film about a Vietnam vet who returns to rescue prisoners of war. 13 THE AQUITAINE PROGRESSION, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $4.50.) A lawyer finds himself caught in a conspiracy to take over the world. 14 THE WISHSONG OF SHANNARA, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $8.95.) The battle against evil continues; end of a fantasy trilogy. 15 SWITCH, by William Bayer. (NAL/Signet, $3.95.) The case of two women, murdered in Manhattan, whose heads are switched. Nonfiction General 1 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (S&S/Touchstone, $8.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 2 IN SEARCH OF EXCELLENCE, by Thomas J. Peters and Robert H. Waterman Jr. (Warner, $8.95.) Lessons from well-run corporations. 3 SON, by Jack Olsen. (Dell, $4.50.) The case of a young psychotic rapist at large in Spokane, Wash. 4 FIRST LADY FROM PLAINS, by Rosalynn Carter. (Fawcett Gold Medal, $3.95.) Memoirs. Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 PENGUIN DREAMS AND STRANGER THINGS, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $6.95.) Cartoons from the syndicated ''Bloom County'' strip. 2 BRIDE OF THE FAR SIDE, by Gary Larson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $5.95.) Cartoons. 3 RAND MCNALLY ROAD ATLAS: United States, Canada, Mexico. (Rand McNally, $5.95.) For 1985. 4 THE SILVER PALATE GOOD TIMES COOKBOOK, by Julee Rosso and Sheila Lukins with Sarah Leah Chase. (Workman, $11.95.) Recipes from the owners of a Manhattan gourmet food shop. 5 * EAT TO WIN, by Robert Hass. (NAL/Signet, $4.50.) A regimen for sports and fitness activities. 6 THE ONE MINUTE MANAGER, by Kenneth Blanchard and Spencer Johnson. (Berkley, $6.95.) How to increase your productivity. 7 MORE SNIGLETS, by Rich Hall and Friends. (Collier/Macmillan, $5.95.) Words that should appear in dictionaries, but don't. Illustrated. 8 GROWING UP CATHOLIC, by Mary Jane Frances Cavolina Meara, Jeffrey Allen Joseph Stone, Maureen Anne Teresa Kelly and Richard Glen Michael Davis (Doubleday/Dolphin, $4.95.) Humor. 9 SNIGLETS, by Rich Hall and Friends. (Collier/ Macmillan, $5.95.) Newly minted words. 10 GARFIELD MAKES IT BIG, by Jim Davis. (Ballantine, $5.95.) Cartoon humor. 11 AAA NORTH AMERICAN ROAD ATLAS 1985. (American Automobile Association/Random House, $5.95.) Maps and traveling advice.

title: THEATER MEETS WITH VARYING SUCCESS ON THE HOME SCREEN
description: Presenting noteworthy plays has always been one of cable's promises, as well as one of its most intricate challenges. Early on, specialized services came into being -such as CBS Cable and the Arts Channel - that were amply stocked with stage productions, but the services themselves quickly posted closing notices; production costs were unmanageably high, and viewership was discouragingly low.

title: A TEACHER REJOICES IN HIS CAREER
description: IT'S becoming more frequent these days.

title: HOME BANKING: EDGING IN THE DOOR
description: KENNETH FRIEDMAN, president of a New York computer service company, was on the phone negotiating a lease for a new car when the leasing company told him his checking account balance was far lower than he had indicated on the application. Immediately, Mr. Friedman went to his I.B.M. PC, called up Pronto, Chemical Bank's computerized home banking system, and within minutes was back on the phone with his balance.

title: MOFFETT'S RUN FOR GOVERNOR GAINS FORCE
description: THE discreet brass letters on the wooden door in the restored office building in downtown New Haven read simply, ''TOBY.''

title: Unitarians Elect New Chief
description: The Rev. William F. Schulz, who pledged to challenge rightist preachers, has been elected president of the 176,000-member Unitarian Universalist Association of Congregations. Mr. Schulz, a 35-year-old from Newburyport, Mass., is believed the youngest person to head a major denomination. He was elected by a 2-to-1 margin Thursday night, defeating Sandra Mitchell Caron of New York, who sought to become the first woman to head a major denomination.

title: MUSICALS ARE EVERYWHERE
description: A LITTLE bit of this. A little bit of that - but mostly musicals.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday on the Adirondacks gave an incorrect telephone number for the Hotel Saranac in Saranac Lake, N.Y. The number is 518-891-2200.

title: STATE DEPT. TIGHTENS SECURITY IN WAKE OF KILLINGS
description: State Department security officials, unnerved by the ease with which a young man smuggled a gun into the building and then killed his mother and himself, have instituted new procedures to screen a wide range of visitors who had easy access.

title: COLLEGIAN RECHES SEMIFINALS
description: Danielle Ammaccapane of Phoenix, who last month won the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship, advanced today to the semifinal round of the ninth Women's Amateur Public Links Championship at the Flanders Valley Golf Course.

title: WHERE CONSTRUCTION IS BOOMING
description: Construction cranes are everywhere these days, standing like a herd of giraffes across the skyline of Washington and its suburbs. There are more job openings for carpenters, bricklayers and other construction workers than there are workers to fill them.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A New Fed Battle The public wrist-slapping of Preston Martin, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board last week, may have severely damaged his chances for the No. 1 job at that august institution. In a highly unusual move, Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve's chairman, publicly chastised Mr. Martin for the vice chairman's remarks about how to handle third-world debt. Mr. Volcker, who was in Japan, went out of his way to criticize his colleague. Calling Mr. Martin's remarks ''incomprehensible,'' Mr. Volcker telephoned his complaints to the Fed in Washington, which released them to the press.

title: BRINGING A.&P. BACK FROM THE BRINK
description: THREE years ago, a national publication said that if James Wood, the chairman of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, could turn the ailing supermarket chain around, he would be a ''miracle man.'' What the publication failed to note was that if the affable supermarket veteran succeeded, he would also be a very wealthy man.

title: 50 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY CITY
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 50 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: NEW CASSETTES: ROSTAND, MAUGHAM AND ELTON JOHN
description: Mozart Three works performed by the Polish Chamber Orchestra, with soloists Alain Marion and Jeremy Menuhin Sony Video 55 minutes. $39.95 Music by Mozart is paired rather nicely here with the feudal castle at Tarascon on the banks of the Rhone in France.

title: WAITRESSES DESERVE MORE THAN TIPS
description: SAY waitress to the average American, and he will visualize a picture painted for him by movies and television. He will see a disheveled woman ignoring her customers as she leans over a counter to flirt with a trucker. This woman will be light on brains and heavy on makeup - the typical waitress.

title: WOLE SOYINKA: WRITING, AFRICA AND POLITICS
description: WOLE SOYINKA, the Nigerian playwright, novelist, poet and essayist, is Africa's best-known writer. He is also one of that continent's most controversial social critics. Several times Mr. Soyinka has gone into hiding or fled Nigeria to avoid reprisals for his criticisms of Government policies. He was twice jailed for political activities, once in 1965 and again in 1967-69, when, as he grimly recounts in his 1972 book, ''The Man Died,'' he was tortured and held in solitary confinement for two years.

title: NEW CASSETTES: ROSTAND, MAUGHAM AND ELTON JOHN
description: The Wind in the Willows Thorn EMI/HBO Video 78 minutes. $29.95 This superb English production is the finest video adaptation to date of Kenneth Grahame's classic bedtime book.

title: Irish Government Has Election Setback
description: Partial municipal election returns released today indicated a sharp setback for Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald's coalition Government halfway through its five-year term.

title: New Setup For Namibia
description: Defying longstanding international pressure for independence for South-West Africa, South Africa tried again last week to legitimize a government of limited powers for the territory. South-West Africa, the former German colony also called Namibia, had been under direct South African rule since the previous local administration collapsed two years ago.

title: BEYOND PORTOBELLO ROAD
description: With recreational shopping fast becoming one of America's favorite leisure-time activities, the traditional European flea market has kept up with the trend, shading progressively from a second-hand bazaar for the underprivileged to a playground for bargain-hunting tourists and collectors. No other institution offers quite the same intriguing possibilities of finding exactly the right vacation souvenir or that one-of-a-kind gift for the folks back home or some long-lost Bernini bronze for a few pounds, a few hundred francs or a few thousand lire.

title: SOLAR MOVES TOWARD PHOTOVOLTAICS
description: FIVE years ago, John Proctor bought a four-bedroom south-facing tract house in Denver, and added a solar hot water system. ''In the coldest, most blizzardy months, when many gas and electric bills hit $200, ours never went over $100,'' he said.

title: THE ART BOOM SETS OFF A MUSEUM BUILDING SPREE
description: There can be no doubt that the tourist and retirement center of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has arrived as a metropolis. Next January, in line with the tried-and-true American belief that you can't have a city without an art institution, it will open a $7.5-million Museum of Art, designed by one of the country's most sought-after cultural edificers, Edward Larrabee Barnes. Meanwhile, across the country in fast-growing San Jose, Calif., the capital of Silicon Valley, an $8 million to $10 million addition is planned for the local art museum, along with a brand-new, $60 million center for science and technology.

title: REFINERS' PROBLEMS LIE IN U.S. MARKET
description: FOUR years ago, at a time of rising oil prices, United States oil company executives cheered when President Reagan removed the last vestiges of Federal control over domestic oil prices. Texaco's chairman, John K. McKinley, praised Mr. Reagan for his ''overall reliance on the free market mechanism.''

title: TEXTILES DEFENDS ITS LAST BASTION
description: FROM the road, the red brick mill looks like scores of other textile plants scattered across the low rolling hills of South Carolina's Piedmont. But inside the walls of the Alice Manufacturing Company's Elljean mill, one of five fabric factories the small family-owned manufacturer operates here in rural Pickens County, the changes are dramatic.

title: CORRECTION
description: Due to an editing error, a story in the June 9 Business section dealing with the history of the Brooklyn Bridge incorrectly identified the bridge's chief engineer. He was Washington A. Roebling.

title: THE DANGERS OF DIVESTITURE
description: THE State Assembly has approved a Democratic-sponsored bill that would require New Jersey to sell $2 billion of its pension funds that are now invested in companies that do business in South Africa.

title: A Run-In Over Criminal Records
description: Mayor Koch last week offered a lesson in discipline to a Head Start program that was having a hard time keeping up with him. The program got into trouble because its board of directors refused to suspend the custodian who had worked there for 15 years.

title: LIEUTENANT SCHELLING, HOW HE DIED
description: A SOLDIER'S LEGACY By Heinrich Boll. Translated by Leila Vennewitz. 131 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95.

title: CUBS' SLIDE HITS 11
description: Curt Ford, in his first major-league time at bat, singled home Ozzie Smith from second with one out in the bottom of the 10th inning tonight to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 2-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs. It was Chicago's 11th consecutive defeat.

title: MEDIATORS OFFER AN ALTERNATIVE TO COURT
description: IN Yonkers, conflicts between neighbors over blaring stereos, unruly cats, loud parties and other annoyances are increasingly being settled at a community dispute-resolution center instead of in court.

title:
STUBBORN DEMOGRAPHICS;

THE MIDDLE CLASS IS ALIVE AND WELL
description: IS the middle class dying? Intuition, reinforced by the highly publicized loss of relatively well-paid manufacturing jobs, tells us that it is at least endangered. Employment data, however, tell a different story.

title: Judge Dismisses a Subpoena For Reputed Crime Chieftain
description: A Federal judge on Friday agreed to dismiss a subpoena for the testimony of Nicodemo Scarfo, the reputed organized-crime boss of Philadelphia and Atlantic City, before the President's Commission on Organized Crime.

title: THE PRODIGIOUS MEMORY OF THE BERNOULLI BOX
description: EVERY now and then a piece of software or hardware comes down the electronic pike that makes one sit up and say, ''This has to be the greatest thing since sliced bread.'' While I personally prefer my loaf whole, that was exactly my reaction to the Bernoulli Box.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The Voice is one of those things that if you go in and change it, you'd ruin it.''

title: SUSAN M. KELLER AND PAUL L. HICKEY ARE MARRIED
description: At St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake, N.J., yesterday Susan M. Keller, a daughter of Mrs. Kenneth W. Keller of Sea Girt, N.J., and the late Mr. Keller, was married to Paul L. Hickey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Hickey of Denver. Msgr. John E. Grimes performed the ceremony.

title: Drinking Age Going to 21 In New York
description: Whether it was motivated by the carrot - saving lives on the highway - or the stick - the loss of Federal aid - the New York State Legislature voted to raise the drinking age last week from 19 to 21. Governor Cuomo, who has campaigned for a higher age for two years, said he would sign the measure.

title: ANN W. OBERRENDER IS MARRIED ON L. I. TO NICHOLAS BLANCKE NOYES, A BANKER
description: Ann Worth Oberrender, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Girard Franklin Oberrender Jr. of Ithaca, N.Y., and Bridgehampton, L.I., and Nicholas Blancke Noyes, a son of Mrs. Blancke Noyes of Darien, Conn., and the late Mr. Noyes, were married yesterday at the Presbyterian Church in Bridgehampton. The Rev. Donald G. Huston, the Rev. Douglas J. Green and the bridegroom's uncle, the Rev. John T. Talbott, officiated. Mrs. Frederick Miles Fitz was matron of honor for her cousin and Albert Gallatin Blakey best man.

title: History's Revenge
description: One of the most surprising things about this revolutionary age is why the American people and their Government are so often surprised by events beyond their borders.

title: UNESCO BOARD SWEATS OUT A POLITICAL COMPROMISE
description: For seven weeks, the 50 members of Unesco's executive board sat in a basement room of the organization's headquarters here trying to figure how to ensure its survival as an ideological meeting ground. Last week, the exhausted delegates reached a compromise on program and budgetary changes but survival was still in doubt.

title: 1.2 MILLIAN CUBANS TRAIN AS MILITIAMEN, SERIOUSLY
description: Two Sundays a month, Sonia Sanchez, a 34-year-old office worker, pulls on fatigues and combat boots and joins other women in her neighborhood to practice firing a rifle, throwing hand grenades and marching. She is one of 1.2 million Cubans, most of them women or men of 50 or older, who constitute Fidel Castro's latest weapon in his quarter-century feud with the United States, the Territorial Militia.

title: PURPORTED SUICIDE TURNS INTO MURDER CASE
description: Two police detectives worked more than five years to convince the authorities that a Louisiana woman did not kill herself but was fed an overdose of barbiturates by three people who wanted to sell her baby.

title: NETWORK FORMS TO AID WIDOWED
description: ''When my wife died two and a half years ago, I got involved in some self-help groups and I found them very useful. I had a lot of shoulders to lean on. I feel I got a lot of help and now I want to pay it back.'' The speaker was Paul Auerbach of White Plains, who has been attending training meetings for the new Widowed to Widowed Network.

title: RED CROSS TO DROP 2 SHELTERS
description: The American Red Cross will not renew contracts to operate two barracks-style city shelters for homeless families that house about 400 people, a spokesman said yesterday.

title:
OUTDOORS;

REDISCOVERING THE SUNKEN FLY
description: I am weary of the reverence accorded the dry fly by many of today's trout fishermen and would like to suggest that its much older but less popular cousin, the wet, or sunken, fly be given proper attention.

title:
INVESTING;

SOME CAVEATS ABOUT REGIONAL BANKS
description: THE Supreme Court's recent decision to allow regional banks to band together is widely expected to cause a flood of takeovers and mergers. It certainly did not take long for the first wave. Last week's announced merger between the Wachovia Corporation of North Carolina and the First Atlanta Corporation, and the acquisition of Florida's Atlantic Bancorporation by the First Union Corporation in North Carolina, highlight the type of combination many on Wall Street expect.

title: LONDON
description: To the Editor: Rain or shine, we enthusiastically endorse walking in London, especially with the guidance of the London Walks organization, highlighted by Donald Goddard (Travel, May 26).

title: ONE SHOPPER'S CHOICE: PAUL-BERT
description: After 20-odd years of browsing through the flea market at St.-Ouen, I have finally settled on Marche Paul-Bert as the most satisfying, for several reasons.

title: CLIMB TO THE TOP OFTEN BRINGS A FALL
description: THE CHICAGO CUBS' 10-game losing streak is an exaggerated example of the fate that an increasing number of teams suffered this season. In the Cubs' case, they struggled to supplant the Mets in first place, then couldn't take the atmosphere once they attained it. Other teams have encountered similar experiences, lapsing into losing streaks just when they seemed to be establishing their presence at or near the top.

title: MARGOT WOOLEY AND GERARD VASISKO ARE MARRIED
description: The marriage of Margot Woolley, assistant vice president for planning and design at the New York City Public Development Corporation, and Gerard F. Vasisko, an associate with the Gruzen Partnership, architects in New York, took place yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in Brooklyn Heights. The Rev. John J. McCormack, the bridegroom's uncle, who is a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Goldthwaite Sherrill performed the ceremony.

title: A Setback for The Doctrine Of Pay Equity
description: The campaign to pay men and women equally for jobs of ''comparable worth'' received a setback last week when the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ruled unanimously that such equalization was not required by Federal law.

title: Deborah Rush Marries Chip Cronkite
description: Deborah Rush, an actress, and Walter Leland Cronkite 3d, the son of Walter Cronkite, the CBS News correspondent, and Mrs. Cronkite of New York, were married yesterday. Msgr. John Corr performed the ceremony at Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in New Vernon, N.J.

title: THE GOSPEL ACCORDING TO LEON ADAMS
description: RECENTLY, JOSEPH E. SEAGRAM & Sons, the huge spirits and wine conglomerate, ran some ads saying, in effect, that alcohol is alcohol, and that whether you're drinking it in a shot of whisky, a can of beer or a glass of wine, the effect is pretty much the same.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE MERRY-GO-ROUND By Oretta Leigh. Illustrated by Kathryn E. Shoemaker. New York: Holiday House. $12.95. (Ages 2 to 5) YOU won't get carried away on Oretta Leigh and Kathryn E. Shoemaker's ''Merry-Go-Round,'' but you might like to go along for a quiet ride or just stand aside and watch the animals pass. There are many animals in their carrousel - elephants, ostriches, sighing giraffes, painted horses, of course, and a dozen or so more. And, at the end of the little book you'll find a wonderful pair of puffy cats, each with a fish in its mouth.

title: A SUMMER OF MUSIC-MAKING AROUND THE STATE
description: FOR the next two months, there will be an abundance of music throughout New Jersey in both scenic spots suitable for picnics and more-formal surroundings. The offerings include orchestral programs, operas, chamber music, light classics and jazz.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Top-Quality Togs, Bargain Tags Oliver's, west of the County Center on Route 119 in the Town of Greenburgh, is one of 14 family clothing stores that began with the name of Factory Warehouse in Bogota, N. J., in 1977. Five stores are in New Jersey now, with other branches in Nanuet in Rockland County, on Long Island and in both Greenwich and Norwalk in Connecticut. All tags are double-marked with the department store prices and Oliver's 35 to 40 percent discount price. The wares are current, first-quality name brand and designer products.

title: TILTING TO RIYADH?
description: THE AMERICAN HOUSE OF SAUD The Secret Petrodollar Connection. By Steven Emerson. 450 pp. New York: Franklin Watts. $18.95.

title: MEXICO CITY DEPICTED AS A SOVIET SPIES' HAVEN
description: American officials say the Soviet Embassy here is increasingly being used to mount espionage operations against the United States and that it has become a major conduit for the illegal diversion of advanced technology to the Communist world.

title: LINDA JONATZKE WEDS DR. ELLIOTT BLUMENTHAL
description: Linda Sue Jonatzke, a learning-disability elementary school teacher in Denver, and Dr. Elliott James Blumenthal, a microbiologist reasearcher and instructor at the University of Colorado, were married yesterday. The Rev. Donald Neale performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in St. Joseph, Mich.

title: To and Fro With Moscow
description: The Reagan Administration moved on two fronts toward normalizing relations with the Soviet Union last week, but Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger seemed to be following a policy of his own.

title: JEAN C. KELLEY IS WED TO MICHAEL SCHNEIDER
description: Jean Consuelo Kelley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel F. Kelley Jr. of Dorado, P.R., and Stratton, Vt., was married yesterday to Michael Robert Schneider, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Schneider of New York. Justice of the Peace Arthur M. Over performed the ceremony at the Kelley home in Stratton.

title: LABOR OF LOVE, WITH A SUBTLE TOUCH
description: AT second glance, the name seems to be misspelled. L-A-N-M-A-R-K, the letters say, etched in the smoky glass so subtly that, at first glance, they don't appear to be there at all.

title: NOVELIST WITH A CAUSE
description: ON WRITING AND POLITICS #1967-1983. By Gunter Grass. Translated by Ralph Manheim. With an introduction by Salman Rushdie. 157 pp. San Diego: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $13.95.

title: TANGO TRACES A SOCIETY
description: When the Argentine tango was introduced to the United States by Vernon and Irene Castle in 1913, it became the rage in ballrooms, theaters and films, as popular as rock and roll is today. It even caused scandals for its blatant sensuality. But the story of this riveting dance didn't begin in 1913, and it didn't end when the style faded from fashion in the 50's. The tango is part of a rich and ongoing 100-year Argentine tradition of rhythmic music, gutsy songs and dynamic couples dancing.

title: SENECA FALLS
description: To The Editor: The story ''The Finger Lakes: 250 Miles by Bike'' (Travel, May 19) in two places identifies Seneca Falls by the National Women's Hall of Fame. With all due respect to the private entrepreneurs who set up this storefront on Falls Street with a $3 admission fee, I must call to your attention the really significant tourist attraction in Seneca Falls run by the United States Department of the Interior.

title: RED SOX BEAT JAYS 5-3, ON LATE RALLY
description: Bill Buckner hit a two-run single in the eighth inning and Marty Barrett hit a home run in the ninth today to give the Boston Red Sox a 5-3 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays in a game delayed by rain for more than three hours.

title: STATES ROLL UP THEIR SLEEVES TO HELP THE FARMER
description: Anne Kanten, Minnesota's Assistant Commissioner of Agriculture, went to pay her respects last week at the Harlan Johnson farm in Renville, Minn. Mr. Johnson, who like many farmers across the region was having financial troubles, walked out to his barn last month and shot himself. The first shot wasn't fatal; he pulled the trigger again.

title: DOCTOR REHIRED
description: The Scottsdale psychiatrist at the center of Arizona State University's Nardil controversy was offered a new contract as a sports psychologist for the Sun Devils, the acting athletic director, Frank Sackton said Friday. Under the contract, however, Sackton said Dr. James Gough would not have the authority to offer psychiatric services or prescribe medications to athletes.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

MEXOICO TO ISSUE WORLD CUP COINS
description: Mexico plans to issue 21 precious-metal coins to commemorate the 1986 World Cup soccer championship which it will host. Six coins will be in gold, 15 in silver. Sixteen of the coins will be proofs, the first to be struck by the Casa de Moneda, the 450-year-old Mexican government mint in Mexico City.

title: A 'TEMPORARY' PROSECUTOR'S OFFICE GETS ITS 5TH OCCUPANT
description: When the post was created, it was given the title ''special prosecutor for investigating corruption in the New York City criminal justice system.'' One reason it was called ''special'' was that it was intended to be temporary.

title: DANCE: HARLEM TROUPE
description: OPENING nights of ballet seasons can be exciting, for they possess the thrill of expectancy. They can also make a company look hesitant, especially when it is dancing in an unfamiliar theater. Closing nights can be exciting, too, for they may sum up a season's achievements, yet the fact that they are final performances adds a certain melancholy. A company therefore is often the most satisfying to behold in mid-season, when it has made itself at home on a stage.

title: G.O.P. CANDIDATE SEATED ON BOARD
description: CAMPAIGNS for seats on the Board of Legislators came into sharper focus last week as one Republican candidate was seated without being elected.

title: AT LEAST 200 MAFIA SUSPECTS ARE ARRESTED IN ITALY
description: The police arrested more than 100 Mafia suspects today in an operation in and around the Sicilian coastal town of Messina.

title: VERBATIM: HARLEM ON MY MIND
description: 'I don't want a big influx of outsiders, I just hope Harlem will become the community I remember - a quiet, safe place to raise children.'

title: Lesson of Hijacking Is That the U.S. Is at War in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Tire Imports
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BOMBS ABOUVE, THE MAZE BELOW
description: THE TUNNELS OF CU CHI By Tom Mangold and John Penycate. Illustrated. 294 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: JANE GORDON ENGAGED TO RICHARD MEYERSON
description: The engagement of Jane Lori Gordon and Richard Allan Meyerson has been announced by her parents, Joyce Gordon of New York and Merrill Ian Gordon of West Bloomfield, Mich., and Bal Harbour, Fla. Mr. Meyerson is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Meyerson of Long Beach, L.I., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The wedding is planned for September.

title: GREEK VESSEL WILL CARRY ON ANCIENT TRIP
description: Culture Minister Melina Mercouri needed three tries today to break a bottle of Champagne that launched an attempt at resumption of a voyage interrupted by pirates 2,300 years ago.

title: EXPOS REVIVE TO TOPPLE METS
description: The Mets treated a crowd of 51,513 fans in Shea Stadium last night to four hours of whirling baseball that seemed to reach a peak of noise and emotion in the seventh inning when 41-year-old Rusty Staub pinch-hit a three-run home run off Jeff Reardon of the Montreal Expos.

title: IS THIS COUPLE TOO ODD, OR NOT ODD ENOUGH?
description: You may well have forgotten that there was once an enterprising soul who translated a Charles Dickens novel into contemporary English in order to ''make it easier to read.'' As I remember it, when James Thurber was confronted with the results of this experiment, he announced with simple dignity, ''What we have here is an important step in the wrong direction.''

title: Parents Seeking an Abortion For Brain-Damaged Woman
description: The parents of Laura Eldrige, a brain-damaged rape victim, searched today for ''one courageous doctor'' to give her an abortion after a physician who had been scheduled to end her pregnancy cancelled the operation.

title: FOR WOMEN ONLY, A MARTIAL ARTS CAMP
description: JOYCE GORDON awoke feeling stiff and sore. It was her third day at camp and for the 38-year-old social-services counselor from Boulder, Colo., the physical activity was taking its toll.

title: A SPECIAL TEACHER IS RETIRING
description: HE began his teaching career late - at the age of 50 -but, given his fervent love for his profession, it is not surprising that Marten Tafel has made up for lost time as an educator.

title: ESTHETICS AND THE LAW SPURRING FACADE RESTORATIONS
description: WHENEVER Marla Perkel looks at her brownstone co-op at 409-411 West 21st Street, she cannot help admiring the facade. ''Recently, we restored the entire ground-floor front,'' she said the other day. ''We rebuilt lintels, had a cornice made from scratch, and then, to top it off, added the most gorgeous custom-made doors you ever saw. The whole project cost about $50,000.'' Mrs. Perkel is among a growing number of owners of cooperatives, condominiums and houses in New York City who are learning about the care and preservation of facades. When their buildings have endured years of exposure to the elements or where architectural ornaments and decoration have either deteriorated or been removed, owners are increasingly deciding that a full or partial restoration is in order.

title: Lesson of Hijacking Is That the U.S. Is at War in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Town Supervisors And the People
description: An article on June 2 [''Towns Seek a Drinking Ban''] enlightens readers about Town Supervisors in Hempstead, North Hempstead and Oyster Bay passing ''home rule'' legislation to modify open-container laws that were judged unconstitutional in 1983. Another article is about smoking-ban ordinances being passed in Nassau County [''Nassau May Relax Smoking Ban Rules''] .

title: BAYREUTH
description: To the Editor: Your issue on music festivals (Travel, May 5) brought back lovely memories. When we decided to add Bayreuth to a month of festivals, although it was nine months away, it was too late for tickets through the usual channels.

title: WHEN LIFE CLOSES IN
description: LEARNING TO SWIM And Other Stories. By Graham Swift. 189 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $14.95. THE SWEET-SHOP OWNER By Graham Swift. 222 pp. New York: Washington Square Press/ Pocket Books. Paper. $7.95.

title: GOING ON IN NORTHEAST
description: NEW HAVEN CAROUSEL With 24 horses and a regal camel restored to splendor, the Lighthouse Park Carousel in New Haven, boarded up in 1977, is back in operation, whirling riders in reverie as it first did seven decades ago.

title: U.S. BUDGET BATTLE STIRS VOTERS' PRIDE IN LEADERSHIP OF PHILADELPHIA'S GRAY
description: The telephones are always ringing, even on Sundays, according to the janitor, in the little ground-floor office on 52d Street across from the Brotherly Love Missionary Baptist Church, a few steps from Jerry's Bar, and less than a block from the elevated station's sign that proclaims this as ''West Philadelphia's Main Street.''

title: DANGER'S HOUR SETS HILL PRINCE RECORD
description: Danger's Hour, the less highly regarded half of a Rokeby Stable entry, caught Foundation Plan nearing the wire to score a two-length victory in the $98,850 Hill Prince Stakes for 3-year-olds yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Protesters in Capital Clash Over Abortion
description: Abortion rights and antiabortion proesters clashed in demonstrations today in front of a women's clinic and at the site of a speech by John Cardinal O'Connor.

title: LISA KAYE BONTI WEDS
description: Lisa Kaye Bonti, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Joseph Bonti of Larchmont, N.Y., was married at St. John's Episcopal Church there yesterday to John Joseph Kennedy, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Lawrence Kennedy of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George Zabriskie 2d and assisted by the Rev. Joseph DeSanto, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride is a bank representative at the Wall Street Clearing Company in New York. Mr. Kennedy is a third-year student at New York Medical College.

title: PRISONERS OF THE HEBDOMAD
description: THE SEVEN DAY CIRCLE The History and Meaning of the Week. By Eviatar Zerubavel. Illustrated. 206 pp. New York: The Free Press/Macmillan. $16.95.

title: A SCHOOL HAILS ITS 'AUTHORS'
description: PHOTOGRAPHERS' bulbs flashed. Browsers wandered from table to table while authors answered questions about their latest hard-cover releases.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

A GREAT BIG RAINBOW OF TROUBLE
description: SISYPHUS had it easy. The mythical figure was sentenced in Hades to perpetually roll a large stone up a hill, almost to the top, only to have it roll back to the very bottom every time. He could have drawn house-painting detail just as easily.

title: DAVID DIAZ, TV REPORTER, MARRIED TO VIRGINIA RUSSO
description: Virginia Russo, an operations producer for WNBC-TV's ''News 4 New York'' program, was married yesterday to David Diaz, a general assignment reporter for WNBC-TV in New York.

title: Railroads and Largest Union Reach Tentative Agreement
description: The nation's largest railroad union today reached a tentative settlement with the association representing the railroads after a round-the-clock bargaining session, according to a Federal official who was monitoring the negotiations.

title: IN A WORLD OF TERROR
description: Once terrorists have taken hostages and hidden them in an urban setting, there is little the strongest power can do to force their release. So even superhawks have effectively conceded in the Beirut hostage crisis. Henry Kissinger warns against ''humiliation'' and says the U.S. must ''take an ominous and strong position.'' But when asked what exactly he would do, he says ''sit tight, be calm, not rattle the cage.''

title: SLAYING CASE JURY HEARS CONFESSIONS
description: The prosecution in the murder trial of a Bronx man accused in the slaying of a young drama student on the Upper West Side last December presented a series of confessions by the defendant as it ended its case last week.

title: Stony Brook And Computers
description: I would like to clarify a remark that appeared in the Long Island Weekly May 26 [''College Applicants Defy Trend''] . In commenting about computer science at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, a member of the admissions staff is quoted as saying that the program is narrowly focused with less emphasis on practical skills. I am afraid that this is misleading.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REMARKS BY REAGAN
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's remarks today at Andrews Air Force Base, Md., paying homage to the four marines killed in El Salvador, as recorded by The New York Times:

title:
GARDENING;

DRY SPELL BRINGS GOOD AND ILL FOR PLANTS
description: EACH season has its own particular characteristics when it comes to its effects on the garden. This season is no exception.

title: CONGRESSMEN JOIN TAX FIGHT
description: LONG ISLAND'S representatives in Washington have joined Governor Cuomo as the most vocal critics of a key provision in President Reagan's tax plan: the elimination of state and local tax deductions.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: OPENING NIGHTS. By Janet Burroway. (Atheneum, $16.95.) Shaara Soole is an awesomely capable woman whose life is a mess. Her son Kevin's dog has just been killed by a car.

title: Environment an Issue In Fort Salonga
description: I commend the article ''Indian Data at Development?'' [May 5] for highlighting one possible obstacle to development plans on a 10-acre tract in Fort Salonga. It should be pointed out, however, that another legitimate concern exists with regard to the fate of this property.

title: Iraq Says It Stymied An Iranian Offensive
description: Iraq said today that 200 Iranians were killed when Iraqi troops threw back an Iranian attack on the southern front of the Persian Gulf war.

title: WIND POWER SHIFTS INTO HIGH GEAR
description: SUMMER has arrived, and high up in California's exotically named mountain passes - Altamont, Tehachapi and San Gorgonio - the wind is blowing. It funnels down through mountain canyons and activates thousands of windmills.

title: LINDA TRUESDALE BRIDE OF A FINANCIAL ANALYST
description: The marriage of Linda Laughlin Truesdale, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Truesdale 2d of Cumberland, Me, to Michael Boyle Kilroy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Kilroy Jr. of Shaker Heights, Ohio, took place yesterday in Prouts Neck, Me. The Rev. Thomas Gariepy performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church.

title: MISS RIGGS WED TO JAMES MEADE
description: Merry Murray Riggs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Riggs Jr. of Providence, R.I., and James Carlton Meade, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carlton J. Meade Jr. of Wellesley Hills and Centerville, Mass., were married yesterday. The Rev. Daniel Burke performed the ceremony at St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Providence.

title: THERE'LL BE SOME CHANGES MADE AT TANGLEWOOD
description: Tanglewood veterans speak of the two sides of the lawn - the Music Shed side, where the Boston Symphony Orchestra plays its weekend concerts before crowds of up to 15,000, and the Music Center side, where the festival's school pursues a more private existence.

title: THEATER IN SHARON MIXES EAST AND WEST
description: DR. WALTER A. FAIRSERVIS JR., an archeologist, has led expeditions to such places as Egypt, Pakistan, India and Afghanistan. This summer, though, he can be found happily puttering about the backyard of his home in Sharon, excavating stones that he will use to build a terrace for his latest project, the East-West Fusion Theater.

title: A WINNING BEGINNING
description: Sandwiched amid sale-tagged summer merchandise, the first of fall's clothes are starting to appear on the racks. Designers are already shuttling around the country to preview their new collections, while store windows and ads are promoting the inevitable change of seasons even as summer starts.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: WHILE resistance to development is nothing new in the Northeast, it is rare among the dead.

title: CASINO OWNERS IN BATTLE OVER A NAME
description: TRUMP CASTLE, this resort city's 11th hotel-casino, opened last week amid mounting tensions between its owner, Donald Trump, and Harrah's, Mr. Trump's partner in a Boardwalk hotel-casino here and now also his only competitor in the Marina casino zone.

title: The Met Is Ending Its Road Show
description: Since its founding in 1883, the Metropolitan Opera has toured the country every year, bringing opera to many Americans for the first time. That tradition is about to end.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HOT WIRE. By James Brown. (Arbor House, $15.95.) James Brown's prose isn't pretty, but then neither are the lives of his frightened, angry characters - three sons and a widowed mother stuck behind the eight ball in a seedy blue-collar backwater of Los Angeles.

title: IS SEX NECESSARY? USEFUL? POSSIBLE? FUN?
description: THE REDUNDANT MALE Is Sex Irrelevant in the Modern World? By Jeremy Cherfas and John Gribbin. 197 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $7.95. MAKING BABIES The New Science and Ethics of Conception. By Peter Singer and Deane Wells. 245 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $14.95.

title: FRENCH INTIMACY IN SMITHTOWN
description: WESTERN Suffolk County is becoming a corner of France, with Lafayette in Smithtown bringing to three the tally of worthwhile French restaurants within a 10-mile radius. This new establishment is off to a good start and is potentially worth two stars.

title: MOVING TO THE MARKET
description: In a reversal of the usual northeast-to-southwest migration, a Texas-based company that specializes in packaging systems for liquid foods is moving its North American corporate headquarters to Connecticut to be nearer its customers and its international headquarters in Switzerland.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption last Sunday with a picture of a cruise ship at a Manhattan pier misidentified the ship's destination. It was Bermuda.

title: Man Slain by Off-Duty Officer During Scuffle in Jersey Park
description: An off-duty township patrolman shot and killed a man Saturday night while trying to break up an argument, the authorities said.

title: Hector Boiardi Is Dead: Began Chef Boy-ar-dee
description: Hector Boiardi, founder of Chef Boy-ar-dee Foods, one of the first packaged Italian food businesses in the nation, died Friday night after a short illness. He was 87 years old.

title: REPUBLICAN PARTY IS ATTRACTING TEEN-AGERS
description: They stuff envelopes, sharpen pencils and make phone calls. They display an unusual new enthusiasm for traditional politics and for their country. They are Teen Age Republicans, and they so active that the Democrats have realized they must find new ways of reaching teen-agers.

title: SUBTERRANEAN II
description: Speaking of the Washington Metro, unlike some subways elsewhere, on this one the passengers can sit facing forward, backward or sideways, as well as stand.

title: STATE MUSEUM: WORKS IN WOOD
description: ''ANDERSON and Anderson: A Dialogue in Wood,'' an exhibition at the State Museum, represents a couple's 35-year collaboration in woodworking.

title: NEW CASSETTES: ROSTAND, MAUGHAM AND ELTON JOHN
description: The Nighttime Concert Featuring Elton John Vestron 53 minutes. $29.95 Filmed last summer at Wembley Stadium, in England, ''The Nighttime Concert'' was a high point of Elton John's ''farewell'' international tour, which followed the release of his last album, ''Too Low for Zero.''

title: We Need to Work With the Rest of the Hemisphere;   A New Holy Alliance
description: To the Editor:

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

MUSIC, MUSIC, MUSIC
description: When Skitch Henderson, music director of the New York Pops, brings his 75-piece ensemble to the grounds of Westchester Community College on June 30, the free outdoor concert will open the county's summer music season.

title: KEY ISSUES IMPEDE COMPROMISE ON CUTTING DEFICIT
description: This year's effort to reduce the Federal budget deficit will reach a critical crossroad next week. After two weeks of sparring, conferees from the House and the Senate are faced with trying to reach a compromise on the crucial issues of Social Security and the military budget, but no one can see a solution at the moment.

title: U.S. DELAYS POSTING WARNING ON SHELTER'S CLOSING
description: The Department of Health and Human Services today delayed plans to post signs at a Government shelter for Washington's homeless warning that the building would be closed on July 10.

title: NEW SUMMER SCHOOL COURSES
description: Summer school for students who have failed courses in 9th, 10th or 11th grades will be available in New York City public schools this summer for the first time in 11 years.

title: FORT GREENE INTEGRATES AS IT GENTRIFIES
description: AT first glance, the signs of the revitalization that has taken place over the past decade in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn seem no different than evidences of gentrification elsewhere.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

LITTLE RED RIDING HOOD AND THE BIG, BAD HOSPITAL
description: I STEPPED into the crowded hospital elevator and smiled at the raised eyebrows of the other passengers. I was a little embarrassed by the pungent aroma emanating from my wicker basket, and somewhat uncomfortable wearing my red raincoat and hood.

title:
ART;

A FOND LOOK BACK AT HARD TIMES
description: NORMALLY, Ibram Lassaw is not given to reminiscing.

title: NEW YORK DEMOCRATIC CHAIRMAN SETS QUIET TONE
description: While George L. Clark Jr. has established a reputation as a freewheeling, outspoken Republican state chairman, his new Democratic counterpart, Laurence J. Kirwan, has emerged as a chairman of a different sort.

title: HERMAN SOKOL, DRUG PIONEER WHO LED BRISTOL-MYERS, DIES
description: Dr. Herman Sokol, a pioneer in the production of antibiotics and a retired president of the Bristol-Myers Company, died Friday night at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, after a long illness. He was 68 and lived in Manhattan.

title: MORRISTOWN RENEWAL STILL DEBATED
description: AS Morristown's Headquarters Plaza urban-renewal project nears completion almost 20 years after it was started, many of the town's 17,000 residents are still arguing over whether it ever should have been built.

title: CHINA STEPS UP DRIVE TO REVIVE BUREAUCRACY
description: Deng Xiaoping's campaign to rejuvenate China's sluggish bureaucracy has been stepped up with the naming of a new Shanghai party chief and the promotion of three 42-year-old officers to top military posts.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES
description: WHEN the Arab oil embargo was declared in 1973, the search for new sources of energy in the United States took on new meaning. Americans no longer wanted to rely on sources that could dry up because of events in far-away countries. The push was on, in fact, to find energy sources - the wind, the sun, the flowing rivers, even the trash bins - that would not run out for any reason.

title: MISS BENEZET MARRIES GILBERT HAHN 3D
description: Barbara Twohy Benezet, a daughter of Louis Tomlinson Benezet of Setauket, L.I., and the late Mildred Twohy Benezet, was married yesterday to Gilbert Hahn 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hahn Jr. of Washington. Canon Charles Martin of the National Episcopal Cathedral, headmaster emeritus of St. Albans School in Washington, performed the ceremony at the school's Little Sanctuary.

title: SHOPPERS' HAUNTS AROUND THE WORLD
description: Many countries have their own version of the flea market. The goods and the language may differ but what most have in common are variety -from antiques to plain junk - bargain hunters, serious collectors and a certain amount of haggling. Here are reports on some outstanding ones:

title: ELIZABETH B. PURDY IS WED TO A. R. THORSEY IN JERSEY
description: Elizabeth Britton Purdy, the daughter of Canon and Mrs. Samuel Edwin Purdy of Mountain Lakes, N.J., was married there yesterday to Arthur Richard Thorsey, the son of Mr and Mrs. Francis Arthur Thorsey of Charlottesville, Va. The bride's father performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, of which he is rector.

title: GENERALS AND STALLIONS BATLING FOR FIRST
description: The Generals finish their regular-season schedule today with a game at Giants Stadium against the Birmingham Stallions that will decide first place in the Eastern Conference of the United States Football League.

title: SOME BOOKS LEAD TO A LIFELONG HABIT
description: WHEN Nancy M. Kline, a librarian at the University of Connecticut, decided to determine what books had made a difference in people's lives, she was not surprised to see titles such as ''Walden,'' by Henry David Thoreau, and ''Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man,'' by James Joyce, turn up on the list.

title: LOUISE AMBLER BECOMES A BRIDE
description: The marriage of Louise dePeyster Ambler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Wistar Ambler of Belmont, Mass., to James Duane Pell Osborn took place yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. W. Murray Kenney performed the ceremony. Mr. Osborn is a son of Mrs. Frederick H. Osborn Jr. of Garrison, N.Y., and the late Mr. Osborn.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CHILDREN'S HOSPITAL. By Peggy Anderson. (Harper & Row, $18.95.) Desperately ill children should evoke a tender response, and the nurses and doctors who care for them should inspire awe, gratitude, admiration.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD PLEA
description: After emotional pleas by 14 Rochelle Park residents for protection of an area they called ''gracious and historic,'' the New Rochelle City Council has ordered its planning commissioner to draw up a resolution creating a city landmark commission.

title: EASY WEARING
description: RELAXING SUMmer evenings call for clothes that are both casual and appropriate for the occasion. Equally important, they should be able to resist the rigors of the season, meaning heat and humidity.

title: CLAUDIA ELLIMAN BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Claudia Lewis Elliman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Trowbridge Elliman of Stowe, Vt., was married yesterday to Thomas Story Jenks Jr., a son of Mr. Jenks of Chadds Ford, Pa., and the late Damaris Jenks. The Rev. James Rains performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Stowe Community Church.

title:
GARDENING;

DRY SPELL BRINGS GOOD AND ILL FOR PLANTS
description: EACH season has its own particular characteristics when it comes to its effects on the garden. This season is no exception.

title: THE PUZZLES OF THE 'RING' WILL NEVER BE SOLVED
description: No one has ever mounted an entirely satisfactory production of Wagner's ''Ring'' and no one ever will. Wagner himself saw to that by making the work internally inconsistent at many points, by mixing musical and theatrical styles, by winding together allegorical and literal meanings in ways that defy untangling. Perhaps the composer, as canny a showman as ever lived, knew that in making his tetralogy ambiguous and often contradictory he insured its survival. Comparisons that have been made with the Bible in that respect are really not so farfetched. It is almost as if the ''Ring'' was designed to create heresies and provoke argument. At any rate, it has done just that for more than a century and appears likely to go right on doing so.

title: SIGNS OF ECONOMIC REVIVAL ABOUND IN NORTHEAST
description: When Ralph Carpinella bought an abandoned, 130-year-old button factory in this run-down industrial city last year, he did so because he was convinced that his area was about to undergo the most sweeping economic revival in generations. And he was correct.

title: MISS CULLUM WED TO A BANK OFFICER
description: Our Lady of the Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in Roseland, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Mary Virginia Cullum, a daughter of Mrs. Francis J. Cullum of Essex Fells and Sea Girt, N.J., and the late Mr. Cullum, to William Charles Obermayer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Obermayer of Seaford, L.I., and Bolton Landing, N.Y. Msgr. Edward Fleming performed the ceremony.

title: PLAYING A SLAM WITH FINESSE
description: The vast majority of men and women are never prominent in anything. To be prominent in more than one area is very rare, but there is one man who is a household word in one area, finance. And he has been highly effective in five others: pharmaceutical research, golf, tennis, gin rummy and bridge.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION
description: FOR this beauty pageant the contestants didn't have to wear bathing suits. But the winner, Ethel Bennett of Amityville, said, ''I wouldn't have minded being seen in a bathing suit, I keep in shape.''

title: 5 - 4 - 3 - 2 - 1...IT'S A LAUNCH!
description: They have names like Apha 3, Sizzler and Mean Machine. Their shapes and sizes vary, much like the boys and girls who have crafted them.

title: THE 'LITTLE FLOWER' IS BACK IN 'FIORELLO!'
description: THE Westbury Music Fair has followed its zesty production of ''Evita'' with the Pulitzer Prize-winning musical ''Fiorello!''

title: MARTHA THORSON MARRIES JAMES GOULD
description: Martha Ann Thorson, a daughter of Mrs. Abram Claude Jr. of Bedford, N.Y., and the late Robert D. Thorson, was married yesterday to James Jay Gould, a son of Josephine Wilkinson-Gould of Boston and Edwin Jay Gould of New York and Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Dr. William E. Foley performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Arthur W. Hargate.

title: BURNING PEACH PITS AND PEANUT SHELLS
description: WOOD has come full circle.

title: REFUGE FOR RECOVERING ALCOHOLICS
description: FOR nearly half a century, the rich and famous, as well as blue-collar workers, executives and homemakers, have come to a pristine hillside farm high above the Housatonic River in Kent.

title: THE VICTIMS INCLUDE U.S.-ISRAELI RELATIONS
description: THE Beirut hostage crisis has all the makings of a tragic play about Middle East politics. Relations between many of the key actors in the region are affected: between Shiites and Shiites, between Israel and the Shiites and between Israel and the United States, to name but a few. It seems certain that all of these actors and relationships will undergo some kind of a change before the last act is played.

title: UNESCO VOTES TO EASE UP ON POLITICS
description: Unesco's 50-nation executive board ended a marathon session Friday night by adopting a modest set of changes for the world educational, scientific and cultural body, promising a limited reduction in politically controversial activities that led the United States to withdraw at the end of last year.

title: CAR POOLS IN NEW YORK HELP DISABLED WORKERS
description: The 80-block commute to and from her Upper West Side apartment used to be one of the most wearisome parts of Mary Jane Dooley's workday. While the complaint may be familiar to most commuters, for Miss Dooley, who uses a folding wheelchair to get around, the frustration was often overwhelming.

title: SHOPPERS' HAUNTS AROUND THE WORLD
description: Many countries have their own version of the flea market. The goods and the language may differ but what most have in common are variety -from antiques to plain junk - bargain hunters, serious collectors and a certain amount of haggling.

title: LEFT-HAND RIGHTS
description: NOT long after Connecticut began selling new turnpike tokens in October 1982, cheats discovered that the coins, sold in rolls of 40 for 17 1/2 cents each, could be substituted in turnstiles for New York City subway tokens, which then cost 75 cents.

title: Quebec Premier Bids Adieu
description: With his dream of making Quebec an independent nation more distant than ever, Premier Rene Levesque announced his resignation last week as leader of the Parti Quebecois, which he founded in 1968.

title: FULL-SCALE BIOGRAPHY
description: HANDEL By Christopher Hogwood. Illustrated. 312 pp. New York: Thames & Hudson. $19.95.

title: POPE AND POLISH AIDE HAVE 'COOL' TALK
description: Pope John Paul II met with the Polish Foreign Minister today in an atmosphere that one Vatican official described as ''rather cool.''

title: A Good Week For Discovery
description: The space shuttle Discovery spent most of last week doing what it was sent up to do. After a faulty first try, it carried out the first space shuttle experiment for the Strategic Defense Initiative, the Government's research program to develop a shield against enemy missiles.

title: NEW CASSETTES: ROSTAND, MAUGHAM AND ELTON JOHN
description: Cyrano de Bergerac Starring Jose Ferrer, William Prince, Mala Powers; produced by Stanley Kramer, directed by Michael Gordon, 1950 Corinth Video 112 minutes. $59.95 It is interesting to revisit Jose Ferrer's film of ''Cyrano de Bergerac'' after seeing Derek Jacobi perform the role in the Royal Shakespeare Company's production on Broadway this season. Mr. Ferrer won an Academy Award as best actor in 1950, and, as was the case with Mr. Jacobi, the performance transcends the play.

title: BONUS FOR VETERANS?
description: At the end of World War II, many returning G.I.'s expected their home states to offer them a bonus - a one-time, lump-sum benefit.

title: EMILY TRAIN WED TO J. A. ROWAN JR.
description: Emily Ligon Train, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell E. Train of Washington, was married yesterday to James A. Rowan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rowan of Fort Myers, Fla. The Rev. Dr. John H. Harper, assisted by the Rev. Donald Etherton, performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in St. Michaels, Md.

title: TAX RISE DEBATED IN VIRGIN ISLANDS
description: Gov. Juan Luis and the 15-member Legislature are locked in a bitter struggle over raising taxes in this American territory 1,100 miles southeast of Miami.

title: Inside Information Environmental Cleanup
description: Lee Thomas, who became head of the Environmental Protection Agency in February, has bested an enemy that made life miserable for his two predecessors - the Office of Management and Budget.

title: FUTILE RAGE, PATIENT EFFORT MARK A WEEK OF TERROR
description: IN the five and a half years since Iranian revolutionaries seized the United States Embassy in Teheran and made a hostage of the Carter Administration as well, America has learned that being a 20th century superpower can count for little in dealing with Middle East adversaries ready to sacrifice their lives to achieve their aims.

title: THE VISTA FROM OVER THE HILL
description: WHEN Neil Armstrong landed on the moon in 1969, President Richard M. Nixon said it was the greatest thing to happen to the human race since creation. Apparently, he didn't know about senior citizens' discounts.

title: MAINTENON
description: To the Editor: Olivier Bernier's delightful article on Maintenon, ''Chateau for a Royal Favorite'' (Travel, May 19), revived memories of a visit to the chateau three years ago. The occasion was a tour of the chateaus along the Loire that also included Chartres.

title: Day 10...Day 27...Day 412...
description: This is Day 10 of captivity in Lebanon for three crew members and 37 passengers of T.W.A.'s Flight 847. For David Jacobsen, the director of the American University Hospital in Beirut, it is Day 27 . . . For Terry Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, it is Day 116 . . . For the Rev. Benjamin Weir, a Presbyterian minister, it is Day 412. The fate of the 40 captives in the hijacking a week ago has become a national obsession. Yet hardly anyone bothers to mention the seven other Americans, just as innocent, who have been imprisoned in Lebanon for weeks and months.

title: 'HAPPY HOUR' BAN
description: A state ban on ''happy hours'' at bars went into effect in Massachusetts on Dec. 10, and the hope was that it would reduce drunken driving.

title: LIBERIAN GETS RESTIVE BOYS TO BE SCOUTS
description: For the ''gronnah boys'' of Monrovia and its environs, there is nothing but time. They cluster at corners, hide in shadows and line the streets, appearing as restive spectators of the passing parade.

title: TEACHERS UNION HEAD IS OPTIMISTIC
description: EDITHE A. FULTON, the 97th and outgoing president of the New Jersey Education Association, bade farewell last week to 117,000 teachers and support staff.

title: REACHING OUT TO SOMEONE WITH AIDS
description: Thank you for the profoundly moving story of Jim Sharp. For those of us who are not part of the gay community, AIDS suddenly became not just a bunch of statistics, but a person.

title: LOUISA B. HASEN BECOMES THE WIFE OF JOHN MATTSON
description: Louisa Bronson Hasen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Hasen of New York and Greensboro, Vt., was married yesterday to John Edward Mattson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Tauno W. Mattson of Lunenburg, Mass. The Rev. Barbara F. West performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: FRAZIER BOUT OFF
description: Beset by legal difficulties, the boxing promoter Regis Levesque said he has dropped plans to stage a fight tomorrow in Montreal between the former world heavyweight champion Joe Frazier and the ex-Canadian champion Robert Cleroux. But Levesque, accused of promoting what the authorities call an illegal fight, insists he will find a way to hold the bout at some point between the 41-year-old Frazier and the 47-year-old Cleroux, both of whom officially retired from the ring years ago. Levesque, who has been staging bouts for 25 years, was charged under a rarely used law that forbids promotion of a fight that isn't sanctioned by an authorized athletic commission. . . . The newly crowned World Boxing Association featherweight champion, Barry McGuigan, whose upset of Eusebio Pedroza thrilled both sides of the Irish border earlier this month, has been notified that he must defend his title by Oct. 8 against Bernard Taylor, the W.B.A.'s top contender.

title: A GOING-AWAY PRESENT
description: TWENTY-ONE YEARS ago, Brother George, Brother Hugh and I celebrated my 21st birthday in a field on the side of a small mountain in the Berkshire hills of western Massachusetts. We were all seminarians at Shadowbrook, a Jesuit novitiate, whose main building was just out of view in a grove of spruce trees below. It was a clear, late winter day, and mild, our field dry and plushy with brown matted wild hay.

title: REBITH OF FORT STANWIX
description: A key link on the water route between the Great Lakes and the Atlantic seaboard, New York State's Upper Mohawk Valley played a strategic role in the early history of the American republic. By dint of careful restoration and re-creation, two imposing mementos of those days are still to be seen: Fort Stanwix National Monument, a frontier redoubt that withstood a British siege in 1777, and Erie Canal Village, a typical mid-19th-century waterway community.

title: U.N. FINDS WIDESPREAD INEQUALITY FOR WOMEN
description: Two United Nations studies on women have concluded that although women have made some gains in education, health, employment and politics in the last decade, equal rights for women are still a long way off.

title: SUZANNE WOFFORD WED IN NANTUCKET TO JAQUES LEZRA
description: The marriage of Susanne Lindgren Wofford to Jacques Lezra y Paull took place yesterday at the summer home in Nantucket, Mass., of Mr. and Mrs. Harris Llewellyn Wofford Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., parents of the bride. The Rev. Phyllis Taylor Wofford, stepgrandmother of the bride and a former minister at the Riverside Church in New York, performed the ceremony.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Detroit Grand Prix. The race, America's only stop on the 1985 Formula I Grand Prix circuit, winds through the streets of downtown Detroit. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Baseball Mets vs. Montreal Expos, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.). Yankees vs. Tigers, at Detroit, 1:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.). Football Generals vs. Birmingham Stallions, at Giants Stadium, 2:30 P.M. Regular-season finale for both teams and battle for first place in the East. (Television -Channel 7, 2:30 P.M Radio - WMCA 570, 2:30 P.M.). Golf Georgia Pacific Atlanta Classic, at Marietta, Ga., final round (Television -Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.). PGA Senior Tournament Players Championship, at Cleveland, final round. PGA Mayflower Classic, at Indianapolis. Final round (Television - ESPN 3 P.M.). Women's Amateur Public Links Championships, at Flanders Valley golf club, Flanders, N.J., final day. Track and Field Fourth annual Kelly Games, at Mt. St. Michael Academy, Murdock and Nereid Avenues, the Bronx, 9:30 A.M. The competition begins with a 10-kilometer (6.2 mile) race through the streets of the Northeast Bronx. Eamonn Coghlan, the indoor mile record holder who has been out of action with shin splints all spring, has agreed to skip the Footlocker games in Berkeley, Calif. and run the mile here. Over all, 400 competitors are expected, with proceeds going to the Minor Board of the Gaelic Athletic Association.

title: RIGHT USE OF REPLACEMENTS
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SUMMER PROGRAM FOR GIFTED
description: ''IT is my dream - my dream come true.'' That is how Carole B. Berman describes her work as director of the Gifted and Talented Development Center Inc. of Bronxville.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: SIMPLE TASKS THAT GIVE PLEASURE
description: I was glad to read Carl A. Vigeland's essay ''A Mower of Lawns'' (About Men, May 19). For years I have felt, from my female perspective, that simple tasks giving pleasure were allotted more to women in our society than to men.

title: FROM THE GROUND UP, AND UP
description: THE TALL BUILDING ARTISTICALLY RECONSIDERED The Search for a Skyscraper Style. By Ada Louise Huxtable. Illustrated. 128 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $21.95.

title: World's Fairs
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about a ruling by the New York Court of Appeals that denied damages to the mother of a stillborn fetus for her emotional distress misstated the position taken by Judge Bernard S. Meyer. Judge Meyer concurred with the ruling, but not the reasoning adopted by a plurality of the court.

title: WHY O'NEILL IS GETTING $1 MILLION FOR HIS THOUGHTS
description: The publishing industry's appetite for the ''big book'' has always been hearty, but recently it has become voracious. Early this month, Random House agreed to pay more than $1 million for the rights to the autobiography of House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill, Jr. Simon & Schuster topped several other interested publishers with a bid of $900,000 for a book by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the former United States ambassador to the United Nations. And Bantam bid more than $1 million to win a book by Geraldine Ferraro, the Democrats' 1984 candidate for vice president.

title: GIANT GARAGE SALE
description: Fund-raising appeals for the expansion of the Mamaroneck Library and Emelin Theater Center have now gone out to the entire community, its organizers say. On Saturday and next Sunday (10 A.M. to 4 P.M. both days) the Great Community Garage Sale will be held on the grounds of the Mamaroneck High School to benefit the fund.

title: INNOVATIONS ABOUND AMONG COMPACT DISK PLAYERS
description: Unabated interest in compact disks prompts an ever-growing number of audio manufacturers to launch their own brand of CD players. For the most part, the many new models sounding off at the Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago earlier this month were essentially imitations of one another. Considering the uniformly high standard of performance, there's nothing wrong with that. However, several entries stood out by their distinctive design and attracted considerable attention as a result.

title: MONEY-LAUNDERING BILL SEEN AS PRIVACY THREAT
description: In an effort to expose criminals' financial activities, the Reagan Administration has proposed legislation that is drawing opposition from a variety of business, legal and civil liberties groups over its implications for personal privacy.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;

THE CLASSES AND THE MASSES
description: Good photographs can do for social history what television does for current affairs. Visual evidence greatly amplifies the message of even the most thorough and vivid writing: to see is suddenly to believe.

title: FILM OF PRAISE BUILDS LEGEND ON ANDROPOV
description: The legend of Yuri V. Andropov has gained in depth with a new documentary film that portrays him as, among other things, a man who had a fine singing voice and wrote love poems to his wife.

title: HOW TO STAY ON TOP OF REPAIRS TO THE ROOF
description: A GOOD asphalt shingle roof should last anywhere from 20 to 25 years on most houses, but any roof that is more than about 10 or 15 years old should be inspected at least once a year.
