This is a good time of year to do this - after winter storms have passed and before it gets too hot to be able to work on the roof with reasonable comfort and safety.

title: IT'S TIME FOR ACTION TO GUARANTEE ENERGY FOR THE FUTURE
description: Long Island has a lot going for it.

title: MISS GORDON WED TO R. J. AUGUSTUS
description: Leslie Mason Gordon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Emlen Gordon of Morristown, N.J., and Vero Beach, Fla., and Richard John Augustus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony John Augustus of Stamford, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. George E. Chorba 3d performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New Vernon, N.J.

title: BANK IN CHINATOWN CLOSED BY FEDERAL OFFICIALS
description: The Golden Pacific National Bank, a commercial bank based in Chinatown, was declared insolvent and was closed late Friday by the Controller of the Currency after ''irregularities'' were discovered, a Federal banking official said last night.

title:
RESPONDING IN LEBANON AND ELSEWHERE;

BE READY TO FIGHT
description: It should come as no surprise that the United States continues to be attacked by international terrorists. Nor should we marvel at the growing tempo of attacks. We can expect that tempo to continue to increase until and unless the terrorists are shown that the benefits derived from attacking us are slim, and the costs are high.

title: JOHN T. SULLIVAN WED TO ANNE MCCLELLAND
description: St. James' Episcopal Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Anne Henley McClelland and John Thielen Sullivan, both lawyers. The Rev. John Crocker performed the ceremony.

title: SO LONG, RALPH AND ED, HELLO, ''IZZY AND MOE''
description: ''Mel! Mel!''

title: N.B.A. EXECUTIVES DISCUSS NETS' CASE
description: Last Thursday afternoon, Lewis Schaffel, the Nets' chief operating officer, was singing as he walked through the hallways of Byrne Meadowlands Arena, where the team has its offices.

title: TRACING THE ROOTS OF STATE'S OFFICIAL HERO
description: NOW that Nathan Hale is the official hero of the State of Connecticut - Governor O'Neill signed the proclamation into law June 6 - more people will be searching out his roots. They will not lack places to look.

title: UAL ADDS HERTZ TO TRAVEL BUSINESS
description: UAL's purchase of Hertz from RCA was considered a canny step by some analysts, but others were more cautious. In buying the nation's leading car rental company for $587 million, UAL's chairman, Richard J. Ferris, added another travel-related business to United Airlines and hotel operations. The deal, and United's proposed acquisition of Pan Am's Pacific routes, lets UAL use some of its cash surplus. But some analysts say UAL is not concentrating enough on expanding its fleet of planes.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: THEY did it again to men at the Godmothers' fifth annual Baste 'n Broil at the Princess Restaurant in Lodi on June 14.

title: DEBATE ON WESPORT HOUSING
description: MAYOR William A. Collins of Norwalk, who contends that Westport is not doing its share in meeting Fairfield County's housing shortage, is planning a televised debate on the issue with a Westport Planning and Zoning Commission member.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: RANEY. By Clyde Edgerton. (Algonquin Books, $12.95.) When Raney Bell Shepherd, a Free Will Baptist from North Carolina and narrator of Clyde Edgerton's first novel, marries Charles Shepherd, a liberal Episcopalian from Atlanta, neither one is prepared for the compromise in store.

title: SIMPLE TASKS THAT GIVE PLEASURE
description: Mowing a lawn is indeed a lovely, even sensual, experience whose simple pleasures Mr. Vigeland captures. But he mows his lawn with a power mower that he concedes is too noisy.

title: THE GETTY MAKES ROOM FOR PHOTOGRAPHY
description: Dressed in a wool tweed sportscoat and purple bow tie, Weston Naef does not yet seem completely acclimatized to the sun-drenched, laid-back boulevards of Santa Monica. But he has other things on his mind these days than California's ambiance. As curator and caretaker of the photography collection of the world's most cash-rich museum, Mr. Naef is in the midst of organizing a department that will rival and possibly surpass those of the Museum of Modern Art, the Art Institute of Chicago and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Mr. Naef's own curatorial domain until last year. It is the opportunity of a curator's dreams, and the envy of most of the photography world.

title: STEEP DECLINE ENDS IN COSMOS' DEMISE
description: As recently as five years ago, the Cosmos played soccer in front of full stadiums around the country and around the world. But now, after one of the swiftest declines in American professional sports history, the team is finished, beset by financial problems and an inability to attract fans.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:In August I plan to take my granddaughters, aged 7 and 10, to Vancouver, Wash., and would like suggestions on what to see and where to stay. Do you suggest including Vancouver, Canada, on this trip? -R. S., Weston, Conn. Answer:The major sightseeing attraction in Vancouver, Wash. (which is connected to Portland, Ore., by a bridge across the Columbia River) is the Fort Vancouver National Historic Site. The 165-acre area includes the site of the Western headquarters depot of the Hudson's Bay Company and the partially reconstructed Fort Vancouver, once the military and trading base of the Pacific Northwest. The house of the factor, who was chief administrator for the company's western region, a bakery, kitchen, blacksmith's shop and Indian trade store have been reconstructed. The site, which also has a museum and program of tours and talks, is open daily from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is free; information: 206-696-7655. The Ulysses S. Grant House Museum (206-694-4002) contains Indian and military artifacts. (Grant was stationed in Vancouver in 1852-53.) It is open daily except Monday from 1 to 4 P.M.; admission is $1, for children aged 7 to 11, 50 cents.

title: 'COUNTRY GIRL' AND 'BABY' OPEN
description: CLIFFORD ODETS'S melodrama ''The Country Girl'' has always appealed to stage directors. Its story about a great actor fallen on hard times and alcoholism who is rescued from the edge of the gutter by a theatrical director who believes in the actor's talent seems to fulfill the need of theater people to believe their own backstage lore. To those not mesmerized by show business mythology, ''The Country Girl'' is an overwritten soap opera filled with unpleasant, self-centered characters.

title: WHAT HAPPENS IF WASHINGTON CHANGES THE RULES?
description: THE United States Conference of Mayors, made up of representatives of cities of at least 30,000 people, last week held its first gathering since President Reagan's submitted his 1986 budget and tax revision plans. The annual meeting, in Anchorage, ended with an unusual display of bipartisan unanimity: only one ''no'' vote was audible on a resolution urging Congress to amend the tax plan to keep deductibility of state and local taxes and the tax-exempt status of municipal bonds. John Herbers, a correspondent of The New York Times, talked with the mayors of six cities: Chandler, Ariz., in suburban Phoenix, San Francisco, Savannah, Ga., Scranton, Pa., Sunnyvale, Calif., a suburb of San Jose, and Tulsa, Okla. Excerpts from their discussions of the effect of the President's proposals follow. WHO SHOULD DEFINE THE PUBLIC PURPOSE? Terry Young: Tulsa, Okla.: Democrat The tendency with people in elected office such as myself is to go with the more popular issues in terms of voter support and not perhaps carefully examine the other components. We've been focusing on the state and local tax deduction issue. While that is important - to the taxpayers, to local governments to a lesser extent -the real problem we have in that tax reform package is the virtual elimination of tax-exempt revenue bonds.

title: NEW EFFORT TO REVAMP GOTHAM HOTEL
description: New efforts are under way to renovate Fifth Avenue's Gotham Hotel, an elegant Beaux-Arts structure that has been closed for more than four years.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HUMAN RIGHTS IN POST-MAO CHINA. By John F. Copper, Franz Michael and Yuan-li Wu. (Westview, Paper, $15.) When the Cultural Revolution ended with Mao Zedong's death in 1976, the new Chinese leadership began a modernization drive that has opened up a xenophobic nation to the West and introduced free markets into a backward economy.

title: Fighting Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: OLD HOPES FLOURISH IN DIM LIGHTS
description: JIM DESHAIES, the starter for the Columbus Clippers, had his good rising fastball, and on this night, at least, his infielders were remarkably superfluous. Besides striking out nine Richmond Braves, Deshaies forced all but four batters for the International League leaders to hit the ball in the air, leaving little for his infielders to do but catch pop-ups and take throws from the outfield.

title: A LANDLORD AND TENANT GUIDE
description: A 48-page handbook titled ''What Every Landlord and Tenant Should Know'' and produced by the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, a nonprofit, public-interest organization, has just been published. It is the fifth edition in a series that began 34 years ago.

title: 'DIM LUSTRE' DEPENDS UPON SUBTLETIES OF TUDOR'S STYLE
description: Antony Tudor's ''Dim Lustre'' received a dim revival by American Ballet Theater in its recent season at the Metropolitan Opera House and balletgoers immediately started pondering what had gone wrong. One of our century's greatest choreographers, the British-born Mr. Tudor has been associated with Ballet Theater since its first season. But because he is a painstaking craftsman, the Tudor repertory is not a large one, and any Tudor revival is eagerly awaited and carefully scrutinized.

title: NAVRATILOVA WINS FINAL IN ENGLAND
description: Martina Navratilova won the $175,000 Women's Grass Court tennis title today, easily beating Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 6-3, in a 69-minute match played in a swirling wind.

title:
ANTIQUES;

FESTIVAL TO CELEBRATE HACKENSACK RIVER
description: GONE from the Hackensack River basin and the Meadowlands are the marsh pirates who preyed upon merchants and travelers of old, among other things waylaying shipments of New Jersey cordwood destined for the fire grates of New York City.

title: HOSTAGES IN LEBANON: WHERE SAFETY IS TAKEN SERIOUSLY BETTER TECHNOLOGY OR BETTER TECHNICIANS?
description: The hijacking of a Trans World Airlines flight by terrorists who boarded at the Athens airport has prompted complaints by Greek officials and others that the technology of airport security needs improvement. Most experts, however, say they believe existing security devices are fairly effective; their main shortcomings are their human operators.

title: Budget, Tax Plans Mark Time
description: As the week opened, Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, issued the by now familiar warning, this time before a dinner of the New Hampshire Association of Commerce and Industry. ''The longer the budget is delayed,'' the majority leader said in Nashua, N.H., ''the less chance there will be to accomplish tax reform or much else this year.'' But back in Washington, prospects for compromise between the House and the Senate on a blueprint for spending for 1986 made little or no progress. President Reagan's proposal for tax revision was having problems even among its supporters.

title: LIFTING PITCHERS: BASEBALL'S SECOND-GUESSING GAME
description: RICK SUTCLIFFE stood on the pitcher's mound at San Diego's Jack Murphy Stadium last October with a season hanging in the balance. His season had been remarkable: a 16-1 record for the Chicago Cubs after a midseason trade, a victory in the first game of the National League playoffs and a 3-2 lead over the Padres in the seventh inning of the fifth and final game.

title: CALANDARS
description: Horse Shows Today - Glastonbury Equestrian Center, Glastonbury, Conn. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (203) 633-6216.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WINTER DOVES. By David Cook. (Overlook, $15.95). With the publication of ''Walter'' several years ago, the English novelist David Cook offered a piercing account of his retarded protagonist's efforts to make sense of senseless events - including the deaths of his parents and his own forcible institutionalization - as he grows into adulthood.

title: DAVID P. DUNNE WED TO MARGARET E. LEAHY
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y., yesterday, Margaret Ellen Leahy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Joseph Leahy of Yonkers, and David Patrick Dunne, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Dunne of Rye, were married by the Rev. Thomas F. Madden.

title: FAST-MEDICINE CENTERS RUN INTO TROUBLE
description: Along a commercial strip in East Meadow, L.I., the Taco Bell and the Friendly Ice Cream Shop have been joined by a doctors office. This kind of storefront medicine, offering quick care without appointments up to 16 hours a day, has sprouted across much of the country over the past three years. More than 2,300 such clinics are now operating on Main Streets and in shopping centers in the United States, according to an industry trade group. Many are owned by large health care chains.

title: BRAZILIANS STILL UNSURE SARNEY CAN DO THE JOB
description: Two months after the death of Brazil's immensely popular President-elect, Tancredo Neves, his name is barely mentioned in public. Yet, as his successor comes under mounting criticism for lack of strong leadership, Mr. Neves's absence is increasingly being felt.

title: Salvador's War Claims Six U.S. Victims
description: The United States, distracted by the hostage drama in Lebanon, got a shocking reminder last week of its involvement in other danger spots. Six Americans - two businessmen and four marine guards at the American Embassy in San Salvador -were killed along with seven other people when gunmen opened fire on three outdoor cafes.

title: How Transit Lost $100 Million
description: Officials of the agency that operates New York City's subways and buses said last week that they had failed to collect, and may not be able to recover, as much as $100 million from the city, state and Federal Governments. The problem is sloppy bookkeeping: the Transit Authority is unable to document work performed by its employees.

title: A LOOK INSIDE BASEBALL'S CONTRACT NEGOTIATIONS; PLAYERS: 'THE TIME IS LATE
description: BASEBALL'S collective bargaining agreement between the Major League Baseball Players Association and the club owners expired last Dec. 31. Representatives of both sides in the ongoing negotiations were interviewed recently by editors and reporters of The New York Times about the issues and the possibility of another baseball strike. In 1981, the players struck for 50 days. Following are edited transcripts of the interviews.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: RANDOM HARVEST, by James Hilton. (Carroll & Graf, $4.50.) The title comes from World War I battlefield reports that ''bombs fell at random.'' One shell affected the memory of an English soldier, Charles Rainier, and the plot revolves around him and the two women he has married. In 1941 Rose Feld described the story as ''completely real and convincing.'' James Hilton (1900-1954) was also the author of ''Lost Horizon'' and ''Good-bye, Mr. Chips.'' A memorable screen adaptation of ''Random Harvest'' was made in 1942. WEAPONS AND HOPE, by Freeman Dyson. (Cornelia & Michael Bessie/Harper Colophon, $6.95.) ''Weapons and Hope'' is a layman's guide to the concepts and problems of nuclear deterrence. Our reviewer, Michael Howard, said it is ''excellent and talks a great deal of sense about that most misunderstood and complicated problem, arms races.'' Freeman Dyson, a physicist at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., urges nuclear disarmament on the military. NOP'S TRIALS, by Donald McCaig. (Warner, $3.95.) Last year our reviewer, Jack Sullivan, called ''Nop's Trials'' an adult novel for animal lovers and said it ''does justice to both its human and canine characters.'' The protagonist is Nop, a border collie, and the plot concerns his abduction by villainous rednecks and his rescue by the sheep farmer who owns him. Mr. Sullivan said Donald McCaig, ''himself a Virginia sheep farmer, writes with an authenticity and crispness that brings a surprising liveliness to the story.'' LONG TIME PASSING: Vietnam & the Haunted Generation, by Myra MacPherson.

title: 'RSEEDING' AN OLD PASTURE
description: A farm pastureland that dates from the 18th century is being turned into an 84-unit condominium town-house development on a 350-foot high hillside in the hamlet of Millwood in Westchester County.

title: BARBARA CANNON WEDS R. C. JONES
description: The marriage of Barbara Sherman Cannon, a bond market analyst at Salomon Brothers in New York, to Robert Carlisle Jones, an assistant vice president at Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York, took place yesterday. The Rev. Henry Gugino performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the Niagara University (N.Y.) Chapel.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WRITING OF WOMEN: Essays in a Renaissance. By Phyllis Rose. (Wesleyan University, $14.95.) In ''Woman of Letters'' Phyllis Rose probed the relationship between Virginia Woolf's stylistic experiments and her life, and in ''Parallel Lives'' she held that the ''scripts'' five Victorian marriages followed offer lessons to us today.

title: 2 NAVY INQUIRIES FAILED TO FAULT DOCTOR WHO WAS LATER DISMISSED
description: The top heart surgeon who was dismissed from the Navy's flagship hospital in Bethesda for incompetence in April was investigated at least twice in 1983 and was left undisturbed each time, the Navy acknowledged today.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HELMS AND HUNT: The North Carolina Senate Race, 1984. By William D. Snider. (University of North Carolina, Paper, $9.50.)

title: M. ELIZABETH HEATH WEDS
description: The marriage of M. Elisabeth Heath, a daughter of Mrs. Sherwood Orr Heath of Rumson, N.J., and the late Mr. Heath, to Craig Bryant Rich, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Harold Rich Jr. of Plandome, L.I., took place yesterday. The Rev. George Willis performed the ceremony at St. George's by the River Episcopal Church in Rumson.

title: BLIND TREASURER IS ISSUE IN MT. KISCO
description: THE request by Mount Kisco's treasurer, Carmen E. DeFrancesco, who is blind, to relinquish his duties as receiver of taxes has prompted a Village Trustee to call for his resignation. But the Mayor and the three other trustees have expressed their ''full confidence'' in Mr. DeFrancesco, who oversees investments of $14 million a year and a payroll for 90 employees.

title: TIME WELL SPENT
description: ONE OF THE most interesting experiments in my kitchen occurred recently after I spoke wishfully of a dish I had dined on many years ago while a student at a hotel school in Lausanne, Switzerland. It is a dish of classic French cookery called toulousaine. The filling for the dish is generally served in a baked puff-pastry shell, almost unquestionably the most difficult of all pastries to make; it is nearly impossible for an unskilled cook to create.

title: MISS LEBOUTILLIER IS MARRIED
description: At St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York yesterday Clelia LeBoutillier, a daughter of Mrs. G. Cheston Carey of Baltimore and Martin LeBoutillier of Lyme, Conn., was married to Thomas Elling Zacharias, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Elling Zacharias of Essex, Conn. The Rev. John Andrew officiated.

title:
WINE;

CHOOSING A BOTTLE TO MATCH THE CHEESE
description: SETTING out a platter of cheese and a bottle or two of wine simplifies home entertaining - particularly during summer months when most of us would rather spend our time outdoors than in the kitchen preparing hors d'oeuvres. However, matching today's popular cheeses and warm weather quaffs can be tricky, with results sometimes less than palate pleasing.

title: TWO ARE TIED IN ATLANTA GOLF
description: David Frost of South Africa fired an 8-under-par 64 and Danny Edwards birdied the final hole for a 68 to leave them tied for the lead after the third round of the $500,000 Georgia-Pacific Atlanta Golf Classic.

title: Housing 'Revival'
description: To the Editor:

title: THE PUBLIC AND PRIVATE JOE PAPP
description: PACING BACK AND FORTH IN HIS cluttered office, Joseph Papp lights up a Havana cigar and starts reciting some of the Duke's lines in ''Measure for Measure.'' Papp is directing a new production of the play - which this weekend kicks off the Shakespeare Festival's 30th summer season - and his set and costume meeting has soon turned into a one-man exercise in acting. Playing various characters, Papp roams about the room, punching the air for emphasis, pulling his jacket lapels up for effect. His intermittently interrupted monologue also bounds from subject to subject, as he expounds upon his concept of the play, sandwiching his opinions between puns, lengthy asides on the quality of sunlight in Brooklyn, sexual imagery in ''Henry IV,'' and maybe a few bars from ''Hallelujah, I'm a Bum'' or ''Brother, Can You Spare a Dime?''

title: MUSIC: NORFOLK CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL OPENS
description: NORFOLK, Conn., June 21 - Although it is technically celebrating its 45th anniversary this summer, the Norfolk Chamber Music Festival can trace its ancestry back to 1899, when invitational concerts began being held regularly in Whitehouse on the Battell estate.

title: CHILDREN'S NUCLEAR-WAR FEARS IN DISPUTE
description: Are children preoccupied with fears of nuclear war? Yes, according to several well-publicized studies. But lately, questions have been raised about some of those studies, and a dispute is brewing among social scientists, psychiatrists and psychologists over the methods of research behind the reports and the political uses to which they have been put.

title: NEWARK
description: WHEN John-Michael Caprio left Newark after graduating from Arts High School, he had no intention of returning to live in the city where he had grown up. But two years ago Mr. Caprio, now director of music for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, learned that the former Newark estate of Maria Jeritza, the late opera diva, was for sale. He could not resist coming back to look at it.

title: Laser Technique Clears Arteries
description: They're not about to trade in their scalpels, not yet anyway. But surgeons at the Texas Heart Institute said last week that they have been using lasers to help remove blockages from coronary arteries that can cause chest pain and heart attacks, and the results are promising. Dr. James Livesay, principal investigator for the Houston team, said the hand-held device has so far been used on six arteries in three patients undergoing bypass surgery.

title: CELEBRITIES TO JOIN LIBERTY FESTIVITIES
description: Buddy Ebsen, star of the former television series ''Barnaby Jones,'' also happens to be an avid sailor who once dreamed about boating in New York but never had the chance to do it. That is, until now. Ebsen, who will admit only to being more than 70 years old, is planning to sail Friday in the Dewar's Celebrity Regatta near Battery Park.

title: TEATIME: A BIT OF BRITAIN IN ARGENTINA
description: ''Under certain circumstances there are few hours in life more agreeable than the hour dedicated to the ceremony known as afternoon tea,'' Henry James wrote of the British custom in his novel ''The Portrait of a Lady.'' Luckily, the British carried the tradition to South America in the early 1800's when they came to build the railroads, and in Argentina not even the Falkland Islands war of 1982 has uprooted the practice.

title: Chemical Company Bombed in Brussels
description: A bomb damaged a building housing offices of the West German chemical company Bayer A.G. today, and a previously unknown environmentalist group said it had placed the bomb to protest the company's dumping of chemical waste in the North Sea.

title: WANT A SENSITIVE JOB?
description: Two of the most sensitive jobs in the Pentagon have been vacant for several months. They both involve supervising the cost of military procurement contracts, an activity that is now under the scrutiny of a new Presidential commission and is still a favorite subject for Congressional hearings.

title:
DINING OUT;

THE NOT-SO-MYSTERIOUS FAR EAST
description: WITH summer here and the accompanying desire for lighter dining, Oriental fare comes to mind. The two little restaurants reviewed today - one is Japanese and the other Vietnamese - offer a number of engaging dishes that are satisfying without being the least bit heavy (and at moderate prices).

title: Landlord's Lodgings
description: A Los Angeles municipal judge decided last week to make the punishment fit the crime: She sentenced a landlord to 30 days in jail and then ordered him to spend an additional 30 days living in one of his own rundown apartments. The landlord, Dr. Milton Avol, a neurosurgeon from Beverly Hills, was found guilty of having ignored a court order to improve conditions at two buildings he owns.

title: MISS CUSHING HAS WEDDING
description: Hilary Murray Cushing, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Murray Cushing of New York and Quoque, L.I., was married yesterday to John Douglas Block, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Block of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's parents in Quogue.

title: AUSTRALIAN WOMAN WRITERS
description: To the Editor:

title: TRUMBULL CARY IS MARRIED TO ELEANOR CUNNINGHAM
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill, Mass., yesterday Eleanor Lamont Cunningham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Cunningham Jr. of Brookline, Mass., was married to Trumbull Cary, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Cary of East Aurora, N.Y. The Rev. Donald G. Bitsburger performed the ceremony.

title: LAOTIAN REFUGEES CROWD THAI CAMP
description: More than 32,500 Laotians, most of whom fled across the Mekong River in the last year, are now crowded into a detention center in northeast Thailand that was built to house no more than 20,000.

title: FACING UP TO GERMANY'S PAST
description: BY MAY 8, 1945, THE DAY Nazi Germany capitulated, Richard Freiherr von Weizsacker, a 25-year-old Wehrmacht captain, had made it back to his grandmother's farm in southwest Germany. The war had profoundly affected the young baron. Nearly six years earlier, on the second day of Hitler's invasion of Poland, he had been 300 yards away when his older brother Heinrich was killed by a bullet that pierced his throat as he clambered over a railroad embankment. The 19-year-old Richard kept mournful watch over his brother's body that night.

title: Jazz
description: What kind of a big band plays music from El Salvador and Spanish Civil War songs alongside compositions by Carla Bley? The Liberation Music Orchestra, an all-star group first organized in the late 60's by the bassist Charlie Haden, in a gesture of musical solidarity with Third World struggles. Arrangements by Miss Bley and Mr. Haden embrace so many kinds of music that the Liberation Music Orchestra can sound like a European brass band, a Salvation Army street-corner combo, or a daredevil free-jazz band - sometimes all in the same selection.

title: Apt. Dept.
description: As usual, the lawmakers waited until the last minute to take up New York's basic rent-regulation laws, and as usual, they extended them for two more years. But Albany isn't finished with housing just yet.

title: A Ruling For The Over-60's
description: In a decision with broad implications for the enforcement of the Federal law against age discrimination, the Supreme Court ruled last week that airlines may not compel flight engineers to retire at age 60.

title: THE STURGGLE TO SAY GOODBYE
description: I NEVER knew it could hurt so much. I never knew there would be stores I could not enter, closets I could not open, foods I could not cook, scribbled notes I could not bear to read, photographs I would have to turn face down because their images - of a man and woman bursting with smiles on their wedding morning one far away October day - would make me weep. I never knew that the tears could come so hard that one could almost lose one's breath with crying, that crying could become another language, a language without syllables.

title:
ART;

THE AMERICAN CITY IN PRINTS, 1900 - 1950
description: A MEASURED and thoroughly enlightening survey of American prints from 1900 to 1950 will be on view at the Bergen Museum of Art and Science through July 7.

title: WHAT PROMPTED SPY ACCUSATIONS
description: If the story told by Barbara Walker is true, the inquiry that led to the arrest of John A. Walker Jr. for spying might not have begun but for a dispute one of their daughters had with her estranged husband over custody of a child.

title: CABLE TV
description: The film sleeper of the cable week is ''Fraulein Doktor'' (1969), a dazzling cat-and-mouse thriller of World War I spies and counterspies, due on Saturday at 3 P.M. on the USA channel. This is a strange but riveting movie -- a Yugoslav-Italian production in English topped by a roster of British players, with Suzy Kendall in the title role, Kenneth More, Capucine and Nigel Grees.

title: RACE ON AGAIN
description: The Belgian Grand Prix, postponed on June 2 because of deteriorating track conditions, has been rescheduled for Sept. 15, according to Bernie Ecclestone, president of the Formula One Constructors Association. Ecclestone made the announcement in Detroit on the eve the of the city's Grand Prix event.

title: Thailand Is Seeking a Place To Move 50,000 Cambodians
description: After a series of meetings this week, Thai officials and international aid organizations are still searching for a place to move more than 50,000 civilian followers of a Cambodian guerrilla army.

title: SOME STILL SEE HOPE FOR HUMAN RIGHTS
description: When the Western countries signed the Final Act of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe in 1975, they, in effect, traded recognition of Europe's postwar borders for a pledge that the Soviet Union and its allies would show more respect for individual rights.

title: INGENUITY
description: Neither of the two American entrants in the first of the three 1985 Interzonal Tournaments for world championship aspirants held in Tunis, Tunisia, was able to achieve one of the top four places that would have put them into the next step of qualifications. Yet Maxim Dlugy, a 19-year-old international master from Queens, and Nick DeFirmian, a 27-year-old international master from Oakland, Calif., turned in some outstanding individual performances.

title: No Headline
description: Grasshoppers and beetles, the scourge of farmers since biblical times, are chewing their way through some of the West's best crops for the second spring in a row, adding to the financial burdens of already struggling farmers.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS 'ESTABLISHMENT' FIRES BACK
description: Once again last week civil rights lobbyists put the Reagan Administration on the defensive as a Senate committee considered the nomination of William Bradford Reynolds to be Associate Attorney General.

title: SHOPPERS' HAUNTS AROUND THE WORLD
description: Many countries have their own version of the flea market. The goods and the language may differ but what most have in common are variety -from antiques to plain junk - bargain hunters, serious collectors and a certain amount of haggling.

title: SLAIN AMERICAN IN HONDURAS FOR 'ADVENTURE'
description: The brother of a Queens man slain by an Honduran Army patrol in a rugged border area of Honduras said yesterday that the man was neither a soldier of fortune nor a smuggler but was simply an expert welder who had probably been exploring the countryside.

title: HIGH SCHOOL GRADUATES FACE GENERALLY TIGHT JOB MARKET
description: A million high school graduates will hunt for permanent jobs in the next few months in a generally tight market, according to analysts.

title: FUSS WITHOUT FEAR
description: DR. HAROLD J. Liverworth, world's foremost authority, has comforting news for fussy men. In his new book, ''Fuss Without Fear,'' the doctor urges such men to ''fuss to their hearts' content'' and ignore ''so-called scientific studies'' suggesting that fussiness shortens life expectancy, spoils outdoor picnics and reduces the amount of time spent watching television.

title: FRIENDS CALL PILOT IN HIJACKING A MAN OF DEEP FAITH
description: For several days now a sign beside a store here has urged: ''Pray for John.'' And today many did here in the hometown of John L. Testrake, the pilot of flight 847.

title: AMEX 1ST IN O-T-C OPTIONS
description: The American Stock Exchange has left the New York Stock Exchange, the Chicago Board Options Exchange and the rest of the pack far behind in the three-week-old race to trade options on over-the-counter stocks.

title: Colombia Rebels Kill 6 Police
description: Colombian guerrillas killed six policemen in an ambush in the western Valle del Cauca region, the police said here today. They said nine other policemen and three civilians were wounded in the attack Saturday night.

title: CORRECTION
description: An answer in the Saturday News Quiz incorrectly described the error that resulted in the failure of a space laser test. Ground controllers sent instructions to the shuttle Discovery in feet instead of nautical miles. A dispatch from Cape Canaveral in some copies last Thursday also misstated the error.

title: Foreign Banks in Japan
description: The Ministry of Finance accepted on Saturday the applications of nine foreign banks to open trust banking businesses in Japan. The foreign banks involved are Citibank, Chase Manhattan, Manufacturers Hanover, Morgan Guaranty Trust, Chemical Bank; Bankers Trust, Credit Suisse, Bank of Switzerland and Barclays Bank.

title: IVORY TOWER RUMBLINGS
description: LAST week, college presidents meeting in New Orleans decided for perhaps the first time in history that college athletics are too important to be left to the college athletic departments.

title: ...BUT BELL'S CHAIRMAN FIGHTS FOR INDEPENDENCE
description: After 12 years as chairman of Arthur Bell & Sons P.L.C., the Scotch whisky concern, Raymond Miquel has come to value his independence. He says the possibility of forsaking his leadership to Ernest W. Saunders, chief executive of Arthur Guinness & Son P.L.C., is out of the question. ''I personally would find it impossible to work under the Guinness regime,'' he said in London.

title: AIRLINER DISASTERS: HISTORY'S WORST
description: June 23, 1985: An Air-India Boeing 747 plunges into the sea off the Irish coast, apparently killing all on board, and an Indian official attributed the crash to an explosion. Sept. 1, 1983: A Korean Air Lines 747 is shot down by a Soviet fighter after flying through Soviet airspace near Sakhalin Island. All 269 people aboard are killed. Dec. 1, 1981: A chartered Yugoslavian Inex-Adria Airways DC-9 slams into a fog-shrouded mountain near Ajaccio, Corsica, killing all 178 people on board. Aug. 19, 1980: Fire bursts out aboard a Saudi Arabian Airlines L-1011 Lockheed TriStar jet as it waits to taxi at Riyadh airport. All 301 people aboard are killed. Nov. 28, 1979: An Air Zealand DC-10 carrying 257 people on a sightseeing flight from Auckland to the South Pole, strikes Mount Erebus in Antarctica. There are no survivors. May 25, 1979: In the worst domestic air disaster, a Los Angeles-bound American Airlines DC-10 crashes shortly after takeoff from O'Hare International Airport in Chicago, killing all 272 aboard and two men on the ground. Nov. 15, 1978: A chartered DC-8 jetliner carrying Indonesian Moslems home from a pilgrimage to Mecca, Saudi Arabia, crashes outside the airport at Colombo, Sri Lanka, killing 183 of 259 passengers. Jan. 1, 1978: An Air-India 747 bound for the Middle East sheikdom of Dubai with 213 persons aboard explodes in the air and plunges into the sea less than two minutes after takeoff from Bombay.

title: A PERSONAL CRUSADE AGAINST PROSTITUTION
description: Kathleen Barry is a soft-spoken Brandeis University sociologist whose first concern as a feminist was rape - she was a co-author of the first Stop Rape Handbook in 1972. ''In those days,'' she said, ''I thought that nothing could be worse than rape.''

title: SAUDI ARABIA AND BAHRAIN DENOUNCE HIJACKING OF JET
description: Saudi Arabia and Bahrain today condemned the hijacking of the Trans World Airlines jetliner and the taking of hostages, bringing to at least eight the number of Arab governments that have denounced the hijacking.

title: Fatal Shooting By Officer Studied
description: Investigators are interviewing more than a dozen people who witnessed the fatal shooting of a Carteret man by a rookie policeman, the Middlesex County Prosecutor said today.

title: Bridge: Gracefully Conceding Defeat Can Sometimes Be a Mistake
description: Bridge players, like chess players, are expected to concede gracefully when defeat is inevitable. There is a point at which determination lapses into obstinacy, serving only to waste time and annoy the opponents.

title: Write Your Congressman - Carefully
description: Can citizens who write their Congressman to sound off be sued for libel? Yes, says the Supreme Court, and unanimously at that. It has ruled that a citizen exercising the constitutional right ''to petition the Government for the redress of grievances'' is just as vulnerable to a libel suit as a newspaper publisher or anyone else who expresses an opinion on a public issue.

title: ESTIMATES OF TAX IMPACT CHALLENGED
description: Influential members of Congress have begun to challenge the Reagan Administration's estimates of the effects of its tax revision plan and are calling some of the arguments used to defend the proposals inconsistent.

title: A SURGE OF SYMPATHY FOR JEWS IS SENSED IN POLAND
description: In Tarnogrod, a town that before the war was one of Poland's nearly 1,000 shtetls, or Jewish market villages, a small group of visitors from Israel, the United States and France gathered recently to hear hundreds of local schoolchildren, all gentiles, promise to look after the recently discovered common grave of the more than 2,500 Jews shot there by the Nazis in 1942.

title: The Worm and the Apple;   Central, But Not Grand Bus Unstop
description: Picture yourself, a stranger in town, emerging from the 42d Street exit of Grand Central Station. You want to find the crosstown bus.

title: Canadian Sales Off
description: Canadian seasonally adjusted retail sales fell 1 percent in April, to $10.46 billion, after a 3.4 percent increase in March, the Government agency Statistics Canada said Friday.

title: WHY, FOR EVERYONE'S SAKE, WE NEED OUR WILDERNESS
description: To the Editor:

title: PADRES TOP GIANTS AS BEVACQUA HITS 2D GRAND SLAM OF YEAR
description: Kurt Bevacqua hit his second grand slam of the season - only his second home run this year - as the Padres defeated the San Francisco Giants, 6-1, today.

title: Concerned Scientists No 'Small Minority'
description: To the Editor:

title: Khomeini Said to Shift Gulf War Tactics
description: In a major strategy change, the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini has ordered Iranian forces to use ''defensive'' guerrilla tactics in the war with Iraq, an Iranian official says.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: MONDAY, JUNE 24, 1985

title: U.S. AVOIDING PUBLIC REACTION TO ISRAELI MOVE
description: Administration officials said today that in their private view the Israeli decision to release 31 Lebanese detainees might be helpful toward eventual freeing of the 40 American hostages.

title: JUMBO-JET CRASH MIGHT BE A FIRST
description: If, as most aircraft experts believe, the Air-India Boeing 747 that crashed in the Atlantic Ocean yesterday was downed by a bomb or other sabotage device, it would apparently be the first time a jumbo jet crashed for that reason.

title: ARTICLE LINKING POPE WITH LEFT AROUSES A FUROR
description: An article in the Zionist magazine Midstream that accuses Pope John Paul II of promoting Marxism and suggests his attempted assassination in 1982 was staged by the Soviet secret service to camouflage his leanings has caused a furor among members of the magazine's editorial board.

title: GUINNESS CHIEF SETS AGGRESSIVE BID...
description: Stout is not whisky, but Ernest W. Saunders believes that his experience in selling the dark, thick brew can be put to good use if his company, Arthur Guinness & Sons P.L.C., succeeds in its $425 million bid to take over Arthur Bell & Sons P.L.C. and its whisky operations.

title: MAY ORDERS UP 22% FOR MACHINE TOOLS
description: Orders for American-made machine tools increased 22 percent in May from the previous month and shipments rose 5 percent. The increases were paced by strong growth in the metal-cutting industry and offset by losses in the metal-forming machine tool sector, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association said in a report to be released today.

title: Gallup Poll Finds G.O.P. Backed in Big Problems
description: More Americans trust the Republicans than trust the Democrats to handle the nation's most important problem, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Oh Say Can You Sing
description: As everyone knows, the most difficult challenge in American sport is getting through the pre-game national anthem without tripping. Just trying to remember the words of ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' has done in a number of celebrity singers, and those who do manage to get the words right still have to deal with the tune.

title: SHIITE IS SAID TO OFFER TO SEND HOSTAGES TO SWITZERLAND IN EXCHANGE
description: The Swiss Government said today that Nabih Berri, the leader of the Lebanese Shiite militia Amal, had formally offered to send the American hostages in Beirut to Switzerland if the Lebanese prisoners held by Israel are released, as the Americans' captors are demanding.

title: BRUBECK REUNION STARS MEMBERS OF OLD GROUPS
description: IT was a night of musical reunions for Dave Brubeck Saturday at Avery Fisher Hall as part of the Kool Jazz Festival.

title: ASTRONAUTS HOLD NEWS CONFERENCE FROM THE SHUTTLE
description: Amid preparations for a return to earth Monday, the astronauts of Discovery held a televised news conference today in which they talked of wine, dreams and alien spacecraft, and took time to reflect on the Middle East hostages.

title: How the U.S. Should Handle Nicaragua
description: Once again, United States policy toward Nicaragua has failed at a critical juncture. Congress recently voted $27 million in ''humanitarian aid'' to the ''contras'' fighting the Sandinista regime. This will not end the conflict; it will only make matters worse.

title: Robin E. Cohen Weds Peter Thomas Shapiro
description: The marriage of Robin Ellen Cohen, an associate in the New York law firm of Kramer, Levin, Nessen, Kamin & Frankel, to Peter Thomas Shapiro, an associate in Rosenman Colin Freund Lewis & Cohen, New York lawyers, took place yesterday at Garvin's Restaurant in Greenwich Village. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony.

title: Why, for Everyone's Sake, We Need Our Wilderness
description: To the Editor:

title: Outstanding Schools Named
description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett has named 277 public and private secondary schools as models for the nation.

title: House Wants an Alternative To Dismantling a Submarine
description: The House voted Friday to tell President Reagan to look at other possible uses for a Poseidon submarine instead of dismantling it in order to comply with the strategic arms limitations treaty of 1979, which has not been ratified.

title: PALESTINIANS IN SETTLEMENTS BITTER AT SYRIA'S ROLE
description: A thin shaft of sun from the shell hole threw just enough light to show the dark stain where the blood of 16-year-old Maha Lazziz was spread over the wall of what had been her home.

title: BAXTER BID IS TERMED FRIENDLY
description: Baxter Travenol Laboratories will drop its $3.7 billion offer for the American Hospital Supply Corporation if that company's board of directors opposes the plan, a source close to the deal said yesterday.

title: CANNON SHELL SCORES UPSET
description: Cannon Shell, the longest shot in a field of six, got an easy early lead and lasted to win the $87,000 True North Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Fed Backs Barclays Unit
description: The Federal Reserve has approved a request by the BarclaysAmerican Corporation, a subsidiary of Barclays Bank P.L.C. of Britain, to establish a new bank in Wilmington, Del. The bank, which will be called Barclays Bank of Delaware, will be the company's first bank holding company and its ninth operating division in the United States.

title: Claudia Philippe Wed To H. Donald Rosen
description: Claudia Philippe and H. Donald Rosen were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Peter X. Sickinger in South Salem, N.Y. The Rev. Robert L. Rafford, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Nepal Bombings Protested
description: One-third of Nepal's elected lawmakers demanded today in Parliament that the Government resign ''on moral grounds'' for not preventing the terrorist bomb blasts that killed seven people in Nepal. More than three dozen legislators in the Parliament, which is not divided by party, called on Prime Minister Lokendra Bahadur and his 24-member Council of Ministers to quit for not safeguarding the people.

title: Prof. Ted L. Stein Dies at 32; Aided Case on Iran Hostages
description: Ted Stein, a professor at the University of Washington School of Law, died June 12 in a fishing accident in northern Oregon. He was 32 years old and lived in Seattle.

title: Jersey Girl Shot; Brother Sought
description: A 17-year-old youth was wanted for questioning today in the shooting of his 12-year-old sister and the attempted strangling of his 18-year-old sister, the police said.

title: Eagles as Pets
description: To the Editor:

title: SPECIAL LOOKS AT NANCY REAGAN AND HER POWER
description: WHO is Nancy Reagan?

title: Franklin Library
description: BBDO Direct has become agency for Franklin Library, a division of the Franklin Mint that markets six series of books. It previously did its advertising in-house and expects to spend $5 million through BBDO Direct during the coming year. Franklin Mint is a subsidiary of American Protection Industries.

title: EXCERPTS FROM TALK WITH SHULTZ
description: Following are excerpts from Secretary of State George P. Shultz's interview on the ABC News program ''This Week,'' as recorded by The New York Times:

title: A GRIM NIGHT AT A HOSPITAL ON THE IRISH COAST
description: The bodies of passengers and crew members from Air-India Flight 182 began arriving here early Sunday afternoon in a wave of helicopters. By the time the 25th settled onto the damp airport tarmac a little after 10:30 P.M., a routine had been established.

title: CONFLICT INVESTIGATION SOUGHT
description: After years of accusing his main rivals in promotion of having hidden managerial control of fighters, Bob Arum has admitted that one of his company's officers, Akbar Muhammad, has had a percentage of the earnings of Donald Curry.

title: 12,000 RALLY FOR MUGABE IN ZIMBABWE
description: About 12,000 chanting supporters of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe came out today to demonstrate support for their candidate as Zimbabwe prepares for its first elections since 1980.

title: MORE GREEDOM EXPECTED FOR STATE U.
description: A bill relaxing the state government's tight control over the State University is expected to be enacted as the Legislature tries to wrap up its work for the summer this week.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Was Alvin Crowder, the former Washington Senators' pitcher, ever elected to the Hall of Fame? What were his best seasons in the majors and did he ever win a World Series game?

title: 8 Eaglets in Nesting Project Arrive at Massachusetts Site
description: Eight young American bald eagles have arrived at the Quabbin Reservoir from Canada as part of a five-year project aimed at restoring the birds to Massachusetts.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 24, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Information meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Vienna Airport Is Sealed Off For 50 Minutes After Threat
description: Vienna's international airport at Schwechat, just outside the Austrian capital, was sealed off for 50 minutes today after a bomb threat, the police said.

title: Oslo Shuts Mission in Beirut
description: The Norwegian Embassy in Beirut, Lebanon, has been closed because of unsafe conditions in the ravaged city, the Foreign Ministry announced today. A press spokesman said the staff of two had been evacuated to Damascus, Syria.

title: CAPITAL COSTS AND TAX PLAN
description: TO fend off corporate critics of the President's tax plan, Administration economists are polishing up an analysis of the plan's effect on the cost of capital for company investments. The study, though incomplete by the weekend, finds that all industries would do better than they do now.

title: FORD HANGS ON AILING ARGEnTINA
description: As one of the oldest operating American companies in Argentina, and the only remaining United States auto maker here, Ford Motor Argentina S.A. has always been a hallmark of stability in the difficult Argentine economy. But, inflation, labor troubles, financing costs and the market's unpredictability have shaken its standing as the industry leader.

title: INDIA ORDERS CRASH INQUIRY AS KIN MOURN VICTIMS
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi ordered a judicial inquiry today into the crash of the Air-India jetliner as relatives and friends of the victims mourned.

title: Reactor at Sacramento Reports Water Leak
description: Operators of the Rancho Seco nuclear power plant reported a leak of radioactive water today from a pipe connecting one of two steam generators inside the reactor building.

title: VIDEO CAMERAS RECORD TRADITIONS IN NEW WAY
description: At William L. Dickinson High School in Jersey City, student activities are being recorded with a video camera for what is to become a ''yearbook'' for the senior class.

title: General Foods Denies Rumors
description: Officials of the General Foods Corporation denied again yesterday that the company had been involved in merger talks with Philip Morris Inc. or any other companies. The food and packaged goods company also said it had not been approached by anyone and that it had no statement to make.

title: BIG LIST OF NEW TREASURY ISSUES
description: The Treasury is coming to market this week with a heavy load of securities. In its mini-refunding, the Treasury will sell $6.5 billion of 4-year notes on Tuesday, $6 billion of 7-year notes on Wednesday and $4.5 billion of 20-year bonds on Thursday. This will raise $13.88 billion in new cash.

title: EXPOS WIN ON METS' MISCUES
description: The Mets were grudging in their assessment of the Montreal Expos yesterday, but the team that was a popular choice to finish last has established itself as a threat to win the division title the Mets covet.

title: BRYANT AND HARVIN LEAD STARS, 38-10
description: Kelvin Bryant and Allen Harvin each scored twice today to lead the Baltimore Stars to a 38-10 regular season-ending United States Football League victory over the Tampa Bay Bandits.

title: YANKS MULLED WIGGINS DEAL FOR RANDOLPH
description: IN announcing the Yankees' drug-abuse program for their minor league teams early this season, George Steinbrenner spoke sternly about how players with drug problems ''won't be tolerated on this team either. We know of a few in the past.'' And yet the Yankees' principal owner recently ignored his principle. He considered trading Willie Randolph to the San Diego Padres for Alan Wiggins, who had cocaine-related problems again early this season after a cocaine-possession arrest nearly three years ago.

title: Oklahoma Bank Failure
description: A spokesman for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said the loans and $84 million in deposits of the First City Bank N.A., Oklahoma City, which failed on Friday, would be assumed by City Bank and Trust of Oklahoma City, a newly chartered institution. In a statement issued Friday, the F.D.I.C. blamed the failure on deposit brokers taking advantage of the bank's high interest rates. The insuring agency said it had advanced $56.9 million to City Bank and Trust in the deal.

title: A Tall Price in Bid For the Coliseum Site
description: Although plans to build the world's tallest skyscraper on Columbus Circle have been shelved, the redevelopment of the New York Coliseum site still inspires astonishment.

title: Catching Up
description: Last July, Malcolm Scott, a second-year tight end, was waived by the Giants for ''inability to adhere to team and club policies,'' the definitinon of which was: failure to rehabilitate himself after completing a program for drug use. Scott has not played a single down of pro football since, which, given the circumstances of his departure from the Meadowlands, is no great surprise.

title: The Worm and the Apple;   Central, But Not Grand Signs to Squint At
description: The big departure board above the ticket windows in Grand Central Station still works, and so do the loudspeakers. Even so, Metro North recently augmented its train announcement system with new signs.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Beneficial Corp., a Wilmington, Del., financial services holding company, has elected to its board Dr. Susan Wachter, associate professor of finance at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Study Says Seat Belts Reduce Hospital Costs
description: Average medical costs for passengers involved in automobile accidents while not wearing seat belts are twice as high as for those who remembered to buckle up, according to a study released last week.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, JUNE 24, 1985

title: Subway Consultants Do Engineers' Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: HEIEN TAKES CYCLING TITLE
description: His skates are in the closet, but Eric Heiden is still sprinting to victory.

title: GANNETT REVAMPS SUNDAY SUPPLEMENT
description: Since late February, when the Gannett Company bought Family Weekly, industry observers have been waiting to see what Gannett would do with the Sunday newspaper magazine, whose circulation ranks second behind Parade.

title: HENDERSON IS IN A GROOVE AFTER A DIFFICULT START
description: IN Oakland, where he played for six glorious seasons, he was loved for his riveting style of play and his infectious smile.

title: Failed Bank's Officer Held
description: An officer of the failed Strong's Bank of Dodgeville has been charged with writing a $2.6 million check against an account that held only $200.

title: Marketing Push
description: Bill Rosenberg, chairman emeritus of Dunkin' Donuts and a heavy investor in standardbred horses, decided one day last year to look at the struggling harness-race business as if it were his successful pastry game. If the breeders were the doughmakers, the owners the distributors, and the tracks the retail outlets, why weren't trotting and pacing as hot as French crullers?

title: W. M'ILHENNY DIES, MAKER OF TABASCO
description: Walter Stauffer McIlhenny, patriarch of a Louisiana dynasty that has put Tabasco sauce on the world's tables for more than a century, died Saturday night at Lafayette General Hospital in Lafayette, La. Mr. McIlhenny, who had suffered a stroke on Wednesday, was 74 years old. He lived on the family's antebellum estate on Avery Island, in the bayou country of southern Louisiana.

title: People
description: Gerald Sherman, Murray Gaylord, William Tucker, Stuart Epstein and Philip Cohen, management supervisors, have been promoted to group senior vice president at Scali, McCabe, Sloves.

title: LUNDY SINGS WITH TRIO
description: The first concert in a series being presented by Soundscape as part of the Kool Jazz Festival in the atrium of St. Peter's Church on Friday was primarily notable for the manner in which the high, echo-filled atrium treated the two performing groups.

title: 68 Aliens Arrested in Florida
description: Border Patrol agents raided apartment complexes and trailer parks Friday and arrested at least 68 aliens, most of whom were in the area to work its vegetable fields, a Border Patrol official said. All but one of the aliens were thought to be Mexicans in this country illegally, said Marshall Metzgar, the chief patrol agent here.

title: ANALYSTS SEE HIGHER DOW
description: WITH the economy finally showing signs of improvement, the investment community is busily devising scenarios to take advantage of a hoped-for revival in the stock market.

title: U.S. Continues Study Of a Chinatown Bank
description: An investigation of the Golden Pacific National Bank in Chinatown, declared insolvent and ordered closed Friday night by the Federal Comptroller of the Currency, is ''still in its early stages,'' a Federal spokesman said yesterday.

title: BIG BAND AND DAVID MURRAY
description: THE BIG BAND, led by the tenor saxophonist David Murray, has made a mixed impression, both in occasional club appearances and on its new record. Though the performances were intermittently thrilling, some of the musicians did not seem very familiar with the scores, and the occasional episodes of inaccurate or sloppy playing kept Mr. Murray's dense scoring from coming through as clearly as it might.

title: Rebels Said to Attack Army Depot in Uganda
description: Government troops beat back a guerrilla attack today on an army depot near Jinja, Uganda's second-largest town, military sources there said.

title: The Basics Crumble
description: A case-hardened Washington baseball fan returned from a visit to Memorial Stadium in Baltimore the other evening, shaken and unsure that the nation's capital, still negotiating for a major league team, was ready for relations with the National Pastime at all. Through the stands, as the Orioles were losing to the Yankees, strode a vendor hawking ''chilled white wine, vino blanco d'Italia.'' What, the visitor wondered, would H. L. Mencken have said to that?

title: Bhopal Talks Impasse Seen
description: Face-to-face negotiations on compensating victims of last December's gas leak disaster in Bhopal, India, ended after one short meeting on Monday, and no further talks are planned, sources close to the case said last week.

title: No Headline
description: Miss Lowenstein Wed To Warren H. Feder

title: SENIOR WEEKS ARE PARTY TIME ON THE JERSEY SHORE
description: There had been many special moments for Jackie West during her high school senior week at the Rosemont Hotel here.

title: SEXUAL HARASSMENT CASE NEARS TRIAL
description: A lawsuit accusing a former ABC official of sexual harassment is scheduled to go to trial Friday in Federal District Court in Washington.

title: Pornography Gets a Break in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: GENERALS LOSE BID FOR TITLE IN EAST
description: The Generals lost their final game of the regular season today, 14-6, as the Birmingham Stallions kept Herschel Walker under 100 yards and came away with the Eastern Conference title.

title: Turkish Cypriots Hold Parliamentary Vote
description: Turkish Cypriots voted in parliamentary elections today in a further attempt to consolidate their republic in northern Cyprus.

title: CHINA'S AIRCRAFT MARKET
description: China's move to deregulate its civil aviation system has created a potentially vast market for foreign aircraft manufacturers, including Boeing and McDonnell Douglas.

title: Emily F. Rubin and Chris Jennewein Are Married
description: Emily Farber Rubin, who received an M.B.A. degree this month from Dartmouth College's Amos Tuck School of Business Administration, and James Christopher Jennewein, assistant managing editor for features of The Atlanta Journal and The Atlanta Constitution, were married in Washington yesterday. Rabbi Harold White performed the ceremony at the Regent.

title: Abortion for Rape Victim Again Sought by Parents
description: The parents of a brain-damaged invalid who was raped 20 weeks ago prepared today to move their daughter to a hospital in hopes a doctor there would perform an abortion, their attorney said.

title: E.E.C. Jobless Drop
description: Unemployment in the European Economic Community fell to 10.9 percent of the work force in May from 11.2 percent the month before, the community's statistics office said Friday. The number of people listed as out of work dropped to 12.3 million, from 12.6 million in April.

title: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH LEADER OF SHIITE MILITIA
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Nabih Berri, the leader of the Shiite Moslem movement Amal, on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press,'' as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: EXCERPTS FROM AN INTERVIEW WITH RABIN
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation,'' as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Ratings Stable For Latin Debt
description: When Federal bank regulators met in Washington 10 days ago, they chose not to downgrade the debt of either Peru or Argentina, according to people close to their deliberations.

title: GETTY GIFT BRINGS JOY TO BRITAIN'S NATIONAL GALLERY
description: It is a common fantasy that the J. Paul Getty Museum in California has untold millions to spend every year on works of art, is both rapacious and piratical in its ways, and is particularly set upon taking over the ancestral collections of Britain. Every day of the week - so the scenario goes -someone from the Getty calls upon a disconcerted duke and makes him an offer he cannot refuse.

title: Japan Cabinet For Tariff Cuts
description: The Cabinet of Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone recommended across-the-board 20 percent tariff cuts Friday on 2,400 agricultural and industrial items as part of the Government's ''action program,'' a package aimed at rectifying Japan's huge trade surpluses.

title: Some Hard-to-Hear Shouts
description: As the M-104 bus reached the intersection of Broadway and 97th Street, Alison Goldstein, a computer consultant, watched as a little boy was scanning the passing scene from his seat.

title: What? Refuse a Subsidy Payback?
description: For American taxpayers, it ought to be the deal of the year. The owners of some big oil tankers built with $300 million in Government subsidies are trying eagerly to give the money back. The Reagan Administration is eager to accept it, and both Senate and House budget committees are counting on receipt of the money.

title: T.W.A.'S BRIEF, FUTILE BATTLE
description: The full-page advertisement that Trans World Airlines ran as an ''open letter to Carl Icahn'' sounded like fighting words. Mr. Icahn had accumulated 25 percent of the airline's stock. ''If you thought we'd just stand by and do nothing while you try to take over our company,'' T.W.A. warned, ''think again!''

title: PYGMY CHIMP READILY LEARNS LANGUAGE SKILL
description: A 4-year-old pygmy chimpanzee at a research center near Atlanta has demonstrated what scientists say are the most humanlike linguistic skills ever documented in another animal.

title: 150,000 See Brazil Qualify
description: Brazil qualified for the World Cup in Mexico next summer after it played Paraguay to a 1-1 deadlock yesterday in before a crowd of 150,000 in Rio de Janeiro's famed Maracana Stadium.

title: DISABLED AND ABLE CHILDREN
description: THE playground was in Queens. It was a hot, humid afternoon, but the international group of 19 planners, architects and designers didn't seem to notice as Roger Hart and two of his assistants guided them past the swings and seesaws. ''Bringing disabled and nondisabled children together in a play setting may result in a quality of contact that can't be achieved in other environments,'' he was saying.

title: SURGE IN NEAR COLLISIONS, ALOFT AND ON GROUND, WORRIES AIR SAFETY EXPERTS
description: Air-safety experts are worried by a recent surge in traffic problems, including a near-collision between two Eastern Airlines jets on Thursday and a runway collision in Birmingham, Ala., the same day in which the pilot of a small plane was killed.

title: Commercial Credit
description: The Commercial Credit Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Control Data Corporation, announced Friday that it would discontinue taking consumer deposits and close savings accounts in 12 of the 16 states in which it offers those services. The four states in which it will continue to offer the services are Ohio, Delaware, Maryland and Pennsylvania, according to a Control Data spokesman. The company said the action was part of a plan to scale back its involvement in consumer savings.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Looking at it from here, with trouble all over the world, not just the Middle East, it looks very strange as you see the boundaries and the border lines disappearing.

title: ITALY ELECTING PRESIDENT: MACHIAVELLI MEETS PIRANDELLO
description: Italy will elect a President on Monday in a vote that is expected to end the political career of one of its most popular postwar leaders, 88-year-old Sandro Pertini.

title: A Mobile Music Man
description: Of course, the West Side can always astonish. Sharing a tune by Madonna with the entire neighborhood, a young man made his way down Broadway on Saturday afternoon with not one box, but two.

title: SETTING THE STANDARD
description: IT would have been easier to accept the role of No. 2, to spend the rest of her career treated as the Queen Mother of tennis who still dominated most of the women on the tour. Chris Evert Lloyd had all the creature comforts - a home in Florida, another in London - and a handsome husband who elicits squeals from British schoolgirls. There were thoughts of starting a family. What was there to prove? Mrs. Lloyd had already earned her place among the all-time greats in a professional career that spanned 12 years and withstood the challenge of two generations of players. Some of her opponents were now half her age.

title: A SERVICE ECONOMY, THEY SAY
description: America, economists and others tell us, has become a ''service economy.'' I'm not sure what that means exactly. The phrase itself has become a cliche, but I wonder: Where is the service?

title: MILLER SETS RECORD FOR TOUR EARNINGS
description: Alice Miller won the Mayflower Classic by six shots today, claiming her fourth victory of the year and establishing a Ladies Professional Golf Association record for earnings in a season.

title: SAN FRANCISCO DEBATES LIMITING OFFICE TOWERS
description: The San Francisco Board of Supervisors is scheduled to vote on a zoning plan Monday afternoon that has been heralded as determining the shape of downtown San Francisco for decades to come.

title: Investors Unsure of Outlook
description: The credit markets went on a roller-coaster ride last week that has dumped them, slightly dizzy, at the start of what promises to be another difficult week, according to a number of market analysts.

title: THE VIOLENT COAL STRIKE
description: The bitter, violent strike being waged by the United Mine Workers of America against the A. T. Massey Coal Company and Massey subsidiaries in this area reveals much about labor relations and the nation: How hard men will fight for jobs and how hard others will fight to take them, the change taking place in many industries, how violent this country can be and how violence is still used in labor-management relations in this country.

title: A 1794 Ship's Passport Ends Up in Washington
description: From Washington's office to an office in Washington: the slightly unlikely story of a 190-year-old ship's passport that seems to have spent most of its existence tucked away in a cabinet.

title: Lawyers Consider Discipline Changes
description: The policy committee of the State Bar Association this weekend adopted several recommendations on how lawyers are disciplined, but refused to open disciplinary meetings to the public, officials said.

title: Elizabeth Ann Greitzer Married to Jeff Durrell
description: The Governor's Room at City Hall was the setting yesterday for the wedding ceremony of Elizabeth Ann Greitzer and John Jeffrey Durrell. Associate Justice Leonard Sandler of the Appelate Division, First Department, New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: A Money-Minded Chicken
description: Farther down the West Side, a giant chicken was handing out fliers in front of the Bojangles restaurant at 23d Street and Seventh Avenue.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: BEHIND D'ARCY'S BENTON TIE
description: THE events that led up to the agreement for the largest merger in agency history began last March when a mutual friend brought together John S. Bowen, chairman and chief executive of Benton & Bowles, and Hal Bay, chairman and chief executive of D'Arcy MacManus Masius.

title: 1 MAN DROWNS
description: A storm on Lake Erie Saturday caused the drowning of a fisherman and cast two girls adrift in a rubber raft for 16 hours before they were rescued today, the authorities said.

title: New Accountant
description: A one-time newspaper reporter, Morrie Helitzer, is now publisher and editor in chief of New Accountant, a magazine for professionals that is due out in September and then will publish six times a year during the school year. Based on a controlled circulation of 50,000, the advertising rates have been set at $2,750 for a black and white page and $3,550 for a four-color. Mr. Helitzer's new office is at 33 Village Square, Glen Cove, L.I.

title: U.S. PUZZLED BY WHITWORTH FINANCES
description: The charge that Jerry A. Whitworth earned hundreds of thousands of dollars selling secrets to the Soviet Union raises a question that puzzles both his friends and Federal investigators: Where might the money have gone?

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 24, 1985:

title: CITY SERVICES FOUND IMPROVED
description: The Koch administration has improved the delivery of basic city services in the last four years, reversing the major declines caused by the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, according to a private study of municipal services released yesterday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: QUANTUM REALITY. Beyond the New Physics. By Dr. Nick Herbert. 268 pages. Anchor/Doubleday. $16.95.

title: 6th Cheese Is Recalled; Inquiry in Baby's Death
description: The Federal Food and Drug Administration and state health officials have recalled a sixth product made by a suburban cheese plant where faulty pasteurization equipment has been linked to 38 contamination deaths nationwide, the authorities said.

title: LLOYD REQUESTS 1-DAY DELAY
description: Chris Evert Lloyd, co-seeded as the No. 1 player in the women's draw, has requested a one-day postponement before playing her opening singles match at Wimbledon because of a stiff neck.

title: 4 Hurt as Jet Dives to Avoid Oncoming Plane in Michigan
description: An American Airlines jet with 70 people aboard dived to avoid an oncoming plane over Lake Michigan today, injuring three flight attendants and a passenger, officials said.

title: FUNK VAMPS BY MILES DAVIS SEPTET
description: MILES DAVIS has earned the right to play large parts of a concert with his back to the audience - as he did Friday night - and the remainder crouched and hidden, behind sunglasses and under a black hat.

title: Fed Said to Distress Sprinkel
description: Beryl W. Sprinkel has been singularly quiet since becoming chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, avoiding public appearances, speeches or interviews until he finishes assembling his staff. But Mr. Sprinkel, a monetarist, is distressed with the Federal Reserve Board's management of monetary policy, according to some of his friends in the Administration.

title: FLAMENCO OF PACO DE LUCIA
description: AN austere flamenco guitarist, a floridly virtuosic solo pianist and a jazz-fusion quartet - all sharing the same bill Saturday at Carnegie Hall - offered a portrait of Spanish jazz that could hardly have been more varied. Produced in cooperation with the Spanish Ministry of Culture, the program, ''Spanish Night,'' was headlined by the flamenco guitarist Paco de Lucia, who performed Andalusian gypsy music both solo and with his quintet.

title: Jody Isselbacher Wed to S. J. Coukos
description: Jody Frieda Isselbacher, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Kurt J. Isselbacher of Newton and Woods Hole, Mass., was married yesterday to Stephen John Coukos, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Coukos of Watertown, Mass. Judge Haskell C. Freedman, who is retired from the Middlesex Probate Court, performed the ceremony at the Harvard Club of Boston.

title: Joanna Beatty, Engineer, Wed to R.K. Maddock 3d
description: Joanna Beatty, a daughter of Dr. Edward Beatty and Carol Leedham Brennan of New York, and Robert Kent Maddock 3d, a son of Dr. Maddock Jr. and Jane Helm Maddock of Salt Lake City, were married yesterday at the Yale Club in Manhattan.

title: SHIITES, FAULTING ISRAEL, RULE OUT RELEASE NOW
description: A spokesman for the Shiite Moslem militia Amal said today that it had no plans to release any of the American hostages in response to Israel's decision to free 31 prisoners.

title: Needham Takeover
description: Needham Harper Worldwide will acquire Lane & Huff Advertising, San Diego, on July 1 and change its name to Needham Harper Worldwide, San Diego. That agency, with $10 million in billings, primarily from Home Federal Savings and Loan, will report to Gerrold E. Rubin, president of the Los Angeles office.

title: Account
description: Loctite Corp. to Fahlgren & Swink, Cleveland, for its chemical adhesive and sealant products.

title: WORRISOME BANK OBLIGATIONS
description: The nation's 15 largest banks have accumulated almost a trillion dollars in liabilities - obligations such as bank-issued guarantees, and commitments to make loans and purchase foreign exchange - that do not show up on their balance sheets.

title: Great Lakes Water
description: To the Editor:

title: INCREASE IN YOUNG MEN'S SUICIDES AROUSES CONCERN OF HEALTH AIDES
description: A new Government study on suicide in America is making researchers wonder how to reach a new group of potential victims: men who are apparently healthy.

title: Speeding L.I. Boat Lands Atop a Car
description: A 39-foot motorboat traveling at high speed ran aground, jumped several feet into the air and landed on a car parked in the driveway of a Long Island home Saturday evening, the police said today.

title: Saatchi Purchase
description: Saatchi & Saatchi, the publicly held British agency with an acquisitive itch, has just announced its first purchase in Canada, Hayhurst Advertising, with about $66 million in billings in American dollars. The Canadian agency, with offices on Toronto, has among its clients Chesebrough-Pond's, Nabisco Brands and Nestle. It has had an affiliation with the New York-based Saatchi & Saatchi, Compton, for the last six years.

title: TIGERS SILENCE YANKEES
description: One day, Frank Tanana was laboring for a last-place team. The next, he was thrust into the middle of a pennant race. Don Mattingly says that can make a difference in a man.

title: BOMB IS SUSPECTED AS CAUSE
description: An Air-India Boeing 747 plunged into the sea off the Irish coast today, apparently killing all 329 people on board, and an Indian official said an explosion was believed to have caused the crash.

title: LARGEST RAILROAD UNION REACHES A TENTATIVE PACT
description: The nation's railroads have reached a tentative agreement with the largest railroad union, which promised increased productivity in exchange for a salary increase.

title: ROSBERG OF FINLAND WINS DETROIT PRIX
description: Keke Rosberg of Finland, overcoming an unscheduled stop 14 laps from the finish, drove a Honda-powered Williams through the downtown streets to a solid victory in the Detroit Grand Prix today.

title: SPANISH SAY THEY PLAN TO STAY TOUGH
description: Spanish officials say the Beirut hostage crisis has frustrated Madrid's diplomacy in the Middle East and complicated the handling of Basque terrorism at home.

title: CASH CROP SUPPLANTS MOONSHINE
description: The deep foliage, lush hills and remote valleys of southern West Virginia for decades concealed the illegal activities of backwoods moonshiners.

title: G.O.P. PRESIDENTIAL POSSIBILITIES OFFER EARLY SHOW OF 1988 FORM
description: This was not exactly an early cattle show for the 1988 campaign, but Republican leaders from the Middle West had no trouble rounding up most of the expected Presidential contenders for a gathering here this weekend.

title: JOE PASS IS SURPRISE GUEST OF FITZGERALD AT CARNEGIE
description: WHEN Ella Fitzgerald was joined by the guitarist Joe Pass - a surprise guest at the singer's Carnegie Hall concert Friday night -one had the thrill of watching two supreme virtuosos engaging in an impromptu musical frolic that had the feel of two musicians falling in love. The pair, who have worked together extensively in recent years, make a wonderfully harmonious match.

title: Nicaragua Reports Clashes With Rebels
description: Fierce fighting between Government troops and United States-backed rebels in northern Nicaragua left 40 rebels and a Nicaraguan officer dead, the Defense Ministry said today.

title: A Detailed List
description: Federal law requires that nominees for ambassador submit to the Senate a list of all political contributions made in the previous four years by the proposed diplomat, his or her spouse, their children, parents, grandparents, brothers and sisters and all spouses of those relatives. The purpose is to put on the public record, before confirmation hearings, any evidence that the President's choice might have earned the nomination by helping finance the political career of the President or other candidates of his party.

title: N.A.A.C.P. HEAD ASSAILS CIVIL RIGHTS POLICIES
description: In his keynote speech tonight before the 76th annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Benjamin L. Hooks, the group's executive director, denounced the Reagan Administration's civil rights policies, but said that more than ''endless recrimination'' was needed to oppose those policies.

title: Judge Accused in Killing Of Wisconsin Lawyer
description: A judge has been charged with first-degree murder in the stabbing death of a lawyer on Saturday.

title: 2 WEEKS OF SCREENING, BUT NOT ONE JUROR IS SELECTED IN STEWART DEATH CASE
description: After two weeks of jury screening, not a single juror has been chosen in the trial of six transit police officers charged in the death of a Brooklyn art student after what prosecutors have described as a brutal police beating.

title: YOUNG AND GIFTED
description: How vividly I remember my days at the playground in grade school. I was known as ''El Stupido,'' and I used to crouch behind the garbage can to hide my shame. I was the teachers' woe, and was thought to be a lost cause. This went on until my parents transferred me from private school to a public school with an active child-study team.
