The psychologists discovered I was gifted, and so I moved from the ranks of the near-retarded to those of the highly regarded.

title: John Cone Dies at 77; Ex-Justice in New York
description: Justice John E. Cone, the former administrative judge of State Supreme Court in Kings and Richmond Counties, died Saturday of heart failure in New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 77 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Rumania's Trade Status
description: To hear Nicolae Gavrileseu, Rumania's new Ambassador to Washington, tell it, renewal of most-favored-nation trade status for his country is in grave doubt. To hear Congressional aides tell it, the Ambassador should relax.

title: MONTREAL PUBLISHER HAS MURDOCH-LIKE GOALS
description: Pierre Peladeau, publisher of Le Journal de Montreal, says his favorite writer is Honore de Balzac because of the way the 19th-century French novelist combined style, substance and sex appeal.

title: Dear Voter Name Here
description: One of the most burdensome jobs of members of Congress, providing ''constituent service'' or ''casework'' for the voters in the home district, may finally be moving into the Computer Age. A Norwalk, Conn., company called Aristotle Industries has developed a computer program designed to permit a conscientious representative to track every constituent request for help and its response as well as to identify voters in the home district with a personal interest in, say, Social Security or some other issue.

title: Recital: On Piano, Steven Glaser
description: THE pianist Steven Glaser, who made his New York debut at Merkin Concert Hall Thursday night, studied with the late Nadia Reisenberg at the Juilliard School. Mr. Glaser has many of his teacher's qualities: technical command, a piano tone that is brilliant but not ostentatious and a virtuosic, large-scaled and somewhat old-fashioned interpretation.

title: BLUE JAYS TOP RED SOX, 8-1, AMID BRAWL
description: Ernie Whitt hit his first career grand slam, and Rance Mulliniks had a two-run homer today as the Blue Jays routed the Boston Red Sox, 8-1, in a game marred by a brawl.

title: Activist Physicians
description: In an unusual mixture of therapy and politics, Physicians for Social Responsibility is going to follow up on a graphic television drama about nuclear war tonight by staffing telephone banks in three cities through which viewers may talk with doctors and psychiatrists about the program and the problem.

title: ROBERT McA. LLOYD
description: Robert McAllister Lloyd, former head of the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association, died at his home Friday after a long illness. He was 87 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Response to Terrorism
description: Terrorism is contagious. Now there is the lost Air India plane and the explosion in Tokyo airport to add to a single week's headlines about hostages in Beirut and the blast at Frankfurt. Apart from the obvious need to insist on observing security precautions, there is a need to fight this international epidemic. President Reagan said he will name a task force to make recommendations. What the U.S. decides to do, he said wisely, ''must not be done in pointless anger,'' though his press spokesman underlined the sobering effect by saying he ''could not rule out military action'' of retaliation once the American hostages are safe.

title: ECLECTIC DESIGN DISTINGUISHES A NEW SOHO SHOP
description: From the street, the SoHo building looks like a cross between a fairy tale castle and a medieval church preserved behind glass. Mosaic-covered spires rise above a Gothic wood and iron gate. Only the loosely scripted signature ''Susanne Bartsch'' on the glass window indicates that the facade might be the entrance to a retail shop.

title: 2 AMERICANS IN SOVIET BALLET FINALS
description: Two American dancers, one trained in China and the other in Puerto Rico, have reached the Soviet-dominated final round of the Fifth Moscow International Ballet Competition.

title: Effect of I.R.S. Bottleneck
description: Administration officials may be more worried about another feature of the tax plan than those affecting industrial investment.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JAZZ Whoever learned to play jazz piano, learned it from Bud Powell, a jazz expert was saying the other day when he heard that a tribute to the great pianist was part of the Kool Jazz Festival. The concert in honor of Earl ''Bud'' Powell, who died in 1966, will take place today at 8 P.M. at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street.

title: THE LONGEST-RUNNING GAME IN TOWN
description: Enacting legislation is hard work, often frustrating and time-consuming. With the big push now on in the 99th Congress for House and Senate action on a number of major bills, here is a game that shows just how intricate and fraught with pitfalls the legislative process can be.

title: ARCO CHIEF TO RETIRE IN OCTOBER
description: Only two months after announcing a bold financial restructuring plan, the Atlantic Richfield Company announced today that William F. Kieschnick, its 62-year-old president and chief executive, would retire this fall.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;

Net Gain
description: What has 12 arms, 12 legs and 24 Wimbledon titles?

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Coming off their first winning trip of the season, the Yankees return home for the first visit by the Orioles.

title: Israel Says It Reserves Judgment on Mengele
description: The Israeli Government said today that it was reserving its conclusion on the identification of the remains of Josef Mengele, the Auschwitz death camp doctor, pending its own examination of the evidence.

title: BLAST KILLS 2 AS CARGO IS UNLOADED FROM CANADIAN AIRLINER IN JAPAN
description: Threats against Air-India had prompted Canada to increase security measures for the jumbo jet that crashed in the sea near Ireland, officials said today.

title: GROWING PAINS FOR BOXING IN KOREA
description: KIM HYUN CHI, a prizefight promoter longing for a cold and miserable day, surveys the meager turnout at his Sunday afternoon boxing show. Balmy weather has kept the crowd small, and Kim decides to get rid of some of the extra folding chairs in the Munhwa Auditorium. Outside, it is so balmy that the security police, who seem to be everywhere in Seoul, have taken off their black helmets and put down their riot shields.

title: Bailor Sidelined
description: Bob Bailor, the Los Angeles Dodgers utility player, was placed on the 15-day disabled list, effective last Tuesday, the National League club announced today. Bailor aggravated a hamstring pull on Tuesday night in a game against San Diego. Bailor is the 11th disabled Dodger player this season.

title: NETS MAY LOOK BEYOND COLLEGE COACH
description: Lewis Schaffel, the Nets' chief operating officer, said today that because of his experiences in the team's ill-fated attempt to sign Rollie Massimino, he is less convinced that the Nets should narrow themselves to hiring a college coach. But he added that he wasn't exactly sure what kind of qualifications and credentials the new coach should have.

title: U.S.-BULGARIA RELATIONS TAKE A TURN FOR THE 'NOT SO GOOD'
description: Last year a United States military attache driving a car with diplomatic license plates in the Bulgarian countryside was shot at by a Bulgarian soldier. The soldier missed.

title: SOVIET LINKS A U.S. MILITARY BUILDUP TO HIJACKING
description: In the view of the Soviet press, the United States is using the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines plane and the holding of 40 passengers and crew members as hostages as a pretext for a military buildup in the Middle East and for an ''anti-Greek campaign.''

title: VAN HEUSEN PRESIDENT PROMOTED TO TOP POST
description: Bruce J. Klatsky has been appointed chairman and chief executive of the Van Heusen Company, a subsidiary of the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation. He succeeds Charles J. Smith, who has taken early retirement after serving as president and then chairman of the company since 1975.

title: LINKS TITLE IS WON BY AMMACCAPANE
description: Danielle Ammaccapane of Phoenix, the 1985 collegiate women's golf champion, defeated Kristie Kolacny of Grand Junction, Colo., 6 and 5, today to win the United States Golf Association's ninth Women's Amateur Public Links Championship at the Flanders Valley Golf Course.

title: PERSISTANCE WINS MORE RAVES FOR GLENNE HEADLY
description: When Glenne Headly was cast as Raina in ''Arms and the Man,'' which represented her Broadway debut as well as the chance to co-star with Kevin Kline and Raul Julia under the direction of John Malkovich, she was terrified. ''I thought it was too good to be true and would never really happen,'' she recalls.

title: EXPIRATIONS STIR A FRENZY
description: SEVERAL days before last Friday's ''triple witching hour,'' many professional stock traders again braced for a wild final 60 minutes in the life of three key market forces: index futures and stock and index options. And a wild 60 minutes it was. The market, as measured by the Dow Jones industrial average, soared to close up 24.75 points, at 1,324.48.

title: TERRORISM: EUROPE IS LEADING SITE
description: Western Europe was the site of the largest number of international terrorist acts last year, according to a study on international terrorism in 1984 published here today by the Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies.

title: City Opera Lectures Will Analyze Bel Canto
description: The New York City Opera will accompany its coming ''Bel Canto Festival'' with a series of Monday-evening lectures and panel discussions - starting today - on the composers, singing styles and exponents of what has come to be called the bel canto period in opera: the age of Rossini, Bellini and Donizetti. The speakers and moderators will include Bridget Paolucci, Gregory Sandow, George Jellinek and Beverly Sills.

title: FROM CABLE TO THE AIR, 'CAT ON A HOT TIN ROOF'
description: ONCE again, Tennessee Williams's ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' is being decked out in a promising production and, once again, the play itself founders. This new version, first seen on cable's Showtime and now being offered -tonight at 9 o'clock - on WNET/ Channel 13, stars Jessica Lange as Maggie, Tommy Lee Jones as her injured husband, Brick, Rip Torn as Big Daddy and Kim Stanley as Big Mama. Brick's weak brother, Gooper, and Brick's scheming wife, Mae, are played by David Dukes and Penny Fuller. The American Playhouse presentation, produced by Phylis Geller, has been directed by Jack Hofsiss. Imposing credits, all in all, but the seriously flawed play eludes their efforts.

title: 'Buy American' May Mean 'Pay More'
description: The New Jersey Legislature wants the state to buy only American-made products. A bill to that effect breezed through both houses this spring after the state's turnpike authority dared to test some Volvos as police cars. It may look like an election- year crowd-pleaser, but if it becomes law it would cost the taxpayers money, maybe also some jobs. Both Governor Kean and Peter Shapiro, his Democratic opponent, know that; let them both denounce this ill-conceived protectionist measure.

title: Peter S. Fader Is Married To Miss Park, an Engineer
description: Wilhelmina Park, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Man Hi Park of Hoffman Estates, Ill., was married yesterday to Peter S. Fader, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey Fader of Merrick, L.I. Rabbi Mordechai Rosen performed the ceremony at the Highland Park (Ill.) Country Club.

title: U.S. AID IS SECOND-LARGEST SHARE OF INCOME
description: Government programs provide more than $1 out of every $10 received by Americans as income, the Census Bureau has reported.

title: OUTDOORS: RAINBOW IS GOOD OMEN
description: A WET and windy afternoon on Lake Sunapee produced only one smallmouth bass for Vic Pomiekco and me, but we reversed our luck the following morning by catching our limit of brook trout in less than three hours.

title: Plane Crashes in Brazil, Killing All 13 Aboard
description: A twin-engined airplane crashed today while making an emergency landing in the state of Mato Grosso in the northern Amazon, killing all 13 people on board, airport officials said.

title: ISRAEL TO RELEASE 31 OF 766 PRISONERS SEIZED IN LEBANON
description: Israel announced today that on Monday it would free 31 of the 766 Lebanese and Palestinian detainees it has been holding in a camp outside Haifa.

title: INTERVIEW WITH PERES ON U.S. NEWS PROGRAM
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Prime Minister Shimon Peres on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press,'' as recorded by The New York Times:

title: RIGHT TO LIFE PARTY PICKS RABBI TO RUN FOR MAYOR
description: An Orthodox rabbi from Brooklyn has been designated by the Right to Life Party as its candidate for mayor.

title: COMMERCIAL METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
INMAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $348,699. c-After a loss of $31,188 from discontinued operations.

title: SUFFOLK OFFICIAL LOSES AN APPEAL OVER SHOREHAM
description: A state appeals court, upholding a lower-court ruling, said yesterday that the Suffolk County Executive lacked the authority to institute an emergency evacuation plan for the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: FAMILIES SEEK MEETING WITH REAGAN
description: A number of the families and friends of the American hostages from the Trans World Airlines plane in Beirut say they are increasingly frustrated by what they regard as a lack of action by President Reagan. Some say they are demanding a meeting with him.

title: JAMAICA HIT BY GENERAL STRIKE
description: A general strike, called by major unions to protest layoffs and the high cost of living, began on this Caribbean island today, and union leaders asserted that it would last at least three days.

title: NEW COUNCIL BILL IS OFFERED ON RIGHTS OF HOMOSEXUALS
description: A new homosexual-rights bill, intended to overcome a variety of objections, was announced yesterday by city officials and other politicians and by homosexual-rights activists.

title: Bomb Threat on U.S. Airline
description: More than 400 people were evacuated from a People Express Airlines' Boeing 747 today after a bomb threat forced the aircraft to make an unscheduled stop at O'Hare International Airport here, the police said. The threat was telephoned to the airline's Los Angeles reservation office after the flight had been airborne for several hours, a spokesman for the airline said.

title: BRITISH SECRETARY UNDER FIRE
description: EDUCATION in Britain is in disarray. Teachers are disrupting the schools, not through one major strike but with short work stoppages. The Government wants higher academic standards; teachers want higher pay. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher stands for deregulation of industry; but Sir Keith Joseph, her Secretary of State for Education and Science, wants tighter central controls.

title: Tour of the Isles
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin; his wife, Diana; their three children, Daniel, Matthew and Jonathan, and a staff assistant returned yesterday from an expenses-paid, 10-day fact-finding tour of Ireland, Northern Ireland and England.

title: REPORTER AND 2 OTHERS GUILTY OF FRAUD FOR INSIDER TRADING
description: R. Foster Winans, a former WallStreet Journal reporter, was found guilty yesterday of using advance knowledge of Journal articles to make illicit profits in the stock market.

title: SHIITE INSISTS U.S. PULL ITS WARSHIPS BACK FROM COAST
description: The Shiite Amal militia leader, Nabih Berri, added a new condition for releasing the 40 American hostages today, saying the United States must pull back warships cruising off Lebanon.

title: GENERAL INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: b-Net income.

title: U.S. Aide Says Tons of Food Are Sitting in Sudanese Port
description: A United States official said today that tons of food had not reached famine victims in the western Sudan because a key railroad has been carrying religious festive goods instead of relief supplies.

title: REAGAN TO GET PLANS FOR AIR SECURITY
description: President Reagan will receive a ''comprehensive package'' of recommendations from the Transportation Department today on measures to increase aviation security after the surge in terrorist actions in the last 10 days, according to a high-ranking department official.

title: KRIZIA OPENS WITH FALL LINE
description: The Krizia boutique opened last Thursday and was immediately discovered by Madison Avenue shoppers. There were women waiting to get into fitting rooms to try on woolen sweaters, tweed suits and leather pants. They seemed so eager to buy their fall wardrobes that it was hard to believe it was only the beginning of summer.

title: Conable's Farewell
description: Barber B. Conable, who retired last year after 20 years in the House of Representatives, finally left Washington yesterday, several months later than he had hoped.

title: CORRECTION
description: A list of history's worst airliner disasters yesterday incorrectly described the crash of an Air- India jet on Jan. 1, 1978. There was no explosion before the Boeing 747 went out of control and crashed into the sea off Bombay.

title: Invaders Win
description: Randy McClanahan recovered a blocked punt for a touchdown as the Oakland Invaders turned three first-half Houston turnovers into 17 points and went on to defeat the Gamblers, 31-21, tonight in the United States Football League. The Invaders (13-4-1) converted a pair of turnovers by Houston (10-8) into 10 points during a 57-second span of the first period. Oakland first made a field goal, then cashed in on McClanahan's blocked punt.

title: New League's Roster
description: Connecticut Colonials Veterans Memorial Coliseum, New Haven, Conn., capacity 5,500. Key players: Bruce Kuczenski and Butch Graves. Long Island Knights Hofstra College, Hempstead, L.I., capacity 2,800.

title: SHUTTLE LANDS SAFELY AND IS HAILED AS A SUCCESS
description: Swooping out of the western darkness the space shuttle Discovery came to a safe and smooth landing at dawn today to conclude what a space agency official called ''one of the most successful missions'' in the shuttle program.

title: LABOR SECRETARY TELLS N.A.A.C.P. OF U.S. AFFIRMATIVE ACTION GOALS
description: Labor Secretary Bill Brock said today that the country would ''have to have some form of affirmative action for the foreseeable future.''

title: WAITING GAME
description: It's a long, long while from May to September and, as usual, the Butterfly was waiting in the wings.

title: WES MONTGOMERY IS REMEMBERED
description: THE music of the guitarist Wes Montgomery, who created the most distinctive style on guitar since Charlie Christian appeared in 1939, was reviewed in a Kool Jazz Festival concert at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night by a company of musicians that included five top guitarists and Mr. Montgomery's brother, Buddy, a pianist and vibraphonist.

title: Stevens Leaves At Chromalloy
description: William E. Stevens, president and chief operating officer at the Chromalloy American Corporation since 1982, announced yesterday that he was leaving the company, effective immediately.

title: CHICAGO'S BOWIE AND BIG BAND
description: With free admission, comfortable outdoor seating, and consistently adventurous programming, the concerts at Brooklyn's Prospect Park band shell have become the Kool Jazz Festival's biggest bargains. On Friday, for example, one was able to hear a superb big band led by Lester Bowie, the trenchant, puckish trumpeter from the Art Ensemble of Chicago.

title: Bridge: Dutch Have Been Successful In Developing Players' Skills
description: Intelligent organization can improve the international bridge prospects of any country. It is important that the best players have frequent opportunities to play against each other, and against stars from neighboring countries.

title: Texaco Is a Casualty Of B.&B. Merger Plan
description: Although it did not disclose it at the time, Benton & Bowles resigned Texaco, its client of 24 years, on Friday afternoon, soon after its board agreed with the plan to merge with D'Arcy MacManus Masius. D'Arcy is the agency for Amoco, the bigger piece of business.

title: . . . Bridge Experiment
description: Quite a bit farther down the East River, another trial bus run is scheduled to begin in September, linking downtown Brooklyn and Brooklyn Heights with lower Manhattan.

title: Death Penalties and Life Sentences in a Civilized Society
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
U.S. EMBASSY TO REDUCE SOVIET STAFF
description: The State Department plans to reduce the number of foreign nationals working in American embassies in Soviet-bloc countries because many of them are believed to be spies, Government officials said today.

title: JOHNSTOWN AMERICAN COS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SARDINIAN EASILY WINS ITALY'S PRESIDENCY
description: Francesco Cossiga, a Christian Democrat from Sardinia, was elected President of Italy today.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: WHILE some of us are thinking about picking up an extra swimsuit before heading for our summer vacations, other people out there are buying fall clothes. The stores are not exactly full to the brim with woolens and cashmeres, but the first taste of fall has appeared. And certain styles have been, as the stores like to say, checking out. At the top of most lists are leathers, tapestries and paisleys. Saks Fifth Avenue reports strong interest in black or bright-colored leathers and suedes and has already sold out and reordered a $670 red leather jacket by Begedor Italia. The fact that leather jackets look just fine with white linen pants may explain their unseasonal success. Similarly, Ralph Lauren's short leather jacket at $540 has sold well at Henri Bendel, and Macy's private label bomber jacket at $156 has been a hit.

title: KOCH TO BEGIN TV ADVERTISING DRIVE
description: Even before he formally announces his candidacy for a third term, Mayor Koch today is to begin a television advertising campaign that will concentrate on his administration's record rather than his personality.

title: GLOBAL ACTIONS TO FIGHT TERROR URGED BY SHULTZ
description: The United States called today for worldwide action against ''the despicable acts of terrorists'' in recent days.

title: CARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $708,000 from life insurance proceeds.

title: Unhappy Move
description: Lonnie Smith, the outfielder traded by St. Louis to Kansas City last month, says ''the American League stinks'' and that he wishes he were still playing for the Cardinals. ''It would have been nice to be a part of it,'' Smith said in Monday's editions of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, referring to the Cardinals' recent success.

title: AIRLINES' SECURITY TEAM TO VISIT ATHENS AIRPORT
description: Greece has agreed to allow a special security team from the International Air Transport Association to visit Athens this week to try to help improve airport security there, an association spokesman said today.

title: NETS ARE EYEING WARRIORS' CARROLL
description: Amid the problems surrounding their coaching situation, the Nets' evaluation of player personnel has largely been ignored. But not for long.

title: Group Says It Planted The Bomb in Frankfurt
description: A previously unknown group calling itself the Peace Conquerors has taken responsibility for the bombing at the Frankfurt airport last Wednesday, and warned that it will explode a jumbo jet ''before the end of the month.''

title: ANTHOLOGIES MAKING A COMEBACK ON TV
description: For the first time in years, the networks are investing heavily in anthology series. NBC has ''Steven Spielberg's Amazing Stories'' and ''Alfred Hitchcock Presents.'' CBS will broadcast a completely new version of its old hit series, ''The Twilight Zone,'' and a half-hour comedy anthology series, ''George Burns' Comedy Week.'' In addition, Home Box Office has already beat the networks to the punch with its own new anthology series, ''Ray Bradbury Theater,'' which has been playing to its subscribers for the last two months.

title: Growth Lag Is Predicted
description: Worldwide economic growth will slow in 1986 as international trade falls off and output declines, a United Nations report issued today predicted. The World Economic Survey said that a slowdown in the rate of growth of the American economy would not be offset by acceleration elsewhere.

title: THE PRODIGY AND THE PROF
description: When the Mets open a three-game series against the Cubs in Chicago today, Dwight Gooden will be pitching with an extra day's rest. He usually pitches with four days' rest, and that's as it should be. Another manager might have succumbed to the temptation of starting Dwight Gooden against the Montreal Expos on Sunday with only three days' rest, especially with the Mets not scheduled yesterday. But not Davey Johnson, the manager who wisely wraps Doctor K's 20-year-old right arm in cotton and puts it in a velvet box between starts in the Mets' five-day rotation.

title: VMS Realty to Buy Holiday Inn Units
description: The Holiday Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell as many as 28 hotels to VMS Realty Inc. of Chicago for more than $400 million.

title: 2 POLICEMEN INDICTED IN HIT-AND-RUN
description: A veteran police officer has been indicted as the hit-and-run driver of an unmarked patrol car that struck an 11-year-old girl as she rode her bicycle on a Queens street in April. A second officer was also indicted in the case.

title: FEDERAL AGENCIES SAY 3 STATES ARE NOT ENFORCING 55 M.P.H. LIMIT
description: Two Department of Transportation agencies have found that three states, Maryland, Vermont and Arizona, have violated a Federal law requiring enforcement of the 55 mile-an-hour highway speed limit.

title: BALLET: HARLEM TROUPE'S 'GISELLE'
description: DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM'S vivid ''Giselle,'' staged for the company by Frederic Franklin, offers new insights into the classic, with its transplanting of the story to antebellum Louisiana. And Stephanie Dabney, Donald Williams and Keith Saunders enhanced that freshness with interpretations that were their own when they took over the leads on Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, where the company performs through Saturday.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from London yesterday on the crash of an Air-India jet referred incorrectly to a bombing last Wednesday at the airport in Frankfurt, West Germany. Authorities have not determined who was responsible for the attack.

title: Luxury Models
description: Tony Barone, introduced to the press as Creighton's new basketball coach, sounded a lot like Lou Carnesecca when he was asked what he would do to keep the Omaha area's top prep players at home: ''They won't get away. Creighton University is too fine a school for a young man from this area to go away. We're going to be a Cadillac basketball program, and it's tough to go to a Volkswagen when you've got a Cadillac right at home.''

title: Reagan and Sound Effects
description: President Reagan likes to tell stories about what it was like in the old days when he was a radio announcer, especially if the kicker of the story makes a point about America. The other day he told members of his Advisory Council on Private Sector Initiatives:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 25, 1985

title: LARGE CLAIM SEEN FROM PLANE CRASH
description: The crash of the Air-India airplane off the Irish coast on Sunday could result in the largest property insurance claim in aviation history, insurance experts said yesterday.

title: Rozier to Oilers
description: The Former Heisman Trophy winner Mike Rozier will leave the Jacksonville Bulls of the United States Football League and accept a four-year contract with the Houston Oilers of the National Football League, his agent said. Art Wilkinson said his client had agreed to a package reportedly worth $1.7 million, or $425,000 per season. An Oilers spokesman said the team ''understands they have accepted our proposal'' but added that the former Nebraska running back ''has not signed because we are awaiting clarification from the N.F.L. office on signing U.S.F.L. players before August 1.''

title: PROBLEMS FOR METS, CUBS
description: Dwight Gooden will be on the mound but Darryl Strawberry will still be on the bench when the Mets open Round 2 this afternoon in Wrigley Field against the Chicago Cubs, a team with a 12-game losing streak and a longing for redemption.

title: 11,500 Are Evacuated In Coast Pesticide Fire
description: Winds lofted toxic fumes from a smoldering chemical fire over a wide area today, raising to about 11,500 the number of people forced to evacuate their homes, officials said.

title: DECISION IS NEAR 'ON FLUTIE'
description: Doug Flutie, the Generals' wounded quarterback, will have X-rays taken of his fractured collarbone Tuesday, and if Dr. Mark Schottenfeld, the team's orthopedic surgeon, likes what he sees, Flutie can play.

title: DANCE: ROBBIN'S 'CAGE' AT CITY BALLET
description: INSECTS were on the march on Saturday night at the New York State Theater. The belligerent bugs were those in the New York City Ballet's production of ''The Cage,'' Jerome Robbins's dance-drama about a species resembling the mantis.

title: New Hurdle
description: Carl Lewis has never been one to limit himself, and so maybe nobody should have been surprised by those reports that he was planning to add the high hurdles to his repertory of skills. As it turns out, the reports were not without substance, although the plans have been placed on hold for a little while.

title: S.E.C. Proposal Set
description: John S. R. Shad, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said yesterday that in July the commission would make a proposal to require that tender offers not discriminate against specific shareholders. The proposal would curb the use of the existing law, whih was cited earlier this year by the Unocal Corporation in its defense against a bid by T. Boone Pickens. Unocal made a buyback offer, but excluded the shares held by Mr. Pickens. Mr. Shad said that the law was meant only to halt companies from buying their shares from inside groups, in preference to other shareholders.

title: From the Fleece Into the Myth
description: For 10 years, Senator William Proxmire has been doling out ''Golden Fleece'' awards each month for what he sees as waste and mismanagement of taxpayer money.

title: FRISHBERG PLAYS PIANO AND SINGS
description: DAVE FRISHBERG may have been booked for the Kool Jazz Festival's solo piano series at Carnegie Recital Hall because he started his career as a jazz pianist. He still is a jazz pianist but he has also become a writer of songs that are wry and witty comments on contemporary life and nostalgic (but still wry and witty) memories of what he refers to in one song as ''the dear, departed past.''

title: THE CONCRETE WALL OF SILENCE
description: We've all heard of the Blue Wall of Silence, the code under which cops stay mum about rogue cops who poison the barrel. But not much is said of the Concrete Wall of Silence, the code under which real estate developers and contractors stay mum about the corruption in the construction industry.

title: NITZE SAYS SOVIET AGAIN OFFERS A 25% MISSILE CUT
description: The Soviet Union has proposed a mutual reduction of 25 percent or more in launchers for intercontinental nuclear weapons, the Reagan Administration's senior adviser on arms control said today.

title: North Carolina Hospital Bonds
description: The North Carolina Medical Care Commission tentatively priced $128 million of health care facilities revenue bonds yesterday through underwriters led by Paine Webber.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE IMAGE AND OTHER STORIES. By Isaac Bashevis Singer. 310 pages. (Farrar Straus Giroux. $17.95) Morris Pintchover is an accountant, and also a Yiddish poet, ''a little man with yellow tufts of hair around a bald spot.'' His wife, Tamara, also a poet (though she never gets published,) has left him for Lenchner, another writer, and a Communist, well known in and around the library cafeteria on East Broadway ''as a schnorrer and a cynic.'' In his anguish, Pintchover comes to consult the anonymous narrator of ''Advice,'' the opening story in Isaac Bashevis Singer's new collection.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Cheap Power Waiting to Be Found
description: Remember ''brownouts''? On steamy August days the power company would be forced to cut voltage, and air-conditioners would slow to a wheeze. Thanks to the collapse in demand for electricity in the wake of the energy crisis, brownouts are ancient history.

title: THE 13 TEAMS OF CNN
description: THE briefing was impressive.

title: CHEESE IS LINKED TO 44TH DEATH
description: The death toll from a rare bacteria today rose to 44 as California's top health official reported that 428 stores continued to sell contaminated cheese after it was recalled, and one even cut its price as a ''fast-sale item.''

title: John Kennedy Hailed As Patriot by Reagan
description: President Reagan, at a dinner to raise money for the John F. Kennedy Memorial Library, saluted the slain President tonight as a ''fiercely, happily'' partisan who reveled in the rough-and-tumble of political battle.

title: 20-Year Term For Dominelli
description: A Federal judge today sentenced the financier J. David Dominelli to 20 years in prison for masterminding a multimillion-dollar investment swindle.

title: American Medical Shifts
description: R. Royce Diener, chairman and chief executive of American Medical International Inc. for the last decade, said yesterday that he intends to resign as chief executive on Aug. 31, the end of the company's fiscal year.

title: Why 'Huck Finn' Lost Christmas 1884 Sales
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN ACCUSED OF SABOTAGING BUDGET TALKS
description: The chairman of the House Budget Committee accused President Reagan today of trying to ''bust up'' the budget process and suggested that House and Senate budget conferees might not be able to reach a compromise before the Fourth of July Congressional recess.

title: Two in Day Care Are Dismissed
description: Two day-care center employees who the city said were suspended from their jobs last week because they had been convicted of felonies have been dismissed, a spokesman for the city's Human Resources Administration said yesterday.

title: CHESEBROUGH-POND'S NAMES STAUFFER HEAD
description: Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. said yesterday that Roy Sambrook had been named president and chief operating officer of the Stauffer Group, its chemical products and services subsidiary.

title: 4 Indians Die in Clashes Of Moslems and Hindus
description: Four people have been killed and more than 20 wounded in Moslem-Hindu clashes in the west Indian textile center of Ahmedebad.

title: Ex-Captives Urge U.S. Aid
description: Three diplomats once held by terrorists said today that the Government should provide financial and medical assistance to all American personnel taken hostage. The three are Diego C. Asencio, held by leftists in Colombia for 61 days in 1980; Thomas D. Boyatt, held six days in a Palestinian hijacking in the 1960's, and L. Bruce Laingen, a hostage in Iran from 1979 to 1981.

title: Wings Choose Neale
description: Harry Neale, the former coach of the Vancouver Canucks, was named head coach of the Detroit Red Wings yesterday. In making the announcement, Jim Devellano, the team's general manager, said that he ''talked to 10 different people about coaching the Red Wings, but I always kept coming back to Harry Neale.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MASTER BUILDERS Where better to show the work of two leading Japanese architects than in a building designed by a Japanese architect. ''New Public Architecture: Recent Projects by Fumihiko Maki and Arata Isozaki,'' is the exhibition on view through Sunday at Japan House, the attractive black-fronted building at 333 East 47th Street (752-0824), which blends a sense of Japanese delicate and spare decor with the spaciousness of a modern atrium (the work of Junzo Yoshimara and Gruzen and Partners).

title: Discharging Elderly Patients Quicker and Sicker
description: To the Editor:

title: DELINQUENT MORTGAGES SET RECORD IN QUARTER
description: In the face of a relatively sound economy, a record number of American families have been falling behind in their monthly mortgage payments, a banking group here reported today. Far fewer, but still a near-record number, are losing their homes to foreclosure.

title: HOCKEY PLAYERS TRY TO SCORE IN NEW ARENA
description: Just what are these hockey players doing here, staring into computer consoles, punching buttons, shouting instructions into a telephone, wearing long-sleeved shirts and ties and even teeth?

title: SMOG-BOUND MEXICO CITY: HAS IT SEEN THE LIGHT?
description: It is still too early to draw a deep breath of relief - at least without coughing - but Mexico's Government is showing new signs of interest in halting the capital's environmental decline.

title: ENJOYABLE DATA BASE SOFTWARE
description: ONE of the distinguishing characteristics of good software is that it is fun to use. This attribute is not very quantifiable; in fact, it is quite subjective, particularly when you consider that a true computer aficionado finds anything having to do with computing a digital delight. Only too often, the rest of us find sitting down at the keyboard a plain bore.

title: INTEREST RATES MOVE HIGHER
description: The credit markets struggled through a slow session yesterday and interest rates edged higher, as most investors cautiously waited on the sidelines in advance of a heavy schedule of Treasury security offerings set for the next three days.

title: ANDREW CYRILLE, PERCUSSION
description: ALL-PERCUSSION concerts are a tricky proposition, even when the drummers are as virtuosic as Andrew Cyrille, Famoudou Don Moye and Milford Graves. Their trio, Pieces of Time, performed Saturday at Brooklyn's Prospect Park Bandshell, Ninth Street at Prospect Park West, and wisely mixed melodic segments with salvos of drumming.

title: Center-Right a Victor In Turkish Cypriot State
description: The center-right National Unity Party of Rauf Denktash, the Turkish Cypriot leader, today won the first parliamentary elections in the Turkish Cypriot state of northern Cyprus, but fell short of an overall majority.

title: U.S. CITIZENSHIP CITED IN TRIAL
description: A retired professor who was jailed during World War II for disregarding emergency orders that removed 120,000 Japanese-Americans to internment camps testified today that he had hoped the United States Constitution would protect him from imprisonment.

title: RECORDERS HUNTED IN AIR-INDIA CRASH
description: Helicopters and ships searching the Atlantic waters into which an Indian jetliner plunged Sunday morning recovered one more body today, along with debris that officials hope will explain the plane's sudden destruction.

title: LONGTIME U.S. AIDE TO U.N.
description: Walter Maria Kotschnig, a Foreign Service officer who was present at the formation of the United Nations and who went on to represent the United States at conferences worldwide for more than a quarter century, died Sunday of Alzheimer's disease at Penns Wood Village, a nursing community near Newtown, Pa. He was 84 years old and, until four years ago, lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Careers;   Child Care Programs For Offices
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago few corporations interested themselves in child care. Women took maternity leave, if there was such a plan, and then often did not return to the company. Now children have become a major extracurricular interest of corporations that want to retain women, at jobs ranging from secretarial to high-level executive positions.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 25, 1985

title: Stocks Slip, With Dow Off by 3.92
description: Stock prices slipped a little yesterday as Wall Street corrected some of the excesses of Friday's strong technical rally.

title: COURT REINSTATES ANGRY LAWYER, 33
description: It was a fight over principle and pride between a 33-year-old lawyer from Bismarck, N.D., and the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.

title: MORTON IRA ELSON
description: Morton Ira Elson, an artist with The New York Times for 40 years, died Sunday at Boca Community Hospital in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: FARM HOUSE FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-After a charge of $1.8 million for the quarter and year due to an unfavorable tax adjustment. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $716,000.

title: DAVIS WATER & WASTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split declared in March.

title: RESCUE OF DERELICT SALYUT 7
description: Soviet astronauts have taken unusual steps to save a derelict space station, according to Western space analysts.

title: Business and the Law;   Responsibility For Job Safety
description: THE recent murder conviction of three Chicago-area corporate executives in the death of an employee from cyanide poisoning was certainly a landmark in criminal law, but many job-safety and legal experts question whether the case will become a precedent for prosecutors or a deterrent to corporations.

title: U.S. PANEL SAYS CUBAN EMIGRES RUN A BET RING
description: A group of Cuban-American racketeers operates a $45-million-a-year illegal gambling syndicate in New York City and New Jersey, often killing competitors and burning down their businesses, a Federal commission on crime said yesterday.

title: Sudan to Restore Ties With Ethiopia, Aide Says
description: A Government official here said today that the Sudan and Ethiopia planned to restore diplomatic relations for the first time in two years.

title: Airliner Lands in Emergency
description: An Eastern Airlines flight from Newark to Atlanta made an emergency landing today at Washington National Airport after a sudden loss of cabin pressure, the authorities said.

title: BANK'S CLOSING INCENSES DEPOSITORS IN CHINATOWN
description: The closing Friday night of a small New York bank important to the city's Chinese community touched off a demonstration yesterday amid charges that an officer of the bank had taken money from people but never established accounts for them.

title: Finns Return Soviet Missile That Strayed in Maneuvers
description: Finland has returned to the Soviet Union the remnants of a Soviet target missile that strayed off course in December, crashing into Lake Inari in the far north of the country, a Government report said today.

title: Revenue Raisers
description: To the Editor:

title: New Smokestack Rules To Cut Sulfur Dioxide
description: New regulations on power plant smokestacks mean utilities and factories across the country will have to reduce emissions of sulfur dioxide, a major precursor of acid rain, by 8 percent.

title: Turner Listings
description: The Turner Broadcasting System, pursuing its takeover bid for CBS Inc., told CBS stockholders that Turner class B common stock and callable preferred stock, both part of its bid, had been approved for listing on the American Stock Exchange. In a 220-page prospectus sent to shareholders in connection with the bid, to be financed entirely by Turner securities, Turner said it was also applying to the Amex to list its debt securities.

title: PYGMY CHIMPANZEES: A RARE BREED
description: PYGMY chimpanzees are the most enigmatic of the four great ape species. Only about 60 are in captivity and further exports of the apes from the Zaire River basin, where the only wild population lives, are outlawed. In the United States, members of the species are kept at the San Diego Zoo and in Atlanta at the Yerkes primate center of Emory University and the associated Language Research Center.

title: LOW NUMBER GIVEN FOR ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: A panel of the National Academy of Sciences estimated today that there are two million to four million illegal aliens in the United States, a figure substantially smaller than previous authoritative estimates.

title: San Francisco Vote Delayed
description: The Board of Supervisors today postponed a vote on a measure that would restrict the height of downtown buildings and the amount of office space that could be constructed each year. The board voted 7 to 4 to delay debate until July 1. The plan, covering about 470 acres, would cut the maximum building height to 500 feet from 700 feet.

title: FULLER, H B CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $1,574,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $86,000 for the quarter and $32,000 for the 6 months, a provision of $435,000 for the 6 months for losses on the disposal of discontinued operations and an extraordinary loss of $729,000.

title: Iranian Official Denies Any Role in Hijacking
description: The Speaker of the Iranian Parliament, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, denied today that his country had anything to do with hijacking the Trans World Airlines plane and the taking hostage of 40 people in Beirut.

title: A VW Shutdown
description: Volkswagen of America Inc., a subsidiary of Volkswagenwerk A.G., said it would place 2,400 hourly workers at its Westmoreland, Pa., car assembly plant on temporary layoff the first two weeks of July because of parts shortages.

title: SOME GOVERNORS BACK REAGAN PLAN
description: Several leading Governors, after meeting with President Reagan, expressed support today for his plan to eliminate the state and local deduction from the Federal income tax.

title: Who Pays the Tax on Taxes
description: Congress's pivot man on taxes, Chairman Dan Rostenkowski of the House Ways and Means Committee, has called the proposal to end the deduction for state and local taxes the most controversial item in President Reagan's entire tax plan. Properly so. Even though it picked up support from a few more governors yesterday, the Administration cheapens the debate when it pretends that only New Yorkers protest. Tax deductibility should be a vital concern of every state, and of every county, town and school district that levies a tax.

title: SCIENTISTS RUSH TO HARNESS ENZYME'S DESTRUCTIVE POWER
description: THE discovery that an enzyme secreted by a common fungus can rip apart even the sturdiest of organic molecules has launched a score of laboratories in Europe and America on a race for potential payoffs. Prizes awaiting the winners may include a cheap method of decontaminating soil and water, a biological process for converting coal into liquid fuel and a key to harvesting valuable chemicals from agricultural waste.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Chevron Corp. has elected Robert E. Daniel president of Chevron Resources Co. and William E. Foster president of Chevron Land and Development Co.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 9.50-10.00 ** Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: WHEN A DRAMATIST JOINS THE PERSONAE OR, THE PLAY'S NOT THE THING
description: There were times during rehearsals for ''The Foreigner'' when Larry Shue would stumble over a line or forget a cue, and frankly, he confided, it was extremely embarrassing.

title: BUSH SAYS AIR-INDIA CRASH SHAKES WORLD'S CONSCIENCE
description: Vice President Bush said today that the crash of an Air-India jetliner had ''shaken the conscience of the world.''

title: Lebanon Government Is Powerless at Airport
description: The Lebanese Government has had little to say about the Beirut hostage crisis.

title: Champion, Boise Debt May Be Downgraded
description: In separate announcements yesterday, Moody's Investors Service placed the debt ratings of the Champion International Corporation and the Boise Cascade Corporation under review for possible downgrading.

title: OFFICIAL TESTIFIES PARK REJECTED EXIT
description: A former official at the Great Adventure amusement park testified today that the corporation had rejected a fire exit for its Haunted Castle fun house because it would have been near a shallow moat that officials viewed as a safety hazard.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 25, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: IN THE SUBURBS, SOCCER IS BECOMING NO. 1 SPORT
description: Soccer has replaced Little League as the most popular pastime among youths in much of the New York metropolitan area.

title: RED SOX TROUNCE TIGERS, 9-2
description: Jim Rice drove in two runs with a triple and homer tonight to lead the Red Sox to a 9-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

title: Disney Channel Fills Vacancy From Outside
description: The Disney Channel, the family-oriented pay cable television service, yesterday named John F. Cooke as its president. He succeeds James P. Jimirro, who resigned last week as head of the Walt Disney Productions subsidiary.

title: Gloomy View On Mostek
description: The United Technologies Corporation, citing a worsening semiconductor market, said that it was re-evaluating its presence in that business.

title: DEATH PENALTIES AND LIFE SENTENCES IN A CIVILIZED SOCIETY
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp. said that it agreed to postpone until July 8, from June 28, the purchase of the common stock of Signal Cos. in its tender offer for up to 22 million shares at $45 each. The postponement gives the antitrust division of the Justice Department more time to review the transaction.

title: A ROBOT ARM ASSISTS IN 3 BRAIN OPERATIONS
description: For the first time in medical history, doctors have used a computerized robotic arm to help with actual surgery on the human brain, researchers said today.

title: MSI DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Arco Sets Offer Of $800 Million
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company announced yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of up to $800 million of debt securities that may be offered by the company at various times.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: MUSIC: PIANIST MAKES DEBUT
description: LAURA SPITZER'S piano debut Sunday afternoon at Merkin Concert Hall was engaging and expert, well above the average for such introductions. She played Bach, Chopin, Bartok, Ravel and Virko Baley with what seemed to be a lively interest in the ways and means of each work, and left one interested in hearing her ideas about others.

title: On the Move at Interior
description: The next Assistant Secretary of the Interior in charge of the Federal Government's fish, wildlife and parks services is to be William P. Horn, a deputy under secretary who has a reputation for settling Government disputes with Indians.

title: RANDOLPH DEFLECTS RUMOR, ORIOLES
description: Willie Randolph heard the rumors, but he was neither angered nor inspired by them last night. He only thought it would be fitting if he were to hit two home runs on the same day his name was mentioned prominently in yet another unfulfilled trade.

title: Youth, 17, Slain; Boy, 14, Arrested
description: A 17-year-old youth was shot to death last night on a street in Brooklyn and a 14-year-old boy was arrested as a suspect in the killing, the police said.

title: TV TESTIMONY BACKED FOR ASSAULTED CHILDREN
description: Children who say they have been sexually abused could testify over closed-circuit television instead of in a courtroom, under a bill approved by the Assembly today.

title: BRITISH REPORT I.R.A. PLAN TO BOMB RESORTS
description: Scotland Yard said tonight that it had uncovered a plot by the Irish Republican Army to plant bombs at 12 English seaside resorts this summer.

title: Star's New Publisher
description: Ian G. Rae, editor and publisher of The Star, is surrendering the title of publisher to Peter W. Eldredge, who is coming aboard from New York magazine, where he was ad director. Both publications are Murdoch magazines. Mr. Rae will continue, however, as chief executive. Mr. Eldredge, 41 years old, had worked previously for Money magazine at Time Inc.

title: Meadow Road Sweeps Trot
description: Meadow Road completed a sweep of the Statue of Liberty Trot series tonight, winning the one-mile finale at the Meadowlands in a track record 1:54 2/5. Driven by Torbjorn Jansson, Meadow Road, from Sweden, took the lead soon after the start of the $185,000 race, held a narrow margin most of the way and then took command entering the stretch.

title: SUBMARINERS RECALL JOHN WALKER AS A COMPETENT RADIOMAN
description: Shipmates who served with John A. Walker Jr. aboard a submarine 20 years ago say the man accused of spying for the Soviet Union was a competent radioman with a good Navy record.

title: TEXTILE QUOTA BILL IS OPPOSED
description: Five Cabinet officers have warned that a textile quota bill that commands co-sponsorship of a majority in both houses of Congress would impose a ''very high cost'' on consumers, violate international obligations, invite retaliation and provide the domestic industry with ''unprecedented'' protection.

title: AGCA OFFERS TO PERFORM A RESURRECTION FOR REAGAN AND U.N. CHIEF
description: Mehmet Ali Agca, the convicted assailant of Pope John Paul II, returned to the witness stand here today, offering new testimony and contradictory versions of several events.

title: DR. WARREN C. COWGILL
description: Dr. Warren C. Cowgill, professor of linguistics at Yale University, died of cancer last Thursday at the Yale Health Service Infirmary.

title: HOT INDEPENDENT TV STATIONS
description: The realm of independent, commercial television stations has never been richer. Staggering sums have recently been paid for big independents in major markets.

title: 20 Years After Desegregation Summer
description: Just 20 years ago, I drove from New York City to Jackson, Miss., with Bill Robinson and Nancy Stearns. We were summer interns assigned by the Law Students Civil Rights Research Council to various civil rights law offices in the South. We agreed that Nancy and I, both white, would not sit next to Bill, who is black, from the moment we reached the Mason-Dixon Line. To sit any other way was too obvious a sign to any state trooper that we were civil rights ''agitators.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Georgetown Coach John Thompson says he is not a candidate for a head coaching job in the National Basketball Association this year. ''I'm going to be here at Georgetown,'' Thompson said after he was asked by a television reporter whether he might take the helm of the New Jersey Nets. ''They can't afford me in the N.B.A.'' . . . Monique Berlioux, who resigned two weeks ago as director of the International Olympic Committee, has been hired by the city of Paris as an adviser to help the city in its bid to get the 1992 Olympic Games.

title: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Learning To Love Long Hauls
description: Every working day for eight years, Mark Cheeseman has logged more than 200 miles between his home in Martinsburg, W.Va., and his job on Capitol Hill. He wouldn't have it any other way.

title: A LIFE IN SCIENCE
description: THE 4-year-old pygmy chimpanzee named Kanzi has entered an exasperating ''contrary'' phase. If his human companion suggests walking to the treehouse, he will invariably insist, punching symbols on a keyboard, on going somewhere else.

title: TERRORIST LINK STILL UNCONFIRMED The Transportation Department is preparing recommendations for President Reagan on ways to improve airport security. Page A8.
description: Security at Canadian airports, which Prime Minister Brian Mulroney described as among ''the most stringent in the world,'' was tightened today after the Air-India crash that killed 329 people and the explosion of a bomb carried on a Canadian plane to Japan.

title: Receiver Moves Bevill Accounts
description: The 25,000 retail municipal bond accounts of Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Inc. have been transferred to Moore & Schley Municipals Inc. of Florham Park, N.J., by Bevill, Bresler's receiver, Richard Hill.

title: A 20 Percent Tax-Simplification Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: PERCEPTRONICS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: INSTANT LEAGUES ARE OFTEN DOOMED
description: Optimistic sports promoters believe television can solve all their problems: Get your sport on the network, let those tens of millions of viewers out there see your soccer, your hockey, your football, and - why, you'll make it instantly.

title: JAPANESE LOOK FOR EXPLOSIVES IN AIRPORT BOMBING
description: The Japanese police today pursued an investigation into a baggage explosion at Narita airport Sunday that killed two people, but they declined to say whether they saw a connection to the crash of an Air-India jumbo jet off the Irish coast.

title: Study of Black Females Cites Role of Praise
description: The failure of teachers to encourage black females to become achievers early in elementary school inhibits both their academic and social development, two University of Florida researchers reported today.

title: INTERCO INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
NEW ORLEANS HOTEL BUSINESS DEPRESSED SINCE FAIR
description: In the aftermath of the disappointing 1984 World's Fair, the New Orleans hotel business has fallen into a depression that is expected to deepen.

title: Acorn Computer Seeks Financing
description: Acorn Computer, the British personal computer maker, said it was seeking outside financial support because its situation had deteriorated sharply since Olivetti of Italy stepped in with a rescue package earlier this year.

title: REAGAN CANCELS CALIFORNIA TRIP, CITING HOSTAGES
description: President Reagan today canceled a nine-day Fourth of July vacation at his California ranch because of the hostage situation in Beirut, the White House announced today.

title: LIBRARY'S LUNCH CROWD LOSES SEATS
description: For scores of office workers in Manhattan, lunch time on the steps of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue is a midtown ritual.

title: MCRAE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: b-Net losses.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS MOVE SEEN
description: Sanford I. Weill, the president of the American Express Company, is expected to resign, Wall Street sources said last night.

title: COMGEN TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VATICAN DOCUMENT DISPLEASES JEWISH GROUPS
description: The Vatican issued a document today on relations between Christians and Jews that immediately drew sharp criticism from several leading Jewish organizations.

title: U.S. Ships Off Lebanon
description: The world's second nuclear-powered aircraft carrier was sailing from Haifa, Israel, to Livorno, Italy, when it was dispatched to waters off Lebanon in response to the hostage crisis. Built after two years of delays in the delivery and testing of its nuclear plant components, the Nimitz is equipped with rockets, missiles and more than 90 aircraft. It was commissioned in 1975 at an estimated cost of $1,881 million. Displacement: 91,487 tons. Aircraft: More than 90. Complement: 6,300, which includes 3,000 assigned to air wing. Missiles: Three launchers with Sea Sparrow missiles. Gunnery: Three 20mm Mark 15 Close In Weapon Systems. Rockets: Mark 36 Super Rapid Blooming Offboard Chaff, used as large decoys. Speed: About 30 knots. Endurance: 13 years for reactors, 16 days for aviation fuel. Combat Ships of the Nimitz Group Navy department spokesmen say that normally a battle group is accompanied by one or more ships carrying fuel, ammunition and supplies. Frequently there is also an attack submarine, though the U.S. Navy, as a matter of routine, does not comment on the identity or whereabouts of submarines. South Carolina. A nuclear-propelled guided-missile cruiser equipped with two 20 mm Mark 15 guns, two 5-inch guns and 80 surface-to-air missiles. Commissioned in 1975 and built for $180 million. Kidd. One of the most powerful destroyers in the U.S. fleet, designed for general warfare instead of anti-submarine warfare. Equipped with two helicopters, two 5-inch guns, 68 surface-to-air missiles and two torpedo launchers.

title: To Clean Up the Defense Mess
description: For defense contractors, the best deodorant is competition. For lack of it, they have slid en masse into a stench of fraud and deceit. An army of accountants and auditors and a festoon of regulations have merely offered the excuse to add excessive overhead charges without securing simple honesty, much less efficiency or quality.

title: CAPITAL FUNDS RISE 56% IN CITY'S '86 ARTS BUDGET
description: A new conservatory at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, exterior renovations at Carnegie Hall, locker rooms for the guards at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a new portable bandshell to be used by the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic are among the projects that will be financed under a Cultural Affairs Department budget that includes a 56 percent increase in capital funds for fiscal year 1986.

title: N.B.A. HOPEFULS FIND A SHOWCASE
description: After failing to make the Chicago Bulls' roster as a 1983 seventh-round draft choice, Ken Orange joined his father in the construction business in Oklahoma and tried to erase a lifelong ambition for a pro basketball career. Unable to forget, he is back trying again.

title: CORNING GLASS WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
Michigan Investigators Look For 2d Plane in Near-Collision
description: Federal investigators searched today for a private airplane that came within 50 feet of a jetliner with 70 people aboard, but the authorities said it might never be found.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The advance of the Sixth Fleet toward our shores forces us to add one more condition - this time for the Amal movement - and that is the withdrawal of the Sixth Fleet from our coast.''

title: Chess: Defender Takes the Offense For Use of Passive Defense
description: In recent years, passive defense has been vilified to the point that it is considered not only inept but also perhaps cowardly. The sober fact, however, is that it is often the only correct choice.

title: A.T.& T.'S COMPUTERS TO TIE IN WITH I.B.M.'S
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, still struggling to establish its computer offerings, announced a series of new products today that will enable its machines to communicate with I.B.M. mainframes.

title: STERCHI BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CHRONIC ARGUING BETWEEN PARENTS FOUND HARMFUL TO SOME CHILDREN
description: SOME feuding parents try to hide their fighting from their children; others make a point of letting their children see that parents do become angry at each other. There are parents, too, who do not seem to care much one way or the other.

title: 2 Larchmont Beaches Shut by Raw Sewage
description: Westchester County health officials closed two private beaches today because a malfunction at a pump station was allowing raw sewage to be discharged into Long Island Sound.

title: Staggering Odds
description: A 3-year-old colt named John Espo won the fourth race at Belmont Park the other day, and any hunch player who liked him and who was very much in the know was also halfway home toward a $14.20 quinella and a $25.80 exacta. John Espo was named for John Esposito, the owner of a bar that abuts the track, and the fourth-race runner-up was named Too Much to Drink.

title: COMPUTER HORIZONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
Rape Victim's Parents Seek Doctor for Abortion
description: The parents of a pregnant, mentally incompetent woman who was apparently raped while strapped to a nursing home bed have been unable to find a doctor to perform an abortion, a family lawyer said today.

title: Advertising;   A.A.F.'s Head Sets Agenda
description: GLEN W. FORTINBERRY, chairman of Ross Roy Inc. of Detroit, was elected chairman of the American Advertising Federation the other day. And, he feels the same way about both his paid job and his nonpaying one.

title: SOLZHENITSYN SECLUDED AS WIFE BECOMES A CITIZEN
description: Natalya Solzhenitsyn came out of the seclusion of the Green Mountains today to take the oath of United States citizenship, but her husband, Aleksandr, the exiled Russian author and winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature, remained behind at the couple's fenced and forested estate 20 miles from here.

title: ROBERT E. BANKER
description: Robert E. Banker, an official with Doubleday & Company for 34 years, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Sands Point, L.I. He was 68 years old. Mr. Banker, a former captain with the Army's Medical Administration Corps, retired in 1982. He is survived by his wife, Nancy Kincaid; three daughters, Mary Quinn of Elmont, L. I., Kathryn MacKenzie of Cambridge, Mass. and Alexandra Bleek of Roslyn Heights, L. I., and by a sister, Mary Banker Certain of Wichita, Kans.

title: 'SILENT PIONEERS' PROFILES OF HOMOSEXUALS
description: A FORMER waitress from Chicago named Merle sings:

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Ed Whitson, the Yankee starter, is starting to achieve some success after a poor start.

title: Rebels Destroy Bridges In Southeastern Peru
description: Maoist guerrillas blew up two bridges on a key highway in southeast Peru, causing about $180,000 in damage, officials said today.

title: New Butcher Sentence
description: Jake Butcher was sentenced today to 20 years in prison on charges that he defrauded two Kentucky banks of $4.2 million.

title: Blast Rocks Johannesburg
description: An explosion extensively damaged a central Johannesburg office building today; the police said there were no injuries. The South African Press Association said the blast was on the 15th floor of the building. The blast was the latest of several bomb attacks around South Africa.

title: Democrat on National Panel Switches to Republican Party
description: As the Democratic National Committee gathered today to plan for the 1986 elections and beyond, the party's leadership was stunned when one of its number switched to the Republican Party.

title: Looking for Exit
description: John Candelaria, the disgruntled Pittsburgh Pirates pitcher, has apparently cleared the way for his long-awaited exit visa from the Pirates. According to Joe L. Brown, the Pirates' general manager, Candelaria has waived his right to veto a trade.

title: Bad Road Plate Shuts A Bus Lane to Tunnel
description: A loose metal plate in the express bus lane on Route 3 to the Lincoln Tunnel forced the closing of the lane, and traffic backed up more than a mile in North Bergen, N.J.

title: VULNERABLE AMERICA
description: As the hijacking of Flight 847 began to look like another long-running hostage story, someone put to me a question many Americans may be asking:

title: Lion and Tiger Bites
description: For those who wonder why lion and tiger bites are bad for you, The Journal of the American Medical Association has some enlightenment.

title: Met Attendance One for the Book
description: If the Mets remain on their current track, they won't be there at the end - infequent hitting, spotty pitching and suddenly abysmal defense will all share the blame - but they will nonetheless finish the season in the record books (the New York editions, anyway).

title: LESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
OFFICIALS IN INDIA CAUTIOUS ABOUT ASSERTIONS ON BOMB
description: The Indian Government responded cautiously today to separate assertions by anonymous callers that a Sikh extremist group and a Kashmir radical movement were responsible for the crash Sunday of an Air-India jumbo jet off Ireland.

title: UNDERWATER EXPLORING IS BANNED IN BRAZIL
description: A DISPUTE between the Brazilian Navy and an American marine archeologist has led Brazil to bar the diver from entering the country and to place a ban on all underwater exploration.

title: Texas Inmate Is Moved For Scheduled Execution
description: Charles Milton, a condemned inmate, remained in a small cell outside the Texas execution chamber early today while his attorneys made a final, unsuccessful appeal before the United States Supreme Court to halt his execution, scheduled to be carried out before dawn.

title: DRIVERS' BRAIN WAVES TESTED FOR USE OF SPECIFIC DRUGS
description: A DEVICE that can distinguish the brain waves of people under the influence of various intoxicants from those of clear-headed drivers is being tested by the police in a number of New Jersey communities and is being provided to law enforcement agencies in Washington, D.C., and New Orleans, according to the IEEE Spectrum, a publication of the Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers.

title: Bomb Threat on Austrian Jet
description: An Austrian Airlines passenger jet on a Rome-to-Vienna flight with 65 people aboard returned to Rome tonight after the airline's office in Vienna received a bomb threat, airline officials reported. Police bomb squads checked the baggage while the 60 passengers and 5 crew members waited in a transit lounge, an airline spokesman said.

title: FIRE MARSHAL WOUNDS 2 YOUTHS
description: A city fire marshal shot and critically wounded two youths who attacked and tried to rob him on an Upper East Side street early yesterday, the police said.

title: Davis Is Said to Keep Stake
description: Marvin Davis has discussed selling his half of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation to Rupert Murdoch, his partner in the movie studio, but decided against it, a source close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: U.S.O.C. to Begin Tests
description: The United States Olympic Committee has started a program to control the use of banned drugs by athletes competing for spots on the 1988 Olympic team.

title: WIMBLEDON GETS OFF TO SLIPPERY START
description: It was a contribution to tennis that Ivan Lendl did not appreciate or find particularly noble. On a day when rain and slippery conditions eventually forced a postponement of 66 of 67 matches, Lendl was not placated by knowing he was the only player to advance to the second round at Wimbledon.

title: ARGENTINA'S BOLD RESCUE PLAN
description: In the months following Argentina's surprise appointment of Juan Sourrouille as Economics Minister in February, hopes faded that he could somehow rescue the country's troubled economy.

title: BUFFALO MOURNS ITS OWN
description: Families and friends mourned today for six Buffalo-area women who were aboard Air-India Flight 182 that crashed in the Atlantic off the coast of Ireland.

title: AMERON INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SOME TURNOVERS ARE ACCOMPANIED BY TREMORS
description: The day-in and day-out bureaucratic horsepower of a Cabinet-level department starts with Assistant Secretaries and goes down from there. They are the people who generate the ideas, write the papers and go to the almost daily interdepartmental meetings. And they are the people who currently are a subject of considerble concern at the State Department.

title: PART OF TAX PLAN MAY BE REWRITTEN BY ADMINISTRATION
description: The Reagan Administration is re-examining aspects of its tax revision plan that appear to be disadvantageous to middle-income families in which both parents work, the chief tax official at the Treasury Department said today.

title: Measuring Down
description: The depth of Mike Schmidt's struggles this season can be measured in any number of ways, but perhaps the most telling is the absence of what had become a very familiar long ball.

title: TOURISM LOSS APPEARS LESS THAN EXPECTED BY TRAVEL AGENT
description: The Air-India disaster and the bomb deaths in the Narita airport in Japan, following so closely on the Beirut hijacking, appear to have led some travelers to cancel or alter their vacation plans, but the impact has been less than some travel companies had anticipated, according to some company spokesmen.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) - Purchased the contract of the right-handed pitcher Roy Smith from the Maine Guides of the International League.

title: China Joins Antarctic
description: China has joined the list of countries with established bases in Antarctica as the time approaches for resolution of that continent's future. Under the present Antarctic Treaty, which becomes open for revision in 1991, only those countries actively engaged in Antarctic research have a say in administration of the treaty.

title: RABBI URGES NEW FOCUS FOR REFORM JUDAISM
description: Saying that ''even the Almighty'' must find the Friday evening temple service ''utterly boring,'' a leader of Reform Judaism called today for the elimination of the service ''as the centerpiece of Reform religious expression.''

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: CHIEF'S RETIREMENT EXPLAINED AT ARCO
description: It was only after William F. Kieschnick was convinced that the Atlantic Richfield Company's $4 billion restructuring program was working well that he decided he would retire next autumn as president and chief executive, Mr. Kieschnick said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review on Thursday of a performance by the Asian American Dance Theater misidentified the choreographer of ''Flight to the Moon.'' She is Yung Yung Tsuai.

title: Determined Recruiters
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson won the election handily.

title: Privately Fighting Apartheid
description: ''Constructive engagement in South Africa can mean two very different things. It can mean the Reagan Administration's discredited policy of quiet diplomacy - so quiet there are serious doubts it exists at all. Or it can mean efforts by United States citizens acting in a private capacity to give moral and financial support to the many South Africans - white, black, colored, Indian - working to bring peaceful change to their country.

title: PLANS FALTER FOR A WORLD'S FAIR IN CHICAGO IN 1992
description: Plans for a 1992 World's Fair to showcase Chicago as an international city are almost dead or very dead, depending on who is talking.

title: Discharging Elderly Patients Quicker and Sicker
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAEL FREES 31 PRISONERS ACROSS LEBANON BORDER
description: Israel released 31 Lebanese detainees from the Atlit military prison today and set them free in south Lebanon.

title: PANDA WATCH IS ON AGAIN
description: The great panda watch has resumed at the National Zoo, where the female Ling-Ling has finally begun showing signs of coming into heat.

title: DESIGNERS ADD A SPORTY INGREDIENT TO FURS
description: Sportswear has come a long way from the playing fields, where it originated in clothes that would not interfere with the swing of a golf club or a dash across a tennis court. It has even been accepted for evening wear - in trousers with shirts, or sweaters with long skirts, clothes that maintain their casual, nonrestrictive air, although they can be in opulent fabrics. Carrying this feeling further, furs are the newest field where sportswear designers have made an impact.

title: Wiesel Tells of Group Formed to Improve Ties
description: Elie Wiesel, chairman of the United States Holocaust Memorial Council, yesterday announced the formation of a West German-American group to ''bear witness together'' to the scars of World War II and ''open new avenues'' of understanding between the two countries.

title: Metropolitan Life, Crossland Capital
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said that it had agreed to buy the Crossland Capital Corporation, which is based in Los Angeles, from the Crossland Savings Bank F.S.B. of Brooklyn for more than $200 million.

title: Sunday Experiment . . .
description: On her way to visit a friend in the hospital one Sunday a few years ago, Anna H. Clark was waiting at 86th Street for the York Avenue bus. And waiting.

title: Come Blow Your Horn
description: The first person to play a saxophone, naturally, was the Belgian inventor who patented it in 1846, Antoine Joseph Sax, known as Adolphe, who created such a horn specifically for French martial music by Hector Berlioz. Today an estimated 2,000 people worldwide play classical music on the saxophone. (No estimate available for jazz sax.)

title: RUSSIAN SPACECRAFT SCHEDULED TO HOVER ABOVE MARTIAN MOON
description: IN contrast an earlier reluctance of the Russians to provide advance information on space flights, they now have provided Western scientists with extensive details on the Soviet Union's 1988 mission to Mars.

title: TOKHEIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Market Place;   Food Issues Latest Stars
description: FOOD-PROCESSING companies, regarded as dull investments only a few years ago, are now stellar performers in the stock market. They were in the spotlight again last Friday, when takeover rumors sent shares of the General Foods Corporation soaring 10 3/4 points, to 82 3/8.

title: Appeal to Marcos on Press
description: The Committee to Protect Journalists has appealed to President Ferdinand E. Marcos to help protect journalists in the Philippines. Twelve journalists have been killed there since January 1984, the group said, and no one has been brought to trial. In a letter sent June 7, the New York-based group asked Mr. Marcos to investigate the killings and to stop what it called Government harassment of journalists who write on politically sensitive issues.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD MILITARY BASES' LIMITS ON ACCESS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a person who has once been barred from a military base has no constitutional right to re-enter the facility, even during an ''open house'' to which the general public is invited.

title: HEINZ, H J CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
FEDERAL AVIATION SAFETY EXPERTS DESCRIBE A NUMBER OF CLOSE CALLS
description: Air safety experts voiced concern today about the prospect of aircraft colliding at busy airports, saying a rash of close calls in recent months suggests ''a distinct breakdown'' in the way airport traffic is being controlled.

title: JUST PLAIN WORD PROCESSING
description: THERE are dozens of word-processing software programs on the market today, each one promising to transform a personal computer and printer into a magical super typewriter.

title: WARNER-LAMBERT CHOOSES PRESIDENT
description: The Warner-Lambert Company announced several promotions of its top officers yesterday, including the election of Melvin R. Goodes as president and chief operating officer.

title: New Board At Eureka
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that the directors of the Eureka Federal Savings and Loan Association have elected a new board after agreeing to voluntarily resign their posts.

title: GOING BEYOND THE SCANDALS
description: MARSHALL CRISER, the president of the University of Florida at Gainesville, stood outside the hotel ballroom where 197 of his fellow presidents and chancellors were talking about abuses in recruiting athletes last week and observed, ''There are a lot of people in there who wish they were doing something else.''

title: U.N. as Soviet and East-Bloc Espionage Base
description: To the Editor:

title: Bad Guys, Bad Suits
