description: More terrifying than their automatic rifles or the looks of fierce brutality on their faces were their clothes: black polyester suits with garishly wide lapels.

title: RISE OF UP TO 6.5% IN STABILIZED RENTS IS SET FOR NEW YORK
description: Tenants in thousands of rent-stabilized apartments in New York City will pay rent increases of up to 6.5 percent under measures adopted yesterday by the Rent Guidelines Board.

title: CANADA IS OPENING INQUIRY INTO AIR CRASH AND BOMBING
description: The Government has begun a major investigation involving the security forces of several other countries to find out whether terrorists were responsible for the Air-India crash that killed 329 people and a second fatal aviation incident in Japan. Both involved flights originating from Canada.

title: SABATINI IS FACING BIGGEST CHALLENGE
description: As the year unfolded and Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina began to capture the public's fancy with tennis strokes that belied her age and looks that had already earned her a clothing endorsement contract, Patricio Apey turned his thoughts to Wimbledon and decided that his 15-year-old protegee might be ready to play in the most prestigious tournament after all.

title: TEXAS BANK DISCLOSES INVESTIGATION BY S.E.C.
description: Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. disclosed today that it was the subject of a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into whether it misrepresented its financial health to investors between 1981 and 1984.

title: ARGENTINE DANCER WINS GOLD MEDAL IN MOSCOW
description: An unknown young Argentine dancer, Julio Bocca, dazzled the fifth Moscow International Ballet Competition to win a gold medal today, with Soviet dancers winning most of the other prizes.

title: Victim in Mass Murder Case Identified by Police on Coast
description: The authorities today identified one of six victims whose remains were found on the mountain compound of a dead survivalist who is linked to the deaths or disappearances of 22 people.

title: Citicorp's Auction
description: Interest rates rose at Citicorp's regular weekly auction of commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day commercial paper at an average rate of 7.58 percent, up from 7.05 percent last week. A $50 million issue of 182-day commercial paper sold at an average 7.718 percent, up from 7.124 percent.

title: Bond Prices Continue Retreat
description: Bond prices continued to slide in light trading yesterday, as traders reacted negatively to economic and political news from Washington, developments suggesting that economic activity may be picking up at the same time that momentum in Congress for an agreement on next year's Federal budget appears to be slowing down.

title: VESTAUR SECURITIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The net income figures represent net investment income.

title: Bill Expected to Pass In Albany Aiding CBS
description: A bill that would give CBS Inc. and other New York-based companies strong defenses against corporate raiders is expected to be approved by the New York State Legislature within the next several days.

title: LOCAL STRABERRIES WIN ON FRESHNESS
description: WEDNESDAYS at 5 A.M.

title: SANDINISTAS IN PLEDGE TO INDIANS
description: Nicaraguan Government leaders pledged this week to grant autonomy to Indians and other residents of this country's restive Atlantic Coast region despite a breakdown of talks last week with the Indian coalition known as Misurasata.

title: A Million for the Met
description: Elsewhere in the Met, a dedication was taking place yesterday.

title: Renault to Sell Stake in Renix
description: Renault, the financially troubled French auto maker, said that it planned to sell its interest in an automotive electronics company. Renault said it was selling its 51 percent interest in Renix Electronique S.A. of France to the Allied Corporation, which had owned the other 49 percent and is a major auto industry supplier.

title: Israelis Bid Aviation Agency Take Up Anti-Terrorist Steps
description: Israel asked the International Civil Aviation Organization today to reconsider anti-terrorist measures the agency had rejected previously for political and budgetary reasons.

title: SOPHISTICATION SPICES SOUTHERN FOOD
description: IF a recent culinary foray to North Carolina is any indication, we are becoming one of the least parochial nations on earth where food is concerned. Not long ago, restaurant-going in any but the largest cities of the South was virtually unknown. The best food was thought to be in homes or in boarding houses, and most of that, while frequently wonderful, was standard: fried chicken and country ham, long-cooked greens, black-eyed peas, okra, grits, corn bread and spoon bread. For dessert, pecan pie, sweet potato pie, doughy fruit cobbler or angel food cake. Spices consisted mostly of black pepper in generous amounts, dried sage and herbs like fresh parsley and garlic.

title: Pride Air, New Carrier, Picks Needham Harper
description: The newly formed Pride Air airline, which will fly coast to coast in the southern region with New Orleans as its hub, has hired Needham Harper Worldwide's Los Angeles office to make it well known.

title: PEGASUS GOLD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in U. S. dollars. Year-ago first quarter results have been restated to reflect currency reporting change.

title: Candidacy
description: Carol Bellamy (an announced candidate for Mayor) complained yesterday that Mayor Koch (an unannounced candidate for Mayor) is ''in the Rose Garden with his back turned to the public and voters are getting shortchanged.''

title: 3 Killed by Shots From Car
description: Three men were killed and a fourth was wounded early Monday in a hail of shots fired from a passing car, the police said.

title: Notice Given at D'Arcy
description: John B. Balson, who has been president of D'Arcy MacManus Masius/ North America, said yesterday that he had told his management a month ago that if the agency merged with Benton & Bowles, as it now plans to do, he would look elsewhere. ''I was brought in to do a certain thing, and I did it,'' he said.

title: HOOPES TO QUIT PUBLISHER POST
description: Townsend Hoopes, president of the Association of American Publishers, has announced that he will retire in the late summer of 1986. Mr. Hoopes has been head of the 15-year-old association since 1973.

title: Best Week Ever
description: A postscript to the Mets' big week at the gate: Buoyed by the 306,865 who invaded Shea Stadium for the Chicago and Montreal series, the National League drew a total of 1,231,755 fans during the seven days that ended Sunday, and that is a league record for any week in any year. The top-drawing series was the Mets' four-game pummeling of the Cubs, which was witnessed by 172,092.

title: 'WE ARE THE WORLD' MEETS A CONTINENT OF MISERY
description: The concept, developed during a telephone call between Harry Belafonte in New York and a producer in Los Angeles, sounded tricky: gather together the hottest names in American pop music, cut a hit record and make a fortune for the famine victims of Africa.

title: Stalking the Complete Dinosaur
description: Each time ground is broken in Washington for a new building, Peter Krantz speeds to the site with posters that warn ''Caution: Dinosaurs'' and add, in fine print, ''This Is Not a Joke.''

title: SIZZLING HENDERSON LIFTS YANKS AGAIN
description: Rickey Henderson, whose last nine games have been routinely phenomenal, had three more hits, drove in three runs and stole his 32nd base of the season last night to help the Yankees crush the Baltimore Orioles, 7-4, at the Stadium. Henderson's average jumped eight points to .360, his season high and the top mark in the major leagues.

title: Appeal Process
description: The first regular season of the United States Football League's grand experiment into the use of instant replays is now behind us, and so it's time to tally up the score, which shows that the coaches made something of a comeback as the campaign progressed: Number of coaches' appeals, 53; number of decisions favoring appeal, 14; number upholding officials' call, 39.

title: Deposit Run in Rhode Island
description: Hundreds of worried customers withdrew millions of dollars today from offices of Commercial Credit Bank on the second day of a run that company officials insist resulted from a misunderstanding.

title: Arco Agrees to Sell Refinery, Stations
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said today that it had agreed to sell its Philadelphia refinery and 576 service stations in Pennsylvania and New York to the Atlantic Petroleum Corporation, a new company, for about $420 million.

title: PILLSBURY CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
GIBNER KING
description: Gibner King, the pianist and vocal coach, who accompanied Jan Peerce, Ezio Pinza and many other vocal recitalists, died June 18 of complications following surgery in Portland, Ore. He was 80 years old.

title: High-Tax States Face Their Responsibilities
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Planning No Yen Bonds
description: David C. Mulford, an Assistant Treasury Secretary, said today that the United States was not considering issuing any bonds denominated in Japanese yen.

title: Vote on Fuel Program
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee voted today to abolish all but $500 million of what once was a $20 billion synthetic fuels program. The bill approved by the committee would abolish the Synthetic Fuels Corporation in 90 days. It now moves to the House Banking Committee.

title: INQUIRY ORDERED INTO CORRUPTION IN CONSTRUCTION
description: An investigation into allegations of widespread corruption and organized-crime infiltration in New York City's multibillion-dollar construction business was ordered today by Governor Cuomo.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Finale of the three-game series and the last visit of Earl Weaver and the Orioles to New York until the last week of September.

title: HIPOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
Trudeau Visits Moscow
description: Former Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada arrived here today for a monthlong visit at the invitation of the Kremlin's North American institute, the official press agency Tass said. He will spend a month meeting Soviet officials and traveling around the country, Canadian sources said. They did not know if he would meet the Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, or other leaders.

title: WEILL'S DEPARTURE OF AMERICAN EXPRESS
description: The American Express Company announced yesterday that Sanford I. Weill had resigned as president and that it had named Louis V. Gerstner Jr., head of travel services, to succeed him.

title: CONSERVATIONISTS URGE POLICY SHIFTS
description: Adding new fields to their established concerns, environmental leaders today called on the United States to reconsider its policies on nuclear weapons and population control.

title: SYNBIOTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DURABLES ORDERS UP 4.1% IN MAY
description: Orders for durable goods rose 4.1 percent in May, the Commerce Department reported today. Analysts saw the gain as further evidence that the economy was rebounding from its winter doldrums.

title: FAST-FOOD LABELS URGED
description: Consumer and health experts proposed this week that products sold in the nation's popular fast-food chains be required to carry ingredient labels. ''Fast-food ingredient labeling is a logical and sensible device to get information to the people who need it the most,'' said Dr. Joseph A. Bellanti, a specialist in allergies at Georgetown University.

title: The Haste to Blame Greece in Hijacking
description: To the Editor:

title: N.B.A. Puts Off Changes
description: Jerry Colangelo, the chairman of the National Basketball Association's rules and competition committee, announced today that the coaches and general managers would recommend to the league's Board of Governors that they delay any action on changes in the draft lottery and the zone defense until next fall.

title: INTERNATIONAL CAPITAL EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $22,000 for the quarter and $123,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $97,000 for the quarter and $286,000 for the 9 months. d-Net loss.

title: May Home Sales Off 1%
description: Sales of existing single-family homes dropped 1 percent in May, the National Association of Realtors said today. Previously owned homes were sold at an annual rate of 3.01 million units last month, down from the April pace of 3.04 million units.

title: Youth Cleared in Case Spurred by Subway Talk
description: A 14-year-old boy accused of shooting a woman and boasting about it on a subway train within earshot of the victim's mother was found not guilty today of delinquency charges in the case.

title: BRIEFS
description: Ames Department Stores Inc., Rocky Hill, Conn., said it had completed its public offering of 3.1 million common shares. The $140 million in proceeds will be applied to repaying debt incurred when it acquired G. C. Murphy Co.

title: SPANISH COURT SENTENCES 2 LEBANESE WHOM HIJACKERS WANT FREED
description: A court here sentenced two Lebanese today to more than 23 years in jail for shooting and wounding a Libyan diplomat.

title: BAXTER BID IS REJECTED BY AMERICAN HOSPITAL
description: The American Hospital Supply Corporation yesterday rejected a $3.7 billion buyout offer from Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc., and said it would proceed with a lower-priced merger with the Hospital Corporation of America that it believes holds better promise for the future.

title: Coin Minting Bill Approved
description: The House gave final approval Monday to a measure to mint commemorative coins to raise money for the restoration of the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island. In addition, the bill authorizes the minting of new silver bullion coins, with the silver for the coins to come from the strategic stockpile, which is awash in unneeded silver.

title: SALVADOR REBELS SAY MARINES ARE FAIR GAME
description: Guerrilla leaders have issued a warning that the killing of four United States marines in a sidewalk cafe last Wednesday was ''only a beginning'' and promised to carry the war to ''Yankee aggressors'' wherever they are in El Salvador.

title: GEN. CHUCK YEAGER LOGS HIS LIFE IN A BOOK
description: Chuck Yeager came to New York the other day on a regular commercial airplane, a standard American Airlines number that left Sacramento Airport at 9:30 in the morning and arrived at La Guardia Airport six and a half hours later. He even had to stop over in Chicago for a connecting plane. Imagine: Chuck Yeager jostling through O'Hare Airport like some regular businessman or student going home for summer vacation.

title: MICHIGAN SHIITES OFFER TO WORK WITH PARISH
description: A group of Shiite Moslems from Michigan has proposed a joint effort with a Roman Catholic parish here to free the 40 American hostages being held in Lebanon, eight of whom are members of the parish.

title: A MANUSCRIPT CENTURIES OLD IS AUCTIONED
description: A fragment of a 1,300-year-old manuscript, found last fall in the binding of a book in the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington, was sold today for $105,600, Sotheby's, the auction house, said.

title: U.S. OPENS DEFENSE IN 1942 INTERNMENT CASE
description: The Government today opened its defense against charges that it suppessed evidence in the conviction of a Japanese-American in World War II for violating military law by refusing to report to an internment camp.

title: BILL TO EXTEND CO-OP CONVERSION LAWS GOES TO CUOMO
description: Laws governing the conversion of rental apartment buildings to cooperatives would be extended for two years under a bill given final legislative passage today by the State Senate.

title: JUNO LIGHTING reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
LILLY INDUSTRIAL COATINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SCOTT & FETZER CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1,128,000 for the quarter and $2,265,000 for the 6 months.

title: A Conflict of Values Behind Child Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 26, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M.

title: INDIA TEMPORARILY HALTS ALL FLIGHTS INTO CANADA
description: India announced today that it had temporarily suspended Air-India flights to Canada in the aftermath of the crash of an Air-India jumbo jet off Ireland with 329 people aboard.

title: PHILLIES BEAT CARDS; EXPOS LEAD GIN
description: Glenn Wilson's three-run double in the third inning, and Jerry Koosman's three-hitter pushed the Philadelphia Phillies to a 3-1 victory tonight over St. Louis that dropped the Cardinals into second place in the National League East.

title: Stalking American Art
description: In 1970 the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American Art undertook a huge effort to register all American paintings, in public and private collections, that were executed before 1914.

title: U.N. as Soviet and East-Bloc Espionage Base
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Neighbors leaning out windows on this warm summer day began to clap as Joselyn Estevez walked by in her crisp, white cap and gown.

title: SHELDAHL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid Feb. 4.

title: Wick Is Surviving the Criticism
description: Representative Daniel A. Mica used to get frequent late-night telephone calls from employees of the United States Information Agency. The callers, who did not give their names, were indulging in a common Washington practice: trying to do in their boss with tips to the Congressman whose subcommittee oversees the agency.

title: U.S. Asbestos Rule Extended
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it would require public schools in 27 states to observe Federal exposure limits in asbestos abatement projects this summer.

title: F.D.A. CHIEF ESPOUSES NEW VIEW OF FOOD LAW
description: The head of the Food and Drug Administration, in a new interpretation of food safety laws, says the agency does not have an absolute legal obligation to ban food additives found to cause cancer in animals.

title: INVALID UNDERGOING ABORTION
description: An abortion procedure that could take 12 to 24 hours was begun on a severely brain-diseased woman, apparently the victim of a rape at a convalescent home, after relatives tried to explain the operation to her, her family said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BACH TO BEATLES Today is the last chance to watch ''Twelve Ten at St. Bartholomew's,'' a program of free Wednesday concerts on the patio of the church at Park Avenue between 50th and 51st Streets. The outdoor concerts will be suspended during the summer and start again in September.

title: In the Drink
description: Dennis Conner, his loss of the America's Cup to the Australians notwithstanding, is still a giant among this country's helmsmen, and so you can imagine the embarrassment some time back when he put his 42-foot sloop, Lobo, on the rocks during the Admiral's Cup trials and then required 25 minutes to free her.

title: Green Feels Unloved
description: Times are tough, says Dallas Green, the general manager of the Chicago Cubs. Speaking of the club's efforts to overcome neighborhood opposition to installing lights at Wrigley Field, Green said before the Cubs' loss to the Mets, ''The law's got us, the Legislature's got us, the City Council's got us and we're 0-12.

title: ZIYAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: Pennsylvania Unit Revenue Offering
description: The Lehigh County Industrial Development Authority of Pennsylvania tentatively priced $55 million of 9 3/8 percent pollution control revenue bonds, due in 2015, for the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company. The underwriters are headed by the First Boston Corporation.

title: TRIDEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $48,000 for the quarter and $307,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: Leon Greenberg Dies; Authority on Alcohol
description: Dr. Leon Greenberg, an authority in the study of alcohol and the inventor of the Alcometer, the first machine that analyzed the breath for alcohol, died Sunday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 78 years old. Dr. Greenberg, who wrote and lectured widely on alcohol, invented the Alcometer in the 30's. He also invented the Alco-Calculator, a slide-rule device that indicates what the blood alcohol level would be if certain amounts of alcohol were consumed over varying periods.

title: Head Says C.&W. Has Rebounded
description: HANK MALFA, who likes to call himself ''the kid from Brooklyn,'' took over the presidency of the newly restructured Cunningham & Walsh in the latter part of October 1984. That followed by only a few days Brown & Williamson Tobacco's departure from the Chicago office.

title: Celebrating Folklife
description: At 10:30 this morning, four drummers from India will begin performing on the Mall, to be followed by a Louisiana gospel group called the Zion Travelers and a band of seven Irish-American musicians. This overture to the Smithsonian's 19th annual Festival of American Folklife gives a fairly accurate idea of the diversity of the celebration itself, whose themes this year are India, Louisiana and Cultural Conservation, with the last taking in a good deal of territory.

title: CASUALTY BUSINESS SUFFERED BIG LOSSES
description: With the announcement yesterday that it plans a partial divestiture of its Fireman's Fund Insurance Companies, the American Express Company is easing out of the property and casualty business at a time when the industry is starting to reverse a long-term adverse pricing cycle.

title: NO FAULTS FOUND IN COAST CHEESE EQUIPMENT
description: Pasteurization equipment that produced cheese suspected in dozens of food-poisoning deaths worked properly but may have been strained beyond its capacity, officials said today.

title: U.S. TO REPLACE MANY EMBASSIES AND CONSULATES FOR BETTER SECURITY
description: The State Department has decided to renovate or replace almost half of its 262 embassies and consulates around the world because the existing buildings are vulnerable to espionage or terrorist attack, department officials said today.

title: SEARCH NATURAL RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: ARGUELLO MAY RETURN TO RING
description: Beer money may be the only thing keeping 33-year-old Alexis Arguello from making a comeback. It is, apparently, the only money the three-time world champion has left.

title: Group Cites Indonesia In Rights Abuse Report
description: Amnesty International, the human rights group, said in a report issued yesterday that thousands of civilians in East Timor had disappeared or had been illegally detained, tortured and executed by the Indonesian forces of President Suharto's Government.

title: PRESSURE MOUNTS ON SHIITE LEADER
description: The Shiite militia leader Nabih Berri appeared to be under mounting diplomatic pressure tonight to take major steps to end the 12-day hostage crisis.

title: MONOGRAM OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BUDGET OFFICE MOVES TO KILL DRAFT OF OIL WELL SAFETY RULE
description: The Office of Management and Budget is putting pressure on Federal regulators to kill a proposed safety rule designed to protect 95,000 workers in the oil and gas well-drilling industry.

title: WILTON ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Flutie to Rejoin Generals
description: Doug Flutie passed a physical examination today and will rejoin the Generals as an active player Thursday when they begin rehearsals for their playoff game here Monday night against the Baltimore Stars.

title: WEINBERGER AGAINST TAX POSTPONING
description: Taking a position at odds with the Reagan Administration's tax revision plan, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger told Congress today that he favored abolishing an accounting practice that has allowed many military contractors to pay little or nothing in taxes in recent years.

title: U.N. CHIEF URGES ISRAEL TO FREE PRISONERS
description: The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, called today for the ''early release'' by Israel of 735 Lebanese and Palestinian prisoners whose freedom has been demanded by terrorists holding 40 American hostages in Beirut.

title: KIRKLAND FIGHTS TEAMSTER 'RAIDING' IN PUBLISHING
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. is acting to block a bid by the teamsters' union to move into organizing workers in the publishing industry.

title: U.S. Critical On Yen Talks
description: Two days of talks on opening Japan's financial markets ended today with the United States criticizing Japan for setting too slow a pace.

title: QUICK & REILLY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: A TERRIFICALLY lovely evening on the Great Lawn of Central Park. Warm weather has returned and, along with it, the Met in the Park concerts and happy, humming crowds. Daniel C. Beaudoin and a group of his opera-loving friends are early arrivals, each one having brought along a share of their standard picnic fare: fruit, cheese, bread. To celebrate the start of summer as well as the outdoor concert season, someone produces a bottle of champagne, appropriately festive and perfectly chilled. Mr. Beaudoin is elected to do the bottle-opening honors. Dilemma: Should he catch the cork or should he let it fly? He decides to live dangerously.

title: CORRECTION
description: A London dispatch in some editions Monday, on the crash of the Air-India jumbo jet, incorrectly described the aviation background of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India. He is a former pilot for Indian Airlines.

title: BIG BEAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 25
description: b-Including a gain on the sale of land of $605,000.

title: I.B.M. CHALLENGES A.T.& T. IN A MOVE ON LONG DISTANCE
description: Intensifying its push into telecommunications, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it was acquiring a major stake in the MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest long-distance telephone company.

title: STAGE: 'ONE-MAN BAND,' AT SOUTH STREET THEATER
description: ROMANCE is back - on 42d Street, of all places - a little scuffed and battered, but bright-eyed and pure of heart. There is not a single embrace in James Lecesne's ''One Man Band,'' but this musical sets the imagination off on a tour of romantic devotion that is shamelessly satisfying. You leave the South Street Theater with a new faith in passion, the pursuit of the perfect woman, the superior worth of any oddball who loves and loses, and with echoes in the mind of songs about loving and growing wise.

title: PLAN FOR LIE-DETECTOR TESTS
description: A Florida Congressman said today that he would introduce legislation to let the Defense Department use polygraph, or lie detector, tests for counterintelligence purposes on 3.7 million military or defense contractor personnel.

title: ITALIAN PROSECUTOR CALLS AGCA INCREDIBLE
description: Mehmet Ali Agca, again contradicting previous testimony, today gave new versions of events leading to the attempted assassination of Pope John Paul II that he says was commissioned by Bulgaria.

title: LOS ANGELES ART MUSEUM SEEKS SUPPORT IN NEW YORK
description: When the permanent home of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles opens its doors to the public, probably at the end of next year, the museum may preside over one of the largest exhibition areas for contemporary art in the United States.

title: Kidnapped Man Freed; $60,000 in Savings Gone
description: The police said today that an 81-year-old man was tied up and strapped to a bed for nine months while a woman cashed $60,000 worth of his checks and stock certificates.

title: 21 DIE AS FIREWORKS BLASTS DESTROY PLANT IN OKLAHOMA
description: At least 21 people were killed this morning in a series of explosions that leveled a fireworks plant near this rural village of about 200.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IN the world of culinary nomenclature, the use of some names is restricted. To name one example, a tournedos Rossini must be made with beef fillet cooked and served with foie gras, truffles and Madeira sauce - otherwise, it is not beef Rossini. By contrast, some names can be applied to a range of dishes whose basic ingredients vary.

title: Yeutter's Trade View
description: Clayton K. Yeutter, who is expected to be confirmed this week as President Reagan's chief trade negotiator, said at his Senate confirmation hearing today that the nation's $123 billion trade deficit was ''intolerable and unsustainable.'' He added that ''simultaneous, almost instantaneous,'' action was needed to redress it.

title: VMS Chairman Bullish On Hotel Investments
description: A day after the proposed $400 million sale of 28 Holiday Corporation hotels to VMS Realty Inc. was announced, Peter R. Morris, VMS's chairman and chief executive, had some advice for those who have backed away from investment in real estate until the tax picture clears.

title: JEWISH GROUP IN DRIVE FOR CHURCH-STATE SUITS
description: The American Jewish Congress, saying it is alarmed at the ''Christianizing of America,'' has assembled a fund-raising group of prominent lawyers to support litigation related to the separation of church and state.

title: Some Opening Lead Tactics Can Be a Help to Both Sides
description: Some of the refinements in opening leads that have been introduced in the past two decades represent double-edged swords. They slightly enlarge the information available to the opening leader's partner, but they also help the declarer. Who gets the best of it is a moot point.

title: BUILDING NEIGHBORHOOD PRIDE WITH BLACK GROUPS
description: One by one, as the setting sun's rays drop below a certain threshold and trip one photoelectric cell after another, the gaslight-style lanterns in front of each row house in the 1600 block of North Robinson Street automatically come on under the sycamore trees. First here, then there, then over there. By the time night has fallen the entire block, like most others in the surrounding West Philadelphia neighborhood, is bathed in light designed to discourage crime.

title: DUMONT RESIGNING AS U.S. ATTORNEY
description: The United States Attorney for New Jersey, W. Hunt Dumont, announced today that he was resigning to become vice president and general counsel of First Jersey Securities, a brokerage concern based in New York.

title: Ohio Utilities to Merge
description: Two electric utility companies in Ohio said yesterday that they would merge into a newly formed holding company, creating the first such consolidation in recent years.

title: RICK KUHN RECALLS POINT-SHAVING CASE
description: A former Boston College basketball player who has spent two years in prison for conspiring with professional gamblers to rig games told a Federal commission on crime yesterday about his role in the scandal and warned college athletes not to ''jeopardize their futures'' by succumbing to the temptations of ''big money.''

title: VALUE OF ONE LIFE? FROM $8.37 TO $10 MILLION
description: When a construction crane fell on Brigitte Gerney last month as she walked along Third Avenue, pinning her for six hours, the city leaped into action. Hundreds of police officers rerouted traffic throughout the Upper East Side. Two cranes were brought from other boroughs to lift the one that had fallen. Doctors from Bellevue Hospital set up a mobile hospital at the construction site. Emergency Service rescue workers risked their own lives to save hers. Once she was freed, the police halted traffic for 30 blocks along Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive to speed her trip to the emergency room.

title: Terrorism Embargo
description: To the Editor:

title: Meaning No Disrespect
description: What can be more tempting to a judge than to lower the boom on a lawyer lacking in proper respect? Chief Justice Burger, the nation's most powerful judge and long a champion of civility at the bar, deserves special praise for resisting that temptation in the case of Robert Snyder of Bismarck, N.D.

title: HARTMARX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
WESTERN STEER-MOM 'N' POP'S reports earnings for Qtr to May 17
TRANZONIC COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
3 Britons Questioned On Brussels Soccer Riot
description: The British police today questioned three people suspected of causing a riot at a soccer match in Brussels last month in which 38 people died.

title: PRICE CO LTD reports earnings for 12 wks to June 9
GOODEN HELPS CUBS TIE MARK FOR HAPLESSNESS
description: The longest losing streak in baseball this season reached 13 games today when the Chicago Cubs encountered Dwight Gooden and did not survive.

title: ABC, Capital Cities Approve Merger
description: Shareholders at both the American Broadcasting Companies and Capital Cities Communications Inc. yesterday voted in favor of the $3.5 billion merger of the two companies. The merger, expected to be completed by early 1986, still requires approval from the Federal Communications Commission.

title: SEVEN OAKS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
Eastern Vote Held On Merger Curbs
description: Frank Borman, chairman of Eastern Airlines, said at the company's annual meeting that a preliminary count indicated that shareholders had rejected proposed anti-takeover measures. The meeting, however, was adjourned until Monday to give shareholders more time to vote. Mr. Borman said that he did not expect any bids for the airline, and added that the company's debt of more than $2 billion would serve as adequate protection from an unwanted buyer.

title: THE REAGAN THREATS
description: There were signs tonight that President Reagan, by hinting at unspecified retaliatory moves within several days, may be hoping to provide an incentive for the Shiite leader Nabih Berri to free the 40 American hostages under the prodding of other governments.

title: TRANSTECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $1.6 million from the sale of real estate.

title: DRUG-TEST FAILURES WON'T BE REPORTED
description: Becton Regional High School students who fail new mandatory blood and urine tests for drug abuse next fall will not have their names turned over to the police, the school board has decided.

title: Chris-Craft's Stake in Warner
description: Chris-Craft Industries has increased its stake in Warner Communications Inc. from 28.5 percent, to 29.4 percent of the New York-based entertainment and communication corporation's shares outstanding.

title: AS INDIANS' RANKS IN CANADA GROW, OLD CONFLICTS ARE ALSO TRANSPLANTED
description: Ever since Canada lowered barriers to immigration in the 1970's, people from India have come here by the thousands to follow their dreams of a better life.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Recalled Billy Hatcher, outfielder from Des Moines in the American Association.

title: The Old and New Manager
description: Earl Weaver, in the visiting manager's office in Yankee Stadium Monday, leaned back in his chair and put one foot up on his desk. Then he removed his black-and-orange Orioles cap and placed it on his rubber-soled baseball shoe, and he sat there talking to guests with his shoe wearing his hat.

title: WINE TALK
description: WINE and travel are inextricably entwined. Half the romance of wine stems from where it is made. There is a fellow in Berkeley, Calif., Ralph Montali, who makes delightful wines in a plant near the railroad tracks in one of the worst sections of town. The idea makes economic sense and has yielded good results, yet something is missing.

title: MCI SEES BIG LIFT FROM I.B.M.
description: In inviting I.B.M. to buy into its business, the MCI Communications Corporation has confirmed what many business analysts have long believed: Competing in the deregulated world of telecommunications will require vast amounts of technology, the nation's largest corporations as customers, and a big reservoir of cash.

title: Loving the Cubs
description: These are dark days for fans of the Chicago Cubs, who are in the midst of a seemingly interminable losing streak and have slud, as Dizzy Dean used to say, from first to fourth place in the National League. But their loyal Washington supporters, huddled under the banner of the Emil Verban Memorial Society, are preparing to celebrate any minor evidences of recognition that may occur.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ALTHOUGH 168 years have passed since Dr. James Parkinson first described as ''shaking palsy'' the disease that now bears his name, medical science has thus far been unable to unravel the cause or causes of most Parkinson's cases or to devise a cure.

title: Firecracker in Oil Tank Kills Boy and Injures 4
description: Four teen-age boys Monday threw firecrackers into an old oil tank, setting off an explosion that killed one of the four, injured his father and the other three boys and rattled windows a mile away.

title: Rains Claim 18 in Bombay
description: Torrential rains killed at least 18 people here today and forced transportation services and financial markets to close. The weather bureau recorded about 16 inches of rain, the highest since the monsoon began, in the last 24 hours.

title: Mancini's Choice
description: Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini may or may not have made up his mind to retire, or he may or may not have made up his mind not to retire. Don't ask his manager, because he doesn't know.

title: RACAL ELECTRONICS PLC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Net income figures represent profit attributable to members of the parent company.

title: DECISION DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: TWO OFFICERS SHOOT A GUNMAN TO DEATH IN A SUBWAY STATION
description: A man brandishing a revolver was shot and killed by police officers in a Brooklyn subway station yesterday after he threatened to shoot a police sergeant, the police said.

title: WEILL'S DEPARTURE AT AMERICAN EXPRESS
description: It came as no surprise to anyone who knows Sanford I. Weill well that he had decided to resign as president of the American Express Company, a $62 billion conglomerate with a diverse range of businesses and run by a large bureaucracy.

title: PENSION INCREASE IS VOTED FOR CHIEF OF STATE'S MILITIA
description: The pension of Vito J. Castellano, the major general who commands the state's Organized Militia, would rise from $12,300 a year to $54,000 under a bill passed by the State Senate and Assembly on Monday.

title: REITMANS (CANADA) LTD reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
BLACK AND JEWISH LEADERS CALL FOR NEW HARMONY
description: Blacks and Jews share responsiblity for a ''breakdown of interaction'' between the two groups, David Saperstein, co-director of the Religious Action Center, and Benjamin L. Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said at a joint news conference today.

title: Bashing Weinberger
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, a consistent target of liberals, seems to have lost some of his luster in conservative eyes, too, now that the momentum of the military buildup is declining.

title: Matagorda Bonds Priced At Par for Texas Utility
description: An $81.7 million issue of pollution control revenue bonds for the Matagorda County Navigation District No. 1 of Texas, in behalf of the Central Power and Light Company, was tentatively priced at par through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: NBC FILM TRACKS START OF FIVE SINGERS' CAREERS
description: COMBINE cinema-verite with music video, dip into ''A Chorus Line'' for a cue or two, and you will begin to perceive the broad outlines of ''Reaching for the Stars,'' a two-hour film on NBC at 9 o'clock this evening. This exercise in entertainment docudrama, produced and directed by Bill Dunne for Dick Clark Cinema Productions, is a marketing package within a package, ingeniously devised to launch a singing group called ''Girls Rock Club.'' The product is a trifle too synthethic, but the biographies of the five struggling young women selected for possible fame are genuinely affecting. There is still a lot of mileage to be had in the story of the unknown who gets the opportunity to step out on that fabled stage of public performance and come back a star.

title: Last Dance?
description: All in all, things could be a lot better for the Gamblers. In what was probably a swan song under the dome - the switch to a fall season would mean direct competition with the Oilers - the U.S.F.L.'s Houston-based, playoff-bound franchise drew only 15,797 Monday night for the final regular-season game.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review in Weekend Friday of Satyajit Ray's film ''The Home and the World'' incorrectly described one of the actors, Victor Banerjee. He did not receive an Academy Award nomination for his performance in ''A Passage to India.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We will not allow this country to become a killing ground for international terrorism.'' - Deputy Prime Minister Erik H. Nielsen of Canada. [A10:1.]

title: Big Project On Hudson In Jersey
description: FOR all the projections and proposals for the New Jersey side of the Hudson River, the 18-mile-long sliver of land stretching from Fort Lee to Bayonne is still largely undeveloped.

title: A RARE 1620'S MEAL IN A LIVING MUSEUM
description: ''I DO board for Governor Bradford,'' said Thomas Cushman, carrying woven trays piled high with the small but thick loaves of freshly baked bread called cheates, ''but I've been sent over to labor.''

title: U.N. as Soviet and East-Bloc Espionage Base
description: To the Editor:

title: Talks on Afghan Dispute Said to Move Ahead
description: The United Nations mediator at talks between the Foreign Ministers of Afghanistan and Pakistan said today that negotiations on a political settlement of the Afghan conflict had ''moved forward'' during a three-day meeting here.

title: David Goodstein Dies at 53; Advocate for Homosexuals
description: David B. Goodstein, former publisher of The Advocate, a national publication based in Los Angeles, who was a leading spokesman for homosexuals, died Saturday at Sharp Memorial Hospital in San Diego from complications after surgery for bowel cancer. He was 53 years old and lived in Malibu, Calif.

title: APOGEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
F-H INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to March 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $13,948,000. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $2,417,000 and an extraordinary gain of $1,409,000.

title: EGYPT'S LEADER URGES WASHINGTON NOT TO USE FORCE IN HOSTAGE CRISIS
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt today condemned the Beirut airline hijacking and other acts of terrorism, but urged the United States not to resort to military action to free the hostages or to retaliate.

title: JOHNSON PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $478,000 for the quarter and $1,008,000 for the 9 months.

title: Hello, New York Sports Fans;   Modest Steps to Save Horse Racing
description: New York State's trotting and thoroughbred horse racing is in trouble. The tracks at which trotters pull sulkies and jockeys ride in saddles are losing business and state tax receipts, the latter declining from $170 million in 1970-71 near $100 million. The history and thrills of this old sport make it worth saving if that can be done at modest cost to taxpayers. A pending bill in the Legislature, if further improved, deserves a try.

title: F.D.I.C. SEEKS MERGER FOR CHINATOWN BANK
description: In an effort to quickly allow most depositors of the Golden Pacific National Bank access to their funds, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation yesterday began seeking a merger partner for the Chinatown bank that was closed last Friday by Federal authorities.

title: HISE-RISE IS PROPOSED ATOP BROWNSTONE ROW
description: An unusual plan to save the facades of three century-old brownstones on East 79th Street by building a 19-story apartment tower above and behind them was presented yesterday to the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: TIGERS AND MORRIS THWART RED SOX
description: Jack Morris pitched his third shutout of the season, and Darrell Evans hit a two-run homer tonight as the Detroit Tigers beat the Boston Red Sox, 3-0.

title: Carter to Bullets
description: Fred Carter, who was Kevin Loughery's assistant coach for the Chicago Bulls before Loughery was dismissed at the end of the season, will become an assistant to Gene Shue, coach of the Washington Bullets. He replaces Bernie Bickerstaff, who was recently named head coach of the Seattle SuperSonics. . . . Bill Walton of the Los Angeles Clippers flew to San Francisco yesterday to undergo a physical examination by Dr. Thomas Silva, the Boston Celtics' team physician.

title: Never Exit Raging
description: When America was a serious place marriage was a rich source of comedy.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 26, 1985

title: 5-NATION POLL ON U.N. FINDS HOPE AND FRUSTRATION
description: On the eve of the 40th anniversary of the signing of the United Nations charter in San Francisco, citizens of five major industrialized countries have expressed hopefulness, tempered by disappointment, about the organization, according to a poll by The New York Times, CBS News and the International Herald Tribune.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 26, 1985

title: Saatchi & Saatchi Seen Covering Many Angles
description: It is the considered opinion of Charles D. Crane of the brokerage firm of Oppenheimer & Company, that no agency anywhere has ''approached the worldwide business service market from as many angles as Saatchi & Saatchi.''

title: Panel on Constitution Named
description: President Reagan today named Chief Justice Warren E. Burger to head an 18-member commission to plan for the 1989 bicentennial of the Constitution.

title: BUSH, IN GERMANY, DISCUSSES SHIITES
description: Vice President Bush said today, apparently in a reference to Israel's imprisonment of more than 700 Lebanese Shiites and Palestinians, that ''people held against international law should be released.''

title: New President Set For Merged T.W.A.
description: Richard D. Pearson, who only a year ago was appointed executive vice president and chief operating officer at Trans World Airlines, will succeed C. E. Meyer Jr. as president of the carrier when it completes its merger with the Texas Air Corporation late this year, the airline announced yesterday.

title: UNDERSTANDING THE BUSINESS OF SPYING
description: The more one learns about the Walker family, the more one is mystified by this network of seamen - John, his son Michael, his brother Arthur and his longtime friend Jerry A. Whitworth - charged with selling military secrets to Moscow. The crucial question is: Why? What motivates people to live such dangerous lives, to risk life imprisonment and betray their country?

title: Comings and Goings
description: Muhammad Ali, the three-time heavyweight champion, and his third wife, Veronica, filed for divorce in Los Angeles Superior Court, said her attorney, Frederick J. Glassman. They were married eight years and have three children. . . . Jim Haney, assistant commissioner for the Metro Conference, was named commissioner of the Missouri Valley Conference.

title: Film Theater Planned At Lincoln Center Site
description: The Film Society of Lincoln Center has been given a $1.2 million grant by the Walter Reade Foundation for construction of a film theater in the Lincoln Center complex.

title: UNDERSTANDING THE BUSINESS OF SPYING
description: Democracies often manifest somnambulistic tendencies. One unintended advantage of the Walker spy case may be to show us, before it is too late, just how vulnerable we are to the increasingly sophisticated espionage of the Soviet Union.

title: GRUNTAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: 41-Year Sentence In Park Rape Case
description: A 23-year-old man suspected of committing several rapes in Central Park was sentenced yesterday to 41Z to 125 years in prison in one attack.

title: Gorbachev on a Visit to Kiev In His Meet-the-People Style
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, visited factories and research institutes in Kiev today, exhorting Ukrainians to undo bottlenecks that slow the introduction of new technology.

title: Accounts
description: Ligne Roset, a French furniture manufacturer, to AC&R Advertising and AC&R Public Relations.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: HINAULT HARBORS NO DOUBTS
description: The 72d Tour de France gets under way Friday, and already Bernard Hinault has reduced the three-week bicycle race to a single question: ''Look at the results last year - Fignon first, me second and Lemond third. Now Fignon won't be there. What answer do you get?''

title: Pan Am Will Resume Athens Service Friday
description: Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it would resume service to Athens on Friday.

title: NETS' PRESS TACTICS PUT OFF MASSIMINO
description: Maybe if the Nets had moved a little more quickly, Rollie Massimino would have been their coach. But the weeklong negotiations, coupled with speculation in the news media, gave the 50-year-old Villanova University coach too much time to think about what he would be leaving behind.

title: CHANCELLOR CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
ANDERSON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,628,175 for the latest year and $2,255,612 for the prior year.

title: Three Corporate Perspectives
description: The world's biggest computer maker, long dominant in mainframe machines, I.B.M. came from behind in the last five years to grab a leading share of the personal computer business as well. Since early 1983 I.B.M. has bought about 20 percent of Intel, the big semiconductor maker, which designed the key microprocessor used in the PC line.

title: ROBOT DEFENSE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Japanese Doctors to Examine A-Bomb Survivors in Hawaii
description: A team of Japanese doctors will offer free medical examinations to Hawaii residents who survived the World War II atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of erroneous material in a Government announcement, a Washington dispatch by The Associated Press in The Living Section last Wednesday gave an incorrect deadline for comments on a proposal to raise the permissible concentration of fluoride in drinking water. The deadline is July 15. Comments should be addressed to the Office of Drinking Water, Environmental Protection Agency, 401 M Street SW, Washington, D.C. 20460.

title: BE-BOP IS HAVING A REPRISE
description: AT the annual Kool Jazz Festival, audience reactions are often more intriguing than the programming. Some performers never really get started because of the festival's stop-watch timing, which may be necessary financially but can be inimical to a music that does not churn out its creativity by the clock. But curiously enough, there always seems to be time for cheers and standing ovations, and which musicians are getting them can be an accurate barometer of an audience's changing tastes.

title: DEMOCRATS MOVE TO SET NEW AGENDA
description: Members of the Democratic National Committee gave overwhelming support today to the efforts of their chairman, Paul G. Kirk Jr., to reshape the party's image and political agenda.

title: U.S. GIVES WARNING OF REPRISAL STEPS AIMED AT LEBANON
description: The White House, stepping up its efforts to free 40 Americans held hostage in Beirut, warned today of economic and military reprisals unless the captives were released in the ''next few days.''

title: New-Car Sales Off By 7.4% in Mid-June
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles declined 7.4 percent in the June 11-20 period from a robust pace at the same time last year, the nation's major manufacturers reported here today.

title: West German Is Indicted
description: A man suspected of belonging to the West German Red Army Faction was indicted today on charges of complicity in a 1981 bombing of the headquarters of the United States Air Force at Ramstein in which nine people were wounded, the Federal prosecutor's office said. The man, Helmut Pohl, 41 years old, is also accused of armed bank robbery, the office said in a statement.

title: Newsweek to Postpone 2d Issue on Technology
description: Newsweek is going to postpone the second annual publication of Newsweek Access, a special issue covering new technology that would have been sent free next November to executive subscribers. The announcement was made by Steve Price, the publisher, He said that while the first special issue last June was a distinct success, the signs of change in the high-technology marketplace indicate that Newsweek should wait before trying a repeat.

title: Clearinghouse Clerks Strike
description: Clerical employees of the Depository Trust Company, a clearinghouse for the New York Stock Exchange and other securities markets, went on strike yesterday after contract negotiations broke down.

title: Profit Taking Cuts Dow Rise to 2.47
description: Wall Street roared out of the starting gate yesterday on new evidence that the economy is strong, but at the finish stock prices were only moderately higher as investors engaged in profit taking.

title: DE TOMASO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: FILM: 'A MAN LIKE EVA'
description: AS the first phrases of Verdi's ''Traviata'' overture are heard on the soundtrack, the camera moves toward the facade of a rather handsome, going-to-seed, suburban villa, vaguely Victorian in design. The world is seen in half-light, but whether it's morning or night is impossible to tell.

title: 20 Take Blame in Frankfurt
description: Twenty claims of responsibility have been received for last Wednesday's bomb blast at the airport here, but little faith is placed in them, the prosecutor's office said today. As an example, a spokesman cited a letter from an ''Armenian Justice Committee'' that said it had carried out the attack against Turkish workers returning home from West Germany.

title: SOVIET REPORTED TO BUILD UP NUCLEAR ARSENAL
description: The Soviet Union is in the midst of nuclear weapons building boom that could double its arsenal of nuclear warheads by the mid-1990's if treaty restrictions are removed, according to new forecasts by Government intelligence agencies.

title: The Questions On Free Trade
description: THE big United States trade deficit is still widening. Despite an increase in real gross national product of just three-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter, imports rose by 5.4 percent, to $85.2 billion. In its current Financial Digest, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company says, ''Imports are not simply increasing in pace with U.S. economic growth, but are displacing U.S. production at an accelerating rate.''

title: SHIITE POWER STRUGGLE IN LEBANON IS CALLED A KEY TO HOSTAGE CRISIS
description: A power struggle is under way in southern Lebanon between fundamentalists who want to turn the largely Shiite region into an austere Iranian-style Islamic republic and a more secular, Westernized group that wants to preserve the open Lebanese character of the area.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Chase Manhattan Bank has appointed six senior vice presidents: Lynn R. Anderson, Mary B. Maguire, Chris J. Matlon, Fraser P. Seitel, Jeffrey A. Sell and Philip L. Toia.

title: South African Rebels Promise More Attacks
description: The leader of the African National Congress said today that the group would step up its guerrilla war against white rule in South Africa even if that causes many more civilian casualties.

title: Coast Residents Return After 2 Fires Put Out
description: A warehouse full of toxic chemicals continued to smolder today, but more than 7,500 evacuees were told they could return home after two of three blazes were extinguished by evening.

title: Guidry Learns To Compensate
description: He doesn't throw quite as hard as he used to, and so 34-year-old Ron Guidry, like most other pitchers of advanced tenure, has had to find ways to compensate. Two of those ways are a change-up and a slow curve, and a third is control so exceptional that he has walked only 14 batters in 112Z innings this year, the best ratio in the American League.

title: Looking Ahead
description: Working already on posterity, the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation board met in Washington yesterday and came up with a cost estimate and named an executive director to get the project moving.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS BILL AIMED AT IMPROVING AIRPORT SECURITY
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee today adopted by voice vote a bill aimed at improving security at foreign airports.

title: Macmillan Offers Convertible Issue
description: Macmillan Inc., the book publisher, is offering $75 million of 7 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures, due in 2010, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: SALICK HEALTHCARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Truck Crash Shuts Brooklyn Artery
description: A tank truck carrying heating oil crashed into a guard rail on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway yesterday, closing the six-lane road between Cadman Plaza West and Atlantic Avenue and causing jams for hours.

title: WALTER R. STAUB
description: Walter R. Staub, retired managing partner of the Stamford, Conn., accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand, died Saturday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 80 years old.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THROUGH THE SAFETY NET. By Charles Baxter. 216 pages. Viking. $14.95. IN the title story of Charles Baxter's new collection, a psychic tells Diana that he foresees ''calamity'' in her life. ''What kind? The Book of Job kind. I saw your whole life, your house, car, that swimming pool you put in last summer, the career, your child, and the whole future just start to radiate with this ugly black flame from the inside, poof, and then I saw you falling, like at the circus, down from the trapeze. Whoops, and down, and then through the safety net. Through the ground.''

title: Hawerchuk Signs
description: Dale Hawerchuk, the Winnipeg Jets center, signed a long-term, multimillion-dollar contract yesterday.

title: Japan Bank In U.S. Deal
description: The Industrial Bank of Japan Ltd. agreed yesterday to buy a 75 percent interest in the American banking, trust and leasing businesses of Schroders P.L.C., the big British merchant bank.

title: PENSION DISPUTE CREATES IMPASSE IN BUDGET TALKS
description: The House-Senate conference on the 1986 budget broke up this afternoon after the conferees reached a deadlock on Social Security.

title: RUSSIANS APPEAR WARY IN THE HOSTAGE SITUATION
description: Though the Soviet Union has said little in public about the American hostages held in Lebanon, Western and Arab diplomats believe that the situation is not to the Russians' liking and that they may try to help resolve the crisis.

title: ELSCINT LTD reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Rain Storms Kill 3 in Japan
description: Torrential rains that have lashed southwestern Japan for the last five days killed three people and injured five others, the national police reported today.

title: AT LEAST 135 U.S. AGENTS FOLLOWING UP CLUES IN NAVY SPY INQUIRY
description: The search for members of a Navy spy ring has turned into one of the largest espionage investigations in American history, involving more than 100 agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and more than a dozen bureau field offices, officials said today.

title: MCENROE GETS OFF TO A CALM START
description: When John McEnroe's opening-round match at Wimbledon was suspended because of the slick conditions on Centre Court Monday, it only postponed the inevitable: That McEnroe would eventually win as he did today, defeating an Australian, Peter McNamara, 6-4, 6-3, 6-4, and that the private life of the world's best tennis player would be scrutinized by the British press.

title: Pride Air Begins Flights on Aug. 1
description: Pride Air, a new national airline founded and financed primarily by its employees, said that it would begin taking reservations on July 8, with its first flights scheduled for Aug. 1. Substantially all of Pride Air's initial capitalization of $15 million was contributed by employees, most of whom were formerly with Continental Airlines, which filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: 1 Count Dismissed In Stun-Gun Case
description: A judge yesterday threw out a misdemeanor conspiracy count against five Queens police officers charged with assaulting prisoners by beating them or torturing them with an electric stun gun.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Gastronomic Beachhead Brooklyn Heights, its uncontested charms notwithstanding, has never been known as an area of gastronomic interest. The explosion of restaurants, take-out shops and specialty food stores that struck Manhattan seemed to pass this neighborhood by. In the last six months, however, several take-out shops have opened, possibly heralding a culinary renaissance for the area.

title: THE INTRUSION OF TELEVISION IN THE HOSTAGE CRISIS
description: TELEVISION has been reporting on the hostage crisis; it has been a participant in negotiations to end the crisis as well. At the same time, it sometimes appears to come close to rationalizing terrorism. Television does not mean to do this, but it is implicit in much of the coverage. Show that Shiite Moslems are poor and deprived. Point out that a hijacking, say, or a bombing is the weapon of the powerless. Terrorism is not something just to be deplored, then; it is something to be understood.

title: BLOCK H R INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
HOUSE APPROVES MEASURES TO LIMIT PENTAGON FUND
description: In what some members said was an angry reaction to reports of fraud and waste at the Pentagon, the House of Representatives today overwhelmingly approved an array of measures to crack down on military contracting.

title: HENRY P. COLE
description: Henry P. Cole, a retired Wall Street stockbroker, died of pneumonia Saturday at Athol (Mass.)

title: TIC INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a $102,000 tax benefit. c-Net loss

title: Slow the Flow of Stadium Suds
description: Disturbed by the drunken rowdiness he recently witnessed at Yankee Stadium, State Assemblyman Richard Brodsky proposes to require alcohol-free ''family sections'' at New York's main spectator events. It's worth trying.

title: Yes, There Is Something We Can Do
description: Nothing will come of new measures to protect air travel unless governments unite to improve security arrangements and, above all, to punish nations that protect known terrorists.

title: HENRY KALLEM
description: Henry Kallem, a New York artist and an abstract expressionist, died of an apparent heart attack Monday at his summer home in Monhegan Island, Me. He was 73 years old.

title: OFFICIALS IN IRELAND DISCUSS HOW TO APPROACH INQUIRY INTO AIR-INDIA DISASTER
description: Officials began discussions today on how to investigate the crash of an Air-India airliner that fell into the Atlantic on Sunday, taking 329 people to their deaths.

title: PARK AIDE SAYS HE 'NEVER SAW' SMOKE ALARMS
description: An official of the Great Adventure amusement park testified today that he had never seen any smoke detectors in the park's Haunted Castle, where eight teen-agers died in a fire last year.

title: TRAVELODGE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
YOUNG UNWED MOTHERS LEARN A TRADE
description: DENISE RUTLEDGE is 4 feet 8 inches tall - tall enough, her friends say, to be a secretary or a computer programmer, but a welder? Two months ago, however, Miss Rutlege startled them by building an 8-foot-high Sheetrock wall, demolishing it with a hammer, then carefully reconstructing it.

title: DRYING VEGETABLES AND FRUITS AT HOME
description: ONE way to preserve summer's fresh fruits and vegetables for enjoyment throughout the year is to dry and store them. The Harvest Maid Dehydrator dries fruits, vegetables, meat and fish easily and evenly in the home. With this cleverly designed machine you can make everything from banana chips, cinnamon-flavored apple rings and granola mix to yogurt bits, beef jerky and spicy corn chips.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 9.50-10.00** Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: From Toe to Head
description: Amid the tangle of ballet shoes and tights in Cassandra Phifer's dressing room are piles of sequins and a glue gun. Miss Phifer, a principal with the Dance Theater of Harlem, is making all the headdresses for ''La Mer,'' which has its New York premiere tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: JAPANESE PONDERING IF BOMB WAS MEANT FOR AIR-INDIA JET
description: Japanese police investigators were considering the possibility today that the bomb that exploded inside baggage from Canada at Narita Airport on Sunday went off by mistake and was actually intended for an Air-India flight from Tokyo to Bombay.

title: Time to Make SUNY A Public Corporation
description: To the Editor:

title: Fever Subsides For Pipelines
description: THE takeover fever affecting natural gas pipeline stocks has suddenly subsided, thanks in large measure to prospects of new Government regulations that are viewed by Wall Street analysts as cutting into the future profits of this giant industry.

title: DANCE: Sally Gross
description: SALLY GROSS works in a style that is very much her own and that keeps on developing, quietly but steadily, every year. She presents her dances infrequently, and so ''In the beginning . . .,'' a program of eight short pieces performed on Thursday at Miss Gross's Westbeth studio, was an event.

title: Uncertain Future
description: The future of Mike Norris is uncertain, even at the Class A level. Sandy Alderson, the general manager of the Oakland A's, said Norris's pitching stint at the team's Modesto farm club was being cut short.

title: Terror and the United Nations
description: It's one of the many ironies of our time that the nations of the world are now involved in another spasm of international terrorism precisely on the 40th anniversary of the signing of the peace charter of the United Nations.

title: IN 2 DAYS, JACKSON FUFILLS 3 PROMISES
description: At a political reception, in a sermon and at a high school commencement, the Rev. Jesse Jackson made good several longstanding promises during a two-day trip to New York this week.

title: NAZI-HUNTERS PICK NEW TOP TARGETS
description: With Josef Mengele now widely acknowledged to be dead, leading Nazi-hunters have been reassessing their priorities while primarily blaming West Germany for the failure to capture and try the death camp doctor.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Protesters' Shacks Razed by Cornell
description: Cornell University crews today tore down today 15 shanties built by anti-apartheid protesters opposing the university's investments in companies doing business in South Africa.

title: Logging Road Is Barred Near Tribal Worship Site
description: Generations of Indians traveled to the high country of the Siskiyou Mountains for religious and medicinal ceremonies, and that tradition should continue without the roar of trucks and loggers' saws, according to a Federal appeals court.

title: GERSTNER REVITALIZED TRAVEL UNIT
description: For all of the publicized moves into stocks and bonds and cable television, what pays the rent at American Express is still credit cards, traveler's checks and travel.

title: OFFICERS MUST PAY $2.3 MILLION TO WIFE MAIMED BY HUSBAND
description: A Federal jury awarded $2.3 million today to a woman who contended that Torrington police officers had violated her rights by failing to protect her from an attack by her estranged husband.

title: UPSTATE JUDGE IS NAMED TO U.S. COURT OF APPEALS
description: Roger J. Miner, a Federal district judge from upstate New York, was nominated yesterday by President Reagan for a seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Japan to Lower Tariffs
description: Japan announced today that it would cut tariffs on more than 1,800 products in the first stage of a program to improve access to its markets.

title: PARLIAMENT MAY BE DISSOLVED
description: Portugal's Socialist Prime Minister formally submitted his resignation today amid predictions that Parliament would be dissolved and elections called.

title: STAGE: LONDON QUARTET OF SHAKESPEARE ROYALTY
description: Although tourist theatergoers often think of London in terms of cats (as in ''Cats'') and mice (''The Mousetrap''), it is Shakespeare's ''bottled spider,'' Richard III, who has seized the imagination of London audiences this year. Antony Sher's bravura portrayal of the villainous king for the Royal Shakespeare Company is the town's hottest black-market ticket. The play is sold out until the fall - after which Mr. Sher plans to depart for the West End premiere of ''Torch Song Trilogy'' -and hardly a day goes by without a newspaper feature extolling the 36-year-old, South African-born actor's prowess.

title: REFORM RABBIS REJECT A CALL TO REASSESS FRIDAY SERVICES
description: Reform rabbis meeting here today rejected a call by their outgoing president to reassess the movement's 100-year-old emphasis on Friday night temple worship.

title: U.S. Inquiry Sought On Hiring Practices
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan asked the General Accounting Office today to investigate the hiring and salary practices at federally financed sewer projects under construction in New York City.

title: Nixon Calling
description: Former President Nixon telephoned the Georgetown home of Benjamin C. Bradlee, the executive editor of The Washington Post, Tuesday night during a surprise party for John Lindsay, a Newsweek correspondent who is seriously ill. The reason for his call was to deliver a get-well message to Mr. Lindsay.

title: Anderson, Clayton Is Dropping B.&B.
description: Anderson, Clayton & Company, Houston, announced yesterday that it would be dropping Benton & Bowles as an agency after more than 30 years because of its impending merger with D'Arcy MacManus Masius.

title:
WHEN TERRORISTS TAKE HOSTAGES;

NATIONS AREN'T INNOCENT
description: Nothing can justify the terrorism practiced by the Shiites, the Iranians, the Palestinians and other desperate groups who wage war on innocent victims. But then what can justify terrorism as introduced and practiced by most of the great powers whenever it served their ends over the past century or so?

title: West German Vessels Collide
description: A West German Navy submarine collided with the motor vessel Wilhelmine Oltmann in fog today near the mouth of the Kiel Canal, the coastal police said.

title: SIKH SUSPECT TOOK EXPLOSIVES COURSE
description: One of two Sikhs being sought for questioning in the crash of the Air-India jumbo jet off Ireland and an airline baggage explosion in Japan took a course in explosives at a private school for mercenaries near here, according to the school's director.

title: Brain-Damaged Woman Survives an Abortion
description: A brain-damaged woman, whose parents said she was raped at a convalescent home, was listed in good condition today, a day after doctors completed an abortion on her.

title: Soviet Defector Sentenced To 20 Years in Bank Robbery
description: A former Soviet warrant officer who defected to the West in 1979 by scaling the Berlin Wall has been sentenced to 20 years in prison for a bank holdup and shooting.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HALLEY'S FLIGHT Halley's Comet, which appears every 75 years, will become visible to the naked eye in January. But the Hayden Planetarium is starting the introductions early - today, in fact -with ''Halley's Comet: Once in a Lifetime,'' a 16-minute mini-feature that runs through November 24. The film, which is narrated by William Shatner of ''Star Trek'' fame, will examine the history, best ways of seeing the comet and the space probes being planned for the event by Japan, the Soviet Union and the European Space Agency.

title: Attendance Mark
description: Attendance at major league baseball games reached 20 million Tuesday night, the earliest date that mark has been reached. Attendance reached 20 million on June 27 in 1984. But the season started a week later this year, meaning there have been 54 fewer dates (875) this season than when the mark was reached last season (929).

title: SLOW START FOR TV AD SEASON
description: During the last two weeks of June, when many New Yorkers are winding down for summer vacations, the three major TV networks are frantically making deals with advertisers clamoring to buy time on next season's prime-time shows.

title: Pact Ratified At Fremont
description: The ratification of a landmark contract for members of the United Automobile Workers at the joint General Motors-Toyota auto making venture is ''icing on the cake'' for workers, according to a union official.

title: SOVIET COUPLE PLEAD GUILTY IN PLEA BARGAIN AT SPY TRIAL
description: In a plea bargain with the Government, a Soviet emigre couple accused of spying with an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation pleaded guilty today to avoid possible life sentences.

title: ERROR AID YANKS' RALLY IN 9TH
description: Earl Weaver asked about voodoo dolls - a silly question perhaps, but not when you stop to consider the unlikely events that transpired last night at the Stadium.

title: Capital Dining: Much Better, but . . .
description: In this city, where power is the bottom line, what you eat is less important than where you eat and with whom. Which would seem to explain why Duke Zeibert's, where the food is not highly rated, is nevertheless crowded with high-powered people at lunch, while only a few feet away at Le Pavillon, a French restaurant whose menu would rank at or near the top in any city, there are empty tables.

title: Where the Chancellor Missed
description: Chancellor Nathan Quinones has issued his first report card on New York City's school system, which is to say on his own performance. He is entitled to be pleased about better reading and math scores and a slight increase in daily attendance. But over all, the Chancellor's first-year performance should be marked only satisfactory.

title: Its a Matter Of Time for Bol
description: If you thought that expansion, balanced schedules and playoff formats were the only hot topics of talk in pro basketball these days, then you were on the outs when the subject turned, as it frequently has, to Manute Bol's age.

title: Required Reading
description: Education and Value Excerpts from a recent report by the trustees of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, as inserted into the Congressional Record by Senator Robert T. Stafford, Republican of Vermont:

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: US MEDICAL ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-There are no comparable figures because the company was then operating as a number of general partnerships.

title: Pollution Bonds For Middle South
description: Claiborne County, Miss., tentatively priced yesterday a $44 million issue of pollution control revenue bonds to be used by Middle South Energy Inc. for its Grand Gulf nuclear project, through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: WILANDER UPSET BY YUGOSLAV
description: His opponent was one of those players who appear to lie in wait at Wimbledon, as if hiding in the grass that transforms their game and makes them suddenly formidable. So even before Mats Wilander walked onto Centre Court today to face the overpowering serves of Slobodan Zivojinovic, he understood this would not be one of those ceremonial first-round matches that are usually regarded as dress rehearsals.

title: REMOTE CONTROL PANELS THAT TAKE CARE OF IT ALL
description: Like a shirt with concealed buttons, the rooms in a duplex apartment in U.N. Plaza -newly redecorated by L.J.K. Design of New York -seem to have something missing: The walls have no switches of any kind and look oddly blank.

title: Letter: On Subways;   The Graffiti Battle Is Being Fought
description: To the Editor:

title: L. Frank Baum in Mickey Mouse Land
description: To the Editor:

title: PILLSBURY CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: WEDCO TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $49,000. c-Net income

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Cubs, at Chicago. Finale of the three-game series. This is a rematch between Ron Darling and the Cubs' Rick Sutcliffe, who faced each other 10 days ago; both pitched five-hitters but Darling got some offensive help and won, 2-0. (Television - Channel 9, 4 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 4 P.M.) Golf United States Golf Association Senior Open, at Stateline, Nev. Opening round for players age 50 and over at the Edgewood Tahoe course. Arnold Palmer, coming off an 11-shot victory in the Senior Tournament Players Championship in Ohio last weekend, goes for his second Senior Open title. The 55-year-old won in 1981. Danny Thomas Memphis Classic, opening round. This tournament was played the first week in August of last year, and Bob Eastwood won it. Manufacturers Hanover Westchester P.G.A., at Darien, Conn. The final in this tournament for the area's top professionals. Tennis All England Championships, at Wimbledon. The fourth day of action. (Television - HBO, 5 P.M. to 8 P.M. taped.) Other Events BASKETBALL: Stroh's Rucker Pro Summer League fourth annual Herman (Helicopter) Knowings Memorial Scholarship Classic, at Hunter College Subterranean Sportsplex, 68th Street and Lexington Avenue. The women's all-star game at 6 P.M. and the men's all-star game at 8 P.M. help to raise scholarship money in the name of the legendary Knowings was killed while driving a gypsy cab in 1980. United States Basketball League: Wildwood (N.J.) Aces vs New Jersey Jammers at William Paterson College, Wayne, N.J., 7:30 P.M., and Rhode Island Gulls vs.

title: U.N. REPORT SAYS FINNS HELPED 11 DESERT SOUTH LEBANON MILITIA
description: A United Nations board of inquiry has established that 11 Christian-led militiamen deserted to the Shiite Amal militia in southern Lebanon earlier this month and that Finnish soldiers of the United Nations helped in the desertion.

title: CANADIANS MOURN AIR-INDIA VICTIMS
