description: Flags at Government buildings flew at half-staff across Canada today to mourn the 329 victims aboard an Air India jumbo jetliner, as investigators continued to explore the possibility that terrorists were involved in the crash of the plane Sunday.

title: Kenney Signs
description: The quarterback Bill Kenney has signed a four-year contract with the Kansas City Chiefs believed to be worth $2.5 million.

title: ALBERTA PREMIER QUITS AS HEAD OF GOVERNING PARTY
description: The Premier of Alberta resigned today as head of the province's governing Progressive Conservative Party, a step likely to lead to his departure as government leader as early as September.

title: GENESEE BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CORRECTIONS
description: A Dallas dispatch yesterday on a speech on Jewish-black relations at a meeting of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People misidentified Morris B. Abram. He is a member of the United States Commission on Civil Rights and a former head of the American Jewish Committee. He has never been an official of the Anti-Defamation League.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 27, 1985

title: THE DANCE: 'FALL RIVER'
description: THERE was excitement Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, when Dance Theater of Harlem offered a pleasant new ballet and a shattering performance of Agnes de Mille's ''Fall River Legend.'' Miss de Mille's dance-drama about Lizzie Borden, the shy New England woman who was accused of murdering her father and stepmother with an ax, helped make the evening memorable. ''Piano Movers,'' the new work, added a touch of amiability to the occasion.

title: Vice Chairman Quits Pillsbury
description: The Pillsbury Company said today that its vice chairman, Winston R. Wallin, would be leaving the company to become president and chief executive of Medtronic Inc., a Minneapolis-based manufacturer of implantable medical devices.

title: JAZZ FESTIVAL SHOWS OFF HEALTHY ART
description: THE Kool Jazz Festival is now in full swing, and a cursory glance at its programs might suggest mere business as usual. Many of the old familiar names are there, recognized greats in the now nearly century-old history of jazz. Their presence seems to indicate that jazz and George Wein, the Kool producer, rest comfortably secure within their world, sure as to who and what they are and unthreatened - artistically, conceptually and even commercially - by other musical styles.

title: Krickstein Loses
description: Aaron Krickstein joined Mats Wilander as the only seeded men eliminated in the first round when he was defeated by an American, Bud Schultz, 6-4, 3-6, 7-6, 6-4. In other feature matches, Jimmy Connors, seeded third, beat Stefan Simonsson of Sweden; Anders Jarryd, also of Sweden and seeded fifth, defeated Claudio Panatta of Italy; Yannick Noah beat Brad Gilbert of the United States, and Tim Mayotte defeated Trevor Alan of Australia. Page B14.

title: Baltimore Gas
description: Baltimore Gas and Electric offered $100 million of 10-year floating-rate notes. The notes, which mature on July 1, 1995, were priced at 99.55. The rate will be reset and interest is payable quarterly at 110 basis points over three-month Treasury bill bond equivalent, with an 8 to 12 percent range. Paine Webber acted as lead underwriter for the offering, which has been rated AA- by McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei, AA-2 by Moody's and AA- by S.&P.

title: COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for Year to May 31
Bridge: Transfer Plays Rare Tactic For Most of Those at Table
description: Transfer bids are now common, used by more than 80 percent of the experts by a recent count. But transfer plays are rare indeed: The majority of players are probably unaware they exist.

title: SHULTZ WANTS U.S. FORCEFUL IN U.N.
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz characterized the United Nations tonight as a ''troubled organization,'' but added that the United States ''must play a forceful role in the United Nations to protect its interests.''

title: Pandas at National Zoo Fail in Mating Attempt
description: Scientists at the National Zoo said today that it appeared Ling-Ling, the female giant panda, passed through this year's reproductive cycle without mating with her partner, Hsing-Hshng.

title: OTHERS DEPRESSED, FREE HOSTAGE SAYS
description: The American hostage freed in Beirut today, James Dell Palmer, arrived here en route home and told reporters that the 39 other Americans were ''very depressed.''

title: SALVADORAN OFFICER LINKED TO KILLINGS
description: Three previously unknown witnesses gave new testimony today that a Salvadoran Army captain directly participated in the killing of two American agrarian advisers and the head of the Salvadoran land-redistribution institute here in 1981, according to a senior official of the United States Embassy.

title: HUNT FOR TWO SIKHS CENTERED ON BRITISH COLUMBIA
description: Authorities hunting two Sikhs for questioning in connection with the mysterious crash of an Air-India jumbo jet and a airline baggage explosion in Japan are concentrating their search on British Columbia, where about 80,000 Sikhs live.

title: FINK OFFERS PLAN TO SHIFT BUSINESSES'TAX BURDEN
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink today released the details of legislation designed to inject what he said was ''fundamental fairness and equity'' into the way in which businesses pay taxes in New York.

title: Ohio Utilities' Merger Enhances Two Careers
description: Back in 1948, when Robert M. Ginn was applying for his first job - in the finance department at the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company - the interviewer asked him about his career goals. ''Someday I'd like to make $10,000 a year,'' Mr. Ginn answered.

title: CANCER ANTIBODY TESTING FAILS
description: New tailor-made antibodies may not be as effective against some cancers as hoped because the cancers can change to avoid detection, two groups of scientists reported today.

title: I. Goldberg & Partners Eager for Accounts
description: Only last month it was announced that Irwin Goldberg, executive vice president and co-creative director of Nadler & Larimer, would be vice chairman and executive creative director of the agency that had been reorganized into Calvillo, Shevack, Goldberg & Partners.

title: UNION AT KENNEDY SHUNS BEIRUT JET
description: A union at Kennedy International Airport refused to service a Lebanese airliner when it arrived there Tuesday, and the union's leader said yesterday that he would ask his members to do the same thing on Saturday when the airline's next flight is expected.

title: ALLEGATIONS OF MONEY LAUNDERING DISPUTED BY JERSEY CASINO OPERATOR
description: The owner of an Atlantic City casino yesterday disputed assertions by Federal authorities that heroin traffickers ''laundered'' at least $1 million from drug sales through his gambling house in 1982.

title: UNITED SOFTWARE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FOOD LION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 15
QUALITY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: I.B.M.-MCI LINK SEEN SPEEDING DEREGULATION
description: The proposed partnership between the International Business Machines Corporation and the MCI Communications Corporation could speed up the continuing deregulation of the telecommunications industry, according to Federal officials involved in telecommunications policy.

title: CRIMINAL INQUIRY IN CHEESE CASE
description: Citing a ''strong possibility'' that unpasteurized milk had been deliberately used in tainted Mexican-style cheese, Los Angeles County District Attorney Ira Reiner announced today that his office would conduct a criminal investigation into an outbreak of Listeria, a bacterial disease that has killed 48 people since mid-March.

title: MUSIC: 'ROBERT LE DIABLE' AT THE PARIS OPERA
description: It's not often that an opera company revives a work hardly anyone has heard and then notes demurely in the upper left-hand corner of the program that this is the company's 755th performance of the piece. But that's what happened Monday night at the Paris Opera, with the unveiling of its new production of Meyerbeer's ''Robert le Diable.''

title: Wiggins Deal Pending
description: The San Diego Padres and the Baltimore Orioles have worked out a deal that would send Alan Wiggins to Baltimore, pending final agreement of all parties, according to Ballard Smith, the president of the Padres. ''There is no deal until everybody's agreed,'' Smith said, noting that the trade must be approved by both leagues' offices, the Major League Players Association and Commissioner Peter Ueberroth.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Tuesday about rising delinquencies on home mortgage payments incorrectly reported the name of a private Government-created investment organization. It is the Federal National Mortgage Association.

title: BLUESKY OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
MCI Chief Expects To Stay in Charge
description: Wall Street analysts expect the International Business Machines Corporation to eventually buy all of the MCI Corporation, but that does not faze William G. McGowan, MCI's chairman and chief executive. Not only does Mr. McGowan think MCI will preserve its free-wheeling style, but he thinks that he will remain very much in charge of the nation's No. 2 long-distance telephone company.

title: NEW DESIGN FOR SIGHT AND SOUND
description: It wasn't so long ago that a large-screen television installed in the living room created a focal point for home activities. Everyone could gather in one room and watch a show.

title: Alexander Unit
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., the insurance broker, said that it had reached an agreement in principle to sell the Lloyd's of London insurance management operations of its Alexander Howden Underwriting Ltd. to executives of the subsidiary. The subsidiary is part of its Alexander Howden Group, which it bought in 1982. Alexander & Alexander earned $10.7 million in the first quarter of 1985 after losing $49.6 million last year, when it wrote off $77.1 million for discontinued casualty operations.

title: Somalia Reports Cholera Is Spreading in Camps
description: A Health Ministry official has reported a new outbreak of cholera among famine refugees in northwestern Somalia and said it was spreading to refugee camps in the central and southwestern districts.

title: Let Banks Sell Insurance
description: Banks think they can sell insurance more cheaply and conveniently than insurance companies. Insurers apparently think so too, for they are fighting an effort by banks in New York State to enter the business. In fact they are going further, asking Congress for a national prohibition against the underwriting or brokerage of insurance by banks.

title: STANDUN INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $188,000 for the quarter and $268,000 for the 6 months.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: NEW tools make it easier to work on big outdoor painting jobs such as siding, masonry or fences. Paint rollers can be a lot faster than a brush on some surfaces, and flat painting pads can be preferable for some jobs. Even spraying, once limited to professionals, is now popular with amateurs because there are new types of ''airless'' paint sprayers designed for amateurs.

title: RULING ABOUT SABBATH WORK SEEN AS HAVING SLIGHT IMPACT
description: The bluntness and near unanimity of yesterday's Supreme Court decision on Sabbath work were surprising, according to people on both sides of the case. They suggested, however, that the impact of the ruling was likely to be small.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 27, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: 10,000 Names
description: George McDonald's image as an unorthodox candidate remained intact yesterday as he set up a table outside St. Patrick's Cathedral to collect signatures on Democratic designating petitions to qualify for the primary for City Council president.

title: RSI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Technology;   New Methods To Clean Coal
description: THE technology of burning coal is undergoing what energy experts say is the largest advance in more than a century. Hundreds of companies are researching and applying methods to burn the traditionally dirty fuel as cleanly as oil. They include large boiler makers, utilities and engineering companies as well as small industries.

title: FREDERICK PACKARD, PROFESSOR OF SPEECH AT HARVARD U., DIES
description: Frederick C. Packard Jr., who was a professor of speech and dramatics at Harvard University for 45 years, died of Alzheimer's disease Monday in a nursing home here. He was 86 years old.

title: Canadian Economy Up
description: Canada's economy grew four-tenths of 1 percent in April, led by the first monthly rise in industrial output this year, the Government reported today. The gross domestic product increased to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $128.7 billion (Canadian) from $128.2 billion in March and $123.1 billion a year earlier.

title: Advertising;   The House Agency Fights On
description: HOUSE agencies are not necessarily house agencies, as a very independent Edgar Jay House, age 31 and Yale class of '75, is determined to prove.

title: Big Fishing Prizes Are on the Line
description: Those bewildered by the fascination that organized, big-money competitive angling holds for some will be further befuddled by Ray Scott's announcement that more than two-thirds of a possible total of 225 entrants have already signed up for an $845,000 black bass tournament this October. The tournament, which has an entry fee of $5,000, will be held on a lake in Disney World, Fla.

title: SAN FRANCISCO LOOKING BACK TO U.N. BIRTH
description: Hostesses handed out white carnations and the San Francisco Boys Choir sang a specially written song of peace as this city celebrated the signing of the United Nations Charter here 40 years ago today.

title: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVCE co reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
MENGELE WAS REPORTEDLY HELD IN P.O.W. CAMPS RUN BY U.S.
description: Josef Mengele was detained in a series of American prisoner of war camps at the end of World War II, but was released into the American occupation zone in Germany without being identified, according to a report here.

title: IMPACT OF FLUTIE DOUBTED
description: If Doug Flutie plays, his presence will make little difference in Monday night's playoff game at Giants Stadium between the Generals and the Baltimore Stars, according to the Stars' defensive captain.

title: ANJELICA OF THE HUSTONS, BACK IN THE FAMILY FOLD
description: At 15, Anjelica Huston took the gift of movie stardom and threw it in her father's face. At 33, tougher and less rebellious, she gratefully crept into a smaller role in her father's latest movie and ran off with the picture.

title: Missing Face
description: Met fans who want to buy the revised edition of the club's yearbook, the one that comes out at midseason, may notice that a familiar face is missing from the team picture. The photo session was last Friday, and all the players attended except George Foster, who, stuck in traffic, missed it as cleanly as if it were one of those sliders down in the dirt.

title: IN EAST HARLEM, FIRST 'PERCENT' ART
description: A pink, 4-ton, 14-foot-high sculpture was unveiled in an East Harlem park yesterday, becoming the first artwork to be built under a new program that requires 1 percent of the construction funds for new city buildings to be spent on art.

title: HERS
description: THERE was a phone-in program about dating on the radio this morning, and the host, an earnest man with a cause, had just asked a 37-year-old self-proclaimed achiever to describe his physical appearance for the women in the listening audience.

title: Cadillac, Daon Sale
description: The Cadillac Fairview Corporation said it and the Daon Development Corporation had sold a jointly owned office building on Market Street in San Francisco for $140 million to two limited partnerships sponsored by Merrill Lynch Hubbard Inc., a unit of Merrill Lynch & Company.

title:
GARDENING;

BIRDS FIND HAVEN IN BROOKLYN YARD
description: ONCE a traditional gardener unbends enough to become a wildflower gardener, it is an easy step to wildlife gardener. One such city gardener is Joan Mullin of Brooklyn, who lives on a street of comfortable, detached houses with tidy front yards.

title: New Tulane Case Plea
description: A former Tulane student will plead guilty to charges of conspiracy, making him the third defendant to reach a plea-bargaining agreement in the basketball point-shaving scandal. Court records revealed that Mark Olensky, 21 years old, a former accounting major from Fair Lawn, N.J., would enter guilty pleas to two counts of conspiracy to commit sports bribery. One additional count of conspiracy and 10 counts of sports bribery against Olensky were dismissed by prosecutors.

title: POLITICAL BUDGET
description: The deadlock in the House-Senate negotiations over the budget is a case of 1986 politics overtaking 1985 policy questions.

title: Cooper Settles S.E.C. Charges
description: Cooper Laboratories Inc. settled charges today brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it failed to promptly disclose its sales of Frigitronics Inc. shares at a time when there was market speculation that Cooper might be trying to take over Frigitronics.

title: Dow Edges Up 0.78, to 1,323.81
description: Stock prices rose slightly yesterday on Wall Street, but investors remained conservative as they continued to hear mixed reviews about the nation's economy and pessimistic forecasts over Federal budget talks.

title: The High Cost of Lehman's Talent
description: Private investment banking firms have been able to woo, and hold, talented people by offering lucrative packages of salary, annual bonuses and shares in the firm. For some of the 72 partners at Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, this added up to well over $1 million a year - not even counting the growing value of their shares.

title: GREEN PARTY BLUES: JUST A NORMAL PARTY? HORRORS!
description: In its six years of existence, the Green Party has been living on a roller coaster of electoral expectations.

title: EXCERPTS FROM COURT OPINIONS ON LAW FOR EMPLOYEE TIME OFF FOR SABBATH
description: Following are excerpts from opinions by the Supreme Court today in its 8-to-1 decision that states may not require employers to provide time off for religious observance. Chief Justice Warren E. Burger wrote the majority opinion. Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote a concurring opinion. Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist dissented without opinion.

title: APPLE SEEKS SUPPLIER LINKS
description: Apple Computer Inc. wants to increase ties with outside software and hardware suppliers in an effort to quickly increase the versatility of its Macintosh computer, Apple's president and chief executive, John Sculley, said here today.

title: AMERICAN SPORTS ADVISORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
Retrenchments Set By Intel and Gould
description: In separate developments reflecting difficulties in the semiconductor industry, the Intel Corporation said yesterday that it would lay off about 950 employees and Gould Inc. said that it would take a $150 million write-off in the second quarter.

title: Vietnamese Visits Moscow
description: The Vietnamese Communist Party leader, Le Duan, traveled to the Soviet Union with a delegation today for an official visit, the Hanoi radio announced in a broadcast monitored in Bangkok.

title: FROM CONSUMER AFFAIRS TO ARMS CONTROL POLICY
description: THE stereotype of home economics as the domain of those who want to learn to cook thicker stews or sew straighter hems has stuck in the nation's mind like burnt cake in a baking pan. ''You figured you would be a homemaker or a teacher or, if you were really ambitious, a nurse,'' said Meredith Fernstrom, a graduate of the University of North Carolina, discussing what it was like to be a college home economics major in the 1960's.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;

'THE FENCES ARE TOO CLOSE'
description: In the glow of sunset before the softball game began, the manager stood behind the high home-plate screen at Montclair State and signed autographs.

title: 4 More Held in Britain In Purported Bomb Plot
description: The British police detained four more suspects today in an operation aimed at stopping what they described as a plot by Irish Republican Army guerrillas to bomb seaside resorts.

title: TENTATIVE PACT SET IN WALKOUT AT CITY'S HOTELS
description: A tentative contract was agreed on yesterday in the 26-day-old strike against 53 of the city's busiest hotels, and workers began abandoning their picket lines.

title: Closing Up Money Laundries
description: Banks and law enforcement agencies are finally moving against money-laundering - the disguising of illegally earned cash. Until recently, too many bank tellers did not even twitch when brought bags of limp $20 bills and asked for large cashier's checks. Banks are supposed to report suspicious cash but most are just starting to comply. Federal agents, spurred by Congress and the President's Commission on Organized Crime, are at last coordinating with banks and taking action.

title: FUN HOUSE PATROL CALLED A SUBSTITUTE FOR ALARMS
description: A former Great Adventure amusement park official testified today that an employee assigned to walk continually through the park's fun house was a good alternative to installing smoke alarms.

title: China Deal Gets Funding
description: The International Finance Corporation, a branch of the World Bank, said yesterday that it had approved its first investment in China.

title: SERVICE CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Public Discontent
description: The New York Coliseum was subject and setting, as more than 150 West Siders met Tuesday night to talk about the redevelopment of the Columbus Circle site.

title: Western Airlines
description: Gerald Grinstein, chief executive of Western Airlines Inc., told securities analysts that the airline's recovery continued into the second quarter, and he predicted it would earn at least $14 million for the period. He said this would equal the company's record second-quarter profit, which was posted in 1979. The airline, which has had extensive losses, reported a record first-quarter profit this year of $13.3 million.

title: OFFICIALS DRAW ANOTHER BLANK IN AIR-INDIA SEARCH
description: Searchers spent another futile day today searching for clues to why an Air-India jumbo jet crashed into the sea near here.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HER FIRST AMERICAN. By Lore Segal. 287 pages. Knopf. $15.95.

title: People
description: * Frank Macina has been promoted to senior vice president at Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson.

title: KOUSA DOGWOOD IN ITS TIMELY BLOOM
description: Kousa dogwoods are in bloom. For many, this is the quintessential tree because the Cornus kousa has everything. Its best quality is its timing. It comes into flower about a month after the beloved native dogwood, Cornus florida, fades. The flowers (showy bracts actually) are the same creamy white shade of the May blooming trees, but they do not have the nipped edges.

title: Scurry Suspended
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates indefinitely suspended the pitcher Rod Scurry yesterday for failing to follow a drug care program he began last season following treatment for cocaine dependency.

title: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
OPEC Board Meets
description: The board of governors of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries met today to discuss OPEC's ministerial conference here next week. The governors' meeting is expected to last until Friday.

title: BAXTER MAY PURSUE AMERICAN BID
description: Saying that it had arranged a new $2.5 billion line of credit, Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. announced yesterday that its board would meet today to try to decide whether to pursue the American Hospital Supply Corporation. American Hospital Supply rejected a $3.7 billion buyout offer from Baxter on Tuesday.

title: A BANKER IS STABBED IN A DISPUTE IN PARK AT A SOFTBALL GAME
description: A 24-year-old bank officer was critically wounded when he was stabbed in the heart by a spectator while playing on Chemical Bank's co-ed softball team in Central Park last night, the police said.

title: Rutherford Is Ready To Resume Winning
description: Johnny Rutherford, the three-time Indianapolis 500 winner who has been recuperating more than he has been racing during the past two years, believes that he may be ready to return to his championship form, if his new car cooperates.

title: DECISIONS BY LILCO FOUND IMPRUDENT IN FOUR AREAS
description: The decision to hold the Long Island Lighting Company responsible for $1.35 billion of the cost overrun on the Shoreham nuclear plant is based on a finding by two hearing officers that the company had made ''imprudent'' judgments in four major areas.

title: Slow Turnstiles
description: Dwindling attendance and the United States Football League's switch to a fall schedule almost certainly mean that the Gamblers have played their last game in Houston, and, as usual, that kind of thing has caused some uneasiness on the team. Gerald McNeil, a wide receiver who spent his college career at Baylor, put the best possible light on the situation in a postgame interview the other night, when he said, ''I'm from Texas, and I like to play in Texas, but they've got footballs in every state.''

title: THE STAGE: 'SOMEWHERE BETTER'
description: THE production of ''Somewheres Better'' directed by Jeff Martin at the Vineyard Theater lets a group of unusually harmonious actors create memorable characters, and they make the most of their opportunities. The play was the first written by the actor William Wise and was first seen in 1981. It is obviously the work of a young writer; it takes on too many themes and has some serious plotting problems. But it is very much an actor's play and the current version shows that aspect of it to a great advantage.

title: THOMAS ROY JONES
description: Thomas Roy Jones, retired chairman and chief executive officer of Daystrom Inc., died of cancer Friday at his home in Carmel, Calif.

title: PERES AND KEY ISRAELI AIDES HOLD CLOSED-DOOR SESSION
description: Key members of the Israeli Cabinet held an extraordinary session behind closed doors tonight, and there was speculation it was called to discuss an offer by the Shiite militia leader Nabih Berri to turn over the American hostages to a Western embassy in Beirut.

title: ITT Director Resigns Post
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that Alvin Friedman had resigned after 15 years as an outside director ''to pursue other personal interests.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 9.50-10.00 ** Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: IACOCCA MAKES APPEAL FOR ELLIS ISLAND FUNDS
description: Vowing to throw the ''biggest party this city has ever seen'' when the job is finished, Lee A. Iacocca promised yesterday that the restoration of the Statue of Liberty would be completed in time for its 1986 Fourth of July centennial celebration.

title: VALTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $125,000 from early retirement of debt. c-After a gain of $238,598 from pension plan termination and the fourth quarter credit of $125,000.

title: U-Haul Faces F.T.C. Charge
description: The Federal Trade Commission charged today that U-Haul International Inc., the nation's largest renter of trucks and trailers, had used ''sham litigation'' in an illegal attempt to monopolize the moving equipment rental market.

title: THIS CAN'T BE YOGURT INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The share earnings were adjusted for three 3-for-2 stock splits effective Oct. 26, 1984, Feb. 22 1985, and May 24, 1985.

title: Magnavox Order
description: The Magnavox Government and Industrial Electronics Company, a unit of the North American Philips Corporation, won a $37.6 million Army contract for terminals.

title: ORANGE-CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After tax credits of $9,000 for the quarter and $38,000 for the nine months. Earnings for the latest quarter and nine months reflect a $2 million writedown of citrus inventories because of a decline in selling prices.

title: JAPAN SAID TO FIND BITS OF COMPUTER-CHIP BOMB
description: The Japanese police were reported today to have found evidence suggesting that a sophisticated timing device constructed with electronic chips had been used to touch off a fatal explosion in baggage at the Narita airport outside Tokyo.

title: Goldhirsh's Publisher
description: J. Peter Huestis, 47, director of sales and marketing of McGraw-Hill's Byte magazine, is joining Bernard A. Goldhirsh's Inc. magazine as publisher on July 14. It was a job that Mr. Goldhirsh was temporarily filling for about a year.

title: SOVIET WILLING TO HELP, BUT PUTS BLAMES ON U.S.
description: A spokesman for the Soviet Foreign Ministry asserted today that the hostage situation in Beirut was an outgrowth of American policies, but he suggested that Moscow might be willing to do what it could to help resolve the crisis, The spokesman, Vladimir B. Lomeiko, speaking in a news conference, declined to say whether the Soviet Union was in fact helping.

title: First Union Notes
description: The First Union Corporation offered $100 million of senior floating-rate extendible notes.

title: JUDGE BARS TIMES SQ. WORK, PENDING A STUDY
description: A state judge has barred construction on the Times Square redevelopment project until its sponsors study the construction's impact on the water tunnel under the Avenue of the Americas.

title: 'TELEVISION'S VIETNAM: THE REAL STORY,' ON PBS
description: THE most interesting thing about ''Television's Vietnam:

title: Lloyd's Plans Inquiry
description: Lloyd's of London said today that it would investigate the conduct of three of its ill-fated insurance underwriting syndicates.

title: 2 Soccer Officials Ousted
description: The United States Soccer Federation announced yesterday it would not renew the contracts of Alkis Panagoulias, the coach of the national team, and Karl-Heinz Heddergott, the national director of coaching.

title: Wife of Beirut Hostage To Ask Mexican Help
description: The wife of an American hostage was trying today to meet with President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico when he visits Nuevo Laredo on Friday.

title: Bahram Aryana Dies; Ex-Iran Chief of Staff
description: Gen. Bahram Aryana, Chief of Staff of the Iranian Army during Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi's reign and an opponent of the current Government, died in a hospital here last Friday, relatives said Tuesday. He was 79 years old.

title: JAPANESE ACCUSED ON CHIPS
description: A small Boise, Idaho, microchip manufacturer has accused seven leading Japanese semiconductor makers of cutting their prices nearly 50 percent below production costs to win sales unfairly in the American market for memory chips that serve as the building blocks of computers.

title: ANOTHER SEVEN AMERICANS HELD HOSTAGE IN LEBANON
description: In addition to the 39 Americans - 36 passengers and 3 crew members - from the hijacked Trans World Airlines plane, there are seven other Americans being held hostage in Lebanon.

title: Landslide Kills 9 in India
description: A landslide caused by torrential rains killed nine people today in Kerala State in southern India, the Press Trust of India said.

title: Conrail Bills Introduced
description: A bipartisan group of legislators introduced bills today authorizing the sale of Conrail to an investor group that said it would sell the freight railroad's stock in a series of public offerings. The legislation, introduced in the House and Senate, endorses the $1.2 billion bid for Conrail made in May by a group of investors headed by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: PATTERN PROCESSING TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
DISMISSAL FOR STUN GUN ACCUSER
description: Saying the defendant had been ''sufficiently punished for the alleged crime,'' a judge in Queens yesterday threw out a drug charge against a teen-ager who was the first of several people to contend they had been tortured with an electric stun gun by police officers.

title: 'WELD' CONNECTING FLORIDA IS FOUND
description: Using artificial earth tremors to probe through surface deposits many miles deep, Cornell University scientists believe they have found the geologic suture where Florida and southern Georgia became connected to North America 250 million years ago.

title: Script Ohio Fails in Return
description: Script Ohio, one of the top classic prospects earlier this year before undergoing knee surgery, returned to the races with a dull fifth-place finish in the Sir Gaylord Purse yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: WHEN YOUR MOST RECENT GADGET IS ALREADY OBSOLETE
description: SIX months after Dr. Michael Salesin became the first person on his block with a videocassette recorder, he realized that it was obsolete.

title: 7 KILLED AS HAND GRENADE ATTACKS HIT TOWNSHIPS NEAR JOHANNESBURG
description: Hand grenade attacks in black townships killed seven people today and explosions in Transkei, a so-called tribal homeland, set a huge fuel depot ablaze, knocked out a power station and cut off the capital's water supply, the police said.

title: WHITE HOUSE VOWS A STIFF FIGHT FOR REYNOLDS
description: With the Senate Judiciary Committee set to vote Thursday on the nomination of William Bradford Reynolds to be Associate Attorney General, White House officials said today that they were prepared to wage a long fight in his behalf.

title: SIKES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
NO LONGER A NOVELTY, VCR BEING ADAPTED TO PERSONAL USES
description: AMANDA SCHARE is a convert. ''I didn't want it but now I love it,'' she said of the video cassette recorder bought two years ago for her Huntington, L.I., house. ''I can tape the news and watch it after dinner, I can see a movie and not wait in line, I can control my television set. It used to control me.''

title: HOW TO GET BIG SOUND IN SMALL CITY SPACES
description: With the newly popular CD's - laser-scanned compact disks - packing big sound onto little records, many audio buffs despair of finding houseroom for adequate playback equipment. Hefty amplifiers and bulky speakers to encompass the cascades of sound pouring from these new disks may be all very well for listeners luxuriating in large rooms. But what about those who live in smaller urban spaces?

title: VAUGHN PERFORMS AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: SARAH VAUGHAN is the rare singer who defies gravity by advancing in technical facility as the years fly by. Miss Vaughan recently turned 61, an age at which most jazz voices have begun to suffer severe losses both in power and vocal fiber. Miss Vaughan's singing, however, remains a bastion of tonal security and her phrasing is still embellished with an outrageously rich and rounded vibrato. More than ever, her huge, ripe alto suggests an all-purpose horn whose still-deepening baritone register can be downright thunderous.

title: IF THE PRESS WERE TAME
description: What would it be like if the press in this country, as in so many others, were an official mouthpiece? If its role were to be a cheerleader instead of a skeptic?

title: Comings and Goings
description: Doctors plan to recommend surgery for Richard Dotson, a right-handed pitcher for the Chicago White Sox, said Paul Jensen, a team spokesman. Jensen said dye testing on Dotson showed impingement of the artery and nerve in the right shoulder area. . . . Jody Davis, the catcher for the Cubs who has missed eight games because of gastrointesinal bleeding, is expected to fly to Pittsburgh with the team Friday for a weekend series with the Pirates, a club spokesman said. . . . Ed Pinckney of Villanova, the Phoenix Suns' No. 1 draft pick, has decided not to attend the team's rookie and free-agent camp this week because he does not have a signed contract.

title: VOLCKER SAYS TAX PLAN DOES LITTLE ON BORROWING
description: In his first public comment on President Reagan's tax-revision plan, Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that it did not go far enough to encourage business investment and discourage business borrowing.

title: PHOTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''If Miss Liberty was a symbol of hope, Ellis Island was a symbol of reality.

title: Arco Settlement
description: The Energy Department said it had approved a final settlement of oil overcharge claims against the Atlantic Richfield Company in which the company would pay more than $67 million. The agreement, tentatively signed in January, settles reported violations by Arco of Federal oil price controls from Jan. 1, 1973, through Jan. 28, 1981, when the controls expired, the department said.

title: South Carolina Housing Issue
description: An offering of $155 million worth of term bonds by the South Carolina State Housing Authority was repriced yesterday.

title: EARNING A DEGREE IN DECORATIVE ARTS
description: ''TWENTY-FIVE years ago, decorative arts were not considered worthy of serious study,'' says Marilynn Johnson, a former associate curator in the American Wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: KOCH AND BELLAMY EXCHANGE VOLLEYS AT CITY HALL
description: City Hall is a graceful old building with a main floor that is divided in two: Mayor Koch occupies the west wing; City Council President Carol Bellamy occupies the east wing, and a marble rotunda divides them.

title: DEMOCRATIC CHIEF URGES QUICK RULES REVIEW
description: The Democratic Party's Fairness Commission held its first meeting today, with the party chairman urging its members to complete their review of the party's Presidential nominating rules quickly and resist a major overhaul of the process.

title: FINANCIAL PLAN FOR CITY VOTED BY STATE BOARD
description: The State Financial Control Board unanimously approved Mayor Koch's four-year spending plan yesterday, after the city had sharply reduced the size of its predicted budget deficit for 1987.

title: WORK SAFETY AGENCY NEVER CHECKED FATAL FACTORY
description: The Federal agency responsible for protecting the health and safety of workers never inspected a fireworks plant near Hallett, Okla., where at least 21 people were killed on Tuesday, according to a Labor Department memorandum.

title: Schrom Wins One-Hitter
description: The Twins' Ken Schrom pitched a one-hitter against the Kansas City Royals tonight, but needed Roy Smalley's pinch-hit, two-run single in the ninth inning to win, 2-1, from Minnesota.. Although Schrom (7-5) had only allowed a one-out single to Willie Wilson in the third, he was trailing by 1-0 going into the ninth.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, has named Alan T. Fletcher president and managing director of its Wilkinson Sword Consumer Products division, a unit of its International Group.

title: N.B.A. EXPANSION UNLIKELY FOR 1986-87
description: Commissioner David Stern announced today that the National Basketball Association will begin accepting applications from cities seeking expansion teams.

title: U.S. May Be Net Debtor
description: The United States suffered a record $78 billion decline in its international investment position in 1984, reflecting a speedy plunge toward the status of a net-debtor nation, the Government said today.

title: HAMMOCKS FOR SUMMER
description: HAMMOCKS for those lazy days of summer can be found in a number of stores. Abercrombie & Fitch sells the Pawley's Island hammock, which is handmade of cotton twill, with stretchers of seasoned oak.

title: MOVE INTO WORLD OF COMPUTER NETS BY INTELLIGENCE UNIT RAISES DOUBT
description: As computer and communications technologies advance, the nation's largest intelligence agency has become involved in keeping foreign powers, private corporations and criminals from electronically eavesdropping on the computer and communication networks of Government and private institutions.

title: F.B.I. SEES DUARTE ON 4 MARINES
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte said today that agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation had met with him regarding the killing of four American marines and nine other people last week.

title: WHAT'S NEXT: FLAT TV'S ON THE WALL
description: THE swift technical coming of age of electronic home entertainment naturally prompts speculation about the forms these media might take in the future. An inkling of things to come could be gained this month at the Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago, where the makers of audio and video equipment took the wraps off their latest creations.

title: UPS AND DOWNS OF LIFE IN BASEBALL
description: Ron Hassey has seen both sides of the baseball life. It is not necessary to ask him which he prefers - Cleveland or Chicago - because he endured ''six hard years,'' as he put it, playing for the uninspiring Indians before spending a short time on the Cubs' division-winning 1984 team.

title: AN ABC TALE OF THE MICROCHIP WORLD
description: LANGUISHING in the ratings cellar these days, ABC seems determined to get rid of every mistake stockpiled on its programming shelves. Tonight at 8 o'clock, for instance, the ''ABC Thursday Night Movie'' is really an open-ended pilot for a nighttime soap opera entitled ''Midas Valley.'' In the best high-concept manner, the show's premise can be condensed into a single sentence, thoughtfully supplied by the network: ''The micro-electronic revolution has exploded in Northern California's Midas Valley, and the baby-boom children lit the match.'' The producers obviously did not anticipate the current bearish news about the silicon-chip business. That's the least of their problems. ''Midas Valley'' begins with a swank party that Drew Hammond (Robert Stack) has arranged to celebrate the engagement of his Franklin (Joseph Hacker) to the beautiful Dr. Sarah Corey (Linda Purl). Among the ominously buzzing guests are Drew's daughter Lillian (Shanna Reed), described as prodigal, and Lillian's powerful boss George Carew (George Grizzard), described as ruthless. Carew is scheming with, among others, a gang of Japanese nasties, and his partner and lover is Mitsi Kawamato (France Nuyen). Carew is wont to snarl things like, ''Tell your friends in Tokyo to keep their kimonos on.''

title: Prices Mixed in a Light Day
description: Bond prices were mixed in light trading yesterday, as credit market participants chose to shrug off developments that could have sent yields lower across the maturity spectrum.

title: OBSESSION LEADS TO PARALYSIS
description: On Jan. 23, 1968, the North Koreans seized the Pueblo, an electronic intelligence ship, killed one crewman and captured the remaining 82. The prisoners were cruelly treated and subjected to trial as criminals. The Johnson Administration worked hard behind the scenes for their release. It took 11 months.

title: COATED SALES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
PENALTY FOR LILCO ON SHOREHAM COST TO BE $1.35 BILLION
description: The Long Island Lighting Company was penalized $1.35 billion today for mismanaging the construction of its Shoreham nuclear power station.

title: COMMUNICATIONS & CABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Reynolds Metals
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said it would temporarily idle 49,000 tons of primary aluminum capacity and temporarily lay off 250 workers associated with the cutback. It said a potline at Troutdale, Ore., that produces 25,000 tons a year would be halted this weekend as well as a line at Longview, Wash., that produces 24,000 tons a year. After the cutbacks, Reynolds said, it would be operating at 65 percent of its consolidated primary aluminum capacity.

title: GORBACHEV WARNS ARMS TALKS MAY FAIL
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned today that the Soviet Union would reassess its participation in the Geneva arms talks if the United States continued ''marking time'' there, as he put it.

title: INDIA ACTS TO STEM AIRLINE TERRORISM
description: Indian Government and airline officials announced today that they were putting new measures into effect aimed at forestalling terrorist attacks on airports and airliners. The steps include more rigorous rules for checking baggage.

title: Run by Depositors Subsides
description: A three-day run on the Commercial Credit Bank apparently has peaked after millions of dollars were withdrawn by worried customers, a company spokesman said today.

title: HOUSE WOULD CURB ANTISATELLITE TEST
description: The House of Representatives voted today to impose a moratorium on tests of antisatellite weapons against targets in space so long as the Soviet Union refrained from similar testing.

title: WALKOUT AT CEMETERIES ENDS
description: A seven-week old strike at 10 cemeteries in metropolitan New York ended yesterday when the cemeteries agreed to enter binding arbitration with the strikers' union, according to Jack Sweeney, a Federal mediator.

title: Chairman of A.M.C. To Join Textile Concern
description: W. Paul Tippett, chairman of the American Motors Corporation, said he will join Springs Industries, a Fort Mill, S.C., textile company, as president on July 15. He said he would retain the title of chairman at A.M.C. at least until a board meeting on July 8.

title: Nothing Wrong With Negotiating on Hostages
description: To the Editor:

title: CLARK, J L MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Conservation Wouldn't Replace Shoreham
description: To the Editor:

title: CALENDAR: A CHESS PROGRAM
description: Courses, Workshops and Lecture Tours, New York School of Interior Design, 155 East 56th Street, 212-753-5365.

title: Pesticide Fire Forces 2,000 to Flee 2 Towns
description: A chemical spill and fire at a pesticide plant today released a 300-foot cloud of black vapor that sickened 115 people and forced the evacuation of 2,000 residents of two desert communities.

title: FRANCE SAYS IT IS 'AVAILABLE' IN HOSTAGE CRISIS
description: France, responding to a proposal by the Shiite militia leader Nabih Berri to turn the American hostages over to a Western embassy in West Beirut, said today that it was ''available'' to help resolve the hostage crisis.

title: CANADA WEIGHS PROJECTS TO SELL WATER TO U.S.
description: After years of jealously guarding their water, Canadians, who possess more than one-fifth of the world's fresh, usable supplies, are beginning to consider projects to sell it to Americans.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGES MORRIS BROWN COLLEGE - Named Harold Merritt head basketball coach.

title: A REHEARSAL FOR A 'STICKUP': TAPE LINKED TO BRINK'S CASE
description: A jury in Manhattan listened yesterday to a taped discussion that the prosecution described as a rehearsal for an armed robbery planned by a group called the Revolutionary Communist Military Command.

title: ZANY ART FOR TODAY
description: THERE are television sets, mirrors, tables and lots of chairs, of course.

title: FILM: DOCUMENTARY ON HOMOSEXUALS
description: ''BEFORE STONEWALL:

title: Walking for Jobs
description: On the Upper West Side, high school students were walking for jobs -and finding it frustrating.

title: DEPOSITS OF CHINATOWN BANK SOLD
description: The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, one of the biggest banks in Asia, agreed yesterday to acquire $117 million of insured deposits of the Golden Pacific National Bank, the Chinatown bank that was closed last Friday by Federal authorities.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 27, 1985

title: DANCE: JACOB'S PILLOW IN 53D SEASON
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival opened its 53d season Sunday afternoon with a program called ''Gala International '85'' that turned the entire festival grounds into a stage for dancing. The celebration was divided into two parts, one of which resembled what back in the 1960's might have been called a ''happening.''

title: IRAQIS BREAKS LINKS WITH LIBYA, SAYING IT SUPPORTS TEHERAN
description: Iraq broke relations with Libya today to protest what it said was a Libyan alliance with Iran. Iraq and Iran have been at war for 57 months.

title: Nothing Wrong With Negotiating on Hostages
description: To the Editor:

title: Ontario Liberal Government Ends Long Progressive Rule
description: A Liberal Government headed by Premier David Peterson was sworn in today, ending 42 years of Progressive Conservative control of Ontario, Canada's most populous province.

title: ENTRE COMPUTER SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Felix Greene, Reporter, Dies; Visited North Vietnam in 60's
description: Felix Greene, a foreign correspondent who was one of the first Western reporters to visit North Vietnam when he traveled there for The San Francisco Chronicle in the 1960's, died in Mexico of cancer June 15.

title: TV'S COLLUSIVE ROLE
description: The Shiite gunmen who hijacked Trans World Airlines Flight 847, and their patron, Amal leader Nabih Berri, have proved once again how easy it is for terrorists to make television their accomplice.

title: HIGH COURT VOIDS CONNECTICUT SABBATH LAW
description: In the second decision this month reaffirming the principle of government neutrality toward religion, the Supreme Court today invalidated a Connecticut law that gave employees an unqualified right not to work on their chosen Sabbath. The vote was 8 to 1. Writing for the Court, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger said the state law imposed an undue burden on both employers and on nonreligious employees, who he said also had ''strong and legitimate'' reasons for wanting to avoid weekend work.

title: PLYMOUTH RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
description: b-After a loss of $57,000 on disposal of a discontinued product line and a tax credit of $30,000 for the quarter and the six months. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of a product line of $379,000 for the quarter and $632,000 for the six months. Year-ago results for the six months were restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: CLASS ACTION AGAINST PHILLIPS IS UPHELD
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the state courts of Kansas properly permitted a nationwide class of 28,000 oil and gas lease owners to sue the Phillips Petroleum Company for unpaid interest.

title: On the Missile Job Front
description: One of the most sensitive jobs in the Pentagon is about to be filled by Brig. Gen. Charles A. May.

title: Bombing on Israeli Beach
description: A small bomb exploded harmlessly on a crowded beach today, the Israeli radio reported. The bomb caused no casualties, said the radio, which gave no further details.

title: EXPOS STOPPED BY REUSCHEL
description: Rick Reuschel, making a comeback after three seasons with arm problems, stopped the Montreal Expos, 11-2, tonight as the Pirates snapped a four-game losing streak.

title: THE DANCE: 'TANGO'
description: ''TANGO ARGENTINO'' opened at City Center on Tuesday and will play there through Sunday. It ought to stay forever. The idea of two or so hours of tango dancing and music may seem a little relentless. But the evening speeds by as fast as the dancers' flying feet and knees. The staging, by Claudio Segovia and Hector Orezzoli, is inspired, with the musicians sitting on a raked bandstand behind the dancers and singers who zip through the show's 31 numbers. The costumes are simple, chic and inventive. But most of all it is the seasoned performers who make this the sort of show that drove the audience to a roaring standing ovation.

title: On the Baltic Front
description: Each June the United States reaffirms one of its lesser-emphasized foreign policies: that this country does not recognize the Soviet Union's hegemony over the Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. The three are now republics of the Soviet Union, but Washington agrees with emigre organizations that insist their homelands are illegally ruled from Moscow.

title: Stewart Heads Atheneum
description: Thomas A. Stewart, editor in chief of Atheneum Publishers since 1979, has been named president and publisher, the book company announced yesterday. Mr. Stewart, a 1970 graduate of Harvard University, was previously a senior editor at Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, and had been an editor at Farrar, Straus & Giroux and at Grossman Publishers. Alfred Knopf Jr., formerly president as well as chairman of the board, remains chairman of Atheneum.

title: Measure Gives Military Power in War on Drugs
description: The House, casting aside Pentagon opposition, voted tonight to give the military new power to help the civilian authorities stop and arrest drug smugglers.

title: Market Place;   Rumors Spur Northwest Air
description: EVER since Trans World Airlines Inc. agreed several weeks ago to cast its lot with the Texas Air Corporation as an alternative to a takeover by Carl C. Icahn, airlines have become a hot property on Wall Street.

title: IN COLLEGES, HOME ECONOMICS GOES BEYOND THE HOME
description: THE field of home economics sends its graduates off on a broad array of career paths.

title: LTV Exchanges
description: The LTV Corporation announced yesterday that it intends to commence a number of exchange offers that will extend maturities of around $640 million of its long-term debt. The issues involved range from the company's 5 percent subordinated debentures due Jan. 15, 1988, to its 6 3/4 percent subordinated debentures due April 1, 1994.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Sports of The Times column yesterday misspelled the name of the wife of Earl Weaver, the Baltimore Orioles' manager. Her name is Marianna.

title: Boesky Stake
description: Ivan F. Boesky, the New York investor, holds a 9.8 percent stake in the Southland Financial Corporation, he disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Boesky said he had bought 1.6 million Southland shares as part of the ''general investment activities'' of several companies he controls and not to gain control of Southland. He said he had paid $29.4 million for his stake.

title: SHEARSON'S 'NEW' LEHMAN
description: When Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. moves later this year into its newly constructed lower Manhattan headquarters, two stalwart traditions of the old Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb culture will go with it: the elegant partners' dining room and the silver boxes with the unlimited free cigars that Lehman partners have enjoyed for years.

title: 4 VILLAGES MOURN IN LOSSES
description: Four stunned rural communities responded with quiet generosity today to the needs of their neighbors, families of victims of a fireworks explosion that took 21 lives Tuesday.

title: RECALL URGED OF HEART VALVE SAID TO HAVE A SERIOUS DEFECT
description: Inspectors for the Food and Drug Administration have found ''serious problems'' in the manufacture of artificial heart valves by Shiley Inc. that was linked last year to the deaths of at least 64 people.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amdahl Corp., Sunnyvale, Calif, said it had introduced two new high-performance computers.

title: C.D. Rates Fall Again
description: Rates on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds declined again in the week ended yesterday.

title: STUDY PROJECTS REVENUE LOSS UNDER REAGAN TAX PLAN
description: The Congressional Budget Office reported today that President Reagan's tax revision proposals would cost the Government a significant amount of revenue over the next 15 years.

title: PARKER PEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a pre-tax gain of $690,000 from the sale of the company's 80 percent interest in First Deposit Corp.

title: U.S. ALTERS MILEAGE RULES, AIDING FORD AND G.M.
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today announced changes in its formula for measuring automobile fuel economy, an action agency officials said appeared to bring all American automobile makers into compliance with Federal law.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: U.S. IS REPORTED TO BE WEIGHING SHIITE OFFER ON MOVING HOSTAGES
description: The United States was reported today to be exploring the possibility of taking advantage of an offer by Nabih Berri, the Shiite leader, to move the American hostages to a Western embassy in Beirut or to a third country such as Syria.

title: Brooklyn Woman, 42, Is Slain In Apparent House Robbery
description: A 42-year-old woman was slain in her home in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn last night in what appeared to be a robbery, the police said.

title: Sri Lanka to Hold Talks With Tamil Separatists
description: The Sri Lanka Government and Tamil separatist political and guerrilla groups are to hold talks in the tiny Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan, a Cabinet spokesman said today.

title: Krickstein Loses to Schultz
description: Aaron Krickstein was 14 years old when he last played at Wimbledon, losing in the second round of the juniors competition. This year marked his return, and the crowd at Court 5 was considerably more interested. Krickstein was seeded 10th and, at age 17, is considered the best among the younger players in the United States.

title: METRO AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Baseball;   Table Setters Help Their Teams Feast
description: They are the latest style in baseball, the newest achievers, probably the next winners. Some people call them ''rabbits.'' Managers refer to them as ''my one-and-two men.'' In the talk of the trade, they ''set the table'' for the big hitters who follow.

title: AUTO RACE IN QUEENS CALLED OFF
description: Plans to hold a Formula One Grand Prix auto race in a Queens park in September have been canceled, Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern said yesterday.

title: THE SHIITES: ISLAM'S MINORITY, ITS ROOTS DEEP IN CONFLICT, IS RISING IN POWER
description: A few days ago, the official radio in Yemen urged the Lebanese Shiite hijackers of the T.W.A. airliner in Beirut to follow the example of Ali ibn Abi Taleb in their treatment of the American airline hostages.

title: WILLIS K. WING
description: Willis K. Wing, an editor and literary agent for more than 50 years, died June 17 in the Kendal-Crosslands retirement home in Kennet Square, Pa. He was 85 years old.

title: A Golden Oldie
description: When in the course of human events it became necessary to insure the preservation of the parchment document, the National Archives put it in a enclosure of laminated glass with a yellow cellulose inner layer, all in an atmosphere of humidified helium. That's how the Declaration of Independence has been kept since 1951, and that's why the uninitiated among the thousands who see it in the Achives Rotunda on the Fourth of July might be surprised that it looks a shade golden. It will be on view from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M., and the celebration around the archives will include cannon and musket firing, people in colonial costumes and, at 11 A.M., a reading of the document by Glenn Taylor, a Washington actor.

title: The Hole a Farmer Finds Himself In
description: To the Editor:

title: $100 Million in Bonds From Port Authority
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday offered $100 million of 35-year consolidated revenue bonds.

title: A Better Air-Conditioning Shutoff Time for New York Drought
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITICISM OF PHILADELPHIA GROWS OVER BOMBING OF RADICALS' HOME
description: As the city comes under increasing criticism for the bombing of a radical group's home, it is proceeding with plans to rebuild 61 houses that were destroyed by fire as a result of the May 13 confrontation.

title: Pogo Stock Offer
description: The Pogo Producing Company, an oilfield services company, said Northwest Industries was planning to sell its 4.8 million Pogo shares, about 26 percent of the stock outstanding. Pogo, which filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the proposed secondary public offering by Northwest, said it would not receive any of the proceeds. Northwest is being acquired in a leveraged buyout by Farley Metals Inc. and its affiliates.

title: NEW FIRE BURNS FOR A TENOR TURNED IMPRESARIO
description: The Italians call it ''fuoco divino,'' divine fire. It is the burning inspiration that drives the creative spirit and makes great painters and great composers and great tenors. Some men have it and hold it. And some men, like Michael Scuderi, flirt with it, then let it slip away.

title: AM CABLE TV INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
On the RR Front
description: The Ronald Reagan Marine Railway is now in operation at Pago Pago on the island of Tutuila, American Samoa, the United States territory in the South Pacific. The railway, which is not for transporting passengers but for moving ships around the drydock at Pago Pago harbor, was built with Federal funds.

title: CUBS END 13-GAME SLIDE
description: On a sunny afternoon before 35,876 cheering fans in Wrigley Field, the Chicago Cubs finally did it today: They won a game after 13 straight losses.

title: COURT STRENGTHENS LIBEL PLAINTIFFS' HAND
description: In a long-awaited ruling, the Supreme Court today made it easier for some private individuals to recover damages for libel.

title: Senator Kennedy's Killer Denied Parole a 7th Time
description: The California Board of Prison Terms today denied parole to Sirhan Sirhan, rejecting his seventh bid for freedom after serving 17 years for assassinating Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

title: LEBANESE MILITIA FREES A HOSTAGE WITH AILING HEART
description: The Shiite Amal militia leader, Nabih Berri, released one of the 40 American hostages today and proposed that the others be placed in the custody of a third party until Israel frees 735 mainly Shiite detainees.

title: Tracy-Locke Chosen
description: Tracy-Locke, the Dallas subsidiary of BBDO, has been tapped by Compushop, a computer retailer with 55 shops in 13 states and a reported $4 million ad budget. The client was recently acquired by Bell Atlantic. It was announced last September that Compushop had taken its general advertising in-house from N.W. Ayer, Chicago.

title: Women Entrepreneurs Are Focus of Quarterly
description: The top management of Entrepreneur Inc., a Los Angeles publishing company that has a magazine of the same name, has a new magazine scheduled for September publication called Choices For Entrepreneurial Women. It will be a quarterly with a cover price of $2.50, and the ad rates based on a 75,000 initial circulation will be $1,500 for a four-color page and $1,200 for a black and white. Wellington Ewen and Rieva Lesonsky, publisher and managing editor, respectively, of the older magazine will hold the same positions with the new one.

title: Walking for Peace
description: Some talked. In New York, they walked.

title: Sperry Purchases
description: The Sperry Corporation said it would buy an artificial intelligence-based product from Texas Instruments Inc. for about $42 million over three years. The so-called Explorer Systems will be used in Sperry's Knowledge System product line.

title: Rebels Kill 2 in Peru
description: Two policemen have been killed in a guerrilla attack on a rural police outpost in northeastern Peru, the police said today. They said Shining Path guerrillas armed with submachine guns took part in the fierce 15-minute skirmish on Monday.

title: MONFORT OF COLORADO reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
ROBBINS & MYERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income after net from discontinued operations of $519,000 for the quarter and $1,198,000 for the 9 months. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,128,000.

title: Indian Classics
description: A concert of Indian music featuring instruments rarely heard in the classical raga tradition will take place tonight at 8 at the Samaya Foundation, 75 Leonard Street (362-0290) in TriBeCa. The concert will feature Daya Shankar on shahnai (Indian oboe), Tarun Bhattacharyya on santoor (hammered dulcimer), Vishwa Mohan Bhatt on slide guitar and Ishwar Lal Mishra on tabla drums. Tickets are $8; information, 966-4444.

title: THE PAIN OF TRANSFERS IN JAPAN
description: When Ikuo Takeuchi's company asked him to move to a new job far from home, he agreed to go. But he had to leave his family behind so his son could keep his place in a well-known high school. A year later, Mr. Takeuchi collapsed and was hospitalized for severe asthma. When his wife visited his small Tokyo apartment, she found he had not eaten breakfast for six months. Then she saw a bottle of whisky on the table.

title: Mosely Charge On Earnings
description: The Mosely, Hallgarten, Estabrook & Weeden Holding Corporation, a Wall Street securities firm, yesterday reported a charge against earnings of $10.5 million that it said it could not find.

title: Pope in 2 Mideast Meetings
description: Pope John Paul II discussed the Middle East situation in separate meetings today with Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel Meguid of Egypt and Mayor Elias M. Freij of Bethlehem, which is in the Israeli-occupied West Bank. The Vatican described the audiences as private and gave no details.

title: Boy, 3, Is Rescued in Queens After Bus Terminal Abduction
description: A 3-year-old boy was abducted from the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown Manhattan yesterday, but the child was rescued by the police five hours later in Queens, the police said.

title: About Face
description: Montreal's third-string catcher, Sal Butera, says he never expected to be on the throwing end of a major league pitch, but that is what happened Wednesday night at Pittsburgh, where he made his mound debut for the short-staffed Expos after the Pirates had opened up a 9-0 lead in two innings en route to an 11-2 thrashing.

title: CULP INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-Reflects a charge of $455,000 for the cost of litigation settlement. c-Reflects a charge of $200,000 for plant consolidation costs and a charge of $375,000 for inventory writedowns.

title: 4,000 Turks Applaud New York Orchestra
description: The New York Philharmonic was applauded with enthusiasm by a Turkish audience of nearly 4,000 people who packed the Sports Hall on Wednesday night for the orchestra's only performance in Istanbul.

title: Topics;   Day Trips Tropical Bronx
description: The world's tropical rain forests, pressed by population and development, are rapidly being reduced to fragments - but not in the Bronx. There, a 37,000-square-foot fragment has just been produced.

title: On Terrorism
description: Before the seizure of the Americans now held hostage in Lebanon and before the State Department decided to replace or rebuild 125 embassies and consulates for security reasons, Foreign Service officers were demonstrably dissatisfied with the protection their Government was giving them against terrorism.

title: $100 Million of Notes Are Offered by Textron
description: Textron Inc. yesterday took advantage of favorable market conditions and offered $100 million of 11 percent notes due in 1995 at a price of 99.70, to yield 11.05 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Watch the Economic Warning Signals
description: The economic debate absorbing Washington is dangerously narrow. While the President, the Congress and the media are preoccupied with budget-cutting and tax trade-offs, few are giving serious attention to the economic warning signals flashing ''trouble ahead.''

title: Storm Batters China Region
description: A major storm has killed or injured 11 people, marooned 100,000 and severely damaged farmland and crops in China's coastal, food-producing province of Fujian, the state-run China News Service said today. The agency said the storm hit Fujian this week with heavy rains that flooded five counties in the Jiulong Valley.

title: Honoring a Defender Of the Arts
description: Anyone who has heard the roar of Councilman Edward L. Sadowsky knows that he would be right at home in a building flanked by lions.

title: SSC&B: Lintas USA
description: Ian McGregor, a 38-year-old native South African, who arrived at SSC&B: Lintas USA as a vice president and account supervisor in 1982, was promoted to a management supervisor in seven months and was raised to senior vice president a year ago, has just been promoted to executive vice president. He will be overseeing the Noxell Corporation toiletries division and Johnson & Johnson's baby products. He must be on that well-publicized fast track.

title: Baxter Chief Aims At Other Ex-marine
description: The company biography of Vernon R. Loucks Jr., president and chief executive officer of Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc., stresses his service in the Marine Corps.

title: Diner's Journal
description: I AM often asked to recommend a restaurant within walking distance of Fifth Avenue's museum row, from the low 70's to about 92d Street. One place worth seeking out is Le Refuge, an enchanting little French bistro on 82d Street near Lexington Avenue where you can have a tasty light lunch in an enchanting rustic setting. Le Refuge is reminiscent of a family-run restaurant in rural France - exposed woodwork, pale yellow walls, fresh flowers and open shelves where you can pick up a jar of mustard or preserves on the way out.

title: AT VILLAGE VOICE, A CLASHING OF VISIONS
description: With the sale of The Village Voice last week, one of the most internally divisive and bitter periods in that fractious, often-radical newspaper's history has entered a quieter phase, at least temporarily.

title: Retail Chain Names 2
description: Montgomery Ward & Company yesterday named two executive vice presidents: Marvin A. Stern, merchandising, and William J. McCarthy, operations.

title: JUSTICES BAR PENALTIES BY UNIONS FOR MEMBERS WHO QUIT IN STRIKE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 4, that a worker who resigns from a labor union during a strike may not be penalized by the union for doing so.

title: STRIDE RITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
40TH SEASON OF MUSIC IS READY AT CARAMOOR
description: Caramoor has been called the most stylish and civilized music festival in the nation. And starting tomorrow, this elegant country retreat only an hour from New York City will begin to celebrate its 40th summer season.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''These violent acts constitute a worldwide problem, are not limited by geographical or political boundaries and no nation and no airline of the world is immune to such acts.'' -Assad Kotaite, president of the International Civil Aviation Administration's council. [A1:5.]

title: STOCKMAN SAYS TAX INCREASE MAY BE BEST BUDGET SOLUTION
description: In a sharply worded off-the-record speech here, President Reagan's budget director, David A. Stockman, has sounded a new alarm that Federal budget deficits have become intractable and that sizable tax increases may be the only solution ''consistent with fiscal sanity.''

title: AMERICAN IS ARRESTED IN CHINA
description: An American businessman has been formally arrested and charged with causing a hotel fire that killed 10 people in Harbin, his lawyer said today.

title: American Motors Sees Progress in Union Talks
description: The chief negotiator for American Motors said today that the company and the United Automobile Workers were making progress in contract talks on the eve of a company-imposed deadline for keeping its Wisconsin plants open.

title: Topics;   Day Trips Priceless Tour
description: A Manhattan woman recently served as a tour guide for visiting relatives who do not care about dining fashionably (though they love studying menus in restaurant windows and saying, ''Who pays these prices?'') or traveling by cab (getting around by subway is one of the things to boast about to friends back home).

title: Time Magazine to Start Statue of Liberty Ads
description: The July 8 issue of Time magazine, out next week, will carry the first of 18 full-page ads in space donated by the publication that will promote contributions to the Statue of Liberty/ Ellis Island Foundation.

title: Bond Prices Register Gains
description: Sentiment in the credit markets turned distinctly bullish yesterday, as bond prices spurted higher and interest rates tumbled in response to the favorable demand for the third and final leg of the Treasury's mini-refunding operation.

title: FINAL EPISODE OF 'CALL TO GLORY: JFK'
description: A ONCE-PROMISING weekly series comes to a close Sunday in the form of a television movie. ''Call to Glory: JFK'' will be broadcast on Channel 7 at 9 P.M. In a way, the conclusion demonstrates what went wrong with the Tisch/Avnet Production.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell $3.10 billion, to $215.74 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Gross Sets Record
description: Michael Gross set a world record in the men's 400-meter freestyle race yesterday with a time of 3 minutes 47.80 seconds in the West German national swimming championships at Remscheid, West Germany.

title: An Uncertain Penalty
description: When the state of Virginia executed 32-year-old Morris Mason earlier this week, it demonstrated once again that the death penalty is a hideously uncertain punishment, by no means reserved only for those indisputably responsible for the most terrible crimes.

title: Back in the Park
description: Tommie Agee, who in 1969 performed heroics in a city-owned park named Shea Stadium, is returning for an encore. The 42-year-old Agee has been hired by the Parks and Recreation Department to a full-time, $23,000-a-year job in which he will give baseball clinics and lectures, part of New York's effort to steer youths away from drugs and other street trouble. The formal announcement is expected within the next few days.

title: Sports of The Times;   Impressions of Fantasyland
description: The sentries swung open the iron gates and the press van rolled onto the grounds at Wimbledon like a courtesy bus taking visitors to the entrance at Disney World. Once inside, a tennis fan may as well be visiting the Magic Kingdom or Fantasyland, for Wimbledon is in a world of its own, removed from the realities of everyday life.

title: ART: THE COLORFUL FLUORESCENT BARS OF DAN FLAVIN
description: PHOTOGRAPHED in black and white, it looks like an extraterrestrial contraption and may well retain a special-effects look when viewed at night. In reality. the object, installed at cornice level in the Castelli Gallery, 420 West Broadway, is Dan Flavin's latest - two 32-foot-long rows of fluorescent bars in pink, yellow, blue and green. Both arranged in this chromatic order, the upper row consists of four long bars, the lower of 16 short ones.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE REJECTS REYNOLDS FOR JUSTICE POST
description: In a vote widely regarded as a severe defeat for President Reagan and his civil rights policies, the Senate Judiciary Committee today rejected the nomination of William Bradford Reynolds to be Associate Attorney General.

title: SONGS OF ALCEU VALENCA, FROM BRAZIL'S NORTHEAST
description: ALCEU VALENCA, a self-taught guitarist, singer and writer of songs in the tradition of Brazil's rugged Northeast, will make his New York debut in the Kool Jazz Festival's Afro-Brazilian presentation called Tropical Surge, tonight at 8 at Carnegie Hall.

title: QUESTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
DOW GAINS 8.40 POINTS TO A RECORD 1,332.21
description: News that Congressional budget negotiations would resume after two days of inactivity sent the Dow Jones industrial average to a record finish.

title: Faint Undersea Signals Heard Near Crash Site
description: Faint signals have been detected from the seabed that could be from the flight recorders of the Air-India jet that crashed Sunday in the North Atlantic with the loss of 329 lives, investigators said today.

title: Purolator Head Leaving To Join IU International
description: William H. Waltrip has resigned as president, chief executive and a director of the Purolator Courier Corporation to become president and chief operating officer of the IU International Corporation.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DOROTHY WORDSWORTH. By Robert Gittings and Jo Manton. 318 pages. Illustrated. Oxford. $17.95. DOROTHY WORDSWORTH worshiped her brother William - ''fraternal affection,'' she once wrote, ''has been the building up of my being, the light of my path!'' She was also a writer who deserves to be remembered on her own account, not simply as William's sister; her journals, first published long after her death, have a lasting interest quite apart from their documentary importance. But it is easy enough to see why she has generally been treated as a subordinate figure, a mere satellite in the Romantic constellation.

title: HOUSE BROADENS SPYING DEATH LAW
description: The House overwhelmingly approved a measure today that would change military law to permit the death penalty for espionage by members of the armed forces in peacetime.

title: DR. NORMAN ELLIOTT
description: Dr. Norman Elliott, a retired physical chemist at the Brookhaven National Laboratory who had worked on the Manhattan Project, died of cancer Monday at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital in East Patchogue, L.I. He was 77 years old and lived in Blue Point, L.I.

title: U.S. SAYS 7 MISSING MUST ALSO GO FREE WITH AIR HOSTAGES
description: The United States demanded today that seven Americans missing in Beirut be freed as part of any arrangement for the release of the 39 airliner hostages.

title: Boston Bank Delays Report
description: In an apparent sign of discord, the board of directors of the Bank of Boston Corporation announced after a long meeting yesterday that it would delay taking any action on a report by a group of outside directors on responsibility for the bank's failure to properly report more than $1 billion in cash transactions.

title: May Deficit at $40.5 Billion
description: The Federal Government suffered a $40.5 billion budget deficit in May, the biggest monthly deficit total on record, the Treasury Department said today.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: WHEN a boy travels back in time to encounter the sexy, flirtatious teen-age girl who will someday become his mother, what's a screenwriter to do? That was the problem faced by Robert Zemeckis and Bob Gale in writing their original screenplay ''Back to the Future,'' which Mr. Zemeckis has now directed. Extricating the hero from this potentially ticklish situation was ''always the trickiest part of the story,'' according to Mr. Zemeckis. ''We spent the most time trying to shake that one out.'' The solution, he says, is one of the things he likes best about the finished film, which opens Wednesday.

title: Ribbing Stockman
description: When David A. Stockman brought Rachel, his new daughter, in to meet his staff at the Office of Management and Budget, number crunchers there seized upon the moment, with tongue in cheek, to give him a lesson on how his proposed Federal budget cuts would affect the Stockman finances now that the family has grown to three. The news is not good.
