The crunchers concede they larded the calculations with hokum - but with not much more, they say, than sometimes shows up in stab-in-the-dark projections of where the Federal budget is headed. One official, conjuring up familiar capital financial concepts, argued that, anyway, if the Stockman figures prove flawed in detail, they nevertheless could turn out to be correct in general direction.

title: GUN SHOW A WEAPONS SUPERMARKET
description: There was everything from .50-caliber machine guns, which require Federal clearance to purchase, to kits to make a .30-caliber Gatling gun, which almost anyone could buy, to an array of military-style assault weapons.

title: Young Achievers
description: One year before Denise Horne left her troubled home at the age of 16 for a new ''family'' in a West Side foster group, she began writing poetry.

title: STANDARD COMMERCIAL TOACCO CO reports earnings for Year to March 31
Emhart Buys Unit
description: The Emhart Corporation said it had acquired the Arcotronics Group from Wedge International Holdings B.V. for $53 million in cash and $8 million in assumed debt. Arcotronics, a capacitor producer with 1984 sales of $71 million, has plants in Italy, West Germany, Britain and the United States. Emhart said the acquisition was part of a European expansion plan for its electrical/electronics group.

title: SERVED AS THE PRESIDENT, 1976-1982
description: Elias Sarkis, who as President of Lebanon from 1976 to 1982 was unable to restore peace between clashing factions, died yesterday at his Paris home, the Lebanese Embassy in Paris announced. He was 60 years old.

title: ASSEMBLY GIVES JERSEY'S BUDGET FINAL APPROVAL
description: A $9 billion state budget for the new fiscal year gained final passage in the Assembly shortly before midnight today.

title: One Client Fewer For Koch the Columnist
description: Mayor Koch may not think his official campaign has begun yet, but The Staten Island Advance does.

title: A.T. T. HAS A 100-YEAR LEAD ON THE COMPETITION
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE ROLL-CALL VOTE RESTRICTING U.S. TROOPS IN NICARAGUA
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 312 to 111 by which the House of Representatives today banned the use of United States combat troops in Nicaragua.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 28, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: SINCE La Reserve opened two years ago in the Rockefeller Center area it has been overshadowed by its celebrated midtown neighbors Le Cirque, Le Cygne, La Cote Basque and The Four Seasons. La Reserve was known only as a comfortable midtown way station with a charming ambiance and undistinguished food.

title: BIG U.S. COMPUTER DEAL FOR A.T.& T.
description: The National Security Agency chose the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday to supply it with up to $946 million in minicomputers and services for a new, classified project.

title: WALTER GOLDWATER
description: Walter Goldwater, a tournament chess player and antiquarian who owned the University Place Book Shop - one of the last survivors of New York's Bookseller's Row - died Monday at University Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MUSEUM TENTATIVELY ACCEPTS PEROT OFFER TO MOVE TO TEXAS
description: The trustees of the Museum of the American Indian voted tentatively yesterday to accept $70 million from H. Ross Perot, the Texas computer executive, and to move the museum to Texas.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 9.50-10.00** Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TOKYO POLICE ASSEMBLE EVIDENCE IN BOMBING
description: Police officers finished collecting physical evidence at the international airport near here today, but they declined afterward to say what type of bomb they believed had caused the baggage explosion on Sunday that killed two people.

title: Following The Leaders
description: Last summer in Los Angeles and at Stanford, the United States Olympic soccer team, despite abundant hopes, failed to get past the first round. This April the North American Soccer League became defunct. Last month the national team failed to qualify for the 1986 World Cup. Last week the Cosmos, the N.A.S.L.'s crown-jewel franchise, bowed to reality and shut down, abandoning plans for a summer-long series of international matches that were to have been played in the absence of a league schedule.

title: LIBERTY FESTIVITIES TO BEGIN TODAY
description: Eight world-class yachtsmen are expected to team with a group of celebrities for a regatta today as a preliminary to the four-day Liberty Cup match-racing series in New York Harbor that begins tomorrow.

title: 2 FACE CHARGES IN A BANK THEFT OF $23 MILLION
description: Two of the city's top concrete-industry executives were indicted yesterday on charges of stealing $23 million from two New York banks in a scheme that involved fraudulent transfers between two accounts.

title: Australia Paper Accord
description: Printers and journalists voted today to end a nine-day strike at Rupert Murdoch's national newspaper, The Australian, after a court ordered unions to negotiate with management. The dispute involves new production techniques.

title: White's Whites Ruled Off-Color
description: Anne White opened play by sporting some nontraditional tennis whites, but her match was postponed by darkness.

title: FALTERING PIRATES LOSE TO EXPOS, 4-2
description: Tim Raines hit a two-run homer and Jeff Reardon earned his major league-leading 22d save as the Montreal Expos beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-2, tonight.

title: 2,000 Pounds of Cocaine
description: Drug agents seized about 2,000 pounds of cocaine, two speedboats and four sports cars and arrested 10 people in a raid on a waterfront home this morning. Sheriff Richard Wille said the cocaine, stuffed in 30 duffel bags, was believed to have come from South America via the Bahamas and was intended for distribution in the North.

title: DEADLOCK ON DIPLOMATIC NOMINEES EASES SLIGHTLY
description: Reagan Administration nominations for several important diplomatic posts, held up for months by opposition from conservative forces led by Senator Jesse Helms, finally began to move through the Senate today.

title: CALLIGRAPHY WITH A NEW FLAIR
description: There is a small but growing group of calligraphers in the New York area whose work goes beyond envelope addressing and the well-penned wedding or bar mitzvah invitation. Instead, they specialize in one-of-a-kind special projects that run the gamut from the serious to the lighthearted.

title: Goetz Fails in Attempt To Quash Indictment
description: An appeals court yesterday unanimously denied a defense motion for dismissal of an attempted-murder indictment against Bernhard H. Goetz, who shot four young men on a subway train last December.

title: CBS SETTLES SUIT CHARGING HARASSMENT
description: CBS has settled a lawsuit brought by an employee who charged the company with sexual harassment, CBS said yesterday.

title: Haden Leads Orchestra
description: The bassist Charlie Haden will lead his 12-piece Liberation Music Orchestra, featuring the French horn player Sharon Freeman, the tenor saxophonist Dewey Redman, the pianist Amina Claudine Myers, the trombonist Craig Harris and the drummer Paul Motian, tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil , 88 Seventh Avenue South above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets begin tonight and tomorrow at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; also Saturday at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and Sunday at 1 A.M. There is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: JMB REALTY TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of property of $2,000,000 for the quarter and $3,500,000 for the nine months.

title: First Chicago, Comptroller Deny Sale Rumors
description: Rumors that Federal regulators are seeking a buyer for the First National Bank of Chicago were denied yesterday by the bank and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency. First National is the principal subsidiary of the First Chicago Corporation, the nation's 10th-largest bank holding company.

title: Bridge: Jim Becker, Club Proprietor, Finds Time for Tournaments
description: Proprietors of bridge clubs are in general too busy to compete regularly and seriously in tournaments. An exception is Jim Becker, manager of the successful Beverly Club, at 130 East 57th Street.

title: Fayva to Jordan, Case
description: Jordan, Case & McGrath is stepping out this morning with a brand new account, the Fayva chain of 650 shoe shops operated by the Morse Shoe Company of Canton, Mass.

title: Case Solved
description: The great mystery concerning the whereabouts of Malcolm Scott (Sports World Specials, June 24) has been solved.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: BLUES in a variety of forms will be in the Kool Jazz Festival spotlight during this windup weekend. Featured will be Ray Charles, Johnny Otis, Etta James, John Mayall, African sources and Brazilian variants as well as the music of New Orleans, old and new - memories of Louis Armstrong and performances by Dr. John.

title: ROCK: THE LONE JUSTICE BAND
description: LONE JUSTICE, the Los Angeles-based rock band fronted by 20-year-old Maria McKee, has received more advance critical acclaim than any other new West Coast act to arrive in years. While its pleasantly peppy first album doesn't bear out the extravagant claims that have been made for it, in the group's local concert debut at the Bottom Line (15 West Fourth Street), Wednesday night, its members displayed an impressive power and coordination.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 28, 1985

title: EUROPEANS RETALIATE ON TARIFFS
description: The European Economic Community today announced higher tariffs on walnuts and lemons imported from the United States in retaliation for Washington's restrictions on imports of pasta from the 10-nation bloc.

title: A.T.& T. Has a 100-Year Lead on the Competition
description: To the Editor:

title: New Push for Europe
description: After a decade of doldrums, members of the European Community are getting worried enough about their future to seek new momentum. Already, though, high expectations for this weekend's Common Market summit meeting in Milan have sagged.

title: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Pryor's Dime
description: The Capitol casts a peculiar spell on some people, producing a reaction far more lasting and powerful than the casual tourist's hushed awe. When David H. Pryor first walked into the hallowed legislative halls about 1950, he was a schoolboy from Camden, Ark., about to become a House page.

title: SOVIET SPEECH ON ARMS ASTONISHES STATE DEPT.
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it was ''astonished'' by what it called a thinly veiled threat by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, to suspend the Geneva arms control talks.

title: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 15
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $147,000 and a gain from the sale of County Seat Stores Inc. of $24,163,000, or 65 cents a share.

title: DANCE: HARLEM TROUPE PERFORMS 'LA MER'
description: THE Dance Theater of Harlem has found a pretty, lyrical ballet for its repertory in ''La Mer'' by Domy Reiter-Soffer, performed for the first time in New York on Wednesday at the Metropolitan Opera House, where the company performs through Saturday. That look of lyrical prettiness is deceptive, though, for the ballet also captures the buried turbulence and surprises of the Debussy score to which it is set.

title: CHINATOWN BANK SET TO REOPEN
description: The Canal Street headquarters and the three branches of the failed Golden Pacific National Bank are expected to open today under the management of the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation.

title: Portuguese President Plans To Dissolve the Parliament
description: President Antonio Ramalho Eanes of Portugal decided today to dissolve Parliament but plans to maintain the current Government for the moment, an official statement said.

title: GOLDEN WEST HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to May 25
description: b-Includes carryback credits of $318,000 for the quarter and $737,000 for the year.

title: Parker Hannifin
description: The Parker Hannifin Corporation, a Cleveland-based industrial machinery company, said that it had agreed to acquire Schrader Bellows Inc., a subsidiary of Scovill Inc., for about $77.5 million. The purchase of Schrader, a maker of pneumatic automation products with 1984 sales of $114 million, would ''augment Parker's broad line of hydraulic and pneumatic products,'' Paul G. Schloemer, president of Parker Hannifin, said.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL PITTSBURGH (NL) - Traded Steve Shirley, minor league pitcher, to Detroit for Sid Monge, pitcher with Nashville of the American Association.

title: A Son's Death, A Father's Crusade
description: Representative Charles E. Bennett is an emotional man, brimming with crusading zeal, personal hurts and angry candor. By his own admission, he is often ''inches away from tears.''

title: New Interest in Pirates
description: A group of corporate executives that includes Douglas D. Danforth, the chairman of Westinghouse Electric Corporation, has emerged as the only local potential buyer of the financially troubled Pittsburgh Pirates, Mayor Richard Caliguiri said yesterday.

title: Elias in 'Pearls'
description: Rosalind Elias, the Metropolitan Opera mezzo-soprano, is starring in ''Pearls,'' presented by the Jewish Repertory Theater, 344 East 14th Street.

title: Scottish Music
description: The singer Alison Kinnaird and the harpist Christine Primrose will perform Scottish traditional music tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Alternative Museum, 17 White Street (966-4444). Tickets are $7.

title: ANDRETTI PLOTS MEADOWLANDS STATEGY
description: They were at opposite ends of the tent, a lot farther apart than they figure to be on the track Sunday, but there was a feeling of closeness today between Mario Andretti and Bobby Rahal.

title: BID TO TOUGHEN MURDER PENALTY FAILS IN ALBANY
description: Efforts to win passage this session of a bill allowing some murderers to be sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole failed today.

title: OHIO UTILITIES' DEBT
description: The Standard and Poor's Corporation announced yesterday that it was placing the combined $4 billion debt of both the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company and the Toledo Edison Company under review because of the proposed merger between the two utilities. The rating service may downgrade the debt rating on Cleveland Electric and upgrade the debt rating of Toledo Edison. S.&P. said, ''Both utilities are involved in the construction of three nuclear plants and are already cash-short,'' it said.

title: Keeping the Constitutional Faith
description: In striking down a Connecticut law that let any employee take off from work on his chosen Sabbath, the Supreme Court has drawn a useful line between yielding to the demands of religious interests and accommodating them. The decision gives hope that rulings like last year's approval of a city-sponsored Nativity display were only momentary lapses from the rule of strict government neutrality on religious matters.

title: Insurers Seek Policy Change
description: The insurance industry, as expected, proposed yesterday that limits on claims in many business policies include for the first time the costs of the legal defense in liability cases.

title: HOUSE RESTRICTS SENDING OF G.I.'S INTO NICARAGUA
description: The House voted today to limit any move to use United States combat troops in Nicaragua, but only after the measure had been weakened by a battery of Republican-sponsored amendments.

title: Quartet at Jazz Center
description: The Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street near East Third Street (505-5660), will present the tenor saxophonist George Coleman with his quartet tonight at 9:30 and 11. Tomorrow at 9:30 and 11 P.M., the saxophonist Jimmy Heath will lead a sextet in a program dedicated to Charlie Parker. Tickets are $8, $6 for students and the elderly.

title: AUTHOR OF BOOK ON POPE ORDERED TO PRODUCE NOTES
description: In an 8-to-3 decision holding that the press and religion clauses of the First Amendment did not apply to the case, the full United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia ruled that the author of a controversial biography of Pope John Paul II must comply with a subpoena to produce his notes or be held in civil contempt.

title: FILM: 'ST. ELMO'S FIRE'
description: IN the realm of films about close-knit bands of school friends, ''St. Elmo's Fire'' falls midway between ''The Big Chill'' and ''The Breakfast Club.'' Its characters are old enough to enjoy the first flushes of prosperity, but still sufficiently youthful to keep their self-absorption intact. But soon enough, they will be forced to give up their late-night carousing at a favorite bar and move on to more responsible lives. In the film's terms, which are distinctly limited, this will mean finding a more sedate hangout and learning to go there for brunch.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Tuesday about insurance claims expected to result from the Air-India plane crash Sunday incorrectly described the maximum liability that airlines have under the Montreal Agreement. It is $75,000 per passenger and covers travelers whose tickets have a point of arrival or departure in the United States.

title: SCREEN: 'SONGWRITER'
description: WILLIE NELSON and Kris Kristofferson declare war on the music business with ''Songwriter,'' and they very nearly win. This chaotic comedy, which devotes itself to the lighter side of what the screenplay calls ''moguling,'' also further establishes the maverick directorial touch of Alan Rudolph. Mr. Rudolph, who last directed ''Choose Me,'' this time works in a snappier, much messier, less languid style. Though ''Songwriter'' is an original, it recalls the director's earlier ''Roadie'' in its choppiness, its knowing view of show business, and its humor, which tends to be exuberantly rude.

title: CCA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After tax credits of $369,433 or 7 cents a share for the quarter and $563,799 or 11 cents a share for the six months. c-Net loss, which reflects losses from discontinued operations of $20,451 for the quarter and $451,516 for the six months. d-The company said it did not have year-ago sales figures because it was engaged in a now-discontinued medical products business.

title: FRANK LORIMER, DEMOGRAPHER
description: Dr. Frank Lorimer, a demographer and sociologist, died Sunday in Wakatane, New Zealand, where he was working on a philosophical treatise, ''The Challenge of the Global Crises.'' He was 90 years old.

title: TENTATIVE ACCORD REACHED WITH CITY TRANSIT WORKERS
description: Negotiators announced a tentative agreement yesterday on a new transit contract that would raise the pay of city bus and subway workers by nearly 18 percent over the next three years.

title: NO SALVADOR ACTION YET ON OFFICER TIED TO KILLINGS
description: Salvadoran Army and legal officials said today that no action had yet been taken against a Salvadoran Army captain who has been accused in new testimony of helping to kill the head of the Salvadoran land redistribution institute and two Americans here in 1981.

title: Hibernia-Fidelity
description: The Hibernia Corporation of New Orleans has reached an agreement in principle to acquire the Fidelity National Financial Corporation of Baton Rouge, La., in a deal valued at $74 million, Fidelity said.

title: BAXTER PUTS PRESSURE ON AMERICAN
description: Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. intensified pressure yesterday on the American Hospital Supply Corporation to reconsider its merger proposal by guaranteeing that all shares would be exchanged for either $50 in cash or an equivalent amount of stock.

title: PARIS AND BONN TO PRESENT A UNITY PLAN AT COMMON MARKET PARLEY
description: France and West Germany will present a plan for closer European political unity at a two-day meeting of European leaders that opens here Friday, both Governments said today.

title: Sohio to Eliminate 450 Staff Positions
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said that it would eliminate about 450 corporate staff positions over the next several months.

title: KEY TO DISEASE SEEN
description: Scientists have discovered a previously unidentified gene in the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: JUDGES HEAR PLEAS ON 3 MILE ISLAND
description: Groups opposed to the reopening of the undamaged Three Mile Island reactor argued in court today that despite six years of hearings, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission did not adequately consider whether the plant's owner was trustworthy before it voted last month to allow operations to resume.

title: RoadKnight in Concert
description: Margret RoadKnight, an Australian folk, blues and jazz singer and comedian, will be making two appearances this weekend.

title: COMMUNITY PSYCHIATRIC CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
American Express Unit Fills Vacant Presidency
description: The American Express Company announced yesterday that Aldo Papone had been named president and chief operating officer of its flagship subsidiary, the American Express Travel Related Services Company. The appointment is effective Monday.

title: INTERMETRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BRITISH PENSION FUND BUYS MANUSCRIPT PIECE
description: The pension fund of Britain's state-owned railroad said today that it paid $105,600 for a fragment of a 1,300-year-old manuscript sold by the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington.

title: Export Control Act Extended
description: Congress passed and sent to President Reagan today a bill extending for four years the Export Administration Act, which gives the Government authority to control exports for security or foreign policy reasons.

title: YANKEES POISED TO MOVE
description: Trade rumors aside, the Yankees appear to have reached an important juncture in their season - that is, if the period leading up to the All-Star Game break can be considered important.

title: Swap Speed for Seat-Belt Limits
description: The Transportation Department says that Arizona, Maryland and Vermont are failing to enforce the 55-mile-an-hour speed limit, jeopardizing their rights to Federal highway subsidies. What it doesn't say is that the limit is casually disobeyed in every state. The question now is whether the benefits of this limit - in lives and gasoline saved - are worth the cost in driver frustration. One possible compromise would be to raise the limit on lightly traveled interstates and to compensate for the added danger and fuel consumption with mandatory seat-belt use and gasoline taxes.

title: STEVENS CONSIDERS SELLING FOUR UNITS
description: J. P. Stevens & Company, the nation's second-largest textile manufacturer, said yesterday that it was considering selling four of its apparel fabrics units and expects to take a write-off of about $85 million in the third fiscal quarter ending in July for anticipated costs of the restructuring.

title: Promotion at Hearst
description: Gilbert C. Maurer, 57 years old, the president and chief executive of Hearst Magazines, has been given the additional title of executive vice president of the Hearst Corporation, a slot that has been unused since Frank A. Bennack Jr., president and chief executive of the corporation, was promoted out of it in 1979. Before joining the Hearst organization in 1973, Mr. Maurer was with Cowles Communications, serving as publisher of Venture magazine and, later, president of Family Circle.

title: NAVY CHARGES DOCTOR WITH KILLING 4 IN OPERATIONS
description: The Navy today formally charged Comdr. Donal M. Billig with killing four patients at its flagship hospital in Bethesda, Md., when he bungled their surgery.

title: PIRANDELLO'S 'HENRY IV'
description: AT the time of his death, Luigi Pirandello, the celebrated Italian playwright (1867-1936), was under contract to play the dramatist in a Hollywood screen adaptation of his classic comedy ''Six Characters in Search of an Author.'' What it might have been, only heaven now knows. Pirandello's presence in the cast might possibly have saved it from the ''improvements'' and clarifications that have marked all other Pirandello film adaptations I've seen, including M-G-M's 1932 version of ''As You Desire Me,'' directed by George Fitzmaurice (''Mata Hari'') and starring Greta Garbo.

title: When the Brain Dies, Questions of Volition End
description: To the Editor:

title: ENSERCH TO WRITE DOWN ASSETS BY $225 MILLION
description: Hard hit by falling oil and gas prices, the Enserch Corporation said yesterday that it would write down its assets by about $225 million before taxes in the second quarter.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing U.S. Grand Prix, at the Meadowlands, opening day. After the gates open at 8 A.M. there will be practice sessions all morning and part of the afternoon for Sunday's race, and visitors can also see the Motorsports Expo in the Giants Stadium Concourse. The Cart/Indy car qualifying heats begin around 2 P.M. Baseball Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Opener of a three-game weekend series. The Yankees dropped three out of the four games they played earlier this month in Milwaukee. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Cardinals, at St. Louis. Opener of three-game series. The Mets and the Cardinals do not meet again until September in Shea Stadium. The Cardinals have won five out of the nine games between the two teams this season. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M. Radio -WHN 1050, 8:30 P.M.) Bicycling The Tour de France, opening day. The three-week race kicks off with a time-trial prologue in Vannes in Brittany. Bernard Hinault is the favorite to win a record-tying fifth Tour de France. Greg Lemond, the American who finished third last year, is another favorite. He is a teammate of Hinault on the La Vie Claire team. Boxing Paul DeVorce vs. Tyrone Jackson, 12 rounds for vacant New York State featherweight championships at the Felt Forum, Madison Square Garden. First preliminary, 7:30 P.M. DeVorce, from Yonkers, is 20-2 and rated No. 1.

title: Celanese Corp. Wins Attention
description: THE Celanese Corporation, one of the world's largest producers of man-made fibers, is drawing plaudits on Wall Street for a restructuring strategy that has enhanced the company's prospects and propelled its stock to new highs.

title: Legal Abortion Backed By Spanish Parliament
description: The Spanish Parliament enacted a law legalizing abortion today, ending a 40-year-old ban on the procedure in this predominantly Roman Catholic country.

title: FRENCH TV TO SHOW DOCUMENTARY
description: French state-run television, after arousing a storm of protest by canceling the planned broadcast of a documentary on the World War II Resistance in Paris that was critical of the Communist Party, has rescheduled the program for next week.

title: HERR PROVING HIS POINT TO FOES AND FORECASTERS
description: Tommy Herr remembers it well: Bruce Sutter took his hike as a free agent last winter, and people began to mourn the passing of the St. Louis Cardinals. And this was the team that won the World Series two years earlier.

title: China Builds Steel Plant
description: China has completed the first plant at its troubled Baoshan steel complex, The People's Daily reported today. The $363 million plant near Shanghai has a capacity of 6.5 million tons a year, it said. Planning errors caused China to interrupt the project in 1980 and cancel $1.5 billion of contracts, since renegotiated, with Japanese and West German suppliers.

title: Jamaica Working Again After General Strike
description: Most public employees returned to work today after a general strike disrupted electricity, water and communications for three days.

title: Flight 182's Challenge to Gandhi
description: There is increasing agreement that a bomb destroyed Air India's Flight 182 off the Irish coast, but we may never know whether the Boeing 747 was blown up by Sikh militants, as some of them have reportedly claimed. Yet, in the minds of many Indians, the 329 men, women and children on the Toronto-Bombay flight were victims of a stepped-up global effort aimed at destabilizing their democracy. I fear that the prospect of a reasonably early resolution of India's most pressing problem - the Punjab, where Sikh separatists have been agitating to establish a theocratic state called Khalistan - may have also disappeared with Flight 182.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Acapulco Restaurants of Pasadena, Calif., which operates Mexican restaurants in California and Oregon, has elected Phillip Ratner president and chief operating officer.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: LORD and Lady Romsey of England are here with one of their dining room chairs. The chair is French, with tapered legs, and upholstered in a fabric designed by Lord Romsey's uncle, David Hicks. On Wednesday, the Romseys took the chair to a black-tie dinner at Le Perigord Park where it was much admired by their 50 guests, a collection of interior designers and connoisseurs of fine furniture.

title: TRANSFERS REDUCED IN U.S.
description: In the United States, companies are asking fewer managers to transfer than they did in the 1970's.

title: A Walk in the Village
description: In the early 18th century, the streets of Greenwich Village near the Hudson River were marketplaces to receive produce and other provisions. Today, residential buildings share the area with a variety of warehouses.

title: FILM OF SAKHAROV REACHES THE WEST
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and rights advocate, is ''seriously ill,'' according to a report here based on recent Soviet videotapes.

title: U.S. WILL END CURBSIDE CHECK-INS AS PART OF DRIVE ON AIRLINE TERROR
description: Curbside check-ins of luggage for international flights will be ended as part of an effort by President Reagan to reduce the vulnerability of American airlines and airports to terrorists, Transportation Secretary Elizbeth H. Dole announced here today.

title: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH 3 HOSTAGES
description: Following are excerpts from an interview broadcast by ABC News with three of the American hostages in Lebanon, Allyn Conwell of Houston, Ralf Traugott of Lunenberg, Mass., and the Rev. James W. McLoughlin of Geneva, Ill., as recorded by The New York Times:

title: WHITE HOUSE QUIET ON BEIRUT ACTIONS
description: The Reagan Administration maintained a tight news blackout on developments in the Beirut hostage crisis today, and the White House took steps to quell criticism by frustrated families.

title: AUCTIONS
description: The Dorotheum, the world's oldest auction house, is combining some ancient and modern business practices to increase profits. As a result, sales have doubled in less than a decade, but criticism has risen sharply, too.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday ASIAN AMERICAN FILMS Nineteen films by Asian and Asian American film makers are on the agenda for a three-day festival that begins tonight at the Rosemary Theater, 133 Canal Street. The eighth annual Asian American International Film Festival opens at 7:15 with a program that features ''Dollar a Day, 10 Cents a Dance,'' ''Stopover,'' and ''Beacon Hill Boys.'' The 9:30 program is ''There Was a War When I Was a Child.'' On Saturday, ''Homecoming'' will be shown at 2:30 P.M., ''36 Chowringhee Lane'' at 4:30, ''Yato'' and ''Unfinished Business'' at 7 and ''Insiang'' at 9. Sunday's programs are ''Uproar in Heaven'' at 2:30, ''Wong Sinsang,'' ''Kites and Other Tales,'' ''Cruisin' J-Town'' and ''Wataridori: Birds of Passage'' at 4:30, ''Wang Yien, the Puppeteer,'' ''Masters of the Wok,'' and ''Sweet Jail: the Sikhs of Yuba City'' at 7 and ''Fine Line'' and ''The Fall of the I-Hotel' at 9. Tickets are $5 for each program. The reservations number is 925-8685.

title: HANNS SWARZENSKI, A SCHOLAR
description: Dr. Hanns Swarzenski, a scholar of medieval art and former curator of decorative arts and sculpture at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, died last Saturday at his home in Wilzhofen, West Germany. He was 81 years old.

title: Some Common Sense On Gasoline Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Elections in Peril, Bolivian Leaders Warn
description: The Government warned today that strikes that have crippled two major cities and shut down the central bank also threaten to postpone the July 14 presidential elections.

title: INERTIA DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SECOND TURK IN ROME TRIAL DENIES ROLE IN ANY PAPAL PLOT
description: The former leader of an organization of Turkish migrant workers in West Germany, accused of conspiring with Mehmet Ali Agca to assassinate Pope John Paul II, said today that he was ''never the head of a terrorist organization called the Gray Wolves.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 28, 1985

title: PAY TO RISE 23% OVER 5 YEARS
description: Hotel workers yesterday roared approval of a settlement ending their 27-day strike against 53 of New York City's busiest hotels and began returning to work.

title: The Pressures On Free Trade
description: WHAT can be done about the yawning United States trade deficit, which reached a record high of $123 billion last year and is rising still higher this year?

title: RENT CONTROL FOR BUSINESS DEBATED
description: In an occasionally raucous hearing at City Hall yesterday, officials, landlord representatives and lease-holding merchants argued the merits and flaws of proposals to institute rent control for commercial property.

title: ART: SOL LEWITT DRAWING AT BROOKLYN MUSEUM
description: SOL LEWITT is the latest artist to be invited to put his stamp on the Grand Lobby of the Brooklyn Museum. His ''Pyramid,'' a 20-foot-high by 60-foot-wide wall drawing, is a familiar LeWitt - a blend of Conceptual Art and Minimalism that sets out to question perception and to define a space between artistic categories. It is not, however, a first-rate LeWitt, the kind of modular work or wall drawing in which his austere, ascetic, iconoclastic approach is pushed to a level of razor-sharp insight.

title: LOUDLY, PEKING PROCLAIMS: SPIT AT YOUR OWN PERIL
description: Among the pleasant surprises awaiting people returning to Peking for the first time in years has been the relative quiet on city streets. The horn-honking that used to produce a dawn-to-dusk cacophony has been silenced, and so, until recently, were the blaring loudspeakers attached to public buildings.

title: ART: AT THE WHITNEY, MICHAEL HEIZER WORK
description: ALMOST wall-to-wall and floor-to-ceiling, Michael Heizer's single work ''Dragged Mass Geometric'' occupies the main gallery on the fourth floor of the Whitney Museum, Madison Avenue at 75th Street, so fully that there's hardly room for the viewer.

title: WERNER DREWES
description: Werner Drewes, a German-born painter who later became a founding member of the American Abstract Artists group, died last Friday at Fairfax Hospital in Reston, Va. He was 85 years old and lived in Reston.

title: ACCORD ON MALPRACTICE PLAN REACHED BY ALBANY LEADERS
description: Governor Cuomo and the legislative leaders announced agreement today on a plan to curb the rapidly rising malpractice insurance premiums paid by physicians in New York State and to increase coverage doctors can obtain against high malpractice judgments.

title: Organist Ejected
description: When a dispute broke out Wednesday night at a minor-league game between the Clearwater Phillies and the Osceola Astros at Clearwater, Fla., Wilbur Snapp was the only person ejected by Umpire Kevin O'Connor.

title: THEY'RE OFF AND RUNNING IN MINNESOTA
description: Horse racing came to Minnesota Wednesday with the opening of Canterbury Downs in Shakopee, Minn., just outside of Minneapolis-St. Paul. Every reserved seat in the new house was sold, and a crowd of 15,000 bet $850,000 on the nine races.

title: Surgery on Wrong Foot
description: When Robb Johnston, the projected starting safety for the University of Wisconsin this fall, awoke from surgery, he knew something was wrong: the foot he expected to throb felt fine.

title: LENNAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Dining Out Guide: Elegance
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. EL INTERNACIONAL, #219 West Broadway (226-8131) -

title: Thank You, Mr. Delacorte
description: And uptown, another angel was being honored.

title: Aouita Records 2d-Fastest 5,000
description: Said Aouita of Morocco ran the world's second-fastest 5,000-meter race today, and Steve Cram of Britain recorded the third-fastest 1,500-meter time on Bislett Stadium's new synthetic track.

title: Quake Hits in Caribbean
description: Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands were shaken by a strong earthquake Wednesday afternoon that drove frightened residents into the streets, the authorities said. There were no immediate reports of damage. The United States Geological Survey in Washington said the earthquake registered 5.5 on the Richter scale.

title: MITEL CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to May 24
SMUCKER, J M CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FILM: CLINT EASTWOOD IN 'PALE RIDER'
description: AS the Book of Revelations puts it, ''Behold a pale horse: and his name that sat on him was Death.''

title: BRIEFS
description: Air One Inc., St. Louis, said it had submitted a reorganization plan to a Federal Bankruptcy Court calling for the airline to begin scheduled and charter service within 60 days with two Boeing 727-200 aircraft.

title: Earnings Mark
description: On The Road Again became the leading money-winning pacer by capturing the $125,000, 1 1/2-mile second leg of the World Cup tonight at the Meadowlands.

title: OPENING DELAYED
description: The 63d Street subway tunnel, which has been under construction for 14 years and was scheduled to open later this year, has serious flaws and will not open on time, transit officials said yesterday.

title: BUDGET CONFEREES ON 10-DAY RECESS
description: House and Senate negotiators got together to talk again about the 1986 budget this afternoon, but left for a 10-day recess without breaking their deadlock over the Social Security cost-of-living increase.

title: PAPER SAYS U.S. REPORT CRITICIZES LANCE'S BANK
description: Bert Lance, the chairman of the Georgia Democratic Party and President Carter's first budget director, has engaged in illegal, unsafe and unsound banking practices, according to a confidential report by Federal bank examiners described in Friday's editions of The Atlanta Constitution.

title: MICHAELS PUTS OFF HIS DECISION ON FLUTIE
description: Doug Flutie practiced with the Generals today for the first time since his left collarbone was fractured June 1, but Coach Walt Michaels reserved his decision to use Flutie against the Baltimore Stars in the playoff game here Monday night.

title: BROADWAY
description: THINGS are humming in the offices of Lewis Allen, who co-produced ''Annie'' and the current ''I'm Not Rappaport.'' Mr. Allen, who recently announced that he will be bringing the Jason Robards-Jose Quintero revival of Eugene O'Neill's ''Iceman Cometh'' to Broadway and Sam Shepard's new play, ''A Lie of Mind,'' to the Promenade Theater this fall, has another project in the works.

title: 2 RENTAL LUXURY TOWERS RISE IN THE NEW YORKVILLS
description: Along a stretch of York Avenue in the low 90's, where a Midas Muffler shop and two gas stations used to serve the old Yorkville, the new Yorkville is showing its colors, and its rents.

title: E.P.A. AIMS TO CURB TALL SMOKESTACKS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency issued final rules today discouraging power plants' use of tall smokestacks to disperse pollutants over long distances.

title: Love, Despite The 'Regs'
description: It began, like so few capital events, with love. Wilbur Warren, a watchful gray-haired man, said he coveted Lilia Bonner, whose voice is soft as her smile, when he first saw her in the hallway of the Green One wing at the nursing home.

title: United Airlines
description: United Airlines, a unit of UAL Inc., said it plans to increase by 8 percent the available seat miles of Pan American World Airways' trans-Pacific operations as soon as the transfer of those operations to United is completed. The airline said it would add flights to Japan from Los Angeles, San Francisco and New York.

title: SCOTT SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: A BREAKTHROUGH FOR NERVOUS HU NA
description: She played her first match of the 1982 Federation Cup tournament on a July evening in Santa Clara, Calif., and wasn't seen again in public for eight months. Hu Na hid in the homes of sympathetic Chinese families on the West Coast during that time, hoping one day to be granted asylum in the United States. Her second wish was to pursue a professional tennis career.

title: MICHIGAN SHIITE INVITES FAMILIES TO VISIT RELATIVES HELD IN BEIRUT
description: A group of Shiite Moslems from Michigan has invited families of American hostages being held in Lebanon to accompany them on a trip to Beirut.

title: Alcohol a Small Part of Domestic Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Diversifoods Loses a Suitor
description: The Horn & Hardart Company said today that it and Jesart Partners, a partnership that it controls, have ceased their efforts to acquire Diversifoods Inc., an Illinois-based restaurant company.

title: Band at Tramps
description: The Buckwheat Zydeco Band will play New Orleans rhythm-and-blues tonight at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077). Sets begin at approximately 9:30 and 11:30; there is a $9 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: WHITE'S SUIT OUT OF BOUNDS
description: Dusk was falling and thoughts of dinner and tennis talk should have been uppermost in the minds of fans. But many of them lingered at Court 2 today, where Ann White was causing quite a scandal in her Wimbledon attire.

title: Laurels
description: The New Republic is a small magazine, but it is not without laurels. Its publisher, 33-year-old Jeffrey L. Dearth, entered the National Advertising Week Tennis Tournament in New York last week, triumphed in a round robin over executives from such such weighty publications as Good Housekeeping, Parade, The New Yorker, Esquire, U.S. News & World Report and Harper's Bazaar and brought the silver trophy back to Washington for the first time.

title: N.H.L. Settles Antitrust Suit
description: Lawyers for Ralston Purina Company and the National Hockey League announced today that they had settled lawsuits filed against each other over the company's attempt to sell the St. Louis Blues, ending a trial that was expected to last until late August.

title: REAGAN CALLS PLAN REVENUE-NEUTRAL
description: President Reagan insisted today that his sweeping tax revision plan would close loopholes and lower tax rates without a loss in revenue to the Federal Government.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: BALTIMORE GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Year to May 31
VICORP RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 12
HOTEL INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $244,000 from the sale of a hotel in December 1983.

title: Columbia Gas
description: Columbia Gas System Inc. said that its major gas pipeline company had reduced its natural gas prices 11.5 percent, retroactive to April 1.

title: ADVANCED LOGIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Padres Trade Wiggins
description: It's done. Alan Wiggins has left the Padres and is now with the Baltimore Orioles. The two teams finally worked out the details that sent the 27-year-old second baseman to Baltimore for a minor league pitcher, Roy Lee Jackson, and a player to be named.

title: ZIMBABWE WHITES KEEP SMITH IN PARLIAMENT
description: Ian D. Smith, the Prime Minister of this nation when it was still white-ruled Rhodesia, easily defeated his opponent today to retain his seat in Parliament, as voting began in Zimbabwe's first general elections since independence five years ago.

title: COURT BARS SUING THE ARMY OVER MURDER OF SERVICEMAN
description: The Supreme Court today barred a suit against the Federal Government charging that the Army negligently failed to prevent a soldier with a known history of violence from kidnapping and murdering a fellow serviceman.

title: Staff Cutbacks at I.R.S. Are Costing the Country a Lot of Money
description: To the Editor:

title: RETREAT OF THE YUPPIES: THE TIDE NOW TURNS AMID 'GUILT' AND 'DENIAL'
description: Lately, Gil Schwartz has been suffering guilt pangs all over the Upper West Side.

title: Easy Retirement, Hard Cost
description: Memories of New York's decade-old fiscal crisis seem dim as the State Legislature prepares to wind up its current session. A bill gaining momentum in the closing hours would encourage early retirement of teachers but do so by placing a heavy financial burden on municipal governments and local school districts.

title: HIGH OVER NEW MEXICO'S DESERT, A GIANT NONNUCLEAR CLOUD
description: The largest nonnuclear explosion ever set off by a non-Communist nation hurled a gigantic mushroom cloud above the desert here today, rattling windows dozens of miles away. Nothing like it had been seen in the United States since atmospheric nuclear tests were banned in 1963.

title: 'Trash' on Display
description: When is trash not trash? When it is turned into the artwork and other items on display at a Found Object Fair today from noon to 6 P.M. at P.S. 61, 610 East 12th Street. Bags of clean, non-biodegradable trash that was collected by the artist Natalie Dymnicki for a kinetic art piece will be available for inspection along with sculptures, dolls, costumes and instruments also made from refuse by other artists.

title: FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
CRAZY EDDIE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
HELMS SAYS IRAN PLANNED HIJACKING
description: Senator Jesse Helms asserted today that Iran had set in motion the seizure of the Trans World Airlines plane 13 days ago and trained at least one of the original hijacking team.

title: THE RISING TIDE OF MERGERS Merger and Acquisition Activity
description: Last year, the big players were oil companies, with their staggering multibillion-dollar deals. This year, the focus in the ever-rampant game of mergers and acquisitions has scattered, jumping to broadcasting, health care, consumer brands, banks, the airlines and to two newly acquisitive giants: the General Motors Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: ELRON ELECTRONIC INDUSTRIES LTD (ISRAEL)(O) reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The company said latest year net was reduced by about $10,000,000 as a result of the $33,800,000 loss of Elscint Ltd., of which Elron owned about 30 percent.

title: Thrift Units' Earnings Jump
description: Earnings at federally insured thrift institutions during the first three months of this year were up sharply from the previous quarter, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: Nuclear Plant Suit Is Lost
description: The State of Washington is not responsible for $7.25 billion in bonds and interest lost by investors after a public utility association canceled two nuclear power plants, a Superior Court judge ruled today.

title: JURORS DELIBERATING IN THE SLAYING OF ACTRESS ON ROOF ON WEST SIDE
description: The jury in the murder trial of Emmanuel Torres, who is accused of killing a young actress on the roof of her Upper West Side apartment building last Dec. 2, began deliberations yesterday after the prosecution told them her life had been destroyed because of the defendant's ''rage and anger.''

title: 30 IDEAS FOR THE SUMMER CALENDAR
description: NEW YORK is a summer festival, it seems, with the parks full of theater, dance and music, the galleries offering exhibitions with odd and inventive themes, and movie houses bristling with special film series. Familiar institutions suddenly become a place to find the unfamiliar, and the brave new, shoestring efforts that were expected to last a summer or two wake up one June morning to find themselves an enduring feature of the season. 1. One of those familiar institutions, Shakespeare in the Park, has grown considerably more sophisticated as the seasons go by - this is the 30th - but the trees, night sky and easy ambience all add immeasurably to the inventive productions. ''Measure for Measure,'' Shakespeare's dark comedy about love, lust and loyalty, is the current offering at the free Central Park series. Directed by Joseph Papp, head of the New York Shakespeare Festival, this staging is set in Vienna in 1910. Now in preview, it opens officially Sunday and runs through July 21.

title: Gas Explodes in Ruhr Mine
description: A methane gas explosion in a Ruhr Valley coal mine early today injured five miners, hours after a similar accident in the same mine Wednesday killed a miner and hurt 55, the authorities said. Two of the five injured today were hospitalized for burns, according to a spokesman for the mine owner, Ruhrkohle.

title: Swing Your Partner
description: In Congress, incrementalism is the antidote for overreaching. In 1981, although it may have escaped your attention, the lawmakers voted to designate the square dance as the official national folk dance for 1982 and 1983.

title: Bank of New York
description: The Bank of New York Company is offering $150 million of 8 1/4 percent subordinated convertible debentures due 2010 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: 4 Die in Swiss Copter Crash
description: A Swiss helicopter crashed today, apparently after hitting a power line, and the pilot and all three passengers were killed, the Transport Ministry announced. The accident, involving a helicopter operated by Executive Helicopter Services in Geneva, occurred on the edge of the village of Flonnay in southwestern Switzerland.

title: CUBS CAPTURE A HOME RUN DERBY
description: The Chicago Cubs, relishing life on the sunny side of a 13-game losing streak, made it two straight over the Mets today when Rick Sutcliffe outpitched Ron Darling and won, 4-2.

title: BOMED MEDICAL MANUFACTURING INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: DEFENSE RESTS ON 40'S INTERNMENT
description: The Government rested its case today in fighting Gordon Hirabayashi's effort to undo his 1942 conviction for defying the military law that forced 120,000 Japanese-Americans into internment camps.

title: Warriors Match Offer
description: Joe Barry Carroll is not yet through with the Golden State Warriors - or, rather, the Warriors are not yet through with him. General Manager Al Attles said the team would be willing to match an offer from the Milwaukee Bucks calling for the 7-foot center to receive a reported $7.5 million over five years, along with a $2 million signing bonus.

title: COUNTS ON AID TO ALIENS STAND
description: A Federal district judge has refused to dismiss charges against church workers indicted for aiding Central American refugees. The defendants, in seeking the dismissal, contended that the Government had acted ''outrageously'' by infiltrating churches.

title: FRENCH AND SWISS WILLING TO ACCEPT FREED HOSTAGES, BUT NOT HOLD THEM
description: France and Switzerland said in separate announcements today that they were willing to take the 39 American hostages into their Beirut embassies, but were not willing to act, in effect, as jailers.

title: BERRI VOICES OPTIMISM ABOUT HOSTAGES
description: The Shiite militia leader, Nabih Berri, told reporters today that he was ''more optimistic'' than ever that the two-week old hostage crisis could be ended soon ''with American help.''

title: S.A.S. Will End Flights to Johannesburg
description: Sweden, Norway and Denmark agreed today to end all Scandinavian Airlines System flights to Johannesburg to protest South Africa's apartheid policies.

title: Jazz at the Vanguard
description: The saxophonists Frank Foster and Frank Wess will lead a quintet tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is an $10 cover Friday and Saturday, an $8.50 cover Sunday and a one-drink minimum.

title: U.S. Says Uranium Poses Little Risk at Oak Ridge
description: The 51 million pounds of uranium buried or released into the air from a Government weapons plant here over almost three decades poses a minimal health risk, according to a Department of Energy report.

title: FLOW SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings figures reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective March 22.

title: LACK OF SECURITY IN COMPUTERS SEEN
description: Three senior Defense Department officials warned Congress today that the failure of Government agencies and private institutions to protect their computerized communication networks represented a grave threat to the United States.

title: FREED CAPTIVE SEES EARLY RELEASE FOR OTHERS
description: James Dell Palmer, the tired but happy 48-year-old American hostage who was freed Wednesday in Beirut because of a heart condition, was reunited with his wife, Sammie, here this morning and told reporters that he expected the other 39 hostages from the Trans World Airlines jet to be freed soon by their Shiite captors.

title: Payment Ordered to Man Over Fear of Blacks
description: A judge has ordered disability payments to begin to a former city sanitation supervisor who won a worker's compensation ruling based on his fear of working with black people.

title: BIJAN ON BIJAN: SAVVY RETAILER TO THE RICH
description: It was a typical afternoon at Bijan.

title: ISRAEL AWAITS U.S. SIGN ON EUROPEAN INITIATIVES
description: Israeli officials said tonight that they were waiting for a clear signal from Washington before they reacted formally to any French, Swiss or other initiatives for resolving the 14-day-old Beirut hostage crisis.

title: SAND TECHNOLOGY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: William J. Driver Dies; Headed V.A. in 1960's
description: William J. Driver, a former head of the Veterans Administration and of the Social Security Administration, has died of kidney failure. He was 67 years old.

title: TRADE OFFICIAL NAMED TO HEAD LEGAL SERVICES
description: The board of the Federal Legal Services Corporation named James H. Wentzel, an official of the Federal Trade Commission, as its new president today. The corporation provides legal services to the poor.

title: BENNY GOODMAN JOINS JOHN HAMMOND TRIBUTE
description: An unannounced appearance by Benny Goodman brought a nostalgic review of the career of John Hammond, the 74-year-old record producer, to a dramatic high point at Avery Fisher Hall Tuesday night. But nostalgia was only part of the Kool Jazz Festival's ''Tribute to John Hammond,'' who was described by the trumpeter Buck Clayton as ''the world's greatest talent scout.'' Mr. Hammond's search for talent encompassed such a wide range of jazz and pop style that the tribute attracted what amounted to two separate audiences.

title: BASSETT FURNITURE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ASSESSING HOW GIFTS TO CHARITY ARE USED
description: People need help, please give. The message is simple. But potential donors are faced with complicated questions when they try to choose a charity from the thousands that exist.

title: FINAL CHAPTER IS WRITTEN FOR ROUTE 66
description: Route 66, the 2,200-mile highway immortalized in song, novel and television, is officially history, having fallen victim to the nation's Interstate Highway System.

title: Ignorance No Bliss
description: To the Editor:

title: THIS SISYPHUS ROLLLS A WOODEN STOVE
description: Officials of the Environmental Protection Agency often feel as if they are trying to run across an ocean of thick molasses.

title: IT'S MACHINE GUN TIME
description: I think it's time I got myself a machine gun. For years, I've been missing out on all the trends - you know, waiting for V.C.R.'s to get better and cheaper, waiting for the new, improved Nike sneaker, waiting for co-op prices to come down. This time, I'm determined not to be left behind.

title: AN ISRAELI PRESENCE AT U.N.
description: Things Israeli may not be the most popular items at the United Nations, but nobody seems to have told the staff of the Delegates' Dining Room.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report Wednesday in the Briefing column on the Washington Talk page about the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation incorrectly described plans for the Ronald Reagan Library and its Center for Public Affairs. Only the library is to be established at Stanford's Hoover Institution for War, Revolution and Peace.

title:
YOUR MONEY;

WHERE TO FIND HIGHER YEILDS
description: THE sharp decline in interest rates during the last year, particularly in the past two months, has led many savers and investors in bank money market deposit accounts and money market mutual funds to seek different outlets for their money.

title: DATA ARCHITECTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After tax credits of $83,000 for the quarter and $191,000 for the six months.

title: PRICES PAID TO FARMERS HOLD STEADY
description: After dropping for three consecutive months, the prices farmers get for raw products held steady in June, remaining at their lowest average level in more than two years, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: TRADE GAP SWELLS TO $12.7 BILLION
description: The nation's trade deficit swelled to $12.7 billion in May, the second-highest total on record, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: CBS FILES 2D PETITION ON TURNER
description: CBS Inc., in an extensively detailed presentation to the Federal Communications Commission yesterday, again charged that a proposed $5.4 billion takeover by Ted Turner, the Atlanta broadcast entrepreneur, would financially cripple a combined company, throwing the future of CBS into jeopardy.

title: Lindsay
description: It has been 20 years since he was a Congressman, but John V. Lindsay, as treasurer of the Association of Former Members of Congress, still visits the capital regularly.

title: Afghan General Is Killed
description: A top-ranking Afghan Army general has been killed by anti-Communist guerrillas, the official Kabul radio reported today. It said a General Ahmeduddin had been killed in a ''frontal clash with the bandits,'' referring to Moslem rebels fighting the Soviet-installed regime.

title:
PATENTS;

ROOT CANAL IMPLANT
description: A root canal implant and a method of its insertion in a tooth were patented this week by Dr. Richard J. Pitz of New York and Ezekiel J. Jacob, operator of a Brooklyn laboratory that makes medical plastics.

title: Homeowner's Policy Pays Herpes Victim
description: A woman who said that her lover was negligent by transmitting genital herpes to her has received a $25,000 out-of-court settlement under his homeowner's insurance policy.

title: REYNOLDS DEFEAT WILL NOT CHANGE CIVIL RIGHTS POLICIES, OFFICIALS SAY
description: Justice Department officials reiterated today that the Senate Judiciary Committee's rejection of the nomination of William Bradford Reynolds to be Associate Attorney General would not alter the Administration's civil rights policies.

title: SMITH'S PARTY RUNS STRONGLY IN ZIMBABWE ELECTION
description: The political party of Ian D. Smith, a former Prime Minister, won a majority of white parliamentary seats in this black-ruled country, according to returns today from Zimbabwe's first general elections since independence in 1980.

title: CAROLINA FREIGHT CARRIERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 15
COURT BARS $325,000 AWARD TO CHRISTINE CRAFT
description: A Federal appeals court today overruled a $325,000 jury award to Christine Craft, the former television anchor newscaster who waged two court battles against the station she contended had demoted her because of her appearance.

title: Solidarity Says 50,000 Will Strike in Warsaw
description: Leaders of the outlawed Solidarity union said today that about 50,000 workers at three major Warsaw factories would strike Monday to protest Government plans to increase meat prices by 15 percent.

title: COMBINED BHOPAL SUIT IS FILED
description: American attorneys filed a joint suit yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan against the Union Carbide Corporation asking for damages on behalf of all victims of the gas leak tragedy in Bhopal, India, but the Indian Government declined to join the action.

title: TELECREDIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
COMING UP SHORT
description: Dan Galbreath may or may not finally get the Pirates sold to someone who will keep them in Pittsburgh. If he does, he'll have to do a better job, or have better luck, than all the players who have been trying to sell themselves as the team's regular shortstop.

title: BROWN & ROOT
description: The Halliburton Company said today that its subsidiary, Brown & Root Inc., was studying whether to take a ''significant'' write-down on certain investments and marine vessels because of the extended depressed conditions in the marine construction industry.

title: ECLIPSE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-No year-ago results were reported because the company went public Feb. 2, 1984.

title: PRIEST WILLA CATHER ASSAILED FINDS A DEFENDER
description: E.A. Mares clasped his hands against his cassocked knees and bowed his head until his black hair fell before his eyes. After a moment, he stood and spoke, not as the director of education of the Albuquerque Museum, which he is, but as the voice of the long-dead Padre Antonio Jose Martinez de Taos, Mr. Mares's great-great-uncle, who was, to hear him tell it, a man much maligned in the history of New Mexico.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * CBS Inc. said it had acquired an interest in Winterland Producions, a closely held San Francisco-based corporation engaged in designing, printing and marketing merchandise for the music and entertainment industries.

title: PERFECT FIT MERGER
description: Perfect Fit Inc., a furniture company, said it had entered into a definitive merger agreement providing for its acquisition by Home Furnishings Enterprises Inc., a new corporation, for about $33.6 million. The new company is owned by Joseph Vitale, president and chief executive of Perfect Fit, certain other members of Perfect Fit's management and other investors.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Magnificent! The most beautiful cars I've ever seen. How much do they cost, three or four thousand yuan?'' - Huang Liang, in Peking, estimating the cost of a $39,000 Cadillac limousine at about $1,600. [1:6.]

title: GOLF CHAMPIONS IN THE MIDDLE
description: In the last two weeks, golf at its best and golf at its worst have each produced a champion: Andy North, who prevailed among the elite when he won the United States Open at Oakland Hills, and Angelo Spagnolo of suburban Pittsburgh, who carded a 257 for 18 holes at the Tournament Players Club in Ponte Vedra, Fla., and thereby achieved some small measure of fame as the winner (loser) of the Worst Avid Golfer tournament.

title: IN OZONE PARK, A BAROMETER OF PATRIOTISM
description: Motorists passing by George Kanakaris's house in Ozone Park, Queens, are always shouting patriotic slogans - not so much on the order of ''Give me liberty or give me death!'' but rather the articulations of this day and age: ''U.S.A.! U.S.A.!'' and ''Nuke the hijackers!''

title: MURALITS WANTED
description: The Parks and Recreation Department hopes that there are more than 14 young muralists to be found in this city.

title: ISSUES IN HOSITAL STRIKE PERSIST 10 MONTHS LATER
description: Last August, a tentative agreement ended New York City's longest and largest health-care strike. Ten months later, the tentative accord remains just that - tentative - and the remaining issues upon which a formal, two-year contract hinge are still unresolved.

title: SECURITY FOR ATHENS AIRPORT NOW ADEQUATE, EXPERTS SAY
description: Security at the Athens airport, where two hijackers boarded a Trans World Airlines jetliner and forced it to fly to Beirut two weeks ago, has been improved and now meets international standards, a team of security experts announced today.

title:
PATENTS;

AN I.B.M. INVENTION ADVANCES CHIP MEMORY
description: One of a dozen patents related to computer operations issued this week to the International Business Machines Corporation covers a memory with a double use.

title: PHOTOGRAPHER VANISHES IN BEIRUT
description: A freelance photographer disappeared in predominantly Moslem West Beirut on Thursday and was feared kidnapped, friends and colleagues said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend Friday on the musician Alceu Valenca contained an incorrect reference to Luis Gonzaga, who was important in the development of Mr. Valenca's style. Mr. Gonzaga is alive.

title: TOUR DE FRANCE IS UNDER WAY
description: Sixty thousand Bretons turned out here today to cheer Bernard Hinault, the region's favorite son each summer, and he did his best not to disappoint a single one of them.

title: FAILED CHINATOWN BANK REOPENS TO SKEPTICISM
description: Hundreds of people lined up outside the main Canal Street offices of the failed Golden Pacific National Bank yesterday to withdraw their money, even though the Chinatown bank had just been taken over by one of the largest banks in Asia and all deposits were insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: CHILE REACHES DEBT ACCORD
description: Chile and a committee of its creditor banks agreed yesterday on a financial package to reschedule almost $6 billion in loans maturing over the next three years. The accord will give Chile, a major debtor that has been hit hard by lower world prices of copper, its principal export, more time to pay off its obligations.

title: HOSTAGES IN LEBANON: Avoiding 'Direct Linkage';   HOSTAGES EXPECTED TO GO FREE AFTER MOVING TO SYRIA TODAY, HIGH REAGAN OFFICIAL REPORTS
description: A senior Reagan Administration official said tonight that the 39 American hostages from a hijacked airliner were expected to be freed on Saturday after being taken from Beirut to Damascus.

title: RENAULT SEEN SET FOR A.M.C. LOAN
description: France's state-owned auto producer, Renault, is planning to lend $175 million to its 46 percent owned American company, the American Motors Corporation, a union official said in Paris yesterday.

title: WRITER WAS WORLD BANK AIDE
description: William Donaldson Clark, a writer, diplomat, and former vice president of the World Bank, died Thursday night of liver cancer at his home in the Oxfordshire village of Cuxham. He was 68 years old.

title:
PATENTS;

ARTIFICIAL-HEART PUMP
description: A pump intended for an artificial heart was patented this week for the Southwest Research Institute in San Antonio.

title:
PATENTS;

A WEIGHT-LOSS METHOD FOR PARTS OF THE BODY
description: A method of losing weight in a selected part of the body has been invented by two Californians.

title: Bath Iron Works Shut Down In Face of Impending Strike
description: Managers of the Bath Iron Works, faced with a ''sick-out'' on the verge of an impending weekend strike, today ordered all 6,900 workers sent home, the gates locked and construction halted.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 15. 1. This is a way of making evidence disappear. What is happening? 2. The bomb that exploded inside baggage removed from a Canadian Pacific airplane at Narita Airport in Tokyo may have been intended to detonate aboard another flight, according to Japanese police investigators. What flight was it and what was the basis of that speculation? 3. The Long Island Lighting Company was penalized $1.35 billion for mismanaging the construction of its Shoreham nuclear power station. Most of that penalty will be have to be absorbed by the company's (customers/stockholders/customers and stockholders). 4. Its value is $8.37, according to chemists; $650,083, according to the Federal Aviation Administration; and up to $7 million, according to the Environmental Protection Administration. What is it? 5. In separate rulings about the rights of workers, the Supreme Court said that employees (have/do not have) an unqualified right to refuse to work on their chosen Sabbath, and that workers who resign from labor unions in a strike (may be penalized/ may not be penalized) by their unions for doing so. 6. The number of American hostages in Lebanon whose release the United States demanded changed twice, first decreasing and then increasing. What number was demanded in each case and what were the circumstances? 7. The International Business Machines Corporation made a bold move that, according to analysts, will accelerate its efforts to establish a communications network that is to link computers around the world.

title: OFFICIAL STATE PATRIOT IS VOTED BY ASSEMBLY
description: First, the ladybug. Now Uncle Sam.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;

CAPTER 11 FILING BY AVANTI MOTOR
description: The Avanti Motor Corporation, the smallest of the nation's car production companies, has sought court protection from creditors and will move to Detroit, the owner said. The company listed assets of $4.7 million and liabilities of $6.7 million as it filed Thursday under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy law.

title: DOW INCREASES 3.25 TO END AT 1,335.46
description: Stock prices on Wall Street pushed further into record territory yesterday, but most investors reacted cautiously to mixed economic signs reported before the start of trading by the Government.

title: Agencies Can Drown in 'Due Process'
description: Does it make sense that the administrator of a public housing project must wait a year before he can evict tenants whose antisocial conduct have forced good tenants to move? Does it make sense that a school principal must hold an elaborately formal hearing - with witnesses and lawyers - to suspend a student who struck a teacher? Does it make sense that juvenile courts must conduct formal adversarial criminal trials, with endless delays and procedural complications, before they can deal with the social problems of youths accused of minor offenses?

title: INDUSTRIAL ELECTRONIC HARDWARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-After tax credits of $64,656. c-Net income, which includes a tax credit of $408,000.

title: SUMMER EASE IS A JUMPSUIT
description: The jumpsuit, like culottes, slides in and out of fashion with regularity. This summer is one of its ''in'' periods. The one-piece outfit enables a woman to get dressed in an instant, with a minimum of undergarments.

title: Article 086511 -- No Title
description: The Supreme Court today upheld a law from the Civil War era that prohibits veterans from paying lawyers more than $10 for representing them in disputes over veterans' benefits.

title: MDS HEALTH GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
U.S. DELAYED WARNING ON WATER IN FEDERAL PLAZA
description: Federal officials learned that the 10,000 employees at a Government office building in lower Manhattan were drinking potentially unsafe water at least one month before informing anyone, Federal documents show.

title:
PATENTS;

A DEVICE TO INHIBIT SELF-INJURY
description: STAFF members at the Applied Physics Laboratory of Johns Hopkins University in Laurel, Md., have invented an apparatus to inhibit self-injury by autistic children or others who repeatedly injure themselves by beating their heads or other behavior.

title: Books of The Times;   Bombs and Banality
description: A PARISH OF RICH WOMEN. By James Buchan. 185 pages. Atheneum. $12.95.

title: PROFESSOR LAUDS SIX FLAGS POLICY AS 'EXEMPLARY'
description: A professor of management testified today that the decision-making process on safety questions at the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park, where eight teen-age patrons died in a fire last year, was ''exemplary.''

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: An agreement is close to being signed for an Aug. 28 bout between Eddie Gregg and Gerry Cooney for Gregg's New York state heavyweight title, according to Michael Rakosi, the manager of Gregg. The probable site is Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I. In Gregg's last bout, he became the first fighter to knock down Randy Cobb.

title: FREED HOSTAGE ARRIVES IN ARKANSAS
description: Released after 12 days of captivity at the hands of the Shiite Moslems, 48-year-old James Dell Palmer arrived here tonight to a hero's welcome, but declared that Saudi Arabia was now his home and that he intended to return there.

title: JAYS SHUT OUT TIGERS, WIDEN LEAD TO 3 1/2
description: George Bell hit a two-run homer, and Dave Stieb throttled Detroit on three hits tonight as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Tigers, 2-0, in the first game of their weekend showdown series.

title: 6 in Alleged Smut Ring Face U.S. Tax Charges
description: A Cleveland business executive the Government says is the largest pornography dealer in the country was accused with five others today of an elaborate conspiracy to avoid millions of dollars in taxes.

title: TEACHER GROUP TO OPEN DRIVE ON THE DROPOUT
description: Teachers will design and help pay for programs to try to keep students from dropping out of school, the president of the National Education Association said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photo caption yesterday accompanying an article on gun shows misidentified the size of the bore of a machine gun displayed for sale. It was 7.62mm.

title: Man Accused of War Crimes Is Scheduled to Have Bail Set
description: A Federal magistrate said today that he intended to set bail for Andrija Artukovic, accused of overseeing the deaths of 700,000 people as a Nazi collaborator, because the ailing man's imprisonment was cruel and unusual punishment.

title: INDEX THAT SHOWS ECONOMIC TRENDS ADVANCES SHARPLY
description: The Government's index of leading economic indicators, which usually signals changes in the course of the economy, turned sharply upward last month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: METS REGAIN STRAWBERRY BUT NOT WINNING TOUCH
description: Darryl Strawberry played in a baseball game tonight for the first time in seven weeks. But he went 0 for 3 as the Mets lost to the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-2, for their third straight defeat and the fifth in their last six games.

title: POWER PLANT FOR TEXAS
description: A subsidiary of Internorth Inc. will build a new power plant in Texas City to provide electricity to customers of the Texas Utilities Electric Company of Dallas, Internorth announced today.

title: 3 TIED AT MEMPHIS
description: George Burns overcame a double bogey on his 17th hole today to claim a share of the lead with Bill Sander and David Ogrin after two rounds of the $500,000 St. Jude Memphis Classic tournament.

title: CHRYSLER IN A PACT FOR HUTTON CREDIT
description: The Chrysler Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the E. F. Hutton Credit Corporation, the brokerage firm's commercial lending and leasing operation, for $125 million.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture accompanying an item about the Tour de France in the Friday Sports column yesterday, was mistakenly placed over a caption describing Greg Lemond as being among the favorites to win the bicycle race. The picture showed Bernard Hinault, another racer.

title: IT MAY BE UNFAIR TO ONESELF TO DON SACKCLOTH AND ASHES
description: If an expert grinds his teeth as he goes home after a rubber bridge game and then finds sleep elusive, it is unlikely to be because the gods of the game gave him bad cards. His impulse to hit his head against the wall or don sackcloth and ashes is far more likely to be because he has made a slight misjudgment that has proved fatal.

title: Fireworks Factory Blast Is Called Accidental
description: The fireworks factory explosion that killed 21 people was an accident, Federal and state officials said today, adding that there was no evidence of criminal negligence.

title: EX-IDE CIRITCIZES STATUE RESTORATION
description: A former Federal official charged Thursday that the Statue of Liberty restoration project was in ''a total state of chaos'' and that the overseeing foundation had failed to submit appropriate records for review.

title: What Can Be Done About Teen-Age Pregnancy
description: To the Editor:

title: DINING AND SMOKING: A QUANDRY
description: ''If the lawmakers want no smoking in restaurants, O.K.,'' said Andre Soltner, chef-owner of Lutece. ''They should say no smoking at all and we would have no problem. But not just part no smoking. It makes it impossible.''

title: Reagan
description: President Reagan continues to tell jokes to illustrate his points. The other day he said, ''Of course, Communist countries have trouble producing even enough food for their own populations.''

title: MEASURE GIVING STATE U. FISCAL AUTOMONY PASSES
description: A measure to give the State and City Universities of New York greater control of their own financial matters was given final approval by the Assembly early this morning.

title: TORRES IS GUILTY IN THE SLAYING OF ACTRESS, 23
description: A State Supreme Court jury yesterday convicted Emmanuel Torres of stabbing a 23-year-old drama student to death on the roof of her Upper West Side apartment house last Dec. 2.

title: BID FOR CLEVEPAK
description: The Clevepak Corporation, a manufacturer of building products and specialty packaging, said its board had received preliminary proposals for acquisition of the company.

title: WALL STREET STRIKERS MARCH
description: Striking employees of the Depository Trust Company marched through the financial district of Manhattan yesterday in support of their demands, but no new negotiations are scheduled.

title: The Demands of Executive Order 50
description: To the Editor:

title: MAJOR SHIFTS AT INTERGROUP
description: National Intergroup Inc. has made major personnel changes in its aluminum subsidiary following an investigation into unauthorized metals contracts that scuttled a merger with the Bergen Brunswig Corporation.

title: EUROPE LEADERS CONFER ON AIR TERROR
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain urged other European leaders today to strengthen and enforce existing international agreements against aircraft hijacking and terrorism, officials said.

title: FINAL DAYS IN ALBANY ALTER LIFE AT THE TOP
description: Until he abandons his banker's-blue pin-stripe suit for a gaudy sports jacket - his signal that a legislative session is ending - Warren M. Anderson has all but vanished from the Senate chamber, where he usually sits on the right aisle, in the majority leader's chair.

title: PANEL HEARS TUNEFUL PROTEST OF LIMITS ON MUSIC IN CLUBS
description: The walls and ceilings of City Hall vibrated yesterday to the sound not of gavels or partisan debate, but of a brief jam session by a seven-piece band.

title: IT'S THE PLAYERS MOVE
