Miller, said he had been trying to infiltrate the K.G.B. And Nikolay Ogorodnikov insisted that he hadn't known what his wife and Mr. Miller were up to.

title: ROBBINS' NEW BALLET MAY MEAN MANY THINGS
description: Balletgoers seem agreed that ''In Memory of. . .,''

title: NEW CRISIS FOR YOUNG: BEING ALONE
description: JOAN is 16 year old who is depressed, withdrawn and doing poorly in school. Her parents are divorced and her mother has remarried. Rejected by her real father, an alcoholic, she also has to deal with her stepfather and paternal grandmother, who were also problem drinkers. Her stepfather abuses her mother, who is severely disturbed about her current marriage. Joan came to the North Shore Child Guidence and Family Association in Roslyn for help.

title: ON L.I., GO SLOWLY BUT DON'T STOP
description: Restraint is the order of the day in Point Lookout, L.I., a seaside hamlet in western Nassau County where the speed limit is 15 miles an hour, the lowest in New York State.

title: Laura Jean Weiser Planning Marriage To William Lie Zeckendorf in August
description: Dr. and Mrs. Frank Weiser of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Jean Weiser to William Lie Zeckendorf, a son of William Zeckendorf of New York and Chappaqua, N.Y., and Gurie Lie Zeckendorf of New York. The wedding is planned for August.

title: COLUMBINES ARE EASY TO GROW FROM SEED
description: Propagating columbine (Aquilegia) from seed is easy and provides some of the loveliest and rarest varieties of the species. Many of these unusual flowers are not obtainable in nurseries and are only rarely found in catalogues.

title: TEHERAN LEADER ASSAILS HIJACKING
description: The Speaker of the Iranian Parliament today condemned the hijacking of the Trans World Airlines plane by Shiite Moslem gunmen and said Iran was ''totally opposed'' to actions that made hostages of innocent people.

title: QUERULOUS QUESTIONS, AND A FEW ANSWERS
description: Criticism is by nature a monologistic occupation: One speaks to an unseen readership. At season's end, in quest of feedback, I imagined an interviewer appearing with queries on the quirks and quiddities of the theater. Q: Can you spot any trends? A: Fewer animals are working in the theater. Except for D'Artagnan's horse in the musical, ''The Three Musketeers,'' there were no animals, to my knowledge, on Broadway last season. There is, however, an offstage pig in ''Big River,'' and there is a song in his honor. Off Broadway a lamb plays an important role in Sam Shepard's ''Curse of the Starving Class.'' It baas on cue - its and others. The lamb is a ham.

title: Nicaragua Paying Somoza's U.S. Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: Clash in Palm Beach: Newspaper Box Hues
description: The clashing colors on coin-operated newspaper boxes in Palm Beach have been deemed an eyesore by City Council members. They want all the boxes painted pink.

title: FROM ARF TO ZAP
description: MY DOG SAYS ERR-ruff; Little Orphan Annie's dog says arf, and dogs in general say bow wow. They do, that is, if they are American dogs. In Italy, dogs are apt to say bow bow; in Israel, how how; in Japan, wan wan.

title: DELAY IN HOSTAGES' RELEASE SURPRISES SYRIANS
description: The delay in a plan today to transport the American airline hostages to this capital - and freedom - appeared to take Syrian officials by surprise.

title: SABBATH RULES
description: State laws that give employees an unqualified right not to work on their Sabbath are unconstitutional, the Court decided last week.

title: Leslie Woodland Weds Richard Norton Smith
description: St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Portsmouth, R.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Leslie Denise Woodland and Richard Norton Smith. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Gordon J. Stenning, assisted by the Rev. Timothy Collins, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: SIDESWIPES ON A TWO-WAY STREET
description: DETENTE AND CONFRONTATION American-Soviet Relations From Nixon to Reagan. By Raymond L. Garthoff. 1,147 pp. Washington: The Brookings Institution. Cloth, $39.95. Paper, $16.95. DURING the 1970's, after more than two decades of on-again, off-again cold war, the United States and the Soviet Union entered what both sides heralded as a new era of detente. Yet detente dissolved almost as quickly as it took shape: each side blamed the other and the Americans argued among themselves about whether it had failed or never really been tried.

title: LEGISLATORS APPROVE JERSEY HOUSING PLAN OFFERED BY GOVERNOR
description: A plan by Governor Kean to help New Jersey communities implement the State Supreme Court's Mount Laurel II ruling on affordable housing has gained final legislative approval and awaits the Governor's signature.

title: Ellen Rudd Has Wedding
description: Ellen Gentry Rudd, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Rudd of New York, East Hampton, L.I., and Chicago, was married yesterday to David Pershing Herrick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry K. Herrick of Dedham and Orleans, Mass. The Rev. Frederick Schulz performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in East Hampton.

title:
ART;

ALTERING IMAGES IN COLLAGE
description: ONE of the byproducts of frequent gallery visiting is an interest in following the changing developments in an individual artist's career. Currently a number of presentations in the area either raise isssues of change or direct attention to valid experiments using an expanded repertory of materials. Occasionally a show does both, as in the case of Ruth Eckstein's exhibition of photo collages sponsored by the Hempstead Harbor Artists Association in its l2 Village Square Gallery in Glen Cove.

title: STOP THE ROCKETS' RED GLARE
description: I HATE the Fourth of July. Oh, don't get me wrong, I'm as patriotic as the next person. It's the firecrackers and ubiquitous fireworks that I can't stand. I have never understood the pleasure that one can derive from hearing a loud explosion and seeing a large, acrid puff of smoke, and then going back and doing this all over again.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS'S ACE IN THE HOLE
description: LONG Island born and Harvard bred, the new president of the American Express Company, Louis V. Gerstner Jr., bears scant resemblance to the man he replaces, Sanford I. Weill, the Brooklyn deal maker who became a sultan of Wall Street. Where the flamboyant Mr. Weill basks in the glow of media attention, Mr. Gerstner shies from the limelight. But, in his quiet way, Mr. Gerstner has during the past decade masterminded American Express's domination in credit cards, the cornerstone of this $13 billion financial services empire.

title: CHANGES OF IDENTITY OFFERED IN NORWALK
description: THE telephone rang one recent morning at Altered Egos, a Norwalk costume business, and a southern Connecticut corporation placed an order for three gorilla costumes for an upcoming sales promotion. Moments later, four tacky blue jackets and the same number of Michael Jackson wigs were requested by another corporate customer. The door soon opened and an employee of a local balloon-delivery company, dressed as a furry duck, walked in and asked for his pink tights and red heavy-duty gloves. Not far behind was an actor from the Darien Dinner Theater, who needed goatee glue.

title: Anne Armstrong Wed To John Peter Powers
description: Anne Madeleine Miriam Armstrong, a daughter of Mrs. William Henry Armstrong and the late Mr. Armstrong of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to John Peter Powers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Powers of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. William Sexton of the United Church of Christ Congregational in Stamford, Conn., performed the ceremony at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, assisted by the Rev. Peter Loughran, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: BEATRICE RACING TEAM STARTS AT THE TOP
description: The best team money can buy had its car towed off the track this morning, but this afternoon it captured the pode position for Sunday's $640,000 U.S. Grand Prix at the Meadowlands for Indianapolis-type cars.

title: FICTION THAT SHRINKS FROM LIFE
description: TWO years ago I was working in a small town in central Pennsylvania and on certain tired afternoons I would go to a local shopping center and take a bench at the place where two malls crossed. I was there following an urge to understand our new America; surely, I told myself, this was a central point of our common lives.

title: Steven M. Lesser Wed To Pamela J. Sherman
description: Pamela J. Sherman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael S. Sherman of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Steven M. Lesser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry E. Lesser of Randolph, Mass. Rabbi Alex J. Goldman and Cantor Sidney Rabinowitz officiated at Temple Beth El.

title: Meredith C. Davis, Editor and Writer, To Marry Stratford Pressley Sherman
description: The engagement of Meredith Chandler Davis, a freelance editor and writer, to Stratford Pressley Sherman, an associate editor of Fortune magazine, has been announced by the future bride's mother, Marguerite Atkinson Davis of Darien, Conn., and Bal Harbour, Fla. A September wedding is planned.

title: Hurdle Is Cleared
description: For Renaldo Nehemiah and other professional football players, only one minor hurdle remains for them to regain their amateur status in track and field competition. Yesterday, Nehemiah's agent, Ron Stanko, was declaring the event already won, saying: ''I was there. I have the decision.

title: JAZZ: BUCKWHEAT, CAJUN BAND
description: THE Buckwheat Ils Sont Partis Zydeco Band from Mamou, La., which had listeners dancing Thursday night at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street, represents the younger generation of black Cajun music.

title: THE DIET SECRETS OF RUSTY STAUB
description: FEW would argue that the most discerning eater, the most passionate eater, if not one of the most prodigious eaters in all of baseball is Rusty Staub of the Mets.

title: No Sale
description: To the Editor:

title: SIR ROLAND HANNA AT CARNEGIE RECITAL HALL
description: FOR the pianist Sir Roland Hanna, the entire world of jazz is his oyster. He is as much at home in turn-of-the-century ragtime as he is in the works of John Coltrane.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE AMERICAN ATOM: A Documentary History of Nuclear Policies From the Discovery of Fission to the Present, 1939-1984. Edited by Robert C. Williams and Philip L. Cantelon.

title: SPANISH LITERATURE
description: To the Editor:

title: STOCKHOLM
description: Stockholm is ''a city that floats on water,'' a Swedish writer once observed, and ideally one should approach this 700-year-old capital by sea. Situated on 14 islands where Lake Malaren connects to the Baltic, the city seems to shimmer against the sky.

title: Dance
description: If the pickings seem to be pretty slim in New York, dance is popping up everywhere else this week. On Friday, the Paul Taylor Dance Company opens the dance component of the Pepsico Summerfare festival, which runs through July 28 on the campus of the State University of New York at Purchase.

title: HERSHEL WALKER, MAYBE, LIVES UP TO THE LEGEND
description: IT wasn't until the midway mark of the current United States Football League season that New Jersey Generals fans conceded that maybe - just maybe -Herschel Walker might be all right after all.

title: LEGAL AID SHIFTING EMPHASIS
description: TIMES have changed in the legal-services offices in the state. Some use the words ''more professional.'' Others speak of a lost ''sense of mission.''

title: DESIGNED TO BLEND
description: Two 100-year-old rowhouses at 52 and 54 East 72d Street in the East Side Historic District of Manhattan are being demolished to make room for an 18-story condominium apartment building that has the required blessings of the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: BIRTHDAY PARTY Getting the jump on upcoming holiday festivities, the Huntington Historical Society celebrates America's 209th birthday today in an appropriate setting: the David Conklin Farmhouse. Dating to 1750, the homestead, now maintained as a museum, was home to the Huntington family until 1911 and, thus, is furnished in Colonial, Federal and Victorian styles. The birthday party, from 1 to 4 P.M., includes old-fashioned ice-cream cranking, appropriate games and crafts, and the appearance of a ''colonial soldier.'' The farmhouse is at 2 High Street and admission is $1, or 50 cents for children.

title: THE YOUTH OF THE FATHER OF HIS COUNTRY
description: CHAIM WEIZMANN The Making of a Zionist Leader. By Jehuda Reinharz. Illustrated. 566 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $29.95.

title: HOME VIDEO
description: The Lady From Shanghai Starring Rita Hayworth, Orson Welles, Everett Sloane, Glenn Anders; directed by Mr. Welles, 1948 RCA/Columbia Home Video 87 minutes. $59.95 With a bit of a brogue and a touch of the poet, Orson Welles is the seafaring would-be novelist thrown figuratively into a pool of sharks in this hard-to-believe but captivating contrivance.

title: 'THE WORD HANGS BACK'
description: AN UMBRELLA FROM PICCADILLY By Jaroslav Seifert. Translated by Ewald Osers. 80 pp. London: London Magazine Editions. Distributed by Parsons Books, 38 Hill Point, San Francisco, Calif. 94117. Cloth, $12.50. Paper, $6.95. THE Nobel Prize for Literature comes in several varieties. There is the prize that confirms universal recognition, the prize that plays politics, the prize that celebrates the visionary orientation Alfred Nobel originally meant to promote. And from time to time the Swedish Academy awards a prize that seems calculated to redress an oversight; it virtually introduces an author to the world.

title: Miss Souther Is Bride Of William M. Murphy
description: The marriage of Sharon Anne Souther and William Michael Murphy, who graduated in 1981 from the Fordham University School of Law and are associates in the New York law firm of Cahill Gordon & Reindel, took place yesterday at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. Robert S. Hewes, assisted by Msgr. William T. White, performed the ceremony.

title: CONNORS, MAYOTTE GAIN
description: Every toss of the ball was an adventure, every swing of the racquet like an arrow shot in the air. Ivan Lendl had no idea where his serve was landing today, and it created the kind of suspense that captivated an audience but only fueled the talk that Lendl's game is suspect in grand-slam events.

title: WHO'S IN CHARGE OF CORPORATE GIVING?
description: EIGHTEEN months ago, to test a plan for starting a consulting firm devoted to the management of corporate philanthropy, I began to interview chief executive officers of major corporations, many of whom I knew personally. In the process I developed an unusually candid portrait of corporate giving as seen by the men who run 30 of the nation's largest companies.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: LOBBYISTS continue to increase their spending to influence legislation, according to a report by the stat's Election Law Enforcement Commission, which said that 310 groups shared this activity last year.

title: Turmoil in Palau
description: Political and economic problems have troubled Palau for several years.

title: A NEWCOMER IN BRIDGEPORT
description: BRIDGEPORT has been surprisingly short of culinary attractions in recent years.

title: KIND WORDS FOR CITY SERVICES
description: A private, nonpartisan civic group last week praised the Koch administration for improving municipal services in many categories, then added in a footnote that the job was far from done.

title: MALPRACTICE BILL IS APPROVED IN ALBANY
description: A medical-malpractice insurance package was pushed through both houses of the Legislature tonight as lawmakers moved toward summer recess.

title: PREPARATIONS IN GERMANY
description: Preparations at the American military hospital here moved quietly into high gear today, despite reports that a plan to fly the American airline hostages here from Damascus had been delayed.

title: 'DAMES' IN DRYDOCK AT GEORGE ST.
description: IT IS not surprising to see ''Dames at Sea'' sailing into any old summer-stock tent, as it has been for some 15 years.

title: A TINTINNABULOUS FOURTH OF JULY
description: WHILE the sound of the Fourth of July in many Connecticut towns will be the usual pop, boom and whistle of fireworks, in the tiny town of Warren Independence Day is a three-minute chorus of tinkles, bings and bongs.

title: CASTLES IN THE AIR: A VISITOR'S GUIDE
description: When it was damp, drizzly November in his soul, Melville went to sea. My own antidote for the damp-and-drizzlies is to curl up with one of those listings for luxury homes and estates in an upscale magazine and decide which dream house I would buy if I had enough cash socked away in a C.D. These listings are to the ordinary real estate section in the daily paper what the New Balance 1300 is to the ordinary running shoe: the top of the line. Is there anyone who has not, at some time, in some unthrifty corner of his or her soul, coveted a 7.4-acre island off the Florida coast complete with private marina? Or an ''1898 Colonial mansion'' on 13 acres in ''a secluded corner of Connecticut just waiting to be discovered'' for a mere ''$1.5M''?

title: MOZART COMES TO THE BURGER MAT
description: NORTH GLADIOLA By James Wilcox. 264 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95. IN a famous Marx Brothers scene from the movie ''A Night at the Opera,'' Harpo, Chico and a friend sneak aboard an ocean liner in Groucho's steamer trunk and make themselves at home in his tiny cabin. Someone knocks. Groucho shoves the stowaways back into the trunk and opens the door to the visitor. Someone else knocks. And soon the cabin is crawling with waiters, engineers, maids, a barber, a manicurist, a little girl asking if anyone has seen her mother - ''She must be here,'' says Groucho. ''Everybody else is.''

title: CRITICS' CHOICES, PERSONAL FAVORITES
description: Taillevent, the Waterside Inn, Auberge de l'Ill - these and other names of the world's finest restaurants are well known to travelers. But beyond such obvious choices, where do experts eat when they are on vacation. Six food and wine writers of The New York Times were asked to describe eating places that are personal favorites, restaurants to which they return whenever they can. They vary from the modest to the grand and stretch from a cafe in Venice to an an old-fashioned hotel in Memphis. But all have one thing in common - extraordinary food.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES, PERSONAL FAVORITES
description: Taillevent, the Waterside Inn, Auberge de l'Ill - these and other names of the world's finest restaurants are well known to travelers. But beyond such obvious choices, where do experts eat when they are on vacation. Six food and wine writers of The New York Times were asked to describe eating places that are personal favorites, restaurants to which they return whenever they can. They vary from the modest to the grand and stretch from a cafe in Venice to an an old-fashioned hotel in Memphis. But all have one thing in common - extraordinary food.

title: VINTAGE MODELS OF MISS LIBERTY
description: Throughout the Statue of Liberty's 99-year reign over New York Harbor, models and miniatures of the colossus have served as the ultimate symbol of the United States for souvenir seekers, patriots and antiques collectors. The copies - no one knows how many were made - were produced to raise money in France to build the 302-foot-high statue, and in America, to construct its base.

title: BUSH PLANS, THEN PUTS OFF, FLIGHT TO MEET THE HOSTAGES
description: Vice President Bush scheduled a flight to Frankfurt today to greet American hostages and then postponed it once he learned of negotiating snags in Beirut, according to officials in the Bush party.

title: WASTE DISPOSAL
description: To The Editor:

title: Ferraro's Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME VIDEO
description: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe Vestron Video 95 minutes. $69.95 There is a fundamental problem - more of a quibble, perhaps -with this animated adaptation of C. S. Lewis's classic first yarn in his ''Chronicles of Narnia'' fantasy series.

title: Cable TV
description: Building in part upon her own family history, the French director Diane Kurys fashioned ''Entre Nous,'' a powerful story of the friendship of two women that will be shown Tuesday at 8 P.M. and 1 A.M. on Bravo.

title: GENERAL OPPOSES NICARAGUA ATTACK
description: The commander of Army and Air Force combat forces in the United States, Gen. Wallace H. Nutting, says he is strongly opposed to an American invasion of Nicaragua.

title: IN UPSTATE NEW YORK, A FINNISH SAUNA TRADITION CONTINUES
description: Osmo Heila's sauna - a pine shack a half-century old tucked between the lilac trees and the high grass by the creek - fits neatly into the rural landscape. A wood-burning stove sends the temperature soaring to a steamy 200 degrees and draws the sap from the unvarnished planks as hot water gurgles through the old iron pipes.

title: A QUARTET OF STRADIVIARIS
description: Let connoisseurs and iconoclasts argue the relative virtues of instruments by Guarneri and the Amatis; nothing will ever supplant the name Stradivari (popularly known as ''Stradivarius'') in the hearts and minds of the typical string fancier. Only 800 instruments by Antonio Stradivari, the fabled 17th-century Italian craftsman, have survived, but, collectively, they have long since attained the status of legend.

title: Joanne M. Glavin Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Joanne M. Glavin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Glavin of Greenwich, Conn., to Brian S. McClatchy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. McClatchy of Havertown, Pa., took place yesterday. Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan performed the ceremony at St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich.

title: Why the Checkoff
description: To the Editor:

title: Q AND A
description: Question:While vacationing in Newfoundland, we would like to visit St. Pierre and Miquelon, and would appreciate help with transportation there, accommodations and things to see. - J. C., Chicago. Answer:S.P.M. Tours, 38 Gear Street, St. John's, Newfoundland A1C 2J5, Canada (709-722-3892), says it is the only company that specializes in running daily tours from St. John's to the French island territory of St. Pierre and Miquelon. (The islands are part of France but American visitors need only proof of identity to land.) The company offers a package for about $130 a person, double occupancy, that includes round-trip transportation by bus and ferry, two nights at the Hotel Robert in St. Pierre and Continental breakfast. (Prices have been converted into United States dollars.) The bus runs between St. John's and Fortune, on Newfoundland's southern Burin Peninsula, where the ferry leaves for St. Pierre. Another package costing $188 a person combines a round-trip flight on Atlantic Airways from St. John's and two nights at the hotel.

title: A SINGLE MOTHER WONDERS WHAT THE GUILT IS FOR
description: I DO not need the words of experts or quotes from any books. I have the most personal, reliable and honest source. Me. Mama never told me it would be like this. But then again, Mama was never a single mother. Had I known beforehand what it was like to raise two youngsters on my own I'd ... still have done it, but I would have definitely solicited advice from other single mothers.

title: SCREEN: FROM JAPAN, 'VENGEANCE IS MINE'
description: ''Vengeance Is Mine'' was shown at the 1980 New Directors/New Films Series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 22, 1980. The film opens today at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, Seventh Avenue at 57th Street.

title: REVOLUTIONARY VENTURES: SURVIVING AND PROFITING THROUGH THE CENTURIES
description: WHEN President Reagan works out on his exercise treadmill at the White House, he lopes along on belting from the nation's oldest business: J. E. Rhoads & Sons Inc., of Delaware, established in 1702. When President Washington wanted a gift for the Marquis de Lafayette he chose Number Six cologne, a scent still on sale at the nation's oldest apothecary, Caswell-Massey Company (1752), then of Newport, R.I.

title: OPPONENTS CAN GO JUST SO FAR IN NICARAGUA
description: Politicians and diplomats here differ widely in their appraisals of how much support the Government has. The Sandinista Front won 63 percent of the vote in last year's election and can mobilize thousands of people for demonstrations. But opposition leaders say the election was not a fair test and that many Nicaraguans repeat Sandinista slogans only because the Sandinistas are in control. The Government, for its part, has made clear that while it continues to tolerate dissent, there are limits. ''They want to make sure the opposition remembers who is in charge,'' a Western European diplomat said last week.

title: Miss Werner Wed To D. D. Osborn
description: Diane Nicole Werner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Werner of New York, was married yesterday to David Dudley Osborn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Robert Osborn of Scarsdale, N.Y. Judge Miriam Cedarbaum of the Scarsdale (N.Y.) Village Court performed the ceremony at the Chart House restaurant in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Saving the Next Generation
description: A serious measure of a society is how it treats its children, and by that measure, America is in trouble. In the last few years, children have become, before our very eyes, the poorest segment of our population, and every day brings new evidence that their plight is, if anything, growing worse. Think of a social ill: unemployment, continuing at a rate that would have alarmed Americans 20 years ago . . . the decline in family and rise in single-family homes . . . the increase in hungry Americans. All affect children worst.

title: A Child's Death: The Ultimate Tragedy
description: As a bereaved parent, I offer a counter-opinion to ''The Lesson of a Child's Suicide'' by the Rev. Barbara C. Crafton [May 26] .

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Addis Ababa June 16 gave an incorrect figure for the number of people in northern Ethiopia who are thought to be receiving famine relief assistance. According to Ethiopia's relief and rehabilitation commission, 5.7 million of the 7.9 million people estimated to be ''at risk'' are receiving emergency food assistance. The United Nations has estimated that 4.1 million are getting such aid.

title: A JAPANESE RELOCATION CASE TESTS THE VERDICT OF HISTORY
description: Gordon Hirabayashi was a senior at the University of Washington in 1942 when he was convicted of violating a curfew and failing to report to a ''civil control station'' to register for evacuation. Last week Mr. Hirabayashi was in court trying to overturn his conviction. He and his lawyers told a Federal district judge in Seattle that the Federal Government had suppressed evidence showing there was no military necessity for the mass relocation of Japanese-Americans in World War II because there was little threat of sabotage or espionage.

title: THE SHORT SELLERS HANG ON, NERVOUSLY
description: THE stock market's relative strength over the last year has pained short sellers, speculators who sell borrowed stock hoping to buy it back later at a lower price, and a profit. As prices have risen, losses have widened for these bears.

title: CARTOON THE RECORD?
description: Political cartoons in the Congressional Record? It hasn't happened yet. But Representative Andrews Jacobs Jr. is pushing just such a move.

title: Elena Thornton Wed to Musician
description: Elena Martha Thornton, a daughter of Daphne Sellar Thornton of Newport, R.I., and Henry H. M. Thornton of Ridgefield, Conn., was married yesterday to Michael Case Kissel, the son of W. Thorn Kissel of Owings Mills, Md., and the late Mrs. Kissel.The ceremony at St. George's School Chapel in Newport was performed by the Rev. John S. Rogers, the Episcopal chaplain of the school.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SPEAKS LOUDLY AND CARRIES A BIG STICK
description: At the Polana Hotel, Maputo's best, the cola cans bear an imprint that betrays their origin: ''Keep South Africa tidy.'' And in the two duty-free stores in town where the diplomats, foreigners and Mozambiquans with hard currency go to shop, the South African rand is as acceptable as the American dollar, while Mozambiquan money, the meticais, is rejected out of hand.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''It became clear today that when the dust settles, it's going to come down to A.T.&T. and MCI. And MCI has just found a very, very rich partner.''

title: Karen M. Alphin Is Married to Robert W. Balmos
description: Karen M. Alphin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond M. Modugno of Livingston, N.J., and Robert Webster Balmos, the son of Mrs. Edward J. Maude of Montclair, N.J., and James Hutchinson Balmos of New York, were married yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Essex Fells, N.J. The Rev. William Darrell Roberts and the Rev. Dr. David St. George officiated.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SUNDAY, JUNE 30, 1985

title: HONORING THE LIFE AND WORK OF A MODERN-DANCE PIONEER
description: Charles Weidman died on July 15, 1975. He had appeared with his small modern dance company just two days before at his tiny studio-home on West 29th Street in one of the informal Sunday night concerts that were a fixture of the modern dance scene of the 1970's for those in the know. In April that year, Alvin Ailey had dedicated his company's season to Weidman in a salute to ''one of the extraordinary papas of American dance.'' Three months after his death, public response was such that a memorial to Weidman had to be moved to Broadway's Majestic Theater from the Library Auditorium at Lincoln Center.

title: COLLEGE GRADUATE
description: Finally Bernadette Powell got her college degree. She was graduated magna cum laude last Tuesday from Mercy College with a bachelor's degree in social science and psychology. Her mother, Margie Fields, who had always had high hopes for her daughter, was present for the graduation ceremony. So was her 13-year-old son, who gave her a hug to show how proud he was of her.

title: U.S. WOMEN A TOUR DE FORCE IN CYCLING
description: Charlene Nicolson-Ford, a 23-year-old bicycle rider from Berkeley, Calif., fell during a race in Colorado last Saturday and, she recalled: ''I got up immediately and said I don't care if anything's broken. I'm still going to the Tour de France.''

title: IMPROVING THE U.N.
description: 'Our job is not to despair or take refuge in cynicism, but to labor constructively to make the U.N. better serve its original goals. In a world of sovereign nations, competing interests and clashing philosophies, those mechanisms of international cooperation that exist are inevitably imperfect, but all the more necessary.' rrSecretary of State George P. Shultz, rrat ceremonies in San Francisco marking the 40th anniversary of the signing of the United Nations Charter.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: FINDING FIREWORKS In recent years the high cost of mounting and insuring Fourth of July fireworks displays has forced many towns in the county to do without them. But there will still be plenty of rockets, star showers, sonic booms and oohs and ahs from the crowd in at least 10 Westchester communities, plus two in Ulster County. Here they are: ELLENVILLE (Ulster County) -Entertainment and hang-gliding demonstration at 7:30 P.M. Thursday, L.H.J. Airport. Fireworks, 9:15 P.M., 40-minute display. Free admission and parking. Take Route 17 off I-87 to Route 209.

title: Boston University Offers To Run City's Schools
description: Boston University has offered to take over the city's public school system and could run it less expensively and more effectively than the School Committee, according to the university's president, John R. Silber.

title: PERSIAN TIARA WINS HANDICAP
description: Persian Tiara, a long-winded and classy 5-year-old mare, found the long mile-and-three-eighths distance of the $147,200 Sheepshead Bay Handicap to her liking yesterday and scored a late-running 1 1/4-length victory over Key Dancer at Belmont Park.

title: ORGANIZING THE REVOLUTION
description: FIRE FROM THE MOUNTAIN The Making of a Sandinista. By Omar Cabezas. Foreword by Carlos Fuentes. Translated by Kathleen Weaver. 233 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $13.95.

title: THEATER OF LIGHT SOON TO GO DARK
description: FOR 20 years, W. Christian Sidenius has been the impressario of a theater in Newtown unlike any other in the world.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: HOME BARBECUE: ENHANCED POSSIBILITIES
description: BARBECUE is no longer reserved for summer. California-style restaurants that grill almost anything from rabbit and duck to leeks and vegetable kebabs have proliferated across the country. But thanks to this craze, a variety of different woods are now available for home cooks. With this, plus all the ideas and recipes for foods that can be cooked on a fire, the home barbecue has taken on a new dimension.

title: CONFERENCE PONDERS ROLE OF SCIENTISTS IN WEAPONRY
description: A blind woman saw a flash of light. The New Mexican desert suddenly looked small, and a violent ball - purple and green and orange - warmed the faces of scientists five miles away. It was July 16, 1945, and the world's first atomic explosion had just gone off.

title: Andrea Sawicki Wed To David W. Neuhaus
description: Andrea Sawicki, a daughter of Mary Power Sawicki of New Canaan, Conn., and Richard Raymond Sawicki of Redding, Conn., was married yesterday to David William Neuhaus, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Francis Clemens Neuhaus of Wilmette, Ill. The Rev. Edward R. Danks performed the ceremony at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn.

title: ENGLAND
description: To the Editor: I recently spent a month traveling in England, alone and using public transportation. I wish to commend and recommend the services of the British Tourist Office to your readers.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: METRO. By Alexander Kaletski. (Viking, $17.95.) In the 1920's Soviet satire unveiled a hectic world overrun with con men, raconteurs, womanizers and alcoholics bribing their way past rules apparently meant to be broken; readers saw a chasm between the splendid simplicity of revolutionary slogans and the scrambled realities of everyday life.

title: Cynthia Tougas Weds David Jeffrey Penney
description: Cynthia Norcross Tougas and David Jeffrey Penney, 1983 graduates of Princeton University, were married yesterday at the Princeton University Chapel. The Rev. Stanley Moseley, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: QUESTION AND ANSWER
description: Paying for the Water Question: Our co-op applied for permission to disconnect our water meter. We received a letter saying we can disconnect the meter and will be billed at a flat rate. Must a co-op pay for water? . . . C. T. C., Manhattan Answer: Owners of all property where water is used, except churches, schools and other non profit institutions, pay for water, says Howard Cohen, manager of the Manhattan office of the Bureau of Water Register. Commercial and industrial users must have a meter; residential users have the option of being billed at a flat rate based on the amount of frontage and number of stories, families and water-using fixtures. In a multifamily building, one family, one toilet and one bathtub or shower stall are not counted.

title: A Reagan Antecedent In Revolution
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG LINES, SCALPERS AND U.S. TOURISTS
description: IN England it is called queueing, and any American who has waited for playoff or rock-concert tickets can identify with the fans here who camp overnight for the chance to purchase the limited number of general admission tickets that are put on sale every day at Wimbledon. The line forms in the early evening and fans huddle under plastic tents and blankets and listen to music or read.

title: A CAPITAL VISTA
description: A 100-unit condominium apartment tower that has yet to be named will be built on the bank of the Connecticut River in East Hartford, Conn., directly across the river from downtown Hartford and the headquarters of the developer, the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company.

title: UNIVERSIY CHIEF SOUGHT IN HAWAII
description: Dr. M. Cecil Mackey was to have taken over the presidency of the University of Hawaii on Monday, but apparent miscalculations by state officials have caused him to withdraw.

title: Parker Wins Decision
description: The middleweight Curtis Parker of Philadelphia won a 10-round decision today over Ricky Stackhouse of Atlanta, in a nontitle bout here. Parker improved his record to 26-6 with 12 knockouts. Stackhouse fell to 15-2 with 8 knockouts.

title: BLUE LAW REVIVAL SOUGHT
description: ON TWO fronts - the Legislature and the courts - supporters of this resort's Sunday blue laws, lifted by a Superior Court permanent injunction, are hoping to reinstate them.

title: MAKING THE MOST OF FAST-FALLING MORTGAGE RATES
description: THE bad news about the slowdown in the nation's economy has been good news for people shopping for home mortgages. Interest rates, responding to a reduced demand for credit and stable inflation, have fallen to levels not seen since the summer of 1980. Rates, however, have already started to edge upward because of some preliminary reports on the economy's improving outlook.

title: GINGER ROGERS IS BACK -- AS A DIRECTOR
description: EvERYTHING you ever wanted to know about the private life of Ginger Rogers will have to wait until the legendary star finishes her autobiography. And she has put aside writing that to undertake yet another career - as director of ''Babes in Arms,'' the 1937 musical by Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart, which opened last week at Tarrytown's Music Hall.

title: A ONCE-FAMOUS SPA SEEKS REDISCOVERY
description: BRIAN PRUCKER knelt down and filled a champagne glass with water from the tiny fountain in Stafford Springs. He took a sip and posed for a photographer. Never mind that a steady rain was falling, dampening his three-piece beige suit and flattening his blond hair. Mr. Prucker was spreading the word about Stafford Springs' once-famous mineral water.

title: THE WIRTER: TV'S FORGOTTEN MAN
description: The writer in American television is in serious danger of becoming a nonperson.

title: Museum Fire Sale
description: Predictably, the trustees of New York's Museum of the American Indian have all but sealed a deal with billionaire H. Ross Perot to move their priceless collection to Texas. All that stands in the way is New York's commendably determined Attorney General, Robert Abrams.

title: AID SOUGHT FOR BLACKS IN SOUTH AFRICA SCHOOL
description: A fund-raising group has been formed in New York City to help aid black students and hire more black faculty members half a world away, at the University of Cape Town in South Africa.

title: SERVERS LEARN TO HANDLE DRUNKS
description: LORRIE OLSZYK stumbled up to the bar at Pfenninger's Restaurant here and ordered a double vodka on the rocks.

title: BROOKHAVEN WEIGHS HALT IN HOUSING
description: BROOKHAVEN, Long Island's fastest-developing town, may halt further development of multifamily complexes until a revision of the town's master plan is completed.

title: Beatles' Rolls-Royce Is Sold for $2 Million
description: A 19-foot Rolls-Royce, once owned by the Beatles and painted in a psychedelic, floral motif designed with the help of a gypsy mystic, was sold yesterday at auction for $2,299,000, a spokesman for Sotheby Parke Bernet said.

title: HOME OF BASKETBALL MEMORIES
description: Since the Basketball Hall of Fame opened in 1968, some 22 years after the idea was fostered by the National Association of Basketball Coaches, Lee Williams has been its executive director, chief fund raiser and collector of many of the museum's memorabilia.

title: SHOE CHIC: THEN, NOW AND BEYOND
description: Something special is afoot in New York, a kind of historical shoe pageant. It starts with platform sandals that derive from the Greeks, who wore them 3,000 years ago.

title: 19 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY CITY
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 19 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: A DECADE AFTER THE CUTBACKS, NEW YORK IS A DIFFERENT CITY
description: Ten years ago today, New York City's First Deputy Mayor, a ruddy veteran of 40 years in municipal government named James A. Cavanagh, took an action that almost immediately changed the nature of life in the city.

title: IN FLORENCE, ROOMS WITH A VIEW
description: In Florence nowadays there is by law no longer such a thing as a pensione. Pensiones, perhaps best translated as family hotels, now are in the same category as small hotels and must conform to certain hotel regulations. But this is Italy, and it would take more than a law to change the atmosphere of a typical Florentine pensione.

title: AND RICK RAN OFF WITH RENAULT
description: SUSPECTS By David Thomson. 274 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Organization's 38th Satellite Is Launched Aboard Rocket
description: An Intelsat IV-A communication satellite was carried into space today by an Atlas Centaur rocket after a delay caused by the weather.

title: FIVE MOVIES THAT MAKE DEMANDS ON AUDIENCES
description: It's a sad commentary on the state of things that the following may come under the heading of ''news'': you don't have to be locked into eternal adolescence to be able to go to the movies these days. I don't know how true this is for the rest of the country, but Manhattan is currently offering a small number of exceedingly offbeat alternatives to the mostly mindless comedies about what's taken to be teen-age sensuality (''Secret Admirer'') and adventure-fantasy movies featuring robots that may be animated creatures (''Return to Oz'') or live actors (''Rambo'').

title: KENNEDY AIRPORT TIGHTENS SECURITY
description: More stringent security measures have gone into effect at Kennedy International Airport, and passengers, aware of the hijackings and bombings that prompted the new procedures, are cooperating.

title: REEVES, NOT FLUTIE, TO START IN PLAYOFFS
description: Coach Walt Michaels said today that Ron Reeves, rather than Doug Flutie, would be the starting quarterback for the Generals in their United States Football League playoff game against the Baltimore Stars Monday night in Giants Stadium.

title: DEMOCRATS BUOYED BY PLAN OF GEORGIA COACH
description: The Republican Party encountered something unexpected in Southern politics today: a popular college football coach with political ambitions.
